column2: The 1954 Berkshire Festival at Tanglewood, near Lenox, Mass., will consist of four concerts a week for six weeks. The new pattern, established by Charles Munich, will comprise chamber music concerts Wednesday nights, little orchestra concerts Friday nights and concerts by the full Boston Symphony Orchestra on Saturday nights and Sunday afternoons.

THE name of Oswald Jacoby has been associated with contract bridge for so long -- some twenty-seven years, which is about as long as there has been any game of contract bridge -- that it is hard to believe his first bridge book was published only last week. But it is true.
The battle for control of the east New York Central Railroad system continued yesterday, but mostly on the verbal front.
TRENTON, Feb. 27 -- Democratic leaders were conferring here today with Gov. Robert B. Meyner in an effort to avoid a primary contest for the party's United States Senate nomination.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 27 -- Sal Maglie, quietly confident that he will be able to pitch, reported to the Giants today. A week late, because of private business at Niagara Falls, N. Y., the 37-year-old right-hander shrugged off yesterday's blast by Leo Durocher, who scored Maglie for his tardiness, and immediately went to work.

ATOP the big, concrete bunker the young French officer turned his back on the protruding artillery piece, closed his eyes and put a finger in each ear. The gun coughed, and a flash at the end of the barrel split the night. Seconds later a star shell blossomed over a dark blob on the dim horizon.
The formation of a new local agency dedicated to the aid of handicapped persons was announced yesterday by Halsey B. Knapp, president of the New York State Association for Crippled Children, Inc.

Whatever the defects of the prevailing theory of atomic structure may be, it works -- by which the physicist means that it endows him with a considerable power of prediction. He has only to change the ratio of protons to neutrons in a nucleus to perform some astonishing feats in transmutation, at least on paper.

BOITO: Excerpts from Nerone; Aureliano Pertile, tenor; Agossino Rina, mezzo-soprano; Marcel Journet, bass; Salvatore Pollicino, tenor, etc. (Eterna.) Rerecording of acoustic and early electrical disks. A collector's item both vocally and as a cross-section of Boito's seldom-performed opera.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 27 -- Center Eric Unger performed the "hat trick" by whipping home three goals to pace Canada to an 8-to-1 victory over Switzerland today in the world ice hockey tournament.

Dr. Frederick J. Bordt Jr., Associate Professor of Mechanical Engineering at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, and Andrew J. Shine, his associate, have invented and patented what may be ultimately a better way of heating a room than the familiar steam radiator.

The merchandise market was generally quiet last week with the pattern of reorders showing that good business is spotted throughout the country rather than general, according to reports from resident buying offices.

The versatile silhouette varies from slender to flaring. Regency or princess, it calls for the sophistication of smooth curves at waist and hips. Above the waistline the bodice may be draped or smooth.

This is a big year for the electric light and power industry. In January the industry in this country added its fifty millionth customer. Consumption of electricity is at record peaks -- and still rising.

GEOGRAPHY'S changes through the years are reflected by thousands of past and present stamps bearing designs and inscriptions which take note of the transitions. An addition to this geographical record is forecast in official word received here last week from Zomba, capital of Nyasaland in Africa.
Long-harmonious relations between the United States and the Philippines may be disrupted by economic fireworks next Fourth of July unless speedy counter-measures are taken.

DAVID OISTRAKH, the great Russian violinist, is liberally represented on current labels. More than that: Period, Vanguard and Colosseum have released examples of this violinist's work in identical performances.

A COMPANION volume to Mrs. Baity's "Americans Before Columbus," this is an account of the changing face of our continent from its beginning to the coming of man. It is the broadest study of its kind for young people (outside the classroom) that I have seen, including not only geology and paleontology but a brief introductory excursion into astronomy and anthropology.

French cabinetwork by eighteenth century master craftsmen and Royal Gobelin tapestries and other art works from the estate of the late Mrs. Beverly Bogert of New York and other owners will be auctioned Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Six high school scientists, participating in The New York Times Youth Forum, agreed today that there should be a freer exchange of atomic information.

ENTITLED "L'Invitee" in the original, this novel first appeared in Paris in 1943. It was, along with "The Stranger" by Albert Camus, one of the two outstanding revelations of the war years in the domain of French fiction.

MALTA -- It is no good pretending that a Mediterranean island measuring nine miles by seventeen, rugged, densely populated -- richly endowed though it may be in its religious and historical associations -- is an ideal spot for a conventional tourist holiday of fun and relaxation.

Last month, when Frederick Migliarese and Anthony Caperino decided to operate a gasoline station and car-washing service at Remsen and Foster Avenues, Brooklyn, they overlooked one item -- their neighbor's hobby.

SAFETY programs at community levels are getting under way throughout the country under the guidance of the 2,500 delegates who attended the White House Conference on Highway Safety in Washington recently.

WILMINGTON, N. C. -- Be they gourmets or ordinary trenchermen, winter tourists following the coastal routes between Florida and northern points are passing up a treat if they fail to stop at what is known in these parts as an oyster roast.

PRESAGING similar moves by other photographic manufacturers in the near future, price reductions of $10 to $20 from the price list of their cameras was announced last week by Bolsey Corporation of America. Reasons for the price drop, according to Jacques Bolsey, president of the company, are an "anticipated general change in the economic picture" and the company's desire "to pass on to the consumer the benefits of economies."

More than three hundred years ago the English were afflicted with a court known as the Star Chamber because it met in a room with astronomical decorations on the ceiling. The court outlived its uses and overrode its privileges. In the year 1641 Parliament found it "to be an intolerable burden to the subjects and a means to introducing arbitrary power and government" and thereupon abolished it.

Alain Jean de Berc of M. I. T., a Frenchman, has been elected president of the New England Intercollegiate Sailing Association. He succeeds Harvard's John B. Newhall. The meeting was held in Cambridge, Mass.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 57 (AP) -- The United States Information Agency said today it was concentrating on a few key policies in its efforts to promote American ideas abroad.
" There's nothing wrong with your heart, Al," the doctor said.
Fashion's new approach to coats and suits is one showing ease of drape and fluidity of line. The town suit is a soft suit; the coat is so styled that it resembles a dress. Details give distinction.

The Paganini Quartet, so named because each of the instrumentalists plays a Stradivarius once owned by Paganini, gave a recital in Town Hall yesterday afternoon. As always, there was much to admire in this accomplished group's presentations.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 27 (AP) -- Robert Cohen of France tonight captured the European bantamweight title with a sensational three-round knockout of John Kelly, the pride of Belfast. Each man weighed 117 3/4.

LAHTI, Finland, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Arvo Viitanen, the forestry stu-I kdent who helped Finland take scoring honors in the first half iof the world ski championships, itoday won the 18-kilometer crossicount"y race in the SalpausselkaeI Finnish international games for] the third straight year.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 27 -- Ch. Carmor's Rise and Shine, the buff cocker spaniel who was best in show at the recent Westminster Kennel Club show, and at New Haven, tonight won the sporting dog group in the thirty-sixth annual All-Breed event of the Western Reserve Kennel Club.

THE novel of international intrigue has been somewhat in the doldrums for the past few years; but it's a pleasure to report that there seems to be an east wind coming -- as evidence of which you may investigate three recent novels, all highly recommended.

AMONG the treasures in the exhibit of Japanese art that toured this country last year was a thirty-six-foot scroll which depicted frogs, rabbits, monkeys and a variety of other animals disporting themselves in the manner of small boys anywhere.

HONOLULU -- It is difficult to write a report on a tourist's tour of the Hawaiian Islands without sounding like the brochures published by the Hawaiian Visitors Bureau. The latter's big pitch is based on the climate, and whatever they say about it is absolutely true.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- Seton Hall, last year's National Invitation basketball champion, wound up its season tonight wit ha 78-62 triumph over Jona College of New Rochelle. The victory, at the Westchester County Center left the Pirates with a 13-10 mark.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 27 -- Syria's capital city of Damascus was placed under a strict curfew tonight after a day of demonstrations by the populace against the remnants of former President Adib Shishekly's regime, which is still in control.

ESCUINTLA, Guatemala, Feb. 27 -- Guatemala's Communists are not merely agrarian reformers. But the individual agraristas -- those who invoke the Agrarian Law or benefit by it -- are by no means all Communists.

These statements last week by the Senate Majority Leader and the Secretary of State reflected opposing points of view in a long-standing controversy that has welled up again in the aftermath of the Berlin conference of the Big Four. The central issue is the United States policy toward Communist China. In particular it revolves around the Big Four agreement to meet with Communist China in Geneva in April on the problems of the Far East.

FLORENCE, Italy, Feb. 27 -- It is now beginning to look as if Soviet diplomacy has managed to stave off once again enactment of the European Defense Community, that essential aspiration of Washington's present diplomatic policy and therefore Moscow's bugbear.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 27 -- A $20,000 contribution to a fund to preserve Mettler's Woods, a sixty-five-acre tract of primeval forest in East Millstone, was announced here today. The contribution was authorized by the trustees of Old Dominion Foundation, Inc., of New York, according to Dr. William H. Cole, chairman of Rutgers University's Research Council.

I heartily agree with Gertrude Samuels' article, "Time to Retire? There Is None" (Feb. 14). My own experience emphasizes the points she brings out, most especially the "resistance to retirement" cited by Prof. Irving Lorge of Columbia.

At the beginning of the year a group of scientists in the University of California (Drs. Albert Ghiorso, G. Bernard Rossi, Bernard G. Harvey and Stanley G. Thompson) announced that they had created element 99. "Created" is the right word, because there are only ninety-two elements in the earth's crust and atmosphere together.

As a white Northerner who has lived in the deep South for the past twenty-seven years I have been able to note the development in race relations without being as emotionally involved in the matter as many of the native Southerners are.

THE Paris Opera's long- heralded production of Weber's "Oberon" finally had its first performance on Feb. 12 before an audience that held not only Rene Coty, France's new President, but Prince George of Greece as well.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 27 (AP) -- With one second remaining, Capt. Worthy Patterson tossed in a field goal to give the University of Connecticut a 78-77 victory over Holy Cross, the nation's seventh-ranking intercollegiate basketball team, tonight in their battle for a National Collegiate championship berth.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27 (UP) -- William O'Dwyer, former Mayor of New York and former United States Ambassador to Mexico, slipped into Miami in the pre-dawn darkness today to "visit with friends for a few days" in the Florida keys.

However warm the battle for control of the New York Central Railroad becomes between now and the company's annual meeting on May 26, it is unlikely to rival the mighty conflicts which marked the system's history of nearly a century ago.

Seven speakers have been selected to address the first seminar in man-made fibers at New York University, it was announced yesterday. The seminar will last ten weeks and the first session will be held tomorrow. Fibers to be discussed include Orlon, dynel, Dacron, Acrilan, Fiberglas, nylon and vicara. It will be held on ten londays from 7 to 8:45 P. v[. through May 10 and is open to all persons in the textile industry.

THE term "magnificent bastards" is a bit of affectionate slang hurled at the Marine Corps, but the accent in the title of this novel about Red Cross girls and Marines in World War II belongs on the noun rather than the adjective.
Subsidized American steamship lines are contributing more to the Federal Treasury than it costs the Government to aid them against foreign competition through operating subsidy payments.
The Institute of International Education, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street, announced yesterday publication of a pamphlet listing foreign summer schools open to United States students.

MONTREAL, Feb. 27 -- A substitute goalie, Jacques Plante, registered his third straight shutout on home ice tonight as the Montreal Canadiens blanked the New York. Rangers, 5 -- 0, before 14,468 National Hockey League fans at the Forum.

WHEN "The Madwoman of Chaillot" was produced here in 1948 it was obvious that Jean Giraudoux belonged to the great tradition that Yeats had defined. The madness of that old crone represented Giraudoux' dream of an impossible kindness and grace in human relations.

THE operation of the Rialto Theatre, whose film tenants, both first-run and otherwise, have constituted a varied gallery from Frankenstein's monster and French murderers to strip-tease artists, is slated to be taken over next month by the Brandt Theatre circuit.

Four million Americans are expected to spend more than $100,000,000 this year for electric shavers. Manufacturing and selling electric shavers no longer is a hit or miss "gift gadget" affair. It is big business.

STANDARDS are fairly new to the garden scene nowadays, although they are an old type of horticultural specialty. The term actually refers to those plants that are trained to a single stem. Most standards (except roses, which are grafted) start out in the usual way, but as they grow all side branches are removed to force the plant to form a single strong stem.

SHRUBBY clematis is one species of this well-liked genus which too often is overlooked. It makes an excellent addition to a perennial border since it is a hardy, vigorous plant that produces quantities of beautiful bloom.

Seven speakers have been selected to address the first seminar in man-made fibers at New York University, it was announced yesterday. The seminar will last ten weeks and the first session will be held tomorrow. Fibers to be discussed include Orlon, dynel, Dacron, Acrilan, Fiberglas, nylon and vicara. It will be held on ten londays from 7 to 8:45 P. v[. through May 10 and is open to all persons in the textile industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, said today that students who intend to take the college qualification test for military deferment April 22 must file their applications not later than midnight March 8.

STANDARDS are fairly new to the garden scene nowadays, although they are an old type of horticultural specialty. The term actually refers to those plants that are trained to a single stem. Most standards (except roses, which are grafted) start out in the usual way, but as they grow all side branches are removed to force the plant to form a single strong stem.

SHRUBBY clematis is one species of this well-liked genus which too often is overlooked. It makes an excellent addition to a perennial border since it is a hardy, vigorous plant that produces quantities of beautiful bloom.
NYACK, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- Carmine G. DeSapio, the leader of Tammany Hall, sharply criticized tonight what he termed Republican attempts to assassinate the character of the Democratic party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -When the fog of war had cleared week-end in the McCarthyStevens dispute, the feeling here was that the White House had contrived an uneasy truce. President Eisenhower had been drawn into the conflict, but the outcome was still in doubt.
The twenty-year controversy over the merits of public against private power, somewhat quiescent since the advent of the Eisenhower Administration, has erupted once again.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 21 -- Lands that lay unnourished for centuries are now yielding harvests because of enrichment of their soil strata, according to a world report by the Food and Agriculture Organization.

LAST week we left unfinished our discussion of the ponderously portentous style which characterizes so much of our current literary criticism. I was using as my springboard, you may recall, an article by Wallace W. Douglas in the winter issue of The American Scholar.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- It is a long way from Peoria to the Pentagon, but a lot of politicians here are convinced that there is a close connection between the two places in any complete story of the relations between President Eisenhower and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Wisconsin Republican.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 27 (UP) -- Johnny Palmer held a commanding lead at the three-quarter mark of the $12,000 Mexican open golf tournament today with a two-under-par 70. The defending champion, Roberto de Vicenzo of Argentina, trailed by four strokes.

With a record enrollment of 28,623,000 pupils in the nation's public elementary and high schools this year -- an increase of 1,150,000 over 1952-53 -- many communities face serious educational problems.

CRIME on the high seas has gone out of fashion. Sound ships, better food, quarters, wages and a marked decrease in brutality on shipboard have made the sailors lot relatively easy. And so today we rarely hear of mutinous conduct, or of the high crimes that stud past annals of seafaring.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 27 -- Dick Pettit scored two goals today and paced Brown to a 3-1 victory over Princeton in a Pentagonal Hockey League game in Baker Rink.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 27 -- In the projected April 26 meeting at Geneva, the Chinese Communists appear to have more to gain by diplomatic negotiations than by provoking any new crisis in the Far East. At worst, the Geneva conference seems to provide them with an opportunity to join forces with the Soviet Union and to play off one Western power against another, while gaining an international breathing spell for their domestic programs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP) -- A television manufacturers' trade group asserted today that the industry had increased sports income to a record level and that, rightly used, TV could create more and more fans.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 27 -- Dr. K. C. Wu, former Governor of Formosa, has been under heavy attack in the Legislative Yuan (Parliament) here for making critical statements in the United States about the Chinese Nationalist Government.

PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 27 -- Pacific Northwest Governors, trying to conform to the Eisenhower Administration's "partnership" concept of hydroelectric development, are taking the lead in attempting to speed projects and cut delaying red tape.

LAMENTS from Florida resorts that their February high season was a week late in starting and not up to previous winters raised the question whether former Florida vacationists were by-passing that state and going farther south to the West Indies and Mexico.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 27 -- Dr. Henry Steele Commager told 400 college students here today that certain traditional characteristics of American freedom were in danger of falling away and taking our freedom with them.

It is a great satisfaction to The New York Times to be able to announce that this year's gifts to the fund for the Hundred Neediest Cases have set a new record. Somewhat in excess of $400,000, the total is the highest in any year of the forty-two in which the fund has been in existence. In only one previous year, 1946, was this sum approached.

The sale of an original issue of shares of a corporation does not result in either taxable gain or deductible loss under Federal income tax law This rule applies whether the subscription or issue price is in excess of, or less than, the par or stated value of the stock.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic State Chairman, reiterated last night his charges of "ruthless" dictatorship against Governor Dewey and accused him of making "a brazen attempt to rig" the November election for Governor.
THE trend toward smaller or dwarf varieties of plants is as obvious as the reasons for it. Smaller properties mean smaller gardens and, then too, smaller plants in many cases are easier to maintain.

The "miracle on Fourteenth Street" of almost 100,000 shoppers trampling each other at last Monday's sales may stimulate a trend to Washington's Birthday openings in this city. Three Fourteenth Street stores -- Hearn Department Stores, Inc.; S. Klein on the Square and Jonas Shoppes -- decided that Washington's Birthday could be as good a shopping day here as it has been in some other cities.

PARIS, Feb. 27 -- Eighteen candidates have been registered for a by-election tomorrow in the first district of the Seine et Oise Department for the seat formerly held in the National Assembly by Andre Deithelm, Gaullist, who was once Minister of War.

BILLED as a novel of suspense, this book earns its title from the first breathless paragraph. The story-line is a familiar one (what happens when a trio of mad-dog convicts hole up in an average home after a jail break).

HAVANA, Feb. 27 -- The registration of parties for Cuba's scheduled Presidential election in November will end tomorrow, completing another phase in the slow process of restoring constitutional government to this politics-racked island.
On a raw June morning almost ten years ago a man known to the millions he commanded as "Ike" made one of the great decisions of his life -- and of our lives.

JUST about this time each year, the Children's Bureau of the United States Department of Health, Education and Welfare issues its review of highlights in the previous year's services for youngsters and considers the principal trouble spots ahead.

AT hand this week is a brace of nondescript works which survive mainly because each contains a single unforgettable tenor aria that has endeared itself to generation after generation of music lovers. These are Massenet's Werther (Cetra, three disks) and Lehar's operetta, The Land of Smiles (Angel, two disks).

Although an unusually high proportion of all Wellesley College students graduate, those who enter at the age of 16 are the most likely, and those who enter at 19 are the least likely, to complete their college careers. This conclusion has been reached by Miss Mary E. Chase, executive vice president and director of admissions at Wellesley.

ALPINE, N. J., Feb. 27 -- There were nine blind Boy Scouts among the 700 Scouts at Camp Alpine here today, but scarcely any of the others were aware of it so naturally and proficiently have the nine taken to outdoor life.

CAIRO, Sunday, Feb. 28 -- Dissident members of Egypt's ruling military junta restored Maj. Gen Mohammed Naguib to power as President of the republic in a bloodless coup early yesterday that left the fate of the revolutionary regime hanging in the balance.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 27 -- India's over-all deficit for 1954-55 will be nearly doubled by the increasing rate of national development work, Chintaman Deshmukh, Finance Minister, disclosed today in his budget message to the House of the People.

It took Columbia all of the first half to solve Dartmouth's zone defense in a return Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball game in University Hall last night, but when it did the result was a 55-49 victory for the Lions.

THE longest production hiatus in the history of Twentieth Century - Fox will end tomorrow with the start of photography on "Broken Lance." The studio's filming operations began to taper off late last summer and came to a halt in October to await the outcome of its great experiment in CinemaScope -- the release of "The Robe."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 27 -- The Yankee holdout front collapsed almost completely today. In fact, the Bomber camp fairly bristled with news to indicate that Casey Stengel again would be off winging when the regular training grind of the full squad gets under way next week.
Two dozen Girl Scouts were promised jobs yesterday by Trans World Airlines -- in 1965, "when you're old enough to become hostesses."

Washington Birthday promotions which brought heavy traffic to Fourteenth Street raised retail business in the city to about the same level as the similar week a year ago, it was estimated. However, individual merchants estimates varied widely.

THESE volumes give us Charles Dodgson's account of his whole life from his becoming a fellow of Christ Church at the age of 23 until his death at the age of 65, with the exception of part of the summer of 1867 (when he visited Russia), the last three months of '55 and the years '58 to mid- '62 (the journals for which are lost).
The twentieth anniversary of the founding of the Casita Maria Settlement, an East Harlem center devoted to aiding Spanish-speaking residents of the neighborhood, was marked yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 27 -- With forty-five fewer furnaces in blast than were in commission at the corresponding period a year ago ore consumption dipped to 6,995, 621 tons in January and a further decrease is expected that month, according to the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 28 -- Champion Carmor's Rise and Shine, the buff cocker spaniel who went best in show at Westminster, repeated his victory at the thirty-sixth annual Cleveland Classic of the Western Reserve Kennel Club tonight.
The home seamstress who plans to make changes in or additions to her family's spring wardrobe might find useful some new publications or sewing aids.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture today estimated this year's world coffee crop at 5,333,145,000 pounds.

Frank F. Gload, builder who erected the one-story taxpayer at 355-61 Fulton Avenue, northeast corner of Washington Street, in Hempstead, L. I., in 1950, has sold the building to the Edbar Realty Corporation, Arthur Glickman, president, for investment.

The General Electric Company increased its sales last year by 19 per cent, with a volume of $3,128,127,301. This was the highest in the company's history. A record tax bill prevented 1953 earnings of $165,727,889 from exceeding the peak net of $173,423,702 in 1950.

A protest against continued transfer of American-flag vessels to foreign registry was made yesterday by the maritime committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in citing a year's decrease of almost 50 per cent in the active American merchant marine.

A charge that the West was appeasing the Kremlin by refusing to protest Soviet domination of the Baltic States was made yesterday by Representative Alvin E. O'Konski at a rally commemorating the thirty-sixth anniversary of Estonia's proclamation of independence.

With the approach of spring "a young man's fancy lightly turns to thoughts of love," and the season of weddings is upon us. With this in mind, our efforts Were directed to obtaining the prettiest possible design for a wedding dress.
VERO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28 -- After all other players had gone to the clubhouse today Jackie Robinson was still ranging across left field, shagging flies hit to him by Coach Jake Pitler.

The test in 1953 was whether a change to a more nearly normal peace time economy could be made without serious recession and unemployment, Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, declares in his annual report issued for publication today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)-- Representatives of forty In, an tribes today called for continuedj protection and benefits as guar-i anteed to them in treaties with the Federal Government.
A 54-year-old fencing master using only his fists routed four teen-age burglars armed with knives from an East Side penthouse apartment last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- In the midst of Congressional moves to emancipate the American tribal Indian there was released today testimony that caused shock in many Capitol Hill quarters.
The New York Americans defeated the Brooklyn Hispanos, 2 -- 1, at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday to qualify for the Eastern final of the National Challenge Cup soccer competition.
An important collection of early American paintings has been given to the National Gallery of Art in Washington by Mr. and Mrs. Edgar W. Garbisch, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON. Feb. 28 (AP) -- The registrar of the University of Maryland was stabbed to death and her sister injured early today by a housebreaker, who escaped.

Fifty-two persons will get study awards, fellowships and scholarships from the Fund for Adult Education, it announced yesterday. Four-fifths of the grants will go to men and women working in adult education as leaders, teachers, administrators and teacher trainers.

MOSCOW, Feb. 28 -- Sixty prominent officials and public citizens were named by the Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republic today to a committee that will prepare the jubilee marking the 300th anniversary of the union of the Ukraine with Russia. The Russian Republic is the largest and most important of the sixteen constituent republics that make up the Soviet Union.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- The Right Rev. Horace W. B. Donegan, Episcopal Bishop of New York, said today that the Administration had capitulated to the "un-American tactics" of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
Ship owners raised rates further in the ship charter market last week but cargo shippers still hesitated to commit themselves for more than a month or so ahead.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Feb. 28 -- The French delegation to the conference of the Socialist International here approved today a statement supporting the European Defense Community treaty.

PARIS, Feb. 28 -- Gold prices dropped this week-end on the Paris free market to the lowest level in seven years. They now stand less than 10 per cent above the legal price at which the Bank of France purchases the metal.

Living in the suburbs has its occasional advantages, and they are familiar ones to all who do so. Airing the dog is easy by night, and taking a walk in the woods is easy by day. The shoveling of snow and the cutting of grass provide all needed exercise and, as a form of occupation, the garden during the summer outranks even television.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 28 -- Two hundred thousand Moslems staged a mass protest meeting today to denounce "insults" allegedly hurled at the Islamic faith at recent Nationalist and Communist rallies here.

The bodies of two racketeers, each shot through the head, were found yesterday morning in parked cars. One was a block from Mayor Wagner's official residence, the other beside Samuel J. Tilden High School in Brooklyn.
TOKYO, Monday, March 1 -- Gen. John E. Hull, United Nations commander, agreed yesterday to turn over two displaced North Korean civilians to South Korean authorities for investigation.

Dr. Irving Peress, Queens dentist whose honorable discharge led to a clash between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army, said last night that his home had been stoned in "the terrorism that stems from McCarthyism."

The New York Life Insurance Company, one of the largest corporate enterprises in the country, reported yesterday that its total assets had risen to $5,536,787,284 at the end of 1953. Record benefit payments, dividends and sales also were shown in the company's 109th annual report to policyholders, issued by Devereux C. Josephs, chairman. Assets a year earlier amounted to $5,326,218,331.

The Brazilian naval training ship Duque de Caxias arrived here yesterday from Halifax, N. S., for a twelve-day visit. The 11,130-ton vessel is on the homeward leg of a cruise to European and Mediterranean waters that began at Rio de Janeiro last August.
The Air Force wants to know just how wide the Atlantic is, and it hopes to find out by watching a solar eclipse June 30.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Feb. 22 -- The ancient city of Jaffa, situated on a knoll overlooking the historic harbor, is to be converted into a national park devoted to antiquities and archaeology.
The city, which since 1945 has sold its bonds exclusively to its own pension funds and sinking funds, will offer an issue of about $50,000,000 on the open market between June 15 and Aug. 2.

Mayor Wagner's decision to appoint Dr. Harry J. Carman, dean emeritus of Columbia College, to the Board of Higher Education was praised yesterday by Mrs. Margaret S. Lewisohn, chairman of the board of trustees of the Public Education Association.
American schools and colleges must receive more financial support at once if they are to continue to do their job adequately, spokesmen for industry and education agreed yesterday.
Following is the text of the summary and conclusion contained in the report of state officials to Governor Dewey on the city's request for fiscal aid:

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Feb. 28 -- Hendrik Verwoerd, Minister of Native Affairs and the man charged with carrying out the Government's apartheid (racial separation) policy, acknowledged in an interview this weekend that apartheid was moving very slowly.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The aviation technical magazine Aero Digest today reported what it called "exclusive facts" on some of the nation's newest guided missiles.

Sentiment is growing among state as well as Federal officials for legislation making charitable and philanthropic foundations more accountable to the public for the use they make of the funds at their disposal.

The Concert Society of New York completed its first season at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon, and its sixteenth and final concert sustained the high standards of the series, both. in the interest and worth of the music performed and in the artists engaged to perform it.

THE break-up of television's pioneer comedy team of Sid Caesar and Imogene Coca does not come as surprising news. Sooner or later the split was inevitable, both for the two stars and their producer, Max Liebman. The trio's program, "Your Show of Shows," simply had run its course.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, in a personal letter to President Eisenhower, has rejected the United States offer of military aid to India.

NO man living can remember when Washington Street Market was built. Even men who hold market sites handed down by their fathers and grandfathers don't seem to know when the original buildings went up.
WOR and WOR-TV got along Saturday night and yesterday without musicians and will continue to do so until a settlement with their union is reached.

Joan Rowland, a 23-year-old pianist from Toronto, who had been heard in this city in 1948, gave her second local recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Her difficult program was well devised, and all of it was accurately and expressively played.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- The Dewey Administration is considering two proposals for broadening the state's unemployment insurance program to conform, at least in part, to recommendations by President Eisenhower.
Memo to George Washington Bridge motorists:
New financing declined sharply in February.

There is increasing evidence that the Communist tactics are shifting from military pressure in Vietnam to political and propaganda pressure, both there and in France, in preparation for the Geneva conference in April. The tempo of Vietminh military operations has slowed down appreciably.
Mrs. Rebecca Shulman, president of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, outlined last night a program to "clarify the objectives of the Zionist movement" in this country.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Johnny Palmer won the $12,000 Mexican open golf tournament today with a 5 over par 77 for 286 as a rally by Argentine Roberto De Vicenzo fell short by one stroke.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Canada defeated Norway, 8 -- 0, before 4,722 today for its second victory in two games in the world ice hockey championships.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 (AP) -- A deafening explosion blew two three-story buildings to destruction in heavily populated South Philadelphia tonight, killing five persons.

The Reading Company reported yesterday for 1953 a net income of $12,481,217, or $6.92 a common share, compared with $11,676,307 or $6.34 in 1952. Gross revenues were $132,825,609, against $131,854,486.

The Kenmore Hall Hotel, a twenty-two-story and penthouse building on plot 78 by 98.9 feet at 145 East Twenty-third Street, near Lexington Avenue, has been leased by the Kenmore Syndicate, representing Robert M. Souers and Bernard Saltzman, hotel operators.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 28 -- The arrival of Alvin Dark, the news that Whitey Lockman had agreed to terms and an eight-inning intrasquad game, "masterminded" by Comedians Dean Martin and Jerry Lewis made for an interesting day at the Giants' training camp today.
In carrying passengers and cargoes for the nation's armed forces last year, forty-one ships of the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service took time out to engage in missions of mercy.

The past few days have been tumultuous ones in much of the Near East. Yesterday's shootings and riots in Cairo and Damascus followed last week's military coups in Egypt and Syria. Civil war on a large scale is a possibility in both countries, the intricacies of whose internal political situation is best illustrated by General Naguib's quick fall from and then partial return to power.

The New York Telephone Company, largest operating unit in the $12,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company system, reported yesterday that it had caught up with nearly all the record breaking post-war demand for telephone service.

John Patrick, who struck a gold mine with "The Teahouse of the August Moon," aims to branch out in the musical field for the first time. His fancy has been stirred by a song and dance version of Cleveland Amory's successful book, "The Last Resorts," on which Mr. Patrick has taken an eighteen-month option.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Albert A. Beres, commander of the Norwalk (Conn.) Post of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, said today his group "followed to the letter the turning in of names" of persons considered Communistic, as suggested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Students at Finch College headed by Miss Jill McConnell and Miss Sandrea Ogilvie are furthering the success o the annual ball of the college to be held Saturday night in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. Aiding also in the plans are members of the college's alumnae.

The Roman Catholic Church of St. Benedict the Moor, 342 West Fifty-third Street, established in 1883 for Negroes coming from the South, was rededicated yesterday morning to serve Spanish-speaking migrants. Cardinal Spellman presided at a solemen mass, which was celebrated by Msgr. Hugh F. Gilmartin of the Sacred Heart Church, 457 West Fifty-first Street.

LOUIS KRONENBERGER, drama critic of Time, authority on the eighteenth century and witty and erudite writer, is an intellectual whose brow may be formidably high but whose feet are generally planted firmly on the ground. A deft man with a polished phrase, a competent coiner of aphorisms and paradoxes and a cheerfully savage observer of the current scene, Mr. Kronenberger is not pleased by the behavior of his American contemporaries.
The days of the Inquisition are returning with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as "undisputed high priest," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- George M. Humphrey, Secretary of the Treasury, said today he would approve "a selective reduction" in excise (sales) taxes.

The Crimea, until the war one of the "autonomous republics" of the Soviet Union, and since then reduce to the status of a province of the Russian republic, has now become a part of the Ukraine. The Moscow edict ordaining this transfer is explained as a move to assist the "further strengthening of the brotherly ties between the Ukrainian and Russian peoples."

CAIRO, Feb. 28 -- Egypt's recently feuding military rulers made an effort today to re-establish the appearance of unity. Success or failure of their attempts to woo the Sudan into some form of union with Egypt was their most immediate stake.
When the Bellevue housing project is built, it will replace one of the city's tenement villages in which candy store and tavern are town forums.
FERNDALE, N. Y., Feb. 28 -- Seven employes died and twenty-six were injured early today in a fire that destroyed a staff cottage at Grossinger's Hotel, largest resort in the Catskills.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Feb. 28 -- Important measures have been taken to freeze, by voluntary agreement, some of the large surpluses held by Dutch private banks.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Feb. 28 (UP) -- Tony Trabert, national singles champion, defeated Vic Seixas, his Davis Cup team-mate, 6 -- 4, 14 -- 12, today to win the Buffalo Tennis and Squash Club invitation indoor tennis tournament.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Judge Francis J. Good has ordered the Puget Sound Power and Light Company to open its list of stockholders to a shareholders' committee seeking to elect a board of directors favorable to merger with the Washington Water Power Company.

Sacrilege though it may seem to suggest a possible link between the great Chief Justice John Marshall and Karl Marx, when Marshall penned the words, "The power to tax involves the power to destroy," he gave judicial sanction to the fundamental objective of Marxian socialism -- the expropriation of all private wealth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A complete census of manufactures, mineral industries and of retail, wholesale and service trades should be taken "as soon as practicable," a special committee studying the Bureau of the Census said today.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 28 -- New peaks were reached in 1953 by the Tennessee Gas Transmission Company, one of the nation's major transporters of fuel, in net income, volume of natural gas delivered to customers, and delivery capacity of its system.

PARIS, Monday, March 1 -- The Communist candidate ran far ahead in a Parliamentary election in the Department of Seine et Oise yesterday, but a run-off election will be required next Sunday to determine the winner.

Caracas, Venezuela, bursting with the wealth of its oil wells, a city half-Skyscraper half-colonial palace, in a lovely mountain setting and a climate of perpetual spring, will be the scene today of a great opening ceremony. The Tenth Inter-American Conference is bound to be of considerable importance, because these meetings always are truly historic in magnitude.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- special committee of state officials recommended today that Mayor Wagner's request for $50,000,000 in additional real estate taxing power for the City of New York be shaved to $38,000,000.

Four years ago next April the Federal Government entered upon a ten-year program to improve the condition of the Navajo and Hopi Indians. Former President Truman, signing the enabling act, called it "an important milestone in our Government's administration of Indian affairs."
DAMASCUS, Feb. 28 (Reuters) -- Renewed clashes between street demonstrators and troops in the center of Damascus came after the radio this morning had broadcast an appeal for calm.

GUATEMALA, Feb. 28 -- President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman will open a new session of Guatemala's unicameral Congress tomorrow. The President's speech has taken on more than ordinary significance in view of the opening the same day of the tenth Inter-American Conference at Caracas.

While Wes Santee, out in Kansas City, was missing the mark by six and a half seconds in his bid for a four-minute mile, the Eastern varsity track set put on a memorable competitive show at Madison Square Garden.

Gino Penno sang his third major role at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night when he appeared as Radames in the season's third "Aida." This was the part in which the Italian tenor was to have made his debut, but, because of his illness on Feb. 13, he did not sing it then, and in the meantime he has appeared as Alvaro in "La Forza del Destina" and Manrico in "Il Trovatore."

On Feb. 18 you published a letter from Rollo May protesting a bill introduced in the New York State Legislature for the definition of the practice of medicine in relation to nervous and mental disorders. In his letter Dr. May made a number of grossly erroneous statements, and these call for specific corrections.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Eisenhower defined United States world leadership today as a reflection of the fervent desires of all Americans "for an enduring peace" and preservation of "our way of life."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- There seemed to be no point in shilly-shallying or beating about the bush. The manly way to do it was to fire the question point blank in relentless, prosecuting attorney style. The witness, Stan Musial, already had been sworn in and either had to answer or take refuge behind the Fifth Amendment.
TOURANE AIR BASE, Vietnam, Feb. 28 (AP) -- The 252 United States airmen and officers in Indo-China can hear the gunfire, but they never get into the fray.
A wide variety of exhibitions is offered among the art attractions in museums and galleries this week.

LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Labor party opponents of West German rearmament made it clear today that they had no intention of compromising with their leaders even though the issue was threatening to wreck the party.

TENAFLY, N. J., Feb. 28 -- The Lyle Campanile, a landmark here since 1912 and a monument to a strange romance of that day, will disappear tomorrow, under the encroachment of a changing and growing suburban population. The major work of demolition was completed yesterday and all that remains to be moved tomorrow are fragments of stone.

Corporation Counsel Adrian P. Burke announced yesterday that he had retained the engineering concern of Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., and Manfred K. Toeppen of Los Angeles to help the city oppose rate increases sought by the New York Telephone Company.

WRIGHT, Wyo., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Wreckage of the Western Air Lines Convair, which crashed Friday with nine persons aboard, was spotted today by a search plane near this town, west of the Black Hills and in prairie country. There were no signs of life.

TRENTON, Feb. 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner conferred here for several hours today with Democratic state leaders in an unsuccessful attempt to agree on a candidate for the party's United States Senate nomination.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said yesterday that he did not believe President Eisenhower "wants to curb my powers." Asked about Washington reports that the President was seeking to restrain him, the Senator replied:...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused eight major ice cream manufacturers and fifty-five of their subsiriaries of engaging in unfair methods of competition in the sale and distribution of ice cream.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28 -- Things seem to fall into a fixed pattern with the Yankees. They have a routine they follow with exacting zeal until October finds another pennant and world championship tucked away.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Following are the votes of the mem-j bers from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Con'ess during the period Feb. 20 through Feb. 27.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The Atomic Energy Commission soon will lose one of its most brilliant public servants. He is Prof. Henry DeWolf Smyth, who has been a commissioner since 1949.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- The events of the last week have been one of a conflicting character and on the whole have tended to depress rather than to strengthen the markets.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 28 -- Failure of the managing board of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation to reach agreement last week in Paris even in principle on plans for enabling the European Payments Union to continue operations after June 30 has aroused great uneasiness in Switzerland.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP) -- Increased distribution of surplus butter and other government-held food to unemployed families was proposed today by three Democratic Senators.
LONDON, Feb. 28 -- Delay in reaching agreement on Britain's share of a new company to work Iran's oil fields has held up negotiations here among eight oil concerns.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 28 -- Modern Madison Avenue may trace its advertising roots to the Renaissance, an exhibition of "emblem books" in the Princeton University library, indicates.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -Arriving here from New York, Mr. McCarthy disclosed that his subcommittee tomorrow "probably" would question an Army "major." He would not identify the officer, however, or indicate why he had been called to testify.
AARE, Sweden, Feb. 28 -- Stein Eriksen, Norwegian and Olympic slalom champion, ran true to form today by easily capturing the slalom title in the world championships.
Canon Darby W. Betty, preceptor of the New York Cathedral (St. John the D{vine), in a sermon there yesterday morning emphasized the value of love in solv[ ng problems in human relations.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 28 -- The tenth Inter-American Conference meets here tomorrow in no quaint atmosphere of Colonial Spain, but in a group of university buildings that are modern to the point of being almost startling.
Holy Cross and Bowling Green of Ohio accepted bids yesterday to the National Invitation basketball tournament, which is scheduled to open with a triple-header at Madison Square Garden on Saturday.
Last year for the first time four advertising agencies in this country had billings of more than $100,000,000.
Cotton prices in the domestic market continued to move irregularly within a narrow trading range last week.

Wendell Anderson, baritone from Boston, gave his first New York program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall George Reeves was at the piano. The arias by Rameau and Lully, the group by Hahn and the songs of Milhaud and Honegger gave French music the preponderance of the program.
CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- Although Republican party historians are in full agreement that the party was born in 1854, a century of dispute has failed to settle the time and place.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 28 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, heading the United States delegation to the tenth Inter-American Conference, arrived late this afternoon.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 28 -- The expected pick-up in steel output did not materialize during the latter half of February, but neither did a significant decline in production take place.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Feb. 28 -- Hashem al-Atassi became President of Syria tonight in succession to Brig. Gen. Adib Shishekly, who resigned Thursday and fled after an army re volt against him. Mr. al-Atassi, who is 80 years old, was Syrian President in November, 1951, when General Shishekly seized power.
The state's chief labor trouble-shooter succeeded yesterday in heading off a total embargo of waterfront truck movements.

The New York Rangers "got a life" last night. They defeated the Canadiens of Montreal, 2 to 0, and kept up their hopes of gaining a berth for the Stanley Cup play-offs that follow the regular National Hockey League season.

Whatever may happen in the Port of New York this week, the public should be aware that since the A. F. L. began its efforts to eliminate racketeering a year ago the port has been at the mercy of almost any incident. This is exactly what has led up to the present imbroglio involving the rival longshore unions, the teamsters union, the trucking industry employers, the New York Shipping Association and the employing stevedores.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 28 -- The pension program established by Loew's, Inc., (parent of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer) ten years ago becomes effective tomorrow.

Last night was an all-Robbins night for the New City Ballet at the City Center. when four ballets by Jerome Robbins, associated artistic director of the company, comprised the program. They were the new "Quartet," "Age of Anxiety," "Afternoon of a Faun" and "Fanfare."

The reader mailbag furnishes the basis for today's column. The first letter is from an amateur cook in Brockton, Mass., who comments on the Pekin duck recipe that appeared here a week ago. The writer of the letter, who has lived in Pekin, says k'ao ya-tze, as the dish is called there, is "one of the world's gastronomic treats." He writes:

It was a springlike day at Newport, R. I. A group of boys was playing softball on the lawn in front of St. George's School, which is pitched on a high bluff. Below, the waters of the Atlantic Ocean glistened. The temperature was about 65 degrees.

Two vocational high school students were told they had been "mollycoddled too much" when Magistrate Joseph A. Martinis in Bronx Court held them in $2,500 bail each yesterday for a hearing today on third-degree assault charges.
Net sales of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation rose 9 per cent last year to a record of $1,582,047,000 and earnings gained 8 per cent, the company reported yesterday.

Jim Marugg was a young sports writer on The Pasadena Star-News when polio struck. He and his mother-in-law, Anne Walters, tell the story of his nine-month fight through the pain and handicap of the disease in "Beyond Endurance," which Harper will issue March 17.

Valonia macrophysa, not an Italian movie star but a marine alga, may have put our scientists on the track of a practicable method of extracting fresh water from sea water. The cell fluid of valonia, it appears, contains forty-two times as much potassium ion as the water in which she spends her life and only a fifth as much sodium ion concentration.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams asserted yesterday that our basic freedoms were under "vicious attack today," and that for the most part the attacks were made "under the guise of virtue."
Examinations for licensed Merchant Marine officers who want Coast Guard commissions will be held today, Tuesday and Wednesday at 80 Lafayette Street.

Racial bias and discrimination "come from the training of little children" in segregated schools, retired Federal District Judge F. Waties Waring declared yesterday. He told the congregation of the Rendall Memorial Church (Presbyterian) at 59 West 137th Street, that "the wall of segregation crumbles only when somebody swings a hammer."
Yonkers Raceway is slated to receive major attention today when the Moreland Act Commission opens its public hearings here on the state's scandal-tainted harness racing tracks.

The Travelers Aid Society of New York will be the beneficiary of the 1954 Belmont Ball to be held on June 11 at the Turf and Field Club at Belmont Park. Proceeds from the forthcoming fete will be donated to the work of the organization, which aids travelers in temporary distress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UP) -- Senator Thomas A. Burke asked the Post Office Department today why it had ended a Military Air Transport contract and had arranged for less frequent mail service to Guam by a private airline.
Silhouettes featuring Empire and princess lines were stressed in the spring collection of ensembles and dresses shown Friday by Lord Taylor in its third floor dress salon.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- The grain trade last week showed little change from recent characteristics. Wheat futures edged up to new highs on the movement for old crop months and to new seasonal highs for the new crop futures. Corn, oats and rye have been conspicuously heavy.
ANTWERP, Belgium, Feb. 28 -- The flow of goods from Western to Communist countries through this great transit port has more than doubled since the death of Stalin, a survey indicates.
BERLIN, N. H., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Art Devlin of the Lake Placid (N Y.) Sno Birds won the international competition today at the Nansen Ski Club's 80-meter hill.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Feb. 28 -- Rene Pleven, French Defense Minister, completed a month's investigation of the Indo-China war situation today and left by plane for Paris. M. Plevin, the highest French official to visit here in many years, will make a report that is expected to have great influence on both French and United States policies in this area.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in February was slightly less than in the preceding month, but larger than in the corresponding month a year ago. This increase resulted from the extra business session on Lincoln's Birthday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- President Eisenhower urged all Americans today to support the Red Cross, declaring that it "abundantly provides faith in the innate goodness of people, in their ability to work together for the nation's good."
PUSAN, Korea, Monday, March 1 -- President Syngman Rhee is again threatening to march north and unite Korea by force.

Doris Humphrey has been chosen as the recipient of the third annual Capezio Dance Award for "her creative leadership in the modern dance and for the repertoire of high distinction with which she has enriched it." Besides the citation, the honor carries with it a prize of $500.
Grants to higher education and social science agencies predominated in the $5,037,113 distributed by the Carnegie Corporation of New York in the 1952-53 fiscal year.

In deals in the Flatbush area of Brooklyn the Manor Realty Company, brokers, sold a one-family dwelling at 1050 East Tenth Street for Leonard Wohlstater to Sidney Lachman and a two-family house at 1552 East Thirty-third Street for Joseph Rodgers to Bernard Schulman.

Bellini's "Norma" will be the new production of the Metropolitan Opera's seventeenth week. Zinka Milanov, who sang the title role in the opera's revival during the 1944-45 season, will be almost the only member of the cast who will not be new to the Metropolitan in her role.

The Lillian Russell Museum, on the second floor of Luchow's Restaurant, 110 East Fourteenth Street, was dedicated last night by Helen Hayes at a party she gave for Jack Benny. The event followed Miss Hayes' appearance on Mr. Benny's television program.

The Society for the Second Performance of American Music, under the direction of Robert Mandell, gave a laudable initial concert Saturday night in the auditorium of the New School. The purpose of the organization is revealed in its name. There is no need to expatiate upon the importance of this purpose, for it is self-evident.

The Rev. Edwin B. Broderick declared yesterday that an effort to live a full Christian life of love and personal helpfulness to others was a better way of observing Lent than mere self-imposed abstinence from favorite foods, tobacco or legitimate recreation.

Although the rate of steel operations this year may be difficult to forecast, the chances of maintaining a generally high level of employment are good for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, according to Eugene G. Grace, chairman.

STOWE, Vt., Feb. 28 -- You can't stop a good skier. Take the case of Billy Beck, the Dartmouth senior who had suffered a broken right ankle while training with the American Federation Internationale de Ski Alpine team at Kitzbuhel, Austria. last month.
It may well be that the old Mark Twain house at 21 Fifth Avenue will be saved from demolition in the nick of time, just as such things would happen in a Mark Twain story.

JESSORE, Pakistan, Feb. 28 -- For the first time since the announcement of United States military aid to Pakistan Prime Minister Mohammed Ali assured Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today that Pakistan did not "want to take Kashmir by force, but by plebiscite."

CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 28 -- The lifting of all Venezuelan censorship on foreign correspondents' messages during the conference of American States was announced today by Ernesto Vallenilla Diaz, secretary general of the conference.

A tree nursery will be established in Israel honoring Mayor Wagner for his efforts in behalf of Israel. The announcement was made last night at the Commodore Hotel at the forty-sixth annual dinner of Bnai Zion, the oldest Zionist fraternal group in this country.

NEW DELHI, India, Feb. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's Congress party is winning an important state election in North India but is losing an even more important special poll to Leftists in the South.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- It was obvious, even to the least expert of the old gaffers in the grandstand, that the stocky outfielder in the Cardinal uniform just wasn't a major league prospect. He had lots of hustle but no range. Manager Eddie Stanky, whose roving eyes never miss a thing, ignored him completely.

LONDON, March 1 -- Sir David Eccles, Minister of Works, outlined in Parliament today the British Government's plan to invest "boldly and heavily" in atomic energy. He offered the plan as a key to expanding prosperity at home and to future "immense orders" abroad.

Rejection of the Bricker amendment and all of the collateral, substitute and compromise proposals that went with it is the one major -- if negative -- action of the Senate thus far this session. Even though a single vote would have changed the outcome, the country is fortunate that that one vote was lacking.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- Puerto Rico's spokesman in Congress said the Puerto Rican gunmen must have been "carrying out a Communist plot" today when they shot five Representatives on the House floor.
The last tenant in the old Mark Twain house at 21 Fifth Avenue moved at noon yesterday as demolition of the American humorist's former home became imminent.

The Texas Gas Transmission Company, one of the nation's largest natural gas pipelines, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $4,724,000 in 1953, an increase of $1,235,000 over its 1952 net of $3,489,000. Earnings were equal to $1.59 a common share last year, against $1.14 a share the year before. Gross revenues jumped to $63,329,000 from $47,455,000 in 1952.

COLOGNE, Germany, March 1 -- Take an American Legion convention in New York and a Shriners' parade in Omaha. Add a dash of the New Orleans Mardi Gras and a pinch of European politics. Sprinkle liberally with confetti and let the mixture soak for several hours in good Rhine wine, German beer and champagne.

Children's Village is giving up a large part of its pioneer program in self-government for maladjusted boys and turning to a new experiment that will seek a psychiatric treatment "climate" instead. The plan will serve fewer boys but will provide more individual attention.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Senators Joseph R. McCarthy and Everett M. Dirksen suggested today "disagreeable" labor camps for armed services personnel who were Communists or who invoked the Fifth Amendment when asked about Communist associations.

Al McGuire will be in the starting line-up to guard Bob Cousy when the Knickerbockers tangle with the Boston Celtics in the feature game of a doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight. Clashing in the opener will be the Rochester Royals and Fort Wayne Pistons.
The March lion made a fairly traditional entrance yesterday.

Because there has been no urgent appeal for the conservation of water we hope that New Yorkers and their neighbors in near-by communities will not feel that all is well in the reservoirs. Our new Water Commissioner, Arthur C. Ford, gave a clear picture of the situation when he said that "while the water-supply picture is not bright, it is not alarming and a shortage is not foreseen."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 1 -- A dispute over television rights caused Hecht-Lancaster Productions to call off today its arrangement with Universal-International to borrow Mari Blanchard to co-star with Burt Lancaster and Gary Cooper in "Vera Cruz."

CAIRO, March 1 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib owes his reinstatement as President of Egypt to agitation begun by eight Communist army officers, according to a statement made tonight by a spokesman for the ruling military junta that deposed General Naguib Thursday and recalled him Saturday.
TOKYO, March 1 (UP) -- Japan will begin building warplanes for the first time since the end of World War II under the terms of an agreement announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower invited seventeen guests to a stag dinner at the White House tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Atomic Energy Commission today announced the first in a new series of test explosions at its Pacific proving ground in the Marshall Islands.
LONDON, March 1 -- Harringay Arena, a London equivalent of Madison Square Garden, was crowded to capacity tonight for the opening of the "crusade" of Billy Graham, American evangelist.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1 -- Prime Minister Nehru's announcement that he favored the withdrawal of United States personnel from the United Nations commission in Kashmir presented a situation without precedent here.
The one-man shows opening yesterday bring forward highly individual modern work.
New issues of more than $36,000,000 of common stock of public utility and industrial companies will be offered to investors today. The offerings are as follows:

Justice is mocked by McCarthy's tactics. His cure is worse than the disease. Our friends abroad are appalled, as your reports show. French and Italian Communists must rejoice to see America more and more divided by this demagogue.

As soon as Stevens became convinced that McCarthy had a case against the Army his cause was lost. He had in effect accepted the McCarthy hypotheses that any form of association with suspect individuals or causes is equivalent to treason and that accusation is equivalent to proof.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 1 -- The oft-delayed trial of Walter G. Winne, the superseded prosecutor of Bergen County, on charges of misconduct in office based on a sixteen-count indictment alleging failure to halt gambling operations began here today.

Tax laws have been a major factor in promoting the growth of charitable and philanthropic foundations in the United States from around 200 in 1930 to upwards of 30,000 today. The benefits conferred by these laws are also a consideration in prevailing efforts to make foundations accountable for their activities.
A house-to-house, block by block inspection of four tenement areas in the city -- one each in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens -- began yesterday.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 13,023 pints of blood in February. Collections last Friday totaled 557 pints, including 193 at Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church, Pelhamdale Avenue and Boston Post Road, Pelham, N. Y., and 144 at the American Express Company, 65 Broadway.
A wiser use of human resources was recommended for Israel yesterday as a means of promoting that country's economic self-sufficiency.
Last-ditch efforts by Federal mediators failed to avert a strike today by 2,200 engineers engaged in vital defense production at the Sperry Gyroscope Company plant in Lake Success, L. I.

Earl Warren was confirmed yesterday as Chief Justice of the United States with the expected virtually total lack of opposition. There wasn't anything whatever to be said against Mr. Warren's character or ability. The so-called "charges" brought against him in Senator Langer's Judiciary Committee were reckless, unfounded and insulting not only to Mr. Warren but to the Senate itself and to the American public.
While rails eased slightly in yesterday's stock market, industrials pushed ahead and brought prices to within shooting distance of the year's high, established on Feb. 5.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 1 (UP) -- Ted Williams, Boston Red Sox slugger, who escaped unscathed from two plane crashes in Korea, broke his collarbone today after fifteen minutes of his first spring training workout.

The long expected merger of Consolidated-Vultee Aircraft into General Dynamics Corporation -- constituting one of the most important corporate complexes in the defense picture -- was approved yesterday by the boards of both companies.

There was madness in the air when the Puerto Ricans stood up in the gallery of the House of Representatives and blazed away. No other explanation makes sense and any other description would be a libel on the friendly Puerto Rican people. They could not be held responsible for the attempted assassination of President Truman a few years ago and they were not.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- After it was all over, Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. observed that "according to the rules of the House, nothing can interfere with the taking of a vote."

A psychiatrist, a theologian, the city's Commissioner of Health, a newspaper editor, the head of a family service agency and directors of two civic groups yesterday presented their points of view on the sources of individual courage. They considered -- each in his own way -- the imperative need for this quality in living today and ways that families may help to foster it.
A new lighting concept and some good-looking variations on conventional designs for illumination are displayed in two new collections of lamps for the home.
ROME, March 1 -- The Vatican announced today that Pope Pius XII had definitely improved during the last few days.

LOS ANGELES, March 1 -- The volume of new construction throughout the nation in 1954 will approach last year's record total of $34,800,000,000, it was predicted today as the nation's contractors opened their thirty-fifth annual convention.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., March 1 (UP) -- Kentucky's Wildcats tonight became the first major college basketball team since 1939 to roll to an undefeated season of twenty or more games. They routed an outclassed Alabama five, 68 to 43, for their twenty-fourth victory.
The $60,000,000 modernization and expansion program of the Detroit Steel Corporation's Portsmouth division at Portsmouth, Ohio, designed to double ingot capacity, has been completed.

LONDON, March 1 -- A leading British industrialist said today that many Britons were hesitating about seeking orders from the Soviet Union and other Iron Curtain countries because of their uncertainty about the permanence of this trade.

In a move to consolidate its facilities, Ar Winarich, Inc., of the Bronx, manufacturer of hair tonics and beauty parlor supplies, has purchased about 150,000 square feet of the Mack Truck property in New Brunswick, N. J. The David T. Houston Company and Simon Newman Jr. were co-brokers in the transaction.
The first commercial shipment of Iranian sturgeon to this country since Iran declined to renew its fishing treaty with Russia and nationalized its fishing industry arrived here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Five members of the Congress of The United States were shot down on the floor of the House of Representatives today.
The Jarka Corporation, one of the world's largest stevedoring enterprises, decided yesterday to stop operating in the Port of New York.

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 1 -- President Hashem al-Atassi brought a promise of the restoration of civilian government upon his triumphant arrival here today after five coup-ridden years of one military regime after another.

Women headed by Mrs. A. Schuyler Clark and Mrs. Kelley Keresey, and including Mrs. James Butler and Mrs. Anthony M. Del Balso, are furthering plans for the dinner dance for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club to be held April 22 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Mr. Butler is president and Edward P. Hamilton is chairman of the board of the beneficiary.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 1 (AP) -- Brown scored its third Eastern Intercollegiate League basketball victory tonight, upsetting Columbia, 60 -- 56, in overtime.

CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- Walter Williams, Under Secretary of Commerce, declared today that "the period of inflation is past" and that "we are passing through a period of readjustment in a manner which I think amazes even us."
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- The Navy asked Congress today for authority to scrap or sell the famed Constellation, its oldest fighting ship.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 1 -- Guatemala forced the first vote of the tenth Inter-American Conference today and was defeated, 14 to 4.

Over the week-end the Secretary of the Treasury, George M. Humphrey, made known his position on proposals for tax reductions that had been put forward recently by the Republican and Democratic leadership respectively. In the process of doing so he has demonstrated anew that he does not regard fiscal policy as something that one picks out of the air as a matter of political expediency.

Manhattan's basketball team registered the highest point total in the history of the college last night when it swept to a 104-to-36 triumph over Brooklyn College in the victor's gymnasium in the Bronx. The victory was the fifteenth in twenty-four starts for the Jaspers.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 1 -- President Marcos Perez Jimenez of Venezuela opened the tenth Inter-American Conference today with a plea for closer unity among the American States on the basis of sovereignty and equality.

KHARTUM, the Sudan, March 1 -- The arrival in the Sudan today of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Egyptian President, revived factional passions of this nascent state in a clash in which at least twenty-two persons were killed. [The Associated Press placed the toll at thirty-one.]

New York churchgoers will mark tomorrow the opening of the penitential season of Lent at Ash Wednesday services in every section of the city. The forty-day Lenten period, not including Sundays, will end with the colorful Easter festival on April 18.
ALBANY, March 1 (UP) -- One center in New York State had skiing today, the State Department of Commerce reported. At Whiteface Mountain the skiing was poor on four to eight inches of wet snow.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- As full-scale spring training got under way today on Miller Huggins Field with more than a score of Yankees scampering all over the place, it would be difficult to say which player drew most attention from the manager.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The narrow margin of one vote by which the Senate refused to give the necessary two-thirds to the final form of the Bricker amendment, and the strong statements why an amendment is needed that were made by those Senators facing re-election among the large majority in favor of restraints on the treaty-making power and Executive agreements, presage the revival of this movement at the next session of Congress.

GUATEMALA, March 1 -- President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman declared specifically today that the Soviet Union had not intervened, was not intervening and did not threaten to intervene in the internal affairs of Guatemala.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower issued instructions today on when and how long the flag of the United States should be flown at half-staff.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Congress put into effect tight security precautions tonight in a sequel to today's shooting in the House of Representatives.

LONDON, March 1 -- Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, told the House of Commons today that Britain made representations to the United States last June and July about the shadowing of British vessels in passage between United States ports. He said there had been no recurrence of this practice.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 1 -- The Hutchinson River Parkway was condemned by engineers today as being so deadly and overcrowded that it should be totally rebuilt for $35,326,000.

American support for Israel because of her strategic position in the Middle East as a democratic nation was urged yesterday by Mrs. Samuel W. Halprin, only woman member of the Jewish Agency for Israel.

Gov. Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico denounced the shooting of members of Congress in Washington yesterday as "savage and unbelievable lunacy which does not express in the most remote way the peaceful and decent nature of the people of Puerto Rico."
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- The Navy announced today it was ending separate enlistment of stewards, a move aimed at changing the present pre-dominantly Negro composition of its stewards' branch.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Earl Warren of California was confirmed by the Senate today as the fourteenth Chief Justice of the United States.
MEXICO CITY, March 1 -- A concentration of troops was reported today in the State of Veracruz, in the area of the new Papaloapam dam.

" A Queen's Royal Tour," originally scheduled to open at the Guild on Thursday will have its premiere this morning. Filmed in Eastman Color, the feature traces the journey of Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh through the South Pacific.
Twenty-two persons responded yesterday to the appeal of Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack for information as to the location of street holes and broken pavements.

Manhattan College will face Dayton and St. Francis of Brooklyn will oppose Louisville in two of the three games that will open the National Invitation Basketball Tournament at Madison Square Garden next Saturday.

The Nebraska Public Power System announced yesterday that it will receive bids on April 6 for $17,600,000 of revenue bonds of the Loup River Public Power District. The issue will consist of $10,000,000 of Series D and about $7,600,000 of Series F. The obligations will be callable and will come due semi-annually over thirty-five years.
LONDON, March 1 -- British Government securities were the firmest spot on the markets here today.

THE English, someone once noticed, are an unpredictable and even paradoxical nation. No one sets more store by traditional decorum, what's done and what isn't, than a right-thinking Englishman. But no one either is more likely to be a rampant individualist cultivating absurd eccentricities than an Englishman.

MIAMI, March 1 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami captured the Miami invitation tennis tourney singles honors by defeating Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., 6 -- 2, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 4, today. It was his sixth consecutive tournament victory.

A fire lieutenant and two firemen received medals and cash awards yesterday for rescues from drowning. William D. Winter, president of the Life Saving Benevolent Association of New York, bestowed the awards in a ceremony in the Municipal Building office of Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.
MIAMI, March 1 (AP) -- Gainsboro Girl, 4-year-old filly who had never gone the mile and a furlong, won the $32,900 Black Helen handicap at Hialeah Park before 21,553 racing fans today.

Busy New Yorker paused a few minutes yesterday morning where two of Manhattan's main thoroughfares cross and were reminded that a hero lay buried there.
