The New York general, William Jenkins Worth, for whom this city's Worth Street and Fort Worth, Tex., were named, was honored by Texans, New Yorkers and the Army at the monument erected in 1857 over his grave at Broadway and Fifth Avenue.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1 -- United Nations economists put forward a warning today that Western Europe might not be able to meet the shock of a deepened recession in the United States.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has vetoed a merger of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., and Colonial Airlines, Inc.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 28 -- United States authorities here are annoyed and concerned over the determined attempt by the Iraian Government to put pressure on Japan to buy Iranian rice well above the prevailing world prices.

The nation's steel mills are expected to produce 1,682,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, on a scheduled operating rate of 70.5 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compares with 1,756,000 tons turned out last week on 73.6 per cent of operations.
Blood collected through your Red Cross is a free gift of the donor, made for neighbor,...
Alexander Flandreau has been appointed sales promotion manager of the arms and ammunition division of Olin Industries, Inc.
SEOUL, Korea, March 1 -- Koreans by the tens of thousands marched through Seoul today demanding that the war with the Communists be resumed and condemning, the forthcoming Geneva conference.

Victor E. Pereira, described as one of the country's top confidence men, was arrested here yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a bench warrant issued by the United States District Court in El Paso, Tex.

Mayor Wagner promised yesterday, in a speech at Police Headquarters, to continue to fight "on the highest level" at Albany for state assistance in the city's financial difficulties. He praised the Police Department, pledge anew complete support of Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams and said city employes should receive adequate compensation.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- It looked like just another working day for the five Representatives. As it turned out, it was one such as they had not experienced in the forty-two years of their combined service in the House.

Coffee prices continued to climb on the New York exchanges while cocoa prices fell for the first time since Feb. 10. Activity was light on most commodities but soybean oil had the second highest volume of the year. Prices moved higher with coffee, soybean oil, cottonseed oil, wool, potatoes, burlap, tin and lead stronger; cocoa, hides and rubber lower, and sugar, copper and zinc mixed.

The shoe industry and the soft goods field in general have gone through a period of readjustment in the last few years and now are approaching a period of good business, according to Irving R. Glass, executive vice president of the Tanners Council of America.

The Student Council of Queens College adopted yesterday a declaration that the publication in campus newspapers of advertisements from organizations on the Attorney General's subversive list would be dangerous to the welfare of the college.
Mayor Wagner joined other city officials yesterday in criticizing Governor Dewey and the Republican Administration in Albany for failing to provide state funds for child day care centers here.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1 -- Three spokesmen for British Togoland peoples put on their colorful African dress today to make an appeal to the United Nations Trusteeship Council.

Sales in New York City's department stores in February were approximately 3.3 per cent more than in February, 1953, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times. This was a comparison of eleven stores with the same eleven stores last year.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Treasury announced tonight that its short term borrowing costs have again gone above 1 per cent a year. Its latest offering of $1,500,000,000 of ninety-one day bills was sold at an average price equal to an annual interest rate of 1.059 per cent.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 1 -- Smith College alumnae have received a suggestion that they withhold contributions to Smith until five faculty members explain their "associations" with a number of organizations.

WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP) -A Senate Banking subcommittee investigating the-rise in coffee prices decided today to hear from the ~fonr clubwbmen who recently went to Brazil to study the Situation. They will appear at a pubUC hearing 'on Friday.

The horrifying riot in Khartum yesterday, with its high casualties and its savage violence and fanaticism, should be a lesson to all concerned and especially to the Egyptians. The demonstration was aimed at President Naguib of Egypt, although he is half Sudanese and to a majority of the politically conscious elements even a hero.

TETERBORO, N. J., March 1 -- Two men were killed here today when a small private airplane in which they were returning from Florida crashed and burned on the center island of a heavily traveled highway. The plane went into a spin while the pilot was attempting a landing at Teterboro Airport in rainy weather.
Market prices of high-grade long-term corporate and Government bonds rose sharply again yesterday.

Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation has acquired a 77 per cent interest in Newport Steel Corporation and will operate it as a majority-owned subsidiary, Louis E. Wolfson, president and chairman of the construction company, announced yesaerday.

IF there is a single book capable of giving the modern sportsman a clear picture of the fish and game situation, involving causes and effects, and the many factors influencing both, that volume is Durward L. Allen's "Our Wildlife Legacy."

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) estimated yesterday that its consolidated net income last year had reached a record high of $553,000,000 after all charges and taxes. This is equal to $9.13 each on the 60,571,082 capital shares outstanding.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 1 (AP) -- Melbourne is willing to stage the equestrian events for the 1956 Olympic Games if six nations enter the tests, but the organizing committee will not interfere if the International Equestrian Federation believes these events should be held elsewhere.

Events today: Eugene Devereaux, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, 12 noon; Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, Frances Yeend, soprano. Lorna Sidney, mezzo-soprano, David Lloyd, tenor, Mack Harrell, baritone, Temple University choir, Carnegie Hall, 8:30.

The Paul Tripp color television program has been "indefinitely postponed in order to allow more time to develop a format," the Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday. The program, which had been in preparation for more than a month, originally was scheduled to make its debut today and to be seen every Tuesday from 5:30 to 6 P.M.
The city will begin a unified drive against juvenile delinquency, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday. Several city departments will participate in the campaign.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Eisenhower Administration stripped Scott McLeod today of his authority over State Department personnel. It left him in charge of security matters.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The American Association for the United Nations heard warnings today that the enemies of the United Nations in this country were numerous, that the United States public was ill-informed about the United Nations and that United States influence in the United Nations was declining.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Averell Harriman declared today that a Democratic Congress was needed to stop hate and suspicion and to reassure the world of the country's adherence to the collective security policy.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- President Eisenhower has pledged to the people of Puerto Rico their independence if they desire it, as did his predecessor, President Truman.

Ben Marden, owner of the Playhouse, will produce next season the musical version of Austin Strong's long-run comedy, "Seventh Heaven," which John Golden successfully presented on Broadway in 1922. The necessary legal papers are being drawn and they will be signed in about a week when Mr. Marden returns from a trip to Venezuela.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 1 (AP) -- Cornell's basketball team easily defeated Dartmouth, 73 -- 53, tonight to pull a game ahead of second-place Princeton in the Eastern Intercollegiate League race.
The City Administration plans to write a "little Wagner labor relations law," covering municipal employes.

FORT EUSTIS, Va., March 1 (AP) -- Willie Mays, New York Giant outfielder, today was discharged from the Army and said he would board a plane tonight for the Giants' spring training camp at Phoenix, Ariz.

Kentucky, which preserved its spotless record through twenty-three games while four of its leading rivals faltered, regained the No. 1 spot in the United Press college basketball ratings yesterday by a slim margin over Indiana.

NEWCASTLE, Wyo., March 1 (AP) -- All nine persons aboard a Western Air Lines plane missing since Friday were found dead today when a search party reached the wreckage in the rugged "breaks" of the Rochelle Hills.

Thomas H. McKittrick will terminate thirty-eight years of international banking and finance experience on March 31. His retirement as senior vice president of the Chase National Bank is scheduled for that date.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 1 -- John Foster Dulles characterized the shooting of the five Representatives in Washington today as "a fanatical rejection of the democratic process."

Among Mayor Wagner's numerous good appointments none is more welcome and reassuring than the restoration of Dr. Harry J. Carman to the Board of Higher Education. No other action of the previous city administration so shocked the people concerned with education as the unexplained failure in 1952 to reappoint Dr. Carman to the board on which he had served with distinction and usefulness for nearly fifteen years.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 1 -- Prince Buu Loc, Premier of Vietnam, said today that he considered a cease-fire in the Indo-China war impracticable. He expressed the view that the rival forces were too scrambled together to permit the implementation of a cease-fire.
WASHINGTON, March 1 (UP) -- President Eisenhower is opposed to any move now to cut personal income taxes by increasing individual exemptions, House Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. reported today.
LONDON, March 1 -- An amendment urging a reduction in the Government expenditure of men and money for defense was agreed upon by the parliamentary Labor party tonight.

The governments of Europe were urged yesterday to establish means of allowing their school children, university students, technicians, craftsmen, members of the professions and others to visit North America. The result, it was contended, would be well worth the loss in dollar holdings, which would amount to "international chicken feed."
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Puerto Rican extremists have been conspiring to harm President Eisenhower if they got the opportunity, according to the Federal Secret Service.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The shooting at the Capitol today has no recent parallel.
A small collection of custom-made clothes designed by John Crice Rich was shown yesterday at the Carlton House.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company went into the "red" in January. Its income statement released yesterday showed the road sustained a net loss of $283,990 before provision for sinking fund requirements, compared with a net profit of $458,851 in the like month last year.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Until the shooting in the House of Representatives today things were somewhat dull.

Politicians and persons with underworld backgrounds or friendships were found yesterday to have been the hidden owners of close to a million dollars' worth of stock in several New York harness racing tracks.

The new turmoil erupting in various parts of the Middle East lends added urgency to the efforts now under way in London to settle the Iranian oil dispute as the best way of stabilizing a key country in that region. The situation is hopeful, because there is no longer any dispute in principle.
CHICAGO, March 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Elizabeth Arden's spring and summer custom order collection, shown yesterday at its salon at 681 Fifth Avenue, will be best remembered for its numerous exquisite flower prints and widespread use of neckline interest.
ALBANY, March 1 -- The Temporary State Commission on Highway Finance Planning recommended today a seven-year program of road construction and repair costing $2,071,900,000.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Congressional Record, unless its official transcript of today's proceedings are changed before tonight's printing, will give no indication that five members of the House of Representatives were shot from a gallery this afternoon.

In your leading editorial, "Surrender to McCarthy," you say, "This fight ought to have been fought on the basic issue of whether or not the Executive branch of this Government, including the Army, is being run by President Eisenhower or by Senator McCarthy."
AARE, Sweden, March 1 -- Ida Schoepfer, a Swiss girl who works in a store in her native village of Fluehli, near Lucerne, won the women's downhill event today in the world ski championships.

Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, promising Rockaway Beach fighter, won a unanimous decision over Clarence Henry, eighth-ranking heavyweight, in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. Jackson weighed 194 1/2 pounds, Henry 182.

A sculptor and furniture maker, Wharton Esherick of Pennsylvania, won a gold medal award in the Design and Craft category of the 1954 National Gold Medal Exhibition, which opens today. Arranged by the Architectural League, the exhibit will be open to the public through March 26 at the league building, 115 East Fortieth Street.
Bock is back -- or at least it will be "officially" next Monday.
The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will rent, not sell, its first color television receivers to the public. No other major television set manufacturer has hinted at such a policy.

ROME, March 1 -- Sixty-six day laborers at Castel-Franco Emilia, in the heart of "Red" Italy, have abandoned the Communist party because they no longer could stand the constant requests for money for party purposes.
Seven men, including a former bank president, were named yesterday in Federal Court as members of an "international stolen bond fencing ring."

The Nike guided missiles will soon be added to New York's anti-aircraft defenses, it was announced yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, commanding the First Army. The fact that the city would have the protection of the new weapon had previously been disclosed in Washington.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 1 -- A three-hour workout had been concluded today and all the Giants had retired to the dressing room. A minute or so later, Leo Durocher and Frank Shellenback, followed by Alvin Dark and Jim Hearn strode to the middle of the diamond and held a conference.

Since the publication in 1944 of "Peter Domanig: Morning In Vienna," Victor White has been working on a trilogy, the story of an ambitious, gifted immigrant seeking place and power in this country. The trilogy will bear the protagonist's name.

Ernest Bloch's Concerto Grosso No. 2 and String Quartet No. 3 were voted yesterday as the outstanding orchestral and chamber music works of 1953 by the Music Critics Circle of New York. This is the first time since the circle began making awards in 1942 that one composer has won top honors in two eategories in one year.
Heavy reinforcements of detectives were sent into all Puerto Rican sections of the city last night soon after Nationalists shot five Congressmen in the House chamber in Washington.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 1 -- Premier Abdullah Yafi ended Lebanon's two-week Cabinet crisis today by succeeding in his fourth attempt to form a Cabinet. Although Mr. Yafi resigned after each failure to form a Cabinet, President Camille Chamoun insisted he remain as a stabilizing element.
NEW DELHI, India, March 1 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru scathingly condemned virtually the entire United States policy in Asia and in the "cold war" today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 1 (UP) -- Canada scored its third straight victory and second consecutive shutout today in the world ice hockey championships by defeating Sweden, 8 -- 0, before a capacity crowd of 16,000 that included King Gustaf Adolf and Prince Bertil of Sweden.
Release to bondholders of validated German dollar bonds of eighty different state, municipal and corporate issues was authorized yesterday by the Validation Board for German Dollar Bonds.

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Active buying support swung into the grain and soybean futures market today, with rapid upturns in September and November soybeans. September soybeans gained up to 9 1/2 cents before there was much reaction.

The spirit of inquiry and investigation is always abroad in this great land; it forms the background for our research agencies and institutions of higher learning, it motivates committees in and out of Congress, it provides the spark of life in countless lucrative and sometimes enlightening quiz programs.
Increased earnings of the Coca-Cola Company last year and the election of Lindsey Hopkins as a new director were announced yesterday by H. B. Nicholson, president.

To meet demands for its products and facilitate its planned expansion into the pharmaceutical field, the United States Vitamin Corporation is merging two subsidiaries into a new major division, Arlington-Funk Laboratories, H. B. Burns, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 1 -- Walter (Smokey) Alston may manage the National League All-Stars in July, as President Walter O'Malley of the Dodgers insists he should, but Alston won't know one way or the other for some time.
How the Communists must delight in the violent explosions on our national scene these last few days!
ATLANTA, March 1 -- The Eisenhower Administration's plan for the disposition of electrical power from government-owned projects was assailed today as "window-trimming."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The State Department, apparently reacting to Congressional criticism of some of its real estate arrangements, announced today that it had asked the United States Air Force to vacate Winfield House in London so that it may be occupied by United States Ambassador Winthrop Aldrich.
ALBANY, March 1 -- The Board of Regents has informed Governor Dewey and legislative leaders that it regards the Administration's educational television bill as overly restrictive.

Preservation through dynamic advertising of the existing "want economy" instead of a "need economy" is urged by Bernard J. Gross, vice president of Weiss Geller, Chicago advertising agency. If customers revert to thinking of products only in terms of needs, he maintains, "then we are surely on the road to recession."
The Chrysler Corporation, the nation's third largest automobile manufacturer, is laying plans for the next century.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was steady yesterday and moderately active. Closing prices were 6 to 17 points net higher than on last Friday, with new crop months showing the most strength.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Former President Truman expressed shock when he heard today that terrorists of the Puerto Rican faction that had tried to kill him had shot down members of Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Civil Service Commission reported today that 355 Federal employes whose personnel files contained some allegations of subversive associations had been separated from the Government payroll between May 28 and Dec. 31, 1953.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Cancellation of the automatic reduction in corporation tax rates scheduled for April 1 was approved today by the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The House of Representatives picked up shortly after noon today the legislative chores it had dropped suddenly yesterday when Puerto Rican terrorists shot down five of its members.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Personal income in January ran at an annual rate of $282,500,000,000, a drop of $2,000,000,000 compared with December but an increase of the same amount compared with January, 1953, the Department of Commerce reported today.
From now until April 26 the most important battlefield in the continuing struggle for the world will be Indo-China.

The world is accustomed to unreasoning violence in the dim bazaars of the Middle East, on the soft margins of Asia, in the festering undergrowth of Africa. But when it breaks out in the ordinarily sedate Congress of the United State, the almost unguarded citadel of government by law, Americans are stunned and incredulous.

The New York City Ballet has added five performances of "The Nutcracker" to its final week's schedule at the City Center, canceling all the programs previously announced for those dates. Since "The Nutcracker" already is scheduled for all performances between March 13 and 18, this will mean that from March 13 on, no other work will be presented during the remainder of the engagement, which ends March 21.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 2 -- Trial of a sixteen-count indictment charging Walter G. Winne with failure to act against gambling in Bergen County moved forward today with the completion of a jury of seven men and seven women.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Governor Dewey approved today two bills extending for another year the abatements in personal income and unincorporated business taxes.

LONDON, March 2 -- Faced with an increasing drift of skilled officers and non-commissioned officers from the armed forces into better paid private industry, the British Government announced today service pay increases, effective April 1. The increases will cost approximately 16,500,000 ($46,200,000) annually.

DALLAS, March 2 -- Fashions here in their quiet way, show a pleasing trend awareness. This was evident yesterday morning when twenty-four members of the Dallas Fashion Center began their showings, which will continue through tomorrow.

The New York Knickerbockers snapped their losing streak at four games last night, defeating the Boston Celtics, 86 -- 71, in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header. In the opener, the Rochester Royals downed the Fort Wayne Pistons, 71 -- 64.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- Mickey Mantle and Billy Martin, who could offer Casey Stengel his two most perplexing problems as he points his Yankees toward a sixth straight pennant, arrived in camp today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 2 -- The Yale University basketball team outscored the University of Rhode Island, 89 -- 93, tonight.
DETROIT, March 2 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports today said:
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- President Eisenhower called on "all men of goodwill" today to join Friday in observance of a World Day of Prayer "to find the way toward the goal of peace."
The cotton futures market closed steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, up 3 to 11 points.
A subway change agent prevented last night a thug who had robbed him from making a getaway.

THE scattergun shooter who concentrates on upland game, and is accustomed to using an auto-loader or slide action shotgun, will be happy to learn of a new Remington product, an auto-loader in .410 gauge.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The start of Senate debate on the Hawaiian statehood bill today was deferred until late this week or next Monday.
Shipping activity here last month hold up well, according to statistics made available by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.
A fact-finding board has limited an award to photo-engravers to $3.75 a week, the same amount they rejected last Nov. 28 in calling a strike against six major New York newspapers.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The National Labor Relations Board laid down new rules today for fragmentizing bargaining units.
The National Labor Relations Board prepared last night to seek a Federal injunction to prevent interunion warfare from shutting down the Port of New York.

MOSCOW, March 2 -- A giant pink and white poster, depicting a pretty girl with deeply penciled eyebrows and rouged cheeks, powdering her face with a fluffy puff, was set up today beside the main entrance to Moscow's central department store, the Mostorg.
The Puerto Rican migration to this country has created a huge educational problem for New York school officials.

Coffee and cocoa prices dropped sharply yesterday on the New York exchanges. Other commodities closed irregularly With cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, rubber and zinc higher; wool, potatoes, burlap, tin and lead lower, and sugar and copper mixed.
GRAHAMSVILLE, N. Y., March 2 -- There is hardly a drop of surface water in sight in this mountain village of 300 population, except after a heavy rain.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., March 2 -- George E. Fahys, retired president of Joseph Fahys Co. and the Alvin Silver Company of Sag Harbor, manufacturer of watch cases and parts, killed himself this morning with a shotgun in the lavatory of his study in his home on Piping Rock Road. He was 89 years old and had been in failing health.
A strong American merchant marine in peacetime means savings of billions of dollars in wartime, Representative Thor C. Tollefson told the House of Representatives yesterday.

PARIS, March 2 -- Rene Pleven, French Minister of Defense, who has returned after a month's tour of Indo-China, is reported to be convinced that there is a chance to attain an Indo-China peace at the Geneva conference starting April 26.

TEHERAN, Iran, Feb. 22 -- Shaban Jafari, a fierce, black-bearded giant called Beemokh (The Brainless One), has become one of the most prominent and perplexing figures on the bizarre scene of Iranian politics.
The New York Stock Exchange's gross revenues crossed the $10,000,000 mark last year for the first time in the institution's 162-year history.

Hope has waned for a settlement in one of the most unusual maritime suits ever tried in New York County. The case, which apparently must now run its course in State Supreme Court, involves the classification of the cargo ship Armar as a "constructive total loss."

The financial community now faces the greatest and perhaps the last opportunity to make the American people stock - ownership-minded, it was said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Public Relations Association at the Vanderbilt Hotel.

One section of the educational television bill backed by Governor Dewey's Administration "is a flagrant violation of academic freedom," the Public Education Association said yesterday. The Association supported the Board of Regents criticism of the bill.
Tacoma, Wash., announced yesterday the sale of a $5,000,000 issue of power revenue bonds to a banking syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation.
LONDON, March 2 -- Warned by Prime Minister Churchill of the dangers of a parachute attack on Britain, the House of Commons tonight adopted the Government's defense program without a vote.
Despite the fact that stock prices on the average closed higher yesterday, the majority of issues finished unchanged or lower for the second consecutive session.
DAMASCUS, Syria, March 2 -- Syria's one-day-old civilian Government, placed in office by an army revolt, lifted the curfew today as its first official act.

At least two "rounds" in the battle for control of the New York Central Railroad are going to be fought only a few doors south of the New York Stock Exchange, within the next two weeks. The New York Society of Security Analysts has issued invitations to William White, president of the New York Central Railroad and Robert R. Young, to address its 1,700 members and members' guests.
ALBANY, March 2 -- The Assembly Rules Committee introduced today, at the request of New York City, a bill to stimulate construction of middle-income housing.

Prime Minister Nehru's criticism of American policy in Asia, and especially of American aid to Pakistan, has undoubtedly widened the misunderstanding between India and the United States, and the Communists can be expected to make the most of it.

THE area marked for the Bellevue housing project near the East River, notorious in recent years for its soot-fall, was once an idyllic spot. Its blackest day was Sept. 15, 1776, when there was no soot at all.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- A dozen grass racing stars, including four foreign-bred horses -- were entered today for the $50,000 Hialeah Turf Handicap tomorrow, final day of this season's Hialeah meeting.

ALBANY, March 2 -- Republican legislators from New York City accused the Wagner Administration today of making a stealthy attempt to deprive school teachers of an equal voice in the management of their $500,000,000 pension fund.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Three hundred eighty-three persons were included today in a broadly defined "subversive" category among 2,427 security risk separations from Government employment during the final seven months of 1953.
A new issue of $50,000,000 Province of Ontario debentures is being offered today by a group headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and Wood, Gundy Co., Inc.

The Fleetwood Singers, who last year sang the Kyrie, Credo and Sanctus of Ockeghem's Missa Prolationum, last night sang the complete forty-minute work. It formed the opening selection of an attractive program that the sixteen young singers gave at Carnegie Recital Hall under the direction of their founder-conductor James Fleetwood.
ALBANY, March 2 (AP) -- Final legislative approval was given today to a Dewey administration bill tightening the state's security-risk law designed to keep the state payroll clear of subversives.

Spectacular and colorful pageantry marked the third annual Mardi Gras Ball of the New York Junior League held last night in a pink and gold setting in the Main Ballroom of the Astor Hotel. The fete served to augment the League's Welfare Trust Fund.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 2 (UP) -- Russia took advantage of one of its satellite countries by whipping previously unbeaten Czechoslovakia, 5 -- 2, today in the world ice hockey championship.

After her sentencing for petit larceny had been adjourned for the eighth time yesterday in Brooklyn Special Sessions, an 18-year-old girl ran out and tried to throw herself under a passing fire truck.

Secretary of State Dulles is to be congratulated on depriving Scott McLeod of his authority over Department of State personnel. Mr. McLeod is partly responsible for the deplorable morale of the State Department and diplomatic service today.

Directors of the Ruberoid Company, $50,000,000 producers of asphalt, asbestos and other building materials, have voted to split its stock on a two-for-one basis, subject to approval of shareholder at the annual meeting April 30.

Congratulations are due to the Board of Estimate and to the Mayor for the recent action which commits the City of New York to the "next step" in its policy of urban redevelopment for Washington Square, and for an important project in Brooklyn. Congratulations are also due to Commissioner Moses.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the board of the Studebaker Corporation, told the annual conference of the American Association for the United Nations today that he believed "the United Nations eventually should be the agency for all technical assistance programs."

Cardinal Spellman and Mayor Wagner assured New York's 400,000 Puerto Rican citizens last night that nobody in this city holds them responsible for the shooting by insular Nationalists Monday of five Congressmen.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 2 -- Pedro Albizu Campos, president of the Puerto Rican Nationalist party, declared tonight that the shooting of five Congressmen in Washington yesterday represented "sublime heroism" on the part of three Nationalists in a new demand for freeing Puerto Rico.
Although construction costs have "skyrocketed" during recent years, "the cost of money" is one factor in the price of a home that has actually decreased, a savings bank executive asserted yesterday.

Cottage cheese, popular in Lent, offers speedy-to-serve protein of high quality at low cost (about 22 cents a halfpound). Its protein is, in fact, of the same excellent kind as that obtained from meat, fish or eggs.

A concerted drive against littered sidewalks by both the Police and Sanitation Departments was promised yesterday by Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain. In a talk to the Outdoor Cleanliness Association, he said he would meet next week with Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams "and we are going to make this a clean city."
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Arthur H. Dean has resigned his post as special deputy to the Secretary of State in charge of plans for a Korean peace conference.

Those who believe that education and added services for children will provide the answers to juvenile delinquency were called upon yesterday to act quickly to stem the "back-to-the-woodshed" trend currently reflected in demands of individuals and organizations to "get tough with the kids" and to "punish the parents."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 2 -- Harvard College decided tonight to accept unusually able and mature students who have completed their junior year in high school.
LONDON, March 2 -- The British Government is planning to seek a substantial relaxation of the embargo restrictions on the sale of manufactured goods, raw materials and shipping to the Soviet Union.
PANMUNJOM, Korea, March 2 (AP) -- Thirty-seven displaced Korean civilians were handed over to the Communists by the United Nations Command today in the final official exchange of the Korean war.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 2 (UP) -- Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla., recent winner of the Miami invitation tennis tournament, was hard-pressed today to score a 7-5, 6-4 victory over Colin Hannam of England in a second-round match in the St Andrew Club invitation tournament.

A fitting tribute to her years as director of Bergdorf Goodman's made-to-order salon was the spring and summer collection presented yesterday at this shop by Miss Ethel Frankau and the two designers, Leslie Morris and Mary Gleason.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Senate's great controversy over proposed constitutional amendments to limit the President's treaty - making powers was reopened today.
New trays and hot plate holders that are cheerful to look at and practical to use can be found at The Willow, 182 West Fourth Street.

AARE, Sweden, March 2 (AP) -- Buddy Werner of Steamboat Springs, Colo., ace downhill racer on the American ski squad, severely sprained his right ankle today when he skied over a small tree during practice.

Six floors in the twenty-six-story building being completed at 99 Park Avenue, southeast corner of East Fortieth Street, have been leased by the National Distillers Corporation, producers of whiskey, which will be the major tenant there.

ROME, March 2 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII quietly observed today the double anniversary of his seventy-eighth birthday and the fifteenth of his reign. Messages from far and near arrived to express wishes for his full recovery.

The question that a shocked public has been asking itself since the Puerto Rican shooting incident in Washington is: How can such a thing happen? To the normal person it makes no sense, especially when one knows that if a majority of Puerto-Ricans wanted independence they could have it.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 2 -- Peru declared herself today among the nations that will support United States moves to bar Communist infiltration in Latin America.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 2 -- A serious move is afoot at the tenth Inter-American Conference to establish a council in Washington in permanent review of economic problems between the United States and Latin America.
Donald Dickson, baritone, who gave his third recital in Town Hall last evening, has had a rather odd career.

Dr. Edward Lasker of New York took the lead with a score of 3 1/2 -- 1/2, yesterday, in the chess masters tournament at the Club Social Metropolitano, according to a report from Mexico City. Four rounds were completed as all pending adjourned games were played off.
A hundred and A fifty years ago, when Thomas Jefferson commissioned Lewis and Clark to explore the newly acquired West, he warned them to be on the lookout for prowling mastodons.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike of Denmark, chief of the Palestine Truce Supervision Organization, reported to the United Nations Security Council today that tension between Israel and Jordan had increased in the last three months.

A total of 655 pints of blood was donated on Monday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Included in the blood gifts were 416 pints given at the Roosevelt Hotel by employes of eleven companies in the Grand Central area.

Social and economic changes in the pattern of American life since 1930 not only have resulted in a rapid multiplication of the number and assets of charitable and philanthropic foundations but also have wrought a fundamental change in their basic goals.

TWO wonderful melodic treats were presented on television on Sunday. One was the bright and gay revival of Cole Porter's musical, "Anything Goes," with capital performances by Ethel Merman, Frank Sinatra and Bert Lahr.

Lambert Co., investment firm, and its wholly-owned subsidiary, the Lambert Development Company of Ontario, Ltd., announced yestereday that their offer to buy all outstanding shares of the Consolidated Toronto Land Corporation, Ltd., had become effective.

MANHASSET, L. I., March 2 -- Edward E. James, director of the new $4,000,000 North Shore Hospital who figured prominently in a bitter controversy between local doctors and the hospital trustees, announced his resignation here today.

The appointment of Miss Charlotte Carr as consultant to the Commissioner of Welfare brings into the city's service a well-informed, competent, humane woman who has already made great contributions in this community. In recent years a leading figure in the Citizens' Committee on Children, she has been a forceful and enlightened spokesman on many problems.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The Marine Corps court inquiring into the germ warfare confession of Col. Frank Schwable was told today that to "persecute a man who has already been persecuted would merely be playing into Communist hands.

The Babcock Wilcox Company achieved the highest earnings in its seventy-three-year history last year despite substantially larger operating costs, according to the annual report, released for publication today.

The Shakespeare Guild Festival Company, off-Broadway semi-professional group, henceforth will function without the services of professional performers. William Thornton, producer of the group, said it was "financially impossible" to meet demands of the Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- California was awarded a judgment against the United States today for $8,985.15 in a $7,561,508.15 claim for compensation for recruiting, equipping and supporting troops to aid the Union side in the Civil War. The ruling was made by the Court of Claims.

"The Diary of a Country Priest," French-made adaptation of the novel by Georges Bernanos, has been selected for the opening of the new Fifth Avenue Cinema, 66 Fifth Avenue, on March 29, it was announced yesterday by Pathe Cinema, which also owns and operates the Paris Theatre.

FORT RENO, Okla., Feb. 26 -- There are many wise men who will tell you that a mule is the most adaptable animal in the world, and the United States Army has just spent two and a half years proving that premise.

An exhibition of paintings titled "The Word vs. the Image," made up of paintings by the French artist Magritte done in the years 1928-30, has opened at the Sidney Janis Gallery. Visitors are likely to be divided at once into groups that automatically hate or respond to this work.

An analysis of African problems by John Cookson, an Englishman with twelve years' experience in Africa, will be issued April 9 by Bobbs-Merrill under the title "Before the African Storm." Mr. Cookson contends that unless "better and more uniform solutions of the race problems are offered by the African powers a storm is inevitable and it may be one which Communists may exploit and which may shake the world."

An accurately aimed police bullet wounded critically last night a hold-up man who used an employe of a delicatessen store on the upper West Side as a human shield. The single shot was fired by Patrolman John J. McCarthy, 34 years old, of the West 100th Street station.
Fish-headed people or people-headed fish are among the images which crowd Victor Brauner's new encaustic paintings, shown at the Hugo Gallery along with work by Miro, Picasso, Wols and Braque.
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
William J. Grafenecker, nemesis of racketeers and corrupt public officials, was named yesterday as chief investigator of the newly created State Department of Investigation.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, asserted yesterday that a permanent peace between the Arab nations and Israel would bring "countless medical benefits" to the Arab people through the availability of Hadassah's medical and social services in Israel.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin told President Eisenhower today that the Puerto Rican Government would "intensify the stamping out by all legal means this lunacy" that caused the shooting of five members of Congress.

LOS ANGELES, March 2 -- John Ireland, stage, motion-picture and television actor, filed suit in Superior Court today for $1,756,000 against two television film-production concerns charging slander and breach of contract.
Lower prices have been the principal factor in depressing textile industry earnings, according to John P. Stevens Jr., chairman of the board of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc.
Yale's polo team gained the final round of the national intercollegiate championship tournament last night by halting Stanford University, 10 to 8, at the Squadron A Armory.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 2 -- In the opinion of Marshal Tito the "cold war" has ended.
The Republican State Administration was accused yesterday by Mayor Wagner of "playing ball with big business."
Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran, Republican leader of New York County, received a fee of $10,000 for his part in the negotiations that led to the establishment of Yonkers Raceway in 1949.

MEXICO CITY, March 2 -- Reports that Dolores del Rio, the Mexican film star, might not receive a visa to enter the United States, aroused indignation today among movie people here and hints of reprisals.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 2 -- A "new deal" bill applicable to American copper-producing companies here was submitted this afternoon to Congress. It was labeled urgent, but the lower chamber has thirty days in which to discuss a subject before sending it to the Senate.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2 -- Twenty-seven hours after he had been discharged from Fort Eustis, Va., and one hour after he had alighted from a plane from Washington today, Willie Mays stepped to the plate as a Giants' pinch-hitter and smashed a 400-foot homer over the leftfield wall.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 2 -- Ted Williams made two miscalculations yesterday at the first full-fledged practice of the Boston Red Sox. He drove up to Sarasota from Miami with the idea of so timing his arrival that he'd miss the formal workout entirely. Then he intended to hold a private workout of his own, unbothered by photographers, reporters, spectators and other kibitzers.

We believe that the city administration's reported plan to draw up a municipal Wagner Labor Relations Law for city employes must be taken with more than a grain of salt. Unfortunately, Mayor 'Wagner is responsible for giving this impossibly ambitious and impractical idea currency.
The lower interest rates that have developed since last fall helped seventeen local public housing authorities yesterday.
We are all shocked by the vicious shooting in the House of Representatives. Fortunately, that terrorist group is small and does not represent the real spirit of Puerto Rico.

The Government's policy of leasing machine tools for civilian production was attacked sharply yesterday by the National Machine Tool Builders Association of Cleveland. The group held the policy is destroying the country's reserve supply.

An electric percolator that brews coffee in almost no time is being introduced in city stores this week by S. W. Farber. The four-cup size produces a pot of coffee in four minutes, the eightcup size in seven minutes and the ten-cup size in eight minutes. The device is among the fastest on the market.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner today declared it illegal for railroads to give free transportation to newspaper or magazine representatives for publicity purposes, on trains making regular revenue runs.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 2 (UP) -- Ted Williams, who broke his left collarbone yesterday in his first spring training workout, is confident he can make a quick return to the Boston Red Sox line-up, he said today.
CHICAGO, March 2 --Erratic price fluctuations in grain and soybean futures featured the Board of Trade session today.

PARIS, March 2 -- The United States has told French officials it would make a declaration of policy on keeping its troops in Europe whenever the French Cabinet fixed a date for a parliamentary vote on the European army treaty -- but not before.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Senate missed being the scene of Monday's bloody shooting fray by Puerto Rican terrorists simply because the visitor's gallery was filled.

TRENTON, March 2 -- Extensive alterations ordered by the administration of former Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and now being made in the Statehouse here are esthetically distasteful to Gov. Robert B. Meyner.

The all-Russian program given by Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall comprised two works that demanded voices and orchestra by two composers who could be considered as diametrically opposed to each other in their esthetic standpoint and in the periods of Russian history they represented.

SUSPENSE once meant a condition of anxious uncertainty. As a descriptive label on book jackets during the last few years the word has lost much of its original meaning. It is used indiscriminately to describe any novel that has a melodramatic central situation and thus covers spy stories, gangster stories, stories about smuggling, mad scientists and stolen jewels, and even detective stories.
BONN, Germany, March 2 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, has offered to meet Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, in Paris next week for a talk on the Saar.
Jimmy Carter, the champion, and Paddy De Marco of Brooklyn completed their sparring yesterday for the world lightweight championship bout in Madison Square Garden Friday night.
Plans are being formulated, at frequent meetings, for the annual luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Nearly New Shop, to be held March 25 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

LONDON, March 2 (AP) -- The Kremlin announced today that Dr. Andrei F. Tretyakov, the physician who was in charge of the treatment of the dying Stalin a year ago, had been dismissed from his post as Health Minister of the Soviet Union.
SANTIAGO, Chile, March 2 (UP) -- Five new Cabinet Ministers were installed today ending a week-long Government crisis.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee attempted today to get a little extra mileage out of twice-told stories.

The City Council received yesterday from its Queens Republican freshman member a resolution calling on the Board of Education to require that every officer and board member of parent-teacher associations take a loyalty oath.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 (UP) -- The chairman eli the Democratic National Corn-i mittee caUed on President Eisenhewer tonight to stop 'coddling" Senator Joseph R. iVfcCarthy to the "detriment of our country and its citizens."'
ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 2 (AP) -- Mrs. Grace DeMoss Smith of Miami today won the medal in the twenty-fifth annual women's South Atlantic amateur golf tournament with a qualifying score of 72.

With the approach of the March 15 deadline for filing Federal income tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service here announced yesterday an extension of hours for assisting taxpayers in this city and in Westchester, Nassau, Suffolk and Rockland Counties beginning next Saturday.
ATLANTIC CITY, March 2 -- Eleven thousand persons, including the Governor of New Jersey, gathered in Convention Hall here tonight to celebrate the 100th birthday of this resort.
Robert R. Young announced last night the names of the first seven of the fifteen directors his group will propose for the board of the New York Central Railroad at the annual meeting on May 26.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 2 -- The Belgian Senate began discussions of the European Defense Community treaty today. Although Paul Van Zealand, the Foreign Minister, urged ratification of the pact, the debate is expected to last several days.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the New York Police sought yesterday to determine how the plot for Monday's shooting in the House of Representatives was hatched and whether additional conspirators were involved.

One important reason why hundreds of millions of dollars of potential investment capital lies idle and unproductive is the "appalling lack of faith of the small investor in the management of American business," Louis E. Wolfson said yesterday.

LONDON, March 2 -- A spokesman for the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company today took issue with an editorial in The New York Times that said Britain was insisting on control of the proposed international company to produce and sell the oil of Iran.

NEW DELHI, India, March 2 (Reuters) -- The Congress party of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, won a clear majority today in the northern state of the Patiala and East Punjab States Union, known as Pepsu, with thirty-two of the sixty seats in the State Assembly, and eleven results still to come.

Hawaiian statehood, coming up shortly in the Senate after its passage last March in the House, ought not to be long delayed. Both party platforms in 1952 urged that this step be "immediate,'' and a year's delay cannot be construed as reckless haste.
OTTAWA, March 2 (Canadian Press) -- The Board of Transport Commissioners today laid down an equalized scale of basic freight rates for Canada to go into effect March 1, 1955.
El Dorado, the magnetic legend that drew hordes of adventurers to the New World in search of fabulous gold, seems to have contained a measure of truth.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower today started the spring reception season by receiving 180 members of the National Federation of Settlements and Neighborhood Centers, New York City.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- A loan of $54,000,000 to the Commonwealth of Australia was announced today by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

TOKYO, March 2 -- Japan's leftist trade unions, quiescent since last year, have launched a full-fledged "spring offensive" against the conservative government of Premier Shigeru Yoshida. Under attack are the Government's "pro-American" policies of retrenchment and rearmament.

Members of the New York Committee of the Frontier Nursing Service will give a rummage cocktail party in behalf of the organization Friday afternoon in the ex-Members Room, Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue at Ninety-fourth Street. Sponsors of the event include a large group of Squardon A ex-members.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Prospects for enactment of the Administration's compulsory automobile insurance bill appeared considerably improved today.
A five-year study of the aging process in the rotifer, a microscopic fresh-water animal, has provided evidence that the age of the mother determines the longevity of the offspring.

Alter Twery, owner of 239-41 East Thirty-third Street, near Third Avenue, has purchased the adjoining five-story apartment house on lot 18.4 by 98.9 feet at 237 East Thirty-third Street from Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, who bought the house about a month ago.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- In a Charter Day address at Howard University, Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby today called racial discrimination morally and economically wrong.
The custom-made collection of Oldric Royce, 16 East Fifty-second Street, presented yesterday, was marked by skillful detail in suits and dresses for day and evening.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 2 -- Leonard Goldstein, production head of Panoramic Productions, today confirmed that a filming agreement between the company and R. K. O.-Radio Pictures was in the process of negotiation. The deal would involve ten pictures to be made within a year with R. K. O. financing.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- New defense production plants must be built well out of New York's metropolitan area to be eligible for special tax concessions from the Government.

LAKE SUCCESS, L. I, March 2 -- Defense work at the Sperry Gyroscope Company plant was halted here today when members of electrical unions on both the day and night shifts refused to cross the Engineers Association picket lines.

A new producing combination has been formed by Joseph Hayes, playwright, and Howard Erskine, former actor, who entered the managerial field as co-sponsor of "Late Love," to present "The Desperate Hours" next season. The script is a dramatization by Mr. Hayes of his first novel, a Literary Guild selection for this month.

CAPETOWN, South Africa March 1 -- Hendrik Verwoerd, Minister of Native Affairs in the Malan Government, introduced a bill today that would empower his ministry to settle elsewhere the largest body of city dwelling industrialized Negroes in Africa.

Station WOR obtained a temporary restraining order yesterday enjoining members of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., from picketing the station's radio and television studios. The picket line, established last Sunday after the station had dismissed its staff of forty musicians, was immediately withdrawn.

GUATEMALA, March 2 -- The regime of President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman is neither Communist nor dominated by Communists. However, it is infiltrated and honeycombed by them to an extent that a showdown would almost certainly be disruptive to the country.

The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States, representing thirty denominations, announced yesterday that 37,000 broadcasts and telecasts of religious programs had been produced through its broadcasting and film commission last year.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- Don Zimmer, whose tenure on the Dodgers this year was made doubtful by Manager Walter (Smokey) Alston yesterday, is not performing like a fellow who doesn't expect to stick around.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Republican national chairman rebuked Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today after the Wisconsin Republican had broadened his fight with high Eisenhower Administration officials.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 2 -- Great things are in store for Soviet farmers: some of them may be able to break even.

Reflecting a 34 per cent rise in sales, net income of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation increased last year to $11,402,791 from the $9,047,514 earned in 1952. Sales of aircraft engines, propellers, simulators and other products amounted to $438,728,482, compared with $326,183,643.

RANGOON, Burma, March 2 (AP) -- Burma's army began an offensive in eastern Shan State today against one of half a dozen Chinese Nationalist forces in the Burma border areas. Speedy progress was reported.

LONDON, March 2 -- Prices continued to fall on the stock markets here today except for those of British funds and oil shares. Industrials attempted to rally but became dull again under late selling. Only automobile shares and individual companies resisted the general weakness.

CAIRO, March 2 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib suggested tonight that "imperialists" were responsible for the bloody disorders in the Sudan that caused him to cut short his visit to Khartum for the opening of the Sudanese Parliament.
The preservation and improvement of three historic Manhattan landmarks were advocated yesterday by Mayor Wagner at the fourth annual luncheon of the Downtown Manhattan Association.
LONDON, March 2 -- Olney conceded victory today in the Shrovetide pancake race to its "traditional" rival, Liberal, Kan.
This country faces economic isolation unless Congress acts to reduce trade barriers, the Export Managers Club was told yesterday by an official of the International Chamber of Commerce.

PARIS, March 2 -- A new Government with widened responsibility and power was formed today in the French protectorate of Tunisia. The ministers will put into effect reforms that the French consider an important step in bringing autonomy to the once riot-torn but now quiet land.

TORONTO, March 3 (UP) -Three goals by Center Don (Bones) Raleigh gave the New York Rangers a 3-3 deadlock with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight and a tie for fourth place with Boston in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Eisenhower turned the other cheek today, and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, always an obliging fellow, struck him about as hard as the position of the President will allow.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Defense Department wants the doctor draft law amended so that suspected subversives can be required to serve as enlisted men rather than officers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council has been asked to drop from its consultative list the Women's International Democratic Federation, a group with semi-official status in Soviet-dominated countries.
Three quite diverse group exhibitions are among the many attractions of the week.

"Big Trucks' Roar Gentled to Purr," said the headline. It was glad news for East Fifty-ninth Street. That swarming bottleneck of clamorous traffic has been praying for such tidings for lo, these many years. Its din-drunk residents have long been obsessed with the perennial question: When are the motor makers going to do something about muffling their Big Berthas?

An increase last week of 1,806,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 179,170,000 barrels, compared with 177,364,000 a week earlier and 157,612,000 a year ago.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- A preliminary agreement between the Red Sox and Washington on a trade involving Mickey Vernon, the Senators' holdout first baseman, was reported to have jelled today.

Not only the United States, but all peace-loving members of the United Nations, owe Arthur H. Dean a debt of gratitude for the distinction with which he conducted the negotiations at Panmunjom last fall on convening the Korean peace conference. The free world is especially indebted to him for the smoothness with which the last stage of the Korean prisoner question was handled.

Member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the Second Federal Reserve District had net profits of $221,000,000 last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its Monthly Review. The figure represents a decline of $7,400,000, or approximately 3 per cent from the $228,400,000 the same banks earned in 1952.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON; March 3 -- C. D. Jackson, administrative assistant to President Eisenhower on "cold war" planning resigned today. The resignation, which had been expected, will become effective on April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -The executive committee of the State and Territorial Health Officers Association were briefed here today on the new Public Health Service "grants-in-aid amendments bill" which would end "earmarking" funds for special diseases.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. March 3 -- Engineers of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development have made specific proposals to India and Pakistan for settlement of the long dispute between the two countries on control of the river waters that keep the huge, dry Indus Basin alive.

The President's statement on the McCarthy-Stevens issue contains a number of important points with which we are sure most moderate-minded Americans -- and, fortunately, most Americans are moderate-minded -- will agree. Although his position is seriously weakened by the fact that he did not take a firm and unequivocal stand much earlier in the battle, Mr. Eisenhower has now expressed plainly the revulsion he and the nation feel toward Senator McCarthy's mode of operation.

MIAMI, March 3 (AP) -- Brookmeade Stable's Picador, a 15-to-1 shot, today won his first race in two years when he took the $64,500 Hialeah Turf Handicap, closing feature of Hialeah Park's record season, before 19,691 fans.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -President Eisenhower and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy clashed today in a struggle that might have lasting effects on the unity of the Republican party.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, today that a preliminary Senate inquiry was under way into the purchase of common stock holdings of the Puget Sound Power Light Company by the Washington Water Power Company.

A strike of 457 teachers, clerks and nurses yesterday closed the fourteen public schools in Bayonne, N. J. The walkout sent 8,499 pupils home from two high schools and twelve primary and grammar schools.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 3 -- Australian tobacco growing should be stimulated by the decision of the American Philip Morris Company to establish a factory for the production of American-type cigarettes in either New South Wales or Victoria.
ROME, N. Y., March 3 (UP) -- "To win that chick . . . with all her vanity . . . just try one thing . . . give up profanity."

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court unanimously reversed yesterday the conviction of Sol Levy, 41 years old, of 1679 East Third Street, Brooklyn, former professional basketball referee, charged with accepting bribes to "rig" basketball games. The reversal was on technical grounds.

Timid, dark-haired, black-eyed Alicia Lopez, smiling shyly, held up her crude painting. In a splash of reds, greens, blacks and dazzling yellows, a small wooden-frame house arose among the clouds. Stairs led to it from the warm-looking earth.

Net income of the Union Tank Car Company and wholly owned Canadian subsidiaries amounted to $4,707,226 last year, against $4,369,928 in 1952, after providing $2,152,000 and $1,577,000 respectively for accelerated amortization of tank cars.

The heat generated by partisan and personal angles of the latest Carthy sally on the Potomac has inverted attention from "what the war's about" -- that is, the struggle for control of the Government. The New York Times' editorial of Feb. 23 touched the heart of the matter in stating that: "The issue is whether Congress has a right to interfere in the actual functioning of an Executive department."

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 3 -- In northern Indo-China, the main theatre of conflict between the French and the Vietminh, the retreat of Communist regulars in northern Laos has created a new and fluid situation.

The local office of the New York State Extension Service in Marketing has revised its leaflet, "Passover Meals," to include more information and several new recipes. The twelve-page booklet is available without charge on request to the agency. 149 Church Street, New York 7.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 3 -- While Chile's delegation at Caracas is ready to make a firm stand for the stabilization of prices of raw materials, the Government here today expressed concern over the determination of one of the two largest United States copper enterprises to cut production 30 per cent.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The New York Central Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to make a sweeping investigation of the campaign of Robert R. Young and his associates to obtain control of the road.

Mortgage lenders have a responsibility to join with community leaders and government in the provision of adequate housing and the rehabilitation of blighted areas, according to Albert M. Cole, Administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency.
CHICAGO, March 3 (AP) -- Federal Judge Win G. Knoch today appointed a trustee for Muntz TV, Inc., but permitted Earl W. Muntz, founder of the firm, to remain as president at a reduced salary.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 3 -- Eric Louw, Minister of Economic Affairs, has announced that he hopes to steadily ease import controls because of the increasingly flourishing condition of the country. He said it should be possible later to remove all import controls.

"The Burning Glass," a new drama by Charles Morgan, one of England's eminent writers, opens this evening at 8 o'clock at the Longacre Theatre under the auspices of the Theatre Guild and John C. Wilson.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Senate approved today the Administration's request for a $1,750,000,000 increase in the borrowing capacity of the Commodity Credit Corporation to assure adequate funds for farm price support operations during 1954.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Feb. 24:
The Greek liner Olympia, now cruising through the Caribbean on one of her two propellers after an engine breakdown, is expected to return to New York on March 11 as scheduled.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The joint legislative committee investigating fraudulent charities gave a clean bill of health today to "Strike It Rich," radio and television program, but declined to pass judgment on its good taste.

CHELTENHAM, England, March 3 (AP) -- Queen Mother Elizabeth watched her star jumper and Grand National Steeplechase hope M'as-Tu-Vu finish far back in the three-mile National Hunt Handicap at Cheltenham course today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. said today the United Nations Character did not justify fears that it could be used for international agreements that would overturn American domestic laws.

In a surprise development early today, the Board of Higher Education decided to dismiss Nat Holman, suspended City College basketball coach, on charges arising from the college's 1950 basketball scandals.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- The Federal payroll decreased 106,259 during the first seven months of the current fiscal year, which began last July 1, Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia,. said today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 3 -- Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, Yale University president, announced today that F. Curtis Canfield, Professor of Dramatic Arts at Amherst College, would succeed Boyd M. Smith as chairman of the Yale University Department of Drama on July 1.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Reductions of 50 per cent in Federal "luxury" taxes and comparable cuts in other excises were approved today by the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives, even as President Eisenhower voiced his renewed opposition.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Eisenhower said today it was all right for his Secretary of Labor to support a Federal Fair Employment Practices Law.
Joint committees of newspaper photo-engravers and the city's newspaper publishers are scheduled to meet today to discuss the fact-finding award announced Tuesday.
PARIS, March 3 -- The Saar question will be discussed here Tuesday between Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, and Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, at the latter's request.

Robert R. Young, before he completes his proposed slate of directors for the New York Central Railroad Company, hopes to "flavor" it with at least one Vanderbilt. The Vanderbilt family has been linked with the management of the road for 100 years.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:

ROME, March 3 -- The Italian Government has agreed to place under the French Area Command in the Mediterranean a sector including the Strait of Sicily and the Italian island of Pantelleria, Italian military circles said today.

STORRS, Conn., March 3 -- The University of Connecticut's basketball team employed a full court press to down Columbia's quintet, 80 -- 64, tonight before a crowd of 3,400 in the Storrs cage. This game was the last regular season contest for the winners, who are headed for the N. C. A. A. tournament.
A program for the curbing and prevention of juvenile delinquency was outlined yesterday by Mayor Wagner after a two-hour conference with key city officials.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 3 -- Venezuelan authorities have put an elaborate guard on John Foster Dulles, the United States Secretary of State, as a result of Monday's shootings in the House of Representatives in Washington.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Central Power and Light Company, a subsidiary of Central and South West Corporation, has filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the sale of $18,000,000 first-mortgage bonds at competitive bidding.

BERLIN, March 3 -- In a new move to hamper West German rearmament, the Communist-controlled Free German Youth organization summoned today boys and girls from all parts of Germany to a mass meeting in Berlin on Whitsuntide, June 6.
MOSCOW, March 3 -- Pravda informed its readers today that Mark Twain's home in New York would be demolished shortly because efforts to raise money to save it from the wreckers had failed.
ALBANY, March 3 -- Charges that helmeted spear fishermen equipped with underwater breathing devices were terrorizing fish in Long Island Sound were denied today.
BERLIN, March 3 -- School children often are disciplined for being too noisy, but almost an entire high-school class in East Germany has been severely punished for unanimous silence.

John S. Sinclair, chairman of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, presented a certificate of merit yesterday to employes of the New York Post Office for their outstanding support of the regional blood program for civilians and the armed forces.

At $7.21, the Dun Bradstreet index of wholesale prices stood yesterday at the highest level in three years. The index was 1 cent above that for the previous week and 14.8 per cent above the $6.28 recorded in the same week in 1953. The previous high was $7.23 for the week of March 20, 1950.
The season of Lent was opened yesterday at the usual Ash Wednesday services.

SAN SALVADOR, March 3 -- Guatemala and Argentina provide a significant case history for the United States in terms of hemisphere policy. They show how international communism and militant nationalism operate in very much the same way.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- An appeal has been made to the South African Government to end its boycott of a United Nations commission investigating racial problems in that country.

BOCA RATON, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- Machine tool shipments for 1954 should exceed one billion dollars, Charles F. Honeywell, administrator of the Business and Defense Services Administration of the Department of Commerce said today.
Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa denied yesterday that any effort was being made to deprive city school teachers of an equal voice in the management of their $500,000,000 pension fund.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -President Eisenhower's new brush with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was treated with great circumspection and reserve today by the top Congressional Republicans.
THE HAGUE, March 3 -- World tin plate production hit a post-war high of 5,792,000 tons last year, the International Tin Study Group has reported here.
The waterfront trucking shutdown spread to New Jersey yesterday and shipping executives warned that a full suspension of cargo operations in the Port of New York was "just around the corner."

BOSTON, March 3 -- Led by Center Billy Cleary Jr., who scored one goal and assisted on another, Harvard's hockey team defeated Princeton, 3 to 1, tonight at the Garden and captured its first Pentagonal League crown since 1937.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- One eagle, three birdies and eight pars by Bobbie Dawson sent the Piedmont, Calif., girl into a favorite's role in the women's South Atlantic golf tournament today.
The recommendation made to the City Council on Tuesday that heads of parent-teacher associations be required to take loyalty oaths was frowned upon yesterday by the United Parents Associations.
ALBANY, March 3 -- Sponsors of the Administration's educational television bill expressed a willingness today to meet objections that have been raised by the Board of Regents.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Eisenhower reiterated today that his aim was to get rid of undesirables in the Government. He said that in his opinion all persons ousted under the security program were bad security risks.

LONDON, March 3 -- In diplomatic terms, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden laid the blame squarely on Egypt today for the riots in Khartum Monday. At least thirty-four persons were killed and approximately 100 injured.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- A Federal grand jury today returned indictments containing forty criminal charges against four Puerto Rican fanatics in the shooting last Monday of five members of the House of Representatives.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -The State Department announced today the membership of a committee to recommend ways of strengthening the diplomatic service, now shaky in morale and low in numbers.

A spokesman for metropolitan milk dealers reported last night that negotiations with operating engineers were deadlocked. He said a strike by 200 engineers employed in the industry could shut off the milk supply for the metropolitan area.
ROME, March 3 -- Problems of interest to the United States and Italy were discussed this morning for two hours by Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce and Premier Mario Scelba.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 3 -Puerto Rico began a study today of whether the Nationalist chieftain, Pedro Albizu Campos, might have violated either the island's anti-subversion law or the terms of his own pardon.

BOSTON, March 3 -- The man who directed construction for the World War II Navy in the United States, Vice Admiral Edward L. Cochrane, U. S. N. (retired), tonight was appointed vice president for industrial and governmental relations at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
AARE, Sweden, March 3 -- Norway's Stein Eriksen, 26-year-old star alpine skier, added the world championship giant slalom to his list of titles today.

THE final tabulation on the New York State deer season has been reported by the New York Conservation Department, indicating that 1953 provided one of the best deer seasons, on the basis of results, in the history of the department.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President Eisenhower said today he would make known in a few days his decision on recommendations of the Tariff Commission for increased protection of domestic wool producers.
JERUSALEM, March 3 -- Menahem Begin, former Palestine terrorist commander, called today for action by the Israeli Air Force to open the Egyptian-controlled Strait of Tiran for Israeli shipping.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a bill authorizing continued recruitment by this country of Mexican farm labor for employment in the Southwest.
BONN, Germany, March 3 -- A little black box that allegedly earns for its manufacturer an annual profit of nearly $200,000 was put on display in a Bonn cafe today.
A major change in manufacturing policy will be undertaken by American Woolen Company, according to a letter and proxy statement sent to stockholders yesterday.

Members of the Cribside Social Service Committee of the Babies Hospital will hold their first Thursday morning Lenten sewing class of the season this morning in the home of Mrs. Ward Melville at 1020 Fifth Avenue. Subsequent meetings will be held in the homes of Mrs. Eugene Holman, Mrs. Neville J. Booker, Mrs. LeRoy K. Howe and in the ballroom of the Colony Club.

DAMASCUS, Syria, March 3 (AP) -- Syria's new Government moved against ousted President Adib Shishekly's National Liberation Movement party today. It sealed all offices of the organization and confiscated its papers.

Coffee prices soared yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, more than wiping out the sharp decline of the previous day. The near-by cocoa option climbed, but the other positions were slightly lower. Prices closed irregularly higher with coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, burlap, rubber, zinc and copper stronger; wool, potatoes, hides and lead lower, and cocoa, sugar and tin mixed.

IrL its first change of ownership since 1936, the apartment house for forty families on plot 50 by 100 feet at 432-34 West Fif-i ty-third Street has been sold by Sophie' Chaitowitz to the Samarz Realty Corporation for investment.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- The Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives voted unanimously today to cite two college professors and two Philadelphia school teachers for contempt of Congress.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced today a two-year, $500,000,000 program of expansion and modernization. It also disclosed record sales and total income and a 4 per cent increase in net earnings in 1953.
The daughter of J. Russel Sprague, Republican leader of Nassau County and political intimate of Governor Dewey, was the hidden owner of $150,000 worth of stock in the Nassau Trotting Association.

The development of the atomic and hydrogen bombs leads to a situation where "there are no more odds for any would-be aggressor," William L. Laurence, science reporter for The New York Times, declared yesterday.

ATHENS, March 3 -- The Greek Rally Government is preparing legislation to alter electoral procedures. It has aroused opposition; but Premier Alexander Papagos has a 240-to-60 majority to rely on for its passage.
When a wife calls the boss on Monday morning to say that her husband will not be in to work because he is nursing a cold, it is often likely that what is being nursed is a hangover.

Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, wife of the Mayor, conducted reporters and photographers around Gracie Mansion yesterday to show them the changes she has made since the Wagners moved into their official residence last Jan. 25.

The permutations and combinations of Syrian politics are much too bewildering for Americans to follow. In any event, a close knowledge of what has been happening is not rewarding. It had been thought and hoped that the normal kaleidoscopic nature of Syrian politics had become a thing of the past under the strong-arm dictatorship of Brigadier General Shishekly.

PORTLAND, Me., March 3 -- A young man named Robert L. Jones, from near-by Biddeford, set up shop today as a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator. Thereby he opened one of the strangest campaigns in Maine annals.
