The West Penn Electric Company, one of the larger independent operating utilities in the Pennsylvania coal producing territory, reported yesterday a net income of $14,490,232. This was equal on a consolidated basis to $3.43 a share on the utility's outstanding common stock at the end of the year.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 3 -- Willie Mays signed his contract with the Giants today. Without even glancing at the figures, the 22-year-old center fielder whom Leo. Durocher called the "defensive equal of Joe DiMaggio, Terry Moore and any other center fielder I've ever seen," agreed to the same terms ($13,000) for which he played before his twenty, one-month hitch in the Army.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- Wheat futures were strong in the early trade today, with buying stimulated by sales of 2,700,000 bushels of red winter wheat to Yugoslavia, which will tend to tighten the cash situation still more.

THE serious essay is flourishing. We have four proofs of that on our table this morning: "Hellenism and the Modern World,"* by Gilbert Murray; "Essays on Education," by A. Whitney Griswold; "The Hedgehog and the Fox," by Isaiah Berlin, and "Humanities," by Desmond MacCarthy. These are able studies on important subjects by authoritative men.

LONDON, March 3 -- Laborites and Conservatives hurled conflicting statistics at each other in the House of Commons today as the former tried to prove that the Government's economic policies had resulted in industrial unrest.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Army was on the grill again today.
A representative collection of newly arrived French and Italian imports was shown yesterday at Russeks.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 3 -- Counsel for Walter G. Winne challenged the state today to produce former Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, ex-Attorney General Theodore D. Parsons, and Nelson F. Stamler, former special Deputy Attorney General, as prosecution witnesses in Mr. Winne's trial on charges of failure to suppress gambling in Bergen County.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's statement on the case of Maj. Irving Peress and of the reply by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy:

Mayor Wagner conceded yesterday that his 1954-55 fiscal program calling for an additional $145,000,000 of state assistance had collapsed under the weight of assaults by Governor Dewey's fiscal advisers.

A count of heads at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Auditorium last evening disclosed that among the millions living in New York, musical center of the nation, there were fewer than ninety persons sufficiently interested in hearing new works by four contemporary composers to attend the Bennington Composers Conference program.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- Bill Terry donned a Dodger jacket and cap and posed for photographers today. The photograph may outrage old-time Giant fans when they see it, but the contribution of the former Giant first baseman and manager to the Brooks was not merely pictorial.

Under the headline "McCarthy Amuses Himself," the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia last Sunday gave its readers a satirically written blow-by-blow account of the recent dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Army Secretary Robert T. Stevens.
With the formation of the American Fund for Westminster Abbey yesterday a drive was opened to enlist American aid in the repair and upkeep of London's 900-year-old landmark.

In a burst of enthusiasm that gave it the heaviest volume since Jan. 12 and sent prices to the best levels since March, 1953, the stock market put on an impressive show of strength yesterday. But trading lost momentum in the late afternoon and the market closed with a small net loss on the day.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Except for the slightly raised prominence of a bony ridge running diagonally upward from his left temple, and an occasional fingering of the bottom button of his vest, President Eisenhower appeared to be completely relaxed today as he faced a press conference fire of questions which he limited in advance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- SuperScope was announced today as the trade name for a film processing system whereby standard shaped movies can be converted for exhibition on the new style CinemaScope screen, which has greater width than height.
NORWALK, Conn., March 3 -- The Tracey Gold Medal problem, which has stumped the Board of Education for five years, was solved last night -- at least to the board's satisfaction.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) Manufacturers' sales, inventories and new orders received all dropped below December levels in January, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The same ethical standards used in judging deep-freeze Democrats in Washington and Costello-Democrats in Tammany must be applied in judging influential Republicans when they are brought before the bar of public opinion. Enough testimony has already been put on the record before the Moreland Act Commission investigating harness-racing tracks to cast doubt on the good judgment of several Republican bigwigs and to raise questions that require answers.

STOUGHTON, Wis., March 3 -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars post of this city has adopted unanimously a resolution denouncing the service record of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and declaring he "outrageously abused and insulted" Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 3 (AP) -- Berseem, disposed of Hill Gail then staved off the stretch challenge of the favored Woodchuck to win the $22,500 Christopher J. Fitzgerald Handicap at Santa Anita today.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Officials of the New York Police Department indicated today that they would prefer to continue their present traffic ticket system rather than the uniform "non-fixable" ticket that will go into effect Statewide on July 1.
The city has asked to be included in the first nation-wide tests of the Salk vaccine to protect children against poliomyelitis.

EL CENTRO, Calif., March 3 -- Officials of several labor unions charged the United States Border Patrol and a local farming concern today with malfeasance in the use of Mexican labor and the handling of captured border jumpers.
ALBANY, March 3 -- Democrats assailed today the Administration's proposal for optional permanent personal registration as an evasion of the basic problem.

Declines in wholesale prices during the past year have allowed Western European countries generally to relax monetary-credit restrictions set up to check inflation of the Korean war period, according to an analysis announced by New York University's Institute of International Finance.
Bearing the greetings of the city, Mayor Wagner last night presented a plaque to the Beth Israel Hospital School of Nursing on the school's fiftieth birthday.
BOSTON, March 3 -- Ask anyone in Irish-filled South Boston what March 17 is famous for, and you are liable to start a fight.
Sales and earnings of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation in 1953 were the highest in its thirty-four-year history.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The House Labor Committee voted today to take away the National Labor Relations Board's major function -- handling unfair labor practice complaints -- and give it to the Federal courts.

A group of educators in convention recently voted to support the President's proposal that 18-year-olds be given the vote. It does not seem logical that these men are courting the political support of their charges, an obvious argument in the case of the Administration's stand.

Few big corporations, if any, take full advantage of the provision in the 1936 Internal Revenue Act that permits them to disburse 5 per cent of net income for various good causes without tax payments.

March 16 was set aside yesterday by Mayor Wagner as the twenty-first annual Port of New York Day, to mark the "unmatched facilities" of this harbor. The Mayor issued a proclamation that he handed to James P. McAllister, president of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York, one of the early sponsors of a "day" for the port.

Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday that fourteen defendants named in a suit brought to wipe out what he called a huge used-clothing swindle that cost donors more than $1,000,000, had consented to be enjoined from further soliciting or collecting of such clothing.
Steady sluices of rain, speeded by forty-mile-an-hour gusts, soaked the city and suburbs yesterday, but did little about replenishing water-short reservoirs.
Because of adjournments, the positions of the leaders remained unchanged yesterday in the chess masters tournament at the Club Social Metropolitano, according to a report from Mexico City.

Annually the City of New York engages in a $25,000,000 guessing game that dwarfs the proverbish $64 question to the size of an amusing. With all the talent, all the attention and all the controversy surrounding the city's big guess we still have no solution to the problem: how much money will be in the "General Fund"?

WASHINGTON, March 3 (UP) -- Air Force pilots were authorized to tell the enemy more than their name, rank and serial number if captured as long as they did not disclose vital military information, a Marine pilot said today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 3 -- The Republic of Colombia drew up today for presentation to the Tenth Inter-American Conference a motion to study price controls on raw materials. It thus has sounded the opening note of what is likely to be the conference's loudest, longest and most vexatious debate.
In an effort to control "unruly and offensive" demonstrations such as those that have taken place recently, the Metropolitan Opera last night adopted a policy of limiting standees to 100.

Debutantes headed by Miss Carolyn Powers Cushman and including Miss Frances Wister are furthering the success of the April 1 performance of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of East Side House and its affiliated philanthropy, the Winifred Wheeler Day Nursery.

PARIS, March 3 -- The question of the presence or exclusion of the Vietminh Government of Ho Chi Minh from the Indo-China talks at Geneva and the conditions of a possible cease-fire on the Indo-China front were discussed in Government circles today.

Typical of the kind of work that occasionally seems to elevate today's handcrafts to the category of an art are the furniture and metal objects in a new exhibit at America House, 32 East Fifty-second Street. The display was arranged by the American Craftsmen's Educational Council and is made up of furniture designed by Loren Manbeck and silver and pewter pieces by Paul Evans.

NEW DELHI, India, March 3 -- India will have her first leftist government in the strategic southern state of Travancore-Cochin, this country's California, provided Communists and Socialists can agree on a Cabinet.

BUFFALO, N. Y., March 3 (AP) -- Lewis D. Gilbert, who claims the title of world's champion small stockholder, settled happily for a draw today in a "match" with Gen. Lucius D. Clay at the annual meeting of the Marine Midland Corporation.

Critics of Mondrian's neo-plastic philosophy are forever asserting that the esthetic was self-contained and allowed for no progression. Fritz Glarner, one of neo-plasticism's foremost proponents, now shows a dozen paintings at the Rose Fried Gallery which, in their innovation. prove that neo-plasticism is a flexible germinal philosophy.

STOCKHOLM, March 3 (UP)--Canada, skating toward a decisive Sunday clash with Russia, tossed a shower of pucks and punches at Germany today for an 8-1 triumph and a perfect record of 4 -- 0 in the world ice hockey championship.
The American Committee for Cultural Freedom proposed yesterday a set of ten standards of ethical controversy to restore a spirit of logical persuasion to public discussion.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 3 -- Eight of the world's major oil companies have entered nine competitive bids for one of the largest parcels of oil business today -- supplying Brazil with its crude oil requirements for five years.

The growing trend toward credit buying in the post-war years continued in the Second Federal Reserve District in 1953, according to the Monthly Review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The District's results paralleled those of the nation.

Homemakers can choose from a variety of styles in two new collections of decorative fabrics designed by contemporary artists. Both groups, one by the Seneca Textile concern, available at Wanamaker's, the other by the Riverdale Manufacturing Company, at Macy's, are printed on textured cotton, forty-eight inches wide.
Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue is a master of custom designs that are never too extreme, always wearable and of exquisite detail.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- The blood bank at Hines Veterans Hospital in suburban Maywood was replenished tonight by twenty-one Puerto Ricans who became donors as a gesture of sympathy for the five Representatives in Congress shot Monday by Puerto Rican Nationalists.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- Billy Martin, Yankee second baseman and the hero of the 1953 world series, who arrived here only yesterday to train with the Bombers until such time as the Army called him, did not have to wait long for his marching orders.
A new general housing plan for slum clearance in Brooklyn was set yesterday for a public hearing by the City Planning Commission. The hearing will take place at City Hall on March 31 at 2 P. M.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- Billy Martin, Yankee second baseman and the hero of the 1953 world series, who arrived here only yesterday to train with the Bombers until such time as the Army called him, did not have to wait long for his marching orders.
A new general housing plan for slum clearance in Brooklyn was set yesterday for a public hearing by the City Planning Commission. The hearing will take place at City Hall on March 31 at 2 P. M.

Various proposals for an all-American plan of economic cooperation are being advanced at Caracas. As the Inter-American Conference gets down to business it is clear that the member states are primarily concerned with economic problems and are seriously searching for ways and means to establish a closer partnership in this field.

The former Electra Theatre and the adjoining taxpayer building at 7414-24 Third Avenue, corner of Seventy-fifth Street, in Brooklyn are under contract of sale by Hazel J. Heissenbuttel to the 5. S. Gould Son's Company which plans to convert the property to use as a supermarket.
The American Committee for Cultural Freedom proposed yesterday a set of ten standards of ethical controversy to restore a spirit of logical persuasion to public discussion.

Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, presented posthumously yesterday its sixth annual Henrietta Szold award for distinguished humanitarian service to Monnett B. Davis. He had served as United States Ambassador to Israel until his death last December.

Representatives of the country's largest advertisers, which last year accounted for the bulk of the nearly $7,800,000,000 spent for advertising, will meet March 17-20 in the Homestead, Hot Springs, Va. The occasion will be the forty-fifth spring meeting of the Association of National Advertisers, where advertising's role in the current "hard sell" era will be explored.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 3 -- From all the talk of what to do about communism in the Western Hemisphere there has finally emerged at the Tenth Inter-American Conference here a plan of action to outlaw the Communist party in all twenty-one republics of the Organization of American States.
DACCA, Pakistan, March 3 -- Tempers and thermometers rose uncomfortably high tonight as charges and counter-charges were hurled by election campaigner in East Pakistan.
Leading producers of toasters, mixers and other small electric appliances reported yesterday that they were enjoying a minor boom.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 3 -- The chief Cuban and Peruvian delegates to the Tenth Inter-American Conference emphasized today the acute danger of Communist infiltration in the Western Hemisphere. They were making the opening speeches of the conference's first regular plenary session.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Post Office Department will conduct a pilot study of two-a-day mail delivery service in the residential areas of three cities for about three weeks.
Investing banking syndicates will offer to investors today $15,845,000 of new public utility and railroad securities of four issues.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 3 -- The New York Knickerbockers advanced their National Basketball Association lead to three games over the idle Boston Celtics by defeating the Philadelphia Warriors, 88 -- 79, at the Westchester County Center in White Plains tonight.

No American city has a greater or more varied need for Red Cross than does New York with its complex population, its many military and naval installations, its port of entry, its thousands of men and women in service and its numerous civilian hospitals.

Four apartment buildings in the Brbnx have been purchased in a single deal by Walter L. Rothschild from a client of Edward R. K. Fiencke, lawyer. The property consists of the structures with 124 apartments at 2755-61 and 2763-69 Sedgwick Avenue and the buildings with forty~two apartments at 2312 and 216 Loring Place.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 3 (UP) -- Cities Service Gas Company, a supplier of fuel for about 600,000 Midwestern home and commercial customers, announced plans today to seek a "substantial" rate increase within a few weeks. The proposed increase was announced by Glenn W. Clark, Cities Service president. He said his company is making studies required by the Federal Power Commission preparatory to filing an application for the higher rates.

HAMBURG, Germany, March 3 -- The Federal Government of West Germany has decided to meet adverse trends in world shipping by forcing German shipbuilders and shipowners into a period of financial consolidation.
The drive of inspectors of the Department of Air Pollution Control against smoke offenders brought yesterday its biggest day in court in terms of total fines collected -- $2,160.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 3 -- The United States filed suit in the International Court of Justice here today against the Soviet Union and Hungary for damages that resulted when a Soviet fighter plane compelled a United States Air Force C-47 to land in Hungary on Nov. 19, 1951.
What's in a name ?

Today's new film is "My Heart Sings," an Italian-made offering starring Ferruccio Tagliavini, at the Cinema Verdi. The Excelsa Film was directed by Mario Mattoli from a story by Ruggero Maccari and features Franca Marzi, Riccardo Billi, Mario Riva, Carlo Campanini and Dorian Gray.

"Isn't One Wife Enough?" an examination of Mormon polygamy, will be published April 8 by Holt. The author is Kimball Young, a grandson of Brigham Young, the Mormon leader. The author, at the age of 12, was ordained into the Aaronic Priesthood of the Mormon Church as a deacon, and later became an elder.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The Assembly approved unanimously today the Administration bill to outlaw the manufacture and sale of switchblade knives. The bill, which now goes to the Senate, was sought by Governor Dewey as an aid to reducing juvenile delinquency.

LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., March 3 -- A Federal mediator is scheduled to meet tomorrow with the contract negotiation committee of the Engineers Association of the Sperry Gyroscope Company as the group's strike against the concern goes into its third day.

Fordham and Manhattan, bound for different tournaments, put on a basketball thriller before a capacity crowd of 4,000 at Fordham's gymnasium and a large television audience last night. The Rams, 8 points behind with less than five minutes to go, won by 73 -- 68 in overtime.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 4 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, told the Tenth Inter-American Conference today that it was time communism was denied the right to survive on this hemisphere. If it persists, it should be treated as a potential danger to peace, he added.

A strong tone prevailed yesterday in coffee and cocoa trading on the New York exchanges. Prices of both commodities were substantially higher. Most items closed firm with coffee, cocoa, potatoes, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, copper, zinc, tin, lead and burlap up; hides lower, and sugar, rubber and wool mixed.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Eisenhower Administration laid its farm proposals before the Senate Agriculture Committee today and ran into threatening weather.

The problem of communism in Latin America is now being tackled at the Tenth Inter-American Conference in Caracas. Secretary Dulles discussed it in his opening speech yesterday; other delegates have also taken it up, and the Dominican Republic has introduced a resolution on the subject.
" Lucia di Lammermoor" was performed at the Metropolitan last evening, with Brian Sullivan making his first appearance of the season as Edgardo.

DETROIT, March A (UP) -- Ted Lindsay's goal with less than five minutes remaining tonight gave the league-leading Detroit Red Wings a 3-to-3 deadlock with the second-place Toronto Maple Leafs before 12,823 fans at Olympia. The tie protected Detroit's eight-point lead over the Maple Leafs.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Debate on statehood for Hawaii opened in the Senate today with a charge that Communist influence in the islands would weaken the United States.
MONTREAL, March 4 -- Canadian manufacturers were told today they were lagging in the race for world markets and should intensify sales efforts in the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- The Government said today it would cut prices on its surplus dairy hoards April 1 when Federal price supports on these products were scheduled to drop from 90 to 75 per cent of parity.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 4 (AP) -- E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reported today record sales of $1,750,000,000 last year, accompanied by high employment and record operating investment and research expenditures. Plant expansion all but set a new mark.

ISFAHAN, Iran, Feb. 18 -- The most famous signature in Middle Eastern art has been changed twice this month as a result of a long, bitter and hitherto unpublicized quarrel between the artist and a son who, he says, has been forging his name on second-rate paintings.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 5 -- Pravda published on Page 1 today a large three-column photograph of Stalin, together with an editorial on the first anniversary of the Generalissimo's death. It praised him for tireless work to achieve steel-like unity in the party ranks and increase the party's fighting preparedness.
A veteran professional claque leader at the Metropolitan Opera observed sorrowfully yesterday that "the business is being ruined by amateurs."

MEXICO CITY, March 4 -- The Mexican Foreign Office announced today that no more than the drafting of details was required for a satisfactory completion of the new agreement to send migrant workers to the United States.

In honor of Representative Alvin M. Bentley, members of the Hungarian National Council have will give blood today to the New York Chapter of the Red Cross at Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Dangerous Mission," an R. K. O. melodrama in Technicolor with Victor Mature, William Bendix, Piper Laurie and Vincent Price, is at the Holiday. Irwin Allen produced and Louis King directed from a screen play by Horace McCoy, W. R. Burnett and Charles Bennett. Betta St. John, Steve Darrell and Marlo Dwyer are in the supporting cast.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., directed its affiliates today to sign no new collective agreements unless they provided for automatic step-ups of minimum rates if the Federal minimum wage rate was raised.
Governor Dewey and the Legislature were officially urged yesterday to establish a new statewide judicial structure patterned after the Federal system.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- For the second time in four days Congress received today upward revisions of numbers of Government employes discharged or resigned last year with "security risk" charges against them.

To pay a 100 per cent stock dividend to holders of record next Friday, March 12, directors of the New Britain Machine Company voted yesterday to increase the authorized common shares. Subject to approval of shareholders at the annual meeting on March 30, the shares will be increased to 1,000,000 from 400,000 and the value changed from no par to $10 a share.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 4 (Reuters) -- Doctors here say that 30 to 50 per cent of all babies born in Indo-China die before they are a year old. Ancient superstitions are a major contributing factor, they add.
LONDON, March 4 -- Activity broadened and prices strengthened in most fields on the Stock Exchange today.

Karl Schroff of the Downtown Athletic Club, seeded No. 3, was among the victors yesterday in the opening round of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association's Class C championship. Schroff won his match from Harold Ashforth, Greenwich F. C., 15 -- 11, 15 -- 13, 16 -- 15.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Eisenhower today nominated J. Ernest Wilkins of Chicago, a Negro attorney, to be Assistant Secretary of Labor in charge of international labor affairs.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- Gulfstream Park started the final forty-three days of Florida's racing season today with a record opening-day crowd of 23,385 that saw Mrs. Charles Silvers' 4 to 1 Ruthred win the $12,700 Armed Handicap in a photo finish.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- Despite a bogey on the final hole, Pat Lesser, national intercollegiate champion, ousted the defending champion, Barbara Romack, from the women's South Atlantic amateur golf tournament today.

New cases of profiteering by some private hospitals in this city were reported yesterday by state Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein. He also complained that supervision over those institutions was inadequate here.
ALBANY, March 4 -- Governor Dewey refused all comment today on the disclosures being made in New York at the hearings of the Moreland Act Commission.

The door - to - door salesman like the expectant father, is, for some unknown reason, a comic character in the popular mind. But become confidential with any of these funny men and they'll tell you outright, door-to-door selling is no joke.

AARE, Sweden, March 4 -- To France went the day's world ski honors today, when vivacious 27-year-old Mme. Lucienne Schmidt of Chamonix outraced thirty-nine competitors to win the women's giant slalom championship.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 4 (AP) -- Following is the text of the address by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, to the Inter-American Conference today:
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $267,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bond reported today.
ALBANY, March 4 -- Indians of New York are looking more and more beyond the confines of their reservations for opportunity as citizens of the state.
Police Deputy Inspector Francis J. M. Robb was named commanding officer yesterday of the Bureau of Special Services and Investigations. Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams made the appointment.
Haarlem House will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Il Trovatore" the night of April 17 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

President Eisenhower's nomination of J. Ernest Wilkins to be Assistant Secretary of Labor for International Affairs is an excellent choice. Mr. Wilkins, the first Negro ever to be named to a sub-Cabinet post, has a splendid, reputation at the Chicago bar, to which he was admitted in 1921.
The New York City Ballet last night gave the season's first presentation of Frederick Ashton's "Picnic at Tintagel" at the City Center.

I wholeheartedly agree with you, as stated in your editorial of March 3, that because of the United States decision to give arms aid to Pakistan "misunderstanding between India and the United States" has been widened.

An $800 across-the-board annual wage increase will be urged by 2,000 postal workers from all over the country at a conference next Tuesday in Washington. The conference has been called by the Government Employes Council, A. F. L., which represents over 800,000 Federal workers, including postal employes.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby today started a legislative move to change all grant-in-aid programs from an "earmarked" to a "state-plan" basis.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- They all but shed tears today as Billy Martin, spunky, scrappy second baseman of the Yankees, packed his belongings and headed west to finish his stint in the Army.

" HOME," the National Broadcasting Company's ambitious daytime, undertaking, is now on the air (11 A. M. to 12 noon, Mondays through Fridays). Commercially, the program is almost certain to be successful.
Hailed as the most modern pier in the world, a new $12,750,000 Pier 57 was dedicated yesterday at West Fifteenth Street.

LONDON, March 4 -- British secret research in aerodynamics and jet engine design is approaching the point where the chief problem in flight is the "heat barrier," air friction at high speeds, called kinetic heat.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Eisenhower refused today to accept Tariff Commission recommendations designed to reduce wool imports. Instead he proposed to await Congressional action on a program to aid domestic wool producers.

A new scientifically designed starling startler has all but cleared the city of State College, Pa., of the objectionable birds -- for the time being, anyway. The method was reported yesterday to the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
Robert R. Young, who seeks control of the $2,600,000,000 New York Central Railroad Company, filed suit yesterday against the company and its fifteen directors.

Gordon R. Clapp has been chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority for the past eight years. He came to T. V. A. to assume a minor position in the personnel department in 1933. His swift rise was due to a combination of technical and administrative proficiency, great energy and, as this newspaper once said editorially, "zeal for the public service and a grasp of the social and economic ideals for which T. V. A. stands."
The Drunkometer, the chemical testing apparatus that ascertains the percentage of alcohol in a person's blood, was upheld in its first local court case yesterday. as "scientifically reliable."
DUBLIN, March 4 (UP) -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera called a general election tonight as a result of the crushing defeat suffered by his Fianna Fail party in two by-elections.
MOSCOW, Friday, March 5 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, called on Europe today to reject the European Defense Community, which he declared was the course to "a third world war."

Attorney General Herbert Brownell keeps pressing for a bill to legalize wiretap evidence. He asserts this is a necessity in helping to indict subversives. His own chief aide, F. B. I. Director J. Edgar Hoover, virtually demolished the necessity for such a bill.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, said today that the Government was considering possible prosecution of leaders of the Puerto Rican Nationalist party whose members shot five members of Congress.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 4 (UP) -- Holdout Mickey Vernon, Washington's American League batting champion, was removed from the trading block by Owner Clark Griffith today in a sudden about-face which had all the earmarks of a salary truce.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A prominent psychiatrist testified today that Col. Frank A. Schwable was "a man without a will" when he wrote a fraudulent germ warfare confession for the Communists in Korea.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Mr. Wilson mixed hard words with soft today in his trans-Potomac exchange with Senator McCarthy.
PARIS, March 4 -- The debate on Indo-China that will begin tomorrow in the National Assembly will be closely linked with France's other great foreign problem, the European army.
Although the calendar promises at least two more weeks of winter, signs of spring appeared in city markets this week.
Beginning some time this afternoon, travelers passing through Grand Central Terminal will be able to set their watches and make their trains with the help of the old familiar golden clock.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A Pennsylvania Railroad attorney and Benjamin F. Feinberg, chairman of the New York State Public Service Commission, were peppered with questions from the bench today by members of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

BONN, Germany, March 4 -- French objections to West Germany's constitutional amendment on rearmament will be discussed by Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, and Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, in Paris Tuesday, reliable sources said today.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The House of Representatives today beat down by a vote of 84 to 61 a Democratic effort to force Scott McLeod, State Department security officer, to abide by the no-politics rules of the Hatch Act.

The Republican leaders of Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau County, as well as important legislators, were named yesterday as the Moreland Act Commission continued its hearing into scandal-tainted harness racing.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 4 -- Dr. Alberto Lleras Camargo of Colombia caused a sensation by announcing at the plenary session of the Tenth Inter-American Conference this afternoon that he would resign as secretary general of the Organization of American States.

LONDON, March 4 -- Conservative, Labor and Liberal voices were raised today in Britain in an acid chorus of disapproval of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and disillusionment in the leadership of President Eisenhower.

You certainly hit the nail on the head in your editorial plea to President Figueres of Cost Rica on Feb. 22. The defection of this leader of Latin-American democracy from the Tenth Inter-American Conference at Caracas leaves the dictatorships he deplores in a stronger position there.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- Democratic leaders will open here tomorrow a two-day rally for the fall Congressional elections.
Spring was anticipated at the fashion show of gay and fresh evening and cocktail dresses created by Gothe and presented by De Pinna yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.
CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) -- Police seized five Puerto Ricans today in a round-up of leaders of the Nationalist movement in Chicago.

Despite a plea yesterday by William W. Remington's wife, Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell refused to reduce the three-year perjury sentence he had imposed on the 36-year-old former Government economist.
PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren of the United States tonight urged all lawyers to contribute a "sizable portion" of their time to the "cause of sound government."

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 4 -- Jackie Robinson said tonight that he believed he had no more than another year of baseball ahead of him and that if he could gain the security of a five-year contract in radio and television he would be through with the game.

The "Symphonic fragments" from Dallapiccola's ballet, "Marsia," were heard for the first time at a Philharmonic-Symphony concert when Guido Cantelli, as guest conductor of the orchestra, played them last night in Carnegie Hall.
HAMBURG, Germany, March 4 -- This metropolis of 1,600,000 inhabitants constitutes a laboratory for studying in the sharpest detail the principal achievements and problems of post-war Germany.

Yesterday's snow flurries in the metropolitan area may have sent flickers of hope through local skiers but, as expected, the flurries only served to prove winter is still with us. So far as the weatherman is concerned, he wasn't fooled. He knew it would amount to nothing.

On Wednesday the President of the United States said he was glad to state that "Senator Knowland has reported to me that effective steps are being taken by the Republican leadership to set up codes of fair procedures" for Congressional investigating committees.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The United States and Israel completed today the formalities for putting into force next month the first general-purpose treaty between the two nations.
BUENOS AIRES, March 4 -- Eric Johnston, president of the American Motion Picture Association, surveyed today recent developments in the United States film industry.

With the opening of the circus at Madison Square Garden on March 31, Prentice-Hall will issue a biography of one of the "big-top's" great entertainers. Emmett Kelly, the sad-faced hobo-clown. Written by the circus publicist, F. Beverly Kelley, "Clown" tells of Kelly's career under the tents in the United States and England and presents anecdotes about men and women famous in circus lore for the last thirteen years.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 4 -- Samuel Goldwyn appeared today to have sewed up film rights to the musical hit "Guys and Dolls," with an offer of a $1,000,000 down payment and 10 per cent of the picture's world-wide gross over $10,000,000.
Auguste Richard has been elected a director of Chemical Fund, Inc. He recently resigned as a senior vice president and director of F. Eberstadt Co., Inc.
PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- Alastair B. Martin, defending title holder from Glen Head, L. I., reached the semi-final round of the national amateur court tennis championship today.
Prominent industrial and business executives will speak at the spring meeting of the Customer Relations Council of the American Trucking Associations April 11-13 at the Palmer House in Chicago.
A new bi-state attack on the transit problems of the metropolitan area was urged yesterday on the Governors and Legislatures of New York and New Jersey.
CHICAGO, March 4 -- An era of increased college enrollment that will eclipse the "golden age" of the G. I. Bill was predicted today.

One of the leading independent radio stations in the country, WNEW, Inc., 565 Fifth Avenue, was sold yesterday to a group headed by Richard D. Buckley, former president of the John Blair Company, radio station sales representatives.
The dismissal of Nat Holman after a fifteen-month suspension from his post as basketball coach at City College was a "denial of the ordinary rules of fair play," his attorney declared last night.

They are No. :2070, a twenty.sevenfamily house; N0. 2074, a thirty:four-family house,, and No. 2076, a building with forty-two apart.ntents and six stores.

The next thirty days were described yesterday as critical. Bernard G. Cohn, president of Independent Retailers Syndicate, Inc., said that retail volume in this period would shape the manufacturers' policies for the fall season.

Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, declared yesterday it was "nonsense" to contend that recent personality clashes had torn the Republican party apart. He did not mention Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, or any member of the Eisenhower Administration by name.
DAMASCUS, Syria, March 4 -- The three-day-old Syrian Government became today the first Arab League member to endorse the recently announced military alliance between Turkey and Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today dismissed price-fixing conspiracy charges lodged against ten metal lath manufacturers in 1946. The commission divided on the verdict, three to two.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- It is now up to Senator McCarthy whether he Will again challenge in deed as he has in word the President's position toward legislative examination of Executive personnel. If the Senator does, and the President maintains the stand he took at his press conference yesterday, other Republicans, including members of McCarthy's committee and subcommittees, must make the choice they have so long avoided.
Pledges by the Democratic and Republican parties to conduct the 1954 Congressional campaign "on a decent level" were asked yesterday by the head of the American Federation of Labor's political arm.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 4 (AP) -- Superior height paid off tonight for Columbia as the Lions defeated the Trinity basketball team, 55 -- 52.

Following is the text of yesterday's recommendation by the Temporary Commission on the Courts for the establishment of a state-wide judicial conference and under it an office of director for court administration:

An information center that beguiles the eye and that, at the same time, answers many questions before they're asked, reopens today in the newly decorated Seventy - seventh Street foyer of the American Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Permission to operate air coach shuttle service every two hours between New York and Washington for a fare of $10, including tax, was asked of the Civil Aeronautics Board today by the North American Airlines.
On net sales of $178,164,701, second largest in its history, the Timken Roller Bearing Company and its subsidiaries last year realized a net income of $10,856,402 against $10,596,534 earned in 1952.

SEOUL, Korea, March 4 -- The United Nations reconstruction programs, including the United States project, have been hampered to a serious extent because of difficulties with the South Korean Government.
TRENTON, March 4 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner disclosed here today that the Democratic nomination for United States Senator had been offered to Representative Charles R. Howell.
Everett M. Patterson has been appointed director of engineering for Avien, manufacturer of aircraft fuel management systems and other aeronautical instruments.
BAYONNE, N. J., March 4 -- The Board of Education turned today to the State Commissioner of Education for assistance in settling the two-day-old strike of 457 teachers and other school employes.
MOSCOW, March 4 (AP) -- Soviet sports authorities said today that it was impossible to send a Russian track and field team to tour the United States at the present time.
THERE were dramatic moments in the quest for the Constance Missal which the Pierpont Morgan Library acquired the other day.

HOUSTON, March 4 (UP) -- Cary Middlecoff used a red-hot putter in 45-degree weather today to card a six-under-par 66 for a one-stroke lead in the first round of the $30,000 Houston open golf tournament.

BOSTON, March 4 (UP) -- Boston outshot and outslugged Montreal in their final game of the season here tonight, but the teams had to settle for a 1-1 tie, improving their National Hockey League standings by one point each.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 4 (AP) -- Cornell University's Republican Club's faculty adviser resigned that post today because the club has invited Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, to speak on the campus this spring or next fall.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 4 Competent French military sources here believe that more than 100,000 men of the rapidly expanding Vietnamese National Army will be first-class shock troops by the end of this year. The army as a whole is expected to total more than 300,000 at that time.

The Federal Government's hydroelectric projects are not for sale. This was stated yesterday by Ralph A. Tudor, Under Secretary of the Interior, at the Municipal Forum at the Downtown Athletic Club. Mr. Tudor, outlining the Eisenhower Administration's policy, said:

AKRON, Ohio, March 4 (AP) -- Sandy Saddler, the featherweight champion, scored a weird victory tonight when Charlie Slaughter of Elizabeth, N. J., suddenly quit in the fourth round and walked back to his corner.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday that commutation and reduced-rate ticket books were now available at gasoline stations in New Jersey and New York near the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels and the three Staten Island bridges.
LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- Sir Winston Churchill said tonight things are looking brighter in Britain.

The attorney for Pfc. Marvin S. Belsky, who was accused by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of being a member of an alleged Communist conspiracy in the armed services, challenged the Wisconsin Republican last night to produce evidence that his client "did anything but perform his duty as a soldier and a doctor."

It will take more than a high-powered committee to boost the battered morale of Foreign Service men in the outposts where the shadow of the current craze for "investigation" has fallen. It should be said at once that there are not so many of them as the clamor indicates.

How can this city hope to tackle intelligently the disturbing problem of traffic accidents when it has no clear statistics or adequate reports on which to base judgments? Every major city except New York not only has accident investigating teams in the field but keeps records that enable engineers to evaluate the cause of mishaps and take proper remedial measures.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 4 -- Police Chief Salvador Roig tightened security measures to v for the Puerto Rican Legislature and top officials after receiving reports that Nationalist ter ists in New York might be hatching attacks here.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 4 -- Premier Chen Cheng declared in a report to the National Assembly today that the projected Geneva conference would be a "waste of time."

Jeanmaire, a leading ballerina, will make her Broadway stage debut at 8 o'clock tonight in the twice-postponed premiere of "The Girl in Pink Tights" at the Hellinger. Co-starred with her is Charles Goldner, a stage and film actor from abroad, who is making his local bow. Both will appear in an "extravaganza" and not a musical comedy as previously announced by the management.
Commissioner of Correction Anna M. Kross restored yesterday to 1,100 employes of her department the right to wear badges on their uniforms while on duty.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 3 points up to 3 points off.

The Crucible Steel Company of America has acquired a 50 per cent interest in the Vacuum Metals Corporation, the nation's only commercial producer of high-purity metals by the vacuum melting process. Vacuum Metals was formerly a wholly owned subsidiary of the National Research Corporation.

ALBANY, March 4 -- Governor and Mrs. Dewey concluded today a series of five luncheons at which they entertained all but seven of the Republican County chairmen in the state. The most notable exception was Senator Arthur H. Wicks of Ulster, whose retirement as Senate Majority Leader was forced by the Governor last fall.

One year ago today, the official Soviet history tells us, Joseph Stalin died. As when a bloody war ends or a deadly plague ceases, his passing lifted a burden of dread from humanity and brought hope that a better future might be beginning. To what extent has this hope been fulfilled?
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The public tightened its use of credit sharply in January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A call for revolution in Brazil to eliminate United States "oppression" and the government of President Getulio Vargas has been published in the latest issue of the Cominform newspaper.

ALBANY, March 4 -- Bills to reduce from $10 to $5 the fee for special automobile registration plates were introduced in the Legislature today by the Rules Committee at the request of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 4 -- Barring unforeseen difficulties, Yugoslavia hopes to dispense with the need for direct economic assistance some time during 1955, her economic chief declared today.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The newly confirmed Chief Justice of the United States, Earl Warren of California, seems to have made a good start.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 4 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, told the Tenth Inter-American Conference today that the United States Export-Import Bank was back in business for economic-development loans.

Myron Sands, who has not been heard in Town Hall since 1947, gave a recital there last night. The young baritone is an extroverted type of singer who happily strides to the stage with confidence, acts out much of the music, and in general throws himself wholeheartedly into his work.

The continuing strength in the bond market carried the price of the Treasury's Victory bond issue of 2 1/2 per cent bonds back to par yesterday for the first time since the market for United States securities was restored to a free basis in March of 1951.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Prices of March, May and July soybeans moved up today to the highest levels since 1948. Grain futures, however, had a weak undertone, especially wheat, which was unable to hold rallies.
SAN SALVADOR, March 4 -- The problem of Guatemala confronts hemisphere policymakers in Washington with an unhappy choice.

Swedish meat balls are one of those foods that should be incorporated in every recipe repertory, Swedish or not. They are thrifty, tempting, easy to do and, because they may be used as appetizer or main course in soup, they also are versatile. They represent an interesting way of dressing up that old reliable hamburger.

As has become almost a habit in recent sessions, the stock market went in one direction for part of the day yesterday and then counter-marched in the afternoon. The change this time was for the better and final prices showed a modest gain. Rails were far stronger than industrials.
TORONTO, March 4 -- Television is a first-class teacher, easily surpassing books and its elder cousin, radio.
The New Mexico Military Institute polo team defeated Cornell's trio, 11 -- 7, at the Squadron A Armory last night.
West Virginia borrowed $5,000,000 yesterday on an issue of road bonds maturing from 1955 to 1979 at an interest cost of 1.9478 per cent.

Representatives of the city's newspaper publishers met yesterday with union leaders of newspaper photo-engravers to review the recommendation of a fact-finding board calling for a $3.75 weekly package increase.

FROM 1920 to 1945 J. H. Williams lived in the teak forests of Northern Burma. For the first twenty-three years he was a jungle boss of the logging operations of a great British company and in charge of the daily labor, physical health and spiritual welfare of some 2,000 elephants. For the last three years, in command of his own elephant corps, he was a lieutenant colonel with the British forces fighting the Japanese.

Donald Bloomingdale, 42 years old, a nephew of Samuel Bloomingdale, honorary chairman of the board of Bloomingdale Brothers, was found dead on his bed yesterday morning in his suite in the Sherry-Netherlands Hotel. The police said his death had been caused by an overdose of barbiturates.

New Issues and the Market Close students of the new-issue market for common stock are wondering whether the improved reception of new equity shares may be setting up a signal for the secondary market to move ahead. On many occasions in the past, indigestion in the new-issue market has preceded a bear market in stocks.

PARIS, March 4 -- Sidi Mohammed el Amin Pasha, the Bey of Tunis, put his seal of approval today on a series of important administrative reforms that give partial satisfaction to nationalist aspirations in the French protectorate of Tunisia.
DETROIT, March 4 (AP) -- General Motors employment and payrolls were higher in 1953 than in any previous year.

Gilda Ferro, 18 years old, and her sister Dolores, 20, were sentenced yesterday in Brooklyn Court of Special Sessions to sixty-days on their pleas or guilty to petit larceny. Their 42-year-old mother, who had been a co-defendant, was acquitted.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Treasury announced today that it will offer $1,500,000,000 of tax anticipation certificates for cash subscription on next Wednesday, March 10.

ATLANTA, March 4 -- "Furious lobbying" by White House and State Department aides was blamed today by Senator John W. Bricker, Ohio Republican, for the defeat of his effort to curb Presidential treaty powers.

Prime Minister Nehru and his Congress party in India have won one battle and lost one in their election struggle with the Communists. In the far north the Congress party won an outright majority in the Patiala and East Punjab States Union. In the far south the Congress party lost to a Communist-Socialist coalition in Travancore-Cochin.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, which included the Washington's Birthday holiday, totaled 595,031 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 23,592 cars or 3.8 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 73,623 cars or 11 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 160,813 cars or 21.3 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- By a unanimous vote, the House of Representatives Ways and Means Committee passed today an excise tax revision bill.
LONDON, March 4 -- British newspaper publishers have asked the Government to approve contracts for the import of additional 100,000 tons of newsprint a year.
The Bryn Mawr Regional Scholarship Fund of New York will be augmented by the proceeds from the performance of "The Girl in Pink Tights" the night of April 20 at the Mark Hellinger Theatre.

Another victory for Dr. Edward Lasker of New York in the sixth round, his fourth in the chess masters tournament at the Club Social Metropolitano, gave him a commanding lead with a score of 4 1/2 -- 1/2, according to a report from Mexico City yesterday.
ALBANY, March 4 -- Governor Dewey sent to the Senate for confirmation today the nomination of Robert E. Blum, Brooklyn department store executive, as a member of the State Board of Social Welfare.
A 16-year-old boy who has been in prison nearly a year as a result of a jurisdictional fight, got a "break" yesterday.

Jimmy Carter, holder of the lightweight championship of the world, will defend his crown tonight against Paddy De Marco. The bout, listed for fifteen rounds, will be held in Madison Square Garden before a crowd of about 8,000.

STOCKHOLM, March 4 (UP) -- Maurice (Moe) Galand, a sharp-shooting left wing from Toronto, fired seven goals past Finland's befuddled netminder today to lead Canada to a 20-1 victory. The Russian players, who attended the game, left early, shaking their heads.

UPPER BROOKVILLE, L. I., March 4 -- Mayor Arthur H. Dean, former special envoy to the Korean peace negotiations, and his wife, Mrs. Mary Marden Dean, village clerk and treasurer, will conduct a tax sale at 10 A. M. Tuesday at their residence.

THE trend to light-tackle fishing in salt water was never more clearly emphasized than in the latest record sheet of the International Game Fish Association, for of eighty-five new records recognized during 1953, fifty-two were for twelve, twenty and thirty-pound test line.

NEWARK, March 4 -- Harold John Adonis, former executive clerk to ex-Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, went on trial here today for income tax evasion. The case, which is being tried before Federal Judge Alfred E. Modarelli and a jury, got under way after a morning session that was devoted to selection of the jury and argument on defense motion for a new postponement, which the court rejected.
ALBANY, March 4 -- Governor Dewey said today that it would be "a shame" and "a disgrace" if New York City failed to give its employes pay increases they deserved.

Plans fo modernizing a row of old tenements in the Columbus m Circle area near the. proposed City Coliseum site were announced: yesterday in connection with the sale of 400 to 406 'W. est Fifty-eighth Street, southwest corner of Ninth Avenue.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 4 -- A question of precedence arose between the United States and Guatemala today but was solved when Foreign Minister Guillermo Toriello of Guatemala yielded and agreed to speak tomorrow instead of today.

NEW DELHI, India, March 4 -- While protesting against United States military aid to Pakistan, Indian officers have discovered with considerable annoyance that their own forces are technically benefiting from Washington's foreign military assistance program.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 4 (AP) -- Bitterly disappointed because of his failure to approach the four-minute mile, John Landy said today that he intended to keep on running and would know within a week about his projected trip to Europe and the United States.
LONDON, March 4 -- The British Government is seeking a formula for the settlement of industrial disputes without recourse to strikes.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 4 -- All season-ticket subscribers and all contributors to the San Francisco Symphony Association were requested today to tell the board of governors whom they preferred as conductor of the orchestra.
Repayments by a wide variety of industrial borrowers cut the volume of New York City bank loans to business $36,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday.
LONDON, March 4 (AP) -- Kirsten Flagstad, Wagnerian soprano, permitted Elizabeth Schwarzkopfs soprano to substitute for hers on two high "C's" in a recent operatic recording.

One-man shows this week were numerous. Among them is work by Julio Girona, a young Cuban painter who offers a buoyant vision of the clamor of forms in his first one-man show at the Artists Gallery. Most of his oils present rounded, sometimes billowing, shapes dilating from a diagonal axis.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 4 -- Apart from the pitcher, the line-up that is likely to open the season for the Giants started as Manager Leo Durocher's Regulars today. With Willie Mays and Ray Katt leading the attack, they turned back the Yannigans, 8 -- 2, in an eight-inning practice game.

In "The Burning Glass," which opened at the Longacre last evening, Charles Morgan has written a scientific melodrama with philosophical overtones. A young British researcher has found a way to destroy the earth by concentrating the heat of the sun. His machine and formula could benefit humanity.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., yesterday attacked as "ridiculous" charges of "waste and featherbedding" against its membership and accused the New York City Transit Authority of inefficient maintenance of the city's subways and buses.

Miss Ruth Hakohen, 28-year- old Israeli resident, was indicted yesterday by a Brooklyn Federal grand jury on a charge of seeking to smuggle into the country 913.45 carats of diamonds worth $104,655. She was also indicted for using a passport issued to her sister, Mrs. Ester Kaz.
MEXICO CITY, March 4 -- President Adolfo Ruiz Cortines returned today from his first official visit to Monterrey, Mexico's "Cinderella City."

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4 -- Back in the old days when that stubbornly opinionated pair, Larry MacPhail and Leo Durocher, bossed the Dodgers, they'd rave annually about all the great right field prospects they had in spring training camp. Then, almost as an after-thought, they'd add reluctantly, "oh, yes, there's also Dixie Walker." Each opening day Walker would be in right field as everyone knew from the beginning.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Secretary of Defense characterized as "just damn tommyrot" today the charges by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that the Army had coddled Communists during the Eisenhower Administration.
Vandals broke into a junior high school in the Inwood section and a restaurant in Fort Tryon Park Wednesday night or early yesterday morning and caused damage estimated at several thousand dollars.

Chain and independent supermarkets captured an ever greatter share of the country's grocery sales last year, according to the twenty-first annual survey of food retailing by the trade publication Progressive Grocer.

Short-sleeved spring coats were included in the collection of coats and suits from Ohrbach's Grey Room that was previewed by the press yesterday. The sleeves -- from just below to well above the elbow -- were accented with cuffs that varied from stitched tailored styles to fluffy fox.
A resolution attacking the conduct of Congressional investigating committees has been adopted by the General Faculty of City College.

Harbison - Walker Refractories Company and subsidiaries cleared a net income of $6,091,713, equal to $4.30 a common share in 1953, it was announced yesterday. This represents a decline of about 7 per cent from the $6,648,636, or $4.84 a share reported in 1952.
WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A spokesman for the Senate subcommittee on juvenile delinquency said today that hearings on a bill dealing with nonsupport probably would open early next week.
Net earnings of the J. C. Penney Company improved last year to $38,472,933 from $37,170,071 in 1952, reflecting a rise of $30,251,170 in sales to a new high.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 4 -- A witness testified today that a telephone company became suspicious of bookmaking during the time Walter G. Winne is charged with failing to stop gambling in Bergen County.

New York University completed its 1953-54 basketball season by overwhelming City College, 59 -- 38, last night. The thirty-ninth meeting of the old rivals attracted 2,500 spectators to Fordham's gymnasium, the neutral site of the contest.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Department store sales in the week ended Feb. 27 were 3 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:
Harold R. Harris, veteran pilot and airline manager, resigned yesterday as president of Northwest Airlines, Inc.
WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The transmissions in about 6,450 medium tanks are being taken apart for correction of faulty assembly discovered in some of them, the Army said today.
CHICAGO, March 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows;
Defiant longshoremen last night threatened a total shutdown of the Port of New York in protest against a Federal judge's order to end their week-old boycott of waterfront truck movements.
DALLAS, Tex., March 4 -- Each day of the Dallas Fashion Center showings this week helped round out definite style trends.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (UP) The Soviet Union has formally asked the United States what it knows about the disappearance of the Russian diplomat, Yuri Rastvorov, in Japan in January, it was disclosed today.

The election of Louis E. Wolfson as chairman and president of the Newport Steel Corporation was announced yesterday. Mr. Wolfson is also chairman and president of the Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, one of the nation's major construction companies.

The 295,000 volunteers in service groups give friendly, faithful service in hospitals, in homes for the aged, on docks where troops are debarking and in United States military hospitals in Japan and Europe.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 4 (UP) -- An Army spokesman said today it "did not know yet" where Billy Martin, the New York Yankee second baseman, would be sent when he is inducted Monday.

ALBANY, March 4 -- A life insurance company issuing slot-machine policies limited to the protection of passengers on scheduled airline flights can be held liable for claims resulting from accidents to non-scheduled planes under certain circumstances.

BALTIMORE, March 4 (AP) -- Siegfried Weisberger, convinced that "the age of the boob is upon us," is closing his world famous Peabody Bookshop, still stocked with 100,000 volumes he says nobody wants to read.

The Sparrows Point Shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Company, which delivered more ship tonnage than any other shipyard in the world last year, may have to close down by the end of this year unless new business comes along.

Clement Eaton, Professor of History at the University of Kentucky and author of "A History of the Old South," has a new work on Macmillan's list for March 30 publication. Entitled "A History of the Southern Confederacy," the volume delves into the military and political aspects of the Confederacy and analyzes the economic and cultural life of the South under the influence of war.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.1 per cent in the week ended last Tuesday to 110.6, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for farm products were responsible for the advance, as the indexes for processed foods and industrial materials remained unchanged.
President Eisenhower, in a letter to the twenty-eighth annual conference of the Secondary Education Board, declared yesterday that mature judgment was impossible without free inquiry.

Three judges before whom cases are pending involving the custody of the orphaned sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, executed atom spies, have agreed to leave to Surrogate's Court the decision about the boys' future guardianship
BALTIMORE, March 5 (AP) -- Mike Agostini of Villanova tied the world record of 6.1 seconds tonight to win the 60-yard dash at the 175th Regiment-South Atlantic A. A. U. indoor track games here.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The number of persons claiming unemployment insurance dipped slightly in the third week in February to a total of 2,168,200, the Department of Labor reported today.
BERLIN, March 5 -- East Germany appears to be seeking to recruit new members for its armed forces, but Western officials doubt that any great expansion is planned.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and prices were unchanged, to 7 points lower.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Mr. Hewitt was characterized today as "undoubtedly a brilliant physicist."
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., March 5 (AP) -- The Army put Cpl. Claude J. Batchelor of Kermit, Tex., a prisoner of war in Korea who changed his mind about staying with the Reds, behind bars today.

CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States Ambassador to the United Nations, said today the United Nations "stands between us and World War III, or the extinction of human freedom, or both."
CAIRO, Saturday, March 6 -- Egypt will elect a civilian constituent assembly within three months to begin assumption of power from the revolutionary military regime.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5 -- Measures taken during the post-war years to ease the flow of private investment capital into under-developed countries are summarized in a memorandum this week by the Secretary General to the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The increasing migration of older persons to warmer climates is creating new problems, the Joint Legislative Committee on Problems for the Aging said today. The report declared that the trend made it more urgent than ever to plan new types of services to the aged. It asserted that the migrations often left a trail of unhappiness.

The prevailing impression left by a reading of the preliminary report of the Temporary Commission on the Courts, addressed to Governor Dewey and the Legislature, is one of dismay at, yet better understanding of, the formidable size and scope of the assigned task.
Commodity prices moved irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 5 -- Vietminh forces destroyed or damaged ten Dakota transport planes in a raid on the Gialam airport near Hanoi early Wednesday. The airport, a few miles from the city, is, after Saigon's, the most important in Indo-China.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey told a Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner tonight that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Republican party are "hollering treason charges" against the Democrats to conceal Republican "panic" at this fall's Congressional elections.
HOUSTON, March 5 (AP) -- Freddie Haas of New Orleans placed a rain-drenched 71 beside his first-round 67 today to take the lead at the half-way mark in the $30,000 Houston open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Major league baseball was dealt one defeat today by the Government in a radio broadcast ruling, and two officials of the national pastime were summoned to a hearing on a bill designed to force August A. Busch, brewery owner, to sell the St. Louis Cardinals.
LONDON, March 5 -- The securities markets here continued to recover today.
Former President Harry S. Truman arrived by train from his home in Independence, Mo., at noon yesterday. He was accompanied by Mrs. Truman.

TOKYO, March 5 -- The Japanese Government is planning a major surgical operation on the nation's swelling imports. For the past year these have been cutting steadily deeper into Japan's dwindling foreign currency reserves.

With the obvious intent of emphasizing that nothing has changed since Stalin's death, the Soviet Government chose the anniversary of his death yesterday to issue a long statement on the Berlin conference which demonstrates that the Stalin spirit still dominates Soviet foreign policy.
A six-year legal battle involving four one-time partners in a fabulous rum-running enterprise of the prohibition era came to a tentative conclusion last night.

CHICAGO, March 5 (UP) -- The New York Rangers got only a scoreless tie with the last-place Chicago Black Hawks of the National Hockey League tonight, but the stand-off moved them into a fourth-place tie with the Boston Bruins, who were idle.

First prize in the chess masters' tournament at the Club Social Metropolitano was clinched by Dr. Edward Lasker of New York, president of the Marshall Chess Club, when he won his adjourned fifth-round game from Alfonso Ferriz in forty-five moves, according to a report from Mexico City yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 -- The North Atlantic Ports Conference today urged the House of Representatives to vote down legislation authorizing this country to join with Canada to build the St. Lawrence Seaway.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 5 -- Secret negotiations are in progress between the Vietnamese nationalists and Chief of State Bao Dai.

Eight members of the Hungarian National Council gave blood yesterday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program in honor of Representative Alvin M. Bentley, Republican of Michigan, who was wounded last Monday in the shooting in the House of Representatives.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 5 (AP) -- Two power-laden entries dominate a field of seventeen entered in tomorrow's $100,000 added San Juan Capistrano Handicap, a race with an international flavor that winds up the fifty-day meeting at Santa Anita Park.
NEW DELHI, India, March 5 -- General Motors announced today the closing of its Indian assembly plant at Bombay after twenty-five years of operation.

MOSCOW, Saturday, March 6 -- The plan to increase Soviet grain acreage on virgin or idle land by 32,100,000 acres in the next two years has been approved. Present production does not cover Soviet needs.
Three metropolitan swimming records were set in the New York University pool last night in time trials for tonight's metropolitan Intercollegiate Conference championship.
Tonight radio station KE2XCC, the experimental FM broadcasting station set up by the late Maj. Edwin H. Armstrong, will sign off for the last time.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- Auto industry chiefs came up with clashing views on the nation's economic outlook today.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- The tendency of many college programs to "reflect an atomic age which puts a new premium on the technician," while generally ignoring cultural and spiritual values, was deplored today at a conference of educators.
The latest estimates showing declines in United States exports and imports for January were said by foreign traders yesterday to reflect some cautious reaction to recession talk.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Arthur Godfrey, the radio and television entertainer and flying enthusiast, will be grounded for six months.

In the interests of a consistent international trade policy President Eisenhower has rejected the Tariff Commission's recommendation that a surcharge be imposed on existing tariff rates on wool. The President's action will doubtless raise protests from the wool growers, who have never been known to be reticent in their demands for governmental assistance and who are a powerful political force in some of the Western states, as well as on Capitol Hill.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Patty Berg, playing out of Fort Myers, Fla., posted a 36, 35 -- 71 today to lead the field in the opening round of the $3,500 Sarasota women's open golf tournament at the Sarasota Bay Country Club.
MOSCOW, March 5 -- Mourning flags of crimson, edged in black, flew in Moscow on the first anniversary today of the death of Stalin.

Two rookie patrolmen assigned to try to solve the Feb. 25 robbery of a Park Avenue beauty parlor spotted two men who appeared to fit the description of the hold-up men and arrested them on a street corner last night.
From the neighboring Cardinal encampment, Manager Eddie Stanky announced that while he, too, would use only rookie hurlers he would have no fewer than five regulars in his starting line-up.
A noted "bone detective" and two other scientists received last night the eighth annual Viking Fund awards and medals of the Wenner-Gren Foundation for the Anthropological Research, Inc.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 5 -- The January Union County grand jury cleared the film "The Moon Is Blue" of obscenity today. It refused to indict the Ritz Theatre management for exhibiting the motion picture in December.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 5 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today that he was "sure that the Army never coddled Communists at all, deliberately."
The following is a round-up of household hints that may be helpful to the homemaker:

LONDON, March 5 -- A slight but significant easing of the deadlocked dispute over Britain's Suez Canal base seems to have followed the meeting Monday between Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, President of Egypt, and Selwyn Lloyd, Minister of State.
PARIS, March 5 -- Premier Joseph Laniel told the National Assembly today that the Conference on Asia fixed for Geneva April 26 did not rule out an armistice in Indo-China before that date.

From reports so far issued, the earnings of the oil industry last year were about 8 per cent higher than in 1952. Of the companies reporting, only a very few have reported earnings lower than in 1952. The slightly better prices for crude oil and products which went into effect at mid-year and the increase in demand accounted for the improved earnings.
MARRAKESH, French Morocco, March 5 -- Terrorists tried today for the second time in six months to kill the pro-French Sultan of Morocco, Sidi Mohammed ben Moulay Arafa.

Laymen should not rush in where lawyers fear to tread. However, the New York State Senate Judiciary Committee has approved a measure, sponsored by Senator Williamson of Scarsdale, which has a very strong "common sense" appeal. This bill would replace the present state legal doctrine of contributory negligence by a rule of comparative negligence.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- Three American housewives, just back from Brazil's coffee orchards, said today Brazilian producers were innocent of any attempt to rig the coffee market. They predicted prices would rise still higher and they put the blame for present high coffee prices on shortages and increased world demand.
In slow, methodical and unexcited fashion, the stock market lumbered uphill yesterday to the best levels since March 30, 1953.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 5 -- Three 10-year-olds had their share of milk today -- milk from United States cows, milk from Yugoslav cows and milk from soybeans. They also tried breads of fish meal.

OTTAWA, March 5 -- Opposition members of the House of Commons, almost universally opposed to what they term "McCarthyism," have begun to question whether the Canadian Government's methods of dealing with communism are as affective or as fair as some persons in this country have been led to believe.

MOSCOW, March 5 -- Israel and the Soviet Union signed today an agreement under which Moscow will deliver 100,000 tons of crude oil to the Haifa refinery. The agreement also included an option for Israel to purchase an additional 100,000 tons of crude oil.
The proposal for a bridge across the Narrows between Brooklyn and Staten Island is now being revived. It should receive a prompt quietus and the project should be turned into plans for a tunnel.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 5 -- Dolores Del Rio, whose visa application still is being considered, will not appear in Twentieth Century-Fox' "Broken Lance."
LONDON, March 5 -- Safeguards against making commercial television in Britain a mere branch of the United States TV industry have been written into the Government's television bill.

Paddy De Marco won the lightweight championship of the world last night. Waging the shrewdest and cleanest fight of his career, the erstwhile "billy goat" from the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn gained a unanimous decision over the defending champion, Jimmy Carter of the Bronx, in a spirited fifteen-round contest at Madison Square Garden.

The sternwheeler Minto, for fifty-five years a familiar sight in the rugged Arrow Lakes region of Western Canada, has steamed on her last paying trip, the Canadian Pacific Railway announced yesterday.

LONDON, March 5 -- Aneurin Bevan has embarked on his most formidable bid for leadership of the Labor party. His prime issue is West German rearmament, which he believes involves the "possibility of the destruction of mankind."

The Fifty-two Association of New York has added another year's stripe, the ninth, to its service sleeve. With the steady flow of men returning from Korea, with rotation bringing more uniforms to this city, including the V. A. hospitals, the slogan that "the wounded shall never be forgotten" holds true.

MIAMI, March 5 -- By plane, bus and private automobile, the Dodger party of about ninety persons moved into Miami today. From tomorrow on the National League champions will be in competition with major league opponents until two days before the pennant race begins.
The United States has finally begun enforcing an international regulation that it ratified eighteen years ago, but no qualified authorities in New York seem to know why.

D. Mallory Stephens, Republican leader of Putnam County, was revealed yesterday as the owner of Yonkers Trotting Association stock on which he received dividends and on which he stands to make at least $210,000.
PHILADELPHIA, March 5 -- Alastair B. Martin will seek his fifth consecutive national amateur court tennis championship tomorrow.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 5 -- For quality and quantity, the current squad of Giants is the best Leo Durocher has had since he became a manager. That's what the man who piloted both the Dodgers and Giants to pennants in the past said today at the conclusion of a long, though light workout.

The prospect of motion-picture censorship in this state even more restrictive than that prevailing before the recent United States Supreme Court decision upsetting the ban against the French film "La Ronde" is being faced in industry circles with foreboding.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- Philip Young, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, said today he assumed that some of the Federal workers dismissed by the Eisenhower Administration as security risks had been hired after the Republicans had taken over the Government.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The House of Representatives today passed and sent to the White House a bill to increase the Government's farm price support funds by $1,750,000,000 to a record high of $8,500,000,000.

DENVER, March 5 (UP) -- The United States Geological Survey announced today that a new vanadium mineral previously unknown to science has been found at the Monument No. 2 Mine in northeastern Arizona.

Operating revenues of Pennsylvania Power Company last year reached a record $12,993,843, up 11.1 per cent from the 1952 total, according to the annual report released yesterday by W. H. Sammis, president.
