The program of the recital given by Artur Rubinstein last night in Carnegie Hall stated simply that "this concert is dedicated to the 100th anniversary of Steinway and Sons." It forbore, however, from specifying that the entire proceeds of the concert were donated to the pension fund for the Steinway employes -- those who in various ways have themselves contributed to the development of the unique instrument of the Steinways' fabrication.

A triple-header starting at 6 o'clock will get the seventeenth annual national invitation basketball tournament under way at Madison Square Garden tonight. The pairings for the opening session are St. Francis of Brooklyn against Louisville, Manhattan against Dayton and Bowling Green against Wichita.
An arsenal apparently intended for shipment to Cuba was seized by the police yesterday afternoon in a raid on a store on the upper West Side of Manhattan.

Fortunately Jeanmaire is the star of "The Girl In Pink Tights," which opened at the Mark Hellinger last evening. She goes a long way toward compensating for a clumsy and witless musical show. She is the French young lady with the boyish bob who first devastated this town when she danced Carmen here a few winters ago.

HONG KONG, March 5 -- On the first anniversary of Stalin's death Red China today stressed the need for "collective leadership" of the Chinese Communist party under the "Central Committee headed by Mao Tse-tung."

A call for sharply increased donations in an annual "One Great Hour of Sharing," scheduled among Protestants for March 28, has been made by the Rev. Dr. Wynn C. Fairfield, executive director of Church World Service. He asks that the original goal of $8,000,000 be increased by at least $3,000,000.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 5 -- Chair passenger service, with seats selling at about $12 a trip, is envisioned by maritime union leaders for daily steamship operation between this port and Los Angeles.

" Beauties of the Night." Rene Clair's latest French-made comedy, with Gerard Philipe, Martine Carol, Gina Lollobrigida and Magali Vendeuil, has been scheduled to have its American premiere at the Fine Arts Theatre after "The Conquest of Everest," according to an announcement by Lopert Films, which will release the import through United Artists distribution.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5 -- Although the name did not appear officially on their 1954 roster, the Yankees, who seem to be operating a peculiar preparatory campaign this spring, considered themselves to have lost another player today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 5 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from an unofficial translation of the speech by Guilermo Toriello, Guatemalan Foreign Minister, at the Tenth Inter-American Conference today:
PARIS, March 5 -- General Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Commander, Allied Forces Europe, said tonight that Americans did not need to be convinced of the importance of the North Atlantic Alliance.
NEWPORT, R. I., March 5 -- Permanent residents of this summer playground are protesting a builder's plan to convert a Victorian-style mansion into modern apartments.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission says that the rapid growth of the electric power and natural gas industries since the end of World War II has greatly increased its responsioilities and because of its limited staff has made it unable to keep up with rate increase applications.
OYSTER BAY, L. I., March 5 -- The 101-foot motor vessel Wanderer dropped temporarily her role as a floating laboratory this week and has just completed a two-day good neighbor mission for the Navy.
Stanley High, a senior editor of Reader's Digest, said yesterday that Americas best export was "our kind of Christianity."

A truck driver and his assistant were seriously injured yesterday when their truck was virtually demolished in a collision with a Long Island Rail Road locomotive at Forty-ninth Street and Fifty-sixth Road, Maspeth, Queens.
ATLANTIC CITY, Saturday, March 6 -- A general-alarm fire destroyed early today the four- story State Villa, a Boardwalk area guest house which once was a famous Atlantic City landmark.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Men who are plagued by pajama legs that creep up are directed to an invention patented this week by Earl C. Schultz of Staples, Minn. It is a sort of garter to be worn on the foot, with straps around the ankle and under the arch and a clip to be attached to the pajama cuff.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at the southeast corner of Park Avenue and Ninety-first Street, known as 1133 Park Avenue, has been sold by Edward C. Sternlight to the 1135 Park Avenue Corporation through Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., brokers.

Some outstanding herbs and spices recently have become available by mail-order from Mario P. Ruggeri of Highland, N. Y. Mr. Ruggeri's claim to distinction in the seasoning field is the fact that he obtains each of his seasonings from the area that is considered to be an outstanding producer of it.

Last night's program by the New York City Ballet at the City Center contained one first performance of the season and two last performances. The first performance was that by Jillana in Balanchine's "Opus 34," in which she replaced Tanaquil LeClercq.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The press of the United States has developed a tendency to entertain rather than to inform its readers, Lester Markel, Sunday editor of The New York Times, said today.

Alexander Pavlovich, 32-year- old Yugoslav seaman, was convicted yesterday by a Federal Court jury of assaulting Robert G. Thompson, convicted Communist leader, with a lead pipe. He will be sentenced next Friday.

The dilemma of United States leadership at the Inter-American Conference, the controversy over Hawaiian statehood, the gathering storm over the McCarthy issue are reminders that our world is bigger than Europe and Asia. The Big Four parley at Berlin revealed that the German question was closely related to the problem of China.
DURHAM, N. H., March 5 -- A bogus professor with a "compulsion" to teach has been unmasked, the University of New Hampshire said today.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A State Department spokesman said today that Scott McLeod was "a trusted and loyal officer" who intended to remain at his post even though he had recently been stripped of much of his power.
Close to half a million children in New York and New Jersey are in the areas selected for the tests of the new poliomyelitis vaccine this spring and summer.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board has spelled out, for the first time, how the Reserve System moved during 1953 from a policy aimed at restraining inflation to one of deliberate easy money.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Eisenhower could give away without any restrictions for foreign aid purposes $2,500,000,000 worth of surplus farm products under the Administration's farm bill, the Senate Agriculture Committee heard today.

Transit workers in eleven major cities in the country have received pay increases since July, 1950, but those on the city-owned lines here have had none, the transit fact-finding committee was told yesterday.
Teachers and others at City College who altered records to favor standing of basketball players face investigation by the Board of Higher Education
Representatives of the city's newspaper unions planned yesterday to hold an emergency meeting Sunday night if newspaper photo-engravers should vote to renew their strike on Monday.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 5 (AP) -- Ohio State and Michigan shattered three Big Ten swimming records tonight in a tight battle for leadership in the Conference championships.
The many uses of the loom, kiln and mallet are treated extensively in three recently published books on arts and crafts. They may be of interest to homemakers or their children.

ALBANY, March 5 (AP) -- The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company announced in newspaper advertisements today that it would shut down 125 of its A P stores at the close of business tomorrow "because we cannot operate our warehouse" in Albany. The stores employ 3,000.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- New construction totaled about $2,320,000,000 last month, a record high for February, the Government reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission may have to explain to Congress a proposal to modify competitive bidding regulations under the Public Utilities Holding Company Act, Representative Louis B. Heller, Democrat of Brooklyn, said yesterday.
Freezing weather covered most of the nation Friday -- including much of the Deep South.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 5 (AP) -- Ogden Phipps' Privacy threw a scare into his backers at Gulfstream Park today when he barely won the $4,000 Atlantic City Racing Association Purse before a crowd of 17,382.

THOSE interested in qualifying for a place on the United States rifle or pistol team, to compete at the International Shooting Union World Championship Matches at Caracas, Venezuela, in November, may compete in tryouts for smallbore, big bore, slow-fire or rapid-fire pistol.
An issue of $37,000,000 of revenue bonds to complete the financing of the West Virginia toll turnpike was placed on the market yesterday by an investment banking syndicate headed by Bear, Stearns Co.
Alfred J. Bohlinger, State Superintendent of Insurance, approved two bills yesterday to revise expense margins for life insurance companies operating in New York.

Two veteran scenic designers and a Pulitzer Prize winning playwright are planning a Broadway repertory company for next season. The designers are Leo Kerz and Harry Horner and the author is Joseph Kramm, whose drama, "The Shrike," won the Pulitzer Prize for the season of 1951-52.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Department of Commerce moved today to put its job statistics in sharper focus.

Guatemala's Foreign Minister, Guillermo Toriello, shrewdly took the offensive yesterday in the conflict over communism in Latin America at the Tenth Inter-American Conference in Caracas. He placed the issue squarely on a basis of alleged United States intervention in Guatemalan affairs at the same time that he denied his country is Communist.

The make-up and objectives of New York City's new Department of Labor raise some rather disquieting questions. A small, informally run division, headed by a $15,000 director, is now succeeded by a department with a $20,000 director. The department will consist of twenty-four employes; the director has two deputies who will supervise the staff, which includes five mediators, two economists, a director of a statistical division and ten clerks and stenographers.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Feb. 25 -- More than 300,000,000 leaflets have been dropped by Nationalist planes over the Chinese mainland since January, 1953, in a continuing "paper war" against the Chinese Communists.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The United States announced today that it would not sign the international tin agreement drawn up at Geneva in 1953.
Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell declared yesterday that industrial peace in the United States must come "primarily and basically" from employe-employer relations and not from legislation.

AIX - EN - PROVENCE, France, March 5 (AP) -- Airmen of three nations turned their attention to the lofty Alpine crags along the French-Italian border in a search today for a missing United States Air Force C-47 with twenty Americans aboard. Darkness forced a temporary halt to the hunt tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The names of 121 officers and enlisted men of the Army and Air Force previously listed as missing in action in Korea and now presumed to be dead were announced today. Those from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were:
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 5 -- A mainland investigator started an inquiry here today growing cut of last Monday's shooting of five members of Congress in Washington by Puerto Rican Nationalists.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 5 -- The question of the Communist menace in the Americas was given first priority in political discussion as the Committees of the Tenth Inter-American Conference began work today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 5 -- Guatemala arraigned the United States today before the Tenth Inter-American Conference. The tiny Central American republic charged that plots of almost every kind of evil had been undertaken against it.
STORRS, Conn., March 5 -- Practical experience with children should supplement textbook study of child behavior for high school pupils.

OTTAWA, March 5 -- Canada's exports dropped by $55,000,000 in January, compared with the same month in 1953. Total exports were valued at $265,400,000, compared with $321,300,000 in January a year ago.

Disgruntled longshoremen shut down most of the Port of New York yesterday with a wildcat strike. Defying a Federal Court no-stoppage order issued on Thurday and ignoring the back-to-work advice of their leaders, members of the old International Longshoremen's Association refused to answer the morning starting whistle at more than half the port's 159 piers.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy quietly withdrew today the $2,000,000 libel and slander suit he filed two years ago against former Senator William B. Benton, Connecticut Democrat.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- A bill for cuts of 50 per cent in most Federal "luxury" taxes was cleared by the Rules Committee today for action Wednesday in the House of Representatives.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 5 -- Charles Starkins was sentenced to twenty-five years to life in Sing Sing Prison today by Judge Cyril J. Brown in Nassau County Court. He was convicted Feb. 16 of second-degree murder in the slaying of his father, Alvin, a retired New York City policeman. His wife, Eileen, 20-year-old mother of two children, was acquitted by the same jury.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, March 5 -- Despite a sharp decline in trade with the United States, Ceylon's net dollar income has increased.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 5 -- The new Syrian Government took its first overt step today toward abandoning isolationist policies of previous regimes by dropping border restrictions between this country and Lebanon.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 5 -- The Malan Government introduced legislation today to enable it to deal with a group of monopolies and trusts that since the days of Cecil Rhodes have largely controlled South Africa's economy. The bill was published by E. H. Louw, Minister of Economic Affairs.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- United States aid to the French and Vietmanese armies remains geared to the expectation of military victory, Harold E. Stassen, Director of the Foreign Operations Administration, said today.

Oil, gas and electricity bid fair to put out of business altogether a device that once was a common sight in home basements and now is becoming, fortunately, increasingly rare. This device, designed for the express purpose of heating water for a household, is known by a number of names, some of them unprintable; however it is, in polite circles, called "a bucket-a-day" or a "monkey stove."
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The four Puerto Ricans accused of shooting five members in the House of Representatives last Monday were entered in court records tonight as having pleaded not guilty.

The annual spring promotion, "The New In Shoes," will open next week backed by the heaviest advertising support ever given to the event, according to the National Shoe Manufacturers Association, Inc., its sponsor.
Realty and business representatives made it clear yesterday that they did not like the city's proposed requirement for the provision of garage space for all new nonresidential construction.
SEATTLE, March 5 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Carpenters, A. F. L., announced today an organizing program to bring 150,000 new members into its union, already one of the world's largest.

Alfred G. Vanderbilt disclosed last night that he had refused an invitation from Robert R. Young to run on an opposition slate of candidates for directorships in the New York Central Railroad Company.

MONTREAL, March 5 (Canadian Press) -- Net profit of $7,533,026 in 1953, compared with $6,880,258 the previous year, was shown today in the annual report of Imperial Tobacco Company. Profits were equivalent to 71 cents a share, compared with 62 cents in 1952.
CAIRO, Saturday, March 6 -- Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Premier of Egypt, said today that Egypt would welcome new talks with Britain on the Suez Canal zone issue.

PRESCOTT, Ont., March 5 (UP) -- Some sixty-four Canadian families living in Ogdensburg, N. Y., and commuting to jobs here have been told by United States Immigration officials to move back to Canada or apply for United States immigration visas.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 5 (AP) -- A new type of "floated" gyroscope, capable of such minute jobs as measuring the width of a city block on the moon, is being produced by Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company.

BOSTON, March 5 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers protected their three-game eastern division lead by gaining their seventh straight victory of the season over the Rochester Royals, 70 -- 66, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

A vacant blockfront parcel on the west side of Ninety-fourth Street, between Fifty-ninth and Sixtieth Avenues, in Rego Park, Queens, has been sold by Horace B. Packer, Inc., of Wellesville, Pa., to a corporation headed by Meyer Bonuck.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration reported today that more than half of its hospital beds were now being occupied by patients with chronic conditions.

Hundreds of service personnel and their dependents who have become confused in their travels from continent to continent have found a strong arm to lean on at Fort Hamilton. It belongs to Rolley E. Wyer Jr., Red Cross field director and a wholesale dispenser of solace and solutions.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- President Eisenhower notified Congress today that five of this country's European allies had shipped strategic goods to Soviet satellites.
STOCKHOLM, March 5 (UP) -- Canada defeated Czechoslovakia, 5 -- 2, tonight and moved close to the world ice hockey championship when Sweden held the strong Russian team to a 1-1 tie.
CHICAGO, March 5 (AP) -- Stewart-Warner Corporation today reported net income of $4,081,000, equal to $3.04 a share, for 1953 compared with net income of $4,234,000, equal to $3.30 a share, in 1952.

BAYONNE, N. J., March 5 -- New peace talks aimed at ending the three-day-old teachers strike will be conducted here tomorrow after the failure of state officials to settle the pay dispute at Trenton today.
If there is anything nonsensical that has remained undiscovered to the present time, McCarthy and Dirksen will invent it.
WINDSOR, Ont., March 5 -- The Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., announced today that it was closing its assembly plant at Bombay because of the Indian Government restrictions on this industry.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 5 (AP) -- The Big Ten Conference today mapped a 1954 regional football television program to submit to the National Collegiate Athletic Association as a replacement for the nationally controlled plan.

" CARNIVAL BY THE SEA,"* by Sigrid de Lima, is the moving story of a lovely lost Eurydice, wandering in the gaudy hell of a modern amusement park. This is a novel to be read slowly, though it often has the pace of a mystery thriller. The light comes obliquely. Swarming shades of the savagely dramatic classical mythology surround the girl, as they did in Eleanor Carroll Chilton's "Shadows Waiting."
ST. LOUIS, March 5 -- Striking municipal employes voted today to return to work, as the result of Mayor Raymond R. Tucker's assurance last night that a new compensation plan soon would be considered.

ELIZABETHTOWN, N. Y., March 5 (AP) -- An Essex County grand jury today returned against B. Gregory Brewster, the former Essex County Attorney, sixteen indictments charging second degree forgery, second degree grand larceny and uttering forged instruments.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (UP) -- The House of Representatives approved today a $1,168,988,000 money bill that includes a cut for the United States Information Agency which operates the Voice of America.

TRENTON, March 5 -- Former Representative Clifford P. Case of Rahway, N. J., officially announced today that he would be a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator, as had been anticipated.

Events today: "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; American Chamber Orchestra, Town Hall, 3; Dubravka Tomsic, pianist, Town Hall, 3; "Boris Godunov," Metropolitan Opera, 7:45; Philharmonic-Symphony, Guido Cantelli conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Amherst College Glee Club and Briarcliff Junior College Choir, Town Hall, 8:30; Martin Canin, pianist, Philip Fatt, clarinetist, and Fausto Esteeves, 'cellist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- John F. Kane, special assistant to Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, resigned tonight. He declared his chief was not receiving the "energetic support" he needed in his controversy with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn won the team title last night in the twenty-ninth annual swimming championships of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at Columbia University. The Terriers, with three first places, finished with a total of forty-one points.

Two of six policemen on trial in Staten Island for conspiracy to commit bribery, perjury and falsification of affidavits to protect gamblers pleaded guilty yesterday. Three agreed to resign from the force. This leaves only one defendant at the trial in the extraordinary term of the Richmond County Supreme Court.

Every three seconds a man, woman or child is injured in an accident in this coun try. Every five minutes someone is killed. The Red Cross teaches people how to protect themselves and how to save the lives of others -- in the home, at work, at play, or on the highway.
Experts in the wide fields of antiques are called upon continually for information and appraisal.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5 (AP) -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals has granted a permanent injunction sought by the National Labor Relations Board to bar the United Mine Workers from using "coercive methods" in organizing nonunion miners.
Six crewmen of the superliner United States were injured yesterday when a lifeboat fell sixty feet to the water from the vessel's boat deck during a routine lifeboat drill.

CHICAGO, March 5 -- Buying of wheat increased substantially after declines in the early trade here today and prices for all deliveries moved up sharply. Mill buying appeared to be on a larger scale and gave impetus to local absorption of the old-crop months.
Certain business men are convinced that the door-to-door vacuum cleaner salesman is becoming a vanishing American.

ONE of the more effective methods of dealing with varied gardening problems is to consult the experts. By this approach the sad and expensive mistakes that can stifle one's taste and talent for gardening can be avoided, and, fortunately, the experts are no more distant than the nearest book store.

GRAHAM GREENE, a storyteller who is usually concerned with weightier matters, and illustrator Dorothy Craigie follow up "The Little Red Fire Engine" with another picture story. Like the earlier book, it is based on the inevitable struggle between the old and the new, with author and artist firmly on the side of the former.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The more or less unsinkable "Bricker amendment," though no longer the personal enterprise of Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, has bobbed hardily to the Senate surface again.
MOSCOW, March 4 -- Minks and diamond brooches, Persian lamb coats and emerald necklaces are on sale along with milk cans and kerosene stoves in Moscow's new big department store on Red Square.

ALBANY, March 6 -- State Controller J. Raymond McGovern accused the Wagner Administration today of attempting to "twist facts" to support "fundamental fallacies" in its contention that New York City is not receiving a fair share of state aid.

SINCE Walter Starkie, the impressive and portly doctor of letters at Dublin, last regaled us with his books of Gypsy adventure -- in Castile, La Mancha, Hungary and elsewhere -- some years and the smoke of wars have drifted past.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 6 -- Ground will be broken here this spring for a new Temple Sholom. The building, occupancy of which is scheduled for the fall, will be situated on Putnam's Hill and will face the Boston Post Road at East Putnam Avenue.

SOMETIMES the average home owner may wonder if there is any hope of transforming a poor lawn into a good one without dedicating his entire life to the task. Well, the answer is "yes," I did it, and the routine that was worked out should work for most anyone, if it is followed faithfully.

A YEAR has now passed since Joseph Stalin died. While he lived, he was the object of idolatrous praise such as few rulers in history have been accorded. His "infallibility," "genius," "wisdom," "unerring foresight" and the like were impressed on the Russian people and the world by every medium of communication.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon ended his holdout siege tonight. After a conference with Vice President Calvin Griffith, the first baseman signed with the Senators for a salary estimated at $30,000.

BERLIN, March 6 -- Vladimir S. Semyenov, Soviet High Commissioner for Germany, rejected today last month's proposal by his Western colleagues that the high commissioners negotiate the lifting of East-West trade and travel barriers in Germany.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 6 -- The South African National Socialist group, which the Hitler regime urged to rise against the Allies in World War II, has announced it will break up.
Plans are being formulated at luncheon meetings at the Waldorf-Astoria for the third annual April in Paris Ball to be known this season as the Bal de la Sole.

THE arrival of the new season's catalogues is now providing gardeners with one of the most pleasant exercises of their art; namely, gardening on paper -- planning for the months ahead and ordering the necessary seeds.
The Moreland Act Commission investigating harness racing in the state recommended yesterday that the state's share of the daily "handle" or betting receipts at the tracks be increased by one-third.

IN London one day last autumn a notable public career came to an abrupt end under circumstances which should have meaning for every man in public office. The victim of the tragedy was Piltdown, called by his highbrow friends, Eoanthropus, and the source of his sorrow was that he had been given a build-up.

In the sale of a business enterprise, an agreement by the seller not to compete may be an important consideration. Such a covenant may have accounting as well as tax consequences affecting both the seller and the buyer.
Paddy De Marco looked anything but a "has been" at the International Boxing Club yesterday.
Woodrow D. Johnson has been named general sales manager of all products of the textile division of the United States Rubber Company.

IN a suburban housing development the house is the thing. The grounds are so negligible that at times it seems the builder must have thought two houses could share gas and water pipes. The available land, of course, must be planted as economically, spacewise, as is possible.

NOTHING is more welcome to the gardener than a timesaver that really works -- and the modern weedkillers certainly qualify as reliable and efficient in that respect. There are three general types, and it is easier to use them to best advantage if something of how they work is understood.
BOGOTA, Colombia, March 6 (AP) -- The Government issued a decree today ordering Colombian newspapers to confine themselves to factual reporting.

A five-year national project to improve the education of women is now under way. Sponsored by the American Council on Education's Commission on the Education of Women, the study will cost $1,000,000 and will be the most comprehensive ever made of women's education in the United States.
AARE, Sweden, March 6 -- It was Austria's day at the world ski championships today, for Trude Klecker, 25-year-old ethnology student from Semmering, won the women's slalom.

THE Texana of Mr. Mirvish's Third, and best, novel is Texas City. Here, in 1947, it will be remembered, a freighter carrying nitrate fertilizer caught, fire, exploded and set off chemical works and oil refineries along the shore.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 6 (AP) -- Three persons were killed and three others seriously injured today when two automobiles collided on Route 1 at the eastern outskirts of town.
Governor Dewey and his fiscal advisers were accused yesterday of being the manipulators of "a shell game" designed to break the city's efforts to set up a sound long-range financial program.

WHENEVER you see a rufous horn-bill on the coping of the Chase Bank call Henry Trefflich. If a troop of rhesus monkeys invades your table some noon at Whyte's get him on the phone. Exotic animals on the loose in lower Manhattan are usually fugitives from Henry Trefflich's faunal trading post at 228 Fulton Street.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 6 -- Marvin Hewitt declared here today that he was "one of the nation's really eminent physicists" and expected job offers from schools, industry or the Government.

PARIS, March 6 -- The French Army has invented no sensational "brain washing" technique to arrive at the impressive result described by President Eisenhower at Wednesday's press conference. He remarked then that 75 per cent of Communist draftees in France were no longer Communists when they completed their eighteen months' training.

CAIRO, March 6 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, President of Egypt, said today that the Egyptian constituent assembly to be convened in July, would have full legislative powers as well as the task of approving a new permanent Constitution for the country.
THE Republican Congressman leaned back in his chair and looked his visitor in the eye. "No, I'm not at all sure I'll run again," he slowly repeated.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- Not only is the Soviet Union employing international sales of gold to assist the financing of its foreign trade program, but gold may now be freely purchased from state stores by Soviet citizens. Not, however, at prices that are likely to encourage hoarding or speculation.
LONDON, March 6 -- British troops in Malaya have been parachuting from military aircraft into treetops and then sliding down special ropes to ambush the Communists.

THE United States "Presidential" or regular series of stamps is on its way out after having been in circulation for about sixteen years. A blue and red 8-cent in a Statue of Liberty design -- announced at Washington and scheduled for release in "the early part of April" -- is the first unit in a new definitive group which will get away from design-standardization and instead will carry a variety of vignettes.
City College's basketball team handed Brooklyn College its worst defeat in the nineteen-year series last night, trouncing the Kingsmen, 93 -- 56, in the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- The Southeastern States Democratic rally started off in the dark and the rain tonight, but the lights soon came on again and spirits were not dampened.
Noah may have been a busy man looking after the animals on the Ark, but Federal animal inspectors here think they are busier.

Mr. Newman writes that he feels sure that Harry Lauder traveled the Keith circuit. I can confirm that. I was a Monday afternoon regular at Keith's Grand Theatre in Syracuse, N. Y., between 1911 and 1915, and I can assure Mr. Newman that Mr. Lauder played the house several times during that period.

HIGHLY regarded in its day, the music of Johan Svendsen is now hardly a memory for concertgoers. His Romance for Violin, once universally played, has gone the way of the Raff Cavatina and Drdla's "Souvenir" into limbo.

WIESBADEN, Germany, March 6 -- The West German Free Democratic party on the second day of its fifth annual convention affirmed its intention to develop into a "third force" between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union and the Social Democratic Opposition.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -Representative Harold H. Velde said today that the House of Representatives Un - American Activities Committee planned to check up on the Justice Department's fight against the Nationalist party.

MIAMI BEACH, March 6 -Democratic spokesmen joined here today in assuring the party that the programs of the Eisenhower Administration were driving the "average people" to the Democrats as "political saviours."

WITH his magnum opus completed, the five monumental volumes of his history of the writer in America, it is natural that Van Wyck Brooks should feel impelled to turn to autobiography. For this impulse we must all be grateful. Whatever differences with Mr. Brooks one may have, it is not possible to doubt that his life in letters has been of the very greatest significance, of a significance that, for our time, is perhaps unique.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- President Eisenhower was host today to Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands at a luncheon in the White House. The Prince is on a tour of United States air bases. The President posed with Prince Bernhard, Netherlands Ambassador J. H. van Roijen, Gen. J. Lawton Collins and Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, his brother.

In the past twenty years the terrace has reached full flower. Something of a novelty in the early Thirties, the post-war building boom made it an integral part of life in the suburbs. So much so, in fact, that this scheme for living invaded even the city, and cliff dwellers by the score now covet that "apartment to let with terrace."

ST. PETERSBURG -- Only the newest maps of Florida show the Holiday Isles. Just off the west coast from St. Petersburg, they are a string of three narrow islands, about twenty miles over-all, their western shores washed by the sparkling Gulf of Mexico and the east by the placid blue waters of Boca Ciega Bay.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- Senators Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, and Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, returned today from a two-week visit to Europe.
BERLIN, March 6 (Reuters) -- East Germany wants to provide a home for the two young sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, the executed atomic spies, the Zone's Communist press said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. -- Until recently Lower (Baja) California, the long narrow peninsula that stretches south of the international border and separates the Gulf of California from the Pacific, was one of the most inaccessible spots in Mexico.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- Industrial activity in Pennsylvania during January was about 16 per cent below December and about 12 per cent under a year ago. Steel production in January was considerably lower, with plants operating at 72 to 75 per cent of capacity.

MONTREAL, March 6 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens pulled into a second-place tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Boston Bruins edged into fourth place, one point ahead of the idle New York Rangers, when they battled to a 3 -- 3 tie before 14,410 fans at the Forum tonight.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 6 (UP) -- Joey Klein of New York, 149, scored a knockout over favored Rocky Casillo of Chicago, 149, tonight in the fourth round of a scheduled ten-round nationally televised welterweight bout in Memorial Hall.

TRENTON, March 6 -- Kurt F. Tentzer, special master for the United States Supreme Court, has been asked to appoint a river master who would enforce the terms of the proposed settlement in the Delaware River water diversion litigation involving New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey.
Methods to achieve a positive character in United States propaganda efforts were discussed yesterday by a panel of secondary school pupils from the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -Irving Berlin sang President Eisenhower a new song, "Gee, I Wish I was Back in the Army," and the President loved it.

In the first five days of the 1954 Red Cross campaign in this city, 30 per cent of the goal of $5,900,000 was raised, George H. Coppers, general chairman, reported yesterday. The campaign began Monday and will continue through this month.
The United States detonated last week its forty-sixth nuclear device and prepared to test in the next couple of weeks its first operating model of a hydrogen bomb.

Sixty motor carriers from four states have formed the Central Claims Conference, a regional affiliate of the National Freight Claim Council, American Trucking Associations. The companies are from Michigan, Ohio, Indiana and Illinois.

ALL too often these days items appear in the papers about sprees of youthful vandalism resulting in damage ranging upward into thousands of dollars. Four youngsters just entering their teens break into a school, smash equipment, chop at desks, mix a witch's brew of paints and ink and clay -- cost of an hour's upheaval, $800.

Having clinched first place in the chess masters' tournament at the Club Social Metropolitano, Dr. Edward Lasker of New York faced Capt. Jose Joaquin Araiza in the seventh and final round yesterday. The match was adjourned with Dr. Lasker in a promising position after forty moves, according to a report from Mexico City.

Now that spring is coming I think 'I should take a vegetable garden into my mind. I plan to plant tomatoes because we like stewed tomatoes. We all like pumpkins and pumpkin pie too, and we can save money at Halloween by having our own Jack-o-Lanterns.
On the cover of your Feb. 28 issue is the Fulton presiding over the entrance to the Senate's Foreign Relations Committee room -- he of steamboat fame? If so, what's he doing there?

THE annual spring complaint of the gardener who enjoys raising his own plants from seed has always been insufficient window space. Now that fluorescent lighting plays such an important part in indoor gardening, the solution for this problem is amazingly simple.
CHICAGO, March 6 -- In nine states a third to one-half of all young men called for military service during the Korean war were rejected for failing to pass the armed forces qualifications test.

BY all odds the most urgent conservation problem facing the American people is the need for protecting Dinosaur National Monument from imminently threatened destruction at the hands of the dam builders in the Bureau of Reclamation.

WHEN a husband leaves home upset by bickering at the breakfast table and roars away to involve himself in an automobile accident, a nagging wife may be 50 per cent responsible. So it's a wise woman who sends her breadwinner away with a smile if she wants to see him -- and the bread -- come evening.

THIS reviewer approached Isaac Deutscher's latest book with reservations, but many of these soon yielded to admiration for a first-rate performance. As the first in a projected two-volume study of Trotsky, it is a brilliant biography and a valuable contribution to political history.

In New York's Criminal Courts Building last week a state investigating commission began to lift the curtain on the harness raceways situation -- a situation involving many important Republican state politicians. From Monday morning till yesterday afternoon witnesses paraded to the stand; reporters worked frantically to keep pace with the flood of testimony; new names and new disclosures hit the headlines each day.

LAST week the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives, at work on its tax-reform program, approved among other things a reduction of the 15 per cent Federal tax on travel to 10 per cent. At the same time the National Conference for Repeal of Taxes on Transportation was enlisting nation-wide support for its campaign to eliminate all taxes on transportation.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The White House is playing a waiting game with Joseph R. McCarthy. Men around the President have a theory that the American people will get bored with the Wisconsin Senator or that he will discredit himself or come to an abrupt political end.

James Bassett, new publicity director for the Republican National Committee, came out of a White House meeting on Friday saying that he had discussed with the Cabinet and with Republican leaders how to "tell the Administration's positive story during the coming year."

Certain groups of stocks have been showing strength recently because some investors think they know what the Eisenhower Administration will do to bring back good times before Election Day, say Wall Street economists.

The welfare fund of the Friends of Greece, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the performance of "The Confidential Clerk" Thursday night at the Morosco Theatre. Proceeds will be used for the rebuilding and re-equipment of the medical center on the Island of Ithaca.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- Agriculture Department spokesmen said today that the Government butter buying this year might be "just as much or more" when compared with 1953.

TO a greater or lesser degree, every act of selection and choice is one of self-revelation. Even within the stereotypes of fashion, a woman reveals her personality. But you can tell more about a person from his choice of a work of art than from his choice of a hat.

As the list of uses for weed-killers grows longer, so has the list of equipment with which to apply them. Manufacturers have improved sprayers so that they are easier to use, do their jobs better and help make weed-control as simple and satisfactory as possible.
As far as any real progress toward greater economic cooperation by Western Hemisphere nations is concerned, the Caracas conference might better have been postponed.

IN his review of my book "The Joker," Justin O'Brien writes that I "as a refugee from Hitler and Stalin, doubtless lived many of the experiences" of my hero. Now it so happens that I have had the good fortune to be a refugee neither from Hitler nor Stalin.

INSECTS did not evolve to entertain humans, but they could not have done better if they had done it on purpose. Ever since Biblical times ("Go to the ant, thou sluggard"), those sweet and gentle humans, the nature lovers, have played around with insects.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 6 -- The Hill School of Pottstown, Pa., captured its fifth straight prep school wrestling crown tonight by scoring 34 points in the nineteenth annual title tournament at Lehigh University. Stevens Trade School of Lancaster, Pa., was runner-up with 31 points, but won four individual championships compared with two for The Hill.

The Hutterites are an Anabaptist religious sect, settled in ninety-three small self-contained hamlets of the United States and Canada. Drs. Joseph W. Eaton and Albert J. Mayer of the Department of Sociology and Anthropology, Wayne University, Detroit, Mich., have made an intensive study of them.

ERNEST BLOCH, who will celebrate his seventy-fourth birthday on the 24th of next July, won last week two of the three awards voted by the New York Music Critics Circle for outstanding works performed for the first time in this city during the year of 1953.
A new cargo line that will link Eastern Canada with the Mediterranean will begin operations from Montreal in mid-April.

The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis and the American Red Cross announced yesterday that they would provide enough gamma globulin for 1,900,000 doses to the Office of Defense Mobilization for distribution to areas with a high frequency of polio epidemics.
The fastest half-mile ever run on a flat armory floor was turned in by Tom Courtney, a 20-year-old junior from Fordham, in the New York Pioneer Club meet last night.

MY memories are splashed with colors of gardens I have not planted. I have loved them and left them -- gardens of every sort -- vegetable, window sill, roadside and meadow, forest and dooryard. My pet is a little birch log, hollowed out and stuffed full of eidelweiss.

ANYONE who has grown a rose will encourage others to do so and contend that roses are easy to grow. The only real problem is which roses to plant. That depends on what is wanted from the rose. The purpose to which the plant will be put and the time that can be spent on its care are of primary importance.
Youthful competitors in figure and speed skating found conditions to their liking yesterday at the fourth annual ice carnival at the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park.

ONE of the arts which seems on the way to obsolescence is that of writing the Novel of Adventure. In this, the hero passed through the mazes and labyrinths of danger, pursuing less the girl than the salvation of his own soul. Adventure now consists of the flight of space cadets to the outer fringes of the moon, where men with odd heads live in gas masks.
FOLLOWING are excerpts from comment on some of the more important exhibitions reviewed in The Times during the week just closed. Exhibitions are reviewed in the daily columns.

After seeing "Ondine," I cannot concur with your critic's opinion that it is "a magical play," "ideal theatre" and "a bright work of art." In a jungle of mood, fable and fantasy I searched in vain for Giraudoux' message, his meaning, his motivating purpose in creating the play.
Private schools were urged yesterday to fight against "fraudulent cocktail courses" and restore respect for scholarship.

Yesterday's round-up by the Puerto Rican Government of a group of members of the Nationalist party is described as having no connection with the fusillade in the House of Representatives last Monday, in which four Puerto Ricans took part. Nonetheless this energetic action by Gov. Munoz Marin shows his determination to stamp out this insane organization.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The United States foreign aid chief in Colombia, a Texas campaigner for Eisenhower in 1952, resigned today with an explanation that was promptly disputed by Foreign aid headquarters here.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland, said today that the changes of statehood for both Alaska and Hawaii would be jeopardized if the two proposals were combined.

Your editorial on March 1 under the heading "Death Stalks the Navajo" rightly concludes that the high death rates among these people from preventable diseases are disgraceful and that it is our national responsibility "to do something about it."

LAGOS, Nigeria, March 6--Sir John Stuart MacPherson, Governor of Nigeria, opened the annual budget session of the House of Representatives today and declared every effort was being made to have the new Nigerian constitution in final form by the end of July.

The city's transit fact-finding panel completed its hearings yesterday in the dispute over a new agreement between the Transit Authority and unions representing the 44,000 employes of the city-owned lines.
The honorary chairmanship of the board of judges of the 1954 Elks national youth leadership contest has been accepted by Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

THE fallacy of the theory that the sea is a bountiful and limitless provider, regardless of the fishing pressure, is being emphasized with unpleasant regularity these days on both coasts, but the persistence of commercial fishery interests to oppose protective control continues despite apparent danger signs.
HOUSTON, March 6 (UP) -- Freddie Haas of New Orleans today posted a 1-under-par 36, 35 -- 71 to hold his 1-stroke lead at the end of 54 holes of the $30,000 Houston open golf tournament with a 209.

BIGGITY, the banty rooster, deserved his name. In the city he drove the neighbors crazy with his mischief, invaded their yards and even stole a cherry pie. He might have learned better manners when he went to the country, but fierce, unruly Biggity he remained -- a troublemaker right to the end of the story.

PARIS, March 6 -- A serious rift has occurred in the high command of the French Communist party. Jacques Duclos, acting head of the party, voiced sharp criticism today of Auguste Lecoeur, who has held third place in the party's upper councils.

WAITSFIELD, Vt., March 6 -- Competing in a light snowstorm, Bob Bourdon, the 37-year-old manager of the Mount Mansfield News Bureau, turned in an impressive performance this afternoon as he swept down the Mad River Glen's Grand Canyon trail to capture the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association's senior grand slalom championship.

OSLO, March 6 (AP) -- Norway's Martin Stokken won the 50 - kilometer cross - country race of the 1954 Holmenkollen Ski Week today. He finished one minute ahead of Sweden's Sixten Jarnberg, the winner of the last Thursday's 15-kilometer test.

ONCE there was a real cat that climbed the Matterhorn. Peterli, the cat in this story, does likewise, starting off one day to look for field mice. And if he doesn't always land on his own feet, he is smart enough to manage to land on Emil's feet.
Robbing drunken seamen has been made harder in the world's major ports, thanks to the United Seamen's Service.

THE novice who first ventures into the seed store this spring may seem to find nothing but organized confusion. He soon learns that it isn't a question of choosing between this seed packet or that, but that he is faced with other decisions.
Operators of American-flag tramp ships are now making what may prove to be a "last- gasp" effort to convince the Federal Government to create an operating subsidy for their industry.

THE use of image, symbol and the power of suggestion in art have rarely been more variously illustrated in local exhibitions at one time than in four of the new exhibitions. These factors have become increasingly important in the art of the last half-century and are notably present in much contemporary work.

In divorce cases the television set goes to the parent who obtains custody of the children. -- Ohio.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -With five months remaining to file, eight members of the House of Representatives -- five Republicans and three Democrats -- already have announced candidacies for the Senate in coming primaries.
DETROIT, March 6 (AP) -- The auto makers have begun their fight on the bootlegging of new cars, but they expect the job to be a tough one.

French Premier Laniel did not rule out the possibility of a truce in Indo-China prior to the Geneva conference, which meets on April 26, when he presented his case to the National Assembly last Friday. He did, however, spell out some of the terms that the Communist Vietminh would be obliged to accept before a truce could be entertained by the French and Vietnamese.

NEW DELHI, India, March 6 -- The recurring friction between India and the United States has reached an unprecedented tempo with President Eisenhower's announcement of American military aid to Pakistan. This move followed months of protests by India against the arming of her nearest neighbor and principal adversary in international quarrels.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 6 (UP) -- President Tito warned Americans today that the actions of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy might undermine American Government prestige abroad.

CITIES along the Gulf Coast from Mobile to New Orleans will hardly have put away their Mardi Gras make-believe when spring will be upon them with its floral festivals and tours of homes and gardens. Throughout the South, from the mouth of the Mississippi as far north as the Potomac, where Washington's Cherry Blossom Festival is scheduled for March 31 to April 4, festival and tour committees are preparing for their annual spring celebrations.

Public debate on whether the proposed development of hydroelectric power at Niagara Falls should be under public or private auspices began yesterday on the eve of Congressional hearings.

WE noticed in the most recent Secker Warburg catalogue that "A Gross of Pajamas" (U. S. title: "7 1/2 Cents"), Richard Bissell's novel, was now available for English consumption. The catalogue copy caught our eye right off.
WASHINGTON, March 6 - The Pentagon groped all week for a policy on the treatment of suspected Communists in uniform that would satisfy Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 -- A resumption of trade with Communist China as a means of creating waterfront jobs in San Francisco and other coastal cities was advocated at a convention today of the Warehousemen's division of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 6 -- Mr. and Mrs. Quinto Maganini of New York and Greenwich, Conn., have presented to Cornell University a collection of paintings and sculpture.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., March 6 -- With the 1954 field training season to be opened for New York National Guard in Camp Smith, Peekskill, tomorrow, headquarters command officers announced today the dates the Westchester units will visit the camp.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 6 -Finland's general election comes tomorrow and Monday. About 2,500,000 persons are eligible to vote. At the last election in 1951, those voting were 74.6 per cent of the registration.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 6 -- Illinois swept six first places and accounted for one of two shattered records in romping to its fourth straight Big Ten indoor track championship today.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 6 (AP) -- Rain and wind, with temperatures in the 50s, today halted play after nine holes in the second round of the Sarasota women's open golf tournament. Mrs. Babe Zaharias, Chicago, held a two-stroke lead at the end of 27 holes.
LOS ANGELES -- The average motel patron doubtless is quite unaware of it, but he has recently undergone as detailed a reading of his commercial pulse and inclinations as probably ever has been taken.

Business was booming last week in budget and popular-price dresses, casual wear and teen wear and was improved in other ready-to-wear categories, resident buying offices report.

SEOUL, Korea, Sunday, March 7 (AP) -- South Korea informally charged yesterday that, once "the treacherous Japanese" have been rearmed, they might join the Communists. The South Koreans urged United States support of a "matching Korean force."
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Supreme Court is a little behind in its work and may have to put on steam to catch up.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 6 -- Yale's all-winning swimming team swept to its 112th consecutive dual-meet victory today with a 60-24 decision over Princeton at Dillon Pool. The triumph was the Elis' sixth in the Eastern League race.
A serious unemployment situation exists in New York City and the nation, local leaders of the Congress of Industrial Organizations warned yesterday.

THE Earth of the far future is plagued with many problems: what to do about its conquerors, the "Spacers," descendants of the men who settled the stars; where to employ people thrown out of work by robots; why mankind prefers to live in a few gigantic megalopoles, and how to discover the murderer of an eminent Spacer.

Women headed by Mrs. C. Herbert Appleby, chairman of the executive committee, and Mrs. John G. Kilbreth, chairman of the patron and patroness committee, are working toward the success of the annual spring frolic and tea dance for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York.

DALLAS, March 6 -- Mild weather improved department store sales in most cities of the Eleventh Federal Reserve District last week as merchants pushed new-season merchandise heavily. End-of-month clearances also drew good response.

I was privileged to attend the exhibition of American drawings of three centuries, assembled for the United States Information Agency by the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service and shown at the Cooper Union Museum.

JERSEY CITY, March 6 -- A state-wide search for a prowler who invaded two Roman Catholic convents early today was started after nuns at St. John's Parish Convent and St. Paul's Convent here were assaulted by a man with a switchblade knife.
MIAMI BEACH, March 6 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said tonight that President Eisenhower had accepted "McCarthyism" as the Republican party's "best formula for political success."

TEHERAN, Iran, March 6 -- Denis Arthur Wright, British Embassy counselor who reported to the embassy here three months ago as charge d'affaires, flew to London today. He will advise the chief executives of eight major oil companies who are discussing the formation of a consortium to market Iranian oil. The executives are arriving in London this week-end and are expected to begin top-level meetings Monday.
CARACAS, March 6 -- The Tenth Inter - American Conference is completing its first week of work in an atmosphere of speculation and uncertainty, with an underlying feeling of tension.

SPEED LAMKIN'S second novel, with its literary overtones of other writers, other books, is a disappointing performance. Essentially a gay and even frivolous account of life in Beverly Hills and told by a smug person who is attached to the Hollywood bureau of Life magazine, the novel has all the glitter, and none of the depth, of a sugared meringue.

THE factual story of Helen Keller, whose triumph over affliction has served as an inspiration for the blind, mute and deaf all over the world, has been filmed for the first time in a feature-length biography titled, "Helen Keller in Her Story," it was learned last week.
Senator Herbert H. Lehman deprecated yesterday President Eisenhower's recent statements on Senator Joseph F. McCarthy as having compromised the country's unity in favor of Republican party unity.

THE gardener's power to change the weather is no greater now than in prehistoric days. Through the ages man has devised a remarkable number of ways to counteract the weather or to adapt himself, his gardening and his garden to it. Except for such devastating occurrences as floods, tornadoes, hail, searing heat, freezeouts, there are the knowledge, techniques, materials and equipment to handle many adverse weather problems.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- It's been thirty-four years since Frank Frisch, now a graying Hall of Fame immortal, first saw a spring training camp. That was at San Antonio in Texas when the fabled Fordham Flash, just a few months off the campus but already on the lordly Giants, reported to John McGraw. Baseball and the Flash have changed considerably since.

TO say of a writer that the chief charm of her books lies in the fact that she is obviously a nice person is about equivalent to murmuring that she is good to her mother. In the case of Emily Kimbrough, however, the statement is as complimentary as it is accurate.

Two years ago, a young lady of 11 came to this country with her parents. Her father, Professor of International Law and Diplomatic History at the University of Ljubljana in Yugoslavia, was here on a fellowship from the Rockefeller Foundation. After Mr. Tomsic's fellowship was up, he returned to his native Yugoslavia, but Dubravka and her mother remained.

Pool - Violets and Kings Point Tie for Second City College swimmers won the Metropolitan Collegiate Conference championship in the New York University pool last night. The Beavers ran up 74 points in toppling New York University, the Conference champion for the last three years. The Violets counted 59 points and were tied by the squad from the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I.

Mayor Wagner and Governor Dewey were principal targets last night for lampooning by the Inner Circle at a dinner attended by 1,100 persons in the Astor Hotel.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 6 -- Princeton's basketball team rolled to its ninth straight victory tonight, defeating Dartmouth, 67 -- 57, in an Eastern League game before 2,900 spectators in Dillon Gym.

SPRING, the season which uncounted people consider the finest of the year, is almost a reality. Although calendars say it doesn't begin for another two weeks, gardeners will not wholly agree. And gardeners are stirring not only in New York City and its suburbs but in San Francisco and Cleveland, Savannah and St. Louis as well.

THE annual intercollegiate bridge tournament is one of the few remaining competitions in which players have an opportunity to compete against par scores. Every hand played has been prepared in advance to test the contestant's skill in bidding or play or both. In the usual tournament one can profit as much or more from the opponents' errors than from his own good play.

AT some time or other the gardener asks himself whether he should have a fruit tree or nut tree on the property. Ten years ago, my answer would have been "no." But today the answer would be a qualified "yes."

JULIA EDWARDS, in the Indiana of the Eighteen Eighties, faced a problem that besets many 16-year-olds today. She gives her first love to a youth whose worthlessness is apparent to everyone else, but to which she is willfully blind.

Members of the Committee for Scholarships of the Cornell University-New York Hospital School of Nursing have arranged a card party and tea in behalf of their scholarship fund for the afternoon of March 16 at the hospital nurses residence, 1320 York Avenue.

ALBANY--Interest in enforcement and possible extension of the Mitchell Law, which sets up the hotel fire-safety code for New York State, was suddenly revived here last week following the deaths of eight employes in a Sullivan County resort hotel staff dormitory.

IN an admittedly frank bid for a "minority" audience, Station WATV, on Channel 13, will realign its Monday night schedule beginning March 15 to offer two hours of what it calls "high I. Q." programming.

ARCADIA, Calif., March 6 -- By Zeus, a 4-year-old colt, stunned the more distinguished performers in an international line-up today with a record-breaking triumph in the $119,200 San Juan Capistrano Handicap.
LONDON, March 6 -- An army of sixty divisions is the ultimate "semi-official" objective of West German rearmament, Harold Wilson asserted today.

PART of the nightmare quality of Sigrid de Lima's third novel stems from its setting, which is a seaside town in California, out of season -- a kind of Luna Park, filled with architectural monstrosities in which form follows function too slavishly.
LONDON, Feb. 26 -- Airplanes at Heathrow Airport, west of London, are landing on the site of what is described as the first example of a prehistoric Iron Age temple recorded in Britain.

IN 1837 Dom Prosper Gueranger became the abbot of the Benedictine Abbey of Solesmes, a village near Le Mans in France. One of the tasks he imposed on his monks was to study old musical manuscripts. Though the project at first was to obtain music for the monks' own use in the abbey, it developed into one of history's great accomplishments of musical scholarship.

The City-Wide Slum Prevention Committee, composed of twenty-seven representatives of religious, civic, business and social service organizations, announced yesterday its position on five housing problems.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed today without comment a bill liberalizing pensions for members of Congress and their employes.

The spring benefit committee of the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association has taken over a block of mezzanine seats for the April 1 matinee of the Easter Show at Radio City Music Hall. The motion picture that will be shown in addition to the Easter pageant will be "Rose Marie," starring Ann Blythe, Howard Keel ad Fernando Lamas.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 6 -- Retail sales last week held to the lower pattern that has prevailed throughout the year, and while minus signs were the rule the extent of the decline was described as modest. Spring buying has been set back by severe cold.

PAPERBACK-COVER art being what it is, it shouldn't surprise a reviewer to find an honest, dignified novel beneath the gaudy front cover of Theodore Pratt's "Seminole." Actually, this is a far more competent historical re-creation than many of its hard-cover competitors.

NEW DELHI, India, March 6 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told India's business leaders today his Government intended to raise "enormous funds" within the country "so we will not need to go about on crutches supplied by others."

THE life-of-the-party act is standard in daytime radio and television, but no one practices it more diligently than Garry Moore. For some twenty years he has been a perpetual juvenile with a crew hair cut and bow tie, catering primarily to the daytime emptiness of homes with fathers gone to work and children off to school.
Should corporations be allowed to practice engineering on the same general basis as licensed professional engineers?
CHICAGO, March 6 -- A pledge that 80,000 men and women would help the United Jewish Appeal to achieve its goal of almost $120,000,000 was made here tonight.
Brownies, Intermediates and Seniors from the 2,000 troops of the Girl Scout Council, of Greater New York gave $3,682 yesterday to the Juliette Low World Friendship Fund.

Parents interested in giving their children an early start in learning foreign languages may now enroll them in a University of Wisconsin German class. The department of German will teach spoken German to fourth and fifth grade children in the Madison area during the spring term. The new class is in keeping with the national trend to encourage an early start in the study of foreign languages.

United Cerebral Palsy of New York City again will be the beneficiary of the opening night performance of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus on March 31 at the Madison Square Garden. Through the generosity of John Ringling North, president of the circus, the entire proceeds will be donated to the beneficiary.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Reductions of $3,000,000,000 in expenditures budgeted by President Eisenhower for the 1955 fiscal year were proposed today by Senator Harry F. Byrd.

WHEN it comes to flowers for cutting, many of the shrubs and small trees produce an abundant supply. They may not equal the quantity and variation of color from the more popular annuals, perennials and bulbs but the range is sufficient to please almost any flower arranger.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 6 -- The United States has granted the Government of Maj. Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi another $6,000,000. This brings the total United States emergency grants to $51,000,000 since General Zahedi, in a Royalist uprising last Aug. 19, replaced Dr. Mohammed Mossadegh as Premier.

CHLOROPHYLL, the stuff that makes your garden green, is the key to all life on earth. This mysterious pigment is the substance that enables all plant and animal life on this globe to grow and survive.

THE redbud was in full bloom. So was the pink dogwood. Unfortunately they were growing so close together that the lovely dogwood flowers appeared to be a shocking pink and the soft magenta of the redbud looked like a crudely tinted chromo. Neither gave any quarter.

DETROIT, March 6 -- A further increase in unemployment in the Detroit area has taken place. The total went to 140,000, or 9.3 per cent of the working force, on Feb. 15, it was announced today by the Michigan Employment Security Commission.

ONCE in a rare while a writer tackles a tired theme with a vigor and imagination that results in a book altogether new and different. This Edgar Pangborn does with the concept of alien agents on this earth. His thesis is that here and now there are Martians residing among us.
A sign painter in Dallas made up window placards reading, "Coffee grounds, slightly used, 10 cents a pound," for his restaurateur trade.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- To the consternation of this Sunshine City's oldest inhabitant, it did something more than rain today. It poured. What is more, it poured all day long to wash out the opening game of the exhibition season at Al Lang Field, where the Yankees and Cardinals had been scheduled to clash.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 6 -- An estate in north New Rochelle that long has been a garden show place is being converted into a new home for Iona Grammar School.

This novel, too, alternates between exaltation and enervation, like a cyclist pedaling strenuously uphill and then whirling madly down. The distance covered is the same, but to the reader one seems so much longer than the other.

JUST this month remains to complete the winter cruise season during which the cruise fleet expects to establish a record with the biggest winter business since the war. By the end of March it is estimated that 55,000 vacationists will have sailed, since Christmas, on shipboard holidays in Caribbean, South American and Mediterranean waters.

PHILADELPHIA, March, 6 -- Cornell knocked Pennsylvania's quintet out of the Eastern Intercollegiate League title race by posting a 57-56 overtime triumph before a crowd of more than 8,000 at the Palestra tonight.
ROME, March 6 -- The tale is told that at Yalta, when reference was supposedly made to the views of the Pope, Stalin inquired with heavy sarcasm, "And how many divisions does he have?"

RICHMOND, March 6 -- North Carolina in 1953 produced 43.4 per cent of the national output of hosiery of all types, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond. That state's contribution to warmer feet consisted of 830,000,000 pairs of stockings and socks. PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -- Alastair B. Martin of Glen Head, L. I., won the national amateur court tennis championship for the fifth successive year today with one of the finest performances of his career.
PUERTO RICO -- the sun-soaked Caribbean island whose name has been thrust into prominence by deeds of violence -- is a poor land, rich in only one thing -- people.

CLEVELAND, March 6 -- With the number of ocean-going foreign freighters visiting the Great Lakes increasing sharply, American and Canadian shipping operators are urging steps to control the activities of the vessels from across the seas.

A new total teamwork approach to the complex therapy of arthritis is reported in this month's issue of the Bulletin, published by the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation for distribution to physicians.
Christmas is a long way off, but a preview of Santa's pack will be offered to more than 12,000 toy buyers in New York this week.

PHOTOGRAPHY MAGAZINE'S 1954 international picture contest, with $25,000 face value in Series E United States Savings Bonds as prizes, will open Tuesday and run to July 1, the magazine announces in its April issue, out this week.

RYE, N. Y., March 6 -- New York captured the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Class A doubles team championship at The Apawamis Club today by sweeping its three matches with both Westchester and Long Island in the second annual round-robin competition.

Because of uneasiness resulting from the recent Puerto Rican Nationalist violence in Washington, a special detail of detectives has been assigned to guard former president Harry S. Truman during his visit in New York.

In "a Valentine for Joyce" (Feb. 14) Gilbert Millstein quotes some unmannerly remarks made about me by a person who claims once to have been "a dear friend" of mine. The person involved was never a-friend of mine; he was a dear acquaintance -- and still is.
EL AUJA, Israel, Feb. 22 -- Nature long ago wove a geographical design that made it inevitable that this desert road center would be fought over century after century.

GUATEMALA, March 6 -- Foreign Minister Guillermo Toriello's address in Caracas yesterday accusing the United States of seeking to intervene in Guatemala's internal affairs under the pretext of wiping out communism in the hemisphere has stirred wide comment.

MIAMI BEACH -- Slow in getting started, the midwinter tourist season in Miami Beach is now expected to be almost as good as in past years. Except for the Christmas-New Year Week when thousands of visitors poured in for Orange Bowl activities, December and January were not up to expectations.

A new publication, "Designing Elementary Classrooms," has been prepared by the United States Office of Education. It emphasizes that the elementary school classroom is a most important part of the school plant and that classrooms can be designed to meet the needs of the school child and his educational program.

THE owner of a modern ranch house, perplexed as to how his property should be planted, is in good company. This style of house also has the old-line landscape architect in a tizzy, wondering what to do with it.

Erasmus Hall High, Jamaica, Columbus and Franklin K. Lane moved into the quarter - final round of the City Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs yesterday by scoring first-round triumphs at Madison Square Garden.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- Last August, when the winegrowers of France began barricading the roads and halting all traffic through the vineyard country, their intention was to call the nation's attention to the "wine crisis."

LONDON, March 6 -- The rapidly widening rebellion within the British Labor party focused attention this week on the most important situation in British politics today. What is at stake is far more than whether Clement Attlee or Aneurin Bevan shall lead the party.

Of the six principal divisions of employe benefits in the distribution field, hospitalization is the most common, provided by 94 per cent of all the companies covered in a survey just published by the Domestic Distribution Department of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

IT should be stated at the outset that there is no such thing as the "average" new (or, for that matter, old) home owner. What would be nearer the truth is to say that they all share certain pleasures as well as problems.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 6 -- There is, here in the desert region, resentment of talk that the swing in spring training camps is toward Florida. And, as the Giants and Indians launched the exhibition season in 85-degree temperature today, the local citizenry was delighted by the announcement that because of rain, only one contest was played in Florida.

THE Sauter-Finegan band poses a problem for those looking for authentic sound reproduction. This band and its sound were created in a recording studio, infiltrated by microphones, nursed by engineers. When the band appears in person it is trying to reproduce as closely as possible its studio-created sound. In this case, are studio contrivances more authentic than ballroom realism?

FIVE new full-length dome cars went into service last week on runs of the Santa Fe's streamliner, El Capitan, between Chicago and Los Angeles. The cars, part of an order for fourteen placed by Santa Fe with the Budd Company, cost $345,000 each.

LOUISVILLE, March 6 (UP) -- Churchill Downs officials disclosed today that 137 3-year-olds were nominated for the eightieth running of the $100,000 added Kentucky Derby, May 1, with Cain Hey Stable's Turn-to at the top of the star-studded list.
Changes in the National Bankruptcy Act proposed by leading credit groups are designed to speed settlement of business failures and liquidations.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 6 -- Puerto Rico's controversy over independence, which exploded in gunfire in Washington this week, is a continuing conflict of reasoned arguments at home. The opposing sides endorse differing political ends but acknowledge a common economic enemy -- Puerto Rico's widespread hunger.

Interrogation of persons and groups opposed to the regime of Cuban President Fulgencio Batista was conducted over the city yesterday by the police and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 6 (AP) -Two Americans, including a Jesuit priest, were killed last night in a motor collision on the Baghdad-Najar highway.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 6 (AP) -- The French hurled back stubborn Vietminh forces both around embattled Dienbienphu and in the vital Red River delta today in some of the bitterest fighting since the Communist-led rebels stepped up their Indo-China offensive.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 6 -- Spring Hill Farm's Dr. Stanley, a 10-to-1 shot, furnished a mild surprise by driving to victory in the $15,000 added Appleton Handicap before 19,921 at Gulfstream Park today. His triumph capped a day of upsets, which produced among other sidelights a $1,158.10 daily double.

Your editorial of Feb. 28 entitled "Star Chamber: New Style" reminds one of the trial of Sir Walter Raleigh in 1603. Accused of treason, Raleigh, a national hero, was not allowed to face his one accuser, a confessed perjurer who had signed the testimony against Raleigh under the threat of torture.

It is not known how many women are on the boards of directors of advertising agencies, most of which are privately owned. But it is a safe bet that Mrs. Jean Wade Rindlaub, who last week was named a director of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., is one of very few who are agency employes and directors at the same time.
A BAND CONCERT: Viennese tunes by Ziehrer, Novotny, Weldemann, etc., expertly played by Julius Herrmann and his "Deutschmeister" band. (Westminster, ten-inch.)

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, March 6 -- The sale of United States farm surpluses to the Netherlands is being blocked by the inability of the two countries to agree on who shall benefit from the purchase money.

ONE of the recommendations to the stretched-out, expanse of CinemaScope which the eager promoters of the process have been ardently preaching here and there is that it finally provides the movies with the physical proportions of the stage.
Two upsets sent the seventeenth annual National Invitation basketball tournament off to a spectacular start before 16,259 spectators at Madison Square Garden last night.

BOSTON, MASS., March 6 -- Harvard and Yale played a 5-to-5 tie on the Boston Garden ice with 6,540 fans looking on before the game was halted by a midnight curfew. Center Dave Ingalls knotted the score for the Elis, who were forced to come from behind three times, with 1 minute 19 seconds remaining.
LONDON, March 6 -- The fire-wrecked hull of the Canadian Pacific liner Empress of Canada was raised upright from her side in fifty-six minutes in a Liverpool dock today.

NEWARK, March 6 -- Somewhere in Germany a United States Army major, and somewhere in Washington, his wife, may be interested in learning that Stanley Akus, manager of the Robert Treat Hotel, believes they are entitled to refunds for their two-day visit here two weeks ago.
IN The Times of Feb. 21, Bosley Crowther ascribes the recent declaration of the principal motion picture company presidents in support of the Production Code to a "strong push of current expediency."

FORTUNATELY, the vegetable varieties that freeze well are adapted to growing under a wide range of garden conditions. Anyone who has tried freezing the various kinds of vegetables is soon willing to admit that only a few are really worth it.

Before I visited New York briefly last month, tickets had been purchased for me for an afternoon performance of "The Solid Gold Cadillac." A conference on the afternoon of the matinee made it necessary for me to pass the tickets along to someone else, but when I appeared at the box office the following evening an hour before curtain and explained the situation I found a sympathetic ear and a seat.
CAIRO, March 6--The Middle East in the last ten days has been in the grip of another of the political convulsions which seem to be endemic in this area.

THE descendants, direct and collateral, of "The Beggar's Opera" keep appearing in fresh guises. Some months ago there was a resplendent color film starring Laurence Olivier; it carried the original name and might be described as a direct descendant.

ONE of the most beautiful pieces of choral music that the nineteenth century has to offer is Gabriel Faure's Requiem. Like all of this composer's music, it is delicate, understated and refined. Not for Faure the huge forces and apocalyptic frenzies of Berlioz.
