BONN, Germany, March 6 -The West German Government is planning the biggest reductions in income and corporation taxes recorded in any Western country since the end of World War II.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 6 (UP) -- A New England industrialist said today he believed former Senator William Benton's charges that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was guilty of perjury, fraud and calculated deceit of the American people.

The New York Public Library's lecture on art at 6:15 P.M. Tuesday will take up "The Art Book Today," with Milton Fox, artist and editor, as lecturer. Mr. Fox I will discuss "taking art out of the ivory tower and putting it on the parlor table." This talk is one of a free series in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 6 (AP) -- The Big Ten was coy today on the subject of what it will do if the conference proposal for regional football television is rejected by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

CHICAGO, March 6 -- Plans for expansion of Chicago area in dustrial facilities to the extent of $30,852,000 were announced during February, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. The value of proposals during the month was $10,411,000 over the 1953 month's $20,441,000.
As soon as a postman removed the nest of bluebirds in a Georgia mailbox to deliver his letters, the birds returned, threw out the mail and rebuilt the nest.

THE third annual Capezio Dance Award goes this year to Doris Humphrey. It will be presented officially on Tuesday at a luncheon at the St. Regis before a distinguished audience from the world of dance, music and theatre, when William Schuman, president of the Juilliard School, will act as honored guest of the committee of selection in making the presentation.

Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter deserves strong commendation and support for suggesting in his article, "Traffic Jam in the Courts" (Feb. 21), a new and realistic approach to a problem in court congestion that is adding up to a denial of justice.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6 -Historic Washington Square, where hundreds of patriots are buried in unmarked and long-forgotten graves, will soon become a national memorial to the unknown soldiers of the American Revolution.

MANY of the herbs known to the amateur gourmand or budding herbalist were brought to America by the colonists. Some of the travelers escaped from colonial gardens and naturalized themselves. But many other herbs are native to this country.

The Cunard Steam Ship Company, Ltd., reported last week that first class accommodations were available for all of its sailings this year. Eastbound cabin-class reservations may be made for March and April to a limited extent, the company said, but space in this category will be open in May, June and the first half of July only if cancellations are made.

Mount St. Michael and Fordham Prep finished in a deadlock for team honors yesterday in the fourth annual relay carnival sponsored by the little Rams on the outdoor board track of Fordham University. Twenty schools from the metropolitan area competed.

JONATHAN BINGHAM'S book is an excellent report of what Americans on missions of technical assistance have been learning and doing. If all goes well, a similar report some years hence should be even more enlightening. But even now his survey of Point Pour accomplishments makes exciting reading, as well as necessary homework for thoughtful Americans willing to understand the new world slowly unfolding in the broad underdeveloped areas of Asia, Africa and South America.

ARTE CLASICO FLAMENCO: Bulerlas, Solea, Fandango, Granadina, Alegria; Ramon Montoya, guitarist (Philharmonia). The 74-year-old Montoya does not generate as much excitement as some of his younger colleagues, but perhaps he makes up for it in clarity and refinement of style.

Fabricone woolens manufactured in Prato, Italy, will be distributed in the United States under the company trade name, according to Miss Della M. Grattan, president of the D. M. Grattan Company, New York. Heretofore, she said, importers have sold the goods under their own names.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The resignation of Roger M. Kyes as Deputy Secretary of Defense was announced by the White House today.
An international narcotics dealer described as the successor to the late racketeer, Irving (Waxey Gordon) Wexler, and a woman accomplice have been arrested here.
UNHAPPY the writer who creates too good a first novel! From that point on, work as he may, readers and reviewers will mutter, "Good book, yes . . . but not up to that wonderful first."

LONG before the first sundials, wild flowers were telling the time of day and even the state of the weather. And they are still doing it with quaint charm and surprising accuracy. On a summer day, every hour from dawn to dusk is marked by the opening and closing of certain flowers.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- A Republican Senator tonight assailed Adlai E. Stevenson's speech to a Democratic rally in Miami as "reckless" but a Democratic Senator said he was laying "it on the line."

THE springs of human behavior are often hidden. An obscurely motivated murder or other criminal act of violence frequently receives cursory news coverage, so that the real story gathers dust in some probation report or psychiatrist's court affidavit.
MARRAKESH, Morocco, March 6 (Reuters) -- France today pledged sweeping measures to uproot terrorism in this French protectorate.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A group of Congressmen who protested against proposals to arm the Arab states has been told that only "token" deliveries of arms have been considered. These assurances were given by Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Acting Secretary of State, and Henry A. Byroade, Under Secretary.
The National Cargo Bureau last week reviewed its first calendar year of service as an official agency devoted to supervising the safe storage of shipborne cargo.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- Senator H. Alexander Smith, chairman of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee, said today Republican members had reached a "general understanding" to back a modified plan requiring union strike votes by secret paper ballot.

THERE was a time when the jungle-wallahs retired after long years of exile in India, Malaya. Burma and Assam, drank steadily for a few years, complained bitterly about the English weather (they had complained with equal bitterness in the jungle) and were wheeled out in bathchairs along the promenade, still mumbling about the elephants they had brought down there forty years ago.

A better feeling was evident last week in financial markets with the start of a new month. Stock prices, reflecting the change in sentiment, turned stronger in more active trading and reached their best levels in a year.
LONDON, March 6 (Reuters) -- West Bromwich Albion, favorite to win the English League championship and the soccer cup, was held to a 2-2 draw today by lowly Sheffield United.
Bond prices are about where they were before the market was cut loose three years ago from the support of the Federal Reserve System and made to shift for itself.

THERE are several short cuts for growing vegetables of which I can think, but the greatest one in my opinion is the development of Midget sweet corn. This short season crop can provide even the smallest garden with a few ears of corn in summer.

PHOTOGRAPHY is the most self-conscious of the arts. The act of photography has been glorified in the newspicture magazines, and even in the newspapers. Publisher and reader enjoy shoptalk together. The editor continually points to "best shots," or "newspicture of the week," confident that his clientele is following every move of the shutter, * * *

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 6 -- There has been a reshuffling of posts in the leadership of the Communist party of Bulgaria. According to some sources here, it recalls the spectacular rift in the party's hierarchy in 1949 that led to the purge of many leaders accused of plotting with Marshal Tie who a year earlier had led Yugoslavia out of the Cominform.

The best solution of the vexing problem Justice Hofstadter discusses is to adopt the doctrine of comparative negligence in accident cases. This doctrine, Justice Hofstadter notes, is realistic and is commonly practiced in courts of his area, though not formally legalized.
NEW ORLEANS, March 6 (AP) -- T. P. Morgan's Grover B., a 25-1 shot, took an early lead today to stage a major upset in the $66,000 New Orleans Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

IN the garden there is a special fragrance to match the spirit of the season and the time of day. Faintly scented apple blossoms evoke the delicacy of spring, pungent, chrysanthemums catch the tang of fail and a blend of alluring perfumes suggests the richness of summer and the changing moods of the day.
The warfare between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Administration last week turned largely on three press conferences. The conferences were held by:

NICE, France, March 6 (UP) -- The wreckage of a United States Air Force transport, missing with twenty persons since Thursday, was spotted today in the "graveyard of planes" in the French Alps. Pilots reported no signs of life.

In behalf of Greenwich House, a theatre party will be held at the performance of "Ondine" the night of April 21 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. Manton B. Metcalf Jr. is chairman of the benefit committee, and Herbert Scheftel is president of the beneficiary's board of managers.

DEFINITIVE days are just ahead for business. Consumer buying the next four to five weeks may well bring a halt to the downward cycle and while there does not seem to be too much promise of a rise, the prospects of a leveling-off movement are good.
Communism's "new look," decreed by the fashion experts in Moscow, is changing the political hemline of the Communist party in the United States.

With rain early in the week and cold weather at its end, department store sales were estimated by retailers at about 4 to 5 per cent under the business of the same week a year ago. The cold particularly affected the buying of spring apparel.

Orange juice, buckwheat cakes with butter and maple syrup, and steaming hot coffee stand for a real American breakfast. But in other parts of the world people start the day quite differently. Dutch children like chocolate sprinkles on bread and butter, the Cantonese eat raw fish slices in rice gruel and the Pakistanis a dab of highly spiced vegetables and thin cakes made with clarified butter.

ANYTHING goes now, or can be made to go, in the size and shape of motion pictures as the result of two new technical developments which came out of the laboratory stage last week to challenge CinemaScope. The innovations, which may well serve to stabilize the exhibition branch of the industry, are VistaVision and SuperScope.
Communism's "new look," decreed by the fashion experts in Moscow, is changing the political hemline of the Communist party in the United States.

With rain early in the week and cold weather at its end, department store sales were estimated by retailers at about 4 to 5 per cent under the business of the same week a year ago. The cold particularly affected the buying of spring apparel.

Orange juice, buckwheat cakes with butter and maple syrup, and steaming hot coffee stand for a real American breakfast. But in other parts of the world people start the day quite differently. Dutch children like chocolate sprinkles on bread and butter, the Cantonese eat raw fish slices in rice gruel and the Pakistanis a dab of highly spiced vegetables and thin cakes made with clarified butter.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 6 -- Yale's track team, winner in the I. C. 4-A meet, added the Heptagonal track title to its collection tonight.

Women active in behalf of the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Association have taken over blocks of seats in the mezzanine of the Radio City Music Hall for performances of the Easter show on the afternoon and night of April 12.

With huge quantities of last year's crops impounded in Government loans, a moderate tightness has developed recently in the "free" supplies of cotton and wheat. This has resulted in some strengthening in prices.

IF 3-year-olds could read they would probably have been a littleincredulous about the recent furor in the papers over spanking. It started when the headmaster of the Cathedral Choir School here in New York, Canon Darby W. Betts, informed parents of the boys that he was instituting paddling as a punishment for demerits.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 6--The United States laid before the Tenth Inter-American Conference today a draft resolution condemning international communism as foreign intervention and calling for joint action against it when needed.

THE pleasant tradition of the town band concert in the public square may have passed from the American scene with the tandem bicycle and President Taft, but in Mexico it is flourishing. It is, at least, in Oaxaca, the lovely capital city of the state of the same name.

" A plumber ought to keep his brain bucket on because he's likely to wind up in a prang." A whole new lingo like this is springing up at U. S. Air Force bases and jet training fields in this jet age. Translated the sentence means: 'A stupid pilot ought to keep his crash helmet on because he's likely to wind up in an accident caused by pilot's error."
FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 6 (UP) -- A "lunchtime bandit" today confessed nine bank robberies, including one for which a man is serving a prison sentence.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Republican party leaders in coming weeks will turn their attention to the job of perfecting plans to tell the "positive" story of the Eisenhower Administration's program in this year's Congressional elections.

PLEASANT PLAINS, Ill., March 6 -- "Water witching," regarded as an art by its advocates and as mere superstition by others, is being relied on extensively to find underground water in the farming area near here.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 6 (UP) -- Ohio State won five of seven events tonight to retain the Big Ten swimming championship for the sixth straight year.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (UP) -- The Department of Justice is conducting an investigation of former corruption in the Federal Government.
The National Labor Relations Board will go into Federal Court tomorrow to seek a contempt citation against the striking International Longshoremen's Association and its leaders.

AN electronic flash unit capable of delivering full-charge flashes every half second has been announced by Speedlight Center, 128 West Thirty-second Street. Designed for use with rapid sequence cameras, such as the Robot, Ditto, Foton and miniatures equipped with a motor-drive accessory, the new light source is the Repetitive Flash, a $34.95 accessory for the Mighty Light speedlight.

ONE of the best German war novels was Theodor Plievier's "Stalingrad." His new novel again has as its setting the fighting between the Red and the Nazi armies but the time and place have shifted from encircled Stalingrad to the Red Army's first desperate and disorganized attempts to stem Hitler's march on Moscow.
MOSCOW, March 6 -- Mikhail Zoshchenko, whose writings were excoriated by Andrei A. Zhdanov several years ago, reappeared today with a critical analysis of Soviet literature.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Administration's attitude toward British talk of relaxed East-West trade is cooperative and understanding. There is very little difference between the thinking of men like Harold E. Stassen and the officials who operate strategic trade controls in Washington, and their counterparts in London.

FORTY-THREE years ago this April the first "International Flower Show" opened at Grand Central Palace. Sponsored by commercial growers only, the show was a complete flop financially, and consisted entirely of one floor of tables covered with cut flowers and potted plants.

THE psychoanalyst, usually fiction's varmint, provides this earnest novel with a hero as right as outnumbered and finally as triumphant as a dead-shot sheriff in a Western. Courageously reversing the literary process that ordinarily rewards medical insight with prattfalls or strait-jackets.
Columbia University will be host this week to almost 4,000 school editors at the thirtieth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association.
ROME, March 6 -- Pope Pius is now able to take solid food every day, but still in such small quantities that he cannot yet get along without artificial feeding, Vatican officials revealed today.

DOWN on Second Avenue, corner of Houston Street in a building which list the Bagel Bakers Union on the third floor, rehearsals have been going forward for a new musical, "The Golden Apple" -- on the fourth floor.

Having had the experience of bringing an automobile accident case to trial in Supreme Court two months and six days after the accident occurred, I know that delay is not an essential part of the administration of justice.

IN the past few years, gardening, once one of the more strenuous forms of physical exercise, has been transformed into a relatively gentle outdoor sport. Transformed, that is, for anyone who can afford one or two of the bewildering variety of power tools now on the market.

BAYONNE, N. J., March 6--This city's public schools will reopen Monday morning, following the settlement tonight of a strike of 457 teachers, nurses and clerks who had walked off their jobs at noon last Wednesday.

In the President's budget for 1953 the recommendation is renewed for an increase of the debt limit from $275 billions to $290 billions. The House has approved this proposal but it is still before the Senate.
LONDON, March 6 -- Billy Graham, the handsome, immaculately tailored American evangelist, opened a three-month "crusade" here this week before a capacity crowd of 11,000 in Harringay Arena.

IN "Asia and Western Dominance" K. M. Panikkar professes to give a picture of the political and social relations between Asia and the West from the arrival of Vasco da Gama in India in 1498 to the year 1945. He devotes eighty-five additional pages to a discussion of Christian missionary activities in Asia.

Companies lacking the financial resources needed to equip and staff an adequate research laboratory have found the answer to their problems in the work of the Armour Research Foundation of Illinois Institute of Technology.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Pan-American World Airways told the Civil Aeronautics Board today that Northwest Air Lines had taken an "unsound" position regarding tourist air service between the Pacific Northwest and Hawaii.

AN earnest effort to take a large public behind the scenes with a symphony orchestra was made on television last week. The brave enterprise was undertaken by Edward R. Murrow on his program "See It Now," and while it did not quite come off either as a show pure and simple or as an educational guided tour, it was a worthwhile experiment.
BOSTON, March 6 -- A movement to "draft" former Gov. Paul A. Dever as the Democratic nominee for Governor of Massachusetts was under way this week.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 6 -- The long-awaited attack on United States economic policies toward Latin America has begun in the Tenth Inter-American Conference. Colombia and Chile led the criticism in unusually blunt statements.

HOME frozen fruits provide a variety of tasty desserts and at the same time are nutritious. Almost all fruits may be frozen satisfactorily, but the quality of the final product depends largely upon the variety of the fruit, the stage of maturity and whether it is processed by sugar, syrup or plain-packed methods.

VIEWED from Europe, United States foreign policy does not look quite the same as when viewed from Washington. This is true both of its broad outlines and of the more or less authoritative, yet more or less varying, interpretations of it that go out periodically from Washington to enlighten, and sometimes to startle, an anxious world.

ROY CAMPBELL, South African poet and sportsman, has written a loose-jointed, irritating and fascinating story about his native country. Not infrequently it reminded me of a nineteenth-century travelogue, for Mr. Campbell is relentlessly determined to cram in every possible bit of information concerning the flora and fauna of the region.
EAST LANSING, Mich., March 6. (UP) -- Purdue finished first in three events today to capture its sixth Big Ten Conference wrestling championshij.

One of the regular features of recent Presidential press conferences has been an effort by reporters to get the Administration to provide a breakdown on its figure of persons dismissed from the Government as "security risks." Last week there were no questions about the breakdown. Figures had been given out. But there was still confusion and controversy about what they meant.

GRINNELL, Iowa, March 6 -Dr. Taraknath Das, president of the India Foundation and a professor of political science at Columbia University, said today that the United States was making a serious error by offering military aid to Pakistan.

The White House has announced that Henry C. Alexander, president of J. P. Morgan Co., will act as chairman for the forthcoming campaign of the American-Korean Foundation to gain even broader support in this country. Mr. Alexander will head a nation-wide organization that will bring to every State and major city the plans for helping Korea and Koreans.

Plans for a ten-story printing-school building, the first of its kind in the country, have been adopted by the New York City Board of Education. Industry is to serve as a partner with the school board, and will contribute both material supplies and guidance in developing the new school.
TRENTON, March 6 (AP) -- Trenton High School kept its championship with 47 points today in the twenty-second annual New Jersey Interscholastic Athletic Association swimming meet.
The announcement that drastic measures are required to meet the Soviet Union's basic food requirements appears to be a sharp blow at the prestige of Premier Georgi M. Malenkov.

A woman listed as a typhoid carrier here since 1931 is presumably responsible for the illness of her grandchild whom she visited recently in Union, N. J., according to Dr. Morris Greenberg, head of the bureau of preventable diseases of the city's Health Department.

THE best thing that can be said of Kurt Singer's latest opus about spies and spying is that it is not quite as silly as his last -- which dealt with thirty ladies whom Mr. Singer, with little authority to back him up, has dubbed the "World's Greatest Women Spies."

Low salaries for teachers can be an expensive economy for a state, the Arizona Education Association has just concluded. The $300 which Arizona nominally saves in maintaining a $3,300 starting salary, compared with adjacent California's $3,600 level, cost the state a hypothetical $580,000 last year alone, an association study indicated.

THE 1954 catalogues list a surprising number of plants favored in generations past, but neglected for long periods. The reasons for this ebb and flow of favor are not always easy to understand. There is, of course, the natural pendulum swing of popularity.
MIAMI, March 6 -- The Brooklyn Dodgers lost to the Milwaukee Braves, 3 -- 2, in their opening exhibition of the spring training season today.
ATLANTA, March 6 (AP) -- Another cooperative effort by the press and bar to solve the problem of news picture, radio and television coverage of court trials was proposed here today.

DR. ERIK CHISHOLM, the Scotch composer-conductor who heads the music department of Capetown University in the Union of South Africa, came here last December with scores and recordings of two of his short operas. His hope was that he could get them performed in the United States, and he gambled his annual vacation in making the effort. He went to the major publishers.

MANY people will probably be interested in "The of Frontiers of Economic Knowledge'' not only for its economic content but for any light it sheds on the thinking and social outlook of its author, who now occupies the important position of chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

Among topics which are currently subjects of nation-wide observance we find that this week is dedicated to those who wear the four-leaf clover symbol and rally under the green and white banner of the 4-H Club. Last there be any in this great cosmopolitan community for whom the four H's present mysteries similar to the proverbial four things beyond the comprehension of Agur in the Old Testament, a word of explanation may be appropriate here.

The American Chamber Orchestra, which used to be known as the Mozart Orchestra, yesterday afternoon gave a program at Town Hall devoted entirely to its former namesake. What gave the concert special interest was that all the music performed was composed while Mozart was still in his 'teens.

BY one of those not uncommon coincidences in the publishing field, two books for children on flower arranging appear simultaneously, where none was before. And a good thing, too, for all over the country children are turning up in increasing numbers at junior shows and classes, armed with chicken wire, florist's picks, pinholders, clay and other paraphernalia of the cult.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 7 -- The Commonwealth Government today arrested six members of the Communist party.

SULLIVAN, Ind., March 7 -- Will H. Hays, who left President Warren G. Harding's Cabinet to clean up movie morals in the Nineteen Twenties, died today of heart ailment at his home here. He was 74 years old.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 7 (Reuters) -- A Mau Mau "general" -- one of twenty-six advised by a captured leader of the terrorist cult to give themselves up -- has surrendered, it was officially announced today.

The American Can Company attained record sales of $660,581,470 last year despite a strike that closed thirty-five of its operating units throughout December, according to the annual report, released for publication today. Sales in 1952 were $621,697,691.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Republican majority in the House of Representatives stood ready tonight to whisk to passage a $1,000,000,000 cut in "luxury" and other excise taxes opposed by the Administration.

This week three major exhibitions of contemporary American art and many one-man shows are on view. One of the distinctive organizations in its field, the American Abstract Artists, opened its eighteenth annual exhibition yesterday at the Riverside Museum.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The United States Information Agency announced formally today the creation of a new post, Chief of Religious Policy, and the appointment of a Quaker from Indiana to fill it.

STOCKHOLM, Swelden, March 7 (UP) -- A fast-skating, hard-checking Russian team won the world ice hockey championship today by routing a heavily-favored but highly-nervous Canadian team, 7 -- 2, before 17,000 fans at the Olympic Stadium.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 7 -- The Government is discovering that South African wives will not do their own housework.

Problems facing adoption agencies and adoptive parents in the United States are mirrored in Europe, Canada and South America, a United Nations survey reveals. Findings of a study of adoption practices in fifteen countries were released yesterday by the United Nations' Department of Social Affairs in collaboration with the International Union for Child Welfare.
Girl Scout Week was opened yesterday with special services and processions in thousands of Protestant and Roman Catholic churches over the country.

SEBRING, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- An Italian-built Osca, owned by Briggs S. Cunningham of West Palm Beach, Fla., and driven by Sterling Moss of London and Bill Lloyd of Greens Farms, Conn., flashed to victory in the Florida International Grand Prix tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The "space men" of the General Services Administration are busy trying to cut the Government's rent bill of more than $50,000,000 a year.

LONDON, March 7 -- Herbert Hoover Jr., oil adviser to the United States State Department, arrived here by plane today for what was expected to be final talks on an agreement to set up a new company to work Iran's oil fields.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 7 (AP) -- The Communist-led Vietminh carried their war against French Union forces today into a sector where United States air technicians are working. The rebels made a spectacular raid on Catbi Airport, three miles from the North Indo-China port of Haiphong.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias played tweny seven holes of golf today for the first time since her cancer operation last spring and won the Sarasota women's open tournament with 223 for fitfy-four holes.

Arturo Toscanini devoted himself to two works by Beethoven late yesterday afternoon when he conducted the second concert of his current series at Carnegie Hall with the N. B. C. Symphony. They were the "Leonore" Overture No. 2 and the "Pastorale" Symphony.

Little by little, with much wrenching of the soul, corporation managers are abandoning the financial faiths of their Horatio Alger Jr. childhoods. No longer do they believe that investors -- the people who supply the money for corporate expansion -- are Titans with needle-pointed pencils, figuring out the last eighth of intrinsic value.

ALBANY, March 7 -- The Joint Legislative Committee to Study Horse Racing warned today that an increase in the state's share of pari-mutuel revenue from harness racing would endanger the continued existence of six of the eight trotting tracks in the state.
Baltimore's Maritime Exchange, threatened with eviction after fifty-five years of reporting ship movements in the Chesapeake Bay port, has taken a new lease on life for the next six months a least.
The Rev. Dr. L. Wendell Fifield traced yesterday the origin of America's religious freedom to a dream almost 350 years ago in the quiet town of Scrooby in Central England.
AARE, Sweden, March 7 -- Austria took the first three places today in the men's downhill race, the final event of the Alpine section of the world skiing championships.
LOS ANGELES, March 7 (UP) -- James Roosevelt was selected tonight by the Democratic twenty-sixth district nominating committee to be its candidate for the House of Representatives.

Uneasiness, and open protest, in Seoul, Korea, concerning both the prospective rearming of Japan and the issue of recognition for Red China, which will be raised at Geneva, create fresh problems for the United States in its relations with the Government headed by Dr. Syngman Rhee.

The author of the phrases "Nobody but Nobody Undersells Gimbels" and "It's Smart to Be Thrifty" for Macy's, Miss Bernice Fitz-Gibbon, announced yesterday that she soon would open her own advertising and merchandising consultation service here.
The appointment of Thomas D. Nicholson as associate astronomer of the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium was announced yesterday by Joseph M. Chamberlain, general manager and chief astronomer.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 7 -- Uruguay, in the next few days, will introduce at the Tenth Inter-American Conference a resolution for the creation of a hemisphere customs and trade union similar to that of the British Commonwealth.

According to reports from Zurich, Switzerland, there is uneasiness in some quarters in Europe concerning the future of the E. P. U. (European Payments Union). Substantial differences exist among certain of the eighteen members of this currency area, and whether these differences are satisfactorily resolved in the next few weeks will determine whether the agreement is is extended after June 30

Adlai E. Stevenson, as the leading attraction Saturday night at the Democratic fund-raising dinner at Miami Beach, naturally spoke as a Democrat. He, like every one else who had paid $100 for the privilege of being there, was looking forward to the November elections -- the mid-term punctuation of President Eisenhower's Administration.
ALBANY, March 7 -- Accident liability insurance as a "must" in automobile registration was recommended today in a legislative report.

Two apartment houses in the Bronx have been purchased by Hyaned Estates, Inc., from Mollie Pintel, Jack Halpern and others. The buildings are at 2087 Prospect Avenue and 770 East 180th Street. They are assessed at $101,000 and were sold for cash over mortgages totaling $83,000.
Devotion to the Virgin Mary was urged yesteray by the Rev. Francis F. Reh at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Cardinal Spellman presided.
Israel, which has been forced to take to the sea for economic survival, now has the second largest merchant fleet in the Near East.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 7 -- The Indonesian Government's decree of a levy of 66 2/3 per cent on transfers of funds for profits and certain services caused a sharp reaction in Indonesian securities on the Amsterdam stock market last week.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 7 -- Flames flamed by brisk winds swept over eighty acres of cattails and salt marsh grass west of the Wantagh Causeway today, causing a brief halt in traffic to Jones Beach.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Representative Carl Vinson, Democrat of Georgia, has recovered his sense of humor since the shooting in the House gallery. (He wasn't there at the time.)

LONDON, March 7 -- Two members of an expedition that will attempt to find a route up Mount Kanchenjunga, an unconquered 28,146-foot peak in the Himalayas, left Southampton for Bombay today on the liner Corfu.

DETROIT, March 7 (UP) -- Alex Del Vecchio and Bill Dineen scored 23 seconds apart in the final period tonight to give the pace-setting Detroit Red Wings a 2-2 tie with the Montreal Canadiens in a National Hockey League game before 14,089 fans at Olympia.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- Even the palm trees on the outer fringes of the field shivered in the cold. The weather here has embarrassed the Chamber of Commerce no end. It has been cold, rainy and miserable. The opening game on the appealingly named Grapefruit Circuit was washed out yesterday and Floridians were indeed lucky that it didn't snow.
MOSCOW, March 7 -- To a United States television salesman, Moscow today would be a dream of a paradise -- hundreds of thousands of eager customers clamoring for the privilege of buying sets.

BONN, Germany, March 7 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, made his first public appeal today for the return of German private property in the United States seized after the outbreak of World War II.

WHEN Van Wyck Brooks came to choose a title for the volume of his massive history of the writer in America that dealt with the period from 1885 to 1915 he called it "The Confident Years." It is with those same confident years that he is concerned in his new book published today, "Scenes and Portraits: Memories of Childhood and Youth."*
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 7 -- The cruzeiro, for lack of gold or hard currencies to act as ballast, has continued to weaken recently.

BOSTON, March 7 (UP) -- Wingman Joe Klukay scored twice and moved into the twenty - goal circle for the first time in his career tonight as the Boston Bruins routed the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 -- 0, and gained a firm hold on fourth place in the National Hockey League.
Parks Commissioner Robert Moses asked the Board of Estimate yesterday to increase the budget for the city's park system. He did not specify, however, how much more he wanted.

The exodus of Broadway shows continues. The latest to join the outgoing parade is "Lullaby." The Don Appell comedy, starring Mary Boland, is listed to close Saturday night at the Lyceum after its forty-fifth performance.
CLEVELAND, March 7 (AP) -- An interracial group of Roman Catholics, seeking a Knights of Columbus charter, voted today to lay their case before the Vatican's chief emissary in the United States.

The responsibilities of parents toward intellectually superior children were considered during a discussion last week by a family relations counselor, a social worker, a librarian, an educator and a young college student. The program was conducted for parents and teachers at Hunter College by the Metropolitan Association for the Study of Gifted Children.
A Sofia radio broadcast has given the first indication that the Soviet Union has begun to share the fruits of its progress in nuclear physics with its Eastern European satellites.
TORONTO, March 7 -- Simpsons-Sears, Ltd., completed its first year of operation on Jan. 6 with a net profit of $1,336,176, the annual report shows.

Alfredo Antonini, who conducted the C. B. S. Radio Orchestra in yesterday afternoon's Twentieth Century Concert Hall broadcast, had two works on his program -- Henry Cowell's Hymn, Chorale and Fuguing Tune No. 8, and George Antheil's Serenade for String Orchestra.

BERLIN, March 7 -- East Germany's Communists published today a new statute eliminating the post of chairman of the party's Central Committee. That post is now held jointly by President Wilhelm Pieck and Premier Otto Grotewohl, as co-chairmen.

Earnings of the American Smelting and Refining Company dropped sharply last year from the 1952 level, largely because of falling lead and zinc prices, the company announced in the annual report, released for publication today.

Former President Harry S. Truman endorses "entirely" the speech in which Adlai Stevenson declared that President Eisenhower had accepted "McCarthyism" as the Republican party's "best formula for political success."

Margaret Landers of the Ohrbach Athletic Association and George Pappas of the New York Athletic Club won metropolitan senior swimming titles yesterday at the St. Mary's Recreation Hall pool, the Bronx.
Martin Ettington has been appointed general manager of engineering of the American Locomotive Company.
PARIS, March 7 -- Auguste Lecoeur, third-ranking leader in the French Communist party, was removed today by the party's Central Committee from his post as secretary for party organization.
ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Dewey today commended the Moreland Act Commission investigating the harness racing scandals, declaring it was making a fair, thorough and impartial inquiry.

Brigham Young, the only former winner in the seventeenth annual National Invitation basketball tournament, will take on St. Francis of Loretto, Pa., tonight when the post-season event resumes with a triple-header at Madison Square Garden.

Dr. Bella V. Dodd, a former member of the national committee of the Communist party, warned yesterday that the "materialistic philosophy," which she said was now guiding public education, would eventually demoralize the nation.

The two-story building containing a 700-seat theatre, five stores and lofts on plot 118 by 100 feet at the southwest corner of 101st Avenue and 114th Street, in Richmond Hill, Queens, has been sold by the Fullerton Theatre, Inc., to the Glimm Realty Corporation for investment.

A 52-year-old man, his arms clutching two children he was trying to save from a smoky fire on the fifth floor of a Harlem tenement early yesterday, apparently lost his balance while sitting on a window ledge and tumbled into an alley.

The first of three Encore Concerts was given on Saturday evening in Carnegie Recital Hall. The series is being sponsored by Gerald Tarack and Jerome Maggid in an effort to help young artists appear before the public.

TRENTON, March 7 -- Samuel Bodine, Republican state chairman, said tonight that former Representative Clifford P. Case of Rahway would be the party's candidates most likely to win the New Jersey Senate race in November.

HOUSTON, March 7 (UP) -- Dave Douglas of Grossinger, N. Y., carded a 5-under-par 32, 35 -- 67 today to win the $30,000 Houston open golf tournament with a seventy-two-hole score of 277, a magical number in the event's history.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $78,471,777,552. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Soybean futures usurped the spotlight in Board of Trade activities last week. Violent price swings were the rule, the market working up to the highest level since 1948 when a peak of $4.41 was established.

Taking the lead at the outset, New Mexico Military Institute regained the national intercollegiate indoor polo championship by routing Yale, 13 to 3, in the final of the fifteenth tournament at the Squadron A Armory yesterday.

David Kamerman bought the four-story building containing eight apartments on lot 28 by 103 feet at 206 East Seventieth Street from Harry Mack through Lewis B. Freeman, broker. The parcel is assessed at $34,000 and was sold for cash over a first mortgage of $21,000.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Congress was told today that not all the information available to prevent and cure diseases was being put to work.

PARIS, March 7 -- The French have cornered the market in the world's most expensive fish. By their capture of four out of the six known specimens of the coelacanth or the "fish with legs," they have become the envy of zoological institutions everywhere.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. will take another long step next summer in its twelfth-year program of bringing Latin America into an increasingly friendly and profitable relationship with the United States.

It seems to me that your two editorials, Feb. 24 and 26, respecting the McCarthy investigation and Hanson Baldwin's article in The Times of Feb. 28 are pretty far off base in respect to the real issues.
Both adjourned seventh-round games in the chess masters' tournament, concluded yesterday at the Club Social Metropolitano, were drawn, according to a report from Mexico City.
A five-man Canadian commission will begin hearings today at the Bar Association of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, on the black market in babies.

Dullness prevailed in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Rates fluctuated within a limited area and the amount of business transacted was reported as light in comparison with other sessions.

CAIRO, March 7 -- Egypt's Revolutionary Tribunal today found Mme. Zeinab el Wakil Nahas, wife of former Premier Mustafa Nahas, guilty of corruption and abuse of power. It ordered the confiscation of her property, said to be worth at least $250,000.
Vera Appleton and Michael Field gave a two-piano recital last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The concert was a benefit for the Carl Friedberg Music Foundation.

MEXICO CITY, March 7 (UP) -- Cuba won the first two gold medals of the seventh Central American games today when Alexandrina Herrera set a meet record in the women's discus and Roberto Lopez won the high jump.

Charles Anthony, tenor from New Orleans, Saturday night reaped his reward for being one of the winners of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air. He made his debut at the Metropolitan in the small role of the Simpleton in "Boris Godunov," but he did it so well that probably few who saw the performance will forget him.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- Bobby Hill of Columbus, Ohio, crossed the finish line first today in the 200-mile national championship motorcycle race over the road and beach course.
MIAMI BEACH, March 7 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that he would demand equal free television and radio time to reply to last night's speech by Adlai E. Stevenson.

Last year the Red Cross collected 1,791,650 pints of blood for about half the community hospitals in the nation. Beside this Red Cross financed program, the Red Cross also procured blood for the armed forces and continued to build reserves of blood products for vital emergencies.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- Dr. Neil H. Jacoby, a member of President Eisenhower's Council of Economic Advisers, said today the nation could not be "talked" into a full-scale depression although loose talk could lead to a "mild setback."

The New York Knickerbockers lost to the Rochester Royals for the first time this season yesterday, 91 -- 88, at Madison Square Garden. A crowd of 8,727 watched the National Basketball Association contest.

NICE, France, March 7 (AP) -- A French-American ground party dodged six avalanches stirred up by helicopters today to reach the wreckage of a United States Air Force C-47, which crashed Thursday a mile and a half up in the Alps.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 7 -- The Giants and Indians got baseball prices for a football score today as the Cleveland club humbled Leo Durocher's squad, 23 -- 10, before an overflow crowd of 7,190 fans. It was a farcical exhibition, marred by weird pitching and inept fielding.

The Central Conference of American Rabbis and the Union of American Hebrew Congregations proposed yesterday, through their Joint Commission on Social Action, that the 475 Reform Jewish congregations in this country establish local committees to "put the social principles of Judaism to work."
BONN, Germany, March 7 -- A spokesman of the West German Defense Office emphatically denied today an allegation made in Britain that the Bonn Government was contemplating an army of sixty divisions.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 7 -- The Sierra Club revealed today the contents of a hitherto unpublished and critical report by the Corps of Army Engineers on the proposed upper Colorado River storage project.

Off Times Square, just out of range of the Square's heavy artillery of light and noise, there is a diner that stays open twenty-four hours a day. It has three kinds of customers: the dawn people, the lunch people and the after-midnight people.

Any New Yorker with a yard may be able to dig his way into scientific fame with a teaspoon. The odds are against him, but the American Museum of Natural History suggested yesterday that he try. As explained in the March issue of the museum's periodical, Natural History Magazine, the procedure is fairly simple, requiring no purchases larger than a few stamps.

A total of $123,308 in minimum wage underpayments was collected by the New York State Department of Labor on behalf of 3,760 workers in 1,536 establishments in the state during the last three months of 1953.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 7 -- Ten fellowships at the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovoth for fundamental research in the exact sciences are being offered to foreign scientists.
ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Dewey announced today the selection of Robert Moses, New York City Construction Coordinator, as chairman of the State Power Authority.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 7 -- The cost of living in oil-rich Caracas may play a role in inter-American diplomacy, forcing an acceleration of the discusions here.

This morning in Caracas the political committee of the tenth Inter-American Conference will begin consideration of the United States-sponsored draft resolution condemning international communism. Moderately worded, the resolution's stress is on joint consultation among the American republics and, as its opening clauses indicate, its proposals are in line with previous action taken at the ninth international conference of American states and at the fourth meeting of their foreign affairs ministers.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 7 -- The United States faces a hard struggle to win more than a bare majority for acceptance of its anti-Communist resolution in the form it was presented to the Inter-American Conference yesterday.

Friedrich Gulda gave his only recital of the season Saturday night. Although he devoted himself solely to sonatas by Beethoven, the pianist's strong points, as well as his weak ones, were definitely evidenced in this soul-searching music.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 7 -- After long delays and involved negotiations, the Netherlands appears on the verge of getting a new complex of industries, centered in a boom town.

WIESBADEN, Germany, March 7 -- The West German Free Democratic party concluded its fifth annual convention here today with a pledge to continue its support of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's policy of European integration.

Two reports on the American penal system are scheduled for publication this season. On April 15, Holt will issue "Assignment: Prison Riots," by Peg and Walter McGraw, a husband and wife team that toured prisons with a tape recorder. Ballantine Books will publish in May John Bartlow Martin's new work, "Break Down the Walls."

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Foreign Service Journal, unofficial but authoritative spokesman for United States career diplomats, announced today its sponsorship of a $3,850 essay contest on "The Organization of American Representation Abroad."

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A Democratic member of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's subcommittee charged today that the Republicans had built up the Wisconsin Senator by dodging party responsibility for his activities.

A six-man fact-finding committee representing various groups of dissident stockholders of the American Woolen Company made a critical but hopeful report yesterday after a special meeting in the Commodore Hotel.

New York City is still growing as a prime employment center in the metropolitan area, but the job concentration here is being steadily counterbalanced by new employment opportunities in near-by suburban municipalities.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 7 -- The Argentine Government, in an attempt to keep the Brazilian market as one of the largest out lets for its wheat crop, has offered to sell at $76 to $78 a ton. This was reported today by Ataliba Barcante, chief of the Brazilian wheat development program.
MEXICO CITY, March 7 -- Mexican authorities have noted a rise in the number of Communists traveling here from other Latin-American countries the last few months.
RIO DE JANEIRO, March 7 -- The Brazilian Government ordered the National Bank of Development to study means of rehabilitating the country's merchant marine and the reorganization of Lloyd Brasileiro.
NEW YORK CITY'S only woman ambulance driver right now is Marguerite Schmit, an energetic blonde who drives for Beth David Hospital on alternate Sundays on the 8 A. M. to 8 P. M. hitch

The present management of the New York Central Railroad, the nation's second largest railroad system, is "coercing" its employes to fight his attempts to take over control of the road, Robert R. Young charged yesterday.
The popular double bill of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" will return to the Metropolitan Opera during its eighteenth week, which opens with "Boris Godunov" next Monday evening.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Supreme Court is approaching a decision in the public school segregation cases, the most important issue involving racial relations it has faced in ninety-seven years.
The thirty-eighth International Flower Show opened yesterday at 2 P. M. in Kingsbridge Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx.
Governor Dewey's administration was accused yesterday of trying to force upon the city a 1954-55 fiscal program amounting to "financial strangulation."

The Collegium Musicum of New York has for its subname "A fellowship for the performance of chamber music." Yesterday afternoon, when it had completed its third season of subscription concerts, the spirit of fellowship was much in evidence, for the members took turns performing and always there was self-effacing devotion to the music in hand.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Post Office Department expects to save $250,000 a year by decentralizing its repair of mailbags and pouches.

PITTSBURGH, March 7 -- Some sources interpreted the three-point drop in steel ingot output to 70.5 per cent of capacity last week to mean that things had taken a real turn for the worse. But there were still many who did not believe that a major recession was in store for the steel market.
PARIS, March 7 -- Negotiations starting here tomorrow will seek to pave the way for the solutions of two major French problems, the European army treaty and Indo-China.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 7 -- Turkey denationalized her petroleum resources today and opened them for development by foreign companies.

In bygone days, according to "Encyclopedia of Cookery" (Wise, 1948), a large turbot was the traditional dish at a festivity or family reunion, especially in Lent. The whole fish came to the table in a long porcelain dish, necklaced with curly parsley that had been moistened and then dipped in paprika.
MIAMI, Fla., March 7 -- Producing only two hits, both in the ninth inning, the Dodgers again lost to the Braves, 9 -- 2, today. The Milwaukeeans swept the two-game exhibition series.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 7 -- Property owners of North Street are up in arms against a proposed $500,000 parochial high school, which they contend will "alter the neighborhood's essential characteristics."

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 7 -- Many banks and exporters in Switzerland have been notified in the last few days that leading foreign-trade banks in West Germany are willing to open "foreign Deutschemark accounts."
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization announced today that it had granted rapid tax write-offs on sixty-six new or expanded defense facilities costing $59,004,411.

Women have moved into another male domain. In twenty United States cities they have proved themselves highly efficient in parking and traffic control and the trend to the greater employment of women traffic policemen is rising.

Newspaper photo-engravers accepted the recommendations of their leaders yesterday and voted to take a $3.75 weekly package increase offered by the publishers of the six major New York City newspapers. The vote was 209 to 76.

Scoring three goals in the first period and adding one more near the end of the game, the Toronto Maple Leafs subdued the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night. The Broadway Blues, showing nothing in the way of an attack, were unable to beat Harry Lumley in the Toronto nets at all, with the result that the Leafs skated off the victors by the score of 4 to 0.

Rumors swept the Sabbath-quiet waterfront yesterday that the "wildcat" walkout by members of the old International Longshoremen's Association would end today. Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the scandal-smeared I. L. A., gave some credence to these reports by predicting that his resentful followers would be back on the job this morning.

The ship charter market finished last week with rates up in some cases and stable in most others. The volume of cargoes shipped picked up a little over the previous week, mostly owing to the increased chartering of coal ships.

That was a whopping big cake that they rolled into the Hotchkiss School dining hall recently. It was a pretentious two-color job, with gobs of frosting, lighted candles and appropriate lettering. And, to make sure nothing would go amiss, the biggest aluminum four-wheel dining-room wagon was used to convey the cake.

HARTFORD, March 7 (UP) -- Lawrence D. Howley, convicted of a bank robbery another man has confessed, may be freed from Federal imprisonment this week, but it would be only to face arrest by the state.

Prices of cotton futures achieved small net gains last week after early strength was curbed. At the close Friday active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 11 to 17 points, or 55 to 85 cents a bale, compared with the week previous.
MIAMI BEACH, March 7 (AP) -- The Democrats opened a drive today to fix responsibility for the actions of Senator McCarthy on the President.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa made public yesterday the first of a series of periodical reports he plans to make on the activities of his office. The report stressed his recent announcement that he intended to reduce interest charges on city debt by broader use of short-term serial bonds.

Since last December the Soviet press has given increasing attention to a new project to raise grain production substantially by plowing up more than 30,000,000 acres of virgin and fallow land, half in Kazakhstan and half in Siberia, the Urals and the Volga Valley.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 6 -- Prof. Raphael Lemkin, author of the United Nations Genocide Convention, warned today that the usefulness of the pact was endangered by provisions in the proposed Covenant on Political and Civil Rights.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 7 -- Cambodia has made great strides toward full independence since 31-year-old King Norodom Sihanouk launched his campaign to attain complete sovereignty for his country more than a year ago.

Rachel Koefod, a pianist from Minnesota, made her local debut in a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. She was heard in Mozart's Sonata in C (K. 330), Liszt's Sonata in B minor, Schumann's "Kinderscenen," Saeverud's "Kjempervise-Slatten," Ravel's "Jeux d'eau" and Dohnanyi's Capriccio in F minor.

OSSINING, N. Y., March 7 -- Twenty-seven novices pronounced three-year vows of poverty, chastity and obedience and forty postulants donned the habits and white veils of novices this afternoon at a combined reception and profession ceremony in the motherhouse of the Maryknoll Sisters here. The Roman Catholic order is dedicated to foreign missionary service.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- Every twenty seconds last year some hospital patient received a transfusion supplied by American Red Cross blood donors, E. Roland Harriman, chairman, said today.

PARIS, March 7 -- A big week for foreign trade is opening in France tomorrow. Finance Minister Edgar Faure and Bernard Lafay, Under Secretary for Economic Affairs, will open the Congress of Professional Exporters, which will be attended by numerous business men, farmers, merchants, Members of Parliament and commercial counselors who have been called to Paris from French embassies and consulates abroad.

The National Cash Register Company achieved the largest sales in its seventy-year history in 1953. Consolidated sales of all products and services totaled $260,912,851, or 15 per cent above the $226,554,764 of the year before.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 7 -- A faculty member at Mount Holyoke College has constructed a "thinking machine" that can solve problems in logic, it was announced here today.

Toy sales have increased every season for more than twenty years and now everyone is trying to get into the act. During the last two years, many non-toy outlets have moved into the field. Automotive supplies stores, furniture establishments and supermarkets are increasing their inroads.

American business is carrying on a "vast, even though spontaneous, anti-recession campaign." This is the conclusion of Gordon C. Bowen, president of the Premium Advertising Association of America, after looking over the plans of exhibitors for the association's show in Chicago during the first week of May.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Following are the votes of the members of Congress from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls during the period Feb. 27 through March 6:

The restoration of historic Grace Church has been finished ahead of schedule. Last night -- the 108th anniversary of the building's consecration -- its Gothic spire was lit by floodlights as church members joined in a community service of thanksgiving.

It was just twenty years ago, in 1934, that legislation was enacted permitting limited branch banking for commercial banks in this state. At that time the issue of branch banking was one on which bankers were deeply divided, and on which emotions all too often prevailed over logic and realism.
STORRS, Conn., March 7 -- The "importance of volunteer work in a democracy" was discussed by several women who attended the eighth annual 4-H Local Leaders Conference here yesterday.

WAITSFIELD, Vt., March 7 -- Four youngsters teamed with their parents this afternoon to capture top honors in the two-day United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association family tournament at Mad River Glen. They were Patricia, Susan, Fred and Hank, who helped to make a romp of the event.
Seven new films are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

LONDON, March 7 -- The stock markets have remained in the quiet and cautious mood into which they relapsed in the middle of last month after their gallant but unsuccessful effort to break through the previous high record of post-war security price levels.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- A small group of United States officials in Indo-China is carrying on what is considered to be the most important and the most delicate of the United States Information Agency's programs in the Far East.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 7 -- The Russ-Field Corporation, independent producing company formed by Jane Russell and her husband, Robert Waterfield, has signed a three-year, six-picture partnership agreement with United Artists, which will participate in the financing and profits of the new company.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- It was quantity rather than quality that the Yankees and Cardinals put on display today as they got the exhibition season off the mark at Al Lang Field before 5,011 chilled fans.

" Through the Red Cross, Americans have helped the men and women in our armed forces * * * the people of the nation have constantly relieved the pain and suffering of fellow citizens trapped by natural disasters. The homeless and the hungry have been sheltered and fed.
Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy said yesterday that the city's relief rolls were growing at the rate of 1,000 persons, or 2 per cent, every week.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 7 -- Scientists of the world have pondered for years the possibility of adapting plankton, the minute animal life of the sea, as a source of food. In Thailand 5,000 tons yearly already are being taken from adjacent water and utilized for human consumption.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today announced plans for a gala celebration of the Republican party's centenary. The exercises will be at the party's birthplace -- Ripon, Wis., on March 20.

THE elevation of Art Carney to the top spot on Jackie Gleason's show, which took place Saturday evening over the C. B. S. network, was deserved recognition of a gifted performer. For a good many viewers, Mr. Carney always has been at least half the show, often more.

Well-tailored shirtwaist dresses and blouses with a touch of feminity will be among this spring's most popular fashions. Made of crisp, washable fabrics and accented with neat details, the dresses shown today by Patterns of The Times will make a woman feel chic and appropriately dressed for strolling, business or sports, as well as for many household activities.
ROME, March 5--The "Wright case" has divided Venice against itself in a way that has few precedents in the troubled history of the city.

ATLANTA, March 8 (AP) -- Edward J. Florio, 58-year-old longshore boss from Hoboken, N. J., was released from the Federal Penitentiary here yesterday and today was taken into custody on a New Jersey indictment.

A warehouse for Alexander's Department Store is planned on adjoining sites purchased by Oncrest Realties at 2 and 10 East 190th Street in the Bronx. The property is now occupied by two dwellings on lots 60 by 100 feet and 55 by 100 feet.
Late and cautious orders for both wool and synthetic textiles will place garment manufacturers in a precarious position for delivery of summer and fall merchandise, according to mill representatives.
HONG KONG, March 8 -- About 10 per cent of China's rural population is "short of food" and another 10 per cent is living in "famine areas," according to the Peiping People's Daily.

Many reservations have been made for the annual luncheon and card party in behalf of the Jesuit Missions and the building fund of the Loyola School to be held on Thursday in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. William C. H. Georgi de Mallerais heads the benefit committee.

The man whom almost nobody in America knows about except for the name he gave to the vast New World -- Amerigo Vespucci -- is the subject of a life-story exhibit in the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- Robert T. Stevens, the Secretary of the Army, was applauded Saturday night at the White House Correspondents Association dinner. But the Secretary, who recently was in a dispute with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, did not realize that President Eisenhower was partly responsible.
A bill providing for the establishment of an Air Force Academy was passed yesterday by the Senate after prior approval by the House of Representatives.

LONDON, March 8 -- The danger of a Communist election victory in British Honduras [black area on map] six weeks hence has caused that colony's governor to appeal to London for aid, authoritative sources here disclosed.
An oddly matched assortment of stock ~or a retail pet shop went on display yesterday when Vganamaker's d~partment store ,openecl its new animal division.

Indiana's Hoosiers, who show a 19-3 record for one of college basketball's toughest schedules, were named national champions by The United Press board of coaches yesterday for the second year in a row.
Development of a new type of synthetic rubber with an unusual resistance to corrosive chemicals was announced yesterday by the M. W. Kellogg Company.

Fashions for contemporary living were emphasized in the collection of suits and dresses designed by Muriel King for Stein Blaine and shown to the press yesterday. Dual-purpose, quick-change costumes, adaptable to all hours of the day, were seen in handsome fabrics.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- Lawrence B. Sheppard of Hanover, Pa., was re-elected to a four-year term as president of the United States Trotting Association today.
A destitute family of eleven from Port Deposit, Md., arrived here by bus at 5 A. M. yesterday with a tragic story they hoped to tell on the radio-television program "Strike It Rich."

Fifty-nine local housing authorities having subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration have advertised for sale on March 16 issues of temporary loan notes with an aggregate value of $160,536,000. The major borrowing authorities will be the following:
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that civil monopoly charges filed against building constructions unions and employers in Chicago were subject to the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.
Le Roy Sanitarium, a proprietary hospital at 40 East Sixty-first Street, has been bought by the Osteopathic Hospital and Clinic, Inc.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 8 -- An international light plane squadron, called the "First Aerial Frendship Caravan" and sponsored by the Mexican Government, left here today on its journey through Central America and Mexico to the United States.
MOSCOW, March 5 -- Oranges imported from Israel are a brisk selling item in the Soviet Union. Currently they are being sold for 4 rubles 50 kopeks and 5 rubles each, depending on size.

The stagehands stopped work at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday for ten hours and picketed the theatre for two and a half hours. But an hour before curtain time they returned to their posts, and the regularly scheduled performance of "Tannhaeuser" went on.

Sweet potatoes, now selling for about 12 cents a pound, are of two types, the red-skinned variety with moist orange flesh, incorrectly called yams, and the yellow-skinned variety will dry, mealy flesh. The two should not be mixed in a dish, because they vary in texture and require different cooking times.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 8 (UP) -- G. B. Abt, a New York accountant testifying at the opening of a stockholders' suit to block the sale of R. K. O. Pictures Corporation stock to Howard Hughes, said today that he disagreed with parts of R. K. O. financial statements released in 1952 and 1953.

An urgent appeal was made yesterday for women volunteers for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Mrs. E. Roland Harriman, chairman of volunteers of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, said that there was a serious need for more women to assume bloodmobile and center duties so that the program could continue to obtain large quantities of blood.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., March 8 -- An extreme range of speed is part of the day's work for civilian and military test pilots at Republic Aviation Corporation here. The flying scien tists spend most of their time in the air testing the new swept-wing Thunderstreak fighter-bombers built here, but their flight duties also call for flying slow transports.

The controversy over tax policy in Washington, which has been largely vocal up to the present, is now entering the stage of legislative hand-to-hand combat. And the Administration faces the prospect of fighting off assaults on its program in two separate engagements, from two directions.

JERSEY CITY, March 8 -- Bernard M. Hartnett, Hudson County Supervisor, once an important cog in the Democratic organization headed by former Mayor John V. Kenny of Jersey City, will run for re-election as an independent in the November elections in opposition to the Kenny forces.

The Presbyterian Hospital is assuming a wider responsibility for providing comprehensive medical care for patients in health as well as sickness, it was reported yesterday in the annual report of the institution.

The glamour, ease and luxury of ocean surface travel lured a record 899,461 passengers to North Atlantic Steamships last year, while another 313,858 travelers in a hurry took the aerial "high road" between the continents.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 8 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer is keeping a finger on the pulse of contemporary American life.

Tenants in Federally aided housing projects in New York City must sign certificates of non-membership in organizations designated as subversive by the Attorney General of the United States or face eviction, the Appellate Division, Second Department, ruled yesterday.
Vandals invaded a public school on the lower East Side last night and did extensive damage to school property and records.
Mayor Wagner urged a business income tax yesterday as part of a basic change in the city's tax structure and promised new help for the building industry.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 8 -- What's going on here? The Baltimore Orioles, who, as the St. Louis Browns last year lost 100 games and finished last in the American League, today won their third straight of the exhibition season, which is only three days old.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The White House today announced the appointment of Vice Admiral John H. Cassady as Commander in Chief of United State's Naval Forces in the Eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean.

In a letter in The Times of Feb. 15 a writer urges that Congress pass pending legislation calling for the return to German owners of property vested by the United States during the war. Aside from problems stemming from the use of much of this property already to compensate former United States prisoners of war, the reasons presented by the writer are of questionable validity.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The Temporary State Commission on Rents will urge the Legislature to decontrol all business and commercial property renting for more than $7,500 a year beginning May 1, 1955.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 8 -- John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, denounced international communism in the Americas as "alien intrigue and treachery" in a speech before the Tenth Inter-American Conference today.

TRENTON, March 8 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today granted county prosecutors the right to ban the distribution and sale of publications they deemed objectionable or obscene. It further condoned the setting up of censorship committees to aid them.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Deputy Secretary of Defense after May 1 will be the present Secretary of the Navy, Robert B. Anderson.

PARIS, March 8 -- A negotiation that may affect both the Indo-Chinese war and the future of the French Union, formerly called an empire, began here today. It represented an effort by the leaders of France and Vietnam to define in treaties the independence promised to that Indo-Chinese state.
Coordination under one unit of all the city's scattered agencies to meet the problem of alcoholism was asked yesterday. This step, it was held, would aid more alcoholics and save the city money.

The removal of the stained glass Statue of Liberty window from Joseph Pulitzer's old World Building on Park Row was scheduled for this morning as the first step in transferring it to the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A national highway program was approved today by the House of Representatives with a voice vote.

Coffee prices resumed their climb yesterday on the New York futures market while cocoa fell the 100-point one-day limit. Volume improved, with Coffee registering the most sales since Jan. 13 and the domestic sugar contract since April 10.

CHICAGO, March 8 (UP) -United States District Judge Win G. Knoch today ordered trustees for Muntz TV, Inc., and two subsidiaries to report to him on April 9 on the status of the companies, named in involuntary bankruptcy proceedings here, and on the allegations of mismanagement made against the Muntz concern.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The House Labor Committee rejected today a motion to outlaw all forms of compulsory unionism now allowed by the Taft-Hartley Act. The vote was 18 to 6.
PARIS, March 8 -- The French Government is seeking to expand trade with Communist countries, Edgar Faure, France Minister, said today.

The St. Regis Paper Company plans to increase its common stock by 2,504,286 shares, it was disclosed yesterday. The company's annual report showed peak sales in 1953 and earnings the second highest on record.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, a prisoner of the Korean Communists for three years, testified today that he would take poison rather than be captured again.

The Federal Maritime Board has authorized Moore-McCormack Lines and the Pacific Argentine Brazil Line to intervene in the application of the Grace Line for increase of its subsidized service from Pacific Coast ports to Mexican, Central American and South American west coast ports.

Men, women and children are not only visitors but also exhibitors in the thirty-eighth International Flower Show. This annual preview of the garden year may be seen today through Saturday from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. at the Kingsbridge Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, Bronx.

An accumulation of week-end orders helped carry stock prices, as measured by The New York Times composite average of fifty issues, to their best levels of the year in early dealings yesterday. But there was relatively little enthusiasm to the move and as the session progressed the list gave ground.
Senator McCarthy threatened last night to take legal action to force the leading radio and television networks to grant him free time to reply to Mr. Stevenson.

Serious problems of form, design and content are seriously treated by the thirty sculptors now exhibiting at the Sculpture Center. No single style is permitted to dominate. Artists work in a range all the way from the sensuousness of Nina Winkel's "Summer," with its reflections of Maillol, to the taut geometrics of James Kleege and William Talbot.

Ralph (Tiger) Jones of Yonkers supplied a spectacular finish to the main bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night when he knocked out Bobby Dykes of Miami, Fla., in 2:12 of the tenth and last round.
A business site of 78,820 square feet just west of the intersection of Hempstead and Fulton Avenues in West Hempstead, L. I., has been purchased by the Merriport Corporation from John S. Olsen.

" The Goldbergs," starring Gertrude Berg in the role of Molly, will return to the air over the DuMont television network Tuesday, April 13, from 8 to 8:30 P. M. It will replace the program of Bishop Fulton J. Sheen, who will be off the air until October.
The United States Supreme Court upheld a court decision yesterday allowing stockholders to save taxes by voting themselves a stock dividend and then selling it.

Operations of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company in 1953 resulted in a net profit of $5,215,867, equal to $6.52 a share, it was announced yesterday. This represents an increase of 32 per cent over the $3,937,792 or $4.92 a share cleared in 1952.

KANSAS CITY, March 8 (UP) -St. Peter's of Jersey City experienced little trouble in defeating Wayland College of Plainview, Tex., 76 to 63, in the opening round of the National Intercollegiate (N.A.I.A.) basketball tournament today.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Lester Markel, Sunday editor of The New York Times, told President Eisenhower today that "a kind of fear" was being bred in were poorly informed on public affairs.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 8 (AP) -- The text of the speech today by John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, at the Tenth Inter-American Conference:

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 8 -- Local dispatches reported today renewed heavy fighting by Islamic rebels on the tip of northern Sumatra. Achinese guerrillas attacked Bireuen, a major seaport 105 miles southeast of Kutaradja, capital of the Achin region, and three other minor towns, the reports said.

Two five-story buildings containing fifty-one apartments at 565-569 Academy Street has been sold by the Pleasantville Realty Corporation to the Maxeff Realty Corporation for cash above mortgages of $128,000. The property occupies a plot 75 by 100 feet at the corner of Post Avenue. Allan S. Feldman Co. and Joseph Panman were the brokers.
OTTAWA, March 8 -- The secret screening of civil servants for security reasons was defended today by Clarence D. Howe, acting Prime Minister.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Treasury announced tonight that its short term financing costs went up slightly over last week's.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- Continued dry conditions in the hard winter belt, along with indications that a strong cash wheat would develop shortly, gave the wheat market a strong tone today, with buying at times fairly general.

CAIRO, Tuesday, March 9 -Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, recently reinstated as President of Egypt, won back last night the posts of Premier and head of the ruling military junta he surrendered only twelve days ago.

The new production of "The Threepenny Opera" will make its debut at the Theatre de Lys tomorrow night instead of tonight. The attraction gave a preview Sunday night and ran overtime, according to a representative. As a result, the producers, Carmen Capalbo and Stanley Chase, decided to cut half an hour from the performance.

The Regional Plan Association's two-year study of employment trends in the metropolitan area is tremendously encouraging to those concerned about New York City's future. The survey covered a nine-year period from 1942 to 1951, so some allowances must be made for war and the transition to peace, but the association feels that the general conclusions are valid as of today.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that testimony given to Congressional committees could not be used to obtain a conviction in criminal cases in state courts.

TOKYO, March 8 -- The United States and Japan signed today a long-awaited mutual defense assistance agreement for progressive Japanese rearmament with American military and economic aid. The documents were signed by Ambassador John M. Allison for the United States and Foreign Minister Katsuo Okazaki at ceremonies in the Foreign Office here.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8 -- Yankee power, which yesterday had produced three homers and ten runs, faded to a whisper today to leave Casey Stengel almost bereft of speech.
