The Memorial Center for Cancer and Allied Diseases is starting a $10,000,000 Assurance Fund campaign for an attack against cancer on the widest possible front.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 8 (AP) -The French tightened their defenses today from Hanoi to the key supply port of Haiphong. The entire area was alerted as rumors spread that the Communist-led Vietminh was preparing a push to catch the eye of the big powers before they meet in Geneva.

Domestic and export shipments of zinc increased last month, the American Zinc Institute reported yesterday. Smelter stocks continued to rise -- but at a much slower rate than had been widely anticipated.

Joseph P. Ryan, former president of the old International Longshoremen's Association, lost yesterday six court motions in which he sought to escape trial on charges of stealing $45,000 in union funds.

I understand that hearings are concluded on the highly controversial issue of whether we should or shouldn't put dams in Dinosaur National Monument. However, the die is not yet cast, and I have some thoughts to state which may well have been obscured in the heat of the battle.

Plans to raise an estimated $23,000,000 by the sale of debentures and common stock were announced yesterday by Stewart E. Lauer, president of York Corporation, in a letter to stockholders. The company proposes to sell about $18,000,000 of debentures and 220,000 shares of common stock.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8 -- The Dodgers appear to be in a "lose 'em all" streak. Tonight they absorbed their third straight defeat when the Cincinnati Redlegs belted three first-line pitchers and one rookie for fifteen hits and a 10-to-0 decision.
Wholesale prices of coffee and sugar advanced yesterday, foreshadowing a further rise in the per-cup combination of the two commodities.
Niagara and Western Kentucky nailed down the first two berths in the semi-final round of the seventeenth annual National Invitation basketball tournament last night.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The United States praised the Netherlands today for having been the first nation to complete ratification of the six-nation European Defense Community arrangement.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 8 -The University of Pennsylvania basketball team closed its season with a 92 -- 72 decision over Harvard tonight.

HARTFORD, March 8 (UP) -- Lawrence D. Howley, 35 years old, walked out of prison today after serving eight months for a $25,000 bank robbery he did not commit and was promptly put behind bars again, charged with a $300 restaurant hold up.
SEBRING, Fla., March 8 (UP) -- Officials awarded cups today to the over-all and class winners in the fourth annual twelve-hour Grand Prix endurance race for sports cars.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 8 -- The police corraled three more Nationalists today on charges of violating the anti-subversion law.
BONN, Germany, March 8 -- The West German Government is preparing an export drive into Latin America.

The housewife who wonders if her new plastic dishes will melt in the dishwasher or how long plastic upholstery should last without cracking will be interested in an effort of the youthful plastics industry to set up principles of good manufacturing and retailing.
James J. Moran, imprisoned mastermind of the $1,500,000 extortion rackets that shook the Fire Department several years ago, has broken his long silence in a seventy-five-page hand-...

The Metropolitan Electrical Appliance Dealers Association will police the advertising copy of its members and others in the field. Moe Sleicher, of Sleicher's, White Plains, is chairman of a committee to draw up a code and report back to the association.

ALBANY, March 8 -- The Senate approved tonight a bill to make it easier for prosecutors to obtain convictions in murder cases when the site of the crime is unknown. The vote was 32 to 23, with five Republicans joining all eighteen Democratic Senators in opposition.

I wish to voice a protest against the intrusion into the privacy of the home by commercial organizations through the telephone. Lately I have been summoned by phone from my work, from my guests, from my bed, to be asked by some stranger whether I have television.
DETROIT, March 8 (AP) -- More agencies connected with the production and sale of automobiles are getting into the "bootlegging" discussion.

Mike Griggs, seeded No. 1 of the Williams Club, advanced to the third round of the Metropolitan Class C squash racquets tournament by defeating Bill Ethridge, Field Club of Greenwich, 12 -- 15, 15 -- 12, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 13, yesterday at the Down- town Athletic Club.

Steel-making operations, which fell off slightly in each of the last two weeks, are expected to slow a little more this week. The industry's average rate is scheduled at an estimated 68.9 per cent of theoretical capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The Kings County Democratic executive committee will meet Thursday to consider the proposed resignation of Kenneth F. Sutherland as Brooklyn party leader. The meeting will be held at 11 A. M. at 4-5 Court Square, the county headquarters.
The advent of two new public relations agencies was announced yesterday, and the profession announced establishment of its own "news wire."
WASHINGTON, March 8--Five American musicians have been selected to spend four weeks in West Germany as guests of the Federal Republic.
Eight persons recently savored in an East Side apartment a buffet supper of enough culinary interest for us to pass along to readers the menu and some of the recipes.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 8 -The race for first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League ended in a deadlock tonight as Princeton defeated Cornell, 48 to 44, before a capacity crowd at Dillon Gymnasium.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Senate leaders today pressed for a showdown on how the hydroelectric power potential of the Niagara River should be developed.

The General Public Utilities Corporation, successor holding company to the defunct Associated Gas and Electric Corporation system, reported yesterday a net income of $20,924,595 for 1953. This was equal to $2.36 a share on outstanding common stock, compared with $18,491,740, or $2.24 a share, in 1952.
LONDON, March 8 -- Market prices had a ragged appearance at the close today. Activity of the morning petered out in later trading but on balance there were more small rises than declines.
A Montreal judge presided as hearings opened here yesterday to gather evidence on the sale of Canadian babies to couples in New York.

" How the Soviet Aristocracy Lives" might well be the title applied to the series of articles appearing in these pages from this newspaper's Moscow correspondent regarding the wares sold by the new giant Moscow department store, the GUM. These articles have apparently been made possible by the easing of the long-standing Soviet censorship against the cabling abroad of Moscow prices, and the information we now have helps explain why the prohibition was enforced.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was extremely quiet yesterday land prices closed 3 points higher to 1 point lower than last Friday.
BOSTON, March 8 (AP) -- Ted Williams may return to baseball sooner than expected.
ALBANY, March 8 -- The Lockwood Committee on Ethics recommended unanimously to the Legislature tonight the enactment of a code of fair procedure for official investigations.

The Hollywood Film Council, A. F. L., now has the Sandy Rock Sioux Tribal Council, headed by Chief Black Hoop, and the Bureau of Indian Affairs of the Department of the Interior on its side in protesting the filming in Mexico of "Sitting Bull."
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Communications Act of 1934 as amended contains this section on the granting of equal time on broadcasts:

BUFFALO, N. Y., March 8 (AP) -La Salle's Explorers gained a 76-74 overtime victory over Fordham tonight. Fran O'Malley tied the score with one second of regular time left in the opener of the 1954 National Collegiate A. A. Regional basketball playoffs.

The bill recently introduced in the New York State Legislature to restrict to physicians the care of sufferers from "nervous and mental disorders" has evoked a letter in your columns for March 1 from Drs. Cotton, Galdston and other distinguished physicians and psychiatrists; they claim that the concern of Rollo May and other psychologists that such a bill would "impede progress in psychology and in mental hygiene" represents merely "hysterical pretensions."

The annual Newbery Award for "the most distinguished book for children" was presented yesterday to Joseph Krumgold for his book ". . . And Now Miguel." At the same ceremony, Ludwig Bemelmans received the Caldecott Award for "the most distinguished picture book" -- "Madeline's Rescue."

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced details of a plan today to sell to the public most of its interest in about $77,000,000 worth of loans. The project has many of the features of an investment trust.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee today killed for this session a bill to give tax relief to distillers with large stocks of whisky for which they have no ready market.

Your star chamber editorial on Feb. 28 about the perils of McCarthyism was magnificent. You spoke of the Wisconsin Senator's creating a situation where anyone who is mildly liberal can be brought under suspicion. Elsewhere I have described a kind of daisy chain of guilt by verbal association which illustrates your point.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 8 (AP) -- H. J. Nail Jr.'s En Fleur, a 5-year-old black daughter of Apache, scored her first triumph of the winter when she took the sixth race, one of the two features on the Gulfstream Park card today.
Representatives of the publishers of six New York newspapers and Local 1 of the International Photo-Engravers Union of North America, A. F. L., will meet tomorrow to sign a one-year contract.

HELSINKI, Finland, Tuesday, March 9 -- Finland has chosen a Rigsdag (Parliament) similar to the one that President Juho K. Paasikivi dissolved last December because of its failure to agree on the country's economic problems.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- President Eisenhower told Congress today that the United States had shipped $7,700,000,000 worth of weapons and other military equipment to its Allies since October, 1949.

Enough toys to awe even Santa Claus were displayed yesterday at the opening of the American Toy Fair at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels and at the International Toy Exhibit at the Governor Clinton Hotel. The more than 1,400 displays apparently did awe the buyers, since "looking" was reported heavy but ordering was in only small quantities.
ALBANY, March 8 -- Despite a $91,000,000 construction program in the last five years, the State University is facing an acute building problem, its trustees said today.

A Brooklyn tavern keeper's dream's of Venturing into West Forty-seventh Street were smashed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber. The court upheld the State Liquor's Authority's decision that the "sensitive and troublesome" block between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue was no place for a boniface from Brooklyn's Sheepshead Bay and Brownsville areas.

For its bow to spring, Henri Bendel presented a ready-to-wear collection yesterday. Included were fashions from leading American designers, copies of French couture imports, copies of Bendel Original designs and French boutique ready-to-wear originals.

Prime manufacturers of merchandise which used to be sold almost exclusively in variety stores (at one time known as 5 10's) are seeking new outlets for their goods and are having no trouble in finding them.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Treasury today made public the record of gold transactions between the United States and other countries in 1953 showing a big swing of foreign countries to a more prosperous position.

The eighteenth annual exhibition of the American Abstract Artists at the Riverside Museum includes paintings and sculpture by more than fifty members and, in addition, work by nine contemporary abstract artists of Japan.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (UP) -- The Senate approved today construction of a $125,000,000 Air Force Academy to train the nation's future fliers. The House has passed a similar bill.
LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., March 8 -- Assembly lines at the Sperry Gyroscope Company plant were back at full production strength today with the blessings of the striking Engineers Association.

The business of "painting the lily shows no sign of depression or recession. The international Beauty Show opened at the Statler Hotel yesterday with the prediction of a 1954 gross at the retail level in 137,000 beauty shops of better than $1,000,000,000.
Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican of Wisconsin, said last night the Austrian Government should honor "the just claims" made against it by the Austrian victims of nazism.
BONN, Germany, March 8 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, chief of the Bonn Government, is going to Paris tomorrow with a written proposal for a settlement of the Saar issue between France and West Germany.
Harness raceway spokesmen contended yesterday that the plan for the state to take $6,000,000 from the tracks' share of betting receipts would halt the growth of the sport.

New records in production and sales were achieved last year by the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company whose tax bill of $31,200,000 held earnings of $17,977,771 to the second highest in its fifty-one year history.
LONDON, March 8 -- British women fighting for equal pay in public services staged a colorful mareh on Parliament today.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- A deal to sell Spain surplus United States wheat worth more than $20,000,000 to help finance the construction of military bases in that country appeared today to be nearing completion.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Treasury announced today a reduction of 12 per cent in the additional duty imposed last May on imports of wool tops from Uruguay.

Under a mutual defense assistance pact signed with the United States Japan undertakes to rearm progressively to the limit of her manpower and economic resources. In return the United States undertakes to assist Japan in this effort by supplying, as rapidly as these can be used, arms, equipment, food and financial aid.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 8 -- The Yugoslav Government has decided to go ahead with the much-resented forced loan program. Under this plan enterprises will be required to advance to the Government 50 per cent of the reserves they accumulated last year.

In the New York Times International Edition of Feb. 12 your correspondent Thomas F. Brady makes comparison between Belgium and Holland in fulfilling their military commitments in NATO. He writes that the Belgian Army, "a big one for a country of 8,500,000 inhabitants, complements the forces of Belgium's neighbor, the Netherlands, whose main achievement is a first-class small navy."

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Assistant Secretary of Defense Donald A. Quarles said today that in keeping the people informed about technological developments, Russia got technical aid on weapons development "on a silver platter."
Net income of the Westinghouse Air Brake Company in 1953 declined 5 per cent from the previous year's level although sales increased 55 per cent.
Practically everybody is in favor of conservation, but the real test comes when a specific issue arises and a choice has to be made.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 8 -- Princeton University, defending champion in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League, has scheduled twenty-four games for the 1954 season, R. Kenneth Fairman, director of athletics said today.

" The Execution of Private Slovik," a new work by William Bradford Huie, has been scheduled for April 22 publication in two editions. It is an account of the "only" American soldier since 1864 to pay the death penalty for desertion. Private Slovik was convicted by the Army and shot while in France on Jan. 31, 1945, for "desertion to avoid the hazardous duty of close combat."
ALBANY, March 8 -- The Senate approved unanimously tonight a bill to give the protection of the state to the cormorant. The bill now goes to the Governor for his signature.

" Go, Man, Go!" a biographical drama about Abe Saperstein and his Harlem Globetrotters professional basketball team, which arrives at the Globe, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Cine matographer James Wong Howe makes his debut as a director with "Go, Man, Go!" and Anton M. Leader produced for United Artists release.
JERUSALEM, March 8 -- Prime Minister Moshe Sharett cautioned the United States Government today against arming Arab "wreckers of peace."
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 8 -- Spring was in the air in Westchester today and the budding issue with the Board of Supervisors was golf.
The International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., appeared yesterday on the verge of winning a bitter four-year battle over the Left-Wing United Electrical Workers.

LONDON, March 8 -- A report that Maj. Gen. Fazlollah Zahedi, Iranian Premier, threatened to resign last night in a dispute with the Shah over the control of the Iranian Army arrived in London tonight.
The big show in antiques, a yearly event at Madison Square Garden, opened yesterday with 200 dealers taking part. It is the tenth annual National Antiques Show, and it will run through Sunday.
New lighting fixtures for use in every room of the house are available through decorators at Lightolier, 11 East Thirty-sixth Street.

EVERY day of sunshine between now and the second Saturday in April brightens the prospects for the opening of the trout season, and as a result of the mild winter and the recent thaw, there is some hope for lower streams, warmer water and better conditions on the big day.
OTTAWA, March 8 (Canadian Press) -- C. D. Howe, Acting Prime Minister said today steps had been taken to safeguard Canada's position in the Japanese market for the next two years.
BOSTON, March 8 -- Former President Truman said today that there was "only an eyeful" of Communists in the whole country. What was more, "I'm not afraid of 'em," he added.

The performance of "Ondine" on the night of April 8 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre has been taken over to augment the Viewpoint School Scholarship Fund. Mrs. William M. Stevens is chairman of the benefit committee and Mrs. George W. Merck is co-chairman.

An extra dividend of 10 cents a share and a quarterly dividend of 25 cents on the common stock, both payable on March 31, have been authorized by directors of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation. The company did not declare a special dividend at this time last year.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- The Administration abandoned hope today of keeping the House of Representatives from cutting excise taxes almost a billion dollars.
The Government moved yesterday to crack down on the Puerto Rican Nationalist party here because of the shooting of five members of Congress in Washington a week ago.
The number of unemployed in the city and state rose again last week after declining the week before.

BERLIN, March 8 -- With Walter Ulbricht expected to emerge next month as the undisputed chief of the Communist apparatus in East Germany, it is believed here that he will probably resign his governmental post as Deputy Premier.

The National Labor Relations Board asked a Federal judge last night to fine the old International Longshoremen's Association and jail three leaders of its West Side locals for their part in a strike that has shut down the harbor.
WASHINGTON, March 8--The most powerful Democrats in Congress have no intention of following the lead of Adlai E. Stevenson in directly attacking Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and President Eisenhower.
Net profit of the Celanese Corporation of American last year increased to $10,652,977 from $9,214,367 earned in 1952, despite a lower sales volume, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

The Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman conductor and musical director, elected to perform Richard Strauss' opera "Ariadne auf Naxos" in concert form, with a new English translation by George and Phyllis Mead, last night in Town Hall.

The evolution of giant air transports with four to five times the capacity of present-day freight planes was predicted yesterday by Donald Douglas Jr., vice president of military sales and a director of the Douglas Aircraft Company.
ALBANY, March 8 -- Following is the text of the proposed code of fair procedure for investigating agencies recommended by the Special Legislative Committee on Ethics in Government.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 8 (UP) -- Five of the seven visiting teams that competed in the 1954 world ice hockey championships packed their bags today and prepared to return home. They were in unanimous agreement that the Russians deserved the title.

Robert Moses has now taken on the New York State Power Authority as one of a dozen or more jobs he handles with miraculous ease. The news is good, because the authority at the moment has two tasks of great importance to accomplish.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 8 -- Charlie Grimm was aghast when he first saw the full page advertisement which ran in both the Milwaukee and Bradenton newspapers. A brewing concern paid for the ad and enthusiastically extended a welcome to the Milwaukee Braves as "The 1954 World Champions."
The Board of Health adopted yesterday a new rule requiring owners of residential buildings in the city to identify themselves so that tenants and sanitary inspectors will know where to complain.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Republican National Committee tonight sidetracked Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and assigned Vice President Richard M. Nixon to deliver the Administration's reply to political criticism by Adlai E. Stevenson.
LONDON, March 8 -- The Comet, Britain's jet airliner, will return to the world's airways March 23.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 8 -- Highly encouraged by political developments in Bolivia, the United States State Department is preparing to support a request for $15,000,000 in economic aid this year to the Government of President Victor Paz Estenssoro.

Joseph Rosenstock, general director of the New York City Opera Company, yesterday announced the signing of twelve newcomers for the spring season. The engagement will open Thursday, March 25, at the City Center with a revival of "Salome."

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 8 -- A movement headed by Chile for a special hemisphere economic conference to be held in about six months is growing rapidly among the Latin-American states. While the United States is lukewarm to the plan, indications are that it will go along with it.
WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Henry C. Alexander, president of J. P. Morgan Co. has assumed the national campaign chairmanship of the American-Korean Foundation at the request of President Eisenhower.

A continuance of the long fight against the dual rate proposal of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference was indicated yesterday with the announcement that the Ishrandtsen Company, Inc., was preparing a formal protest to be filed with the Federal Maritime Board before March 23.
One of the simplest methods for the amateur decorator to use in formulating a color scheme is demonstrated anew in a large group of room settings at Altman's.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 9 -- Balloting began here today for the election of twelve Teheran deputies in the forthcoming Majlis (lower house of Parliament). The voting was extremely light and orderly.

Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad Company meet today and Wall Streeters will be watching the Chicago wires carefully for news from the meeting. The Milwaukee Road, as a result of those warm winds which blew in the early months of the year, finished 1953 with a net income before sinking funds of $2.08 a share, compared with $2.67 a share in 1952.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, indicated today that he was not much impressed by Adlai E. Stevenson in the role of a military commentator.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Senate Republican leaders moved today to reduce Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's freedom of action as a critic of the Eisenhower Administration.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9 (AP) -- Skilled surgeons worked eighty minutes today to wire Ted Williams' fractured left collarbone, an eight-day-old break which has attracted virtually as much attention as the late Babe Ruth's famed stomach ache caused by overindulgence in hot dogs and pop.
The Public Service Commission has been asked by the Consolidated Edison Company to permit it to introduce natural gas into Manhattan and additional areas in the Bronx.
ALBANY, March 9 (AP) -- A plan to ban all politics in proposed Regents - chartered educational television broadcasts was dropped today.
LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- The Spanish ocean liner Monte Urquiola brushed up her scraping acquaintance with London's bridges again today.

State and local government agencies borrowed more than $45,000,000 in the public bond market on serial bond issues yesterday. The major borrowings were by the State of Delaware, a Nebraska public power district, a California water district and a New York school district.

PARIS, March 9 -- French and West German leaders agreed today to negotiate on the Saar on the basis of a proposal that it become a "European territory" economically attached to France. This was the result of a meeting between Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, and Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister, at the Foreign Ministry here.
The macaroni industry is concerned over a durum wheat shortage, which results from a heavy rust disease. This disease has severely reduced the crop for the last two years.

A new decision by the National Labor Relations Board illustrates the delicate nature of the board's duty in seeking to follow the national policy of minimizing industrial strife and at same time giving employes the right to the democratic choice of their own bargaining representatives.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- A Federal Power Commission hearing on a $154,200,000 natural gas pipeline project ran into a procedural snag today. The hearing concerns the American Natural Gas System's request for authority to build a 1,200-mile line from southern Louisiana gas fields to Michigan.

LONDON, March 9 -- Britain's formal ties with the projected European Defense Community tightened today. However, the political uproar over West Germany's rearmament within that organization increased.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- Military affairs leaders of the House of Representatives today rejected Senate amendments to a House-approved bill authorizing the Air Force to build its own academy to train the nation's future fliers.
MEXICO CITY, March 8 -- Mexico is in the midst of a great debate on the country's most urgent problem -- land -- and whether Mexico's land reform has worked or not.
The Phelps Dodge Corporation, second largest domestic copper producer, last year increased its net income to $40,776,529 from $37,277,549 earned in 1952, reflecting the highest sales in its history.

The Lockwood Committee on Ethics, set up at the suggestion of Governor Dewey, has delivered to the New York Legislature a code of fair play for official investigations which, in spirit and principle at least, sets a fine example for Congress, where it is more needed than it is in this state.
ALBANY, March 9 -- A bill revising regulations on the weight and length of heavy duty trucks was introduced in the Legislature today.

GOOD morning, ladies and gentlemen! Have you ever thought about thought? Of course you have. All men and women who think at all sometimes think about thought, its importance and limitations, its significance and difficulty.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 9 -- Bolivia accused the Organization of American States today of ignoring a pressing need for social development in Latin America, especially in Bolivia.
ALBANY, March 9 -- The Legislature has reached a bipartisan agreement to vote each of its 206 members a $1,000-a-year expense allowance.
Every so often a collection comes along that almost defies description with its prettiness and charm. Such was Hattie Carnegie's show yesterday at her 42 East Forty-ninth Street salon.
LONDON, March 9 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler declined today to make any definite commitments on the subject of equal pay for women in public services.
TOKYO, March 9 -- The Japanese Government moved swiftly today to implement the Mutual Defense Assistance agreement signed yesterday with the United States.

This age may go down in some future history books as the Atomic or Electronic -- or perhaps Ionic -- Age, but it should be recorded also that this was an age when everybody tried to Make Everything Easier.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Figures made available today showed January sales of retailers at $12,386,000,000. This was a drop of $668,000,000, compared with the corresponding month last year.

GENEVA, March 9 -- A "marked improvement in the political atmosphere" and the "slow process of political healing now developing" were the dominating themes as the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe began its ninth session here today.
The break-up of the "empire" controlling Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways was urged yesterday by the Moreland Act Commission that has been investigating the state's harness tracks.

Residents of Philadelphia, Atlanta and other distant cities are becoming as adept as New York and suburban gardeners in finding the new home of the International Flower Show. This thirty-eighth annual display is in Kingsbridge Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, Bronx, and may be seen from 10 A. M. to 10 P. M. each day this week.

The young Vietnamese Government, with the aid of the United Nations and the United States, is making a frontal attack on infant mortality. The first thing that had to be done was to make some sort of survey and estimate of the rate. The returns were appalling.
PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that the Administration's reply to criticism by Adlai E. Stevenson would reflect the views of President Eisenhower.
TORONTO, March 9 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leaf hockey club today wired a request to the Soviet Ambassador in Ottawa for permission for the National Hockey League club to visit Russia in May.
NASHVILLE, Tenn, March 9 (AP) -- Kentucky, the nation's top-ranking basketball team, defeated Louisiana State University, 63 to 56, tonight to win the Southeastern Conference title.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Wednesday, March 19 (AP) -- The United Nations Command charged yesterday that the Communists flagrantly denied displaced civilians in North Korea the right to register and return south under the armistice agreement.
CHARLESTON, S. C., March 9 (UP) -- The free world's first pilotless bomber squadron capable of carrying atomic war heads sailed today for Europe and a secret base "fairly close" to the Iron Curtain.
HUNTINGDON, Pa., March 9 (UP) -- Tiny Juniata and Lebanon Valley Colleges severed athletic relations today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 (UP) -- Hollywood's most lavish wedding in eight years took place tonight when Joan Benny, adopted daughter of Jack Benny, television-radio comedian and his co-star, Mary Livingston, was married to Seth Baker, a New York stockbroker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Baker of New York.
CAIRO, March 9 -- One-fifth to one-third of Egypt's future constituent Assembly may be appointed by the ruling military junta instead of elected by popular vote.

The price of refined lead advanced one-quarter cent a pound yesterday to 12 3/4 cents, New York basis. The increase -- the first since last July -- was initiated by the St. Joseph Lead Company, the largest domestic producer, and other sellers soon followed.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Sweden, Norway and Denmark appealed to the State Department today to let Scandinavian Airlines make flights to Los Angeles and San Francisco.

DUBLIN, March 9 -- Premier Eamon de Valera announced tonight that he had advised President Sean T. O'Kelly to dissolve the present Dail Eireann (Parliament) April 24. Nominations for a new Dail will close May 4 and the election will be held May 18.

A judge is a "properly certified champion of justice" whose job "goes beyond the mere deciding of cases," Harold R. Medina, United States Judge for the Second Circuit, declared last night. A judge, he said, must also stand up for justice in the world outside the courtroom.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. warned members of his department yesterday that he would not tolerate any form of dishonesty. Those found guilty of dishonest practices will be dismissed from the department, he said.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- Members of the armed services who win money at dice must pay Federal income taxes on their winnings even if they are serving abroad, the Internal Revenue Service said today.

LONDON, March 9 (AP) -- A Labor member of Parliament who holds a Navy officer's commission told the House of Commons today Lord Nelson could not qualify by accent for admission as a cadet to the Royal Navy now. The debate was on the Navy budget.
TRENTON, March 9 -- Representative Charles R. Howell agreed here tonight to accept the Democratic designation for United States Senator.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., March 9 -- Officials here are studying an assertion by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York that it will close an outgrown parochial school and compel the community to educate the pupils if the villagers defeat plans for a new building.
ALBANY, March 9 -- The Democrats failed today in a maneuver aimed at rolling back residential rents to the level of last April, when the 1953 Legislature approved a 15 per cent increase.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 9 (AP) -- Vietminh commandos raided another post north of Haiphong last night and captured several French noncommissioned army officers. The French quickly ordered a tightening of the security guard around United States-serviced airfields in the area.
Typical of the work of one school of ceramists in this country is the large collection of new objects on exhibit in the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 529 pints of blood yesterday, including 274 at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street. Employes of downtown banks are marking "Bank Week" for the program by contributing blood at the Federal Reserve Bank every day through Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- The Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League title went to Cornell tonight for the first time in thirty years. With one of the most spectacular finishes in the history of the circuit, the Ithacans won, 46 to 44, in the final second of the play-off with Princeton at the Palestra.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 9 -- Turkey adopted today a bill prescribing heavy prison sentences and fines for newspaper men whose writing "could be harmful to the political or financial prestige of the State," or were "an invasion of private life. The vote in the Grand National Assembly was 301 to 32.

Plans for a new apartment building on the upper East Side were announced yesterday by Edgar I. Levy and Associates, who have purchased for the purpose the properties at 315 to 321 East Seventy-second Street and 316 East Seventy-third Street, a T-shaped plot fronting 100 feet on Seventy-second Street and twenty-five feet on Seventy-third Street.

Twelve teen-agers will face hearings in Youth and Children Courts this morning in the wake of disorder and vandalism at Lower East Side public schools. Their offenses ranged from an attempted strike for "better school hours" to defacement of classrooms and destruction of books and records.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- New crop wheat futures registered substantial gains today, but the March and May buying was checked by liberal deliveries to be made on March contracts. Active buying lifted the old crop futures later in the session.
Two free throws by Jim Plecas, with one second remaining in the overtime period, gave Yale a 66-64 victory over Columbia last night in the losers' gymnasium.
Two boys were heroes in a fire that broke out at 12:50 P. M. yesterday in the auditorium of Public School 25, Tinton Avenue and 149th Street, the Bronx.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday, 2 points lower to 4 points higher than on Monday.
ALBANY, March 9 -- If next fall's state election is close, the winners may not be definitely known until Nov. 26 -- twenty-four days after the election on Nov. 2.

BONN, Germany, March 9 -- Allied inspection of West German industries to prevent the manufacture of military goods has been greatly reduced and control regulations have been noticeably liberalized in the last two or three years.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 9 -- Three Central American states turned in optimistic reports today on the Latin American economic situation. However, one of the three, Panama, warned that the full objectives would not be attained until the United States outlined its foreign trade policy clearly and amply.
VIENNA, March 9 -- The Austrian Government has offered an advance payment of $1,200,000 pending a final settlement of the problem of heirless property of Jewish victims of nazism.

Long Island is one of the fastest growing territories in the United States, and since the end of World War II the Long Island Lighting Company has been connecting 28,000 new electric customers and 11,000 gas customers each year.

The Soldiers, Sailors and Airmen's Club will be the beneficiary of a card party Monday afternoon in the clubhouse of the organization at 283 Lexington Avenue. Mrs. Maurice P. van Buren is chairman of the benefit committee and Mrs. Nelson B. Sackett is co-chairman.
James B. Carey, head of the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O., predicted yesterday that the end of the road was in sight for the rival Left-Wing United Electrical Workers.
The half hundred exhibitions of this most crowded week of the art season are as diversified as they are numerous.
Mayor Wagner will take to television on his own monthly program to tell New Yorkers what he is doing to cope with major city problems.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 9 -- It may be difficult to believe that anyone would be satisfied with a pitching effort that yielded four runs and seven hits, including five doubles and a triple, in three innings. Yet Sal Maglie, who turned in such a performance today in his spring exhibition debut with the Giants, was pleased with his showing against the Baltimore Orioles.
ALBANY, March 9 -- The appointment of Robert Moses to the State Power Authority was confirmed today by the Senate without any affirmative votes from the eighteen Democratic members.
ALBANY, March 9 -- Except for state restraints, New York City's local officials would tax the city out of existence, State Controller J. Raymond McGovern said today.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Guy Roberts of Clearwater took the lead today in the first heat of the international midwinter Snipe Class championship regatta.
PARIS, March 9 -- The French National Assembly voted authorization today for negotiations for peace in Indo-China at the five-power conference in Geneva.
ALBANY, March 9 -- Republican legislators from New York City accused Mayor Wagner today of making a new sneak attempt to get control of the New York City teachers' pension system.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Robert B. Anderson, Secretary of the Navy, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be Deputy Secretary of Defense.
The second anniversary of the garrison coup staged by Fulgencio Batista in Cuba occurs today. There is nothing to celebrate.

The Governments of countries throughout the world are anxious to welcome American students and educators, whether they make overseas trips to enlarge their college credits or to advance themselves in their professions, George Gardner, educational director of Pan American World Airways, said yesterday.

The tradition is that thanks to the modern decline of "bel canto," no cast can be assembled today capable of singing Bellini's "Norma" in a manner vocally and interpretively adequate to the commands of its difficult, florid music.
ALBANY, March 9 -- The motion picture industry attempted today to persuade an Assembly committee to kill two bills spelling out the grounds on which the state could censor motion pictures.
The carpet industry will wait for spring sales to pull it out of the doldrums.

UPPER BROOKVILLE, L. I., March 9 --AE thirty-eight-room mansion and fifteen-acre estate owned by the Soviet Union and assessed at $116,850 was auctioned today for $544.88. That sounds like a serious capital loss to the Communists, but Moscow's representatives here have two years to get up the $544.88, plus interest, and redeem their showplace.
MIAMI, March 9 -- The Dodgers' scheduled game with Cincinnati tonight was canceled because of rain.

Women active in behalf of the scholarship fund of Miss Hewitt's Classes have taken over a large block of seats in the mezzanine of the Radio City Music Hall on the afternoon of April 9 to augment the fund. Mrs. Turner Catledge and Mrs. Thomas Crimmins Burke are co-chairmen of the committee in charge of the plans for the event.

MONTREAL, March 8 (Canadian Press) -- Ireland let it be known today that she was gunning for a place in the Canadian market and wouldn't be satisfied until her dollar-sterling trade balance was righted.

The three-story office building at 236 Broadway in Brooklyn has been sold by the Consolidated Edison Company to a client of Reuben Lesser, attorney. Walter Scott Co. and Mary Cooper were co-brokers in the transaction.

A collective memoir by victims and survivors of the German destruction of the Warsaw Ghetto will be published March 24 by Praeger. It has been titled "Martyrs and Fighters: The Epic of the Warsaw Ghetto." The book was edited by Philip Friedman, who drew upon eyewitness accounts, personal documents, letters, battle reports and "defiant last testaments." Mr. Friedman was founder and director of Poland's Central Jewish Historical Commission.

The decision at the highest levels of the Republican party that it will be Vice President Nixon and not Senator McCarthy who will officially reply to former Governor Stevenson's speech of last Saturday night is one that will be welcomed by all Americans who want to see the G. O. P. unequivocally declare its independence of the demagogue from Wisconsin.

Top-seeded Duquesne experienced great travail while third-seeded Holy Cross advanced with ease last night into the semifinals of the seventeenth annual National Invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 9 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers sank thirty-two free throws tonight and beat the Milwaukee Hawks, 72 -- 65, in a National Basketball Association game on the neutral floor of the Indiana State Fair Grounds Coliseum.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 9 (UP) -- Penn State and Notre Dame advanced into the National Collegiate regional tourney tonight as the Nittany Lions downed Toledo, 62 to 50, and the Irish trimmed Loyola of New Orleans, 80 to 70.

BALTIMORE, March 9 (AP) -- The Ampac Washington, a 10,448-ton surplus wartime tanker, was put up for sale at auction today, and the highest bid was made by the Security First National Bank of Los Angeles for $305,000.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Duc de Fer, the undefeated son of Spy Song, meets fourteen other 3-year-olds in the $15,000 added mile-and-an-eighth Fountain of Youth Handicap at Gulf-stream Park tomorrow.
Chief City Magistrate John M. Murtagh opened yesterday a new part of Municipal Term Court to deal exclusively with landlords whom he called "housing scofflaws."
James J. Moran's hand-written appeal from his conviction for extortion asserts that he was the victim of a conspiracy seeking revenge on his political patron, former Mayor William O'Dwyer.

Though egg prices have started their seasonal ascent, they are still reasonable, especially if one compares them with meat. Nutritionally, they equal meat in protein. A dozen large Grade A white eggs, which weigh a pound and a half, average 69 cents.

CHICAGO, March 9 -- Motorola, Inc., announced today that its 1953 sales had set a new high, the total of nearly $218,000,000 topping the record set in 1950 by 23 per cent. Net profit last year showed a modest increase.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9 -- The St. Louis Cardinals have had a rather illustrious line of left-handed pitchers over the past quarter century or so. They included Bill Sherdel, Wild Bill Hallahan, Bill Walker, Max Lanier, Howard Pollet and Harry Brecheen. But something new was added last season -- Harvey Haddix. In his first full campaign as a major leaguer this astonishing little southpaw with the poise, savvy and control became a twenty-game winner.
PHILADELPHIA, March 9 -- The development of a paper-thin contact lens was announced today at a meeting of the Philadelphia County Optometric Society.

THE moment is at hand for the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company to hold resolutely to their refusal to grant time for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to answer Adlai E. Stevenson.

With announcement of the election of Norman Jay as president and Donald Burr as vice president of Hazel Bishop, Inc., first figures were made public yesterday on the growth of the relatively new cosmetics concern.

The Azuma Kabuki Dancers and Musicians opened their second program last night at the Century Theatre, and another beautiful program it proved to be. Five of the seven numbers were new, and the two that were held over from the previous program were the stunning "Tsuchigumo" or "Dance of the Spider" and the tender and touching "Ninin-Wankyu" or "Memories."
Thirteen home-rule resolutions asking the Legislature to enact pending bills designed to "take the profit out of slums" were adopted yesterday by the City Council.

Investment banking syndicates will place on the market today more than $50,000,000 of new securities. Among the offerings are mortgage bonds and common stock of public utility companies and capital stock of a national fire and casualty insurance company.
TOKYO, March 9 -- The wholesale poisoning of animals has been legalized in Japan in an attempt to wipe out rabies.
Two-hundred off-duty firemen a 500-foot petition to the Budget Director Abraham D. Beame yesterday in a demand that they have a voice in the preparation of the city's 1954-55 budget.

BOSTON, March 9 (AP) -- A final decree was entered today in Superior Court by Judge Frank J. Good ordering the Puget Sound Power and Light Company to make available to a stockholders' commitete a complete list of stockholders on or before March 15.

Buying was erratic at the toy exhibits in New York yesterday. Major manufacturers reported better bookings than last year while the producers of smaller lines said early ordering had been running behind 1953.

HAVING failed in their efforts to eliminate marine pollution in the famous Mud Hole area by means of state legislation, the Joint Anti-Pollution Committee of the New York Bight is carrying its appeal to the President, hoping that Federal action will force the polluting agency to dump waste material well off shore.

Still bidding for the fourth berth in the National Hockey League play-offs, the New York Rangers skate against the Chicago Black Hawks tonight at Madison Square Garden. The Broadway Blues tackle the Bruins, occupants of fourth place, in Boston tomorrow night.
Julio Pinto Gandia, the slight, fiery leader of the Puerto Rican Nationalist movement in New York, emerged yesterday from seclusion to accept a subpoena to appear before the Federal grand jury.

Reports from the Inter-American Conference at Caracas indicate that support is steadily piling up for the United States resolution for united action against the threat of international communism. The Latin-American states are hypersensitive on the subject of intervention, particularly from the "Colossus of the North," and the reluctance to follow United States leadership will inspire amendments and prevent a unanimous vote.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Atomic Energy Commission is convinced that power from atomic energy ultimately can be produced cheaply enough for general use and will work toward that goal with five new atomic furnaces.

BONN, Germany, March 9 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's visit to Greece and Turkey marks another step in a systematic program of the Germans to regain their political and economic position in areas where they once played important roles.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9 -- Miss Cora Du Bois, an anthropologists, has been appointed by Harvard University and Radcliffe College to the Samuel Zemurray Jr. and Doris Zemurray-Stone-Radcliffe Professorship.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A Senator and a farm organization leader joined today to show a split within the Administration on how best to sell this countrys' farm products in world markets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 9 -- A movement to end the thirteen-year rule of Richard F. Walsh as international president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Machine Operators of the United States and Canada has been started by union locals in four northern California towns.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, made his bid today to bring Alaska and Hawaii into the Union at the same time.

Some punishment and criticism are necessary in child training, to enable youngsters to adjust satisfactorily to a social group, according to Dr. Eleanore M. G. Holzman. However, she emphasized yesterday, this must be consistent with the amount of praise and encouragement that are just as essential in developing normal behavior patterns.

Under the auspices of the Social Service Auxiliary of Stony Wold Sanatorium, a luncheon and fashion show will be held on March 24 in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the tuberculosis sanatorium. Mrs. Duncan R. Linsley is chairman of the auxiliary and Mrs. Hoyte Joyce is president of Stony Wold Sanatorium.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 9 -- The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission today said it would go after "hard core" violations of anti-trust laws "instead of 'testing' the limits to which these laws might be applied or extended."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 9 -- Liberia signed today two agreements with the United Nations Technical Assistance Administration, one of which renews for another year a contract covering the assistance of an expert in reorganizing its civil service.

There's a guard rail going up around an exhibit that is opening today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. Otherwise, the children who visit the display may, with the best will in the world, make short work of it.

A naval and merchant marine veteran, Capt. George M. Wauchope, who went through eleven amphibious assault landings in the Pacific in World War II, has been selected for promotion to the rank of rear admiral in the Naval Reserve.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 9 -- Dr. Mahmoud Azmi of Egypt, chairman of the Human Rights Commission, declared today it would be a "tragic moment" if governments decide not to accept the United Nations' future covenants on human rights.

All isn't serene in the Shubert empire. Milton Shubert, who was named head of the theatrical firm in the will of his uncle, Lee Shubert, as well as an executor and trustee of the estate, seems to be taking an increasingly inactive part in the affairs of the organization.
SAN JUAN, March 9 -- The Puerto Rican Senate created a special committee today to investigate the causes and spread of Nationalist terrorism.

Between 1 and 2 P. M. yesterday the stock market underwent a change. Led by a few coppers, most of the aircrafts, a handful of chemicals and virtually all the tobacco and television issues, it moved to higher ground.
Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, declared last night that "the answer to McCarthyism is not to be found in personal attacks on the Senator."

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- United States officials said today Mexico had agreed to permit recruiting of farm labor directly on the Mexican border. Under a compromise expected to be announced tomorrow, the office of Representative Harold D. Cooley, Democrat of North Carolina, reported there would be six border recruiting stations.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A bill providing the most comprehensive overhaul of Federal tax laws since 1875 was formally reported to the House of Representatives today by its Ways and Means Committee.

MUNICH, Germany, March 9 (Reuters) -- Bavarian authorities announced today that Camp Foehrenwald, where more than 1,700 homeless Jews are living, would be dissolved by April 1 next year. The camp's occupants will be given a chance to emigrate or to settle in already designated cities in Germany.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 8 -- So far, increased independence has been a success in Cambodia.
The New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle will be a part of a 26-story office building rather than a separate convention and exhibition hall, as planned originally.

Reflecting a record gross operating income in 1953, net income of the Skelly Oil Company was $31,276,785. This was the second highest profit in its thirty-four-year history, and compared with $28,032,692 earned in 1952.

The Police Headquarters building at 240 Centre Street is "inefficient, ineffective and built in the wrong part of the city," Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams declared yesterday. He recommended moving the headquarters "to the midtown area near the tunnels and bridges."
CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A new court to deal with all cases involving children and families in trouble has been proposed by a special committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The House of Representatives passed today the Administration bill for construction of diagnostic centers, hospitals for the chronically ill, rehabilitation facilities and nursing homes with Federal aid.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP) -- A psychiatrist who survived torturous Nazi interrogations declared today that no man alive could withstand Communist brainwashing such as was applied to American airmen who signed false germ warfare confessions.

GUATEMALA, March 9 -- Twenty-five plantation owners in the neighboring town of Escuintla where land invasions have been an everyday occurrence, have appealed to President Jacobo Arbenz Guzman in their agrarian conflicts.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A challenge to the constitutionality of New York State's banking law was argued in the Supreme Court today.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 9 (AP) -- Archie Moore, the light-heavyweight champion, carrying the heaviest fighting weight of his career, gave a savage beating to the Pittsburgh heavyweight, Bob Baker, tonight to win by a technical knockout in 2:08 of the ninth round.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A new warning of the possible involvement of United States troops in the Indo-Chinese war was sounded in the Senate today.
The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, top military defense planning board, gave assurance last night that the United States was not building a Maginot Line of atomic defenses.

Suits, ensembles and dresses by top American designers and a few original imports from leading Paris couture houses were shown yesterday by Rosette Pennington at a luncheon in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Former President Truman and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy engaged in a duel of quips here yesterday at a distance of several blocks.
ALBANY, March 9 -- The Assembly Banking Committee approved the amended savings bank branch bill today by a vote of 9 to 5 with one member abstaining from voting.

Lines that are unusually wearable mark the collection of French and Italian fashions imported by Bergdorf Goodman and shown to the press yesterday. Handsome fabrics provided a common denominator for all the famous couturiers but there was decided contrast in silhouette interpretation and detail.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 9 -- The will of Miss Eugenie Annie Tangiers Smith provides that her home, the manor of St. George, overlooking the Great South Bay at Mastic, in the Town of Brookhaven, be used as a museum and the 126 acres of land surrounding it as a park "for the people of the Town of Brookhaven and the public at large."
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- A regulation permitting brokers and dealers to trade in interest coupons detached from validated German bonds, was adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission today.
MOSCOW, March 9 -- Izvestia told young Russians heading to distant South Siberia today that that region was not as remote as they might think.

MEXICO CITY, March 9 (AP) -- Federal troops caught up with a fleeing band of Henriquistas south of Cuernavaca yesterday and killed eleven members of that opposition political group, the Government announced today.

SAKKARA, Egypt, March 9 -- Archaeologists began today to explore the interior of what is believed to be the second oldest pyramid tomb thus far discovered in Egypt. It is an uncompleted step-pyramid of the III Dynasty, built here more than 4700 years ago.
SAN MATEO, Calif., March 9 (UP) -- Kingly, a mud-loving son of Sir Gallahad III, got up in the last step to win the $11,300 Springtime Handicap as Bay Meadows opened its 1954 racing season today.
Louis Tannenbaum, quiet spoken and diffident, has stepped into one of the hottest retail posts in the city. But he takes it all calmly.
London's Festival Ballet will make a tour of the United States and Canada next season, opening in Quebec Oct. 10. Anton Dolin is artistic director.

Despite the many excellent programs conceived by able and earnest citizens in public and in private life to halt the rising tide of juvenile misconduct it is not possible to say that they have thus far been conspicuously successful. It is true that the problem is being attacked on a number of fronts, but there seems to be lacking that measure of top-level coordination which is indispensable to a fruitful solution.

Details of a proposed merger of the H. B. American Machine Company and Susquehanna Mills, Inc., were announced yesterday by Victor Nemeroff, president of H. B., and Kenneth B. Cook, president of Susquehanna. Stockholders of the two companies will be asked to approve the merger at special meetings of both companies on March 22.

NEWARK, March 9 -- A Government witness at the income tax evasion trial of Harold John Adonis testified today that in September, 1950, the defendant described himself as "a lobbyist and go-between for the pinball operators and the Government."

An important service rendered by the Red Cross to our Armed Forces is in the matter of emergency leaves. The Red Cross is brought into the picture only when there is a question concerning the emergency request.

Luther A. Huston's article in The Times of March 8 is a brilliant summation of the five cases now pending before the United States Supreme Court dealing with racial segregation in public schools. We commend The Times and Mr. Huston on making available to the public this clear exposition of the principles involved in these momentous cases.

Notwithstanding the Northern Pacific Railway's stake in oil and gas developments in the Williston Basis of North Dakota and Montana, the road does not expect "maximum" returns from drilling activities for some time.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 9 -- The Yankees almost won a game in spectacular fashion today. Then they blew it, 6 to 5, as Lou Boudreau's Red Sox toppled the world champions for the second afternoon in a row, a state of affairs that startled Manager Casey Stengel no end.

Details of a proposed merger of the H. B. American Machine Company and Susquehanna Mills, Inc., were announced yesterday by Victor Nemeroff, president of H. B., and Kenneth B. Cook, president of Susquehanna. Stockholders of the two companies will be asked to approve the merger at special meetings of both companies on March 22.

NEWARK, March 9 -- A Government witness at the income tax evasion trial of Harold John Adonis testified today that in September, 1950, the defendant described himself as "a lobbyist and go-between for the pinball operators and the Government."

An important service rendered by the Red Cross to our Armed Forces is in the matter of emergency leaves. The Red Cross is brought into the picture only when there is a question concerning the emergency request.

Luther A. Huston's article in The Times of March 8 is a brilliant summation of the five cases now pending before the United States Supreme Court dealing with racial segregation in public schools. We commend The Times and Mr. Huston on making available to the public this clear exposition of the principles involved in these momentous cases.

Notwithstanding the Northern Pacific Railway's stake in oil and gas developments in the Williston Basis of North Dakota and Montana, the road does not expect "maximum" returns from drilling activities for some time.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 9 -- The Yankees almost won a game in spectacular fashion today. Then they blew it, 6 to 5, as Lou Boudreau's Red Sox toppled the world champions for the second afternoon in a row, a state of affairs that startled Manager Casey Stengel no end.
MINNEAPOLIS, March 9 (AP) -- The Wisconsin Central Railway Company has returned to private operation after twenty-two years in receivership and reorganization.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 8 -- As Parliament continued today to discuss the Social Plan and budget for 1954, observers noted that several substantial changes had been made in the drafts as a result of committee debates and hearings.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Senate Democrats drew together today in support of policies that forecast an attempt by them to fight the coming Congressional campaign almost wholly on economic issues.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (UP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley introduced legislation today to set up a sixteen-member special commission to study the problem of international agreements and report to Congress by March, 1955.

JERSEY CITY, March 9 -- At one of the shortest budget hearings in this city's history, the City Commission today adopted the 1954 municipal budget with its record-breaking high tax rate of $84.18 on each $1,000 assessed real estate property valuation.

James Reston's expert analysis of March 7 in The Times of McCarthy's influence in Congress underlines the fact that once a man has attained political power he can be deprived of that power only by political means. Indignation must be not only felt, it must be expressed in democratic action because, as Elihu Root once said, a member of Congress feels that an organized minority will punish where an unorganized majority will not protect.
Financial matters, all on the bright side, occupied the dole-gates of the American Kennel Club at their annual meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.
Government approval no longer is required for the chartering of privately-owned, American-flag tankers to foreign interests for periods up to six months.

STOCKHOLM, March 9 (AP) -- A Swedish athletic official who is "noted for my neutrality," said today "some international body such as the Olympic Committee someday will have to decide something about Russia's state-financed amateurs.

The twelfth floor in the fifteen-story and penthouse building going up at 579 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of East Forty-seventh Street, has been leased by Weed Co. and Weed Television, sales agents for radio and television stations.
ALBANY, March 9 -- The Senate approved by a vote of 38 to 17 today a bill providing for a uniform system for selecting juries in the fifty-seven counties outside New York City.

Increasing numbers of Americans share the fears of leading Senators relative to the forthcoming Geneva conference. In spite of the assurances of Secretary Dulles, the concrete concessions made by the three Western Foreign Ministers to the Soviet world appear to jeopardize the position not only of the Federal Republic of Germany but also the Republics of China and Korea.
The General Motors Corporation, the worlds largest manufacturing enterprise, attained in 1953 the highest dollar sales ever reported by any company -- $10,027,985,482.
LONDON, March 9 -- A Labor spokesman in Parliament challenged today Britain's need for a separate Royal Navy and a Royal Air Force.

A one-day strike of 2,500 workers employed by eighteen of this port's smaller ship repair concerns ended late yesterday afternoon when the employers granted a wage increase of 10 cents an hour across the board. The settlement wound up six months of negotiations.
MEXICO CITY, March 9 (UP) -- Without winning a single championship, Mexico scored heavily in track and field events today to whittle Cuba's unofficial lead in the Central American Games to 2 points.
MOSCOW, March 9 (AP) -- The Soviet Army newspaper Red Star sees the Broadway play "The Teahouse of the August Moon" as "camouflage for the true activities of the Americans on Okinawa."
A $100,000 contempt action proved no more effective yesterday than a Federal injunction in getting striking longshoremen back to work.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- On top of the White House, President Eisenhower broils steaks for his friends, wearing his chef's cap and apron.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 9 -- Guatemala's principal delegate walked out of a plenary session today at the Tenth Inter-American Conference while the Dominican Foreign Minister was speaking on the Communist danger.

Extra guards were assigned yesterday by the Police Department and the Waldorf-Astoria Towers to protect Senator Joseph R. McCarthy against a threat. Early yesterday morning a Spanish-speaking man telephoned the hotel and warned the Senator to get out before "something terrible" happened to him.
A $100,000 contempt action proved no more effective yesterday than a Federal injunction in getting striking longshoremen back to work.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 9 -- Guatemala's principal delegate walked out of a plenary session today at the Tenth Inter-American Conference while the Dominican Foreign Minister was speaking on the Communist danger.

Extra guards were assigned yesterday by the Police Department and the Waldorf-Astoria Towers to protect Senator Joseph R. McCarthy against a threat. Early yesterday morning a Spanish-speaking man telephoned the hotel and warned the Senator to get out before "something terrible" happened to him.

LONDON, March 10 -- A Parliamentary attack on one of the biggest theatrical producing combinations in London was started today by Labor Member Woodrow Wyatt. Mr. Wyatt introduced a private bill to control nonprofit producing companies.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Eisenhower today pledged anew that wherever the Federal authority extended he would do his utmost to bring about racial equality. The President made the pledge at the Freedom Fulfillment Conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
ACCORDING to the reports from several states, including New York, the hunting accident ratio was the lowest on record, despite the large increase in the number of hunters.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
The first all-transistor telephone system is being operated experimentally by the Bell Telephone Laboratories at Americus, Ga., 135 miles south of Atlanta.
LONDON, March 10 -- The Government told Parliament today that it planned to ratify the convention on minimum standards of social security adopted by the International Labor Conference in 1952.
ALBANY, March 10 -- The Assembly Judiciary Committee approved today a proposed constitutional amendment to permit construction of the controversial Panther Mountain Dam in the Adirondacks.
MOSCOW, March 10 -- The name of the city of Dzaudzhikau is being changed back to Ordzhonikidze [cross on map].
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Eisenhower promised today not to involve the United States in war without a declaration of war by Congress.

Bloomingdale's had a comprehensive showing of leading spring fashion trends in top-name designs yesterday in the Pierre Hotel. Coats were from houses such as Ben Gershel and Leto Cohn. Suits and dresses bore the labels of Ben Reig, Adele Simpson, Harvey Berin and many others.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 10 -- John Foster Dulles has turned a shaky start into an apparently heartening success for the United States at his first inter-American conference.

The power of objects -- their ineffable presence in both material and spiritual provinces -- is underlined in Walter Murch's oils at the Betty Parsons Gallery. These accurately rendered portraits of inanimate objects are forceful reminders of relationships between "things" and people, and of the intangible significance of "things" in human life.

Frank Selvy of Furman, Fordham's Ed Conlin and Coach Johnny Jordan of Notre Dame were honored yesterday at the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association annual awards luncheon at Leone's Restaurant.

Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d will produce a special ninety-minute television program on Sunday, March 28, at 8 P. M. that will feature musical highlights from their Broadway productions during the last eleven years.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10 -- The United Nations plans to drop a diplomatic word to the West German Government that it would be happier not to have a former Nazi serve as Bonn's observer here.

Harry Gross, former head of the $20,000,000-a-year Brooklyn bookmaking ring, was charged yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court with failing to file an income tax for 1950. The Government accused the 39-year-old bookmaker of concealing at least $63,087 in income for that year.
Four thousand school editors will swarm onto the Columbia University campus today to open the thirtieth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association.

Hubert S. Aldrich, president of the New York Trust Company and chairman of the 1954 fund campaign of the New York Heart Association, yesterday presented research awards to nine medical scientists doing studies on the heart.

OMAHA, March 10 (AP) -- Crystals of pure iron, one hundred times stronger than any known metallic crystal, have been developed in the General Electric Company's research laboratory, G. E.'s top research official said tonight.

The police of the Borough Park station in Brooklyn arrested forty-six boys last night to prevent, they said, a scheduled fight among three teen-age gangs. The boys were gathering in Fifteenth and Sixteenth Avenues and Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Streets.
OTTAWA, March 10 -- Canada has no immediate intention of recognizing the Communist Government of China, Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of State for External Affairs, told the House of Commons today.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 (UP) -- The Harvard Lampoon today chose "The Robe" to head its list of the "Ten Worst Movies of 1953," terming the film the "greatest setback to Christianity since Nero."

MESA, Ariz., March 10 -- Leo Durocher, the spirited skipper of the Giants, who long ago learned that he "can't win 'em all," stubbornly refused to become alarmed, following his team's fourth straight setback.

This year's grapefruit crop is the largest in the history of the fruit, which was introduced commercially to American tables at the turn of the century. The 1953-54 harvest is expected to total 42,000,000 boxes, of which 38,000,000 will come from Florida.
ALBANY, March 10 -- The Senate approved over solid Democratic opposition today a bill to remove the present $500,000,000 ceiling on borrowing by the State Thruway Authority.

LONDON, March 10 -- The Conservative party today recorded another decisive victory in a by-election. Thus it bolstered its position for the critical period ahead when the active leadership of the party inevitably will pass from Sir Winston Churchill to Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Roy M. Cohn, chief counsel of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which Senator Joseph R. McCarthy heads, said today he had been ordered to report to Camp Kilmer, N. J., for training as a National Guard officer June 12-25.
The Midtown Squad, "elite" corps of the Police Department, is facing abolishment.
Red Cross aid to victims of disaster is a gift from the people of America. Shelter, food, clothing and medical care are given without charge to all sufferers during the emergency phase.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Eisenhower aligned himself today with the growing opposition in the Republican party to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy but stopped just short of an open break with him.
The rent racket in Harlem is disgraceful and requires urgent action.
Although interest and prices faded near the close, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday managed to make a high-water mark since March 27, 1953.

Two tax bills have emerged from the House Ways and Means Committee in the past few days. Since they differ enormously in character and scope it is important, for purposes of avoiding possible confusion, that they be clearly identified at the outset.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The Assembly Judiciary Committee approved today a bill spelling out the grounds on which the state might censor a motion picture found to be immoral or of a nature to incite to crime.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, asked Congress today to amend the immigration laws to permit judicial review of deportation orders.

GENEVA, March 10 (AP) -- The Soviet bloc tried unsuccessfully today to get both East and West Germany admitted to membership in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe before Germany is unified.

The Chinese Communist Government in Peiping has tight control of the country, Foster Halley, Detroit regional correspondent of The New York Times and former Times correspondent in the Pacific, declared yesterday.

Amid cries of "race prejudice" and accusations of hasty action the City Planning Commision approved yesterday the proposed new state-financed $19,046,000 housing project for the Castle Hill section of the Bronx.

PHILADELPHIA March 10 (AP) -- Bobby Jones, an unranked middleweight from Oakland, Calif., scored a major upset tonight with a split ten-round verdict over Philadelphia's Gil Turner at the Arena. Turner weighed 151 pounds and Jones 155 for the nationally-televised bout.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Following are the texts of two bills proposed today by the Special Legislative Committee on Ethics. The first would bar public officers, legislators and party officials from engaging in certain activities; the second would establish a code of ethics for legislators, public officers and party officials.
General Li Tsung-jen charged yesterday that his dismissal from the Vice Presidency of China was a "bogus show" "cooked up" by by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.
JERUSALEM, March 10 -- The Israeli Government published today a resume of press criticism of Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, chief of staff of the United Nations truce supervision organization for Palestine.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Government told the Supreme Court today that one provision of New York's banking law conflicted with Federal law and should be struck down as unconstitutional.

A move calculated to create a better balance among the teams of the National Hockey League was made yesterday when the board of governors adopted a new draft rule. Meeting at the Hotel Biltmore, the represetnatives of the six clubs in the circuit voted to permit the selection of players out of a common pool every September.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 10 -- Cambodia is rapidly working out her own foreign policy to go along with the political and financial independence she expects to formalize in the new treaty with France.

Retail business in England, France and Switzerland is generally good, though there has been a slight slowdown in England and France in recent months, a retailer just returned from a tour of these countries said yesterday.
A special group of spring fashions -- some available immediately, others to be ordered -- was included in Milgrim's "Couturier" collection that was previewed by the press yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The United States and the Soviet Union took another step today toward a possible conference on President Eisenhower's proposal for the peaceful pooling of atomic-energy resources.

An ownership of more than twenty-five years has been ended in the sale of three four-story garden-type apartment buildings at 35-04, 45-06, and 35-16 Thirty-first Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, by Mrs. Catalina Paez MacManus.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today calling for reductions of 50 per cent on April 1 in most Federal "luxury" taxes and comparable cuts in other excises. The vote was 411 to 3.
Jon Crain, tenor, made an unexpected debut on short notice at the Metropolitan last evening, singing the role of Alfred in "Die Fledermaus."
LONDON, March 10 -- For the second time in less than a month British Communists have been badly beaten in attempts to gain control of major unions.

CINCINNATI, March 10 -- Charles Adair Harrell of San Antonio, Tex., who has served almost twenty-five years as city manager in five cities, was chosen Cincinnati city manager today by unanimous vote of the nine-member City Council.

Between the hours of 5 and 7 last night the Rev. J. J. Lynch, member of the squash racquets squad of the New York Athletic Club, lost two matches in the Metropolitan Class C singles championship, but there may be a "recount" on one of them.

Duquesne's top-seeded quintet will face Niagara and Western Kentucky will tackle Holy Cross in the semi-finals of the seventeenth annual National Invitation tournament tonight at Madison Square Garden. The Duquesne-Niagara clash will open the program at 7:45 o'clock.
BIG BEAR LAKE, Calif., March 10 (AP) -- The challenging art of skiing is being mastered by a group of determined, one-legged men.

For those who have been wondering whether Marc Blitzstein's adaptation of "The Threepenny Opera" would stand up in a dramatic performance in the theatre as well as it did in concert form at the Brandeis University Festival in 1952, the answer was provided last night in Greenwich Village's Theatre de Lys.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 10 (AP) -- St. Peter's College of Jersey City put on a driving finish to oust the Regis Rangers of Denver in the second round of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament today, 63 to 58, before a crowd of 4,500.

I was particularly struck by Gordon Graham's letter published Feb. 22 on the textile tariff issue because this was one of the rare instances in which a high-tariff advocate acknowledges that a flat comparison of wage rates may not be a wholly accurate key to the price advantage one country supposedly has over another.

The bill introduced into the State Legislature by Senator Greenberg seeks to amend the Medical Practices Act to cover nervous and mental disorders. Under it only licensed physicians would be able to practice psychoanalysis, although other disciplines have laid claims to competency in this field.
