MADISON, Wis., March 10 (UP) -- University of Wisconsin librarians said today they were trying to find out how they got a batch of business records, some more than 700 years old.
On record sales of $792,381,721, the Borden Company and its consolidated subsidiaries increased net income 15 per cent to $20,264,156 in 1953 from $17,667,137 the year before.

The seven-story loft building at 135 Grand Street has been sold by Kate Raskin to the 135 Grand Street Corporation, which insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company. The Tricap Realty Corporation was the broker.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules, except where direct quotation was authorized.

ALBANY, March 10 -- Ignoring a special message from Governor Dewey, the Assembly defeated today a bill designed to meet court objections to the State's year-old program of chemical tests for drunken drivers.

A stockholders committee of American Woolen Company headed by A. M. Sonnabend, Boston industrialist and hotel owner, urged immediate acceptance yesterday of the Textron, Inc., offer for American Woolen's common stock.

The Queens Chamber of Commerce announced yesterday its opposition to legislation in Congress and in the Legislature designed to put the Long Island Rail Road under the exclusive jurisdiction of the Public Service Commission.
Representatives of six major daily newspapers in the city and of Local 1 of the International Photo-Engravers Union of North America, A. F. L., signed a new contract yesterday.

A food associated with the Jewish feast of Purim, which comes a week from today, is the hamantash. This three-cornered pastry already is on sale in many bakeries in the city. One chain of candy shops, Barton's Bonbonniere is offering it for the first time this year.

MOSCOW, March 10 -- The wife of a United States diplomat served a tossed salad of crisp green lettuce and beautiful red tomatoes at a recent dinner party. She then topped this by producing a great platter of gleaming fresh celery.
The city of Baltimore, Md., announced yesterday plans for borrowing $36,050,000 in the public market on general obligation bonds. The sale is to take place on March 30.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 10 -- Premier Prince Buu Loc was expected today to return from Paris early next week to confront the upsurge of opposition to his Government that has developed here. The Premier has been holding talks with the French regarding full independence for Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Senator Robert C. Hendrickson announced tonight his withdrawal as a candidate for the Republican nomination for United States Senator from New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, who is a great one for friendly physical gestures, threw his arm around the shoulders of Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, when they met in the Capitol basement today.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Labor Department today reported nonfarm employment dropped by 300,000 in February but showed a slackening in the jobless trend.

Plans for a North Jersey district office have been announced in connection with the purchase by the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company of the land at 236-48 South Harrison Street and 33-35 Sanford Street, East Orange. The site contains about one and one-half acres and fronts 150 feet on South Harrison Street and eighty feet on Sanford Street.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 10 -- "It all depends on the big guy," said Lou Boudreau simply. The skipper of the rich Red Sox didn't have to draw diagrams to explain what he meant. The inference was much too clear. As everyone in New England knows, the big guy is Theodore Samuel Williams, left-handed hitter extraordinary.
ROME, March 10 -- The Chamber of Deputies voted its confidence in Premier Mario Scelba and his Cabinet tonight. The margin was 300 to 283 with one abstention.

Lew Christensen's little ballet, "Con Amore," which the New York City Ballet presented last season for the first time, is now enjoying an entirely new production. It had its premiere on Tuesday, when the Azuma Kabuki Dancers were also having a premiere, but it was repeated last night and will be given one more performance tonight.
Treaty laws not enacted by Congress should be limited.
A coordinated display of home furnishings, entitled "Interior of the Year," opened yesterday in an apartment at 107 Waverly Place.
MIAMI, March 10 -- The Dodgers finally broke their losing streak tonight when they beat the Phillies, 7 -- 6, but it took them eleven innings and three hours and nine minutes to do it.

CALGARY, March 10 (Canadian Press) -- Reserves of Alberta's new Pembina oil field have been estimated at between 762,000,000 and 952,960,000 barrels by three companies seeking pipeline permits in the area, seventy-five miles southwest of Edmonton.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Eisenhower said today that, like most Americans, he had no definite answer to the problems of discipline and compassion raised by the Schwable case.

RANGOON, Burma, March 10 (AP) -- Burmese troops have captured Mongton and Wanmekin [cross on map], two villages near Thailand's border which have been occupied by Chinese Nationalist guerrillas for five years.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 10 (AP) -- The French fire-bombed a Vietminh stronghold and repelled numerous raids by the Communist-led rebels in the Red River delta of northern Indo-China, army headquarters said today. One Vietnamese militia post fell to the rebels.
Columbia's baseball team held its first outdoor practice yesterday at Baker Field. The squad will work out daily in preparation for the season's opener in three weeks.

The "big names" among entertainers don't like to cross the line to advertising, but many sponsors want them to. That's why the talent now handles some commercial announcements on radio and television.

TUXEDO PARK N. Y., March 10 -- What is believed to be the old Continental Road, which George Washington's engineers built through the marshes here in 1778, came to light today with the draining of Lake Wee-Wah.

The Navy has lost 15,000 rounds of ammunition somewhere in the waters of New York Harbor and has been sending teams of divers down daily since last Saturday looking for the explosives. But there is no sign yet of a single shell.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Sea O Erin, from the barn of the Hasty House Farms, scored a four-length victory in the $18,500 Fountain of Youth Handicap at Gulfstream Park today, but the glitter of the race was lost when the undefeated Duc de Fer was scratched because of the muddy track.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, March 11 (AP) -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, president of South Korea, says he probably will send delegates to the Geneva conference but "we must have iron-clad assurances there will be no sellout of Korea."

Perseverance by three detectives who for weeks have been patiently checking on pawnshops in Harlem, Manhattan and Brooklyn has paid off with the arrest of two expensively dressed young women charged with the theft of $25,000 in jewelry from three East Side apartments.

ALBANY, March 10 -- The Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals urged today that the Temporary State Commission on the Courts postpone for a year its request for legislative action on a major reorganization of judicial administration in the state.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Secretary of Defense and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy reported today after a two-hour discussion that they had "no arguments'' on how to handle Communists drafted into the armed forces.
ROME, March 10 -- Italy's new Premier, Mario Scelba, is a man of courage and an artful politician.

" The Golden Apple," the John Latouche-Jerome Moross musical, opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Phoenix Theatre, Second Avenue and Twelfth Street, under the auspices of T. Edward Hambleton and Norris Houghton.

EDWARD R. MURROW'S television program on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was an exciting and provocative examination of the man and his methods. It was crusading journalism of high responsibility and genuine courage.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10 (AP) -- Johnny Bratton, former welterweight champion, was fined $3,000 today by the Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission for "not putting forth his best efforts" in a ten-round losing fight with Johnny Saxton last Feb. 24.

Universal Pictures Company, Inc., in the three months ended last January enjoyed its best first-quarter business in several years, Milton R. Rackmil, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UP) -- The Senate Labor Committee today approved a bill to ban racial and religious discrimination in employment, but there appeared little chance that the con troversial civil rights measure would win Senate passage.
Cargo operations at the New York Port of Embarkation have diminished so greatly since the end of the Korean conflict last July that the Army plans to give up two of its five Staten Island piers.

OTTAWA, March 10 (Reuters) -- A renewed flow of British investment is coming to Canada and is receiving wide attention at a time when Canada, because of her expanding economy, is reaching out for capital.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Ezra Taft Benson said today he "probably" would recommend that President Eisenhower veto any extension by Congress of present high, rigid farm price supports.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Although the business slowdown often has been termed an inventory adjustment, the inventory factor alone does not explain the decline, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said today.
LONDON, March 10 -- Commons was told today that a commission of inquiry would be appointed presently and flown to British Honduras as a matter of urgency.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- President Eisenhower urged separate consideration of Hawaiian and Alaska statehood proposals today as a Senate vote neared on linking them in one bill.

Today's new film is "Rhapsody,'' a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer romantic drama in Technicolor with Elizabeth Taylor, Vittorio Gassman and John Erickson, at the Radio City Music Hall. Lawrence Weingarten produced, Charles Vidor directed and Fay and Michael Kanin wrote the screen play from an adaptation by Ruth and Augustus Goetz of the Henry Handel Richardson novel, "Maurice Guest."
WASHINGTON, March 10 -The February average of basic commodity prices, and spot primary market prices on Tuesday and a week earlier are shown below:
United Air Lines, Inc., handled a record volume of business last year, but rising costs reduced earnings.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 -- Things finally perked up for Casey Stengel today. His Yankees snapped their two-game losing streak by topping Bucky Harris' Senators, 4 to 3. But it took a deal of doing.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 10 (AP) -- Following is the text of a speech by Secretary of State John Foster Dulles today before the Economic Committee of the tenth Inter-American Conference:

MANILA, March 10 -- President Ramon Magsaysay passed a test of political leadership on foreign policy today. He established firm control as a result of a dispute that has been threatening to split the Nationalist party and impair cordial relations with the United States.

There are two household devices which seem to be growing uncomfortably obsolescent. One is the Lazy Susan. Now if you go to the dictionary and look up Lazy Susan, you will get some disconcerting news. A "muffin stand," it says, and it mentions three legs.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 -- Business was advised today not to be "panicked into short-sighted economies" whenever the outlook became dubious.

If one cares to believe the Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia, the brightest pages in the history of Soviet invention are just around the corner. There is something about the salubrious soil and climate of Siberia, the newspaper tells us, which just naturally seems to stimulate man's inventiveness.
CHICAGO -- March 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The unusual step taken by President Eisenhower at his press conference yesterday in commenting favorably on Senator Flanders' criticism of Senator McCarthy is a significant and encouraging piece of news. While the President did not give blanket endorsement to Mr. Flanders' attack, he did make it clear that he, too, felt Mr. McCarthy was endangering the Administration's serious legislative program through the familiar tactics of diversion, disunity and destruction.

An increase last week of only 33,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 179,203,000 barrels, compared with 179,170,000 a week earlier and 159,434,000 a year ago.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, announced last night that he had begun an inquiry into alleged improper practices in the purchase of athletic equipment for the college

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that the United Nations was going ahead with plans to provide a meeting place, translators and other officials that will be needed for the Far Eastern conference opening in Geneva April 26.
BUFFALO, March 10 (AP) -- The Schine Theatre interests were ordered today to show cause why they should not be cited for contempt in connection with a 1949 anti-trust decree.

The Visiting Nurse Service of New York did not hold its customary tea yesterday on the birthday of its famous founder, Lillian D. Wald. That was because the former Lower East Side settlement house agency was too busy moving its headquarters into a former Upper East Side millionaire's mansion.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 10 -- "The King and I," now approaching the end of its three-year Broadway run, will be brought to the screen by Twentieth Century-Fox.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 10 -- The South African Government apparently is taking measures to prevent an increased inflow of European National Socialists and sympathizers with Hitler's doctrines.
PHILADELPHIA, March 10 -- Harold E. Stassen declared tonight that the free peoples of the world were winning their drive for peace, prosperity and progress through voluntary partnership.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 10 -- A long-standing boundary dispute between Ecuador and Peru suddenly became a hot issue at the Tenth Inter-American Conference today. It overshadowed the main question -- Communist intervention in the Americas -- at the Political Committee's meeting.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Senator Wayne Morse spiked efforts today to force a quick decision on the way to develop the power potential of the Niagara River.

The American Chamber Opera Society, which earlier this season gave us the first production in this country of the singularly neglected and valuable "Paris and Helen" of Gluck, revived last night in Town Hall the delightful comedy of Rossini, "La Gazza Ladra," in a fashion that made for a spirited and distinctive entertainment.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 10 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles pledged the United States today to improved economic relations with the Latin-American republics. He made the pledge to the Tenth Inter-American Conference.
NEWARK, March 10 -- The Federal grand jury today returned a two-count indictment for income tax evasion against Albert Anastasia, reputed former head of the Brooklyn gang known as Murder, Inc.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Two of the three co-medalists in the South Florida golf tournament at the Palm Beach Club were beaten in today's opening round of match play.
LOS ANGELES, March 10 -- A conflict between the City of Los Angeles and the State of California over "progressive" education seemed to be heading for a showdown today.

Permit me to amplify the admirable dispatch published Feb. 24 from your correspondent Thomas F. Brady about the city of Saint Lo and the Franco-American Memorial Hospital and to correct one inaccuracy.

Frank Giordano has purchased the three-story apartment house accommodating eight families at 109 Park Place in Brooklyn from Carl B. Thorwaldsen. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Even adults could understand the children's art exhibit that opened this week at the East River Savings Bank, 41 Rockefeller Plaza. "Fluffy Cat," for instance, was a fluffy cat and no mistake; "The Green Sea" had fish floating through it, and "Silly Joe" was the portrait of a foolish-looking snow man.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Some Senate Democrats asserted today that they could prove that the Eisenhower program for ridding the Government of subversives and other risks was no more effective than that of the Truman Administration.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation will get no more than one bid for the purchase of a whole $65,000,000 issue of Baltimore and Ohio Railroad collateral trust bonds posted for sale next Monday, it was predicted yesterday.

LONDON, March 10 -- The strength of British Government securities was the main feature of a generally cheerful securities market here today. Gilt-edge issues improved by as much as one-quarter of 1 per cent.

HAVANA, March 10 -- Communism has been eradicated from Cuba, peace has been restored among the nations of the Caribbean and preparations have been made for holding general elections in Cuba next November, President Fulgencio Batista said today.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 10 -- Two hundred and fourteen landowners, whose property carries an assessed valuation of more than $8,000,000, won the opening skirmish tonight in their battle against a parochial high school.

Cocoa prices plunged the 100-point daily limit yesterday on the New York exchange. Metals continued active with copper registering the most sales for any day since trading reopened on June 6 and zinc and rubber having their third highest daily volumes of the year.

The Dun Bradstreet index of wholesale food prices for the week ended yesterday stood at $7.25. This was the highest figure the index has shown for any week in the last three years. The index represents the aggregate wholesale cost of a pound each of thirty-one foods in common use.

The tangled affairs of Colonial Airlines became even more complicated yesterday. Branch T. Dykes, president, at the last moment sent telegrams to Eastern Air Lines and National Airlines withdrawing Colonial's offer to consider a proposal from each at 3:30 yesterday afternoon for acquisition of Colonial's assets.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned more active and stronger yesterday, closing very steady, unchanged to 17 points higher than Tuesday, led by the strength in old March.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- February sales of retail stores totaled $11,900,000,000, the Department of Commerce said today in a "flash" report. The figure shows a rise of about 1 per cent from January and a drop of about 5 per cent compared with February a year ago.

MOSCOW, March 10 -- Pravda, in the longest and most detailed discussion of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy which it has yet published, asserted today that President Eisenhower "on the whole supported McCarthy."

Assigned the difficult task of proposing a code to govern the conduct of legislators, public officials and political party officers, the Lockwood Committee on Ethics has wound up its work with a body of principle and commandment to which, in our opinion, New York State can point with justified pride of leadership.
Warnings yesterday that the Port of New York faced "six months of labor chaos and a permanent loss of its commercial pre-eminence" marked the sixth day of the outlaw dock strike.

MOSCOW, Thursday, March 11 -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Defense Minister, warned the world yesterday that the Soviet Union's armed forces were equipped with every technique of modern warfare, including the most up-to-date jet planes.

MOSCOW, March 10 -- Pravda, in the longest and most detailed discussion of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy which it has yet published, asserted today that President Eisenhower "on the whole supported McCarthy."

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) --The Department of Agriculture reported today that production o citrus fruits this season might reach 187,775,000 boxes, com pared with 175,530,000 last season. This forecast is virtually the same as one the department made a month ago.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 10 -- The National Assembly of Nationalist China voted by an overwhelming margin today to dismiss Vice President Li Tsung-jen.
ALBANY, March 10 -- The Lockwood Committee recommended unanimously today a comprehensive code of ethics to guide public officers, legislators and party officials.

The academic advisory board of the Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L. I., ended yesterday a three-day study of the institution's educational program. A report on the conclusions was given to Rear Admiral Gordon C. McLintock, superintendent of the United States Maritime Service, who will forward it to the Maritime Administration in the Department of Commerce.

Charles Munch provided further proof at Carnegie Hall last night of his special affinity and affection for Berlioz. He conducted a performance of "Romeo et Juliette" that was not only complete but that also made vivid how truly the composer was entitled to call the piece a dramatic symphony.

SCHENECTADY, March 10 -- Votes by show of hands today indicated that an "overwhelming" majority of the members of Local 301, United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, were behind their officers' decision to shift the big General Electric Company union to the C. I. O.
Television viewers across the country continued to voice their reaction in ever mounting numbers yesterday to Edward R. Murrow's critical report on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10 (AP) -- Ted Williams tonight was pictured as "very optimistic about his athletic future."

CHICAGO, March 10 -- Thirty persons were injured and scores more were shaken up late today when the Pennsylvania Railroad's Liberty Limited and the Burlington Line's Minneapolis Zephyr collided in the Union Station train shed.
One-third of the personnel employed by the privately owned and operated American merchant marine two years ago is "on the beach" today, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

Before the thirty-eighth International Flower Show reopens at 10 A. M. today in Kingsbridge Armory, Kingsbridge Road and Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, new flower arrangements and new displays will have been set in place and those that have been on view since Sunday will have been refurbished.

A five-year plan to bring more girls into the Girl Scout movement and to strengthen existing units was voted yesterday by the board of directors of the Girl Scouts of the U. S. A. As an initial step, the board voted an appropriation of $200,000. The total cost of the program is estimated at $869,000.
TAMPA, Fla., March 10 (AP) -- Jams E. Clark of Shreveport, La., won the national midwinter .22-caliber pistol championship today with an aggregate of 889, a record for a civilian.
MEXICO CITY, March 10 (UP) -- Cuba won three more championships and rewrote the record book today but failed to budge Mexico from its lead in the Central American Games.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 10 -- Scores of persons were wounded, many critically, today as gangs of armed toughs toured polling places attacking persons suspected of being opposition voters and Communists.

A two-goal rally in the final period enabled the New York Rangers to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Broadway Blues had a difficult task against their last-place rivals, who waged a stubborn fight before submitting to the 4-to-2 defeat.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 3:

WILMINGTON, Del., March 10 (UP) -- An executive of the R. K. O. Pictures Corporation testified in Chancery Court today that he considered the offer of Howard Hughes to purchase all the company's stock for $23,489,478 a "fair" offer.
BONN, Germany, March 10 -- A fabulous yacht for Aristotle Socrates Onassis will sail this spring from the North, German port of Kiel.
The Moreland Act Commission appointed by Governor Dewey to investigate the harness tracks exonerated Secretary of State Thomas J. Curran yesterday of wrongdoing in his track dealings
NAIROBI, Kenya, March 10 (Reuters) -- Britain gave the Africans, Asians and Arabs ministerial posts in Kenya today as a first step toward multi-racial government in this troubled colony.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 10 (UP) -- Bobbie Dawson, the medalist, of Piedmont, Calif., defeated Mrs. Helen Wise of Ponte Vedra, Fla., 7 and 6 today, as favorites advanced easily in the first round of the Florida East Coast women's golf championship.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 10 (AP) -- Finally cracking through after six years, the New York Knickerbockers tonight turned in an 85-76 victory over Minneapolis on the Lakers' home floor in a National Basketball Association test tonight. It was the first time in nineteen games the visitors had beaten the Lakers in the Minneapolis Auditorium.

Late last year Harcourt, Brace published James Thomas Flexner's biography of Benedict Arnold and John Andre entitled "The Traitor and the Spy." On March 31 a new biography of Arnold will be issued by Harper. It is Willard M. Wallace's "Traitorous Hero."
The location of the Kingston-Rhinecliff Bridge across the Hudson River has been shifted three and one-half miles north and the span design radically altered.

CHICAGO, March 10 -- After touching a new crop high for May wheat and the highest price on the current upturn for the March, prices reacted sharply today. Pressure was especially heavy on the new crop wheat deliveries, which were influenced by the possibility of showers in the Southwest.

Three members of the police bomb squad and an Army captain were injured yesterday at Fort Tilden, Queens, by a hand grenade that exploded while they were examining the cache of arms seized here last week from a Cuban conspiracy ring.
Comparisons between the earnings of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company and the New York Central Railroad Company "are not valid," William White, president of the Central, declared yesterday.

Julio Pinto Gandia, 45-year-old leader of the Puerto Rican Nationalist party here, was threatened yesterday by a Federal Judge with a contempt-of-court citation if he should refuse to answer questions today before a Federal grand jury.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The President covered these topics in his news conference today:
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Republican Senate leaders "suggested" today a uniform procedure for investigating committees but made clear that there would be no attempt to enforce the code.
Spot prices of zinc, lead and quicksilver advanced yesterday.
The rights of United States exporters and importers to place shipping risk insurance in the most favorable markets were declared yesterday to have been infringed by recent changes in Mexican laws.

A subpoena calling on Mrs. Brenda Frazier Kelly to testify in the assault trial of Pietro Francesco Mele was withdrawn yesterday after a psychiatrist's affidavit said that her appearance in court might cause "a mental collapse and place her in a psychotic state, with serious consequences."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Herbert Hoover said today that $5,000,000,000 to $7,000,000,000 a year could be saved if Congress would follow all the recommendations he expected the new Commission on Government Reorganization to make.

IN spite of current rages to secede to other ages, Raymond Aron remains a twentieth century man. As a historian he is aware that other times have occasionally been more tranquil. As a philosopher he must often wonder whether humanity is quite bright in its zeal for repeating the past's mistakes. Yet he disdains the luxury of despair.

The code of fair procedures for state investigating agencies recommended March 8 by the New York Special Legislative Committee on Ethics in Government is disappointing in many respects. Perhaps it was visionary to expect more than just a step in the right direction, considering that New York's own agencies have been comparatively free from criticism, but the proposed code would do little to prevent the abuses made familiar by the McCarthy or Velde committee.

The regional Red Cross Blood Program received 984 pints of blood Tuesday, including 190 at the Federal Reserve Bank, 33 Liberty Street. Employes of forty-three downtown banks are marking "Bank Week" for the program by giving blood at the Federal Reserve Bank every day through Friday.
CAIRO, March 10 -- The $18,500 Easter egg of an empress, last owned by a king, was sold today to a New York art dealer.
TRENTON, March 10 -- Samuel L. Bodine, Republican State Chairman, reached by telephone tonight at his home in Flemington, said that he was "very pleased at Senator Hendrickson's decision."
The Kings County Democratic executive committee will meet at 11 A. M. today at its headquarters at 4-5 Court Square to try to elect a county leader to succeed Kenneth F. Sutherland.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 10 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, said at a press conference today that as far as he was concerned the question of the nationality of military officers supervising the cease-fire in Kashmir "does not arise."

While paperbacked books -- chiefly Westerns, mysteries and sex-adorned historical romances -- have done well enough in recent years, better grades of paperbacks generally have not. The reason seems to be that no publisher has gone beyond books that have been all but out of print.

Gardens, flower arrangements, displays of cut flowers and plants and booths stocked with garden supplies and equipment are special points of attraction for non-gardeners as well as gardeners who visit the thitry-eighth International Flower Show this week.

PARIS, March 11 -- Furniture built for an imaginary person nine feet tall is on exhibit at the Salon of Household Arts at the Grand Palais. The exhibit, which is currently on video, is titled: "If you were a child."

MOSCOW, March 11 (AP) -- The fish may be clever in Soviet waters, especially down south in the Sea of Azov, but the Government says that is no reason why Soviet fishermen cannot catch as much as they are supposed to.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat of New York, said today New York State's plan to build new power plants at Niagara Falls was "only the first step in the program of the private utility companies to eliminate the municipal and rural cooperative systems."
BONN, Germany, March 11 -- West German Government spokesmen declared here today that they did not know of any official plans to appoint a new West German observer to the United Nations.
PARIS, March 11 -- France's second modernization plan was submitted today to the council of French officials and business leaders who supervise its operation.
In the highly selective fashion that has become usual lately, the New York Stock Exchange rolled ahead yesterday to a new high point for the year.

Two distinguished and eminently serious musicians -- Guido Cantelli, the young and greatly gifted conductor, and Jascha Heifetz, the king of violinists -- gave notable performances, and raised questions of interpretation for the innocent bystander at the concert given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall.

TAMPA, Fla., March 11 -- It has been almost thirty years since the Chicago White Sox last trained in Florida. Like the brisk little eager beavers they were, they swooped down here and discovered the hotel at which they were to be quartered was still in the blueprint stage. They went away -- and they didn't return till this season.

Borrowing in anticipation of tax needs appears to have been the major influence in a rise of $14,000,000 in New York bank loans to business last week. The advance was the first in five weeks and cut the total contraction in business credits since the start of this year to $542,000,000, against a decline of $102,000,000 a year ago.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 4 points up to 5 points off, with the near months showing relatively greater strength than the distants.

Residents of the city's public housing projects are going to have to pay the same rate for gas and electricity as the occupants of private projects -- and that means increased rates for the public housing consumers. The city withdrew yesterday its petition for a special low-rate classification for the public housing projects.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- A Senate showdown on a long-forecast Republican effort to unseat Senator Denis Chavez because of alleged election irregularities in 1952 drew near today. A Republican-controlled Senate subcommittee formally filed its expected report recommending that the New Mexico Democrat's seat be held vacant.

An unusual program of choral music was presented last night in Town Hall by the Concert Choir under the direction of Margaret Hillis. The twenty-three well-trained young singers of the group turned their attention to pieces like Jannequin's "La Guerre," Banchieri's "Festino" and three Debussy songs that are seldom heard on the regular recital beat.

TRENTON, March 11 -- Nearly two score prospective candidates descended on the State House here today to file nominating petitions for the one seat in the United States Senate and fourteen House seats at stake this year.
The negative approach in advertising seems not to be waning. Insertions scheduled for Bacardi rum use the theme that the product has fewer calories than one egg or two ounces of hamburger.
The New York City Ballet at the City Center last night presented the first of two performances of William Dollar's "The Five Gifts," set to Dohnanyi's "Variations on a Nursery Rhyme."

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Guido Cantelli conducting, Jascha Heifetz, soloist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; Festival of Spanish Dancing and Music, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Fordham University Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:40; Roberta Long, soprano, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Army reported today it had been subjected to direct threats by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and his chief counsel, Roy Cohn.

LONDON, March 11 -- Britain will hold trials of defense methods against biological warfare in the waters of the Bahamas this year. The announcement tonight by Duncan Sandys, Minister of Supply, said similar trials had been carried out "in recent years" off the coast of Scotland.

New items for various rooms of the house have been assembled for a Gala Week of Home Furnishings to open Monday at Wanamaker's. Programs and demonstrations related to homemaking will be held during the week.

Color television moved much closer to the American living room yesterday. Frank M. Folsom, president of the Radio Corporation of America, said his company would begin production of color sets in ten days or three weeks ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- The House Appropriations Committee decided today to spend $2,000,000 putting a river under a dry-land toll bridge near Decatur, Neb., which in four years has not collected a toll.
The Atomic Energy Commission has found no new uranium in the New Jersey-Pennsylvania area it began to survey by air last month.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Mrs. Annie Lee Moss, suspended Army Signal Corps employe, softly but flatly denied all Communist party activities or membership today.
Two alternate play-off schedules for the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division round-robin eliminations were drafted yesterday by Maurice Podoloff, president of the professional league.

The attack on Senator McCarthy by Adlai E. Stevenson in his recent Miami speech will be applauded by Communists, fellow-travelers and soft-brained pseudo-intellectuals, who make up probably the largest and noisiest segments of the anti-McCarthyites.

After top-seeded Duquesne had polished off Niagara, 66 -- 51, in the first semi-final, Holy Cross uproariously reversed the formula course of the seventeenth annual National Invitation basketball tournament by upsetting second-seeded Western Kentucky, 75 -- 69, at Madison Square Garden last night.

ROME, March 11 -- On the eve of the fifteenth anniversary of his coronation the Pope was stated in the Vatican to be continuing his slow but steady progress toward recovery from the grave stomach ailment that incapacitated him almost seven weeks ago.

The Macon Umbrella Corporation, in an expansion move, has leased the one-story building at 1-39 Harrison Place in Brooklyn from the Windsor Manufacturing and Repair Corporation in a transaction negotiated by the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- During the weekended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $100,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The Port of New York Authority nnounced yesterday plans .for a pubHo borrowing of $20,000,000 on a new issue of consolidated bonds. The issue is to be sold at sealed bidding on March 31, according to present plans.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 11 -- The Secretary of Labor, James P. Mitchell, said tonight that a good company and a good union could live together "without trying to tear the employe apart."

The new spring look, made wearable for the woman who has reached the gracious look of mature years, was present in the collection of dresses made for Jay Thorpe by the Taylor Importing Company. They were shown during luncheon yesterday in the Terrace room of the Plaza Hotel.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- President Eisenhower's plan for Federal health reinsurance was introduced in Congress today.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- United States Tax Court records disclosed today the Government was seeking to take trust funds established for Joe Louis' two young children as a partial collection on back income taxes allegedly owed by the ex-heavyweight champion.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- A spokesman for twelve of the thirteen unions making up the Conference of American Maritime Unions urged today the closing of the merchant marine academy at Kings Point, L. I., and four state maritime academies in New York, Maine, Massachusetts and California.

ALBANY, March 11 -- The Joint Legislative Committee on Comic Books warned today that unrestricted publication of lewd and obscene comic books, pocket books and magazines was threatening the spiritual, mental and physical welfare of the state.

A year's delay in legislating a reorganization of state court administration, through setting up a new Judicial Conference, seems to be in the cards as the result of a joint hearing in Albany. This is disappointing, in view of the obvious merits of the plan advanced by the Temporary Commission on the Courts, which gave it priority among other reforms under consideration.
Roy M. Cohn and G. David Schine first attracted international attention as a partnership during their whirlwind tour of Europe in the spring of 1953.
Thirty-one smirking members of two Brooklyn teen-age gangs, arrested Wednesday night to avert a gang war, were told in Brooklyn Adolescent Court yesterday that they would be better off in jail.
ALBANY, March 11 -- Today was Ladies' Day in the Assembly, the annual occasion when male legislators gallantly step aside to let the seven members of the fairer sex run the show.

A statuette of Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, one in a collection of representations of wives of all the Presidents on display at the National Antiques Show at Madison Square Garden, was stolen yesterday from its "First Ladies" exhibit. The collection was insured by the fair management for $100,000.
John J. McCloy, former Assistant Secretary of War, yesterday denied charges by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, that a wartime policy had let "undesirables" into the Army.

ST. LOUIS, March 11 -- The conference of the National Society for Prevention of Blindness was told today that an experimental drug, diamox, was proving "most exciting" in the treatment of the serious eye disease, glaucoma.

Rear Admiral Henry Shipman Cone, who retired Aug. 31, died Wednesday of injuries suffered in a fall or jump from a fifth-floor window of St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens. He had been a patient there for a number of weeks.
LONDON, March 11 -- The House of Lords devoted an entire afternoon of debate today to the case of Paul Garland who was expelled from the Boy Scouts for being a Communist.

The Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service will complete within a few days the conversion of two war-built cargo vessels into heavy-lift ships capable of handling railroad locomotives and other bulky items as easily as a shoreside steam shovel scoops up a few yards of earth.
The Studebaker Corporation, leading "independent" in the automotive industry, had an 81.2 per cent setback in earnings last year despite a gain of 1.5 per cent in sales.

The defense of the Middle East against Soviet aggression is essential to our own security and that of the free world. That's why we helped to defend Greece and to arm Turkey. On the same principle of providing weapons for those able and willing to use them in self-defense we're now offering military aid to Pakistan.
In introducing Yanni Evangelides as the designer of its custom order salon yesterday at this store, Bonwit Teller presented no unseasoned neophyte.

The Navy is still looking hard though unsuccessfully for the 14,460 rounds of three-inch ammunition it lost overboard in Gravesend Bay. The Navy is quite unhappy about the whole thing and especially so since it turned out yesterday that the shells are live.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams reluctantly suggested yesterday that small taxicabs should be tried here for thirty months.

Shipments of rayon and acetate in yarn and staple fiber in February totaled 80,900,000 pounds, a figure close to shipments in January, but 11 per cent under those in February, 1953, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Americans soon may be able to eat their stored butter at a bargain price, but they will still pay in the end.

Although the Police Band was dissolved Feb 8 by Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams, it will perform in its usual style next Wednesday when the Irish march up Fifth Avenue in the St. Patrick's Day parade.

Geraldo Ramos Valdes of Havana, better known as Nino, the Little One, will meet James J. Parker, a native. Canadian who now lives in Paterson, N. J., in the main bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The are scheduled to box ten rounds.
An off-duty policeman, who had just said good-night to his fiancee, was shot and critically wounded by a would-be hold-up man in Brooklyn early yesterday.
PARIS, March 11 -- Experts here agreed today that the principal problem for the negotiations soon to begin over the Saar would be economic.

Edward R. Murrow, named last night as having been an adviser for a planned summer session of Moscow University, was listed among twenty-five outstanding United States educators apparently connected with the project.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- The Senate Labor Committee unanimously approved President Eisenhower's nomination of J. Ernest Wilkins of Chicago to be Assistant Secretary of Labor.
The outlaw dock strike got worse yesterday.

Four new films will open at local theatres this morning. "Night People," a Twentieth Century-Fox Technicolor production filmed in CinemaScope with Gregory Peck, Broderick Crawford, Anita Bjork and Rita Gam, is at the Roxy. Nunnally Johnson produced, directed and wrote the screen play from a story by Jed Harris and Thomas Reed. Walter Abel, Buddy Ebsen, Casey Adams and Jill Esmond head the supporting cast.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Department store sales in the week ended March 6 were 11 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The Court of Appeals rejected today a motion by James J. Moran, former Deputy Fire Commissioner of New York City, for a reargument on his extortion sentence.
William White, president of the New York Central Railroad Company, had two important visitors in his offices at 230 Park Avenue yesterday: Clint W. Murchison and Sid W. Richardson.

NEW ORLEANS, March 11 -- The latest tests on children with the anti-polio vaccine have revealed that the vaccine provides the body with lasting defensive powers against the three types of viruses causing the disease, it was reported tonight.

TAMPA, Fla., March 11 (AP) -- M/Sgt. Huelet L. Benner, defending champion, was top man in today's shooting and moved ahead for the over-all title in the sixteenth annual midwinter pistol championships today.
Congratulations on your story about the Morgan Library acquiring the "oldest book." Your reporter, Sanka Knox, handled decidedly difficult material with wonderful clarity.

THOSE unable to await the opening of the statewide trout season, normally opening on the second Saturday in April, can compete with the crowds at the special rainbow trout season scheduled for the Finger Lakes streams on April 1.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 11 -- The French campaign that is being planned against the Vietminh forces for next winter is based on the belief of French military circles here that the Communist military strength cannot be increased. It is considered certain the Red forces cannot expand at the rate at which the Vietnamese National Army is growing.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Atomic Energy Commission said tonight that twenty-eight Americans and 236 natives were "unexpectedly" subjected to "some radiation" during the recent atomic test in the Marshall Islands but all those exposed were "reported well."

AVON, Conn., March 11 -- Registered Republicans in this town of 4,000 will be asked at a caucus March 18 to make a "choice" between President Eisenhower and Senator Joseph McCarthy as the leader of the Republican party in the nation.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., March 11 -- Fires of suspicious origin in two separate parts of the Washington Junior High School here caused $20,000 to $25,000 damage today but failed to suspend classes for any of the 900 pupils.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) -- The Government "soon will be at the mercy of General Motors" on any new contracts for Army tanks, Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said today.
The interesting recipe appearing today for a Bengal-style lamb curry comes to us from Richard Kent, an American of British birth.
MIAMI, March 11 (AP) -- Turn-to, winner of Hialeah's Flamingo Stakes and now being pointed for the Kentucky Derby, left by train today for Lexington, Ky., to begin his spring campaign.

THE town will have an extraordinary visitor a week from today. Col Bernt Balchen is expected to arrive here then by plane from Thule in Greenland with O-Tah, one of the four Eskimos who reached the North Pole with Robert Peary on April 6, 1909.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 11 -- Ecuador proposed today that an extraordinary conference be held next year to study aspects of rights in the continental shelf.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 11 -- The Soviet Union is only one step from active participation as a contributor to the United Nations Technical Assistance Administration.
The nation's production of steel dropped to 7,083,000 net tons last month -- a decline of 20.7 per cent compared with the same month last year.

Twenty-six public loaders on the Brooklyn waterfront were accused yesterday of failing to file Federal income tax returns for 1950, 1951 and 1952. United States Attorney Leonard P. Moore filed criminal information charging the men with concealing incomes totaling $580,000.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Following is the text of the Department of the Army's report on the "Schine case":
American families are changing -- some are in serious trouble and may break down -- but generally they are not dying out.

Britain's Conservative Government has won the fifth successive by-election While it is true that the elections were in traditionally Conservative constituencies, the significant feature of this series of victories is that in every case the candidates won by a larger vote than their predecessors.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, March 11 (Reuters) -- The 83,000-ton Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth reported on her arrival here today that two passengers had suffered broken bones, social events had been caneceled and interior decorations were smashed in the vessel's stormiest Atlantic crossing of the winter.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., March 11 -- (AP)J. P. Richards, owner of radio station WCEM here, tonight cancelled the Fulton Lewis Jr. program on which Senator McCarthy appeared to answer critics.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 11 -- The Puerto Rican Commonwealth Government assured the people today that it maintains its "profound respect for civil rights" despite recent arrests it held necessary for the island's security.

Jean Follett's "paintings" at the Hansa Gallery depend largely on materials other than paint, and might more aptly be called constructions. She has incorporated wisps of wire, tools and metal in compositions that invoke associations with ritualistic primitive art.

The 1953 Heywood Broun Award for the year's best journalistic work in the Broun spirit will go to Ralph S. O'Leary, a reporter for The Houston Post, for a series of articles on the Houston chapter of the Minute Women of the U. S. A., Inc.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UP) -- Americans cut down on their cigarette smoking last year for the first time since the tobacco scarcity of World War II, the Agriculture Department said today.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., March 11 (AP) -- The Army's largest peacetime paratrooper and equipment drop since World War II brought death to two jumpers today and hospitalized thirty here. About fifty other men suffered minor injuries.

All who go down to the sea in ships may well pause a moment today in memory of Andrew Furuseth, whose long struggles, resulting in the Seaman's Act of 1915, struck the shackles of peonage from seamen who, until then, had been liable to imprisonment for leaving their jobs.

Buying improved yesterday at the two toy shows here. Reports from the American Toy Fair at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels and in private showrooms indicated that buying was running on a par with last year's market. Importers at the International Toy Exhibit at the Governor Clinton Hotel noted fair to good volume.
The United States delegation to the Tenth Inter-American Conference at Caracas is extricating itself from economic entanglements in skillful manner.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 11 -- A wind-and-dust storm that threatened to blow the athletes out of Maricopa County caused the cancellation of today's exhibition game between the Giants and the Cubs.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 11 -- Casey Stengel and his Yankees today got their first glimpse of the 1954 model Brave -- a cast quite a few believe the Bombers will be seeing again next October in the world series. If, after it was all over, the Ol' Perfessor still had any doubts it could only have been on the score of whether his own lads would make it.
ALBANY, March 11 -- Governor Dewey is planning to discuss two major aspects of the harness racing scandals in a special message to the Legislature tomorrow.
CHICAGO, March 11 -- Sharp declines in wheat and soybeans carried other grains down today and the Board of Trade markets generally had a heavy undertone.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 11 -- Election Commission clerks began today a check of 6,330 signatures that demand the recall of Mayor George Dempster.

BONN, Germany, March 11 -- The Federal Government's tax reform bill, reducing income and corporation taxes by 2,300,000,000 Deutsche marks (almost $550,000,000) was submitted today to the Bundesrat or upper house.
BOSTON, March 11 (AP) -- Textron, Inc., went to court today to back up its offer of stock and cash in exchange for a controlling interest in the far-flung American Woolen Company empire.

MIAMI, March 11 -- Tonight the Dodger regulars produced a batting punch for the first time. A three-run homer by Duke Snider in the first inning and a grand slam by Billy Cox in the third -- both off Murry Dickson -- put the game beyond reach of the Phillies, who were beaten, 8 -- 3.
Action on the bill before the State Legislature to permit the sale of liquor in the Broadway theatres has been deferred because there is "no chance of it passing during the present session."

Although Ben Hogan has announced that he will limit his tournament golf this year and consequently let his British open crown go by default, a visiting Britsh golf official yesterday expressed the hope that Hogan would cross the seas again.

NEWARK, March 11 -- A contest for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator was assured late tonight when City Commissioner Salvatore A. Bontempo, Director of Public Affairs, entered the April 20 primary race.

BERLIN, March 7 -- What its designers believe to be one of the largest public libraries in Europe has, with United States aid, been built on the very doorstep of the Communist world. It is only four blocks from the Soviet sector of Berlin.

Dr. Benjamin Spock, whose book on baby and child care has served as an authority for millions of puzzled young mothers and fathers, declared Wednesday night that he wished parents would "stop taking professional people so seriously."

As New York has grown in size so has the amount of man-caused unsightliness. Wherever one goes around the city, whatever extremes in business and residential districts are seen, there is always the unpleasant evidence -- discarded papers, edibles, broken umbrellas, crates and cartons.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 11 (Reuters) -- Capt. Gerald Griffiths, 43, today was sentenced to five years' imprisonment and dismissed from the British Army for having ill-treated Africans while fighting anti-white Mau Mau terrorists. He had been acquitted of murder last November.

Your appraisal of the proposed "City 'Wagner Act'" as an "Impossible, ambitious and impractical idea" reflects less good judgment and imagination than is your custom. The city employe today is without doubt the clearest victim of underprivilege in the American economy, primarily because of the denial to the city employes of true collective bargaining. It is this denial of genuine collective bargaining which the proposed municipal Wagner Labor Relations Law, is intended to remedy.

An encouraging picture of the military situation in Indo-China has been drawn by Malcolm MacDonald, British High Commissioner for Southeast Asia, who has just completed a month-long survey on the spot. He believes that the plan of General Navarre, which is based primarily on the build-up of the Vietnamese Army, is being successfully accomplished, and the result should be apparent later this year.

LOS ANGELES, March 11 -- The city's Board of Education today began a study of the possibility of excluding from the public schools state-imposed textbooks considered too "progressive" or otherwise undesirable.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Col. Frank H. Schwable described today how a mature man could be conditioned to accept as real the fictions he had invented to appease the Communists.
ALBANY, March 11 -- Republican leaders were convinced today that they could bring this year's session of the Legislature to a close by the end of next week.
A zipper that won't stick or jam is ready for immediate distribution, according to Alexander Konoff, president of Conmar Products Corporation.

A year ago the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People started a ten-year campaign to clear away the remaining racial barriers by 1963, the centennial of Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation. On Wednesday President Eisenhower spoke at a Washington meeting of the N. A. A. C. P. pledging the continued support of his Administration in the campaign against discrimination "based on inconsequential facts of color or race."
Landlords who continue to violate the housing laws may find their rents cut. This threat was made yesterday by Mrs. Bernice Rogers, Deputy Commissioner of Housing.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 11 -- This capital's parliamentary elections ended quietly tonight after three days of violence and irregularities that impressed Iranian and foreign observers by their candor and extent.
MOSCOW, Friday, March 12 -- Vyacheslav M. Molotov declared in a Moscow election address last night that the Soviet Union was seeking no special security position in Europe.

Thomas Jefferson and Christopher Columbus High Schools gained the semi-final round in city Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship before 6,000 spectators at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Jefferson defeated Lafayette, 79 -- 58, while Columbus downed Taft, 69 -- 47.
The new issue of State of Israel development bonds yielding 4 per cent has been cleared for public offering by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
CHICAGO, March 11 (AP) -- Movements in the livestock markets today, as reported by the Department of Agriculture, follow:

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 11 -- The United States called on the Tenth Inter-American Conference today to issue a "simple, clear and direct" warning to the leaders of international communism to keep hands off the Americas.

The 1953-54 "Friends of the Philharmonic" campaign ended yesterday with a tea at Gracie Mansion in honor of 250 regional chairmen and campaign workers from the five boroughs of New York, and Westchester, Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) --The Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives today approved a bill carrying $410,335,000 for flood control and navigation projects in the fiscal year to start July 1.
Prices on popular cuts of veal showed a downward trend this week, the Consumer's Service Bureau of the City Department of Markets reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 11 -- Enthusiasm for cooperative effort is on the rise among Yugoslav peasants, Edwin R. Henson of Washington reported today. Popular reaction to the relaxation of governmental control over community projects has been a genuine stimulus toward voluntary participation, Mr. Henson declared.

ROME, March 11 -- Premier Mario Scelba's Government suffered a grave setback this morning when, under fire, it announced that the chief of national police had been suspended at his own request. This development came little more than twenty-four hours after the Government had received a vote of confidence.

BERLIN, March 11 (UP) -- A naturalized United States citizen disclosed today that he had risked arrest and a long prison term to woo his stepdaughters from communism and smuggle them out of the Soviet zone of Germany.
Four young librarians at the Brooklyn Public Library, here from England in an exchange plan, seemed yesterday to be well along toward becoming, on their return, goodwill ambassadors for Brooklyn.
The Morelana Act Commission investigating harness racing announced yesterday it had found only three state employes who owned stock in trotting tracks or affiliated corporations.
A few scattered friends and admirers will pay tribute today to the memory of Andrew Furuseth, on the hundredth anniversary of the great sea labor leader's birth.
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 11 (UP) -- Pat Torza of Hartford, Conn., sank two 15-foot putts in succession today to advance into the semi-finals of the Florida East Coast women's golf championship.
Edward M. M. Warburg, general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, was honored last night at a dinner in recognition of his fifteen years of effort in behalf of needy Jews over the world.
This will be a year of tough competition but prices will remain generally stable, Paul H. Nystrom, president of the Limited Price Variety Stores Association, predicted yesterday.

LONDON, March 11 (AP) -- World steel production last year set a record of 230,000,000 tons but the rate of increase may slacken "unless there is a sharp recovery of general business activity in the United States," the British Iron and Steel Federation said today.

Operations of the Santa Fe Railway System in 1953 resulted in a net income of $77,185,997, according to the report issued yesterday by F. G. Gurley, president. This compares with $70,737,705 a year earlier.

RED BANK, N. J., March 11 -- An official of a Catholic War Veterans post withdrew tonight previous protests directed at a B'nai B'rith film on community prejudice and in effect apologized to townspeople here for having passed out "erroneous" information.

MONTREAL, March 11 (Canadian Press) -- Thomas W. Eadie, president of the Bell Telephone Company of Canada, reported today that the company's earned surplus stood at more than $14,000,000 at the end of 1953. Addressing the seventy-fourth annual meeting of company shareholders, Mr. Eadie said the surplus, "which is equivalent to dividend payments for little more than seven months," is not adequate.

Forty-eight Democratic district leaders wrangled for two and one-half hours yesterday trying to select a successor to Kenneth F. Sutherland as Kings County leader, but the only agreement was to hold another meeting on April 8.

"Minutes of the Last Meeting," a new book by Gene Fowler, has been scheduled for April 2 publication by Viking Press. It is about Sadakichi Hartmann, a "half - Japanese, half - German wraith," described on the book's jacket as "poet, self-proclaimed genius, artful rogue and moocher sans pareil."

A Manhattan peak-hour traffic ban on parking, loading and unloading at curbs will be extended Tuesday to Brooklyn. The "all-rolling" regulation has been in effect since Dec. 1 on four major crosstown arteries and on one-way avenues in Manhattan.

Style: rich; material: intricate. ;That m/ght serve as a general comment -on "The Golden Apple," which was acted and sung at the Phoenix last evening. It is a satire written by John Latouche with music by Jerome bioross, and an enchanting prod/ction designed by Wi/liam and Jean Eckart with vivid costumes by Alvin Colt.
ALBANY, MARCH 11 -- Governor Dewey urged the Legislature today to appropriate $50,000 to establish a program of experimental classes for children who are seriously retarded mentally.

ROSLYN, L. I., March 11 -- The Air Force is extending the eyes and ears of its aircraft warning network 250 miles to sea along the Eastern Seaboard by using hundreds of coastal vessels that normally sail those waters.

HONG KONG, March 11 -- Communist China's first nation-wide census has been completed in more than three-fifths of the country, the Peiping radio said tonight in an overseas broadcast. The broadcast said findings in all parts of the country had revealed a "steady increase in population."

MONTREAL, March 11 (UP) -- Harry Lumley scored his thirteenth shutout of the season and defenseman Jim Thomson got his first goal in three years tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs blanked the Canadiens, 3 -- 0, before 14,516 fans. Montreal took a three-point grip on second place in the National Hockey League.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 11, (AP) -- The Hasty House Farms Stable captured its second stakes event in as many days at Gulf-stream Park as Queen Hopeful, 3-10 choice, outclassed four other 3-year-old fillies in the $10,000 Orchid Stakes before 15,976 today.

The so-called "leadership" of the Republican party in the Senate has shown its contempt for the President, for the welfare of the party and for public opinion by the way in which it has answered the demand for establishment of uniform rules of fair procedure for investigative committees.
The history of the Pacific opened a new chapter this week as Japan took a major step on the long road back from defeat and surrender.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 11 -- Colombia and Peru were reported today to have virtually reached an agreement on the release of Victor Raul Haya de la Torre. The Peruvian radical leader has been in refuge in the Colombian Embassy in Lima for more than five years.

DETROIT, March 11 (UP) -- Glen Skov and Gordie Howe each scored twice tonight as the pacesetting Detroit Red Wings beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 to 2, in a National Hockey League game before 9,291 fans at Olympia.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Unemployment continued to rise in February, but the question of how much has spread confusion and controversy in the Government.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced yesterday that it was scaling down its demands to the Interstate Commerce Commission for a 33 1/3 per cent increase in all commutation fares.

J. D. SCOTT'S "The End of an Old Song"* is almost a good novel. It is written with much verbal facility and even with a stern, bleak sort of beauty that is entirely in keeping with its melancholy theme and with its setting in the lowlands of Scotland. Mr. Scott is quite knowing about certain general types of character and several representative human emotions.

The annual exhibition of work by candidates who have been nominated for grants of $1,000 each from the National Institute of Arts and Letters opens to the public tomorrow at the American Academy Galleries, Broadway between 155th and 156th Streets.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 11 (UP) -- Art Larsen, of San Leandro, Calif., defending champion, defeated Lorne Main of Vancouver, B. C., in the quarter-final of the Masters tennis tournament tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy struck back tonight at criticism of him by Adlai E. Stevenson, Edward R. Murrow and Senator Ralph E. Flanders.
MEXICO CITY, March 11 (UP) -- Mexico dominated track and field, swimming, basketball, tennis and baseball in the Central American games today.
In State Supreme Court yesterday both sides rested in one of the most unusual maritime cases ever tried in New York County.
PARIS, March 11 -- The Tunisian reform plan designed to compromise differences between Nationalists and the local French population was attacked today by both sides.

The State Supreme Court denied a motion yesterday by WOR that a temporary injunction be granted to prevent picketing of the station's radio and television studios by members of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L.

BERLIN, March 11 -- Some officials in West Berlin are concerned over what they suspect is a Communist campaign to discredit the West by planting reports in the Western press that can easily be disproved. They point out that in recent days several such stories have appeared.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Senate disregarded Administration wishes in voting today to put Hawaiian and Alaskan statehood proposals into a single bill.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- Red Star, the organ of the Soviet Ministry of Defense, cited today a number of marshals, generals, admirals and other military figures who had been nominated for Sunday's general elections as evidence of what it called "the basic closeness and unity of the Army and the people."

Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, former President of Cuba, phoned a statement from Miami yesterday seeking to refute an assertion by President Fulgencio Batista on Wednesday that Dr. Prio had "protected" Communist elements during his regime. General Batista overthrew Dr. Prio two years ago this week.

A contempt-of-court action for failure to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating subversive activities was instituted yesterday against an American employed by a United Nations agency in Paris.

DETROIT, March 11 -- A tempered iPered criticism of the plan for mass vaccin, ati0n of children against infantile-paralysis this i spring and summer was made today by one of the leading re-earch men in that field.

BERLIN, March 11 -- Some officials in West Berlin are concerned over what they suspect is a Communist campaign to discredit the West by planting reports in the Western press that can easily be disproved. They point out that in recent days several such stories have appeared.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Senate disregarded Administration wishes in voting today to put Hawaiian and Alaskan statehood proposals into a single bill.

MOSCOW, March 11 -- Red Star, the organ of the Soviet Ministry of Defense, cited today a number of marshals, generals, admirals and other military figures who had been nominated for Sunday's general elections as evidence of what it called "the basic closeness and unity of the Army and the people."

Dr. Carlos Prio Socarras, former President of Cuba, phoned a statement from Miami yesterday seeking to refute an assertion by President Fulgencio Batista on Wednesday that Dr. Prio had "protected" Communist elements during his regime. General Batista overthrew Dr. Prio two years ago this week.

CAMP GORDON, Ga., Friday, March 12 (UP) -- Pvt. G. David Schine, subject of a controversy over his purported soft life in the Army at Fort Dix, is receiving a rugged soldier's training at Camp Gordon, Army officials reported tonight.

Mayor Wagner, Borough President Hulan E. Jack and Park Commissioner Robert Moses are scheduled to speak at 3:30 P. M. today at the opening of a new boathouse in Central Park. The structure is situated at the Seventy-second Street lake, off the East Drive,
Prices on the New York commodity exchanges were generally lower yesterday. Coffee led the decline with a drop of almost the 200-point daily limit. Cocoa was strong, rising the 100-point limit.

SAN MATEO, Calif., March 11 (AP) -- Willie Shoemaker rode four winners today at the Bay Meadows Race Track, but the fans reserved their biggest hand for a little Japanese-American who scored his first victory in three starts.

CANBERRA, Australia, March 11 (Reuters) -- Qantas Empire Airways, owned by the Australian Government, will soon buy out the British and New Zealand Government interests in British Commonwealth Pacific Airlines as a prelude to speeding up Pacific air services, it was reported here today.

Last night's concert at the Museum of Modern Art by a small orchestra under the direction of Emanuel Vardi brought the pleasant discovery that concertgoers are not always hostile to programs of contemporary music.
BOSTON, March 11 -- Except for the slight hope that mathematics might bring them, the Rangers are out of the running for a play-off berth in the National Hockey League race.

The Ohio Oil Company last year had a consolidated net income of $43,539,172 after charges and taxes, or $6.63 a share, the company reported yesterday. This compared with $39,354,021 or $6 a share in 1952. Net sales and other income increased to $243,655,000 from $225,693,377 in 1952.

A four-hour "last-ditch" fight by Bronx property owners in a public hearing yesterday succeeded in blocking temporarily action by the Board of Estimate on the controversial Castle Hill housing project in the Bronx.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 11 (AP) -- Louise Suggs, top money winner last year, rallied strongly today to take the first-round lead in the women titleholders' golf tournament with a 73.

Public patience is being strained by lack of effective steps to end air pollution in New York City. Aroused citizens are not impressed by melodramatic gestures of a few inspectors personally led by the Commissioner meeting in a cafeteria and swooping down on scattered offending landlords.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The attack on the problem of smoke pollution in the New York City area would be placed on a bi-state basis under a bill approved unanimously in the Senate today.
HONOLULU, March 11 (UP) -- The United States is expected to set off the mightiest nuclear explosion in history sometime between March 15 and 28 at the isolated Eniwetok-Bikini proving grounds.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 11 -- The Southern California Theatre Owners Association has called on Twentieth Century-Fox to "put it up to the public itself" to decide whether stereophonic sound is essential, as the company insists, to the most advantageous showing of CinemaScope movies.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., March 11 (AP) -- The Sullivan County Draft board admitted today it had sent a draft questionnaire to an Army colonel who is retired after forty-one years in uniform. But the board couldn't say why.
Forty-two hundred aspiring young journalists invaded the Columbia University campus yesterday in search of the Who, What, When, Where and Why.
ANKARA, Turkey, March 11 -- Following President Celal Bayar's trip to the United States, Turkey is preparing to intensify a drive to attract United States investors.

BUENOS AIRES, March 11 -- Juan D. Peron has promised to release $500,000 for remittance to United States film companies. Although no contract was signed, the promise was made by the president to Eric Johnston, head of the Motion Picture Association, during the latter's visit to attend the opening ceremonies of the film festival at Mar Del Plata.

Surrogate George Frankenthaler directed yesterday that the will of Mrs. Eleanor Morgan Satterlee be admitted to probate, except for the provisions of the residuary clause that have been contested by her sister, Mrs. Mabel Satterlee Ingalls. The will has been the subject of two trials.

BUENOS AIRES, March 11 -- One of the world's finest private collections of art became the property of Argentina's National Museum of Fine Arts today. Judge Diogenes Santiallan Villar ordered museum authorities to take possession of nine works, including a nude of Correggio and Goya's Love and Psyche.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Ambassador Vladimir Popovic of Yugoslavia said today he was "more hopeful" than ever for a settlement of the long-standing Trieste dispute.
WASHINGTON, March 11 -- The Administration will need the votes of some Democrats to win a showdown battle next week against higher personal income tax exemptions.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Ondine" Monday night at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre for the benefit of the Homemaker Service and the Foster Home Department of the Children's Aid Society. Mrs. Robert J. Lewis and Mrs. Jarvis Cromwell are co-chairmen of the executive committee in charge of the plans for the event.
LONDON, March 11 -- The British Government rejected today a Labor Opposition demand that the conscription term be cut from two years to eighteen months.
The Port of New York Authority reported yesterday a record gross revenue of $59,241,848 for 1953, a 10.1 per cent increase over that of 1952.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 11 -- The ability of Queen Elizabeth II to meet unfamiliar situations is making it easier for her to undergo the repetitive programs of welcome in her tour of Australia.
ALBANY, March 11 -- The Assembly approved unanimously today without debate a bill designed to protect public school pupils from being molested by loiterers and to help curb vandalism in the schools.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 11 (AP) -- The four-day trial of the stockholders suit of Louis Schiff and Jacob Sack of New York to halt the sale of R. K. O. Pictures stock to Howard Hughes closed today in the Court of Chancery, with opposing counsel directed to file briefs by Tuesday and reply briefs by next Saturday.

LONDON, March 11 -- Arguments about the French share appeared tonight to be the only obstacle to an agreement on the division of interests in the consortium that is to approach Iran about taking over oil production there.

Julio Pinto Gandia, leader of the New York branch of the Puerto Rican Nationalist party, was sentenced yesterday to six months in prison for refusing to answer questions before a Federal grand jury investigating the party.

The Eastern railroads filed tariffs with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday that would drastically reduce freight rates on manufactured iron and steel articles. The new rates range from 18 to 20 per cent below present ones. Unless suspended by the I. C. C., they will become effective on March 26.

LONDON, March 11 -- Improvement in British Government securities dominated attention in the stock markets here today. The rise at first was slow but the pace quickened and by the close some funds had risen as much as seven shilling sixpence ($1.05).

BATON ROUGE, La., March 11 (AP) -- Ted Kroll and A1-Besselink, a pair of long-driving New Yorkers, twisted a strong wind into an ally today to share a one-stroke lead in the $10,000 Baton Rouge open with six-under-par 66's.

WASHINGTON, March 11 -- Charles Sparks Thomas, Assistant Secretary of Defense, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be Secretary of the Navy. Mr. Thomas, if confirmed by the Senate, will suc ceed Robert B. Anderson, who will become Under Secretary of Defense when Roger B. Kyes vacates the post on May 1. A successor to Mr. Thomas has not yet been chosen.

GENEVA, March 11 -- A clash between East and West over the question of inviting German representatives to the meeting here of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe threatened today to affect discussion of the reports of technical committees.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Army today announced the names of seventy additional men, listed for more than a year as missing in action in Korea, who are new presumed to be dead. The new list included the following from the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut area:
The nation's merchant fleet ate its way through $97,326,400 of food in 1953, and housewives probably will appreciate that more than one-half of the bills were for meat.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -President Eisenhower left Washington for a quiet country weekend this afternoon after discussing the counterattack Vice President Richard M. Nixon will make on the Democratic party tomorrow night.

Two of the larger member firms of the New York Stock Exchange are merging. Francis I. duPont Co. of New York and James E. Bennett Co. of Chicago, with sixty-two offices between them, will form the country's second biggest brokerage house in number of offices.

PARIS, March 12 -- When Gen. Paul-Henri Ely, French Chief of Staff, visits Washington soon, he is expected to emphasize the view held here that a solution of the Indo-Chinese war depends above all on the United States.

Dolores Wilson, the American soprano who made her debut last February in "Lucia," took on the role of Rosina last night for the first time in her Metropolitan career. The refurbished production of Rossini's "Barber of Seville" also had, as major members of the cast, Cesare Valletti, Gerhard Pechner, Frank Guarrera and Cesare Siepi. Alberto Erede again conducted.

Nino Valdes gained the decision over James J. Parker in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The decision in favor of the Cuban heavyweight was unanimous, but the contest was so dull that the crowd booed as if the award were an injustice.

Although it may seem at first glance to be a domestic matter on which the outside world has little legitimate claim to interest, the bill passed by the lower house of the Japanese Diet legalizing wholesale poisoning of dogs in Japan, on the theory that this would wipe out rabies, will shock the conscience of civilized people everywhere.

May I here commend your excellent editorial of March 3 in which you discussed the Puerto Rican shooting incident in Washington. You correctly point out the irrational and destructive strains in certain forms of nationalism and rightly link them with the wave of assassinations which swept around the world from the Eighteen Sixties to the early years of this century.
