The hardware industry is making all sorts of plans for what it calls not only the industry's biggest promotion, but the biggest ever seen in advertising. It calls the event irha Hardware Week, and makes a point of the lowercase letters, which stand for Independent Retail Hardwaremen of America and identify member stores.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- A $5,000 race at Gulfstream Park appeared today to be attracting more interest than the mile-and-a-quarter $50,000 added Gulfstream Park Handicap on the same program tomorrow.

LONDON, March 12 -- When the House of Commons rose today, after a sitting that had lasted 22 hours 22 minutes, some members felt they should forget about their proposed rise in pay and just put in for overtime.
ASPEN, Colo., March 12 (UP) -- Darrell Robison of Salt Lake City won the giant slalom today with a time of 2:14.2 in the Roch Cup competition at the national ski meet.

Robert R. Young placed his case for control of the New York Central Railroad Company yesterday before that section of Wall Street opinion represented by the New York Society of Security Analysts. William White, president of the road, is scheduled to address the same group on Monday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 12 -Even after the Giants had blasted Mike Garcia en route to a 13-5 victory over the Indians today, Leo Durocher had his worries. Johnny Antonelli, obtained from the Braves, walked seven batters in three innings, making twelve passes issued by the left-hander in five spring exhibition innings.

MOSCOW, Saturday, March 13 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov speaking at a pre-election meeting at the Hall of Columns last night, made a strong new appeal in behalf of Soviet security proposals for Europe.

As the Thirty-eighth International Flower Show rounded out its sixth day at Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx yesterday, the weather man continued to smile upon the event. The sunshine streaming through the high-arched glass roof fooled lilacs and other shrubs into blossoming forth as though they were still in a greenhouse.

BERLIN, March 12 -- Peter Grimes, the Massachusetts travel agent who freed his two stepchildren from their Communist grandfather in East Germany and smuggled them into West Berlin, ran into new travel difficulties today.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, March 12 -- A new relationship seems to be developing between the United States armed forces in Germany and the local populace.
Following are the identifications of the persons mentioned in the memoranda released yesterday by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, chairman of the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations:
Members of the clergy and choirs of the Eastern Orthodox church will attend a celebration tomorrow of the 900th anniversary of "the separation between Eastern and Western Christendom."
Stocks sprinted in yesterday's early trading, established new highs since March 27, 1953, and then, full of week-end uncertainties, backed away.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A report that many secret documents are missing from the great atomic energy plant at Hartford, Wash., has started an investigation.

LOS ANGELES, March 12 -- A national convention of educators urged today that the nation's school children should be free to learn about the United Nations organization as a constructive world institution.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that the Board of Examiners of the New York school system had the power to evaluate the previous experience of a teacher before fixing the teacher's salary.
LONDON, March 12 -- The Minister of State of the Board of Trade cautioned today that Britain could no longer afford increases in costs from wage rises not accompanied by increases in productivity.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 12 -- Seven Puerto Ricans and possibly more have been locked up by Venezuelan police in Caracas without charges during the Inter-American Conference, according to a report brought to the attention of Gov. Luis Munoz Marin today by a lawyer here.
CHICAGO, March 12 (UP) -- A billowing dust storm from the Southwest collided with a blizzard from the Northwest today, dumping beige-colored snow over wide areas of the Midwest.

More than 200 retailers and retail association executives will take up legislative matters of importance to merchants at the annual meeting of the American Retail Federation on Tuesday and Wednesday in the Statler Hotel, Washington, D. C.
TYSON'S CORNER, Va., March 12 (UP) -- The Havenner boys told today how they rescued their 3-month-old puppy from the clutches of a large eagle and then captured the eagle's baby.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Secretary Benson today was challenged to bare the Administration's butter surplus disposal plans to stop speculation in the cottonseed oil market.
BONN, Germany, March 12 -- Despite prospective objections at the United Nations, a former member of the Nazi party was appointed today West Germany's permanent observer there.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- Senator William E. Jenner announced that his Senate internal security subcommittee would launch a public investigation Wednesday "into the handling of Communist files by the armed services."
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 12 -- Vietminh troops closing in around Dienbienphu yesterday provoked a sharp widespread outbreak of fighting at the French airfield bastion on the Tonkin-Laos border.
Grievous errors have been committed in the raising of children because too many bewildered parents have accepted too much untested advice.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, March 12 (UP) -- Penn State upset Louisiana State and its lanky center, Bob Pettit, 78 to 70, to gain the regional final of the National Collegiate basketball tournament before 8,000 fans in the Iowa University Fieldhouse tonight.

In the operation of a society and an economy as complex as that of this country complete and accurate statistics are as essential as are good weather data for aviators. It is this fact that gives special significance to the report on means of improving the work of the Bureau of the Census which a special committee has submitted to Secretary of Commerce Weeks.
Two Women's Swimming Association girls, Carol Giardine and Carin Cone, kept senior metropolitan A A. U. championships in the W. S. A. pool last night. Both won easily.
Boys High School of Brooklyn won the Public Schools Athletic League indoor track and field championship for the eighth straight time last night.

The fantastic story of the efforts of Senator McCarthy and his right-hand man, Roy M. Cohn, to bludgeon the Army into giving special privileges to their colleague Pvt. G. David Schine has at last come to light. The restraint of Army officials from Secretary Stevens down in withholding this remarkable tale from public view is a tribute to their powers of self-control.

Carl Gerosa has purchased the business property 50 by 86 feet at 310-12 East 149th Street in the Bronx and will replace the present two-story building with a two-story office and store structure. The second floor in the new building, which will be air-conditioned, has been leased by the Prudential Insurance Company.
NEW DELHI, India, March 12 -- India's Communists lost a disorderly round in Parliament this week.
Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, announced yesterday that Harry (Bobby) Sand had been named records officer.

Net earnings last year of the Underwood Corporation, a leading manufacturer of typewriters, was $844,923, or $1.13 a comomn share, the annual report disclosed yesterday. It was the most unfavorable result for any year since 1932, when the company had a loss of $762,071.

For the last five days fourteen Navy divers have been groping about the bottom of Gravesend Bay looking for 14,460 "satisfied" but loaded three-inch shells in their canisters, aluminum or blue containers thirty-seven inches long and six inches in diameter.

The Moreland Act Commission that has been investigating harness racing said yesterday that it had erronously characterized as innocent of "impropriety" an employe of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board who owned raceway stock.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The State Court of Appeals ruled today that three defendants in the murder of a payroll messenger for Reader's Digest were entitled to a hearing by the Westchester County Court on their application for a new trial.

Maurice Schwartz may come to the rescue of the Yiddish theatre that once flourished along Second Avenue. He has been asked to take over the Second Avenue Theatre for the presentation of Yiddish productions next season.
Two-thirds of the 1,800,000 income taxpayers in upper Manhattan are apparently awaiting the Monday midnight deadline before filing.

Representatives of several racial and religious groups appealed yesterday to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to end "tenant selection policies" in the Parkchester housing project in the Bronx.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., March 12 (AP) -- The United Electrical Workers Union, independent, said tonight that it had obtained a Federal injunction forbidding its largest local from taking any steps to secede.

Directors of the Pyrene Manufacturing Company, makers of fire extinguishers, yesterday declared a dividend of $10 a share out of surplus, payable April 8. The last dividend was 30 cents, distributed in December, 1952.
Thirteen persons were indicted yesterday by Federal grand juries on charges of income tax fraud, failure to file returns, or tax evasion.

Father Time is familiar to everyone as he has been pictured for centuries in almanacs and elsewhere, and most of us are acquainted with at least a few members of his large family. Greenwich time is the British uncle of our Eastern, Central, Mountain and Pacific time, all cousins to a less-widely known relative from the maritime provinces of Canada called Atlantic time.

The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 704,917 shares of additional common stock. The issue, the first since September, 1951, is the largest in the company's history.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 12 -- The Senate approved today Belgium's joining the proposed European Defense Community. The vote was 125 to 40, with two abstentions. The Senate vote was the last step in Belgium's parliamentary approval of the treaty establishing the six-nation community. The Chamber of Deputies, or lower house, ratified the pact in November.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 12 -- A Yugoslav Government spokesman today accused Mario Scelba, Premier of Italy, of harming present negotiations on Trieste. According to the spokesman, Signor Scelba did so by recalling the Western powers' statements supporting Italian claims to the territory.

The grip of union leaders who follow Communist party policies is being steadily broken. The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America (Independent), which has been in hot water since 1946, when it was in the C.I.O., with its leaders at that time accused of slavishly adhering to the Communist line, is now apparently about to lose 20,000 members.
The Fashion Group, a noncommercial organization of women engaged in fashion work, gave its second International Fashion show yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

VIENNA, Saturday, March 13 (AP) -- The Prague radio said today Communist Czechoslovakia had protested to the United States against an alleged violation of that country's territory by two United States planes.

Good work appears to have become a habit with the Equity Community Theatre this season. Already credited with superbly managed revivals of "Detective Story" and "The Corn Is Green," the project now has added a third, John Patrick's "The Hasty Heart," which was given its first performance in the DeWitt Clinton High School Auditorium in the Bronx last night.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 12 -- A subcommitee of the Tenth Inter-American Conference of finance and economic ministers agreed today to the desirability of holding a hemisphere economic conference. The unanimity of opinion, although no vote was taken, indicates that the conference is a virtual certainty.
Earnings of the Western Maryland Railway Company during February continued to compare unfavorably with those of a year earlier but they were slightly better than in January.
Just what the title "Loophole" is supposed to mean is never made quite clear in the Palace's new offering, but one thing is sure: it's the tag on a mighty respectable little melodrama.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers:

The five-story house on lot 25 by 103 feet at 18 West Twelfth Street, in Greenwich Village, which was purchased recently by Edward Schwartz, operator, has been resold to Alfred B. Bernstein of Washington, D. C., for renovating. The seller had bought the property from Alice M. Kaplan.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Democrats will soon drop what a spokesman called a "bombshell" in the pending battle over tax legislation. The target will be George M. Humphrey, the Secretary of the Treasury, and his stock holdings in various companies.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said tonight his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations would soon begin a study of "claims of bribery, corruption and fraud" in Government operations in Alaska under the Truman Administration.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 12 -- Hecht-Lancaster Productions has come up with another new property, "The Last Chukker," a story of mystery, intrigue and wild animals set in pre - war Burma.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular but fairly active yesterday, and closing prices were 6 points off to 3 points up.
A woman dress manufacturer and two men were held in high bail yesterday in Felony Court after they had been accused of destroying property in a scheme to collect insurance.
GENEVA, March 12 -- The Soviet Union submitted precise proposals on international trade today to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

By the margin of a single point, Columbia won the epee team title the fifty-seventh Intercollegiate Fencing Association championship began at New York University's Alumni Gymnasium at University Heights yesterday.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago is preparing plans to distribute stock which may be valued at $55,000,000 to its stockholders over a period of years. The distribution will consist of the common stock of the Northern Illinois Gas Company, a new Commonwealth subsidiary, which is now owned by Commonwealth Edison.

Harold Hinton was a good newspaper man, versatile, a fluent, rapid worker, a genial companion with a talent for telling stories well, and a patriotic citizen always ready to answer the call of his country. He had been with The New York Times for more than thirty years, much of his service done in the Washington Bureau, from which he covered at one time or another almost every beat.
Losses from the outlaw dock strike, already reported to be in the millions of dollars, may mount to staggering totals if the walkout continues into next week.

On March 1 you published a letter from Joseph Cromwell Sampson in which the writer denounced progressive income taxes and inheritance taxes as "un-American." There are so may innuendoes and omissions in Mr. Sampson's statement that some answer seems warranted.

Vice President Nixon will deliver an address tonight from 10:30 to 11 o'clock over Channels 2 and 11 and the C. B. S. and N. B. C. radio networks. The speech will be in answer to charges made in a broadcast last week by Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential candidate in 1952.

QUEEN VICTORIA steals the show. Later members of her remarkable clan have more time upon the stage of Pierre Berton's Canada-flavored chronicle, "The Royal Family."* But the lady Kipling called the Widow of Windsor towers above them, as she should, in massive propriety, never letting us underestimate the power of a matriarch.
Twenty-three more West German bond issues will be readmitted to trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Monday, the Exchange announced yesterday.

The rapid rise in demand for frozen foods and the extra efforts put into sales by fresh fruit and vegetable producers should cause the canners to-step up their sales efforts. This was the substance of a talk yesterday by E. E. Willkie of Pacific American Fisheries, Inc., of Bellingham, Wash., before the Utah Canners Association at Salt Lake City.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Following is the text of a series of memoranda to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy regarding the controversy involving Roy Cohn and G. David Schine, released by Senator McCarthy today:
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 12 -- Dinh Xuan Quang, acting Premier of Vietnam, admitted today that the Vietnamese Government maintained secret control over news dispatches sent abroad from Saigon.

A new novel by Louis de Wolh, "The Second Conquest," will be issued March 24 by Lippincott. It is a story that combines science-fiction with Christian philosophy and thinking. Mr. de Wohl is the author of several historical novels, including some about the lives of famous saints.
The Rogers Peet Building at Broadway and Thirteenth Street has been acquired by the 842 Broadway Association, a syndicate headed by Lawrence A. Wien.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today an application by Edward Lamb for renewal of a TV station license at Erie, Pa., was being held up because of charges that he has been a member of the Communist party.

NEWARK, March 12 -- Safety, a whiffle-hound, his master, Peter, and an imp called Danger are on the way to supplanting other imaginary characters in the hearts of youngsters all over the country if the interest in them shown by elementary school children in this area and elsewhere is an indication.
The State Division of Employment caught up last year with 20,749 persons who had claimed unemployment insurance benefits to which they were not entitled.
Mayor Wagner intervened yesterday in the wildcat pier strike that has throttled the Port of New York for eight days.
TOKYO, March 12 -- Japan will ask the United States for seventeen warships including two powerful destroyers.

HELSINKI, Finland, March 12 -- A Finnish trade delegation will leave for Moscow tomorrow to try to arrange a five-year trade agreement providing part payment in gold or hard currencies for Finnish merchandise.
ROSLYN, L. I., March 12 -- The Five Fathom Club of Roslyn High School tested equipment and "skin diving" techniques last night in preparation for an Easter vacation expedition to the Florida keys.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 (AP) -- Navy's Ken McCally dropped in a one-handed set shot with three seconds to play to give the middies a 69-67 victory over Cornell, the Ivy League champion, in a semi-final contest of the Eastern Regional National Collegiate play-offs at the Palestra tonight.

MIAMI, March 12 (AP) -- Club owners of the American and National Leagues announced after separate meetings today that they had approved the recommendations of the major league pension committee, "subject to some minor revisions."

AUGUSTA, Ga., March 12 (AP) -- Louise Suggs held stoutly to her lead at the midway point of the women's Titleholders' golf tournament today despite a competitive course record of 70 turned in by Mrs. Babe Zaharias.
NEW ORLEANS, March 12 (AP) -- Nineteen 3-year-olds were named today to start in the $40,000 added Louisiana Derby tomorrow at the Fair Grounds.
BONN, Germany, March 12 -- The United States planes shot at by a Czech MIG today landed at Neubiberg Air Base, near Munich, with no one hurt.

A Puerto Rican paroled convict was seized by the police in an upper Broadway drugstore telephone booth last night while he was blandly informing Federal agents that he planned to assassinate President Eisenhower.

Builders, contractors, home craftsmen and other citizens are going to pay less for plywood. Yesterday all doubt of a general price break evaporated. M M Woodworking Company, a top producer, put out a price list that will go into effect Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The United Electrical Workers asked for an injunction today to prevent the General Electric Company from suspending workers who decline on Constitutional grounds to testify before Congressional committees.
Adolf Buchler is a name familiar to older New Yorkers, who remember this Hungarian - born baker for his fine pastry shop that was a landmark on Lexington Avenue for more than thirty years.

MIAMI, March 12 -- The Red Sox of Boston came into Miami Stadium tonight with a record of having won five straight games by one run. When the game had ended their winning streak had ended with it -- and the only thing preserved was the one-run margin.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 12 (2P) -- Ted Wells of Wichita, Kan., captured the international midwinter Snipe class regatta today without winning a heat.

ROME, March 12 (AP) -- Demands mounted tonight on Premier Mario Scelba for a quick and thorough investigation of alleged scandal in high places in the Italian Government. The situation already has resulted in the resignation of Dr. Tommaso Pavone as national police chief.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Two Chicago export houses and their former Washington representative were penalized today for alleged bribery of a Department of Commerce employe.

LONDON, March 12 -- The British Government has suggested to the Egyptian Government that it cease its running campaign of anti-British propaganda in the Sudan if it seriously wants an early agreement on the Suez Canal base.
Daniel Rybb, concert manager and contrabass player of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, will present a series of ten "pop" concerts in Carnegie Hall beginning May 7.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- John G. Adams, a South Dakota lawyer, has been counselor of the Army Department since Oct. 1, 1953.

ROME, March 12 -- The improvement in the Pope's health was underscored today when he received a committee of three cardinals as a special concession made to him by his physician on the fifteenth anniversary of his coronation.
CAMP KILMER, N. J., March 12 -- Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker, Commanding General of this post, has said he has been touched and encouraged by the "loyalty" shown to him from President Eisenhower down.

The Government of the Republic of Egypt has leased a store in the International Building at 630 Fifth Avenue in Rockefeller Center for a tourist bureau and an information center. The store is just off Fifth Avenue between East Fiftieth and Fifty-first Streets.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress for authority today to reallocate for security risk investigations $1,150,000 appropriated for other purposes.

TOKYO, March 12 -- Yahachi Kawai, President of Japan's House of Councilors, urged the Welfare Committee of the upper chamber today to give careful consideration to the bill legalizing the wholesale poisoning of animals in an attempt to wipe out rabies here.
The Brooklyn Diocesan Union of the Holy Name Society has asked the New York State Legislature to authorize mandatory punishment of any student or individual who attacks or injures a teacher.
The American Civil Liberties Union took steps yesterday to set clear its part in the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Edward R. Murrow, Columbia Broadcasting System commentator.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 12 -- The United States delegation is confident the Tenth Inter-American Conference will pass a resolution tomorrow for joint action to be taken by the American republics if any of them came under Communist domination.
CAIRO, March 12 -- The leader of the Egyptian feminist movement announced today she intended to fast "to my last breath" if necessary to win political rights for women.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- No rain of consequence materialized in the Southwest and as a result there was active buying today of both new and old crop wheat futures, both by commission houses and local shorts who had extended their lines on yesterday's forecast for moisture.

ITHACA, N. Y., March 12 (AP) -- Pittsburgh's wrestlers scored two pins and five decisions tonight to place seven of its eight men in the semi-finals of the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championship.
Three New York State school districts announced yesterday plans for the sale of $3,852,000 of bonds.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, announced today that Lieut. Gen. John W. O'Daniel soon would take command of the United States military assistance group in Indo-China.

Stockholders of the Goebel Brewing Company at a special meeting in Detroit yesterday, approved issuance of 200,000 shares of 60-cent convertible preferred stock of $10 par value, subordinate to the present 4 1/2 per cent preferred.

ROME, March 12 -- Italy intends to stabilize her land forces at the present strength of fifteen and one-half infantry divisions. The plan is to improve the quality of units now in existence rather than increase their numerical strength.

LONDON, March 12 -- Britain is eager to arrange preliminary talks with the United States and France on the Geneva conference. These would prepare a common front against expected divisive diplomacy of the Soviet Union and Communist China.

After drinking a pint of whisky in a Harlem apartment, three school girls yesterday pummeled a 13-year-old girl and punched and scratched two teachers in Public School 136, Edge-comb Avenue and 136th Street.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 12 (UP) -- Cary Middlecoff of Memphis battled gusty winds and sliding tee shots today to carve out a one-under-par 71 and a tie with Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., for the lead at the halfway mark of the $10,000 Baton Rouge open golf tournament.

PARIS, March 12 -- Summer muffs and berets in flowered cotton faille or taffeta warp print, worn with dark town ensembles, were a part of the delightful spicing of Dior's boutique collection just inaugurated.
LONDON, March 12 -- British Government securities continued to strengthen and took the limelight on the Stock Exchange here today. They gained much as 11s 3d ($1.57 1/2).
Park Commissioner Robert Moses entered a strong public plea in Mayor Wagner's presence yesterday for continuation of city department bands.

A 21-year-old clerk in the Argentine delegation to the United Nations was sentenced yesterday to a seventy-four day workhouse term by Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh when he was unable to pay a $1,850 fine for thirty-seven unanswered traffic tickets.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's special message to the Legislature today on harness racing:

Coffee prices climbed the 200-point daily limit in all but the spot month yesterday on the New York exchange, while cocoa tumbled the 100-point limit. Other prices moved irregularly with sugar, zinc, copper, potatoes and wool mixed; burlap, hides and lead lower, and cottonseed oil, soybean oil, rubber and tin higher.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 12 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates belted six home runs to rout the Milwaukee Braves, 25 -- 11, in an exhibition today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 12 -- Dr. Mahmoud Azmi of Egypt defended today the restrictions placed by Egypt on Israeli-bound shipping while passing through the Suez Canal and the Gulf of Aqaba. Dr. Azmi told the United Nations Security Council that Egypt was exercising the right of visit, search, and "possibly seizure," and was not imposing a blockade.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The New York Central Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to determine whether the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company had actually sold its large stockholdings in the Central.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 -- A perverse fate continues to take a lot of joy out of the life of Casey Stengel this spring.

Unlike any other voluntary welfare organization, the Red Cross has a Congressional charter that is not merely a license to operate, but a legislative statement of definite responsibilities to the American people.
TRENTON, March 12 -- a detachment of the New Jersey state police has been guarding the Phillipsburg home of Gov. Robert B. Meyner since Wednesday.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Governor Dewey endorsed today the Moreland Act Commission's major recommendations for putting teeth into laws governing harness racing.

SANTA FE, N. M., March 12 -This region has a little style center all its own. Its significance touches some of the most colorful phases of the history of New Mexico. Into it are woven the fashions of Civil War days, costumes of the Indians and the enterprising efforts of a few women from the East and South who adopted Santa Fe as their home a generation or so ago.

The European Defense Community, key to adequate Western defense and further European unification, has advanced another step toward realization with Belgium joining Germany and the Netherlands in completing parliamentary ratification of the six-nation treaty.
MEXICO CITY, March 12 (UP) -- Mexico and Cuba staged their biggest oint-making spree of the Central American games today to lengthen their' one, two. lead in the championship race.

TRENTON, March 12 -- Party leaders viewed with little concern today the eleventh-hour entry of Salvatore A. Bontempo, Newark City Commissioner, into the race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.
ALBANY, March 12 -- Governor Dewey was assailed by a Republican Senator today over public development of new power facilities on the Niagara River, which Mr. Dewey favors.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.1 point over the week ended March 9 to 110.6 from the revised index of 110.7 for the preceding week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said today. Reduced average prices for processed foods more than offset increased average prices for farm products.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- A House Armed Services subcommittee voted today to save two old fighting ships -- the frigate Constellation and Admiral David Farragut's Civil War flagship, the Hartford.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A $6,000,000 economy cut was viewed today as threatening to wreck the educational exchange service of the overseas information and goodwill program.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Broadcasting-Telecasting, a radio television trade journal, praised the industry today for turning down Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's demand for equal time to answer Adlai E. Stevenson's recent attack on the Republican party.
We, members of the City College Club, were shocked by the recent decision of the Board of Higher Education to terminate the services of Prof. Nat Holman.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said Thursday night, after attacking the veracity of Edward R. Murrow, that he chose to stand with Abraham Lincoln who had said:
BONN, Germany, March 12 -- Respect for German war veterans and the release of German war criminals held by the Allies were demanded today by leading West German politicians.

MEXICO CITY, March 12 -- A hard-riding pistol-packing bandit in the old style who has been terrorizing the State of Morelos today offered to give himself up if the Mexican Army granted him a safe conduct.
Edward R. Murrow said last night that he would plead "neither ignorance nor youth" for having served on the advisory council for a summer session in Moscow University in 1935.
Employes of forty-three downtown banks gave 1,225 pints of blood to the Red Cross this week in the regional Blood Program's fourth annual "Bank Week." Last year's contribution was 1,148 pints.

Any child in Queens who is handicapped by orthopedic disabilities, cerebral palsy, rheumatic fever or heart disease is eligible now for an extensive rehabilitation program being conducted at Queens General Hospital. A new diagnostic and rehabilitation center was opened recently in the hospital's Queensboro Pavilion.

EDMONTON, Alberta, March 12 (Canadian Press) -- Increases in Canada's established liquid petroleum reserves continue to outpace the annual production rate. New discoveries and extensions of known pools accounted for a 300,000,000-barrel increase last year.

LONDON, Saturday, March 13 (UP) -The Communist Hungarian news agency announced today that the former head of Hungary's state security authority, Gabor Peter, had been sentenced to life imprisonment for "crimes against the state and the people."
WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole said today it might take months to determine whether 264 persons sprinkled with atomic dust in the Pacific had suffered any injury.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Legislation to consolidate two existing commissions into a bi-state agency to continue studies of rapid transit facilities in the New York metropolitan area was introduced in the Legislature today.

DETROIT, March 12 (AP) -- The industry's big three -- General Motors, Ford and Chrysler -- will account for 97 per cent of this week's automobile output, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. The statistical agency said the three concerns would produce 107,834 of the industry's 111,179 cars.
BERLIN, March 12 -- The Soviet Union has rejected an appeal by the Western commandants in Berlin that the Iron Curtain that divides the city be lifted.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 12 (UP) -- Kurt Nielsen of Denmark, using a cannonball serve and a surprising gamble, outlasted Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, 6 --3, 5 -- 7, 12 -- 10, in the quarterfinal round of the men's singles at the masters invitation tennis tournament today.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Mar. 12 (AP) -- The defending champion, Syracuse University, gained an early lead on points with Army's cadets in close pursuit tonight in opening round action of the thirty-first Eastern intercollegiate boxing tournament.
SEOUL, Korea, March 12 -- South Korean officials have become increasingly outspoken in their attacks on United States policy toward their country.

The largest cargo ship in the world, which dwarfs all commercial ships afloat with the exception of a few passenger liners, is now being outfitted at Kure City, Japan, and is expected to be ready for sea trials in about a month.

Central Park's new boathouse on the Seventy-second Street Lake opened yesterday with Mayor Wagner, Park Commissioner Robert Moses and Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack taking he day's only rowboat ride in the company of three "girl friends," age 6, 7 and 8.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- A poll-taking device providing a secret ballot won a patent this week for Carl C. Ginsburg of Staten Island.
Schoolboy and schoolgirl editors attending a Columbia Scholastic Press Association meeting yesterday displayed a keen interest in communism and some weariness with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Western lumbermen today pressed their complaint to Congress that forest policies of Government agencies are forcing them out of business.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today angrily charged the Army with attempted blackmail in an effort to stop his exposure of Communists. Army authorities promptly declared the assertion was "fantastic."
LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 12 (AP) -Kentucky Democrats today urged former Vice President Alben W. Barkley, who has spent forty-eight of his seventy-six years in public office, to serve six years more.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 12 (UP) -- A second Reagan High School English teacher lost his job today after reading selections from "Studies in Classic American Literature" to his 14- and 15-year-old students.

The deflation of Senator McCarthy (mostly by himself) which has taken place this week will have a decided effect on opinion abroad. The Senator's grandstand plays for publicity have succeeded in making him almost the best-known American in the foreign press.

THE Ontario fishery biologists have been tampering with nature again, and, having created the "splake" by crossing the lake trout and the squaretail, they decided to see what could be done with a pike-muskellunge, combination.
A drive for $4,500,000 in capital funds will be started shortly by the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church.
Mrs. Robert F. Wagner hurried back to Gracie Mansion from Mitchel Field in a helicopter yesterday to keep a luncheon engagement.

NORWALK, Conn., March 12 -The police announced today the arrest of three striking employes of the Hat Corporation of America on charges of burglary with personal violence and aggravated assault in connection with an attack on a man who was employed at the hat factory last February.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -Following are the texts of statements issued today by Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army; John G. Adams, Counsellor of the Department of the Army; Senator Charles E. Potter, Republican of Michigan; and of a joint statement by Senators John L. McClellan of Arkansas; Henry M. Jackson of Washington, and Stuart Symington of Missouri Democrats:
WASHINGTON, March 12 (UP) -- The Export-Import Bank announced today it approved eleven loans for a total of $171,900,000 during the second half of 1953.
MUNICH, Germany, March 12 -- Two United States military planes flying near the Czechoslovak border were attacked today by a Soviet-made MIG jet, Bavarian police reported.

Madison Square Garden will resound to the cheers of basketball devotees from 9 A. M. to past 11 P. M. today. The big arena will house two schoolboy games in the morning, a professional contest in the afternoon and a pair of college games at night.

The taxpayer property at 134-19 to 134-31 Northern Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, has been sold by the estate and heirs of John Schumacher to the 134-21 Northern Boulevard Corporation, represented by Joseph Lubin, attorney. Starke, Cook Ryan were attorneys for the sellers and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Unemployment in February rose by 584,000 to a total of 3,671,000, according to preliminary estimates compiled by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce.

Your editorial on "Craft vs. Industrial Units" admirably calls public attention to the dangers of fragmentation which threatens industrial bargaining units even where these arrangements have adequately served employer and employe needs for many years.
