HACKENSACK, N. J., March 12 -- A New York City importer identified today forty-seven checks he had issued to cover $19,140 he had lost gambling at Joe Adonis' ''Barn" in Lodi during the winter of 1947-48.

Philippine Vice President and Foreign Minister Carlos Garcia has made a thoughtful proposal in respect to the Philippine Trade Act which will, shortly be presented by Ambassador Romulo here. This is that the application of the restrictive proposals of the act, scheduled to begin on July 4 of this year, be postponed for another eighteen months.

A turbine engine less than forty inches long and about two feet square, built by the Boeing Airplane Company of Seattle as an experiment, has proved to be a versatile power plant whether it is used on the ground or taken up high above the clouds.
On this week's busy calendar of art events are eight shows of work by contemporary painters and, at the Saidenberg Gallery, a selection of oils and water-colors by Paul Klee.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Senator A. Willis Robertson, Democrat of Virginia, said today that Hawaii should not receive statehood until "more definite progress has been made in dealing with Communist efforts" to use it as a "base for assaults on our democratic way of life."

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- The Government today extended the rapid tax write-off privilege to cover the full cost of protective construction undertaken by a defense-supporting plant in any of the country's 193 target areas.

Tucked away in the middle of Chester Bowles' fine article, "A Plea for Another Great Debate," is a statement that should underlie our whole foreign policy and, indeed, our whole national life. "And is there not a broader issue, indeed a fundamental moral issue, implicit in this new policy, which in all conscience we should resolve with our eyes open."

Reports of sharp differences of opinion among maritime leaders on the Federal ship subsidy program were confirmed last week with the issuance of a special shipping study conducted by industry men. The study had been made at the request of Robert B. Murray Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce.

LONDON, March 13 -- Somewhere in western Java, there are fossil remains of a race of men who an expert believes lived probably at least 1,000,000 years ago and were the ancestors of all the hominidae, or family of man.
A majority of six students from 9 to 14 years of age agreed last night in a television discussion that parents and teachers would do well to guide the reading of the very young.

IN 1945 Georges Simenon settled permanently in the United States; and inevitably this most prolific of modern novelists (who has himself no precise notion of how many hundreds of novels he has written in the past quarter of a century) soon began to look upon the American scene as novelistic material.

With two separate and distinct programs of poliomyelitis control under way this spring, there is some understandable confusion in the minds of many concerning the status of our national fight against this crippling disease.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 (AP) -- La Salle ran away from Navy in the second half tonight to score an easy 64-48 victory in an Eastern regional national collegiate basketball tournament final. La Salle qualifies for the March 19 semi-final round at Kansas City.

ALBANY, March 13 -- An impending change in the state election law -- one that appears certain of legislative approval -- will give both major parties more time to make up their minds about candidates and issues this year than they have had since 1938.

THE rustler, in many clever guises, still operates in the cattle country. Styles have changed. He is no longer a grim, armed man on horseback, with his band of equally hard-faced confederates, who would sometimes round up an enormous bunch of cattle and head them toward the North Star. Today, he is usually, though not always, a sneak with a pick-up truck or a trailer built for hauling cows.

Department store sales for the week ended March 6 in the United States were 11 per cent below sales in the same week a year earlier, according to the Federal Reserve Board. In measuring the impact of a later Easter this year -- Easter Sunday is April 18, two weeks later than in 1953 -- the board recommends that an allowance of 5 per cent be made for the month as a whole.

This newspaper last week published a photograph of a new structure in West Berlin, soon to be opened, which is called in English the American Memorial Library. A bright glow of light, clearly visible from the Soviet sector four blocks away, already shines from this spot nightly into the darkness of the Communist world.

SO many dreadful things have been done in the name of cuteness that one approaches a fantasy about a family of coins with a certain apprehension. There is no need for such qualms, however, in the case of Louis MacNeice, English poet, critic and radio dramatist, who has concocted an amiable bit of tomfoolery with wit, taste and never a trace of archness.

The invention of a pill in 1884 that could be crushed to a powder has made the Upjohn Company not only a leading pharmaceuticals manufacturer serving the entire world but a prize-winner in the field of advertising and promotion.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., March 13 -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower prowled through mud and rain today to inspect work on their Gettysburg Battlefield home. They plan to retire to it when they leave the White House. The President, rain dripping from his brown felt hat and his trousers tucked in five-buckle galoshes, surveyed the renovation work and remarked with a broad grin: "This doesn't look like much now, does it?

" BIPARTISANSHIP in foreign policy" has become one of those political phrases which can be twisted to mean whatever the user wants it to mean. But as the description of a smoothly equated course of action by the two major American parties it is a statement of the unattainable, of a partnership in which the official responsibilities allocated in the Constitution of the United States would be disregarded.

THE preface to "New Short Novels" reminds us that the short novel -- "long for a short story, short for a novel" -- has always met with American publishing resistance, despite its notable achievements in our own literature, and in Europe.

PARENTS are constantly being told of the importance to the child of "a place of his own" in the home. In these days of cramped living quarters this advice is not always easily implemented but some ideas of school architects and educators on the subject might be of help.

NEW DELHI, March 13 -- Communists and Socialists throughout India have taken new heart from the repudiation of Prime Minister Nehru's Congress party in the recent special elections to the Travancore-Cochin State Assembly.

IN one of the more personal essays in this book, Sir Desmond MacCarthy winds up an imaginary conversation with a hopeful young reviewer with the words: "We (the professors and the critics) are coral insects building the reef that protects the lagoon of literature from the restless sea of nonsense and confusion.

NAPLES, March 13 -- The most direct roadway to the heart of the Soviet imperial system is along the connected inland waters of the Mediterranean, Marmora and Black Seas. Ever since Russia became a great power in the eighteenth century this has been her soft underbelly.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 13 -- Three more Connecticut town caucuses will be asked Thursday night to make a "choice" between President Eisenhower and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as the leader of the Republican party.

WHEN even as sane an Irishman as I (probably incorrectly) think I am starts to write about Saint Patrick's Day he feels a powerful temptation rising up in him to commit the Irishman's mortal sin -- i. e., to play the Irishman. "Out with the whishkey," he says to his wife, nay commands his wife.

THE Metropolitan Opera rarely quarrels with its customers -- it can hardly afford to -- but ten days ago General Manager Rudolf Bing cracked down on some of them. He did this, to be sure, on the complaints of a big majority.

LAST week's Treasure Chest carried a quotation from Cyril Connolly's "Ideas and Places" which I mean to use as a - basis for today's remarks. You may recall that Mr. Connolly, in discussing literary repputations, hazarded the guess that time would not deal kindly with the writers who bulked so large on the English literary horizon during the first quarter of the century: Shaw, Wells, Bennett, Galsworthy, Chesterton and Belloc.
LOS ANGELES, March 13 -- The California International Flower Show is in full swing today at Hollywood Park.
Twenty to fifty persons arriving daily at New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, are reportedly being gouged for taxicab transportation to suburban points.

At New York City's toy exhibition a flexible kite attracted attention because boys can make it maneuver like an airplane, crash it repeatedly and make it take off again undamaged -- even in the rain. The kite comes out of the Du Pont laboratories.

IN this picaresque novel William Corbin rings a provocative change on the usual pattern of stories about D. P.'s in this country. Unlike the average fictional newcomer, Nico La Flamme hadn't the slightest wish to fit into the American way of life.

THE morning is bright, crisp and cold, and the green station wagon with the lettering, "The Institute for Advanced Study," is making some routine pick-ups around town. The driver stops for Dr. Kurt Godel, mathematics department, a slight, stooped man in a huge coat who murmurs good morning as he takes a seat behind the driver and lapses into silence.

IN view of discrepancies in published estimates of the amount of money which the Egyptian Government received for the royal "Palace" stamp collection at the February auctions in Cairo, Bernard Harmer, head of the New York house of H. R. Harmer, Ltd., the London firm which served as professional adviser to the Government, has made available an explanation intended to clarify the confusion.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 13 -- By a vote of 17 to 1, the Tenth Inter-American Conference adopted today an anti-Communist resolution advocated by the United States. It was designed to serve as a warning to the Soviet Union to keep out of the affairs of the Western Hemisphere.

A UNIQUE bridge tournament will begin Saturday at Monte Carlo -- unique in several ways. It will be the first big tournament ever to offer cash prizes: the Sporting Club there, which in past years has been the scene of the biggest and most glamorous gambling of all time, has put up 3,000,000 francs (about $12,000), plus various items of merchandise, all to go to the winners as do prizes in golf tournaments.

THE airlines are ready to begin the busiest season in their history. The records they set during the spring and summer are not expected to show a smooth progression up the curve that registered the heavy travel gains during the peak seasons of 1952 and 1953, but almost to an airline they agree that during the next six or seven months there will be notable increases in international travel over last year.
PARIS, March 13 -- The congress of the Radical party adopted a resolution tonight asking special conditions for the National Assembly's ratification of the European army treaty.

THE title of this book by Chesly Manly, a correspondent who has covered "the proceedings of the U. N. and other international conferences for The Chicago Tribune," suggests a dislike for much that has happened between 1933 and the present day.

Albert Myers, executive of Myers Brothers in Springfield, Ill., predicted last Oct. 20 that retail stores throughout the country would soon be charging for major alterations of men's wear. He made his forecast at a meeting of the Young Men's Group of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers in Chicago.

Columbia's team demonstrated an all-around proficiency to annex the three-weapon honors in the fifty-seventh annual intercollegiate fencing championship, completed yesterday at New York University's Alumni Gymnasium on University Heights.

MANITOWOC, Wis., March 13 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy asserted tonight that "as long as I am in the United States Senate, and I hope it is a long time, I don't intend to treat traitors like gentlemen."

THIS is an account of the summit of a woman's life. It is also the story of one of those women who insist that they can be independent of men. The place is Cannes -- with some flashbacks of Albuquerque -- and the time is today or, perhaps, only yesterday.

SINCE her death in 1943, a young intellectual Frenchwoman named Simone Weil has begun to loom in the eyes of many as a major religious figure of our time, a unique and authentic candidate for sainthood.
Fourteen American colleges have ffone'international for summer study and travel.
" Stick 'em up!" may not be the words used by modern bank robbers but, whatever the phrasing, the command is being heard more frequently these days.

COLUMNIST of Le Figaro in Paris, former adviser to De Gaulle, one of France's leading sociologists and perhaps her foremost political commentator, Raymond Aron here tries to analyze the significance of the increasingly terrifying twentieth century. "

LONDON -- We have no national festival (such as we had two years ago) in Britain this summer. No Coronation, either. Instead, there is just Britain, a land of unrehearsed loveliness, clothed in a patchwork of green meadows, cathedrals, castles, cottages and coastline -- attractions which, the seers of the travel industry believe, will draw more visitors this year than ever before.

IN the last ten years so many books have appeared in which space travel has been discussed in everyday language that there would seem to be little excuse for another. Clearly aware of this plethora, Martin Caidin, author of "Jets, Rockets and Guided Missiles" and "Rockets Beyond the Earth," has done his best to produce something different.

" WHAT is one?" said Linda. This sentence stands alone on the first page of an attractively different counting book by Nancy Dingman Watson -- and, as mother reads, the young child gets acquainted with Linda, the little girl in the picture opposite the text.

WHETHER or not Louis XV actually said, "After me, the deluge," he says it in "Royal Merry-Go-Round." What is more, he lives up to it. By the time he draws his last sinful breath, France has lost most of her colonies and the tumbrels of revolution are almost ready to roll.
Customs collections dipped and ship movements rose, both slightly, in the Port of New York last month, Robert W. Dill, Collector of the Port, reported yesterday.

The American China Policy Association asked Secretary of State Dulles yesterday to seek a recess in the forthcoming Geneva conference until the Soviet Union complies with agreements made in the past. The association strongly supports the Chinese Nationalist Government, now in Formosa.

The Charles T. Wilson Company, Inc., rubber and produce dealer since 1910, announced yesterday it would discontinue its rubber trading activities, effective tomorrow. The Wilson company will continue as an investment trust, handling the interests of Mr. Wilson.
Canadian Pacific Steamships, Ltd., placed an order last week for the second of two 22,500- gross-ton passenger liners.

TROUBLE with music critics is they're squares. The people who read them and pay them any mind aren't any better. Squares, all of them. When they talk about pianists, they take off into the wild blue yonder about Horowitz, Rubinstein, Serkin, Casadesus, Novaes, Hess.

AFTER taking a grand, or orientation tour of this city the traveler can safely branch out for himself and go, for instance, to the Church of Santa Maria in Cosmedin. There he will be struck by the unique simplicity and austerity of this tiny fourth-century church. Built in the days when the memory of persecution was still fresh in the minds of the Christians, the church retains even now the atmosphere of the Catacombs.

LONDON, March 13 -- Col. Frank Norman, a business and civic leader of Westminster, the heart of the British Commonwealth, was accused today of having attempted to smuggle more than $500,000 worth of strategic copper behind the Iron Curtain.

ROME -- With the pilgrimages of the Marian Year added to the general travel boom, Italy is going to be a crowded place this coming season. But now, fortunately, one may with a clear conscience advise would-be visitors to this country to travel in the deep south. The springing into existence of a chain of medium-priced, modern hotels has changed Italy's tourist geography overnight.

An honest Portuguese laborer has just returned to his former employer here an overpayment of $4 he received for helping dig the Eighth Avenue subway nearly thirty years ago. The conscience-stricken man sent the money in Portuguese currency from his home in Marco de Canavezes, a little mill town and spa twenty-three miles east of Oporto, Portugal, where the people are honorable but hardly rushed.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Republican leaders opened a campaign today aimed at convincing taxpayers that they might get no new relief at all this year if Democrats should win an impending battle in the House of Representatives for higher personal exemptions.

LONDON, March 13 (Reuters) -- West Bromwich Albion, seeking the two top prizes of British soccer in one season, today downed London's Tottenham Hotspur by 3 -- 0 in the sixth round of the Football Association Cup competition.

THIS will be the final week of the New York City Ballet's season at the City Center, and it will be devoted exclusively to presentations of George Balanchine's new version of the full-length "Nutcracker." Maria Tallchief will dance the Sugar Plum Fairy at all performances, and Andre Eglevsky and Nicholas Magallanes will alternate as the Prince. These are the last performances scheduled by the company for New York until next fall.
LONDON, March 13 -- Britons were reassured today that ultimately the United States would do "the right thing" about "McCarthyism" and were cautioned not to be too critical of events in America.

CAIRO, March 13 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, Egypt's President, and members of the ruling military junta have learned in the political upheavals of the last fifteen days how badly they need each other. But the lesson was an expensive one.

Holy Cross, with a take-charge performance, decisively defeated top-seeded and favored Duquesne, 71 -- 62, in the final of the seventeenth annual National Invitation basketball tournament last night. A capacity throng of 18,496 at Madison Square Garden witnessed the upset triumph of the Crusaders, who had been ranked third in the draw for the twelve-team tourney.

CINCINNATI, March 13 (AP) -- Joe Miceli of New York defeated Johnny Lombardo of Mount Carmel, Pa., in a furious ten-round boxing contest tonight. The judges unanimously gave the decision to Miceli, who weighed 150 1/2 to Lombardo's 150.

TORONTO -- This city will soon have a new sight for its out-of-town visitors. It is the 4 1/2-mile municipal subway, which opens for business on March 30. Inviting fugitive straphangers from New York to take a ride on the local line may seem like recommending a busman's holiday, but Toronto is proud of its achievement -- Canada's first underground rapid-transit railway -- and not without reason.

ISTANBUL -- Long the eastern frontier of pleasure travel, Turkey is now engaged in a major effort to expand its hotel accommodations and transportation facilities in anticipation of the largest tourist influx in its history this spring and summer.

THE art of George Grosz has been largely inspired by the grimmer side of life in the last generation. From the militarism of World War I Germany and the chaos, despair and moral wreckage of post-war Berlin, arose his fiery hatred of oppression and corruption which found vent in some of the most savagely satiric drawings of our time.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 13 (AP) -- Pitt won the Eastern Intercollegiate wrestling championship tonight in its first try in the tournament.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 -- Misfortune cracked down on Charlie Grimm's Braves today. The Milwaukeeans, in bowing to the Yankees, 3 to 2, also lost the services of their brilliant outfielder, Bobby Thomson, for from two to three months.

CLEVELAND, March 13 -- Great Lakes vessel owners could send their fleets up the lakes for ore the first of next month, but will delay opening the 1954 shipping season because of curtailed operations in the nation's steel mills.

The women golfers of the district will be playing courses far and wide this year, according to the schedule just released by the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association. Mrs. Theodore W. Hawes of Baltusrol, vice-president and tournament chairman, has a list of events that will keep the competitors active from the middle of April until October.

EUROPE and Asia are separated by a seventeen-mile stretch of water enshrined in history, mythology and the minds of those who have fallen under its peculiar spell. The Bosporus is not just one imposing view; it is a kaleidoscopic succession of such views, forever mingling land, water, men and ships in new combinations.

YUGOSLAVIA is enjoying its best post-war music season, featuring domestic and foreign artists. Leon Goossens, the English oboist, just finished a tour of the country. The Gebel Trio of Vienna was a highlight of the Austrian-Yugoslav artists' exchange at the beginning of March.

While millions of Americans were struggling with their 1953 income tax returns last week, a three-cornered battle was shaping up in Washington over taxes for 1954. These are the participants in the battle, the positions they have taken, and the developments last week:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 13 -- Westchester's future water needs will come under close scrutiny for the first time when Simon P. Carman of Binghamton is installed on Monday as the first engineer of the county water agency.
Leonard-Rogers, now 25 years old, became president of Rogers Imports, Inc., upon the death of his father at the age of 45 in 1951.

PARIS -- The lady from somewhere in the United States who was caught in the big transport strike here last August and swore afterward that she would never set foot again in France -- has she relented? French tourist officials hope so, for they are counting on several hundred thousand of her compatriots this year and would not like to think she still holds a grudge and has been spreading the bad word around.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Foreign Operations Administration has 286 vacancies for experts in its world-wide technical assistance program, and very few job applicants.
Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has been offered equal time on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network to reply to an attack on him by Edward R. Murrow on the "See It Now" program.

AFTER years of deriding Hollywood for its stress on the "colossal" and the "gigantic," the Kremlin's film-makers have apparently decided to go in for something a little "supercolossal" themselves. That would seem to be a fair conclusion from the news that Moscow has now begun to build far and away the largest movie-making installation in Soviet history, a monster studio with about 6,000,000 square feet of floor space, complete with all the latest gadgets.
STOCKHOLM, March 23 (AP) -- Gunder Haegg predicted today that Britain's Roger Bannister would be the first to run the four-minute mile -- possibly this year -- "because he has brains."

PARENTS who have grown reading-hoarse during the pre-school years may find that the tables turn with this book. The nursery crowd will enjoy it, but "In Came Horace" is primarily geared for the beginning reader -- one who likes to demonstrate his new art verbally.

CAPETOWN -- South Africa is in the midst of a campaign to attract American tourists. Last month a tour arranged by the South African Travel Bureau for nineteen American travel agents served to correct the idea that travel in the South African Union is "African" in the sense of roughing it.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 13 -- According to the semi-official news agency Yugopress, this year is a "decisive" one in the Yugoslav economy. Construction of large post-war industrialization projects is drawing to a close.

CAIRO -- Egypt's spring tourist season has been squeezed rather tightly between a running series of political upsets and summer, which comes early, stays late and is hot in this part of the world. For those who can disregard the political situation, the climate is good through April, and the Government is making every effort to attract spring tourists.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 13 -- Pitching, somewhat on the erratic side this spring, was solid today as the Giants defeated the Indians, 3 -- 2. Jim Hearn, Ruben Gomez and Al Corwin limited the Cleevland club to six hits, while the New Yorkers collected eight against Bob Lemon, Dick Tomanek and Lefty Bill Wight. Hearn, after a couple of unimpressive earlier starts, was the standout.

Practically everybody knows that Albert Einstein is famous, but only a few know precisely why he is famous. The theory of relativity -- or, if one prefers, the Unified Field theory -- changes our lives, but the equations on which it depends are beyond the ordinary grasp.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Quietly and without the aid of singing commercials, the United Nations and two of its related specialized agencies are doing a spectacular job in saving international travelers a lot of time and fuss at airports, road frontiers and customs inspections.

THE little wide-range, high- fidelity recording of jazz that has appeared so far has been apt to lay more stress on audio range and instrumental clarity than on whatever music a record might contain. But high-fidelity jazz now appears to be ready to give up grinning at itself in a mirror and to settle down to a matter-of- course existence.
JERUSALEM, March 6 -- Hebrew University, "the alma mater of Israel reborn" as it was called by the late President of Israel, Dr. Chaim Weizmann, is in serious financial straits.

THE HAGUE -- In tourism as in politics, the Netherlands is a sober country. Extravagance, lavishness and exoticism are things the Dutchman appreciates and searches out -- when he goes abroad. When he is at home, and when he welcomes foreign visitor, he is thoroughly restrained.
Vittorio Giannini's opera after Shakespeare, "The Taming of the Shrew," was produced by the N. B. C. Television Theatre yesterday afternoon in the Centre Theatre.

LYDONVILLE, Vt., March 13 -- Egil Stigum, Norwegian-bred Dartmouth sophomore, catches on fast. Although in this country less than two years, he speaks English as well as a native American. Today he proved he was quick in skiing too, when he placed first in the downhill event that opened the two day Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association's championships.

BONN -- The West German Federal Republic, proud of being once again among the standard tourist countries of Europe, has improved accommodations and transport for visitors to its beautiful towns and countryside.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 13 -- Three Mayors and twenty-three Trustees will be elected in Suffolk County next Tuesday.

MOTORING abroad by American visitors to the British Isles and throughout Europe will set a record in volume this year, according to data from the international travel department of the American Automobile Association and other travel agencies.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- March, a test month of the recession in President Eisenhower's book, is nearly half spent.

More concern among Jews over Semitism and less about anti-Semitism was urged by Rabbi Joseph H. Lookstein in a sermon yesterday morning at the Kehilath Jeshurun Synagogue, 117 East Eighty-fifth Street.

WHEN he entered the United States Naval Academy, Courtney Lee was convinced that he was a coward. He feared he would disgrace the memory of his father, a World War II hero. But the disciplined routine of study and athletics, his friendship with a former marine and a growing awareness of the Navy's great traditions gave him inner strength.

A FICTITIOUS lady named Miss Rose Blossom staked her claim for patent rights to a mythical red-marked white camellia as part of the Federal Government's first plant patent exhibit, unveiled this week at the National Capital Flower and Garden Show.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 13 -- As temperatures worked higher and springlike weather prevailed over much of the district, interest in wearing apparel and accessories revived and modest gains in sales were recorded last week. Still many departments were lagging, notably the durable lines.

IF some friends of mine had time for just one trip within Sweden I would urge them to go to Visby on the Baltic island of Gotland, "the city of roses" that has to be seen to be believed. Imagine some dream city lifted straight from a fairy-tale to a beautiful isle set in the sea. That is walled, medieval Visby.
BONN, Germany, March 13 -- West German newspapers have given much space to the seventy-fifth birthday of Prof. Albert Einstein, which occurs tomorrow.
A resolution expressing "shock" at the Board of Higher Education's dismissal of Nat Holman, suspended City College basketball coach, was adopted yesterday by the college's alumni association board.

ATHENS -- A lot of tourists are expected here between now and November. There are several indications, including the letters received by residents from friends and acquaintances across the Atlantic who make the friendly but ominous threat, "This year we'll make it."
NEW ORLEANS, March 13 -- Joe W. Brown's entry of Gigantic and Bobby Brocato ran one, two today in the $50,900 Louisiana Derby, closing feature at the Fair Grounds.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 13 -- Turkey's two principal opposition parties today endorsed the formation of a broad anti-Government electoral coalition aimed at turning this country's next Parliament into a Constitutional Assembly.
HARRISBURG, March 13 -- Officials of four states that operate turnpikes are making a serious attempt to find a basis for agreement on uniform measures to promote safety.
THE National Broadcasting Company's mobile color unit and crew are not going to be inactive very long.
GENEVA, N. Y., March 13 -- Plans for a new $500,000 state park here at the head of Seneca Lake have struck a serious snag after months of seemingly smooth sailing.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March 13 (AP) -- Maryland won two individual championships and piled up 35 points tonight to dethrone Syracuse as team champion of the Eastern Intercollegiate boxing tournament.

THREE years ago few people in the movie business had any real hope for the future of United Artists. The citadel of independent producers, founded in 1919 by Mary Pickford, Charles Chaplin and the late Messrs. Douglas Fairbanks, D. W. Griffith and William S. Hart, was financially and artistically moribund.

All over the world medical societies are commemorating this month the centenary of Paul Ehrlich's birth and emphasizing his influence on medical thinking, an influence as profound as that of Pasteur and Koch. Just what it is that sets a man like Ehrlich apart as a scientist can never be fully explained.

The Walden School in New York City, celebrating its fortieth anniversary this week, has had considerable influence on the nation's educational philosophy. One of the early progressive schools, Walden took the lead in breaking away from the rigid book-centered pattern of the traditional school program.

The United Engineering and Foundry Company in 1953 had a net income of $3,806,031, equal to $1.52 a common share, against $3,772,906, or $1.51 a common share, the year before, according to the report issued for publication today.
TAMPA, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- The United States Army red squad won the team championship of the national midwinter pistol shoot today with an aggregate of 3,452.
CHICAGO, March 13 (AP) -- Professional golfers this year will be chasing down the fairways after the game's richest summer purse, an expected $525,000 accruing from some twenty-three tournaments.

IT could scarcely be an exaggeration to claim Franz Kafka as the most intriguing talent of our time. One hesitates to say "genius" and so one puts down the word "talent" -- but the word instantly becomes inadequate to the demons and angels that thronged Kafka's skull.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 13 -- Another page was added today to the most unusual record in the world of sports -- Yale's long string of swimming successes under the direction of Coach Robert J. H. Kiphuth.
ROME, March 13 -- Premier Mario Scelba ordered today that anyone entering any Italian Government office must sign a register at the door.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, who loves to attack, found himself on the defensive this weekend in the most important and perhaps climatic struggle of his entire stormy political career.

Tomorrow midnight is the deadline for the filing of Federal income tax returns. Returns may be filed in person or by mail. Internal Revenue officials warned that mailed returns must carry a post-office cancellation mark not later than Monday midnight if penalties are to be avoided.

DETROIT, March 13 -- Camille Henry, making a determined bid for "rookie of the year" honors, scored four-goals tonight to lead the New York Rangers to a 5-to- 2 victory over the Detroit Red Wings at Olympia.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 13 -- Speeding over the grass track at the Sydney Sports Ground, Hector Hogan equaled the world record of 9.3 seconds today for the 100-yard dash.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 13 (UP) -- Illinois easily won its fifth straight Big Ten gymnastics championship today, but Carl Rintz of Michigan State stole the meet spotlight.

Favored by good weather, re-[ taft business last week inched ahead of the same week a year ago. The 1953 week was marked by rain on two days. RetailersI estqmted that they would showl a gain of 2 to 3 per cent in the year-to-year comparison.
Columbia's baseball team will open its seventeen - game season against Queens College on March 30, according to the spring schedules announced yesterday by Ralph Furey, director of athletics.
GENEVA, March 13 (Reuters) -- Britain unveiled a plan for encouraging East-West trade today and won firm United States support for it.

DURING and after revolutions there are always men and women who are, as the publishers of "Former People" aptly describe them, "too insignificant to be worth shooting and yet for whom there is no place under the new regime."
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 13 -- Communist-led Vietminh troops have made their biggest attack so far against the vital road and railway linking Hanoi and Haiphong, the two main cities of North Vietnam.
SODA SPRINGS, Idaho, March 13 (AP) -- Idaho's large deposits of phosphate ore will be further tapped as a result of the construction of another multimillion-dollar electric furnace here.

BELGRADE -- For potential tourists, getting to Yugoslavia has been one of the major problems. Most Western tourists seem to stop short in France or Italy and few ever get beyond Trieste. Yugoslav tourist officials are tackling this problem with vigor and have announced improved and increased transport to the resorts along the Dalmatian coast.

A PLACE may be marked by Baedeker by as many stars as are in the firmament and yet be deserving of one more. Such a place is Delphi. No traveler in Greece has failed to sing the praises of this place, the center, the omphalos of the earth, and none has praised it adequately.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., March 13 -- A white dog with red markings, Ch. Whistle Stop High Note, became best of breed tonight in the 127-dog specialty of the Cocker Spaniel Club of Long Island.

As one who studied the pre-war ultra-nationalist movement which finally brought Japan to its destruction, and who has observed its revival in the post-war era, I would like to add a few points to Lindesay Parrott's informative article from Tokyo entitled, "Anti-American Groups Again Active in Japan."

THIS latest gift to America of Gilbert Highet is not history, anthropology, psychology, sociology or philosophy. It is the story told, movingly but quietly, of "man's unconquerable mind." It is a paean of praise, worthily and majestically intoned, of man's humanity to man rising above and even obscuring those spots of time and splotches of earth made red with the blood of war and strife.

BRUSSELS' Grand' Place has not altered since five centuries ago. Indeed, any modification of the picturesque tall houses with Flemish stepped gables and gilded cornices would be sacrilege. The only touch of outward modernity about these old facades and about the ancient City Hall, which occupies one side-of the Grand' Place, is that they are floodlit at night.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- Winter and summer, Florida's forty-three state parks and memorials, which are visited annually by more than a million persons, constitute one of the state's major tourist attractions. These tracts cover a total of 71,062 acres and have an estimated value of $51,000,000.

Women headed by Mrs. Edgar K. Moses and including Mrs. Hamilton Southworth and Mrs. Whitman Knapp are furthering the success of the performance of Ringling Brothers and Barnum and Bailey Circus on the afternoon of April 9 at the Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the James Weldon Johnson Community Center.
French furniture and modern prints head the offerings this week in auction houses here.

SAN DIEGO, Calif. -- Visitors to San Diego who turn off U. S. 101 just north of town where signs point to Mission Bay will find themselves coursing through one of the most remarkable recreational developments in the country.

WHEN I was a farm boy (some sixty years ago) there were no soil conditioners except those that came from the barn or chicken yard, and few if any experiment stations where soil samples could be sent for testing and recommendations. Certainly not the ideal in soil management, but that's the way it was in those days.

A KING'S treasures are being auctioned off these days in Cairo at prices which could be called a king's ransom. They are the royal treasures of ex-King Farouk, a fabulous collection of stamps, coins and silver, clocks, jeweled boxes and other works of artisans, that he left behind when he abdicated Egypt's throne following General Naguib's coup of July, 1952.

A constitution establishing the only bicameral form of student legislature in the country and ceding to students greater control over campus activities has been ratified by the undergraduates of Fordharm College.
LONDON, March 13 -- Sir Miles Thomas, chairman of the British Overseas Airways Corporation is scheduled to fly early tomorrow to the scene of the airliner crash at Singapore.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- The downtrend in employment in Pennsylvania which began last fall continued through February. Of all major groups of industries only leather increased employment since the first of the year and this reflected a seasonal pick-up.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 13 (UP) -- Mrs. Grace DeMoss Smith of Coral Gables, Fla., playing brilliant golf most of the way, won the Florida East Coast women's championship today with a 4-and-3 victory over Mrs. Marge Lindsay MacMillan of Decatur, Ill.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- The yawl Escapade held a two-mile lead over Caribee, last year's winner, at 8 o'clock to night in the annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race.

JAPAN'S cherry trees will soon be in pink and white blossom and the countryside will assume the storybook appearance and atmosphere so well delineated in the familiar Japanese prints. Spring is the best time of year for the tourist to be in Japan.

BRUSSELS -- The number of Americans coming to Belgium is increasing each year -- about 100,000 last year, 17 per cent more than in 1952. But the Belgians still think that visitors should stay longer, leaving their hurry-up habits at home and sampling in more leisurely fashion the wide range of attractions of a country that offers relaxation as well as sights.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney said today he and other Senators next week would propose Commonwealth status for Hawaii and Alaska as a substitute for the statehood bill.
TEHERAN, Iran, March 13 -- Hossein Fatemi, the firebrand Foreign Minister of the Mossadegh regime, was captured by the police today after a protracted search.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 -- California, which has beckoned to millions of migrants in the postwar period, is paying its old age "pensioners" $18,000,000 to $19,000,000 a month.

WHEN an actor averages one thousand fan letters a month and more than 75 per cent of the missives come from admiring females, Hollywood producers sit up and take notice. Jack Palance brought seasoned movie masterminds bolt upright in their leather backed swivel chairs by becoming a Mr. Somebody in less than four years without the customary abracadabra ministrations of high-powered studio publicity machines.

RIO DE JANEIRO -- Dollar bargains and increasing hotel comfort nearly everywhere are prominent points in South America's attractions for tourists this year. Prices are rising everywhere in terms of the local currency, but so is the value of the dollar, and in many cases, as a result, prices for North Americans are comfortably lower than a year ago.

IN the early Nineteen Hundreds Henry Augustus Shute of Exeter, N. H., tickled the irreverent and outraged the righteous with "The Real Diary of a Real Boy," purported daybook of a juvenile near-delinquent in a post-Civil-War Yankee town.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Mar. 13 -- The United States Forest Service is mapping detailed plans to fight future fires on the roof of Los Padres National Forest along the Santa Ynez mountain range back of Santa Barbara.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The decision by Mr. Kennan to run for Congress reflects the conviction of the distinguished scholar that political action is necessary to combat the "real evil abroad in this land."

AUGUSTA, March 13 (AP) -- Louise Suggs sagged into a momentary tie with Patty Berg today, but pulled away on the last eight holes to take a three-stroke lead with 220 in the women's Titleholders golf tournament.

TWO record companies, represented by a series of allied works, are paying homage to the American composer of chamber music. The more ambitious of the efforts is by Columbia, which is continuing its Modern American Music Series with six disks. Classic has a two-disk set entitled American Woodwind Symposium, which is played by the New Art Wind Quintet.

Benjamin Franklin captured the Manhattan title and Franklin K. Lane collared the Queens crown by winning their quarter-final games in the city-wide Public Schools Athletic League basketball play-offs at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

A seminar for managing editors and news editors will begin tomorrow at the American Press Institute of Columbia University. Twenty-six newspaper men from sixteen states, the District of Columbia and Hawaii will take part in the two-week program.

STOCKHOLM -- Sweden is making a more intensive bid for the tourist business this year than ever before. Judging by advance reservations, last year's record number of American tourists will be exceeded in 1954 by a handsome margin.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright said today he was convinced that the Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations and access to confidential Federal Bureau of Investigation files and "gets any information it wants from those files, whether the information has been authenticated or not."

IN "Johnny Forsaken" G. B. Stern tells a story of great charm without interfering at all with its author's talent for rollicking digression. Johnny and his Felsea Dramatic Society give Miss Stern all the scope she needs for her excellent sense of theatre, cheerful satire and expert mimicry.
