WHILE Liszt was at Weimar he had a brilliant student in Julius Reubke, the son of a German organ builder. That composer-student died in 1858 at the age of 24, but he left one work for which he has since become famous among devotees of the organ. It is his Sonata in C minor on the 94th Psalm and two new recordings of it are included among recent organ releases.

HAVE you ever heard the ringing of the Bells of Ireland? Since I refer to the little green bells of a plant called Molucella laevis, you probably have not. However, I've been told that Irish people actually can hear such music and, they say, the ringing is done by the leprechauns.
NEW HAVEN, March 13 -- A volunteer squad of sixty "T-men" is closely watching driving habits in this area.

FLOWER arrangers in particular have a lot of long-range planning to do when it comes to deciding what to plant in the border. For the fact is that some flowers lend themselves better to design and have better keeping qualities than others. The everlastings are especially desirable in these respects.
TOKYO, March 13 -- The Japanese Diet began this week its great debate on the newly signed Mutual Defense Assistance Agreement with the United States.
The Moreland Act Commission sent to Governor Dewey yesterday a breakdown of the direct and indirect ownership of stock in the state's harness racing enterprises.

SPONTINI'S final opera, "Agnes von Hohenstaufen," which he wrote in 1829 when he was Kappellmeister for King Friedrich Wilhelm III of Prussia, will be revived for the Florence May Festival. The performance will be the first in Italy and, it is believed, the first anywhere since Spontini's revision in 1837.
MENLO PARK, Calif., March 13 -- An experiment here in preparing persons to live usefully instead of vegetating after retirement is attracting nationwide attention.

TO have standards means practically to select and reject; and this again means that one must discipline one's feelings or affections, to use the older word, to some ethical center. If the discipline is to be effective, so that a man will like and dislike the right things, it is as a rule necessary that it should become a matter of habit, and that almost from infancy.
Job opportunities have declined one-third since a year ago, according to a recent survey of "help wanted" advertising in 114 cities throughout the nation.
It's All Ancient History "Plausible, vain, resolute and violent, he was one of the necessary evils of an aggressive democracy."

MOST histories of science deal almost exclusively with the results of research, new instruments and experiments and theories. The non-technical problems confronting investigators receive far less attention. To be sure, we learn that science was once distrusted and bitterly opposed, and the tale of Galileo's humiliation before the Inquisition has often been told.
TEHERAN, Iran -- The traveler in the Arabian Levant has more than the ordinary amount of adventurousness in his spirit or he would not come in search of amusement and instruction to these parts.
LONDON, March 13 -- Britain is prepared to expand her political commitments in support of the European Defense Community.
MOSCOW, March 13 (AP) -- Soviet citizens go to the polls tomorrow from Riga to Vladivostok to elect a new Supreme Soviet (Parliament). There will be no change in administration or polices.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., March 13 (AP) -- The University of Pittsburgh won its third consecutive Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championship tonight as the thirty-first annual meet ended in Mryl Jacobs Memorial pool at Lehigh University.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 13 (UP) -- A crowd of 30,122 helped usher in the Lincoln Downs racing season today and saw Ralph Lowe's Pictus, the 9-to-10 favorite, score a nose triumph in the $10,000 Inaugural Handicap.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Following are the texts of telegrams and letters exchanged by Senator McCarthy and Secretary Stevens on the Schine case. First is a letter Senator McCarthy's office said was sent to Mr. Stevens Dec. 22:
HONG KONG, March 10 -- Bootlegging reached "serious" dimensions in various parts of rural China last year, according to the Tientsin newspaper Ta Kung Pao.

THE Yugoslavs like to call Dubrovnik the "Pearl of the Adriatic." Lake Bled, nestled in the Julian Alps, is as pretty and pleasant a mountain resort as one is apt to find anywhere. Opatija, once a playground for fun-loving East Europeans with money, is a fine sea resort.

INDUSTRIAL activity continues to decline. With the carloadings, steel and paper-board components at their lowest points for the year, the Times Business Index for the week ended March 6 slipped to 176.3, almost 3 points below the level of the preceding week.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va. -- Monticello, the home of Thomas Jefferson, will open to the public again tomorrow after four months, during which the historic mansion underwent the most complete renovation job in its more than a century and a half of existence.

The depression-ridden scrap industry, a key supplier for the nation's steel mills and foundries, has under study a multi-faceted program, including a bid for Government aid, to help it weather its most serious crisis in sixteen years.

In "Communism in Guatemala: A Case History" (Feb. 21), Flora Lewis tells the story of how the Communists have deeply entrenched themselves on our doorstep, and notes that the United States is studying just how they managed to do so.
Somewhat obscured by the New York Central Railroad Company wrangle, a similar conflict is moving toward a showdown in the half-billion-dollar New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 13 -- Samuel Tufano's Wise Margin came from far back to win the $66,100 mile-and-a-quarter Gulfstream Park Handicap before a crowd of 20,642 fans today.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., March 13 (AP) -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute won the N. C. A. A. hockey championship tonight by defeating favored Minnesota, 5 -- 4, in overtime.

If Dr. Irving Morton Goldstein of the University of California is right, Sigmund Freud, creator of psychoanalysis, is wrong. Freud taught that certain images and designs are symbolically male or female. His disciples made visual perception tests on this assumption and concluded that men and women differed in their reactions to the symbols.

Chester Bowles' article, "A Plea for Another Great Debate" (Feb. 28) is most pertinent. His point that such a debate would at least clarify what seems to be an important shift in our policy is well taken.
A hundred thousand marchers are expected to swing up Fifth Avenue in the annual St. Patrick's Day Parade on Wednesday.

BOSTON, March 13 (AP) -- The four top-seeded pairs -- headed by the No. 1 team of James Ethridge and Carl Badger of Greenwich, Conn. -- advanced to the semi-finals today in the national doubles squash racquets championship at the Harvard Club.
Dr. G. J. van Heuven Goedhart, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, warned last night that the refugee problem throughout the world still was serious.

PARIS, March 13 -- National attention has been centered on the run-off election on Sunday between the Communist Andre Stil and Mme. Germaine Peyrolles of the Catholic Popular Republican party in the Department of Seine et Oise.

If the Reconstruction Finance Corporation succeeds this week in passing on its holdings of $65,000,000 of Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company bonds to private investors, it will be by the old-fashioned "let-the-buyer-beware" method.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A four-week procession of witnesses has ended in the disturbing case of Col. Frank H. Schwable. All that remains now is for the lawyers on both sides to make their closing arguments Monday.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 13 -- Contests for public offices in eleven Westchester County villages will be decided Tuesday. Nine other villages will elect unopposed candidates.

Two years ago a Japanese student and an American student who had just returned from a year's study in Berlin sat down together to explore the possibilities of making the relationship between foreign students and their college a more personal one. Both of these boys felt that the program of orientation as established by their institution -- Swarthmore College -- was a good one as far as it went.

Dr. Jerome Spar of New York University has just completed an analysis of New York City's weather records for the last eighty-three years. He finds that the city's weather is warming up at the rate of 3.3 degrees in a century. At this rate New York will be as hot as Singapore in a few centuries.

EDINBURGH -- Americans, who beat a holiday path to Scotland last year in bigger numbers than ever before, went home with pleasant memories of Europe's most ancient kingdom, a colorful land of 30,000 square miles, most of it still unscarred by the swift on-rush of modern times.

EVERY trout fisherman, who advances from the worm to the fly, eventually approaches the next step, actually a normal progression, and decides he will never be happy until he fishes for Atlantic salmon. The probing then begins for a river where good fishing is available at bargain rates.

Although confidence is still widely held that, an improvement in business will occur soon, a point is fast approaching when something more than optimism will be needed as a sustaining influence. In about a month, the first quarter corporate reports may not make such good reading as the annual reports now at hand.
The Fourteenth Street Association announced yesterday that it had applied for, and had been assured it would get, a Park Department permit to hold a Loyalty Day celebration in Union Square on May 1.

MUNICH, Germany, March 13 (AP) -- United States authorities delayed tonight answering an accusation by the Czechoslovak Government that two United States Navy planes had flown into Czechoslovakia's uranium-mining region before they were driven out by a cannon-firing MIG jet interceptor.

A tentative schedule of thirty-eight championship regattas and several distance races has been drawn up by the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound for next season. The dates will be acted upon by the delegates at the spring meeting in the New York Yacht Club on March 29.

DALLAS, March 13 -- Temperatures soaring into the 90's in parts of Texas during the week brought an upturn in department store sales, particularly in spring clothing lines. Sales that had been lagging slightly behind last-year levels were as good as or slightly better than the year-ago period, merchants reported.

LISBON -- A few years ago few foreign visitors came here to discover all that this enchanting country and its helpful people have to offer. However, the situation is changing rapidly. Each year brings 20 per cent more American visitors, and greater numbers also from other European countries.

VICE PRESIDENT THOMAS R. MARSHALL remarked in his "Recollections": "There are a great many things which I believe that I know are not so: for instance, I believe that the Democratic party is always right."

Russia and her satellites are making a renewed effort to increase their sales of crude oil and products in the international markets. According to information in the oil industry, these sales now approximate 80,000 barrels daily to the Western nations, or nearly double the rate a year ago.

STORRS, Conn., March 13 (AP) -- Springfield College's swimming team captured six of ten first places today to win the thirty-fifth annual New England Intercollegiate Swimming Association championships, edging Williams, the defending champion, 69 -- 58.
CLIO, Ala., March 13 (UP) -- This farm community was left almost destitute today by the disappearance of its banker and the bank's money and records.

MADRID -- Spain is gradually losing its status as Europe's best tourist bargain, but it is offering instead more variety per dollar than before. The steady influx of foreigners, both permanent and transient, in the past year has given impetus to new business enterprises catering to their needs.
Following is the text of Vice President Richard M. Nixon's reply last night to Adlai E. Stevenson, as recorded by The New York Times:
BESIDES the Day of St. Patrick this week a second saint's day falls this Friday and many Italian-Americans, especially those of Sicilian background, will set special tables in honor of St. Joseph.

JERUSALEM -- It is now possible to see, with approximately the degree of comfort expected by American tourists, the place where Lot's curious wife was turned to a pillar of salt, where Goliath was foolish enough to come within a stone's throw of David, where Joshua ordered the sun to stand still.

ALBANY, March 13 (AP) -- Albany political reporters, pretending they were the politicians they write about, tonight washed scandal-tinged Republican leaders clean of sin and portrayed Governor Dewey as a reluctant candidate for re-election.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Eisenhower has deceased an ambitious legislative program for his party and the nation, but for a variety of perplexing reasons he is having a hard time getting much attention for it.

IN an age where conversation is reputedly on the wane, Professor Gilbert Highet offers weekly proof on the radio that the communication of ideas through the spoken word is not yet a lost art. His one-man tour of the world of books is called "People, Places and Books," and is broadcast over WQXR each Tuesday night from 9:05 until 9:20 o'clock.
I respectfully submit to your critic the suggestion that no talent, however great, can be expected to produce masterpieces exclusively.
CARACAS, March 13 -- The basic fact emerging from the Tenth Inter-American Conference here is that, despite all cries of despair about it, Pan-Americanism still works.

IN less than a month the trans-Atlantic liner business will swing into the annual rush season, and travel specialists predict that in its eastbound phase the period will extend through July, and perhaps to a diminishing extent well into August.
After many years of Soviet newspaper silence on the subject. Pravda has given the mass of Soviet citizens some of the elementary facts about the atomic age.

TORONTO, March 13 (AP) -- Douglas McLaggan of the Montreal Badminton and Squash Club, the top-seeded pro and defender, advanced with other seeded players to the second round of the Badminton and Racquet Club's second annual pro-amateur squash racquet tournament today.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- Comment tonight by members of Congress on Vice President Richard M. Nixon's speech divided sharply along party lines.

HOLLOMAN AIR, FORCE BASE, N. M., March 13 (UP) -- An Air Force colonel will take a rocket-propelled ride that will send him spinning at 750 miles an hour into a pool of water. Col. John P. Stapp, director of the test project here, will try to find out what kills jet pilots who parachute from their planes at high altitudes.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 13 -- Prof. Albert Einstein today urged all intellectuals "to refuse to cooperate in any undertaking that violates the constitutional rights of the individual."

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 5 -- Now that the Queen's visit to Melbourne is over, work is beginning in earnest in preparation for the 1956 Olympic Games. By the middle of the year all the major buildings will be well under way.
The New York Knickerbockers clinched first place in the Eastern Division of National Basketball Association by defeating the Syracuse Nationals yesterday at Madison Square Garden.
THIS can be a critical spring for rhododendrons or any other broadleaved evergreen. Even some of the narrow-leaved evergreens such as yew have already shown evidence of wind damage.
A "custom - made" education fitted to the child has been fashioned for New York's public school children, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, reported yesterday.

Expenditures by United States residents on foreign travel topped $1,077,000,000 in 1953, bringing the over-all total of dollars spent by Americans in this way to $6,351,000,000 since the end of the war, according to a report by the American Express Company.

THERE are many dramatic sights in Israel, but it is Jerusalem that casts a spell over me. The Old City sits on a hill, as ancient as sin and yet standing for the religious hopefulness of millions of people all over the world. It is hard in its rock, and its history is harsh and bloody.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, March 13 -- Penn State snapped Notre Dame's eighteen-game winning streak tonight with a 71-to-63 decision in the final of the National Collegiate regional tournament to advance into the national tourney semi-finals against La Salle.

AROUND 1951, Alan Moorehead, expatriate Australian journalist ("The Traitors," "Montgomery," "African Trilogy") and novelist ("The Rage of the Vulture") made a trip through the center and north of his native land, the part that is mainly uninhabited.

FOR the 1954 "Ano Santo Compostelano" (Compostelo Holy Year) are two Spanish stamps received by Scott Publications, Inc. At the center column of the "Portico de la Gloria" of St. James Cathedral in Compostelo stands a sculptured figure of one of the Twelve Apostles -- St. James the Greater, whose reputed bones were discovered in Spain some time after 789.
At least under present law, a stock dividend of preferred stock declared on common, where only the common was outstanding at the time of declaration, is not taxable.

WASHINGTON, March 13 - Senator McCarthy is getting careless. He used to ask people whether they were for or against Communists, which was safe enough, but now he is asking them whether they think he tells the truth. This is a reckless question.

COLUMBIA, S. C., March 13 -- Brookfield Farms took two races in today's Palmetto Trials, with I Que running a half-mile in the Governor's Handicap in 48 seconds flat and Ifabody finishing the Getaway half mile in 0:48 1/5.
Americans will be able to shake the pepper pot with old-time zest this year. Prices are coming down.
Mayor Wagner's efforts to win peace on the waterfront ran into a dead end yesterday. So, consequently, did hopes for an early end to the nine-day-old wildcat pier strike.

THE first mistake the author of "Eight Bailed Out" made was to jump out of his Liberator bomber and into the political cauldron of Yugoslavia. Not that he and the crew had much choice. They were heading home from a mission over Ploesti when the bomber floundered.

Early spring or late, March is the month of the peepers. Come income tax deadline, first daffodils thrusting up, the life-glow in weeping willow twigs, and the bogs and lowlands echo with the yee-yeep of the hylas. It's a rare year when they miss the middle of the month by more than a week or so.

THE New Dance Group, which started a new series of annual festivals last year at the Ziegfeld Theatre, will give a second season at the Lexington Avenue "Y" beginning March 30. There will be six performances, on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday evenings and Sunday afternoon.

JOHN WESLEY was the leading figure in the revival of the Reformation and the reformation of the religious revival in eighteenth-century England. He lived in every decade of that century. Educated at Oxford where he was Fellow of Lincoln College, he knew ten languages and wrote over 200 books and edited hundreds of other publications.
MOSCOW, March 13 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov has warned that a new war with modern arms would mean the "destruction of world civilization."

In our preoccupation with Senator McCarthy's methods we must not lose sight of the great constitutional question raised by his assertion of the right to investigate an Executive department as much as he chooses. This assertion is a direct attack upon the time-honored principle of separation of powers inherent in our constitutional system.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Testimony indicating that this country's Allies have cooperated in keeping strategic materials from the Soviet bloc in Europe and the Chinese Reds was released today.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A rare contest, the struggle over an effort to unseat a member, is in prospect for the Senate amid the heaviest of political undertones.

COMING in the wake of the New York. International Flower Show is the New England show, which opens today at 1 P. M. in Boston's Horticultural Hall. Held as usual in the Mechanics Building, this year the show commemorates the 125th anniversary of its sponsor, the Massachusetts Horticultural Society.

LOS ANGELES, March 13 -- James Roosevelt's formal entry into the 1954 Congressional lists this week underscored the large question mark hanging over California's prospective contribution to the Eighty-fourth Congress.
A series of conferences to find remedies for the nation's traffic accident problem will be held here next month.
FOLLOWING are excerpts from comment on some of the art exhibitions reviewed in The Times during the week just closed. Exhibition reviews appear in the daily columns.
Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "The Girl in Pink Tights" Wednesday night at the Mark Hellinger Theatre for the benefit of the Child Education Foundation.

SIMILAR in treatment and format to Miss Ripley's "Leonardo da Vinci," this is a concise introduction to the life and chief works of that other titan of the Renaissance, Michelangelo. As in her earlier study, Miss Ripley sticks to the facts without resorting to fictionized narrative, characters or dialogues.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce estimated today that state revenues rose to $18,000,000,000 last year while spending by the states increased to about $17,000,000,000.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 13 -- South Africa's color bar has placed the Government in a quandary in regard to the defense of Africa, now being discussed at the Dakar defense conference.
SOME people hunt big game in darkest Africa. Some challenge the highest peaks of the Himalayas. Some race fast cars on narrow, curved roads in Mexico. And some run opera houses.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 13 (UP) -- Kurt Nielsen of Denmark upset top-seeded Vic Seixas and the tourney defender, Art Larsen, turned back Sweden's Sven Davidson today in semi-final matches of the masters invitation tennis event.

IN the enormous task of giving us "good reading" from five or six generations of German story-tellers. Robert Pick has succeeded admirably. He has resisted the temptation of selecting historically "representative" stories -- which often don't reach today's readers -- and of presenting nothing but dazzling literary novelties.

WHEN children, adolescents and adults; private organizations and public agencies; professional recreation leaders and relatively untrained volunteers can pull together for the good of a community's children, word of their accomplishment is bound to travel.

BY taking hold of a provocative idea, Charles Morgan has written an interesting melodrama. There is some disparity between the idea and the play, which is entitled "The Burning Glass." Mr. Morgan's gift for philosophical speculation is superior to his knack for play-writing.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 (AP) -- The major leagues have not banned telecasts of exhibition games to major league cities, Warren Giles, National League president, said today. This came after a report had swept the country that owners decided to prohibit such telecasts. Giles added that it was the result of a misunderstanding.
MANITOWOC, Wis., March 13 -- Senator McCarthy tonight received a mixed reception in his home-state territory when he addressed the annual dinner of the Chamber of Commerce on its "Bosses Night."

PARIS, March 13 -- It appeared this week that the French and West Germans were at last about to discuss seriously the long-evaded question of the Saar. At least what they called a basis for discussion was accepted by Konrad Adenauer, Chancellor of the Bonn Republic, and Georges Bidault, French Foreign Minister.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 13 -- Manai Sophiaan, secretary general of the Indonesian Nationalist party, has openly warned this country that communism's global offensive is also directed at Indonesia. He declared further that the Nationalist party would fight any movement that sought only to divide Indonesia and bring about internal chaos.

A gentle acceleration of business is noted in most categories of ready-to-wear by resident buying offices as the Easter season draws closer. Moderate-priced dresses and junior styles are booming. Suits and coats are finding extra business although it is spotty. Sportswear is enjoying good trade.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- Democratic Senators attacked the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra T. Benson, on three fronts tonight as opposition to the Administration's farm policies continued.
LOS ANGELES, March 13 (AP) -- Royalty flew through the sonic barrier for the first time today, but the excitement came later when the engine died in a slower plane.
YOKOHAMA, Japan, March 11 -- For approximately four months, a United States business man has been held in jail here under conditions bordering on solitary confinement while awaiting trial.

ROME -- Italy has a convenience for the traveler with which many American tourists are unacquainted but which can help cut costs and multiply the pleasures of economic travel in that country. This device is the albergo diurno, translatable literally as a day hotel.

PARIS -- The visitor to France who intends to spend most of his time in Paris may yet feel a desire to move away from his base for a few days and discover something of the French countryside. The Ideal way of doing so in a short time is to visit the Loire Valley or the Ile de France.

DES MOINES, March 13 -- A public opinion poll conducted throughout Iowa last week, showed that 20 per cent of those questioned believed that what Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had been doing "was mostly bad," 15 per cent "mostly good" and 29 per cent "half good and half bad."
PARIS, March 13 -- Leaders of Vietnam have proposed an "association" with France that would be more like that within the British Commonwealth than the ties now characterizing the French Union.
Chester D. Seftenberg, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Air Force, has been named treasurer of Lear, Inc., Los Angeles.

I ONCE heard a wise clergyman say that today's churches, being intended for the people of our times, should be so designed that the people of our times will recognize them and feel that they are being addressed to them. He was thus in effect saying that religion must be dynamic and alive to be acceptable to the modern educated man.
MAIQUETIA, Venezuela, March 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles left Maiquetia airport for Washington this afternoon with a happy smile of triumph.
Today Clark Hill Dam is just the name of a Federal hydroelectric installation. In days to come it may represent an historic testing ground of Administration power policy.
Two men who have participated for many years in major port activities in New York have been selected for honor awards by two organizations.

THE Cape is temptation. In the naked veldt, the dusty bush and the patchy jungle lands of southern Africa, stretching wearily northward to the confines of the Congo, the white man has to resist the suave appeal of the Cape. It speaks to the alien in the black man's continent with the voice of all the things that are dear to him.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon lashed out tonight at Congressional Red hunters who by their "reckless talk and questionable methods" had divided Americans on the anti-Communist issue and diverted attention from President Eisenhower's legislative program.

When Dr. Walter Kempner of Duke University's School of Medicine came out in 1944 with his rice diet as a corrective of high blood pressure, the medicos read what he had to say with interest but also with skepticism. Much of the skepticism has subsided, so that many physicians are following Dr. Kempner's instructions.

It was Dr. Jules Freund of the city's Public Health Research Institute who opened the door to the development of the Salk vaccine against poliomyelitis, according to Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health.

THE scene of this exotic novel is a mansion on a Caribbean island. The actors include the Master of the Manor -- who is also an addict to drugged cigarettes; his long-suffering wife; and the three grown daughters who come home for a holiday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 -- When the Red Sox breezed into this sprawling metropolis the other day, Jim Piersall breezed in with them. There is an airy quality about Piersall that almost borders on the ethereal, especially when he plays the outfield. Then he's a disembodied spirit who suddenly materializes in the most unexpected places and performs feats of ghostly magic.

Pre-spring weather, almost warm enough for shirt sleeves, means that Mister Skipper, his Mate, and his small fry, who have the rating of deckhands, are just about ready to begin spending their Saturdays and Sundays at their yacht club or storage yard. They will first peel back the tarpaulins for airing and then plan the schedule of cleaning, sanding, painting and varnishing.

WHEN Joseph Buttinger, one-time leader of Austria's underground Socialists in the Thirties published his memoirs ("In the Twilight of Socialism") he added fresh fuel to the debate on "what happened to democratic socialism?"

An increasing tendency to blame the public schools for everything that goes wrong in society was attacked here yesterday at a nation-wide conference of psychiatrists, psychologists and social workers.

MOSCOW, March 13 (AP) -- When the Soviet Communist party blasted composers for straying from the party's musical line, it meant simply that "the people paternally point out the composers' mistakes." That's how Aram Khatchaturian interprets it publicly today.

TRENTON, March 13 -- Salvatore A. Bontempo, Newark City Commissioner, announced today that he would withdraw from the Democratic Senatorial primaries. His decision, reached after a two-hour conference here with Gov. Robert B. Meyner, removed the possibility of a contest within the party.

In Henry Steele Commager's otherwise excellent article, "Ten Guides for Our Foreign Policy" (Feb. 21), we read a reference to "the Nolan substitute" for the Bricker amendment. Since United States Senators have such an influential part in shaping foreign policy, I think they are entitled to have their names spelled correctly.

CHICAGO, March 13 -- The pace of business in February in the Chicago area slackened, compared with the optimistic tone achieved during January, the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago reported in its monthly survey.

NEW DELHI -- India has decided to shoot for those tourist dollars in 1954. The tourist, in turn, is encouraged to shoot at India's tigers. Government-approved shikaris, or hunters' agents, will now arrange a ten-day jungle sortie for $620 a person, including all expenses except drinks and smokes, and with a clear shot guaranteed.

MRS. KEOGH'S fifth novel, with its charming line drawings by the author's artist-husband, is likely to appeal particularly to those readers who relish vicariously the convulsive pleasures of extra-marital sin. Otherwise, this tale of Ellen and Sandy Hunter, and the effect upon their lives of another man's frank desire for Ellen, is disappointingly slight.

MADRID, March 13 -- The Falange party appears to have won an important economic battle. It has sought political control of Spain's private enterprise and a determining voice in how United States economic aid must be apportioned among industries.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 13 -- The year 1952 marked the first post-war recession in the production of wood pulp, according to the "Yearbook of Forest Products Statistics, 1953." The book was released this week by the Food and Agriculture Organization.

YORK, Pa., March 13 -- George F. Kennan, the former Ambassador to Russia and foreign policy expert, announced today that he was a candidate for the Democratic nomination to Congress for Pennsylvania's nineteenth District.
MIAMI, March 13 -- The Dodgers treated the Red Sox with even less consideration today than last night, beating the American Leaguers; 5 -- 0, before 3,196 fans.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 13 -- Loans for commerce, industry and agriculture made by member banks of the Federal Reserve in leading cities of the Far West dropped $21,000,000 in the week ended March 3, the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco reported yesterday.

VIENNA -- Lifting of travel restrictions in Eastern Austria by the Soviet occupation authorities was an important item of international news last year. It is big news in 1954 for Austrian-bound Americans, for it means that Vienna, Lower Austria and the Burgenland are again open to them after fourteen years.
The modern teaching methods used in the New York City school system were defended yesterday by Vito F. Lanza, a vice president of the Board of Education.
A program to keep the American tanker fleet from fleeing to foreign flag was recommended to Congress last week by the Independent Tanker Association of Licensed and Unlicensed Personnel.
ATHENS, March 13 -- The Greek Government has expressed concern over current litigation in Washington in which Greek ship-owners are involved, principally the Niarchos group and its affiliates.
The groundwork that Dr. Paul Ehrlich laid for recent developments in immunology and antibiotics was reviewed yesterday at a conference commemorating the 100th anniversary of his birth.

Despite yesterday's rain, a good-sized crowd flocked through the doors of Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx as the Thirty-eighth International Flower Show prepared to end its week-long stay. Officials said the over-all attendance had been the fourth largest in the history of the show. The record attendance year was 1946. when the exhibition was resumed after a lapse during World War II.

IT is amusing when it is not irritating to realize how quickly matters of art, especially, can become bogged down with semantics. The reflection is borne in upon us by the perusal of an article refreshing for its plain common sense as well as its critical perspective by Winthrop Sargeant in The New Yorker of recent date.
A call to large-scale cooperative buying as the solution to pressing problems faced by small lumber yards was sounded last week.

WINNIPEG, Man., March 13 -- Traffic officials here are deeply interested in moves to make automobile insurance compulsory in New York State. Manitoba was the first Canadian province to pass a measure modeled on the New York safety-responsibility law.

THE new Federal excise bill, adopted last week by the House of Representatives and now awaiting action by the Senate, will reduce by $100,000,000 the amount the 15 per cent Federal transportation tax has been adding each year to the cost of business and pleasure travel.
HAVERSTRAW, N. Y., March 13 -- There will be contests in elections next Tuesday in six of the eleven incorporated villages in Rockland County.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 13 -- Die Burger, principal organ of the governing Nationalist party, reported today under front-page banner headlines that the Soviet Union was engaged in uranium espionage in South Africa.
Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the performance of "Faust" next Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Scholarship Fund of the Vassar Club of New York.
PARIS, March 13 -- The children of twelve countries went back to their classes at the most international school in the world this week.

BATON ROUGE, March 13 (UP) -- Bud Holscher, a youthful golfer making his first tour, and Chandler Harper broke from the pack with sizzling under-par rounds today to move into a tie for the lead after three rounds in the $10,000 Baton Rouge open.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- A collection of records recently uncovered in the dust and history of the Internal Revenue Bureau's attic shows some of the early tax trouble of the Republic.

COPENHAGEN -- "Wonderful Copenhagen" is more than a movie song hit. The capital of the Danes is truly wonderful. In fact this whole country of 4,000,000 gay and hardworking people merits the adjective.

TRURO, England -- "Britain's Riviera," the title applied to the two most southwesterly of England's counties, sounds too tempting, but it is none the less fair. Although Devon and Cornwall differ a great deal in their traditions and scenery, they form a peninsula that juts 150 miles out into the Atlantic.
LAST week may be remembered as the week that broadcasting recaptured its soul.
WASHINGTON,, March 13 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, sent Senator Joseph R. McCarthy a sharp telegram today in which he accused the Senator, in effect, of lying.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Sunday, March 14 (UP) -- Winds of more than 100 miles per hour swept through middle Georgia last night, killing four persons, injuring some twenty-five and causing $10,000,000 damage at Fort Benning and Lawson Air Force base.

Last week it was reported that the Indo-Pacific Fisheries Council had been meeting in Bangkok, Thailand, to discuss plankton as a food. Plankton is a generic name for multiple billions of minute plants and animals on which about every creature in the sea lives, from the whale down to the oyster.

ALTHOUGH they were swamped by a monsoon and plagued by a succession of accidents, the cast and crew now filming "The Purple Plain" in the jungles here have found both the work and the country exotic beyond expectations.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- A high Government official indicated today the United States had set off the most powerful hydrogen blasts yet achieved at the Eniwetok testing grounds.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 13 -- In one half of the towns of Fairfield County it is so quiet politically that one may hear a ballot drop when the Republicans hold their Town Committee elections Thursday.
MINEOLA, L. I. March 13 -- Indifferent balloting is expected in most of Nassau County next Tuesday when home-rule officials will be elected in fifty-two incorporated villages.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 13 -- The Albert Einstein Award, one of the highest honors in science, will be given this year to Dr. Richard P. Feynman, 35-year-old Professor of Theoretical Physics at the California Institute of Technology.

The 500 members of the emergency division of the New York Police Department, generally the first at accident and disaster scenes and probably the city's most important first-aid team, are Red Cross trained.
Seven thousand Columbia College alumni from the New York area have been invited to join in the eighth annual Dean's Day celebration Saturday.

MEMPHIS, March 13 (UP) -- Southeastern Conference officials were told tonight what the S. E. C. would get out of a Cotton Bowl tie-up, but there were no indications whether the offer would be accepted.
PARIS, March 13 -- The eighteen French Cardinals and Archbishops issued today a statement defending the Roman Catholic hierarchy's restrictions on the worker-priest mission in France.

HONG KONG, March 13 -- A tightening of state economic control has been taking place in Communist China under what the Peiping Government calls the "general line of the state in its transition toward socialism."
THE time will pass when men will maintain an inflexible position for or against traditional or contemporary architecture.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., March 13 -- A Staten Island bank president, David L. Decker of Port Richmond, today was elected the new commander of District No. 4 of the United States Power Squadrons. Decker was chosen at a week-end conference of yachtsmen from the seven affiliated units, New York Squadron, Bronx, North River, Northern New Jersey, Staten Island, Palisades and Shrewsbury.

THROUGH one politico-geographical oddity or another, the map of Europe has become lightly sprinkled with a number of handkerchief-size independent states which have retained their independence (more or less, depending on the state) down through the years.

TOMORROW morning from 7 to 9 o'clock -- and Mondays through Fridays thereafter -- C. B. S. television will put forth "The Morning Show," an entertainment-news-music series designed to compete directly with N. B. C.'s "Today" as the breakfast companion of millions.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 13 -- The United States invited the Latin-American nations today to begin parleys at the Inter-American Conference here leading to bilateral tax treaties.

MILWAUKEE, March 13 (AP) -- The Rev. Robert Richards made the first 15-foot pole vault of the indoor season tonight in the Milwaukee Journal indoor track games. He cleared the height by 1/4 inch before 9,300 fans in the Milwaukee Arena.

LAST year the Royal Dramatic Theatre in Stockholm had a great success with Eugene O'Neill's powerful drama, "A Moon for the Misbegotten." The National Theatre in my native Oslo is currently rehearsing the play. And yet, incredible though it seems, this last work of the great American playwright has never been presented on his own Broadway.

SINGAPORE, Sunday, March 14 -- A British airliner, London-bound from Australia, somersaulted and burned in landing at Singapore's airport yesterday and killed thirty-three of the forty persons aboard. The victims included at least three Americans and a Canadian.

ALTHOUGH he ostensibly was vacationing abroad, Jose Ferrer managed to mix business with pleasure. The actor did not come back empty-handed but returned with a property which he plans to film independently, it was learned last week.

OSLO -- Norway is without doubt the most inexpensive country in Scandinavia for the American tourist. Not only are Norwegian hotel prices much lower than in the rest of Scandinavia but bills are also pleasantly devoid of the many "extras" so dear to the hearts of hotelmen in this part of Europe.

THREE factors control the planning of a successful European budget tour. They are: (1) it costs an average of $10 to travel from one European captital to the next one, (2) the more countries you see in Europe the more you obtain from your investment in trans-Atlantic fares, and (3) following out the usual regional circle tour of guidebooks can mean wasteful retracing of ground.
The following is Samuel Taylor's foreword to his comedy hit, "Sabrina Fair," which has been published by Random House.

Pietro Francesco Mele, 31-year-old Italian movie producer, left here yesterday aboard the liner Queen Mary -- and this time he made his exit good. Two months ago Mr. Mele was taken from the American Export liner Constitution by representatives of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office in connection with an assault charge.
The first of the spring series of dances for young persons, the Senior Holiday Dance, will be held next Saturday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.

IN several recent novels William Brown Meloney has introduced us to the town of Haviland in Dutchess County, N. Y. To an upstate New Yorker, Haviland is a puzzling community, quite urban on some occasions and very small-townish on others, but it is never dull

Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of the Rockefeller Institute of Medical Research, will he the keynote speaker at Boston University's thirteenth annual Founders' Day Conference which opens on Tuesday for three days. Improvement of instruction, research and community action in the field of human relations will be the goal of the conference.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 13 -- A memorial exhibition of 200 pieces of African sculpture from the Linton collection was opened today at the Yale University art gallery and design center. The collection is one of the largest private groups of Negro folk art in the United States.

THE ideals which animate today's artists are various indeed and not always explicit or easily discoverable. This is to be expected, for artists seldom say anything more enlightening about their work than they exemplify in it. But one of them, Lee Gatch, contributes to his retrospective exhibition at the Borgenicht Gallery a series of comments, a sort of log-book of his progress over the past twenty-five years, which is very much to the point.

WHEN I returned on the boat train to Cherbourg, just two weeks after arriving in Paris for a vacation -- with two bottles each of Chartreuse, perfume and brandy; a Dufy lithograph and two pairs of Moroccan babouches -- I had a pocket fairly empty of cash, but a head filled with memories.

THERE are three very special sights in France which I would want my friends to see. They are not esoteric things, but they are stirring. They are the Louvre, Chartres Cathedral and the floodlit chateaux of Touraine.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13 (AP) -- Jean Cronstedt of Penn State, a native of Finland, was the star of the twenty-seventh Eastern Intercollegiate Gymnastic League individual championships tonight, winning three of eight events.

RIO PIEDRAS, P. R., March 13 -- The Puerto Rican Commonwealth Government's round-up of Nationalists and Communists was endorsed here today by Rexford G. Tugwell, insular Governor from 1941 to 1946, even though he labeled both groups utterly "marginal."

NO question about it, the 75-year-old Lord Dunsany is one of our favorite crochets. A friend of ours, whose property was adjacent to the Lord's, used to regale us with delicious stories about the old fellow, one of which we'll pass along.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UP) -- The nation's first full-scale atomic power plant will be built at Pittsburgh and operated by the Duquesne Light Company, the Atomic Energy Commission announced today.

Licenses to conduct pari-mutuel gambling races in the state are restricted in number by law. The State Harness Racing Commission, appointed by the Governor, issues licenses every year to the franchise holders. It also allots racing dates.

WHEN Anita Loos voiced suspicion recently that her adaptation of the French comedy hit, "The Amazing Adele," might wind up as a musical she must have been playing prophetess. For this morning's intelligence is that contracts are in the making and "The Amazing Adele" really is going to wind up as a musical with a couple of young men, Albert Selden and Robert Wells, supplying the tunes and lyrics respectively.
GENEVA -- This summer in Switzerland the by-word will be "up." More than ever before the trend is to the high places. And more than ever before the country is geared to satisfy that demand.

Horrors! They held a "fixed" swimming meet at Mercersburg (Pa.) Academy. Form took a nose-dive. Favorites finished last in almost every event. But there was no scandal. The purpose was to entertain visitors during the midwinter week-end.
MEXICO CITY, March 14 -- The Mexican Ministry of Economy is considering a plan for a hemisphere raw-materials stockpile along the same lines as the United States ever-normal granary.
BOSTON, March 14 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins, led by Wingman Fleming Mackell, whipped the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 0, tonight and dropped the Leafs to third place in the National Hockey League.

PITTSBURGH, March 14 -- Sentiment in the steel industry last week was a little darker than the ingot rate -- or the volume of fresh orders -- indicated. The production rate was off 1 1/2 points to 69 per cent. It began to look as if there was little chance of a significant upturn in the steel rate this month.
In this era of textile experimentation, blended and mixed fabrics of two or more fibers are increasingly important in the fashion world. The latest combination unites silk and wool.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- The Communist Hungarian Legation in this city has been detected operating a clandestine radio transmitter, Congressional testimony disclosed today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 14 -- The Agrarian Affairs Minister, Mohammed Hanafiah, has confirmed reports of new land disturbances in East Sumatra's rich estate belt.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 14 -- The crisis that has arisen in the European Payments Union because so many member countries are now in either an extreme creditor or an extreme debtor position cannot be overcome by any makeshift changes, official and business quarters in Switzerland believe.

MOSCOW, March 14 --Under blue skies and a bright March sun more than 115,000,000 Soviet citizens marched to the polls today to elect 1,331 members of the Supreme Soviet, the nation's highest legislative body.

Continued idleness of four city-owned piers on Staten Island, and the prospect of two more being vacant in the near future, is causing serious business losses there. A special committee of civic leaders is striving to correct the situation.

Activity in the foreign exchange market picked up considerably during the past week. Business was reported to have been much heavier than in many of the recent sessions. Though the British pound sterling continued to maintain a steady undertone the Canadian dollar turned soft in mid-week, then followed an irregular trend for the balance of the week.
LONDON, March 14 -- In spite of the fact that in a good many respects the business outlook remains obscure, there still is a mood of confidence in the City.

The Russians are attempting to earn time to consolidate the territorial gains they have already made by tempting the free nations into a "bargain," according to Representative Charles J. Kersten, Republican of Wisconsin.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 14 -- Helen Traubel, former Metropolitan Opera star and occasional television companion of Jimmy Durante, is about to make her movie debut.
MIAMI, Fla., March 14 -- Walter (Smoky) Alston, the Dodgers' manager, today was named pilot of the National League All-Star team by Warren Giles, league president.
LONDON, March 14 -- About twenty of a group of British business men canceled their projected flight to Berlin today for trade talks in East Berlin with representatives of Communist China.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today that it would be good news "throughout the world we must lead" if President Eisenhower's leadership was as resolute and undivided as Vice President Richard M. Nixon had described it last night.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 14 -- Communist-led Vietminh forces launched a massive assault last night against Dienbienphu in what may become a decisive battle in the Indo-Chinese war.

The need for a strong Zionist movement for the building and safeguarding of Israel as well as for "the cultural survival of the Jewish people everywhere" was underscored yesterday by two Zionist leaders.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- Government advisers warned Congress that United States air research is lagging and that the consequences could be disastrous.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- Sixty million taxpayers will square their accounts with the Government tomorrow by paying a record $70,000,000,000 in income and corporate taxes, Treasury experts said today.
The New York Rangers waged a commendable contest against the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman charged yesterday that Mayor Wagner's Administration was yielding to pressure of racial bigots in delaying final authorization of low-rent public housing projects in certain neighborhoods.

Only pure scientists, lured into deep caverns in a search for a legendary Eden of mangoes and breadfruit, would emerge happily laden with fruit bats. These bats were among the 97,830 zoological and botanical specimens brought back from New Guinea by the fourth Archbold Expedition.
A program was proposed yesterday to curb the use of election laws by political bosses for their own purposes.

Except for the Communists, the Belgian Senate has ratified the European Defense Community by a nonparty vote. Considering the rigid lines dividing the parties, this nonpartisan approval of a step without precedent in the history of the present kingdom is an event in the life of Belgium and of Europe.

A research project is under way at Lenox Hill Hospital to determine whether the functioning of certain mentally retarded children can be improved through psychiatric treatment of the youngsters and guidance for the parents.
General Foods Corporation, one of the world's largest manufacturers of packaged grocery products, began moving its home offices from Manhattan to White Plains yesterday.

A report seeking gradual decontrol of commercial rents has been submitted to the Temporary State Commission to Study Rents and Rental Conditions, it was announced yesterday by Harry B. Helmsley, chairman of the business and commercial rent committee of the Real Estate Board of New York.

The youthfulness and simplicity of line in this spring's fashions make it possible for teen-age girls to wear dresses closely resembling those of their mothers. The three patterns selected today by Patterns of The Times show the newest silhouettes of the season adapted for younger girls.

MIAMI, Fla., March 14 -- The Dodgers today belted the Boston Red Sox into submission for the third straight time. The victory ran the Brooklyn winning streak to five games as the Dodgers pared competition here until next Friday night, when the Yankees will be their opponents.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 14 -- Thousands of Puerto Ricans showed their solidity with the United States today.
BOSTON, March 14 -- General Allen said today that he "didn't consider it anything out of the way" to build a dog run and kennel adjoining his home at Government expense.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- Congress has been alerted to look for a sharp step-up in draft calls, despite the end of the Korean conflict and a cut in the size of the Army.

OLDSMAR, Fla., March 14 -- A little more than a fortnight ago, Tony DeSpirito, America's leading jockey in 1952, flew down to Miami to ride Black Metal in the $100,000 Flamingo Stakes at beautiful Hialeah. He strolled into the jockey room to don his working clothes. The other jocks looked up in surprise at the sight of this comparative stranger.

Vytautas Bacevicius, as customary in his piano recitals, divided his program among standard composers and himself. In Town Hall on Saturday evening, he played Franck's Prelude, Fugue and Variations, a Chopin group, Liszt's Tarantelle, short pieces by Curlionis, Debussy and Tcherepnine, and his own Sonata, Op. 43, No. 4.
VIENNA, March 14 -- The Socialist party made a net gain of 160 mandates in 240 municipalities in the province of Carinthia today over a combined People's party and independent list.
The Union of South Africa will enter the refining and petrochemical industry this summer with a plant costing about $100,000,000.

TROY, N. Y., March 14 -- Fifteen thousand persons lined Troy's downtown streets tonight to welcome home the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute hockey team, which won the National Collegiate championship last night by defeating Minnesota, 5 -- 4, in overtime at Colorado Springs, Colo.

The United Defense Fund has named General of the Army Omar N. Bradley as its campaign chairman. The fund is the federated money-raising-body for the United Service Organizations and five other voluntary health, welfare and recreation services for men and women in the defense program.

The concert given by Arturo Toscanini and the N. B. C. symphony yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall, and broadcast to the nation, was one of the most impressive and memorable of his performances here.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The re-appointment of Gordon R. Clapp as Administrator of the Tennessee Valley Authority is not certain. His seven-year term expires in May.

WHEN, St. Augustine was the metropolis of Florida 120 years ago it was only a frontier village of 3,000. It was old and it boasted a cathedral and a fort, but the wilderness began only a few miles away. All the rest of Florida was wilderness. Here and there were a few orange groves and plantations. To the south were several tiny Army posts.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Labor committees of the House and Senate are slowly grinding out new versions of the Taft-Hartley Act. If the two products can be reconciled into law it will be the most unexpected feat of this Congress.
Three more new Mariner-type ships have been ordered into idleness by the Government, Louis S. Rothschild, Maritime Administrator, announced over the week-end.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., March 14 (AP) -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, whose skaters restored the prestige of Eastern hockey by winning the national collegiate tournament, placed four men on the Associated Press all-tournament team.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 14 -- World leaders in science, philosophy, education, government and the arts sent greetings today from many parts of the earth to Prof. Albert Einstein on his seventy-fifth birthday.
PARIS, March 14 -- Mme Germaine Peyrolles, an advocate of European union, won a decisive victory today over a Communist in a run-off National Assembly election in a Paris suburb.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 -- Paul Richards and his White Sox, touted by many as perhaps the Yankees, most formidable rivals this year, dealt the world champions a deal of mischief today.
The highest sales in its history and its best earnings from operations in twenty-seven years were recorded by the American Locomotive Company last year, the annual report disclosed today.
A Police Department spokesman confirmed reports last night that there was "strong speculation" that the department's Midtown Squad might be abolished within the next-few days.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 14 (AP) -- Louise Suggs stood off heavy pressure today and won her second women's Titleholders golf championship with a record 293 for the seventy-two holes.

The appointment of Capt. George Patrick Kenney of the Coast Guard as officer in charge of marine inspection in this area was announced yesterday by Rear Admiral Louis B. Olson, commander of the Third Coast Guard District. Captain Kenney replaces Capt. F. W. Richardson, who retired on March 1 after thirty years in the service.

Governor Dewey's special message to the Legislature, the bills that go with it and the Moreland Act Commission's inquiry that substantiated the need for reform should go a long way toward cleaning up the harness racing game. The legislation will put this industry under the state's thumb, drastically. Who will say that it was not needed, not justified?
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- The text of Adlai E. Stevenson's statement on Vice President Richard M. Nixon's speech:

The "Operator 25" service has been so successful in furnishing the names of local dealers in nationally advertised products through phone calls to Western Union that the telegraph company is now going to handle it exclusively.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- United States members of the military observer's team in Kashmir travel on United Nations orders, but with American passports, a United Nations official explained today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 14 -- The Tenth Inter-American Conference appears to be setting a record for a minimum of secret politics. Thus far, as best as anyone could learn, there have been no horse-swapping, no deals and no secret agreements.

The Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble completed its third season last night with a program at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. The program followed the ensemble's regular pattern -- that is, it consisted of unusually scored works, both classic and modern, with members of the group taking turns in performing.
INCHON, Korea, Monday, March 15 -- The Forty-fifth (Thunderbird) Division was on its way today to New York, where it is scheduled to parade up Broadway April 22.

Members of the Catholic Court Attaches Guild of the City of New York were urged yesterday to read Roman Catholic publications "based on morality and justice." They were advised to be wary of secular newspapers and magazines, whose "views and methods of reporting" were said to be based on "expediency and a desire to manipulate public opinion."

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Congress is beginning to realize that its urge to investigate is getting it into trouble -- even to a point of bad repercussions, on both sides of the political fence, in election returns.
Leading this week's art events is the 1954 Whitney Annual of American sculpture, water-colors and drawings which opens Wednesday.

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., March 14 (AP) -- The thunderless, herdless Thundering Herd of Marshall College must remain thunderless and herdless. The buffalo, for Marshall's purposes, is extinct. A fruitless three-year search for a live bison has just been abandoned by the student senate.

MEXICO CITY, March 14 (UP) -- A Colombian cyclist and a Venezuelan woman swimmer handed Mexico its only setbacks today as the athletes of the host nation continued to dominate the Central American games.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- Fog and light winds plagued the fleet of thirty-two today in the annual St. Petersburg-Havana yacht race.

The paper that he read in New Orleans says as much. It breathes an optimism born of long and intensive study and of experimenting which began several years ago with animals and early in 1952 with children.

He was referring to the indications that after the Bricker imbroglio has ceased, "lawyers, judges, historians and professors of English will become even more involved" about what the "Founding Fathers really intended the Constitution to mean."

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The question whether United States forces in Europe should be reduced was reopened today by the subcommittee on defense activities of the House Committee on the Armed Services.

Public housing costing a billion dollars has given this city 70,000 low-rent and medium-rent apartments since 1936. Of these, 54,000 have been built since 1946, when the return of World War II veterans turned a serious housing shortage into a crisis.
Wagner's "Parsifal" will return to the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera Friday evening, March 26.
Succulent pork loin roast with a crisp, well-browned crust and tender, flavorful flesh may have been the choice for last week-end. It was attractively priced, generally at 69 cents a pound.

Stockholders of the American Natural Gas Company will vote on a proposal to increase the authorized capitalization from 4,000,000 to 5,000,000 common shares at the annual meeting on April 28. There are 3,684,276 common shares outstanding.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The key men in the Army's fight with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy are John Adams, the Army counsel; Fred Seaton, Assistant Secretary of Defense for public affairs, and Struve Hensel, former Defense Department counsel.

SYRACUSE, March 14 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals tied the Boston Celtics for second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association by romping to a 113 -- 83 victory over the division winning New York Knickerbockers tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- President Eisenhower will carry an appeal directly to the nation tomorrow night in an effort to hold tax cuts to the level proposed by his Administration.
CHICAGO, March 14 -- Smith, Barney Co. of New York and Chicago has been appointed financial adviser for a $1,500,000,000 expressway from Chicago to Miami.

LONDON, March 14 -- A new "landing sight," intended to make it possible for supersonic fighters to make clean, sure landings on aircraft carriers, has been developed for the Royal Navy, the Admiralty announced today.

Despite irregular movements last week, cotton prices generally advanced onto firmer ground, New York Cotton Exchange closings on Friday ranging from 22 points higher to 5 points lower than on the preceding week-end. The only net recession was that for the distant July delivery. In the previous week the market had gained 11 to 17 points.
SEA GIRT, N. J., March 14 -- Plans to create a state bathing beach here met sharp opposition today from Mayor Edward T. Doyle and leaders of civic groups.

NAHA, Okinawa, March 14 (UP) -- Islanders slogged through dismal weather to the polls today to elect twenty-nine men who will govern the strategic Ryukyus under the guidance of the United States civil administration.

The Civil Service Reform Association urged the City Council yesterday to endorse the bill now before the Legislature to reorganize the Municipal Civil Service Commission. It also would add the functions of personnel director to those of a chairman chosen by the Mayor.

Gen. Mark W. Clark, retired, has written a follow-up to his "Calculated Risk," covering the last seven years of his career as an Army officer. Entitled "From the Danube to the Yalu," the author describes his contacts with the Communists on the battlefield and over the conference table since he first encountered "Communist duplicity as United States High Commissioner for Austria in 1945."

The first sizable shipments of wine to come from Israel since that state was formed are arriving here for Passover. In all, 20,000 cases (twelve bottles each) are expected, almost half of which already are here. The first lot goes on sale this week in retail shops for about $1.50 a bottle.

The Population Reference Bureau says that about 3 per cent of the nation's population move from one state to an other each year. Many more persons undoubtedly move intrastate; the Institute of Life Insurance estimates that this year 31,000,000 people will pull up stakes and move to other homes.

New attempts to end the ten-day-old pier strike got nowhere yesterday. Business leaders warned that the tie-up would force the layoff today of thousands of workers in industries that are dependent on the port.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 14 (AP) -- Former Foreign Minister Hossein Fatemi, number two man in the deposed Mossadegh regime, will go on trial on treason charges in about two months, Iran's chief prosecutor said today.

QUEBEC CITY Que., March 14 -- "We want to show the bushmen of the Canadian northland -- the trappers and game wardens -- what wealth they may be walking around on. And what to do about it after they recognize it."

Instruction in water safety in this city has probably saved more lives than any other local Red Cross activity except the blood program. When the program was initiated here in 1924 New York had one of the nation's highest drowning rates. In that year
WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Civil Service Commission has turned up the names of 116 former Government employes who have refused to testify to their loyalty before Congressional committees.

ROME, March 14 -- Communism's most direct assault on the free world west of the Iron Curtain is being made in Italy. Italian inexperience with democracy, economic imbalance and individual regional traditions are being exploited by a brilliantly organized Communist party to threaten the existence of parliamentary institutions.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr., the Attorney General, today denied a statement that the Senate subcommittee headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had access to confidential files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Administration's plan to block any sharp dip in the nation's economy is two-thirds completed. The program will be "ready to roll" within a matter of weeks whenever President Eisenhower decides that broad action is necessary.

Precepts governing the obligations of Christian workers to society and to their employers were laid down yesterday by the Rev. Edward J. Hogan, spiritual director of the Social Order Forum of St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church, 980 Park Avenue.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 14 (AP) -- Turn-to and Porterhouse, two of thoroughbred racing's top 3-year-olds, arrived at Keeneland yesterday to prepare for Kentucky's spring racing season. Both are highly regarded candidates for the Kentucky Derby at Louisville on May 1.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $78,373,243,716. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
The methods being used by five utility companies to gain control of Niagara River power were attacked yesterday by Robert Moses, new chairman of the State Power Authority.
PARIS, March 8 -- This is the story of a sophisticated young white woman who lived among, and perhaps ruled over the colored people of Africa about 5,000 or 6,000 years ago.

NEWARK, March 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner announced today the appointment of four of the five members of the state commission to regulate bingo in New Jersey. He gave the names in the first of a series of television and radio "Reports to the People" on the operations of New Jersey's Government.

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- A disturbing situation is developing here between the two major political parties: they are allowing their angry argument over partisan domestic policy to interfere with their cooperation in the field of foreign policy.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (AP) -- The Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson, has authorized the Air Force to take full control and operation of its own recruiting system on July 1. It now shares recruiting with the Army.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 14 -- World production of coal continued in 1953 to decline from the peak reached in 1951, the United Nations reported today in its Monthly Bulletin of Statistics for March. The rate of decrease was insignificant compared with that of 1952, but it involved continuance of a shift away from North American importance in the field, in favor of eastern Europe and Soviet Russia.

The Venezuelan Line, which withdrew from the Flota Mercante Grancolombiana last summer, has completed arrangements for operating six steamship services connecting Venezuela with New York, Baltimore, Philadelphia and New Orleans.

LAKE SUCCESS, L. I., March 14 -- Engineers at the Sperry Gyroscope Company plant here who have been on strike since March 2 voted tonight to accept a company settlement offer and to return to work tomorrow. The vote was 692 to 250.
Mayor Wagner will enter his first "budget retreat" late this week or early next.

Policies of nonviolent resistance similar to the pacifism of Mohandas K. Gandhi in India were advocated yesterday as "desperate remedies for our desperate ills" by John Haynes Holmes, founder and minister emeritus of the nondenominational Community Church of New York.

CHICAGO, March 14 (UP) -- Rookie Jacques Plante posted his second consecutive shutout and his fifth in fourteen games tonight as the Montreal Canadiens downed the Chicago Black Hawks, 6 -- 0, to take second place in the National Hockey League.

Most reference books give the year of Amerigo Vespucci's birth as 1451. Perhaps this error, if such it was, would not have mattered to him if he could have sustained beyond doubt his claims to have discovered and mapped the shores of South America.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- If a person likes to cook, make beds or wait on tables, he might find a career at the White House.

Columbia's adaptation of the James Jones novel, "From Here to Eternity," was voted the best film of 1953 in the thirty-first annual poll of motion picture critics conducted by the trade paper, The Film Daily. It received 274 of the 311 votes cast.

CHICAGO, March 14 -- Wheat futures, with the exception of the March delivery, registered new high points for the season, But from the top levels of the week there were reactions due largely to profit-taking sales.
GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany, March 14 (AP) -- West Germany and Austria shared top honors as the nineteenth Arlberg-Kandahar ski festival ended today.

VICE PRESIDENT RICHARD M. NIXON deserves a Peabody prize all his own. Apparently he is about the only man -- certainly among the major political figures -- who refuses to play video's irritating little game of hide and seek with a director or camera man.

ALBANY, March 14 -- Governor Dewey is planning to send the Legislature tomorrow a special message proposing legislation "to take harness racing out of politics and keep politics out of harness racing."

A recent issue of the New York Times carried an article entitled: "African Hopes of Self-Rule Raise Cocoa Cost, Imperil 5-Cent Candy Bar." According to the writer, the price of cocoa has risen eight times in the New York market since the beginning of the Second World War, a situation attributed by American cocoa merchants to the manipulation of the market by the British Marketing Boards of the Gold Coast and Nigeria.

APPLETON, Wis., March 14 (UP) -- Senator McCarthy said today he had a "secret witness" who could back up his charge that Mr. Stevens had tried to divert him from investigating the Army by offering to provide "dirt" on the Navy or Air Force.

An unusual commission to freight forwarders, to stimualte trade from Florida to Puerto Rico, has been announced by Trailer Marine Transportation, Inc., which operates a truck-trailer ship on the southern run.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 14 -- What happened today to Bob Feller and Hal Newhouser, two former pitching greats, who, between them have posted 449 American League victories -- 249 for Feller -- was not pleasant to see.
ALBANY, March 14 -- A bill to legalize the sale of "modified" skimmed milk has been fortified with 600 vitamin units in an effort to make it more acceptable to the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- A special Senate subcommittee said tonight that it planned to study the possible effects of radio, television, movies and comic books on juvenile delinquency.
Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that his Administration's plans for necessary expansion of public services and pay rises for city employes were being blocked by bad faith on the part of the state.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was informed last night that the invitation he received to reply over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network to an attack on him by Edward R. Murrow, C. B. S. commentator, was to him "personally" and was "not subject to transfer to anyone else."

WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Secretary of State Dulles returned to Washington today with praise for the sixteen American republics that followed his lead in adopting a policy of joint action against communism at the Tenth Inter-American Conference.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 14 (UP) -- Bob Toski, a relative newcomer to the golfing trail, fired a four-under-par 68 in the final round today for a 279 and first place in the $10,000 Baton Rouge open. The round was played in forty-degree weather.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- Roy M. Cohn acknowledged tonight that the staff of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations was being asked to sign a loyalty pledge to him.
The British Government's decision to aid in the production of aircraft by ordering "development models" as well as prototypes for testing has been heartily applauded by Britain's leaders of aviation.

Rights are being offered to holders of Wisconsin Public Service Corporation common tock to subscribe for 316,867 new shares of the common at $18.40 a share on the basis of one new share for each seven shares held on March 12.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 14 -- The most successful dog show the Saw Mill River Kennel Club ever held filled the County Center with dogs, exhibitors and spectators today.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 14 -- Speaking on problems of convertibility, Finance Minister Johan van der Kieft said last week:
Five new films, including imports from France and England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

We hope Mayor Wagner succeeds in ending the crippling waterfront strike. His first effort over the week-end was bound to fail because the A. F. L. had already indicated its rejection when sounded out in advance.

PHILADELPHIA, March 14 (UP) -- Four members of an alleged interstate meat theft ring were arrested in a parking lot today as they were transferring "several thousands of dollars" worth of meat, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

A program titled "Seldom Performed Music by Early Composers" was presented at the second Encore Concert Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The participating artists were Claude Chiasson, harpsichordist; Jose Figueroa, violinist, and William Arrowsmith, oboist.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 14 -- Tony Ziluca, with Hiccup, and Tim Chadsey, sailing Mavourneen Deegan's Penny, tied for top honors in championship frostbite dinghy racing today at Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Each totaled 43 points after four races.

WASHINGTON, March 14 (UP) -- Angry members of Congress have demanded that generals who build costly doghouses with Government funds or similarly use taxpayers' money be punished or removed from the service.

Premier Malenkov's declaration that a future war with modern weapons means the "destruction of world civilization" is to be welcomed if it means that the Kremlin rulers have finally faced up to the realities of nuclear weapons. Throughout the post-war period the official Soviet propaganda line has followed quite a reverse policy, seeking to hide from the Soviet people the true power and potentialities of these weapons.
MIAMI BEACH, March 14 -- The United States must continue to exercise its role of leadership in the interests of world peace, Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said here tonight.

Ferruccio Tagliavini made his single appearance of the season with the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night. The role he sang was that of Rodolfo in the last of the 1953-54 performances of Puccini's "La Boheme." He was the only member of the cast who had not appeared in any of the previous ten showings of the opera.

Hungarian Freedom Day was observed yesterday by 1,000 persons in the Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street. It marked the 106th anniversary of the Hungarian revolution of 1848 against foreign domination.
The color line is slowly giving way in many Southern colleges and universities.

STOWE, Vt., March 14 -- Brooks Dodge, just back from Aare, Sweden, where he competed with the American Internationale de Ski team, today won the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association giant slalom championship.

ASPEN, Colo., March 14 (AP) -- A Dartmouth College student, Chiharu Igaya, won the national slalom and downhill combined championship today by placing first in the slalom event that closed the three-day ski carnival.

Francis B. Sayre, veteran American diplomat and former chairman of the United Nations Trusteeship Council, declared yesterday that "unless Christianity became a potent force" communism would, continue to expand over the face of the globe.

The awarding of eight fellowships of $3,000 each was announced yesterday by James Kellum Smith, president of the American Academy in Rome. The grants are for one year beginning Oct. 1 and include stipend, travel allowances, free studio and residence at the academy.
During the last three years John D. Rockefeller Jr. has given $58,000,000 in securities and other assets to the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, a foundation set up in 1940 by his five sons.

New versions of that popular lighting device, the brass lamp, are included in a new collection now available here. Designed by Edmond J. Spence for the Rembrandt Lamp Corporation, the table lamps are at Modernage, 116 East Thirty-fourth Street, while standing ones can be found at We Moderns, 227 East Sixty-seventh Street.
EVANSTON, Ill., March 14 -- Dr. K. C. Wu, former Governor of Formosa and holder of high posts in the Chinese Nationalist Government, announced today an open break with Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek.
