BELLMORE, L. I., March 14 -- Eight-year-old Elizabeth Cortez bought the wrong kind of birthday card for a playmate yesterday. She started back to exchange it. On her way she was killed by a hit-and-run driver.
WASHINGTON, March 14 -- The Administration's programs in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare are crystallizing so rapidly it takes a special chart to keep track of them.
The local ship-charter market continued on even keel last week. However, the West Coast trade developed a slight list but not enough to cause any distress signals yet.

Racial and religious hatreds, discrimination and "unnatural segregation of the members of our Christian family," were condemned yesterday by the Most Rev. Vincent S. Waters, Roman Catholic Bishop of Raleigh, N. C.

On March 1 you published a letter from a number of psychiatrists and the president of the New York County Medical Society in which they offered their views on a bill introduced into the State Legislature which would define as medical practice the diagnosis and treatment of "mental and nervous disorders."

BOSTON, March 14 (AP) -- Diehl Mateer Jr. of Philadelphia and Richard Squires of New York won the national squash racquets doubles championship today by upsetting top-seeded James Etheridge and Carl Badger of Greenwich, Conn., 11 -- 15, 15 -- 9, 15 -- 9, 18 -- 16.
Two additional airlines have entered the International Air Transport Association's interline traffic agreement, bringing to 101 the number operating under its terms.
Churchgoers must have a "personally possessed religion" so that they can find a Christianity of their own, the Rev. Dr. T. Guthrie Speers said yesterday.

The board of directors of the United Service for New Americans ratified yesterday an agreement to merge with the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society into a single world-wide Jewish migration agency to be known as United Hias Service.

There may be a decision before the end of this week on the advisability of moving "The Golden Apple," the new musical at the Phoenix Theatre on Second Avenue, to a Broadway playhouse at the end of its downtown run.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March I4 (UP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., trounced Kurt Nielsen, Copenhagen, in straight sets, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 3, today to retain the masters invitation tennis championship.

RUTHERFORD, N. J., March 14 -- "Nobody won the war, but we have a fighting chance to win the peace," Dr. Daniel A. Poling, president of the World Christian Endeavor Union and chairman of the All-American Conference to Combat Communism, declared here this morning.

NEW DELHI, India, March 14 -- It is reliably understood that United States military personnel assigned to the United Nations cease-fire observer team in Kashmir will henceforth be permitted to enter India only on United Nations and not United States passports.

ROME, March 14 -- Newspapers of all political tendencies predict that Foreign Minister Attilio Piccioni will resign at the Cabinet Council Tuesday. Some even say he has already tendered his resignation and that it will be accepted Tuesday.

ALBANY ,March 14 -- The Wagner Administration urged the Legislature today to revise the New York City gross receipts tax on investment companies so as to increase the city's revenue from it by $200,000 a year.
TAMPA, Fla., March 14 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves, minus the services of Bobby Thomson and Eddie Mathews, slugged Cincinnati Redleg pitchers for seventeen hits and a 14-8 victory today.
BERLIN, March 14 -- Leaders of East Germany's Socialist Unity (Communist) party have launched a drive to rid their organization of Western-oriented "social democratism."
TOKYO, March 14 -- A strong "buy Japanese" campaign will be launched here this month with the beginning of a new fiscal year as a means of preserving Japan's dwindling supply of foreign currency.

MANILA, Monday, March 15 -- The Philippine Government prepared today to oppose a United States claim to permanent ownership of certain military bases in the Philippines based on a position reportedly taken by Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. in Washington.

PARIS, March 14 -- France can increase her trade with the Soviet Union and the satellite states, but to do so she must get a considerable revision of the lists of products now forbidden for export to the East, in the opinion of Finance Minister Edgar Faure.

The 900th anniversary of the final separation of the Eastern and Western Christian churches was commemorated yesterday afternoon at Great Vespers conducted at the Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava, 15 West Twenty-fifth Street. Bishop John of Cleveland, representing Metropolitan Leonty of the Russian Orthodox Church in North America, and Dean Doushan J. Shoukletovich of St. Sava's Cathedral took part.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 14 -- The Netherlands Jewish community expressed profound disappointment today with the role played by Roman Catholic officials in the search for missing Jewish war orphans.

Fighting off a game Squadron A bid in the second half, the New York Polo Club captured the Metropolitan League indoor polo championship, 14 to 10, in the final-round match of the annual tournament at the Squadron A Armory yesterday afternoon.

Winners of the Eastern Division title for the second straight year, the New York Knickerbockers will open their eighth straight National Basketball Association championship play-offs tonight against the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 15 -- Vietminh attackers breached another French strong point last night in the battle for Dienbienphu, according to official French information released here today.

MOSCOW, Tuesday, March 16 -- The Presidium of the Supreme Soviet appointed today Georgi Fedorovich Alexandrov, a veteran Communist party ideologist and party philosopher, as Minister of Culture succeeding Panteleimon K. Ponomarenko, who has become the party chief in Kazakhstan.

The expert and fastidious playing of Leonard Rose, 'cellist, in the late Frederick Jacobi's Sonata for 'Celo and Piano was a highlight of last evening's concert at Town Hall by the Musicians Guild. It was the fourth concert presented by the Guild this season.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation failed today to sell its holdings of $65,000,000 of bonds of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company.

The president of the Municipal Board of the Nationalist party of Puerto Rico, was sentenced here yesterday to serve six months in prison for refusing to answer questions before a grand jury investigating the terriorist organization.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs said today the United States would have to consult with its Allies now if it expected support in an emergency for the "new look" defense policy.
ALBANY, March 15 -- The administration's optional permanent personal registration bill was modified tonight in an effort to make it more palatable to Nassau County.

DELFZIJL, the Netherlands, March 9 -- The lowly cockle, which normally whiles away the centuries beneath the surface of the sea floor, has been plucked from its resting places near here and put through an investigation.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- Representative George H. Fallon, Democrat of Maryland, returned to the House chamber today, the first of five members shot by Puerto Rican fanatics to resume his legislative duties.

HONG KONG, March 15 -- Indo-China's Comunist-led insurgents announced today they had captured the height of Doclap, less than two miles north of the main French sub-sector protecting besieged Dienbienphu in northwest Vietnam.

It doesn't pay to be a villain. That was the theme of the main act in last night's variety and wrestling show at Madison Square Garden as Verne Gagne, 221, Excelsior, Minn., won from Hans Schmidt, 245, Chicago, on a disqualification.
Producers' stocks of refined copper continued to rise during February, and at the month's end were at the highest level since November, 1949.

Fresh greens, heralds of spring, already are appearing at the produce stalls. We welcome them each year about this time not only for their nutritiousness, but also for the fresh taste they bring to menus.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Federal Government lost in the Supreme Court today an attempt to assert dominant authority over water power development in navigable rivers.

The Board of Higher Education decided last night not to release any part of the transcript made of its important meeting on March 3 at which it was agreed to oust Nat Holman as basketball coach at City College.
New table accessories, whose usefulness equals their good looks, can be acquired at a number of shops here.
This is flood tide week for the channels that carry the public's money.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 15 -- Twentieth Century-Fox will build a feature-length Cinema-Scope production around the Ice Capades show that has been touring the country for the last fourteen years.

The Standard-Oil Company of California will reduce oil imports in the second quarter by 10,000 to 12,000 barrels a day below the January-February levels. T. S. Petersen, president, said yesterday this would bring Standard's import level down to about 23,000 barrels daily, which would be about 35,000 barrels a day below the level of the second quarter of 1953.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that the Seagram and Schenley liquor combines had agreed to refrain from illegal price-fixing within their giant organizations.

Among the numerous art exhibitions opening this week is one at the Kootz Gallery given over to abstract paintings by Georges Mathieu, who has made a considerable name for himself among younger French artists.

With the increase in the number of veterans as a result of the Korean hostilities and the maintenance of our armed forces at peak peacetime level, the Red Cross program for veterans continues as a significant service.

NEW HAVEN, March 15 -- Mayor Richard C. Lee, taking note of idle, non-productive city-owned property, today proposed that four abandoned public schools be razed and the sites converted into parking lots and playgrounds.

CHICAGO, March 15 (AP) -- A new high for the year was set in the cattle market today when high prime steers sold at $31.75. Prime steers were scarce and actively wanted, selling strong to 25 cents higher.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- President Eisenhower threw his prestige and influence tonight into a battle over income tax reduction.

TORONTO, March 15 (AP) -- Three track athletes who have made close bids for a four-minute mile will compete in the British Empire Games at Vancouver this summer. The mile run promises to be the highlight event of the July 30-Aug. 7 games.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Counsel for Col. Frank H. Schwable today urged the Marine aviator's "full and complete exoneration."
ALBANY, March 15 -- The Senate and Assembly Rules Committees proposed legislation tonight to increase the pay of members of the Legislature from $5,000 to $7,500.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 15 -- French headquarters announced tonight that thousands of Communist-led Vietminh troops had smashed through the northern defenses of the Dienbienphu fortress at one point and were advancing toward the heart of the base.

Daniel S. Brush 3d, as executor, has sold the two-story two-family dwelling at 3306 Avenue K in Brooklyn to Joseph Dolcemaschio. The sale was made through A. DeVito as broker and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The Treasury Department asserted today that million of persons would be relieved of any tax obligation whatsoever if the Democrats succeeded in raising personal exemptions.

A birthday cake was cut yesterday to mark the 148th anniversary of the Orphan Asylum Society for the City of New York. The celebration was held in the Graham School at Hastings-on-Hudson, the institution that the agency maintains for children of broken homes whose families are in the low income group.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, refused today to say whether he had recommended the 18 per cent cut in Army manpower called for in the "new look" defense program.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The Navy disclosed today it would start work next year on its third atomic submarine, but gave no details how she would compare with her two sister craft.
FRESNO, Calif., March 15 (UP) -- Home runs by Stan Musial, Ray Jablonski and Wally Hood paced the St. Louis Cardinals to a 16-to-7 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.
Despite safety programs, the American maritime industry still has one of the highest percentages of accidents and illnesses in the nation, the Marine Index Bureau reported yesterday.
LONDON, March 15 -- Britain intends to play "a full part" at the Geneva conference next month, Anthony Eden assured an anxious Labor member in the House of Commons today.

Brucie, an angelic looking cocker spaniel with snappy habits, cost its owners $7,500 yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Owen McGivern awarded this sum to a guest it had bitten in the nose. The victim required plastic surgery.

CHICAGO, March 15 (UP) -- The regional office of the Public Housing Administration was embarked today on one of the biggest series of real estate deals in the nation's history. It is in the process of selling to private purchasers 7,000 rental housing units built by the Government during World War II.

DACCA, Pakistan, March 15 -- The Government announced tonight a budget for the fiscal year starting April 1 that was described by Pakistanis in the Urdu superlative of "behtreen" -- magnificent, or wonderful.
LOS ANGELES, March 15 -- General of the Army Omar N. Bradley today accepted the national campaign chairmanship of the United Defense Fund.

BOSTON, March 15 (UP) -- Vince Martinez of Paterson, N. J., scored a technical knockout over Ronnie Harper of Roanoke, Va., tonight. Referee Johnny Martin stopped the scheduled ten-rounder at Boston Garden at 2:07 of the second when blood from a cut over his left eye affected Harper's vision.

Los Angeles announced yesterday that it had designated March 23 for the sale of an issue of $40,000,000 of flood control district bonds. Dated May 1, the bonds will come due annually on May 1 from 1955 to 1983.

NEWARK, March 15 -- The Federal Government rested its case this afternoon against Harold John Adonis, former executive secretary to ex-Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey, who is charged with defrauding the Internal Revenue Service of $11,809 in 1948.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission ordered today an investigation into the difference between interstate and intrastate railroad commutation fares on four lines that serve New Jersey.
MEXICO CITY, March 15 (UP) -- Capturing all five final events, Mexico won the Central American Games swimming title today by the biggest margin in the history of the event.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The nation received its first look today at two radically new Navy fighter planes that can take off "straight up" and land "straight down" -- apparently eliminating the need for runways or carrier decks to operate.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 15 -- Before the Giants stopped the Baltimore Orioles, 13 -- 8, with a twelve-hit attack today for their fourth straight triumph, Leo Durocher spoke glowingly of Ray Katt's progress in recent spring exhibition games.

The men's clothing industry operated at 85 per cent of capacity during January, compared wth 81 per cent in the 1953 month and 73 per cent in January, 1952, according to the Clothing Manufacturers Association.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's radio and television address to the nation last night as recorded by The New York Times:
New Yorkers over the age of 69 are second to the Puerto Ricans among the city's top social problems, Henry L. McCarthy, Commissioner of Welfare, said yesterday.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 15 (UP) -- T. P. Morgan's Plus Fours, the 4-to-5 favorite, and T. M. Roach's John Willie, the 14-to-5 choice, accounted for separate divisions of the split Central Falls Purse at Lincoln Downs today before a crowd of 10,446.

Magistrate John R. Starkey reluctantly dismissed twenty-eight teen-agers in Brooklyn Adolescents Court yesterday. The youths, members of rival gangs, had been arrested last Wednesday as the police got word that the Rebels and Hawks, from Borough Park and Bath Beach, were to invade West Flatbush to do battle with the Ditmas Dukes.
Ford, Bacon Davis, one of the nation's oldest engineering and construction firms, is observing its sixtieth anniversary this month.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 15 -- With or without hits the Dodgers' winning streak retains an amazing vitality. Today at Holman Stadium the Brooks won their sixth straight game, scoring two unearned runs in the ninth inning to defeat the Washington Senators, 2 -- 1.
FORT DEVENS, Mass., March 15 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Roderick Allen said today he would "gladly" pay for a doghouse he built with $1,200 in taxpayers' money if the Army requested it.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 15 -- The United States filed a statement with the International Court of Justice here today challenging the award of indemnities by the United Nations Administrative Tribunal to eleven United States citizens dismissed by the United Nations for refusing to answer questions about alleged subversive activities.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 15 -- The Tenth Inter-American Conference condemned racial discrimination today and called on the twenty-one American republics to enact legal and educational measures for its abolition.

William White, president of the New York Central Railroad Company, detailed the management's past stewardship and plans for the $2,600,000,000 carrier yesterday. He also disclosed that the present board will be aided in its gathering of proxies for the annual meeting of stockholders by Henry S. Sturgis, who has volunteered his full-time assistance.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Miss Bertha S. Adkins, assistant to the Republican National Chairman, said today that the McCarthy-Stevens controversy should be investigated by the Senate, and impartially.

Jane Froman, the singer, who fought for several years to overcome the effects of leg injuries received in a wartime plane crash, received an award yesterday for her courage. She was on her way to entertain troops when her plane went down off Lisbon in 1943.
The New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, which has mailed out 50,000,000 pencils in the last forty years, wrote finis yesterday to that form of fund solicitation.

" The Challenge of Man's Future," an analysis by Harrison Brown, a geochemist, will be published Friday by Viking Press. The author discusses present birth rates and food problems and the world future if the population increases, the living standards of now underprivileged peoples go up and resources rapidly diminish.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Industrial output continued to slide during the month ended March 6 -- a period when seasonal factors normally mean an upturn -- the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
A baby girl was killed and twelve families were made homeless yesterday when fire swept the rear apartments of a six-story tenement at 2197 First Avenue, near 112th Street.
Sheraton Corporation of America, hotel chain, is offering to its stockholders $3,273,800 of new 6 per cent debentures due in 1979 for subscription until March 29.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy rejected suggestions from the Republican Senate leadership today that he call off his speaking tour this week and proceed to bring out "all the facts" in his controversy with the Army.

The proximity in which white and Negro families dwell in public housing has resulted in better interracial attitudes, a research psychologist reported last night on the basis of studies in four cities.

The five-story business building on lot 44 by 100 feet at 982 to 992 Madison Avenue, southwest corner of Sixty-seventh Street, has been purchased by Jack Brause, operator, in a deal negotiated by the Cross Brown Company.

LONDON, March 15 -- In a rare show of unity, British's two major political parties jointly warned Egypt today that to continue her anti-British agitation in the Sudan might disrupt law and order there and lead to administrative chaos.

For the fourth successive year, the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., operated at peak production in 1953. Sales reached a new high record and earnings were the third best in its history, according to the 1953 annual report issued yesterday by John F. Thompson, chairman, and Paul D. Merica, president.

Nate Brooks of Cleveland, North American bantamweight champion, easily outpointed Henry (Pappy) Gault of Spartanburg, S. C., in a ten-round non-title bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

The present battle for the French Union outpost at Dienbienphu in northern, Tonkin may prove to be the ultimate battle for Indo-China. It may seem strange that a struggle for an outpost should have repercussions in Paris, Washington, Geneva and Moscow.
Today's lone film newcomer is "La Ronde," French-made adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler's play, "Reigen," which starts simultaneous showiness at the Bijou and Little Carnegie Theatres.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Supreme Court today barred Alabama and Rhode Island from challenging the constitutionality of the Submerged Lands Act of 1953. The action was by a 6-to-2 decision.
No more burning of refuse at private dumps in the city will be permitted after April 1.
Six member teams of the Eastern College Athletic Conference and two guest squads were named yesterday for next December's Holiday Festival basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden.
LONDON, March 15 -- Britain remains firm in her intention to retain Cyprus and "there is no change" in her opposition to the idea of a plebiscite there, diplomatic quarters said tonight.
LONDON, March 15 (UP) -- Two United States Navy planes fired on Friday by a Communist-Czech MIG-15 were unarmed and could have fired back only if they had slingshots," a Navy spokesman said today.

MADRID, March 15 -- The Spanish people learned today that their bread supply had been assured until this summer by the United States decision to sell Spain 300,000 metric tons (10,000,000 bushels) of surplus wheat.

OSLO, Norway, March 15 -- Crown Princess Martha has suffered a relapse resulting from a liver ailment and is in critical condition. A bulletin issued tonight said repeated blood transfusions had been given to her during the day, but that the 53- year-old Crown Princess was unconscious.
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15 (UP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics hit five home runs today as they defeated the Boston Red Sox, 10 to 7, for their sixth victory in a row.
Trading took place in the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in German dollar bonds of private corporations for the first time since 1941.

The sportswear boutique, with its fashions from such far-flung markets as Alberquerque and Italy, provided one of the most exciting highlights of Abraham Straus' new third-floor fashion collection yesterday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 15 -- Even the usually inspiring presence of Allie Reynolds failed to arouse Casey Stengel's Yankees out of a surprising training slump today.
ALBANY, March 15 -- A bill to require inspection of automobiles at privately owned inspection stations is to be introduced in the Legislature Wednesday with the backing of Governor Dewey.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy accepted an invitation yesterday that he appear on Edward R. Murrow's television program over the Columbia Broadcasting System's television network. He suggested April 6 as the date, and Mr. Murrow agreed.

Robert McCray took a philosophical view of a legal "clerical error" that had cost him six years in prison. The error was rectified belatedly in General Sessions yesterday, when Judge John A. Mullen granted the prisoner his freedom.

Your story on March 9 about the gluttonous cormorant and Albany's possible wing of protection is high-grade reporting. The news was dressed with interesting (and accurate) side-lights -- which is so typical of your articles.

President Eisenhower's decision to go on the air last night and to throw the weight of his office and his personal prestige behind Secretary Humphrey's tax program is an example of courageous and, we hope, effective leadership.

ONE man looks at a stream and sees trout, but another sees only a wasted potential in kilowatts, and soon another "flood control" project is proposed and the river begins to provide power instead of trout.

CLEVELAND, March 15 (AP) -- This year and next the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company will raise its post-war expansion outlay to $273,000,000. In a report to stockholders, the company said this total would be reached by expenditures in 1954- 55 of $63,000,000 for new construction and expansion.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The Senate today passed and sent to the White House a bill to exempt natural gas companies doing business within a state from Federal regulation. Passage was by voice vote after the Senate had rejected, 52 to 25, a motion by Sentaor Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, to send the measure back to the Senate Commerce Committee with orders to hold hearings.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 15 (AP) -- The Indianapolis Motor Speedway announced today the naming of three of last year's top twenty big car drivers and the national midget racing champion to drive in the thirty-eighth annual 500-mile race here May 31.
BONN, Germany, March 15 -- The current international debate on East-West trade has sharpened the appetites of West German industrialists, businessmen and politicians for Iron Curtain markets.

LONDON, March 15 -- Strength in British Government securities was the feature of the stock markets here today. Elsewhere trading was restrained by the approaching end of the bookkeeping account. Tomorrow is the last day of dealing for the final account of the Stock Exchange year.

A delegation from the Tennessee Valley is scheduled to call on President Eisenhower today, carrying a petition, signed by 40,000 Valley residents, for the reappointment of T. V. A. Chairman Gordon R. Clapp. There are more compelling reasons than the 40.000 signatures -- though these prove something -- why Mr. Clapp should be named to go on with the work he has done since David E. Lilienthal left T. V. A., in 1946.
ALBANY, March 15 -- Following is the text of Governor Dewey's special message to the Legislature today on harness racing:

HOGANSBURG, N. Y., March 15 -- Eight Indian children lost their lives early today when flames destroyed a two-story house on the St. Regis reservation here near the Canadian border. They were trapped in the building despite efforts of their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul Cree, to save them.

WINDSOR, Ont., March 15 (AP) -- A substantial increase in the sale of vehicles by Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., raised dollar sales in 1953 to a record Rhys M. Sale, president, told shareholders today in a preliminary report on last year's operations.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 15 -- Jim Busby and Pete Runnels of the Washington Senators were each batting .186 or thereabouts last June. Each was in a slump that was beginning to act like quicksand, dragging them lower and lower until they disappeared from sight. Manager Bucky Harris was so concerned that he even mulled over the idea of benching Busby.
The New York Stock Exchange membership of Hollis Hunnewell has been transferred to Benjamin T. Burton of Burton, Cluett Dana.

The thirty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the American Legion was celebrated at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday with a luncheon of twenty-eight Legionnaires who at one time or other were members of Paris Post 1, the Legion's first post.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 15 -- Reverse commuting came into its own in Westchester today when the New York Central added Train No 465 to its Harlem Division schedule.
LOS ANGELES, March 15 (AP) -- Lockheed said the XFV-1 was undergoing preliminary tests, with the first flight still weeks away. Convair said its plane was still at its San Diego plant.

HAVANA, March 15 -- The Caribbee, a fifty-seven-foot yawl owned by Carleton Mitchell of the Annapolis (Md.) Yacht Club, won the twenty-first annual St. Petersburg, Fla., to Havana race in Class A by crossing the finish line in Havana harbor at 10:37:36 A. M. today.

Three bandits, stole $8 and a policeman's pistol at 9:30 o'clock last night in a scuffle at the George Meisner Company paint store at 306 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn. The robbers drove off in an Emergency Squad radio patrol car, but it was recovered later.
The editorial on censorship at Albany in your issue of March 11 is a service to all who cherish our constitutional guarantees of free speech and a free press.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The housewife's budget was a major topic of discussion at the Senate Finance Committee's hearing today.
Among the continuing good buys in beef is top sirloin roast, selling for 79 cents a pound in one large chain.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 15 -- A dispute over fishing rights in the Sea of Galilee erupted today in an exchange of fire between Syrian and Israeli shore batteries north of the pear-shaped sea.

" No new contracts have been reported" was again the highlight of the monthly report of the Shipbuilders Council of America. It was the fourteenth consecutive time the council used the phrase in reporting steadily shrinking ship construction activity in this country.

The thirty-seventh season of Stadium Concerts will open at Lewisohn Stadium on Monday evening, June 21, and will continue through Saturday, July 31, Mrs. Charles S. Guggenheimer, the chairman, announced yesterday.

Helicopters weighing as much as 100 tons and with top speeds of 180 miles an hour were foreseen yesterday by Frank N. Piasecki, one of the country's leading designers and producers of rotary-winged planes.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 16 (AP) -- A Japanese sea captain said today that an atomic blast in the Bikini island area on March 1 showered "snow-white ashes" on his fishing boat for two hours and blistered the skin of all twenty-three men aboard.

In her column of March 1 Anne O'Hare McCormick states: "The Crimea, until the war one of the sixteen 'autonomous republics' forming the Soviet Union, and since then reduced to the status of a province of the Russian Republic, has now become a part of the Ukraine."
BORDENTOWN, N. J., March 15 -- Eight inmates, ranging in age from 19 to 21 years, escaped tonight from the Bordentown Reformatory here.

Shares on the New York Stock Exchange last month pushed ahead to the highest average month-end price since Feb. 28 last year, the Exchange reported yesterday. The average level at the end of this February was $42.53, compared with $42.03 at the end of January and $42.56 a year earlier.
Reflecting the 18.9 per cent increase in sales to a record $193,592,531, net earnings of the Fruehauf Trailer Company rose to $6,950,344 in 1953 from $5,711,525 cleared the year before.
GENEVA, March 15 (Reuters) -- Britain said today she was willing to buy substantial quantities of food and raw materials from Communist countries in return for exports of consumer goods.

DETROIT, March 15 -- The Packard Motor Car Company today reported an increase in sales in 1953 over 1952 of 43.6 per cent to $335,819,000, but a drop in net earnings of $177,297 compared with the previous year, to $5,440,966.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Republicans are using a "divide and conquer" strategy on the farm front in Congress.

The directly contradictory statements of Senator McCarthy and his chief counsel, Roy M. Cohn, on the one hand, and Secretary Stevens and his chief counsel, John G. Adams, on the other, cannot be left dangling as they now are in midair. The Senate, which created the McCarthy committee, has a clear responsibility to investigate this matter and establish all the facts.

Chain and mail-order sales declined 2.3 per cent in February, marking the seventh consecutive month that sales had dropped, in comparison with the same month of the previous year. The down-trend started in August after sixteen months of consecutive gains.

In an important by-election in a Communist stronghold in suburban Paris an outspoken advocate of the European Defense Community has defeated a Communist candidate pledged to wrecking it. The election was, in effect, a plebiscite on the Defense Community, which was the main issue in the bitterly fought contest.

People from here to Walla Walla are reading significance into every happening in connection with the fight for control of the New York Central Railroad. Yesterday Harry "Gus" Beck, manager of Schwartz' Restaurant, 54 Broad, Street, observed something.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Supreme Court today ordered a Federal District Court to grant to Joe Accardi of Newark, N. J., a hearing to determine if unfair procedures had been used by the Government in refusing to stay an order for his deportation.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Treasury announced tonight a slight drop in its short term borrowing costs.
WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to review a decision that the Korean conflict was a war.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A proposed amendment to the Federal Constitution to lower the voting age from 21 years to 18 was approved, 7 to 3, by the Senate Judiciary Committee today.
ALBANY, March 15 -- The Senate was scheduled to approve tonight two bills increasing the statutory limits on the amount of money that life insurance companies can spend for expenses.
Government agencies adopted a "get tough" policy yesterday toward wildcat pier strikers. These were the developments:...

A twelve-year-old contemporary house on the edge of a deer park in a Copenhagen suburb is the testing ground for the elegant, sculptural furniture designed by Finn Juhl. This, he says, is because he likes to try everything out at home on himself, his wife and his 13-year-old son before it is presented to the public.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands March 15 -- The sea arms of the southwest Netherlands must be closed. This was the unanimous recommendation of the Government's Delta Commission, set up thirteen months ago to investigate means of preventing the recurrence of disastrous floods.
A serious shortage of teachers and a general lack of adequate facilities are threatening the effectiveness of the city's junior high schools.

About 2,750,000 of a total of 4,500,000 Federal income tax returns were filed here in person and by mail yesterday, the deadline. Close to $2,000,000,000 in taxes was received in the Manhattan and Brooklyn district offices. Total tax receipts in this city last year came to $10,500,000,000.
Freedom of thought and expression is an essential part of civilization and anyone who would suppress it is a "traitor to mankind," Dr. Ralph Barton Perry said last night.

Dr. Frank L. Boyden, Deerfield (Mass.) Academy headmaster, who has been active in boys' athletics for more than fifty years, yesterday received the Sportsmanship Brotherhood's 1953 citation for his outstanding contributions to the cause of good sportsmanship.

Young women headed by Mrs. Stass Reed, and including Miss Mary Jane Lansburgh, are aiding in the arrangements for the tour of New York homes on April 14 and April 21 for the benefit of the New York Chapter of the Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation. Mrs. Russel L. Cecil is chairman of the executive committee for the benefit.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- The confirmation of the long pending deal with Spain, which called for about 10,000,000 bushels of wheat, stimulated buying of the old crop wheat deliveries this morning. At the same time continued dryness in the Southwest brought support into the new crop months.
This story begins with a moral: If you intend to leave suddenly with $243,500 be sure to tell your bride. Otherwise, the law will be on your trail.
ALBANY, March 15 -- Governor Dewey proposed today that all public officials and major political leaders be barred from having any connection with horse racing of any kind in New York.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP) -- Republicans generally praised President Eisenhower's defense of his tax policies tonight as forceful and convincing. Capitol Hill Democrats, however, decribed themselves as mainly unconvinced.

The city's developing war against juvenile delinquency would be materially helped if a substantial number of additional teachers could be employed as soon as possible, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, told the City Council's rules committee yesterday.
VIENNA, March 15 (AP) -- Poland announced today a radical change in the nation's agricultural policy.

The Moreland Act Commission, which investigated harness racing, said yesterday it had found so "false in all respects" the charges of "influence peddling" contained in a letter offered by former Representative Hamilton Fish that it had excluded the letter from its records.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Harlow H. Curtice, president of General Motors Corporation, said today that he was highly optimistic about the business outlook for 1954. He gave his estimate of the situation at his first press conference in Chicago since he became chief executive of the world's largest industrial enterprise. He is here attending the Chicago Automobile Show.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 14 -- Children are a less powerful force in preventing divorce in South Africa than in other countries, according to a United States specialist in domestic problems.
ATHENS, March 15 -- Greece plans to take her case for possesion of Cyprus to the United Nations unless Britain agrees to a plebiscite on the island.

Two new 7,200-deadweight-ton cargo ships will enter the Mediterranean-New York freight services of the French Fabre Line this year, according to James W. Elwell Co., Inc., general agents for the line here.
REGINA, March 15 (Canadian Press) -- A major oil discovery, "the most encouraging" in Saskatchewan to date, was announced in the Legislature today by Premier T. C. Douglas.
The largest "pitched battle" of the Indo-Chinese war was still raging yesterday around the isolated French fortress-outpost of Dienbienphu in the Thai hill country.

I believe that you have expressed the sentiment of the great majority of Americans when you editorially suggested that Congress "act now, generously and realistically, to help our friends and make stronger allies." May I point out a practical approach to the problem, which would help both the United States and the underdeveloped countries.

This newspaper yesterday published the portrait of a lady who lived in Africa some 5,000 or 6,000 years ago. The loose thousand years, more or less, do not matter so much now. The lady was probably beautiful, active, forceful and perhaps fond of light wines and beers or even heavier liquors.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday. Closing prices were 6 points lower to 16 points net higher than on last Friday, with the strength most pronounced in new crop months.

Advocating world peace is not a commercial enterprise, the Appellate Division, Second Department, ruled yesterday. The court made this observation in dismissing an information against Harry H. Purvis, owner of a building atop of which was a sign urging support of the United World Federalists, Inc.
YORK, Pa., March 15--George F. Kennan, foreign policy expert and gentleman farmer, formally became a candidate today for the Democratic nomination to Congress.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 15 -- Officials of Nassau County and the Long Island Rail Road agreed today on a plan for settlement of the bankrupt road's back taxes.

Construction of the $100,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel was halted yesterday in the wake of an adverse court ruling. In a 4-to-2 decision the New Jersey Supreme Court held that the Port of New York Authority had embarked illegally on the project by failing to obtain express permission from the Legislatures of New York and New Jersey.

NEW DELHI, India, March 15 -- The Indian Government has "returned" applications from Washington for visas for United States officers assigned as replacements to the United Nations observer team in Kashmir.
Oils and aircrafts staged a vigorous rally in the final ninety minutes of yesterday's stock market but the close generally was irregularly lower.
PICKSTOWN, S. D., March 15 -- Another milestone in the long struggle to control and utilize the Missouri River was reached here today.
VIENNA, March 15 -- Ten Hungarians have escaped from Budapest to Vienna after being caught three times and shooting two Communist policemen. The group included three women and a 5-year-old child.

WASHINGTON, March 15 (UP) -- The State Department said today that one of its officials was a few years late in announcing the silencing of a secret radio transmitter operated by the Hungarian Legation in Washington.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 15 -- The Tenth Inter-American Conference began debate today on measures to end European rule over colonies in the Americas.

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation, manufacturers of plumbing, heating and ventilating equipment, last year lifted sales by 7.6 per cent to $298,268,000, second highest in its history, from the 1952 volume of $277,153,664.

A regular schedule of business conferences between New York and Chicago by means of two- way closed-circuit television is to start soon on a regular basis. The disclosure was made yesterday by Irvin P. Sulds, president of Business Television, Inc., in a talk before the Advertising Men's Post 209, American Legion, at the Lexington Hotel. Other cities will be added as required.
ROME, March 15 -- Italian communism has succeeded in capturing the great bulk of the country's traditional Left-Wing vote and at the moment is not being seriously challenged for its possession.

Most women, whatever their clothing budgets, will benefit from a perusal of a pamphlet published by the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics of the United States Department of Agriculture. Prepared by Miss Clarice L. Scott and entitled "Buying Women's Coats and Suits," this timely and practical booklet may be ordered for 15 cents from the Superintendent of Documents, Government Printing Office, Washington 25.

A new radioactive technique by which a single small piece of tissue from a victim of a crippling muscle affliction is used to make an accurate diagnosis of the person's ailment was described here yesterday at a conference on new industrial uses of atomic energy.
ALBANY, March 15 -- Alfred C. McKenzie of Brooklyn and Jay Kramer of New York were appointed by Governor Dewey tonight to fill vacancies on the State Labor Relations Board. Both are lawyers.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 15 (AP) -- Mohammedan, owned by Isaac J. Collins of Lancaster, Ohio, won his first purse of the winter as he defeated ten other sprinters in the $3,500 Blaze of Glory Purse today, as Gulfstream Park ushered in Florida Derby Week before a crowd of 16,701.
" Faster, Faster," a new comedy-drama by William Marchant, has been scheduled for production here next season by Jay Julien.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., March 15 -- Novembers of insurgent Local 301 of the United Electrical Workers approved today a proposal by their officers to secede and affiliate with the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O.

CARACAS Venezuela, March 15 -- Guatemala made public today a proposed resolution for the Tenth Inter-American Conference prohibiting economic boycotts of any American republic by either another American nation or by a group of nations.

CHICAGO, March 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, despite a welter of controversies in which he is involved, will be this week one of the busiest and apparently least expensive speakers on the banquet circuit.

Many voices of spring do not find their way into poems or music descriptive of the season. Bird songs, rains softly falling, a warmer wind, peepers in the meadows are all spring voices, to be sure -- literature and music have done well by them.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 15 (AP) -- Dr. K. C. Wu, former Governor of Formosa who angered the Chinese Nationalists by asserting yesterday that Formosa was a police state, incurred further rebukes here today.
ALBANY, March 15 -- Mayor Wagner urged the Republican leaders of the Legislature today to speed approval of a bill designed to stimulate the construction of middle-income housing in New York City.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 12 -- While Florida's deep, brimming green mainland is still to be seen from the ports of the British Overseas airplane bound for the islands of the Caribbean, the cool voices and the folkways of the world-spread subjects of Her Majesty make the traveler acutely aware that he has left the jurisdiction of the United States.

Prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges with cocoa, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, silk, zinc, copper and hides higher; coffee, potatoes, lead and tin lower, and sugar, rubber, burlap and wool mixed. Rubber had the third largest daily volume of the year.
SUFFERN, N. Y., March 16 -- Local officials were elected in eleven Rockland County villages today. Six polls were contested. Five village slates were unopposed.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Daniel W. Tracy resigned today as president of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. L.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- Roaming, owned by Herman B. Delman of New York, drove to a length-and-a-half victory in the $13,050 Winter Wonderland Handicap before 16,626 at Gulfstream Park today.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- A virtually complete catalogue of this country's weapons -- existing, new, in production and ordered for production -- turned up today without any kind of secrecy label.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that United States exports in January totaled $1,089,900,000, about 17 per cent below the monthly average in 1953, and 16 per cent below exports of January, 1953.

The Erie Railroad Company "tentatively" expects a 7 1/2 per cent decline in freight traffic this year and is making economy moves to offset the drop according to the annual report issued yesterday by Robert W. Woodruff, chairman, and P. W. Johnston, president.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has signed legislation to pay Matthew J. Berckman, Jersey City, N. J., steamship company employe, $16,119 for information that led to forfeiture to the Federal Government of gold bullion valued at $171,197, about to be shipped from this country.

A commuter rode the Long Island Rail Road for three years for only a few dollars by fraudulent use of the present pass-type commutation ticket, an examiner for the Public Service Commission was told yesterday.

Avenues with two-way traffic are more efficient than one-way avenues for mass transportation, the New York City Omnibus Corporation asserted yesterday. The company's findings ran counter to the Department of Traffic's contention that all longitudinal avenues must be made one-way to relieve Manhattan's traffic jams.
ALBANY, March 16 -- Following is the roll-call vote by which the bill requiring owners of motor vehicles to carry liability insurance passed the Assembly today, 91 to 54.
Private staterooms in trans-Atlantic air service have been introduced by Pan American World Airways on the routes between New York, Paris, Rome, Frankfurt and Beirut.

Charles K. Paul had been named executive assistant to the director of marine terminals of the Port of New York Authority, Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the bi-state agency, announced yesterday.

Young women headed by Miss Marie Lufkin and including Miss Marjorie Weigold are furthering the success of the lecture tea for the benefit of the Maryknoll missions and the missions of the Society of the Holy Child in Africa.
CHICAGO, March 16 -- Bullish weather reports were ignored to a great extent in the wheat market today, and prices for both old and new wheat futures met free selling which resulted in sharp declines.

A 4-year-old disciple of interplanetary television drama decided yesterday afternoon to make his own leap through space from a second-floor bedroom in Brooklyn. He was brought safely to earth after a Superman catch by a flash-footed high school girl.

CAIRO, March 17 -- Two British service men were killed and two others wounded in a fusillade of shots from ambush yesterday in the Suez Canal zone, British military authorities announced tonight. Two other soldiers are missing, the announcement said.
Spring hides around an elusive corner. When it does arrive, the desirable season may bring along cheaper gasoline, at least in the regular grade, for the motorist.

An admittedly interested party once remarked that there were only two types of people in the world: the Irish and those who wished they were. While this generality may be a bit too sweeping, today would appear the least propitious time to challenge it.

LONDON, March 16 -- Lord Hore-Belisha marked his return to parliamentary life today after nearly a decade's absence, and demanded that the decision on use of the atomic bomb should not rest solely with the United States.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that seventeen issues of German dollar bonds would be reinstated to dealings at the opening of business on Thursday, March 18.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- John Foster Dulles asserted today that President Eisenhower had the authority, without consulting Congress, to order instantaneous retaliation against any attack on the United States or its allies in Europe and the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower was notified today of "keen competition" in private industry for purchase of twenty-seven Government-owned synthetic rubber plants which cost close to half a billion dollars.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- John Byler, the Retail Federation's board chairman and vice president of the W. T. Grant Company variety store chain, said retailers would be glad to cooperate with the Labor Department if only there was a way to increase wages in the industry and maintain profits without having to increase prices.
A song program of unusual interest, intelligently prepared and conscientiously sung, was offered in Town Hall last evening by Helen Phillips, soprano.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 -- The nations of Asia are too busy with internal affairs to worry about the "cold war," Louis St. Laurent, Prime Minister of Canada, reported here today.

Last night Democratic leaders took to the air waves in an effort to reply to the previous night's broadcast by President Eisenhower and to justify their proposals for increasing personal exemptions under the individual income tax by anywhere from $100 to $400.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed quiet but steady yesterday, 2 to 8 points net higher, than on Monday, with new crop months showing the most strength.

On the theory perhaps that if better behavior is to be exacted of them under new codes of ethics they ought to be better paid for it, our New York legislators are considering an increase of salary for themselves, from the present $5,000 (raised from $2,500 in 1948) to $7,500.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 16 -- Only the United States has taken a stand against any demand or request by the Tenth Inter-American Conference for the elimination of European colonies in the Americas.

Members of the Port of New York Authority met yesterday with New York and New Jersey officials to draft remedial legislation so that the bi-state agency can proceed with construction of the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Secretary of State Dulles was stumped today when he was asked whether the joint United States-British decision of last Oct. 8 to return Zone A of Trieste to Italy still represented the position of the United States Government.

Because parents and teachers view a child and his problems in different lights, they may find more help in handling behavior difficulties by "pooling" their thinking when problems arise, Dr. Harry N. Rivlin declared yesterday. Dr. Rivlin is chairman of the department of education and director of teacher education at Queens College.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 16 -- Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, Chief of the Army General Staff, said today that the Arab states were girding for war against Israel.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, advised the nation's business men today to improve their personnel policies as one way of achieving industrial peace.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 16 -- George E. Etzell, Minnesota Republican National Committeeman; announced today that he looked with disfavor on a proposal to bring Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin into this state to campaign against Democratic Senator Hubert H. Humphrey.
When the Mennen Company added a foam shave cream packaged in an aerosol container to its line of toiletries a year or more ago, there were more than a few complaints.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Geneva Far Eastern conference may be delayed as a result of the Soviet Union's stalling tactics, Secretary of State Dulles said today.

BONN, Germany, March 16 -- German newspaper men in Bonn have received "official warnings and even threats" because they disclosed West German budget secrets, the executive committee of the Federal Press Conference stated tonight.
Edward R. Murrow, Columbia Broadcasting System commentator, presented a second half-hour installment last night of his television exposition of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's methods.

MEXICO CITY, March 16 (AP) -- Venezuela took the lead in the baseball play-off of the Central American and Caribbean Games today, defeating Nicaragua, 10 -- 7, while Mexico lost its first game to the Dominican Republic, 3 -- 2.

Despite past protests and efforts at redress in the long series of Communist attacks on our planes two more unarmed American military aircraft have been shot at and damaged by Soviet-built fighters darting from behind the Iron Curtain, this time, fortunately, without loss of life or limb.

The consolidated net income of the Texas Company last year reached a record $192,600,078, or $7.01 a share, according to the company's 1953 annual report signed by J. S. Leach, chairman, and Augustus C. Long, president. This compares with $181,242,172, or $6.59 a share in 1952.
The City Council adopted a home-rule resolution yesterday urging the Legislature to enact a bill abolishing the Civil Service Commission and creating a personnel department.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 16 -- Given the day off -- their first -- the Giants went over to Mesa to watch the Cardinals play the Cubs today.

TOKYO, March 16 (Reuters) -- A Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman said tonight that the boat had been ninety miles from the heart of the explosion, which the United States Atomic Energy Commission described at the time as from an atomic device and as "the first in a series of tests."
ROME, March 16 -- The Italian Cabinet rejected the resignation of Foreign Minister Attilio Piccioni today. Thus a Government crisis that many persons had foreseen was averted.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today an increase of 200,000 tons in the 1954 sugar marketing quota for the United States, placing it at 8,200,000 tons.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The Air Force took the wraps off one of its newest weapons today.

Bob Provizzi, Corona, Queens, middleweight, stopped the winning streak of Danny Rubino, Hoboken, N. J., at eight by gaining a split decision in the feature bout of eight rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Provizzi weighed 155 1/2, Rubino 161.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Democratic leaders of Congress took their fight for higher personal income tax exemptions to the nation tonight over radio and television.
ALBANY, March 16 -- With Democratic help, Governor Dewey's compulsory automobile insurance bill was approved in the Assembly tonight by a vote of 91 to 54.
David O. Selznick, the movie producer, has been engaged to produce a commercially sponsored two-hour television program on Oct. 24 that will be carried simultaneously on three networks.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 16 -- An uproar has been created here by charges by former Gov. K. C. Wu that an attempt had been made on his life in Formosa and that the Nationalist regime was holding his son as hostage.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on issues of loan notes totaling $59,280,000 for the temporary financing of nine projects backed by subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration.

Rudolf Firkusny was the soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra last night when it presented its eighth concert of the season at Carnegie Hall. Eugene Ormandy conducted and the work in which they collaborated was Beethoven's "Emperor" Concerto.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Senate Rules Committee voted 5 to 4 today to ask the Senate to unseat Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat of New Mexico, for alleged election irregularities in 1952.

A family ownership of eighty-seven years has been terminated in the sale by the estate of Frederic E. Gilbert of the seven-story building at 298 Fifth Avenue and 2 West Thirty-first Street to a client of Rueben Lesser, attorney. Horace S. Ely Co. were the brokers.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, chairman of the Joint Congressional Atomic Energy Committee, said tonight that the United States had the hydrogen bomb and could deliver it anywhere in the world.
BOSTON, March 16 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins battled into the National Hockey League playoffs tonight by whipping the league-leading Detroit Red Wings, 4 to 2, before 6,766 fans at the Boston Garden.

Member banks in the Second Federal Reserve District had net profits after all charges but before dividends last year averaging 7.3 per cent of capital funds. The rate of return for these banks in New York, northern New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn., was unchanged from the previous year, but the seven size-groups into which the banks are divided for analysis had a mixed experience.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Suspension of all tariff duties by this country might result in an annual increase in imports of $800,000,000 to $1,800,000,000.
BOSTON, March 16 -- A Boston University professor is doing his best to give leisure time activities back to the family.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today the United States Information Agency had rejected as "not suitable reading" for its purposes two books he had written.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 16 -- Harold Lamb, the novelist and historian, has set to work on a screen treatment of his own story "Hannibal of Carthage" for Universal-International.
Retailers may attempt to make the violation of a state Fair Trade law a criminal act.

The New York Mortgage Exchange, which was organized about a year ago by Harry Fromkes, president of the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company, will hold its first public selling session on April 6 at the Roosevelt Hotel.

Kentucky's undefeated Wildcats yesterday were rated as the nation's No. 1 college team by the sportswriters and broadcasters participating in The Associated Press poll. The Wildcats appeared to be well on their way to a final top ranking for the fourth time in six years.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies, although needing hitting strength and reserves, today disposed of Eddie Waitkus for cash. The 33-year-old Waitkus went to the American League's Baltimore Orioles.

Gross operating revenues of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation last year amounted to $135,922,543, the highest in its history. This represented an increase of 44.8 per cent over 1952 for one of the nation's largest natural gas pipelines.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 16 (AP) -- Bert (Yank) Levy, master of the "quick, quiet kill," who once taught G. I.'s the art of commando warfare, asked the State Pardon Board today to remove "the only real blot" on his record -- a holdup conviction twenty-seven years ago.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 17 -- The Japanese police attempted to find and remove from public sale today some 12,000 pounds of fish landed from a vessel showered with radioactive ash during the recent atomic tests at Bikini Atoll.

At the annual meeting of the Gulf Interstate Gas Company held yesterday in Houston, Tex., Howard B. Keck, president of the Superior Oil Company of California, was elected a director, increasing the board membership to six.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, defended the "new look" defense program before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee today.

Radical alterations in the concept and design of the New York Coliseum were disclosed yesterday when Robert Moses made public the final plans for the huge redevelopment at Columbus Circle. He said it would have the largest exhibit area in the country "under one roof."
The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will leave on a five-week Western tour in 1955 immediately after its Carnegie Hall season.
LINCOLN, R. I., March 16 (UP) -- R. E. Harper's Tanbark scored a nose victory over Unrestricted today in a stretch duel at Lincoln Downs to win the $3,500 Warwick Purse before a crowd of 8,509.

The Corinthians, founded back in 1933 by the late Ted Delano to get non-owners acquainted with yachtsmen so that Corinthian crews could be readily obtained for racing, held an anniversary dinner last night at the New York Yacht Club.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- The air of complacency that the Yankee brass believed it had dispelled weeks ago with the sale of Vic Raschi to the Cardinals, was still hovering over the world champions today.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 16 (AP) -- A conclusion that Minneapolis and St. Paul can support major league baseball in a financially successful way has been made by a Twin Cities committee, The Minneapolis Star and The St. Paul Dispatch reported today in the first of three articles.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Signs of a filibuster against the bill to give statehood for Hawaii and Alaska appeared in the Senate today. They came from Southern Democrats and other opponents in a debate that was heard by few Senators.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 16 -- The United States withdrew today its recommendation that the hemisphere economic conference be held in Washington and will support Brazil's invitation to hold it at Rio de Janeiro.
Curfew will ring every night for the youngst of this city if Councilman Thomas J. Mirabile of Brooklyn has his way.

You could have begun one of the longest bon voyage parties in maritime history aboard the Greek liner Olympia yesterday. Passengers who lugged their baggage aboard in anticipation of a noon sailing were advised that the ship would not leave from her West Forty-eighth Street pier until tomorrow.

Exuberant students of the Thomas Jefferson High School wrecked the interiors of two subway cars last night in giving vandalistic vent to their joy over the victory of the Brooklyn team in a basketball tournament.
A small fire due to an electric welding torch caused more excitement than damage yesterday on a tenth floor roof of Macy's department store at Broadway and Thirty-fourth Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 16 (AP) -- Ted Williams of the Boston Red Sox was discharged from Sancta Maria Hospital today, a week after undergoing an operation to set and pin a fractured left collarbone injured in a spring training fall in Florida on March 1.

Federal Judge William Bondy continued in force yesterday a temporary restraining order barring insurgent Local 301 of the United Electrical Workers in Schenectady, N. Y., from seceding and affiliating with the International Union of Electrical Workers, C. I. O.
Although no closing date has been announced, it is likely that "The Prescott Proposals" will end its run on April 3 at the Broadburst Theatre.
MOSCOW, March 16 -- The first of a 20,000-case shipment of Israeli oranges went on sale in Moscow grocery stores this week at prices materially lower than last year's.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- World steel production increased a little over 22,000,000 tons during 1953, the Department of Commerce said today. United States production accounted for nearly eighteen and a half million tons, or 83 per cent, of the world advance.

After spending seventy-two games in establishing themselves as the best team in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division, the New York Knickerbockers last night devoted forty-eight minute; to tearing down that hard-earned reputation.

Dealers in scrap metal other than iron and steel look for generally good business volume this year, spurred by continued lively export demand according to industry spokesmen who addressed the National Association of Waste Material Dealers yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The United States assured Canada today, that disposal of our surplus agricultural products would not interfere with Canada's normal international trade.

ALBANY, March 16 -- A law giving the state the right to examine welfare funds operated for the benefit of industrial wage earners is being drafted by the Dewey Administration for enactment at this year's legislative session.

Charles Edison, former Governor of New Jersey and former Secretary of the Navy, announced yesterday that 500,000 signatures had been obtained on a petition opposing the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.
ALBANY, March 16 -- The long fight over permanent personal registration for voters headed toward its end today.
The City of Chicago announced yesterday that it would offer on April 6 issues of bonds totaling $33,100,000. The obligations will come due serially on Jan. 1 from 1955 to 1972.

" McCarthy and His Enemies: The Record and Its Meaning," by William F. Buckley Jr. and L. Brent Bozell, will be published March 30 by Henry Regnery. It is an examination of the charges and counter-charges made by the junior Senator from Wisconsin and by his adversaries.

Through his proposal that the Medical Practice Act be amended to include "mental and nervous disorders" Senator Samuel Greenberg has accomplished a most significant forward step for his fellow citizens. The New York State Medical Society, following extensive study, has enthusiastically endorsed this proposal, which would assure every individual that intensive effort would be instituted to prevent unqualified persons from diagnosing and treating nervous and mental disorders.

A collection of folk crafts of Okinawa was exhibited last night in the mezzanine lounge of the Martin Beck Theatre, where the stage attraction is "The Tea-house of the August Moon," a comedy about a military occupation team on Okinawa. More than fifty pieces of pottery, lacquerware, textiles and photographs were included.

Continuing the "rocking chair" market of the past several days, stocks moved ahead in the morning yesterday and back in the afternoon. The net result was almost nil. The New York Times combined average fell 0.21 to 190.34. Industrials fell 0.23 to 314.46 and rails fell 0.19 to 66.22.

Blood is needed for an emergency operation at a hospital -- and the Red Cross Motor Service wings into action. Last year, over the nation a monthly average of 8,200 Motor Service volunteers contributed 1,320,200 hours of driving service.
The world's most powerful device for bombarding the atom, designed to penetrate deeper than ever before into the inner citadel of the material universe, has gone into successful operation.

It is good to learn that the Air Force is extending its aircraft warning system against attack from without. Brig. Gen. J. W. McCauley has announced that by using hundreds of private coastal vessels the aircraft spotting network has been spread 250 miles out to sea along our Eastern seaboard.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Secretary of State Dulles declared today that the anti-Communist declaration approved in Caracas would have a "profound effect" in combatting international communism in the Western Hemisphere if the resolution was "properly backed up."
LONDON, March 16 -- Drastic use of insecticides has suppressed the plague of flies that infested Britain's most populous south coast shore resorts, between Beamy Head and Selsey Bill.

A spring town wardrobe for the smart young woman was presented yesterday at a fashion show in the De Pinna dress salon. The collection was designed by John Moore for Talmack. Mr. Moore, who won this year's Coty Award, was introduced to the audience.
ALBANY, March 16 -- Frank E. Gannett disclosed today that he wrote the letters that Hamilton Fish was barred from reading into the record of the Moreland Act investigation of harness racing.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- Representative Angier L. Goodwin, Republican of Massachusetts, disclosed today that he had asked an Interstate Commerce Commission investigation of the railroad management activities of Patrick B. McGinnis.

CLEVELAND, March 16 (AP) -- William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, predicted today that William White would win his fight with Robert R. Young and remain president of the New York Central Railroad.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 16 -- Ted Williams is as perceptive an authority on every phase of the hitting art as there is in baseball. His judgments are to be respected. Late last season the opinionated Mr. Williams offered his estimate of Harvey Kuenn, then a 22-year-old rookie shortstop on the Detroit Tigers.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 16 -- There were no breaks in the streaks of the Dodgers and Senators after their second meeting today before an overflow crowd of 5,100. The Brooks won, 3 -- 2, giving them seven in a row. The Senators have lost the same number and have won none.

SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, March 17 -- The South Korean Government announced today that non-Governmental representatives from several Asian states would attend an anti-Communist conference in Korea next month.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 16 -- Fifty-two villages in Nassau County held local elections today. In forty-four voters ratified unopposed slates. Eight had contests.
PARIS, March 16 -- The Indo-Chinese war in 1954 will be only a small burden on the French military budget, Edouard Frederic Dupont told the National Assembly tonight.
A home-made time bomb exploded yesterday in a washroom on the lower level of Grand Central Terminal. Three men were injured slightly, and little property damage was done.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- James K. Knudson, a Government career man with five children, asked President Eisenhower today not to reappoint him as a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission. He expects to improve on his $15,000 Government salary in private business.

TOWNSFOLK who shake in cold Fifth Avenue blasts as they watch the St. Patrick's Day march each year must know that icy winds have been part of the parade tradition in this city for more than 100 years.
OLDSMAR, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- Sunshine Park ended its fifty-two-day meeting today, posting betting and attendance totals that set records for its eight years of operation.

Men's and boys' wear and piece goods and household textiles turned in the best sales performances in January as compared with results in the same month of 1953 in Second Federal Reserve District department stores.
The Lazy Susan and Silent Butler becoming "uncomfortably obsolescent"? In New York, perhaps; in Westchester, never.
The date of Wednesday, March 10, has been chosen by lot for the newspaper editions to be entered in the twenty-fourth annual exhibition of newspaper typography, sponsored by N. W. Ayer Son, Inc.

Irving Maidman, real estate operator and investor, reported yesterday that he was awarded a contract for the demolition of the thirty-year-old Vanderbilt Theatre at 148-154 West Forthy-eighth Street which he will replace with a six-story garage.
WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower invited fifteen guests to a White House stag dinner tonight.
NEW ORLEANS, March 16 (UP) -- Clarence Cameron White, Negro composer and violinist, was named today the winner of the 1953-54 Benjamin Award for Tranquil Music.
There'll be a lilt in the stroke of noon today, for that's when Mayor Wagner, as grand marshal, will step out for the start of the St. Patrick's Day parade,

Directors of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, Newark, N. J., elected Lyle McDonald as chairman of the board yesterday and Donald C. Luce as president, effective on March 27, when George H. Blake, president since 1945, will reach the retirement age of 70.
CHICAGO, March 16 -- A railroad executive today described pooled service as one of the most promising fields that must be explored further by the railroads in seeking greater economy in operations.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The State Liquor Authority reported today that disciplinary actions against licensees for selling alcoholic beverages to minors reached a record of 358 during 1953, an increase of 80 per cent over the previous year.

Building and permanent financing amounting to $1,506,000 has been arranged by J. Halperin Co., brokers, for a 168-family apartment house to be built soon on the east side of Locust Avenue, north of Union Street, in New Rochelle, N. Y. The loans were insured under Section 207 of the National Housing Act.
Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin High School gained the final of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
HANOI, Vietnam, March 16 -- Fighting diminished last night and today in the bitter battle for Dienbienphu.

Bernard Newman, designer for Bergdorf-Goodman, illustrated yesterday his fashion philosophy -- women should look pretty -- with thirty spring and summer costumes that defined his interpretation of pretty as understated elegance. Feminine, graceful and easy were ready-to-wear originals that were expertly simplified and precisely balanced.
The Army and Navy of yesterday have lost two of their surviving links with the present in the recent deaths of Lieut. Gen. Robert C. Richardson and Admiral Henry Braid Wilson.

THE landlocked salmon enthusiasts who are planning a trip to Maine immediately after ice-out probably will find fishing possible on some of the southern waters on opening day, April 1, according to Bob Elliot of the Development Commission, who has queried the wardens on ice-out prospects.
The National Dairy Products Corporation plans record capital expenditures of about $36,000,000 this year, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 16 -- The Indonesian Communist party has renewed its call for a national front to achieve "complete national independence" for Indonesia. The Nationalist Premier, Ali Sastroamidjojo, sent a message of greetings and several ministers representing the Nationalist splinter parties attended the opening ceremonies, which attracted 2,000 persons.

NEWARK, March 16 -- A jury of nine men and three women today found Harold John Adonis guilty of willful evasion of income taxes in 1948. The defendant, who is 46 years old, had been executive clerk in the office of former Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

Aggressive action to meet inensified competition from other countries was urged on American exporters yesterday. This was the objective of the Export Managers Club's thirty-fourth annual convention as it opened at Statler Hotel with the theme: "Make the Market."

MOSCOW, March 16 -- Sergei Prokofieff's long-awaited ballet, "Tale of a Stone Flower," to which the composer dedicated many of the closing years of his life, finally has been brought to the stage of Moscow's Bolshoi Theatre.

Twice a year Gimbels presents a collection that equals the most professional sleight of hand trick. This is their presentation of import designs and American-made copies that are so identical it requires the closest scrutiny to tell which is which.

NEW DELHI, India, March 16 -- India will make a formal demand to the United Nations for the removal of United States cease-fire observers in Kashmir if Secretary General Hammarskjold fails to act on New Delhi's informal representations.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 16 -- Eleven contests marked the local elections in twenty incorporated villages in Westchester County today. In the other nine, the elections were uncontested.

DETROIT, March 16 -- A grimy coal ship of the Wyandotte Transportation Company tied up at her dock in the lower Detroit River early this morning after a sixty-mile trip from Toledo with coal. For shipping men, spring had arrived.
Investment banking syndicates submitted twenty-one bids yesterday for the purchase of three issues of public utility securities valued at more than $23,500,000. The issues were awarded as follows:
RIVERHEAD, L. I., March 16 -- Ten villages in Suffolk County named local officials today, six without contests.
MOSCOW, Wednesday, March 17 -- The Soviet Election Commission reported today that 120,321,192 voters, or 99.98 per cent of those eligible, cast ballots in Sunday's election to the Supreme Soviet.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 16 (AP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., fresh from his triumph in the Masters invitation tennis tournament in Jacksonville, won two singles matches and contributed to a doubles victory today in the Everglades invitation tournament.

The Mayor of New York, a Southern editor, an executive of a big corporation with plants in the South and officials of the National Urban League agreed last night that progress was being made in the United States toward the solution of racial problems.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Secretary of State Dulles authorized for direct publication a section of the transcript of his news conference today bearing on the "new look" in foreign affairs and military policy. Following are excerpts from that section:

In opening today its 1954 exhibition of contemporary American sculpture, water-colors and drawings, the Whitney Museum is putting on the last of its long series of annuals in its present home. By late spring the museum hopes to be moved to its new quarters adjoining the Museum of Modern Art, where it will officially reopen in the fall.

The twenty-first annual observance of Port of New York Day -- set aside each year to extol this harbor as the greatest in the world -- was held yesterday under a brilliant sky, but at the same time under the leaden cloud of waterfront troubles that have virually immobilized the port.
Chief Justice Irving Ben Cooper of Special Sessions declared yesterday that if the courts had adequate facilities 95 per cent of early offenders could be rehabilitated.

A vacant plot of about 18,000 square feet at the southwest corner of Hempstead Turnpike and Cunningham Avenue in Uniondale, L. I., has been purchased by the Sun Oil Company for improvement with a service station. Martin L. Meyer was the seller and William A. White Sons were the brokers in the transaction.
The Halpern-Ten Eyck bill exempts the high school administrator (assistant to principal) from competitive examinations.

Reversing a lower court, the Supreme Court of New Jersey in a 4-2 decision has found that the $100,000,000 third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel is not a "mere addition" but is "in every way a major new crossing facility and is not the less so because it will function in harness with the existing twin tunnels."
CHICAGO, March 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows.
