TAMPA, Fla, March 16 (AP) -- Billy Bruton, Milwaukee Braves' center fielder, stepped into an outfield hole and sprained his ankle today as the Braves bowed to the Chicago White Sox, 8 -- 3.
Offices of the Internal Revenue Service in New York City received "tubs" of mail yesterday containing many millions of dollars in last-minute income tax returns.

The United States Olympic Association has set $1,000,000 as its fund-raising goal. It is estimated that it will cost that much to finance American participation in the 1955 Pan American Games in Mexico City and the 1956 Olympics in Cortina, Italy, for the winter events, and Melbourne, for the main program.

CHICAGO, March 16 -- The Government took full title today to the huge plant on the Southwest Side where Studebaker Corporation made airplane engine parts in World War II and has been producing jet engine parts since 1951.

Senator McCarthy's subcommittee yesterday decided that it will do the investigating of the charges and counter-charges involving the members of its own staff and high officials of the Department of the Army. This is a little like saying that Mr. McCarthy has now graciously agreed to investigate himself, for the subcommittee has been under his domination ever since he became chairman.

THE individual who likes television with breakfast now has two places to turn. After watching the National Broadcasting Company reap a profit with its show, "Today," the Columbia Broadcasting System has responded with "The Morning Show."

Attorneys for Wilhelm Furtwaengler, German orchestral conductor, filed suit yesterday in the New York Supreme Court to halt sales by Urania Records, Inc., of an unauthorized recording allegedly made from a radio performance conducted by Mr. Furtwaengler in 1944.
CHICAGO, March 16 -- Senator McCarthy will be one of the busiest and poorest paid public speakers appearing on the banquet circuit this week. His bookings for the week are as follows:
PARIS, March 16 -- Several plans aimed to bring the advantages of the automatic washing machine to families of insufficient means are being tried in Paris and the French provinces.
BONN, Germany, March 16 -- The West German trade unions have aligned themselves with the Social Democratic party and big industrialists in supporting a legalized recartelization of industry.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 458 pints of blood on Monday. Included was a donation of 217 pints from Local 1, Amalgamated Lithographers Union, C. I. O., at its headquarters, 113 University Place.

ALBANY, March 16 -- A detailed report on financial relationships between Senator William F. Condon, Yonkers Republican, and E. J. Petrillo, president of the Yonkers Contracting Company, was submitted today to Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

ALBANY, March 16 -- The twenty-six Republican members of the Legislature from New York City accused Mayor Wagner today of "double-talk" in his reply to a series of Dewey administration reports that denied the city additional state aid and taxing powers.
In an editorial of March 10 entitled "Surplus" Food, calling for their distribution through American private agencies, your editorial writer says:

ROME, March 16 -- The Italian Communist party has skillfully managed to penetrate important segments of Italy's structure. This penetration extends to the armed forces, the pseudo-independent Left-Wing Socialist party and even the administrative apparatus of the Vatican.

LONDON, March 16 -- The Spanish Ambassador told a group of thirteen Labor Members of Parliament tonight to mind their own business. The Laborites had protested against the forthcoming trial of fourteen Basques charged with illegal strike activities.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's subcommittee voted today for a complete public exposition of his latest dispute with the Army.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York has performed a public service with its clear and bold report on the state of families and children seeking justice in the courts. The report, based on two years of study, conferences and public hearings, is clear and logical.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Eisenhower was noncommittal today on the reappointment of Gordon R. Clapp as Administrator of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 -- Seth Clark Beise, 56, was elected president of the Bank of America, the world's largest bank, by the board of directors today.
The flight of trade from the Port of New York gained momentum last night as flying squads of outlaw pier strikers blocked back-to-work moves in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

Stage, screen, radio and television stars will perform with the regular entertainers of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus's opening night, March 31, at Madison Square Garden. The performance will be for the benefit of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- President Eisenhower approved today a new law for the control and protection of migrant workers from Mexico.
The Midtown Squad was abolished as a separate unit yesterday by Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 16 -- Two major hospitals here are the beneficiaries of a new kind of industrial philanthropy.

LONDON, March 16 -- The stock markets here were steady today, with British Government securities continuing to strengthen and a firm undertone to industrials. Most of the buying of gilt-edge issues was for undated or long-term stocks, which rose as much as the equivalent of 52 1/2 cents.
WORCESTER, Mass., March 16 (AP) -- Archbishop Richard J. Cushing, Roman Catholic spiritual leader in the Boston archdiocese, collapsed tonight during an address on the eve of St. Patrick's Day.

HONG KONG, March 16 -- Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, Commander in Chief of the Vietminh forces in Indo-China, called on his troops today to "continue to encircle" the French defenders of besieged Dienbienphu in northwest Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed today and sent to the Senate a $430,983,700 bill to provide money for work on flood control, navigation, hydroelectric projects and other civil functions of the Army in the year starting July 1.

BOSTON, March 16 (AP) -- Judge Charles Fairhurst late today denied an application of Textron, Inc., for a preliminary injunction to restrain the American Woolen Company from holding its annual meeting scheduled for March 23.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy said today that no vital atomic secrets were missing from the Hanford atomic plant at Richland, Wash.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 16 -- The Western powers have agreed to back a resolution calling on Egypt to permit Israel-bound ships to pass through the Suez Canal.
Al Weill, who has guided four boxers to world crowns in different divisions, believes that Willie Troy, 21-year-old Washington middleweight, has an excellent chance of becoming his fifth champion.

There is still much to be done "in preparing the citizens of the metropolitan area to receive the devastating impact of a nuclear attack," Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, adviser to the Mayor on Civil Defense, told Mayor Wagner yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, March 16 -- Pattom Thanu Pillai, leader of the Praja-Socialist party, was appointed Chief Minister of Travancore - Cochin state today by the Rajpramukh (Governor), the Maharajah of Travancore.
A 38-year-old blonde beauty-parlor worker, who refused to answer questions before a grand jury investigating union welfare funds, was held yesterday in $75,000 bail as a material witness.
Another company has joined the ranks of those expressing confidence in America's economic future by investing heavily in new and improved plant facilities.
" Double taxation" took 68 cents of the potential dividend dollar of the United States Steel Corporation last year, the nation's largest steel producer disclosed in its annual report released today.
ALBANY, March 16 -- Proponents of the Panther Mountain Dam in the Adirondacks suffered a major setback today when the Senate defeated a Constitutional amendment authorizing its construction.
The State Congress of Industrial Organizations yesterday put the number of unemployed in the state at more than 500,000.

HONG KONG, March 16 -- Dr. K. C. Wu, who holds a Ph.D. from Princeton and has an impressive administrative record, served the Nationalists more than twenty years before he resigned as Governor of Formosa last year. As Governor he administered a provincial regime whose territorial domain was virtually the same as that of the Nationalist Central Government.
The man in the Atomic Energy Commission responsible for classifying nuclear data warned here yesterday that an "ostrich-like" attitude about atomic secrets could lead to a national catastrophe.
Following is the text of an article by John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, in the April issue of Foreign Affairs:

B'nai B'rith, the oldest Jewish service organization, adopted on Monday a program for aid to Israel. It was agreed upon by the order's administrative committee at a meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

It can be said -- and let no one now contradict this by sending along more snow -- that spring pretty certainly is on the way. There are such worthy indications as buds on the trees, gaily colored crocuses smiling at the sun and frost-elevated stones standing solemnly in the middle of the lawn.

Alexander Bicks and Lawrence E. Walsh were reported yesterday to be the most likely to receive appointments of the many candidates for judgeships in the United States Court for the Southern New York District.

American imports of Dutch agricultural products amounted to $50,000,000 last year, $12,000,000 in 1947 and $10,000,000 in 1939. These figures tell American consumers they are using an increased number of items from Holland. If the Dutch have their way, their exports to this country will continue to grow.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 17 (UP) -- Cary Middlecoff, Freddie Haas and Wally Ulrich took down top money today in the $5,000 St. Patrick's Day pro-amateur golf tournament while the galleries followed Ben Hogan and Sara Snead.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -The United States and Canada agreed today to "do their part" toward restoring the currencies of the non-Communist world to a basis of freer convertibility in terms of dollars and gold.

The Greystone Hotel, a fourteen-story building with roof garden at the southeast corner of Broadway and Ninety-first Street, has been purchased by Herbert R. Weissberg and Louis R. Miller, who have insured title with the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 888 pints of blood Tuesday. Inmates of Sing Sing Prison gave 271 pints on the first day of a two-day donation. Employes of the M. W. Kellogg Company, engineering and contracting, 225 Broadway, gave 240 pints.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17 -- International welfare organizations are preparing to press for the compulsory support of dependents abandoned in other Countries when the United Nations Economic and Social Council meets here March 30. Representatives of eighty of these groups were present this morning at a briefing on the provisions of two proposed conventions that are to be considered by the council.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -The Defense Department has refused to cooperate with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in promoting the forthcoming film, "Prisoner of War."

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Syrian Ambassador, Farid Zeineddine, suggested today that the United States and other countries halt arms shipments to Israel because of what he called unprovoked attacks on his country.

Today's new film is "Anita Garibaldi," an Italian-made biographical drama starring Anna Magnani in the title role, and featuring Raf Vallone, at the Cinema Verdi. Dialogue of the Italian Films Export release is Italian and there are English sub-titles.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Eisenhower directed the National Science Foundation today to survey the Government's research and development program. They now cost more than $2,000,000,000.
YORK, Pa., March 17 -- George F. Kennan, ex-Ambassador to Russia, withdrew today from the contest for Democratic nomination to run for Congress.

Top Protestant leaders called yesterday for eight procedural reforms in Congressional investigating committees and a single joint committee to investigate subversive activities. The reforms would protect the rights of witnesses and accused persons and groups, and would restrict the powers of committees, their chairmen and staffs.

LONDON, March 17 (Reuters) -- Sheffield Wednesday today reached the semi-finals of the Football (soccer) Association Cub competition by scoring a 2-0 victory over the Bolton Wanderers, runners-up in the knockout play last year.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy declared tonight that he did not "give a tinker's damn" about criticism of his red-hunting "methods" no matter "how high or how low" were critics in either political party.
MIAMI BEACH, March 17 -The first union pension program modeled on the Federal social security system was set in motion here today by the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union, A. F. L.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 17 (AP) -- Top advertising men warned the Association of National Advertisers today of "rough roads ahead."
MINNEAPOLIS, March 17 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers routed the Rochester Royals, 109 -- 88, in their first game of the National Basketball Association Western Division play-offs tonight.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- The Darby Dan Farm's Atalanta packed the top weight of 122 pounds to victory in the $17,350 Suwanee River Handicap at Gulfstream Park today. The durable mare, scoring her first triumph of 1954, was an 11-4 chance.
GENEVA, March 17 -- Britain and the Soviet Union agreed today on the wording of a resolution on the study of means for the development of trade within Europe and especially between East and West.

TOKYO, March 17 -- Japanese authorities moved today to bar from national or foreign distribution tunafish from the Sampan Fukruyu Maru, showered with ash from a hydrogen bomb explosion off Bikini March 1.

A strongly worded policy statement denouncing the American Communist movement as "an international conspiracy to seize power" was issued yesterday by the board of directors of the Civil Liberties Union.

For her debut recital last night in Town Hall Helen Brainard, a pianist from Massachusetts, took on a demanding program consisting of Beethoven's last Sonata (Op. 111), Schumann's "Kreisleriana," Prokofieff's Seventh Sonata, Mozart's D minor Fantasy and the first performance of Boris Koutzen's "Eidolons."
Robert F. Wagner, who, besides being Irish on his mother's side (she was a McTague) is the Mayor of New York, was grand marshal of the St. Patrick's Day parade yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The drive to oust August A. Busch Jr., owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, from organized baseball will get a public hearing tomorrow before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 17 -- Walter O'Malley, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, said today it was "indicated" there would be "some excess money" from radio and television All-Star game and world series receipts, which would be given to old-time ball-players.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 17 -- The Yankees' curious course of training for their sixth straight pennant was still moving in reverse today to the growing annoyance of Casey Stengel.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 17-- The standing committee of the Kuomintang (National party) decided today to expel Dr. K. C. Wu, former Governor of Formosa, from the party. He was accused of having made "malicious attacks" on the Kuomintang and the Chinese Nationalist Government.
TORONTO, March 17 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs regained second place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens before a capacity crowd of 14,572.
BONN, Germany, March 17 -- In the week since the Adenauer-Bidault meeting in Paris, France's terms for a settlement of the Saar issue have reportedly stiffened.
Jerome Cohen, a catcher, yesterday was elected captain of City College's baseball team for the coming season.
The Aluminum Company of America's vast expansion paid off last year as production, sales and earnings reached the highest levels in the company's sixty-five-year history.

The appointment of Capt. Olin T. Mirteenes as chief of the Maritime Administration's ship custody branch in this area was announced yesterday by Capt. Hewlett R. Bishop, Atlantic Coast director of the agency. Captain Mirteenes succeeds Clarence D. Mercer, recently retired.

On record net sales of $451,964,697, the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company had net earnings last year of $36,864,785, Harry B. Higgins, president, reported in the seventieth annual statement issued for publication today.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Department of Justice has asked the Federal Court of Claims to dismiss a $8,697,115 suit filed against the Government by the United States Lines and has filed a counterclaim for $17,000,000.

The people who defend the tactics and attitude of Senator Joseph McCarthy have, it seems, a vocabulary as limited and ill-defined as the Communists. We have long since become accustomed to such phrases as "capitalist imperialism," which are signal phrases of communism, and indicate that no thought or consideration is necessary when the Communist speaks.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday, and closing prices were unchanged to 6 points lower than on Tuesday.

The right answer to the charges that Dr. K. C. Wu has leveled against the Chinese Nationalist Government is not his expulsion from the Kuomintang party or the tirade of indiscriminate abuse of him that has come from Formosa. That the Nationalists on the island should feel that he has taken advantage of his position in the United States to make his case is only natural. But that is not the answer.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Senate Permanent Subcommitte, on Investigations, announced today it had voted to recommend contempt of Congress citations against three balky witnesses -- Corliss Lamont, wealthy New York leftist; Albert Shadowitz, a New Jersey engineer, and Abraham Unger, New York City lawyer.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur will confer with President Eisenhower tomorrow and also will be the honored guest at a White House luncheon.

BOSTON, March 17 (AP) -- Syracuse's Dolph Schayes scored nine points in the first three minutes of a five-minute overtime period tonight and the Nationals defeated the Boston Celtics, 96 -- 95, to take the lead in the round robin play-offs of the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association.
Two investigations -- one just ending this week, the other just beginning -- are of major importance to service morale.

MOSCOW, March 17 -- The Soviet Foreign Office announced tonight that, after consultation with Communist China, it had accepted Western proposals to hold the Geneva conference in the Palais des Nations, the old League of Nations building.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced the filing of a consent decree against Electronic Medical Foundation of San Francisco.

CHICAGO, March 17 -- Wheat futures showed considerable strength here today. Old and new crop futures prices reflected the tightness in red winter wheat and the serious drought conditions in the Southwest, respectively. Buying was inclined to slow up on the rallies.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 17 (AP) -- Enrique Bertolino of Argentina shot a course record 64 in the second round of the Uruguay international golf tournament today to take a four-stroke lead with a thirty-six hole total of 132.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 (AP) -- The American Cancer Society tonight for the first time cautiously voiced its "suspicion" that cigarette smoking had something to do with lung cancer.

The three-generation household is disappearing in this country, sociologists tell us. Grandparents who used to live with their married children now dwell by themselves. And when they do, eating often becomes a problem.

I have just heard President Eisenhower's tax talk. Unfortunately, he was not forthright in discussing the Administration's proposal to give preferred treatment to one kind of personal income -- namely, income from dividends received from corporations.
AUSTIN, Tex., March 17 (AP) -The Texas Supreme Court today ordered a district judge off the bench because of a suit brought against him by lawyers who practice in his court.
LONDON, March 17 (Reuters) -- The world's first mastless liner, the $16,800,000 Orient Lines Orsova, sailed from here today on her maiden voyage to Australia.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 17 (AP) -- Joyce Ziske, 19-year-old from Waterford, Wis., fired a two-over-par 76 today to win the qualifying medal in the women's North and South invitation amateur golf championship.

H. R. Reeve Jr. of the Bayside Tennis and Racquets Club, seeded No. 1, gained the quarter-finals of the national squash tennis championship at the Yale Club last night. He defeated R. D. Lillien of the Princeton Club, 15 -- 4, 15 -- 8.
ALBANY, March 17 -- Governor Dewey asked the Legislature today to require semi-annual mechanical examinations of all automobiles at private garages licensed by the state.

TROY, N. Y., March 17 (AP) -The chairman of the Democratic National Committee tonight accused Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and his supporters of running a "hate campaign" designed to "convert the fear and hatred that Americans feel for communism into fear and hatred of other Americans."

When the time comes today for the House of Representatives to vote on the tax reform bill we hope that every member will pause for a moment to ask himself what he believes in his heart is good for the nation. If this question is honestly put, and honestly answered, it is difficult to understand how the President's proposal can fail.
WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- The Democratic National Committee today questioned the "fairness and impartiality" of the television industry "in its treatment of the two major political parties."
The timeless shapes and handsome glazes that distinguish the ceramics of Gertrud and Otto Natzler are again on view in a new collection at Georg Jensen 667 Fifth Avenue.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 17 -- The Communist League has dropped 70,000 members in the last sixteen months. The semi-official news agency Yugopress said those dropped "could no longer meet obligations relevant to party organization."
A happy concatenation at the Metropolitan Opera these days reunites two composers, Gioacchino Rossini and Vincenzo Bellini, in the two operas for which they are respectively most cherished.

A new line of British-built Nash small cars to sell in this city for less than $1,500 was announced yesterday by the Nash motor division of the Nash - Kelvinator Corporation. The vehicles will go on display tomorrow in Nash dealer showrooms.
BERLIN, March 17 -- Britain, France and the United States accused the Soviet Union today of hedging on Western proposals for lifting East-West barriers in Germany.

I wonder if such name-calling, so uncharacteristic of The Times, contributes anything of value to an understanding of the problem.

Stock prices fluttered uncertainly on small volume most of yesterday, changing direction every hour or so. Then in the final ninety minutes while New York's commercial banks were announcing lower lending rates for prime paper, the market took a big step upward.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 10:

PARIS, March 17 -- French air power will have priority in the 1954 defense budget, Defense Minister Rene Pleven told the National Assembly tonight. He said the aim would be to meet the promise France had given to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to have 1,000 combat planes by the end of this year.
PARIS, March 17 -- A move toward a showdown on the long-delayed European army treaty was made today by the Foreign Affairs Committee of National Assembly.
New York City's controversy with the state over city finances is symptomatic of a country-wide problem, Frank S. Adams, city editor of The New York Times, declared yesterday.

Following is the text of a statement adopted here yesterday by the General Board of the National Council of Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., urging procedural reforms in Congressional investigating committees and a single joint committee on subversive activities:

An investment banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will place on the market today a new issue of $12,000,000 of first mortgage 3 1/8 per cent bonds of the Pennsylvania Electric Company at a price of 101.665 to yield 3.04 per cent.

ATHENS, March 17 -- Field Marshal Alexander Papagos, Premier of Greece, described his Government's policy on Cyprus today as "rendering the best possible service to reinforcement of security in the southeastern Mediterranean and the maintenance of the democratic bloc."
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Eisenhower said today that Maj. Gen. Roderick Allen ought to live in his doghouse.

Among the various reasons for the Soviet Union's keen interest in trade with the West one must be that it is an extremely profitable business for the Soviet Government. Frank A. Ayer, international copper mining consultant, and Walter H. Sammis, president of Ohio Edison Company, have been named the 1954 winners of the Egleston Medal, Columbia University's highest award "for distinguished engineering achievent."
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Turkey will get an extra $30,000,000 in economic aid this fiscal year as the result of President Celal Bayar's visit to the United States.

The Uniondale Union Free School District No. 2 of Hempstead, L. I., sold yesterday $4,950,000 of bonds due from 1955 to 1983 to a banking syndicate headed by R. L. Day Co. at a bid of 100.82 for bonds bearing interest of 2.9 per cent.
Directors of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel have decided to ask the Government to help tide the industry over its slump by stockpiling steel ingots made from dealer scrap.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has elected Chester F. Gilbert vice president and general manager of the Westinghouse Credit Corporation, it was announced yesterday by George G. Main, treasurer of the parent company and president of the new subsidiary.

Sol A. Rosenblatt, attorney, renounced all gifts and powers of distribution given to him under the will of Countess Dorothy Dentice Di Frasso, it was learned yesterday in Surrogate's Court. He was residuary legatee in the contested will of Mrs. Eleanore M. Satterlee, granddaughter of J. Pierpont Morgan.

LONDON March 17 -- Two bookmakers and two other men were convicted today of one of the most notorious "switches" of race horses in recent British track history -- the substitution of Santa Amaro for Francasal last July 16.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- A current survey by the Department of Commerce and the Securities and Exchange Commission reported these finding today:
Three outbreaks of violence yesterday in New York's strike-paralyzed port brought pleas for more adequate police protection along the sprawling waterfront.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Washington Post purchased today The Washington Times-Herald from Col. Robert R. McCormick.

The nation's proved reserves of crude oil and natural gas liquids at the close of last year amounted to 34,382,750,000 barrels, according to a report made yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. This represents an increase of 1,425,545,000 barrels over the 32,957,205,000 reported as of Dec. 31, 1952.

Something of a stir was caused yesterday in city departmental circles when a new official Fire Department roster appeared -- the first since September, 1951 -- without any "honorary" officials listed.
CHICAGO, March 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A textile scientist yesterday indicated that cotton, through chemical modification, would be able to provide stronger competition to synthetic fibers and wool in new markets.

ROME, March 17 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano, stated today that the Pope's health continued to improve but emphasized the slowness of his recovery. It added that the Pope's convalescence was likely to be "not short."

Watch for the battle of the filter- tip cigarettes as competition grows. R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company has appointed William Esty Company to handle advertising for its Winston, a king-size filter-tip cigarette, and campaign plans are being worked out.

Plans are being formulated at meetings in private homes for the 1954 Belmont Bail, to be held at the Turf and Field Club, Belmont Park, on the night of June 11, the eve of the running of the Belmont Stakes. Funds realized from the fete will be donated to the Travelers Aid Society of New York.

Six three - story apartment houses at 5203 to 5213 Sixth Avenue in Brooklyn were purchased by the Estate Securities Company from Morris Gurwits and were immediately resold to an investing client of Bernard Sommer, attorney.
" The Burning Glass," the Charles Morgan drama, will terminate its Broadway engagement at the Longacre Theatre on March 27.
The police here took extra precautions early today to guard prominent officials after receiving a warning that Puerto Rican Nationalists planned to kill "important people" in the city.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Vietminh siege of Dienbienphu, a hard-pressed French outpost in the Vietnamese jungle, had the worried attention today of officials responsible for United States military commitments overseas.

ALBANY, March 17 -- The State Commission Against Discrimination reported today that in 1953 it disposed of 283 formal discrimination complaints, finding sixty-two based on "probable" bias of color, religion or nationality.

TRENTON, N. J., March 17 (AP) - William G. Smith, casket manufacturer who has been critical of the American Woolen Company management, today asked stockholders to elect four directors chosen by a committee he heads.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 17 -- That Dodger winning streak is getting a trifle ponderous and soon may collapse of its own weight. Today the Brooks rallied to beat the Chicago White Sox, 5 -- 1, at Holman Stadium for their eighth straight victory.
More than 800 teachers and administrators from across the country are expected to attend the twenty-seventh annual Junior High School Conference tomorrow and Saturday at New York University.

Operations of the Republic Aviation Corporation last year resulted in a net income of $8,314,301, slightly ahead of 1952, and a backlog exceeding $1,000,000,000, according to the annual report of Mundy L. Peale, president, released today.

Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, cited the Irish last night as an example to be emulated by the peoples of Communist-ruled nations. He addressed the dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick at the Astor Hotel.
A revival in American ship construction was predicted at the annual meeting yesterday of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation by Louis E. Wolfson, chairman.

MONTEGO BAY, Jamaica, March 14 -- The importance of this island to the security of the non-Communist world against the "international communism" which, as this is written, is the contemporary theme of John Foster Dulles at Caracas could quickly be determined by any student in elementary geography.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17 -- The United States will pass the problem of whether to withdraw American observers from Kashmir to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 17 -- Writers, actors and directors who "feel they can afford idleness" were singled out tonight by Jack L. Warner, vice president of Warner Brothers, as contributing to the production slump that had brought about marked unemployment in Hollywood during the last year.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Republicans gained significantly in their fight against higher personal income tax exemptions today as the House of Representatives opened debate on the omnibus tax reform bill with a showdown on the issue due tomorrow.
The German Government recently made an effort to obtain a release of the funds which were confiscated under the laws affecting enemy aliens.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., March 17 -- Estate owners, Audubon societies, garden clubs and wildlife fanciers asked the New York State Water Power and Control Commission today to reject plans for a dam on the Mianus River in Connecticut that would create a finger-shaped reservoir reaching a mile into Westchester County.

French and Italian imports shown by Macy's yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel gave importance to three major silhouettes that were illustrated by originals and line-for-line copies in spring and summer fabrics. All will be available Monday in the store's Little Shops.

BRADENTON, Fla., March 17 -- Branch Rickey's conscience was beginning to bother him. Being considerably more foresighted than anyone else in the baseball business, the Mahatma had boldly signed every good young ballplayer within reach during the war-time period when others were fearfully retrenching.
Reflecting record production and sales in 1953, net profit of the International Paper Company and its subsidiaries increased to $58,542,518 from $52,125,952 in the previous year.

An eighty-five-page survey of how foreign newspapers report United States news and how the United States press reports on countries abroad was made public yesterday by the International Press Institute.

ROME, March 17 -- Communism, virtually checked in northern Italy, is making its most important advances in the south. There the democratic Center bloc is further weakened by a resurgence of the Right.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a "hit-run" strike waged by a telephone union was "a form of economic warfare entirely beyond the pale of proper strike activities."
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Eisenhower said today that he believed that Robert T. Stevens had told the truth in the Army's controversy with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 17 -- The aluminum industry will make only small inroads into world steel markets for many years to come, United Nations economists predicted today. However, they also contended that steel producers could not afford to ignore this growing competition.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- President Eisenhower asserted today that he would plunge the country instantly into battle against any aggressor.

The newest look to enliven spring blouses, designed to complement suits, is the "hidden neckline." Developed to wear with suit jackets with the new low, away-from-the-throat necklines, they do not show above collars and give the chic-bare look so essential to this fashion.

Gross-eyes in children can be cured without surgery in 90 per cent of the cases if treatment is begun when the crossing first appears, a British authority on optics asserted yesterday at Columbia University.

ALTHOUGH the reports on big fish seem to have been rather thin during the winter season in the tropical waters, the light-tackle fishing seems to be improving considerably, and reports from southern and western Florida indicate that the tarpon will make an early appearance this year.

The Latin-American countries put the United States on the spot at the Inter-American Conference in Caracas. We were alone in taking a stand against the Argentine resolution calling for an end to colonialism and "foreign occupation" of territories in the Western Hemisphere.

LONDON, March 17 -- The official leadership of the British Labor party asserts that it is undismayed by the Bevanite rebellion over West German rearmament. This controversy, it says, reflects a "healthy" spirit within the movement.

" Living Dangerously," a new work by F. Spencer Chapman, will be issued March 31 by Harper. Mr. Chapman, author of "The Jungle Is Neutral," describes his adventures traveling by kayak in Greenland, mountain climbing in the Himalayas, stalking tigers in the Malayan jungle and his experiences as a prisoner of war of the Japanese.
LONDON, March 17 -- The stock markets here were cheerful today although not busier. Prices finished higher in nearly all groups but some gains were reduced in late dealings.

Proposed increases on Westchester bus lines of 5 cents on regular lines and 3 cents on zone fares and school buses were opposed yesterday by community spokesmen at a hearing before the Public Service Commission at 233 Broadway.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 17 -- The Latin-American countries cautioned the United States today not to dump its agricultural surplus on world markets at reduced prices.

The United Corporation, once one of the nation's largest public utility holding companies and now an investment company, has completed the sale of all securities required to be disposed of under the Public Utility Holding Company Act of 1935. This was announced yesterday by William M. Hickey, president, in his 1953 annual report to stockholders.
The United States Government was urged yesterday to reconsider its restrictions on trade with Communist countries to permit an increase of non-strategic exports.

LONDON, March 17 (Reuters) -- A minor purge in the top ranks of the Polish Communist party was indicated tonight as the Warsaw radio listed the names of 127 members of the new Central Committee of the United Workers (Communist) party.

The 11 East 87 Corporation, headed by Armino A. Campagna, obtained a building loan of $751,500 from the New York Trust Company on the twelve-story apartment house it is building at 11 East Eighty-seventh Street. Title insurance was furnished by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The first grand-scale and critical Senatorial examination of foreign and high military policy since the Eisenhower Administration took office is in prospect.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Shattering power hundreds of times greater than any previous man-made explosion was unleashed when the United States set off its hydrogen explosion No. 2. That detonation in the mid-Pacific proving grounds two weeks ago also:...
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 17 -- Nineteen American nations voted today to ask for complete elimination in the Americas of colonies under European sovereignty.

WASHINGTON, March 17 -- An examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission recommended today that his agency investigate the stock relationships of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western, the New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) and the New York Central Railroads.

TEL AVIV, March 17 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Moshe Dayan, Israeli Army chief of staff, reported today to the Defense and Security Committee of the Knesset (Parliament) in Jerusalem on the incident in the Negev.
STRATFORD-ON-VON, England, March 17 (AP) -- The 1954 Shakespeare season opened last night with a new "accent on youth," but the experiment drew only faint applause from British critics.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules, except where direct quotation was authorized:

MEXICO CITY, March 17 (AP) -- Cuba picked up 19 points in shooting events today and Jamaica assured itself a chance at the play-offs in water polo as the Central American and Caribbean games neared an end.
ALBANY, March 17 -- The Assembly approved today a Senate bil giving the City of New York and individual counties the right to decide whether they want permanent personal registration.

SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, March 18 (AP) -- The United Nations Command demanded today the release of two soldiers from Canada's Black Watch Regiment who were seized in the Korean neutral zone yesterday by Communist guards.

The continuing recession in business activity and in the demand for credit reached the banks' prime interest rate yesterday, breaking the basic quotation of 3 1/4 per cent for business loans to 3 per cent
ALBANY, March 17 -- The Assembly approved tonight one of the key measures in Governor Dewey's program for cleaning up harness racing.
HANOI, Vietnam, March 17 -- The lull in the ground fighting for the French bastion of Dienbienphu has now lasted for two days and two nights.

TRENTON, March 17 -- Walter P. Margetts Jr. withdrew tonight from the race for the Republican designation for United States Senator. His sudden, but not unexpected, action ended the possibility of a primary contest for that post within the party.

While "The Sun Shines Bright" is an apt title for Republic's folksy comedy - drama, which opened yesterday in some twenty neighborhood theatres, the brightness ends then and there. With due respect for the immaculate cleanliness of this Argosy production, based on three of Irvin S. Cobb's "Judge Priest" yarns, it would be harder to imagine a more laborious, pedantic and saccharine entertainment package.
CAIRO, March 16 -- Egypt's most influential elder statesman said today that he favored his country's participation in a regional defense organization linked with the West.

The Putnam Trust Company of Greenwich, Conn., has elected three new directors, it was announced yesterday by C. C. Francis, president. They are Frank Pace Jr., former Secretary of the Army; Dr. S. Willard Price, superintendent of Greenwich schools, and Edwin Thorne, New York banker. All are residents of Greenwich.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 17 -- So you want to be a baseball writer? Travel about the country with an interesting major league club, like the Giants? Mingle with the big shots of the diamond, come and go in comfort -- first class all the way?

BERLIN, Conn., March 17 (AP) -- A stockholder in the Connecticut Light and Power Company filed a statement at the annual meeting here today saying the company's proposal to build a $20,000,000 generating plant on Manresa Island in Long Island Sound off Norwalk is "foolhardy."

LONDON, March 17 -- Hopes for a quick settlement of Britain's most serious industrial dispute were blasted today when the Confederation of Shipbuilding and Engineering Unions rejected the employers' wage-rise offer.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told the Senate today that the country's greatest health need was for hospitals for the chronically ill.

Detectives raided a brownstone house in Harlem yesterday morning and recovered $25,000 worth of stolen items. Under arrest were the caretaker of the building, a hold-up suspect, and a woman whose husband was being sought as the "biggest fence in Harlem."
WASHINGTON, March 17 (UP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney introduced legislation tonight proposing to grant commonwealth status, rather than statehood, to Hawaii and Alaska.

An increase last week of 199,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. On March 13, supplies were 179,583,000 barrels, compared with 179,384,000 a week earlier and 160,869,000 a year ago.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 17 -- Adlai E. Stevenson asserted tonight that the United States' future prestige abroad would depend on good political manners at home.
Sharp differences in operating results for 1953 were reported yesterday by two of the nation's leading magazine publishers.
WASHINGTON, March 17 -- The Treasury announced tonight that it had accepted bids for $1,501,159,000 tax anticipation notes to be dated March 22 and to mature June 24. The average price was 99.75.

LONDON, March 17 -- The dispute among oil companies about the price of "buying into" the proposed international oil concession for Iran has been put up to the United States and British Governments, informants here declared.

MOSCOW, March 17 -- The electoral ticket headed by Premier Georgi M. Malenkov polled the largest popular vote and the highest percentage figure -- 99.79 per cent -- and the smallest number of negative votes ever recorded in a Soviet election, according to data made public today.

PARIS, March 17 (Reuters) -- An American citizen wanted for questioning about subversive activities before a New York Federal grand jury was said today to have invoked his rights as a United Nations employe here to refuse a subpoena.

In the many years it has been under consideration the Columbus Circle Coliseum has undergone several changes of concept, as might have been expected. It now emerges in presumably final form as a mammoth, flexible and versatile exhibition hall, public parking garage for 850 cars and a twenty-story skyscraper office building as an added starter, all to cost $30,000,000.
American antiques in an Early America atmosphere will be on display and sale today at the ninth antiques fair arranged by Silvermine Tavern at Silvermine, Conn., a few miles from Norwalk.

VICTORIA, B. C., March 17 (Canadian Press) -- The heads of big Canadian and American enterprises, competitors for vast British Columbia and Yukon water rights, held a secret meeting yesterday in the office of Premier W, A. C. Bennett of British Columbia.

One of the country's largest corporation's yesterday took a step that won't return a cent of profit to it. The Bell Telephone System made its transistors available royalty-free to hearing-aid manufacturers.
The Atlas Corporation had an indicated net asset value of $38.50 a share on March 16, according to the annual report released yesterday by Floyd B. Odlum, president of the investing concern.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 17 -- Eleven persons were machine-gunned to death today in an ambush of a bus near Beersheba, and Israel called on the Jordanian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission to investigate the incident immediately.

The problem of national defense, which involves the defense of the whole free world, is so vast and so complex that the "new look" prescribed for it by the Eisenhower Administration has inevitably raised many questions leading to differences of opinion and some confusion.
CHICAGO, March 17 -- A civil anti-trust suit against the "Big Four" meat packers was dismissed by action of the Government today.

The increased earnings of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company in 1953 resulted largely from "major additions to physical plant, extensive mechanization, modernization of methods and facilities,'' according to the annual report to stockholders.

ALBANY, March 17 (AP) -- Perfection of the hydrogen bomb has increased necessity for continuance of the state's multi-million- dollar civil defense program, the New York Civil Defense Commission reported today.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 17 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox ended their losing streak at five by toppling the Washington Senators to their eighth straight loss, 10 -- 6, before 1,341 fans at Tinker Field today.
LONDON, March 17 -- British officials are worried about the behind-the-scenes struggle in the Sudan to alter the balance of the Governor General's international advisory commission in Egypt's favor.

PARIS, March 8 -- French pre-historians are convinced that at leas one race of Stone Age men had a well developed ear for music. These Stone Age men played an instrument that looked like a huge marimba made of rock.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., March 17 -- A check for $20,814 was received today from the Long Island Rail Road in full settlement of back taxes.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., March 17 -- The denunciation as Communists sympathizers of a candidate for the presidency of the local Parent-Teacher Association and her husband, a veteran stage and screen actor, dead-locked tonight an election meeting of the organization.
OTTAWA, March 17 -- The Opposition Conservative party today closed its two-day annual conference with a general attack on Government policy.

CAIRO, March 16 -- The newest wave of armed attacks by Egyptians on members of the British armed forces in the Suez Canal zone and British counter-measures were the subjects of protests exchanged between Britain's Ambassador and Egypt's Foreign Minister today.
Four top Soviet leaders last week told their people in guarded language that nuclear weapons had increased Soviet strength, implying that Russia could reply in kind to any nuclear attack.

Commodity prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges with potatoes, cottonseed oil, hides, burlap, wool, rubber, silk, zinc, tin and lead stronger; cocoa and sugar lower, and coffee, soybean oil and copper mixed.

ALBANY, March 17 (AP) -- Senate Republicans worked out three changes in Governor Dewey's ethics legislation today, and the Finance Committee chairman, Austin W. Erwin of Geneseo said the final draft answered all objections among the lawmakers.
NEW HAVEN, March 17 -- The arrival of the first ocean-going general cargo ship to touch this port since the end of the clipper ship era was hailed today.
ALBANY, March 17 -- The Dewey Administration bill to authorize an additional $50,000,000 real estate tax levy by the City of New York was submitted formally to the Legislature today.
MEXICO CITY, March 17 -- The Mexican Government has asked the Export-Import Bank for allocation of $23,000,000 remaining in its line of credit there.

Benjamin Franklin High of Manhattan's upper East Side and Thomas Jefferson High of Brooklyn will meet at Madison Square Garden today for the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship. The title game will be preceded, at 3:15 P. M., by a third-place play-off between Christopher Columbus High of the Bronx and Franklin K. Lane High of Queens.
SAUK CITY, Wis., March 18 (UP) -- An editor started printing petitions today for a recall election for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy so the state could "shake off the cloak of McCarthyism."

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today made public letters from two insurance company officials supporting a request of the New York Central Railroad Company for an investigation of stock transactions involving Chesapeake and Ohio and Central holdings.
LOS ANGELES, March 18 (AP) -- Tenley Albright of Boston took a long glide today in defense of her national title in the United States figure-skating championships.

In terms of purchasing power for staple foods, the Soviet ruble is currently worth less than 7 cents, rather than the 25 cents that is the official rate. This conclusion emerges from a comparison of current prices in Moscow and New York for eighteen staple food items.
A handful of blowgun darts, the points of which may have been dipped in the fabled poison curare, have been stolen from an exhibit in the American Museum of Natural History.
PARIS, March 18 -- Premier Joseph Laniel was reported today to believe the time had not yet come to fix a date for the National Assembly's debate on the European army treaty.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- Representative James E. Van Zandt said today that the Capital and some of its suburbs would have been destroyed if they had been the target of the hydrogen device recently exploded in the Pacific.
Four Brooklyn teen-agers were held in heavy bail yesterday at Brooklyn Adolescent Court for a hearing next Monday on charges growing out of fights between neighborhood gangs.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 18 -- Thirty-two colleges, including a strong representation from Yale, winner last week of its eighth straight league championship, were included among the more than 200 competitors in the Eastern Intercollegiate Swimming League individual competition tonight.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 18 -- Gov. John Davis Lodge, acting as chairman of the New England Governors Conference, announced today the appointment of a committee of ten New Englanders to study the peacetime use of atomic energy in the Northeast.

In their ivory tower inside the Hayden Planetarium yesterday, the astronomers squinted through their telescopes, squinted at the Nautical Almanac and announced that the ecliptic of the sun would cross the celestial equator at the vernal equinox at 10:54 P. M., Eastern Standard Time, tomorrow.

PARIS, March 16 -- Summer umbrellas are of plain pastels, occasionally of flowered print. Those in dark rich winter tones should be put away along with fur coats. This was proclaimed with emphasis by the exhibit of French makers held today in the Galerie Royale.
NEWARK, March 18 -- The Newark Board of Education voted unanimously tonight to grant a $400 across-the-board increase to teachers and other personnel in the Newark school system.
Stockholders of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company approved changes in employe retirement plans yesterday and elected as directors David L. Luke 3d and E. Crawley Williams Jr.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, March 18 (Reuters) -- A record stand of 338 by Everton Weekes, who had a double century, and Frank Worrell (167) helped to put the West Indies in a commanding position against England on the second day of the fourth test cricket match.

Four policemen guarded Mayor Wagner yesterday as he began his budget retreat in the Municipal Building. Two plainclothes men accompanied Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief United States delegate to the United Nations, as he appeared at a United Nations press conference.
Craftsmen over the world have supplied the new handwoven fabrics now on view at Jack Lenor Larsen, Inc., 60 East Fifty-eighth Street.
Particular emphasis was given to the importance of active parent associations in implementing church school programs at a panel discussion yesterday on "Family Life Education in the Churches."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, March 18 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, was named today to the eighteen-member Swedish Academy, elite of Swedish learning and letters. In his chair, numbered seventeen, he succeeds his father, Hjalmar Hammarskjold, distinguished Swedish statesman, lawyer and politician who died late last year at the age of 91.
Tenzing, the Sherpa tribesman who climbed Mount Everest with Sir Edmund Hillary, has been refused permission to leave India and come to the United States to be honored for his feat.

GLASCOW, Scotland, March 18 (Reuters) -- The Skerryvore Lighthouse, one of the largest in the world [cross on map], guarding the Atlantic approaches to the rock-strewn western coast of Scotland, has been completely burned out and abandoned.

The crisis on the waterfront is the first real test of Mayor Wagner's courage and the resourcefulness of his new Labor Department. His announced determination to put an end to the invasion by "goons" at pier-heads will, we hope, be carried through promptly and vigorously.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 18 -- A Brazilian proposal to recommend United Nations trusteeship for colonies in the Americas met unexpected defeat in the Political Committee of the tenth Inter-American Conference tonight.

SACLAY, France, March 18 -- French officials demonstrated here today the newest of the experimental atomic piles with which this country hopes to begin establishing a place in the world race for nuclear energy.

Tax borrowing raised New York bank loans to business $225,000,000 in the week through Wednesday, the largest weekly increase on record. The advance compares with a gain of $109,000,000 in the similar period a year ago and with the previous high of $175,000,000 in September.

MOSCOW, March 18 -- Nearly four out of every five of the 1,347 members of the Supreme Soviet, Russia's highest legislative assembly, who were elected Sunday are new to that body, a survey of the complete electoral lists showed today.
CHICAGO, March 18 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy told 450 wildly cheering South Chicago automobile dealers today that he never would be "a rubber stamp" for President Eisenhower.

The relentless tax collector, civilized man's nemesis since the pilgrimage to Bethlehem and earlier, is not above borrowing from the barnyard and the bagatelle to extract the last tax dollar, a visit to the Internal Revenue Office discloses.

LONDON, March 18 -- Jack Solomons, Britain's premier boxing promoter, has decided to enter the political ring against Dr. Edith Summerskill, Labor Members of Commons and Britain's premier critic of the manly art.

A blue-ribbon panel of 300 veniremen will be called April 19 for the grand larceny trial in General Sessions of Joseph P. Ryan, retired president of the old International Longshoremen's Association. Ryan, 69 years old, is to be tried on a fifty-one-count indictment that charges he mishandled union funds.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The earmarking of Federal funds for chronic disease hospitals will not bring health services to persons with long-continuing illnesses, Congress was told today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- During the week ended yesterday member bank reserves increased $667,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The principal changes supplying reserves were decreases of $396,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $155,000,000 in other deposits with Federal Reserve banks, and $101,000,000 in money in circulation, and an increase of $66,000,000 in reserve bank credit.

ROME, March 18 -- The United States is determined to prevent a Communist conquest of Italy. Luring the past ten years United States aid to this country, excluding hundreds of millions of dollars worth of finished military goods, has totaled $3,274,821,828, of which two-thirds came in the form of direct grants.
The regional Red Cross Blood Program received 773 pints of blood Wednesday, including 345 pints at Camp Kilmer, New Brunswick, N. J., and 170 at Sing Sing Prison.
A proposal to merge Nesco, Inc., into the New York Shipbuilding Corporation will be submitted on April 23 to special meetings of stockholders of record of March 26.
Overcrowding in the municipal hospital system declined more sharply in 1953 than in any year since 1949, when it had risen to a post-war peak.
Stores can improve their summer business by stepping up promotions, Bernard F. Gimbel, chairman of the board of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., declared yesterday.
TAIPEI, Formosa, March 18 (UP) -- One Air Force officer was drowned and six others were rescued today when they were forced to bail out of a crippled C-119 Flying Boxcar over the Pacific.
The Bamberg Philharmonic Orchestra of Bamberg, Germany, will make its first apearance in this country on Sunday afternoon, April 4, with a concert at Carnegie Hall.

The twentieth floor in the twenty-three-story building being completed by Simon Brothers at 477 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of East Fifty-first Street, has been leased by the Ford Motor Company for executive offices.
CLIO, Ala., March 18 (AP) -- Royal Reynolds, the trusted banker whose disappearance threatened this town with financial ruin, returned home voluntarily tonight.
The majority report of the Randall Commission, recently released publicly, has had the effect of intensifying the dejection which pervades our merchant marine.
The State Liquor Authority began action yesterday to take away the Roosevelt Raceway license of Harry M. Stevens, Inc.

LONDON, March 18 -- Anthony Eden's leadership of the Conservative party appeared assured today. The Foreign Secretary, who is expected to succeed Sir Winston Churchill as Prime Minister, was elected president of the National Union of Conservative and Unionist Associations.

Joe Giardello and Willie Troy, two of the nation's most prominent middleweights, will meet in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The fight has caught on with boxing fans, and it is expected to attract a crowd of 10,000 and a gate of $40,000.

Electric skillets (or flaying pans, depending on one's choice of term) are on the market here for the first time. These versatile versions of that kitchen indispensable are particularly practical where cooking facilities are limited.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- Israeli sources said that the possibility of an appeal to the Security Council was being discussed in the delegation and in the Foreign Office.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, was notified today that the Legislature would reject Mayor Wagner's middle-income housing program.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 18 -- Time was running out today for United States decisions on economic matters in the Inter-American Conference.
DOVER, Del., March 18 (UP) -- R. K. O. Pictures Corporation stockholders today approved overwhelmingly the sale of the movie company to Howard Hughes for $23,489,478.

A coordinated effort of the three great faiths -- Catholic, Jewish and Protestant -- is seeking in the first weeks of spring to focus public attention on the need for financial and other material assistance for overseas relief and reconstruction. Cash and material contributions for this great work of the three faiths are expected to total $100,000,000 in the coming year.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Wheat futures underwent substantial recessions today on a forecast of showers or snow flurries in the Southwest. Although there were few advices during the day showing any precipitation of importance, rallies were rather feeble.

The First Boston Corporation, investment bankers, announced yesterday the election of Francis S. King to its board of directors. He has been with the corporation or its predecessors since 1926 and a vice president in charge of sales at the Boston office since 1948.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A scrapbook containing ninety missing letters from President Theodore Roosevelt to Owen Wister turned up just in time for inclusion in today's opening of the Library of Congress' "Wild and Woolly West" exhibit.
Mayor Wagner promised yesterday to curb violence along the waterfront and to provide adequate police protection for longshoremen who wanted to work.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan told members of the Insurance Brokers Association of the State of New York yesterday that it was their moral duty to turn over evidence of crime to his office. He indicated that in the past they had often failed to do just that.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 17 -- The young Constitution of Jamaica requires the party in power to go to the people at least once in five years; hence in December at the latest there will be an election on the island. "It may come before," says the Chief Minister, William Alexander Bustamante, "if I find I cannot carry on and so report to His Excellency, the Governor."
A stockholders' fact-finding committee came out yesterday in support of the management of American Woolen Company in the fight that is being waged for control.

More than 15 per cent of the privately owned American merchant marine is sailing under the flags of Panama, Honduras and Liberia, the nations to which the Maritime Administration announced recently it would permit some shipowners to transfer their vessels.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 18 -- Frank Erickson, former big-time bookmaker, admitted in court here today that the late Willie and Solly Moretti had been his agents in obtaining locations for his New Jersey bookmaking operations.

SAKKARA, Egypt, March 18 (UP) -- A 5,000-year-old pyramid caved in today on workers digging into the burial chamber of a forgotten Pharoah. The mishap recalled the superstitution that an ancient curse guards the tombs of the Egyptian kings.

Guido Cantelli commenced his concert with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with the seldom played D major symphony of Luigi Cherubini. This is the one symphony that Cherubini, the highly esteemed composer of the operas "Medes" "The Water-carrier," and other works of the kind, wrote, and this on commission from the London Philharmonic Society.
Sir Pierson Dixon arrived here yesterday to become Britain's chief delegate to the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, backed to the limit today the Army's charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. said today that if necessary he would not "shrink" from using the veto to prevent the seating of Communist China in the United Nations Security Council.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The war in Indo-China was discussed by President Eisenhower and General of the Army Douglas MacArthur today in a meeting that covered other international and national problems.

The Rev. Dr. Carl McIntire, president of the fundamentalist International Council of Christian Churches, took sharp issue yesterday with a policy statement adopted on Wednesday by the general board of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.
BERLIN, March 18 -- Soviet rejection of yesterday's renewed demand by the Western powers for Big Four negotiations to facilitate East-West travel and trade in Germany seemed almost certain tonight.
DETROIT, March 18 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay and Bill Dineen scored third-period goals tonight to enable the Detroit Red Wings to gain a 3-3 tie with the Boston Bruins before 10,172 fans at Olympia.

No one who knows anything about the American Civil Liberties Union would suspect it of being subversive or in sympathy with communism The A. C. L. U. has stood firmly for many years for old-fashioned American principles of freedom and democracy. Those principles never could be reconciled with Russian communism or with the counterpart communism that we have in this country.
Dr. James L. Wilson of 216 West 137th Street is paying back his "debt" to the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons after forty years -- and paying it nearly sixty times over.

THE bright weather is swelling the buds on the trees, bringing the 'chucks from their burrows and providing trout fishermen with an optimistic outlook for the opening day of the fishing season, for many of the popular streams are in better condition right now than they often are on the second Saturday in April.
Battle lines were drawn yesterday on the issue of higher commutation fares affecting 50,000 passengers daily on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

The dock strike is having little effect on supplies of fresh produce for the city, marketing experts of the United States Department of Agriculture reported yesterday. The major part of fresh fruits and vegetables sold here come in from near-by growing regions by truck or from other areas by rail.

JERSEY CITY, March 18 -- A Navy physician, demonstrating the use of a self-contained air-pack mask in underwater rescue work, narrowly escaped with his life here today when his gear became fouled thirty feet under the Hudson River.

VERO BEACH Fla., March 18 -- Not even the mighty Yankees could break the Dodgers' winning streak, which was stretched to nine games at Holman Stadium today by a 4-1 victory over the five-time world champions.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- A move developed in the Senate today to force baseball to sever all ties with busenss concerns subject to the anti-trust laws.
ST. PAUL, March 18 -- Governor C. Elmer Anderson announced his candidacy for re-election today and thus ended a long period of speculation and maneuvering in the state Republican party.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 18 (AP) -- Joyce Ziske shot two-under-par golf today for a 4-and-3 victory over Virginia Dennehy, Northwestern University student from Lake Forest, Ill., in the first round of the women's North and South amateur invitation tournament.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 18 (AP) -- Members attending the spring meeting of the Association of National Advertisers were told here today not to be so "bowled over by the glamour of television that you miss the many opportunities available in other advertising media."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 18 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States delegate, declared today that as far as he knew Washington's loyalty investigations had not turned up a single case warranting dismissal from the United Nations.
LONDON, March 18 -- Egyptian leaders are reported to be angry and impatient with what they consider British procrastination over recent moves in the Suez Canal zone dispute.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, today suggested a thorough investigation by the Interstate Commerce Commission into "interlocking relationships" between four Eastern railroads and several big banking houses and insurance companies.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- State Department officials conferred today with other members of the United States delegation to the United Nations and requested a transcript of the Lodge press conference. Neither the propriety of Mr. Lodge's remarks nor the accuracy of the reports of the conference was questioned.

The maximum fluctuation of cocoa futures prices during a day on the New York Cocoa Exchange has been doubled by the board of managers. Effective April 26, during a single trading session cocoa prices can move 200 points (2 cents a pound) from the previous day's close but not more than 200 points from the highs or lows of the day.

The City of Philadelphia has under consideration selling an issue of about $42,000,000 of bonds around May 15. Some $26,000,000 will be refunding bonds maturing over eighteen years. The rest will be to finance capital improvements.

THE pleasures of prophecy are few and gloomy and prophets of disaster are rarely any more popular than Jeremiah or Cassandra. But if prophets who base their warnings on masses of statistics and scientific data could command the attention granted so freely to ranting demagogues some steps to avert the catastrophes they predict might just possibly be taken.
CHICAGO, March 18 -- The care of the chronically ill is this country's most important health problem, a conference of physicians, hospital administrators and welfare workers was told today.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Guido Cantelli conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; Liederkranz Club of New York, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Rey de la Torre, guitarist, Town Hall, 8:30; National Arts Club Chamber Chorus, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Blue Eternal and Menolene, stanch favorites in the betting, performed to expectations as they captured the two sections of the $7,500 added Gulfstream Park Dinner Stakes today.
LONDON, March 18 -- The Government announced today it was cutting support prices for milk, pigs and cereals, but retaining its present scales for fat, cattle, sheep and eggs.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 18 -- Israel formally blamed the Jordanian Government today for the massacre of eleven travelers in the ambush of a bus yesterday at Scorpion Pass in the Negev near Beersheba.

Dr. Dov Joseph, Israeli Minister of Development, who arrived here yesterday, sharply condemned the ambush of a bus near Beersheba in which eleven Israelis were machinegunned to death. The Israeli official said that his nation's "patience is just about exhausted and the situation is grave."

Shortly before his death, Will Hays turned over to Doubleday the manuscript of his memoirs. The book covers the entire career of the man who was a member of President Harding's Cabinet and later head of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America (better known as the Hays Office).
HONG KONG, March 18 -- North Korea has launched a three-year plan for restoration of its war-damaged heavy industry with Soviet material and technical assistance, the Peiping radio said this morning.

As you pointed out so clearly in your editorial of March 17 it is indeed disappointing that the charges involving the veracity of the Secretary of the Army and of Senator McCarthy are to be investigated by Senator McCarthy's subcommittee. You also wrote of the advantage of having the more judicious Senator Mundt replace Senator McCarthy as chairman as well as of having only public hearings and sworn testimony.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 18 (AP) -- Navy's crew, riding the longest winning streak in collegiate rowing history with twenty straight, will participate in seven regattas this year, the Naval Academy disclosed today.

SYRACUSE, March 18 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals today pinned on the New York Knickerbockers, Eastern Division champions, their second straight setback in the National Basketball Association's round robin play-offs, 75 -- 68. It was the second victory in a row for Syracuse.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 18 -- The motion picture industry is being urged by the United states Information Agency to expand its participation in foreign film festivals.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr. of Pocono Manor, Pa., excelled with a round of 64, eight under par, today as two teams of professionals deadlocked for the lead after the first round in the $15,000 international four-ball golf tournament.

The four-story converted dwelling on plot 20 by 100 feet at 486 First Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Rosemarie Maguire to Ethel A. Klenk in a transaction negotiated by L. L. Yearsley. The same broker also reported the sale of the two-story one-family house at 360-A Fifth Street for Deborah Vetter and Grace Underhill to Anthony Balestieri.
In an advance that grew in power and volume, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday made the widest gains since Feb. 3.

OTTAWA, March 18 -- People are much the same all over the world and if the West can contribute to the well-being of the East, the East has much it can teach the West, Prime Minister Louis St. Laurent told the House of Commons today on his return from a six-week trip around the world.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., March 18 (AP) -- Paced by George Mikan, who scored 28 points, Minneapolis took the lead in the Western Division National Basketball Association round-robin play-offs tonight by defeating Fort Wayne, 90 -- 85.
New York has acquired 550,000 acres for state forests and expects to buy that much again, members of the Northwest Lumber Manufacturers Association were told yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 18 -- Any sizable increase in unemployment will bring difficulties for travelers aid societies, Mrs. George Hemlin Shaw of New York said today.
WASHINGTON, March l8 (AP) -- A House Judiciary subcommittee set out today to make Communism a crime in the United States.

TRENTON, March 18 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today charged former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman, now Director of the State Division of Employment Security, with "misconduct in office" and suspended him pending a further investigation.
The Greek liner Olympia was left at the poet again yesterday as her sailing was postponed until midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Democratic proposal for higher personal income tax exemptions was rejected by the House of Representatives today, 210 to 204, in a dramatic if close victory for President Eisenhower.
Robert Moses, new chairman of the State Power Authority, charged yesterday that Elliott V. Bell had been forced to resign as vice chairman and member of the authority.
ALBANY, March 18 -- A bill to give the State Superintendent of Insurance specific authority to examine the affairs of union welfare funds was introduced in the Legislature tonight.
AVON, Conn., March 18 -- President Eisenhower overwhelmingly defeated Senator Joseph R. McCarthy tonight in a Republican "grass roots" party leadership test in six Connecticut communities.

Alastair B. Martin of Glen Head, L. I., national singles title-holder, and Frank Shields of New York led the field into the semi-final round of the national amateur court tennis doubles championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday.

Setting up a sound program of group insurance in a large company is no job for amateurs, it was demonstrated yesterday by two officials of the Ford Motor Company. They addressed 700 business officials at a special conference on employe group benefits in the Roosevelt Hotel called by the American Management Association.
The United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York announced yesterday that it had received a loan of $20,000,000 from seven New York banks and that the money would be utilized to aid Israel.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- A survey showed today that consumers were somewhat less confident about their personal financial prospects than a year ago.

After two days of debate the House of Representatives voted yesterday on the proposal of the Democrats to attach to the Administration's omnibus revenue bill a provision that would have completely distorted its meaning and would have undone most of the progress made under the Eisenhower Administration to bring the federal budget under control.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange continued to fluctuate in a narrow range yesterday and active months closed 1 point higher to 3 points lower than on Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 (AP) -- Setting a new high-run tournament record, Joe Canton of Watervliet, N. Y., defeated Morris Pearlstein of Atlantic City, N. J., 150 -- 62, in the world pocket billiard championship today.
OMAHA, Neb., March 18 -- Farmers during 1954 must be prepared to cope with the greatest crop storage problem in history, Department of Agriculture officials declared today.

GREENWOOD, S. C., March 18 -- With its new Durst going into high gear, Greenwood Mills, one of the few remaining great family-owned textile enterprises in the South, has completed its $20,000,000 expansion program, started soon after the end of World War II.
Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, charged President Eisenhower last night with unwillingness or inability to control attacks by "radical Republicans" like Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized a 10 per cent increase in the railroad mail rates.
The New York City Transit Authority designated Sidney H. Bingham yesterday, as executive director in addition to his present post as general manager.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Chaplain Patrick James Ryan, a Roman Catholic, to be Chief of Chaplains of the Army with the rank of Major General. He would succeed Maj. Gen. Ivan L. Bennett, a Baptist, who is due to retire April 30.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Prize winners among the photographers who flash bulbs at the President today showed their blue-ribbon pictures to him. More bulbs, of course, were flashed for the occasion.

Thomas Jefferson High of Brooklyn captured the Public Schools Athletic League basketball championship by routing Benjamin Franklin High of Manhattan's upper East Side, 82 -- 57, before 4,000 spectators at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 18 (AP) -- A confident Kid Gavilan said today he would knock out the middleweight champion, Bobo Olson, and then challenge Rocky Marciano for the world heavyweight title.
Nine students from the Bronx High School of Science ended the school day yesterday in unusual fashion -- in a hospital. And, they avered, they never felt better.

When the Anheuser-Busch-interests bought the St. Louis Cardinals last summer they did not obtain the services of Harry Carey, baseball announcer, for the very good reason that Mr. Carey was long in the employ of Griesedieck Brothers, another St. Louis brewery.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- Presbyterian minister denied "categorically" today that he ever had been a Communist and called communism "an evil thing" that free men must resist at any cost."
