CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 18 -- Adlai E. Stevenson counseled tonight an alertness to the revolution of "rising expectations" among the colonial peoples of the world.

VIENNA, March 18 -- After months of hesitation, the Polish Government has fallen in line in declaring for Moscow's new policy of conciliating the consumer and the farmer. Dispatches from Warsaw indicate that this was the principal feature of the second congress of the Polish United Workers (Communist) party, which has just concluded.

A site for a shopping center on the west side of Grand Avenue, between Irene and Georgia Streets, in Baldwin, L. I., has been purchased by the Dawood Realty Company of Mineola from Frederick J. Siyufy in a transaction negotiated by Sydney M. Siegel Co., brokers.
The United Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday net income of $21,193,733, equal to $6.22 a common share, for 1953.This compares with $17,809,391, or $5.18 a share, in the preceding year.

Once again, in a spring collection of French and Italian imports literally translated into American-made coats, suits and dresses, Ohrbach's proved that high fashion can be obtained at reasonable prices. This collection, viewed by the press yesterday, will be available to the public Monday.

Any errant choir boy who is called up on the headmaster's carpet at the new $500,000 St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church Choir School will be treading very softly indeed. The carpet is a deep-piled soft, handmade Moroccan rug in the headmaster's office-apartment, well designed to cushion even the shock of a demerit.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into reports that eight Cuban Negro baseball players have been ordered to "get out of town" by officials of Winter Garden, Fla.

TOKYO, March 18 -- The Japanese Government decided today to make no immediate protest or claim for indemnity or damages to the fishing boat Fukuryu Maru and its crew off Bikini on March 1 when the atomic bomb test was staged there.

IT has taken the Park Department 100 years to get at the job of labeling its Central Park gates, or entrances, but it has a start on the project now. A little old gentleman has just finished the job at Fifth Avenue and Seventysecond Street, chiseling out "Inventors Gate."
LONDON, March 18 -- Alan Winnington, correspondent of The London Daily Worker with the Communist forces in Korea, has been refused a renewal of his passport by the British Government.

The Phillips Petroleum Company operated in 1953 at the highest earnings level in its 36-year history despite a substantially larger tax bill than in 1952, according to the annual report released today.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Following are the texts of statements before the Senate Armed Services Committee today by Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense; Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army; Adm. Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; and Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff:

Coal barge workers in this port are seeking an increase of more than 22 per cent in their present monthly base pay of $225, William E. Cleary, executive vice president of the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York, reported yesterday.
ALBANY, March 18 (AP) -- Mr. Mitchell and Senator McCarthy each charged the other today with inciting "religious bigotry." They are two of the country's most prominent Roman Catholic laymen.
A soldier was injured in a jeep accident in World War II. Instead of reporting to the Army medics, he arranged with his first sergeant to do light duty with his own outfit until he recovered.

LONDON, March 18 -- The stock markets were quieter today and price movements narrow and irregular except in German bonds. The main restraining influences were said to be the approach of the budget and continued uncertainties about American business activity.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 -Grants totaling $280,069 for fellowships and for cancer research were voted today by the Board of Directors of the American Cancer Society. Governor Walter J. Kohler of Wisconsin, chairman of the board, presided.

The aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange rose 69,513 shares between Feb. 15 and March 15, the exchange reported yesterday. The latest figure, 2,792,457 shares, was the highest reported since May 4, 1932.

Five new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Saadia," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer adventure in Technicolor with Cornel Wilde, Mel Ferrer, Rita Gam and Michel Simon, is at the Normandie. Albert Lewin produced, directed and wrote the screen play, from a novel by Francis D'Autheville.

Recently, in The New York Times, other newspapers and over the air, there has been much discussion about juvenile delinquency. Social problems such as lack of parental guidance and religious training, slum areas, overcrowded public schools, shortage of teachers, broken homes and insufficient recreational facilities have been shown to be contributing causes.

Prices were irregular at the close yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Coffee, zinc, wool, silk and tin were higher; cottonseed oil, hides, potatoes, rubber and burlap moved lower, and cocoa, sugar, soybean oil, copper and lead closed mixed. The domestic sugar contract registered the most daily sales since last April 10 and zinc had the largest number of trades since Nov. 19.
ALBANY, March 18 -- Two of the three major bills sought by Governor Dewey to clean up harness racing received Senate approval today as the Legislature sprinted toward a final adjournment on Saturday.

ROME, Friday, March 19 -- A vigorous campaign to eradicate communism from the whole state machinery and from all other phases of Italian life within the reach of the Government was announced this morning. This decision was taken by the Cabinet Council, which met yesterday, and was made public this morning by Premier Mario Scelba's office.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 18 (AP) -- Tony Trabert rushed through a singles and a doubles match today in his first appearance in the Everglades invitation tennis tournament but Hugh Stewart's gallant stand against Vic Seixas surprised the spectators.

REGINALD ROSE is a television writer to be watched. He is the author of "Thunder on Sycamore Street," presented on 'Studio One" this week over C. B. S., and it was a drama of uncommon sensitivityy, craftsmanship and valor. Next to George Orwell's "1984' it was as fine a work as "Studio One" has done this season.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 18 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany arrived here today for an eight-day state visit. Both Germans and Turks hope his stay will reverse a recent deterioration of economic relations between the two countries.
Harold S. Vanderbilt, who in recent years has been reducing his investment in the New York Central Railroad, doubled his holding of the road's stock last month.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The Assembly approved today by a narrow margin a bill that would permit a savings bank to open one branch office within fifteen miles of the city in which its main office is situated.
The chef de protocol of the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus made known through diplomatic channels yesterday that its closing number this year would be dedicated to the United Nations.
Sidney Blackmer has agreed to appear in Leonard Lee's mystery melodrama, "Hang Together," and contracts are being drawn for signing soon.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 18 -- With his Giants on a five-game winning streak, Leo Durocher will not necessarily have to fly through the clouds to Las Vegas tomorrow morning. He could walk on them. The New York manager today saw Willie Mays clout a homer and two doubles and Johnny Antonelli pitch four walkless innings as the Giants turned back the Cubs, 9 -- 6.

The campaign chairman of the Greater New York Fund yesterday accused the managements of thousands of metropolitan concerns of imposing "obstructions" in the path of the fund's efforts to reach this city's labor force of 3,500,000 persons.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 8 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:

HAVANA, March 18 -- The Cuban People's party, known as the Ortodoxos, will not participate in the general elections scheduled for November, according to an announcement by the Executive Committee today.

A collection of summer dresses by Philip Hulitar was presented yesterday by Milgrims at the Plaza Hotel Soft lines were seen in appliques, hand-painting, lace, intricate draping and mushroom pleating.

LONDON, March 18 -- Communist China's admission to the United Nations, once that nation is purged of aggression, was proposed tonight by Sir Gladwyn Jebb. It was suported by Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the world organization.

TOKYO, Friday, March 19 (AP) -- Dr. John J. Morton, director of the United States Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission at Hiroshima, said today the twenty-three Japanese fishermen victims of the Bikini hydrogen blast would recover completely in about one month.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 -- Transamerica Corporation's consolidated net profit for 1953 was $27,652,030, or $2.82 a share, Frank N. Belgrano Jr., president and board chairman, told stockholders today in the 1953 annual report. For 1952 the comparable net profit was $23,914,285, or $2.43 a share.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Statehood foes today held out a lure of a Federal tax exemption if Alaska and Hawaii would accept commonwealth status.

After an investigation into alleged, irregularities in the office of the Queens County Medical Examiner, grand jury reported yesterday that it had seen evidence of questionable practices in connection with autopsies. However, in the absence of any unlawful intent, it suggested remedial action rather than criminal prosecution.
Iron Curtain countries may soon receive offers of Chilean Copper.

The press, the Government and the public have areas of responsibility in helping to assure that a free press fulfills its role in American democracy, Turner Catledge, managing editor of The New York Times, declared last night.

The constant border incidents that have marked the shaky truce in Palestine have now culminated in a particularly shocking crime which has brought new tension to the whole region. This crime is the cowardly massacre of a busload of Israeli holiday-makers in the Scorpion Pass in the Negev desert, in which eleven men, women and children were killed.
The text of the letter sent to Governor Dewey by Mayor Wagner yesterday follows:

NEW DELHI, India, March 18 -- Indian employes of the United States Embassy and affiliated agencies are being checked by the criminal investigation division of the Indian equivalent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 18 -- French Union forces at Dienbienphu braced today for possible renewal of the Vietminh mass attacks. It is thought that the enemy preparations are virtually complete for a revival of the ground assaults that were discontinued Sunday afternoon.

A blockfront in the downtown financial district containing a bank building and two-story post office building has been purchased by Webb Knapp, Inc., from the Seamen's Bank for Savings. The tax valuation is $2,400,000, of which $1,000,000 is land value.
MADRID, March 18 -- The Roman Catholic Bishop of Barcelona has urged adoption of stern measures to repress what he termed proselytizing by United States Protestant sects in Spain.
HARTFORD, March 18 -- Republican caucuses met tonight throughout the state to elect town committees, and seemed to be judging the incumbents on the party's record in the last town elections.
Mayor Wagner served notice yesterday on Governor Dewey that he would make the state's failure to give the city fair financial treatment an issue in the campaign for Governor next fall.
GENEVA, March 18 (Reuters) -- The United Nations Economic Commission for Europe unanimously approved today a British-Soviet resolution urging increased East-West trade.

A joint project to test the commercial feasibility of upgrading Southern iron ore and iron-bearing materials for use by the steel industry was announced yesterday by the National Lead Company and the Republic Steel Corporation.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Governor Dewey today named Reinhard A. Hohaus of Bronxville, vice president and chief actuary of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, to head the reorganized state commission on pensions.

Some vigorous, robust piano playing was offered last night in Town Hall by Frank Amey, who gave a debut recital. Mr. Amey went about such diverse pieces as Scriabin's Fifth Sonata, Bach's C minor Partita, Beethoven's Sonata in E (Op. 109) and his own Sonata in much the same manner -- with heavily marked accents, fast tempos, and somewhat hard, brusque interpretations.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- Following are the roll-call vote by which the House today defeated a Democratic-backed move to increase by $100 the personal exemption for income taxpayers and their dependents, and the vote on final passage of the tax reform bill:

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Saturday totaled 609,883 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 19,316 cars or 3.3 per cent more than for the preceding week, 90,300 cars or 12.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 99,092 cars or 14 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

The Sunday Magazine of this newspaper recently published some examples of the new lingo, or jargon, springing up at United States Air Force bases and jet training fields. For instance, a blow torch is any jet plane. A. spam can is any propeller- driven aircraft. A prang is an accident caused by the pilot's error. There is one minor hazard connected with trying to keep up with jargon.
WASHINGTON. March 18 (UP) -- The Navy reported today it had 328 officers and men in various security or loyalty risk categories who were either being investigated or "controlled."
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower called today for "constant vigilance" against violations of civil liberties and a heightened public awareness of the importance of those liberties.

" Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," opera's inseparables, returned to the repertory last night at the Metropolitan. Scheduled for a season off, they came to the rescue, like the fearless Mounties, when difficulties prevented the revival of "Simon Boccanegra."

BONN, Germany, March 18 -- The Social Democratic party has introduced a motion in the Bundestag, the lower house of the West German Parliament, to permit citizens of all Western countries to enter and visit Germany without passports.

BEERSHEBA, Israel, March 18 (Reuters) -- Israel charged tonight that another shooting incident had taken place on the Israeli-Jordanian border, after formally accusing Jordan of responsibility for yesterday's slaying of eleven Israelis ambushed in a vacation bus.
ALBANY, March 19 -- The twenty-six Republican legislators from New York City accused Mayor Wagner today of playing "callous politics" with the welfare of the city's residents.
MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, March 19 (AP) -- Armco Steel Corporation annuonced today it would spend $33,000,000 in 1954 to streamline operations and reduce costs.

The British Government has formally denied, in a memorandum to the Department of State, that the gigantic liners Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth carried American troops to the war areas in World War II for a price.

KANSAS CITY, March 19 (AP) -- Bradley and La Salle tonight moved into the final of the National Collegiate basketball championship. The Braves toppled Southern California, 74 -- 72, in a duel decided in the final minutes and La Salle easily beat Penn State, 69 -- 54.

It is common knowledge that the manner in which the Secretaries of Agriculture have purchased and stored butter to support the price at which dairy farmers could sell their cream has seriously curtailed consumer demand for butter. This need not have happened, however.
Native Dancer probably will fly to England in July for the rich King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes at Ascot if he is handicapped with "prohibitive" weight in this country.
LONDON, March 19 -- The London gold market, which has been closed for more than fourteen years, will be reopened on a restricted basis on Monday.
Suffering from multiple injuries, Thomas Rubino, a Brooklyn dock union official who nearly lost his life in a brutal beating last Feb. 18, said yesterday he could not remember who did it.

DACCA, Pakistan, March 19 -- The death of the Moslem League in East Pakistan, the country's largest province, loomed tonight. The party was founded in this country almost seven years ago, when India, of which it was a part, became independent of Britain.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 19 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy rose from his sickbed tonight to level a twenty-count indictment for "treason or gross stupidity" against the Demo cratic party. Replying to attacks on "McCarthyism" by Adlai E. Stevenson, the 1952 Democratic Presidential nominee, the Republican Senator from Wisconsin named Mr. Stevenson as attorney for the defense and asked whether he pleaded "guilty or not guilty" to each count in the indictment.

The contribution of book publishing to "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof," the theme of Columbia University's Bicentennial, will be discussed tomorrow in a broadcast over WNYC from 1 to 1:30 P. M. Participants in the program, which will open the station's week-long Book Festival, will include Mayor Wagner, Grayson Kirk, president of Columbia University, and Douglas M. Black, president of the American Book Publishers Council.
ALBANY, March 19 -- Legislation embodying a major reclassification of the civil service system and a $13,200,000 salary increase for state workers was introduced in the Legislature today.

CLEVELAND, March 19 (AP) -- Len Truex won the mile run, and Horace Ashenfelter gained an easy two-mile victory as they retained their meet championships tonight in the fourteenth annual Knights of Columbus competition.
The return of preferred stock financing for public utility markets will be visable in the new-issue market next week.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 18 -- The State Department has solved the problem of what to do about President Eisenhower's executive order of Nov. 6 eliminating the "restricted" security classification.

Chemicals and aircrafts took control of the stock market yesterday and pulled it ahead by main power. Oils, rails, steels and motors followed with gains wide enough to push The New York Times combined average to another new high since March 25, 1953, and to take the Times industrial average to its best since June, 1930.

AVON, Conn., March 19 -- The Avon Committee to Support President Eisenhower was still elated today at the size of its caucus victory last night. Town Republicans, by a vote of about 350 to 1, chose President Eisenhower over Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as the national leader and symbol of the Republican party.

The old Capitol Paint Company building at 47 Rodney Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Alter B. Belfer, as trustee, to Ernest and Ralph Sohnen for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $50,000. The property is assessed at $137,400. Elliott J. Finkelstein was the broker and the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company insured title. Laurence Rubin was attorney for the seller and Saul C. Kaufman acted for the buyers.
The Red Cross aims to make certain that every possible penny of every dollar that is contributed brings returns to the American people in the form of service, relief or training.

MEXICO CITY, March 19 (AP) -- Angry fans rioted at the Municipal Auditorium tonight when the Mexico-Panama basketball play-off test for the championship of the Central American Games was called off after a dispute over referees.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Seventeen 3-year-olds were entered today in the $100,000 added Florida Derby to be run at a mile and an eighth at Gulf-stream Park tomorrow.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 19 -- This fabulous gambling resort saw two big league clubs in action for the first time today. The game that the Giants and the Indians staged for a record 9,088 fans was a tremendous boost for baseball.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Cuts of 50 per cent in most Federal "luxury" taxes and comparable reductions in ether excises were approved today by the Senate Finance Committee despite the opposition of the Eisenhower Administration.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee recommended today restoration of $215,000,000 of the $300,000,000 cut last year from the Veterans Administration budget.
The twenty-second annual convention on family life under the auspices of the Family Life Bureau of the National Catholic Welfare Conference will be held Wednesday through Friday in New Orleans.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein accused a Wall Street securities house yesterday of engaging in fraudulent practices int handling customers' securities while the firm was in fact insolvent.
Retailing in the urban centers of Brazil has taken giant steps toward modernization in the last seven years, Mrs. Tobe Coller Davis declared yesterday.

CLIO, ALA., March 19 (AP) -- A small-town banker whose mysterious twelve - day absence brought fears of financial ruin to his farming community, took an overdose of sleeping medicine, a doctor said today, after promising to pay off all depositors in full.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 19 (AP) -- The furor over colonialism at the Inter-American Conference cost Christopher Columbus a monument today.

MIAMI, March 19 -- The Dodgers' winning streak reached ten games tonight at Miami Stadium when Peewee Reese lined a single to left with two out in the ninth inning to give the Brooks a 2-1 triumph over the world champion Yankees, whose losing string now stands at six.
CHARLESTON, S. C., March 19 -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, warned today that attacks on the integrity of Army officers were a threat to national security.
Empire State citizens from Buffalo to Staten Island saved a lot of money last month.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 18 -- While it is generally conceded that the squaw dress originated in Santa Fe, Tuscon is recognized as the center of production of this gay and colorful style.

Roy M. Cohn, chief counsel for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Subcommittee on Investigations, obtained deferment from the draft twice, in 1945 and 1946, while seeking entrance to the United States Military Academy.
BONN, Germany, March 19 -- West German industry has begun a concerted maneuver to kill the Allies' anti-cartel law.

WINTER GARDEN, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- The City Council said today that Cuban Negro ball players of the Washington team's farm system in training here would be given ful protection and the same consideration as any Winter Garden citizen.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., March 19 -- Marian Hall, a new $929,000 science and arts building on the campus of Marymount College for girls was dedicated at ceremonies here this afternoon. Its opening for the fall term this year will mark completion of the second phase of a master plan of expansion to meet the needs of an enrollment of 540 students.

LOS ANGELES, March 19 (AP) -- Tenley Albright, 18-year-old freshman pre-medical student tonight put on a precise free-skating performance and won her third straight senior women's title in the United States figure skating championships.
Immediate action by lenders on the thirty-year Government-insured mortgages on homes was urged yesterday by Thomas H. Quinn, president of the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.
A Bronx theatre manager unwittingly staged the hidden ball trick yesterday and two would-be robbers were caught off base.
ROME, March 19 -- A large crowd in St. Peter's Square cheered Pope Plus this morning when he made his first appearance in public since he was taken ill eight weeks ago.
ALBANY, March 19 -- Mayor Wagner's $21 - a - room - a - month housing program was rescued today from impending strangulation in legislative committees by a series of last-minute amendments.
The following books of a religious and an inspirational nature have been issued recently:
The New York Young Republican Club has adopted a resolution censuring Senator McCarthy for "irresponsible and reckless conduct" in his investigation of alleged Communists.

Operations last year of the Cleveland - Cliffs Iron Company and its consolidated subsidiaries resulted in a net profit of $9,137,122, third highest in the company's history, according to the report issued yesterday.

Medical science scores a knockout over witchcraft toward the end of eight long reels in M-G-M's and Albert Lewin's "Saadia," which arrived yesterday at the Normandie. At least, we presume it is a knockout, though it truly is hard to tell from the badly disjointed continuity in this handsome but hopeless color film.
The Kings County District Attorney's office said early today that ranking police officers in Brooklyn were believed to have provided protection for a multi-million dollar policy racket.

PARIS, March 19 -- A spokesman for Elsa Schiaparelli, well known Paris dressmaker, denied reports today that the Schiaparelli establishment on the Place Vendome would be temporarily closed. It was confirmed, however, that the traditional methods of making and selling haute couture clothing would be transformed because of a vastly diminished market for expensive, custom-made women's clothes.
ROME, March 19 -- Premier Mario Scelba's new policy of getting tough with communism is regarded in Italy as a complete break with the past.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 19 -- A proposal for a study of laws of the American states affecting human rights was approved without opposition today in a committee of the Tenth Inter-American Conference.

CHICAGO, March 19 (UP) -- Pete Conacher turned in the first hat trick by a Chicago player this season and Al Rollins earned his fifth shutout of the National Hockey League campaign tonight as the Hawks closed their home season with a 7-0 victory over the Boston Bruins before 6,418 fans.

CAMDEN, N. J., March 19 -- New York City's first new fireboat in fourteen years slid smoothly and proudly from her ways here at 1:48 P. M. today. She was greeted by an ear-piercing "hello" from other vessels in the Delaware River.
VALLEY STREAM, L. I., March 19 -- The Chief, a rather white swan, is on guard against the world around the lake in Valley Stream State Park, where his mate sits on her nest of eggs.

Some unusual music was on the program Rey de la Torre played on the guitar last night in Town Hall. A sonata by Mauro Giuliani received what was said to be its first complete performance in New York, and there was other original guitar music by Milan, Fuenllana, Dowland, Robert de Visee, Sor, Llobet and others.
NEW DELHI, India, March 19 -- Early Indian action to absorb the small remaining Portuguese and French possessions along this country's coastline was indicated today.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- a Congressional investigation of the immense hydrogen explosion in the Pacific March 1 has been started to determine whether adequate security and safety precautions were taken in the area.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A safety device that keeps unoccupied automobiles from rolling downhill won a patent this week for Emory Jones Brown of Towson, Md. When the driver's seat is occupied, the "automatic roll preventer" is inoperative, but if the driver gets out and leaves the car in neutral the driveshaft is locked automatically so that the rear wheels cannot turn.
A 12-year-old Pakistani girl was inducted into the Camp Fire Girls yesterday, and then all the teen-agers sat down and ate a Pakistani meal.

Fifteen hundred policemen stood watch at the piers yesterday. The result: no waterfront violence in New York for the first time in three days. tor of the A. F. L. pier union, asserted that, with assurances of police protection, "the full responsibility for opening the port now rests completely on the shipping association."
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The future of Col. Frank H. Schwable was placed today in the hands of Gen. Lemuel C. Shepherd, commandant of the Marine Corps.
BONN, Germany, March 19 -- Frustration threatened West Germany tonight in its long campaign to get the European Defense Community treaty and the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies ratified.
VIENNA, March 19 -- A reorganization of the Polish Government was announced in a Warsaw radio broadcast today. The change was similar to the one that took place in Hungary last year.

William White, president of the New York Central Railroad Company, three other directors of the railroad and the Central itself yesterday asked for a dismissal of a stockholders' suit brought against them on March 3 by Robert R. Young and Allan P. Kirby.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Despite tricky thirty-mile-an-hour wind gusts, Tommy Bolt and Dick Mayer knocked eleven strokes off par for the Normandy Shores course today to move into first place in the $15,000 international four-ball golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The United States and the Soviet Union completed today an exchange of proposals for international handling of atomic energy.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Dr. Lillian Moller Gilbreth, psycologist, research scientist and industrial consultant, will receive the Washington Award for leadership in engineering on April 7 at a meeting here.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged at 110.6 during the week ended March 16, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for processed foods were offset by lower average prices for farm products and industrial materials.

HOUSTON, March 19 -- President Harold W. Dodds of Princeton University struck out here tonight at what he called "grossly exaggerated" charges that universities "are full of Communists and subversive fellow travelers."
WASHINGTON, march 19 --Dr. Howard A. Rusk said today that the Administration bill to extend Federally-aided hospital construction would help the national rehabilitation program.
Mayor Wagner resumed yesterday his budget retreat in the office of Budget Director Abraham D. Beame in the Municipal Building.

DAYTON, Ohio, March 19 (AP) -- An Army captain who died after passing out and falling against the rear cockpit controls sent a jet trainer into a fast roll at 42,000 feet today, the Wright-Patterson Air Force Base announced.
HANOI, Vietnam, March 19 -- The French continued their intensive round-the-clock bombing of Vietminh positions encircling Dienbienphu last night and today.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Delay if not disruption of the projected Senate investigation into the Army-McCarthy controversy was threatened today.
True to his promises, Premier Scelba of Italy has now launched a determined campaign against both communism and a reviving fascism.

Two five-story store and apartment buildings at 146-48 West Sixty-eighth Street have been purchased by Seymour M. Tanenbaum from the Estate of Lizetta Kahn and others in a cash deal negotiated by Sidney Goodman, a broker. There are six stores and twenty apartments in the property, which is assessed at $66,000. Title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Governor Dewey's compulsory automobile insurance bill was defeated, 29 to 26, in the Republican-controlled Senate today by a combination of Republican opposition and Democratic political maneuvering.
I found your recent editorial "Inter-American Conference" extremely interesting. Your newspaper has a justly recognized tradition of understanding for the peoples and problems of Latin America.
LONDON, March 19 (AP) -- Judy Devlin of Baltimore, and Iris Cooley, daughter of a London river policeman, won their semi-final matches tonight in the all-England badminton tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Scott McLeod, the State Department's security officer, has told Congress that he found fewer subversives in the department than he had expected.

ALBANY, March 19 -- Governor Dewey's recommendation that public officials and employes and the officials of political parties be barred from having interests in pari-mutuel horse racing was approved by the Assembly today by a vote of 98 to 49.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The following is the statement read by Secretary of State Dulles today to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee:
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 19 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said tonight that the United States soon must formulate a "reasoned policy" with respect to China in quest for world peace.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, March 19 (Reuters) -- England, facing a record West Indies total of 681 for eight declared -- the highest scored against England in twenty years -- made a sound start of 130 in its reply on the third day of the fourth test cricket match.

The armory at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street promises to be a busy place for the next week. When the doors open at noon today for the eight-day Do- It-Yourself Show, some individuals will be laying floors, others hanging paper.
CAIRO, March 19 -- Relations between Britain and Egypt are under the greatest strain in two years following the murder today of a British major in the Suez Canal zone.
WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- Robert T. Stevens, Secretary of the Army, approaching a showdown fight with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, got a pat on the back today from the Army's Chief of Staff.

THOSE who wonder why new postings prevent access to many lakes, streams and hunting areas often can find the answer merely by using their eyes to survey the damage done and the litter left by a few anglers and hunters, whose actions have forced landowners to protect their property by posting it against trespass.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 19 (AP) -- Joyce Ziske, the medalist, today continued to master both the opposition and par as she led the way through an upset-free second round of the North and South women's amateur golf tournament.
The Curtis Publishing Company and consolidated subsidiaries announced yesterday that net sales and net income in 1953 increased 7 per cent and 11 per cent, respectively, above results posted in 1952.
The Nichols Medal of the New York Section of the American Chemical Society was presented here last night to Prof. Charles Phelps Smyth of Princeton University.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- A Federal spring crop planting report today indicated another year of high-level production.
Alastair B. Martin of Glen Head, L. I., and Frank Shields of New York, the defenders, reached the final of the national amateur court tennis doubles championship yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Ambassador Abba S. Eban of Israel asked urgently this afternoon to see Secretary of State Dulles in connection with the killing of eleven Israeli bus passengers at Scorpion Pass. Mr. Dulles may see the Israeli envoy tomorrow.

Sixty-eight blowgun darts were turned over to the police last night after the boys who took them from the American Museum of Natural History had read that the missiles might have been treated with a deadly poison.

NEW DELHI, India, March 19 -- The failure of Tenzing, the Mount Everest climber, to obtain permission in India to visit New York for the Explorers Club dinner tonight, was the result of a combination of misunderstandings.

ALBANY, March 19 -- A bill authorizing the Port of New York Authority to build the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel -- a project that has been under way since September, 1952 -- was rushed through the Legislature today and sent to Governor Dewey for his signature.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., March 19 (AP) -- The public is probably more concerned with "dull and mediocre" advertising than with poor taste in advertising, the Association of National Advertisers was told here today.

Maurray Edelman, 40, led the field into the second round last night in the senior metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships at the McBurney Y. M. C. A. The event will continue today with afternoon and evening sessions.

JERUSALEM, March 19 (AP) -- The Israeli Government asked tonight that Jordan take "drastic measures" to end "the intolerable situation" that brought on an ambush in which eleven Jews were killed. Israel also asked the United Nations to "call Jordan to task" for the massacre.

Lita Lipscutz a first-year student at the Juilliard School of Music, has received first prize in the sixth annual Young Composers' Contest of the Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concerts Committee.

If we start with F sharp on the piano and run up five black keys we are playing a scale familiar the world over and known in very ancient times. Our own Indian tribes had it, and so did -- or do -- the people of China, Greece and Peru. Musicians speak of it, from its five tones, as pentatonic.

The usual end-of-the-week lull did not materialize yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Volume was better than normal in most markets. Cottonseed oil registered its best sales since Dec. 19 and potatoes had the largest number of trades since Feb. 19.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Athletics hit four home runs of Rookie Ben Johnson today and defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 10 -- 6.

Customs officials are being instructed to withhold appraisement on imports of fur felt hat bodies from communist Czechoslovakia pending a full-scale investigation of "dumping" charges, trade sources reported yesterday.
Forty students preparing for the Methodist ministry and degrees of Master of Arts in Religious Education spent yesterday afternoon and evening visiting three Roman Catholic institutions.

CHICAGO, March 19 -- Soybean futures had the spotlight today. Heavy buying of a general kind started a wave of short covering which lifted prices to new highs for the season on the March, May and July contracts.

IT may come as a surprise to some readers that the great Gustave Flaubert had written a novel called "Bouvard and Pecuchet,"* that he had devoted eight years of his life to it and that, though he came close to ending it, the book remained unfinished and unrevised. Luckily, Flaubert left behind a clear-cut synopsis of what would have been his last section and it is printed at the close of the volume.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 19 -- Guatemala charged in the Inter-American Conference today that an editorial in The New York Times on colonies "proves once more there is an alliance among the colonial powers."
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Rising unemployment in March has affected nearly all cities and all industries.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday and closing prices for active months rose 7 to 19 points.

Germany's fleet of sea-going tankers will take a sizable jump this year with the addition to its ranks of five large vessels. At the beginning of the year West Germany had a fleet of seventy-four vessels of approximately 270,000 deadweight tons in service.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday ordered his deputy and battalion fire chiefs to speed up their radio reports from the scenes of fires to Fire Headquarters.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- The New York Yankees' repeated efforts to keep Johnny Sain from retiring paid off today when the seasoned right-hander reported to the club's spring training base here.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 19 (AP) -- Sixty-nine skiers will take off down the downhill course on Baldy Mountain tomorrow in the fourteenth annual Harriman Cup races.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner recommended today that Pan-American World Airways be given renewed authorization to operate its round the world air services across the Pacific and through the Far East.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; "La Forza del Destino," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Robert Goldsand, pianist, Town Hall, 3; Robert Baker, organist, Temple Emanu-El, 4; National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Town Hall, 5:30.

To commemorate the founding of "the first university in North America" in 1553, the University of Texas Press will publish a facsimile edition of Francisco Cervantes de Salazar's "Life in the Imperial and Loyal City of Mexico in New Spain and the Royal and Pontifical University of Mexico."
ANKARA, Turkey, March 19 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will pay a two-day visit to Italy as the guest of Premier Mario Scelba following his trip to Turkey.

HACKENSACK, N. J., March 19 -- Frank Erickson, the gambler, refused today to admit any connection with the former dice and card game syndicate of Joe Adonis, but his testimony was refuted by a former associate.
Park Commissioner Robert Moses said yesterday that he would not heed the advice of "amateurs" on Park Department development plans in the area under which a section of the Queens corridor sewer runs.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (UP) -- Representative Frank M. Karsten, Democrat of Missouri, said today Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, was "in error" when he asserted that the St. Louis Cardinals' expenses were being charged against profits of the Anheuser-Busch brewery for tax purposes.
CHICAGO, March 19 -- The Commission on Chronic Illness endorsed today the fluoridation of drinking water as a protection against tooth decay.
An 18-year-old girl listened closely to a tape recording this week and heard, for the first time in her life, her voice free of a nasal speech defect.

The twenty-sixth annual Eastern States contract bridge tournament began at the McAlpin Hotel yesterday with contests for men's and women's pairs. There were eighty-two men's pairs and fifty-six women's pairs entered. Play will continue through March 28 with ten championship titles to be decided.

H. Robert Reeve Jr. of the Bayside Tennis and Racquets Club, former champion and seeded first, reached the semi-final round of the national squash tennis championship at the Yale Club yesterday. He beat Norman D. Forster of the New York Athletic Club, 15 -- 4, 15 -- 10.

The problems and successes of amateur artists from 2 to 82 were discussed yesterday at the twelfth annual conference of the Committee on Art Education at the Museum of Modern Art. The last sessions will be held tomorrow.

Lumber production for the week ended March 13 was 3.9 per cent below the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 2.2 per cent and orders were up 2.5 per cent.

Former Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind abruptly ended the fifth session of Walter Winchell's pre-trial libel examination yesterday with the statement that Mr. Winchell and his attorney had "sabotaged" the session.

Chaminade High of Mineola, L. I., defeated All Hallows of the Bronx, 61 -- 50, last night in the final of the Catholic high school silver jubilee invitation basketball tournament at the Knights of Columbus court in Brooklyn.

CINCINNATI, March 19 (AP) -- Roger N. Baldwin, national chairman of the American Civil Liberties Union, said tonight Senator Joseph R. McCarthy "has so confused Communists with Patriots that the distinction has become blurred, to the great advantage of the Communists."
Sales of real estate in Manhattan last year amounted to $323,178,479, an increase of more than $1,250,000 over the total for 1952, when transactions aggregated $321,806,638.

Retail advertising in newspapers is likely to be slow to pick up because of the late Easter, but losses in comparison with 1953 are likely to be made up by heavy gains in April. The linage figures then will be up against the post-Easter letdown of 1953.
WASHINGTON, March 18 -The State Department is notJ aIohe' mong the Federal agenciesl that have invented new ways of withholding data previously classified "restricted."
Bidding was spirited yesterday for a franchise to operate the Brooklyn-Staten Island ferry line, with nine companies making offers.
TRENTON, March 19 -- The investigation ordered yesterday by Gov. Robert B. Meyner into purchases by the State Division of Employment Security was proceeding here today behind closed doors.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 19 -- The Latin-American states voted tonight that the Inter-American Conference call on industrialized member states -- meaning the United States -- to refrain from any restrictions on imports of raw materials.
The State of Rhode Island announced yesterday that it would receive bids March 31 on $5,600,000 of bonds dated April 1, 1954, and due April 1, from 1955 to 1974.

ELATH, Israel, March 18 -- The courage that is building this port, in sight of Jordan, Saudi Arabia and Egypt, is not wavering despite the massacre of eleven Israelis on the road leading north from here.

The spiked-shoe clan will convene tonight at Madison Square Garden for the last time this year. The occasion is the thirty- fifth annual indoor games of the New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus. The thirty-one-event carnival, involving 600 athletes, will start at 7:30 o'clock.

Obviously increasing pressure from several quarters for further consideration of the early admission of Communist China to the United Nations has impelled the chief of our delegation to assert that he would not shrink from the use of the veto to prevent that admission, but that he does not believe this course will be necessary.

The vernal equinox, scheduled for 10:54 P. M. today, is a fairly well-fixed occasion, as such things go, varying only within a range of some forty-eight to sixty hours. Its exact time has to be determined each year from astronomical calculations based upon the movements of the earth around the sun.

LONDON, March 19 -- The most significant clue so far to the crash of a British Comet jet airliner in the Mediterranean last January was annouced today by the British Ministry of Civil Aviation. It was that one of the De Havilland Ghost jet engines raised from the floor of the sea had proved to have lost a turbine rotor disk.

On April 11, 1951, our good Canadian friend Lester Pearson, then and still Secretary for External Affairs, told us in plain language that "easy and automatic" relations between Canada and the United States were a thing of the past. He was right in the sense he meant it, which was that Canada was no longer willing to be "merely an echo of somebody else's voice."

Twenty construction workers were rescued at noon yesterday from the flaming thirteenth floor of an unfinished Brooklyn apartment house. A crane operator lowered them to the ground in a huge bucket and no one was injured.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Saturday, March 20 -- An Air Force C-119 "Flying Boxcar" crashed and burned near here last night killing all eighteen service men aboard.
Thomas Hinton, 46-year-old former policeman, was convicted last night of protecting gambling on Staten Island.

LONDON, March 19 -- R. A. Butler, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today that for the first time the sterling area had been able to increase its gold and dollar reserves at a time when there were signs of a decline in United States production.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- The Defense Department's refusal to cooperate with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in promoting "Prisoner of War" was attributed today by Allen Rivkin, author of the movie, to the pending court-martial by the Army of a group of former G. I. prisoners of the Communists in Korea.
PALM-BEACH, Fla., March 19 (AP) -- Art Larsen, Tony Trabert and Gardnar Mulloy had no serious trouble today in advancing to the semi-final round of the Everglades invitation tennis tournament.
CHICAGO, March 19 -- David Rockefeller, trustee of the University of Chicago and grandson of its founder, today linked isolationism and totalitarianism as products of "mass insecurity."

LONDON, March 19 -- Suggestions later confirmed that the Treasury would reopen the London gold market enlivened what had been a rather quiet session here today. British government securities in particular reacted favorably, substituting gains of as much as 7s 6d. ($1.05) for early losses.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 19 -- Expenditures for American public schools by 1960 at the rate of $4,500,000,000 a year greater than at present was proposed today by Beardsley Ruml, economist.
The reconstitution of the Theatre Authority as an organization with full powers of approval over benefit shows has been accomplished after months of negotiations.
BOSTON, March 19 -- A former $50-a-week Boston constable was in jail here today as a pyramid of his financial transactions crumbled.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 19 -- What is considered to be the most perfect specimen of a human figure out of the past was brought to light today. The body of a 10- year-old girl of the Inca civilization emerged with startling realism from an ice packed cave that had preserved her through four centuries.

The New York Legislature moves into its final day of the 1954 session with a highly creditable record of achievement, written in spite of the fact that this is a state election year. The meeting began on Jan. 6 in an atmosphere charged with politics, and the Democrats have done what they could, to the limits of irresponsibility at times, to build a platform for November.
Royal Little, chairman of the board of Textron, Inc., yesterday took his fight for a merger with the American Woolen Company to bankers and brokers said to control 45 per cent of the Woolen stock.
ATHENS, March 19 -- Squads of police were protecting the British Embassy here tonight as a result of anti-British demonstrations over Cyprus.

The election of Anthony Eden as president of the National Union of Conservative and Unionist Associations, succeeding the Marquess of Salisbury, is interpreted as confirming the expectation that he will be the successor to Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill when the latter retires.

NEW ORLEANS, March 19 (UP) -- A sister-in-law of Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black, her husband and Aubrey Williams, former National Youth Administrator, were accused today of having Communist ties at one time.
SAUK CITY, Wis., March 19 (UP) -- Leroy Gore transformed the office of his small-town weekly newspaper today into headquarters of a movement to return Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to private life.
What was called the first display here of post-war Korean goods opened in a window exhibit at Lord Taylor's yesterday.

Under a plan that allows registered nurses to complete one year of academic studies for a degree while on active duty in the Army, Miss Gertrude M. Skinner of 921 St. Nicholas Avenue was commissioned a second lieutenant in the Army Nurse Corps Wednesday.

GUATEMALA, March 19 -- United States imperialism was the main target at a meeting called yesterday evening at the Girl's National Belen School by the recently founded Youth Committee Against Foreign Intervention. The Committee is composed of several pro-left youth organizations, including the University Students' Democratic Front.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 19 -- Errol Flynn and Warner Brothers have agreed to an amicable termination of their twenty-year association.

You published a letter written by Philip C. Jessup to which, I presume, you gave the caption America vs. McCarthy. I would like to know on what basis Dr. Jessup has arrived at the conviction that the majority of Americans find the Wisconsin Senator distasteful.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles was asked today to press at the forthcoming Geneva Far Eastern Conference for the release of thirty-two United States citizens jailed without cause in Communist China.
Joe Giardello scored an easy victory over Willie Troy of Washington in the scheduled ten-round star bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
A former New York magazine writer arrived here by plane from Ceylon yesterday claiming she was "a kidnapee of the American Government."

After studying the commercial possibilities of nuclear power for five years, the Atomic Energy Commission has awarded to the Duquesne Light Company of Pittsburgh a contract for the construction of a 60,000-kilowatt plant. The total cost will be about $30,000,000, of which the Atomic Energy Commission will bear $25,000,000.

The Government struck a blow yesterday at the marriage of wealthy, 67-year-old Mrs. Dyoll Prather Herman and her husband, Percy William Herman, 49. The couple were married in West Palm Beach, Fla., on March 3.

WASHINGTON, March 19 -- The Washington Post has taken on about 500 of the 1,300 men and women who became unemployed when The Washington Times-Herald was bought and merged with the morning daily newspaper.

Legal restrictions have caused the New York Telephone Company to refuse to lease wires connecting burglar alarms from private premises to telephone- answering bureaus, according to testimony yesterday before the Public Service Commission.
WASHINGTON, March 19 -- John Foster Dulles assured Congress today that the Administration's policy of "massive retaliation" was not intended "to turn every local war into a general war."
The following is a round-up of household products that may be of help to the homemaker:
PRINCETON, N. J., March 19 -- After the second day of the Eastern Intercollegiate individual swimming championships at Princton University's pool, honors were relatively well distributed.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 19 -- Egypt today denounced a Western-backed resolution calling on her to allow ships bound for Israel to pass through the Suez Canal.

Francis Guth, a young business man with an intense interest in food -- he cooks it as well as he discusses it -- recently moved from Boston to Mexico City. This epicure, who also has lived in many parts of Europe, now sends us a lively report of gastronomy in the Mexican capital.

Young women headed by Miss Lisa Turnure and including the Misses Patricia Fisher, Daphne Towne and Cary Fox, are aiding in the plans for the annual luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the Nearly New Shop to be given Thursday in the Main Ballroom of the Plaza.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 19 -- Rockville Centre, which has been trying for five months to settle a dispute with a neighboring village over night baseball, took its case to Nassau Supreme Court here today.

One of the items in the new show of John Rood's semi-abstract sculpture at the New Gallery is a rounded, polished boulder. Burrowed into its smooth surfaces are two deep shadowed holes. It resembles strangely an Aztec mask and it is called "Owl."
MOSCOW, Saturday, March 20 -- The Soviet Government has directed a stiff warning to Turkey against the expected signing of a new pact with Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) (UP) -- William O. Douglas, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, led a band of hikers out of Washington by train today headed for Cumberland, Md., and the start of a 189-mile walk along the old Chesapeake Ohio Canal.
The Port of New York bristled yesterday with signs and portents -- some wishful, others real -- that the dock strike might be nearing an end.

SIX years ago the use of magnetic tape recorders was confined in large part to the music industry, where their flexibility, economy of operation, relative portability and other factors of convenience moved them rapidly into a dominant position.

IT is time to discuss standards. The problems involved in arriving at objective standards affecting equipment and records are examined elsewhere in this section, and their importance cannot be minimized. But if and when such standards are adopted in the industry, their purpose will be to protect the consumer and to help him toward richer enjoyment.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- Dr. Walter C. Lowdermilk, United States soil conservationist, has been retained by the Secretariat of the United Nations for six months as a consultant on one of the most ambitious projects yet undertaken by the world organization. He is already active in his new post.
DENVER, March 20 (AP) -- A new weapon in the horror class with atomic and hydrogen bombs is being made and stored at the Rocky Mountain arsenal near Denver.

JAZZ fanciers had, as they were once wont to say, "eyes" for LP when it came along to break down the time limitations inherent in 78 r.p.m disks. Now at last, they felt, some of the more fabulous moments in jazz -- those relaxed sessions when Louis, Dizzy, Hamp, Pres or whoever, created chorus after remarkable chorus -- could be recorded in their entirety.

ELIZABETHTOWN, N. Y., March 20 (AP) -- B. Gregory Brewster, Crown Point attorney, pleaded guilty today in Supreme Court here to thirty-one felony counts of second-degree forgery and uttering forged instruments. He was charged in sixteen indictments with forging the names of four State Supreme Court justices to divorce and annulment decrees, and an adoption proceeding.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Two airlines -- Northwest and Trans World -- said today they would oppose a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner's proposal that Pan American World Airways retain the exclusive United States-flag air route across the Far East.
Three Health Department and two Hospitals Department workers received cash awards totaling $140 last week under the city's employe suggestion program.

I TAKE exception to Mr. Peyre's statement in his review of Simone de Beauvoir's "She Came To Stay" that "the first shock comes in childhood, when we realize that there is more than ourselves in the world." To a normal human being this revelation is a pleasant excuse to exercise the fantastic wonderment of curiosity.

HE is a New England poet, perhaps the New England poet, and reaps all the advantage there is in being true to a particular piece of earth -- true to its landscape, its climate, its history; its morality, its tongue. But he is in the same breath a poet of and for the world.

" Remembrance of Things Past" by Stewart Holbrook (March 7) brings forth many recollections of the same nostalgic quality as the author describes. To Mr. Holbrook's reminiscent catalogue of such items as the railroad depot, the streetcar, the general store, barber-shop quartets, train whistles, and threshing machines, I would like to add one item of particular meaning to New Yorkers.
HANOI, Vietnam, March 20 -- French air attacks against the Vietminh forces around Dienbienphu reached a new stage of intensity last night and today.
MANILA, March 20 (UP) -- President Ramon Magsaysay announced today a five-year economic development program for the Philippines, estimated to cost 4,000,000,000 pesos ($2,000,000,000).

FORT WORTH, March 20 (AP) -- Oklahoma A. and M. rallied today to win the All-Southwestern recreation track and field meet. The Aggies captured the final event, the mile relay, in the record time of 3 minutes 17.2 seconds to beat the University of Houston for the team title, 39 points to 38 1/2.
LINCOLN, R. I., March 20 (UP) -- Pictus, owned by Ralph Lowe, gained an easy victory in the $10,000 Providence Handicap on a muddy course at Lincoln Downs today for his third victory in a row.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- President Eisenhower was guest of honor tonight at a dinner of the White House News Photographers Association at which he presented awards to eight winners of the eleventh annual photo contest.

DENVER, March 20 (AP) -- Peoria's Caterpillars won their third straight national A.A.U. basketball championship tonight with a 63-55 triumph over San Diego, a club that couldn't match the champions' manpower or finesse in the tense closing minutes.
Submission of the Eisenhower Administration's program for long-term economic cooperation between the United States and other free nations is expected this week, according to reliable informants here.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 20 (AP) -- Willie Mosconi of Philadelphia, the world champion, today claimed a world record run of 526 in pocket billiards.

THE uncertain present prods us to try to peer into the future, each with the equipment of whatever special knowledge he may have. The results, whether reported by biologists, economists, physicists or students of political history, have not been encouraging.

BIRDS are not the only creatures to head north in the spring. There are also the flocks of tourists that have been wintering in Florida. Their migration has already begun, and for the motorists that can mean one of two distinct possibilities.
WASHINGTON, March 20 -- President Eisenhower has won a major battle in the House of Representatives, but more than a few seasoned politicians think he may have lost a war.

After seventeen years of litigation and political controversy, title to the country's offshore lands apparently has been settled. Last week, the United States Supreme Court denied to Alabama and Rhode Island the right to challenge the Submerged Lands Act of 1953, which vested the title in the contiguous states to their historical boundaries.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I. March 20 -- A pioneer program for the treatment of retarded children is scheduled to start May 1 with the opening of a Coordination and Development Center in the new wing of Nassau Hospital at Mineola.

The tide began running out last week for the old International Longshoremen's Association. At the very time that it was clamping an almost total blackout on the great Port of New York, the crime-soaked pier union appeared to many observers to be moving toward its own destruction.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Supplemental appropriations of $30,300,000 were voted at today's closing session of the Legislature.

ALFRED SHEINWOLD has had a reputation for nearly twenty years as the writer best able to explain contract bridge to beginners. Though this may be displeasing to him personally (because the cognoscenti have tended to regard him rather as an analyst of the more recondite phases of the game) he has apparently reconciled himself to making the most of it and has had published two bridge books for beginners.

STRONG advocate though I am of marriage, I do wonder as to its desirability for fictional private eyes. Real-life ones, to be sure, are perfectly apt to enjoy unspectacular monogamy; but in fiction, the wife is prone to clutter up the story (so much so that an occasional author has been forced to kill her off) or to turn her tough-pro husband into merely one half of a Bright-Young-Couple team.

OTTAWA, March 20 -- By-elections in two Liberal constituencies in Quebec and two Conservative strongholds in Ontario will be watched closely tomorrow for evidence of any shift in public opinion. Last August, in the general election, the Liberals won 170 of the 265 seats in the Canadian House of Commons.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- The National Catholic Music Educators Association announced today it would hold a nation-wide scholarship contest for Roman Catholic high school and college seniors, with $2,000 in cash awards and scholarships valued at $8,000.

PANSIES and English daisies, daffodils and iris, camellias and climbing roses, to say nothing of all the flowers in between, are blooming in the back yards, front yards and patios and terraces in this part of the country.

THE average construction cost of a one-family house has increased from $5,525 in 1946 to $9,946.50 in the first ten months of 1953, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. More and more people are interested in any and all hints on how to get more house (or a better house) for less money.
Plans for a seven-story, $5,100,000 building to house the New York School of Printing were approved last week by the Board of Education.

The vernal equinox is both a time and a place. The time was 10:54 Eastern standard time last night. The place is off in the direction of the Great Square of Pegasus in a region where there are few stars.
PARIS, March 20 -- Doubts that the French Government intends to bring the European Army Treaty to a vote have hardened in the last few days because of two striking facts.

THAT doughty little citizen of the art cinema world, nestling on the Fifth Avenue shore of our own Bohemia and closed these last four months for extensive alterations, will reopen its doors on Monday, April 4.

SEVERAL operas from La Scala are planned by Angel Records. "Cavalleria Rusticana" will be sung by Callas and Di Stefano, and the same two singers will be featured in a complete "Norma." Poulenc's opera, "Les Mamelles de Tiresias," will be available in a few weeks. Mattiwilda Dobbs, who caused much excitement in her New York debut a fortnight ago, will be represented on two recital disks.

FRANCONIA, N. H. March 20 -- For most of the season there has been a lack of snow in New Hampshire's White Mountains, causing the postponement and cancellation of several important events. Today, officials staging the national seniors' downhill championship on Cannon Mountain ran into the other extreme. There was too much snow.

ELROY JOHNSON, the lobster-fishing philosopher of the Bailey Island Johnsons, remarked once that it takes all kinds of people to make an island. Elisabeth Ogilvie has gathered about all these kinds into her newest novel and said approximately the same thing.

ALBANY, March 20 (AP) -- Despite the defeat of his automobile insurance bill, Governor Dewey tonight acclaimed the 1954 session of the Legislature as "the most successful in recent years, measured by solid achievements in the interest of all the people."

RICKY STERN, homeward bound to Ohio with his family, lost Hamlet, the hamster he had bought in Colorado, and thereby started a train of events that united boys from four states in a Hamster Club. Previously Ricky had rebelled at being the middle member of the family.

Running a superb race throughout, Tom Cummings of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School scored a major upset in winning the senior mile run at the twenty-seventh annual city Catholic High Schools Athletic Association track and field championships yesterday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

Women headed by Mrs. Harold H. Hackett, chairman, and Mrs. Kneeland L. Green, vice chairman, are furthering the success of the third anniversary luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service. The event, which will be held on Wednesday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre, has been arranged by members of the Spence-Chapin Corner Shop Committee.
The Rudolf Steiner School, whose unorthodox methods of teaching were greeted with raised eyebrows a quarter of a century ago, celebrated its silver anniversary yesterday.
RIPON, Wis., March 20 -- The Republican party kindled "freedom's flame" tonight before a little white schoolhouse here to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of the G. O. P.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., March 20 -- A local Methodist parish has accepted the offer of a Jewish congregation for the use of its synagogue while the Protestant church is being torn down to provide a site for a new edifice.
TRENTON, March 20 -- The New Jersey Legislature will reconvene here on Monday after a five-week winter recess.
MOSCOW, March 20 -- Soviet newspaper readers were informed today that "modern technology" permitted rockets with atomic warheads to be sent "many thousands of kilometers."
SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 (AP) -- "There's your desk. Do any darn thing you want to do."

ANOTHER sign of the times: Off-Broadway houses are currently presenting the most talented and most original musical plays of the season. "The Threepenny Opera," by Kurt Weill and Bert Brecht, is taxing the seating capacity of the miniature Theatre de Lys in Christopher Street.
Robert Goldsand gave his second piano recital of the season yesterday afternoon in Town Hall.
Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey told last night of his states latest efforts to combat juvenile delinquency. In the same speech he praised Italy's efforts in this line.

Starlings, pigeons and other birds become a nuisance in some towns. Drs. Hubert Frings and Joseph Jumber of Pennsylvania State University decided to find out what could be done about scaring them away. They describe their work in Science.

The General Reinsurance Group, consisting of the General Reinsurance Corporation and the North Star Reinsurance Corporation, have announced that premiums written amounted to $34,741,303 in 1953, against $35,066,472 in the previous year. The group's underwriting profit was $2,023,109, compared with an underwriting loss the previous year of $146,862.

No one will deny the wonders and magnificence of astronomy, one of the great sciences which endure as a monument to man's powers of reason and observation. But the annual recurrence of the vernal equinox makes one aware of hidden forces so accurate and so sensitive that the observer can scarcely escape a feeling of awe and wonder.

CUMBERLAND, Md., March 20 (UP) -- Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court proved to be an old infantry sergeant today, tricking a band of hikers to march seven miles farther along the trail than originally planned.

THE best advice that can be given to a prospective visitor to Rome is to take a room along the Via Venti Settembre. Quite a stretch of this street is taken up by the rambling facade of the Quirinal, a baroque palace, once papal, later royal, now the residence of the President of the Republic, Luigi Einaudi.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 20 (AP) -- Mickey Owen's line single down the left field line in the ninth inning drove home the only run as the Boston Red Sox chalked up a 1-to-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers before 3,166 fans today.

BEARS, bears and more bears! Here are fascinating nature tales about four pairs of cubs learning to live in the big, wild world outside their safe dens, struggling for existence against man and his gun.

POGO, a small dog who is not to be confused with Walt Kelly's possum, has in the past accompanied his inquisitive master, John, on investigations of such diverse fields as a gold mine, a farm, freight trains and airplanes.

The President has directed the National Science Foundation to survey federal research and development programs that now cost us well over two billions a year and that need coordination. His statistics and his recommendations are those to be found in the foundation's annual report of 1953.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 20 -- The California combination of Correlation and Jockey Willie Shoemaker won the $146,250 Florida Derby before a record crowd of 31,764 at Gulfstream Park today.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, or at all events what in hostility or in salute is called "McCarthyism," will figure prominently in the Congressional election campaigns this summer and autumn.
Alastair B. Martin of Glen Head, L. I., and Frank Shields of New York retained the national amateur court tennis doubles championship yesterday.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 20 -- Senator Ralph Flanders, Republican of Vermont, tonight praised Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's speech last night "indicting" the Democrats.

PARIS, March 20 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is a very unpopular man in France and gets a very bad press. The turn of events in the United States that put him on the defensive was seen here as a hopeful sign that perhaps he could be stopped.

THE first major move in the East toward lower railroad coach fares came last week when the Pennsylvania and the Baltimore and Ohio announced an experimental one-third reduction in round-trip rates between Philadelphia and Pittsburgh, and Pittsburgh and Baltimore-Washington.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 20 -- Minority votes blocked an overwhelming first-ballot re-election victory for President Chiang Kaishek here today in the Chinese National Assembly. Nevertheless he got almost 90 per cent of the validated vote and his re-election on the second ballot is regarded as virtually certain.

KANSAS CITY, March 20 -- Dust storms and unseasonable weather worked against a higher movement of retail trade and sales declines ranging from 5 to 10 per cent below a year ago were the rule throughout the area. Fashion goods lagged, and furniture and big ticket items continue slog, in demand.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -Experts who assisted the (Randall) Commission on Foreign Economic Policy believe that freer exchange of currency and nondiscrimination in trade practices abroad are within closer reach than they have been since 1945.

The Washington Post and The Times-Herald have been the "left" and "right" of Washington journalism. The Post is owned by the banker Eugene Meyer, who bought it at a bankruptcy sale in 1933 for $830,000. It supported the foreign policy and most of the social legislation of Roosevelt and Truman, but was often critical of New Deal financial policy.
The opposing forces were squaring away last week for the next extraordinary chapter in the extraordinary story of Joseph R. McCarthy.

In behalf of the Armed Forces Emergency Relief Funds of the Army, Navy and Air Force, a dinner and reception will be given on April 6 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower heads the sponsors of the benefit, which will be televised nationally from 9:30 to 10 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

HOUSTON, Tex., March 20 -- There is growing evidence that the popularity of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is waning in Texas. The Senator, until his episode with President Eisenhower and Secretary Stevens, commanded much support in this area.
WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- The United States has greatly expanded the danger area around the mid-Pacific atomic testing grounds.

WANAQUE, N. J., March 20 -- A man who was driving home at 3:45 A. M. today with a bag of hamburgers for his wife set off a destructive chain of events. It resulted in damage to two trucks, a brick building and a fire hydrant, which was dragged through the streets, the loss of thousands of gallons of water and the unceremonious dunking of a borough employe in a hole filled with cold water.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 20 (AP) -Newspapers must become more inviting in their appearance, more lively, and more interesting to the public, a printing house executive said today.

HERE is a flight of romance that soars on wings, a tale of adventure that rings like the bite of an axe into a tree trunk on a frosty morning. Its enjoyment will likely depend, to a considerable extent, on the sentimental boiling point of the individual.

THE refulgent glow which bathes this story of an English mansion reminds us irresistibly of those stirring lines of Mrs. Felicia Hemans which we used to recite as a child: The stately homes of England, How beautiful they stand! Amidst their small ancestral trees, O'er all the pleasant land.

IT was an inspired thought on the part of Edmond Cahn to have New York University Law School, where he is Professor of Law, commemorate the 150th anniversary of Marbury v. Madison with a symposium analyzing the effects of that historic decision on contemporary America. "Supreme Court and Supreme Law" is the product of that commemoration.

HERE we are again at Merry Hall, with Beverley Nichols as host. It will be remembered -- or will it? -- that B. N., much against the advice of friends, bought Merry Hall, a Georgian house not too far from London, apparently for the sole purpose of ridding the garden of atrocities left by previous owners, including the late lamented Mr. Stebbing, unlamented, be it said, by the new owner.

The North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference yesterday served formal notice on all shippers that it would reapply the dual-rate system on April 1. Under this system a contract shipper receives a 10 per cent discount on freight rates.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 20 -- Authorities here are beginning to deal with increasing requests for permission to immigrate and inquiries about investment from abroad.

LONDON, March 20 -- Conservative trade unionists were urged to oppose political "domination" of unions by the Labor party today. The Conservatives' assault on the Socialist stronghold in the union movement was gaining momentum.

WE need to know more about Communist penetration of the American Government. We need to know whether it is possible that many subversive agents are still in the government structure and what harm they can do there.

IN the spring a home owner's fancy likely turns to thoughts of completing a major project around the house. It may be turning over the lawn, digging a driveway or cutting out a patio. All most certainly are man-sized endeavors requiring a considerable output of physical energy and significant use of back muscles if done manually.

GREAT NECK, L. I., March 20 -- This rapidly growing suburban community has become recognized throughout the country for the emphasis it places upon good schools. Less than twenty-five miles from New York City, the town is utilized to a large extent as a "bedroom" of New York. The majority of residents commute to work.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 20 -- When the Phillies reported here for the first time almost a month ago, they were overstocked with pitchers and dreadfully shorthanded in infielders. The unusually imperturbable Steve O'Neill was quite concerned about the situation even though baseball men have long held to the theory that it's impossible for any manager to have too many pitchers.

Here are some ideas for details to be added (and subtracted) from men's clothing -- some practical, some impractical: All are suggested by hastily dressed males who make no claim to professional expertise, yet have to get dressed every day.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 20 -- For some time, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has been looked upon with much disfavor by most Southeasterners and recent developments, particularly his direct clash with President Eisenhower, appear to have diminished further the measure of support he commands in this area.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 20 -- High Turkish officials believe the Soviet Union is prepared to train its diplomatic guns on the proposed Turkish-Pakistani pact when the Geneva conference on Far-Eastern Affairs with the Western Big Three and Communist China opens April 26.
