In a sense these years of ungracious living, split-second schedules and low-ceilinged living-rooms full of huge, television cabinets, may be called the Age of the Bouillon Cube.

RECENTLY the Egyptian Government decreed an end to flirting in public. "Any man caught flirting with a woman in an Egyptian street," says this decree, "shall be locked up for seven days, and if he repeats the crime within a year he will be sentenced to prison for six months."
MOSCOW, March 19 -- Sovetsky visky, a new and, it may be predicted, popular drink went on sale this week.
Jeanmaire in "The Girl in Pink Tights" afforded this theatregoer a thoroughly delightful evening.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 20 -Delegates to the Tenth Inter-American Conference here agreed today that the Bogota pact on peaceful settlement of disputes was inoperative and needed revision. They disagreed as to what should be done about it.

TRENTON, March 20 -- Top Democratic party policy-makers, including Gov. Robert B. Meyner, met here today with Representative Charles R. Howell to organize his campaign for the United States Senate seat at stake this year.

HANS WERNER HENZE'S "Boulevard Solitude" is a work of imagination and beauty, and, apparently, endowed with the power to shock badly. Rarely in recent years has the introduction of any new music aroused along with the enthusiasm of its admirers such rejection in the form of frenzied fury as did this new opera when it was given for the first time on an Italian stage at Naples on March 4.

A visionary recently described the store of tomorrow as a place where the customer would stand quietly on a moving platform which would carry him past the merchandise. He also conceived a store which revolved around the customer. His audience didn't blink. Electronics has made the miracle commonplace.

MIDWESTERNERS flying to Europe from Chicago, Detroit or Minneapolis via New York City now can go through the paper work essential to departure for foreign lands at their home airports. Having checked in there, they need not go through the performance again when transferring here from their domestic plane to the one that will carry them overseas.
Spring arrived at 10:54 o'clock last night as New York's temperatures headed toward the freezing mark.

From the University of California comes the news that its $9,000,000, five-billion-volt bevatron has fired its first atom-smashing projectiles. Bevatron is short for "billion electron volts" and a sort of nickname for "proton synchrotron," meaning that the machine fires protons or hydrogen nuclei at bits of matter.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 20 -- The education subcimmittee of the Massachusetts Commission to Investigate Communists questioned today five Smith College faculty members whom an alumna had accused of being sympathetic to communism. The college administration said all five had denied the charge.

Palmer's "Spanking -- The Pros, Cons and Maybes" (March 7), may I say that I am shocked that in a city and country harboring the headquarters of the United Nations, an organization devoted to halting the use of force against the weak by the strong, there is a large number among us who advo cate such force (being themselves strong) against the weakest, most helpless of human beings -- a child.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- The Government will soon begin buying surplus potatoes to bolster prices. It will be the first such buying since 1950.

With the economic outlook uncertain and elections coming up, the issue of taxes has become an explosive one this year. At the heart of the issue is a question that is heavy with political overtones. The question is: Should primary emphasis be placed on and to business and industry, or on aid to consumers to stimulate the economy?

VANCOUVER, B. C. -- On both sides of the international line, the Pacific -- Northwest is skier's country. Heavy snowfall and high mountains provide some of the finest terrain for winter sports to be found anywhere in the world.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- A new plan for overcoming reluctance in Asia and the Middle East to invest capital in domestic development was unveiled today by a spokesman for private banking interests.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 20 -- Double triumphs by five competitors marked the Eastern intercollegiate individual swimming championships that ended tonight at Princeton University's Dillon Pool.

THE search for stories is a film perennial, but perhaps the longest, most intensive -- and anxious -- of such searches ever carried out by a British studio has just ended, though the result is not yet revealed.

Men who once did everything but sell tickets to get the rights to show albums have had a decade or so to study figures. DES MOINES, Iowa, March 20 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy appears to have suffered a serious loss of face during the last two weeks in the Missouri Basin area.

The students of Columbia University will share in the celebration of the university's 200th anniversary through a three-day conference beginning Friday.
LOS ANGELES, March 20 (AP) -- With one knee bandaged, the 13-year-old girl fell and winced, then got up to continue her graceful performance in the United States figure skating championships.

Because teachers' colleges and their laboratory schools are slow to adopt new practices, the quality of teaching in public schools is not improving as rapidly as it should, Dr. Thomas M. Barrington reports on the basis of a study he conducted under the sponsorship of the Institute of Administrative Research of Teachers College, Columbia University.
ATLANTA, March 20 -- Gov. Herman Talmadge declared today that there was no change in the plans to dismiss any state employe who failed to sign Georgia's new loyalty questionnaire by April 1.

The first day of spring at Barnard College was marked by the release yesterday of a survey on what Barnard students do during their summer vacations. The survey was conducted by members of a class in introductory statistics under the direction of Dr. Marion H. Gillim, associate professor of economics.

WITH U. S. TASK FORCE 90, Off Iwo, Sunday, March 21 (AP) -- Leathernecks of the United States Third Marine Division stormed ashore at Iwo island today in the largest amphibious maneuver since World War II.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams promised yesterday to deal "swift and stern justice" to grafting policemen involved with the policy ring uncovered in Brooklyn.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 20 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers swept to their third straight victory in the National Basketball Association play-offs tonight, beating Fort Wayne, 78 -- 73, in the western division.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 20 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer concluded two days of meetings with leading Turkish officials today after having won a promise that Turkey would exercise her influence to obtain ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty by France and Italy.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 20 -- Loans for commerce, industry, and agriculture made by member banks of the Federal Reserve in leading cities of the Far West dropped $18,000,000 in the week ended March 10, the Federal Reserve Bank reported yesterday.

MONTE CARLO, March 20 -- The strongest field of international contract bridge experts ever assembled played today the first of six scheduled sessions in the Monte Carlo international individual championship match.

In New York City last year, about one-third of the blood used in tranfusions for civilian ill and injured was provided through the Red Cross Blood Program. Approximately 105,000 pints were used for such civilian purposes in addition to 113,000 pints collected here for national defense.
ALBANY, March 20 (UP) -- Republicans in the Legislature tonight began a move to draft Governor Dewey for a fourth term. However, Mr. Dewey maintained silence on his political future.
CLEVELAND, March 20 (AP) -- Paul Bixler rejoined Coach Paul Brown today, taking a Cleveland Browns job he turned down more than eight years ago to become head football coach at Ohio State University.

CAMDEN, N. J., March 20 (AP) -- Walter H. Donovan, executive vice president of the Garden State Racing Association, said today that 575 2-year-olds remain eligible for the second running of the Garden State, world's richest horse race.

FORTUNE shone upon the little village of Sant' Antonio, clinging to its sun-soaked cliff above the Mediterranean. Since old Biagio had found the foot in a near-by vineyard, no one had thought or talked of anything else. For it must be the long-lost foot of St. Stephen, and it would bring fame to the good people of Sant' Antonio. Fame and pilgrims and trade.

BATAVIA, N. Y., March 20 -- What is said to be the world's largest television assembly plant under one roof is to start production here Monday. LOS ANGELES, March 20 (AP) -- Tenley Albright captured her third straight United States figure skating title last night with a clean sweep of the first-place votes in the women's senior division.
Senator George W. Della has been elected a director of the American Bankers Life Assurance Company of Florida. He is president of the Maryland Senate.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 20--The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development closed its permanent mission to Turkey today on the demand of the Turkish Government. Pieter Lieftinck, former Finance Minister of the Netherlands and chief of the bank's mission, will leave Ankara tomorrow.

Colder weather during the weeR caused department store sales to dip well below the same week a[ year ago. Retailers estimated that' volume was 10 to 11 per cent under 1953. TOKYO, March 20 -- Japanese frozen tuna for export to the United States will bear a Government stamp certifying the fish to be free from radioactivity.

F. raid, then hotfooted back to Sweden loaded with bombing statistics in time to make the next night's broadcast.

Plans are being advanced at frequent luncheon meetings for the April 22 performance of "By the Beautiful Sea," with Shirley Booth, for the benefit of the Woman's Hospital, Division of St. Luke's Hospital. Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell is chairman and Mrs. Clendenin J. Ryan, co-chairman of the benefit committee.

Miss Barbara Cavanagh and a committee are aiding the sale of tickets for two performances of current theatrical productions that have been taken over to raise funds for the Children's Village. The performances are those of "Ondine" April 6 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre and "The Confidential Clerk" on April 27 at the Morosco.

PROBABLY the most scientific, most scholarly and most gargantuan personality on television these days is the American Museum of Natural History, a flora-and-fauna repository splendidly stocked with Brontosaurs, Ph.D.'s and 11,000,000 other specimens.
HARRISBURG, Pa., March 20 -- A trim young smooth fox terrier, Ch. Flicker of Kidsgrove, became best in show tonight in the ninteenth and largest event of the Harrisburg Kennel Club.

CHICAGO -- The growing activity in the stereo field in this country during the past few years progressed on a wide front with the introduction of several new stereo cameras and related equipment at the five-day Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association show here last week.

NEW ORLEANS, March 20 -- Clifford Durr, a former Federal official, grabbed Paul Crouch, an ex-Communist, and shouted, "I'll kill you," after Mr. Crouch had testified today that Mr. Durr's wife had been a pawn in a Red plot.

ROME, March 20 -- Piero Piccioni, son of the Italian Foreign Minister, was accused by a witness in court today of being the "assassin" for a gang of narcotics smugglers who have been linked to the mysterious death of Wilma Montesi.

AFTER experimenting with various methods of printing, the Bureau of Engraving and Printing at Washington disclosed last week, through the Post Office Department, that production of the forthcoming 8-cent blue-and-red stamp in the Statue of Liberty design is being carried on simultaneously by two of the methods: on flatbed rectilinear four-plate presses and on rotary sheet-fed two-plate presses.

FOR THIS WEEK: Apply a grubproofing material to lawns to reduce the Japanese beetle population in summer. . . . Bring out bird baths that have been stored during winter, and repair and paint outdoor furniture. . . . Start seeds of salvia, strawflowers, scabiosa and ageratum in a coldframe, but post pone tomato sowing until six weeks before the outdoor transplanting date.

Four American Governors will leave next Sunday for Korea to observe conditions there and report to the American people upon their return. The mission, which is being undertaken at the request of President Eisenhower, will include Dan Thornton of Colorado, John Fine of Pennsylvania, Johnston Murray of Oklahome and Robert Kennon of Louisiana.

EXCEPT for the seasonal activities of a few Massachusetts and Maine fishermen, commercial tuna fishing has not been an important industry on the Atlantic coast. However, the expansion of this industry is certain if the surveys of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service develop a profitable method of taking these fish.

You will, I imagine, receive many protests from your readers on Mr. Oakes' article, and I realize that my protest cannot change the policy of the great and immensely revered New York Times. Nor do I write hoping to change your policy because our country is hopelessly divided.

SEOUL, Korea, March 20 -- President Syngman Rhee and his top advisers discussed today whether the Republic of Korea should accept an invitation to attend the Geneva conference on Far Eastern problems next month.

KNOWING the American taste for mixed drinks, wine interests in Turin developed a generation or two ago the Americano cocktail. Strangely, it caught on much more rapidly in Italy than it ever has here.
TORONTO, March 20 (UP) -- The New York Rangers dropped the Toronto Maple Leafs from second place tonight when they drove five goals past Harry Lumley for a 5-2 victory before a crowd of 12,957.

HAIFA, Israel, March 9 -- Israel came in for praise as well as censure today when Archbishop George Hakim, the highest prelate here of the Greek Catholic Church talked about the treatment his flock receives from the Government.

IT'S "Oscar" time again in Hollywood. Excitement over who will get what award will end Thursday night when the presentation ceremony by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is expected by N. B. C. to draw a television audience of 43,000,000 persons minimum.

The second annual spring festival known as "Paris in New York" will open with a cocktail party and reception next Saturday at the St. Regis Roof. The fete will continue through April 30. Mme. Jacques Balsan is chairman of the committee.
NEW DELHI, March 20 -- The Central Government has recovered $250,000,000 of hidden income up to the end of last December, it was disclosed today in the annual report of the Finance Ministry.
HANOI, March 20 -The big pitched battle now raging at Dienbienphu provides a striking demonstration of the changes that have occurred in the Indo-China war since it began.

ON the afternoon of March 13 the N. B. C. Television Opera Theatre made it possible for us to see and hear Vittorio Giannini's music-drama after Shakespeare, "The Taming of the Shrew," and this in one of the company's most brilliant productions.

Mr. Holbrook observes that "except for volume New York City sounds much like St. Johnsbury," and suggests that this lack of distinctive metropolitan personality is due to the disappearance of the trolley car.

KANSAS CITY, March 20 (AP) -- La Salle's Explorers burst the Bradley bubble tonight with a brilliant third-quarter spurt that carried them to a record-shattering 92-76 triumph and the National Collegiate basketball championship before a crowd of about 10,500.

ROME, March 20 -- The Wilma Montesi case, which has caused Foreign Minister Attilio Piccioni to offer his resignation and shaken Premier Mario Scelba's Government to its very foundations, has been hanging over Italy like a threatening cloud for almost a year.

An entirely new test for distinguishing between different types of tuberculosis germs has been developed at the National Jewish Hospital at Denver. The "catalase test," as it is called, is an aid in determining the treatment that patients should receive who become resistant to isoniazid.

AMONG the many books about New Orleans (all too many, some will say) this one occupies a special place, with its own unique mood, its warm flavoring, its tender evocation. If Donald Demarest never writes another volume -- and after this happy debut he assuredly will -- he has achieved the nearly impossible, a "different" one about Creole town, brilliantly personal, yet also a resourceful re-creation of its recent past.

LOS ANGELES, March 20 -- Perhaps the local Chamber of Commerce may not like this, but the indisputable fact is that rain today washed out the scheduled exhibition game here between the Giants and Indians.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- Political thunder is crackling angrily across the country. Subversives and the economic state of the nation are burning issues. Fights are coming up between parties and within parties.
The annual radio engineering show, described as the world's largest will open at 11 A. M. tomorrow in Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx.

STAMFORD, Conn., March 20 -The emergence of the Young Republican Club as a political factor in this city is generally considered to have been the most interesting development in Thursday's Republican primary elections.

SAN MATEO, Calif., March 20 (AP) -- Determine, a Kentucky Derby-bound star owned by A. J. Crevolin of Alhambra, Calif., won the $15,000 added San Jose Handicap at Bay Meadows today by two lengths. The time for the six furlongs on a muddy track was 1:12 4-5.

AT 13, Bradley Allen had more grit and wisdom than most girls of her age. She needed it -- this Kentucky mountain girl -- for after her mother's death her father "gave her away" to the Marston family and rode blithely off to new pastures.

Murray Edelman successfully defended his 136.5-pound title in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union senior wrestling championships at the McBurney Y. M. C. A. last night. The 40-year-old Edelman, representing the home club, won his six contests, two on Friday and four yesterday.

Dienbienphu is a broad valley in the remote northwestern part of embattled Vietnam in Indo-China. The valley, about 180 miles west of the coastal city of Hanoi, commands the normal jungle trails (roads do not exist) from Vietnam to neighboring Laos.
ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Dewey's compulsory automobile insurance bill was defeated for a second time in the Senate tonight as the Legislature ended this year's session.

BONN, Germany, March 20 -- Germans inevitably draw a parallel between "McCarthyism" and Hitlerism and there is just a little bit of "schadenfreude" in their comments on the current controversy over the Wisconsin Senator.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 20 -- India's United Nations delegate visited Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today to urge the withdrawal of United States observers in Kashmir.

FOR many years, the phonograph record industry has had standards which cover a wide variety of record features. These standards cover such details as the size of records, the size of the center hole and the shape of the recording stylus.

BOSTON, March 20 -- The Boston Celtics defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 79 to 78, today and eliminated the New Yorkers from Eastern Division play-offs of the National Bas ketball Association. A basket by Bill Sharman with seventeen seconds left gave the Celtics their second victory of the round-robin series and sent New York down to its third straight play-off defeat.
Arnica and bandage sales are slipping and callouses are replacing blisters among the white-collar workers of steamship row.

A Wilmington, N. C., constable tried to serve an eviction notice on some tenants in a three-room frame home but found no one home. A week later he returned and the house was gone.

If this were a completely rational world, the announcement that the United States and Soviet Russia had completed an exchange of proposals for the international regulation of atomic energy would be a cheerful and hopeful occasion. It might even lead us to forget the terrific experiments that have been going on in the Pacific and which are soon to be followed by even mightier manmade upheavals.
Robert D. Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, indicated last night that the nation's "New Look" foreign policy amounts to waving the big stick plus an olive branch.

MIDGET flowers and vegetables are gaining wider and wider acceptance from gardeners. Perhaps a natural revolt against over-emphasis of the super-colossal awakened this awareness of the other extreme in size.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 20 (AP) -- Flory Van Donck of Belgium carded a two-under- par 69 today to regain the lead in the 90-hole international golf tournament with a 54-hole score of 205.

Passengers on the Staten Island ferryboats yesterday started to use the temporary ferryhouse at South Ferry. when another step toward rebuilding the entire terminal was taken. At 11 P. M. Friday workers of the Gramercy Construction Corporation began retransferring the remaining turnstiles to new locations and at midnight the altered operation was functioning smoothly.

Global wind has been investigated during the past five years by a group that is directed by Prof. Victor P. Starr of Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The group includes Dr. Edward N. Lorenz and Dr. Hsiao-Ian Kuo of the M. I. T. meteorology department and Dr. Robert M. White of the Air Force Cambridge Research Center.

British comment on the statements by President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles on the circumstances in which the United States would use the atomic bomb is concerned chiefly with the question whether the United States would make this fateful decision without consulting her allies.

Two performances of the full-length "Nutcracker" today will bring to a close the New York City Ballet's ten-week season at the City Center. The Azuma Kabuki Dancers and Musicians from Tokyo will continue at the Century Theatre through Saturday evening, presenting the same program (their second) that they have been offering for the past two weeks.

A SPRING-LIKE note was offered last week by the Highway Research Board, which has been busy sampling the attitude of drivers toward trees along the sides of roads. The board reports after intensive study that trees are, by and large, a good thing.

GARWOOD, N. J., March 20 -Scores of local residents and others in near-by communities gave blood today for John Ecob, a 6 1/2-year-old sufferer from hemophilia, an incurable disease characterized by a tendency to uncontrollable bleeding.

THOSE show people who work in theatres outside New York rather than bestride Broadway like unemployed Colossi should find comfort in the career and maxims of Alan Schneider, director of "The Remarkable Mr. Pennypacker."

GOOD, solid meaty fare is how a Victor spokesman describes forthcoming releases. There will be Toscanini, in Dvorak's "New World" Symphony and a coupling of Mozart's G minor and Haydn's "Surprise." A complete "St. Matthew Passion" will be done by the Toronto Symphony under Sir Ernest MacMillan, and the Shaw Chorale will be heard in Schubert's Mass in G.

LIVELY speculation about the future of school television has been aroused by the Government's proposals to form the Independent Television Authority, which would compete commercially with the B. B. SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 20 -- The semi-annual meeting of the board of directors of the Inter-American Press Association which opened here today. registered some victories for freedom of the press in the Western Hemisphere in the last six months.

PARIS -- The twenty-five miles that separate Dijon from Beaune in eastern France present to the traveler who has time to see it a panorama of gently rolling hills covered with grape vines. This is the Cote d'Or country which produces the celebrated Burgundy wines, and Dijon and Beaune are two off its great centers.
THE Board of Education is starting, this year, a long-range program that is intended eventually to bring sound equipment in the public schools of New York City up to high-fidelity standards.
BELIZE, British Honduras, March 20 (Reuters) -- Wide emergency powers have been granted to the Governor of this British Caribbean colony.
ALBANY, March 20 -- The Legislature authorized New York City today to levy $50,000,000 a year more in real estate taxes in the next five years.

ELIZABETH, N. J., March 20 --Thomas Jefferson and St. Mary's, both from Elizabeth, captured titles in the thirty-sixth annual New Jersey State Inter-scholastic Athletic Association basketball tournament. Five crowns were distributed in afternoon and evening tests before a capacity crowd of 5,800 at the Armory.

MONTREAL, March 20 (UP) -The Montreal Canadiens outplayed the National Hockey League champion Detroit Red Wings tonight to score a 6-1 victory in their last home game of the season.
KANSAS CITY, March 20 (AP) -- The National Association of Basketball Coaches today voted to revamp the one-and-one free throw rule to put the premium on good shooting rather than inaccuracy.

Approval of the sale of the motorship Gadsden to the Sword Line, Inc., by the American Eastern Corporation has been granted by the Maritime Administration. A TASTING recently held for food writers at the St Moritz Hotel in New York put the focus on vermouth as an ingredient in fine dishes. This was a relatively new idea in cooking, and as such held interest for the guests.

Harold Callender's excellent article, "Europe's Schizophrenic View of Us" (March 7), struck me as being one of the most informative pieces you could have printed at this time. It is the kind of reporting badly needed in the American as well as the European press because it furthers understanding of other peoples and as such is at a premium right now.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Senate Republican leaders today forecast an Administration victory in the Congressional battle over increasing income-tax exemptions even if the Senate should vote against them.

The Albert Einstein College of Medicine has named William Smith, Westchester civic and communal leader, as the first Westchester founder. On Thursday evening Mr. Smith is to be honored by the Lincoln Park Jewish Center of Yonkers at a special dinner at which a plaque is to be presented to him by Dr. Samuel Belkin, president of Yeshiva University.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony gave its final young people's concert of the season yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall under the direction of Wilfred Pelletier The theme of the program was "The Story of the Opera."

The National Association for American Composers and Conductors presented three new works yesterday afternoon at its second annual orchestral concert at Town Hall. The works were performed by the Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman conducting.

With nonchalant grace, marvelous Mal Whitfield racked up a repeat "double" in the thirty-fifth annual New York Chapter, Knights of Columbus, track meet at Madison Square Garden last night. New York's final spiked-shoe carnival of the 1954 season attracted 10,000 spectators.

If the $6,000,000 slash which the House of Representatives voted last week is sustained by the Senate it will mean the elimination of a large part of the foreign student exchange program, including the Fulbright scholars. It will also be a terrible disappointment to hundreds of students of various nations who have hoped to use the exchange program to study the principles of democracy.

NOW that pussy willow buds are beginning to show silver, the Bartlett Tree Expert Company says it's time to apply dormant sprays. This is merely a spray that is applied before the buds of trees and shrubs begin to swell and open.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Governor Dewey's recent reorganization of the State Power Authority has raised hopes for an early settlement of the four-year-old dispute over development of additional hydro-electric power at Niagara Falls for the benefit of American industries, homes and farms.

CHICAGO -- A box camera designed by Raymond Loewy was one of the principal attractions at last week's trade show here. It is the $15.95 Anscoflex, a reflex camera which sets a surprisingly high standard in the field of low-cost cameras.

The charm of a wildflower garden lies in its infinite variety and the simplicity of its upkeep. The native plants listed below have been selected for their adaptability, time of bloom and amenable growing habits. But violets, for example, which will grow under almost any conditions, have been omitted. So have the beautiful but aggressive plants like tawny hawkweed and the common daisy.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (UP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, has lost the second round in his battle for authority to order wire-tapping for evidence against spies and saboteurs.

HALIFAX, N. S., March 19 (UP) -- The seagoing tug Frances towed the 7,000-ton British freighter Triland into Halifax harbor today, fourteen days ofter the British ship's fuel was exhaused battling huge seas 385 miles east of here.

WELLSVILLE, N. Y., March 20 (AP) -- James A. Farley declared tonight that "conflicting views" among many of the state's Democratic party leaders were hampering the party's outlook for a comeback in the November elections.

WHICH of the two great Christian seasons has inspired the most music, Christmas or Easter? Ask this question of almost anyone in the street and the answer is likely to be, unhesitatingly, "Christmas." Yet if Good Friday is included as part of Eastertide -- and one cannot very well not include it -- the correct answer is "Easter," by quite a large margin.

TRENTON, March 20 -- This city has embarked on an ambitious program that promises to remove the worst of its slum reas and at the same time greatly expand its downtown retail shopping center.
Four youths who beat a patrolman early Thursday and took his service revolver were held in $15,000 bail each yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on charges of felonious assault.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP) -- The Army announced today that the numerical designation and colors of four National Guard infantry divisions federalized in the Korean war -- the 28th, 31st, 37th and 43d -- will be turned back to their states in June.
ALBANY, March 20 -- The Thruway Authority has fixed June 24 as the target date for the official opening of the first section of New York's toll superhighway.
CHICAGO -- Extraordinary variety marked the offerings in accessory items at the photographic trade show held here last week by the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association.

When an official of an advertising agency mentions with pride that his is a "Four-A agency," he is not referring to a Dun Bradstreet rating. He means that his organization is a member of the American Association of Advertising Agencies founded thirty-seven years ago through the amalgamation of a number of regional agency associations.

LONDON, March 20 -- The Royal Air Force is on the threshold of a complete new look of its own. It has begun to replace its obsolescent post-war aircraft with new jet fighters and bombers as modern as any in the world. And it has started stockpiling atomic bombs.

DETROIT, March 21 (UP) -- A shot from center ice by Jim Thomson enabled Goalie Harry Lumley of Toronto to win the Vezina Trophy for the lowest number of goals allowed although his Maple Leafs were routed, 6 -- 1, tonight by the National Hockey League champion Detroit Red Wings.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- President Eisenhower is expected to name this week several trade missions to explore the possibilities of expanding international markets for surplus American farm commodities.

When Gen. Paul Ely, Chief of Staff of the French armed forces, begins his discussions in Washington this morning on the problems of the war in Indo-China he will have some ground for a more encouraging outlook than he would have had a week ago.
Disagreement over when color television should be introduced to the public has split the set-manufacturing industry.

The New York Philharmonic-Symphony, which announced on Jan. 26 that Guido Cantelli would be one of its guest conductors next season, said yesterday that the length of his engagement would be eight weeks, twice as long as his guest engagements of the last three seasons.

Varied weaves are achieved through the use of different fibers in combination with Fortisan in a new collection of sheer curtaining materials. The fabrics are available through decorators at Cheney-Greeff Co., 4 East Fifty-third Street.

The Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary had a consolidated net income in 1953 of $14,394,239, equal to $7.75 a share, compared with $15,590,497, or $8.39 a share earned the year before.
LOS ANGELES, March 21 (AP) -- A family entry and a hometown girl starred in the concluding events last night of the United States figure-skating championship.

When the explosion of a hydrogen weapon six hundred times more powerful than the bomb that flattened Hiroshima is almost unheard above the din of the McCarthy controversy, Americans are not likely to be paying much attention to the mere human explosions popping up in various parts of the earth, particularly in the Middle East.

Ivan L. Willis of Chicago, vice president of International Harvester, the other night accepted an award from the Urban League on behalf of his company for its stand "in maintaining equal employment in Southern plants without regard to race, creed or color."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 21 (Reuters) -- President Tito's Government disclosed today that it was holding 158 Christian clergymen in prison. Mainly, they are charged with pro-Nazi activity during World War II or hostile attitudes toward the regime since.

For thirty-one years lawyers, police officials, scientists and laymen have argued the pros and cons at the lie detector. They still have not reached any unanimity about its accuracy or its legal or moral merits.

NEW ORLEANS, March 21 (UP) -- Mrs. Clifford Durr, accused of having "full knowledge of a Red spy ring," today called Paul Crouch, a former Communist, a "grinning, lying dog." She said she did not blame her husband for having attacked Mr. Crouch at a Senate Internal Security subcommittee hearing yesterday.

Now that spring is here, roast pork, best suited to cold weather cookery, will be deleted from many menus. For what may be its last appearance of the season, a recipe different from standard methods is suggested.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- In the view of an American official, United States Point Four technical assistance may have prevented Iran from slipping "behind the Iron Curtain."
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The final session of the Republican Eighty-third Congress approaches the midway point in a mixed and somewhat tense relationship with President Eisenhower.

Most of the $7,654,000 of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad income 4 1/2 per cent bonds that were converted into 76,540 shares of preferred stock late in February and early this month were purchased by the Frederick C. Dumaine Jr. interests, a spokesman for an opposition group announced.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 21 -- Petitions supporting the establishment of a Roman Catholic High School on North Street, as proposed by St. Mary's Church parish, were circulated this morning at masses in the five Catholic churches here.

Nine hundred thousand dollars out of West Germany's first reparations payments to Israel will be used this year for Jewish cultural rehabilitation throughout the world. The program calls for scholarships and fellowships to victims of the Nazis and for rebuilding cultural institutions and treasures destroyed or dispersed during the Nazi regime.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., March 21 -- The Rev. Dr. Leslie D. Weatherhead delivered here this morning the first in a ninety-day series of sermons and lectures in this country by which he is seeking financial aid in the rebuilding of City Temple Church, London, destroyed by German bombs in 1941.

The revenues of Time, Inc., last year were the highest in the company's thiry - one - year history, according to the annual report by Roy E. Larsen, president, and Maurice T. Moore, chairman, issued for publication today.

The New York Shipping Association, representing 170 shipping and longshore hiring companies, holds the key to the dockers' strike. If, at its meeting today, it decides to act with vigor and assume its responsibilities it will doom the strike to an early end.
BOSTON, March 21 (UP) -- Five hundred deaf persons today "heard" a performance of "Pilate's Daughter," America's oldest passion play, through the medium of sign-language.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 21 -- Two natives of Dutch colonies challenged today the fundamental premise of the anti-colonial movement at the Tenth Inter - American Conference -- namely, that all colonies wish complete independence.
PARIS, March 21 -- A sharp controversy has developed both in the French Cabinet and among administrative officials over liberalization of trade.
Members of Local 6, International Typographical Union, A. F. L., employed by major New York daily newspapers, voted yesterday to accept a $3.75 weekly package recommended by a fact-finding committee.

WITHIN the first four months of 1954, the bicentennial of Columbia University, at least six books by Columbia professors will have been published. It might be coincidence, but it looks almost like institutional advertising. Allan Nevins' "Ford" and Gilbert Highet's "Man's Unconquerable Mind" are already out.
ALBANY, March 21 -- A show of strength by private power interests in the closing hours of the Legislature's session has revived the Panther Mountain Dam controversy.
The "most subversive" of all ideas now prevalent is the belief that right and wrong are human creations, the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken asserted yesterday.

As we near the statutory date of April 1, when Mayor Wagner will submit to the Board of Estimate his first executive budget, the Citizens Budget Commission reminds us that the entire city financial picture is not black, that there are, in fact, several "bright spots" in it.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 21 -- A Swiss banking consortium granted last week to the Italian "Medio Credito" a credit of 100,000,000 Swiss francs ($23,200,000) to help prolong the European Payments Union beyond June 30.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy proposed tonight lie detector tests for all witnesses in the Senate investigation of his dispute with the Army.
HANOI, Vietnam, March 21 -- According to French sources, the offensive potential of the Vietminh around Dienbienphu could have been smashed if the French had had more B-26 light bombers last week.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 21 -- Do you remember the advertisements which appeared in the magazines a generation ago? The eye-catcher was the line, "They laughed when he sat down at the piano!" Then, of course, the fellow, who supposedly couldn't play at all, promptly made like Paderewski with the ivories.
A prominent Washington churchman entered the lists against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy yesterday with the charge that his methods were "diametrically opposed" to divine compassion.
The violinist Erica Morini was presented in recital Saturday evening at Hunter College as the ninth event of the college's 1953 54 subscription series.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, March 21 (UP) -- Tom Corcoran, a Dartmouth College student, knifed through an icy, 50-gate slalom course on Sun Valley's Ruud Mountain in 3:12 today to win the fourteenth annual Harriman Cup combined ski championships.

Among the blessings of a French birthright is the privilege of having, in effect, two birthdays. Nearly every child in France learns to celebrate not only the anniversary of his arrival but also the fete of the saint for whom he is named.
The "Battle of the Century" took a new turn last night.
ALBANY, March 21 -- A "draft Dewey" movement was in full swing today among Republican legislators as they viewed the results of this year's legislative session.

MOSCOW, Monday, March 22 -- The Soviet Union has sent another sharp protest to Greece against her agreement granting military bases to the United States, the third such complaint that the Soviet Union has made to various powers in almost as many days.

JERUSALEM, March 21 -- The killing of eleven Israelis Wednesday in a bus has re-established in the Negev a tense gun-packing way of life. It is like the regime in the United States during the opening of the West when Indian raiders and bandits like the James brothers were a constant menace to peaceful settlers.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 21 (AP) -- Joyce Ziske, the medalist, forced into extra play after losing a three-hole advantage with eight to play, beat Barbara Romack, 1-up today on the nineteenth to join Mary Lena Faulk in the final round of the North and South women's amateur golf tournament.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $83,635,451,716. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

MINEOLA, L. I., March 21 -- The 200 Nassau County employes working nights at Roosevelt Raceway are not likely to lose their part-time jobs as a result of the harness racing legislation passed last week in Albany.

This newspaper welcomes the offer of the junior Senator from Wisconsin to investigate the press -- meaning by the press, we suppose, all means of public communication, including radio, television and the unamplified human voice. If the junior Senator isn't scared at what he proposes we are sure the press isn't.

JERUSALEM, March 21 -- The very slender chance of catching the men who killed eleven Israelis last Wednesday in the Scorpion Pass ambush seemed to be fading tonight. Meanwhile, the investigating staff of the Mixed Armistice Commission completed its work.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- To break a deadlock on the Saar the State Department is seeking to bring about another meeting between French Foreign Minister Georges Bidault and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany.

Yesterday afternoon's Twentieth Century Concert Hall program, which was broadcast over the C. B. S. network, saw Oivin Fjeldstad make his United States debut as a conductor. Mr. Fjeldstad is musical director of the Norwegian Broadcasting System.
American merchant shipping carried only 29.1 per cent of the nation's foreign trade in September, the latest month for which statistics are available.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 21 (AP) -- Gov. James F. Byrnes of South Carolina "is guilty of McCarthyism at its very worst," Walter White, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said today.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Dean Pike suggested here today that Senator McCarthy be removed as chairman of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

The Senate Committee on Government Operations was urged yesterday by the American Civil Liberties Union to drop contempt proceedings against Corliss Lamont, an author and a former member of the union's board of directors.
A Roman Catholic Bishop from Kenya, British East Africa, yesterday termed Mau Mau uprisings there more nationalistic than Communistic.

" New Faces," the revue that has been touring the country since it left New York last March, will return here for a limited engagement, to begin at the St. James Theatre on the evening of April 18 (Easter Sunday).
AUSTIN, Tex., March 21 (UP) -- A Texas legislator said he would "urge and fight for secession from the United States" as a last resort to keep Negroes from attending the state's white public schools.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) -- The Federal Government spent $34,100,000,000 from last July 1 through Dec. 31, and had authority to call on the Treasury to pay out $126,800,000,000 in the future.
After thirty years of concern over its mass transportation problems, the New York metropolitan region faces a basic decision. It must resolve the rivalry between rail and rubber.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 21 (AP) -- Dick Mayer sank an 18-foot putt on the first hole of a "sudden death" play-off today to win the $15,000 international four-ball golf tournament for himself and his partner, Tommy Bolt.

Two flights up over a savory steak-house, the Club Theatre is currently acting Jean Cocteau's "The Infernal Machine" on weekends. The address is 115 West Fifty-second Street. The schedule provides for performances on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays.

Stuart Fastofsky gave his postponed violin recital Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. With the adroit Peter Howard at the piano, the youthful artist was heard in a series of performances marked by technical skill, sensitivity and taste.

Easter is only a short time away. New bonnets and costumes will make their debut on Easter Sunday and continue in good stead throughout the spring season. For this time of year, ensembles lead in popularity. Patterns of The Times illustrate three different fashion trends for Easter costumes, consisting of jackets over dresses.

BOSTON, March 20 (UP) -- In a free-scoring finale, the Boston Bruins wound up their regular National Hockey League season by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 9 -- 5, tonight before 6,059 fans at the Boston Garden.

FRANCONIA, N. H., March 21 -- Last fall, Bob Bourdon, 37-year-old news bureau chief at Stowe's Mount Mansfield development, wrote and published a book titled "Modern Skiing." Today, he proved he knew how to put his theories to use by completing a sweep on Cannon Mountain of the national seniors' downhill, slalom and combined championships.
Four works were presented at Saturday evening's concert given by the Society for the Second Performance of American Music at the New School.
SAN JUAN, P. R., March 14 -- The blind can learn to visualize the moon, the clouds, the stars, themselves, depth, shadows. They are being taught to sketch and draw in three dimensions.

MIAMI, March 21 -- The victory-starved Yankees were no longer hungry after they finished with the Dodgers at Miami Stadium today. The world champions' losing streak was ended at seven games and the Brooks' string of eleven triumphs also was finished.

This week's most important art event is the international loan exhibition of paintings and drawings by Sargent, Whistler and Mary Cassatt. The show of works by America's three most famous expatriate painters opens at the Metropolitan Museum on Friday.

In both houses of Congress the dispute over the future of Government farm policy seems to be nearing the showdown stage. Secretary of Agriculture Benson has told the House Agricultural Committee plainly that he will ask President Eisenhower to veto any Congressional effort to extend present high rigid price supports.

Substantial salary increases for the heads of most city departments and agencies are being considered by the Board of Estimate. Some of the contemplated increases may be voted by the board at its regular meeting next Thursday and become effective April 1.
The colleges that gave shape to the American game of football in the Eighteen Seventies are now trying to save it.
WASHINGTON, March 21 (UP) -- An international food committee said today that the long-range answer to farm surpluses was increased consumption, not production slashes.
Seven new films, including importations from France and England, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

LOS ANGELES, March 21 -- Foster Castleman and Hank Thompson blasted three-run homers and led the Giants to a 9-1 victory over the Indians at Wrigley Field today. Add to the long-range hitting of the New Yorkers the fine pitching of Jim Hearn and Ruben Gomez and little wonder Leo Durocher left 'em smiling tonight.
PARIS, March 21 -- A resolution rejecting the idea of the European army was adopted here today after a two-day session of opponents of the treaty in the six countries that have signed it.
PARIS, March 21 (AP) -- The fabulous Czechoslovak distance runner, Emil Zatopek, was an easy winner today in a cross-country race that may result in his being banned from international competition.
Tragedy struck in a Brooklyn patrolman's home early yesterday. An intruder, a nephew by marriage, fell mortally wounded as he was beating the patrolman.

LOS ANGELES, March 21 -- One of the biggest contracts in the history of the National Park Service, involving potentially upward of $100,000,000 as well as the interests of millions of future visitors to the Grand Canyon, is approaching its conclusion in Washington.
KWANDAE, Korea, March 21 (UP) -- South Korea formally took over command of its first unified field army today at this east-central Korean town on the Thirty-eighth Parallel.

The Metropolitan Opera will begin its twentieth week with performances in Baltimore on Monday and Tuesday, March 29 and 30. On Wednesday evening the company will return to the Metropolitan with "Tannhaeuser," in which Blanche Thebom will sing her first Venus of the season.
District Attorney Edward S. Silver said yesterday he would begin today to present evidence about the Brooklyn policy ring to the Kings County rackets grand jury.

In his report published March 12 on the recent reforms in Tunisia your correspondent quite justly observed that the hostility shown by the Tunisians and the French colony toward the reforms expresses the fundamentally different conceptions of Tunisia's political future.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 21 -- California has officially and sharply criticized the $1,134,643,000 Upper Colorado River storage project recommended to Congress by the Secretary of the Interior, Douglas McKay.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 21 -- Reversing a marked downward trend in production, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced today that its schedule for the year would be raised from eighteen to twenty-six features. This will be two more pictures than the studio turned out in 1953.

" Freedom Against Itself," by Clarence Streit, has been scheduled for June 9 publication by Harper. In his new book, the author of "Union Now" shows why the free nations, by remaining "a house divided," are creating "the most dangerous tension of our time."
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the period March 13 through March 20:
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 21 -- Mrs. Robert B. Choate's Sealyham terrier, Ch. Robin Hill Roll Call, was named best in show tonight at the thirty-eighth Providence County Kennel Club event.

ROME, March 21 -- The charge made in a courtroom here yesterday that Piero Piccioni, son of the Italian Foreign Minister was an "assassin for a gang of narcotics smugglers was considered so excessive that all newspapers in Rome handled it with circumspection.

The Rev. Hugh McCandless, preaching at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, appealed yesterday for support of the Episcopal Church's Builders for Christ campaign. He declared that it was "infinitely more effective than military programs" in getting at communism's underlying causes.
ALBANY, March 21 -- Governor Dewey is contemplating a special session of the Legislature in May or June to consider measures for taking the Long Island Rail Road out of bankruptcy.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., March 21 -- Four persons were killed in Morris County this morning in two auto accidents.
TAMPA, Fla., March 21 (AP) -- Warren Giles, National League president, today issued a statement answering criticism of the St. Louis Cardinal owners and the team's waiver deal for Vic Raschi.
The general trend of cotton prices, especially those for the new crop, was moderately upward last week, although movement was irregular and within a relatively narrow trading range.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The decision by the Secretary of State, John Foster Dulles, in the John Paton Davies case again has been postponed.
CHICAGO, March 21 -- The wheat market has reached the point where it is extremely sensitive to weather news, and any suggestion of drought relief brings on free selling.
Mayor Wagner made an all-out effort early today to start a back-to-work movement snow-balling on the strike-snagged waterfront.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff are discussing various new contributions to the war in Indo-China.

The city will pay a ticker-tape tribute to the Forty-fifth (Thunderbird) Division of the Army on April 22, Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the Mayor's Reception Committee, announced yesterday. The division will be the first to return home as a unit from Korea.

Casper H. Citron, former regional director of the Small Defense Plants Administration, announced here yesterday he would run in the Democratic primary against Representative James G. Donovan. The contested seat in Congress is the one from which Mr. Donovan ousted Vito Marcantonio, the left wing leader, in 1950.

Import shipments of steel mill products from Belgium and Luxembourg, suppliers of one-third of this country's foreign steel requirements, have declined to about half of last year's level in recent months, shipping sources reported here yesterday.

A blockfront containing 20,400 square feet of land at 1618 to 1634 First Avenue from East Eighty - fourth to Eighty - fifth Streets has been resold after a brief ownership by the Green Hill Realty Corporation to Harry Horwitz, operator, for cash over mortgages amounting to $200,000.

LONDON, March 21 -- Last week was gilt-edge week in the stock markets here. By gilt-edge is meant Government stocks, which in their rise have come near the best levels since the general election in 1951.

Arturo Toscanini, who will be 87 years old on Thursday, conducted his penultimate concert of the season with the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The Overture to Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" and Tehaikovsky's "Pathetique" Symphony were the works he led.

Hall Overton of Michigan and Leonard Rather of California were the composers called to the attention of the New York public at Saturday night's concert of the Composers Forum at the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University.

One important ingredient has been left out of "Western Enterprise in Far Eastern Economic Development: China and Japan"* by G. C. Allen and Audrey G. Donnithorne, although it gives an otherwise excellent account of foreign merchants in the Treaty Ports -- Shanghai, Canton, Tientsin and so forth -- on the China Coast.

Fred H. Harrison, an outstanding three-letter athlete at Yale some fifteen years ago, is to be Phillips Andover Academy's new athletic director. The appointment was announced by Headmaster John M. Kemper last week. However, it will not go into effect until June, 1955.
Although they encountered sterner opposition than they expected, the Canadiens of Montreal defeated the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night.

Although your editorial policy has been very clear in condemning McCarthyism, your issue of March 12 carried a well-written letter in defense of the junior Senator from Wisconsin. As usual, the publication of that letter illustrated your fair policy of giving both sides of controversies.
The law designed to protect the consumer from wearing apparel and fabrics that are so highly flammable as to be dangerous when worn will go into efect on July 1.
Four months of preparatory work was compressed last night into a thirty-seven-minute televised preview of the day's news being put together by The New York Times.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 21 -- The closing session of the board of directors of the Inter-American Press Association adopted a resolution here today providing for a responsible system for auditing the circulation of Latin-American newspapers. This will be done by an "Office of Certified Circulation," which for the first time in hemispheric journalism will give the newspapers south of the Rio Grande a system comparable to the United States Audit Bureau of Circulation.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 21 -- Ludwig Erhard, Economic Minister for West Germany, said last week that he personally would not think of letting Germany break with the European Payments Union or proceed independently or with a small group of countries to convertibility.

The Syracuse Nationals beat the New York Knickerbockers, 103 -- 99, at Madison Square Garden yesterday in the final game of the campaign for the local quintet. The game meant nothing to the Knicks who already had been put out of the play-off on three straight defeats.

Secretary of Labor Mitchell strikes a common-sense note in his speeches and public statements when he emphasizes that industrial peace arises primarily and basically from day-today working relationships at the plant level rather than from legislation.

LONDON, March 21 -- Three young scientists recounted today a story of a new "Kon-Tiki" adventure, a 3,000-mile drift on ocean currents from Africa to the Caribbean. Unlike their predecessors, the Thor Heyerdahl party in the Pacific, who used only the Kon-Tiki, a balsa raft, these young men had a boat as well as a raft.

CAIRO, March 21 -- Britain renewed today demands on Egypt for action to end a series of armed attacks on British forces in the Canal Zone that have cost five lives in the last ten days. Four Britons and an Egyptian have been killed.

PITTSBURGH, March 21 -- The steel operating rate last week was off 1 point to 68 per cent of rated capacity. In some quarters this was believed to mean that the steel industry does not face any sharp drop in production.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 21 -- Not the least tantalizing sight to be seen these days from the windows of the aging commuter trains that ply between New York and Stamford, Conn., is a group of ten dazzling new railroad cars parked in the freight yard here.
New York will be the fourteenth state to compel motor vehicle inspection as a condition of registration.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Stronger defenses against economic decline are needed, the Committee for Economic Development suggested today.
The Philharmonic Women's Club gave its third annual concert for the benefit of the Friends of the Philharmonic late yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall.

Adlai E. Stevenson, who spent a quiet week-end in this city, went last night to New Jersey, where he will sandwich a political luncheon in Trenton today between sentimental visits to Princeton University, his alma mater.

The manufacturer and the retailer will have a good chance to get together at the three-day symposium and exhibit of the Point-of-Purchase Advertising Institute in the Statler Hotel beginning on March 30.

City Democratic leaders called last night for Federal and state aid for mentally retarded children. They made the plea at a $100-a-plate dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for the benefit of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children Inc.

TORONTO, March 21 -- An attractive little woman known affectionately as The Queen Bee to her friends in the mining industry is starting her eleventh consective term as president of the Prospectors and Developers Association.

THE Clem Youngs -- he's an advertising man who came out of Nebraska and she was a model out of Minneapolis -- have found that New York, much as they like it, isn't a good place to try to raise triplets.

Assets of state-supervised banks in the United States increased $4,400,000,000 last year, bringing their resources to a record $110,391,293,000, it was announced yesterday by Lynwood K. Elmore, president of the National Association of Supervisors of State Banks.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- A black miniature poodle here from England since the fall and bearing a great reputation in that country became best-in-show tonight at the event of the National Capital Kennel Club.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 21 -- There are increasing signs here that Communist China is gaining strength in its campaign to take over Nationalist China's seat in the United Nations. Britain, which has recognized the Peiping Government, and Canada, which has not, have given indications in the last few days that they will vote in favor of admitting its representatives.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., March 21 -- Dr. Frederick D. Patterson, former president of Tuskegee Institute, said today that the need for Negro institutions in this county would continue for some time even if courts ruled out segregation.

The Most Rev. Walter Patrick Kellenberg, who will be installed as the sixth Roman Catholic Bishop of Ogdensburg, N. Y., next Thursday, pontificated yesterday at 10 A. M. mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The spring tree-planting campaign of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association was started yesterday with a ceremony in front of the building at 907 Fifth Avenue.

Catholic Charities in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York provides a "resistance to secular thinking, materialistic philosophy and communism," Adrian Burke, Corporation Counsel of the City of New York, declared yesterday morning.
MOSCOW, March 21 -- One high planning official has lost his job and the posts of at least two more important individuals are in doubt as a result of Soviet grain deficiencies, it became known today.
MOSCOW, March 21 -- Beware of love at first sight.

The whirlwind of juvenile crime that we are reaping now is, to a great extent, due to an almost complete lack of discipline which has developed during the last twenty years in the home as well as in the schools. Progressive education, permissiveness (which word covers a multitude of sins), coddling by social workers and well-meaning but misguided "do-gooders" are some of the factors which helped to bring about the present disastrous situation.

The Soviet diplomatic notes delivered last week-end to Turkey and the Netherlands are classic examples of Moscow's interference in the affairs of other states, interference which once again belies the oft-repeated Kremlin claim of respect for others' sovereignty.
The American Tramp Shipowners Association charged yesterday that the Government had permitted an $81,000,000 investment by its members to be turned into "slave capital."
ALBANY, March 21 -- The Legislature took the following principal actions during the 1954 session, which ended last night:
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Ezra Taft Benson is getting set for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
CHICAGO, March 21 -- An engineer-inventor is working on a unique plan for transporting natural gas in barges drawn by towboats that would use vapors from their payloads for fuel.
BONN, Germany, March 20 -- In the four and a half years since the Bonn Republic was established, the Allies' control apparatus in Germany has been drastically and dramatically curtailed.

CHICAGO, March 21 (AP) -- The National Council of Presbyterian Men closed its sixth annual meeting today by sending President Eisenhower a message commending him on his leadership "in the direction of Christ."

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Senator Walter F. George of Georgia, the ranking Democrat on the Finance Committee, said tonight that he was reserving the right to vote for a cut in excise taxes on household appliances.

Finnish seamen, incensed at the "reactionary social policies" of a shipping company owned by the Soviet Union, recently called a successful strike against the line and forced Russia to give in to the workers.
WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The State Department is studying the possibility of demanding at the Geneva Far Eastern conference the release of thirty-two United States citizens jailed in Communist China.

Rates for foreign exchanges followed an irregular trend during the course of trading in the past week. British pound sterling and the Canadian dollar moved narrowly in a market that lacked the activity of the previous week.

Headed by Al Parselis, who scored eight goals, the Ramapo Polo Club rode into the semi-finals of the national 12-goal championship tournament by beating the New York Polo Club, 11 -- 9, at the Squadron A Armory yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations is planning to write on Tuesday the ground rules for its inquiry into the dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.

Stockholders of Canada Southern Oils, Ltd., will vote at a special meeting April 20 on a proposal under which assets of the present company would be divided among three successor companies. The existing corporation, which had $26,900,000 of assets Dec. 31, 1952, owns securities of oil and gas exploration and development companies in Canada, Wyoming and Colorado.
Arthur B. Bisguier defeated Edward T. Vano, and Abe Turner won from William J. Bryan in the eleventh and final round of the Manhattan Chess Club championship tournament yesterday.
HARTFORD, March 22 -- John M. Bailey, Democratic state chairman, is starting on a tour of Connecticut this week to find out whom the party wants to nominate for Governor in June.
CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- The Bendix-Westinghouse Automotive Airbrake Company of Elyria, Ohio, today accused two Chicago concerns of counterfeiting its parts.

The twenty-sixth annual Eastern states contract bridge tournament, which began last Friday, turned last night from the pair events of the week-end to the team contest for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy. A field of thirty-seven teams entered for the two qualifying rounds last night and tonight, with knockout matches scheduled during the rest of the week for the sixteen teams that qualify.
The Congress of Industrial Organizations voted yesterday to keep its no-raiding pact with the American Federation of Labor in the deep freeze until more federation unions had signed up.

Artur Rubinstein helped the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra and its conductor, Dimitri Mitropoulos, to raise $20,000 for its pension fund at Carnegie Hall last night. The redoubtable pianist played three concertos, and, if the orchestra and Mr. Mitropoulos will forgive the expression, he put on a one-man show.

TILTON, N. H., March 22 (UP) -- The real-life mother of "Cheaper By the Dozen" said today she had a new "job" cut out for her as a result of being the first woman chosen for one of the nation's highest science awards.
A device similar to that previously used only by the Civil Aeronautics Administration is now being made available for other fields by Magnecord, Inc., Chicago, maker of magnetic recorders.
A word on tax policy, centering on the objections to raising income-tax exemptions:

TRENTON, March 22 -- The New Jersey Legislature approved tonight a bill designed to permit the Port of New York Authority to resume work on the new third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel. An hour later Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed the measure.

At this time of year the harried suburbanite is faced by another of the unanswerable, seasonal questions. It is: What makes all those holes? Last autumn, when things were put in order against the winter, the entire place was smooth.

The Legislature, which adjourned Saturday, was criticized by the Liberal party yesterday as "neglectful of the general welfare of the people of the state by refusing to take advance steps for economic planning and make upward revision of unemployment benefits."

Myles Horton, who was ejected from a hearing of the Senate Internal Security subcommittee in New Orleans on Saturday, asserted yesterday that he had never been a Communist and that he had been prevented from making a statement emphasizing that he did not intend to invoke the Fifth Amendment.

The largest sports caterer in the country admitted yesterday to the State Liquor Authority that the concern had violated state law by failing to list a secret partner in its liquor and food concession at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -The Federal Bureau of Investigation has warned all police agencies that it now was possible for enemy agents to smuggle compact atomic sabotage bombs into the United States.
MELBOURNE, Australia, March 22 -- Queen Elizabeth's plans are being altered because of an epidemic of poliomyelitis in Western Australia.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 22 -- A gun fight occurred yesterday in Bahati, an African settlement of Nairobi, as a result of which 15,000 residents were confined to their houses today and 400 detained for questioning.

LOUIS XI, that strange and sinister monarch who did so much to strengthen royal power in France and transform a host of semi-independent feudal fiefs into a unified nation, is one of the least attractive rulers in history -- and one of the most interesting. He is interesting because he was clever, ruthless, intelligent, superstitious and mysterious.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -Sixty-six men, women and children who had escaped from the Soviet Union, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia landed at National Airport today from Munich, Germany, to begin new lives in the United States.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- House hearings will he opened Friday on the operations of the Military Sea Transportation Service.
ALBANY, March 22 -- A Joint Legislative Committee has been assigned to draft a constitutional amendment to ease restrictions on highway construction in the State Forest Preserve.
Claire Barlow disclosed a coloratura voice of exceptional promise at her debut last evening in Carnegie Recital Hall.

PINEHURST, N. C., March 22 (AP) -- Joyce Ziske, the medalist, never ahead until she dropped a winning 30-inch putt on the final green, upset the national champion, Mary Lena Faulk, 1 up, today to win the fifty-second North and South women's amateur golf championship.
The Institute of Radio Engineers opened its show yesterday at Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx. It was business for the electronics specialist; heaven for the gadget man.

Dollar volume of drafts paid in February by the Latin-American nations again exceeded that of new drafts drawn. Thus, the aggregate draft indebtedness of those countries to United States exporters declined last month for the tenth consecutive time, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 22 -- The United States came off an unexpected victor today in a test of strength with Guatemala when two resolutions presented by the latter country were voted down in the full economic committee at the Tenth Inter-American Conference.
TETERBORO, N. J., March 22 -- Secret Service agents told an unusual story today of a secret panel, hidden gold mixed with a deadly poison and a young chemist for whom gold no longer glitters.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Congress was asked today a question that had been bothering many farmers:

LONDON, March 22 -- The House of Commons was told today that the British Government was determined to bring about the "maximum of trade" with the Soviet Union without sacrificing security considerations.
The Fire Department abruptly rang down the curtain yesterday on the Circle-in-the-Square, one of New York's most popular off-Broadway theatres.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- A three-man division, of the Interstate Commerce Commission today permitted railroads operating in the Eastern part of the country to make a 15 per cent reduction in freight rates on a long list of manufactured iron and steel articles, effective March 26.
OTTAWA, March 22 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian National Railways had record revenues of $696,622,451 in 1953 but barely broke even with a surplus of $244,017.
Nanki-Poo will woo and win Yum-Yum for eight performances beginning tonight when "The Mikado" opens at the President Theatre.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Army disclosed today that it had ordered all officers to sign new loyalty certificates.
LOS ANGELES, March 22 -- A brilliant fashion spectacle took place today in the Embassy Room of the Ambassador Hotel under the auspices of Theta Sigma Phi.
Twenty-one of the top feature films released by United Artists since 1919 will be shown by the Museum of Modern Art Film Library in commemoration of the company's thirty-fifth anniversary.
LONDON, March 22 -- The stock markets here began the week on a dull note today and prices in nearly all sections declined slightly.

BOSTON, March 22 (AP) -- Doctors reported today "calcification (bone healing) is just starting to form" in Ted Williams' fractured left collarbone. The doctors gave the Boston Red Sox outfielder permission to leave tomorrow for his Miami home.
LAKELAND, Fla., March 22 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs reached right-hander Dick Donovan for three hits and three runs in the second inning today and defeated the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 3.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 22 -- It was lots of fun while it lasted, but apparently that new game they were trying to popularize under the name, "Swat the Yankees," was destined to be nothing more than a passing fad.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Supporters of the St. Lawrence Seaway complained bitterly today at a new delay by the House of Representatives on a hill authorizing the United States to join Canada in building the project.

MONTEVIDEO, March 22 (AP) -- Flory Van Donck of Belgium won the Uruguayan international golf championship by eight strokes today with a 90-hole total of 345, fourteen under par over two different courses.
LONDON, March 22 -- Britain, protected for centuries by twenty-one miles of channel, now finds her greatest threat 600 miles away.
OTTAWA, March 22 -- Lester B. Pearson, Secretary of State for External Affairs, outlined today the conditions under which Canada would reconsider diplomatic recognition of Communist China.
BONN, Germany, March 22 -- Allied authorities have indicated that they are prepared to grant permission to the West German soap manufacturers to organize a cartel under these three conditions:

Strange things have been happening in the world of Soviet arts and letters these past few months. Some of the men who suffered most severely in the earlier post-war Communist party crackdown on artists, composers and writers have appeared as spokesmen for greater intellectual liberty.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has arranged to borrow Swiss francs equivalent in value to $11,600,000 on a long-term bond issue to be sold March 23 in the Swiss capital market.
PHILADELPHIA, March 22 -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, said today that Senator McCarthy "Should not participate in the hearings" on his dispute with the Army.

It seems only yesterday when to raise the question of what should be done in the case of a business recession was to divide a majority of the adult population into two reciprocally hostile and irreconcilable camps. In one camp would be found those diehards who advocated a policy of "letting nature run its course."

A study of the list of deputies elected last week to the Supreme Soviet indicates that about 10 per cent of the members of the Central Committee of the Communist party of the Soviet Union elected in October, 1952, have already fallen from power.
CHARLESTON, S. C., March 22 -- After two weeks of rehearsal, the Dock Street Theatre, Inc., has canceled a production of DuBose and Dorothy Heyward's "Porgy."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 22 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold gave assurances today that there would be no discrimination against women in the hiring policy of the United Nations.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- A warnning against excessive contraction of installment credit was voiced today by J. L. Robertson, member of the Board of Governor of the Federal Reserve System. He addressed the National Installment Credit Conference sponsored by the American Bankers Association here.
ALBANY, March 22 -- A large number of Assemblymen who left the Capitol this week-end thinking they had assured motorists two license plates for their cars in 1955 are in for a disappointment.
OTTAWA, March 22 (Canadian Press) -- The Liberal and Progressive Conservative parties each retained two constituencies in today's four Federal by-elections in Ontario and Quebec.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 22 -Maj. Gen. Jean Dechaux, air commander for Tonkin, said today that he would be happy to have Allied planes help in the battle of Dienbienphu. He added that he could find targets for ten times the amount of air bombardment the French were able to mount in North Indo-China.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 22 -- Adlai E. Stevenson advised the seniors at Princeton University tonight to express their thoughts fearlessly and fight "corrupt men" and "hacks" who would pervert democracy in this country.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 22 -- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors approved a plan for settlement of the bankrupt Long Island Rail Road's back taxes and a 50 per cent reduction of its assessments for future tax payments.

Any way you look at it, that was ruthless, reckless partisanship -- politics at its worst, and damn the public interest -- that Democratic Senators displayed on compulsory automobile insurance on the final day of the legislative session at Albany. Judging from the vote in the Assembly last Tuesday, one had a right to assume that the Democratic party leadership was for compulsory insurance.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22 -- "Tip on a Dead Jockey," a short story by Irwin Shaw published three weeks ago in The New Yorker magazine, has been purchased by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

TEANECK, N. J., March 22 -- The week beginning April 1 was proclaimed in this township today as "Ten Commandments for Parents Week" by Mayor Henry Deissler. The objective is to combat juvenile delinquency by calling to the attention of parents the "Ten Commandments for Parents" being employed by the Knights of Pythias in a statewide drive against delinquency.

PARIS, March 22 -- Several ministers met with Premier Joseph Laniel this evening to discuss the French attitude toward moves to transfer the sovereignty over four French settlements in India to the Indian Government.
Mayor Wagner appealed yesterday to striking longshoremen to return at once to their jobs.

Army, Navy and Coast Guard officers inspected yesterday the mighty-thewed cargoship Pvt. Leonard C. Brostrom, a vessel that can load with its own tremendous cargo booms a locomotive or other bulky objects weighing up to 150 tons.

THE HAGUE, Netherlands, March 22 (Reuters) -- Royal Dutch airlines (K. L. M.) disclosed today that it was holding off on purchases of jet airliners until United States manufacturers had developed successful competitors to the British-made Comet.
Quality of construction rather than a quantity of new patterns characterizes most of the collections of carpeting introduced this spring.

Trading was active in many markets yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Rubber registered the best volume since Sept. 23 and potatoes and the world sugar contract had the heaviest daily sales in a month.

Four members of the Brooklyn morals squad of the Police Department testified yesterday before the Brooklyn rackets grand jury as the panel opened its investigation of the policy ring uncovered in the borough last Friday.

PARIS, March 22 -- The Paris police have developed a new weapon that they believe will give them a marked advantage in their "cold war" against the Communist sign painters who decorate this capital and its environs with Soviet propaganda.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Republicans in the Senate took a new tack today in their effort to void the 1952 Senatorial election in New Mexico.
