If we think of spring and summer menus in terms of chicken and veal, cold meats and smoked pork, fish and fruit, then we must immediately think, too, of the white wines of Germany. For these finest of all white wines, agreeable at any time, are especially good with warm-weather foods.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today rejected a suggestion that it investigate the drive by Patrick B. McGinnis and associates to obtain control of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- The Government added nineteen minerals today to the list of strategic metals it would help explorers find by granting financial aid.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 22 -- Branch Rickey's Pittsburgh Pirates made the Brooklyn Dodgers go into the ninth inning today before the National League champions could push over the winning run for a 3-2 victory.
A Puerto Rican has been chosen by Tammany as a district leader here
WASHINGTON, March 22 -The president of the American Bar Association declined today to serve as special counsel for the investigation into the fight between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army.
LONDON, March 22 (AP) -- Show business marched on the House of Commons tonight -- to try to keep United States entertainment from dominating Britain's commercial television project.

Many reservations have been made for the luncheon and fashion show in behalf of Stony Wold Sanatorium to be held tomorrow in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Social Service Auxiliary of the sanatorium. Mrs. Duncan R. Linsley heads the benefit committee.
Beginning next fall New Yorkers will see civilians, including housewives, directing children at school crossings.
LONDON, March 22 (Reuters) -- The London Gold Market reopened today as sedately as if it had been closed for only a weekend instead of since 1939.
BOSTON, March 22 -- The American Woolen Company, disclosed today a new policy of cooperation with communities facing the liquidation of eleven mills.

A battle of the beers is brewing. In recent months various brewers have been asserting in printed media and on the air that their beers had less sugar or more flavor or were less fattening. To these statements F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company has prepared a reply, to break soon in newspapers nationally, in which it retorts that "the one big difference in beers today is flavor, and flavor has no calories."

In regard to your March 18 editorial "Colonies at Caracas" this reader fails to see the logic in agreeing that Russian penetration of the Western Hemisphere, via communism, can be treated locally at Caracas and then ruling that previous penetrations by France, England and the Netherlands, by colonialism, must be treated by the United Nations.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 22 -- Diplomatic sources here called attention today to the ever- increasing commitments undertaken by President Tito's government in its Balkan agreement with Greece and Turkey.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Governments of the United States and the Philippines announced today action aimed at extending their reciprocal free trade agreement.
MANILA, Tuesday, March 23 -- President Magsaysay has asked for continued free trade with the United States for perhaps another eighteen months beyond next July 3.

The way was cleared yesterday for Gustav (Bubi) Scholz, unbeaten German middleweight, to proceed with his scheduled ten-round fight with Al Andrews, Superior, Wis., at Madison Square Garden Friday night.

NORRISTOWN, Pa., March 22 (AP) -- The will of William McLean Jr., vice president and treasurer of The Philadelphia Bulletin Company, who died on March 10, was filed for probate today. The estate was estimated at $200,000 and upwards.

Bankers, brokers, security analysts and other financial officials were ignored by Robert R. Young at lunch time yesterday. He treated 150 "proxy" clerks to a filet mignon repast in the Bankers Club. Mr. Young made it clear to his guests that he appreciates that their task in the forthcoming final round in the battle for control of the New York Central Railroad will be onerous.

LAUREL, Md., March 22 (AP) William H. Foales' Just Sidney and R. C. Hanna's Candle Wood couldn't be separated by the camera in the six-furlong Governmental Purse today, and finished in a dead-heat for first.

Russian chess players, in Buenos Aires for a series of four matches on eight boards with Argentina, outmanveuvered their opponents in the first session, winning two games, drawing three and adjourning three, according to South American news sources.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Marine Corps today ended published speculation about the reserve rank of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy by stating that he was a lieutenant colonel and had been for a year.

CHICAGO, March 22 -- A pause in the demand for red wheat and the prospect of moisture in Southwestern winter wheat states weakened the wheat futures market today. It was the last day of trading in March contracts and this contributed to disturbing influences.
KAISERSLAUTERN, Germany, March 22 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Miles Rebel, former Army chief of legislative liaison, was ordered back to Washington for temporary duty today.

Chicago's two-year reign over New York's amateur boxers was ended last night when a squad of doughty leather pushers from Gotham pounded out a 5-to-3 victory in the Golden Gloves intercity program at Madison Square Garden.
Mineapolis, Minn., announced yesterday that it would receive bids April 1 on $5,238,000 of bonds dated May 1, 1954, and due May 1 from 1955 to 1974.
The Cities Service Company, one of the largest petroleum and natural gas companies in the United States, set new operating and financial records last year.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The bill to reduce excise taxes by more than $900,000,000 will come up for Senate action Wednesday or Thursday. It was not part of the President's tax program, but the Administration is not expected to make any strong effort to reduce this slash in revenue.

H. Robert Reeve, top ranking star representing the Bayside Club, gained a berth in the final round of the national squash tennis singles championship last night by defeating Robert A. West, Princeton Club, in straight games.

GENEVA, March 22 (AP) -- The Soviet Union, Communist China and North Korea have asked that three entire hotels and extra villas be turned over to their delegations to the Asian conference starting here April 26.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (UP) -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell today announced the resignation of William L. Connolly, director of the Bureau of Labor Standards since 1947.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- A sharp decline in the number of defense plant expansion projects qualifying for Federal tax benefits was indicated in the newest listing of tax certificates issued today by the Office of Defense Mobilization.

Young women, former students at Bennett Junior College, are furthering the success of the performance of the Easter show at the Radio City Music Hall on the night of April 27 for the benefit of the building fund of the college, which is in Millbrook, N. Y. A large block of seats in the mezzanine of the theatre has been taken over to augment the fund.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 22 -- The United States served notice today that it would work for tighter United Nations control of the world-wide agencies dealing with health, education, agriculture and other specialized fields.

Though some Republican members of the Senate have done their best to help the public forget about it, the President last January submitted to Congress a comprehensive program of legislation on which he has said that the Republican party would have to stand or fall in the elections this November.
A committee of experts on poliomyelitis has commended the City Health Department for its plan to try the new Salk vaccine on school children in six health districts here starting early in May.

In The Times of March 16 there appears an editorial entitled "A Victory for E. D. C."; the last sentence of that editorial reads: "If that process (the elimination of all save three candidates on the second Seine-et-Oise ballot and the increase in the second ballot voting) could be repeated throughout France and Italy the Communists would soon be cut down to a strength which would eliminate them as a major political menace."

To men and women already in the armed services and to thousands who face induction, the Red Cross gives free survival swimming instruction, providing the skill to protect life in water emergencies arising from training accidents or combat. This course is part of the safety services conducted by your Red Cross.
American artists who found inspiration abroad are represented in a large group exhibition at the Knoedler Galleries.

THE past week-end found first channel bass of the season being taken from the surf at Buxton, a few miles north of Hatteras Inlet, which local anglers insist is a happy omen for an active season on these copper-colored fish.

As the Geneva conference approaches it is evident that new pressure is building up in various parts of the world for an effort to try to buy "peace" in the Far East at the price of Western concessions to Communist China in the shape of general recognition, membership in the United Nations and enlarged trade.

ANKARA, Turkey, March 22 -- After a week of frantic political maneuvering Turkey's two principal Opposition parties are ready to concede failure in their attempt to forge an anti-Government coalition for the crucial general election May 2.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- The Treasury Department reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had decreased to the lowest point in a month.

KANSAS CITY, March 22 (AP) -- Rockhurst College of Kansas City beat Bevo Francis and Rio Grande (Ohio) College, 56 -- 50, in a basketball game tonight. The losers' coach, Newt Oliver, called his team off the court with a little less than two minutes left in protest against the officiating.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 (UP) -- Stan Musial socked a single, triple and homer and drove in four runs today as the St. Louis Cardinals spotted the Philadelphia Phillies a three-run lead and then breezed to a 9-3 victory.

LONDON, March 22 -- In nine months of fighting in Kenya the security forces have wrested the initiative from the Mau Mau terrorists, Oliver Lyttelton, Colonial Secretary, told the House of Commons today. He was reporting on his trip to the colony where he made proposals for constitutional changes.

LONDON, March 22 -- The dispute over wages between film producing companies and their laboratory technicians widened today. If it is not settled by April 9, virtually all British motion-picture production will stop.
It is still winter in the North Atlantic, vernal equinox and the calendar notwithstanding, according to officers and 2,245 passengers of three liners that made port here yesterday.

CLEVELAND, March 22 -- A resolution demanding that all general practitioners have the right to place patients in hospitals was adopted unanimously today by the Congress of Delegates of the American Academy of General Practice.
CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was somewhat irregular yesterday. May lost 4 points, but other months were up 3 to 14 points.

LONDON, March 22 -- Britain served notice on Egypt today that resumption of the deadlocked Suez Canal talks was "not possible" so long as British soldiers were being murdered, wounded and kidnapped by Egyptians in the canal base.

The northbound voyage of the 20,000 ton passenger liner Uruguay of the Moore-McCormack Lines will terminate at Baltimore next Monday, instead of continuing to New York. Indications are that the ship is slated for an indefinite lay-up.

Orlando Zulueta, third-ranking lightweight from Cuba, won a unanimous decision over Dennis Pat Brady of the Bronx in the feature bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

Pastel springtime colors and soft feminine ruffles replace a tailored look popular in recent years in a series of model bedrooms at McCutcheon's. Arranged by Mary L. Brandt, the bedrooms combine old and new styles in imaginative settings, all fitted with ready made ensembles.

CLIO, Ala., March 22 (UP) -- Royall Reynolds, local banker, was jailed on embezzlement charges today when he failed to make good a promise to pay off depositors and his bondsmen withdrew his $7,500 bail.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 22 (AP) -- Basketball's controversial one-and-one free-throw rule was rewritten today to place a premium on good shooting and at the same time make it tougher on the offender.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 689 pints of blood on Friday and Saturday. Included in the donations were 258 pints given Friday at Fort Monmouth, N. J., on the second of a two-day collection totaling 711.
It is late spring in San Francisco. The days are warm and bright and there is excitement in just living here.

The agreement among the presidents of the Ivy group of colleges, establishing principles and policies and also an enforcement agency for the conduct and control of their athletics in conformity with the spirit of amateurism, has been welcomed by educators in all sections of the country.
Looking ahead to a dry summer, the city's water commissioner called upon the public yesterday to follow a voluntary conservation program.

There are indications that the steel business will improve as the year progresses "and as steel inventories in the hands of fabricators are reduced," according to the annual report of the Republic Steel Corporation.
JERUSALEM, March 22 -- A spokesman for the Israeli Army made the announcement tonight that the identity of some of the killers of eleven Israelis last Wednesday in a Negev bus was known.

In view of our rising unemployment -- now above three and one-half millions -- the House of Representatives' passage of a bill to reduce the "luxury" and other excise taxes is not only unwise but inopportune when we realize that an increase of personal exemptions would do a lot more to bolster our economic welfare.
Stocks opened soft yesterday, strengthened after midday, scored 107 new 1954 highs and closed soft in a flurry of selling. Aircrafts were strong all day and twelve made new highs.
DETROIT, March 22 -- For nine weeks department store sales in Detroit have been 6 to 26 per cent below the levels of the comparable weeks of 1953.

ROME, March 22 -- Premier Mario Scelba warned today that delay in the solution of the Trieste problem made Italy's ratification of the European Defense Community treaty "more difficult." He did not say, however, that his Government considered a Trieste settlement to be a condition for Italy's participation in the European army.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused the maker of AD-X2, the controversial battery additive, of "false and misleading" advertising in contending that his product could pep up tired, old storage batteries.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 22 -- The committees of the Tenth Inter-American Conference are pressing to complete the agenda by Sunday, the target date. A move to extend the meetings to the end of the month seemed tonight to have been dropped.

Net profit of the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company in 1953 amounted to $21,943,569, equal to $6.58 a share on 3,267,209 common shares, according to the report released yesterday by W. A. Roberts, president. This was $2,514,286 less than the $24,457,855 or $7.98 each on 2,955,339 common shares earned in 1952.

Negotiations for taking the Long Island Rail Road out of bankruptcy are continuing between the state-created Long Island Transit Authority and the Pennsylvania Railroad, the line's principal stockholder.

WASHINGTON, March 22 -- In 1953 the United States exported to foreign countries goods and services valued at $21,300,000,000. This included $4,300,000,000 of military supplies and services furnished under the military aid programs.

Italian futurism flourished for no more than four years, 19101914, but it was one of the most picturesque and vital episodes in the story of twentieth-century painting. And now, at the Janis Gallery, with important paintings on loan from European collections, it is, for the first time in America, given the presentation it deserves.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -- Robert Tripp Ross, former Republican Representative of Jackson Heights, Queens, assumed today the office of Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Legislative Affairs.

A new aluminum alloy makes its debut this season in necklaces, bracelets, earrings and pins. The finish of the metal has been perfected to give it the appearance and wearing qualities of gold. It is guaranteed not to corrode, chip, or wear away in a life-time. Looking massive and chunky, it is as light as a feather.

" I don't know why people should express surprise at a professor writing a best seller. It seems to me much more amazing that a physician -- Dr. Cronin (a very delightful person) -- should be a successful novelist. But no one seems surprised at that at all," said Samuel Shellabarger for a newspaper interview at the publication of his second best-seller "Prince of Foxes," in 1947.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 22 -- Back at their home training base, after an interesting visit to Las Vegas and an unprofitable one to Los Angeles, the Giants were unable to work out today as scheduled. The same rain that forced the athletes into idleness canceled tonight's fifth annual exhibition game against the Mexican All-Stars for the benefit of the Friendly House.
WASHINGTON, March 22 -The immediate dispatch of a new group of twenty-five United States B-26 bombers to IndoChina to reinforce the French Air Force was forecast by Pentagon officials today.

ALBANY, March 22 -- Superintendents of state institutions will see to it that bathtubs are filled with water before they retire at night. That is, they will if they want to be law-abiding superintendents.

ROME, March 22 -- The trial of Silvano Muto, who is charged with having spread "false and alarming rumors" in publishing accusations in connection with the death of Wilma Montesi, was suspended today. The case will be resumed after the judiciary has carried out an exhaustive investigation in the light of new evidence.

BUENOS AIRES, March 22 -- President Juan D. Peron warned labor tonight that the Government was going to maintain a hands-off policy in current nation-wide negotiations of collective-bargaining agreements.

BONN, Germany, March 22 -- A compromise on the question of Allied approval for the new rearmament clauses in the West German Constitution was reported to have been worked out today by the three Allied High Commissioners in Bonn.
CLEVELAND, March 22 -- Four disabled persons who, a few years ago, would have been doomed to a life of helplessness paraded across a stage here today.
A Fort Monmouth, N. J., radar engineer, reinstated after an Army suspension last fall, has been suspended again by the Army.
NEW DELHI, India, March 22 -- India is again undergoing civil disturbances focused on a hunger strike, the late Mohandas K. Gandhi's frequent weapon against the former British rulers.

CHICAGO, March 22 (AP) -- Bob Brady of San Francisco, the defending champion, advanced today to the quarter-finals of the United States Handball Association national singles tournament. He beat Sam Sauer of Buffalo in a third-round match, 21--3, 21--5.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Lieut. Gen. Laurence C. Craigie to be commander of Allied air forces in Southern Europe.
Forty small inland waterways operators have banded together to protest against pending Federal legislation that they charge would benefit only a small number of highly prosperous barge lines.

Sale by R. G. LeTourneau, Inc., of its earthmoving equipment business and its manufacturing plants at Peoria, Ill., and Toccoa, Ga., last year resulted in a net profit for the yeor of $11,225,260. This was disclosed by the annual report released yesterday by R. G. LeTourneau, president.
In at least one respect the seriousness of New York City's regional mass transportation problem seems to have been exaggerated.
TORONTO, March 22 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks said today the United States economy was "in excellent shape."

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 22 -- The first person pronoun has disappeared from the Dodger lexicon without a trace. Charlie Dressen took it to Oakland with him. Everything's a lot quieter at Vero Beach this year just as it will be in Flatbush during the months just ahead.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 22 (UP) -- Reigh's Double and Brandy's Last accounted for the biggest daily-double pay-off of the Florida season -- $1,527 -- at Gulfstream Park today and Mrs. J. Kelly's Very Special won the featured Golden Shores Purse before a crowd of 14,847.
TRENTON, March 22 -- The New Jersey Legislature was asked today to approve $31,000,000 in new taxes to meet the rising costs of education in this state.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 22 -- The Randall Commission report, which is expected to provide the basis of President Eisenhower's foreign economic policy, was criticized today as inadequate by a group of seventeen economics experts.
Three petitions bearing on the activities of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin were circulating in various parts of the country yesterday.
Stockholders of both Susquehanna Mills, Inc., and H. B. American Machine Company at separate meetings yesterday approved a merger of the two companies.

Home remodeling and improvement will make a record this year with a gross volume between $6,000,000,000 and $7,000,000,000, and will go well beyond if the Administration's new housing proposals are accepted by Congress, according to C. N. Nichols, managing director of the National Established Roofing, Siding and Insulating Contractors Association.

Nancy Silsbee, pianist from Buffalo, who played three seasons ago at Times Hall, gave her second recital last night at Town Hall. Her program consisted of Bach's Partita No. 6, his Chromatic Fantasy and Fugue and shorter pieces by Pachelbel, Couperin and Ravel.

Eliminating nonessential property from the tax-exempt class would open up one added source of "great revenue" for the city, Leffert Holz, a vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York and chairman of its taxation committee, suggested yesterday.

The forty-one member lines of two trans - Pacific conferences plan to set a minimum rate of $12 a ton for most goods transported from Japan to Atlantic Coast ports in this country and $9 a ton on shipments to the West Coast, it was reported yesterday.
SOMEWHERE in these United States are three unfortunate and unhappy men who probably do not know that an odd and striking book about their miserable lives has just been published.
Public offerings of new issues of corporate securities valued at more than $71,000,000 will be made today by investment banking syndicates.

It seems certain that the Tenth Inter-American Conference, now nearing its end in Caracas, will pass a resolution reaffirming hemispheric faith and hope in human rights. This is a good thing to do, and those who are cynical about the immediate practical effects of such a declaration can be ignored.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- Several Chinese physicians and scientists have been forbidden to leave this country for fear their expert knowledge might fall into Communist hands.

Agreement was reached yesterday on a new two-year contract between the Harbor Carriers of the Port of New York and the Tidewater Boatman's Union, Local 993-1 of the independent International Longshoremen's Association. The settlement involved a monthly base pay incrase of $30.

The Gulf Oil Corporation last year chalked up the highest sales and earnings in its fifty-three-year history and has budgeted about $250,000,000 for capital expenditures in 1954, according to the annual report issued for publication today.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 23 (AP) -- The beleaguered French Union defenders of Dienbienphu reported today that they had beaten back a sharp Vietminh attack on one of their battalions. They said they had killed 175 of the Communist-led rebels.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23 -- Hal Roach Jr. announced today an ambitious program of film production this year both for theatrical release and television. Most of the activity at the Roach studio in Culver City will be for the TV market, but seven features will be made for theatres. Two of the latter will be in color.
BONN, Germany, March 23 -- The United States can never bring about the economic integration of Europe without international industrial cartels, a German industrialist declared in Cologne last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23 -- The Arab states told the United Nations Security Council today that they feared Israel's walkout from the bus massacre inquiry would lead to an Israeli attack "somewhere" in the Arab world.

MADRID, March 22 -- British authorities in Gibraltar expressed deep concern today over the possibility of serious incidents during the visit of Queen Elizabeth II there May 10. They said exceptional steps were being taken to tighten the security measures.

ALTHOUGH some of the "fresh run" salmon enthusiasts look severely down their noses at those who find sport in angling for the "kelt," otherwise known as the "spring salmon or black salmon," these early season angler are increasing each year, and the season opens on some rivers in New Brunswick and Nova Scotia on April 1.
NEW DELHI, India, March 23 -- India will buy industrial equipment and machinery from Rumania, according to an agreement signed today.

New Yorkers cannot expect relief from "nuisance taxes" or high real estate taxes so long as a "politically minded Governor and Legislature" continue "double taxation" of the city, Mayor Wagner declared yesterday.
An ultimate "cure for the real estate cancer -- the blighted area" was predicted here yesterday by Guy T. O. Hollyday, Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration.
The University of Kentucky, after serving a season's penance as the result of basketball scandals, yesterday reclaimed its position as the nation's No. 1 college quintet.
MADISON, Wis., March 23 -- The man who started a recall movement against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is going to continue it despite widespread doubts that it is constituionally possible.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Vic Raschi, former Yankee star, hurled six scoreless innings, his best performance of the spring exhibition series, to start the St. Louis Cardinals toward a 6-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves today.
" The Girl Most Likely," a new comedy by Irving Brecher and Jo Swerling, has been scheduled for presentation here early this fall by Albert Lewis.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Republicans in Congress will be called on to toe the mark of party regularity by the White House when President Eisenhower submits his foreign trade recommendations next week.

Reports indicate that Canadian business may not have been doing so well lately. But it is spending more money than ever. The Bank of Montreal in its March Business Review reports that expenditures for new construction and equipment so far this year come to $5,383,000,000.

Lubomir Vichegonov, Bulgarian bass who joined the Metropolitan Opera in the 1948-49 season, assumed his sixteenth role there last night. Since it was that of Pimen, the monk-historian in "Boris Godunov," it was like the majority of Mr. Vichegonov's roles here -- that is, important but not stellar.
The three-article series on transit problems by Leonard Ingalls, concluded in The Times this morning, began with this paragraph:
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- How business in various lines continued to ease in the opening months of this year was described by the Department of Commerce today.
The Fira Benenson couture collection, which was shown yesterday at Lord Taylor, was elegant, ageless and understated.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Following is the 53-to-36 roll-call vote by which the Senate today rejected a resolution to declare vacant the seat of Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat of New Mexico:

ST. AGUSTINE, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Tom Robbins, defending champion from Larchmont, N. Y., and yesterday's medalist with a two-under-par 70, defeated Col. C. D. McAllister of Orlando, Fla., 2 and 1, in the first round today of the American Seniors Golf Association tournament, an event for players 50 years old and over.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP) -- The applications of six Negro youths for admission to Girard College -- an institution for orphaned boys -- were rejected today and a city councilman said he would press for a court appeal.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Federal Civil Defense Administration today announced the first continental test, to be held on June 14 and 15.

Of two men accused of cruelty in the pursuit and recapture of an escaped steer, one was exonerated yesterday and the other was paroled for trial in the Court of Special Sessions. This action was taken by Magistrate Milton Solomon after a preliminary hearing in Lower Manhattan Court, Second Avenue and Second Street.

To judge by "The Mikado," which was sung at the President last evening, the spring season of Gilbert and Sullivan is going to be a pleasant one. Dorothy Raedler, the lady Pooh-Bah of the occasion, demonstrated her talent for staging the operas when she conducted the rites of Savoy at the Jan Hus House a few years ago.
THE HAGUE, Netherlands, March 23 -- Production of tin concentrates declined in all important producing areas during January, the International Tin Study Group reported today.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 23 -- George F. Kennan, former director of the State Department's policy planning staff, said tonight that the nation had been operating since World War II in "a form of schizophrenia."
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- There are days in Washington when the trouble seems to be caused not by the evil but the amiable qualities of the human heart. This was such a day.

SEVEN years ago Miss Lola Kovener, a soft-voiced, red-haired lady, wandered through lower New York on quiet week-ends in search of old buildings. She wanted to write them into her novel about the city in the early nineteenth century.

Two personal accounts of life in India will be issued soon. Next Wednesday Harper will publish Santha Rama Rau's new book, "This Is India." Miss Rama Rau, daughter of Benegal Rama Rau, Governor of the Reserve Bank of India, describes the places she has enjoyed in her native country and the things she holds most significant.
This is the second of three articles on the Flammable Fabrics Act.

MONTREAL, March 23 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens opened the defense of their Stanley Cup championship tonight with a 2-0 victory over the Boston Bruins. The Canadiens lead the best-of-seven cup semi-finals series, 1 -- 0.
ALBANY, March 23 -- The New York National Guard has ordered a special investigation into the service record of Roy M. Cohn, counsel to the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
BALTIMORE, March 23 -- This city's waterfront was nearing a strain on its port facilities today, as a result of the dockers' wildcat strike in New York.

The question in Indo-China is not whether the French will be able to hang on to their strong point at Dienbienphu. It is not even whether, with increased aid from the United States, they can eventually win that costly and exhausting war. The French Chief of Staff, General Ely, has been discussing the military aspects of the situation in extremely candid talks with the President, Admiral Radford and other top officials in Washington.
PARIS, March 23 -- The French Government and leaders of Vietnam appear to be deadlocked in negotiations over Vietnamese independence.

KARACHI, Pakistan, March 23 -- Three men, including a dismissed major general of the Pakistani Army, have been arrested on a charge of conspiracy to assassinate King Faisal II of Iraq. They were said to have been hired by a foreign government opposed to Iraq's entering a defensive military alliance with Turkey, Pakistan and the United States.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Ted Kroll of New Hartford, N. Y., missed the competitive course record by one stroke today as he fired a 35, 30 -- 65 to take the first-round lead in the two-day, $10,000 pro-amateur tournament at the Seminole Golf Club.

BUFFALO, N.Y., March 23 (AP) -- The Bell Aircraft Corporation today announced 1953 net earnings of $3,465,423, equal to $3.92 a share of common stock, compared with $3,043,441, or $3.46 a share in 1952.
BERKELEY, Calif., March 23 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren cautioned today against letting the country "run short of intellectual ammunition" by short-changing higher education.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 23 -- Preacher Roe is a whimsical philosopher from Ash Flat in Arkansas. He speaks with a drawl and with a twinkle in his eye. The Preach has become an elder statesman of sorts now that he's passed his thirty-sixth birthday. The young kids in camp listen with fascination when he speaks although they never are too sure whether it's safe to believe everything he says.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today there were no plans to send a United States diplomatic representative to the Vatican.
BIRMINGHAM, March 23 (AP) -- The Birmingham City Commission today amended city segregation laws to permit mixed competition by Negroes and whites only in professional baseball and football games.

TUCKAHOE, N. Y., March 23 -- The Tuckahoe Police Associates Athletic Club, forerunner of the Police Athletic Leagues for children throughout the nation, suspended activity tonight because of "political interference."
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today he had called for "clarifying" hearings on the security case of John Paton Davies Jr.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Senate rejected today by a roll-call vote of 53 to 36 a Republican effort to oust Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat of New Mexico.

In regard to your editorial comments anent "Red China and the U. N.," and your reference to Sir Gladwyn Jebb's and Secretary General Hammarskjold's views on the matter of the admission of Communist China to the United Nations organization, may I say I think they are only facing facts in their approach.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 23 -- A trend toward South European cooperation that may eventually bring Italy into the tripartite Balkan pact has been observed here by optimistic diplomats.

LONDON, March 23 -- A British engineering company announced today it had signed a contract with Soviet authorities to supply 1,000,000 ($2,800,000) worth of milk bottling machinery to the Soviet Union.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, March 28 -- The Israeli Government declared today that the outcome of the case of the attack on the bus had "created a situation of utter gravity."

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- John H. Miles' John B. P., a 3-year-old colt that had failed to win in nine previous starts, took the $3,200 Saxony Purse at Gulfstream Park today. Timed in 1:43 2/5 for the mile and seventy yards over a fast track, the offspring of Alquest and Broken Bough paid $20.20 for $2.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 23 (AP) -- Seeded players ran up against gallent tries by three young collegians today before winning their way into the third round of the sixth annual Good Neighbor tennis championship.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Representatives of the American shipping industry will appear before the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee tomorrow in support of a small-ship sales bill favoring Brazil.

Heavy lines indicate sections of the city's rapid transit system scheduled for improvement in the Transit Authority's $658,000,000 construction program. Also indicated by a heavy line is the route of the proposed Second Avenue trunk line -- still an expensive uncertainty in future transit plans.
ATLANTA, March 23 -- Gov. Herman Talmadge issued executive orders today removing almost all major objections that had been voiced against Georgia's new loyalty questionnaire.

SEOUL, Korea, March 23 -- President Syngman Rhee said today that his Government had not decided whether to accept or reject an invitation to attend the conference at Geneva next month on Far Eastern problems.

I offer this comment on your editorial "A Notable Victory," concerning passage by the House of Representatives of the Administration's tax bill. To paraphrase the injunction quoted therein, it seems to me that you both underestimate the intelligence of the American people and their knowledge of the facts on this issue.
One of the nation's top retailers asserted yesterday that sharp declines in the economy can be averted.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- Eddie LeBaron, the Washington Redskins' tiny quarterback, jumped to the Canadian football League today in a climax to a long-simmering feud with Coach Cury Lambeau.

A midnight meal of scrambled eggs and toast turned out on a hotel hotplate is more often the rule in backstage life of show business than lobster and champagne. Recently a member of this department viewed the Japanese equivalent of the theatrical supper when she visited the Kabuki dancers in their Windermere Hotel rooms after midnight.
CLEVELAND, March 23 -- Rest in bed for long periods still is a necessary part of any treatment for tuberculosis, the American Academy of General Practice heard today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 23 -- The Economic Committee of the Tenth Inter-American Conference, after three hours of wrangling, approved tonight a hybrid resolution endorsing land reform where it is considered necessary.

Graphic work by Braque, at Galerie Chalette, ranges from etchings of the cubist period to color prints of the last three years, some of which reveal innovations in technique, particularly in a net-like or web-like textural effect.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., warned the Transit Authority in a telegram yesterday that operating changes on the system were causing a drop in the morale of authority employes.

Plans are beinf formulated for the Kips Bay dinner dance April 22 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club. Mrs. A. Schuyler Clark is chairman of the executive committee for the event, Mrs. Kelley Keresey is co-chairman, and among their aides is Mrs. Edmund C. Lynch.
IWO ISLAND, March 23 (AP) -- The United States Third Marine Division concluded today the major part of an amphibious maneuver covering atomic warfare problems.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The Republican leadership of the House of Representatives lined up today behind a move to bring the Administration's housing bill to the floor for debate and a vote next week.
New York's County Fair, billed as "a full day of county fair fun in the heart of the city," will be held next Tuesday at the 101st Division Armory, park Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street.
Work on both sides of the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel will resume at 8 o'clock this morning after an eight-day interruption.

Pan American World Airways will begin on May 1 to sell round-the-world trips and other flights on the installment plan. The airline's passengers in all parts of the United States will be able to make down payments of 10 per cent for flights to Europe, South America, Africa or the Far East and complete the payments in monthly installments.

The twenty-one man opposition slate headed by Patrick B. McGinnis, Wall Street stock broker, which is seeking to obtain control of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, owned more than 15 per cent of the road's voting stock as of March 1, according to the group's proxy statement.

LONDON, March 23 -- The securities markets here remained undecided today under the influence of the approaching budget and of the labor situation. Slight selling upset some prices although the undertone was still described as satisfactory.
PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (AP) -- C. A. (Tim) Temerario, professional and college football line coach, was appointed today to that position at the University of Pennsylvania.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., March 23 (UP) -- Spur Baby, one of the top prospects for Saturday's Arkansas Derby at Hot Springs, had no trouble proving his eligibility today. He won the featured Jonesboro Purse by four lengths at Oaklawn.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Republican Senators were urged at a strategy meeting today to stand fast against further changes in a House-approved bill for sharp reductions in "luxury" taxes and other excises.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Further drought warnings were posted on Capitol Hill today.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The United States offered France today whatever additional assistance she required in the Indo-China fighting. It made clear, however, that an "aggressive" training program for the Vietnamese forces was expected in return.

CAIRO, March 23 -- The Egyptian President, Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, expressed today a lack of concern over the British Government view that resumption of negotiations for settlement of the Suez Canal zone dispute was impossible under present conditions.

A radio news program in which a personality or issue in the news will be reported on at length will be presented over the N. B. C. network on Mondays through Fridays from 10:15 to 10:30 P. M., beginning next week. Entitled "The Heart of the News," the program will present both sides of any controversy, but will not draw editorial conclusions, the network said.
ROME, March 23 -- Several hundred university and high school students staged noisy demonstrations on the Trieste issue in Rome's center this morning.
All films to be made by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Paramount will be equipped with Perspecta stereophonic sound tracks.
The date for appearance of stock car taxicabs on the city's streets was postponed yesterday from April 1 to July 1 by the City Council.

The words and music of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d virtually will blanket the television channels on Sunday evening through the largest hook-up of TV stations -- including all four major networks -- ever assembled for a commercial program.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission agreed today to study a proposal that the New York Central Railroad stockholders have the right to secret balloting in future meetings of the company.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- The controversial list of 2,486 who had been separated from Government employment since last May as "security risks" includes names of dead persons.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and active months declined 11 to 26 points.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 23 (AP) -- Britain was embarked on an anti-Communist drive in a third Caribbean colony today after seizing documents in raids on two left-wing centers in this West Indies island capital.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 23 -- Hendrik Verwoerd, Minster of Native Affairs, bitterly attacked conditions in the Johannesburg Negro slums today in introducing in Parliament his first slum clearance measure. The new legislation empowers him to move Negro slum dwellers by force.
MONTE CARLO, March 23 -- Jan Wohlin of Sweden came from behind this afternoon to take a lead over a field of international contract bridge stars in the Monte Carlo individual championship.

The Red Cross Gray Lady in a military, veterans or civilian hospital is a comforting sight to a restless, helpless patient. She does a thousand and one things -- the sort of things that you would do if you could.

Usually nothing but a consummate work of art is able to leap across five centuries to touch intimately and immediately the heart and brain of a living man. Only a piece of art fashioned through the most sophisticated artifice can create that kind of universal experience which nature left-handedly is making and unmaking all the time.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused Sunshine Biscuits, Inc., Long Island City, Queens, N. Y., of price discrimination in violation of Federal fair business practice laws.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- The armed forces today informed the National Petroleum Council they will need 83,000,000 barrels of jet fuel for aircraft in the year beginning July 1, an increase of 83 per cent over this year.

It is an interesting phenomenon of post-war European history that some of the best pages have been written by elder statesmen. President Luigi Einaudi of Italy, who is 80 years old today, fully deserves a place in the Hall of Fame that includes such names as Churchill and Adenauer, to pick a few living men.

Yesterday was assembly and get-acquainted-day for most of the twenty-four young giants, measuring all the way up to a lofty 6 feet 11 inches, who arrived in New York to start practice for the eighth annual East-West College All-Star basketball game in Madison Square Garden Saturday.
Sales in lower Manhattan featured realty transactions reported yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 23 -- Leo Durocher had his regular line-up listed to oppose the Cubs today. Suddenly, the Giants' manager remembered that he had not seen much of the young hopefuls in his camp and, less than an hour before game-time, he scratched the varsity and posted eight other names.
An exhibition of Spanish-Mediterranean eighteenth-century folk art at the Kolean Gallery is composed entirely of charmingly naive religious paintings on glass.

The appointment of Fredric R. Mann as chairman of the executive and finance committees of the National Container Corporation was announced yesterday in a proxy statement sent to stockholders. The proxy statement was sent in conjunction with the call for the annual meeting on April 15 in Jacksonville, Fla.

EVANSTON, Ill., March 23 -- The Chinese Nationalist Government on Formosa was accused today by Dr. K. C. Wu, former Governor of the Nationalist island refuge, of attempting to confuse world opinion on the state of democracy under President Chiang Kai-shek.

LONDON, March 23 -- An attempt by the Bevanite faction in the Labor party to deter the French Socialists from supporting the European Defense Community Treaty has exposed anew glaring differences within British Socialism over German rearmament.
The gigantic task of transporting the 6,000,000 riders every weekday on the New York City transit system poses the toughest of all transit problems in the metropolitan area.

Today's new film is "Guilt Is My Shadow," a British melodrama featuring Patrick Holt, Elizabeth Sellars, Lana Morris and Peter Reynolds, at the Beekman, Gramercy and Eighth Street Playhouse. Ivan Foxwell produced the import for Associated British Picture Corporation and wrote the screen play with Roy Kellino, who also directed, based on a novel by Peter Curtis. Stratford Pictures is distributing.

Aircraft stocks yesterday added sharp new gains on top of their recent advances, then broke with even greater abruptness. The momentum of their decline was sufficient to drag down the rest of the market for the widest losses of 1954.

Blood donors gave 615 pints on Monday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program. Included were 139 pints given at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens, and 122 at Wyoming Temple, 2626 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, by the Thirteenth District, International Order of Odd Fellows.

Ernest Hemingway will receive in May the Award of Merit medal of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and a $1,000 prize for his contributions as a novelist. The academy's choice was made known yesterday by Archibald MacLeish, president of the academy.

The coming of spring has not escaped mention in this corner, but nobody has noticed that on the day before the one appointed by the Almanac as the first of the season so often celebrated by the poets Central Park's miniature Rocky Mountains put on a very special show.
ROME, March 23 -- Premier Mario Scelba's six-week-old Government won important victories tonight in its first secret ballots in the Chamber of Deputies.
Los Angeles County, Calif., borrowed $40,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance flood control installations.
CHICAGO, March 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, March 23 -- Sir Winston Churchill has made "smooth and friendly" arrangements for consultation with President Eisenhower and the United States Government on the use of atomic bombs in any war involving the United States and Britain.
MEXICO CITY, March 23 -- West Germany displayed its resurgent industrial might today in an exhibition of $25,000,000 worth of manufactures and machinery.
KANSAS CITY, March 23 -- A sleek new British pamphlet that anyone can buy for five shillings -- about 70 cents -- is being studied by leading American scientists with avid interest.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., March 23 -- Although net earnings declined, the Sprague Electric Company's net sales reached record figures last year for the fourth consecutive year and the outlook is considered good in both the military and civilian fields this year.

DETROIT, March 23 (UP) -- Marty Pavelich, who scored only nine goals during the regular season, fired home two unassisted tallies tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings to a 5-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the opener of their best-of-seven game Stanley Cup play-off semi-finals series.

Coffee and cocoa prices resumed their climb yesterday on the New York exchanges. The markets generally closed irregularly lower, with cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides, rubber, silk, zinc, tin and lead off; sugar, potatoes, burlap, wool and copper mixed, and cocoa and coffee higher.
CHICAGO, March 23 -- The grain futures markets here were weak today.
For a quarter of a century "big-time" football has been the problem child of educators in American colleges and universities of high academic rating.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- A seasonal upturn in sales of consumer goods and financing volume now can be expected, Arthur O. Dietz, president of C. I. T. Financial Corporation of New York, said today. He addressed the American Bankers Association's National Installment Credit Conference.
Through a gift of $500,000, Yeshiva University will establish the first college for women under Jewish auspices.

During the last few years thousands of families living in lower Manhattan have been forced to move out of their low-priced apartments to make room for new projects not available to most of them because of high rents. Simultaneously, a number of large but outmoded hotels have been razed and replaced with other high-priced hotel apartments or office buildings.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 23 -- Back from their East Coast trip during part of which they scarcely covered themselves with glory, the Yankee players today discovered fresh evidence that their mentor, Casey Stengel, wasn't fooling when he said he meant to win that sixth straight pennant "or else."

TRENTON, March 23 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared here today that a complete revision of New Jersey's tax policies appeared inevitable if the state was to balance its budget during the next few years.

Color selection by the consumer, for the most part, is not governed by scientific rules or sociological events, but by purely personal preferences, five of a panel of six color experts agreed yesterday.

A COMEDIENNE who somehow seems to have been overlooked this season is Betty White. It is a slight that should be corrected because she is an immensely personable young lady with a very real talent in a number of directions, and a high quotient of charm.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson testified today before a Senate Appropriations subcommittee, but he did not get to say much about figures.

New York City is the electronics capital of the world this week as thousands of specialists in this field attend the sessions of the Institute of Radio Engineers. A layman who listens to the conversation in the halls at the Waldorf-Astoria and other meeting places will hear references to such exotic subjects as Fourier transforms, transistors, microwaves, the theory of random noise, and the like.
A threat that the city might move to seize the racetracks within its boundaries was made yesterday in the City Council.
I am writing to you from London. I am the Mayor of Hackney, one of the largest boroughs, with a population of over 170,000.

The National Republican Club adopted last evening a resolution declaring that the essential elements of American fair play and impartial procedure required that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy disqualify himself as a member of the subcommittee investigating the dispute between him and the Army.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- President Eisenhower entertained at another White House stag dinner tonight, with the accent on sports.

JERUSALEM, Jordanian Sector, March 23 -- Israel announced tonight that she would boycott the Jordanian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission. She failed earlier today in an attempt to have the commission condemn Jordan for an attack by an unidentified band last Wednesday on an Israeli bus at Scorpion Pass in which eleven persons were killed.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, March 24 -- Mao Tse-tung presided yesterday over a meeting of the committee that is drafting a new constitution for Communist China, the Peiping radio said this morning. His reported reappearance on the public scene followed a prolonged absence that was accompanied by considerable speculation about his health.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23 -- New Zealand told the United Nations today that Egypt's restrictions on Suez Canal traffic violated international law and concerned every maritime power.

PEARL HARBOR, March 23 (AP) -- The Navy said tonight that the tanker Patapsco had received "light and not dangerous contamination by radioactive fallout" during the recent hydrogen test at Bikini atoll.
Directors of the Industrial Brownhoist Corporation yesterday elected Louis T. M. Ralston as president and member of the executive committee to succeed Hoyt E. Hayes, who resigned "under protest."
From the welter of street signs that assail the eye in New York, the Museum of Modern Art has selected as a typical example of the prevailing chaos a lamp post near its doors.
The Departments of Health, Hospitals and Welfare have joined forces to discover and treat tuberculosis among the hundreds of homeless men who drift about the city.

CHICAGO, March 23 -- Hulburd, Warren Chandler, Chicago securities and grain dealer, will merge about May 1 with Fahnestock Co., New York investment banking firm, it was learned today. The firm will continue under the Fahnestock name.

New York's courts are seriously handicapped in their efforts to combat juvenile delinquency because they lack adequate psychiatric and probationary services, three members of the city's judiciary said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy fought back alone today against mounting bipartisan pressure to remove him entirely from the Senate subcommittee investigating his dispute with the Army.

The duo-pianists Arthur Gold and Robert Fizdale presented two new works by Francis Poulenc and Paul Bowles at their Town Hall recital last evening. Both works were written for Gold and Fizdale and were having first performances here.
SEATTLE, March 23 (AP) -- A pair of University of Washington students gained the lead in the doubles today as the American Bowling Congress tournament moved into its fourth day.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) -- Counsel for Mrs. Anne Lee Moss said today that the Pentagon had not yet answered a request either to reinstate the suspended Army Signal Corps employe or to give her an early loyalty hearing.

As part of efforts to assist New York exporters in the port shipping tie-up, all import licenses due to expire March 31 on United States shipments will be extended by Chile for thirty days. The Commerce and Industry Association of New York announced the Chilean decision yesterday; it was a result of its request for cooperation.

Displacement of dining room by the dining area of the living room and the on-a-tray meal eaten in silence before the television set are bringing about a whole new concept of merchandising based on the snack.

Recently President Eisenhower at a press conference stated that there would be "no involvement of America in war unless it is a result of the constitutional process that is placed upon Congress to declare it." This language is an authorized and direct quotation.

BONN, West Germany, March 23 -- The West German Government, banking on its continued favorable balance of payments and its accumulated reserves, has taken the penultimate step toward free convertibility of the Deutsche mark into foreign currencies.
LOS ANGELES, March 23 (AP) -- Dick Haymes today was ordered deported to his native Argentina on a charge of illegally re-entering the United States after visiting Rita Hayworth in Hawaii last June.

BOSTON, March 23 -- An irate stockholder of the American Woolen Company, armed with proxies for more than 60,000 shares, prevented the company from doing any official business at its annual meeting here today.
WASHINGTON, March 23 -- President Eisenhower nominated Arthur Larson, dean of the University of Pittsburgh Law School, today to be Under Secretary of Labor.
MOSCOW, March 23 -- A sharp satire directed against xenophobia is published in the latest issue of the Writers Union magazine Znamya.

Thirty-seven contract bridge teams entered the second of two qualifying rounds in play for the Curt H. Reisinger trophy yesterday in the Eastern States tournament at the McAlpin Hotel. Sixteen teams were to qualify for the final rounds beginning tonight.
Walter P. Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, yesterday expressed opposition to a shorter work week as the way to ease national unemployment.

MONTREAL, March 23 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, National Hockey League champions for the sixth straight year, placed four men in the first seven top scorers, according to the final statistics released today.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (UP) -- The nation's 4,864 national banks had assets of more than $110,000,000,000 and deposits of almost $101,000,000,000 on Dec. 31, Controller of the Currency Ray M. Gidney announced today.

While Gustav Scholz, unbeaten German middleweight, and Al Andrews, Superior, Wis., continued work yesterday for their ten-round fight Friday night at Madison Square Garden, George Gainford, former manager of Sugar Ray Robinson, was attempting to stop the bout in connection with a civil suit against Scholz.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 23 -- Dr. G. J. Van Heuven Goedhart, High Commissioner for Refugees, advocated today a five-year plan for a permanent settlement of the refugee problem at a total cost of $40,000,000.

TOKYO, March 23 -- The Japanese Cabinet today tentatively turned down a Socialist proposal for a full investigation of the nuclear explosion near Bikini March 1 and the injury to twenty-three Japanese fishermen that resulted.

The board of United Medical Service, New York's Blue Shield Plan, has elected as its chairman Dr. Louis H. Bauer, past president of the American Medical Association. The election took place yesterday at the annual meeting of the board at 2 Park Avenue.
Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company is preparing a $50,000,000 financing program, according to a proxy statement sent to stockholders yesterday.
Renewed violence failed to check yesterday a scattered but steady return to work by longshoremen in the strife-swept Port of New York.
ALBANY, March 23 -- Bills providing an emergency increase of $25,000,000 in state aid for education and creating a special commission to study school finance were approved today by Governor Dewey.

George P. Monaghan, state harness racing commissioner, said yesterday he would issue "conditional licenses" to the three metropolitan trotting associations within two days. The announcement followed a meeting at Monaghan's office, 135 Broadway.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 23 -- Victor Raul Haya de la Torre, Peruvian radical leader, who has been living under protection of the Colombian Embassy in Lima for the last five years, will be allowed to leave Peru under safe conduct.
Technical progress made recently in American laboratories and colleges was described and demonstrated yesterday at the national convention here of the Institute of Radio Engineers.

Sister Marie Marquette, a Maryknoll sister and director of a small hospital in a Bolivian jungle, calmly explained yesterday how her order had adapted its medical skills to meet such peculiar jungle complaints as, say, an alligator bite.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 23 -- The woman who devotes her time exclusively to homemaking is no more her own boss than her job-holding sister.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23 -- Carl Erskine became the first Dodger pitcher to go the route today as the Brooks unloosed a fourteen-hit attack for a 10-2 victory over the Athletics at Connie Mack Field.

NEW DELHI, India, March 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru lectured the United States again today on its collective-security arrangements, which, he said, have created "insecurity, uncertainty and instability" in Asia.
A merger between Northeast Airlines, Inc., and another airline still is a "live" possibility, according to George Gardner, president.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23 -- Carl Erskine became the first Dodger pitcher to go the route today as the Brooks unloosed a fourteen-hit attack for a 10-2 victory over the Athletics at Connie Mack Field.

NEW DELHI, India, March 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru lectured the United States again today on its collective-security arrangements, which, he said, have created "insecurity, uncertainty and instability" in Asia.
A merger between Northeast Airlines, Inc., and another airline still is a "live" possibility, according to George Gardner, president.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Eisenhower said today that he thought the House of Representatives had been doing an awfully good job.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The controversial question of transferring surplus United States shipping tonnage to foreign flags was aired in two Congressional committee hearings today.
ALBANY, March 24 -- Governor Dewey coupled high praise for this year's session of the Republican-controlled Legislature with an attack on Democratic tactics today.
CAIRO, March 24 -- Egypt has received a British note interpreted here as amounting to a formal breaking off of the Suez Canal zone negotiations.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Rhode Island asked the Supreme Court today for a rehearing in the off-shore oil cases.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Eisenhower discussed these topics at his news conference this morning:
WEEHAWKEN, N. J., March 24 -- Construction work on the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel was resume today here and in Manhattan.
CHICAGO, March 24 -- Bankers were urged today by a fellow-banker to show "guts and gumption" in offering consumer credit that would stimulate the economy, despite the risk of small losses.

LONDON, March 24 -- The stock markets here were slightly more confident today. British funds progressed and industrials recovered from early dullness. Gold minings and other South African shares rose after budget proposals became known.
An unnamed police lieutenant in the Brooklyn morals squad was linked yesterday to the policy ring uncovered last Friday in the borough by the Kings County District Attorney's office.

JERUSALEM, March 24 -- The Israeli Government has asked the Western powers to call an immediate session of the United Nations Security Council to discuss the massacre of eleven bus passengers in the Negev last Wednesday.

Plans are being formulated at frequent meetings for the preview of the exhibition of paintings, known as the Fifty American Artists, to be held on the night of April 21 at the Schoneman Galleries in East Fifty-seventh Street for the benefit of the Virginia Day Nursery.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, Thursday, March 25 (UP) -- The Moscow radio said in a broadcast monitored in London early today that United States intelligence reports were found in a compartment of the Trans-Siberian Railway express train.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Representative William E. Hess, Republican of Ohio, citing reports of favoritism in the armed forces, called on Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, today to tell Congress whether ball players called to military duty were getting special treatment.

LAUREL, Ind., March 24 (AP) -- Apprentice Walter Blum, who had ridden three winners yesterday, took four races today, including the featured $4,000 Fort Meade Purse with Isidor Bieber's King Jolie and by so doing became the leading rider of the meeting.

Two members of the court 'of Charles II are the subjects of biographies scheduled for publication two days apart. Farrar, Straus Young will issue on April 21 John Harold Wilson's "A Rake and His Times: George Villiers, Second Duke of Buckingham." On April 23, Crown will publish Charles Norman's "Rake Rochester," a life of John Wilmot, second Earl of Rochester. Both books present portraits of Restoration England.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Eisenhower said today that the freedom of all Southeast Asia was of transcendent importance to the entire free world.

BONN, Germany, March 24 -- A West German Government spokesman rejected tonight France's latest conditions for approving the rearmament amendment to the Bonn Constitution. Bonn officials professed to be surprised and stunned by the conditions.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Despite claims that it was paying its own way, the Tennessee Valley Authority last year saddled a $47,000,000 deficit on American taxpayers, Colter H. Moses, chairman of the Arkansas Power and Light Company, charged tonight.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams acted early today to strengthen the security forces on the strike-torn New York waterfront.

CLEVELAND, March 24 -- The annual scientific gathering of family physicians of the United States spent most of their third day of sessions today listening to various experts who told them what not to do to their patients.
The New York City Consumers' Price Index declined 0.2 per cent last month.

By a week from today Mayor Wagner must present his executive budget for the city's fiscal year starting July 1. The discrepancy between desires and revenues is wide, and this is not an easy budget to make up.

In The Times' special section last Sunday, "Report on Men's Wear," there was a charming little one-column piece by Herbert Mitgang, in which as an avowed amateur the author suggested certain improvements in the male attire.

Protestant churches have received 4,144,366 Roman Catholics as members in the United States in the past decade, according to a survey reported in The Christian Herald, a Protestant periodical without church ties.

H. Robert Reeve Jr., seeded No. 1, lived up to expectations last night at the Yale Club and recaptured the national squash tennis title. He defeated J. L. Porter of the host club, 15-2, 15-4. Reeve, of the Bayside Tennis and Racquet Club, also has been a Metropolitan squash racquets champion.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 24 (AP) -- Gov. John S. Fine's special textile study committee recommended a program calling for a new study of Pennsylvania's corporate tax structure, and special efforts by the state Commerce Department to keep the textile industry in the Commonwealth.
KANSAS CITY, March 4 -- A biologist described today how man might bring the feeling of a mountaintop into a crowded room by changing its ionic content, and thereby contribute to his well-being.

MILAN, Italy, March 24 -- Rise Stevens, mezzo-soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Company, scored a notable artistic success tonight at La Scala Theatre in the title role of a new opera entitled "The Daughter of the Devil." It was the first of three one-act operas staged tonight.
SOME sportsmen's groups are now urging the Governor to veto a recently passed bill which would permit "first-class towns" in the state to prohibit the discharge of firearms within their boundaries.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24 -- The Yankees today exploded fifteen hits, including homers by Bill Skowron and Hank Bauer, to flatten Manager Lou Boudreau's Red Sox, 11 to 7, extend the Bombers' winning streak to three games and snap Boston's at five.

PARIS, March 24 -- Premier Joseph Laniel's unwillingness to bring the European army treaty to a vote without a Saar agreement and United States and British guarantees was conveyed to France's legislators today. Daniel Mayer, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee, transmitted the message.
PARIS, March 24 -- Col. Christian de Castries, the defender of Dienbienphu, to whom President Eisenhower paid tribute today, is a decidedly untypical French Army officer.

As a British airman who recently spent seven days in transit in the City of New York I would like to take this opportunity of expressing my grateful appreciation of the hospitality shown to me by all the New Yorkers with whom I came into contact.
An economic study of the railroad industry by a private research agency was announced yesterday by W. P. Kennedy, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen.
AMMAN Jordan, March 24 -- Jordan turned down today a request by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nation to sit down with Israel at a high level conference on armistice disputes.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Nothing on the economic front calls for a slam-bang emergency program, President Eisenhower asserted today. What is needed -- a crying need he called it at his news conference -- is action on his legislative program.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ruled today that employment of a State Senator on "a loose commission arrangement" would not bar a construction company from receiving a contract for a section of the Thruway.

BONN, Germany, March 21 -- Thirty-four per cent of the 874 members of the West German diplomatic corps once belonged to the Nazi party. All of them are officially described in Bonn as having been only "nominal" party members, not "real Nazis."
The recent passage of the Officer Limitations Act by the House of Representatives is the first milestone on the long road back to improved service morale.
CHICAGO, March 24 -- Last year was another good year for the stockholders of Sears, Roebuck Co. and especially for the tax collectors, the company disclosed in its annual report made public today.

VERO BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- There are all sorts of wondrous machines, gimmicks and gadgets at the Dodger baseball factory here. Into the assembly line each day are poured some 400 youthful ball players in various stages of development.
MINEOLA, L. I., March 24 -- Nassau County's long-awaited reapportionment, creating six Assembly Districts out of the present four, was formally approved here today.
HANOI, Vietnam, March 23 -- The scope and strength of recent Vietminh activity in the Tonkin Delta area is causing serious concern in official quarters here.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 24 (UP) -- With left hooks and looping rights Charley Norkus, a Jersey City heavyweight, gained his second consecutive victory over Danny Nardico, Tampa's light heavyweight contender, on a unanimous decision in their ten-round bout tonight.

The office of State Controller J. Raymond McGovern arranged yesterday to use public employe pension money to finance school construction for two Hempstead, L. I., school districts -- those of Seaford and Island Trees.
TARRYTOWN, N Y., March 24 -- Raucous thumping and banging of pile drivers all night in the Hudson Valley here are converting Sleepy Hollow into a sleepless nightmare for some residents.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

CHICAGO, March 24 -- Wheat prices declined to the lowest points in a month, but rallied sharply later and recovered the loss. Buying by brokers with milling connections, a sharp rise on the Minneapolis market and the upturn in soybeans stimulated a general covering movement among shorts in the final hour.

Western Hemisphere countries have been really good economic neighbors since World War II. The Chase Bank's quarterly publication, "Latin American Business Highlights," says post-war Inter-American trade has gained more rapidly than that with any other area.

Methods Engineering Council, industrial management consultants, in 99 Park Ave; Television Programs of America, Inc, motion pictures for television, in 477 Madison Ave -- Cushman Wakefield, Inc, agents.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) -- The Soviet Union put new pressure on the United States today for information about a missing Soviet diplomat, Yuri Rastovorov, who disappeared in Tokyo last January.

MONTE CARLO, March 24 -- Jan Wohlin, Sweden's foremost contract bridge expert, finished well ahead of an international all-expert field yesterday to win the Monte Carlo individual championship and with it the first prize of 500,000 francs (about $1,450).

Adele Simpson, one of the top American designers, has a sound approach to fashion. Her credo is that clothes should be geared to the "well-dressed American woman's way of life -- that may be pretty and exciting but never eccentric or unwearable."
DETROIT, March 24 (AP) -- Chrysler Corporation has developed a gas turbine engine and tested it in a current model automobile.
A suspended Fort Monmouth scientist will receive a hearing today at Governors Island on a charge that he is a security risk because of a family tie to a suspected Communist.

A decline last week of 184,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 179,399,000 barrels, compared with 179,583,000 a week earlier and 163,324,000 a year ago.
NEW DELHI, India, March 24 -- The United States and the Soviet Union shared equally today in an assessment by Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of the blame for current world unrest.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation are inviolate and will remain so while he is President, General Eisenhower declared today.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 24 (UP) -- Freddie Dawson of Chicago scored a six-round technical knockout over the British Empire welterweight champion, Barry Brown, tonight, inflicting such a severe beating that the loser announced his retirement from the ring after the bout.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 24 (AP) -- Following is an English translation of a declaration on human rights approved today by the Political-Juridical Committee of the Tenth Inter-American Conference:

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., and its subsidiaries increased sales and earnings in the twenty-six and fifty-two weeks ended last Jan. 30, over the corresponding periods a year before, according to the operating results announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 24 -- George F. Kennan, former top State Department planner, called tonight for exploring new techniques in foreign policy.
The average market price of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose in February to $100.28, the highest level at a month-end since Feb. 28, 1951. The figure on Jan. 31, 1954, was $99.32.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 24 -- The Republic of Indonesia formally asked the Netherlands Government today to resume negotiations on ending the union that binds the two countries. Such negotiations, the Indonesians said, should include the question of transferring Dutch - controlled West New Guinea to Indonesian sovereignty.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- Tom Robbins, defending champion and medal winner, scored in the second round of the American Seniors Golf Association tournament, beating Judge Lloyd Beatty of Glen Ridge, N. J., 7 and 6, today.
BROWNS MILLS, N. J., March 24 (AP) -- An 8-month-old girl was burned fatally as fire spread through a second-floor apartment on Lakehurst Road today.
New issues of utility securities valued at more than $22,000,000 will be placed on the market today by investment banking syndicates. The offerings are as follows:

MINEOLA, L. I., March 24 -- Nassau County District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta warned school officials today to stop "interfering" with police investigations involving students or face arrest and prosecution.

The Staats-Zeitung, German language daily, expects to leave its present publishing center on North William Street in the Brooklyn Bridge approach area about Sept. 1, it was learned yesterday in connection with details of a leasing deal for new quarters in Woodside, Queens.
An event of much interest to lovers of Italian opera, the first appearance of Gino Penno as Canio in "Pagliacci," took place last evening at the Metropolitan.
MESA, Ariz., March 24 (UP) -- Catcher Mickey Grasso of Cleveland broke his left ankle during an exhibition game today with the Chicago Cubs and will be lost to the Indians for at least three months.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 24 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, off on what appears to be a story buying spree, announced today the purchase of Daphne Du Maurier's novel, "Mary Anne," which will be published April 29 by Doubleday.

After several months of negotiations, seven television stations and the Empire State Building officials have reached no agreement as to new rental fees for the use of the building's tower as a transmitting site beginning April 30.

KANSAS CITY, March 24 (AP) -- A New York Times story stating that a British Government booklet for sale to the public for 70 cents a copy contained hitherto secret atomic information created an international furor today.
Thomas J. Curran, New York Secretary of State, opened the Republicans' 1954 campaign last night by indicating what should be the party's line of defense in two states.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24 -- Delegates of the Big Three Western powers met today with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold to take up the sharpening tensions between Israel and the Arabs.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Senate voted tonight to cut in half the present 10 per cent Federal tax on refrigerators, ranges, toasters and other electric, gas and oil household appliances.
BONN, Germany, March 24 -- The dismissal of forty workers from a maintenance depot in Munich was inflated today into a campaign to pin a McCarthyism label on the United States Army in West Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) -- Congress was notified today that it might as well count lost a lot of money it had spent adding wooden floors and waterproof roofs to Eskimo igloos.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- Menolene, a 2-year-old filly, raced within one-fifth of a second of the track record for three furlongs while scoring her fourth victory in five starts in the $12,150 Singing Tower Stakes at Gulfstream Park today.
Dr. Detlev W. Bronk, president of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, called yesterday for a campaign against the "still wide areas of ignorance" to achieve "the great new age of man."
