A newspaper boy in Baltimore recently used the strap of his carrying bag as a tourniquet to keep a child of six whose leg had been severed by train from bleeding to death.

Many parties will be given at the annual luncheon of the Canadian Women's Club of New York to be held on Saturday in the Peacock Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. John White Delafield heads the committee in charge of arrangements for the event.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Average prices at the consumer level throughout the country eased off last month.

The Moscow radio has exhorted Soviet youth to make sure that the first man to reach the moon is a Russian. The voice on the Soviet radio was that of the Russian scientist A. Obruchev, and his message was that "the planetary system awaits a Soviet Columbus."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned stronger yesterday, advancing 5 to 17 points, with new crop months relatively stronger than old crop months.
Joseph P. Lash, correspondent of The New York Post at the United Nations, said in a letter made public yesterday, that Paul Crouch had lied about him to Senate investigators.

Directors of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation have approved an extra dividend of 5 cents a share and a dividend of 10 cents a share on the common stock, both payable April 15. Similar dividends were distributed on Jan. 15.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 24 -- A dispute between the estate owners of North Street and townsfolk intent upon establishing a parochial high school in that one-time exclusive residential area was joined in earnest here tonight.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 24 (AP) -- The old pros of the Minneapolis Lakers, George Mikan and Jim Pollard, sent their team out in front in the first game of the Western Division final play-off series tonight by beating the Rochester Royals, 89 -- 76, in the National Basketball Association.

Directors of the International Business Machines Corporation recommended yesterday a split of the common stock on the basis of one-quarter of a share for each share held or five shares for four. The response to the announcement was a four-point rise in the price of the stock on the "big board" to 297, one point short of the year's high.

From the West Coast Jose Ferrer sends word that he has given up his interest in "The Dazzling Hour," the Anna Bonacci French play that he had planned to co-produce on Broadway next season with Gilbert Miller.

The Longwood Corporation, headed by Nathan Sherman and Abraham and Paul Krantz, has purchased the commercial property at 55-63 West Palisade Avenue in Englewood, N. J. The sellers were Louis Liebowitz, Sidney and Harold Vann and Bessie Vaniewsky J. I. Kislak., was the broker.
MIAMI BEACH, March 24 (AP) -- Seeded players continued to find the going rough in the Good Neighbor tennis tournament today.
ALBANY, March 24 -- The Public Service Commission today denied the Long Island Rail Road permission to issue its commutation tickets on a calendar month basis.
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- Favored teams today stroked their way into the doubles quarterfinals in the United States Handball Association tourney.

A painting by Paul Cezanne that authorities agree is one of the finest works of the father of the contemporary art movement, has just been acquired by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. It is the first Cezanne at that museum.
LONDON, March 24 -- The question has been raised here of the ultimate usefulness to the Western defense of any pact agreed upon in the present political atmosphere.

Nearly three weeks ago disgruntled longshoremen of the old racketeer-dominated longshoremen's union shut down most of the Port of New York in defiance of a federal court's no-stoppage order. On March 10 the National Labor Relations Board initiated proceedings to punish certain individuals and locals for civil and criminal contempt.
Mayor Wagner called last night for immediate action by President Eisenhower to end the twenty-day-old waterfront strike.
VERO BEACH, Fla., March 24 -- A four-run surge in the ninth inning against Johnny Podres gave the Cardinals a 5-2 victory over the Dodgers at Holman Stadium today.

MOSCOW, March 24 -- For the last ten days it has been impossible to buy an ordinary ironing board in Moscow. Not at the great G. U. M. department store on Red Square, not at the big Mostorg store on the Petrovka and not at any of the dozens of smaller household goods stores around the city.

Organizations representing the city's 40,000 school teachers and its 130,000 other employes were resentful yesterday over what they considered the gross inadequacy of pay rises suggested to them in conferences with Mayor Wagner and Budget Director Abraham D. Beame.
BOSTON, March 24 -- The National Association of Cotton Manufacturers made known today preliminary plans for observing the 100th anniversary of its founding in May.

The year 1953 was "the most important" for the liquor-importing industry and prospects for 1954 are bright. These were the reports made yesterday to the first sessions of the two-day annual meeting of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers at the Plaza Hotel.
MEXICO CITY, March 24 -- A Mexico City newspaper charged today that public authorities were extorting 10,000,000 pesos ($1,250,000) annually from merchants in the capital.

JERUSALEM, March 24 -- The United Nations chairman of the Israeli-Jordanian Mixed Armistice Commission denied today he had prejudged the case of the killing of eleven Israelis in a bus last week. He also denied that his abstention from voting in the commission deadlock favored Jordan over Israel.

Directors of the W. A. Sheaffer Pen Company elected Craig R. Sheaffer chairman of the board yesterday. A son, John D. Sheaffer, was named to the new post of vice president in charge of foreign manufacturing.

Specialists in work with children agreed yesterday that handicapped youngsters and "so-called normal" boys and girls should share alike in youth's experiences -- from nursery school to camp to college. Just how this sharing might best be achieved was still open for discussion, however, at the end of their meeting.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Thirty-four private marketing and distributio experts will leave next month for Europe, Asia and Latin America to seek markets for United Stat farm commodities.
NEWARK, March 24 -- Two and a half ounces of whisky at one time was ruled adequate today for New Jersey bar customers.

The rich New York market is analyzed in a study released yesterday by The New York Times. Family spending is examined by income groups in the first such survey since a detailed analysis was made early in the depression years of the Thirties by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

NEW YORK'S second annual Book Festival is raging amiably through the springtime skies from the towers of the town's municipal radio station, WNYC. This airborne celebration of literature is presenting about 100 different programs in the course of the week, all dedicated to the exhilarating proposition that there is nothing wrong with reading that more reading will not cure.

The New York Post Office has maintained a steady flow of foreign mail during the pier strike but the cost has included much schedule juggling, heavy wear on vehicles, long hours and not a few headaches.
Corn, a native American grain, still holds an important place in family meals. It was first domesticated and cultivated by the Indians in the New World long before white men reached these shores.
Russian chess players, who will be here in June, defeated Argentina, 5 -- 3, in the first round of the international matches in Buenos Aires, according to South American news sources.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 24 -- Nineteen of the twenty-one American republics resolved today to try to guarantee human rights and freedoms to all persons.

A large subscription has been reported for the annual luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the Nearly New Shop, to be held today, March 25, in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Miss Louise Edgar, president of the Nearly New Shop, is honorary chairman, and Mrs. J. Randolph Grymes Jr. is active chairman of the benefit committee.

A Bronx grand jury found yesterday that there was no evidence of a crime in the case of Jack Molinas. A former Columbia University basketball captain, Mr. Molinas was suspended last January from the Fort Wayne (Ind.) Pistons professional team for betting on his team.
Development of a revolutionary new type of atomic reactor for the production of electricity from atomic energy was announced yesterday at the annual convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Eisenhower expressed hope today that the logjam would loosen up very shortly on admissions to this country under the Refugee Relief Act of 1953.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- two words spoken so quickly they sounded like one with an entirely different meaning threw President Eisenhower's official stenographer into something of a flap today.

On March 15 you published a letter from S. G. Antor, Secretary General of the Togoland Congress, on the price of cocoa. Most observers attribute the phenomenal rise in the world price of cocoa in recent years to the effect of expanding demand for a commodity the production of which cannot swiftly be increased.

YONKERS, March 24 -- When Curtis B. Blanchard, 58 years old, 446 Warburton Avenue, was stricken with heart ailment at 12:01 o'clock this morning in his home, his stepmother Mrs. Caroline Blanchard, 77, who lived downstairs, started upstairs to aid him and fell dead of heart attack.
Senator Ralph E. Flanders called last night for a "moral offensive" against the Soviet Union as the most effective way of achieving world disarmament.
LONDON, March 24 -- Philip J. Noel-Baker, a former Labor Cabinet minister, urged the Government today to help raise more funds for United Nations relief and development agencies around the world.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission has had nine employe security cases, two of them involving loyalty questions, since President Eisenhower's new security program went into effect last year.

The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission has approved a definite route for the expressway's northeast extension, to the north of Scranton, and will proceed with the financing soon. Thomas J. Evans, chairman of the commission, made the announcement yesterday.

Robert Moses, recently named chairman of the State Power Authority, challenged yesterday to a debate Ralph H. Tapscott, whom he referred to as chairman of the board of trustees of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York. They would discuss whether Niagara hydro-electric power should be developed by the private utility companies.
The formation of a national advisory committee for CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Everywhere, Inc.) was announced yesterday by Murray D. Lincoln, president of the organization.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 24 -- The Baltimore Orioles today defeated the Giants, 4-3, and moved to within a step of the Cactus Circuit championship. Even if Manager Jimmy Dykes' outfit should lose tomorrow's finale to the Giants, it will finish tied with the New Yorkers in the Arizona version of Florida's Citrus League.
YONKERS, N. Y., March 24 -- The State Education Commissioner has been asked to look into a charge that the Yonkers school district is not providing adequate facilities for pupils.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24 (AP) -- Lew Worsham gained his first golf tournament victory today since the spectacular wedge shot that captured the $25,000 first prize in the Tam o'Shanter "world championship" last year.

Roosevelt Raceway has asked George P. Monaghan, Harness Racing Commissioner, for permission to increase its $1.50 general admission price to $2. General admission at the local thoroughbred (flat) tracks is $1.95.
A price tag of $275,000,000 was put on the Port of New York's current work stoppage yesterday as it entered its twentieth day.

CALGARY, Alberta, March 24 (Canadian Press) -- The natural gas market in the United States is growing and the 100,000,000 cubic feet a day earmarked for export to the United States from Canada is the minimum rather than the maximum his company would ask for, John F. Merriam, president of the Northern Natural Gas Company, told the Alberta Petroleum and Natural Gas Conservation Board here today.
The Washington Water Power Company has spent $175,000 in diamond and core drilling in western Montana on the Clark Fork River, testing for a firm foundation for a new hydroelectric plant.
Some quite promising violin playing was put on display last night in Town Hall by David Davis, who was making his debut on the occasion.

I was shocked to hear of the results of the latest nuclear explosion in the vicinity of Bikini. We have again brought tragedy to the Japanese people. Though our war with Japan is over we have, unwittingly it is true, committed an act of aggression against them.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 17:
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP) -- President Eisenhower said tonight there was great need to conserve water and mineral resources and to develop young scientists.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 24 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold emphasized today the importance of "timing" in connection with any moves to admit Communist China to the United Nations.
BALTIMORE, March 24 (AP)-Two of the dozen stockholders present at the Nash-Kelvinator meeting complained that Hudson shareholders were getting more out of the deal than their stock was worth.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced tentative rules and regulations today for enforcement of the Flammable Fabrics Act, to go into effect July 1.
With the great expansion in use of parking meters, plans are going forward to sell advertising space on these devices in many municipalities.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A Senate committee chairman, who had lost a son on Guam in World War II, told his committee today that its investigation into a limited field of "security risks" had put unwarranted black marks on the armed services as a whole.
SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., March 24 -- Dean Erwin N. Griswold of the Harvard Law School said tonight that some recent Congressional investigations had been "clear violations" of due process of law.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in 1953 recorded the greatest sales and earnings in its twenty-two-year history. Sales of $820,466,739 nearly doubled the $438,122,395 volume of 1952. Earnings climbed 70.7 per cent to $15,462,079, despite a tax bill of $32,800,000, more than twice net earnings.

DETROIT, March 24 (AP) -- Stockholders of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation and Hudson Motor Car Company today approved plans to merge the two concerns into a new company to be known as American Motors Corporation.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- The March 1 hydrogen explosion in the Marshall Islands surpassed the expectations of the United States scientists who devised it, President Eisenhower said today.

TORONTO, March 24 -- Five men and one woman will leave this city Friday to tackle a 200-mile trek with skis and climbing irons across some of the toughest unexplored glacial terrain in the Canadian Rockies.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 24 -- The Netherlands Government has seized the initiative toward forcing the European Coal and Steel Community to take action against cartels.

In arranging its current exhibition of street signs the Museum of Modern Art has drawn on cities as distant as Detroit and London for good examples. For a "horrible example" to point up the contrast it didn't have to search so far. This "horrible example" is the lamppost at Fifth Avenue and West Fifty-third Street in Manhattan, only a few steps east of the museum's entrance.

Thirty-one vessels totaling 55,140 gross tons were added last month to the roster of oceangoing and miscellaneous vessels on order or under construction under the supervision of the American Bureau of Shipping.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UP) -- Representative Usher L. Burdick, Republican of North Dakota, today denounced as a false "smear" sworn testimony given to the House Un-American Activities Committee recently by a self-styled former Communist.

Despite the defeat of the compulsory automobile insurance bill, George H. Hallett Jr., executive secretary of the Citizens Union, said yesterday that the record of the 1954 Legislature was one of "solid accomplishment." He added that the union's program fared better than in any other recent year.

MONTREAL, March 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian pulp and paper industry was told today more efficient production methods and stabilization of operations throughout the year are needed to bring down the high cost of wood in areas east of the Rocky Mountains.
WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and Drew Pearson, columnist, fired new barrages in their feud today.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Under pressure from producers and members of Congress, the Government got back into the potato market today to bolster prices.
Cocoa and coffee prices soared yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Coffee was up the 2 cents a pound daily limit in all positions and cocoa was within 5 points of the 1-cent limit in most months.

LINCOLN, England, March 24 (UP) -- Prince Aly Khan's Nahar, the only French entry in the field of thirty-two, got a brilliant ride from J. Massard today and scored a length-and-a-half victory over Mrs. M. A. Farr's Sailing Light in the ninety-fourth Lincolnshire Handicap at the Carholm track.

CHICAGO, March 24 -- A recommendation urging the appointment of a nonpartisan commission to replace Congressional investigating committees appeared today in the Christian Advocate, official publication of the Methodist Church. The magazine said in an editorial:

The concert given by the Bach Aria Group, William H. Scheide director and program annotator, with an imposing list of soloists and the chorus of the Robert Shaw Chorale, Robert Shaw, conducting, last night in Carnegie Hall was devoted entirely to solo and choral music by J. S. Bach.

Throughout March the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association at Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street has been cele brating the eightieth anniversary of its founding. The past eight decades have witnessed the flowering of this community center -- the oldest Jewish Y in continuous existence -- into a dynamic force in New York City's life.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- President Eisenhower made it plain today that he did not want Senator McCarthy to sit as a judge in his own dispute with the Army.
Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company took no action on a dividend on the common stock at their monthly meeting yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 -- One of the characteristics of the Los Angeles market is that fun and high fashions mingle. The perfectly fitted suit, the glamorously sophisticated style and the whimsical in play clothes all find their place in the picture.

Wall Street took a long look at the capital gains situation yesterday. It noted that the 1953-54 bull market started a little more than six months ago. Some investors apparently thought it might be a good time to take profits.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 24 -- The spending of the family's money was evaluated at meetings here today at the Farm and Home Week Program at Cornell University.

Prime Minister Nehru of India is one of the world's most influential statesmen, the leader of a great nation with which we in this great country desire friendly and harmonious relations. These reasons alone are sufficient to make us weigh his words carefully and to be distressed at his indictment that our policy has created "insecurity, uncertainty and instability" in Asia.
WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Cropland damaged by wind erosion in the drought-stricken Southern Great Plains has increased tremendously since January.

It is understandable that of all the things that happened at the Tenth Inter-American Conference in Caracas, Venezuela, the announcement of the plans to release the Peruvian leader, Haya de la Torre, aroused the greatest emotion. The Haya case has dragged on for more than five years and it has always been highly charged with emotion.

NEW ORLEANS, March 24 -- A "great national conspiracy" against human decency is taking form throughout this country, the Most Rev. Michael J. Ready, Roman Catholic Bishop of Columbus, Ohio, charged here today.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 24 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner motored here today from near-by Trenton to view what is expected to become New Jersey's first executive mansion.

ALBANY, March 24 -- The state is planning to spend $26,000,000 on arterial highways within the city of New York in the next twelve months, Bertram D. Tallamy, Superintendent of Public Works, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules, except where direct quotation was authorized: ...
Richard A. Lester, Professor of Economics, Princeton University, in a recent letter condemns the Administration's proposed tax relief for dividends.
An electronic future far overshadowing past accomplishments was predicted last night at the annual dinner of the Institute of Radio Engineers.
BELIZE, British Honduras, March 24 (AP) -- A former leader of the People's United Party has testified before a special investigator that the party received money and material from Guatemala.
Speaking to the question, "Is the Bill of Rights Under Attack?", John B. Oakes, editorial writer of The New York Times, replied yesterday in the affirmative.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 805 pints of blood Tuesday. Members of the Masonic order gave 321 pints at the Grand Lodge, 71 West Twenty-third Street. Employes of Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, 30 East Forty-second Street, gave 199 pints on the first day of a three-day donation.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Governor Dewey sharply reminded the Wagner Administration today that he had the power to remove both the Mayor and Police Commissioner of New York if there was a breakdown of law enforcement on the waterfront.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 24 -- Finance Minister Nicolaas C. Havenga announced today tax reductions for the next year. In presenting the budget he also listed a further decrease of the public debt in terms of percentage of the annual national income, a substantial surplus for the year past and an estimated surplus for the coming year.
The Eastern States contract bridge tournament entered its sixth day of play last night with two team-of-four contests.
The proposed merger of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation and Hudson Motor Car Corporation is off for at least twenty days. Nash-Kelvinator directors decided yesterday to defer action on the deal that long.

LONDON, March 25 -- A whale named Jonah is one of the biggest problems facing British transportation. Jonah will be brought to London to be exhibited if a way can be figured out to get him across the English Channel. It is too late for him to swim. Jonah has been dead for some time, although a refrigerator plant in his innards keeps him fresh -- or fairly fresh.
White letters pulsed out the word "police" in a red panel atop a radio car yesterday afternoon in the rainswept gloom of Pier 14, Hudson River.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- New support was claimed today for the campaign that started two weeks ago to "draft" Roy M. Brewer to run against Richard F. Walsh, incumbent president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.
Nat Holman appealed to the State Education Commissioner in Albany yesterday to overrule his dismissal as City College basketball coach.

A rookie patrolman, a suspected mugger, and a pedestrian were slightly wounded early yesterday as four plainclothes men broke up an alleged mugging attempt off Times Square. The police fired nine shots.

The Radio Corporation of America announced yesterday that it had begun commercial production of color television receivers at its plant in Bloomington, Ind. The plant is geared to produce 2,000 color sets a month, but plans call for production of 10,000 receivers by the end of this year.

Port Newark took another substantial step in its comeback and enlarging future yesterday with the dedication of a new $6,000,000 marine terminal improvement, built to most modern specifications by the Port of New York Authority for use by the Waterman Steamship Corporation.
GUATEMALA, March 25 -Four opposition Congressmen barely escaped falling into the hands of an angry mob during last night's legislative session.

A CHAP who likes to worm out origins of things got fussing among old records the other day to find out when New York had its first circus. He was inspired by a news note that Ringling's show would open in Madison Square Garden the end of this month.

Edward Steichen, dean of American photographers, was honored last night on his seventy- fifth birthday. Members of Mr. Steichen's family, photographers, art directors and patrons, bankers, military men, publishers, editors and artists gathered to pay tribute to the lens artist at a dinner at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

BUENOS AIRES, March 25 -- Argentina's Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it had taken all steps possible to prevent the population from being harmed by any radioactive air. The commission has mobilized the Argentine Air Force, naval air units and the meteorological service in its precautionary battle.
BONN, Germany, March 25 -France stood aside today and opened the way for final ratification of the European Defense Community treaty by West Germany.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A national project to erect a 100-foot-high "Freedom Shrine" in the Capital was started here tonight by Kenneth D. Wells, President of Freedom Foundation at Valley Forge, Pa.

The first year of operations of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., as a merged enterprise resulted in a net income of $8,996,000, equal to $2.14 a common share, the company reported yesterday.
The Eastern States contract bridge tournament entered its seventh day of play last night with four team matches and an individual contest.

To the food stores, working on speedy turnover and a short mark-up, the idea of a sideline is highly attractive. Many of the big chains have installed hardware, magazines, clothing items, drugs and even appliances.
The Flammable Fabrics Act was hailed yesterday as "the Food and Drug Act of the fashion industry" by Mrs. Andrew C. Cope, a leader in the consumer movement in this state.
OGDENSBURG, N. Y., March 25 -- The Most Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg was installed today as the sixth Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Ogdensburg.
Dr. Franklin D. Murphy, chancellor of the University of Kansas, asserted last night that American medical schools should turn out "competent" physicians rather than "vague, idealistic" researchers.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 25 (UP) -- The Cleveland Indians suffered their second jolt in two days when it was announced today that Outfielder Harry (Suitcase) Simpson had suffered a fractured arm in a sliding mishap and would be lost to the team for at least six weeks.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -Powerful Republican forces in the House of Representatives were prepared to throw two haymakers tomorrow at the Eisenhower Administration's public housing program.

Argentina's chess team offered strong resistance in the second round of the international series with the Russian grand masters and drew the three games that were finished at Buenos Aires, according to a report received from South American news sources yesterday.
CHICAGO, March 25 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, reassured private power interests tonight that the Administration was "not going to scuttle the reclamation program."

ALBANY, March 25 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill giving to the Board of Regents broad supervisory powers over nonprofit educational corporations organized to operate noncommercial television stations.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 25 -- Although two Cardinals were thrown out at the plate today they still contrived to beat the Dodgers for the second straight day, 2-1, before 5,331 at Al Lang Field. The Redbirds now have a four-game winning streak.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- Republican and Democratic members of Congress took the Administration to task today because only six persons have been admitted to this country under the emergency refugee relief program.

President Eisenhower left no doubt of his estimate of the stake of the free world in the struggle in Indo-China when he told his news conference that it was of "transcendent importance.'' However the war started, he said, Vietnam had manifestly become "one of the battlegrounds of the people who wanted to live their own lives against the encroachment of Communist aggression."

CHICAGO, March 25 -- The sales of Montgomery Ward Co. declined $85,462,948 in the fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, and net income was $8,398,178 lower than it had been a year earlier, the company said today in its annual report to stockholders.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- In his Phi Beta Kappa speech at Mount Holyoke College, referred to in this space today, Dean Griswold of the Harvard Law School said of legislative inquiries:
HANOI, Vietnam, March 25 (AP) -- French planes dropped streams of fire bombs on Vietminh troop positions around besieged Dienbienphu today in a tremendous aerial assault.
The statement by Mayor Wagner on city salaries and taxes follows:
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 25 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority moved today to assure completion by 1956 of the proposed link between the New Jersey toll road and the Pennsylvania Turnpike.
The cotton futures market of the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, with active months off 5 to 11 points.

A suspended Fort Monmouth engineer declared his opposition to communism at a First Army hearing yesterday. The main charge against him is his brother-in-law's reputed record as a Communist official and employe, the engineer's lawyer reported last night.
ROME, March 25 -- Italian communism indicated today it would join battle with the Government in defense of the privileges it had enjoyed for a long time.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -The United States has acknowledged that the two American planes recently attacked by a Czechoslovak jet fighter "inadvertently" crossed into Czechoslovak territory.

CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Bob Brady of San Francisco, seeded No. 1, and Vic Hershkowitz of Brooklyn, seeded No. 2, today gained tomorrow's semi-final round in singles competition of the United States Handball Association tournament.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $568,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
The Transit Authority gave a lukewarm reception yesterday to proposals by private operators to take over Manhattan and Queens bus lines owned by the city.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 25 -- A Toledo light bulb manufacturer and three of its subsidiaries today filed a 21-million-dollar suit in Federal District Court here against General Electric Corporation. The action was brought under the anti-trust laws for profits alleged to have been lost due to a conspiracy by a light-bulb monopoly.

Denunciation of the recent ambush and slaying of eleven Israelis was voiced yesterday by the Jewish National Fund of America, land-purchasing arm of the Zionist movement in Israel, and Hadassah, women's Zionist organization.

TOKYO March 25 (UP) -- Radio active ashes from Soviet atomic explosions in Siberia and the United States test in the Pacific are raining on Japan, a Socialist member of the Japanese Diet [Parliament] said today.
KANSAS CITY, March 25 -The discovery of a new disease the fourth new one found recently to be due to an inherited "error" in the physiology of its victims -- was announced here today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 25 -- After attaining a quotation of 54 cruzeiros 50 centavos to the dollar on Monday, the cruzeiro commenced to weaken again on Tuesday and is quoted today at 57 cruzeiros 50 centavos to the dollar, a drop of three cruzeiros in three days.

MOSCOW, March 25 -- Four members of the United States Military Attach's office in Moscow were charged with espionage today by the newspaper Trud. The paper called for their expulsion from the Soviet Union.

Summonses were issued in Flatbush Magistrate's Court yesterday to the author and the publisher of the novel "From Here to Eternity," and also to the producers of the motion picture based on the novel.

CLIO, Ala., March 25 (AP) -- The family of hospitalized Royall Reynolds chipped in with contributions today to trim the deficit in the defunct Clio Merchants Exchange from an original $75,000 to perhaps $9,000.

Any extension of this country's reciprocal trade program without provision for further tariff cuts will be only a weak token of goodwill toward countries desiring expanded trade, a leading importer spokesman declared yesterday.

Although spring is almost one week old, there's still lots of snow in the northlands. A new snowfall was reported for a number of areas in Vermont and New Hampshire yesterday, and there will be plenty of opportunity to ski this week-end if enthusiasts don't mind a trip.

FRANKFORT, Germany, March 25 (AP) -- Hopes that an all-German team would represent divided Germany in the European track and field championships in Switzerland next August were smashed today by a new East German move that widened the rift in German sports.
Consumers, becoming aware that retailers are keeping a careful eye on inventories, particularly of apparel, have begun to complain about the difficulty of finding wanted sizes and favorite colors.

Textron, Inc., announced plans yesterday for further expansion into the non-textile field with the acquisition of the MB Manufacturing Company of New Haven, specialists in analysis of vibration and devices for its cure in the aircraft and general industrial fields. MB's gross sales last year were $8,000,000.

The Metropolitan Museum will open to the public today a remarkable exhibition of the paintings, prints and drawings of three famous American "expatriate" artists -- John Singer Sargent, James McNeill Whistler and Mary Cassatt.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Another threat to long range merchant marine planning in this country is developing in Congress, aimed at the industry's most vulnerable point -- subsidies.

A small company of leaders in the racket-encrusted International Longshoremen's Association is staging a revolt against law and order and decent trade unionism in a desperate gamble to maintain its hold on the waterfront. By officially sanctioning the mob-directed wildcat strike these leaders are defying federal authority, which has cited some of them for contempt of a restraining order issued three weeks ago.

When I read your fine editorial asking that the United States Government continue to send shipments of surplus food overseas, and Harold Oram's letter telling of 1,500,000 poor refugees in Hong Kong, I thought I should tell you how a first shipment of surplus milk arrived in Hong Kong through Catholic War Relief Services just as I was leaving last fall.

As the Nassau County police and school authorities met in special conference yesterday to thrash out a common approach to juvenile delinquency problems new bomb hoaxes emptied two high schools in the county.

TAIPEI, Formosa, March 25 -- President Chiang Kai-shek said today that the Chinese Nationalist Government was ready to "accept and investigate" any charges of undemocratic practices in Formosa. He pledged that the Government would "make corrections" if the charges were true.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 25 -- Israel charged Jordan tonight with unwillingness to take any step to alleviate the border tension.
The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York announced yesterday that it expected to raise a record $15,100,000 in contributions and pledges before the close of its fiscal year on Sept, 30.

SALT LAKE CITY, March 25 -- Mental patients from all wards of the Veterans Administration Fort Douglas Station Hospital attended a full-scale performance of "La Boheme" in the hospital's well-equipped theatre last night -- and found it good.
Plans for a $1,750,000 development program to improve campus facilities and expand professional programs were announced yesterday by Pratt Institute, 255 Ryerson Street, Brooklyn.

LONDON, March 25 -- The stock markets were rather quiet today. In view of large sums locked up in the new Imperial Chemical Industries issue, British funds continued to improve. But industrials moved irregularly. The I. C. L 30,000,000 ($84,000,000) loan was oversubscribed more than ten times. South African shares continued to gain on the strength of yesterday's budget report.

The two-story office building at 88-22 161st Street in Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by the Liroma Realty Corporation. It has been acquired for investment by the Colonial Real Estate Associates, headed by Max Roth. L. J. Phillips Co. and Alex P. Watts were co-brokers in the transaction and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
The Illinois Central Railroad and the Central Railroad of New Jersey raised $8,115,000 in the public market yesterday to help finance acquisition of equipment costing about $10,980,000.

In the second annual Boy Scouts of America benefit double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night the Ramapo trio defeated the Squadron A team. 17 - 11. and the Meadow Brook side edged the New York Polo Club, 13 -- 12.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -The United States Court of Appeals today upheld the right of the armed forces to court-martial civilians for major crimes committed while in military service.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- Representative Harold D. Cooley, Democrat of North Carolina, accused Harold E. Stassen today of "unwarranted" use of aid funds to send 5,000,000 food packages to persons in nineteen countries last Christmas in Operation Reindeer.

The Consumers Power Company, one of the largest electric and gas utilities in Michigan, reported yesterday a net income of $25,420,965 for the twelve months to Feb. 28. This was equal to $2.95 a share on the company's common stock outstanding at the end of the period.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- The House reversed its budget- cutting drive today and voted an extra $55,000,000 for Federal aid to schools.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday a net income of $189,453,450 for 1953, or $6.61 each on 28,673,192 capital shares. This compares with $174,030,499, or $6.07 a share, in 1952. The company's sales increased to $1,080,425,000 from $1,015,309,000 in 1952.

The busiest and hardest-working patients at St. Vincent's Hospital are the disabled and crippled, fighting their way out of the bedridden class and back to independence. They are in the corridors learning to walk, getting treatment in the therapeutic tank or the exercise room, building muscles, relearning control and coordination.

Varied divertissements by stars of the theatrical world will be presented at the dinner to be given on Sunday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the public services program of the American Theatre Wing.

The corrosive effect of acute anti-McCarthyism upon human judgment could not be better exemplified than in the suggestion of Walter D. Binger in your letter column that Senator McCarthy "be barred from the hearing room during the testimony of Roy Cohn and the [War] Departments' representatives.''

NEWARK, March 25 -- The Port Authority's new $6,000,000 marine terminal at Port Newark, to be used for foreign and domestic cargo operations by the Waterman Steamship Corporation, was formally dedicated today.

GOVERNOR DEWEY'S approval yesterday of the bill authorizing educational television stations in this state is a welcome turn. A sound legal foundation now has been laid for this new medium, thanks in no small part to enlightened cooperation between the Governor's office and educators to make sure that there would be no impingement on academic freedom in educational broadcasting.
The 1954-55 season at the Metropolitan Opera will open Monday evening, Nov. 8, and will run for twenty-two weeks, closing the following April 10, Rudolf Bing, general manager, announced yesterday.
Luxuriously curved and over-scaled sofas built in sections predominate in a large collection of upholstered pieces now at Altman's. Also included are examples of severely straight designs.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -Rumors, quickly and authoritatively denied, spread across Capitol Hill today of a "settlement by resignations" of the Army's controversy with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 25 -- Distribution as a factor in the cost of foods was discussed here today by Miss Helen G. Canoyer, dean of the State College of Home Economics.

On a rutted road in Korea a uniformed man bounces along in a jeep. His uniform is dusty and he is dog-tired, but he can't stop for a rest because he carries a message that must get through to a service man.
ALBANY, March 25 -- James R. Macduff, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, began tightening license renewal regulations today to weed out drivers whose physical condition might constitute a safety hazard.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Congressional leaders decided today to create a professional Capitol police force.
Bank lending to business in the New York area is declining again, following the brief interruption last week caused by borrowings for tax purposes.
SYRACUSE, March 25 -- A record-breaking triumph by Ford Konno gave Ohio State its first National Collegiate swimming title of 1954 in the Orange pool of Syracuse University tonight.

MONTREAL, March 25 (UP) -- Dickie Moore set two scoring records tonight as the Montreal Canadiens took a 2 -- 0 lead in their four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-final playoff with an 8 -- 1 victory over the Boston Bruins. The game also established a mark for penalties.

Two "key figures" in a $1,000,000 diamond smuggling ring were arrested yesterday by United States Customs inspectors. They were charged with conspiracy to smuggle, receive and secrete diamonds into this country.

Another important step toward European unification and a better Western defense structure has been taken as a result of the approval by the Western Powers of two amendments to the German Constitution. These amendments specifically legalize a limited German rearmament and Germany's membership in the European Defense Community.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 609,959 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The Brown Shoe Company, with an annual production capacity of 25,000,000 pairs of shoes, has acquired 48 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Regal Shoe Company, which has 121 retail outlets and annual production capacity of about 1,000,000 pairs of shoes.

The International Boxing Club is carrying the "new talent" idea in boxing right into Madison Square Garden where, tonight, it will present a card headed by a match between Gustav Scholz of Berlin, Germany, and Al Andrews of Superior, Wis.
Ella Goldstein, pianist, played her only New York recital of the season last evening at the Theresa L. Kaufmann Auditorium of the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A states' rights conflict among President Eisenhower's advisers apparently had become dead-locked.

LONDON, March 25 -- Frederic Lloyd, general manager of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company, will leave for New York Sunday by plane to open preliminary negotiations for an American season of Gilbert and Sullivan operas later this year.
Both management and its opposition in the New York Central Railroad Company had important announcements for the road's shareholders yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25 -- The United States, olution under which the United Nations Security Council would call on Egypt to remove restric-Britain, France and Denmark today endorsed a New Zealand restions on Israeli-bound shipments passing through the Suez Canal.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- A vicious spring storm roared across the midcontinent today, leaving at least four dead in three states and a trail of heavy damage.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Charles Kenneth Claunch, who has been working at the White House since 1929, was called in a week ago by President Eisenhower, who said he was sorry that Mr. Claunch would have to leave the executive mansion.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Following is the 76 to 8 vote by which the Senate tonight passed the excise tax reduction and extension bill and sent it back to the House for action on Senate amendments:
WASHINGTON, March 25 -The Eisenhower Administration is understood to be approaching the forthcoming Geneva conference in a gingerly spirit and in a determination to play it down.

Two new films will arrive in first-run theatres today. At the Astor, the attraction is "Red Garters,'' a Western musical satire in Technicolor, produced by Paramount with Rosemary Clooney, Jack Carson, Guy Mitchell, Pat Crowley, Joanne Gilbert and Gene Barry.
The 3-year-old colt Turn-to, who has been the future-book favorite for the Kentucky Derby, won't run in the May 1 race. Perhaps his race-running days are ended.

LONDON, March 25 -- The House of Commons approved tonight the Government's television bill to permit advertising on television. The vote was 296 to 269 on the second reading, the main legislative stage of the bill's progress.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- A House subcommittee has approved two provisions in the new appropriations bill that would reverse long-standing policies affecting the Tennessee Valley Authority.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 25 -- Bob Wiesler, the 23-year-old left-hander Manager Casey Stengel tabbed last winter as a top mound prospect for 1954, today became the first Yankee hurler to go seven innings.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 13 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from previous periods:
CHICAGO, March 25 -- The wheat market was lower most of the day and deferred deliveries were weaker than nearby contracts.

WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State, testified today that "young Soviets" apparently still were pulling wires in the State Department as he said they had been during World War II.

Raytheon Manufacturing Company of Waltham, Mass., one of the country's leading producers of electronic equipment, has leased the sixteenth floor in the sixteen-story and penthouse building going up at 589 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of East Forty-eighth Street.

C. P. Donat has been appointed sales manager of X-ray and medical products of the International General Electric Company and Paul J. Frosch has joined the headquarters staff of X-ray and medical products as supervisor of engineering and procurement.

MOSCOW, Friday, March 26 -The Soviet Government announced today that East Germany had become a sovereign state. Soviet troops will remain in East Germany temporarily by agreement with the East German Government, the Soviet announcement said.
CAIRO, March 25 -- Egypt's military rulers announced today plans to end their revolutionary mission and surrender all power to a civilian government in July.

Robert Frost half-seriously dated his sonnet "Once by the Pacific" as "about 1880." He would have then been 6 years old. Today he is 80, and while his stature has increased through the years his early poems as well as his most recent ones possess the same sensitivity and meaningful power that have made him one of our greatest poets.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 25 (AP) -- Bob Wingate, former national public links champion from Fayetteville, N. C., upset the medalist and favorite, Tom Robbins of Larchmont, N. Y., in the American Seniors Golf Association tournament today.

BONN, Germany, March 25 (AP) -- The United States High Commission announced today a new policy under which it will be possible to release top-ranking German war criminals from Landsberg prison without announcing their names.

The New York City Opera opened its spring season handsomely last night in the City Center with a performance of "Salome" that was effectively mounted and dramatically delivered, and in which members of the cast, notably Phyllis Curtin, the Salome, and Walter Cassel, the Jochanaan, distinguished themselves by the originality and significance of their performance.

" The Girl on the Via Flaminia" won't be homeless. Forced to discontinue after Sunday night's performance at the Circle in the Square because the Fire Department ruled that the cozy theatre lacked proper safety precautions, Alfred Hayes' hit play will resume next Thursday night at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre.

TRENTON, March 25 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner appointed Dwight R. G. Palmer today to be New Jersey Highway Commissioner. If confirmed by the State Senate, the Short Hills industrialist will assume his new duties April 14.

Counsel for a group of stockholders of Algam Corporation, owner of Yonkers Raceway, announced yesterday plans for forestalling the possible "swallowing up" of the corporation by the Yonkers Trotting Association. The association conducts harness racing at the track as a tenant of Algam.

ALBANY, March 25 -- Liquidation of the Judicial Council, which has been functioning since 1934 to improve the administration of justice in New York, may be forced by a short and heretofore unpublicized section of the supplemental budget bill.
BALTIMORE, March 25 -- In the last three weeks the Port of Baltimore has become the booming beneficiary of the diversion of cargoes and ships from New York's strike-bound docks.

Seven little men from Malaya, where much of the world's natural rubber is produced, bounced into New York yesterday from London with all of the top prizes for men in the All-England badminton tournament in their luggage.

MONTE CARLO, March 25 -- The all-French contract bridge team of MM. Ghestem, Bacherich, Tintner and Suusman took the lead today in the Monte Carlo team-of-four championship with a match point score of 150.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 25 (2P) -- Hal Burrows, ranked thirteenth in the United States and sixth in the tournament, scored a mild upset today by defeating Kurt Nielsen in the quarter-finals of the Good, Neighbor tennis tournament.
ALBANY, March 25 (AP) -- The State Civil Service Commission, stepping up its drive against disloyalty, today listed the Communist party as subversive under the state's "security risk" law.
CLEVELAND, March 25 -- A campaign of "retaliation" against detractors of the family doctor was promised today by the new president of the American Academy of General Practice.

A volume of AmericarLa by John Tebbel, author of "The Life and Good Times of Williarfi Randolph I-Iears," will be published April 29 by Dutton entitled "George Washing'con's Axnerica." The book highlights all the landmarks associated with American h/story through Washington andI shows how he appeared to the people during his lifetime.

THE Boone and Crockett Club presented awards to twenty-three winners in the annual big game trophy competition at a dinner held last night at the Hall of Mammals of the American Museum of Natural History.

BERLIN, Friday, March 26 -The Soviet announcement that it was granting full sovereignty to the East German Government had been expected. It was considered as a move to increase the prestige of the East German regime as an aftermath of the recent inconclusive four-power talks in Berlin.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 25 -- Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, informed Jordan today that he did not intend to pursue the question of direct Israel-Jordan negotiations on the implementation of their armistice agreement any further "for the present."

Though Bernard Lorjou has occupied a prominent place among younger French painters since 1945, the present exhibition of his still-lifes and occasional figures at Wildenstein's marks his first American one-man appearance.

The Boeing Airplane Company, which last year turned in the greatest sales and earnings in its thirty - seven - year history, proposed yesterday to split its stock by issuing one additional share for each share held.
BERLIN, Friday, March 26 (AP) -- The text of the Soviet Government statement on the State of East Germany, as distributed by the A. D. N. news agency:
Two Cubans, seized last March 5 with an arsenal of firearms and hand grenades in an upper West Side store, were named yesterday in a six-count indictment.

TOPEKA, Kan., March 25 (AP) -- A verdict of acquittal was directed today in the trial of Lester Luther, former United States District Attorney and his one- time assistant, Nicholas F. Lopes, on Government charges of conspiracy to obtain attorney fees illegally.

CARACAS, Venezuela, March 25 -- A series of resolutions that would amount to a general charter of the rights of women in the Americas won a unanimous vote in a plenary session of the Tenth Inter-American Conference today.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that he and the Board of Estimate were committed to extension of the city's 3 per cent sales tax to cover commercial services.
CHICAGO, March 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
LONDON, March 25 -- The "terrifying" hydrogen weapon may prove a deterrent to war because of its terrible destructiveness, Anthony Eden declared tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The State Department disclosed today that the United States will buy 100,000 tons of copper from Chile at the world market price.
A protracted lay - up of the port's 450 tugs and related harbor craft could effectively cripple a major part of the harbor's commercial life, shipping men said yesterday.

When President Eisenhower signed the emergency immigration bill last August, allowing the permanent admission of 214,000 additional refugees during a three-year period, he described it as "a significant humanitarian act and an important contribution toward greater understanding and cooperation among the free nations of the world."

JERUSALEM, Jordanian Sector, March 25 -- Postponement by Mr. Hammarskjold of the United Nations invitation to a conference on the Israeli-Jordanian crisis was regarded here as the second serious blow in three days to the moderate Israeli Government of Moshe Sharett.
City Council President Abe Stark accused State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman yesterday of "malicious slander" against members of the Board of Estimate.

The coming week will bring price decreases for milk and butter. Next Thursday appreciable reductions in retail butter prices are expected when the new Government program for dairy products goes into effect.

THE ball players had a new complaint this year and it wasn't about the weather, which certainly would have been the most justifiable kind of gripe. Florida's weather for the past month was both "unseasonable" and "unusual." To put it bluntly, it was bad. It would have been pleasant for polar bears and penguins, but not for pelicans and ball players.

DETROIT, March 25 (UP) -- Gordie Hannigan scored twice tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-to-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings and even their four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup semi-final series at one game each.

The possibility of consolidating Municipal Court districts is being studied, President Justice Daniel Gutman announced yesterday. Justice Herman C. Stoute is chairman of the committee on centralization.
LONDON, March 25 -- A British business man who returned recently from Moscow said today that the Soviet Union had signed orders for approximately u50,000,000 ($140,000,000) worth of British goods.
All his life, Robert Frost, famous American poet, said yesterday, he has been trying by "craft or courage" to temper the "hurry and overcrowding" of the world.

For a food that combines the virtues of being inexpensive, easily prepared and delicious when served in a large variety of ways the potato has an amazing ability to pose problems. The Irish potato famine a century ago helped produce one of the great migrations that shaped our population.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -The State Department said tonight the Soviet proclamation of sovereignty for East Germany was a "sheer facade."

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- At 11 o'clock this morning one of the most important -- and yet one of the most obscure -- committees in Washington met in Room 374 of the Old State Department Building on Pennsylvania Avenue.

The occasion was not one for adventure along new paths, but it is a safe bet that a great many of the patrons at last night's concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall were satisfied. The program was all Tchaikovsky's, and it is no risk to predict that Tchaikovsky is here to stay.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Atomic Energy Commission acknowledged today that radioactive strontium 90 could cause bone damage if it entered the human body.

Japanese medical authorities treating fishermen exposed to the radiation from the March 1 nuclear explosion at Bikini are seriously concerned because they have learned that the long-lived radioactive substance strontium 90 was in the ash which has fallen over wide areas of the Pacific, Tokyo broadcasts report.

Plans for altering the five-story and basement dwelling at 42 East Sixty-fifth Street into two duplex apartments and offices were announced yesterday in connection with the purchase of the property by Dr. Robert D. Huebner for occupancy. Assessed at $67,000, the property is 20 by 100 feet and was sold for cash in a deal negotiated by Mrs. C. T. Messing of the Madison Realty Company.

Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo set aside yesterday a guilty verdict against John A. Brullman, 31-year-old suspended policeman charged with violating the Civil Rights Act. He had been convicted in Brooklyn Federal Court Nov. 4 as a result of an alleged assault on a transit employe.
BONN, Germany, March 25 -West Germany's Government reacted quickly and scornfully tonight to the Soviet announcement that the East German Communist Government would become independent.
Following is the text of the telegram sent to President Eisenhower yesterday by Mayor Wagner:

The internationally known Swedish industrialist, Dr. Axel L. Wenner-Gren, has sold his one- third interest in Mexico's telephone and telegraph communications for a price understood to be in the neighborhood of $8,000,000. The purchasers were the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the L. M. Ericsson Company of Sweden, each of which previously had held close to a one-third voting interest in the Mexican system.
After a long fight to hold his city job and protect his pension rights, Nicholas Lana was formally retired yesterday by unanimous vote of the Board of Estimate.
The shipping industry sought yesterday to speed striking longshoremen back to work by putting into effect a "package" wage increase of 10 cents an hour, retroactive to last Oct. 1.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The first emergency grant of Federal money -- $200,000 -- was made today to help tie down the land in the dust storm areas of the Southwest.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee was encouraged today by a top-secret report on the progress of plans for protecting the United States against atomic attack.

Abraham Fleischer, who owns an auto body shop in Newark, N. J., plans to extend his operations to Paterson where he has purchased the former Paterson Motor Sales building at 33 McLean Boulevard from Rosenkopf Brothers. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (UP) -- Three former Communists gave testimony today contradicting a Congregational minister who denied last week he ever knowingly had supported the Communist cause.

Prices on the New York Stock Exchange declined yesterday for the third straight day and touched the lowest levels in a month. But there were signs of strength even in the recession. Volume dropped away -- 1,720,000 shares against 1,900,000 on Wednesday -- and there were rallies near the close in most parts of the list.

Formation of a special committee to watch how the Board of Higher Education conducts its study of possible subversive activities and respects individual rights was announced yesterday by the Alumni Association of Queens College, Inc.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 25 -- The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences tonight ended officially the 1953 movie awards season by presenting its "Oscar" statuettes for distinguished achievement to more than two dozen artists and technicians.

From the time a child discovers the wonderful process of thought and finds that he is capable of making decisions he is -- perhaps until some point late in life -- torn between the desire to conform and the urge to be different -to be individual.

SYRACUSE, N. Y. March 25 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals defeated the Boston Celtics, 109 -- 94, tonight in the opening game of the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division best-of-three play-offs before 5,353 fans.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- John S. Coleman, chairman of the Committee for a National Trade Policy, expressed satisfaction today over the reception given to officials of his group in a half-hour conference with President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -The Federal Trade Commission charged today that the "Fashion Academy Gold Medal Award" was a deceptive scheme.
NEW ORLEANS, March 25 -The business of being a father went out with oil lamps, a prominent sociologist told the National Catholic Family Life Conference here today.

Strength was evident in coffee and cocoa trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa rose the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions and coffee continued strong in the most active trading since Jan. 13. Commodity prices closed generally higher with cottonseed oil, rubber, zinc, lead, tin, potatoes and burlap stronger; silk lower, and sugar, soybean oil, hides, wool and copper mixed.

OTTAWA, March 25 -- Canada favors having the North Atlantic Treaty Organization discuss and agree as far as possible on the circumstances under which "massive retaliation" against an aggressor would be deemed justified.

Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, said yesterday that telephone operators at the Consolidated Edison Company had described Ralph Tapscott as chairman of the board within the last twenty-four hours.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- Earl H. Blaik, football coach and director of athletics at West Point, was among fourteen guests invited to a White House stag dinner tonight. Others invited were:
Rain and fog yesterday hampered operations at New York's airports, while strong winds caused small craft warnings to be hoisted along the coast.

PHOENIX, Ariz, March 25 -- "I've never seen you pitch better than you did today," Alvin Dark told Jim Hearn. "You had great stuff." This after Hearn had hurled six innings and was the loser, 3 -- 1, to the Baltimore Orioles in the Giants' final game here.
WHITE HAVEN, Pa., March 25 -- Ground was broken this afternoon for the 110-mile northeastern extension of the Pennsylvania Turnpike, first north-south leg of the superhighway.
VICTORIA, Spain, March 25 -Spain's regionalism came to the political fore today with the opening here of the trial of seventeen Basques charged with "seditious separatist activities."
A new method of dealing with teachers suspected of being members of the Communist party will go into effect before the end of the month. They will be charged with lying under oath.

New York and Chicago commercial banks should not wait for new legislation to revamp regulations that curb their earning power, but should move to correct things themselves, an authority on bank stock investment suggested yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 25 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today closed the record in hearings on a move to get Western Union Telegraph Company out of the international telegraph business.
WASHINGTON, March 25 -The Senate passed tonight a bill calling for more than $1,000,000,000 of reductions in Federal "luxury" taxes and other excises.

A particularly disturbing element of Prime Minister Nehru's criticism of the decision of Washington to extend military assistance to Pakistan has been his request for the withdrawal from Kashmir of those members of the United Nations ceasefire observation team who are United States nationals.

Some tentative conclusions on the benefits to a group of mentally retarded youngsters from a special pilot recreation project in upper Manhattan were presented last night by Dr. Howard M. Newburger. He addressed the Parents Association for Children With Retarded Mental Development, under whose auspices the program is being conducted.

We remind home cooks today of the culinary potentialities of old crop potatoes, which are excellent for baking or boiling or for use in a scallop or soup. Extra heavy supplies of this vegetable are on hand now and it is essential that they be marketed, as the new crop spuds already have begun to arrive.

The Association on American Indian Affairs, 48 East Eighty-sixth Street, warned yesterday that "homeless poverty" was in store for thousands of American Indians if a series of bills withdrawing Federal services was enacted by Congress.

PARIS, March 26 -- Mlle. Antoinette Brun, Roman Catholic social worker of Grenoble, appeared before a court in Riom today to answer charges of kidnapping "without violence" two Jewish war orphans, Gerald and Robert Finaly.

For the last three weeks Jakob van der Werff has been leading the life of a clairvoyant whose crystal ball has been so clouded by evil portents that he can look ahead for only a few days, if that, instead of for months as he's used to doing.
"The greatest collection of shooters, rebounders and general all-around basketball players ever to appear in one game will be presented at Madison Square Garden tonight."

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 26 -- The New York Giants broke camp at Phoenix, Ariz., today and flew here by chartered plane, but otherwise had a day off. They will begin their annual homeward tour against the Indians tomorrow.

MONTERREY, Mexico, March 26 (AP) -- A Mexican airliner, waved off from landing in a dust storm here last midnight, carried eighteen persons to death moments later in a flaming crash in the Salinas Mountains nearby. [Cross on map.]

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Harold E. Stassen, Director of the Foreign Operations Administration, left by plane for London today to help frame a new Western policy on trade with the Communist countries of Europe.

Because he considered the plaintiff's testimony "incredible perjury," City Court Justice A. David Benjamin in Brooklyn Supreme Court set aside yesterday a $75,000 award by a jury in a negligence action.
BERLIN, March 26 -- United States officials here reported today that more than 100,000 members had been purged from East Germany's Socialist Unity (Communist) party since the June riots of last year.
Parents, under proper conditions, make wonderful submarines. So say the Merry-Go-Rounders, an adult dance troupe that performs principally for children.
Teen-age vandalism against schools spurred authorities to action in metropolitan-area communities yesterday. One Nassau County judge promised jail terms for bomb pranksters.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.2 per cent to 110.8 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. An increase of 0.8 per cent in the average prices for farm products was the major reason for the advance, as the prices of all other commodities rose only 0.1 per cent on the average.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the Methodist Church said tonight that he thought the American public was "fed up" with Congressional investigations, except, perhaps, for "an investigation of the investigators."

Four teams began semi-final play here last night for the Curt H. Reisinger trophy and the eastern contract bridge team-of-four championship, and seventy-five teams entered the second and final round for the Commercial and Industrial team trophy.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., March 26 -- The New Jersey Department of Education is expected to give up before June 30 its extensive work in the field of educational television.
TOKYO, Saturday, March 27 (AP) -- Two more "atom dusted" fishing boats showing radiation effects from the Bikini test blast on March 1 were quarantined by Japanese authorities today.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- United States diplomatic authorities today found the Soviet proclamation of "full sovereignty" for East Germany the natural outgrowth of a campaign to embarass the West German Government and strengthen Moscow's own position in its shaky satellite.
The New York Central Railroad Company moved yesterday in Supreme Court here to curtail a proposed pre-trial examination of its president by Robert R. Young.

Locks and keys are curious devices. To borrow a phrase from the book-jacket blurbs, they may be considered on many levels: as necessary adjuncts to civilization, as evidence of man's mechanical genius or as a disease.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (UP) -- President Eisenhower urged Congress today to tighten up the Taft-Hartley law by giving the states broader jurisdiction over labor-management disputes.

Mrs. Le Brun Rhinelander heads the committee for the thirty-third annual New York Book Week of the American Merchant Marine Library Association, which will open on April 5. Throughout that week books will be collected to replenish the libraries of the United States Merchant Marine, lighthouse, lightships and Coast Guard stations.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, with active months off 2 to 5 points.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 26 -- Herewith some morning-after and random jottings on the Academy Awards, Hollywood's annual artistic and social display:

FORT PIERCE, Fla., March 26 (UP) -- Branch Rickey, general manager, today revealed an arrangement which will make the Pittsburgh Pirates the fastest-moving team in baseball -- off the field, at least.

BONN, Germany, March 26 -- President Theodor Heuss signed today the constitutional amendment permitting West Germany to rearm within the framework of the European Defense Community when that organization is established.

AINTREE, England, March 26 (UP) -- Coneyburrow, a bay gelding owned by I. E. Levy of Ireland, tonight was made a 7-to-1 favorite to win the 111th Grand National Steeplechase tomorrow over Aintree's four-mile-856-yard course with its thirty hazardous jumps.

TRENTON, March 26 -- The New Jersey Public Utility Commission today granted the Central Railroad of New Jersey the right to completely revise its main line passenger train schedules, effective April 25.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Gen. Paul Ely, French Chief of Staff, flew back to Paris today with a promise of twenty-five additional B-26 light bombers for the Indo-China war.

LONDON, March 26 -- Britain unveiled today her newest semisecret weapon, a 30-mm. aircraft cannon, which is already being mounted on a Supermarine Swift jet fighter. It is stated that the Swift will be able to pour "eight times more high explosives" on to an enemy target than had been possible with previous weapons.

The principle of moving a product into distribution by offering it in a tie-in with another is rapidly becoming an accepted merchandising method, even where the products are not even distantly related.
CAIRO, March 26 -- Pressure for an immediate return to civilian rule in Egypt came today from two influential segments of the community -- the press and the bar.
LONDON, March 26 -- There was a more cheerful tone on the securities markets here today. Quiet trading persisted but prices were a little firmer.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 26 -- Bao Dai, Vietnam Chief of State, made a vigorous denunciation of Communist aims in Vietnam here this morning. Addressing an assembly of several thousand Vietnamese national Army troops, he called for a new effort to defend the country from the Communist menace.

A thirty-two-foot frontage is being added to the already huge stage of the Jones Beach (L. I.) Marine Amphitheatre to bring the action of shows closer to the patrons. The extension also will provide much needed space for Guy Lombardo's forthcoming extensive production, "Arabian Nights."
KANSAS CITY, March 26 -- Former President Truman said today at the 125th national meeting of the American Chemical Society that he had a suggestion for President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Applications by Small business men for loans from the Small Business Administration have increased to a rate of 450 a month, Wendell B. Barnes, administrator of the agency, said today. He added that official estimates last fall were that the number of applicants would not exceed 250 a month.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, March 26 (UP) -- Enrique Morea of Argentina gained the men's singles final today in the international tennis tournament by rallying to defeat Budge Patty, 1950 Wimbledon champion from Los Angeles, 2 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Soviet Union will return in May and June thirty-eight small naval craft from the lend-lease ships it received from the United States during World War II. These will be a first installment of the several hundred lent to Russia.

MONTE CARLO, March 26 -- A spectacular last session drive today won the Monte Carlo team-of-four championship for the all-British contract bridge team of Mrs. Rixi Markus, Terence Reese, Boris Shapiro, Leslie Dodds and Kenneth Konstam.
LAUREL, Md., March 26 (AP) -- With Pete Moreno up, Double Speed, undefeated last year, will make his 1954 debut in the Cherry Blossom Stakes against ten other 3-year-olds tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (AP) -- Luther Lassiter, Elizabeth City, M. C., captured the unofficial world pocket billiard title tonight by beating Irving Crane, Binghamton, N. Y., 150 -- 120, in the final match of the two-week tourney.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The new stockpiling order was hailed by members of Congress from the mountain mining states. Senator Wallace F. Bennett and Arthur V. Watkins, Republicans of Utah, acclaimed it, Mr. Watkins calling it a "very wise move."
Price cutters are smiling. Some courts are beginning to frown on fair trade, a principle that permits a manufacturer to set minimum store prices in forty-five states.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 26 (AP) -- Gov. Goodwin J. Knight late today commuted the death sentence of Wesley Robert Wells, convict condemned to die April 9 for throwing a cuspidor at a guard, to life imprisonment.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., March 26 (AP) -- Tabor Academy of Marion, Mass., tonight upset Carteret School of West Orange, N. J., 63-56, in a semi-final of the annual Eastern States invitation scholastic basketball tournament.
The New York Tuberculosis and Health Association is providing technicians' salaries for one year so that Harlem Hospital will be able to start taking chest X-rays of all its patients on admission.

BONN, Germany, March 26 -- An interesting debate on rearmament is taking shape among war veterans and their families. It has been stimulated by the United States film "From Here to Eternity." This story of barracks life is enjoying a great success in Western Germany, impressing many and depressing even more.

SPARTANBURG, S. C., March 26 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Didrikson Zaharias gave the younger pros and amateurs a lesson in golf today with a par-71 that was good for a three-stroke lead in the first round of the second annual Peach Blossom - Betsy Rawls tournament.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 5.4 per cent below that in the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 1.5 per cent and orders down 3.6 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board recommended today that the Latin American routes of Pan American Grace Airways (Panagra) and Braniff Airways be consolidated.
WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- American Airlines said today it had halted discussions with the Mexican Government aimed at temporary permission to operate non-stop between New York and Mexico City.

The four - story apartment house accommodating twenty-four families at 105-25 Eighty-eighth Street in Woodhaven, Queens, has been sold by Joseph Briller to the Zegus Realty Corporation, represented by Myron Goldman, attorney.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- Two suitcases containing what he described as evidence of "a great conspiracy to sabotage the United States defense program in Europe" were hauled before a Federal grand jury today by Robert E. Bowen, 36-year-old engineer.
Business and civic groups were prompt to protest yesterday against Mayor Wagner's proposal to extend the city's 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services.

OTTAWA, March 26 -- The Opposition argued today that Canada's policy toward Communist China remained ambiguous despite attempts by her Prime Minister, Louis St. Laurent, and her Secretary of State for External Affairs, Lester B. Pearson, to clarify it.
TEL AVIV, Israel, March 26 -- David Ben-Gurion cautioned Israelis today not to expect the United Nations to protect their lives but to rely upon their own defensive power.

Women headed by Mrs. Robert E. Blum and Mrs. William G. Lord, co-chairmen, are serving on the executive committee for the preview of the exhibition of American paintings, known as the "American Panorama."

Senator McCarthy in Chicago declared that no one, high or low, Democrat or Republican, was going to stop him. I trust that President Eisenhower can recognize a declaration of war when he hears one and can see that war with the Senator must be fought as total war.

When the legislation permitting use of the stock-car sedan as a taxicab in New York streets was passed late last year a ninety-day waiting period to April 1 was allowed to give time for possible amendment. In the meantime a new city administration, a new City Council (but with many holdover members) and a new Police Commissioner have come along.
MOSCOW, March 26 -- Pravda gave its support today to a professor of biology who charged Prof. Trofim D. Lysenko with participating in a "mockery of Soviet science."

When children's sex education is under discussion, the points of view of specialists vary. Some contend it should be the sole responsibility of parents; some say that schools or other agencies should provide instruction for youngsters; still others feel it would be best for such agencies to provide classes for the parents and let them pass on the information to their boys and girls.
"We're lacquer-happy this season," designer Tommi Parzinger remarked as he pointed out the highlights of a new collection of furniture introduced this week at his showroom, 441 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Mrs. Annie Lee Moss, a middle-aged woman who testified she never had heard of Karl Marx, won temporary reinstatement today in her Army job.
