WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's proposal to put limited Government support behind private health insurance plans was attacked today by the United States Chamber of Commerce.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 26 -- Beating the Yankees is not an easy piece of business for the Dodgers, their new skipper, Walter (Smokey) Alston, is beginning to find out.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Diplomatic sources report that the United States is making headway in secret negotiations with Yugoslavia toward preparing a temporary settlement of the Trieste problem.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- Art Larsen, San Leandro, Calif., defeated Hal Burrows, Charlottesville, Va., in a 2-hour 45-minute five-set match in the Good Neighbor tennis tournament today. The score was 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 3.
Mayor Wagner has decided to take a brief and somewhat uneasy vacation in the Caribbean.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 26 -- The Latin-American republics, by an overwhelming majority, voted today to reinforce the protection traditionally given political refugees.

Gustav (Bubi) Scholz made a successful American debut last night, defeating Al Andrews of Superior, Wis., in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden. The decision in favor of the middleweight from Berlin, Germany, was unanimous.
Admission prices for the Metropolitan Opera Company's 1954-55 season have been readjusted, mainly in an upward direction.

"GRANDFATHER'S elder brother, Randolph, was just 20 in the spring of 1862, when General Johnston borrowed him and sent him up in a balloon to map McClellan's dispositions around Yorktown," J. Bryan 3d tells us in his new book, "Aircraft Carrier."* "Uncle Ran had never even seen a balloon before; this one was made of tarred cotton, lifted by hot air from a pine-knot fire.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- James L. Morrill, president of the University of Minnesota, today said teachers using the Fifth Amendment to avoid testimony regarding communism do a "deeply damaging disservice."
Goodhue Livingston Jr., a member of the City Planning Commission, urged Mayor Wagner yesterday to oppose the transfer of city-owned bus lines to private operators.

WEST NYACK, N. Y., March 26 -- A delinquent pet raccoon vandalized a large Victorian-style house on Strawtown Road early today.

MOSCOW, March 26 -- The Soviet military newspaper Red Star today described the explosion of a hydrogen bomb as reminiscent of possibly the greatest explosion ever witnessed by man -- that of the million-ton meteorite that fell in the remote Stony Tunguska River area of north central Siberia.

OBERLIN, Ohio, March 26 (AP) -- Dean Erwin Griswold of the Harvard Law School told an audience of 1,800 at Oberlin College today the privilege against self-incrimination embodied in the Fifth Amendment had a sound value that should be preserved.

The Government yesterday moved again to bring to trial William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, on charges of conspiracy to teach and advocate violent overthrow of the United States.

A seventeen-day cruise aboard the Empress of Scotland was lengthened by a day for 324 passengers yesterday when the returning ship ran afoul of the dock strike and could not quite reach her pier. The vessel, which was to have docked at 1:30 P. M., arrived on time, but high winds made docking inadvisable without the use of tugboats.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York City, denounced today the Middle East policy of the Eisenhower Administration.

Erich Leinsdorf brought the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra, of which he is the musical director, with the Rutgers University Choir and assisting soloists to Carnegie Hall last night, in a program that required both vocal and instrumental forces for its presentation.

The official organ of the Soviet trade unions, Trud, accuses four members of the United States Military Attache's staff in Moscow of being spies and demands their expulsion from the country. The story is that the four officers made notes of Soviet installations on a trip on the trans-Siberian railroad last September.

THE first angling migration of the season will get under way next Wednesday when the early season enthusiasts head for the Finger Lakes area and the opening of the special trout season there on Thursday morning.
The new supertanker Flying-A-New York was delivered yesterday by the Newport News Shipbiulding and Dry Dock Company to the Tide Water Associated Oil Company.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 26 -- Re-entry of the Matson Navigation Company into the Australia-New Zealand passenger service from California was submitted to stockholders today as a "top priority project."

The Toledo Edison Company, which serves more than half a million persons in a 2,500-square-mile area in Toledo, Ohio, and surrounding territory, reported yesterday a net income of $5,330,150 for 1953.

A few weeks ago Water commissioner Ford described the city's water-supply situation as "not bright." How he is forced to call it "serious." While there may be no immediate cause for alarm, water storage is only at 67.3 per cent of capacity when it should be at 85 to 90 per cent at this time of year.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- A Russian-born Chicago housewife, wearing a veil and speaking in whispers, refused today to say whether she knew if the Rev. John A. Hutchison had attended a Baltimore Communist meeting in 1936.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday that many of her friends felt they could no longer talk things over with those of different beliefs, or read anything remotely "leftist or Communist."

Soviet chess players in Buenos Aires repeated their success of the opening round with Argentina by again winning, 5 -- 3, in the second round, according to a report received yesterday from South American news sources.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 26 (AP) -- John T. Brady's Real Brother, the 19-20 favorite, survived a four-way photo finish for a nose decision in the $3,500 Shaw Purse before 12,906 at Gulfstream Park today.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A new stockpiling program calling for expanded purchases of some thirty-five to forty metals and minerals was ordered today by President Eisenhower.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., March 26 (UP) -- Georgia's Gov. Herman Talmadge said today that ending segregation in Southern schools would "create chaos not seen since Reconstruction days."
NEW ORLEANS, March 26 -- A high proportion of working mothers were accused here today of acting to destroy the American home.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- In a security move, the United States has restricted a woman observer at the United Nations to stay within a seventy-block mid-Manhattan area.

LONG BEACH, N. J., March 26 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said here tonight that substantial state aid for beach erosion work along New Jersey's 120-mile shore probbably would not be forthcoming for at least a year.
The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A is considering offers of sites in four cities for "a suitable home where all departments and units would be located under a single roof."

ALBANY, March 26 -- Dr. Frederick J. Moffitt of Albany was appointed today as Associate Commissioner of Education for elementary, secondary and adult education. He has been with the State Education Department since 1941.
"Parsifal" was performed at the Metropolitan last evening, with Ferdinand Frantz in his first appearance with the company as Gurnemanz.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 26 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union formally warned Iraq today that participation in any Western-sponsored defense pact for the Middle East would be regarded in Moscow as "an unfriendly and hostile act."
The old International Longshoremen's Association, already under heavy attack, suffered yesterday what may be its most damaging blow of all.

As the waterfront strike entered its fourth week yesterday an examiner for the National Labor Relations Board reported to that agency his finding that last December's representation election had been won by the old International Longshoremen's Association through fraud and violence.

Consolidated net income of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation amounted to $1,612,199, equal to 17 cents a common share, for the three months ended Feb. 28, the report disclosed yesterday. In the corresponding quarter of the previous year, net income was $2,860,241 or 31 cents a share.
To work or not to work is the dilemma faced by rank-and-file longshoremen in the current stoppage in the Port of New York.

Gross operating revenues and net income of the Southern Pacific Company for the first two months of this year were 16.6 per cent and 45.4 per cent, respectively, below the results attained in the corresponding period of 1953.
HARTFORD, March 26 -- A three-member committee was appointed today by the Connecticut Development Commission to study the "present status and future possibilities of harbor development in the state."

The Public Service Commission yesterday rejected a proposal by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad that it participate in hearings by the Interstate Commerce Commission on a higher commuter fare.

The Senate's action on the first revenue bill of this session, the bill cutting excise taxes, is strictly in line with historic precedent. The original House version of the bill provided for a one-year extension of present levies on alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, gasoline and automobiles and certain accessories.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., March 26 -- Prince Bernhard of The Netherlands said here today that one of the serious drawbacks of the present North Atlantic Treaty Organization's air forces was that they did not have a standard all-weather fighter plane.
Work by two contemporary Japanese printmakers can be seen in New York galleries.
ROME, March 26 -- Thirty-five extreme Left - Wing Senators asked the Government today to declare Mrs. Clare Boot Luce, United States Ambassador, persona non grata.

BERLIN, March 26 -- There are growing indications that Moscow is preparing to put into effect the plan of Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, for an all-Europe security system to rival the European Defense Community.
VITORIA, Spain, March 26 -- Their six lawyers demanded in court here today the acquittal of seventeen Basques indicted for activities against the Spanish Government.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 26 (AP) -- A runaway, pilotless jet plane flying towards San Diego was herded back to sea by the pilot of another Navy jet today.
CAIRO, March 26 -- Mustafa Nahas, veteran leader of the Egyptian Wafd party and former Premier, was released from house arrest tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, urged the Government today to bring pressure on the Baltimore Ohio Railroad to force speedier repayment of a $65,000,000 Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan.

ASHLAND, Ky., March 26 -- Former Vice President Alben W. Barkley said tonight at his home in Paducah that he would announce tomorrow afternoon his decision on whether to seek the Democratic nomination for Senator in the Kentucky primaries Aug. 7.

The Detroit Red Wings, who recently wrapped up their record sixth straight pennant in the National Hockey League, yesterday placed three players on the United Press all-star team for the 1953-54 season.

Henri Deering was in fine form for his piano recital last night in Town Hall, and for the greater part of the evening he demonstrated experienced, well-routined playing. He was at his best in a French group, where he presented short pieces by Poulenc, Ravel, Faure and Debussy in a relaxed, urbane manner.

More than 200 of America's leading women track and field athletes will compete in the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships tonight at the 102d Engineers Armory, Broadway and 168th Street.

JERICHO, Jordan, March 26 -- Foreign Minister Hussein Fakhry el Khalidy welcomed today as "recognition of the correctness of the Jordanian position" the cancellation by Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, of his request that Jordan meet Israel in high-level bilateral talks on armistice questions.
BERLIN, March 26 -- The Soviet Union has agreed on four-power talks regarding ways to ease conditions of imprisonment for the seven surviving top Nazis being held in Spandau Prison.

In an uptown Manhattan investment deal, the five-story apartment house at 276-78 Sherman Avenue, near West 207th Street and Broadway, has been purchased by the Bernef Realty Corporation, a client of Saul Berger, broker.

WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP) -- The House Banking Committee, meanwhile, working late into the night, put a final stamp of approval on an omnibus housing bill aimed at spurring private industry to take up where public housing left off. The bill is distinct from the appropriation for low-rent public housing projects.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives voted today to kill the public housing program as soon as all previously made commitments had been met.
SYRACUSE, March 26 -- Demonstrating all-around proficiency, Ohio State's team held a substantial lead in the National Collegiate swimming championships tonight at the Syracuse University pool.

Dr. T. Duckett Jones, medical director of the Helen Hay Whitney Foundation, asserted here yesterday that science was on the threshold of important biological developments that ultimately would reverse the process of hardening of the arteries.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- An 11.3 per cent cut in the Atomic Energy Commission's budget request for the 1955 fiscal year was approved today by the House of Representatives Appropriations Committee.

Because.security. duty under' rugged field conditions presents morale problems often more.-, difficult to handle: than those - arising from. actjual combat, Red' Cross, at the request of the' ..De.lense Department, as stepped up its well}ire lrogram for American troops: in the:Far East andIas initiaed supplemental' recreao '. tion activities for isolated un.i'f.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 26 -- A proposal that the United States and the Soviet Union adopt a "standstill agreement" freezing armament levels was made today by David F. Cavers, Associate Dean of the Harvard Law School.

Two famous coin collections have been combined by Stack's Auction Galleries for public sale next month at Steinway Hall, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street. Among the 3,500 American and foreign coins to be auctioned will be an 1804 silver dollar, a rarity that had been called "the king of American silver coins."
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy picked another fight with the Eisenhower Administration tonight -- this time over cheese instead of Communists.
ALBANY, March 26 -- Governor Dewey today signed a bill authorizing the Public Service Commission to require that all intercity buses be equipped with speed-recording devices.

Herbert W. Rogers has been elected president of the Lithium Corporation of America, producers and sellers of lithium compounds, succeeding the late K. M. Leute. Mr. Rogers had been secretary and general counsel since 1941.

Events today: 'Norma," Metropolitan Opera, 2 1. AL; "Carmen," City Center, 2:30; Myra Hess, pianist, Carnegie Hall 3; Dorothy White, singer and pianist, Brookly Academy, 3; lbert Baker, organist, Temple Emanuel, 4; "Gala Performance," 1Vietropolitan Opeffa, 8:30; 'lie Fledemaus," City Center, 8:15, .and p 'hfiharmoc-Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos conducting, Laszlo ,Varg, 'cellist, Carnegie ll'2ll; 8:45.

Mayor Wagner paid tribute last night to the aid of voluntary private welfare organizations as a supplement to public aid for those in need. In an address over Station WNYC, he cited in particular the New York Catholic Charities, which is seeking $2,515,000 to meet the minimum needs of 189 charitable agencies in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

NEW DELHI, India, March 26 -- The Government announced today severe restrictions on the free movement within Indian territory of officials from Goa, Portuguese settlement south of Bombay. The action was said to be in retaliation against similar treatment accorded to Indian visitors to Goa.

BOSTON, March 26 -- The Pilot, official weekly of the Boston Roman Catholic Archdiocese, "reserved acceptance" today of a report that 4,000,000 American Catholics had joined Protestant churches in the last ten years.

CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- The defending champion, Bob Brady of San Francisco, and Vic Hershkowitz of Brooklyn scored victories today in the semi-finals of the United States handball singles tournament.

CHICAGO, March 26 -- The grain market reflected contrary and conflicting price currents today. Both gains and losses were registered in all pits except that of wheat. Wheat rallies failed to hold, and further disappointment was registered in regard to the easy tendency in cash wheat, May reflecting this especially.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 26 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer of Latrobe, Pa., who recently returned to Wake Forest College after a Coast Guard hitch, clipped par by seven strokes today to take a one-stroke lead in the opening round of the $10,000 Azalea open golf tournament.

There has been much said and written concerning the necessity of building good labor relations between the immediate parties, management and labor, instead of expecting Congressional committees or federal and state laws, such as the Taft-Hartley Act, to do the job.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- The manner in which the experimental Navy plane that is to take off straight up will land on its tail is still blanketed by security. But a patent issued this week discloses a measure that might be applied in case of engine failure at an altitude too low for maneuvering into a safe glide.

WASHINGTON, March 26 -- A tax policy to be applied on presently tax-free Federal power projects is being studied by the Administration. This move is another in the continuing reversal by Republican leaders of the public power policy developed over twenty years by Democratic Administrations.
Growing popularity of felt in the apparel trades has created a market for fine Italian wool felts, according to Miss Della Grattan, head of the D. M. Grattan advertising agency.

BALTIMORE, March 26 -- Reversing an earlier decision, Baltimore longshoremen today joined those in other East Coast ports in a boycott of ships diverted from New York's strikebound waterfront. The Baltimore longshoremen set a deadline of 6 P. M. today for the embargo.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 26 (AP) -- Porterhouse has suffered a bruise on his foot but his trainer, Charles Whittingham, said today he expected it to cause little delay in the colt's training. The bruise is on the inside quarter of the right forefoot.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., March 26 -- Trofim D. Lysenko "has caused great and enduring harm to Soviet agriculture," Prof. Theodosius Dobzhansky, Columbia University geneticist, declared in a report circulated at a conference that opened at Arden House here today.

It may be different, but it will be entirely logical to see women civilians doing guard duty at school crossings beginning next September. Some three hundred cities in the United States are using civilians to good advantage in this work. A few cities have been doing it for twenty years.

One of man's most persistent afflictions -- the common hangover -- is the subject of a new research project at Yale University's Center of Alcohol Studies. Dr. Selden D. Bacon, director of the center, reported this yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Committee on Alcoholism in the Statler Hotel.

The management of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad announced yesterday that it had filed a complaint with the Securities and Exchange Commission alleging that the anti-management forces of Patrick B. McGinnis had used misleading proxy material.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- House and Senate conferees squared away today for a battle over two key provisions added by the Senate to the $1,000,000,000 excise tax reduction bill.

With a mixture of Communist make-believe and the old Russian knack for building Potemkin villages the Soviet Government proclaims the Soviet zone in Germany, now parading as the "German Democratic Republic," to be a sovereign state free to decide, "at its own discretion," its internal and external affairs.
NEWARK, March 26 (AP) -- The criminal bribery complaints against an official of the Jarka Stevedoring Company of New York and three longshoremen were dismissed today at the request of the Government.
The following is a round-up of new do-it-yourself items that may be of interest to the homemaker:
CHICAGO, March 26 (AP) -- Eastern teams, led by Cornell and Columbia, paced the tenth annual National Collegiate fencing tournament through the opening-day three-weapon competition today.

TOKYO, March 26 -- The lower House of the Japanese Diet (Parliament) adopted today two of the most controversial measures of the conservative Government's legislative program. They impose severe penalties on teachers and academic organizations engaging in political activities.
The joining together of Madison House and Hamilton House, two famous old settlements, into Hamilton-Madison House is an occasion to review some of the history of their work on the lower East Side.
MONTEREY, Calif., March 26 -- Russian material, including newspapers, periodicals and textbooks, in the library of the Army Language School here has been removed for "review."

Cocoa prices shot up the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions at the opening of trading for the second consecutive day yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, and did not waver from that 100 point rise. Short covering and dealer buying were induced by reports that European countries were making additional purchases of actuals, further reducing tight supplies.

A leading manufacturer of kosher foods has just set up one of the first kosher test kitchens in this country. In doing so, the B. Manischewitz Company in its Jersey City plant has applied ancient dietary laws in a setting as modern as tomorrow. It is interesting to see how old prescriptions of the Jewish religion have been followed in a present-day commercial test kitchen that at first glance looks no different from any other.
"The Forgotten Pioneer: The Life of Davy Crockett," by Marion Michael Null, is the only book published today. Issued by Vantage Press, it sells for $3.50.
WASHINGTON, March 26 -- President Eisenhower has decided to let the American people see a motion picture of what its most terrifying weapon, the hydrogen bomb, can do.

Because the 1954 United States open golf championship will be played at Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, N. J., the Metropolitan Golf Association has found it necessary to designate six courses for the sectional qualifying rounds.

Stocks yesterday continued the recovery that started in the Thursday lunch hour. By the close The New York Times combined average had regained 1.87 points of its four-day loss and stood at 190.83, just 3.80 points below the March 19 peak.
LEWISTON, Me., March 26 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's recent speeches "have the hard ring of Hitlerism behind them," Averell Harriman said tonight.
Dr. George N. Shuster, president of Hunter College declared yesterday that failure to respect the dignity of man was undermining our concepts of citizenship.
ROME, March 26 -- Dr. Konrad Adenauer, West German Chancellor, obtained from Premier Mario Scelba today a promise that Italy would ratify the European Defense Community Treaty as soon as possible.
We were all very much shocked to learn of the sudden passing of Harold Hinton. He was a true newspaper man if ever I knew one.

MEXICO CITY, March 26 -- Mikhail Samoilov, commercial counselor of the Soviet Embassy here, recently dropped a hint at the Ministry of Agriculture that the Soviet Union might like to buy Mexican meat.

LONDON, March 26 -- Judged by preliminary statements, the British and United States Governments will enter the Western Big Three talks here next week sharply divided on the merit of widening East-West trade.

OMAHA, March 26 (AP) -- The Republican National Chairman, Leonard W. Hall, said today that the dispute of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, with the Army had hurt. Then he put down the prime 1954 campaign issues as the economic well-being of the nation and the "never ending" battle with communism.
Dungarees and overalls were in vogue yesterday at Coney Island as workmen prepared the resort for the bathing suit season.
NORMAN, Okla., March 26 (AP) -- Three defending champions grappled their way through the quarter-finals of the twenty-fourth annual national collegiate wrestling tournament tonight before 2,500 fans.
Demolition work for the new $14,300,000 State Supreme Court Building in downtown Brooklyn will get under way soon and is expected to be finished by October or November.
Scrutiny of all public places in the city in a drive to close firetraps was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr.

"THE CRYSTAL," yearbook of the Port Jefferson (L. I.) High School, is ready to go to press -- except for two important pages. These have been left open, as they are each year, for a report on an annual event that is a significant part of the school year and which will come this year on April 12 to 15, the senior class trip to Washington.

WESTERNS have preoccupied Hollywood continuously over the forty-six years since Broncho Billy made the original horse opera in 1908, but a 1954 feature aptly titled "The Cowboy" is claimed to be the first authentic story of its subject.
SCHENECTADY, March 27 -- A third union entered the battle today to represent 20,000 production workers at the General Electric Company plant here.
TRENTON, March 27 -- Political observers seem to agree that the 1954 State Legislature is still in low gear.
ALBANY, N. Y., March 27 -- Appointment of three committees of the New York State Bar Association was announced this week by Hunter L. Delatour, the president. The appointments were as follows:

IT is a long time, in fact over a generation, since it has been possible to take seriously any American poet as both an accomplished and a genuinely popular artist. The last writers to lay claim to such a role were Robert Frost, Amy Lowell and Carl Sandburg.

BOTH the French command and the American military observers in Indo-China are agreed that if the war against the Communists is to be won it will have to be won by a larger and more effective Vietnamese military force.
A Brooklyn magistrate yesterday told the parents of seven youths, arrested for rowdy acts at 3 A. M., that putting them in a room with a couple of "husky cops" would cure their behavior.

ARTURO TOSCANINI'S way with Beethoven's Missa Solemnis is justly celebrated for its fire, its almost metaphysical identification with the spiritual elements of the music, and its sheer propulsive power.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 27 -- Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to Egypt, was named today by the University of Notre Dame as the recipient of its Laetare Medal for 1954.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The fat is out of John L. Lewis' welfare funds.

A more selective admissions policy; provision for improving the quality of teaching through lighter work loads and greater rewards for excellence; adequate use of educational television as an extension service; lighter teaching loads for faculty members doing outstanding research; and greater recognition for superior students -- these were among the recommendations made by the self-examination committee created at the University of North Carolina.

A college-type "alumni survey" to discover what graduates are doing after five years out in the world is being undertaken by the Los Angeles City school system. The survey's objective is to ascertain the effectiveness of vocational guidance in the schools.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 27 -- Much behind-the-scenes jockeying is going on to determine the Democratic party's candidate for Lieutenant Governor in the election next November.
The recent reduction from 3 1/4 per cent to 3 per cent in the prime rate on bank loans to business will have an inevitable impact on bank earnings this year.
Signs that the business decline has abated are noted by the National. Association of Purchasing Agents.

IT is a curious fact that the British, in tarrying a couple of centuries in India, seem to have stifled much of India's gift for letters. India has, of course, several ancient literatures of her own, and I know, too, that contemporary novelists like Mulk Raj Anand and R. K. Narayan have had some success in depicting various facets of present-day Indian life.
The World Jewish Congress, in a special report issued yesterday, emphasized that the status of Jews in the Arab world was "unrelievedly dark."

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- The Eisenhower Administration is beginning to be plagued by an exodus of "one-year men." This is a term rather broadly applied to those who put limitations on the time they were prepared to give the Government service when they took jobs in the rosy dawn of a new Republican regime.

Those watchdogs of the retail trade, the resident buying offices, see no reason for pessimism. In constant touch with their stores throughout the country and never given to undue optimism, they feel that sales in the first half of this year will approximate the very good figures of 1953.

Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden, tournament chairman of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association, announced yesterday a list of tournaments for this year. The association was organized four years ago for the low-handicap golfers of Westchester and Fairfield Counties.
Six youthful television panelists gave varying opinions yesterday on the success of the recent Big Four Conference in Berlin. One rated it an "absolute failure."

HONG KONG, March 27 -- Mao Tse-tung who failed to appear at a number of important functions in Peiping after reportedly attending a Chinese Communist Politburo meeting last Dec. 24, suddenly reappeared on the public scene this week.

SAIGON, March 27 -- Prince Buu Loc, Premier of Vietnam, returned here today from Paris where he has been heading the Vietnamese delegation engaged in discussion with the French on the implementation of independence for Vietnam.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 27 (UP) -- The White Sox hammered Robin Roberts for six runs in the fourth inning on five hits, two hit batsmen and an error and went on to defeat the Phillies, 12 to 4, today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 27 -- The best news for the Southwest was a break in the drought. Generous rains fell over much of the district. The Federal Reserve Bank's index of department stores, using the 1947-49 years as a base, show that daily overage sales, seasonally adjusted, are 9 per cent larger than the base period, compared with a 15 per cent gain a year ago.

PADUCAH, Ky., March 27 -- Alben W. Barkley announced tonight that he would attempt to regain his seat in the United States Senate. The 76-year-old former Vice President of the United States said he was renouncing the life of a country squire to seek the Democratic nomination in the Kentucky primaries Aug. 7.

TOKYO, March 27 -- The case of the Bikini fishermen has become Japan's newest political football. In the press, the Diet and public forums, it has been kicked around more than alleged corruption in the Yoshida Government or Japanese acceptance of the United States Mutual Security Assistance agreement.

MOST of us have wondered at one time or another just how the mind of man is going to stand up against the utterly alien stresses and strains of space travel. We need wonder no more. Hollywood has just solved this most troublesome of all questions implicit in space travel.

There were indications last week of a critical test ahead for Western policy in the Far East. At stake in the test are issues with far-reaching implications for Western security in Southeast Asia and in Europe, and for relations among the members of the Western coalition, particularly between the U. S. and France.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 27 -- Two Princeton undergraduates have had the ingenuity and the luck to set up a series of weekly interviews with United Nations leaders over the campus radio station WPRU.

IN his compact, readable "The Gentleman of Renaissance France," W. L. Wiley, Professor of French at the University of North Carolina, has offered us a truly praiseworthy book. Copiously footnoted and well-provided with illustrations, bibliography and index, it is basically a work of scholarship.

Those who believe that, in today's era of specialization, the family doctor is a thing of the past should have been in Cleveland last week at the sixth annual meeting of the American Academy of General Practice.

WRITTEN with detachment and fortified by a massive documentation, "A Study of Bolshevism" is a most illuminating exposition of Bolshevik ideology. It not only has theoretical importance. It has a direct bearing on a realistic appraisal of current Soviet policy toward the West.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 27 -- A Suffolk County yachtsman, V. Aldric Beere of East Patchogue, who does most of his cruising in Block Island and Cape Cod waters, today was elected commander of District No. 3 of the United States Power Squadrons.
The arrest of two men and two women was said yesterday by District Attorney Sidney O. Simonson of Staten Island to have ended a policy ring that did a business of $500,000 a year.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, March 27 (AP) -- Col. John C. Robinson, a veteran American Negro aviator who flew for Ethiopia for several years, died today of injuries from a plane crash two weeks ago.

For some months Wall Street has been watching the course of the "dark blue chips" -- the standard investment-type common stocks used in calculating most market averages -- and wondering how long their prices can continue to rise and their yields to fall.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The unemployment figures for March have been gathered in the outlying precincts. They will be computed and published in a week or two. If they show another increase, political pressures for more economic stimulants will rise, too, for serious unemployment is bad politics.

NOTHING could attest more vigorously the substance and stamina of the New York City Ballet than the perilous season it has just weathered. Everything, including itself, placed obstacles in its way, and some of us who cherish it highly are not breathing easily yet.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., March 27 -- Bard College will start a Ninety-fifth Anniversary Fund drive next week. The goal will be $100,000 in working funds, to be used chiefly for student scholarships.

"TV Takes to Color," by Jack Gould (Feb. 28) names the primary colors as red, blue, and green. In school more than fifty years ago I learned the primary colors as red, blue and yellow. Green is made by mixing blue and yellow.

FIFTY years ago there was a school of fiction that pictured the South as the fairest land under heaven. Today there is a school that pictures the South as a sort of Krafft-Ebing land of psychopathia sexualis. William T. Polk, in "Southern Accent," satirizes both schools, seeks to picture the region as it actually is, to tell what it is doing, thinking and becoming.

The busiest basketball team in the land will be in Madison Square Garden day and night today. It is the Harlem Globetrotters, famed for court monkey-shines as well as solid basketball. The opponents will be the 1954 College All-Americans, whose line-up will include many of the recent season's foremost players.

IT has become increasingly apparent to observers of the home furnishings markets that so-called modern design is entering a new phase. More surface decoration, more superficial ornamentation have become the rule.

ONE might reasonably expect that the normal course of events in 1954 would produce a great national debate on the foreign policy of the United States. This has happened before when an election year coincided with a time of appraisal of far-reaching and costly action by the United States abroad.

THE installment plan will be extended to air transportation on May 1 when Pan American World Airways begins to sell tickets on time. After making a 10 per cent down payment, passengers will be able to take off on their trips, with up to twenty months to pay the balance.
AUGUSTA, Ga., March 27 (AP) -- Private Schine was labeled "a good soldier" by his commanding general today after his graduation.
Former Senator William C. Benton of Connecticut declared yesterday that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy would be "overwhelmingly defeated" if the Wisconsin Republican were up for re-election today.
The Health Department is reminding landlords of multiple dwellings that they have until April 1 to post their name and address, or that of a responsible representative, on their premises in the city.
VOLUNTEER SERVICE PHOTOGRAPHERS invite 200 amateur photographers to participate in a picture-taking cruise of New York Harbor, by tugboat, on the afternoon and evening of Saturday, May 22.
A Brooklyn youth was burned to death early yesterday morning when the automobile in which he was riding struck another and burst into flames on the Belt Parkway near Fresh Creek Bridge in Canarsie.

TORONTO, March 27 -- Tony Leswick scored a third-period goal tonight that put the Detroit Red Wings on the road to a 3-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and a 2-1 lead in their Stanley Cup play-off semi-finals.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 (AP) -- A campaign to raise funds for a $10,000,000 heart and cancer hospital in memory of Jim Thorpe was begun tonight on the eve of the first anniversary of the death of the famed Indian athlete.
ALBANY, March 27 -- A bill outlawing the sale of switchblade knives in the state was signed today by Governor Dewey.

Borough President Hulan E. Jack of Manhattan gave the name of Nathan D. Perlman Place last week to the area of Fifteenth to Seventeenth Street, between First and Second Avenues, in honor of the late Special Sessions justice.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Spruille Braden, former Assistant Secretary of State, said today that his recent attack on "collectivists" in Government was not aimed at the "fine group" of Foreign Serive career officers.

TREACHERY lurks at the "corner" of the Netherlands coast around which ships turn on their way to German ports. Tides run swiftly between the islands, storms make up suddenly, the surf thunders over reefs and sandbanks which shift without warning.
ITHACA, N. Y., March 27 -- The long-range development of Cornell University will progress this spring through a $22,000,000 building program.

TRENTON, March 27 -- Rider College has become the first institution of higher education in New Jersey and probably in the United States to offer a regular course of instruction for blind telephone operators.

NEW DELHI, India, March 20 -- Neediest peasants in fifty- four villages near New Delhi have up-to-date plows and other farm tools because of the enterprise of a St. Paul, Minn., insurance company, whose agents sold "aid for India" along with policies in six states.

When the New York State Board of Regents holds its eighty-seventh convocation in Albany on April 8 and 9, prominent educators from the state and nation will gather to celebrate a triple anniversary. The state will observe the 170th anniversary of the establishment of the Regents, the 100th anniversary of the founding of a separate Department of Public Instruction and the fiftieth anniversary of the creation of the present State Education Department.
MEXICO CITY, March 27 (UP) -- Gary Cooper said tonight he would consider making a movie in Russia only if it created better understanding among the nations of the world.

PRIMITIVE tribes and even civilized nations have long understood the subtle cruelties of ostracism and banishment. Cut off from contact with people or places held dear, offenders against their kind have been left from earliest times to "wander in outer darkness" with small hope of returning again to the warmth and friendliness of their former life.

LONDON, March 27 -- Harold E. Stassen arrived here today by air from Washington with a small group of experts. They will confer Monday with British and French Government teams on how to expand nonstrategic trade with the Soviet bloc.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- Two of the best known Soviet military commanders, Marshal Ivan S. Konev and Army Gen. Vasily I. Chuikov, have participated in the Ukrainian Communist party Congress this week in Kiev.

IN port, Cope, master of the Dauntless, was a bit of a braggart, hot-tempered, suspicious, irked by details of the fishing business. At sea, he was a different man: a cool, vigilant skipper, devoted to his ship and men. His shore grievances, imagined or not, were carried away by the winds.
Civil rights questions were examined yesterday by 400 college students at the Columbia University Student Council's Bicentennial Conference on Rights of Free Americans.

Whether it's cloudy or sunny as June, whether it rained last night or brought a few desperate snowflakes, you can walk into any country or suburban hardware store and think it's mid-May. The snow shovels are out of sight, and the coarse salt and the wild-bird seed.

NEXT Sunday, with Bernard De Voto as narrator, the Museum of Natural History and the C. B. S. television network will reconstruct history and take viewers of "Adventure" on a guided tour of the 2,500-mile journey of the Lewis and Clark Expedition.
The 1953 Legislature violated the State Constitution in its reapportionment of a Senate district in Queens, James M. Power, president of the Board of Elections declared yesterday.

One feature of the new revenue bill that should appeal to those who are seeking, by amendment of the Internal Revenue Code, to benefit taxpayers in the lower brackets is the provision for the reduction of double taxation of dividend income.

WASHINGTON -- The capital will hold its annual cherry-blossom festival this week, and in connection with the event another monument is being added to Washington's landscape. This is a twenty-ton ornamental granite garden lantern, a gift from Japan to the United States symbolizing the renewed friendship between the two nations and commemorating the 100th anniversary of the treaty that opened Japan to United States trade.

THE British film-makers who have traveled to such far places as New Zealand in search for authenticity, this week are starting on a jaunt to St. Johann near Kitzbuhel in Austria where shooting on "The Divided Hearts" is slated to start.

ON Wednesday the circus comes to this town and soon, in small towns all over the country, children will be getting up early, hoping to see the elephants, the ponies, the red-and-gold wagons moving through the spring dawn on the way to the big tent.

OUR books and magazines are full of shark stories, most of them exciting. Many erroneous or downright false. Many tell of gory battles with sharks of all sizes, others concentrate on ways and means of catching them. Surprisingly little of this literature provides any real information about the true ways and habits of sharks or about what interesting animals they are.

According to the President, the scientists who participated in the test on March 1 of what the Atomic Energy Commission vaguely describes as an "atomic device" are themselves astonished at the magnitude of the effect. Had it not been for the contamination by radioactive dust of tuna fish caught by Japanese fishermen who think they were eighty miles from the blast we might be less alarmed by the President's comment than we are.
WINNIPEG, Man., March 27 (Canadian Press) -- Canadian wheat exports for February totaled 10,600,000 bushels, down 3,200,000 from January and 4,000,000 below the ten-year average of February loadings.

Albert C. Young, who has succeeded Harold D. Schaefer as commander of the Brooklyn Power Squadron, heads a group of operations and instruction courses that complete the winter program and lead into the fitting-out period and the pleasure boating season ahead.

UNLESS determination withers -- always a possibility, considering the hard facts of contemporary theatre life -- there is going to be a repertory group functioning in our midst next season. At least, that is the impression you gather from Leo Kerz, the set designer, who, with the Pulitzer prize-winning playwright, Joseph Kramm, and Harry Horner, another designer of sets, is plotting the establishment of The Ensemble.
I have just read the two opposing views presented in your fine debate on church architecture, "The Modern Church -- Or Traditional" (March 14).

AMERICANS planning a European tour rarely lack for advice on what to do and what not to do on the Continent. Sometimes the supply offered by friends and relatives is so overwhelming the desperate victim abandons any attempt to remember it.

HONG KONG, March 25 -- Communist China has again called a halt in the "blind drifting" of peasants into the cities. According to the Peiping People's Daily, a directive was issued jointly by the Ministries of Interior and Labor March 12.

NORMAN, Okla., March 27 (AP) -- The Oklahoma Aggies swept the twenty-fourth annual national collegiate wrestling tournament tonight, winning three individual championships and far outdistancing the field with 32 points.

The inquiry of the McCarthy committee into the case of McCarthy vs. the Army is supposed to begin this week. It has already been postponed too long. But no matter what the reasons may be for delay, they must be overcome so that the hearings can begin at the earliest possible moment.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A Congressional mission that flew 30,000 miles to analyze Far Eastern situations declared today that the security -- even the survival -- of the whole free world was under real threat in Asia.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 27 -- The Commander in Chief of French Union forces in Indo-China appealed personally today to the Vietminh commander to agree to the evacuation of wounded from besieged Dienbienphu.

LONDON, March 12 -- The great reptiles of the past probably suffered from a form of glandular disorder that afflicted them with hideous horny plates and spikes and then killed them, according to Dr. William E. Swinton, dinosaur expert.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., March 27 -- The Long Island Association is on record as opposing the "absentee management and ownership" of the Long Island Rail Road by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

CHICAGO, March 27 (AP) -- Hawaiian-born Carl (Bobo) Olson, 9-5 favorite, will make his first world middleweight title defense against the pride of Cuba, the world welterweight champion, Kid Gavilan, at Chicago Stadium Friday night.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A compromise bill vesting sweeping new powers in the Attorney General to tap wires in suspected spy cases was completed today for House consideration next week.

When four state Governors leave San Francisco tomorrow aboard a Military Air Transport Service plane for a two-week visit to Korea they will be accompanied by Eugene J. Taylor, executive assistant to Dr. Howard A. Rusk, president of the American-Korean Foundation.
The future of Indo-China, and perhaps of Southeast Asia, was hanging in the balance last week.

LONDON, March 27 -- When Queen Elizabeth II comes home May 15 from her tour of her Pacific dominions, church bells will ring and the day may be proclaimed a national holiday. This sceptered isle will try to show its sovereign that it can be almost as demonstrative as those volatile Australians and hearty New Zealanders, among whom she has been visiting these last three months.

EARLIER this month the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation devoted a program of two and one-half hours to the plays of Eugene O'Neill. Some able Canadian actors, assisted by Karl Malden from New York, acted scenes from eight of the O'Neill dramas under the analytical direction of Rupert Caplan.

THE latest technical intruder in the so-called "battle of the 'Scopes" -- meaning, of course,the present turmoil over the new shapes and gadgets for movie screens -- is an interesting do-dad developed by two brothers.

ALBANY -- Governor Dewey cleared the way last week for a major addition to the state's recreational facilities when he signed a bill authorizing construction of a scenic parkway up Prospect Mountain at the foot of Lake George.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- A heavy schedule of pre-Easter clothing promotions helped spur store traffic this week despite uncertain and on a few days unfavorable weather. Spring promotions of household and gardening appliances and materials contributed to the increase in activity.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 27 -- St. Petersburg's multi-million-dollar "Blueprint for Tomorrow" has received tentative approval from the City Council and some phases of the ambitious plan may be under way by fall.
STAMFORD, Conn., March 27 -- This month, for the first time since last September, employe lay-offs in the diversified industries of the city are decreasing instead of continuing to rise sharply.

"BHOWANI JUNCTION" (see page 1) is John Masters' fourth novel about India. A fifth has been written, and with the presses turning at the usual rate, this should be out next year. Five down, as it were, and with how many left to go? Only thirty. Yes, that is right, thirty. All being well, the Savage family of Mr. Masters' tales will overpower by sheer numbers the Forsythes of John Galsworthy.
ALBANY, March 27 -- Next year's Legislature will have nineteen proposed amendments to the State Constitution to pass upon.

WALTER ALSTON, the new manager of the Dodgers, was formally indoctrinated into the Brooklyn system of doing things a little more than a week ago. He had just started to outline his plans for juggling pitchers so that all of them would get work of some sort during a four-game series with the Yankees, when Walter O'Malley, the president of the club, casually interrupted.

DORMANT pruning of raspberries and blackberries is one of the earliest spring tasks for the home fruit grower. Since it can be done now, it helps to satisfy the normal urge at this time of year to be doing something in the garden.

LANCASTER, Pa. -- The two children who came along for the ride on the conducted week-end bus tour of the Pennsylvania Dutch country where the Plain People live and thrive, describe the land of the Amish and the Mennonite brethren as a kind of dream world of long ago, a country they might have conjured up, in their youthful visions but never expected to see.

HERE is the best volume on Chinese thought thus far written in the United States. It is a symposium with nine participants, all but two of them Americans and all but three American-trained. It is one of a series of volumes made possible by the Ford Foundation, and planned by anthropologists who are concerned with the contemporary impact of one culture upon another.

In 1951 three University of Wisconsin scientists, Drs. Arthur D. Hasler, Oscar Brynildson and W. T. Helm, reported that the water of bog lakes could be chemically treated so that they would support rainbow trout. Now they report that they have produced rainbow trout for three years in the same bog lakes after treatment.

TRENTON, March 27 -- Construction of an $8,000,000 cooperative apartment project designed for 800 middle-income families is scheduled to begin within a few months in Jersey City. The first project of its type in New Jersey, it will be erected under Federal supervision, but was made possible by a state law adopted in 1949.
FOLLOWING are excerpts from comment on some of the more important exhibitions reviewed in the Times during the week just closed.
KANSAS CITY, March 27 (AP) -- Ten chemists and chemical engineers received $1,000 awards tonight at a general assembly of the American Chemical Society.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt said today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy did not appear to be one of the "principal disputants" in the Cohn-Schine-Army controversy.

FOR the first time in his respectable, well-regulated life, Kennet was scared. He had spent the night poring over deeds and documents in his London law office, checking and rechecking the papers of one of his wealthiest and most eccentric clients -- and he felt in his bones that something, somewhere, was wrong.

COMMERCIAL airline operations are gradually approaching long - awaited all-weather status, but being able to make punctual arrivals and departures around the clock no matter what the weather is still an ideal rather than a reality.

MOAB, Utah, March 27 -- In a move reminiscent of the rough-tough gold rush days, atom-era prospectors of the Colorado River Plateau have set up a Utah Uranium Miners Protective Association aimed at halting claim jumping.
The vast powers of the Federal and state Governments were mobilized yesterday to smash the strike that has crippled the Port of New York since March 5.
William C. Froewiss, veteran customs official, will retire Wednesday from the sweetest job in the Port of New York.

OKLAHOMA CITY,. March 27 -- George Spencer, the right-handed relief pitcher whose sinkers helped the Giants win the flag in 1951, hurled three shutout innings today as the New Yorkers defeated the Indians, 6 -- 3. A story goes with it.

ELECTRIC appliances designed to ease food preparation are still so new that full advantage has yet to be taken of them in many instances. The amateur chef thinks of his rotisserie solely in terms of a barbecued chicken.

YOU can now buy popular and classical records with your groceries. You can, that is, if you live in the Long Island, Queens, Bronx, Manhattan, or New Jersey areas, where since September supermarkets have been featuring book-style wire racks to mass-market popular and classical records.

IN the war of the artist against the late Victorian public, George Gissing the novelist was a firm and bitter fighter. "Keep apart, keep apart," he cried, "preserve one's soul alive -- that is the teaching for the day.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Administration sources disclosed today that Harold E. Stassen's trip to London was an effort to put the brakes on moves toward relaxing East-West trade restrictions.
MOSCOW, March 22 -- "Visky," the newest Soviet drink is not yet available at the fanciest drinking place in town, the Gorky Street Cocktail Hall.

SHOULD a democratically elected leader remain in office for a long time? Is it good for the state to be governed for an extended period by one man, no matter how gifted, no matter how much the people may want him? Is it good for the leader himself?

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- Debtc contracted in their grandfathers' lifetimes have been canceled over the past few years by fishermen in the Bombay province of India through their abandonment of sailboats in favor of motorized craft.

To help strengthen the Red Cross internationally and to demonstrate the interest of the American people in the welfare of others, the office of international relations of the American Red Cross provides for emergency relief in major foreign disas ters.

Members of the faculty of the Berkshire Music Center will be in New York on April 7 and 10 to audition instrumentalists and singers who wish to apply for membership this summer in the center's orchestra and opera department during the six-week session at Tanglewood from July 5 to Aug. 15.
DENVER, March 27 -- Colorado has a large role in the nation's defense system and is seeking to expand it, but one phase of that role is causing misgivings for some in the state.

Mr. and Mrs. John S. Badeau of Jamaica, Queens, have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Jeanne Hathaway Badeau to Arthur Doak Barnett, son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene E. Barnett of White Plains, N. Y.
JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), March 27 -- The Arab Legion reported today that twenty Israeli soldiers fired with automatic weapons and mortars across the armistice line upon farmers this morning.

Some of the Englishmen who landed on the island of Cyprus with Sir Garnett Wolseley's large force of British and Indian troops on July 22, 1878, may have had a strange feeling that they had been there before.
CAIRO, Sunday, March 28 -- There was no effective government in Egypt today. There was power -- in the hands of the army, where it has always been -- but no means for applying it.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Eisenhower Administration's foreign policy is entering a delicate area -- one potentially dangerous to Republican unity and even to future party success.

ATLANTA, March 27 -- Georgia employment is up slightly and unemployment claims are showing declines for the first time since last September, the State Labor Department reported this week. Unemployment claims, which hit a peak of 30,313 on March 1, have decreased in the last three weeks to 29,936, the report said.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 27 -- Bucky Harris, who seems to have dedicated his life to getting in the hair of the Yankees, saw his Senators really do a job on Casey Stengel's Bombers today as they outslickered the world champions, 7 to 6, in a twelve-inning battle.
From three examples of churches which "he particularly admires," Mr. Bridge has given two churches built in the Middle Ages. Few would deny that we can draw upon such rich heritage for inspiration.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The United States has turned inward upon itself in the first quarter of 1954, but despite the fierce preoccupations of home affairs it has met and greatly expanded its world responsibilities.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- The Soviet Union has delivered a stiff protest to Pakistan against the proposed Turkish - Pakistani treaty. The phrasing in the note was similar to that of last week's note to the Turks.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- About 60 per cent of the manufacturing concerns in Pennsylvania have laid off workers since last September. The layoffs, ranging from 1 per cent to complete shutdowns, have been felt in all ten major labor-market areas of the state and have hit nineteen of the twenty industrial classifications.

STARTING tomorrow and continuing all through next week, Philadelphians and suburbanites will trek to the Commercial Museum, Thirty-fourth below Spruce Street to visit the twenty-seventh annual Philadelphia Flower Show.

ON THURSDAY, the theatre's several eyes will turn toward the Lyceum Theatre, where "King of Hearts" is to open. A few of these will be charitable -- strangers to town probably -- who will hope for a spring hit to go with the Easter parade.

The mounting pressure on the United States Government to relax present restrictions on East-West trade was clearly shown last week by the British Government statement on the subject in the House of Commons. Such pressure, which the British are not alone in exerting, is obviously based on the belief that easing of the restrictions would be automatically followed by a great increase in the volume of exports to and imports from the Soviet Bloc.

AFTER months of discussion, agreement has been reached on a name and a definition of characteristics for a new class of roses. The group will be known as "grandiflora" and the first variety will be introduced to the public later this year.

Candidates for the 1955 election to the Hall of Fame for Great Americans, which is situated on New York University's Bronx campus, may be nominated during the year starting next Thursday, Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, director of the shrine, announced yesterday.
LINCOLN, Neb., March 27 -- Nebraska, long proud of its ability to manage without a sales or income tax, may at long last succumb.

Young women, including the Misses Helen Freeman and Helen Sparrow, are serving on the junior committee for the annual luncheon and fashion show for the benefit of St. Luke's Hospital to be given on April 7 in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.

FOR better or worse, we have entered a period of mass culture, and every day the resultant changes are made more manifest. Literature, all the arts, both in their creation and their reception, are being seriously affected by this new condition.

THE pigeon, just an ordinary New York pigeon, was hatched on a Park Avenue window sill, soon abandoned by his flibbertigibbet mother, and rescued by the Bennetts, a family to whom stray animals gravitated as if by some mysterious law.

THE wish to make a violent break with the past has come to many artists but few of them have acted on the iconoclastic impulse with more gusto and intelligence than the Italian Futurists. Their exhibition of paintings in Paris in 1912 dropped a bombshell on the complacent art world of that day.

Seamen and longshoremen manning and loading the thirty passenger and cargo vessels of the American Export Lines last year earned $29,143,307. These wage payments represented almost half of the line's expenses.

STUDIO machinations being what they are, Fredric March -- who, for some years now, has lived the mellow, semi-retired life he enjoys today -- finds his name ablaze in neon lights all over Broadway, and his career hopping with the kind of activity more properly associated with Tony Curtis or Rock Hudson.

FRAGRANCE is a wonderful something that almost every garden should have and many are the shrubs that can help to provide it. In fact, carefully selected shrubs can produce an almost endless flow of scented blossoms throughout the entire gardening season.
Harold W. McCrae has been appointed manager of development engineering in the communication products division of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc.

In a spectacular exhibition of shotmaking, the Western College All-Stars fought off a fourth-quarter challenge to beat the Eastern All-Stars, 103 to 95, in the eighth annual Herald-Tribune Fresh Air Fund basketball clash at Madison Square Garden last night.

FRANZ KAFKA met Milena Jesenska as a translator -- into Czech -- or some of his early prose pieces. His "Letters to Milena" have now been put into English by Tania and James Stern with a genuine flair for expressing the eccentricities of Kafka's mind.

American exporters are beginning to feel more optimistic about the future. This feeling may seem hard to reconcile with the depressing waterfront situation here, but it has to do with a more basic general problem -- that of getting new business.

I am deeply touched by the predicament of the "Silent Six" in "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial" as reported by Arthur Gelb in your section on March 14. While my sympathies are primarily with the judge advocate, you should know that the profession is not unaffected by the plight of the court, which, cloaked in omniscient silence, is a necessary backdrop to the administration of military justice.

FOR many years the rather unusual Chinese waternut or water chestnut has been imported to this country for use in Chinese restaurants. But nowadays experiments have shown that it may be grown successfully in this country.

The Metropolitan Opera Fund for 1953-54 is less than $200,000 from its goal of $1,250,000, George A. Sloan, chairman of the board of the Mtropolitan Opera, announced yesterday at an intermission talk during the radio broadcast of "Norma."

TAMPA, Fla., March 27 -- Manager Birdie Tebbetts tossed twenty-four players into today's almost three-hour game, but the Dodgers still won it by a 7-4 score after spotting the Redlegs all their runs in the first inning. The Brooks thus ended a losing streak of three games.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 27 -- The back country of Greenwich, for at least fifty years the treasured preserve of wealthy estate owners, who are fighting a losing battle these days, will be invaded by the townsfolk on Monday at two points.

THERE is in Washington an area known as Foggy Bottom, still a semi-slum district, even though within its borders the State Department operates and plush apartments are slowly emerging. The name derives from the combination of three elements that pervaded the precinct in an earlier period: smoke and fumes from a gas plant and fogs from the Potomac.
OMAHA, March 27 (AP) -- Republican leaders from fourteen states called on Congress for a farm program "we all can go out and sell."

A 71-year-old man died and six other persons were injured yesterday as a result of a three-car crash in Whitestone, Queens. The accident closed the Cross Island Parkway for two hours and thousands of autos were detoured to an adjacent service road.
BOSTON, March 27 -- Commander Randall Weeks of Newtonville, Mass., has been appointed executive alumni secretary at Boston University.
CANNES, France, March 27 -- Soviet movie makers are sending the tractors back to the farm. From here on the emphasis is going to be on life and love and realities.

NEWARK, March 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Magda Garibay, 52 years old, was shot and killed in her grocery store today during a hold-up. The police said a bullet pierced her chest as she apparently was trying to get to a telephone to call for help.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- One of the curious attendant circumstances of this era of the Eisenhower Administration, in which the Republican party gives the impression to many that its structural defects make it inadequate to the task of governing the country, is that the President is not using the pressures essential to the success of his domestic program in Congress.
REINHOLD NIEBUHR says in his review of A. Powell Davies' "The Urge to Persecute" that the "final level of absurdity is reached, one feels, in a purely psychiatric approach to political evil."
Among the developments emerging from eighteen pages of statistics for dog activities in 1953, just issued by the American Kennel Club, was that unbenched shows gained over the year before.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., March 27 -- The Senate's investigation of the 1952 New Mexico Senatorial election may bring some tightening of the state's traditionally casual election procedures.

IN 1926, long before foreign films had won wide acceptance in America, a tiny, 256-seat theatre opened on lower Fifth Avenue, dedicated to the unusual, the daring, the unknown in movies. The Fifth Avenue Playhouse, as it was called, soon became a mecca for people seeking fare not to be found along Broadway.
GAINSVILLE, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- Joe Shankle had record-setting speed and spirit today in taking top individual honors of the Florida Relays track carnival.

The annual Sacred Heart tea dance will be held on April 23 at the St. Regis Roof. The Misses Julie Kammerrer and Claire Sheridan are co-chairmen of the junior committee, and Mrs. James J. Beha and Miss Madeleine H. Reilly, are co-chairmen for the benefit.

The liquidation of inventories, particularly in manufacturing industries, continued in the first two months of 1954, according to the March issue of the Survey of Current Business, published by the Department of Commerce. At the same time, thanks to the reduction in income taxes that went into effect the first of the year, personal income available for spending was higher in this period than in the corresponding two months of 1953.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Republican leaders spurred the Senate today toward action on President Eisenhower's legislative program in an apparent effort to reclaim the spotlight from Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 27 (AP) -- Seven top leaders of the New Jersey Daughters of the American Revolution today assailed the society's state regent for allowing a member to make a controversial speech about Kosher labels on canned goods.
IN economic circles 1954 may well come to be known as the year of the obscure oracles. Never before have so many would-be Nostradami speculated on the shape of the American economy.

The Citizens' Committee on Children of New York City, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the performance of "By the Beautiful Sea" on the night of April 27 at the Majestic Theatre. Mrs. Marshall Field and Mrs. David M. Levy are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., March 27 (AP) -- Jack Coleman's jump shot from ten feet out, with seven seconds remaining, kept Rochester alive in the Western division play-offs of the National Basketball Association today as the Royals defeated the Minneapolis Lakers, 74 --73.

Representatives of a hundred labor, fraternal, civic and political organizations in this city will consult together over the next six weeks on how Communist infiltration into their groups can be prevented without sacrifice of their internal democracy.

The proposed cuts in our overseas educational program are bound to constitute another link in the unfortunate chain of disappointments the free world has experienced in regard to America's leadership.
LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- West Bromwich Albion and Preston North End reached the May 1 final of the English soccer cup competition today.
Beginning Thursday, and for 195 days thereafter exclusive of Sundays, a specific group of sports followers will intone, in essence, the words of that other tragic figure, Brutus.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Dr. Dov Joseph, Israel's Minister of Development, declared tonight that the idea that the Arab states would support the Western powers in the Middle East was "painfully illusory."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- Senator Alexander Wiley said today that Indo-China could be kept out of Communist hands if France went on "holding the line."

EVEN in this day of movie wizardry the filming of Jules Verne's "Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea" presents a challenge. Practically all of the action takes place either inside the fabulous submersible, the "Nautilus," or on the floor of the ocean itself.

SHRUBS play a varied and multiple role on a small suburban property. On most places 50 by 100 feet or a little larger, each woody plant must serve at least two purposes -- and many of them three or four.
BANGOR, Me., March 27 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin will be an "unseen guest" at the Maine State Republican Convention next week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 27 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold denied today that he had approved Jordan's reasons for refusing to attend an Israeli-Jordanian armistice review conference.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., March 27 (AP) -- St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn won the Thirty-second annual Eastern States scholastic basketball tournament tonight with a 58-52 triumph over Tabor Academy of Marion, Mass.

FRANCONIA, N. H., March 27 -- Brooks Dodge, recently returned from the world championships in Sweden, captured downhill honors as the two-day United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association championships and Hochgebirge ski competitions opened today on Cannon Mountain.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 27 (AP) -- Little Bobby Toski, the Mighty Mouse of the professional golf circuit, was the Magnificent Mouse today as he burned up the Cape Fear Country Club course with a seven-under-par 65 to take a four-stroke lead after thirty-six holes in the $10,000 Azalea open tournament.

The proposed reconversion of the Little Inch pipeline to a common carrier of petroleum products from the Southwest to the Pittsburgh area has raised many objections from inland barge operators and some Midwest refiners.

In the women's apparel industry high dollar volume does not always mean large profits. Sidney Blauner, president of the Lombardy Dress Company, found that out in 1951 and gave up the position he had held as one of the two largest dress manufacturers in New York.

A GAY and amusing trifle, Cimarosa's Il maestro di cappella, is available from Vox Records. This one-act work, a sort of eighteenth-century precursor of "Tubby the Tuba" and "Alice in Orchestralia," combines music appreciation, a sly dig at Alessandro Scarlatti and good-natured ridicule of conductors who take themselves too seriously.

In about one month the fire department's walkie-talkie radio outfits will be increased by 190 units. Up to now the ten in service have been assigned only to rescue squads and the marine division. Henceforth they will be used for local communications at fires.

THE best parodies, it's generally agreed, are the most straightforward, in which the parodist gives the impression that he could do the work seriously if he wished, but chose instead to point up its absurdities.

In the early Nineteen Thirties, although the B. F. Goodrich Company had long been delving into the secrets of man-made rubber, its chief practical concern with chemistry was selling rubber-lined equipment to handle corrosive materials.
PHILADELPHIA, March 27 -- Six Pennsylvania gubernatorial aspirants were set today to battle for the Republican and Democratic nominations at the May 18 primary.

SYRACUSE, March 27 (AP) -- Carmine Fiore, left-hooking specialist from Brooklyn, scored a unanimous, but unpopular decision over Italo Scortichini of Italy tonight in a spirited ten-round bout at War Memorial Auditorium. Fiore weighed 147 and Scortichini 154 3/4 pounds.

CLEVELAND, March 27 -- Recovering sharply from storm-depressed levels sales of new automobiles reached 1,778, highest of the year, this week and eclipsed the year-ago figure of 1,614. Higher sales were reported in only nine weeks last year.

MANY are the praises of the fancy - leaved caladiums. For few foliage plants offer the scope of brilliant color, the ease of culture or the basis for enthusiastic comment as these gaily colored plants.

BABYLON, L. I., March 27 -- A contract for widening and improving Meadowbrook State Parkway from Merrick Road to Jones Beach State Park has been awarded to Lizza Sons, Inc., of Oyster Bay, on a low bid of $1,222,010.

TO say that a novel is quiet, made for those few hours of contemplation when our minds turn away from our daily nonsense and faces the ultimate questions, usually means the death-knell for a book. However, Ernst Wiechert's "Mass Without a Name" belongs in that select group: it is the saga of a twentieth-century saint returned from purgatory, a saint who must unlearn how to hate so that he can live again.

Former service men and some who are not veterans will engage in a wheelchair basketball tournament of considerable size at the 212th A. A. A. Group Armory, Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street, April 9 to 11.

Dan Bucceroni, heavyweight boxer from Philadelphia, will appear in the main bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, tomorrow. His opponent will be Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson of Rockaway Beach, against whom he is scheduled to go ten rounds.
What was generally believed to be a fad ten years ago has grown into a business with sales of $70,000,000 a year.

Suggested steps to improve the American merchant marine through better ships and better integration between operators and shippers were outlined last week by two officials of the Department of Commerce.

HOW has it happened that Aaron Copland, now in his fifties and accepted on all sides as one of our most distinguished men of music, has not written an opera before? Aside from "The Second Hurricane," a children's piece, which he wrote more than fifteen years ago, his first opera is "The Tender Land."

New York's development as the greatest city in the New World has been due largely to the fact that nature endowed it with a magnificent harbor, with wide, deep channels to the sea and many sheltered inlets and bays. On these assets New York has built 750 miles of docks, warehouses and railroad trunk lines extending from Yonkers, N. Y., to Raritan Bay, N. J.

ALBANY, March 27 -- To date $175,200,000 in public funds has been spent or committed for construction of the ninety-mile Long Island Expressway that will carry mixed traffic from Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn to Riverhead.
The United Press erroneously reported March 20 in a dispatch from New Orleans that Paul Crouch, a former Communist, had been convicted of treason.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 27 (UP) -- Pictus, Ralph Loew's consistent 6-year-old, scored his sixth triumph in ten trips to the post this year when he overtook Grover B. near the wire today to win the $10,000 Woonsocket Handicap at Lincoln Downs.
HARTFORD, March 27 -- The Republicans are getting into a controversy over whether a man or woman should be nominated for Connecticut Secretary of State this year.

The "battle of the seaports" raged last week as a back-scenes accompaniment of the strike that hobbled the Port of New York. City officials, worried about how long the costly tie-up would last, were almost equally concerned about how much of the lost trade would never come back.

THE exhibition of paintings and graphic work by America's "three most famous expatriate artists," at the Metropolitan Museum, immediately recalls an exhibition at the Corcoran Gallery in Washington five years ago.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill. March 27 -- Dr. Andrew C. Ivy, University of Illinois research physiologist and expert on cancer, announced this week that he planned to continue study of the so-called cancer drug, krebiozen.

PITTSBURGH LANDING, Tenn., March 27 -- The ninety-second anniversary celebration of the Battle of Shiloh, one of the major engagements of the Civil War, will be held next Sunday on the bluff overlooking the Tenessee River here.

LAUREL, Md., March 27 (AP) -- Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Ring King, an absentee from the triple-crown races, brought grief to the undefeated California invader, Double Speed, by winning today's Cherry Blossom Stakes.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland March 27 -- Northern Irish Protestants today bombarded the British Broadcasting Corporation with demands for withdrawal of charges of religious discrimination made by Dr. John Carmel Heenan, Roman Catholic Bishop of Leeds, England.

Retailers have a variety of opinions about business in New York City's stores in the week just ended. While agreeing that sales were below the like week of 1953, their estimates of the decline ranged from 2 to 15 per cent.

Twenty volunteer civil defense rescue teams gave a demonstration of their techniques in Brooklyn yesterday. The show, held in the 101st Armored Cavalry Armory, 1579 Bedford Avenue, was also a demonstration of the growing public apathy toward civil defense.
The name of a product and its manufacturer mean far more nowadays than the outlet offering it, in the view of Joseph Kolodny, managing director of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- A casual glance at the current mail files in any Congressional office could lead an observer to a curious conclusion: that the most important subject facing this session of Congress is the question of pay rises for postal workers.

HEPATICA opens the year's wild flower show this week in dry, northern woodlands. Chill winds may blow and the mercury may stand at a shivery level, but it is all one to this intrepid herald of spring, that needs only one sunny day to unfold its blossoms.

THE whole history of human thought is as various, as marvelous, as unexpected, and as inexplicable as other mysteries of this universe. Science, with its search for laws, always oversimplifies. But the wise scientist always makes his way through the realm of law into the region of wonder.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- After two weeks in which the principal Moscow stores had no ironing boards for sale, they reappeared today in the G. U. M. department store on Red Square. But there was no run on the stock.

LONDON, March 27 -- Sir Winston Churchill is being urged to propose an immediate meeting with President Eisenhower and Premier Georgi M. Malenkov of the Soviet Union to discuss outlawing atomic bombs, including the hydrogen bomb.
