BERLIN, March 27 -- To increase their dependability East Germany's para-military forces have been purged of almost one-third of their members since last June, in the opinion of Western observers.

Long-term prospects for expanded production, investments and profits overshadow the significance of the present moderate recession, in the opinion of thirty economists, bankers and educators who participated in a New York University conference here recently.

Although chilly winds and cool nights still make life hectic for the weatherman, spring planting time for roses is beginning in this area. Actually nurserymen time their shipments for arrival at the proper planting date in the particular locality -- north or south, east or west.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 25 (Reuters) -- Belgian television experts are making final preparations for the beginning of a new and ambitious experiment to link the television networks of eight European countries.

WE have been in the recent past intrigued by the voices of cultural liberation raised in the Soviet Union. We have listened to the protests against the bureaucratization of the arts by Ehrenburg, Khatchaturian and Shostakovitch, and wondered aloud what its significance was.
CAIRO, March 27 -- At no time in the last two years have the prospects for settlement of differences between Egypt and Britain seemed dimmer than they were this week.

NORWALK, Conn., March 27 -- The City Council has before it a recommendation to increase the charge of municipal beach facilities to residents of New York. It was received without protest, but an accompanying proposal to set a fee for local residents stirred strong objections, and more are threatened.

ALBANY -- As part of a drive to make highways safer, New York State is about to join fourteen other states in requiring that all automobiles be inspected semi-annually for mechanical defects. Approval of the bill requiring such inspections coincided with the state's first increase in the motor vehicle mileage death rate in ten years.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., March 27 (UP) -- Former President Harry S. Truman told fellow Missouri National Guard members tonight that "the atomic bomb is useless unless we have a strong Army, Navy and Air Force."
The Marine Historical Association, which is rebuilding America's last Yankee whaling ship, the Charles W. Morgan, has struck oil.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- The biggest explosion in the current nuclear tests in the Pacific will be set off next month, probably about April 22, Congressional sources disclosed today.

BONN, Germany, March 27 -- Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner, forecast today that West Germany would regain its sovereignty soon. This will occur, he said, even if the European Defense Community treaty and the Bonn peace contract are not ratified.

IN this exciting and engrossing novel, Arthur C. Clarke, author of "Childhood's End," proves that no villain need spin the plot. Here is extrapolation based upon such careful research, written so skillfully and lucidly, as to become extraordinarily real.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- Mr. Knowland said it was easy for the Democrats "to throw harpoons" from the sidelines.

Dr. Lewis M. Terman, Emeritus Professor of Psychology of Stanford University, well known for his intelligence studies, lectured on his work and his latest conclusions at Washington, D. C., last week before the American Psychological Association.

After a five-week rise that had brought securities prices to their best levels in twenty-four years, the stock market last week suffered its widest decline of 1954. Prices moved lower on four of the five trading days and The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks showed a net loss of 3.09 points for the week.

In the struggle for Europe, the Russians last week made a dramatic move. On Friday Moscow announced that it was granting full "sovereignty" to the East German People's Republic. The statement said East Germany would control its own "internal and external affairs."

THE Allied army that fought first in the second World War seems to be having a last word, too. The British Eighth -- Alexander's and Montgomery's own -- held the German Afrika Korps at bay on the ground just as the R. A. F. did to the Luftwaffe in the air.

HERE is a book that will delight any lawyer who has ever tried a real case and that will kindle the ambition of every law student who aspires to court work. The appeal of the volume, however, is not alone to the lawyer.

The whole issue of compulsory competitive bidding is being revived by public hearings on the proposal to end Federal supervision of the financing of public utility companies already subject to regulation at the state level.

HARRIET'S mother hopefully predicted that Harriet would be unable to stand Al Marco's family "with all their foreign ways." And indeed the girl might have had a hard time adjusting to married life if it had not been for Al's father, gentle, cultivated Pietro.

AINTREE, England, March 27 -- The famed all-Irish combination of owner, trainer and jockey that won the Grand National Steeplechase last year with Early Mist repeated today with Royal Tan, another Irish horse, in one of the most thrilling finishes in recent years.

MIAMI BEACH, March 27 (AP) -- Doris Hart, Miami, ranked No. 2 in the United States, kept the Good Neighbor women's tennis championship in this country today by defeating Helen Fletcher, England's No. 2 star, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4.

KANSAS CITY, March 27 -- Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, surgeon general, told civic leaders this week that the nation at large was expected to benefit from a test project here in rehabilitation of the handicapped.
Spring is here and with it starts a multi-billion-dollar business dependent on pleasure and exercise out-of-doors.
Steady round-the-clock advertising in various media is producing results for many advertisers, but mainly for those who have managed to avoid irritating while "saturating" their market.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 27 -- Despite sometimes drastic efforts to curb religious practices, Communist leaders in Yugoslavia continue to find even their own followers refusing to abandon religious worship.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, March 27 -- The South African Communist movement has begun organizing racial equality committees in every city, town and village. The evident purpose is to reactivate the nearly moribund African National Congress on the basis of the Communist-led multiracial movement and link it to the already Communist - dominated South African Indian Congress and two wholly Communist shadow organizations.

CHICAGO -- The current exhibition of photographs at the Institute of Design here documenting the work of Louis Sullivan, leading architect at the turn of the century, is the product of a unique approach to teaching photography.

IN a world in which nearly everything is rapidly being discovered or exposed, clowns are still mighty mysterious creatures. And clowning remains one of man's weirdest occupations -- not completely art, nor craft, nor profession, but a remarkable combination of all three heavily larded with large chunks of pure hokum and sheer nonsense.

Barnett Janner, long a Labor party member of the British Parliament and now president of the Zionist Federation of Great Britain and Ireland, spoke here yesterday on the significance of Israel to Britain and the United States.

ITALY'S people also face the income tax problem. The Rome Government is currently using a 25-1ire violet stamp to direct their attention to the duty to remit. On this postal adhesive, received here by Vittorio Lo Bianco, is inscribed Article 53 of the republic's Constitution: "Everyone is obliged to contribute to public expenses in proportion to his capacity to pay."
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 27 -- Taps will sound at Fort Slocum soon for the Armed Forces Information School, and part of the military base may be converted into a guided missile establishment.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court, leading a little "blister brigade" of hikers, finished a 189-mile, eight-day walk along the old Chesapeake and Ohio Canal today.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Although lawns are slow in turning green, their appearance will be improved by a thorough raking. Apply top-dressing or lime, if either is needed, and feed with a balanced commercial fertilizer. After loosening soil, scatter seed over thin spots and press down with a rake.

HAROLD LAMB'S previous works, books like "Genghis Khan," "Tamerlane," two volumes on the crusades, "The March of the Barbarians," are based on painstaking research and have established him as a scholarly narrator of medieval history.

JERUSALEM, March 27 -- There is trouble in the air along Israel's border with the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, and squall warnings also fly on the lines separating Israel from the Arab nations to the north and south.
WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Joseph M. Dodge, Director of the Budget since the Eisenhower Administration took office, will leave his post April 15, to return to private life.

WAITSFIELD, Vt., March 27 -- The Amateur Ski Club of New York took the lead in the annual New York City interclub races at Mad River Glen today, with a score of 237.2 seconds. The German Ski Club trailed with 251.4 and the Norway Ski Club had 255.4.

The week's auction offerings cover a wide range. In the many fields represented are historical Americana, Jewish ritual silver and other Hebraica, English antique furniture, Old Masters, nineteenth-century paintings and many categories of decorations.

OKLAHOMA CITY, March 27 (AP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney tonight accused Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of "attempting to wrest control of the [Republican] party from the hands of President Eisenhower and responsible Republican leaders."

A mysterious black ash fell over wide areas of sidewalk, terraces and rooftops in the city yesterday. New York officials could give no explanation for it, but there was a possibility that a meadow fire in New Jersey might have been responsible.

IN 1877 Louis Pasteur reported that the bacteria which caused the malignant disease anthrax could be killed by other harmless bacteria found flourishing in the earth. The great French scientist suggested that some day we might curb disease by pitting microbe against microbe.

AN ailment readily diagnosed by wives, other relatives, and business associates as "trout fever" has now reached the endemic stage. The crisis should be reached by sufferers in most eastern states within the next two weeks.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., March 27 -- The gardens of Westbury House, the home of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Phipps on Jericho Turnpike, and those of Boxwood Farm, the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Hickox in Whitney Lane, will be opened to the public on May 13 from 1 to 6 P. M. for the benefit of the Wellesley College Scholarship Fund.
Sectarian religious sponsorship of social welfare agencies was sharply attacked and strongly defended yesterday at the annual alumni conference of the New York School of Social Work.

The members of the Police Department Band and Glee Club, who formerly spent most of their working days performing or rehearsing, are now doing steady patrol duty. Nowadays, whether rehearsing or performing, they are on their own time, unpaid.

ALL books about African safaris have a tendency to read alike. Guides and white hunters are more or less committed to give their clients an opportunity to shoot the standard game and to do it with reasonable safety. Lions and leopards, buffalo and rhino, elephants, hippo, giraffe and warthogs, together with a dozen species of antelopes and an ostrich or two, make up the regular list.

The Soviet proclamation of the "German Democratic Republic," comprising the central part of the former German Reich, as a fully "sovereign" state under continued Russian occupation, has been rightly characterized in the West as a propaganda maneuver in which the words again belie the facts.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., March 27 -- Prof. Julian Towster of the University of California told a conference of specialists on Russia at Arden House today that Andrei Y. Vishinsky was one of the chief political theorists of the Soviet Union.
Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College, urged teachers yesterday to teach liberalism to combat illiberalism.
SYRACUSE, March 27 -- The National Collegiate swimming championship went to Ohio State's team again tonight.

Parke, Davis Co. has delivered the first polio vaccine ever produced by any commercial company to the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis to be used in the forthcoming nation-wide field trials. The foundation announces that enough vaccine will be ready for the inoculation of about 370,000 children starting about April 12. More will be available later.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Wes Santee of the University of Kansas won the Bankers Mile of the eighteenth annual Chicago Daily News Relays before a crowd of 17,618 in Chicago Stadium tonight. He turned in a time of 4:11.8, one of his poorest efforts of the season.

PARIS, March 27 -- Marshal Alphonse - Pierre Juin, commander of Allied land forces in Central Europe under the North Atlantic Treaty, advocated today an "alternative" to the pending European Defense Community pact.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March -- The yachtsmen's dream of a major basin for small pleasure raft on the Westchester shore the Hudson River is nearer fulfillment as the county prepares appropriate $60,000 for the project.

A step-by-step analysis of the illustrator's work from research to the end product will be made by Florian G. Kraner in a talk on "The Art of Book Illustration" at 6:15 P. M. Tuesday at the New York Public Library. Mr. Kraner, a City College instructor in drawing, calligraphy and other illustrative art forms, will lecture in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building.
VIENNA, March 18 -- In one year Austria has balanced her budget and her trade, stabilized her prices and her currency and turned from a debtor to a creditor of her European neighbors.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho -- Next Sunday the seven busy chairlifts at this famous winter sports resort will come to a squealing stop as the commercial ski season ends. The thousands of "ski bums" and grimly studious "snowbunnies" will have dispersed by then to all the unglamorous towns and schools and offices they came from during the winter.

AN event of unusual significance occurred ten days ago in New Orleans at the season's final concert of the New Orleans Philharmonic Symphony, which Alexander Hilsberg is rapidly developing into a symphonic organization of the first class.
The contract bridge contest for the Eastern States pair championship and the Julian Goldman trophy began yesterday with 170 pairs entered, one of the largest groups of competitors for this title.
WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- Military science has or is devising a selective arsenal of weapons that could kill multitudes in a split second, minutes or years.

Two-way radios in ambulances that take part in the city's emergency ambulance pool have brought a "tremendous improvement" in service. So reports Assistant Chief Inspector Francis A. Burns, head of the communications and records division of the Police Department.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 25 -- From low perch on the American League totem pole to top spine of the Arizona "Cactus Circuit" is quite a hop for an Oriole. The hop has been made.

Estimating the probable traffic forty years hence on a highway whose route is still uncertain may sound like a formidable assignment. Especially if the safety of investments reaching many millions of dollars depends on how good the estimate turns out to be.

SHE had been a school teacher and writer of children's books. He was a Russian baron, straight out of the world of never-again. Both were near middle life when they became acquainted while working in the same Government agency in wartime Washington.

NEW DELHI, India, March 27 -- Mass demonstrations against continued French occupation of four colonies in India broke out today in Pondicherry and Karikal, two of the tiny settlements south of Madras.

A MINOR battle has just broken out in Manchester where the Art Gallery Committee has decided to purchase the "Draped Torso" by Henry Moore, whose sculpture show is perhaps the most important of the current London season.

BOSTON, March 27 -- The Syracuse Nationals won the National Basketball Association Eastern division championship today with an 83-76 triumph over the Boston Celtics in a game marked by a wild brawl in Boston Garden.

THEY are playing today, for the twenty-sixth consecutive year, for the Julian Goldman trophy that goes annually to the winners of the Eastern open pair championship. They have been playing, during the past week, for the Curt H. Reisinger team-of-four trophy in the same Eastern tournament.

Identification of a fourth abnormal form of hemoglobin in human red blood cells was reported by Dr. Harvey A. Itano, senior research fellow at the California Institute of Technology, to the American Chemical Society now meeting in Kansas City, Mo.

MY eye was caught by the statement in David Dempsey's review of "The Magnificent Bastards" that the author, Lucy Herndon Crockett, "spent five years as a major in the American Red Cross in the Pacific."

THE recession has caught up with retail sales. Locally, judging from department store figures, sales are down 10 per cent compared with a year ago. Nationally, they are off about 13 per cent. However, with the pre-Easter peak still ahead, there is a possibility of a reversal in the trend.

IN this era of fission and fusion-weapons, the New York State Legislature has just put on the books a law dealing with the bow and arrow. It seems that some bow and arrow men, 10,000 of whom bought hunting licenses in New York State last year, had also been carrying firearms to administer coups de grace where errant arrows had failed.

WHEN Vice President Richard Nixon took his oath of office a little over a year ago, it was not expected that he would say or do anything worthy of being carved on Rushmore Mountain. It was expected that he would speak of his pride in presiding over the Senate, and would strongly hint that the virtues of the members were so great that they scraped the sandals of the heavenly choir.
The Chicago Catholic Youth Organization team carried off the championship in the National Amateur Athletic Union women's track and field meet in the 102d Engineers Armory last night.

TOKYO, March 27 -- Dr. Hideki Yukawa, Nobel Prize psysicist, has declined an invitation from Columbia University to return as a visiting professor. The scientist intends to remain in Japan, where he heads the Theoretical Physics Institute of Kyoto University.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (UP) -- Interest on G. I. loans made last year could have cost veterans an extra $429,000,000 if a provision recommended by the House Banking Committee had been in effect then, according to Veterans Administration estimates.
A new system for paging and for communicating with personnel has been perfected by Dictograph Products, Inc.
MONTREAL, March 27 -- The rough and tumble, pork and beans days of Canadian north woods lumberjacking seem to be over.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Columbia and New York University tied for the 1954 national collegiate fencing championship, each scoring 61 points in the two-day meet which ended today at the University of Chicago.

CANADIAN television program officials are experimenting with a variety of what are generally called cultural and educational programs. They are trying out, not just in daytime hours, but in good evening time, programs with a provocative content and are seeing some success in the growing amount of home viewer mail which results.

BABETTE DEUTSCH's new book shows again that she can be both a compelling poet and a dull one. She can offer unblushingly such stereotyped phrases as "pathless wood," "patient as the hills," "the moon like a nail paring."
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 27 -- The Tenth Inter-American Conference ended its business here this afternoon on a note of optimism and harmony.

A "county fair" will be held Tuesday by the New York Section, National Council of Jewish Women, in the 101st Armored Cavalry Armory, Ninety-fourth Street and Park Avenue. The event will run from 10 A. M. until midnight.

Well-known women, including Mrs. Johnfritz Achelis and Mrs. Charles L. Morton, are furthering the success of a benefit tea dance to be held Easter Sunday, April 18, in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The fete will serve to raise funds for the New York City Center Gallery of the City Center of Music and Drama.

THE San Francisco Symphony Orchestra next season will be in the hands of a conductor who has no steady favorites among the world's composers, classical or contemporary. The favorite of the moment might be Haydn or Mendelssohn; he might be Stravinsky or Hindemith.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 27 (AP) -- The Hasty House Farms' Pomace scored a front-running, two-length victory in the $10,000 Magic City Handicap before 17,949 spectators at Gulfstream Park today.

PARENTS, teachers, librarians and other adults interested in children's books have long deplored the scarcity of critical histories in this very important field of literature. Their distress must finally have reached receptive editorial ears, for recent months have produced not one but several excellent studies of juvenile books.

WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower reasserted his preference for state over Federal controls "wherever possible" in signing a bill today banning Federal regulation of pipeline carries transporting natural gas within a state's boundaries.

WASHINGTON, March 27 -- Senate Republican leaders expressed confidence this week that the noisy battle between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the Army was increasing measureably the public demand for changes in the rules of Congressional investigators to insure fair play.

The name of Trofim D. Lysenko is well, if unfavorably, known to scientists throughout the world. He led the 1948 offensive for "Soviet genetics" against "Western genetics" in which the dictum of the Central Committee of the Communist party became the decisive element on a scientific problem.

DEMOCRACY would have been impossible without the dissemination of knowledge and its continuance will be impossible without the dissemination of wisdom. For that reason alone this paper-back edition of one of the most profound books ever written, often compared to the Sermon on the Mount, is a publishing event of major importance.

Cancer received even more than the usual attention last week. It was considered at the meeting of the American Chemical Society at Kansas City, Mo., and by a group of newspaper science writers who are visiting cancer laboratories under the auspices of the American Cancer Society.

AKRON, Ohio, March 27 (AP) -- The Army's Chief Engineer declared tonight that because of "badly deteriorated locks," the "modernization of the Ohio River waterway is an undertaking of the highest priority, ranking in urgency with construction of the St. Lawrence Seaway itself."

BREAKING bottlenecks in congested areas to allow a free flow of traffic, eliminating costly delays in urban communities, has become a major objective in the construction program of the United States Bureau of Public Roads.

KANSAS CITY, March 27 -- The scientist's right to search freely for knowledge carries with it the responsibility to participate in efforts to attain freedom for all men, it was emphasized here tonight.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- Moscow has added 2,329,000 square meters (about 25,000,000 square feet) of new residential floor space since 1951, but some of it would "unbalance a man even with strong nerves," Nikolai A. Mikhailov, party secretary of Moscow Oblast (province) reported today.

Two of the New York City Opera's half dozen new sopranos made their debuts at the City Center yesterday afternoon when the company presented the first "Carmen" of its spring season. They were Medelaine Chambers, who sang Micaela, and Peggy Bonini, who sang Frasquita.

CHICAGO, March 27 -- Borg-Warner Corporation, Chicago manufacturer of automotive parts, home appliances and other products, reported today that its sales had reached a record high of $407,379,056 in 1953, an increase of 15.1 per cent from $353,948,112 in 1952.

THERE seems to be no let-up in the flow of nature books. No phase of nature is too obscure or obvious to be neglected -- and no year has lacked its quota of books on wild flowers. The first entry on this subject for 1954 is "The Macmillan Wild Flower Book."
LONDON, March 27 (AP) -- Georgi Mikhailovich Popov has been released from his post as Soviet Ambassador to Poland, the Moscow radio reported tonight.

THROUGH the cooperation of the American Stamp Dealers Association a proposed statute which would have virtually put stamp auctioneers out of business throughout New York State failed of enactment by the Legislature which adjourned a week ago yesterday.

SAN MATEO, Calif., March 27 (UP) -- A. J. Crevolin's Decorated, ridden by Johnny Longden, won the twenty-second running of the $25,000 added Bay Meadows Handicap today as he collared Cyclotron at the wire to win by a nose.

THE wild rose so loved by many a gardener and nature lover may soon have a place of prominence in the field of horticulture. For research has indicated that many wild species are resistant to serious rose diseases.

IN an engrossing, fast-paced novel Miss Whitney explores the problems of migrant labor in a Midwestern town. In Leola there is only one important industry: the Allard Company, vegetable growers and canners. The laborers who work the company's crops are bitterly resented by the local citizens and tension has permeated the whole town.

PARIS, March 27 -- A disturbing and fundamental crisis which is bound to have immensely important repercussions in the United States is now shaping up along the River Rhine. France and Germany, riparian neighbors and traditional enemies, have been slipping into a mood of increasing hostility.

A newly completed small French coastal ship is the first merchant vessel to be fully equipped with a new type of engine that may make serious inroads on the steam and Diesel power now moving world shipping.
ALBANY, March 27 -- The sea bass and striped bass that used to frolic in the Long Island Sound without fear of spear-carrying "frogmen" got some encouraging news today from Governor Dewey.
THE color television situation has changed drastically in the last two weeks. These deductions seem reasonable at the moment:

IN HIS March 14 article in your section Frits von der Lippe makes this statement: "No more than 10 to 15 per cent of the 6,000 members of Actors Equity can count on work each season." I wonder where he got that information.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, March 27 -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have decided to allow without restriction the import of a large number of products from the dollar zone.
A NUMBER of 2x2 slide projectors were introduced by several manufacturers at the photographic trade show held recently in Chicago by the Master Photo Dealers' and Finishers' Association.

UTICA, N. Y., March 27 -- Oneida County, which is accustomed to getting its farm labor from the South, may turn this year to young "city slickers" from New York, according to the State Employment Service, which calls such workers "farm cadets."

RICHMOND, March 27 -- Industrial developments in the Fifth Reserve District are a mixture of good and bad. In Virginia it was announced that a bag manufacturing plant had purchased a 21-acre tract for immediate development and that a new 6,000,000 gallon bulk oil storage and terminal would be constructed on a 74-acre tract near Richmond.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 28 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers finished fast for an 82-72 victory over Rochester today, clinching the Western Division play-offs in the National Basketball Association. Led by George Mikan, with 17 points, five Lakers hit double scoring figures.

Jules Tilles of the Bronx and Boris Raymond of New York won the Eastern States contract bridge pair championship and the Julian Goldman trophy in the American Contract Bridge League's tournament at the McAlpin Hotel last night.
TEANECK, N. J., March 28 -- A cream-colored miniature poodle from Wales added another best-in-show to his record at the fifteenth event of the Kennel Club of Northern New Jersey today.
SEATTLE, March 28 (AP) -- Evidence that living cells harbor "sleeping" viruses that can lead to cancer was reported today at the University of Washington.

I have had put to me, as president of The Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., this question: Are there more or fewer dwelling units in New York City today than there would be if it were not for the public housing program?

LONDON, March 28 -- The stock markets last week were not greatly influenced by reopening of the London gold market after a lapse of fifteen years and further movements toward freeing exchange transactions.
" Musical Talent in Our Schools," presenting music students from public and private high schools in the Metropolitan area, will begin next Sunday at 1:30 P. M. over WQXR.

MOSCOW, March 28 -- Scientific institutions with which Academician Trofim D. Lysenko has been closely associated were sharply criticized at the Ukrainian Communist party congress that just closed in Kiev.

This one is over a saloon. It is the Green Room Studio at 145 Bleecker Street where Strindberg's "Miss Julia," a rarely acted drama, is currently on view on week-ends. The Studio consists of a small hall that is clean and attractive with a small stage at one end; and the two young ladies at the door, also clean and attractive, treat theatregoers like guests.

Aluminium, Ltd., last year had the greatest production of primary aluminum and the highest physical volume and dollar sales in its twenty-six-year history. Earnings, however, declined to $19,475,087, or $2.16 a share, on 9,013,994 shares from the 1952 net of $22,372,289, or $2.48 a share.

NEWARK, March 28 -- State Senator Malcolm R. Forbes, Republican of Somerset County, tonight described as "folderol" Gov. Robert B. Meyner's assertion that his weekly broadcast program was non-partisan.

The Spanish bagpipers will blow their final skirls for Columbus Circle next week. Hoot hombre, they're moving farther uptown to a place where a man can really make himself heard. The pipers, who can pour out anything from an Iberian reel to music for a mass, are members of New York's Galician community.

Two recent shipping news items appearing simultaneously in this newspaper expressed widely diversified concern over the "flight" of national vessels to foreign flags. From Athens came the statement that the Greek Government was making "as attractive offers as possible to get Greek-controlled shipping to give up foreign registrations and sail under the Greek flag."

Two youths in a stolen car were captured in a pincer movement in the Bronx yesterday. Trapped going the wrong way in a narrow one-way street, they tried to flee on foot and were shot down by an off-duty policeman.

Not even the explosion of a hydrogen bomb distracted public attention in this country from the McCarthy issue. But in Great Britain the effects of the March 1 test of the most powerful weapon man has ever invented has pushed McCarthy and all other controversies on American policy into the background.

A battle for the "very livelihood" of private cargo surveyors on the Pacific Coast is being waged in Washington in hearings before the Water Transportation Subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce.
The pulse of the ship charter market remained steady last week, but observers felt it might weaken a bit.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 28 -- Efforts to settle the longstanding dispute between the Alien Property Office in the United States and Interhandel A. G. of Basle over the ownership of the General Aniline and Film Corporation has now reached a decisive stage.

Councilman Thomas Mirabile, Democrat of Brooklyn, has introduced a curfew bill in the City Council. The purpose of this bill is to reduce juvenile delinquency and vandalism. However, a consideration of the facts will show that the passage and enforcement of the bill will wreak much more damage on the innocent majority than on the criminal minority.

In one of his recent, always interesting, columns Meyer Berger discussed the gates of Central Park. He mentioned that although they were named in 1861 one was labeled for the first time this past week.

WILMINGTON, N. C., March 28 (AP) -- Bob Toski shot sub-par rounds of 70, 71 today to win the $10,000 Azalea open golf tournament by three strokes with a seventy-two-hole total of 273, fifteen under par.
PARIS, March 24 -- The Communist morning newspaper L'Humanite has announced that it will soon celebrate its fiftieth birthday.
The styles shown today by Patterns of The Times are for little girls who have ceased to believe that the bunny lays the Easter eggs but who still enjoy egg hunts and egg-rolling.

Cotton prices in the domestic market tended to back and fill last week within a relatively narrow trading range but closed the period with net losses. At the cessation of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 10 to 20 points from the level of the week before.

LONDON, March 23 -- A report about how African elephants dig water holes in the dry river beds of Kenya and thus save the lives of thousands of other thirsty animals has been submitted to the Fauna Preservation Society of London.

Business must provide financial support for the country's institutions of higher learning if they are to remain free of the political influence that accompanies Government aid, Alfred P. Sloan Jr. said yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, March 28 -- Business has been advised to protect its executives from overwork.

New York's Negroes can testify to the worth of democracy by making their "proud, beautiful and valuable" section of the city "representative of itself," Mrs. Anna Arnold Hedgeman, an assistant to Mayor Wagner, declared yesterday.
JERUSALEM, March 28 -- Maj. Gen. Vagn Bennike, Chief of Staff of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization, called on Lieut. Gen. Moshe Dayan, Chief of Staff of the Israeli Army, today.

PITTSBURGH, March 28 -- There was every indication last week that steel output for March would be quite disappointing. This month may have the smallest output since 1949 -- except during the strike in 1952. Output before a strike in 1949 receded to 71 per cent of capacity.
PARIS, March 28 -- France is facing the necessity of urgent decision in this and succeeding weeks on several problems on which the Cabinet and National Assembly are both divided.
CHICAGO, March 28 -- Discouragingly weak markets for cash wheat unsettled wheat futures here last week and substantial declines were registered.

Laszlo Varga, the orchestra's first 'cellist, was the soloist at the Philharmonic - Symphony concert Saturday night at Carnegie Hall. The gifted artist was heard in Lalo's Concerto in D minor on a program also containing Cimarosa's Overture, "La Bella Greca" and Prokofieff's Fifth symphony.
Disapproval of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy dominated the closing sessions yesterday of the Columbia University Student Council's three-day Conference on the Rights of Free Americans.

HANOI, Vietnam, March 28 (AP) -- French forces smashed again today at Vietminh entrenchments surrounding their beleaguered fortress of Dienbienphu, forcing the Communist-led rebels to halt preparations for a new infantry assault.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Postmaster General, Arthur E. Summerfield, may have something to say this week about an old charge that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy abused his free-mailing privileges.

TEL AVIV, Israel, March 28 -- Israel has requested the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization to convoke an emergency meeting of the Israeli-Egyptian Mixed Armistice Commission, an army spokesman said tonight.

The menu for the April in Paris Ball, to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel on April 20, follows the tradition of French classic cookery, as is appropriate for a party that benefits many French interests. Among them are Atlantique, which facilitates the exchange of French and American social workers, and L'Essor, which contributes to the improvement of French underprivileged children.
WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- A campaign to get more milk for the Navy's sailors was under way in Congress today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (UP) -- The United States announced today it was more than doubling its overseas television broadcasts to take advantage of a tremendous increase in the number of foreign TV viewers.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Administration began today a campaign to tell the United States public clearly and dramatically what is at stake in Indo-China. The Administration holds that its Democratic predecessors did not let the public know what the stakes were in China until it was too late. It does not intend to make such a mistake in the case of Indo-China.
The Dean of the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine) took sharp issue with Cardinal Spellman yesterday over the "McCarthyism" controversy and religion in politics.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 28 (AP) -- Karl Olson, discharged from the Army late last season, cracked a single to left center in the eleventh inning today, driving in the winning run as the Red Sox downed the Tigers, 2 -- 1.
CAIRO, March 28 -- A new compromise between advocates of military and civilian rule in Egypt appeared to be in the making here tonight.

The peepers' tinkling symphony. The scratching of a stick drawing a circle in the dirt for a game of marbles. Plowshares slicing moist, brown earth. The crackling ripple of paper on plunging kites. Fire snapping and popping on the windfalls of winter. The fluttering of wings and the warm magic of well-remembered small voices.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The votes of the Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the period March 20 through March 26.
Madison Square Garden proved a delightful stopping-off place for 33,382 persons yesterday as the Harlem Globetrotters performed both afternoon and evening.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Merchant marine leaders in this country are becoming increasingly convinced that the best hope offered in many years for maritime stability lies in pending legislative measures on ship construction subsidies.
LONDON, March 28 (AP) -- The board of the Ford Motor Company here, British offshoot of the American company, announces that group profits soared in 1953 to 5,131,327 ($14,367,715).

The International Society for Contemporary Music held forth last night at the McMillin Theatre. Twelve-tone music, strict or otherwise, was, not unexpectedly, much in evidence, as represented by Rene Leibowitz' Duo for 'Cello and Piano, Seymour Shifrin's Three Songs, Gunther Schuller's Five Pieces for Five Horns and Anton Webern's Five Religious Texts.
Dr. Israel Goldstein, president of the American Jewish Congress, announced yesterday the winners of the Stephen Wise $1,000 awards for 1953 in recognition of achievements in various fields.

Red Cross policy forbids charging members of the armed forces for articles or services. Because rumors persist to the contrary, all Red Cross offices at military installations and hospitals display an official poster saying that all articles provided for service men and all services rendered them by the American Red Cross are gifts of the American people.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 28 (UP) -- Attorneys for two R. K. O. Pictures Corporation stockholders said yesterday they had not decided whether to fight a Chancery Court ruling that removed the last legal barrier to the sale of all R. K. O. assets to Howard Hughes, millionaire sportsman.
ROME, March 28 -- Mrs. Clare Booth Luce, United States Ambassador, said today that an Italian news magazine's report of statements attributed to her was a "fabrication."

The twenty-first week of opera at the Metropolitan, which opens April 5, will present the season's final performances of five operas -- "Cavalleria Rusticana," "Pagliacci," "Rigoletto," "Cosi fan tutte" and "Carmen."

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $79,235,142,716. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
MADRID, March 28 -- The Spanish Government indicated today that it would press Washington for much more United States economic aid during 1955 than the amount said to be under consideration.

DEAN WILLIAM B. BAER of New York University's College of Arts and Sciences cleared up for a lot of New Yorkers yesterday the origin of the quotation, "But Above All Things Truth Beareth Away the Victory," cut into the facade of the library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
MOSCOW, March 28 -- An important change in Communist party leadership places the Moscow Oblast (province) organization in the hands of Ivan V. Kapitonov, a veteran Moscow party worker.

PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- Specialists in child development agreed here yesterday that parents must give their youngsters more than love to help them grow to healthy maturity. They added, however, that "love is a good start."

Saturday night's program at the Metropolitan Opera was listed as a "gala performance," and it was all of that. For the first time since the 1946-47 season, the Metropolitan decided to offer a series of excerpts and ballets, similar to the long-departed Sunday night concerts.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The chair of Librarian of Congress, symbol of intellectual freedom in the eyes of learned organizations, has been vacant since July 13, 1953.

COL. EDWARD RILEY BRADLEY was a horseman of distinction. He also was a gambler of distinction. His horses won the Kentucky Derby four times and his Idle Hour Farm was a respected pillar of the turf. But his gambling made him fabulously wealthy. What's more, the aristocratic colonel was proud of his background and that's why he was able to silence the demagogic Huey Long during a Senatorial investigation.

Christine Chvartazky, 17-year-old Ukrainian-American pianist, made her New York debut yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. The Twenty-four Preludes of Chopin's Op. 28 were her major undertaking, but her program also included shorter works by Medtner, Scriabine and Khachaturian, and she introduced L. Revutsky's Sonata in B minor, Korestchenko's Aveu and Fomenko's Prelude in A flat.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, March 28 -- Two hundred eighty-six officers and men of the Spanish Blue Division, which fought with the Germans in World War II, left here early today en route to Spain after prolonged captivity in the Soviet Union.
" The Teahouse of the August Moon" and "Kismet" won Antoinette Perry Awards last night as the outstanding play and musical of the current Broadway stage season.
The American pavilion at the Venice Biennale, international festival of contemporary art, has been purchased by the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

In Jed Harris' possession is "The Green Lamp," a play with melodramatic leanings that he prizes highly. So much so that the ace producer-director doesn't mind guiding the author, Theodore St. John, on the revisions. All that is known about Mr. St. John is that he is a former Broadway actor who has been attempting to write a successful play.

BOSTON, March 28 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, on a tie-breaking goal by Dickie Moore, won their third straight victory tonight over the Boston Bruins, 4 to 3, in the semi-finals of the National Hockey League playoffs for the Stanley Cup.
The election of Albert E. Bachmann and H. T. Holbrook as vice presidents of the Standard Packaging Corporation was announced over the week-end by Dr. John A. Keenan, president.
MIAMI, March 28 -- Dade County school officials have promised conditionally to send some of the Puerto Rican and Mexican farm workers' children back to classes at the Redland School in Homestead.
OKLAHOMA CITY, March 28 -- Maybe someone should inform the Cleveland Indians that the "New York" on the opposition's uniforms stands for Giants, not Yankees.
THE Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical cavalcade, which was carried last night on most of the country's television stations, was a heart-breaking disappointment.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The President's economic counselors expect a substantial rise in consumer buying next month to end the downward trend in the nation's economy.

Football coaches bemoaning the trend toward curtailed practices will appreciate the plight of Major L. Maitland Blank, baseball coach at Valley Forge Military Academy. His team will open its season next Saturday and he'll be lucky if he gets one pre-season look at his squad.

The New York City Opera Company, which gave its first performance on Feb. 21, 1944, took advantage Saturday night of the flexibility of the second act of "Die Fledermaus" to stage a public celebration of its tenth anniversary.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., March 28 (AP) -- The purchase of 35-year-old Catcher Ray Murray from the Philadelphia Athletics in a straight cash deal was announced here today by Art Ehlers, the Baltimore Orioles general manager.
Some of the blame for swings in the business cycle, said Lord Keynes, lies with the investor who risks his money too rashly when fortune smiles and too sparsely when she gets a cinder in her eye.

CHICAGO, March 28 (AP) -- The Illinois Civil Defense Director said today "Chicago is the No. 1 target of the Russians in any war against this country" and called the city's bomb shelters "death traps."

MIAMI BEACH, March 28 (AP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, the second ranking United States amateur, defeated Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., 3 -- 6, 13 --11, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 3, today to win the men's singles final of the Good Neighbor tennis tournament.

On Feb. 19 Senator Walter F. George, on behalf of himself and two other Democratic members of that body -- Senator Robert S. Kerr of Oklahoma and Senator J. Allen Frear Jr. of Delaware -- introduced a bill designed to raise personal exemption rates in the individual income tax from $600 to $800 in 1954 and to $1,000 thereafter.
HONOLULU, March 28 -- Samuel Wilder King, Territorial Governor, is preparing a proclamation to call the Territorial Legislature into special session on April 5 to assist Hawaii's drive for statehood.
WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Spokesmen for the Administration ruled out any compromise today in two Congressional battles, as two other programs neared a showdown at the Capitol.

New York is less hard hit than the rest of the country by the present business slump. Unemployment here has gone up 40 to 50 per cent in the last year, while the total of jobless in the nation has more than doubled.
With upward of fifty exhibitions of paintings and sculpture in metropolitan galleries and museums, the art season shows no sign of letting up.

PARIS, March 28 -- It is believed here that the European Payments Union would be gravely affected, and might even be broken up, if certain member countries should revert unilaterally to monetary convertibility.
Eugene C. Pulliam Indianapolis newspaper publisher, today becomes the eleventh member of Robert R. Young's proposed board of directors of the New York Central Railroad.
American business is showing more interest in educational programs for executives and rank-and-file employes than ever before.
Chinese-American school children gathered contributions for the Red Cross yesterday along the narrow, crooked streets of Manhattan's Chinatown.
ALBANY, March 28 -- A bill giving the State Superintendent of Insurance ironclad authority to examine the records of union welfare funds was signed today by Governor Dewey.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Senator Homer Ferguson of Michigan told delegates to the first International Planning Conference for Israel here today that the Republican party would continue to play a leading role in forming a "positive policy on Israel and the Near East."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 28 -- The Soviet Union is seeking priority in the Economic and Social Council for debate on its proposal for the removal of obstacles to international trade.

The New York Americans defeated the Castle Shannon eleven of Pittsburgh by 3 -- 0 at Sterling Oval, the Bronx, yesterday to take Eastern division honors in the national challenge cup soccer competition. The Americans took the two-game series with a total of 4 -- 3, overcoming a two-point lead gained by Castle Shannon in the first contest at Pittsburgh.
Daniel J. Riesner, secretary of the New York County Republican Committee, said yesterday that party leaders would do everything in their power to draft Governor Dewey for re-election.

" Secret Document -- Vienna," a French-made spy opus of World War I, put in a curiously flat appearance at the Stanley Theatre on Saturday. Here we have an odd number indeed. Supposedly made only two years ago, its musty mediocrity suggests the same vintage as the action.

Carmine G. DeSapio, Democratic leader of New York County, proposed yesterday that a $30,000,000 extension of the city sales tax to commercial services be named after Governor Dewey -- "the Dewey sales tax."

Great opportunities for public good beckon to those who now volunteer to do the pioneering in educational television in New York, under the authorizing legislation signed by Governor Dewey. A broadly representative base of community leadership is offered in the Metropolitan Educational Television Association headed by Dr. David Henry of New York University.

Charles Munch, at the invitation of Arturo Toscanini, conducted yesterday's broadcast concert of the N. B. C. Symphony in Carnegie Hall. He chose a program in which he is a specialist; it consisted entirely of French music -- Debussy's "Iberia," Ravel's "Le Tombeau de Couperin" and Roussel's "Bacchus et Ariane" Suite No. 2.

TAMPA, Fla., March 28 -- A six-run assault in the eighth inning on Ed Roebuck, rookie right-hander, gave the White Sox an easy 10-5 victory over the Dodgers today. The time of the game was 2 hours 4 minutes -- only five minutes shorter than yesterday's marathon with the Redlegs.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 28 -- Donna Reed, just honored by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences as the actress who gave the best supporting performance of 1953, in "From Here to Eternity," was signed yesterday by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for a second picture, to follow its production of "The Last Time I Saw Paris," in which she will play the sister of Elizabeth Taylor.
No matter what the color of their skin, "all our children must be looked at as the future rich heritage of the country," according to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

The fifth in the series of chamber music concerts presented under the direction of Alexander Schneider was given yesterday afternoon at 6 East Twenty-third Street. The program was devoted entirely to contemporary works that have received the award of the Fromm Music Foundation.
NORFOLK, Va., March 28 -- The Navy's great man-of-war, the battleship Missouri, will get orders this summer to come home from the sea for the Navy's saddest assignment: the mothball fleet.

A. L. Hammell, president of the Railway Express Agency, Inc., called upon his employes yesterday to help the company in its fight against the repeal of Public Law 199. He addressed a communion breakfast of 600 employe members of the Order of Seville, Knights of Columbus, at the Roosevelt Hotel.

William McGrath, Buffalo tenor who sang under Arturo Toscanini in Verdi's "Requiem" six years ago, gave his first New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall The performance was his reward for winning the sixth annual award of JUGG, Inc., a group devoted to helping young singers.
STEILACOOM, Wash., March 28 (AP) -- A northbound Union Pacific freight train was partly derailed crossing a flaming wooden trestle over an arm of Puget Sound early today.

The handicap made the difference yesterday as the Long Island polo team turned back the Squadron A trio, 11 -- 9, in a semi-final match of the National twelve-goal handicap tournament at the Squadron A Armory.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, March 28 -- The Dutch have taken another step toward convertibility. Nonresidents domiciled in European Payments Union countries now may transfer the proceeds of sale of non-securities capital invested in the Netherlands, as well as proceeds from the sale of securities.
The Greatest Show on Earth is in town for the eighty-fourth consecutive year.

Senator Alexander Wiley declared yesterday that any arrangement made in the forthcoming Geneva conference on the Far East that would result in the admission of Communist China to the United Nations would be "spurious and self-defeating."

In one of the most dreaded misfortunes that can strike a ship at sea the British troopship, the Empire Windrush, was gutted by fire in the Mediterranean Sea off Algiers. Four crewmen have perished in the disaster; the British Navy has been deprived of a valuable vessel, and for the officers and crew, her destruction comes as a personal loss.

Tommy Jackson, Rockaway Beach, L. I., heavyweight, making his third appearance in a main event, will face Dan Bucceroni of Philadelphia tonight in a ten-round bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn. Bucceroni, a candidate for a September bout with the world champion, Rocky Marciano, was guaranteed $10,000 for the fight.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- A Democrat on the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations scouted reports that it was "bogged down" in its inquiry into the dispute between high Army officials and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Western European and American newspapers and magazines have lately been flooded by reports from inside the Soviet Union. They tell about priceless television sets, refrigerators, washing machines and vacuum cleaners now being displayed in Moscow department stores.
ST. PAUL, Minn., March 28 (AP) -- Five prisoners, one brandishing a homemade stiletto, slugged a guard and overpowered another to escape from the Ramsey County Jail here today.
Many men have been lost in Brooklyn, but few have shown the intrepidity displayed yesterday by a Polish refugee in trying to get out of that borough.

MONTE CARLO, March 28 -- One hundred and fifty pairs played today through the second session of the Monte Carlo open-pair championship, the final event of the 1954 Monte Carlo contract bridge tournament.
LONDON, March 28 (UP) -- James L. Wick said today that about eighteen of the thirty- seven members of his group of touring American editors and publishers would go to the So- viet Union this week.

BERLIN, March 28 -- West Berlin's leading conservative newspaper, Der Tagespiegel, proposed today that West Germany form close political ties with Spain, Greece and Turkey in view of the poor prospects for the European Defense Community.

There is too often emphasis on the shortcomings of education instead of on the strengths of the nation's schools and colleges, Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, United States Commissioner of Education, said yesterday.

Argentine chess players made an excellent showing against their Russian opponents in the third round of the series of matches in Buenos Aires, losing by 4 1/2 -- 3 1/2, according to South American news sources. The Soviet grand masters, who had won the first and second rounds, each time by 5 -- 3, now lead by 14 1/2 -- 9 1/2, with one round to go.

FRANCONIA, N. H., March 28 -- Brooks Dodge, the American Olympian who did so well in the international ski games in Sweden last month, beat Chiharu Igaya, the Japanese star who is a freshman at Dartmouth, in a close contest for the Eastern slalom title today.

WASHINGTON, March 28 (AP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, and twelve other Senators today called for public rather than private development of hydroelectric power at Niagara Falls.
MEXICO CITY, March 28 -- Fresh radishes, carrots and lettuce graced the prisoners' lunch table at grimy Lecumberri Penitentiary today by courtesy of Lieut. Gen. P. T. Mow.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 28 -- Casey Stengel got his first glimpse today of a couple of old pitching hands who, directly or indirectly, could have a bearing on what the future has in store for the Yankees.
A major legal crackdown is in prospect this week on New York's strike-slowed waterfront.

CLEVELAND, March 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, today linked the welfare program of the Eisenhower Administration to a doctrine expressed by a twelfth century Jewish philosopher.
SAUK CITY, Wis., March 28 (AP) -- A "Joe Must Go" club for a campaign aimed at recalling Senator Joseph R. McCarthy from office was formed here today.

SIMCOE, Ont., March 28 -- Canada's cigarette tobacco growers, who are "steaming" their greenhouses this week in preparation for starting the new crop, have petitioned the Government for a further tax reduction to reduce competition from American manufacturers. A Government decision is expected in April.

MANILA, March 28 -- After three months in office, President Ramon Magsaysay is convinced that the greatest barriers to establishing clean, efficient government in the Philippines are the habits of the past.
New York City in 1953 had its highest delinquency total since the first post-war year of 1946, figures furnished by the New York City Youth Board showed yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 28 -- A movement aimed at overthrowing President Tito's regime was reportedly founded in Belgrade today.
ALGIERS, Algeria, March 28 -- More than 1,500 men, women and children were saved from the blazing British troopship Empire Windrush today.
CARACAS, Venezuela, March 28 -- The Tenth Inter-American Conference closed tonight with the formal signature of twenty republics on agreements reached on a wide range of subjects.

Sidney Raphael, in his recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, drew a consistently pleasing tone from the piano and, in general, played with sensitivity. He was, however, handicapped by technique not altogether reliable; and even the frequent slow tempos he used did not prevent inaccuracies.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation last year established new records in virtually every phase of operation, according to the report mailed to stockholders over the week-end. Gross operating income reached a new peak of $935,465,453, or 9 per cent over the 1952 total of $855,555,632.

LONDON, March 28 -- British politics have entered a peculiar phase in which the great issues of foreign and domestic policy and the strategy and tactics of the two great political parties are linked to the decision of one man on a personal problem.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., March 28 -- Cornelius Shields, the 1952 North American sailing champion, was victorious with his Dainty today as the Larchmont Yacht Club's frostbite fleet set a record by sending thirty-one Interclub dinghies to the starting line.
LONDON, March 28 (AP) -- Two influential British organizations devoted to protecting animals sought changes today in the Grand National Steeplechase to stop "the tragic carnage."
CHICAGO, March 28 -- The Illinois Central Railroad in its annual report to stockholders gave today details of its record vol-use of business in 1953 and predicted a "modest" downturn this year.

Domestic and foreign "isms," like a flock of vultures, "are tearing viciously at the body of individual freedom as if it were already dead." the Rev. Dr. Brainard Frederick Gibbons, general superintendent of the Universalist Church of America, declared yesterday.

Divine blessing on the thirty-fifth annual fund appeal of New York Catholic Charities was invoked yesterday at mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, where Cardinal Spellman pontificated. Three thousand worshipers were present.
Bright students who are admitted to college at the end of their sophomore or junior year in high school are able to do superior college work.
Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., announced details yesterday of its new "snap open" cigarette package, which it describes as the biggest advance since the cellophane overwrap two decades ago.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Conferees of the Senate and House of Representatives agreed today on a compromise bill cutting excise taxes by $999,000,000.
LONDON, March 29 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today called for a meeting of the United Nations Security Council on the general question of tension on Israel's borders.

BALTIMORE, March 29 (AP) -- A suit to force Tri-Continental Corporation, a New York investment firm, to declare an estimated $30,000,000 in dividends was filed today in United States District Court by a stockholder. David J. Conviser, owner of 800 shares of common stock, asked the court to order the corporation to include net realized capital gains for the past three years with net investment income in a dividend.

TAMPA, Fla., March 29 -- There is this to be said of spring exhibition games. They hold few dull moments for a manager even when it is a steaming, drowsy afternoon and his club is running smartly in front.
BERLIN, March 29 -- Thousands of Communist delegates came to East Berlin today for a party congress that is due to establish Walter Ulbricht as the undisputed leader of the party.

Bridges are such commonplace objects to people who live on islands like Manhattan that it is sometimes difficult for us to realize how much excitement a truly gigantic bridge can stir up among artists, poets, engineers or miscellaneous sight-seers from other places.

KANSAS CITY, March 29 -- The story of a world-wide scientific search for a source that may be altering the chemical composition of the earth's atmosphere was presented here today at the 125th national meeting of the American Chemical Society.

SAIGON, Vietnam, March 29 -- French Union tanks and infantrymen smashed a rebel Vietminh strongpoint in a surprise raid west of Dienbienphu yesterday. After a savage battle in enemy trenches and blockhouses the French withdrew, leaving behind an estimated total of 1,000 enemy casualties.

The Burry Biscuit Corporation of Elizabeth, N. J., announced yesterday completion of arrangements for the purchase of all the common stock of LeRoy Foods, Inc., of Brooklyn. A minor cash payment was involved, according to George W. Burry, president of the biscuit company, who refused to specify the amount.
The time is ripe for the textile industry to obtain better design protection, according to Sylvan Gotshal, counsel to The Textile Distributors Institute, Inc.
NEWCOMERSTOWN, Ohio, March 29 (AP) -- Cy Young celebrated his eighty-seventh birthday today by "sitting at home and reading" letters and cards of congratulation.

LAUREL, Md., March 29 (UP) -- Isador Bieber's King Jolie, the 1-to-2 choice, just lasted under a hard ride by Walt Blum today to score by a neck from Mrs. L. Frey's fast-closing Best Air in the $5,000 Georgetown Purse at Laurel Park.

A 57-year-old accountant was arrested and charged with grand larceny early today after officials said he had admitted stealing more than $250,000 from Manhattan State Hospital -- and losing it on the horses.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 29 -Daily newspapers and radio stations in Nassau County rejected District Attorney Frank A. Gulotta's appeal today for a news blackout on bomb scares in the county's public schools.
New York City's merchants last week provided a valuable lesson for the nation's retailers. They showed that buying could be stimulated by a combination of hard selling and good values.
SYDNEY, Australia, March 29 (AP) -- World bantamweight champion Jimmy Carruthers outpointed a fellow Australian, Bobby Sinn, tonight in a twelve-round non-title fight at Sydney Stadium.

Fashion accessories have never spelled "spring" so convincingly as they have this season. Botticelli's painting "Primavera" would be a symbol of the delicacy and freshness of this season's accessory trends.

Professional polish and imaginative designs distinguish the objects included in the forty-ninth annual exhibition of the New York Society of Craftsmen. The exhibit opens today in the Art Gallery of the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel and will continue through April 8.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 29 -- The opening session of the Yugoslav Communist Central Committee meeting today was devoted to an attack on the concept of free political activity.

WILMINGTON, Del., March 29 -- Industrial integrity rather than law is the only really effective guarantee against activities, that threaten public health and comfort. Crawford H. Greenewalt, president of the duPont Company said tonight.

Prices of lead and zinc advanced yesterday, reflecting increased buying demand in the wake of the announcement late Friday that new Government stockpile goals for many metals and minerals had been authorized by President Eisenhower.

A fifteen-story apartment house to contain 334 suites at 2 to 20 Tudor Place was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of ]Ko--g and Buildin gS 'The Fred F. French Investing Company, 551 Fifth Avenue, is the owner and William I. I:Iohauser is the. architect.

The Postal Life Insurance Company has sold its home office building at 511 Fifth' Avenue to Max N. and Norbert..'Natanson and has leased back- space in 'the building for its executive offices. ]The Cross ' Brown Company was the broker and the attorneys were' Judd ' Gurfein for' the seller and Charles Gadd'-for' the buyers.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 -- Columbia Pictures is interested in acquiring rights to "Wonderful Town," the Broadway musical hit based on the comedy, "My Sister Eileen."

THE paintings and watercolors by Lyonel Feininger on view at Curt Valentin's were executed between 1951 and the present -- in other words, after the artist had passed his eightieth birthday. But their zest, the breath of life that is infused into the romantically geometrical landscapes and the lovely clouds of color that envelop their linear rigidities would do credit to an artist at any age.

Twelve hundred wives of cattlemen in sixteen states are banded together in an organization known as the American National Cow Belles. The title may sound frivolous, but the purpose of the group is serious. It is to encourage home cooks to make greater use of plentiful beef.

Some stores are promising to rebate taxes paid on items chat will benefit by changes in the excise laws now being considered by Congress. But consumers appear to be delaying such purchases pending the changes, resident buying offices report.
MADRID, March 29 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco said today that he felt only contempt for those Spaniards who opposed the Falange party.

The American Iron and Steel Institute came up with a report yesterday that should gladden the hearts of hard-pressed economic optimists. The steel industry's operating rate turned upward last week for the first time in five weeks.

Six annual awards for handling of foreign news during 1953 were announced last night by the Overseas Press Club at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Each recipient received a bronze plaque and a $500 gold watch.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse served notice today he would do his utmost to bring about construction of new power plants at Niagara Falls by a public agency instead of by private interests.

MONTE CARLO, March 29 -Pierre Ghestem and Rene Bacherich, leading French contract bridge experts, today headed a field of 150 pairs in the Monte Carlo open pair championship final event. The week-long tournament is being held at the Sporting Club here.
BUENOS AIRES, March 29 -- The results of the Inter-American Conference at Caracas were virtually nil, the semi - official Argentine newspaper Democracia declared today.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A delegation that called on the Attorney General, Herbert Brownell Jr., today reported that he had assured them that the Department of Justice was developing a program to control more effectively the flow of "wetbacks" from Mexico into the United States.
MOSCOW, March 29 -- Charles E. Bohlen, United States Ambassador, delivered to the Soviet Foreign Office today the Western proposals on the practical details of the forthcoming Geneva conference.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Uncle Sam is trying to get into the used stamp business and make a profit.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- An old hand at helping charity and private welfare organizations raise funds today called for Federal action to make it hazardous for "charity racketeers" to operate.

The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission has decided to borrow $233,000,000 to finance construction of the system's 110-mile extension northeast to Scranton and the Pennsylvania share of the cost of a new bridge to be built over the Delaware River below Trenton to connect with the New Jersey Turnpike.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Stone and Webster Securities Corporation and White, Weld Co. will place on the market today a new issue of $10,000,000 of preferred stock of Tennessee Gas Transmission Company.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The State Department today backed up Dr. James B. Conant, United States High Commissioner, who said in Bonn Saturday that the Western powers would find a way to restore Germany's sovereignty soon.
LONDON, March 29 -- The stock markets here were cheerful today with many industrial leaders and individual speculative issues finishing around is (14 cents) up.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 30 (AP) -- Socialists used mounting Japanese tension over the hydrogen explosion as the basis for an attack in the Diet yesterday on the pending United States-Japanese mutual aid defense pact. They demanded, but failed to get, Government assurances that the United States would not stockpile nuclear weapons in Japan.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A thousand striking longshoremen from New York and New Jersey waterfronts marched in protest in front of the White House for more than seven hours today.
DALLAS, March 29 (AP) -- Phil Cavarretta was relieved as manager of the Chicago Cubs tonight and was replaced by Stan Hack, former Cub star now managing Los Angeles of the Pacific Coast League.
CLEARWATER, Fla., March 29 -- The Dodgers, who used to train in this ball park, may not want to see it again for a long time after what happened to them today.

The letter of Emerson C. Ives which appeared on March 24 uses specious reasoning to rationalize admission of Communist China to the United Nations. A previous New York Times editorial had demurred at the attitude of Britain's Sir Gladwyn Jebb and United Nations Secretary Hammarskjold's views that the U. N. might as well take in the Mao Tse-tung Government.

If there were those who had vaguely expected something exciting in the way of news to come out of Sunday night's radio-television interview of Secretary of Agriculture Benson, they must have found that half hour an unremunerative one. But to many others who listened we have an idea that, even though the interviewee didn't produce any white rabbits, it must have been a rewarding experience.

CHICAGO, March 29 (UP) -- Leon H. Keyserling, former chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said tonight the nation's economy was "moving downhill" and tax relief to individuals was needed.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., March 29 (AP) -- The Syracuse Nationals, who fly to Minneapolis tomorrow to play the Minneapolis Lakers there Wednesday in the opening game of the National Basketball Association's championship playoff series, had some encouraging news from their team physician today.

The North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference urged the Federal Maritime Board yesterday to reject objections by the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., against the organization's plan to establish a dual-rate contract system April 1 in North Atlantic trade.
CAIRO, March 29 -- The military rulers of Egypt postponed indefinitely today the plan to turn control over to elected civilians.

Mayor Wagner's election campaign promises on matters requiring money are now coming back to haunt him as he makes his budget, but on one of these matters the promise was fully justified and to keep it less than adequately would be detrimental to the public welfare.

Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, will be chairman of the Junior Achievement "Future Unlimited" dinner to be held Thursday, May 13, at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

Stockholders of the Colombian National Airways (Avianca) have voted to increase the authorized capital stock by 55 per cent during the next twelve months, according to advices from Barranquilla, Colombia.

PARIS, March 29 -- Informed observers here said tonight they believed the purpose of the speech by Secretary of State Dulles was to prepare the Western powers for a barrge of Communist propaganda against their unity.

In 1926, Theodore Hemerline, now 60 years old, was one of the first men to be sentenced to life imprisonment under the Baumes Law. Yesterday, he stood on the threshold of freedom after General Sessions Judge Louis J. Capozzoli reviewed and approved a writ of error (coram nobis) to set aside his first felony conviction in 1911.

The world's largest operating electric and gas utility, the $1,841,492,000 Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will spend approximately $375,000,000 over the next five years for new construction and improvements to its properties.

I have been prompted to write this letter by the recently reported attack on the Republican party, and particularly the claim that the party is really half Eisenhower, half McCarthy. I might explain, incidentally, that I myself am a member of the Tory party here and a strong supporter of Sir Winston Churchill.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday up 2 to 6 points.

If ever a situation was kaleidoscopic it has been that of Egypt in the past three or four weeks. Shifts, turns, overturns, mobs rising first for one faction and then for another, a President descending to the depths one day, rising to the heights a few days later and now falling to new depths -- such is the bewildering scenario that races across the Egyptian screen.

Browning King Co., operator of men's apparel stores, has leased the ground floor and the =-cond and thirdl floors in the twelve-story{ building at 666 Fifth Avenue, between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Street, for its second store on Fifth Avenue.

A local Selective Service Board was ordered yesterday to show cause today in Federal Court why it should not be held in contempt for "disobeying a decision and order of the United States Court of Appeals."

IT was just the other day Sal Maglie pitching batting practice for the Giants, was struck on the right forearm by a rifle shot off the bat of Willie Mays. They rushed the Barber to the hospital for X-rays, fearful that the arm was broken. Fortunately, the pictures were negative. But this could just as readily have been another in the astounding sequence of serious accidents that have befallen major league players this spring.

LONDON, March 29 -- The United States, Britain and France agreed today that the list of goods embargoed for sale to the Soviet Union and its East European satellites could be cut substantially without adding to Soviet war potential.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Another successful hydrogen blast -- the second in less than four weeks -- was set off last Friday by United States scientists in the Marshall Islands. The official word came this evening from Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, who returned to Washington this morning from the Pacific proving ground.

LONDON, March 29 (AP) -- Roland LaStarza moved up to a 2-1 choice tonight to win his international heavyweight fight against Don Cockell, British champion, at Earls Court Arena tomorrow night. A crowd of 18,000 is expected for the ten-round fight.
Pentagon officials and several Congressional committees are still preoccupied this week with the problem of service morale and incentives, and how to improve them.

In a stunning upset that had the crowd roaring, Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, Rockaway Beach heavyweight, scored a technical knockout over Dan Bucceroni of Philadelphia in 1:58 of the sixth round of the main bout listed for ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena last night.
NEW DELHI, India, March 29 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru called today for an end of experiments with the hydrogen bomb.

The development by Bausch Lomb of an improved CinemaScope camera lens for Twentieth Century-Fox and the reduction in price of CinemaScope attachments for theatre projectors were announced yesterday by Spyros P. Skouras, president of Fox, at a trade press luncheon at the Plaza Hotel.
The Cunard liner Queen Mary docked at Halifax, N. S., yesterday instead of Pier 90, North River, a victim of New York's pier strike.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 29 -- A resolution calling on Egypt to remove restrictions on passage of Israeli-bound ships through the Suez Canal was vetoed today by the Soviet Union in the United Nations Security Council.
Following is the text of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles' address before the Overseas Press Club of America last night on "Freedom and Indo-China," as recorded by The New York Times:
SPOKANE, Wash., March 29 (AP) -- A ten-engine B-36 bomber, taking off at sunset, crashed and burst into flames at Fairchild Air Force Base today, killing seven of the ten men aboard.

Strength in nonferrous metals, aircrafts and electrical equipments, was sufficient yesterday to give the stock market the appearance of vigor, despite losses for rails and mixed moves by oils and motors.

CHICAGO, March 29 (UP) -- Joseph Kolodny, managing director of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors, called on the tobacco industry today to hit back at "loose talk." He spoke at the convention of the National Association of Tobacco Distributors.

Women headed by Mrs. Richard E. Edmondson are furthering the success of the annual luncheon for the benefit of the Lots for Little Thrift Shop to be held on May 4 in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Alexander J. McDonnell is president of the Lots for Little Thrift Shop, 1214 Third Avenue, which is a permanent thrift shop established twenty-four years ago to raise funds for various charitable organizations.
Events tonight: Wilhelm Backhaus, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30 P. M.; Clinton Hill Symphony Orchestra, Pratt Institute Memorial Hall, Brooklyn, 8:30.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., March 29 -- Bob Laskowitz of Upsala pitched a three-hit shutout today as his team scored a 5-0 victory over Hamilton College in the opening game of a doubleheader at Viking Field. Upsala won the second contest, 17 -- 1, with the aid of nine Hamilton errors.

ALBANY, March 29 -- New York city received permission from the state today to collect $3,000,000 more in real estate taxes during the fiscal year that begins July 1, as well as $300,000 in a new race track admissions tax.
An immediate 25 per cent increase in the amount the city pays hospitals for the care of public-charge patients is being sought by the United Hospital Fund.

THERE are a number of conservation methods that have been applied to the preservation of moose herds in areas where this big animal showed a decrease in numbers. In most instances closing the season and increasing the protection seemed to solve the problem.
