A struggle for control of Yonkers Raceway, the profitable Westchester trotting track, came into the open yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission made public a letter today from the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, Boston, asking the I. C. C. to grant the request of the New York Central Railroad Company, for an investigation of the activities of Robert R. Young and associates, now seeking control of Central.

Morris Ernst, the attorney, will explore various aspects of traditional American freedoms when he substitutes for Barry Gray for three successive nights over WMCA, beginning tomorrow, from midnight to 2 A. M.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Three Republican Senators sponsored today legislation designed to clean up what they described as a multi-million-dollar traffic in "insidious filth" purveyed in illicit films and booklets.

Governor Dewey's approval of a bill giving the State Superintendent of Insurance authority to examine the affairs of union welfare funds is timely and should promise well for the beneficiaries of these funds.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) Senator Francis Case, Republican of South Dakota, accused the Air Force today of "pretty sloppy handling" of its accounts and collections after hearing testimony that some small commercial air carriers were delinquent on bills totaling more than $800,000 for fuel, parts and services.

Russia's chess players wound up their series of matches against Argentina with a 6-2 victory in the fourth round, in which they won four games and drew four, according to a report from Buenos Aires yesterday.

The opposition group seeking to wrest control of the $500,000,000 New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company from the management claimed yesterday to have "well over 30 per cent" of the road's roughly 1,000,000 shares of stock on its side, "without soliciting any proxies."
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Butter may be as much as 20 cents a pound below its present retail price on Thursday, Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson reported today.

A vacant irregular plot about 108 by 124 feet at the southwest corner of Fortieth Road and Northern Boulevard, Longl Island City, Queens, has been purchased by, the Peerles Weighing and Vending Machine Corporation,represented by Leon Himlnelfarbe, attorney.

In a major policy speech last night, a speech based on conferences with the principal Administration leaders and specifically approved by President Eisenhower, Secretary Dulles sought to impress upon the American people the decisive importance of Indo-China as a key bastion in the defense of the free world.

MILWAUKEE, March 29 (AP) -- Ernie Durando, middleweight from Bayonne, N. J., scored a technical knockout over Ted Olla of Milwaukee tonight in 2 minutes 3 seconds of the eighth round in a scheduled ten-round bout at the Arena.

The most important job for the natural gas industry is to encourage maximum exploration for new gas supplies, Stuart F. Silloway, vice president for finance of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, said yesterday

CAMDEN, S. C., March 29 (UP) -- Peter Thomson of Melbourne, Australia, carded a five-under-par 67 today to win first money in the second annual one-day pro-amateur golf tournament at the Camden Country Club.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- A legislative measure to impose safety regulations on small passenger - carrying boats ran afoul of disagreements today between East and West Coast boat associations and the Coast Guard.

CHICAGO, March 29 (UP) -- There are few fighters as methodical in their training as the world middleweight champion, Carl (Bobo) Olson. He went ahead with his scheduled road-work today in a snowstorm.

TULSA, Okla., March 29 -- Larry Jansen, long recognized as a good cold weather pitcher, did not mind the 39-degree temperature that chilled the Giants, the Indians and an overcoated crowd of 3,075 fans today.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs increased over the last week.

CHICAGO, March 29 -- Grain futures worked substantially lower today, with a wide-open break in rye. Soybean futures were heavy at times but closed on an upswing, which made for sharp price gains for the day. There was long liquidation in wheat, and a little late recovery from the low spots on short covering, but sentiment appeared, to be against the bulls.
Thousands of motor vehicles destined for overseas are jamming storage fields in the metropolitan area because the port is strike-throttled:

Retailers who gear sales efforts to real value rather than price can expect to increase their summer and fall business by 10 to 15 per cent over 1953, according to James B. Lee, president of Frank H. Lee Company, producer of men's hats.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A long-latent economic and foreign policy crisis over the Eisenhower Administration's world trade program began materializing today. It came on the eve of a Presidential message to Congress on the subject.

A one-volume edition containing selections from three decades of William Faulkner's work will be published Thursday by Random House entitled "The Faulkner Reader." In the foreword Mr. Faulkner gives his credo as a writer.
Subpoenas flurried over the strike - stilled waterfront yesterday as a four-barreled legal attack on the old International Longshoremen's Association got under way.

A 17-year-old Marine Corps recruit was under detention yesterday in the Marine barracks at Parris Island, S. C., after the police here said he had made a statement in the slaying of Mrs. Anna Gresh. Mrs. Gresh's body was found last Friday in a tub in her home at 199 Avenue B.

TRENTON, March 29 --The architectural tastes of Gov. Robert B. Meyner are not to be satisfied completely in the State House alterations now in progress. But action today by the State House Commission will assure at least some of the changes he sought in the over-all design of the entrance.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Questions on the adequacy of the pending bill to consolidate all special Federal health grants into a general fund to each state were raised today by Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York.

In a recent letter to you Richard H. Wels claimed that the proposals for the code of ethics suggested by Governor Dewey do not come "to grips with the problem created" by political and party officers owning stock in race tracks.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) March 29 -- Premier Moshe Sharett declared today that he had no direct knowledge of a reported killing of nine Jordanians at Nahhalin.

Gerald D. Sarhis has purchased the three-family house at 65 I-Iinsdale Street in Brooklyn from R. Moses in a transaction negotiated by Slomka Brothers as brokers. Title was insured by the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

IN the winter of 1830 His Majesty's Ship Beagle, a brig of about 240 tons, was beating back and forth in the stormy waters of the South Pacific and the bays and passages of the island archipelago which lies off the great island of Tierra del Fuego. In command was Robert Fitzroy, a young hydrographer and meteorologist whose grandfathers were a duke and a marquis.
Special nurse instructors conduct a popular Red Cross training course in mother and baby care, which is offered without charge by Red Cross chapters, including those in New York.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The State Department said today it was discussing with the British and French Governments whether to bring the disputes between Israel and her Arab neighbors before the United Nations Security Council.
WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- The Treasury and the Federal Reserve system joined forces today in opposing a proposal to put the United States back on the gold standard at this time.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Navy, silent up to now on the fate of the battleship Missouri, acknowledged today that the 45,000-ton vessel was being "tentatively considered" for assignment to the "mothball fleet."

An important feature of the recent speeches by high Soviet leaders was the attention paid to the Soviet housing crisis. Where this subject was usually passed over in silence while Stalin lived, virtually every member of the Party Presidium admitted this time that the housing situation is bad.
A noted Harvard economist declared yesterday that there would be an economic upturn by midsummer "even if we don't do something about it, but it would be better if we did."

CHICAGO, March 29 -A man under a death sentence for murder asked $500,000 clamages in a suit filed here today in Superior Court on the ground his picture was used illegally on a billboard advertising a motion picture.

Bees and humans competed yesterday for lunch-hour sunshine in midtown Manhattan. The humans decided to allow squatter's rights for the insects and proceeded to enjoy themselves in the rest of the city.
HARTFORD, March 29 --The Connecticut Supreme Court upheld tonight the constitutionality of the Connecticut Redevelopment Law. The statute permits cities and towns to condemn and rebuild slum areas.

New York's Fifth Avenue Association sent a good-will trophy yesterday to "Europe's Fifth Avenue," the Lijnbaan, Rotterdam's new shopping plaza. The gilt bowl trophy was presented to Baron J. A. de Vos van Steenwijk, Consul-General of the Netherlands, in a ceremony at his office at 10 Rockefeller Plaza.
ROME, MARCH 29 -- A Center-Right coalition has won a victory whose political repercussions will be felt throughout Italy.
The Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound ratified championship and distance dates for the forthcoming season at its spring meeting in the New York Yacht Club last night.
Labor and management in the photo-engraving field have joined forces to sponsor a scholarship program in the Graphic Arts center of Columbia University.

Contemporary designs and paterns of the documentary type make up a new, spring-like collection of wallpapers at Richard E. Thibaut, 44 East Fifty-third Street. Designed by Fred R. Kazenwadel, the papers are sun and water-fast and comparatively inexpensive.

The favorite silhouettes of the season were featured in a collection of suits and gowns shown yesterday at luncheon at the Carlton House. They were from the shop of Mimi Tuthill at 27 East Sixty-first Street.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 29 (AP) -- A Professor of Greek Literature and two other Swiss went on trial in Federal Criminal Court here today on charges of violating Switzerland's strict espionage laws. They were accused of gathering derogatory information on the International Red Cross at Communist behest.
A plan to replace ninety patrolmen and detectives in the Bureau of Criminal Identification with civilian employes is being considered by the Police Department.
NEWARK, March 29 -- The Waterman Steamship Corporation has scheduled a minimum of ten arrivals and sailings each month at Port Newark.
LOS ANGELES, March 29 -- City authorities have announced they will no longer sanction marathon television shows to raise money for charities.

Robert R. Young asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to rule that pre-trial testimony related to his suit against the New York Central Railroad should not be permitted to touch upon the sale off 800,000 shares of Central stock to two of his business associates.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 29 (AP) -- Jacnot Stable's Amphiblen scored his first victory in two years today in the $3,500 Lucky Me Purse before 13,059 racing fans at Gulfstream Park.
Almost a fifth of New York City boys between 8 and 18 years old were enrolled in Boy Scout organizations last year.
MONTREAL, March 29 -- World commerce returned to the St. Lawrence today as the first ship of the season passed Quebec en route to Montreal, where she is expected to dock tomorrow.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 30 (AP) -- New arrests and a Government official's fall to death centered fresh attention today on Japan's growing shipping scandal, a threat in its early stages to Premier Shigeru Yoshida's Cabinet.

The birth of a baby girl to a stowaway aboard the Moore- McCormack liner Uruguay at sea on St. Patrick's Day was reported here yesterday by ship's officers on the arrival of the liner from South America.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The transcript of the testimony of Spruille Braden before the Jenner Senate subcommittee on March 25 reveals a better-built structure than the spot news dispatches indicated for his circumstantial evidence that the Department of State in the Nineteen Forties made matters easier for the extension of the Soviet party line.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 29 -- Telephone officials climbed uncompleted stairs and temporary ladders today to the top of a 204-foot tower here for the "topping off" of a new multi-million-dollar bomb-resistant headquarters and switching center.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 29 (UP) -- Roderick J. Wilson, one of the accusers of Chief Justice Earl Warren before the Senate confirmed his appointment to the high court, today surrendered to police. The surrender was on an old indictment and Wilson promptly moved to quash it.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- A dozen lines were out tonight to land a special counsel to conduct the investigation into who has told the truth in Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's controversy with the Army.

The "magical name" of Eisenhower will not head this fall's election ballots, the president of the Women's National Republican Club, Mrs. Edward Ewen Anderson, cautioned women party members last night.
The late President Franklin D. Roosevelt deliberately courted the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941, according to a new book written by a retired Navy admiral and published today.
BONN, Germany, March 29 -- Dr. Theodor Heuss, President of West Germany, signed today the laws ratifying the European Defense Community Treaty and the Bonn peace contract with the Western Allies.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The Eisenhower Administration has taken a fundamental policy decision to block the Communist conquest of Southeast Asia -- even if it has to take "united action" with France and other countries to do so.

The battle of the filter-tip cigarettes is getting hotter. With the R. J. Reynolds Winston, a king-size filter-tip, being tested in some markets at 26 cents, a decided price advantage, Liggett Myers yesterday reduced its L. M., a standard-size filter-tip, 4 cents, effective at once.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today there had been no decision on a proposal that he make a good-will tour of Italy.
HARRISON, N. J., March 29 -The Worthington Corporation demonstrated today for the first time its new hydraulic testing laboratory, believed to be one of the largest in the world.
Eastern Steamship Lines, owner of the cruise liners Evangeline and Yarmouth, has received approval of the Federal Maritime Board to transfer the 5,000 gross-ton vessels to foreign registry.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The National Farmers Union said today that its check of Congress showed that the Administration could not muster enough votes to get its farm legislation through "one piece at a time."
I note your editorial on the potato problem in the March 26 issue.
Secretary of State Dulles declared last night that Communist domination of Indo-China and Southeast Asia "would be a grave threat to the whole free community."
PARIS, March, 29 -- Both French and foreign reproof of Marshall Alphonse-Pierre Juin resulted today from his speech Saturday opposing the European army treaty.
SEOUL, Korea, March 29 -- Flights of bombers and jet fighters swept in over South Korea today in theoretical strikes at crucial targets.

Prices of coffee declined sharply yesterday on the New York exchange. This was the first time since March 16 that all months closed lower. During the day all positions dropped the 2 cents a pound daily limit but recovered slightly before the end of the session.

PARIS, March 29 -- Dr. Luther Evans, Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, announced today that he was withholding action in the case of David N. Leff, a staff member. An arrest warrant was issued against Mr. Leff last Thursday in Federal District Court in New York.

WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright told the Senate today that a proposal to give commonwealth status to Hawaii and Alaska was not an alternative to statehood but a step toward statehood and complete independence.

Robert L. Joseph has purchased the English rights to Jean Giraudoux' two-act play, "La Guerre de Troi N'Aura Pas Lieu" ("The Trojan War Will Not Be Fought") and plans to give it simultaneous productions on Broadway and in London early next fall.

GREENWICH, Conn., March 29 -- The first parochial high school in Fairfield County, now being organized by St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, will have its size and to some extent its operation controlled by five conditions imposed by the Planning and Zoning Board of Appeals.

Net profit of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., and subsidiaries, distillers, for the six months ended on Feb. 28 amounted to $11,067,906, equal to $3.83 a share, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $10,229,519, or $3.54 a share a year earlier.

NAHHALIN, Jordan, March 29 -- Nine persons were killed last night when this village of 300 persons was attacked with mines, grenades, automatic weapons and "Molotov cocktail" fire bombs. Thirteen persons were wounded, six critically.

SEATTLE, March 29 (AP) -- Don Gilinski, a teen-age youth bowling with the No. 2 team of Detroit's Cecil Ward All-Stars, rolled into the singles lead of the fifty-first annual American Bowling Congress today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 29 -- Walt Disney is taking his motion-picture studio into television in association with the American Broadcasting Company, which is owned by United Paramount Theatres.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc. in 1953 had the most successful year in its history, with sales and earnings at new high marks.
WASHINGTON, March 29 -- The House Rules Committee struck a telling, perhaps fatal, blow at public housing today.
Effective immediately, city firemen will be assigned, regularly to small theaters where live shows are presented. Small theatres are defined as those seating fewer than 300 persons.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 30 (Canadian Press) -- England's fast-medium bowler, Trevor Bailey, smashed through West Indies' top batting combination to take three wickets for thirteen runs within thirty minutes of the fifth test match opening today.

Ground was broken yesterday for the forty-two-story SoconyVacuum Building to be built on the block bounded by Lexington and Third Avenues and Fortysecond Streets. The structure is expected to be finished in about two years.

New issues of corporate securities totaling $40,900,000 will go on the market today. The offerings consist of public utility mortgage bonds, debentures of a grocery chain store system and convertible preferred shares of a motion-picture production company.

Link-Belt Company sales in the first quarter of 1954 will be 10 to 15 per cent below the volume posted in the first quarter of of 1953, Robert C. Bechers, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday in Chicago.
Three juniors and a sophomore were named yesterday as captains of four Columbia varsity teams for the 1954-55 season.

William Wyer, trustee for the Long Island Rail Road, blamed the state Public Service Commission yesterday for the financial difficulties of the bankrupt carrier. He said that if the applications for passenger fare increases had been approved, the Long Island would not have to tap its reserve fund to meet prevailing expenses.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Following are present excise tax rates and the reductions finally approved today by Congress and awaiting President Eisenhower's signature:

BERLIN, March 30 -- The Soviet Union suddenly stopped issuing visas today to foreigners seeking to enter or leave Berlin. The move, which does not affect citizens of the occupying powers, was clearly designed to support East Germany's bid for Western diplomatic recognition.
OCANA, Spain, March 30 -- A court-martial convicted thirty-four men today of having carried out subversive activities designed "to reorganize the Communist party in Spain." One woman was acquitted.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The President's program for a bold and integrated foreign trade policy program, which he outlined to Congress in a message today, received a mixed reception both from Congress and industry.

To those who have seen at firsthand the fine accomplishments wrought in our large cities by slum-clearance public housing it is discouraging to see the opposition, even to the point of animus, voiced against such housing in Congress, and especially in the House.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The question of whether evidence obtained by wiretapping -- eavesdropping over telephones, the telegraph or the wireless -- should be acceptable in court ran into unexpected debate today.

Enactment of the Administration's legislative program with some additions was urged yesterday by Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican-Liberal of New York, as the best means of coping with economic recession.

Amusements, aircrafts and base metal producers put on brilliant performances in yesterday's stock market and gave an impression of great strength. But although many less volatile issues followed them to some extent, the movement was less than general.

DALLAS, March 30 (UP) -- The Chicago Cubs, playing under the temporary direction of Coach Bob Scheffing while their former manager, Phil Cavarretta, watched from the stands, defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 3 to 1, today in a brilliant pitching battle.

RED BANK, N. J., March 30 -- The National Sweepstakes Regatta on the Navesink River here, for a quarter-century one of the country's recognized "Big Three" race meets for speed-boat daredevils, will be continued this year. The allocated dates are Saturday and Sunday, Sept. 11 and 12.
There is no substantial reason for concern about the economic picture this year, according to Leo Cherne, executive director of the Research Institute of America.

Cocoa prices tumbled yesterday after strong advances in the five previous trading sessions on the New York exchange. Coffee prices continued to ease. Other commodities closed irregular with cottonseed oil, soybean oil, hides and tin mixed; potatoes, zinc and silk lower, and sugar, rubber, wool, burlap, lead and copper higher.

The Jordan-Israel Mixed Armistice Commission (with the Israelis absent) has condemned "in the strongest terms" the "aggression" by a "large group of military-trained Israelis" against the Jordanian village of Nahhalin at midnight of March 28-29. The whole civilized world will join in this condemnation.
KARACHI, Pakistan, March 29 -- A mass campaign for the resignation of the Central Government and the dissolution of the Constituent Assembly will begin Sunday in East Pakistan.

Volunteers in Red Cross production service last year contributed almost 2,500,000 hours of their time, producing more than 16,000,000 surgical dressings for civilian and military hospitals, making and repairing garments for the needy, and producing other articles.
LONDON, March 30 -- Sir Winston Churchill warned the House of Commons today against impeding United States progress toward "overwhelming" strength in hydrogen bombs.
Adoption of the "Buffalo Plan" for solving New York's traffic ills was urged yesterday by unanimous vote of the City Council.

Nineteenth century furniture styles supersede eighteenth century styles in the offerings at the newly opened Provence House, 18 East Fifty-eighth Street. Empire, Directoire, Beidermeier and Regency are very much in evidence as they have been in all traditional collections introduced here recently.

Members of the Columbia University faculty and other authorities in various fields will participate in a new thirteen-week series of discussions on "Invitation to Learning," over the C. B. S. radio network at 11:35 A. M., beginning Sunday. The programs will develop the University's Bicentennial theme "Man's Right to Knowledge and the Free Use Thereof."
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Gen. John K. Cannon, Chief of the Tactical Air Command, will retire tomorrow after thirty-seven years of duty. His is the longest service record of any Air Force officer.

It is quite possible that the main issues of the Geneva conference will be decided before the actual sessions begin. The speech made by Secretary of State Dulles to the Overseas Press Club was a clear statement of the United States position on the questions to be discussed with Communist China.
A three-alarm fire, visible for several miles in downtown Brooklyn, destroyed a mattress factory at 46 Bergen Street early last night.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Opposition to statehood for both Hawaii and Alaska crumpled today in the Senate.

LONDON, March 30 -- Britain, France and the United States announced today "a wide area of agreement" about liberalizing controls so as to permit more Western trade with the Soviet Union and its satellites.

TORONTO, March 30 (UP) -- A sizzling slap shot from the stick of Defenseman Red Kelly, less than four minutes from the game's end, gave the Detroit Red Wings a 2-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight and a 3-1 lead in their four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup hockey semi-finals.

IN their preface to "The Best From Fantasy and Science Fiction: Third Series,"* Anthony Boucher and J. Francis McComas, the editors of that magazine, express considerable scorn for critics who, after reading "an insignificantly small sample" of the current crop of science fiction, express "insignificantly large generalized conclusions."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 30 -- With screeching sirens and an arsenal of firearms, thirty-six policemen brought three veteran criminals from Sing Sing Prison at Ossining to Westchester County Court here today.

TAMPA, Fla., March 30 -- In the wake of the deal that sent Bobby Morgan to the Phillies, Manager Walter (Smokey) Alston today disposed of another infielder, young Don Zimmer, who is rated one of the top entries in the Brooklyn Dodgers' "future book."
LONDON, March 30 (AP) -- Britain's horse-loving, steeplechasing Royal Family was dragged today into the argument over the Grand National Steeplechase.

NOTEWORTHY recent acquisitions backed up by examples from the permanent collections but not previously exhibited make up a very attractive show in main floor galleries at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. Opening to the public today, the exhibition will continue until April 20. Concurrently the showing of work by younger European artists will continue in galleries on the second floor.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, reported today that the number of civilians on Government payrolls dropped 6,125 from January to February. to 2,346,892. He said Government' civilian payrolls aio declined $118,007,000 between December and 'January, the latest figures available, to a total of $756,498,000. Senator Byrd released the figures as chairman of the Joint Committee on Reduction of NonEssential Federal Ex?enditres.

A pretty fair showman himself, Cecil B. DeMille once said, "You can shake the sawdust out of your shoes but you can't shake it out of your heart." Circus folk -- ranging from those billed as the magnificents and the greats to the unbilled roustabouts -- with their attachment for life under the big top will attest to belief in that fact.

The first break in the crippling waterfront strike came last night when tug crews returned to work in obedience to a Federal injunction. Four tugs helped the French liner Ile de France into her North River berth at 6:30 P. M., and union leaders promised there would be no further interference with towboat service.

PARIS, March 30 -- Secretary of States Dulles' speech yesterday on United States policy in Southeast Asia was considered here to have been designed partly to discourage hopes in France of gaining peace in Indo-China by United States concessions to Communist China.
Baltimore, Ohio, borrowed $36,050,000 in the public market yesterday to finance various public improvements on an issue of serial bonds maturing from 1956 to 1990.

CHICAGO, March 30 (UP) -- George Weissman, vice president of Philip Morris and Company, said today that the cigarette industry would "stop business tomorrow" if it thought its product was harming smokers.
Borough President Hulan E. Jack was told yesterday that tenants on the site of the new West Park housing project were being relocated with a minimum of inconvenience.
LAUREL, Md., March 30 (AP) -- William G. Helis Jr.'s Woodlands and Mrs. Ella K. Bryson's Helbo scored popular victories in the divisions of today's featured $4,000 Chevy Chase Purses at Laurel.

MANILA, March 30 -- The Philippine Government announced today the suspension of long-range international operations of the Philippine Air Lines in order to conserve taxpayers' funds for national development.
A drastic reduction in the number of police emergency squads was announced yesterday.

Having just finished an engagement of "The Mikado," the American Savoyards, with Dorothy Raedler as the guiding spirit, turned last night to "The Pirates of Penzance" at the President Theatre. The ladies and gentlemen of the troupe sang it crisply, with relish, cheerfulness and with proper flamboyance.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 30 (Reuters) -- Six Mau Mau terrorist leaders met British colonial officials in a rendezvous at Nyeri today and indicated they would try to engineer a mass surrender of their followers, the Government announced.

"Elephant Walk," Paramount's Technicolor version of the Robert Standish novel starring Elizabeth Taylor, Dana Andrews and Peter Finch, has been scheduled to open on Thursday, April 15, at the Astor Theatre, the company announced yesterday.

Bellevue Hospital honored yesterday the physician who has directed it for longer than anyone in its history of more than two centuries -- Dr. William F. Jacobs, medical superintendent since 1931. He retires May 1, after thirty-seven years in the city's service.

The landlord of an East Harlem tenement whose failure to pay utilities bills left sixteen families without gas, electricity, heat and hot water for almost two weeks, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of multiple dwelling law violations.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., March 30 (AP) -- The General Electric Company said tonight it would recognize no union in negotiating grievances during the current jurisdictional fight between two electrical unions.
The first full year of operations using natural gas has proved profitable for the Brooklyn Union Gas Company.

ia_ contract for the purchase of the building: on plot 100 by 44 feet at the southwest corner of adison Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street has been resold by Jack Brause, operator, to a client of Louis Robbins, attorney, in a d.eal negotiated by Jame. s Felt Co.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 30 -- Misfortune again overtook the Yankees today, although this time the Bombers did have the saving grace of slightly altering the script. Instead of going out at the finish, as they did against the Redlegs in Tampa yesterday, they went into their crackup at the start.

Early this month the United States and Japan signed a mutual aid pact aimed at restoring Japan to the rank of an important World Power. One hundred years ago today these two nations began their formal diplomatic relations in a hastily constructed "treaty house" located three miles from the village of Kanegawa on the shores of Yedo (now Tokyo) Bay.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- John Foster Dulles' plans to mobilize "united action" against the Communists in Indo-China are more ambitious than anything he disclosed in his speech last night.
The Massachusetts Turnpike Authority has decided to bring to market in May a $240,000,000 issue of forty-year revenue bonds.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 30 (AP) -- Bruce Campbell's Marmion, a 3-year-old colt that had failed to win in nineteen previous starts, registered a two-and-a-half-length victory in the $3,200 Lejeune Purse before 11,303 persons at Gulfstream Park today.

TUCSON, Ariz., March 30 -- Frank Patania, an outstanding jeweler in the Southwest, came to the United States with his parents from Messina, Sicily, when he was 10 years old. Even then he had been apprenticed to a jeweler in his native land.
SAGINAW, Mich., March 30 (UP) -- Embarrassed state officials said today they were trying to find a way to return to a congregation a church claimed for $37.78 in back taxes.

LINCOLN, R. I., March 30 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito, returning after a "day off," piloted home five winners on the Lincoln Downs racing card today. He was third in the featured Tiverton Purse, which was won by Mrs. W. Hinphy's Unrestricted.
Speeders and drunk drivers were dubbed by a state official last night as "maniacs behind the wheel."
The reduction in excise taxes approved yesterday by Congress was hailed as a constructive step for reviving lagging retail trade.

Delinquency among children and youths under 21 increased 18.5 per cent between 1952 and 1953 in New York City, and was greater last year than in any year since 1946. The figures are made public by the New York City Youth Board, whose chairman is Justice Nathaniel Kaplan of the Children's Court.

The National Button Association is preparing to file with the Federal Maritime Board a protest against "arbitrary and discriminatory" freight rates on glass buttons by the Continental North Atlantic Westbound Freight Conference, Erwin Feldman, association counsel, reported yesterday.

Young women headed by Mrs. David A. Gimbel and including Miss Jennifer Ballard are aiding members of the executive committee in advancing the plans for the jazz concert to be held on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind.

Three apartmSen houses in the Bronx, two on Wales Avenue and one on St. Ann's Avenue. have !been sold by Isaac Hymamo the Steve-IVIart Company. The property consists ofthe fory-eightfamily house at 471 Wales Avenue, the building with fifty-one apartments and three stores at 451 Wales Avehue and the sixty-eight-family structure at 710-20 St; Ann's Avenue.

New York should have more firemen and fire-fighting equipment, Mayor Wagner said last night in a recorded radio address. It was part of an hour-long documentary over WABC on the work of the Fire Department.

MONTE CARLO, March 30 -- Frank Bodier and Pierre Figeac, two 28-year-old French contract bridge experts, were declared today winners of the open pair championship, the final event in the 1954 Monte Carlo tournament at the Sporting Club.
LONDON, March 30 -- The British people were told today that they would be taking a short cut to national bankruptcy if the prices of their exports rose.
Three special Pullman trains, carrying 617 passengers from the strike - diverted Cunard liner Queen Mary, will arrive at Grand Central Terminal today between 3 A. M., and 9:30 A. M.

It's quite possible that Paul Osborn will collaborate with Joshua Logan in turning "Sayonara," the James Michener novel, into a musical. Mr. Osborn still hasn't decided definitely, but promised to have a decision in a month.
THE hunter planning to stalk deer in the Highlands next fall has an opportunity to get in some valuable practice now, by stalking the woodchuck on the knoll. Or even "off" the knoll, for that matter.
LONDON, March 30 -- Don Cockell weathered a last-round rally by Roland LaStarza and won the referee's decision over the Bronx heavyweight in a ten-round bout at Earls Court tonight.

The American Radio Association, C. I. O., charged yesterday that shipowners were "convertly seeking to undermine sea safety, circumvent their collective bargaining contracts and block the democratic functioning of the Congress by brazen blackmailing tactics."
There will be no increase this season in the general admission price at Yonkers and Roosevelt Raceways.

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 30 (UP) -- Vic Seixas, Wimbledon champion from Philadelphia, opened his bid for the men's singles title in a tennis tournament today by defeating David Rodriguez of Puerto Rico, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, in the first round.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Republicans will attempt to vote a revised Taft-Hartley bill out of the Senate Labor Committee tomorrow.

The chairman of the New York City Housing Authority asserted last night that the construction of six low-income developments designed to accommodate 7,082 families here would have to be abandoned if Congress failed to approve "backlog" public housing funds.

We went back to Le Beaujolais the other day, and are glad to record that the new management of Freddie Lamb has tampered little with this engaging French-style restaurant at 17 East Sixtieth Street. The mussels are as delicious as ever, the hors d'oeuvre varies beguiling and the omelets soft and fluffy, as befits a good French omelet.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 30 -- A new Vietminh assault on Dienbienphu again appears to be near, according to military observers here.
The executive committee of the Mayor's Advisory Council agreed at its first meeting yesterday to undertake a study of juvenile delinquency.
A plan for unifying two major unions in the retail field was approved yesterday by the executive board of the Retail Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. today charged the Torrington Company of Torrington, Conn., in a civil anti-trust action with attempting to monopolize the manufacture and sale of machine needles.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30 -- The United States took the offensive at the opening today of the spring session of the United Nations Economic and Social Council. It reported on the issuance of visas to representatives of organizations it branded as Soviet-dominated.

Many tickets have been purchased for the opening night performance of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus tonight at Madison Square Garden for the benefit of United Cerebral Palsy. Through the generosity of John Ringling North, president of the circus, the entire proceeds from the opening night performance will be donated to the beneficiary.

Textile standards moved a little closer to realization yesterday when the Consumers Goods Standards Board of the American Standards Association approved the scope of a new project for "minimum requirements for all textiles."

DALLAS, March 30 (AP) -- Stan Hack, brought in as manager of the Chicago Cubs in an effort to pick up the flagging fortunes of his old team, said today there was "real potential power" on the club and "we'll be playing every ball game to win."

Members of the Barnard Thrift Shop Committee have arranged a tea in behalf of the Barnard College scholarship fund, to be held on Tuesday afternoon in the home of Mrs. Alfred F. Hess at 875 Park Avenue. Mrs. Percy P. Perkins heads the committee in charge of the arrangements for the event.

THE most exciting young-heavyweight fighter to appear in years swooped unexpectedly into public consciousness Monday night when Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson blew into town. He wrecked the heavyweight picture and turned it topsy-turvy. Rocky Marciano hasn't taken to his storm-cellar yet but the champion of the world had better start making preparations.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- Three insurance groups told Congress today that President Eisenhower's health reinsurance plan would not help persons who could not buy health insurance now.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A parliamentary maneuver aimed at sudden death and a quick burial for the public housing program was successful today in the House of Representatives. But there was an unexpected backfire that cast doubt on whether the program's opponents had actually accomplished their purpose.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and private shipping firms asked Congress today to allow the Navy to guarantee a long-term charter for twenty tankers to be constructed by private industry.

In a major statement of foreign economic policy President Eisenhower yesterday presented to Congress a specific legislative program which, if he fights for it, could become one of the important achievements of his Administration.
PESCARA, Italy, March 30 (AP) -- Christian Democrats beat the Communists in municipal elections in the near-by mining town of Manoppello. The town previously had been a Red stronghold.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 30 -- The United Nations Security Council is as ineffective now in dealing with the Palestine question as it is in settling East-West disputes. Or rather, the Palestine question, on which the United States and the Soviet Union once stood more or less together, has itself become an East-West dispute.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Two key backers of the Administration's farm program proposed today a new system of Federal price supports on dairy products.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Democrats announced today a series of Jefferson-Jackson Day Dinners in fifteen states and the District of Columbia in a drive to eliminate the last $100,000 of a $830,000 deficit resulting from the 1952 Presidential campaign.

A facsimile edition of "The Assassination of President Lincoln and the Trial of the Conspirators," which has been out of print for more than seventy- five years, will be issued April 14 by Funk Wagnalls. The book was written and published in 1865 by Benn Pitman, chief court reporter at the trial.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The State Department said today it had denied a passport to Arthur Miller, playright.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Representive Shepard J. Crumpacker Jr., Republican of Indiana, said today that Ford and General Motors apparently are trying to "monopolize" the auto industry and urged the Federal Trade Commission to investigate.

The question whether field interviewers who gather the data for market research are "employes" or "independent contractors" has been a thorn to concerns processing such information for the benefit of advertisers and media.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Eight months after the ceasefire in Korea, the Army still has under investigation 105 repatriated prisoners of war. They are suspected of offenses ranging from subversion to treason.

Wall Street's big banks have decided to scratch more aggressively for the diamonds in their own back yard. Tired of having the large Government bond houses borrow money out of town to carry positions in Treasury securities, some of the important deposit banks yesterday cut their rate for loans to dealers for carrying Government debt from 1 3/4 to 1 /12 per cent.

The New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street will show free movies on Fridays at the lunch period. Four film "shorts" -- as short as ten minutes and as long as twenty-two -- will make up each hour-long program. The showings will begin at noon and will be repeated at 1 P. M.
Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's statement in the House of Commons in London yesterday on the hydrogen bomb, as distributed by the British Information Services:
ROME, March 30 -- The Cabinet approved today a bill greatly increasing the penalties for tax evasion.

PANAMA, March 30 -- The mystery about which historians and geographers are puzzled may be solved by an expedition setting out this week from Las Palmas in the Darien Province to attempt to determine on just what peak Balboa stood when he first saw the Pacific Ocean.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census said today preliminary estimates of foreign trade in February indicated that exports were larger than in January but that imports fell off.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 30 -- Marshal Tito asserted today that both the East and the West were seeking to destroy his regime and turn it from its unique path toward socialism.

ROME, March 30 -- Government circles said today the European Defense Community treaty would be submitted to Parliament for ratification this week or, at the latest, next week. The forecast followed a meeting of the Cabinet.
Caught in a profit squeeze, three large typewriter manufacturers are revising their price lists upward.
ALBANY, March 30 (UP) -- Governor Dewey opened the way today for the restoration of the historic village of Richmondtown in the Borough of Richmond.

Shipbuilding, ship repair and machinery construction last year increased the business of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company of Chester, Pa., to more than three times the 1952 level. However, net income to a dollar of turnover fell considerably.
On a sales increase of 44 per cent, the Glenn L. Martin Company, aircraft builder, achieved record net income of $15,094,756 last year, 160 per cent above the $5,808,312 cleared in 1952.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The first post-war edition of the official map of the United States was supposed to make its debut today.
CHICAGO, March 30 (AP) -- Spring storms left at least twenty-two dead and a trail of snow from Nevada to New England today.
CAIRO, March 30 -- A few muted rumblings of discontent at the decision to prolong Egypt's military dictatorship filtered today through the press censorship, reimposed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- When Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby urged today a greatly expanded vocational rehabilitation program before a Senate subcommittee the principal criticism she got was that it did not go far enough.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 30 -- Virginia Mayo and Jack Palance are the first performers to be selected for "The Silver Chalice," to be produced for Warner Brothers by Victor Saville from the Thomas B. Costain novel.

AMMAN, Jordan, March 30 -- King Hussein I of Jordan said today that the only way to force Israel to cease armed incursions across the Jordanian frontier was to have the Western big powers halt aid to that country.
MOSCOW, March 30 -- A newsreel of the recent Soviet elections, now being shown all over the Soviet Union, has made history.

NEWARK, March 30 -- The emergence of Port Newark as an island of comparative industry and peace in the strike-plagued waterfront is being scrutinized for object-lessons by public officials and the American Federation of Labor.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Congress completed legislative action today on a bill calling for almost $1,000,000,000 of cuts in Federal excise (sales) taxes, effective Thursday.
Four inquiries were under way yesterday into the case of Alexander P. Maran, 57-year-old accountant who is alleged to have stolen $250,000 in the last ten years from the Manhattan State Hospital.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 30 -- Bert Coffey, a member of the Democratic State Central Committee and of the party's committee in nearby Contra Costa County, confirmed a report today that he had been a member of the Communist party.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The Eisenhower Administration was accused today by Democrats of inadequately preparing the country against a rising Soviet menace in "a period of total danger."

The Missouri - Kansas - Texas Railroad Company is giving serious study to seeking means of recovering traffic volume lost to competing forms of transportation, Donald V. Fraser, president, told stockholders in the 1953 annual report issued yesterday.
The only optometry school in New York State faces extinction on June 30, 1956. The school, one of fourteen in the country, is a department of Columbia University.

The recital given by Wilhelm Backhaus last night in Carnegie Hall, after a twenty-eight-year absence, must be ranked as one of the greatest evenings of the interpretation of Beethoven's piano music heard here in as long a period.

In six months' time American nuclear scientists have apparently overcome an important Soviet technological lead in the hydrogen bomb field. The existence of that Soviet advantage became known only last August when this country's technicians were able to analyze the results of the Soviet thermonuclear blast touched off then.

Customers will soon find much more on-the-spot selling in the stores. Indication of what is coming was shown at the Statler Hotel yesterday when the Point- of-Purchase Advertising Institute opened its three-day symposium and exhibit, the eighth such annual event.

Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson, Rockaway Beach heavyweight, who scored a spectacular upset by halting Dan Bucceroni of Philadelphia Monday night at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn, is expected to see action again the first week of May.
DETROIT, March 30 (AP) -- Increased new car sales have prompted auto makers to advance April production schedules by 5 per cent over earlier projections, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A portrait of President Eisenhower "painted" in colored thread on muslin with a sewing machine was exhibited to women reporters today at the White House.

A 9-year-old boy who had been reported missing for eight days was found in Brooklyn last night curled up comfortably in an attic two blocks from his home. He was hungry, he told the police, and then quickly added that he had no stomach, however, for school.
TOKYO, March 30 -- The Japanese Parliament took the first step today toward ratification of an agreement with the United States for limited national rearmament with American aid.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 30 -- George F. Kennan, planner of the Truman Administration's 1947 "containment" policy toward Soviet expansion, counseled tonight against attempts to solve the world Communist problem by war for violent "liberation" of Soviet bloc people from outside.
FORT BRAGG, N. C., March 30 (AP) -- A big flying boxcar, falling in flames, glanced off an officers quarters, bounced across a parade ground and crashed into a mess hall here today.

The March 25 announcement that Mrs. Edith Alexander was leaving her post as Executive Director of the Mayor's Committee on Unity to join the Mayor's Advisory Council as its Associate Executive Director marks a well-deserved recognition for one of our city's outstanding public servants and denotes the beginning of the dissolution of the Unity committee.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Calling it a "paradox," Representative Clifton Young, Republican of Nevada, said today that as far as he knows the United States and Russia are the only two United Nations members who do not have some kind of free gold market.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's recommendations to Congress on foreign economic policy:
JERUSALEM, Jordanian Sector, March 30 -- A United Nations board condemned Israel in the "strongest terms" today for the attack on the Jordanian village of Nahhalin.

BOSTON, March 30 (UP) -- Montreal's flying Frenchmen, driving for their seventh Stanley Cup, eliminated Boston from the series B hockey play-offs tonight by a 2-0 victory -- sweeping the semi-finals in four straight games.
The Republican State Convention will be held in War Memorial Auditorium in Syracuse Sept. 21, 22 and 23.

Crowds of homeward-bound office workers jammed the lobby and sidewalks near the Paramount Building for an hour and a half yesterday, while police searched the thirty-three-story building for a man who had attacked a young woman clerk there.

Your news story of March 24 and editorial of March 25 on the new exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art prompt me to point out what I and many other residents of West Fifty-fourth Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues consider an "unesthetic" condition.
The largest housing project and a shopping center in Anchorage, Alaska, has been purchased by a New York syndicate for a reported price of $17,000,000.
Nearly everything about the New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle except its purpose was criticized sharply yesterday by Alfred M. Frankfurter, editor of Art News.

Although no decision has been reached by Broadway theatre owners on policies to be followed in connection with the expected reduction in the Federal tax on tickets, in some quarters it was predicted yesterday that the saving would be passed on to patrons.

KANSAS CITY, March 30 (AP) -- The National Collegiate A. A. television committee today recommended a nationally controlled TV football program and promptly ran into major opposition from the Big Ten Conference.
Two men, one of them armed, jumped into a truck that had stopped for a traffic light in Brooklyn yesterday and robbed the driver and assistant of a $7,500 payroll.

Francis W. White, president and executive director of American Woolen Company, received a leave of absence yesterday. Executive direction of the company was turned over to Roy A. Young, Boston banker, who is board chairman.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- President Eisenhower has sent his appeal for liberalization of international trade policies to a Congress controlled by the Republican party which has been lukewarm toward the Reciprocal Trade Agreements policy.

WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- Footsore editors of The Washington Post and Times-Herald offered tonight to compromise with Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas on development of the old Chesapeake and Ohio Canal.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The old International Longshoremen's Association cautioned today against a new labor election on the New York waterfront.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, March 30 -- The editorial opinion of Israel's newspapers today supported, in general, the attack by Israelis on Nahhalin. Only the Communist paper, Kol Haam, condemned the attack.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- The Board of Trade grain market was featured today by see-saw fluctuations in wheat, and by a late break of sizable proportions in old crop soybeans. Rallies in wheat were fairly vigorous at times, but finally they failed to hold, with prices heavy at the close.
ALBANY, March 30 -- Governor Dewey approved today a bill authorizing the Interstate Sanitation Commission to undertake a bi-state study of smoke and air pollution in the New York City area.

WICHITA FALLS, Tex., March 30 -- A 45-degree cold snap, which the local citizenry termed "unusual for the Panhandle at this time of year," had no effect on Sal Maglie's pitching today. But Marv Grissom was unable to protect the slim lead handed him and the Indians defeated the Giants, 2 -- 1.

WHAT'S happened to "I Love Lucy"? At the rate the Lucille Ball program has been going in the last few weeks it's surely jeopardizing its exalted place in the popularity charts. Where once the show was a recognizable and hilarious farce on married life, it currently seems bent on succumbing to the most pedestrian and sophomoric slapstick.

BONN, Germany, March 30 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer summoned a caucus of his coalition parties today to try to restore discipline in the ranks, impaired by France's delay in ratifying the European army treaty.

American Export Lines announced here yesterday that arrangements for breaking off its reciprocal contract with the Italian Line were being completed at Genoa in conferences between principals of the two shipping companies.
Swedish Ambassador Erick Boheman expressed encouragement yesterday over increasing support for liberal trade policies in this country.

DWELLERS in thousands of New York City cold-water flats still use kerosine for room heating and for cooking. No other fuel is available in broad areas of Old Chelsea, farther up the West Side, in marginal slums along the East River and in the Greenpoint and Williamsburg districts of Brooklyn -- among other places.
Three adjectives appropriate in describing the small collection of Nelly Don dresses seen at Macy's yesterday morning are wearable simple and crisp.

The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations should proceed with other investigations if selection of a new counsel in its dispute with the Army is delayed much longer, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said here yesterday.
ALBANY, March 30 (AP) -- Three men who have supervised balloting at many New York Central Railroad meetings plan to sit out the proxy battle to be fought here in May.
LONDON, March 30 -- Business expanded and prices continued to gain on the securities markets here today.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- A clamor to let the public know the power of the hydrogen bomb was rising today, as President Eisenhower received an eyewitness report on the latest test explosions.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices had declined eight-tenths of 1 per cent between mid-February and mid-March.
ALBANY, March 30 -- The state opened its case today in opposition to a $68,850,000 increase in rates being sought by the New York Telephone Company.
PARIS, March 30 -- Some relief was in sight for French taxpay ers as a result of the fiscal reform bill passed on the first reading early today by the National Assembly.
WASHINGTON, March 30 (UP) -- United States manufacturers sold less in February than in January but received increased new orders for goods, the Department of Commerce reported today.

The three-story business building on a plot about 24 by 90 feet at 30-93 Steinway Street in Astoria, Queens, has been purchased by David S. Meister from the heirs of Peter Seitz. Mary Cooper was the broker and the attorneys were Henry Koch for the sellers and Walzer Walzer for the buyer.

The vigor with which federal authorities have begun to carry out the federal-state program outlined last week-end in order to cope with the dock strike is encouraging. A jury has been selected in the contempt of court action against individuals and locals of the old International Longshoremen's Association.

The Lucy Stone League gently reminded the nation yesterday that one of its famous citizens, the Colonial printer John Peter Zenger had the able assistance of an early American career woman -- his wife, Anna Maulin Zenger.

The Lucy Stone League gently reminded the nation yesterday that one of its famous citizens, the Colonial printer John Peter Zenger had the able assistance of an early American career woman -- his wife, Anna Maulin Zenger.
BELIZE, British Honduras, March 30 (Reuter) -- A British investigation has found that the leading political group in this colony has links with neighboring Guatemala.
Operating revenues of Eastern Air Lines, Inc., last year climbed 22 per cent to a new high of $144,468,385, but larger taxes reduced net income to $7,921,367 from $8,513,681 earned in 1952.
The much smaller number of price cuts announced yesterday compared with the April, 1953, reductions appears to reflect the inadequacy of Soviet Government food and consumer goods supplies.
Stocks showed impressive strength yesterday, making the largest gains of 1954 on the heaviest volume since last September.

LONDON, March 31 -- Britain plans to support any prompt and effective counter-measures that the United Nations should decide upon in the event of open intervention by the Chinese Communists in Indo-China.
MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 31 (UP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers scored a 79-68 victory over Syracuse tonight in the first game of the National Basketball Association's championshiOp series.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday. The close was 7 points lower to 10 points higher than on Tuesday, with near months relatively weaker than new crop months.

Members of the Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America, were told yesterday that the 1954 fund drive was $223,949 short of the goal of $857,300 for operating needs. The campaign, which opened Jan. 5, ended yesterday.

High fashion at a low price proved popular yesterday in Bonwit Teller's showing of attractive young summer fashions at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Cotton appeared repeatedly in crisp dark frocks that could go wiltlessly through hot days in town and in short, full-skirted evening dresses.
JERUSALEM, March 31 -- The Israeli-Jordan Mixed Armistice Commission will "carry on" despite the Israeli boycott, its chairman, Comdr. Elmo H. Hutchison of the United States Navy, said today.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Eisenhower called on Israel and the Arab states today to restrain their extremists and permit other nations to help them settle their disputes.

Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, performed his obvious duty in presenting to the public yesterday about as full an account as he could give of what happened on March 1 when a hydrogen bomb of undisclosed but unprecedented explosive power was detonated in the Pacific.
SAIGON, Vietnam, March 31 -- Vietminh forces last night launched a new mass attack against the French defenses at Dienbienphu.

An increase of 985,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 180,384,000 barrels, compared with 179,399,000 a week earlier and 162,878,000 a year ago.

Late today, or perhaps tomorrow, the Senate will make a historic decision. It will vote upon the bill admitting Hawaii and Alaska as the forty-ninth and fiftieth states of the Federal Union. While these two proposals ought to have been considered separately, each on its merits, the fact that they were joined together for political purposes does not alter their basic desirability.
Mexico, which not only has brilliant sunlight but big sombreros to shield the pale Northerners from it, is going after Yankee tourists in a big way.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce today added 100 items to its list of United States products which may be shipped to Western Hemisphere countries without an individual export license for each shipment.

CHICAGO, March 31 (UP) -- Carl (Bobo) Olson, middleweight champion, and his handlers today moved from the Parkway Hotel to a secret hideout in order to escape reporters, photographers, autograph seekers and telephones.

LONDON, Thursday, April 1 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Soviet note to the Western Big Three, in terms of the version handed to the French Ambassador, as broadcast by Moscow radio this morning:
The Fifth Avenue Coach Company and a controlling interest in the jointly operated New York City Omnibus Corporation have been put up for sale.
Sports fans and moviegoers will benefit least, and in some cases not at all, from the new lower excise taxes that go into effect today.
Thoroughbred racing returns to New York today.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Eisenhower discussed these topics in his news conference today:

The New Britain Machine Company announced the election of Ralph S. Howe as president to succeed Robert T. Frisbie, who becomes chairman of the executive committee. Herbert H. Pease continues as chairman of the board.
HOLLYWOOD, March 31 (AP) -- Howard Hughes wrote a personal check for $23,489,478 today to become the sole owner of R. K. O. Pictures, Inc.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 31 -- An international dispute over $2,880,000 worth of gold has become probably the strangest case brought before the International Court of Justice.

JERUSALEM, March 31 (UP) -- Israel charged Jordan with new frontier violations tonight. Tension mounted in the Holy Land with reports that Jordanian troops were massing along the armistice line through Jerusalem.

Anyone who has ever tried to distinguish the number of a house, particularly at night, has no doubt discovered that it is an extremely difficult task. And this situation exists despite the fact that there is an ordinance requiring that: "the proper street number or numbers of such building to be displayed * * * in such manner that the street number or numbers may at all times be plainly legible from the sidewalks."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 31 -- Benny Goodman, who can be as much at ease with his clarinet answering the baton of Arturo Toscanini as when improvising in a jam session, is going to have his life filmed by Universal-International.

MINEOLA, L. I., March 31 -- Members of a newly formed East Meadow school district political group refused today the Nassau District Attorney's invitation to produce evidence backing their charge of corruption on the school board.
Dwellings dominated the trading in Brooklyn in real estate transactions reported there yesterday.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- James M. Cox, newspaper publisher, today urged unity for America in a troubled world.
SEATTLE, March 31 (AP) -- Tony Sparando of Rego Park, L. I., bowled 300 today in the 1954 American Bowling Congress, the thirteenth perfect game recorded in the fifty-one years of the tournament.
The world of colorful make-believe and heart-in-mouth reality unfolded last night in Madison Square Garden as the 1954 Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus began Its forty-day stand here.
New financing rose sharply in March. Bond offerings were the largest for any March since 1948. Stock flotations were the largest for the month since 1929.
New York decided yesterday to welcome motels, but with reservations. That means they cannot be set up in residential or retail districts.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday the promotion of 109 members of the police force. The promotions will become effective at noon today in ceremonies at Headquarters.
The first price reduction for primary titanium since the strong, lightweight metal was introduced commercially eight years ago was announced yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

BUFFALO, March 31 -- Ten sixth grade pupils in the Cleveland Hill elementary school died today in a fire that trapped them in a room of the school's one-story frame annex on Mapleview Drive in suburban Cheektowaga.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 1 -- The lower house of the Japanese Diet approved last evening a defense agreement with the United States to become the keystone of this nation's limited rearmament program.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Dispersal plans for defense production plants in major cities will have to be redrawn in the light of today's hydrogen bomb disclosures.

Coffee and cocoa prices soared yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee rose the 2 cents a pound daily limit in all positions following two days of declines. Cocoa was up the 1-cent limit in all but one month, which rose 0.99 cent. A run of five successive daily limit rises in cocoa was terminated on Tuesday by a 1 cent decline in most months.
Bills were introduced in both houses of Congress yesterday to require that at least half of this country's foreign aid cargoes be carried on American ships.
SARASOTA, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- A Miami orthopedic: specialist informed the Red Sox today that Ted Williams would not be able to take part in baseball workouts until after April 27.

The American Jewish Committee reported yesterday that organized anti-Semitism in this country had changed its tactics radically in the last seven years. The committee stressed the need for vigilance "against malicious movements striving to foment racial and religious discord."
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The United States rejected tonight the Soviet Union's proposals for an all-European security pact and Soviet membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

THE 129th annual exhibition of the National Academy of Design opens to the public today in the galleries of the organization at 1083 Fifth Avenue. Slightly smaller and rather more conservative than last year, the event includes 280 examples of painting, sculpture and graphic art.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Wheat futures showed a stronger undertone today, with commission buying broadening on the recessions. The price course was irregular, but there appeared to be increasing uneasiness over the crop outlook as expected rains failed to materialize in the Southwest.
Tilapia macrocephala is the name of an African fish that can be either a tasty morsel or a tool for the scientific study of the lower vertebrates. It seems to prefer the latter role.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Senate Labor Committee approved a Taft-Hartley revision bill today with the Democrats crying "steamroller." The vote was 7 to 6 along party lines. The bill deals only with President Eisenhower's recommendations, minus an Administration proposal to require Federally conducted elections among workers before a strike could be called.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Personal income in February was at an annual rate of $283,000,000,000, a drop of $750,000,000 from January, the Government announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that United States coffee imports dropped 16 per cent in February but officials said they did not know if the decline was linked to high prices.
On record sales of $228,350,440, Olin Industries, Inc., and its subsidiaries increased its net income 23.2 per cent last year to $13,195,420, the highest level in its history.

The thirty-first annual observance of National Music Week, which takes place this year from May 2 through 9, has received the endorsement of President Eisenhower. This was announced yesterday by T. E. Rivers, secretary of the National Music Week Committee.

Ceramics that might lure the cook into the kitchen as well as enhance the results of her (or his) labors make up the new "Pottery for the Gourmet" exhibit at the Greenwich House Pottery at 16 Jones Street.

LONDON, March 31 -- A slightly cleaned up" and Anglicized version of "Pal Joey," the Rodgers and Hart musical, reached London tonight. In fact a few changes were made by the Lord Chamberlain's Office.

The board of directors of the Seas Shipping Company, Inc., operators of the Robin Line's steamship service to South and East Africa, yesterday elected Winthrop O. Cook as president. He succeeds Arthur R. Lewis Jr., who died in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on March 16.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 31 -- General Manager Branch Rickey's curious assortment of Pirates, generally picked for another year in the basement of the National League, but currently the hottest club of the training season, were still sizzling today.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The United States can now build a hydrogen bomb big enough to destroy any city.

Thousands of slum flats and cheap furnished rooms are falling in New York under the wrecker's iron ball. A third of the displaced tenants are moving into modern public housing, where rents are $9 to $16.50 a room. Undetermined numbers of others are finding adequate quarters in private housing within or beyond the city.

COLUMBUS, Ga., March 31 (AP) -- Gerald Staley, star right-hander, yielded only two hits in seven innings to help the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox in an exhibition game today.

Thomas Perkins Abernethy, author of several books on the Revolutionary and other periods of American history, has writton a new one called "The Burr Conspiracy." In it the author tells how Aaron Burr planned to separate the western part of the United States from the East, unite the western region to the Spanish territory and make himself its emperor.

LONDON, March 31 -- Serious concern over the problem of growing homosexuality in Britain was expressed by some of the nation's leading medical, police and religious leaders in a symposium published today in The Practitioner, a leading medical monthly.

DUBLIN, March 31 (AP) -- Vincent O'Brien, trainer of the Grand National winner, Royal Tan, said tonight he had been suspended for three months following an inquiry by the Irish National Hunt Committee
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- Jordan urged the United Nations today to take "drastic and efficient action" against Israel.
BOSTON, March 31 -- Terms of the proposed merger of the American Woolen Company and the Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted Corporation were disclosed here today.

DORTMUND, Germany, March 31 (UP) -- Twenty former Nazi policemen were found innocent by a West German court here today of shooting to death 110 Jews in the Warsaw Ghetto. They had admitted the mass killings.

The seasonal reminder from Raymond R. Camp that the second Saturday in April is close at hand, and his annual hope "for lower streams, warmer water and better conditions" on this great day have had their effects on more than one household where abide anglers who believe in being prepared.
NAGOYA, Japan, April 1 (UP) -- Canada's Kenora Thistles hockey team scored its seventh victory in a row Wednesday night, defeating the all-Hokkaido squad, 8 to 1, at the Nagoya Sports Center rink
ALBANY, March 31 (AP) -- Workmen today carted away five of the six statues in the Capitol's Gun Room on the first floor to clear the way for installation of new flooring.

Further evidence of the danger of cooling cooked meat at room temperatures has been found in the test kitchens of Swift Co. As a result of its research, the packing concern said that two hours was the absolute time limit for keeping cooked meats at temperatures between 60 and 110 degrees Fahreinheit.

Several dinner parties will be given in advance of the performance of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus tonight at the Madison Square Garden for the benefit of East Side House Settlement. Among the prospective hosts and hostesses are Mrs. Charles Harrison Goddard, Mrs. John A. Brown, Mrs. Philo W. Parker, Mrs. Charles Neuman de Vegvar, Mrs. John W. Sheppard and Frederick E. Donaldson.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- Col. H. A. Toulmin Jr., who was a member of the Army Pearl Harbor Board, said today Admiral Husband E. Kimmel "cannot escape the guilt" for our heavy losses in the Japanese attack of Dec. 7, 1941.

CINCINNATI, March 31 (AP) -- William White, president of the New York Central Railroad, told reporters today he is not worried about his job. Discussing Robert R. Young, who wants to gain control of the railroad, he said:
Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock dismissed yesterday a motion by a draft registrant to cite his local Selective Service Board for conempt for violating an order of the United States Court of Appeals.

A state constitutional amendment to establish a new single city court that would deal with child, youth and family problems has been recommended by the Community Service Society after a two-year study.

Many who are concerned with the urgent need for a solution to the traffic strangulation of metropolitan New York will support the point of view outlined in your cogent editorial of March 24 entitled "Rails vs. Rubber."
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- During February, for the second month, the public repaid personal debt faster than it increased credit for goods and services, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

The Eastern States contract bridge team-of-four championship was won last night by Edgar Kaplan, Miss Ruth Sherman and Eli Jaye of New York, Norman Kay of Merchantvile, N. J., and Boris Koytchou of Paris in the tournament at the McAlpin Hotel.

The Federal Maritime Board yesterday reversed a previous stand and ordered the contract-noncontract rate system of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference held in abeyance. The rate structure, which allows a 10 per cent discount to shippers who use conference vessels exclusively, was to have gone into effect today.

For "distinguished achievement covering the entire work of the recipient," Maxwell Anderson will receive the gold medal for drama from the National Institute of Arts and Letters. The announcement was made yesterday by Marc Connelly, president of the institute.
MONTREAL, March 31 (Canadian Press) -- The Aluminum

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Sales of Marshall Field Co. in March were disappointing, but an improvement is expected this month, Hughston M. McBain, chairman of the board, told stockholders at the annual meeting today.

ALBANY, March 31 (UP) -- A House Un-American Activities subcommittee spokesman indicated today that forthcoming Albany hearings would be virtually statewide in scope. He also disclosed that the investigation would would not be centered on defense plants.

Today's new film is "Rose Marie," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer remake of the operetta, starring Ann Blyth, Howard Keel and Fernando Lamas, at the Radio City Music Hall. The offering was produced in CinemaScope, and Eastman Color, by Mervyn LeRoy, who also directed.
Max J. Etra, lawyer and community leader, was installed last night at a dinner in the Pierre Hotel as chairman of the board of trustees of Yeshiva University. Three hundred persons attended.
KINGSTON, N. Y., March 31 -- A unified approach for publicizing the advantages of the fast- growing Hudson Valley as an attractive region for new industries was initiated here today.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Senator Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said today in testifying for his bill to re-establish a free market for gold that on the outcome of the issue "hangs the ultimate course of American history."

WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- Representative Carl Hinshaw, Republican of California, said today the Congressional Joint Atomic Energy Committee "has every hope" of approving changes in atom control law to speed the development of atomic energy for peacetime use.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 31 -- The Dodgers finally beat the Milwaukee Braves in the third meeting of the clubs this spring, outscoring Manager Charley Grimm's men, 10 -- 7, today. The game was called at the end of the eight innings so that the teams could catch a train for Mobile.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Following the text of a statement and comments on the hydrogen bomb tests read at President Eisenhower's news conference today by Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, Atomic Energy Commission chairman:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 31 (UP) -- Attorneys for the harness race driver, Wayne (Curly) Smart of Delaware, Ohio, said today they had asked the court to dismiss Smart's suit against his suspension as a driver by the United States Trotting Association and the New York State Harness Racing Association.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (UP) -- The Postmaster General, Arthur E. Summerfield, proposed today that Congress surrender its right to fix mail rates as a step toward getting the Post Office out of the red.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., March 31 -- A strike of the Sheet Metal Workers union, A. F. L., today halted all construction work at two vital atomic projects in Oak Ridge.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Robert Moses, chairman of the New York State agency that seeks to build new power plants at Niagara Falls, said today the issue of who is to build them should be decided by the Federal Power Commission.

The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway late last night disclosed that it had filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday details of its recent sale of 800,000 shares of New York Central Railroad Company common stock to two friends of Robert R. Young for $20,000,000.
In Washington and London, but not at Dienbienphu, the hydrogen bomb yesterday overshadowed all other contemporary events.
A 41-year-old business man roared in from the West yesterday with a speed record in a "souped-up" F-51 Mustang fighter plane. He landed at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

UTRECHT, the Netherlands, March 31 -- At one end of the room a pianist tinkles out the sad harmonies of romantic French melodies, Nobody stands around mooning though, and the scraps of conversations that flow through the room are swift and businesslike.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Lindsay C. Warren, the watchdog of the Government's dollars, asked today that he be retired as of April 30 from his post as Controller General of the United States.

A nationwide strike against all major radio and television networks was threatened yesterday by the Radio and Television Directors Guild, A. F. L., unless the chains offer suitable contracts by next Monday.
