Five writers and television commentators whose works dealt with civil liberties received the annual prize awards of the Sidney Hillman Foundation yesterday.

A police detail headed by Assistant Chief Inspector James Nidds, confidential supervisor for Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams, broke up last night what they termed a policy ring doing annual business of between $1,500,000 and $2,000,000 in the city's four boroughs.

PARIS, Thursday, April 1 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin was disciplined by the French Cabinet at a special meeting early this morning for his speech against the European army treaty and for a snub to Premier Joseph Laniel.

MOSCOW, Thursday, April 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Foreign Ministry contended today that Secretary of State Dulles agreed at Berlin that Communist China should meet with other powers in Geneva on an equal footing and now is trying to back out of this.
ST. LOUIS, March 31 (AP) -- Arthur Persley of Red Cross, La., outpunched Canada's Armand Savoie through most of a ten-round bout tonight to score a unanimous decision in the light- weight event.

The schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified. The programs follow:

SAN JUAN, P. R., March 31 (AP) -- Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., gained the semi-finals of the invitation tennis tournament on the Caribe-Hilton courts today, defeating Hugh Stewart of Pasadena, Calif., 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2.
False warnings of bombs in public schools continued yesterday to harass the police and educational authorities on Long Island. The series of bomb scares began several weeks ago.
Activity in aircrafts and low-priced issues swelled trading on the New York Stock Exchange in March to the largest for any month since 1951 and the largest for a March since 1937.

CHICAGO, March 31 -- Charles T. Broderick, economist for Lehman Brothers, New York investment firm, said today that the end of the current drop in business was a possibility by midyear and a strong probability by the end of the year.

KINGSTON, N. Y., March 31 -- Passenger service on the New York Central Railroad's Catskill Mountain Division, which extends 104 miles from Kingston to Oneonta, ended today with Rotary Clubs in seven communities along the line providing the passengers.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 31 (UP) -- The Detroit Tigers reached Robin Roberts for thirteen hits, including a three-run homer in the fourth by First Baseman Charley Kress, to post a 7-to-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies before 690 fans today.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., March 31 -- Three men convicted of the murder of a Reader's Digest messenger at Chappaqua four years ago lost their latest legal skirmish today.

Three new applications of silicones to consumer products and the development of a new family of silicone fluids were announced yesterday by the chemical division of the General Electric Company, Waterford, N. Y.

An hold-up man bent on ransacking the cash register of an uptown grocery yesterday was repulsed by ingenious clerks who sent him fleeing under a cannonade of canned peas, applesauce and sweet potatoes.
The Port of New York Authority sold $20,000,000 of serial bonds in the public market yesterday to refund short-term notes and to cover capital outlays.
LAUREL, Md., March 31 (AP) -- Bea Marony, owned and trained by W. W. Waters, won the $4,000 Patuxent Purse today before 11,189 fans at Laurel Park.

The ship repair yards in this harbor could very well become "graveyards" if the extension of the 3 per cent city sales tax is permitted to include repairs made on steamships, Arthur Hiltebrant, general manager of the Bethlehem Steel Company's New York District shipyards, asserted yesterday.
LONDON, March 31 -- Britain hopes that embargoes on some kinds of trade with the Soviet world can be relaxed step by step without "needless delay," Parliament was told today.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The deep slash in dairy support prices from 90 to 75 per cent of parity, effective at midnight, represents another victory for Ezra Taft Benson.
Investors, glancing at the calendar today, may well refuse to take seriously a tradition that April is a month of lower markets. Here is the record:

WHO reads Faulkner, the Nobel laureate of Yoknapatawpha County? Is he, as we have occasionally been told, a terrifically difficult writer whose stories are veiled in unutterable lore? Well, that's the legend. And legends die hard.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- Two moves designed to get full Congressional approval of wiretapping in cases involving treason, espionage and sabotage were made at the Capitol today.

The regional Red Cross Blood Program will observe "College Day" today. Bloodmobiles will visit Teachers College, Columbia University, 120th Street and Broadway, where residents of International House also will contribute; Fordham University, 441 East Fordham Road, the Bronx, and Fordham University Downtown, 302 Broadway, and City College, 139th Street and Convent Avenue.
A new branch of the Tremont Savings and Loan Association is being opened today at 717 Allerton Avenue in the Bronx. The company's main office is at 1931 Washington Avenue, the Bronx.

A two-story warehouse containing about 400,000 square feet of space is to be erected in the Bronx by the F. W. Woolworth Company. The site, comprising about eight and one-half acres, on the south side of East 132d Street, between Walnut and Locust Avenues, was purchased from the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company.

The Times of March 24 carried dispatch relating to Russian claims to some kind of "first" in connection with the jet airplane. To this was appended what I believe to be some misleading material which stated that Sir Frank Whittle was credited throughout the West with being the developer of the first successful turbine aircraft engine.
LONDON, March 31 -- Prime Minister Churchill agreed today to a full-dress debate in the House of Commons on the hydrogen bomb.

A new comedy, "King of Hearts," by Jean Kerr and Eleanor Brooke, opens at the Lyceum Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock. Elaine Perry, who made her managerial debut last season with "Touchstone," is the producer.

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, announced yesterday the formation of an international council, composed of 100 community leaders in all parts of the country, for the purpose of carrying out the institution's international exhibitions program.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The White House will be guided, in meeting the New York waterfront problem, by the rule that everything is handled locally as long is it can be, President Eisenhower said today.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., March 31 -- Nine members of the Clergy Association of Ardsley, Dobbs Ferry, Hastings and Irvington decried "the prevalent pattern of fear and smear" in commenting today on the pending election of a president of the Hastings Parent-Teacher Association.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 24:

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 -- The Army was disclosed today to have refused a commission to a drafted doctor at Letterman Army Hospital here because of "doubtful loyalty" although he took a loyalty oath and filled out a standard loyalty certificate.
In the new line of attack against those suspected of being members of subversive organizations, the Board of Education yesterday suspended a teacher and charged him with lying under oath.
NEW DELHI, India, March 31 At the Asian prime ministers conference, the Indian Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, will try to bring concerted Asian neutralist pressure to forestall a third world war.
CHARLESTON, S. C., March 31 (UP) -- The Washington Senators today routed the Cincinnati Redlegs, 9 -- 2, before a crowd of 3,675.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Eisenhower signed the $999,000,000 excise tax reduction bill into law today. He voiced hope that the damage to Federal revenues would be offset to some degree by the resulting stimulation of business.

The Kansas Turnpike Authority took first steps yesterday toward financing the construction of a toll expressway to extend from Kansas City to the Oklahoma line south of Wellington, a distance of 234 miles. The Authority plans to sell $140,000,000 of revenue bonds for this purpose in the public market before the fall.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 -- The routine appearance of cancer of the breast in a breed of mice was reported today to have been interrupted after a chemical was fed to animals of several succeeding generations in their daily diet.

MOSCOW, March 31 -- The Soviet Union has proposed that the United States and West European states join a Soviet-sponsored general European security treaty. In return the Soviet Union is prepared to examine the question of assuming membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

HOUSTON, March 31 -- Manager Leo Dur cher's Giants still favored by good pitching and defense, made it nine out of twelve against the Indians with a 4-2 victory over Manager Al Lopez' club today. Jim Hearn and Don Liddle combined to halt the American Leaguers, while Willie Mays contributed two hits, drove in the first run and electrified 8,230 fans with a great catch.

The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, A. F. L., yesterday accused Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health, of lowering an iron curtain between her office and the department's workers.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Defense Department was in the position of a satisfied customer today. It had the hydrogen bomb ordered four years ago by President Truman.

Doubts of the statistical accuracy of a recent article in The Christian Herald reporting 4,144,366 converts to Protestantism from Roman Catholicism in the past decade is expressed in the April 10 issue of America, national Catholic weekly.
Paul Krueger, a bass-baritone who is a faculty member of tthe Juilliard School, made his local debut in a song recital at Town Hall last evening.
TOKYO, Thursday, April 1 (AP) -- Japan asked the United States yesterday not to explode any more atom weapons in the Pacific during the tuna fishing season, from November through March.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., March 31 -- Motorists doubting the legality of radar speed traps that are becoming numerous in Westchester County, must have been convinced today when a driver was convicted in a test case here.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- President Eisenhower made it plain today that this Government was deeply committed to "united action" against any Communist effort to overrun Southeast Asia.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 31 -- George F. Kennan, former director of the State Department's policy planning staff, pictured tonight the nation's "most frightening" problem as a readiness to sacrifice traditional values to fears of communism. He deplored snooping and efforts to ward off "the impact of ideas."

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- A Court of Claims commissioner found today that the Government's war-time order closing down gold mines had deprived Homestake Mining Company of South Dakota and six other companies of the use and benefit of their properties.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- A great deal of firmness will be required to put through the Administration program for a liberalized foreign trade policy, President Eisenhower said today.

The Government's five-year-old civil anti-trust suit against the Celanese Corporation of America was terminated yesterday by the signing of a consent judgment by Judge John F. X. McGohey in United States District Court, Foley Square.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., which operates electric power and light and gas properties in Arkansas, Mississippi and Louisiana, expects its business this year to run 8 to 9 per cent ahead of last year. Gains in electric operating revenues in all major classifications are expected, E. H. Dixon, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.
LINCOLIN, R.I., March 31 (UP) -- Tony DeSpirito booted home four winners at Lincoln Downs today, including R. E. Harper's El Pacho in the feature race, to run his two-day victory total to nine.

MADRID, March 31 -- The United States Department of Defense was understood today to be considering the possibility of changing a site already chosen for one of its major air bases to be built in Spain.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The world's most fearsome weapon, the fusion bomb, was shown in action for the first time here in public today before an audience of representatives of the press and other information media.

Electric power production in the week ended March 27 declined to 8,491,000,000 kilowatt-hours from 8,572,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended March 28, 1953, was 8,075,000,000. Comparative percentages with 1953 follow:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 31 -- A United Nations committee was accused today of trying to start a "witch-hunt" because it had recommended withdrawing consultative status from an organization that Western diplomats have labeled Communist controlled.

KANSAS CITY, March 31 (AP) -- Elmer Dolan, one-time policeman hero of the Greenlease kidnapping case, today was found guilty of lying about how he handled the ransom money. A Federal District Court jury returned the verdict late today against the former St. Louis policeman.
CHICAGO, March 31 (AP) -- The nation's traffic deaths dipped in February to the lowest level in three years.

THE first flush of dawn this morning, sun or no sun, will reveal a devoted if not devout collection of opening day enthusiasts gathered on the margins of Catherine Creek, ready and willing to participate in the special trout season which (appropriately?) opens on All Fools' Day.
WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The Federal Government's sample sale of used stamps, to see whether or not it would be worth while to go into this sideline, grossed $339 today.
ALBANY, March 31 -- Governor Dewey signed today a series of bills that will assure salary increases for virtually everyone who works for the state, including the 206 members of the Legislature.

L. L. White, president of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis Nickel Plate Railroad Company, told shareholders yesterday that the economic decline "should not be looked upon as a forerunner of depression conditions."
Four thousand firemen paraded examples of antique and modern fire engines up Broadway to City Hall yesterday in celebration of Fireman's Day.

The teaching of homemaking should be related not only to modern developments in products equipment but also to the student of today and her problems, several speakers agreed at a meeting here yesterday.
HALLANDALE, Fla., March 31 (AP) -- J. Barry Ryan's Buttevant notched his second straight victory at Gulfstream Park today by capturing the $7,500 Hutcheson Handicap.

Numerous letters have been written to newspapers relative to the din produced by blowing automobile horns within the metropolitan area. A simple remedy exists, and this stupid practice could easily be eliminated if we are willing to profit by the experience of other communities.

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- The statement read by Rear Admiral Strauss at the President's press conference today encourages the conclusion that the United States has mastered thermonuclear energy as a weapon of offense and defense and has no further doubt that it can provide the facilities for essential military production. Moreover, it indicated that:

WASHINGTON, March 31 -- What had been intended as a defeat for the Eisenhower Administration developed as a probable victory today as a parliamentary tangle over public housing legislation began unraveling.
Herbert R. O'Brien, director of New York City Civil Defense, warned yesterday that a mass evacuation of New York's 8,000,000 inhabitants might be the only defense against a hydrogen bomb attack.
LONDON, March 31 (Reuters) -- Pravda announced today the appointment of a woman to a key Communist party post in Moscow.

CHICAGO, March. 31 -- The citizenry of this midwestern village expected to have the Olson-Gavilan fight dominate all conversations for the next few days. Instead, they were buzzing furiously about the upheaval at the Chicago Cubs. The popular Phil Cavarretta was ousted the other day as manager of the Bruins and the equally popular Stan Hack, a Cub idol of yesteryear, was promoted -- if promoted is the right word -- to take his place.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:
OTTAWA, March 31 -- A new trade treaty was signed here today between Canada and Japan.

Dr. Lewis A. Wilson, State Education Commisisioner, has granted a stay in the case of Nat Holman, former City College basketball coach. Under a Board of Higher Education ruling, Mr. Holman had until tomorrow to apply for retirement or be dismissed.

Joseph M. Dodge gave up the board chairmanship of a Detroit bank right after. Mr. Eisenhower's election in 1952 to join the new President's team. When Mr. Truman graciously invited the new Administration to designate a representative to sit in as an observer during the final two months of preparation of the federal budget for 1953-54 Mr. Dodge was the man selected by the White House for that task.
CAIRO, March 31 -- Overt opposition to Egypt's newly entrenched military regime centered today in the universities of Cairo.

ROME, March 31 -- The Italian news magazine Europeo, repeated today its version of remarks that it said Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce had addressed to a group of newspaper men at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington January 5.
PARIS, March 31 -- The first invitation to West Germany to participate directly in a North Atlantic Treaty undertaking has been sent to Bonn.

Colorful, washable, inexpensive clothes for "do-it-yourself" householders, both male and female, were shown yesterday in a presentation gathered from twenty-five manufacturers by the San-forized Division of Cluett, Pea-body Co. The showing took place aboard the New York Central ferryboat Niagara.

The sensational point in the note handed to the American, British and French Ambassadors in Moscow yesterday is the fantastic proposal that the United States be made a party to the European security system which the Russians offered at Berlin and that the Soviet Union become a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
A contract to plan a $6,000,000 high school of aviation trades to be erected in Long Island City, Queens, was signed yesterday.
Clubhouse and other "luxury" seat admissions will cost more when Yonkers Raceway opens the local harness racing season on April 12.
Following is a cross-section of some of the world's important cities, with their areas in square miles, including, for some, part of the provincial limitations:
May I express the mixed feelings with which an English railway enthusiast, at present visiting this country, has learned of plans to install synthetic steam whistles in Diesel locomotives ?
ROME, March 31 -- Eviction proceedings will be started by April 15 against all party and union organizations that occupy buildings or office space belonging to the state.
A new chapter is opening in the struggle for the world between the free nations and the Soviet bloc, Hanson W. Baldwin, military editor of The New York Times, declared yesterday.
With action listed to start Saturday, a forty-five game 1954 schedule has been arranged for the Knickerbocker Intercollegiate Baseball Conference.

The first tourist-fare air services across the mid-Atlantic to southern Europe and to South Africa will be started today by Pan American World Airways. Fares of similar type to the Orient will begin Saturday, when a Northwest Orient Airlines plane departs from here for Tokyo, Okinawa and Manila.

The industrial property at 130-132 Harrison Street in Hoboken, has been leased by the Virginia Metal Products, Inc., of Orange, Va., from the Henze Instrument Valve, Inc., through the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization, broker.
Insurgent elements in the old International Longshoremen's Association yesterday killed a union-inspired move to end their strike, the longest and costliest in the port's history.
Trans World Airlines Inc., reported yesterday record gross revenues for 1953 at $187,220,806. But net income fell to $5,064,392, or $1.52 a share, from $7,660,588, or $2.30 a share, in 1952.

LONDON, March 31 -- Britain's engineering industry and the engineering unions agreed today on wage increases. If adopted they would add the equivalent of $196,000,000 to the annual wage bill of the industry, the backbone of the nation's export trade.

The Queen Mary boat-train operation rolled to a smooth conclusion at 2:18 P. M. yesterday in Grand Central Terminal as 631 passengers arrived from the strike-diverted liner in Halifax and 1,444 others left to board her.

LONDON, March 31 -- The Economic Survey and a new group of favorable dividend statements encouraged the stock markets here today. Buying of British funds increased and prices rose as much as 3s 9d (52 1/2 cents) among undated long and medium term stocks.

Housewives going shopping today will be pleased to find that the prices of key dairy products, particularly butter, have been marked down in grocery stores. From the previous level of 75 to 80 cents a pound, the price of butter is being reduced 8 to 10 cents, while smaller declines are likely for cheese and dried milk.

It would take a mirror of impossible size to give a total reflection of life in this city. Such a mirror might reflect many happy homes -- and many that are not so happy. The Community Service Society, in its 105th annual report, "Mirror on Our Town," gives several glimpses of some of our community's problems as seen by its staff during the year.

PARIS, March 31 -- Rene Pleven, Minister of Defense, stressed today the need for France to maintain her effort for defense to insure that the United States and Britain should maintain their troops in Europe.
HONG KONG, March 30 -- The Chinese Communist party, whose present ranks are officially said to embrace 6,500,000 members, appears to be heading for another "ranks overhauling purge."

PARIS, March 31 -- The Soviet note today on a new European security system was considered here to be an effort to add to the confusion of minds, above all in France, regarding the European army treaty and to undermine the North Atlantic Treaty.
MOSCOW, March 31 -- For the sixth year in succession, the Soviet Government announced tonight a general reduction in retail prices.
Homemakers, confronted with a variety of new sewing machines in recent years, may be interested in a man's appraisal of this equipment, much of it radically different from that of ten years ago.

Two persons, including a 3-year-old boy, perished and four others were injured yesterday in a Brooklyn tenement fire. The blaze was said to have started when a tenant, falling asleep, dropped a lighted cigarette on his overstuffed chair.
The National Labor Relations Board set aside yesterday the December representation election among the Port of New York's longshoremen and ordered a new vote.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Testimony of the Rev. John A. Hutchison and three ex-Communists before the Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives was sent to the Justice Department today for possible perjury prosecution.
The Italian liner Vulcania docked here yesterday morning with a new captain and a number of unexpected passengers in addition to the 521 regular travelers she brought from Mediterranean ports.

Part of a seventy-two-acre estate on Banksville Road in North Castle, N. Y., owned by Mrs. Aurelia C. Bacon, has been purchased by Renry Hart Rice, New York realty man. Mr. Rice bought a portion consisting of twenty acres with a lake, ten-room house, cottage and three-car garage. The Clark Wilcox Company was broker in the sale and title insurance was furnished by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

TRENTON, April 1 -- A successful analysis of the mental development of a baby may be made as early as two months after birth, thus permitting adoptions at an earlier age than heretofore, according to Dr. Waymah Barber, staff psychologist of the Children's Home Society of New Jersey.

TRENTON, April 1 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner warned today that New Jersey would have to levy $89,500,000 in new taxes within the next year if present demands of the State Legislature and the public were to be met. The budget for the coming fiscal year totals slightly more than $236,000,000.
THREE of this week's exhibitions deal principally with landscape and urban impressions in different media, with the approaches of the individual artists being quite different.

BINGLER'S bus trips for horseplayers dropped off yesterday with the start of the spring meeting at Jamaica Race Track, as the Bingler people knew they would. But the company ran two bus loads of sporting gentlemen down to Laurel in Maryland anyway and probably will again today.
Robert Moses said yesterday that the impact of an economic depression could be softened by a program of permanent improvements in housing and public works.

BEAUMONT, Tex., April 1 -- Now it's the Giants who aren't hitting, and though it's hardly a disgrace to bow to Cleveland's Early Wynn, the New Yorkers suffered their first shutout of the spring today. Leo Durocher's men paid the penalty for an anemic four-hit attack, as the Indians collected nine safeties against Ruben Gomez and Al Corwin for a 3-0 victory.

Pirating or "knock-off" of textile designs is an act of stealing as inherently immoral as cracking a safe, according to Frank Leslie of Leslie Co., textile commission concern. The situation, however, cannot be combated by group action under existing laws, he said yesterday, but rather must be resolved by raising the standard of ethics among converters of textiles.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Agricultural research is "one of the most important aspects" of the peaceful use of atomic power, Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss said today. The chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission said a stepped-up program was being planned to put atomic materials to work in farm research.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and closing prices were 3 points lower to 5 points higher than on Wednesday.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 1 (UP) -- Top-seeded Vic Seixas of Philadelphia today advanced easily to the semi-final round of the Caribe Hilton invitation tennis tournament, but Gardnar Mulloy of Miami did the same only after a three-set struggle.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 1 -- World swim marks were lowered by two Ohio State stars, Dick Cleveland and Yoshi Oyakawa, in special trials held today at the Yale University pool.

ROME, April 1 -- Most Italians could not believe their eyes this morning when they read in their newspapers that the Soviet Union had asked to be admitted to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. It was at first generally thought to be an April Fool's Day hoax.

The report of the American Cable and Radio Corporation for 1953, issued yesterday, showed net income of $1,656,659. This was equal to 48 cents a share on the communications concern's outstanding capital stock, and compared with net of $699,444, or 20 cents a share, in 1952.
MEXICO CITY, April 1 -- The failure of the United States and Mexico to agree on a civil aviation treaty has cost United States carriers a lucrative nonstop route between New York and this capital.
Governor Dewey sharply accused the Soviet Union last night of playing power politics in the United Nations with Israel-Arab tensions in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The United States Government's proposal to save Southeast Asia from the Communists by "united action" has strengthened the position of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and his Chinese Nationalists on Formosa.

Hugh Ferris, president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, pointed out yesterday that the issue of the proposed New York Coliseum at Columbus Circle had not been part of the agenda of the chapter's eighty-fifth annual meeting Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

IN arranging the large and well-selected exhibition of paintings by the American academic realist, Robert Henri, who died twenty-five years ago, Hirschl Adler honor an artist whose deep study of European old masters did not prevent him from illustrating the life about him in New York and the Far West with conviction and vitality.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association has questioned a proposed ruling of the Home Loan Bank Board to restrict advertising by federally insured savings and loan associations. The proposed rule is scheduled for public hearing here in April 19.

As far as the civil defense organization of New York and New Jersey is concerned, the same basic plans that were devised to hold atom-bomb damage to a minimum will be invoked if a hydrogen bomb is exploded.

The rehousing of displaced families is a problem in eighty-five United States cities where private redevelopers are rebuilding on slum sites under the Federal-local subsidy (Title I) program. It is more serious in New York than anywhere else.

Total assets of the Manufacturers Trust Company on March 31 were $2,827,499,202, according to the statement of condition released yesterday. This represents an increase of 5 per cent over the $2,691,583,352 reported on March 31, 1953.

BOSTON, April 1 (AP) -- Sandy Saddler, world featherweight boxing champion, due for discharge from the Army April 20, scored his third straight victory of a warm-up campaign tonight with a seven-round technical knockout over Augie Salazar of Oakland, Calif.

Women headed by Mrs. Lewis Armstrong and including Mrs. Alexis C. Coudert and Mrs. James M. Morton-Smith are holding frequent meetings at the Waldorf-Astoria to advance the plans for a wine-tasting reception to be held on April 26 in the Sert Room of the hotel for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center.

I go to Long Island every week-end in the winter, as well as for some of the summer months. I am therefore aware of the increasing traffic, due to the number of new homes being built on the island as well as to the developments that are being prepared.
BOSTON, April 1 -- Samuel P. Sears, the lawyer who will investigate Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's fight with the Army, was a strong supporter of the Wisconsin Senator for re-election in 1952.

ALBANY, April 1 (AP) -- New York City Democrats carried into the Appellate Division today their fight to force the State Parole Board to reveal the name of a prominent "Mr. X," who, they contend, sought a parole for Joseph S. Fay, convicted labor extortionist.

One of the new young designers to join the ranks of those already famous in Los Angeles is James Galanos. He established himself in Beverly Hills a little less than three years ago. A year ago he came here with his first collection. It immediately attracted the attention of connoiseurs in the fashion field.

The price of lead was increased 1/4 cent a pound yesterday to 13 3/4 cents, New York basis. It was the fifth 1/4-cent advance in less than a month. The price is now at the highest level since early last September.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Friday, April 2 (UP) -- Last-minute negotiations to avert a strike of 4,600 American Federation of Labor grain workers against twenty- seven General Mills plants across the nation broke off late last night and union employes began a strike at midnight.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- Following is the 57 to 28 roll-call vote by which the Senate passed the bill granting statehood to Hawaii and Alaska:

Federal Judge Henry W. Goddard yesterday ordered William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, to again submit to a physical examination to determine whether he was able to stand trial on Smith Act charges.

Congratulations to The Times for its stand in opposition to the construction of Echo Park and Split Mountain Dams in Dinosaur National Monument. I am inclined to go even farther than The Times did and question the whole philosophy of using up all of the best reservoir sites in our generation before the need for all of them has arisen and before real progress has been made on the upstream siltation problem.
Mayor Wagner's proposed extension of the 3 per cent sales tax to commercial services was denounced yesterday by representatives of thirty-nine business and trade organizations and individual firms.
The long delay in the investigation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's differences with the Army has added fuel to the smoldering fire of resentment against Congress felt by many in the services.

MOBILE, Ala., April 1 -- Ben Wade struck out Eddie Mathews in the ninth inning with the tying and winning runs on bases today to preserve an 8-7 victory for the Dodgers over the Milwaukee Braves. The triumph was the Brooks' second straight.
LAUREL, Md., April 1 (AP) -- Landseair, backed down to 4 to 5 in the feature, was the sixth straight beaten favorite at Laurel Park today when he finished second.

The Rev. Dr. John A. Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary and Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. A., declared last night that he was prepared to defend his past activities before any investigating body, "civil, Congressional or ecclesiastical."

Members of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association have arranged their annual card party in behalf of the cathedral for the afternoon of April 22 at the Colony Club. The parties have been held each year since the first in 1944, the committee for which was headed by Mrs. Ernest R. Adee and Mrs. Cleveland F. Bacon.
MOSCOW, April 1 -- Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov has convinced experienced Western diplomats here that the Soviet Union wants an end to the "cold war" in the era of atomic arms.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The president of the nation's largest gold mining company testified today that if the price of gold remained pegged at $35 an ounce, production in this country "will continue to decline."
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The Senate voted today, 57 to 28, to grant statehood to both Hawaii and Alaska.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif, April 1 -- Richard Murphy, who served for six years as a scenarist for Twentieth Century-Fox, is about to become a director as well.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The House of Representatives voted today to give President Eisenhower more authority than he had requested to stimulate home building by private enterprise.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Once upon a time a tortoise and a hare had a race. Aesop described it thousands of years ago. In the modern version there also was an octopus and there also were a lot of silly cubs. The story is a little involved but it can be unraveled with just a slight bit of patience.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 1 -- The fate of Dienbienphu continued uncertain tonight at the end of two nights and days of desperate fighting. The French union garrison is battling unceasingly against the Communist-led Vietminh attackers for the little mountain-ringed valley in North Tonkin, 180 miles west of Hanoi.

Largely as a result of a sharp drop in the "indicated" market value of its portfolio of marketable securities, the aggregate net asset value of the Alleghany Corporation, holding company of which Robert R. Young is chairman, fell last year to $56,850,032 from $65,840,329 at the end of 1952.

Business men were full of hope yesterday as the $999,000,000 annual reduction in Federal excise (sales) taxes took effect and gave that much more money to consumers and private enterprise to use at will.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- A Securities and Exchange Commissioner today reported a "discouragingly large" number of violations of S. E. C. rules covering stock and bond men.

CAIRO, April 1 -- Representatives of eight Arab states were reported to have reassured one another today that their governments had no intention of joining Western-sponsored defense pacts or agreements for military aid.

The editor of The Catholic Digest, a monthly magazine, offered figures yesterday aimed at refuting the contention made a week ago by The Christian Herald, Protestant periodical, that 4,144,366 Roman Catholics in America had joined Protestant churches in the last ten years.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 1 -- Joe Adonis, James Lynch, Anthony Guarini and Arthur Longano, who went to prison as a result of their gambling operations in Bergen County, testified today at the trial of Walter G. Winne. Superseded as prosecutor of Bergen County, he is charged with having failed to halt the operations of Adonis and Frank Erickson.
The Columbia University Varsity C Club honored the Lion's award-winning athletes last night at its thirty-third annual dinner.

Bank loans for business purposes in the New York area declined $35,000,000 in the week ened Wednesday causing the cumulative shrinkage in such credit over the first quarter of the year to reach $383,000,000. This compares with a shrinkage of business loans of $88,000,000 for the same period last year.
BANGOR, Me., April 1 -- A descendant of Maine's thirtieth Governor opened a one-man campaign today to make Senator Joseph R. McCarthy an issue in the Republican State Convention.

Ronald Colman and his wife, Benita Hume, have agreed to star in a television version of "Halls of Ivy," their former radio show that was acclaimed by critics and listeners. The program will be filmed by Television Programs of America and made available for showing in the fall.

The following are textual excerpts (with digests of the remaining parts) from Mayor Wagner's message to the Board of Estimate and the City Council in submitting the executive budget for the fiscal year 1954-55:

The Commissioner of Health is to be congratulated on the recent news releases emphasizing the importance her department is giving to tuberculosis. The dramatic happenings of the past two years have tended to create a feeling that at long last this age-old affliction of mankind has been dealt a lethal and perhaps final blow. This is not true.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 1 (AP) -- The Kencal Stud farm's Abbezac, ridden by Charley Burr, carried 121 pounds to a two-length victory in the $3,500 Sunshine purse before 10,881 persons at Gulfstream Park today. Avion finished second with a length and a half to spare over Sampan.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Robert H. Jackson, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, is in a Washington hospital suffering from a mild heart attack.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- President Eisenhower today signed the bill creating an Air Force Academy, which will rank with the military and naval academies.
MELBOURNE, Australia, April 1 -- The Ministry of Trade and Customs issued today a list of forty-one new classes of goods that henceforth may be imported from Japan under license.

LONDON, April 1 -- Herbert Hoover Jr., oil adviser to the United States Department of State, will fly to Teheran tomorrow to prepare the way for critical and predictably difficult negotiations with the Iranian Government.
New York City has borrowed $10,000,000 on bond anticipation notes due Aug. 2 at an interest rate of 1 3/8 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday.

Your editorial on "The Bomb" in The Times of March 28 stands in stark contrast to the letter published on the same page written by Lewis Mumford. Where the latter raised the most profound questions concerning the attitudes of our people and our Government in the matter of atomic energy, your editorial invokes a sacred cow called Science to show why the hydrogen tests cannot be stopped.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby today told Congress that Old Age and Survivors Insurance benefits today are too low for basic retirement.

Norway, a small country proud of its cultural achievements, gave us an evening of its music at Carnegie Hall last night. Wilhelm Morgenstierne, its Ambassador to the United States, was the chief patron, and two of the nation's musicians -- Oivin Fjeldstad, conductor, and Robert Riefling, pianist -- were sent here to join Leopold Stokowski and a local orchestra in presenting this program.
People who grumble about the mail service in New York are going to get a chance to do something about it; they are going to be allowed to pitch in and help speed it up.
SHREVEPORT, La., April 1 (UP) -- Stan Hack's debut as a major league manager today was anything but a howling success as the Baltimore Orioles defeated his Chicago Cubs, 6 to 1.

PARIS, April 1 -- C. Douglas Dillon, United States Ambassador to France, said in a speech today that what was happening in the United States was not a depression but "the demonstration of the flexibility and self-absorption of the American economy."

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson today accused Senator Stuart Symington of having made false and misleading statements in asserting that the Administration has set back the build-up of the Air Force by two years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1 -- Georgi F. Saksin, representative of the Soviet Union, raised his hand and his voice today in the Economic and Social Council to endorse consultative status for the United States Chamber of Commerce.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 1 -- The Arab states demanded today that the United Nations Security Council take up last week's Israeli attack on the Jordanian village of Nahhalin.

We welcome the prompt action of the National Labor Relations Board in upholding the report by a trial examiner setting aside last December's election among longshoremen because of coercion by the old International Longshoremen's Association. The board was subjected to strong political and economic pressures to sidestep, postpone or straddle the issue, but it stood firm.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 601,426 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
LONDON, April 1 -- The stock markets here were stimulated into wider activity and higher prices today. The disclosure of a Government surplus and Wall Street's advance were the motivating factors.
SAN DIEGO, April 1 (AP) -- Norman Gruggs of Overland, Mo., scored the fastest fall in opening round matches of the national senior A. A. U. wrestling championships today.

ALBANY, April 1 -- Governor Dewey approved today a schedule for next fall's state-wide election that had been bitterly criticized by the Democratic State Chairman as "a brazen plan to rig the 1954 election."

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The State Department documented a denial today of the Soviet Union's contention that the United States had agreed to accept Communist China as a fifth great power at the forthcoming Geneva conference on the Far East.

"Do-it-yourself" designs predominate in the annual Spring Craft Exhibit that opens today at the Pen and Brush Club, 16 East Tenth Street. The exhibit will be open daily from 1 to 5 P. M. through April 20.

DETROIT, April 1 (UP) -- Ted Lindsay drove the disk past Goalie Harry Lumley tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 4-to-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs at 1:01 of a second "sudden-death" overtime period.
HOBART, N. Y., April 1 -- Dairy farmers are generally resentful of the cut in the price support for dairy products from 90 to 75 per cent of parity.
Business was urged yesterday to "ignore special interests" and give strong support to President Eisenhower's liberal trade program.

The inflated city sales tax, which was originally given to New York City by the state and was supposed to be temporary to relieve distress caused by unemployment, is now officially being used to pay salary raises and other commitments. It will soon match the real-estate taxes, but without the legal limitations and curbs imposed on real-estate taxes.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 1 -- Nassau County's deposed labor czar, William C. DeKoning Sr., pleaded guilty to two counts of extortion and one of grand larceny in a surprise move in County Court here this afternoon.
BOSTON, April 1 (UP) -- Art Ross announced tonight that he was stepping down as general manager after thirty years with the Boston Bruins.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1 -- The Yankees were in no mood for fooling today regardless of the calendar -- not with a dismal 8-16 won-lost record against major league opposition behind them on the eve of heading north.

EVER since Cain committed the first murder it has been apparent that a conspicuous minority of the human race takes to crime as naturally as ducks to water. A depressingly large proportion of history is concerned with criminals and their crimes. The list of kings, emperors and dictators who were murderers as well as rulers seems almost end less.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Carl (Bobo) Olson, middleweight champion of the world, will risk his title against Kid Gavilan of Cuba in a fifteen-round bout at the Chicago Stadium tomorrow night. The contest is slated to start at 10 o'clock Eastern standard time, and will be televised and broadcast nationally, with the Chicago area blacked out.

Two worthy campaigns for funds that have been conducted in this city during the past few months were reported in yesterday's newspaper as being short of their desired goals. The 1954 Red Cross campaign, which seeks $5,900,000 in New York, finds itself some 25 per cent short of its objective.

Two comely girls with stage stars in their eyes "crashed" the Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus as clowns the other night, performed through the whole show and slipped out with applause ringing in their ears.

Television stations throughout the country began showing "Operation Ivy," the Government film on the hydrogen bomb explosion, immediately after prints were released formally by the Atomic Energy Commission at 7 A. M. yesterday.
PARIS, April 1 -- Alphonse-Pierre Juin, Marshal of France, got his "comeuppance" yesterday, according to those who have been irritated for years by his outspokenly frank tongue and imperious manner.
Many companies spend large sums of money to send messages to themselves.
Mayor Wagner's first executive budget was received yesterday by the Board of Estimate. It calls for the spending of $1,639,388,325 in the fiscal year starting July 1.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $545,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

The late Senator Robert A. Taft is the subject of two books to be published this season. On April 12 Harper will issue "The Taft Story" by William S. White of the Washington Bureau of The New York Times. In it the author discusses the Senator's "conspicuous qualities" as well as his "conspicuous failings and failures."

Emerson Radio of Canada, Ltd., has been established to manufacture and merchandise the complete product line of Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation in that country with Selby J. Sinclair as its president.

A new telephone number of suitably academic and geographic flavor has been assigned to the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. After 1 o'clock Sunday afternoon the institution will answer to OXford 5-4200.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 1 -- The Colombian Government decreed today a tax equivalent to $10 on each 150-pound sack of export coffee. This is the latest in a series of Government moves to offset deleterious effects on the internal economy due to risking coffee profits.

WINNIPEG, Man., April 1 (Canadian Press) -- A new curb on Canadian rye exports to the United States, announced yesterday by President Eisenhower, brought a sharp reaction today on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange and criticism from men connected with the trade.

Chartered banks and trust companies in New York State had record operating earning and net profits in 1953, William A. Lyon, New York Superintendent of Banks, reported yesterday in his annual review of state bank operations.

Coffee prices rose the 2-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday for the second consecutive day on the New York exchange. Cocoa prices opened the 1-cent limit higher but closed lower. Other commodities moved irregularly with cottonseed oil, rubber, lead and silk higher, zinc, hides and potatoes lower, and sugar, soybean oil, wool, burlap, tin and copper mixed.

FORT LEAVENWORTH, Kan., April 1 (UP) -- A court-martial sentenced a 28-year-old Kentuckian today to forty-years' imprisonment for striking an officer while the two were in a Korean prisoner-of-war camp.

LANSING, Mich., April 1 (AP) -- Reo Motors, Inc., said today that a decision will be made next Monday on the reported stock purchase offer by a "non-automotive" New York group. Joseph S. Sherer Jr., president, made the announcement following a meeting of the 50-year-old automotive company's board of directors yesterday.

The Southern Company, which operates electric, gas and transit properties in Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi and Florida, reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $22,369,897 in 1953. This was equal to $1.23 a share on the utility system's 18,087,643 shares of common stock outstanding at the end of the year, and compares with a net of $20,232,110 or $1.18 a share on 17,080,659 shares in 1952.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- The enabling bill for the St. Lawrence Seaway project ran into difficulties in the House Rules Committee today. The chairman, Representative Leo Allen, Republican of Illinois, said it might not be reported to the House until at least late this month.
Retailers slashed butter prices over the country yesterday.

Three vice presidents were named yesterday by Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., advertising agency. They are Richard Allewelt, Robert Barker and William King. Mr. Allewelt joined the agency in 1947 as account manager and was named account executive soon afterward.
ROME, April 1 -- Communist strength decreased slightly during the last twelve months among the 68,000 men and women employed by the Fiat Company of Turin.
TOKYO, April 1 (UP) -- The lower house of the Japanese Parliament approved a resolution today calling for international control of atomic energy and nuclear tests.

A seventy-foot sword, symbolizing the American Cancer Society's fight against cancer, was lighted in Times Square at 7:30 o'clock last night by President Eisenhower from the White House to open the society's 1954 fund-raising drive.
The Long Island Choral Society will present Mozart's Requiem tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, L. I.

Three new films arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Mayfair, the attraction is "The Naked Jungle," a Paramount adventure filmed in Technicolor and starring Charlton Heston and Eleanor Parker. Byron Haskin directed and George Pal produced from a script by Philip Yordan and Ranald MacDougall and the story, "Leiningen Versus the Ants" by Carl Stephenson.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics decreased to 91.3 on Wednesday from 91.7 on Tuesday. The figure for April 10, 1953, was 88.3.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 1 -- Turkish Foreign Ministry sources said today the latest Moscow offer to the Western Big Three was obviously designed to further delay or prevent creation of a European army.

HONG KONG, April 1 -- Communist China's Committee on Political and Legal Affairs has called for tightening of the "people's democratic dictatorship" in 1954. It is reported to have decided to intensify the prosecution of cases related to Government economic policies marked by increasingly rigid state controls.

Grover Loening, pioneer aviation engineer and inventor, has been named chairman of the advisory council of the Institute of Air Flight Structures at Columbia University. The institute was established last December by a grant from the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, and will be organized within the Columbia Engineering Center.
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The General Electric Company today defended its right to suspend workers who refuse on constitutional ground to answer questions of Congressional committees.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The Pentagon promised the Senate Armed Services Committee today a full report on "the mishandling" of the promotion and discharge of Maj. Irving Peress, center of a dispute between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin and the Secretary of the Army, Robert T. Stevens.

Examples of the work of five jewelry designers from the West and Midwest are being shown in the Gallery of America House by the American Craftsmen's Educational Council through April 28. The exhibitors are Margaret De Patta, Mary Schimpff, Robert von Neumann, Bob Winston and John Paul Miller.

THE use of commercial television's theatrical tricks to explain matters of vital public consequence went a step too far in "Operation Ivy," the official Government film showing the explosion of the first full-scale hydrogen bomb.

For the fifth successive day stocks pushed ahead. In yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange prices topped the highs this year and all but broke through the 1953 top of 197.53, set on Jan. 5 of that year. As it was, yesterday's high exceeded the Jan. 6, 1953, mark of 197.00 by a single point.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 11 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams promoted seventy-four men yesterday. At the same time, he increased the pay of thirty-four detectives by advancing them in grade.
New York City's department stores last month equaled their business of March, 1953, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.

The Russian leaders must have anticipated that their bland offer to join NATO would meet with the response it has received in Western capitals. With impressive unanimity responsible statesmen have not only rejected the Soviet proposal to jump the wall, so to speak, and become part of the organization the Kremlin has denounced so fiercely.
The Fedders-Quigan Corporation lifted earnings by 340 per cent in the six months through February, on a 33 per cent sales increase from the level of the same period a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Two areas of American life which already show the impact of Rear Admiral Strauss' statement yesterday are those concerned with defending human beings and our industrial plant from the ratio of dropped thermonuclear bombs which would penetrate any military defenses conceivable of attainment by the United States.
Eggs are abundant at prices about 10 cents a dozen less than a year ago at this time. This good news suggests the omelet as a dish worthy of the home cook's consideration.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 (AP) -- Royal Little, chairman of the board of Textron, Inc., charged today that a group of board members of the American Woolen Company are offering to pay more than $15 a share -- three times their value -- for common stock of the Bachmann Uxbridge Company in a planned merger of the two firms.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday cut the suggested retail price of its 12 1/2-inch color TV set from $1,295 to $1,110.

New Yorkers have been advised to "strive toward safer living and cultivate safer habits in their daily lives throughout the year" by Mayor Wagner in his proclamation setting aside the period from April 5 through April 9 as Greater Safety Week. This year's observance will climax more than two decades of organized accident prevention work by the Greater New York Safety Council in this city.
BONN, Germany, April 1 -- The West German Cabinet approved tonight a statement reaffirming the Government's determination to pursue its present foreign policy of West European unity.

LONDON, April 1 -- Delegates of Britain's shipbuilding employers and of the unions connected with the industry agreed today to recommend to their respective industrial associates wage increases that would give 210,000 workers in the industry pay increases costing the equivalent of $9,800,000 a year.

There was no clear evidence of an improvement in business during March, the monthly letter of the National City Bank of New York, to be issued today, will say. Although the opinion is spreading that the worst decline is over, this is a matter of a faith rather than of statistical demonstration, the letter maintains.

Robert Moses, newly appointed chairman of the New York State Power Authority, is, as expected, putting up a valiant battle on behalf of the state and the public of New York in the Niagara power dispute. He deserves to win, for he is, as usual, fighting in a good cause.
An underlying problem of the city's waterfront, which has been lost sight of in the present labor controversy, is the need for pier rehabilitation, Acting Mayor Abe Stark said last night.
The seven privately owned ferry boats plying between Brooklyn and Staten Island became municipal property yesterday.
A Nassau County Liquor Board investigator was under suspension for five days last month because, he said, he did not know the law.

Coming back to the local stage after an absence of eight years will be Montgomery Clift, who rose to prominence in Hollywood much more quickly than he did on Broadway. "The Sea Gull," opening May 11 at the Phoenix, will mark Mr. Clift's return.
CAIRO, April 1 -- University students and teachers, striking against continuation of Egypt's military regime, have been warned indirectly that their protest was powerless and futile.

There was a meeting of Horseplayers, Inc., at the Jamaica track yesterday. It was a rather well-attended meeting. There were 35,651 customers on the premises for the first of New York's 196 days of racing this year.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Samuel P. Sears, a Boston attorney, was selected today to be special counsel to the Senate inquiry into Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's dispute with the Army. The subcommittee had been seeking a counsel for sixteen days.
LONDON, April 1 -- The British Government rejected today the suggestion of Vyacheslav M. Molotov that the Soviet Union might consider seeking admission to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

That the Soviet consumer welcomes the recent price cuts announced by the Soviet press can be taken for granted. But that there is an element of disappointment in this welcome would also seem likely. Ever since Premier Malenkov's long speech last August, Soviet spokesmen have competed among themselves in describing the abundance of foods and consumer goods immediately ahead.
The American Radio Association, C. I. O., urged licensed ship officers yesterday to think in terms of one union for all mates, engineers and radio officers.

CHICAGO, April 1 -- Crop news from the Southwest reflected increasing concern over the outlook for the winter wheat crop. Pessimistic state reports from Kansas and Oklahoma, following yesterday's report from Nebraska, coupled with the Santa Fe Railroad's April 1 summary, combined to start a substantial buying wave in wheat futures.
NEW ORLEANS, April 1 (AP) -- Raymond (Bear) Wolf resigned today as the Tulane University football coach and the backfield coach, Andy Pilney, was named to succeed him.

FORTUNATELY, the authors of "King of Hearts," which opened at the Lyceum last evening, have a sense of humor and the gift of gab. The authors are Jean Kerr, the economy-size wife of The Herald Tribune's drama critic, and Eleanor Brooke, formerly a student in a class he once gave in playwriting.
Leo Mates, newly appointed Yugoslav Ambassador to the United States, arrived at the International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, at 6:45 A. M. yesterday on a Pan American clipper from London.
CHICAGO, April 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP) -- The economy-minded Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives today cut nearly $59,000,000 from President Eisenhower's budget for the Interior Department.
WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Because of circumstances beyond nearly everybody's control, hydrogen-bomb blast pictures set for release on April 7 are now being shown.

WASHINGTON, April 1 (UP) -- The House Labor Committee voted today to junk the rigid eighty-day "cooling-off" procedure of the Taft-Hartley Act in national emergency disputes in favor of more flexible processes.

ABOUT 2,500 shivering fishermen turned out for the special trout season that opened in the Finger Lakes area yesterday. Some of them, although belatedly, admitted they would have more faith in the weather man's forecast in the future.

First-quarter sales of the Commercial Solvents Corporation are expected to be about 15 per cent above those of a year ago, with earnings also somewhat higher, J. Albert Woods, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Baltimore.
Aided by tremendous tail winds up to 115 miles an hour, three Navy jet fighter planes crossed the United States in less than four hours yesterday for a new unofficial speed record.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr., asked Congress today to enact legislation to protect national defense facilities and resources against sabotage by atomic, biological or chemical methods.

Two 16,500 - deadweight - ton tankers now under construction for the Tide Water Associated Oil Company have been sold to the Western Hemisphere Corporation. The new owner, a Delaware corporation, was represented in the transaction by Mathiasen's Tanker Industries, Inc., of Philadelphia.
The Amerada Petroleum Corporation last year recorded the second largest earnings in its history.

AARON COPLAND'S first full - length opera, "The Tender Land," the libretto by Horace Everett, received its premiere as the first half of a double bill by the New York City Opera Company last night at the City Center.

PARIS, April 1 -- Premier Joseph Laniel tonight described the dismissal of Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin from his high military post in terms resembling those used by President Truman to justify his dismissal of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in 1951.
The prices of three market-basket staples -- milk, butter and eggs -- changed this week in a direction pleasing to housewives.

The explosion on March 1 and 26 of two new models of hydrogen bombs ranging in explosive power from 12,000,000 to possibly 20,000,000 of tons of TNT makes it evident that our scientists and engineers have catapulted mankind in one giant stride from the atomic into the hydrogen age.
JERUSALEM, April 1 -- Jordan is considering two moves to show her dissatisfaction with what is regarded by the Jordanians as United States economic and political favoritism toward Israel.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, criticized yesterday a recent report of the House Appropriations Committee that found fault with the Coliseum project here.

When it became a reasonable certainty some days ago that the excise tax cuts would go through, Vim Stores, Inc., a chain of fifty-four appliance outlets in the metropolitan area, set to work on large-space advertising copy calling attention to price cuts.

AARON COPLAND'S first full - length opera, "The Tender Land," the libretto by Horace Everett, received its premiere as the first half of a double bill by the New York City Opera Company last night at the City Center.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, criticized yesterday a recent report of the House Appropriations Committee that found fault with the Coliseum project here.

When it became a reasonable certainty some days ago that the excise tax cuts would go through, Vim Stores, Inc., a chain of fifty-four appliance outlets in the metropolitan area, set to work on large-space advertising copy calling attention to price cuts.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 2 -- Following are excerpts from the text of Adlai E. Stevenson's speech here tonight at a North Carolina Democratic party rally:
MOSCOW, April 2 -- Moscow's Central Aviation Club now has established a special "astro-aviation" section for the study and development of interplanetary flight.

The bitter struggle at Dienbienphu has reached new heights of savagery these past few days, as human wave assaults by the Communist forces have been repulsed time and again. Though they have been forced to withdraw at some points, the tired and outnumbered defenders have been writing a new page in the saga of heroism.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 2 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said tonight that the Eisenhower Administration was treating the American people as the "targets of a sales campaign" rather than as a mature and responsible nation.
ROME, April 2 -- The Cabinet approved today a bill for ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty. The measure will be sent to Parliament within the next few days.
BOSTON, April 2 (AP) -- The assets of the New England steel development Corporation have been reassigned to the New England Council.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 -- Walt Disney signed an exclusive long-term contract today with the American Broadcasting Company to become the first leading Hollywood producer to enter into formal alliance with television.
A new motion-picture theatre opened on Forty-second Street yesterday and within a half hour was playing to standing room only.
A survey to determine the future course of the Equity Library Theatre is being conducted by the organization's board of directors.

Three new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "The Pickwick Papers," a Britishmade version of the Charles Dickens book, is at the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux. The large cast is headed by James Hayter, James Donald, Hermione Gingold, Donald Wolfit, Nigel Patrick, Joyce Frenfell, Hermione Baddeley, Harry Fowler and Kathleen Harrison. Noel Langley adapted and directed the Langley-Minter Production, presented by George Minter and distributed here by Arthur Mayer-Edward Kingsley, Inc.
One of the New York City Opera's most popular productions, Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro," had its first performance of the spring season last night at the City Center.

Death has claimed Hoyt Vandenberg early, at the age of 55, but he had lived a full life, as public servant and man. A nephew of Arthur H. Vandenberg, he was sometimes credited with being a major influence in persuading the late Senator to a more international point of view.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- President Eisenhower will talk to the nation Monday night about fears, domestic and international.

A mandatory death sentence was imposed in General Sessions yesterday on a 17-year-old slayer of an elderly woman. The imposition of similar sentences on two other youths, who also had been found guilty in the death of Mrs. Anna Levy, 85, in her lower East Side flat last June 2, was put over until next Thursday.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The Army tonight appointed a special counsel to handle its case in the dispute with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Following are the two key roll-call votes in the House of Representatives today on the housing bill. By 211 to 176, the House refused to add the four-year public housing program asked by the President, then by 352 to 36 passed the omnibus housing bill.

Communism and anti-Communism demagoguery have become dangerous threats to our freedom because of national feelings of insecurity, Mrs. Mildred McAfee Horton, wartime commander of the WAVES and former president of Wellesley College, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The House of Representatives rejected President Eisenhower's public housing program tonight on a roll-call ballot of 211 to 176.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Pvt. G. David Schine, formerly non-salaried consultant to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate Investigating Subcommittee, is not qualified for training as a military police criminal investigator, the Army ruled today.

The search for a counsel to conduct the Senatorial inquiry into the controversy between Senator McCarthy and the Army had stretched out for more than two weeks while the investigating committee sought a man of pre-eminent qualifications who would have public confidence as a genuine neutral in this dispute.
BONN, April 2 -- Erich Ollenauer, Social Democratic leader served notice again tonight that his party would never recognize the abandonment of German sovereignty over the Saar to France
SOUTH BEND, Ind., April 2 (AP) -- Notre Dame greeted its head football coach, Terry Brennan, with a brass band and welcoming banners as spring practice opened today.
Net assets of the United Corporation, a former utility holding company which is now an investment concern, increased by more than $5,000,000 in the first quarter of this year.

Events today: "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 2; "Hansel and Gretel," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 2:30; "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; "La Cenerentola," New York City Opera Company, City Center, 8:15; "Rigoletto," Amato Opera Theatre, 150 Bleecker Street, 8:30; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Petri Opera Group, Carl Fischer Concert Hall 8.

GUATEMALA, April 2 -- In his first press conference since returning from the Tenth Inter-American Conference at Caracas Foreign Minister Guillermo Toriello told reporters that Guatemala's delegation had not gone to Caracas to defend communism but the sovereign right of each country to determine its own fate.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- The American Heart Association's increased research into heart and blood-vessel diseases was described today as a reflection of "the tremendous public confidence in and acceptance of the association's program and objectives."

David Michel Torino, Argentine publisher whose journalistic opposition to the Peron regime was translated legally into "desacato" -- disrespect -- and thereby made punishable by imprisonment, is temporarily a free man.
The State Harness Racing Commissioner yesterday promised the trotting track patron an honest run for his money in the future.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April -Westchester's transformation from a bedroom for New York to more of a front office is gaining speed this spring.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Democratic hopes for gaining outright control of the Senate in the fall elections were shaken today.

Pitchers are supposed to be far ahead of batters in early-season baseball games. That wasn't the way it went yesterday at Baker Field, where Columbia pounded out a 13-to-9 decision over the University of Vermont.

The regional Red Cross Blood Program received 813 pints of blood from volunteer donors Thursday. Fordham University students and faculty gave 183 pints at the uptown division and 102 at the downtown division. At City College, 179 pints were collected. Employes of the New York Telephone Company, 435 West Fiftieth Street, gave 147 pints.
TRENTON, April 2 -- A general sales tax and a levy on personal income were recommended today by Republican leaders of the State Senate to meet the rising costs of government in New Jersey.
The Police Department merged three units yesterday into one and made eight more personnel transfers.
NEW DELHI, India, April 2 -- The Government has decided to end free travel between Indian territory and Pondicherry and Karikal, two of the four French settlements in this country.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 2 (UP) -- Vic Seixas of Philadelphia gained the men's singles final in the Caribe-Hilton international tennis tournament today with a 6-1, 6-1, 6-2 triumph over Denmark's Kurt Nielsen, who punctuated erratic play with outbursts of temper.

Fashion may not appear to have anything in common with politics, the cold war or labor troubles on the waterfront. But all these factors have conspired to bring furrows to the brow of a New York importer of Italian velveteens.

The proclamation by Mayor Wagner of the period from April 3 through April 10 as Goodwill Week calls attention to the work of Goodwill Industries, a non-profit, interracial and non-sectarian organization dedicated to the work-training and employment of physically handicapped men and women.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- The United States and Britain came out today against India's proposal to the United Nations for world calendar reform.
The old International Longshoremen's Association, its back to the wall, called off the Port of New York's longest and costliest pier strike yesterday.
New I. R. T. subway schedules have resulted in elimination of week-end and holiday express service on the Flushing, Queens, line and curtailment of local service on the West Side line.
ROME, April 2 (AP) -- Italian movie producers, seeking to safeguard their foreign markets, have decided to have a control board run a morality check on their films.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's scheduled talk on Edward R. Murrow's television program next Tuesday night may be presented by film recording. The Wisconsin Republican made a film yesterday at the Fox Movietone News Studios here, and it was reported that it was for use on the commentator's "See It Now" program.

Rubber prices soared yesterday on the New York exchange in the sharpest rise in almost a year. The volume was the heaviest since trading reopened on the commodity on March 3, 1952. Cocoa prices fell the 1-cent-a-pound limit in all months.
NEW DELHI, India, April 2 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru called today for a "standstill agreement" among the powers that possess atomic weapons.
Business reaction to the Federal excise tax cuts showed a mixed picture yesterday that dampened some consumers' hopes of getting the full benefit of the $999,000,000 annual tax saving.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby stoutly maintained today that holding forty-eight state educational conferences would solve school problems faster than any Federal action.
Price moves in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange were somewhat irregular yesterday. The close in active months was 8 points higher to 4 points lower than on Thursday.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., April 2 (AP) -- Penn State, the defending champion, qualified fifteen men today for the finals of the National Collegiate Gymnastics tournament.

WINNIPEG, April 2 -- The Hudson's Bay Company had a net profit of $3,699,000 from trading in the year ending Jan. 31, it was announced today in Winnipeg. The previous year's net profit was $3,119,000. Surplus on the land account was $582,000 against $468,000 in fiscal 1953.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Ben Gold, president of the Fur and Leather Workers Union, independent, was convicted today of having falsely denied he was a Communist party member and a supporter of its policies.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- The buying movement in wheat gained considerable momentum today, reflecting the increasing concern over crop conditions in the Southwest and reports that Germany would take 6,000,000 bushels of red and hard winter wheat in the next few weeks.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- State Department authorities reacted with interest, but also with skepticism today to a report that Western diplomats in Moscow believed the Soviet Union was sincerely trying to end the "cold war."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 (AP) -- Penny Edwards, the actress, says she is quitting the screen "to do the Lord's work in whatever way He wills."

ALBANY, April 2 -- New equalization rates that will increase the borrowing and real estate taxing powers of ten cities of less than 20,000 population were announced today by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment.
BONN, Germany, April 2 -- The Federal Government was urged today in the Bundestag to protect the West German motion-picture industry by limiting the distribution of American films.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 2.7 per cent below the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were down 1.3 per cent and orders up 8.1 per cent.
CARROLLTON, Ga., April 2 (UP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias trimmed two strokes off par today to take the lead in the first round of the Carrollton women's open golf tournament with a 70.

Convinced that church-sponsored "theatre" can be professional and perform a religious ministry to the community at the same time, the Broadway Tabernacle Church, Congregational, at Fifty-sixth Street, will present a Christopher Fry playlet at 5:30 P. M. each Sunday during April and May, beginning tomorrow.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 2 -- Samuel Goldwyn, leading independent producer, became a central figure in a new Communist controversy today. It was touched off by the Motion Picture Alliance for the Preservation of American Ideals as a result of Mr. Goldwyn's recent purchase of screen rights to "Guys and Dolls."
BOSTON, April 2 -- Mr. Sears, when asked today whether he knew Senator McCarthy, said, "I never met the gentleman."
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 2 (UP) -- Brazilian President Getulio Vargas turned over today to the state oil monopoly all Government oil holdings and assets, with an estimated value of $165,000,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 2 -- An attorney asked the Supreme Court here today to set aside a $28,000 verdict against his client. His grounds were that a juror in the case supple mented the judge's charge by, producing two public library books for the edification of fellow jurors during their deliberation.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, April 2 (AP)--The Federal Court convicted Prof. Andre Bonnard and another Swiss today of violating the nation's strict espionage laws by furnishing derogatory information on the International Red Cross to the Communist-dominated World Peace Council.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 2 -- Nassau Children's Court Judge James N. Gehrig said today that pupils responsible for bomb scares to the county public schools should be sent to some institution.

BARCELONA, Spain, April 2--A group of 285 Spaniards, including veterans of the Blue Division that fought against the Soviet Union in World War II, landed here today. They had spent a minimum of eight years in Russian concentration camps.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The British Cabinet has changed its definition of strategic goods that should be barred from export to the Soviet bloc. This resulted from the visit of Harold E. Stassen, Director of the Foreign Operations Administration, to London last week.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 2 -- Another swimming crown was taken by Ford Konno of Hawaii tonight. Following his triumph in the 1,500-meter event last night, the 145-pound Ohio State undergraduate captured the National Amateur Athletic Union 220-yard free-style championship at Yale University's pool.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 2 (UP) An additional week of Grand Circuit harness racing for Yonkers raceway was announced today as the Grand Circuit released a revised schedule. The changes involve Yonkers and the Wolverine Raceway at Plymouth, Mich.

CLARK, N. J., April 2--A thing that happens seldom or ever in the life of a policeman -- a perfect clue--turned up here today after an automobile had crashed into Mayor Jay A. Stemmer's car, which was parked in front of his home at 21 Sunset Drive.
