UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- Western diplomats have been discussing a plan for an on-the-spot report on Arab-Israeli frontier troubles from the United Nations Peace Observation Commission.

From now on, eleven youngsters may neglect the exploits of Hopalong Cassidy and Roy Rogers and pay a little more attention to their 52-year-old grandmother, Mrs. Mary Rose of 821 East 179th Street, the Bronx.

Nikita Roodkowsky charged in his letter of March 13 that "justification of this destructive force [violence and assassination] is basic in the writings of the founder of communism -- Karl Marx." Then, in support of this accusation, Mr. Roodkowsky says:

The $276,000,000 New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, which serves nearly half a million customers in upper central and northern New York State areas, reported yesterday that it will spend $75,000,000 in the next three years for expansion and new construction.

WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- Assistant Attorney General Stanley N. Barnes said today that complaints of anti-trust law violations skyrocketed last year, posing a problem for the Department of Justice in the face of reduced appropriations for prosecutions.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 2 (AP) -- The trustees of Ducks Unlimited, Inc., today appropriated their largest sum ever -- $450,000 -- for rehabilitation this summer of the migratory fowl breeding areas in Canada's prairie provinces.

The number of ships calling at New York since the beginning of the year is far below the figures for the same period last year, according to the monthly report of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A milk substitute designed for children who are allergic to cow's milk, or who just don't like it, was patented this week by Haines B. Lockhart for Swift Co., Chicago. It is a mineral-enriched meat product that simulates cow's milk in the calcium, phosphorus, magnesium, potassium, sodium and fat content and simulates human milk in the protein and carbohydrate conteent.

Pineapple juice, so naturally sweet that sugar is not added during canning, is selling in many supermarkets this week-end for as little as $1 for eight No. 2 (eighteen-ounce) cans. A single serving of six ounces costs about 4 cents.
Frank Costello asked Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan yesterday to disqualify himself from presiding at the gambler's income tax evasion trial, which is scheduled to start Monday.

The McCarran Act, in denying access to the United Nations by non - governmental representatives who apparently are Communists, is "ruining our reputation" with the rest of the world, it was charged yesterday by Dr. Clyde Eagleton, Professor of International Law at New York University.
The banker's heart was of cold stone, and only one eye regarded the applicant for a loan favorably. That was the eye made of glass. So the story ran.
BANGOR, Me., April 2 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith stepped into the breach today and closed the ranks of Maine Republicans at their biennial state convention.

THE geometrically abstract pictures by Hans Richter at the Rose Fried Gallery that have been painted over a period of forty years derive essentially from the art historical period that immediately succeeded Cubism.

A contest for stockholders' proxies to win control of the Blair Holdings Corporation is centering around what part, if any, Virgil D. Dardi, resigned president, will have in the future doings of the $25,000,000 California investment company.
The seventeenth annual Three Choir Festival presented under auspices of Congregation Emanu-El opened yesterday afternoon with a program honoring the bicentenary celebration of Columbia University.

Reports from Moscow say that some Western diplomats accredited to the Kremlin believe that the Soviet Union is sincere in wishing to end the cold war. These unnamed diplomats are convinced that this is the meaning of the latest note addressed to the United States, Great Britain and France.

For a number of years the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., unlike real estate boards elsewhere, has favored a public housing program for low-income families. It has correctly pointed out that low-rent public housing does not compete with private enterprise.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Lawrence Quincy Mumford, director of the Cleveland Public Library, will be named as the nation's eleventh Librarian of Congress.

ONE by one the winter fishing tournaments are ending, only to be succeeded by summer tournaments. The Bahamas "winter" derby has just ended, with the major awards going to a second-time winner, Mrs. Anne Archbold of Washington.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The project for statehood for both Hawaii and Alaska is certain to die in the House of Representatives unless President Eisenhower should powerfully intervene. Even a Presidential intervention might not save it.

FORT WORTH, April 2 -- More and more the big mid-winter deal between the Giants and the Braves appears to have been a good one for the New Yorkers. That was the one-for-four trade which sent Bobby Thomson to Milwaukee and brought Johnny Antonelli, Don Liddle, Ebba St. Claire and Billy Klaus to New York.

Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday the city's preparations for the first inoculations with the new Salk vaccine against poliomyelitis in six health districts here on April 26.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Spiritual frontiers are even more gravely threatened than land frontiers, Miss Lucile Allen, dean of Pennsylvania College for Women, said here today.

Thirteen Brooklyn Democratic district leaders met yesterday afternoon to try to agree tentatively on a successor to Kenneth F. Sutherland, who has announced he will quit as county leader as soon as his colleagues agree on a successor.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- It figured to be a close fight. It was. It was filled with fury but little substance as Bobo Olson and Kid Gavilan tossed leather incessantly through fifteen frantic rounds tonight.

EDGEWATER, N. J., April 2 -- The Hudson River shad, which usually begins its spawning run upstream during Easter Week, is ahead of schedule this year, in a manner of speaking. Actually, the shad is about on time -- it's Easter that's late.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 2 -- Turkey and Pakistan signed a mutual defense agreement today. They invited nations adjoining them to become members of the alliance.

Library steps came into use in England in about 1750. During the next few decades, this decorative and functional piece of furniture assumed varying shapes and had varying success as units of design. Some steps folded into tables and some into chairs and benches, and almost all were available in over-the-counter sales.
ALBANY, April 2 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed Louis J. Lefkowitz to be an associate justice of the New York County branch of New York's City Court. The post pays $22,000 a year.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to homemakers:

Dispatches from the Netherlands tell of a vast project to dam up a group of wide estuaries of the North Sea which claw into that wet country like fingers of a monstrous hand. In a quarter century or thereabouts seawalls of a size beyond anything of the sort ever constructed are planned to plug those channels whose tides and currents are "deeper and more powerful than those mastered anywhere else previously."

AUSTIN, Tex., April 2 (UP) -- Wes Santee set a blistering pace in the half-mile anchor lap today to lead Kansas to a world record time in the sprint medley relay highlighting the opening of the twenty-seventh annual Texas Relays.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Gen. Hoyt S. Vandenberg, who had served as Chief of Staff of the Air Force for more than five years, died today of cancer at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 55 years old.

Ralph Kelly, retired Philadelphia businessman, who is the new United States Commissioner of Customs, got his first look yesterday at the most important division of his command, New York Customs District 10, where about 50 per cent of the nation's imports and exports are handled.
NEWARK, April 2 -- Harold John Adonis, who was executive clerk under former Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, was sentenced today to five years in prison for income-tax evasion.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- A son of a former Chief Justice asked the Supreme Court today to grant a rehearing in the offshore oil cases.

DETROIT, April 2 (UP) -- Ford outproduced Chevrolet in the first three months of the year and outsold that division of General Motors Corporation in January and February, but G. M. retained over-all leadership, production and registration figures showed today.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., April 2 -- Representative Frank C. Osmers, Republican of New Jersey, told members of the New Jersey Association of Insurance Agents here last night that the Federal Government should get out and stay out of competitive private business. He told 550 members of the group at their seventy-first annual midwinter meeting that their industry was not immune from Government competition.
CHICAGO, April 2 (UP) -- The American Medical Association "strongly condemned" today the implication in advertisements that it approved "any particular brand" of cigarettes.
Eddie Arcaro, the nation's No. 1 jockey, and Nick Wall, at 49, one of the oldest, were injured yesterday when unseated by their mounts at the starting gate in separate races at Jamaica.
LONDON, April 2 (AP) -- The Russian people were told today that hydrogen bombs could destroy "the fruits of a thousand years of human toil."

ROCQUENCOURT, France, April 2 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther denied today Soviet charges that the North Atlantic alliance was an aggressive organization. The Supreme Allied Commander in Europe declared that the plans of his headquarters always had assumed the necessity of absorbing an initial attack by an enemy.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (UP) -- Senator Charles E. Potter proposed today that all "loyalty risks" be banned from military service and that disloyalty be branded on their draft cards.

The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, William Steinberg conducting, heard here a season ago, visited us again last night in Carnegie Hall, presenting on its program the Second Symphony of the 15-year-old, Franz Peter Schubert and the "Lied von der Erde." Gustav

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 -- Admitting this to be the most scrambled pre-season outlook he'd had in his six years with the Yankees, and that the exhibition record to date had been "pretty awful," Casey Stengel today nevertheless expressed the stout belief his Bombers had the over-all strength to win their sixth successive American League pennant.
Mayor Wagner's message explaining and defending his 1954-55 executive budget of $1,639,388,325 was denounced yesterday as a socialistic document.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP) -- The Supreme Court hasn't been the same ever since World War II, but things are returning to normal. The long-absent goose quill is on its way back.

WASHINGTON, April 2--Unemployment rose by 54,000 in March to a total of 3,725,000, the Commerce Department's Bureau of the Census reported today. The increase was the smallest for any month since last October, when unemployment began to climb.

Two Puerto Rican teenagers were ordered booked for homicide at the Morrisania police station, the Bronx, early today by Assistant District Attorney Irvin J. Goldsmith in connection with the fatal shooting on a Bronx street corner at 9:45 P. M. Thursday of Carl Hughes, 14-year-old Negro.
Dr. John F. Erdmann, noted surgeon who died last Saturday on his 90th birthday, left an estate of more than $1,250,000. His will was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court.
I am sure that I am only one of many who share the appreciation expressed by The Times, in its editorial of March 29, of the opportunities now open to educational television in New York.
ATHENS, April 2 -- Spyros Markezinis resigned today as Minister of Economic Coordination. He will be replaced by his deputy, Thanos Kapsalis.
A Government official has declared war on "gobbledygook."

PHILADELPHIA, April 2 -- Nationalist China's Ambassador warned tonight that the Chinese Communists might be counting upon a diplomatic offensive at the forthcoming Geneva conference on Far Eastern affairs.
WASHINGTON, April 2 -- The House Labor Committee voted today to write a pre-strike poll requirement into the Taft-Hartley Act.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 2 (AP)--Veit Harlan, German producer of the motion picture "Jew Suess," destroyed one of the two existing negatives of the film here this morning, he said at a news conference.

WASHINGTON, April 2 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent to 110.9 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for farm products and processed foods were responsible for the increase, as the index for all commodities other than farm products and foods remained unchanged.
Mayor Wagner returned from his five-day vacation in Jamaica, B. W. I., yesterday, to find that the waterfront strike was over.
LONDON, April 2 -- A late reaction left stock prices irregular but still showing gains at the close of the market here today.

The earning prospects of the proposed extension of the Pennsylvania Tunrpike northward beyond Scranton were discussed at a meeting of Pennsylvania officials and representatives of investment houses yesterday at the New York State Chamber of Commerce Building.

KARACHI, April 2 (AP) -- The Pakistani-Turkish pact, to run for five years, had been welcomed by the United States as a constructive step toward bolstering the free world's defenses. The Soviet Union, a northern neighbor of the two Moslem nations, had assailed the alliance, charging it created an anti-Russian "military bloc in the Near and Middle East."
ALBANY, April 2 (AP) -- The State Education Commissioner, Lewis A. Wilson, appealed today to school administrators throughout the state to take "every possible precaution" against school fires.
Requests have been made to city department heads to check "considerable leakage and wastage of water" reported in public buildings.

Edward Hoagland, 21-year-old Harvard College senior from New Canaan, Conn., has been chosen for the 1954 Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship for an untitled novel about a little known part of circus life -- the "first train," which carries the wild animals.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 2 -- The United States and other Western countries supported a proposal today that the United Nations keep up its investigations into forced-labor practices.

More than 300 of the nation's largest commercial air transports stand ready to fly for the military services in event of a national emergency. This fleet is capable of carrying more than an entire division of troops or in excess of 5,750,000 pounds of cargo from Coast-to-Coast in less than twelve hours.

LONDON, April 2 -- Spokesmen for Britain's two great political parties appealed to the Soviet Union today for cooperation in easing world tension. Such a respite would create conditions for international control of nuclear weapons, they said.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 2 -- The issue of religious freedom in Colombia flared again this week. While having caused bitterness and even bloodshed in previous years, this issue had been relatively dormant the last few months.
ALBANY, April 2 -- Harold Keller, State Commerce Commissioner, today described as promising the general prospects for business in the state for the balance of 1954.

An expanded and improved cargo ship service between United States ports and Venezuela has been promised by Guillermo Plaza, president of the Venezuelan Line (Compania Anonima Venezuela de Navigacion). Mr. Plaza said four 4,800-deadweight-ton vessels were now under construction in the Netherlands, with the first of these due here in August.

Hats off to the merchant marine! Your editorial "Bravery at Sea" and The Topics of The Times "A Ship's Flag" were both timely articles and made good reading. Recently you told us about the Empress of Scotland and the Queen of Bermuda docking without the assistance of tugs.
CAMDEN, N. J., April 2 -- About 5,000 employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation walked off their jobs here today in what they called a protest against company policy.
Not averse to increasing lemon consumption, the Sunkist Growers are suggesting the fruit as a flavoring in low-sodium (popularly called low-salt) diets.

BUENOS AIRES, April 2 -- Differences between President Juan D. Peron and Eduardo Vuletich, secretary general of the once-powerful General Confederation of Labor, came to light tonight. Newspapers played up stories about a special conference held this morning among government, labor and business representatives on the President's wage policy.
LONDON, April 1 (Reuters) -- The world's main airlines today increased most of their standard rate fares, but at the same time introduced new tourist services to balance the rises.
HAMBURG, Germany, April 2 (AP) -- The German four-master Pamir, one of West Germany's last great clipper ships, was sold at auction here today for 310,000 Deutsche marks ($73,811).

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 2 (AP) -- While the fans trooped after Sam Snead, who shot a 71 in an opening-round bid to win the $10,000 Greater Greensboro open tournament for a fifth time, Bob Rosburg of Chicago and Rudy Horvath of Windsor, Canada, slipped in almost unnoticed with 67's today to tie for first place.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 2 -- French Union and Vietminh troops clashed in a new sector of the French Dienbienphu defenses last night and today. Attacking the northwest corner of the defense complex, Communist-led Vietminh units occupied two support points in the sector last night.
Losses to business men and workers caused by the twenty-nine-day outlaw dock strike were estimated by industry men last night at close to half a billion dollars.
BOSTON, April 2 -- State and local police today raided the Park Square headquarters of the Massachusetts Communist party.

CHICAGO, April 2 -- Carl (Bobo) Olson was successful in the defense of his world middleweight championship tonight. The Hawaiian from San Francisco just managed to gain the decision over the Cuban whirlwind, Kid Gavilan, in a fifteen-round fight that was thoroughly enjoyed by the fans.

Signature Loan Company, Inc., formerly Federal Loan Company of Pittsfield, Mass., is offering holders of its participating preferred stock rights to exchange such stock for shares of $11 par value 7 per cent dividend convertible stock on the basis of two new convertible shares for each share of participating preferred held.

Aircrafts continued yesterday to fall back from their highs of the last week, and a handful of recent favorites -- notably du Pont, Chrysler, Firestone and Ingersoll-Rand -- were heavy. But no real pre-week-end reaction developed in the stock market.
New hearing procedures in workmen's compensation cases aimed at reducing delays and costs were recommended to Governor Dewey yesterday.

PARIS, April 2 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin contends that a new treaty for a European army could be negotiated within about two months. He believes the French Government should propose this course.
Evidence suggested today that any nation possessing ordinary fission bombs may now have hydrogen bombs.

NOSTALGIA is the heroine of Gene Fowler's beguiling memoir, "Minutes of the Last Meeting."* The central character is Sadakichi Hartmann (1869-1944), a cranky squatter in the republic of art. But the true heroes of the book are John Barrymore and W. C. Fields.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 2 -- Last September, Carl Erskine scored his twentieth victory in the pennant-clinching game at Milwaukee. Today, the little Dodger ace was belted around for eleven hits and seven runs in three innings and the Braves went on to crush the Brooks, 17 -- 2, at Rickwood Field.
PARIS, April 2 -- The French Government protested today to India against measures taken to prevent French authorities from moving from one section of Pondicherry to another.

EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., April 2 -- New aircraft armaments and the complex instrumentation ranges and varied equipment to test them were demonstrated here today at the dedication of the Andrews Engineering Building.

Mayor Wagner's first executive budget calls for city expenditures of $1,639,388,325 in fiscal year 1954-55, starting July 1, an increase of $99,079,170 over the current year. This means that it will cost about $205 for every man, woman and child in this city of 8,000,000 inhabitants to operate the New York government.
ALBANY, April 2 -- Two bills that would have put the "rules of the road" provisions of the Uniform Motor Vehicle Code into effect in New York State next Jan. 1 were vetoed today by Governor Dewey.

LONDON, April 2 (UP) -- The Cambridge eight-oared crew, which will outweigh its Oxford rival by three pounds per man, hopes for quiet water tomorrow when the universities stage their 100th rowing classic on the Thames River.

In planning a room for a pre-school child, parents might find helpful some of the methods used for equipping nursery schools. Characterized by simplicity and practicality, these methods are as useful, to some degree, with a single child as with fifty-five, according to two experts in the nursery school field.

Under pressure from federal and state agencies the leadership of the old International Longshoremen's Association yesterday called a halt to its strike of the piers. The leaders promise that I. L. A. longshoremen will report for work at 8 o'clock this morning.
DETROIT, April 2 (AP) -- The Budd Company will build the bodies for Ford's new Thunderbird model, soon to go into production.

LA CANADA, Calif. GARDENERS and people in general along the Pacific Coast are as enthusiastic about camellias as anyone in the Deep South. Hybridizers are busy here, too, and development of varieties to bloom in colder regions is an absorbing topic.
CAMDEN, S. C., April 3 (AP) -- Repose won the twentieth Carolina Cup steeplechase today by a neck.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Prune rose bushes as soon as danger of killing frost is past. Cut off winterkilled canes and any broken portions on all kinds. Shrub roses and floribundas will need little more except trimming for shapeliness. Remove old canes at ground level and cut back extra-long ones on climbers.
Your article in The Times on "Transition Sculpture," did not get down to the hard facts of life -- who buys?

THE theme of the noble savage exposed to the slings and arrows of civilization is not exactly a new one, but Benjamin Subercaseaux, the Chilean writer, has given it a new twist. His four protagonists -- natives of Tierra del Fuego -- are not corrupted by being transplanted to the London of the Eighteen Thirties for a very good reason: they are already corrupt.

The United States stakes in an often suspicious Asia ranges from the immediate goal of stopping communism to eventual liberation of Asian peoples from hunger and illiteracy, panelists of The New York Times Forum held last night.
New rocket racks mounted beneath fuselages are giving greater take-off power to Boeing B-47 Stratojets built for the Air Force Strategic Air Command, the Boeing Airplane Company announced yesterday.

H.V. KALTENBORN has a brain with what might be called a built-in stop watch. This proves to be handy on his television program, "It Seems Like Yesterday." The dean of commentators can take a one, two or three-minute cue from a director and speak spontaneously for his alloted time on a major news topic without once glancing at a clock.

Fourteen years of service and growth have brought the Pennsylvania Turnpike to a point of junction with the vast system of post-war toll expressways that is fanning out over New Jersey, New York and New England.

BRITAIN'S most popular film actor has his own theory about the heart of the matter. "I've been lucky enough to have three or four good stories in a row," said Jack Hawkins, referring to the latest annual poll of his country's theatre exhibitors.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Congressional leaders received from the nation's military chief today a report on the crisis in Indo-China.

ANYONE compiling a Who's Who of Hollywood will probably end up entitling it Who's Zoo. Ever since Mack Sennett sent the Keystone Cops on their first hilarious chase, the movie capital has been going to the dogs -- and other animals.

The seventeenth annual Three Choir Festival under the auspices of Congregation Emanu-El came to a close yesterday. Following custom, the last of the three programs was integrated with the regular morning Sabbath service at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Voters across the country will elect thirty - four Governors, thirty-five United States Senators and a new House of Representatives of 435 members this year. All states but Kentucky, Louisiana. Mississippi and Virginia will elect all or part of their State Legislatures.

For nearly a month a savage battle has been raging in a remote corner of Indo-China -- a battle whose stakes far exceed the importance of the position being fought over. The position is the French bastion at Dienbienphu, 180 miles northwest of Hanoi in a barren valley, known as the Vietnam "dust bowl."

International trade in wheat appears to be well on its way back to the low level of the immediate pre-war period. With the exporting nations geared to record production, the decline in the international movement of the grain has resulted in burdensome surpluses, especially in the United States and Canada, the two leading wheat exporting nations.

Pending before Congress at this time are ten so-called "termination" bills, which would remove all special federal protection from more than 60,000 American Indians in a dozen states (including New York) and, by giving them a theoretically "equal" status with other citizens, would throw them on the tender mercies of a civilization that every lesson of history shows has used them ill.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 3 (AP) -- Purdue track stars set two records in the seventh annual Southern Relays today, and a Louisiana Tech field man tied another.

HUMOR is an elusive matter, whether it deals with character, situation or presentation. It is also a rare commodity. For anyone to take a teenage boy and follow him and his family, particularly his father, through the years of prep school, and do it all with abounding good humor is probably an impossible assignment.

JERUSALEM, April 3 -- The Arab Bank lost a final appeal in the British high courts Thursday in an attempt to recover 582,000 Jordanian ($1,600,000) frozen by Israeli law in the British-owned Barclays Bank.
CAIRO, April 3 -- The military rulers of Egypt were reported tonight to be preparing a purge of their own ranks and of press elements hostile to the military regime.

The annual spring party for members of the Wednesday Mayfair Dancing Classes will be held on Wednesday afternoon in the ballroom of the Cosmopolitan Club. The classes are held under the direction of Miss Ethel Clarke and Mrs. Louise Irwin. They are the outgrowth of the Adeline King Robinson Dancing Classes, well known to several generations in New York.

MADISONVILLE, Tenn., April 3 -- Representative Pat Sutton of Lawrenceburg, opening his campaign for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate, today accused Senator Estes Kefauver of "coddling" Communists.

" THE LAST NOTHC," an original drama by Frank J. Gilroy, was presented last Tuesday on the United States Steel program over the A. B. C. network. It was very possibly the finest Western play yet done by "live" television -- an excellent production with sustained mood, suspense and characterization.
MANILA, March 22 -- The Philippine Government is spending $1,000,000 to rid soil-rich Mindanao Island of rats and check a reversal of a Filipino migration to the area.
PINE BLUFF, Ark., April 3 (AP) -- Junius Kellogg, Harlem Globetrotter and former Manhattan College basketball star, is in a critical condition here from injuries suffered in a car wreck.

THIS winningly reasonable book, with its suggestive title, is offered by Albert Guerard in the twilight of his academic life; he is now retired from his long-held chair of General and Comparative Literature at Stanford University and from his years at Brandeis, a period which he has likened to Indian Summer.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 3 (UP) -- Two Louisiana State University students who began their evening with a nightclub tour in a state ambulance wound it up early today by "borrowing" a plane and crashing into a house.
Paraplegic war veterans from countries all over the world will be brought together this summer in an international "wheelchair Olympics" to be held abroad.

THE steady growth of commercial aviation in the continental United States, Puerto Rico, Hawaii and Alaska is reflected in recent reports by Civil Aeronautics Administration control-tower operators for 1953.
The founder of American Reform Judaism -- the late Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise -- was honored yesterday at a special Sabbath service in Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

A RADICALLY new Leica camera, the first model of which was introduced in 1924 and originated the 35- mm miniature type, was demonstrated here last week by E. Leitz, Inc., the importers. The most imitated camera in the world and probably the best known, the Leica design has gone through a number of changes in the last thirty years, but never on the broad scale of the latest model.
LONDON, April 3 (Reuters) -- Results of today's British soccer and rugby games:

Hanson Baldwin in "The 'Caine Mutiny' Issue," (March 21), examines the question of obedience to intolerable authority as presented in Herman Wouk's play and in such a real-life case as that of Col. Frank Schwable, who falsely testified to germ warfare under Communist torture.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 3 -- Sales figures of department stores made a poor showing with a year ago, the week preceding Easter, and declines ranged from 10 to 20 per cent. Special promotions timed for the reductions in excise taxes met with only mediocre success.

The New Look is now obsolete. Its theory appeared to be that we would decide whether to meet a local aggression by the Communists with conventional armaments applied at the local level or by retaliation against Russia itself through atomic bombing.

IT is a far cry from the Indian-shot lily of pioneer days to the modern cannas for gardens of today, yet both had the same origin. In fact the canna is so old and has been so widely distributed that its origins and parentage are matters for conjecture.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The long-awaited investigation by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's subcommittee of his controversy with the Army is now being arranged in an atmosphere of partisan tenseness.
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, the Democratic candidate for President in 1952, is again a candidate for office and "is desperately seeking publicity," Leonard W. Hall asserted today.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Further questioning of Samuel P. Sears, its special counsel for the much-delayed investigation of the McCarthy-Army controversy, was projected today by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.

THE mad pace at which new insecticides and fungicides have appeared on the market appears finally to have dwindled to a slow methodical crawl. Recent, more stringent regulations concerning the labeling of new products are partly responsible for this.
Florida, the land of sunshine and hurricanes, is experiencing one of the biggest booms in utility construction in its history.

EL PASO, Tex., April 3 -- A new bid for foreign trade will be made by this largest city on the Mexican border through the erection of a $650,000 international merchandise mart. Occupants will be agents of United States and Mexican and other Latin- American companies. The mart is expected to be completed in June.
Free discussion of moral, social and religious ideas is dangerous because there is no possibility of agreement, Prof. Gilbert Highet of Columbia University declared yesterday.

PARIS, April 3 (AP) -- A French jet fighter plane crashed during a demonstration today and parts of the exploding craft landed about fifty yards from Defense Minister Rene Pleven and his guest, Duncan Sandys, British Minister of Supply.

CARROLLTON, Ga., April 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias soared to a 76 today in the second round of the Carrollton women's open golf tournament, but clung to a one-stroke lead with a total of 146.
DETROIT, April 3 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers are basing their planning on a conviction that the competitive era will be a prolonged one.
A legion of condemned cars is at large in the streets.
It is fitting that this year's theme for World Health Day, which will be observed on Wednesday, is "The Nurse -- Pioneer of Health."
BUENOS AIRES, April 3 -- With nation-wide elections only three weeks distant, President Juan D. Peron has found himself uncomfortably seated on the horns of a critical wage price dilemma.

TODAY'S column continues the discussion begun last week of the questions arising from the rapid growth of mass culture. There is more I want to say about the distribution and reading of books as they are being affected by this growth, and about the parallel changes which are taking place in our attitude toward the fine arts.
John K. Galbraith's article, "Perils of the Big Build-Up" (March 7) which dealt with the ways in which a public figure can be turned into a "superhuman myth" was much to the point.

Soviet diplomatic maneuvering aimed at dividing and weakening the Western world reached a new high point last week with the opening of what may well be the greatest of all "peace offensives." Last Wednesday's Soviet note offering to join NATO was presumably intended by the Kremlin to be a diplomatic hydrogen bomb.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., April 3 -- A new Federal criminal inquiry into New Mexico's much-discussed 1952 Senatorial election is under way.

Among the sailing events scheduled for next summer by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, L. I., is a series of trials to qualify a six-meter yacht for the One Ton Cup. The trials are listed for May 29 to 31. The cup competition will take place on Switzerland's Lake Geneva starting July 25.
TROY, N. Y. LAST winter, in the process of teaching a thirteen-week course in Spanish, I proved for myself the superiority of a direct conversational method of teaching languages by television.

THE sensitivity, knowledge and imagination of a keen observer are obvious in this delineation of an enfant terrible -- a youthful actor-director whose meteor-like orbit touches the strawhat circuit, Broadway and Hollywood, and singes varied citizens in these special societies.

Maj. Gen. Hermann J. W. von Witzleben has called my attention to the fact that the correct name of the German organization which has been studying the history of the Hitler era is The European Publication, of which he is the president.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 3 -- Hopes for establishment of President Eisenhower's proposed world atomic-pool-for-peace appeared to be uppermost in the thoughts of people in this area this week.

CONSUMERS are getting a new tax deal. The cut in excise levies, approved by the President on Thursday, was the most important action of the Republican Administration thus far toward halting the business recession. The reduction reflects years of insistence by trade groups that they had been subjected to discrimination and that the high excises had been arbitrarily imposed.

TELEVISION and radio, with President Eisenhower and other national figures taking part, will usher in the first stamp in the nation's first definitive series in sixteen years. On Thursday the Post Office Department and the State Department will join in ceremonies to be sent over nation-wide networks.

CONFIDENTIAL reports trickling in from the Continent, where a big international tournament has just ended at the Sporting Club (erstwhile roulette headquarters of the world) at Monte Carlo, indicate that the United States sent abroad its best goodwill ambassadors in years in the persons of Howard Schenken, Samuel M. Stayman and George Rapee of New York and John R. Crawford and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. -- Within a few weeks a new kind of travelers' coupons will be turning up in the United States and abroad, bearing the name of UNESCO -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- One of the great controversies in the United States today whirls about the figure of a burly, dark-haired man -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy -- and the effects of his one-man method of searching for Communists in the Government, the Army and industry.

THAT old master of the slick, swift, entertaining yarn is at it again in this, his thirty-ninth novel. The time is the Eighteen Seventies; the place is gaudy, lavish San Francisco; the heroine is young and, despite her pannier, beautiful; the hero is, of course, masculine, witty and, in the mode of all good heroes, in the nick of time when it counts.

BOSTON, April 3 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy said today that he had asked the Army for information on six of its personnel "with known Communist records" the day before the case of Pvt. G. David Schine became public.

A careful reading of both my article on the "New Look" world policy -- "A Plea for Another Great Debate" (Feb. 28) -- and Senator Knowland's answering article, "The 'Instant Retaliation' Policy Defended" (March 21), demonstrates how many of my questions were left unanswered or only partly answered.

LONDON, April 3 -- Renewed attacks by left-wing leaders and concern among Government officials and some Conservative Politicians have added to the strain imposed on British-American relations in this capital.

Good news for sufferers of "heart trouble" came yesterday from Chicago, Ill., where the American Heart Association is discussing chemical cardiology. Contrary to a view widely held, attacks do not usually mean early or sudden death.

CLEVELAND, April 3 -- Steel production in the Cleveland-Lorain district skidded to 57 per cent of capacity this week as plants continued cutbacks. This rate is the lowest for a normal week since 1948. Reflecting curtailed steel mill operations, ore consumption declined to 5,786,725 tons in February.

Mrs. Arthur G. Rouse, committee chairman for the annual card party of the Service Club of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, will give a luncheon for her aides on Wednesday in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

UP in Ithaca, N. Y., this afternoon -- if nothing disturbs the expected tenor of their day -- two families, one with three youngsters and one with four, will spend two active hours at what, for present brevity, we'll call "creative art."

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., April 3 (AP) -- Penn State repeated as national collegiate gymnastics champion tonight, overwhelming twenty-four schools with 137 points. Jean Cronstedt of the Nittany Lions won four individual titles.

REPULSIVE in appearance, reprehensible in his business practices, Mr. Booker, of Booker and Wilmhurst, turns up missing one night (his wife is frantic in a well-bred way) and is later found in, of all places, a new and practically indestructible safe he had just bought and had installed in his office.
PARIS, April 3 -- French news dispatches said tonight that reinforcements had landed at beleaguered Dienbienphu, in Indo-China, the first in a week. The men were parachuted in.

The Turtle Bay Music School at 244 East Fifty-second Street will be the beneficiary of the Tuesday evening performance of "The Golden Apple" at the new Phoenix Theatre, Second Avenue and Twelfth Street.

IT seems to be the prevailing opinion among local drama critics that this season has been a successful one. To a certain extent this may be true; but for one awaiting, somewhat pessimistically, the resurgence of an American drama, the year has been almost barren of hope.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- The big manufacturing, business and residential area of Chicago's Far South Side, the Calumet industrial area, will show an increase in income after midyear, a conference of area bankers concluded.

EARLY in his opening essay in "The Collier's Book of Hunting and Fishing," Ray Camp states his main proposition: "Almost any angler, public opinion to the contrary, has more brains than a trout. Therefore, it is reasonable to assume that he can outwit the fish."
WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The nation's first regular stamp with a religious sentiment will be introduced here next week.

ECUADOR'S Philatelic Agency director, Agustin Vanegas P., sends word that on the 30th of April a series will be issued honoring the United Nations. Seven designs with themes featuring allegories symbolizing the world organization's aims and ideals will be assigned to the following: Postage 3-centavos olive, 4c light green, 5c emerald, 15c dark green, 1-sucre blue-green; and airmail 3c magenta, 4c orange, c red, 30c rose, 2s carmine, 3s brown-orange, 5s light red.
TRENTON, April 3 -- Arnold Constable's fifth branch store will open here in October. The streamlined, modernistic structure will cover a full block and provide an indoor parking area for 3,000 cars.
