CLINTON, N. J., April 3 -- Builder, 2-year-old white and lemon ticked pointer owned by Dr. H. E. Longsdorf of Mount Holly, N. J., and handled by Paul Walker of Farmington, N. C., won the open derby stake today at the annual spring meet of the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club.
QUEBEC, March 30 -- A significant change in emphasis has taken place in the thinking of French Canadians about their language.

City College's track and field team defeated Fairleigh DIckin. son of Rutherford. T. J., 87 to 55s yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. The Beavers captured eleveax of sixteen first places, lnc2uding eight out of nine in the track events.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Congress' normal pattern consists of loafing along for half the session without seeming to accomplish anything. Then, as if by some pre-arranged signal that cannot be seen or heard by the outsider, legislative wheels suddenly begin to whir.

WRITTEN by a distinguished teacher and critic, and containing telling strictures against the stupidities of a widely prevalent deterministic orthodoxy in modern culture, this volume would be memorable in any event.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- United States economic and technical aid in Indo-China will in the future crowd the front lines. It will make itself felt in the large twilight areas that are frequently in the hands of the Government of Vietnam by day and of the Communist-led Vietminh by night.
New York banks are giving renewed attention to the employe "salary deposit account" plan since its recent adoption by the First National Bank of Boston.
BUFFALO, April 3 (AP) -- Mayor Wagner of New York declared today that "the highest plurality ever delivered to Democratic candidates in a state-election" would be produced in his home city next fall.

A 19-year-old Harlem youth with a desire for "good living" was arrested yesterday morning for burglary. He admitted to twenty-five to thirty thefts in apartments on the upper East Side. The police estimated the loot at $50,000.

ON page ten of Gene Fowler's "Minutes of the Last Meeting," W. C. Fields exclaims: "I still think he is a bum." Not Mr. Fowler, of course. Uncle Claude, the triple-martini buffoon, loved Mr. Fowler, as Mr. Fowler has always loved the grand vagrants with whom he has caroused.

THE publishing industry in China has undergone a house cleaning, Communist style. Loose ends have been tidied up; lines of authority have been clearly drawn. The new neatness has been achieved principally by the amalgamation of private publishing concerns into state-owned or joint state- private organizations.
ROBERT ANTHONY EDEN is preparing to take over a job which, under the present circumstances, is the most difficult in the world.

WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE, whose clowns were the worst imaginable, said: "It is meat and drink to me to see a clown." Shakespeare, who could probably do everything else in the writing business, and did so, could not write a clown.

EARLY in 1945 ex-Lieut. Comdr. J. Bryan III, U. S. N. R. (now Colonel, U. S. A. F. R.), went to sea in the U. S. S. Yorktown, a fabulously successful and lucky aircraft carrier. He rode the ship for three months and during this time watched United States naval forces crack the vertebrae of Japanese power.

SINGAPORE, April 3 -- The Malayan Communist party has been driven deep into the jungle, and that is where the final phase of the anti-Communist guerrilla campaign will be fought, according to the Malayan commander.
Companion bills now before Congress, which put the credit of the Government behind loans for private ship construction, are expected to supply "just the boost the shipbuilding industry needs."

ATLANTA, April 3 -- Earnings of member banks in the Sixth Federal Reserve District reached $224,000,000 in 1953, the highest level in the history of this area's banking operations, according to the annual report this week by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 3 -- Lawns in this part of the country do not need water, except in extended dry periods, according to Ralph E. Engel, Rutgers University specialist in turf management. In the dry periods, he said, a thorough weekly watering is enough.

COLUMBIA, S. C., April 3 (UP) -- The Senators exploded with homers by Johnny Schmitz and Roy Sievers and a three-run double by Tom Umphlett to overcome a five-run deficit and beat the Redlegs, 12 -- 7, today before 2,425 fans.
SAN MATEO, Calif., April 3 (UP) -- The Kentucky Derby nominee, Determine, won a stirring stretch duel from Fault Free as he captured the $15,000 added Peter Clark Handicap at Bay Meadows.

Persons who recover from an initial heart attack have a good chance of living for many years, Metropolitan Life Insurance Company statisticians said yesterday. They based this statement on a study of survivorship among a group of men insured as standard risks who became disabled by heart disease, but recovered sufficiently to be considered able to return to work.

A GARDEN built around yellow-flowering shrubs, trees, bulbs and perennials can be a delight to the eye from early spring, into late May. And since perhaps no color is as cheerful after the long dull winter days, most home owners may want to devote at least a portion of their landscaping scheme to a succession of yellow spring blooms.

The Texas International Sulphur Company began the first commercial production of sulphur on the Pacific Coast last week at its new processing plant near San Felipe, Lower California, Mexico. The plant is about 125 miles south of the United States border.

PEOPLE spiral interestingly downward, especially under pressure. Personal despair can be counted upon to produce sexual deviations, experiments with alcohol, or, at the very least, some flouting of society And the alert but compassionate novelist ought to be able to use quite a lot of such ripe material.
DENVER, April 3 -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson's decision to retire at the end of his present term has left Colorado politics in a scramble.

A twenty-eight-event tournament season for the Westchester division of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association was released yesterday by Herman Barron of Fenway, Westchester P. G. A. president.
Local offices of steamship companies have been getting out refunds to passengers who benefit from the drop in transportation taxes.

Twenty-seven advertising executives from newspapers in seventeen states will take part in a one-week seminar on classified advertising beginning tomorrow at the American Press Institute of Columbia University.

Supported by Dr. A. Meyer-Albich, Professor of Natural Philosophy at the University of Hamburg, Germany, and former executive director of the Tropical Research Institute of the University of El Salvador, Dr. E. Leppik of Augustana College, Sioux Falls, S. D., announces his discovery of what seems to be a sense of numbers in pollinating insects.

LE HAVRE, France, April 3 (AP) -- Marshal Alphonse - Pierre Juin, ousted from his French military duties, said today he would leave his North Atlantic Treaty Organization assignment only if he was certain that a Frenchman was named to replace him.

ALTHOUGH it isn't quite up to its predecessor, this volume of fourteen original science fiction stories is excellent. Aficionados will recognize its authors' names: Bixby, Blish, Budrys, Clement, Kornbluth, Del Rey and Williamson, to name a few.

NORTH CONWAY, N. H., April 3 -- Tom Corcoran of Dartmouth captured the individual honors in the Harvard Bromley slalom today, but Middlebury College nosed out the Big Green for the team honors, 655.7 to 656.9.

Luther A. Huston's article on the current exodus of "one-year men" from the Government in The Times of March 28 highlights a problem which is not peculiar to this Administration. It has long been true that qualified men could earn more in private industry than in Government service.

The National Labor Relations Board's order to the old International Longshoremen's Association to end its crippling New York strike or forfeit its right to take part in a new waterfront election focused attention last week on the broad powers vested in the board by the Taft-Hartley Act.

Another square with Horowitz and Rubinstein on the brain would like to commend Howard Taubman for his article, "Liberace -- a Square Looks at a Hotshot" (March 14). If is sad to see that "hotshot" can command so large an audience for mutilated music.

FROM Wednesday through next Sunday, Manhattanites may see a preview of spring and summer to be staged with 10,000 wild plants, trees and shrubs in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Park Avenue at Fiftieth Street.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 3 -- The bureau in the Nationalist party that keeps alive the original doctrine of apartheid has warned against the compromise that has developed here on race separation.

THIS second collection of Barbara Howes' work is beautifully printed by The Caliban Press, and the poems deserve such treatment. She says that To be Ascetic for life's sake, Honest and passionate, Is rare.
The Government announced yesterday that it would like somebody to buy some of its offshore oil as well as several thousand tons of offshore sugar and general cargo.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 3 -- A record-breaking performance by Ford Konno of Hawaii, on the way to winning the 440-yard free-style, featured the national Amateur Athletic Union's swimming championships tonight.
A liberal arts graduate program in history leading to a Master of Arts degree will be reinstated at Hunter College in September, Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, announced yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 3 -- A nine-man Republican Senatorial primary race from which the State's Republican Governor, William G. Stratton, is remaining aloof is a picture of confusion to voters in Illinois.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP) -- Cisco Andrade of Los Angeles, undefeated in about two years of professional fighting, won a unanimous decision from Percy Bassett of Philadelphia, the interim featherweight champion, in a ten-round nontitle fight tonight. Bassett weighed 129 1/2, Andrade 133.

UNDOUBTEDLY, a major irony of the current Broadway season is the fact that although it has been one of the most successful in years, both from the artistic as well as the financial standpoints, three theatres are passing from the fold.

WASHINGTON, April 3 (UP) -- The Fish and Wildlife Service reported today that the United States fishing industry was in a "precarious position" but could be helped a lot if the service had more money to spend.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 -- Contract awards on engine ring projects in the eleven Western states totaled $24,192,837 last week, the Daily Construction Service reported yesterday. This brought the total for the year to date to $453,366,547, compared with $1,025,078,767 for the same period last year.

Retailers' estimates of business last week varied widely. Confused by the unusually-timed pre-Easter promotions in certain stores and the lifting of excise taxes on some items, their guesses on the week's activities varied from unchanged to 10 per cent below last year's dollar volume.
BOSTON, April 3 (AP) -- The first arrest of a Communist under a 1951 Massachusetts statute outlawing subversive organizations was made today.
Columbia University will continue the observance of its 200th anniversary with several commemorative events during its fifty-fifth summer session, which begins July 6.
WAYS and means to reduce motor vehicle accidents on the highways will have top billing at the twenty-fourth annual Safety Convention and Exposition opening tomorrow at the Statler Hotel.

Merchant marine executives long accustomed to hearing "sweet talk" from top-ranking Government shipping authorities were surprised recently by Louis S. Rothschild, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board.
DES MOINES, Iowa, April 3 -- Farmers and ranchers in the Missouri Basin states had their attention fixed this week on the most important item in their economic lives -- the weather.

Yesterday the longest and costliest dock strike in the Port of New York's history came to its end. The walk-out had lasted twenty-nine days. Dockers lost an estimated $8,700,000 in wages. Shipping companies lost $29,000,000. Exporters and importers lost more than $25,000,000.

HONG KONG, April 3 -- Doubtful as they have been about how far the United States might go at Geneva, the Chinese Nationalists on Formosa and the pro-Nationalist Chinese here were obviously encouraged by Secretary of State Dulles' speech.
For the second consecutive year tradition was upset yesterday when Barnard College freshmen defeated the sophomores in the annual Greek Games by a score of 51.5 to 48.5.

WHEN Vice President Nixon stood up before the television cameras a few weeks ago to reassure the nation about -- among other things -- the "New Look" in our foreign policy, he offered as a sort of guarantee of its merit the fact that it had originated in the National Security Council.
ONE of the season's more delightful jacket blurbs describes the setting of Luella Creighton's new novel as "real as a ham sandwich, and as frightening as a hangman's noose."

AUSTIN, Tex., April 3 (UP) -- Wes Santee of Kansas, showing unbeatble form, anchored the Jayhawkers to repeat crowns today in the two-mile and four-mile relays of the twenty-seventh annual Texas Relays.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 3 -- Adlai E. Stevenson urged today that any Government plans to inform the American people on the "implications" of the hydrogen bomb give consideration to the special problems confronting the Allies.

Every year, on the thirteenth day of April, I read with interest an editorial in your great paper on the subject of Thomas Jefferson's birthday. He was one of the greatest of the great Virginians, and well deserves all of the tributes that can he paid him.

CONCERNED primarily with attacking the late Gen. Draja Mihailovich, Herbert Mitgang's review of "Eight Bailed Out" not only distorts historical fact but so misrepresents the eyewitness testimony offered by Major James Inks' remarkable diary that, as its editor, I feel compelled to comment.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 -- The immediate reaction on the West Coast to the H-bomb was somewhat restrained, although there was unquestionably an undercurrent of apprehension.

Just how far retailers can go in letting customers help themselves remains unanswered for many types of stores. Self-service, the subject of hot debate in retail circles, has proven itself, however, in food supermarkets, and is now proving itself in limited-price variety stores.
Why the work of present-day artists does not reach a wider audience is one of the questions that a panel of artists will attempt to answer on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- The recession is not over yet. In recent days, there have been proclamations to the contrary from some non-Government economists and some business men. The official folk here wish they could join the celebration.
Peace -- and thousands of longshoremen -- returned to the docks of the strike-free Port of New York yesterday.

NEWARK, April 3 -- Kenneth Perry of Bound Brook was named today as campaign manager for Clifford P. Case, Republican candidate in New Jersey for United States Senator. The appointment was announced jointly by Mr. Case and Samuel L. Bodine, Republican State Chairman.

IN THE past few years there has been widespread wailing over the decline in the study of stringed instruments in this country -- and with good reason. Here is a story of a few determined people who have been doing something about it in, of all places, the State of Mississippi.

IF the reader turns to page 24, he will see a review of a novel called "The Image and the Search," by Walter Baxter. The book was brought out in England by Heineman. E. M. Forster praised the novel as "serious and beautifuL."
PRINCETON, N. J., April 3 -- Herb Bittlingmaier of N. Y. U. struck out eleven and allowed only six hits today as the Violets defeated Princeton, 4 -- 3, in a ten-inning contest at University Field.

HOWARD HUGHES was well on the way last week toward becoming the only individual who can claim sole ownership of a major Hollywood motion picture company, with distribution offices spread around the world, On Wednesday, in Wilmington, Del., the industrialist turned over to officers of the R. K. O. Radio Pictures Corporation a check in the amount of $23,489,478 to conclude his purchase of all the company's assets.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 3 -- The West called today for new United Nations talks on disarmament and atomic energy control.

ROMANTICISM is a house of many mansions between which there are not necessarily any communicating doors. Two of these separate establishments are inhabited by artists exhibiting this week, one by Enrico d'Assia, at Carstairs, whose romanticism consists of working back in time to a glamorous past that never really existed; the other by Lyonel Feininger; at Curt Valentins, whose genial talents idealize the world about us.

TRENTON, April 3 -- An attempt to halt the Port of New York Authority's vast program for new bridges and tunnels pending a study of the rapid transit needs of the metropolitan area will be the subject of a public hearing here next week.

AN operatic rarity is Mozart's one-acter, Bastien und Bastienne, occasionally seen hereabouts in performance by the Vienna Choir Boys and similar groups. Columbia now offers a one-disk recording made in Vienna, with Else Hollweg as Bastienne, Waldemar Kmentt as Bastien and Walter Berry as Colas.

NEW DELHI, India, April 3 -- Perhaps under the impact of the hydrogen bomb, numerous molders of Indian public opinion have suddenly become skeptical of the Soviet Union's political maneuvers. Formerly they tended to accept Moscow's good faith in everything and always to criticize Western, particularly American, "instransigence."

VIENTIANE, the administrative capital of Laos, is a quiet little French-style town which seems, like the traditional European resident of the country, to be going pleasantly to seed. It basks under a soft blue sky. No one bustles. Laotians saunter along the one main street (paved, courtesy of American economic aid).
The Salvation Army's family service bureaus helped more than 2,000 New York families last year, Brig. Ruth Kimball, secretary of the bureaus, reported yesterday.

MANY a greenhouse gardener has lost his heart to vanda orchids -- and with good reason. The flowers are large and exotically colored. They are heavy in texture, and may stay fresh for two or three months.

WEEK-TO-WEEK care of a lawn has as much to do with its quality and appearance as the elaborate ritual of feeding, weeding and seeding that opens the spring season. Without a proper routine throughout the summer, the hard work put into renovation may quickly come to naught.

TEN years ago Victor White published "Peter Domanig: Morning in Vienna," a long novel about the tribulations and triumphs of a fatherless boy in Austria in the years before and during World War I. Now he has published the first of three volumes with the collective title, "Peter Domanig in America." "Steel" brings Peter to the United States in the autumn of 1919, when he is 17 years old.

AS one of the founders and editors of the lively Paris Review, Peter Matthiessen has already distinguished himself among the youngest literary generation. Now with his first novel, "Race Rock," he assumes immediate place as a writer of disciplined craft, perception, imaginative vigor and serious temperament.
PARIS, April 3 -- The North Atlantic Treaty, born from the shock of the Berlin blockade and given sinews by the attack on South Korea, is five years old tomorrow.

Eleven years and four months ago -- on Dec. 2, 1942 -- a group of physicists stood tensely watching a massive structure set in a squash court at Stagg Field in Chicago. The structure was the world's first uranium pile. A signal was given. Instruments clicked, faster and faster. In a few moments the physicists knew from the clicking that inside the pile they had fashioned the first self-sustaining nuclear reaction.
BALTIMORE, April 3 (AP) -- Eddie and David Choong of Malaya gained the men's singles final in the Maryland invitation badminton tournament by beating India's T. N. Seth and Nandu Natekar tonight.
Economic conditions and public opinion during the next few months are expected to play a decisive part in determining the fate of the newly proposed Eisenhower program on foreign economic policy.
The worker who is unhappy with his job may soon find that he has little company.

I NOTE that Henry F. Graff says in his review of "The Case of Mrs. Surratt" by Guy W. Moore: "His footnotes show great familiarity with the sources -- so great that he is able to call the trial record editor, Benjamin Perley Poore, Ben." In the index to the Moore book I find: "Poore, Ben

BARCELONA, Spain, April 3 -- Moscow's release of 285 Spaniards from concentration camps was held here to be a propaganda maneuver to rally opposition in this country against military collaboration with the United States.

IN the very early days, according to the Nagas who live on the slopes of the Himalayas, God fashioned man out of a kind of bread, popped him in the oven and baked him. But God was in a hurry and quickly removed him from the oven: he was white and doughy -- this was the first white man.

BOISE, Idaho, April 3 (AP) -- Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said tonight that the "sterile, standstill, status quo philosophy" of the Republican Administration "is threatening our economic prosperity today."

SOME conducted tours of European cities are good; others are indifferently operated. The majority take you for a three or four-hour bus tour in the morning and a similar one in the afternoon, visiting perhaps a total of ten major sights for an average cost of $4-$6 plus a tip for the conductor and sometimes added admission charges.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- Authorities said today that the United States had acted with full confidence that Britain and France would concur in brushing aside the Soviet Union's proposals for a European security pact and its suggestion of Communist membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
BERLIN, March 31 -- The United States, in conjunction with West Germany, has gone into business in Berlin in a novel form of foreign aid known as equity financing.
Tax savings of more than $50,000,000 a year are expected to expand the purchasing power of consumers in this area under the Federal excise cuts that went into effect last Thursday.
CHICAGO, April 3 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared here tonight that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had "set out to create a reign of terror in America and, in part, he has succeeded."

There was a new Witch at yesterday's matinee performance of Humperdinck's "Hansel and Gretel" at the City Center. She was Anna Russell, best known to local aficionados as a concert comedienne -- one who sticks little pins and needles into the Muse of Music.

Here is a sketch of what I saw in a dream just after reading "A New Debate in Old Venice" (March 21). I hope you will like my sketch. It would suggest that Frank Lloyd Wright's project for a palazina to be built on the Grand Canal in Venice is not, as Bernard Berenson contends, "out of proportion, out of style, out of harmony with the monumental buildings which line that unique waterway."]

FROM this observer's viewpoint, the 1953 Academy awards for excellence in motion picture making were very well bestowed, on the whole. Outside of one woeful injustice -- the handing of the prize for the best feature-length documentary to Walt Disney's "The Living Desert" instead of to the British-made "The Conquest of Everest" or even "A Queen Is Crowned" -- no staggering faux pas were committed, as there have sometimes been in previous years.

A midnight drive along the tracks of the Long Island Rail Road in Long Island City resulted last night in serious injuries for a 25-year-old man when the Diesel locomotive of a freight train hit the car in which he rode with three companions.

ONE of the wonders of the modern gardening era is the prodigious array of power lawn mowers. Innumerable makes and sizes of reel and rotary types together with sickle bar machines for rough cutting can be found in garden and golf course supply houses.

ALTHOUGH he already has made known his intentions to invade the cinema's precincts with an adaptation of Davis Grubb's first novel, "The Night of the Hunter," producer Paul Gregory has plans for more than just one movie, he revealed last week.

LONDON, March 28 -- Britain's motorists envy the straight high-speed roads of other lands -- the poplar-lined Roman ways of France, the German Autobahn, the Italian Autostrada -- but most particularly, the fabulous New Jersey Turnpike.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, B. W. I., April 3 -- The official West Indies economic body is to meet here Monday to plan a formal protest against a new United States agreement to sell subsidized citrus fruits to Britain for sterling.

PADUCAH, Ky., March 31 -- The former Vice President of the United States was basking in the warmth of the wood fire on the hearth. The radio had just brought the news that he had acquired a new title.

THE Atlantic Coast Line Railroad on May 1 will enter the field of package tours to Miami Beach and other Florida resorts, offering a full range of trips from a low of $91.86 for a one-week holiday to a high of $108.86, plus $7.92 Federal tax on the railroad coach fare.

I can't resist -- after the flood of praise for the box-office good Samaritans -- telling you of my experiences. My husband is totally blind, has a Seeing-Eye dog, and consequently prefers -- for other people's convenience -- aisle seats in the theatre.

CACHING straws in the wind is one of the major pursuits of a novelist (even when he happens to be a minor novelist like Geoffrey Harmer, the narrator of this tale), and the soft sea air of the little West of Ireland town of Bunmeara was full of straws. There were sufficient to make bricks for a large, rambling old house, peopled with fictitious figures, with ghostly peacocks screaming on the lawn.

Even people who like all kinds of birds seem to merely tolerate grackles after they have seen the first dozen or so in early spring. Just looking at a grackle, this seems rather strange, for a grackle is a large, graceful black bird with a beautiful iridescent sheen on its feathers.

EVERY big city throughout the world has its "Broadway" -- its magic center of theatrical life, of actors and audiences, of comedies and tragedies, of hits and flops. In many ways these Broadways differ from ours -- in the way they look, in the plays they choose to perform, in the manner of their performances.

IT IS a new experience to arrive in a great city and find the walls and kiosks in every neighborhood plastered with big, varicolored posters announcing the world premiere of an opera-oratorio by that Bugbear of bourgeois audiences, Arnold Schoenberg.

They're off at Jamaica again, marking the return of horse racing to the "big apple" -- the major New York tracks. Though the voice of the horse player is heard in the North again, the words are somewhat unintelligible to the uninitiated. Here is a short course in basic horse.

ROME, April 3 -- Premier Mario Scelba declared war on the Italian Communists on March 19 when he announced a reversal of the kid-glove policy followed by his predecessors. This week he fired the first gun in his anti-Communist campaign by fixing April 15 as the date on which all Communist and fellow-traveling parties and organizations will either have to move out of Government-owned buildings or face eviction proceedings.

AS part of that scholarly celebration up on Morningside Heights, there is being published a nineteen-volume series, The Bicentennial History of Columbia University. This series, under the general editorship of Dwight C. Miner, Professor of History, boasts seventeen monographs on the university's schools and colleges and a two-volume over-all history, "Two Centuries of Columbia University."

MANY of the old houses of New York City are taking a new lease on life. The Bureau of Records of the Department of Housing and Buildings of this city reports that 686 old houses were remade into modern dwellings last year -- an amazing jump from the eighty-nine similar conversions recorded in 1951.

WASHINGTON, April 3 -- President Eisenhower's proposals of Government incentives for the continued construction of about 1,000,000 houses a year appeared assured today of Congressional approval in the main.

SHAKESPEARE in "Coriolanus" presents a group of servants talking morosely about the peace between the Romans and the Volscians. "This peace," grumbles one, "is nothing but to rust iron, increase tailors, and breed ballad-makers." A cynical comrade assents.

IN all likelihood, the most persistently wholesome first lady of the stage and screen, as distinguished from all other mere first ladies of the stage and screen, is Miss Shirley Booth, a plump, blonde actress with unexpectedly pretty legs who is pushing 48 with marked unconcern and would like to go on acting until she turned into, of all things, a Laurette Taylor or a Beryl Mercer.

DURING recent years there has been a notable increase in the number of first-class writers who deal with religious subjects on the adult level. C. S. Lewis, Evelyn Waugh, Graham Greene -- these names come quickly to mind -- not to mention an impressive delegation of poets and playwrights.

NEW LONDON, Conn., April 3 (AP) -- Admiral Husband E. Kimmel today challenged the contention of Col. H. A. Toulmin Jr. that he (Kimmel) "cannot escape the guilt" for the heavy Navy losses in the Pearl Harbor attack of 1941.

THE Edward Steichen Photography Fund for the purchase of photographs for the collection of the Museum of Modern Art was announced at the recent dinner given by the trustees in honor of Mr. Steichen's seventy - fifth birthday.

" I WISH I knew what the weather was going to be," was the plaintive comment of one of the Long Island county agents last week when he was asked about spring planting. His sentiment will be repeated by many people during the next few weeks, for weatherwise spring is notoriously erratic.
LONDON, April 3 (AP) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers challenged for the English soccer lead today as they registered a 1-0 victory over injury-riddled West Bromwich Albion.
The Silver Cross Day Nursery will be the beneficiary of a tea and cocktail dance on April 28 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

ON THE OHIO RIVER, April 3 -- As the towboat Allied-Ashland pushed her bulky cluster of eight oil barges around a bend in the Ohio River thirteen miles below Louisville, Capt. Willard White leaned over from his pilot's seat and pressed a button that sent three bellows of the bull horn echoing back from the Indiana shore.
PHILADELPHIA, April 3 -- Abdul Monem Rifai, Jordanian Ambassador to the United States, warned here today that continued United States aid to Israel would cause Arab unrest throughout the Middle East.
LAUREL, Md., April 3 (AP) -- Eugene Constantin Jr.'s Royal Bay Gem returned to his 1953 form to win his first stakes of 1954 today, the Laurel Handicap, over seven other starters.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 3 -- The hullabaloo created by the hydrogen bomb has caused Texans to pause and take stock.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., April 3 -- Twenty-nine fifth-grade pupils at Nishuane School here have an invitation to meet President Eisenhower at the White House on May 7. And they can trace to the saying, the way to a man's heart is through his stomach.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 3 (AP) -- Amphiblen and Go a Bit were the winners of the two divisions of the $10,000 added Fort Lauderdale Handicap today before 15,012 spectators at Gulfstream Park.
The Communist-backed May Day celebration in Union Square may not be held this year in May at all.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 3 -- Twenty-nine residents of the metropolitan area are among the 144 college seniors who have received Woodrow Wilson Fellowships for the coming academic year, Dr. Robert F. Goheen, national director of the Wilson program, announced today.

The real investigator in a Congressional inquiry is usually the counsel, who directs the staff in its researches, assembles the materials and keeps the members of the committee informed. If the investigation is extremely technical, the council may do much of the questioning of witnesses.

In Cornell's Aeronautical Laboratory is a hypersonic wind tunnel that tells how intense is the heat that will be generated in the vicinity of a wedge-shaped body when struck by a blast of air moving at a speed of 10,000 miles an hour. The escape velocity from the earth is 25,000 miles an hour, yet astronauts talk glibly of achieving it, though they are fully aware of the heat that will be generated.

SINCE the late summer of last year the Soviet Government has been concentrating more and more of its attention on barnyard affairs. The Kremlin has been the scene of a series of major conferences beginning last September devoted exclusively to farm problems and attended by many hundreds of delegates from all over Russia.
SOMEONE apparently has convinced Dave Garroway, who now spends some fifteen and a half hours weekly before the N. B. C. television cameras, that he should take up radio in his spare time.

LONDON, April 3 -- It is difficult to escape the conclusion that the most serious political casualties from the hydrogen weapon explosions in the Pacific have been suffered by those Governments, in Britain and in Europe, which are the most friendly to the United States.
TOKYO, April 3 -- Official comment from Japanese sources on Secretary of State Dulles' policy speech this week was entirely lacking, aid there was little comment on it in the press here.
The laying of the cornerstone of a new medical students residence hall at Cornell University Medical College will be part of the annual alumni reunion' program there next Friday and Saturday.

AT the opening session of the nineteenth North American Wildlife Conference in Chicago, Ira N. Gabrielson, former chief of the Fish and Wildlife Service and now President of the Wildlife Management Institute, denounced present conservation policies -- or to put it more accurately, lack of conservation policies -- of the Federal Government.

THE value of Merion bluegrass in new lawns is no longer in question. Those who have established lawns of this new improved variety of Kentucky bluegrass agree that it is outstanding. Although perhaps rating a trifle below a perfect bent lawn in quality, the average good Merion lawn will be better than nine out of ten bent lawns as maintained by the average homeowner.

Two hundred persons were driven to the street early yesterday morning when a three-alarm fire swept a six-story tenement building in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The fire broke out in a top-floor apartment at 6 o'clock and was brought under control forty-five minutes later.
YOKOHAMA, April 3 (AP) -- Boxers from the Eighth Army in Korea won the team title tonight in the Army's Far Eastern championships.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 3 -- Politics here is coming to a boil. The Constituent Assembly is scheduled to select a President for the next four years in May. And Lieut. Gen. Gustavo Rojas Pinilla, the incumbent, is expected to be returned to office by an overwhelming vote of the body, which seems to be assuming all the country's legislative functions.

The Suez Canal set a record last year both for the number of vessels in transit and the tonnage of cargo transported. A total of 12,731 ships carrying 90,399,000 metric tons of goods passed through the waterway, besting by 562 ships and 6,951,000 cargo tons the previous annual record set in 1952.
JERUSALEM, April 3 -- An Israeli Foreign Office spokesman said today that Israel would lodge a complaint against Jordan with the United Nations Security Council on Monday.

DALLAS, April 3 -- Don't be surprised if Phil Cavarretta, recently deposed as manager of the Cubs, is signed by the Giants. The 37-year-old Chicigoan worked out with Leo Durocher's club before today's game against the Indians' and made so good an impression he had Durocher digging for complimentary adjectives.

" The Daughters of Atreus," a play by Robert Turney, will be presented this week by the Hunter College Theatre Workshop. Performances will be given Wednesday at 6 P. M. and Friday and Saturday at 8:30 P. M. in the College Playhouse, 695 Park Avenue.

WE do not wish to appear to be making invidious comparisons with anything in particular, but are prone to remark that on beholding the performance with the music of Kurt Weill and the translation of the Bert Brecht book and lyrics of "The Threepenny Opera" down at the crowded little Theatre de Lys on Christopher Street, we had an uncommonly exciting experience.

CAIRO, April 3 (AP) -- The Egyptian Government charged tonight that three Egyptian soldiers had been killed and two wounded by Israeli troops who allegedly ambused an Egyptian patrol just inside the Palestine truce line near Gaza early today.

WITH the current selection of work recently acquired or not previously exhibited examples in the permanent collections, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is clearly embarked on a policy. That policy, agreed upon by the board of trustees and James Johnson Sweeney, director, presents a progressive innovation in museum approach emphasized by the recent purchase of the Cezanne portrait, "The Clock-maker."
Moshe Shapiro, Israel's Minister of Welfare and Religious Affairs, said last night that efforts by the major powers to appease the Arab states constituted "a dangerous error of global strategy."

DALLAS, April 3 -- Department store sales continue a little below last-year levels, but merchants look for a pre-Easter upsurge with warmer weather and the reduction of excise taxes. Meanwhile the Eleventh Federal Reserve Bank in its monthly business summary noted that February department store sales almost equalled January levels and were only 3 per cent below last year, but cold weather brought a dip in March.

SWANSCOMBE, England, March 31 -- Conservationists are striving to save what they consider to be the most important site of prehistoric man in Europe from being turned into a communal rubbish dump. The site is in a vast chalk pit at Swanscombe on the south bank of the Thames Estuary between Dartford and Gravesend.
LONDON, April 3 -- Eliahu Elath, Israeli Ambassador to Britain, voiced his country's alarm here tonight at the fact that the Western powers were supplying arms to the Arab countries bordering Israel.

Well-known women, including Mrs. John A. Morris and Mrs. Lucius D. Clay, are among the sponsors of the dinner and reception for the benefit of the Armed Forces Emergency Relief Fund of the Army, Navy and Air Force to be held on Tuesday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

While the world is preoccupied with the ultimate implications of the new hydrogen bomb as a mighty deterrent to Communist aggression and an instrument of massive retaliation in case of war, the free nations have by no means lost sight of the necessity for developing what Secretary Dulles has called "local defense" to discourage local Communist attacks and to meet them if they do come.
HARTFORD, April 3 -- John M. Bailey, Democratic State Chairman, is sounding party sentiment on a candidate to oppose Gov. John Davis Lodge, Republican, who is expected to seek re-election.

THERE will be thirty concerts in the 1954 Aspen Festival. This is more than usual, for this year -- the sixth in which the festival will be held in the Colorado town -- a tenth week is being added to the festival period.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., April 3 -- Duke, a friendly dog that for fifteen years was mascot of the Police Department here, died last night in an animal hospital in near-by Blue Point. He would have been 16 years old next month.

LEF us not think we are the first to have civilization nor that ours is so perfect that we can offer it as a model to others. Every civilization could justify itself in part and often outstrip us in that part. The Aztec nation, which gave its chosen youth a year of bliss before sacrifieing them to the gods, provided something equaled nowhere else.
LONDON, April 3 -- The Oxford crew swept to a five-length victory over favored Cambridge on the Thames River today in the 100th annual rowing race between the celebrated British universities.
ALBANY, April 3 (UP) -- Governor Dewey outlawed one-man investigating committees in New York State today and warned against "grave excesses" in legislative inquiries.

NEW DELHI, April 3 -- New suspicion of United States motives in Asia has been aroused in some influential Indian quarters by Secretary of State Dulles' call for "united action" against the onslaught of communism in Southeast Asia.

Retailers throughout the country are hopeful that the reduced excise taxes will bring more business on such goods as luggage, jewelry and cosmetics, according to resident buying offices. They also expect that it will revive the dull fur coat business.
NO piropo for Mr. Payne's "Flirtation is a Serious Business" (March 21). The lace of his slip is showing, which, in some countries, is taken to mean that attention is sought.

MOBILE, Ala. -- By underwriting the construction of three bridges with a combined length of approximately two miles, and a causeway equally long, Mobile's Chamber of Commerce has taken a giant step toward bringing honest-to-goodness ocean bathing several dozen miles closer to the city. The bridges and causeway will link Mobile with Dauphin Island, which lies just off the Alabama mainland at the mouth of Mobile Bay.

The disclosure in Washington last week that atomic destructiveness has reached new heights sharply focused attention on the hydrogen bomb and its capabilities. What follow are some of the questions now being asked about atomic energy and the bomb, and the answers to them.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- A busy fighter is an exceedingly difficult fighter to beat. Bobo Olson is a busy fighter. That's why he is still the world middleweight champion today. The methodical workman from Hawaii didn't rest for an instant in his bout against Kid Gavilan in the Chicago Stadium last night but kept applying the pressure.
BOSTON, April 3 -- This week's disclosures of the flaming fury of the hydrogen bomb hit hard in this area.
PARIS, April 3 -- Efforts to supplement the Balkan entente with a precise military alliance among Yugoslavia, Greece and Turkey appear to have run into unexpected snags.

ONE of the many paradoxes of our day is that the same people who are zealous to give the vote to boys and girls of 18 are equally zealous to guard the young of college age against the infection of controversial ideas.

TRENTON, April 3 -- A statistical analysis of 20,134 patients in New Jersey's state and county mental hospitals was made public this week by Sanford Bates, State Commissioner of Institutions and Agencies.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 3 -- Dr. Peyton Rous, emeritus member of the pathology and bacteriology staffs of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research in New York, has been named to receive the Bertner Foundation Award for 1954.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation supplied an answer yesterday to certain depositors of the National Bank of Wappingers Falls, N. Y., who have been wondering (privately, of course) why the bad checks they issued hadn't come back.
The Government's bartering of surplus wheat for Spanish and Italian quicksilver is beginning to cause concern among users of the liquid metal in this country.
Johnson Johnson is not afraid of a recession.
Few persons await the onset of balmy weather more impatiently than the makers of summer furniture and merchants who sell it.

ALBANY, April 3 -- With only eleven days left before the April 15 deadline, only about one out of six state income tax payers has so far filed a return of 1953, the State Tax Commission reported today.

ACCORDING to Hector Berlioz, the pace at which a symphonic work is taken seems to harmonize with the speed at which a conductor's blood flows. In spite of Maelzel and his metronome and a host of Italian indications, tempo remains a somewhat personal matter, subject among other things to pulse and the metabolic rate.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 3 -- Recent reports indicate that 50 per cent of the liberal arts colleges of the country are operating at a deficit. How to make ends meet has become one of the most critical issues facing higher education today.
A fairly wide range of popular types of antique furniture will be auctioned this week at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
PITTSFIELD, Me., April 3 -- This central Maine community is preparing to challenge the notion that the woolen industry must follow the Southern flight of cotton in order to survive.
Campaigning for an increase of $750 a year in pay, the New York Teachers Guild, A. F. L., ran a motorcade from 125th Street to City Hall yesterday afternoon.

TRANSCONTINENTAL motorists who drive by night are in for a sizable shock when swinging southeast into the Salt Lake valley after the grueling mountain-country journey from Denver. Looming in their line of sight abreast of narrow Thirty-third South Street, the visage of Victor Mature may flash into view -- in full color, and high as a five-story building.

Many of the fraternity of power cruiser skippers, returned from Florida or California voyages, recently drew up a list of predicted log plans for 1954. Shaking the winter icicles from their systems and thinking with smiles of spring and summer, Commodore William Edgar John of the year-old Eastern Cruiser Association and others recently prepared a schedule of seven major contests. They are:

WHEN it sang Gilbert and Sullivan operas in the basement of the Jan Hus House, Dorothy Raedler's miniature troupe was known as the Masque and Lyre. There were three and one-half years of mannered revelry under that classical banner.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 3 -- Adoption of a record budget exceeding $1,400,000,000 by the California Legislature before adjournment late this week cleared the way for a state-wide political campaign over which the shadow of Chief Justice Earl Warren is likely to hover.

PARIS, April 3 -- Regardless of violent contests elsewhere the most important assault being made by the Soviet Union against the Western diplomatic position remains that in Germany. The political scales can be tipped one way or the other according to the allegiance of the Germans, Western Europe's most energetic, most dynamic and potentially most dangerous people.
ALTHOUGH halted by manmade obstacles, nature does not concede defeat or relax her vigilance. Once an obstacle is withdrawn, even momentarily, she moves in without delay to regain her lost domain.

OF THE many Americans interested in our foreign relations, a few are concerned about two auxiliary facts: first, that the art of cultural diplomacy is one which we neglect, especially in those fields of modern, creative performance which are respected abroad; and, second, that this neglect is detrimental to our international friendships.

Columbia and Navy opened the twenty-fifth Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League campaign in sub-freezing weather yesterday, but a red-hot pitching performance by right-handler Jim King helped make the occasion a heart-warming one for the Lions, who topped the middies, 6 -- 4.
JERSEY CITY, April 3 -- New York scored its third victory in the sixth annual college all-star basketball game tonight, defeating a New Jersey quintet, 71-67, at the Armory.

After forty-seven years of catering to the healthy appetites of Cunard Line passengers, James Bradshaw is bound home for Liverpool, where he will be content to eat at his own table for the rest of his life.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 3 (AP) -- Julius Boros of Southern Pines, N. C., 1952 National open and world championship tournament winner, birdied the last hole today to tie Sam Snead and Doug Ford at 140 for the thirty-six-hole lead in the $10,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament. They were one shot ahead of Bob Rosburg, Chicago pro.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance on Thursday of "Ondine," starring Audrey Hepburn and Mel Ferrer, at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, which will be given for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Viewpoint School, Amenia, N. Y. Tickets still may be obtained at the Burden Littell Bureau, 150 East Sixty-first Street.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 3 -- The Syracuse Nationals, smashing through with 20 points in the third quarter, surprised the Minneapolis Lakers, 62 -- 60, before 6,277 fans today to even the National Basketball Association final play-off series at one game apiece.

The apocalyptic specter of total annihilation let loose by the first mushroom cloud of an atomic explosion nine years ago has now grown a thousand times more menacing as a result of the monstrous fireball spawned by the vastly more powerful hydrogen bomb.

An unhappy consequence of the compromises made by the Randall Commission in a vain effort to win protectionist support, and now embodied in the President's message on trade policy, is that believers in freer trade find themselves fighting, against heavy odds, for a program that on balance holds out very little hope.
Business and industry plan to hire more college and university graduates in 1954 than they employed in the past year and to pay them higher starting salaries.
John Francis (Jack) Coffey, one of the most popular figures in intercollegiate athletics, was honored yesterday when Fordham's baseball field was dedicated as "Jack Coffey Field."
THIS is the most extraordinary book yet to come forth in the harsh bibliography, pro and con, of "McCarthyism." Measured as a literary and polemical effort it is the most striking.

IT is regrettable that Mr. Klingman is trying to rewrite history. The history of who fought the Nazis primarily in Yugoslavia is on record. Mr. Klingman quotes Major Inks, whose book he edited, and adds his own opinion that it was Mihailovich.
TOKYO, April 3 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida has given his approval for a proposal to merge Japan's two powerful conservative parties.

Sydney A. Weinberg, associate in radiology, and Dr. James S. Watson Jr., lecturer in radiology, both of the University of Rochester, have devised a machine to project X-ray pictures of the heart at speeds as low as six frames a second without flicker. The usual projection speed is twelve to sixteen frames a second.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 3 -- The historic first attempt to cross the Atlantic Ocean by air in the dirigible America will be commemorated here Oct. 15. The ceremony, in honor of the crew and their gray kitten mascot who took off from here Oct. 15, 1910, is part of this resort's year-long centennial celebration

Thirty men were arrested and three others escaped by jumping three stories to the sidewalk when the Police Commissioner's confidential squad broke up a giant dice game two blocks from the Bronx police headquarters late yesterday afternoon.
A College of Business Administration will be opened next fall by Long Island University, Admiral Richard L. Conolly, president of the university, announced last week.

Dallas designers are clever about interpreting the latest high fashion in modified and modish form. They give style without exaggeration. Illustrated are designs from the summer collections of leading houses indicating favored trends. For day, the bloused and soft shirtwaist dress takes a lead position. Popular, too, are suits, dress and jacket ensembles and the full skirted silhouette (generally shown over one or more petticoats) in the princess as well as coat-type dress.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, April 3 (Reuters) -- Dr. Cheddi Jagan, deposed Prime, Minister of British Guiana, was arrested today after defying a Government order not to leave Georgetown.
BONN, Germany, April 3 (AP) -- West Germany's Opposition Socialist party criticized today the use of German Legionnaires by the French to help defend the Indo-Chinese fortress of Dienbienphu.

PARIS, April 3 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle has summoned a press conference for next Wednesday, when he is expected to make a supreme effort to destroy the European Defense Community treaty and replace it with an alternative plan for a European coalition.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, April 3 (Reuters) -- Dr. Cheddi Jagan, deposed Prime, Minister of British Guiana, was arrested today after defying a Government order not to leave Georgetown.

THERE are more than peas and carrots in the vegetable kingdom, especially at this time of year. In the spring, produce stalls in good-sized cities offer a beneficial array of mustard greens, turnip tops, broccoli rabe, dandelion greens, chicory root, leeks, lamb's-lettuce, sorrel.

SOME gardeners feel that spring is not spring until forsythia or other well-known flowering shrubs start to flower. But in my opinion the rarely grown February daphne (D. mezereum) tops them all.
Find, Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's 4-year-old Discovery gelding, won the forty-seventh running of the mile-and-a-sixteeth Excelsior Handicap at the Jamaica Race Track yesterday.
KINGSTON, Jamaica, April 3 (Reuters) -- The English team won the fifth test and gained a split in the series when it defeated West Indies by nine wickets on the fifth day of their match today.

DALLAS, April 3 -- Willie Mays, the 22-year-old kid with a tremendous future, hit a home run, doubled and singled twice as the Giants beat the Indians, 6 -- 1, before 9,069 fans at Burnett Stadium today. The 4-for-4 feat increased Mays' batting average to .420, and the New Yorkers are straining at the leash, impatiently awaiting the April 13 starting bell.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, March 28 -- The Dutch appear to be in for a rationing of news about their favorite public group -- the royal family.

HOWARD RIGSBY is what writers and editors think of as "an old pro" -- a man who has done a little of everything, and most of it very well. He's written crime, Western, horror and adventure fiction; and in a not untypical career, he wrote long for the pulps, "graduated" to hardcover novels and is now concentrating on paperback originals.

PEORIA, Ill, April 1 -- Republican voters of the Eighteenth Illinois Congressional District will have the opportunity April 13 to endorse or to reject the fourth-term bid of Harold H. Velde in the House of Representatives.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 3 -- Expanded recreational activities of Westchester County will be the theme of a "recorama" to be presented Thursday night in the County Center by the County Recreation Commission and the Recreation Executives Association.

TOLEDO, Ohio, April 3 -- The cornerstone for Ohio's first Moslem mosque will be laid tomorrow and a time capsule of the congregation's fourteen-year history with a roll of its fifteen charter members will be buried.
GARDENA, Calif., April 3 -- California laws prohibit gambling, but here, a scant fifteen miles from Los Angeles City Hall, six open gambling casinos are grossing $4,000,000 a year.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 3 -- Everything went into reverse for the Milwaukee Braves today as the Dodgers beat them, 9 -- 1, before an overflow crowd of 10,474 at Rickwood Field.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 3 -- The Yankees, dropping down to Class A minor league competition after compiling a dismal 8-16 record against major rivals, snapped a five-game losing streak today. They vanquished the Jacksonville Braves of the Sally League, 6 to 0.

The fact that Europe on the map of the world looks like a huge peninsula extending westward from a broad base on Asia must have influenced the Russian geopolitickers in their present proposal for a "European defense system."

CHICAGO, April 3 -- Carl (Bobo) Olson skipped out of town early today. The Hawaiian fighter flew home to San Francisco this morning to be with his wife and four children. Kid Gavilan will remain here for a few days before moving on to New York and then to his native Cuba.
DETROIT, April 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon told a Republican dinner tonight that a "substantial part" of President Eisenhower's legislative program would be enacted by Congress.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 3 (Reuters) -- Herbert Hoover Jr., United States Government oil consultant, arrived here from London today and said he was optimistic about a settlement of the three-year-old British-Iranian oil dispute.

CHICAGO, April 3 -- The impact of the H-bomb disclosures on the Midwest has been one of mixed concern and comfort. Many view the latest facts as demonstrable proof to the Russians that we have the means to blast them and their cities from the face of the earth. At the same time, no one believes that the Soviets will not retaliate or that their development of such weapons can be far behind.

HANOI, April 3 -- In good weather today, French planes carried out intensive bombardments of the Vietminh positions and French artillery pounded Vietminh gun positions. The French successfully air-dropped additional supplies to their beleaguered forces.

Answers to many questions of what makes adolescents the way they are will be sought by the University of Michigan Survey Research Center in a study of boys 14 through 16 years of age. The study is to be done for the Boy Scouts of America, to help it better to understand the needs of boys in the Scout movement.

LETTERS intended for posterity -- so goes an old warning -- seldom reach their destination. Mindful of that truth, former President Truman has made as certain as possible that his 3,000,000 papers -- from which he is now writing his memoirs -- will make a safe trip from the present to the future.
THE off-Broadway theatre movement, which has been enjoying an unprecedented vogue after years of plodding semi-obscurity, is suddenly facing the threat of a serious setback.
HANOI, Vietnam, Sunday, April 4 (AP) -- The stout French defenders of Dienbienphu hurled back fresh massive Vietminh attacks early today.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 3 -- A leading real estate appraiser refuted here today the popularly held conception that proximity to airports adversely affects property values.

Ohio State University's team scored 25 points to win a collegiate Weightlifting tournament at the McBurney Y.M.C.A. last night. The seven-man Buckeye squad was first in three classes, second in three and third in another.

The bullish sentiment on the state of the economy that has enveloped the financial community was bolstered last week by enactment of the excise tax law, plans for higher stockpile goals for a host of minerals and metals and an indicated upturn in two key barometric industries -- steel and automotive.

THE meeting of the American Primrose Society in Portland this coming week- end coincides with the start of primrose bloom here in the Pacific Northwest. Long known to poets and gardeners as a symbol of spring, modern hybrids of primroses with glorified colors and increased vigor now offer an almost irresistible invitation to American gardners.
BEAUMONT, Tex., April 3 (UP) -- Bob Keegan and Mike Fornieles held Beaumont of the Texas League to three singles as they pitched the White Sox to a 5-0 victory before 2,831 today.
LOGAN, Utah, April 3 -- Farm incomes "depend far more on general economic conditions than on the level of price supports, the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, declared today.

WASHINGTON -- Several explanations can be offered for the fascination which tours of old homes and gardens hold for spring motorists. All of them are equally valid. In the first place they offer a delightful excuse for getting out into the green countryside after a long winter indoors.

Testifying before a Senate Banking subcommittee, W. Randolph Burgess, speaking for the Treasury Department, and William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, have gone on record against two proposals for gold legislation now before that committee.
The North Channel Bridge, main north-south artery between the Rockaways and Queens, will be closed for repairs for five hours on each of four days this week.

Performances of "The Yeomen of the Guard," the thirtieth annual production of the Blue Hill Troupe, will be presented for three nights starting April 21, and on the afternoon of April 24 in the Hunter Playhouse.

The confusion attendant upon the reduction, as of midnight last Wednesday, of the Federal personal transportation tax from 15 to 10 per cent was lessened by the fact that it is easier to multiply by 10 than by 15. Airline, bus and railroad ticket clerks were alerted in advance of President Eisenhower's signature of the new excise law last Wednesday, and were provided with tables indicating the new tax rate.

This being spring, it is a time when new brooms sweep clean. A time when mothers wait patiently for very young ladies and gentlemen to leave the house so that new brooms can be brought into cluttered rooms and closets where they may sweep away the hopelessly battered, the bent and broken toys acquired and discarded during the long, cold and dark months.

The end of the dock strike will not bring peace to the battered Port of New York automatically. It merely marks the end of illegal warfare against Federal and State agencies by lawless elements which dominate the old International Longshoremen's Association in a stubborn effort to retain their lucrative privileges.

State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick gave fresh support yesterday to the city's drive to correct housing violations. He announced that rent reductions of 50 per cent would be imposed on landlords found guilty in Magistrate's Court of practices dangerous to life or detrimental to health. In one case an even greater cut has been ordered.

Purple vestments, shrouded statues and crucifixes bore out the solemnity of Passion Sunday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning. The somber atmosphere that will mark all services in Roman Catholic churches until Holy Saturday morning was relieved only by the crimson garb of the attending clergy.

Happy over the demand for tickets to her latest entry, "King of Hearts," which contains more than the customary quota of laughs, Elaine Perry is planning to tie up a couple of scripts -- "Anastasia," which has to do with an impersonation of the Czar

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 4 -- Israel was condemned today for two raids in Egyptian territory Friday in which three Egyptian soldiers were killed and one was wounded. A vote of cen sure was adopted by the Israeli-Egyptian Mixed Armistice Commission, which held that "military or para-military armed Israelis" had been responsible.
PARIS, April 4 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault today rejected the Soviet offer to consider joining NATO as a guarantee of European security.

Religion and psychiatry are "team-mates" in mending human lives, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, minister of the Marble Collegiate Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, April 4 -- A former Bronx Zoo resident, Pharaoh, the 16-year-old lion, took an unscheduled swim this afternoon in the moat bordering his domain at the Philadelphia Zoo. He was saved from drowning when zoo officials drained the ditch.

Dr. Goodwin Watson has replied in detail to charges by the Americanism Commission of the Westchester County American Legion that he repeatedly had championed "major and minor objectives of the Communist conspiracy in America."

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 4 -- Arthur Knapp Jr., the defending season champion, had one of his most successful afternoons in dinghy racing today when, with his Agony, he headed the largest Interclub fleet ever to race at the Larchmont Yacht Club at one session.
New demands that management changes be made in Decca Records, Inc., and Universal Pictures, Inc., its 68 per cent-owned subsidiary, were mailed to shareholders of the former over the week-end.
The development of the social court division of the Magistrates Courts and its need for funds to expand were stressed yesterday in Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh's annual report to Mayor Wagner.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 4 -- The Vietminh assault on Dienbienphu slackened today. It is believed possible that the Communist-led forces are unable to maintain the all-out effort against the French-held fortress and that their attack has entered a phase of diminished activity.
That resources for design are world wide was the conclusion reached in a panel discussion at the Eastern Art Association's convention.
Regardless of the outcome of the deadly struggle for power between two rival longshore groups, the whole picture of waterfront employment in New York Harbor will be altered radically this year.

Responding to the world-wide shock caused by the revelations of the destructive power of the hydrogen bomb, the United States, Britain and France have called for an immediate meeting of the United Nations Disarmament Commission, and even Mr. Vishinsky has welcomed this move.

BUENOS AIRES, April 4 -- The rapidly growing General Confederation of Economics has taken a public stand in opposition to a general wage increase. It asserts that prices and wages have become stabilized at a point of "dynamic equilibrium."

Marion Zarzeczna, young Trenton pianist with well drilled fingers, gave her first New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Her program included Beethoven's Sonata Op. 90, Brahms' Sonata, Op. 5, and works by two composers who were present -- Tadeusz Kassern and Constant Vauclain.

The National Child Labor Committee is seriously concerned about two child labor bills (A. Int. 3285 and 3286), which were hastily drafted, introduced in the closing days of the legislative session by the Assembly Rules Committee and rushed through the Legislature with such speed that no adequate opportunity was afforded interested parties to make their views known.

Samuel Johnson once wrote that "being in a ship is being in jail, with the chance of being drowned." Today's stout ships have reduced the dangers of drowning, but seamen might still find Johnson's pronouncement on jail not far wrong. With the limited space available on our merchant marine vessels, in lighthouses, lightships and Coast Guard stations for crew's quarters and recreation, off-duty hours find life and movement restricted.

One hundred acres of land at Bayport, L. I., have been sold by Manlio Vidoni to Raphael Kasper, Edward and Theodore Charney and Max Tannenbaum, builders, who plan a development called Berry Hill-at-Bayport. The Suffolk County tract will be improved with 325 homes in the Cape Cod and ranch styles. Title was insured by the Guaranteed Title and Mortgage Company.
PALERMO, Sicily, April 4 (AP) -- Piero Taruffi, whose special-built Lancia broke down in the Sebring, Fla., twelve-hour race, came back today to win the 1,080-kilometer tour of Sicily.
WILLIAMS GROVE, Pa., April 4 (AP) -- Johnny Thomson of Springfield, Mass., drove to a record-breaking victory today in the season's inaugural A. A. A. big car feature before 12,600 fans.

SYRACUSE, April 4 (UP) -- George Mikan led the Minneapolis Lakers to an 81 -- 67 triumph over the Syracuse Nationals tonight before 8,719 fans, the largest crowd ever to witness a basketball game in the War Memorial Auditorium.

La Salle, National Collegiate basketball champion, and Holy Cross, National Invitation Tournament winner, will oppose Fordham University at the Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx next season. Sixteen home games are on the Ram's schedule, which was released yesterday.

ATLANTA, April 4 (AP) -- Harry Agganis celebrated his promotion to the Red Sox by driving in two runs to give the American Leaguers a 3-2 victory over Atlanta of the Southern Association today before 4,822 fans.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee reported today in a staff survey that "an acute state of tension" existed within the government of Communist-dominated Rumania.

CHICAGO, April 4 -- Price trends in the grain markets were decidedly irregular last week, wheat finally moving up on buying stimulated by unfavorable crop news, while corn and old crop soybean futures had sharp declines.
The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., independent steamship line, cited two more steamship conferences before the Federal Maritime Board last week.

CLINTON, N. J., April 4 -- Wayriels Allegheny Sport, 3-year-old white and liver pointer owned by Dr. J. A. Bans and R. W. Riggins of Knoxville, Tenn., and handled by Herman Smith of Hatchechubbee, Ala., won the $1,000 Imperial all-age stake today as the Jockey Hollow Field Trial Club completed its spring program.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- C. D. Jackson left his White House job last week with the conviction that it was now time for Congress to match President Eisenhower's sense of responsibility by cleaning up the McCarthy issue and getting busy on his program.
The Augustana Evangelical Lutheran Church, one of the major Lutheran bodies in this country, opened a $2,000,000 fundraising campaign yesterday for missionary projects in this country and abroad.

Rights are being offered to holders of common stock of Pennsylvania Power and Light Company to subscribe for 704,917 new shares of common stock at the rate of one new share for each seven shares held. The subscription price is $39.75 a share.

On Sunday night a week ago the guest of the evening on "Meet the Press" was Ezra T. Benson, Secretary of Agriculture. In that half hour of interrogation the Secretary was bombarded with questions covering almost every controversial matter that had come up in his field during his fourteen months in office.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 4 (UP) -- The White Sox blew a four-run lead, then bounced back with three runs in the eighth inning to defeat the Cardinals today, 8 to 5, before an overflow crowd of 12,960.

LONDON, April 4 -- Having grappled or attempted to grapple with the mass of facts and figures presented to the country in the last few days by the government's economic survey for 1953, by exchequer returns covering revenue and expenditures for the fiscal year ended last month and by the annual white paper on national income and expenditures for last year, the stock markets have staged a fresh bull movement of considerable strength and breadth.

BONN, Germany, April 4 -- West German officials expect the United States Congress to release German assets seized during World War II and not to insist on the return of all of the gold looted by the Nazis in Western Europe.

Arthur Krock's column on March 25 presents an argument of former Senator Tydings that a Government employe may defy Congressional inquiry as to Communist affiliations without invoking the privilege against self-incrimination. It is asserted that it would be a crime for a person with such affiliations to accept Government service and that the Fifth Amendment prohibits Congressional questions about the crimes of a witness, requiring presentment or indictment.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Senate is facing the prospect of what some responsible members regard as the likelihood of eventual United States involvement in the Indo-China war on a major scale.
Advertising is no laughing matter, of course. But the Chase National Bank refuses to concede this eternal truth and has hired some of its customers to add laughs to its copy.

The Southern Natural Gas Company expanded its volume of gas sales by 10 per cent in 1953 to a total of 217 billion cubic feet, C. T. Chenery, chairman, told stockholders yesterday. The utility's annual report showed revenues last year up 23 per cent, and operating expenses by the same percentage.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Senator Burnet R. Maybank, Democrat of South Carolina, today proposed to force a showdown designed "to put an end to backdoor assaults on public housing."

Outplaying their rivals most of the way, the Long Island poloists rode off with the national 12-goal championship yesterday by turning back the Ramapo Polo Club, 11 to 8, in the final-round match at the Squadron A Armory.

In the intermission between acts I and II of tonight's performance of "Pagliacci," the Metropolitan Opera will present silver traveling clocks to forty-five veteran employes whose total length of service totals 1,623 years. The ceremony will be on the stage in view of the audience.
GREENWICH, Conn., April 4 -- Final standings for the 1953-54 frostbite season at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, which ended last week-end, were announced today.

Sustained strength in the British pound sterling and an erratic movement in the Canadian dollar marked the trading in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Turnover in transactions was considered to be only moderate in comparison with sessions of some previous weeks.

The Treasury published recently a report which reveals that other countries purchased gold from the United States last year totaling $1,164,200,000. This represents a striking reversal of the trend which prevailed in 1952. In order to balance their accounts with the United States in 1952 foreign nations had found it necessary to sell gold here in the net amount of $394,000,000.
ROME, April 4 -- The town of Cassino and the historic Abbey of Monte Cassino celebrated their rebirth today, ten years after their destruction by Allied bombardments.

Cotton prices in the domestic market held in a relatively narrow trading range last week. The general tendency was for the nearer deliveries to ease slightly. At the close on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 4 to 21 points from the close of the previous week.

CARROLLTON, Ga., April 4 (AP) -- Louise Suggs, the star from Atlanta, came from behind today to overtake Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias and Patty Berg and win the Carrollton women's open golf tournament.
New York policemen gave Senator Joseph R. McCarthy repeated and roaring ovations yesterday.

New York City's Commissioner of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity called upon members of his department yesterday to be patient and understanding about any salary inequities they feel exist and to consider paramount their loyalties to the public.
Five new films, including imports from France, will arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- How does the official "voice" of the Government abroad present an important but often embarrassing episode in contemporary American politics?

" Don't clutter up your dresses with ribbons, frills and furbelows, keep them simple and let the designs speak for themselves." These words were spoken by a young man, 27 years old. His clear blue eyes were serious and the tone of his voice firm as, at the request of the writer, he gave this advice to those intending to use today's New York Times American Designer Series patterns.

BEDMINSTER, N. J., April 4 -- Resolutions inviting the New York Stock Exchange and its member firms to move to New Jersey will be introduced tomorrow in the Legislature by two of its Republican members.

JERUSALEM, April 4 -- Israel's Cabinet discussed today an appeal to the United Nations Security Council for consideration of the troubled border situation. Ambassador Reuven Shiloah, home from Washington on a flying visit, analyzed for the Cabinet the United States policy in the Middle East.

PARIS, April 4 -- French Cabinet Ministers appealed tonight to C. Douglas Dillon, United States Ambassador, to do his best to hasten deliveries to the French Indo-China forces of B-26 planes needed to support the defense of Dienbienphu.

The first of a five-part series on the condition of our national parks appears in The Times today. Describing Grand Canyon, one of the best-known of the parks, this article reveals how facilities, maintenance, personnel and appropriations are totally inadequate to take care of the ever-increasing number of visitors, which last year rose to more than 800,000 persons in this one area alone.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, April 4 (AP) -- Top-seeded favorites went down to defeat in the final round of the Puerto Rican invitation tennis tournament today. Art Larsen of San Leandro, Calif., won the men's title and Shirley Fry of Akron, Ohio, captured the women's crown.

BOSTON, April 4 -- Samuel P. Sears, the Boston lawyer who will serve as counsel for the Senate inquiry into Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's dispute with the Army, frequently has gone on public record against communism and cases in Government and schools where persons would not testify.

NATO is five years old. The anniversary of the signing of the North Atlantic Pact was celebrated yesterday by statements from representatives of the member countries extolling the usefulness of the alliance and pledging continued allegiance to its purposes.

The Bamberg Symphony Orchestra conducted by Joseph Keilberth made its New York debut yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Bamberg is a small town close to the Czech border and its action in sending an orchestra to the Americas (the group has finished a seven-day tour of Mexico and Havana) would be analogous to Kansas City or Tulsa sending an orchestra to Europe.
MOSCOW, April 4 -- The magazine Kommunist, highest ideological party organ, declared today that it was "necessary" to carry on discussion of Trofim D. Lysenko's theories of species formation.

A brief designed to answer objections raised by a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner who opposed a round-the-world air service by Trans World and Northwest Airlines will be filed with the C. A. B. in Washington today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 4 -- Jerry Wald, executive producer for Columbia, has written an outline for a comedy drama dealing with the ups and downs, serious and amusing, in the lives of four girls living away from home and trying to make successful careers in a big city.

A study of a military blunder made famous by a poem, "The Charge of the Light Brigade," will be published April 29 by McGraw-Hill, entitled "The Reason Why." The author is Cecil Woodham-Smith, who became interested in the two men responsible for that blunder while she was writing a biography of Florence Nightingale, a work published in 1951.

Johnny Balquist, Columbia's baseball coach, sat huddled in the Lions dressing room at Baker Field last Saturday following the Lions' Ivy League victory over Navy. Although the game had been over for more than a half hour, he still wore his rubber shirt and jacket.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP) -- The United States Steel Corporation and its subsidiaries are understaking expansion of metallurgical by-product coke-producing facilities at an estimated cost of close to $40,000,000, the Office of Defense Mobilization reported today.
MOSCOW, April 4 -- Moscow's elaborate drinking establishment, Cocktail Hall, was attacked by the Soviet press today for contributing to the delinquency of schoolboys.
The Port of New York, stilled by a strike since March 5, will come alive today with ships and men.
The Climax Molybdenum Company, which produces more than half the nation's output of molybdenum ore, last year increased net earnings 60 per cent to $9,717,000 on record sales of $38,907,151.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., April 4 -- Ch. Parader's Major Domo Lomard, a sable and white 3 1/2- year-old dog owned by Paul and Rose Jolie of Whitman, Mass., was the winner in the specialty of the Collie Club of New Jersey tonight.
