Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh reported yesterday that there was "talk of wholesale indictments of bail bondsmen for charging excessive fees." He declared that the State Insurance Department was failing to supervise bondsmen adequately.
A municipal program to combat juvenile delinquency, costing $41,000,000 for the next fiscal year, was urged yesterday by the Welfare and Health Council of New York City.
PARIS, April 4 -- Jean Monnet will arrive in New York tomorrow on a mission looking to the economic unity and financial rehabilitation of Europe.

GREENSBORO, N. C., April 4 (AP) -- Doug Ford and Marty Furgol tied for top honors in the $10,000 Greensboro open golf tournament with one-under-par 283's today. They will meet in an eighteen-hole play-off tomorrow afternoon, the second in succession for Ford here.

DETROIT, April 4 (UP) -- Dutch Reibel and Red Kelly scored third-period goals tonight to give the Detroit Red Wings a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens in the opener of their best-of-seven-game final series for the Stanley Cup.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Eisenhower will address the nation over radio and television networks tomorrow night on the "multiplicity of fears" that has developed among its people.

PARIS, April 4 -- The steel industry of France is producing 15 per cent more than it is able to sell, according to Pierre Ricard, president of the French Steel Association and vice president of the National Employment Association.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The household of Senator Karl E. Mundt has not been completely at ease since the investigating subcommittee he heads temporarily rejected the suggestion of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that lie detectors be used in the Army-McCarthy controversy.
THERE'S only one explanation for the Bobo Olson-Kid Gavilan championship fight on Friday night. The guys fought twice, once for the sports writers at ringside and once for television viewers at home.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $79,209,302,016. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes follows:

There has been a tendency in recent years to write histories of economic thought in terms of the few men whose ideas still color the world around us. Some day this may lead to an essay on Aristotle, Aquinas, Smith, Ricardo, Marx, Marshall and Keynes, with all others eliminated.
NEW DELHI, India, April 4 -- United States and Indian officials have completed the allocation of $60,500,000 in direct economic aid appropriated for India by Congress for 1953-54.

LOS ANGELES, April 4 (UP) -- Following is the text of a letter from Stephen A. Mitchell, Democratic National Chairman, to Paul Ziffren, California National Committeeman, concerning the candidacies of James Roosevelt and Representative Robert Condon, Democrat of California:

A professor of biology at New York University has been appointed head of the biology department in the University's Graduate School of Arts and Science, Dean Joseph H. Park announced yesterday. He is Dr. Harry A. Charipper, a member of the faculty since 1926. He is also chairman of the biology department at Washington Square College.
Rates in the charter market dipped slightly last week, but brokers debated whether it was a leveling-off, a prelude to the usual summer slump or part of a long-term trend.
SHILOH BATTLEFIELD, Tenn., April 4 (AP) -- A graying daughter of the Confederacy peered at Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant 3d today and said, "Grandfather would turn in his grave if he could see me now."

BOSTON, April 4 -- Rabbi Joseph S. Shubow of Brookline questioned today the appointment of Samuel P. Sears of Boston as chief counsel for the Senate inquiry into Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's dispute with the Army.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 4 -- Cornell University yachtsmen won the McMillan Cup today on a third-place finish that gave them an 18-point total and an elapsed-time mark of 9:27:45 for the Navy Sailing Squadron's two-day intercollegiate event.
In his letter printed March 31 Rabbi D. B. Stolper expressed his disapproval of what he termed "pampering the Arabs, who were actually our enemies in both World Wars."

BOSTON, April 4 -- The American university is "an anvil which has worn out many hammers," Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, the president of the City College of New York, said tonight in reference to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Repair work has been finished on two much-criticized United States air bases in French Morocco and the bill comes to exactly $2,584,962.84, Representative Glenn Davis, Republican of Wisconsin, said today.

The United States Public Health Service and the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis stressed last night that none of the new anti-polio vaccine would be released unless found to be perfectly safe.
Nine scientists have formed the Scientific Research Committee on Mental Illness, Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey, retired, announced yesterday as national campaign chairman of the Mental Health Fund.

LONDON, Monday, April 5 -- Prime Minister Churchill has received nontechnical information from President Eisenhower about the United States hydrogen bomb experiments. He will use as much of this knowledge as he can in a speech in the House of Commons today during debate on the hydrogen bomb.

YOU come across odd collections in town, but you're not apt to match Miss Delphine Binger's 500,000 chicken, turkey and goose wishbones -- twenty years' accumulation. She has room for only a few thousand in her two-room flat at 145 West Ninety-sixth Street. Her aunts and other kin store the rest for her in trunks.

PINE BLUFF, Ark., April 4 (AP) -- The attending physician for Junius Kellogg held little hope tonight for recovery of the former Manhattan College basketball star who was injured in a car wreck near here.

The Peiping People's Daily reports that "the people's democratic dictatorship" of China has advised its peasants to cease their "blind" and "wanton drifting" into the cities. Behind this governmental directive is a story that reveals the unhappy plight of the farmer in Red China.
ALTHOUGH "Babes in Bag-dad" boasts a seraglio of beauties headed by those Hollywood houris, Paulette Goddard and Gypsy Rose Lee, this is definitely one harem to avoid.
MOSCOW, April 4 -- Eleven United States newspaper and radio station editors and owners arrived today for a stay of one to three weeks.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Federal Government may have to use some of the gold it has at Fort Knox to pay for its closing down the country's gold mines in 1942.

CHICAGO, April 4 (AP) -- The Harlem Globetrotters, recovering from three straight losses, defeated the College All-Stars twice today, 84 -- 61, in a runaway afternoon game, and 78 -- 76 in a down-to-the-wire evening thriller.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, April 4 -- The Netherlands Bank has decided to grant dollars for Dutch travelers to the United States and Canada similar to the tourist allowances on visits to other countries -- namely, 1,000 guilders for automobile costs.

Man can achieve a creative solution to the problem of obeying external authority by understanding its nature and adding actions of his own to the commands he is given, Dr. Perry E. Gresham, president of Bethany (W. Va.) College, declared yesterday.

TWO important modern French painters are honored on this week's crowded art calendar. There is Wednesday's opening at the Museum of Modern Art of a retrospective exhibition of paintings and prints by Vuillard, the French post-impressionist who died in 1940.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 4 -- The threat of a break between the two zones of Pakistan became more serious today.

Several major unions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations have joined those of the American Federation of Labor in helping to finance the strike of 1,500 hatters against the Hat Corporation of America in South Norwalk, Conn.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- When the "grass roots" speak, Congress listens and often acts.

ALBANY, April 4 (AP) -- If Congress broadens unemployment insurance coverage an estimated 500,000 additional New York workers will be brought into the system automatically under a bill signed today by Governor Dewey.
SAVANNAH, Ga., April 4 -- The spring training misadventures of the Yankees came within one out of reaching a new low today.
Sales of residential property on the West Side formed the bulk of realty deals reported in Manhattan over the week-end.

PITTSBURGH, April 4 -- For the time being, at least, the long downtrend in steel output has hit bottom. No one in the trade, however, was willing last week to take the stand that a brisk uptrend would set in at once.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt said today that the McCarthy-Army dispute would go to the Justice Department for a possible perjury prosecution if both sides repeated their charges under oath.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles praised today the unity of free men represented by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which was formed just five years ago.

The New York Americans were blanked by the German Hungarians of the German American League, 6 -- 0, in the first round of the annual competition for the Lewis Trophy at the Metropolitan Oval in Maspeth yesterday.

Praises be to you for publishing, in regard to policy and the hydrogen bomb, Lewis Mumford's magnificent call to sanity. May it be read by thoughtful citizens from one end of this land to the other, and may its message be taken up by enough of such to turn the policies of our Government before it is too late.

Total resources of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York as of March 31 amounted to $2,951,737,904, according to the first-quarter statement of condition issued for publication today. This compares with $2,972,598,721 last Dec. 31 and with $2,899,021,670 at the end of the first quarter of 1953.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., April 4 (AP) -- Shozi Sasahara, Chuo University student from Tokyo representing the Japanese Wrestling Association, captured the 136- pound laurels in the national senior Amateur Athletic Union wrestling tournament Saturday night.
GRAND CANYON, Ariz., April 4 -- The Grand Canyon, in which several billion years of the earth's history stand in unique and majestic display, is a breath-taking manifestation of the hand of Creation.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Monday, April 5 (AP) -- South Korea's proposal of an anti-Communist conference of Southeast Asian nations for April 26, the opening day of the Geneva conference on Korea and Indo-China, has run into setbacks.
PARIS, April 4 -- Gaullists and Communists invaded patriotic ceremonies at the Arc de Triomphe today and staged a demonstration against the dismissal of Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin.

Older men and women living on pensions and social security must have employment opportunity to supplement small fixed incomes and satisfy their psychological need "to live productive, useful lives even in old age," the Federation Employment Service reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Stephen A. Mitchell, national chairman of the Democratic party, today withheld the party's support from James Roosevelt and suggested that he get out of the race for a California Congressional seat.
SMITHTOWN, L. I., April 4 -- Phyllis Field's brown mare, Lucky Miss, scored 7 1/2 points to win the junior hunter championship for the third straight year during the Smithtown Hunt trial today.
The Ford Foundation has elected as trustees Mark F. Ethridge and Laurence M. Gould.
Voluntary health insurance organizations that contract to reinsure themselves under the Federal Administration's proposed new program were admonished yesterday against misleading advertising.

BERLIN, April 4, -- Walter Ulbricht, Germany's No. 1 Communist, revealed today Red plans to exploit fears of the hydrogen bomb in an effort to force withdrawal of the United States atomic artillery from Germany.
BALTIMORE, April 4 (AP) -- A pair of Malayan brothers and two Baltimore sisters dominated the finals of the Maryland international invitation badminton tournament which closed today.

New York State's eighty-seven civil defense control centers will take part June 14 and 15 in the first nation-wide test conducted by the Federal Civil Defense Administration. It will be assumed that five bombs have been dropped in the state.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 4 -- The Braves and Dodgers today gave an imitation of a game between the married men and the single men played on picnic grounds, with the spectators mingling with the players.

Arturo Toscanini made his last appearance with the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra last evening in Carnegie Hall. He thereupon concluded his long engagement as leader of that body, which was established for him, and officially ended sixty-eight years of a conductor's career.
Mayor Wagner repeated yesterday his declaration of last month that he would in no circumstances be a candidate for Governor in the 1954 election.
Ray Lumpp, former New York Knickerbocker and New York University star, has been appointed assistant to Howard Cann, basketball coach at New York University.

" WHAT is man that Thou art mindful of him?" the Psalmist asked and then answered his own question by declaring: "Thou hast made him a little lower than the angels and hast crowned him with glory and honor." Such an answer was possible in an age of unquestioning faith and still is possible to those whose faith is untroubled by doubt.
The new world of the hydrogen bomb stands "perilously close to the brink of a new hell," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken, pastor of the Riverside Church, declared yesterday in his sermon.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- Following are the votes of the members of Congress from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls during the period March 27 through April 3.
RIDGEFIELD PARK, N. J., April 4 -- The question facing this community today was: Which came first, the fire or the firemen?
When we read the other day that Karl Eitel had died, we were reminded, and not as irrelevantly as it may seem, of that culinary curiosity called the baumkuchen.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, April 4 -- Malayan mine production of tin in concentrate in February was 4,277 long tons, compared with the 1953 monthly average of 4,688, the International Tin Study Group reported here today. United States production in February was 3,008 tons, against 2,750 in January.

The Administration's new stockpiling policy on strategic metals and minerals has revived speculation on the fate of the third round of post-1950 aluminum expansion, approved by the Government eighteen months ago but never started.
The National City Bank of New York had total assets of $5,868,569,303 on March 31, according to its statement of condition issued for publication today.

" Capriccio," the fifteenth and last opera of Richard Strauss, was produced for the first time in America yesterday afternoon at the Juilliard Concert Hall. The work proved a beautiful one, and it was performed by the Juilliard Opera Theatre in a thoroughly competent and impressive manner.
Warmer temperatures were forecast for today as a Canadian cold front that had pushed temperatures down to record lows moved over the city and out to sea.
A prediction that Israel would not start any aggression against the Arab states was made yesterday by Rabbi Mordecai Kirshblum, president of the Mizrachi Organization of America.

IF Diogenes had encountered Bob Quinn, he'd have thrown away his lantern and ended successfully his search for an honest man. Old Bob died recently at the age of 84. He left no estate because he did not measure wealth in material things. But he was rich in the respect, the love and the admiration of all who knew him during his sixty years in baseball.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 4 -- The United States' supremacy in exports to Colombia is being challenged by Europe.
Specialists in safety at sea will convene Wednesday and Thursday to discuss ways of preventing accidents in the marine industry.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Eight states continued in February to bear the brunt of unemployment increases, a Labor Department report showed today.
Sixty per cent of the 157 manufacturing companies cooperating in a spot check just concluded have been affected by the current business decline.

Mrs. Wendell Willkie, widow of the Presidential candidate, has been named chairman of the women's division of the American-Korean Foundation's $10,000,000 campaign "to help Koreans to hely themselves," Henry C. Alexander, campaign chairman, announced yesterday.

Half a dozen Parthenons -- small-scale versions of the ancient temple on the Acropolis -- rolled up Fifth Avenue yesterday as Greek-Americans paraded. The marchers were observing Greece's declaration of independence 133 years ago.
CHRISTOPHER FRY'S "The Boy With a Cart," a poetic legend about an eleventh-century shepherd-saint, has compelling temporal appeal as well as a reverent quality about it.

The proclamation on March 26 of East Germany as a Soviet style "sovereign" state is, in spite of the obvious absurdity of its pretenses, more than a "joke" or a purely propaganda stunt. It is a new (but not the last) calculated move in a consistent and vigorously pushed Soviet policy adopted since the East Berlin riots in June, 1953.

DALLAS, April 4 -- It was too bad that Willie Mays did little to distinguish himself today while the Giants were losing, 8 -- 4, to the Indians. Aside from helping on a double play, Mays was just another ball player, going hitless before an overflow crowd of 10,875 fans at Burnett Field.

This being the season for veal, a roast of that meat may have appeared in many households over the week-end. Rump is a popular cut. It may be purchased with the bone in -- a high wedge-shaped piece of meat -- or boned and rolled. A rolled rump roast usually has an added wrapping of fat, which melts and bastes the veal during cooking.

Plans for opening the first branch office of the Peoples State Bank of Baldwin, L. I., were announced yesterday in connection with the leasing of space in a new shopping center to be constructed on the west side of Grand Avenue, a major thoroughfare in Baldwin.
Rossini's "La Cenerentola" received its initial performance of the current season of the New York City Opera Company on Saturday night at the City Center.
Grants totalling $1,521,000 for the expansion of educational opportunities were announced yesterday by the Carnegie Corporation of New York.
Developments in the New York Central Railroad proxy battle over the week-end have resulted in another outbreak of name calling.

ZURICH, Switzlerland, April 4 -- A Swiss banking consortium led by the Swiss Bank Corporation and Credit Suisse and including the Union Bank of Switzerland and many private banks has guaranteed the placing of a loan of 50,000,000 Swiss francs ($11, 710,000) to Sweden.
WASHINGTON, April 4 (UP) -- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. urged Congress today to give to the courts power to impose the death penalty on persons convicted of peace-time spying.
Arturo Toscanini conducted his last concert with the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall yesterday.

Business returns have been watched more closely in March this year than in any month of recent record. The chief reason for this was a statement made by President Eisenhower at his press conference of Feb. 17 that a failure of employment to pick up seasonally in March would indicate the need for more drastic anti-depression action by the Government than was contemplated at the time.

The Chase National Bank had total resources of $5,549,140,238 last Wednesday, according to the statement of condition released yesterday. This campares with $5,562,461,665 on Dec. 31 and $5,437,494,346 on March 31, 1953.

NEW CITY, N. Y., April 5 -- Peter Thomas Van Lenten, 18 years old, who was arrested Jan. 12 under the name of Peter Galleher of Spring Valley, N. Y., was sentenced today to seventeen and one-half to thirty-five years for crimes committed in and around Spring Valley.

The fate of low-rent slum-clearance public housing now lies with the Senate, which in past years has, through its own affirmative action and its influence in conference, managed to its credit to keep this program alive.

LAST night's "information talk" by President Eisenhower was much his most successful television appearance. His warm human qualities came through on the home screen as they have not done since he entered the White House.

LONDON, April 5 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden pledged the British Government tonight to use every influence in its power to bring about "fruitful" high-level talks with the Soviet Union on control of the hydrogen bomb and easing of international tension.
CARROLLTON, Ga., April 5 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias, who announced yesterday she would quit competitive golf, has changed her mind.

Early-blooming magnolia trees were thwarted over the week-end in their efforts to bring a springtime effect to the city on schedule. Many of the pink and white blossoms already flowering were nipped by freezing temperatures and will not be on display again until next spring.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 5 -- A top executive of the American Management Association said here today that radical changes lie ahead in the nation's multibillion dollar packaging industry that will revolutionize policies and practices and produce packages with the ultimate in protection and selling values.

A suggestion that industrial advertising agencies improve their work by learning more of the product and its selling problems was advance yesterday by Carlton H. Winslow, vice president in charge of sales of the Cuno Engineering Corporation.
Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, board chairman of Eastern Air Lines, entered the Automobile Racing Hall of Fame yesterday and made far-reaching forecasts on war and peace.

A part of Manhattan, lying west in the Thirties, has been called Chelsea because, before the Revolution, Capt. Thomas Clarke, a British officer, veteran of our French and Indian Wars, built a house there overlooking the Hudson and gave to his considerable estate surrounding the house a name borrowed from England's royal hospital near London.

KARACHI, Pakistan, April 5 -- The immediate recall of United States Ambassador Horace A. Hildreth was demanded today by the United Front party. It charged that he made "uncalled-for remarks" last month when he said defeat of the Moslem League party in East Pakistan did not affect a recent decision by the United States to give military aid to Pakistan.

The twentieth anniversary of Youth Aliyah, a world-wide child rescue and rehabilitation movement through which 65,000 homeless Jewish children have been taken to Israel, was marked here yesterday. Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, which is the official agency of Youth Aliyah in this country, held a commemorative conference at the Pierre Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that the Alaska Steamship Company, Inc., was liable for damages because of the injury of an employe of a stevedoring concern on the vessel Susitna. The vote was 6 to 3.

Rocky Marciano, the world heavyweight champion, and Ezzard Charles, former titleholder, yesterday signed formal contracts for their fifteen-round title fight on Thursday night, June 17, at Yankee Stadium.

Trans World Airlines told the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday that it would start immediately a well-rounded schedule of service at Detroit and Cleveland if its application to include these cities on its westbound transcontinental routes is granted.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Congressional leaders looked to the White House today for help in deciding what to do about statehood for Hawaii and Alaska.

LONDON, April 5 -- A Laborite member sought the Government's assurance in the House of Commons today that former German Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz would not be allowed to assume any military position in the European Defense Community.
The cot%bn futures market onI the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday and closed 4 points lower to 6 points higher than on last Friday.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The United States warned the Chinese Communists today that they were approaching a form of undisguised aggression in Indo-China that might bring major retaliation.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 5 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet Thursday to take up the latest round of charges and counter-charges exchanged by Israel and her Arab neighbors.
ROME, April 5 -- The conference on "Music of the Twentieth Century" met this afternoon to elect a jury that will choose from among twelve works three to receive Twentieth Century Masterpiece prizes.
Guarding the very young and the elderly from accidents in the home was the theme of yesterday's meeting of the home safety division of the Greater New York Safety Council.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Recommendations that the State Department cut sharply the volume of reports its foreign missions send to Washington have been made by the investigations division of the Senate Appropriations Committee.

Four young American singers last night were named winners in the 1954 Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air. The announcement was made by Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan, during a program over the American Broadcasting Company network. The winners are:
MAMMOTH HOT SPRINGS, Wyo., April 5 -- Yellowstone National Park this week was like a man waiting for an avalanche with only a scoop shovel to dig himself out.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 5 -- One of the bloodiest battles in the fight for Dienbienphu resulted from a new attack by Communist-led Vietminh forces last night against a French defense point at the northern end of the main Dienbienphu airfield.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to review the trial of George Edward Grammer, who has been sentenced to hang for the murder of his wife in Baltimore.
COLUMBIA, S. C., April 5 (UP) -- The Tigers hammered Robin Roberts for six hits and five runs in the fifth inning to defeat the Phillies, 8 to 2, today in a game marked by a triple play.
The normally calm members of a Queens parent-teacher association engaged in such a heated wrangle last night on communism, McCarthyism and loyalty that it took a fire gong to disperse them.

Small hats, tipped forward or to one side and featuring combinations of straw with velvet, silk orgundy or dotted swiss, were the highlights of Anita Andra's showing of spring and summer millinery yesterday at the Carlton House. This shop,, at 558 Madison Avenue, stressed a detailed look, interlacing crowns or embellishing brims with applique.
Net income of the MorrisonKnudsen Company, Inc. and its domestic subsidiaries amounted to $5,761,420 last year, or slightly better than the $5,437,672 earned in 1952.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -The Department of Agriculture today announced provisions of the proposed order allotting the 1954 domestic beet sugar quota of 1,800,000 tons, raw value, among processors. The quota is equivalent to 33,644,860 hundredpound bags.

It is the proud boast of the private Negro colleges that in their first hundred years they have given this country most of its outstanding Negro leadership. Until the beginning of the present century they carried complete responsibility for the higher education of Negro youth.

For thirty-eight seconds on Sunday evening Arturo Toscanini's farewell concert with the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra was cut off the air, and for a few moments of that interval his recording of Brahms' First Symphony was sent out to fill the dead air.
Clinics set up here by local chapters of the American Cancer Society to detect hidden cancer in persons who believe they are well have not caught on.
Dr. Ralph J. Bunche expressed the belief yesterday that education now was in the "critical and thrilling" period of transition from segregation to integration.

WARREN, R. I., April 5 (AP) -- Miss Liberty, a new ferryboat to be put into service on the Statue of Liberty run in New York Harbor about June 15, was saved from getting an "unlucky" label at her launching today by the action of a bystander.
Mayor Wagner signed a bill yesterday putting off to July 1 the date when stock taxicabs may be used here.
Under new management, the Bucks County Playhouse at New Hope, Pa., one of the better-known summer theatres, will reopen its doors on May 29.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., April 5 -- Mrs. Louis Jacques Balsan, the former Consuelo Vanderbilt and Duchess of Marlborough, has sold her 135-acre Oyster Bay estate, Easton, fronting on Route 25-A, to a syndicate that proposes to develop a country club.
Two Dalessio brothers, described as the kingpins of book- making and racketeering on Staten Island, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of income tax evasion.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 5 -- Inter-American air defense is becoming more complicated. Little or no attempt is being made to attain unification of equipment.
NEW ORLEANS, April 5 (UP) -- Johnny Klippstein, with a one- hitter for seven innings, and Jim Brosnan combined to pitch the Cubs to a 2-to-0 victory over the Orioles today before 1,062 fans.
WASHINGTON, April 4 -- The Eisenhower Administration is gradually slipping into a manpower crisis at the top policy and Civil Service levels of the Government.

Direct verbal attacks on racial or religious prejudice are for the most part futile, Dr. Charles S. Johnson, sociologist and president of Fisk University, told the American Public Relations Association yesterday.
For the first time in more than a month, business failures in the week ended April 1 showed a decline.

DEAL, N. J., April 5 -- This community received today official thanks of the people of Deal, England, from which this town takes its name, for aid the people here sent to the British community during World War II.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The House of Representatives today voted to give the President permanent emergency powers for civilian defense, after being told that the danger of enemy attack was as great now, if not greater, than in 1950.
LOS ANGELES, April 5 -- A double-barrled cancer treatment at has proved helpful in some advanced cases of the disease in women was reported today by our Los Angeles doctors.

NOW that the Circle In the Square has been moved into the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, playgoers who are interested have a unique opportunity to compare arena staging with proscenium staging. The play is the same one that was delighting so many people downtown before the Fire Commissioner condemned the slum in Sheridan Square.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today struck a blow at moonshiners.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The statement read by Secretary of State Dulles before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today follows:

Two five-story buildings containing forty-five apartments at 660 and 664 East 166th Street in the Bronx were sold by the estate of Eugenie C. Wahlig to Lessam Equities, Inc., which resold them to a client of Sol Polan, lawyer.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 5 (AP) -- Capt. C. E. Loughlin, commanding a submarine squadron in the Pacific, has been ordered to report to the Nval Academy as director of athletics, the Navy Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Interstate Commerce Commission did not have the power to initiate the merger or consolidation of two railroads.
Eugene Gordon, 29 years old, a former Air Force flier, was found dead yesterday in his Greenwich Village apartment at 15 Leroy Street from an overdose of Sleeping pills.
One of the first attempts by recreation specialists to make the hours by young campers traveling to camp sites more productive and enjoyable was revealed yesterday.

THE form chart supplies a reasonably reliable index in every sport -- except one. Although favorites occasionally are upset in all fields of athletics, it's usually safe to string along with the Yankees in baseball, Notre Dame in football, a Native Dancer in horse racing, a Rocky Marciano in boxing and other champions who have made winning a habit. Their innate class invariably caries them to the top.

Homeowners with a liking for antiques, particularly furniture of the much desired early American varieties, will find a fine field for exploration at the Country Antiques Fair. The fair opened yesterday at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Supreme Court overruled today the permament disbarment from Federal courts of Harold Sacher, a New York lawyer who served as a counsel in the 1949 trial of eleven Communist leaders.
LONDON, April 5 -- Confidence and activity were apparent in almost all sections of the stock markets here today.

Donations to the New York Regional Red Cross blood program on Friday totaled 796 pints of blood. Included in that amount were 304 pints taken at Fordham University on the second of a two-day donation totaling 589, and 375 taken at City College on the second of a two-day donation totaling 573. Saturday's collection totaled 320 pints.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today ruled Maryland could not make out-of-state dealers liable for collection of a 2 per cent use tax on goods sold at retail and delivered to Maryland customers.

Senator McCarthy's committee is to decide today whether it will retain Samuel P. Sears, its original choice for committee counsel in the dispute between Mr. McCarthy and the Army. Although Mr. Sears has stated that he had taken no position on "McCarthy or McCarthyism," it developed after he had been selected as counsel that he had taken just such a position as long ago as 1952 and as recently as 1954.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, April 5 -- Reserve policemen and British troops were alerted tonight after minor disturbances that led to the rearrest of Dr. Cheddi B. Jagan, former Prime Minister, and thirty-three of his followers.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Girl high school and college graduates of 1954 face more competition for jobs than did those of last year.

Earnings of Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, construction concern, are expected to equal if not exceed last year's record of $3,494,688, Louis E. Wolfson, president and chairman, reported at yesterday's annual stockholder meeting in the Midston House.

Surrogate William T. Collins set up a dual guardianship yesterday for the two sons of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg, executed atomic spies. Thereby he sought to "insure them an approximately normal and secure life, a life free from publicity and contention."
LONDON, April 5 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from the speeches by Prime Minister Churchill and former Prime Minister Attlee in the House of Commons today:

CHICAGO, April 5 -- Bullish weather and crop news from the Southwest spurred buying in the early trade today, but later the market turned reactionary and suffered substantial recessions compared with the close last Friday.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Brig. Gen. Robert R. Neyland Jr., athletic director of the University of Tennessee and retired Army engineer, is being considered for appointment as chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
After a year's absence the flag of Turkey is being seen again in local waters.
A Federal Court jury of five women and seven men was selected yesterday to try Frank Costello on charges of evasion of $73,437 in income taxes for the years 1946 through 1949.
DURHAM, N. C., April 5 -- The faculty of Duke University has voted against awarding an honorary degree to one of the university's most distinguished graduates, Vice President Richard M. Nixon.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy left here by plane for Phoenix, Ariz., yesterday. He left behind the unanswered question of who would pay a reported $7,500 production cost for the filming of an address he made for Edward R. Murrow's television program.

TRENTON, April 5 -- Three unidentified young men escaped with $2,209 in cash and $39,546 in checks after staging a mid-day hold-up here today. The incident occurred a few blocks from the New Jersey State Prison in front of a branch of the Broad Street National Bank.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The American Medical Association went on record today against the Administration's health reinsurance plan as a possible "opening wedge" for socialized medicine.

TEANECK, N. J., April 5 -- Two resourceful mothers and the Parent-Teacher Association of Washington Irving School here have joined forces to produce a booklet that may well influence the week-end plans of countless families hereabout.

A WEEK-END survey indicated fine stream conditions for opening day of the trout season in New York, as well as all adjoining states, with many streams running clear and much lower than normal for this time of year.

PETER MATTHIESSEN'S first novel, "Race Rock,"* is written so well that one wishes that its characters were more worth writing about. There is an atmosphere of emotional tension and impending catastrophe in these somewhat florid pages which is highly effective. Mr. Matthiessen strains occasionally into overly ornate writing and disconcertingly artificial metaphors, but for the most part he writes with feverish skill and a poet's feeling for words.

PARIS, April 5 -- Secretary of State Dulles' statement that Chinese Communists were participating in the Vietminh action against Dienbienphu received partial confirmation here today. Officials said it had been known that for a long time the Chinese had been present at all echelons of the Vietminh Army, including command headquarters.
SHREVEPORT, La., April 5 -- Second-line pitching, until today almost too good to be true failed the Giants this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- A New York statute that forbade national banks to use the word "savings" in advertising or in conducting their business was struck down by the Supreme Court today.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Supreme Court ruled today, 8 to 0, that "give-away" programs on radio and television did not violate the lottery laws.
NEW DELHI, India, April 5 -- India has delivered new protest notes to France and Portugal regarding happenings in their Indian possessions.

Forty-three employes of the Metropolitan Opera Company, whose service totals 1,623 years, were honored last evening on the Metropolitan stage between scenes of "Pagliacci." The other half of the bill was "Cavalleria Rusticana."

Stocks moved in desperate fashion yesterday and ended the day barely changed. Some little strength for a handful of industrials -- notably tobaccos, metals and papers -- was enough to offset the slump in rails.

BOSTON, April 5 (AP) -- The wife of .Senator 1VcCarthy rec:I ommended 1Vr, Sears as the one[ to defend her husband's posltiori[ in a debate at Boston last March il,. the chairman of the forum. that sponsored the debate said today.

The Rev. Montague White, one of four co-pastors at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, was unanimously elected Moderator of the Presbytery of New York yesterday. The Presbytery includes sixty-two churches in Manhattan, Staten Island and the Bronx.

Another phase of the reorganization of the Police Department's Emergency Service Division was completed yesterday when Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams put into service six new light-duty emergency vehicles.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- President Eisenhower will throw out the first pitch of the baseball season on April 13 and this year he is determined not to hit any umpires.
CHICAGO, April 5 (AP) -- Hor prices nosed into new high territory todv in a strong to 50 cents higher trade. Trading slowed toward the close, but clearance was easily completed.
Eighty pieces of modern painting, drawing and sculpture filled the graduate women's lounge at Columbia University yesterday as the sixth annual students' art show opened in Philosophy Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Capt. James A. Van Fleet Jr., only son of Gen. James A. Van Fleet, former commander of the United States Eight Army, was officially listed as dead today. The announcement came two years after the captain's twin-engine bomber had vanished behind Communist lines in Korea.
GREENSBORO, N. C., April 5 (AP) -- Doug, Ford celebrated his tenth wedding anniversary today by outshooting Marty Furgol, 72 to 75, to win the Greensboro open golf tournament play-off.
Let's not have any further delay in the construction of the New York Coliseum.
A double investigation into an abortion ring accused of a woman's death led yesterday to the arrest of four persons and charges that a number of physicians were involved.

ALBANY, April 5 -- The New York City Board of Elections asked the Court of Appeals today for permission to submit a brief in oppostion to the legislative reapportionment plan approved by the Legislature last November. The court reserved decision.

New designs in gas ranges that include more exact control of burner flames and more even heat distribution in oven and broiler have been created by engineers of the American Gas Association Laboratories. Now it is up to appliance manufacturers to put them into production.
The city's first metered parking lot, in Flushing, Queens, will start collecting coins April 26 with Mayor Wagner scheduled to preside at the opening ceremony.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- President Eisenhower declared tonight that communism could not prevail against the spiritual and material might of the United States.

Bill Konig, a 19-year-old righthander, sent City College off to a sparkling start yesterday in defense of its Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference crown. He pitched the Beavers to a 7-to-1 triumph over New York University in the opening contest of the league race.

ROME, April 5 -- During a one-and - a - half - hour conversation, Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce, United States Ambassador, discussed with Premier Mario Scelba all the principal problems of common Italian-American interest, with special reference to United States aid.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "The Girl in Pink Tights" on the night of April 20 at the Mark Hellinger Theatre for the benefit of the Bryn Mawr College Alumnae Regional Scholarship Fund of New York and Southern Connecticut.

Robert Lowe Kunzig, counsel to the House Committee on Un-American Activities, urged yesterday legislation to make evidence obtained by wire-tapping permissible in the Federal courts. He also said prosecuting officers should be allowed to grant immunity to witnesses accused of being Communists, to prevent their using the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution as a basis of refusal to testify.
TRENTON, April 5 -- The New Jersey Legislature extended an invitation to the New York Stock Exchange today to move to this state and escape "excessive" taxation.
MONTREAL, April 5 -- Fred Rose, who was Canada's only Communist member of Parliament until his arrest in 1946 for involvement in a Soviet espionage ring, will be joined in Poland soon by his family.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 5 -- Police Commissioner John M. Beckmann of Nassau County ordered county policemen today to be more vigilant in areas near the Long Island Rail Road to prevent vandalism on railroad property.

BONN, Germany, April 5 (AP) -- Dr. Thomas Dehler, chairman of the West German Free Democratic party, announced today he would ask the United States to try to break the French-German deadlock over the Saar.

New York housing officials have submitted to the State Rent Commission the names of eight landlords who have failed to remove tenement violations after court convictions. The action was taken to implement a decision by State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick to impose 50 per cent rent deductions on landlords convicted of practices dangerous to life and health.
At bayonet point France is fashioning in the sweltering valley around Dienbienphu a new epic of martial valor that could have greater significance in history than the hydrogen bomb.

TOKYO, April 5 -- Japan will make a new offer to the Philippines for the payment of reparations, it was reported today. The move will be an attempt to stave off a breakdown in the three-year-old negotiations and possible final rejection by the Philippine Republic of the peace treaty signed at San Francisco in 1951.

PARIS, April 5 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin indicated today that Premier Joseph Laniel and Foreign Minister Georges Bidault had supported his refusal to resign his North Atlantic Treaty Organization post unless his terms on a successor were met.

" Seduction of the Innocent," by Dr. Fredric Wertham, a phyisician, will he published April 19 by Rinehart. It is a report on the influence of comic books on youth. Dr. Wertham declares that these publications are an invitation to illiteracy, that they cause an atmosphere of cruelty and deceit, suggest criminal or sexually abnormal ideas and lead to temptation. He suggests as a remedy "a public-health approach to legislation on the subject."

Ralph (Tiger) Jones, fourthranking middleweight, gained the unanimous decision over Billy McNeece, Central Islip, L. I., in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

IT is in their severe, sullen romanticism that Alan Reynolds' slightly grim pastorals, at Durlachers, excel. Reynolds is an up and coming young English artist who chooses to paint near the village of Shoreham in Kent the very scene that inspired the mystical landscapes of Samuel Palmer.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs decreased to the lowest point in more than five weeks.

The eighth game in the match for the chess championship of the world between Mikhail Botvinnik, titleholder, and Vassily Smyslov contested in Moscow, resulted in a draw after fifty moves, according to reports received here yesterday. Botvinnik conducted the white pieces.

With the annual meeting of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company set for a week from tomorrow, new charges and counter charges were hurled yesterday in the battle for control of the $500,000,000 system.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Coffee prices jumped again today and one roaster said the day might not be far off when housewives would be paying $1.50 a pound for the bean in the grocery.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Key Democrats questioned today whether it was suitable for Samuel P. Sears, Boston lawyer, to remain as chief counsel investigating the Army dispute with Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Confronted with mounting alarm over the devastating potentialities of the hydrogen bomb, both President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Churchill spoke yesterday to urge the free world to look upon the favorable aspects of our position -- the "counter-balancing factors," as the President called them -- and to face the new peril of the bomb without panic or hysteria.
Justice Jane M. Bolin of the Domestic Relations Court urged last night that the various family courts be merged.
WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The House Labor Committee approved in detail today a Taft-Hartley amendment to require Government-sponsored secret votes before a union could strike. The vote was 16 to 8.

CAIRO, April 5 -- Egypt's military rulers announced tonight their intention to discipline the three elements most vocal in their opposition to the revolutionary regime -- the press, university students and old-line politicians.

MOSCOW, April 5 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union agreed today to the main "technical arrangements" proposed by the three Western powers for the Geneva conference on the Far East opening April 26. The Soviet acceptance was made in a memorandum handed to Charles E. Bohlen, United States Ambassador, by Vassily Kuznetsov, Deputy Foreign Minister.

BERLIN, April 5 -- East Germany's Communists eliminated the post of party chairman today and thus left Walter Ulbricht as the sole leader at the top of the party structure. He is First Secretary of the Central Committee.

Robert W. Fisher, vice president of Blyth Co., Inc., was appointed yesterday director of a committee of New York financiers to promote the Treasury's sale of Series H savings bonds in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

COCOS ISLANDS, Indian Ocean, April 5 (Reuters) -- Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh received the most sedate welcome of their Commonwealth tour today when they paid a ninety- minute visit to this tropical paradise [cross on map].

SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 -- Federal narcotic agents, who posed as wholesalers and bought heroin at "bargain prices," have smashed a ring that was preparing to send millions of dollars' worth of narcotics into the domestic traffic.

THACA, N. Y., April 5 -- A bipartisan Presidential commission to study the implications of the new hydrogen weapons was recommended by James Reston. Washington correspondent of The New York Times, speaking this evening at Cornell University.

BOSTON, April 5 -- Otis Archer Hood, long-time head of the Communist party in Massachusetts, was arraigned in Boston Municipal Court today in what was considered the first test case of a 1951 law outlawing the party in this commonwealth. Judge Daniel J. Gillen set bail at $10,000. The case was continued until April 15.

Attendance has been large at the four-day show of the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America, which opened Sunday at the New Yorker Hotel. The reduction in the excise tax on luggage from 20 to 10 per cent helped account for the interest.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 5 (UP) -- A state of modified martial law was imposed throughout Nicaragua today following an unsuccessful week-end attempt to assassinate President Anastasio Somoza.
ALBANY, April 5 -- Three bills designed to end a $25,000,000-a-year fraud by phony "charity" promoters were signed today by Governor Dewey.
Jimmy Savo, arch exponent of the art of pantomime, will return to Broadway next season in a musical based on his short novel, "Little World, Hello."

The Safeway Stores, Inc., is offering stockholders rights to subscribe to 267,700 shares of $100 par value 4.3% convertible stock at $100.35 a share on the basis of one new share for each thirteen of common stock held yesterday.
OTTAWA, April 5 -- The fiscal year just ended was the most prosperous in Canada's history.

NAPLES, Italy, April 5 -- The colors of the fourteen Atlantic Alliance powers were flown from flagpoles for the first time today outside the new headquarters of the Allied Forces, Southern Europe in Bagnoli near Naples. The fifth anniversary of the Atlantic pact was celebrated at the same time as the new headquarters was being dedicated.
The trial of the Jarka Corporation and its president, Frank W. Nolan, on charges of bribing steamship executives to obtain stevedoring business, opened yesterday in Special Sessions.
WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -February upturn in sales -- the first in five months -- was reported today by the Department of Commerce.

Pension plans and increased vacation time will be the highlights of negotiations of two merchant marine officer unions when they begin talks with shipowners for new contracts to follow the ones that expire on June 15.

A man must only look at the painting, open the book. At most, space or mechanics stands between him and the artist. But with music, all the composer's hope of communication hangs on the ability of other artists, the musicians. These secondary creators are as necessary to the composer's fulfillment as the public's sight and literacy are to painter and writer.
ALBANY, April 5 (AP) -- One has to have newspaper credentials if he wants to look at the official "public" transcript of debate in the State Senate.
DETROIT, April 5 (AP) -- Michigan Democrats demanded free radio and television time today to answer Vice President Richard M. Nixon's speech of Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Two European wars within a quarter century, in which the United States ultimately became a participant, the loss of China to the Communists and the military stalemate in Korea produced two theories which have been widely accepted.

PARIS, April 5 -- A Vietminh column of 20,000 men was reported here tonight to be heading toward Dienbienphu to strengthen the battered force that has been trying without success to seize the isolated fortress from its French Union defenders.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, disclosed tonight that the British-United States agreement on the use of atomic bombs had been canceled in 1948 by mutual consent of the two Governments.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 5 -- The "trial" here of Dr. Goodwin Watson on charges of championing "objectives of the Communist conspiracy" awaited today the next move of the accuser -- The Americanism Commission of the Westchester County American Legion.
LOS ANGELES, April 5 -James Roosevelt said today that he was going to stay in the race for Congress despite the disapproval of the Democratic National Chairman, Stephen A. Mitchell.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, April 5 -- Warner Brothers will do its part to help increase the pace of film production, which has been lagging in Hollywood for several months. Jack L. Warner announced today that the company had twelve pictures in preparation for filming between now and the early summer.
A ground-air search was started late yesterday afternoon for an Air Force jet pilot who disappeared shortly after taking off on instruments in a heavy overcast at Farmingdale, L. I.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) -- Norman Thomas testified today that to outlaw the Communist party would be unconstitutional and would make it harder for the Federal Bureau Investigation and the public to kep tabs on Red activities.
MOBILE, Ala., April 5 (AP) -- Southpaw Bobby Shantz allowed only three hits today but one of them was a home run by Frank Thomas that enabled the Pirates to defeat the Athletics, 1 -- 0.
TRENTON, ,April 5 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court reaffirmed today its ruling that nonsigners of sales agreements are bound by the state's Fair Trade Act.

A portrait of President Eisenhower in academic garb was presented yesterday to Columbia University. The painting, 40x50 inches, shows Mr. Eisenhower, who is president emeritus of the university, wearing the hood of the Honorary Doctor of Laws degree he received from Columbia in 1947.
Following is the text of President Eisenhower's address last night to the nation on "Multiplicity of Fears," as recorded by The New York Times:

I have read with the greatest interest your editorial of April 3 "Heroism at Dienbienphu." Certainly the defenders of Dienbienphu have earned our highest admiration and praise, and I should like to express my special appreciation to the writer of this editorial for pointing out that in this dark and heroic moment Vietnamese troops are fighting alongside the gallant troops of the French Union.

DETROIT, April 5 -- The Lincoln-Mercury division of the Ford Motor Company announced today that, because of marketing changes, it was eliminating second shifts at its assembly plants in Metuchen, N. J., and St. Louis.

LONDON, April 5 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the 1943 agreement between Prime Minister Churchill and President Roosevelt on the atomic bomb, as revealed by the Prime Minister today. Publication was approved by President Eisenhower, but the White House said the agreement was no longer in effect:
CHATTANOOGA, April 5 -- For the second time this spring three Brooklyn pitchers combined to pitch a shutout today and the Dodgers beat the Braves, 6 -- 0, before 3,100 fans at Engel Stadium.

In Topics of The Times, that most delightful column where we may find spiritual escape and a measure of felicity from the tumult and shouting of McCarthyism versus its enemies, the writer on March 28 makes some serious historical distortions when he says, "The Cypriotes, who * * * are now demanding union with the Greek monarchy, lost their great chance for that in the early days of the First World War.

Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, coffee, rubber, potatoes and silk were lower; wool, copper, lead, tin and burlap closed higher, and sugar, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc and hides ended mixed.

The Voice of America announced yesterday that it had arranged for some 30,000,000 persons in thirteen foreign countries to see and hear President Eisenhower's report to the nation within forty-eight hours of its delivery.
It is unlawful to make a turkey crouch.
Roosevelt Raceway has sold its majority voting stock in Yonkers Raceway for $1,750,000.
JONES BEACH, L. I., April 5 -- A shorter, quicker route to Fire Island State Park will be ready for summer visitors by July 1.

All common shares of American Woolen Company deposited with Textron, Inc., have been accepted by the latter company. At the same time Textron announced that it would extend its offer for American Woolen common on the existing exchange basis until April 19 provided 50,000 additional shares are deposited.

An Interstate Commerce Commission hearing was begun yesterday at 70 Columbus Avenue on a petition of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company for permission to abandon its Christopher Street ferry to Hoboken, N. J.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 5 -- The United Nations Disarmament Commission will meet Friday to establish a subcommittee that will make a closed-door study of the atomic-disarmament problem.

FREEPORT, L. I., April 5 -- Bomb scares that have plagued Nassau schools for a week and a half have lost their humor, County Executive A. Holly Patterson said today in appealing to pupils to "quit this epidemic."
Dallas, Tex., sold $8,800,000 of various purpose bonds in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.1139 per cent for a combination of 5s, 1 1/2s, 1 3/4s, 2s and 2 1/4s.

THE story of the World War II infantryman has been told more effectively than it is in Harry Brown's drama, "A Sound of Hunting." But the play about a squad of filthy and irritable, but not dispirited doughfeet near Cassino in 1944, has been given a rousing presentation in the revival that opened last night at the Cherry Lane Theatre under the sponsorship of Trio Productions and Yale Wexler.
Turn-to's racing days are ended. The Cain Hoy colt, who was a Kentucky Derby favorite until a bowed tendon forced his withdrawal, was retired yesterday by his owner, Harry F. Guggenheim.

Princeton University and faculty members will conduct a series of eight educational television programs beginning April 17. Marking Princeton's first venture into television, the series will be presented over Station WNBT (Channel 4) on Saturdays from 5:30 to 6 P. M.
Fourteen thousand members of rival dock unions worked side by side yesterday to clear the piers of cargo that had piled up during the port's worst strike.

Showroom space on the north side of the ground floor of the eighteen - story office building nearing completion at 430 Park Avenue, between Fifty-fifth and Fifty-sixth Street, has been leased by the Hoffman Motor Car Company, Inc., sales agent for foreign-make automobiles.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 5 (AP) -- Blankets rolled up in tin cans are on the way. A blanket wrapped in moth-proof armor was one of many new gadgets displayed here today at the opening of the American Management Association's National Packaging Exposition.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., April 5 -- The Yankees today still weren' performing in the flawless man net Charles Dillon Stengel, o most anyone else, for that matter would expect of five-time world champions.

As you know, many of the best Filipino musicians died in the last war and musical instruments were lost or destroyed. The only concert auditorium in the Philippines was bombed beyond repair, and the first post-war concert in 1945 was held in the ruins of a Catholic church in Santa Cruz, Manila.

Spokesmen for the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, the United States Public Health Service and leading pharmaceutical manufacturers of the new vaccine for polio stood firmly behind their earlier assurances yesterday that the vaccine was safe.

WASHINGTON, April 5 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to sit in judgment in a case that might spell out whether some $100,000,000 of Government tankers sold at bargain counter prices as surplus property helped prominent people to make huge profits legally.
CLEVELAND, April 5 (AP) -William White, president of the New York Central Railroad, said today his railroad was holding up transfer of 800,000 shares of its stock to two friends of Robert R. Young.

GENEVA, April 6 (AP) -- Military, medical and legal experts from ten nations met secretly here today to study the means available under international law of protecting civilians in wartime against new weapons perfected since the adoption of the 1949 Geneva Conventions.

A tract of 30,000 square feet at Twenty-first Avenue and Chestnut Street in Paterson, N. J., has been leased from the Brown Brothers Investing Company by Peter Mavris and Frank Lami who plan to erect a restaurant there. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker in the transaction.
LONDON, April 6 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer R. A. Butler offered to Parliament today a budget that contained no major changes of policy.

OTTAWA, April 6 -- Another year at least as prosperous as the last was predicted tonight by D. C. Abbott, Minister of Finance, when he produced a budget providing for the heaviest Government spending in Canada's peacetime history.
Maj. Gen. Roger J. Browne, vice commander of the Continental Air Command, appealed yesterday for "a consistent military policy to attain "security with solvency," as sought by President Eisenhower.
Governor Dewey yesterday was urged by the Independent Motion Picture Distributors Association to call an open hearing on the proposed new movie censorship bill before signing it.
ALBANY, April 6 -- Three bills designed to promote better working and living conditions for migrant farm laborers in the state were approved today by Governor Dewey.

The trial of the Jarka Corporation, one of the largest stevedoring companies in the world, and its president, Frank W. Nolan, was halted yesterday when both defendants pleaded guilty to charges of commercial bribing.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Rowland R. Hughes, Deputy Director of the Budget, was chosen today by President Eisenhower to become Budget Director on April 15, when Joseph M. Dodge retires.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 6 -- The tortured battlefield of Dienbienphu was relatively quiet last night.

Books, not leopardskin purses or odd-shaped umbrellas, will be the accessories on 125th Street this Friday evening when teenagers put on a fashion show at the George Bruce Branch of the New York Public Library.

The forty-eight Brooklyn Democratic district leaders were still deadlocked last night on a successor to Kenneth F. Sutherland, who is ready to step out as county leader when his associates agree on a new chieftain. An election is scheduled for tomorrow morning at Democratic headquarters in the Jefferson Building.
GATLINBURG, Tenn., March -- Financial problems are beating the Great Smoky Mountains National Park.
PARIS, April 6 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin was publicly rebuked today by the North Atlantic Council for having spoken against the European army treaty.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 6 -- The United States, in pre-war years the third largest trader with the Soviet world, exported goods valued at only $1,000,000 to countries behind the Iron Curtain in 1953.

STAMFORD, Conn., April 6 -- Passengers riding on a bus between Stamford and New Canaan today were not lonely. In fact, they had enough company to run a railroad. When the passengers boarded the vehicle at the local station of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, they were surprised to learn that they had three chaperons.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A new foreign aid program of $3,497,000,000, one-third of which would be spent to support anti-Communist forces in Indo-China, was submitted to Congress today.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The United States retains, untrameled by foreign agreements, its power to use atomic bombs.
Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Richard A. Butler, "opened" his third budget yesterday since taking office.

American-flag ship operators and exporters should work together as a team to foster foreign trade in the mutual interest, speakers declared yesterday at the monthly luncheon of the Export Managers Club in the Statler Hotel.

The House Labor Committee has approved an amendment to the Taft-Hartley Law requiring the Government to sponsor secret strike votes. Failure to comply would permit employers to discharge strike leaders and to use other forms of discipline. Meanwhile the union or individual could not ask the National Labor Relations Board to hold elections or to investigate complaints.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 6 -- A petition signed by 1,571 students of the University of Texas urged H. R. Cullen today to "reconsider" his invitation to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to be the San Jacinto Day speaker here April 21.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Senate Internal Security subcommittee heard today that shortly before the end of World War II the executive perhaps closest to the Secretary of the Treasury predicted the collapse of the American economic system within ten years.

The combined net premiums written by the American Fidelity and Casualty Company and its subsidiary, the American Fidelity Fire Insurance Company, in 1953 reached the highest volume on record, the twenty-eighth annual report of one of the country's largest insurers of trucks and buses showed yesterday.
KANSAS CITY, April 6 (AP) -- Former President Truman said today the British-American wartime atomic agreement still was in effect.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Federal Government argued in the Supreme Court today that it did not have statutory power to regulate prices of natural gas sold by producers to interstate pipeline companies.

What may be the biggest fish story of all time will be told beginning today at the American Museum of Natural History. It is the museum's new permanent exhibit, tracing the 400,000,000-year history of fishes.
The 390th birthday of Shakespeare will be celebrated by the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy at a luncheon to be held April 29 at the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican of Michigan, announced today he was drafting legislation to strip citizenship from members of the Comunist party or those who gave "allegiance to communism."

HANOI, Vietnam, April 6 -- High French military sources here say they have no evidence that the Communist Chinese have taken part in the fighting at Dienbienphu. They say the French never have killed or captured a combatant with the Vietminh that they could definitely identify as Chinese.
GREENSBORO, N. C., April 6 -- If it is work that the Yankees need to whip themselves into shape for that momentous sixth straight pennant drive, they got it today.

THE Museum of Modern Art will open today to the public the first major retrospective exhibition in this country of paintings and prints by the distinguished French painter, Edouard Vuillard (1868-1940).

Joseph Gavegnano's Coastal Light beat Old Baasket, running in the silks of Stephen Messana, in the main race at the Jamaica track yesterday. The six-furlong event, called the Apache, attracted eight starters, and the competition among four of them was enough to thrill the crowd of 23,588 right down to the wire.
Coffee and butter prices gave retail grocers a big headache yesterday.
BERLIN, April 6 -- The Soviet Union took under advisement today a western proposal to release temporarily from Spandau Prison those of the top seven surviving Nazis who might need hospitalization.
Hopes r fears--that workers will be replaced universally in, the automatlc factory of tomor-J row were branded as "unadulter-] ated rubbish" yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Construction in the first quarter this year reached record figures, the Department of Labor and Commerce reported today.
MONTREAL, April 6 -- One of Canada's oldest shipping services was discontinued today because of lack of business.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower pointed to the Arctic area on a world map today and told the last survivor of Admiral Peary's expedition to the North Pole: "Now we have air bases all along there."

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Thomas P. Pike of Los Angeles to be an Assistant Secretary of Defense in charge of supplies. Mr. Pike now is a Deputy Assistant Secretary.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Eisenhower program and communism will be main issues of the 1954 Congressional campaign, the Republican National Chairman told 1,200 Republican women leaders tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The American Medical Association today denounced parts of President Eisenhower's Social Security program, but some members of the House of Representatives questioned whether the association could speak for most physicians.

How long will we as a people who were supposed to have had the advantage of first developing atomic weapons subjugate ourselves to the fear of what others may do to us with that same weapon or with other instruments of destruction?
An offer by the Henney Motor Company of Freeport, Ill., to buy for $16,500,000 all of the assets of Reo Motors, Inc., and to assume the latter's liabilities, has been accepted by the Reo directors.

MARION, Ohio, April 6 (AP) -- The Marion Power Shovel Company at an annual meeting yesterday reduced its board of directors from fifteen to eleven members as proposed by the management's proxy committee.

ANOTHER few weeks should find the pollock, known in some angling circles as "Boston blues," making an appearance off Montauk, and those who have become converts to ultra-light tackle fishing during the past year will have an opportunity to test their skill.

LOS ANGELES, April 6 -- Intimations of a stiff row between the Democratic party and its California segment developed today over the controversial Congressional candidacies of James Roosevelt and Representative Robert L. Condon.

" I DON'T believe what I know is true," said young Dr. Andrew Carew, trying to find words for his agonizing spiritual dilemma. Andrew was mourning the death of his Roman Catholic faith while admitting in the same breath that it was still so vitally alive within him that he would never know peace again.

The landlord of an East Harlem tenement at 106 East 106th Street, whose failure to pay utility bills left sixteen families without gas, electricity, heat and hot water for nearly two weeks, was sentenced yesterday to ninety days in jail.
LOS ANGELES, April 6 (AP) -- Porterhouse, champion 2-year-old colt of 1953 and favored to win the Kentucky Derby on May 1, may not be able to start in the Louisville race, his owner said today.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 6 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox routed Chet Nichols in the third inning today and went on to defeat the Milwaukee Braves, 10 -- 5, in the opener of their six-game exhibition baseball series.
If the United Nations should ever tire of spreading the world about brotherhood, the students of Public School 9, West End Avenue and Eighty-second Street, stand ready to help them out.

It is fitting that today, the sixth birthday of the World Health Organization, should be called World Health Day. It comes as a reminder of the monumental effort that WHO, in cooperation with the United Nation's Children's Fund and technical agencies, is making to combat disease and ignorance in backward areas of the world and to strengthen the public health services in scores of countries.

The Newspaper Guild of New York, C. I. O., announced yesterday its annual Page One awards. The list was headed by Edward R. Murrow, television and radio commentator, who won the prize in the field of public affairs for "distinguished contributions to the adult and responsible use of broadcasting as a major medium of information and enlightenment.''

TRENTON, April 6 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner will accept tomorrow on behalf of New Jersey a faded parchment bearing the seal of King George I. One of the oldest existing documents relating to the Colonial period in this state, it is to be preserved among Jersey's official archives.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands; April 6 -- The United States found only five friends at court here today.

As one of the observances of the 200th anniversary of Columbia University, there was presented last night in Brander Matthews Hall a revival of the original version of "The Beggar's Opera," first performed in New York by the Hallam Company in the season of 1753-54, that number of years ago.

" Everybody agrees, more or less, that houses and other buildings today have to be modern," Ernesto Rogers, the Italian architect, said when interviewed before he departed for home last weekend. "But what kind of modern -- that's the problem."
WASHINGTON, April 6 -Chinese, along with English, French and Russian, will be an official language at the coming Geneva meeting on Korea and Indo-China.

A[embers of the %Voman's Auxiliary Day Branch of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church have amnged their annual card party and tea for the aftmmoon of April 22 in St. Bartholomew's Community House, 109 East Fiftieth Street.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 6 -- Battle lines were drawn today for an epic war over Westchester County's telephone books.
A fabulous ecclesiastical crown from South America went on exhibit yesterday at Black Starr Gorharn, Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street. It will be on view through April 17.

The "Amos 'n' Andy" television film program has been purchased by the British Broadcasting Corporation for showing to its viewers beginning April 21. The B. B. C. also has bought another American television film, "Range Rider," which is scheduled to start in England in July.
ALBANY, April 6 -- Governor Dewey approved today a tough program for the regulation of the state's scandal-shaken harness racing industry.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -The Civil Aeronautics Administration said today it has started a preliminary study of possible certification of the British turboprop transport, the Vickers Viscount, for airline operation in the United States.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission today announced approval of three more agreements with industrial concerns to join in the cooperative search for practical peacetime uses of atomic energy.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -A fight over a new formula for Federal highway aid to the states tonight forced delay in Senate consideration of a $2,000,000,000 two-year road-aid program.

Now that we have the facts about the hydrogen bomb it should become clear that the doctrine of "massive retaliation" is the most repulsive foreign policy ever seriously proposed on behalf of the American people.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 6 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council ratified today a recommendation by as Committee on Nongovernmental Organizations that the Women's International Democratic Federation be dropped from consultative status.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Leaders today predicted a hard fight in the House of Representatives tomorrow over the "anti-traitor" bill to make wiretap evidence admissible in Federal courts.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) -- Charles A. Lindbergh, first man to fly the Atlantic alone, was chosen today to help pick the site for the first Air Force Academy.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 6 -- Development of a container of "unbelievable" strength made of glass fibers for packaging delicate guided missiles was described here today at the American Management Association's twenty-third National Packaging Conference at Convention Hall.

The Arkansas Fuel Oil Corporation, which underwent corporate simplification and merger proceedings in 1953 as successor to the Arkansas Natural Gas Corporation, reported yesterday gross operating revenues of $135,376,000 in 1953.

Certain aspects of the passing show are characterized by the fact that they never have to change. Variety in this category is anathema. Not to be mysterious about these certain aspects, here is a sampling.
The Government told a Federal jury yesterday that it would prove "by simple arithmetic" that Frank Costello had cheated it of taxes because he had spent far more than his declared income.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, April 6 (AP) -- Two United States soldiers, prisoners of the Russians since yesterday, were released today on orders of Gen. A. A. Grechko, the Soviet commander in Germany.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Samuel P. Sears resigned under fire today only five days after he had been named chief counsel for the investigation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's dispute with the Army.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 6 -- A navigation project by which Colombia eventually will open a vast area of grazing and farm lands is two-thirds completed after two years' work.
Well-known women, including Mrs. Charles N. Breed Jr. and A{rs. Joseph %Nalter Jr., are furthering the success of the preview of the loan exhibition, known as the "Magic of Flowers in Painting."

THERE used to be a comic strip character -- and maybe he's still in existence -- who was named Happy Hooligan. He was a cheerful hobo with a smile that couldn't be erased. Stanley Camfield Hack never was a hobo but so cheerful was his disposition and so inerasable was his smile that his fellow players on the Chicago Cubs nicknamed him Happy Hooligan.
The French Line has appointed Mario Geminiani general agent in Philadelphia, Guy de Berc, general manager in this country and Canada. announced yesterday.

Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan said yesterday that he might eventually extend the mandatory fingerprinting of track personnel to include horse owners, drivers and stable help. He made this statement at Yonkers Raceway during a brief visit to supervise the fingerprinting of the first of 1,800 workers at the track.

DETROIT, April 6 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard snapped out of his scoring slump tonight with two first-period goals twenty-nine seconds apart to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-to-1 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.
LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- Challenger Vassily Smyslov defeated Mikhail Botvinnik, world chess champion, in the tenth game of their series for the world title in Moscow today.

The latest reports on the H-bomb seem to make it more necessary than ever to take another look at ourselves. The possibilities for good and evil that this explosion has made evident are unlimited. To make use of those possibilities for good, and to avoid those for evil, which will bring destruction to all of us, is going to take imagination and clear thinking.

ROME, April 6 -- The two orchestras that will play in special concerts of the Roman Music Conference have begun their contributions. The Rome Radio Orchestra played last night under Darius Milhaud and Victor Desarzens, while the Scarlatti Orchestra of Naples played this afternoon under its permanent conductor, Franco Caracciolo.

Sidor Belarsky, basso, gave a recital in Town Hall last evening assisted by the Israeli violinist Ramy Shevelev. A native of Israel and a veteran of its Army, Mr. Shevelev came to this country in 1949 to complete his studies at the Juilliard School, where he is a member of the faculty.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 6 (AP) -- Frank A. Smith, the leading apprentice rider at Gulfstream Park suffered a fracture of the right collarbone and left shoulder in a spectacular spill from Gay Impulse in the first race today.
