Prices on the New York commodity exchange moved irregularly yesterday. Coffee, rubber, hides, wool, lead and zinc declined; cocoa, cottonseed oil and potatoes advanced and sugar, soybean oil, silk, copper and tin were mixed. Volume generally was normal but hides registered in the heaviest sales since Feb. 11.

The little fur for spring and summer provided the main theme for the Aronowicz showing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. This shop, at 19 West Fifty-seventh Street, also showed a small group of full length broadtails, leopards and mink for fall.

MOSCOW, April 6 -- Izvestia called today for agreements on barring weapons of mass destruction and for a general Far Eastern security pact. The Soviet Government newspaper called for creation of a system of international inspection and control of such weapons, including atomic and hydrogen bombs.
The Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Russell L. Cecil, author of medical textbooks, as its medical director.

The use of plastics in metal-forming tools is likely to be tripled this year, saving industry $30,000,000 by reducing time and production costs, a meeting of the American Society of Tool Engineers was told yesterday.

Under pressure of Communist China -- now knocking at the doors of the U. N. for admission to that agency as a "peace-loving" nation -- the State Department is consulting with various interested Governments concerning the issuance of a joint warning against further Communist aggression in Indo-China.

THERE are the makings of a pleasant game in comparing New York City entries in the original "Century Dictionary and Encyclopaedia," put out sixty years ago, with city entries in the latest edition, called "The New Century Cyclopedia of Names."
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Representative Thurmond Chatham, Democrat of North Carolina, is ready to do business with the Soviet Union and has so informed Georgi N. Zaroubin, Soviet Ambassador.

NEW ORLEANS, April 6 -- Are the Giants tired? Even before the New Yorkers lost to the Indians today, 10 -- 5, looking bad as they dropped their third in a row, Manager Leo Durocher advanced the thought that perhaps his club had been working too hard.
MEXICO CITY, April 5 -- To the bitter disappointment of United States business interests here, the heavily publicized Mexican-American Trade Fair, scheduled for next month, has been postponed.

MOSCOW, March 27 -- On April 7, which is Annunciation Day according to the Julian calendar of the Russian Orthodox Church, finches, larks and pigeons are sold for two prices at Moscow's big Kotelnikovsky bird market.
BONN, Germany, April 6 -Chancellor Konrad Adenauer sounded the alarm tonight in an effort to arouse the Western powers to the dangers besetting his regime from recent international currents.

NO doubt about it, artists' imaginations are inflamed in Mexico, and Robert Davison, whose paintings and drawings on Mexican themes are at the Hewitt Gallery, is the latest to fall under the spell of mysterious disquiet south of the border.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A letter of tribute was sent to each of the 245 nurses in the Public Health Service by Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General, as part of the observance of World Health Day.

" Mamie Doud Eisenhower: A Portrait of a First Lady," by Dorothy Brandon, will be published May 17 by Scribners. The author, a Washington staff correspondent of The New York Herald Tribune, has based her book on personal interviews with Mrs. Eisenhower before she entered the White House and on research in cooperation with friends and members of the Doud and Eisenhower families.
THE intriguing question of whether a television viewers time is worth anything now has been settled by the Supreme Court; it seems it isn't.

Beveridge Webster, who generally gives his recitals in the downtown halls, gave one last night at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. The pianist took the northern hall because it was available and he wanted to get in the New York premiere of William Schuman's "Voyage" before the close of the current season.
Foremost Dairies, Inc., and its subsidiaries last year achieved the highest sales and earnings in its twenty-two-year history.

JERUSALEM, April 6 -- Two Israeli soldiers were wounded by automatic fire in a skirmish near the Egyptian border this afternoon near Kisufim, according to an Israeli Army spokesman. The Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission was asked to consider the case.

CHICAGO, April 6 -- A syndicate managed by four major Chicago Loop banks and a leading bond investment house submitted today the best offer -- a 2.086 per cent interest cost -- for $33,100,000 of City of Chicago bonds maturing variously from 1955 to 1972.

An investor has purchased the six-story store and office building occupied by the E. B. Meyrowitz Company, opticians, at 520 Fifth Avenue between Fort-third and Forty-fourth Streets, from David Green in a deal negotiated by Dwight-Helmsley, Inc., brokers.

SINCE "Patience" was written by Gilbert and Sullivan and has thrived through the seventy-three years since it first was presented, it must be placed in a privileged, unassailable category, like motherhood, mountain air and fresh cow's milk.
PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- Old Pharaoh, the reluctant lion, finally was trapped in his moat at the Philadelphia Zoo this afternoon.

LAUREL, Md., April 6 (AP) -- Maryland's first triple dead heat, and the fifth in the United States since the photo finish camera came into use about twenty years ago, occurred today in the first race at Laurel.
TRENTON, April 6 -- Governor Robert B. Meyner reiterated here today his warning that substantial tax increases were inevitable in New Jersey.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, April 6 -- Former Prime Minister Cheddi B. Jagan and five other arrested leaders of the leftwing People's Progressive party failed today in an effort to get freedom on bail. A magistrate agreed to hear the application tomorrow, along with police objections to granting it.
LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- The United States men's table tennis team scored two shutouts and then bowed by 5 -- 0 to the defending champion, England, as the world championships started today.
Prof. H. David Kirk's letter of April 2 criticizing your editorial "The Bomb" seems to me replete with fallacies.

PITTSBURGH, April 6 -- The United Steelworkers of America, C. I. O., said today that lagging production in the steel and metal working industries in this country had made 189,000 of its members idle. There were 7,700 unemployed in Canada.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy charged last night that there had been an "eighteen-month deliberate delay" in American development of the hydrogen bomb. He demanded to know whether this was caused by "loyal Americans or traitors."
MIAMI Beach, April 6 (AP) -- Miami's Bobby Dykes won a unanimous but unpopular ten-round decision over Joe Rindone of Boston tonight.

The political explosions that have followed the latest series of hydrogen bomb tests are in some ways as frightening as the bomb itself. The emotional reactions to the stupendous blasts in the Pacific have spread far beyond the radius of their destructive power.

The court structure in New York City, especially as it affects youngsters in trouble with the law and with families breaking down, continues to draw fire from the experts, who are clearly fed up with the appalling disregard for how justice is served. Recently the Bar Association of the city criticized the fractional jurisdiction which numerous courts have over these cases.

The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program received 684 pints of blood on Monday. Included were 233 at the Washington Square campus of New York University on the first of a two-day collection and 206 at Public School 156, 229th Street and 137th Avenue, Laurelton, Queens, in a collection from residents of three communities, Laurelton, Springdale and Rosefield Gardens.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield denounced today pay increase demands of postal employe organizations as "nothing less than an all-out raid on the United States Treasury."

NEWARK, April 6 -- Seven persons, including four officials of Belleville, were named today by the Essex County Grand Jury in six indictments charging conspiracy, malfeasance and unlawfully obtaining municipal funds.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 6 -- Revil Mason of the Achaeological Survey of Witwatersrand University, has returned from Southwest Africa with a report that the white lady of Brandberg Mountain is not a white lady at all but a black man.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 6 -- Judge James N. Gehrig of Nassau Children's Court apparently carried out his threat today to put juveniles responsible for public school bomb scares in an institution.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 6 -- The rise in Greenwich's population, which is expected by the Planning and Zoning Commission to double the present 43,000 by 1985, was reflected today in two requests filed with the Planning Commission and the Board of Selectmen.

Pink salmon, the variety canned in greatest quantity, is a timely main dish possibility. -'sixteen-ounce can now is of. fered for 49 cents in many chain stores. This makes p'ink salmon a thriftier choice than the red type, admittedly somewhat superior in flavor. The red, or sockeye, is 65 to 69 cents a one-pound tin.

The P. Lorillard Company, maker of Old Gold, Kent and Embassy cigarettes, has completed plans for a large, fully integrated cigarette plant to cost an estimated $10,000,000 with an additional $3,000,000 for initial equipment.

Textile mills in Italy and Japan are concerned over attempts to establish a new standard for testing waterproof fabrics, according to Della M. Grattan, president of D. M. Grattan Company, New York advertising agency.
PHILADELPHIA, April 6 -- American industry was challenged tonight to exert all its "initiative and talents" to show what it could do now that it had returned to a competitive situation.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- Presdent Eisenhower sent to the Senate today the nominations of eleven men to Federal judgeships.

California, this country's largest producer of asparagus, has just started sending the spring vegetable here in carload shipments. Small quantities of the asparagus have been arriving since late February, but we are now entering the period, which lasts through June, when asparagus is most plentiful.

The "pinball professor," a painless purveyor of practical precepts, was presented yesterday to an enthusiastic audience at the Greater New York Safety Council meeting. The group began on Monday its five-day twenty-fourth annual assembly, at the Statler Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has "under active consideration" an investigation of the recent sale of 800,000 shares of New York Central stock by the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad to interests favorable to Robert R. Young, who is making an effort to obtain control of Central.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The Defense Department asked Congress today to authorize an $896,976,600 program of military public works. In keeping with the Eisenhower Administration's policy of placing first reliance on retaliatory air power, the bill sent to Capitol Hill this afternoon would authorize the Air Force to spend the largest share of that amount, $432,502,000.

New issues of public utility securities totaling more than $16,000,000 will be offered to investors today. The offerings consist of mortgage and common stock being sold to raise funds to pay off bank loans and to finance construction. The new issues are as follows:
The filing of a second will in Surrogate's Court yesterday indicated a contest over the $2,000,000 estate of Gustav Wurzweiler, stock broker. He died last March 2 when 58 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- The first step toward possible "united action" against Chinese Communist intervention in Indo-China has been taken by the United States.
The Ward Wheelock Company will close its doors in the fall.

Public health nurses of the Chinatown office of the Community Service Society were busy yesterday putting up posters in the crooked streets of the community.
CAMDEN, N. J., April 6 -- A sitdown strike today by 6,000 production employes paralyzed the shipyards of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, which is working on a Navy guided-missiles project.

OTTAWA, April 6 -- Lester B. Pearson, Minister for External Affairs described as "unwise" today the suggestion that Canadai should ask the United States to! put a halt to the explosion ofi hydrogen bombs in the Pacific. WASHINGTON, April 6 -- There are still the reasonably major matters of the Dodgers playing the Senators twice and the Yankees three times before the season opens, but Manager Smokey Alston already has looked beyond these exhibitions to the contests that count.
The new chemical compound that has revolutionized the production of the hydrogen bomb now makes it certain that the most dreaded weapon of all -- the cobalt bomb -- also can be successfully built.
The Wagner administration's bill to broaden the 3 per cent retail sales tax to cover commercial services was introduced yesterday into the City Council.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 6 -- United Nations delegates walking into the lounge today saw spots in front of their eyes -- huge blue, green and red spots.

The Institute of Applied Biology in Brooklyn has bought the building of the old Gustave Hartman orphanage at 274 East Second Street and will convert it into a modern 100-bed hospital for the care of terminal cases of cancer.

Its uncertainties aggravated by the Indo-Chinese situation, the stock market had a bad case of jitters yesterday. Virtually the entire list fell sharply, volume expanded and for fifteen minutes the ticker ran behind activity on the floor. Then came a partial recovery.
ROME, April 6 -- Premier Mario Scelba presented a bill for ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty to the Chamber of Deputies this afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 6 -- Eleanor Parker will star in "Interrupted Melody," Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's life story of Marjorie Lawrence, the Australian opera singer who was stricken with poliomyelitis at the height of her operatic career and staged a triumphant comeback as a concert singer.

PARIS, April 6 -- The United States proposal for a collective warning against further Chinese intervention in the Indo-Chinese war was regarded in diplomatic circles here today as a justifiable gamble.
The City Council proposal to punish parents for acts of vandalism committed by their children was broadened yesterday to include private as well as city property.
The city's public schools were defended yesterday against the charge that their program of education was responsible for the increase in juvenile delinquency.
The state will seek today to take some of the dynamite out of the explosive situation left in the wake of the twenty-nine-day pier strike.
PHILADELPHIA, April 6 (UP) -- Ted Williams today announced his plans to retire from baseball at the close of his 1954 season with the Boston Red Sox.

LONDON, April 6 (AP) -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that British planes -- with United States approval -- made observation flights at United States hydrogen bomb tests last month.

WASHINGTON, April 6 -- J. Monroe Johnson, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, refused a request today for an immediate inquiry into whether Amoskeag Company, an investment trust, may vote its holdings of stock of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad at an annual meeting of stockholders on April 14.

More than 1,500 persons attended the opening of the New York Mortgage Exchange at the Roosevelt Hotel yesterday when sixty-nine sales were made for a total of $821,045. The transactions involved forty - one first mortgages and twenty-eight secondary liens on real estate properties in the New York area.
Dedication ceremonies for the $1,500,000 Public School 196 were held last night at 113th Street and Seventy-first Road, Forest Hills, Queens.
Opposition has developed within the New York City C. I. O. Council to the re-election of the group's two top officers, Michael J. Quill, president, and Morris Iushewitz, secretary.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The United States Tax Court ruled today that the Pennroad Corporation, Wilmington, Del., would not have to pay any income tax on $15,000,000 it received from the Pennsylvania Railroad in 1947 in settlement of litigation.

Resignation of Samuel P. Sears as special counsel to the Senate committee investigating the dispute between Mr. McCarthy and the Army was the only dignified and logical outcome possible, once his previously expressed views on the McCarthy issue had become known.

Two contemporary works of genuine quality make a good record for any concert, and that was the achievement on last night's Carnegie Hall program of the Philadelphia Orchestra. If you regard Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 2, which was written in 1900, as music of our time, the whole evening had a flavor that was not too remote.

With "Anniversary Waltz," opening at 8 o'clock tonight at the Broadhurst, the collaborating team of Jerome Chodorov and Joseph Fields will have a trio of shows running simultaneously. The other two are musicals -- "Wonderful Town" and "The Girl in Pink Tights."
WASHINGTON, April 6 -- A grave foreign policy debate engaged the Senate today over the military crisis in Indo-China.
WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) -Senator John J. Williams charged today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation lent $3,838,786 in 1949-50 to a home-building concern that "unquestionably was insolvent."

WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would sell 170 million bushels of Government - owned corn from the 1948 and 1949 crops at reduced prices. The aim is to dispose of it before it deteriorates.

WASHINGTON, April 6 (UP) -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford asserted today that the pulverizing punch of hydrogen weapons did not require any change in United States military strategy or air-defense programs.
A strike of eleven news deliverers cut off newspaper and magazine deliveries yesterday to 700 stands in the Ridgewood section of Brooklyn and Queens.

BO McMILLIN raced to his right and then cut back sharply to slash through the hole off tackle. The big left guard had pulled out of the line and whipped through the hole ahead of him to lead the interference. The guard artfully flattened the last defender with a thunderous block and McMillin, young and swift, fled 50 yards for a touchdown in the charity game.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Administration bills to put into effect President Eisenhower's foreign trade program will reach Congress next week at the latest.

Regina Price, in her Town Hall debut last night, sang a program a little off the routine aspects, what with several songs by Tchaikovsky and four Vivaldi arias. More conventional were the Handel group and three Schumann lieder.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Committee, told a Senate subcommittee today that the Government planned to spend $427,400,000 more in the fiscal year beginning July 1 to push ahead with "greatly increased production of thermonuclear weapons."

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of upstate New York, chairman of the Joint Atomic Energy Committee, on the delay in developing a hydrogen bomb, which Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, charged last night was deliberately held up for eighteen months:
The regional Red Cross Blood Program received 529 pints of blood on Tuesday, including 238 from the Washington Square campus of New York University.

Listener reaction, expressed in telephone calls and telegrams, heavily favors Edward R. Murrow, commentator, over Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in their television duel, the Columbia Broadcasting System reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- The General Services Administration today asked about 400 debtors to arrange for about $140,000,000 in private refinancing to pay off their Government obligations. Administrator Edmund F. Mansure said the debtors purchased surplus World War II plants and gave the Government mortgages.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 7 (AP) -- Tennessee Republicans and Democrats alike praised the appointment today of Ray H. Jenkins as special counsel for a Senate subcommittee's investigation of the McCarthy-Army dispute.

The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission raised $233,000,000 in the public market yesterday to finance a 110-mile extension of the turnpike north to Scranton and a bridge link to the New Jersey Turnpike over the Delaware River.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Supreme Court took under advisement today the question of whether the Federal Power Commission has jurisdiction to regulate sales of natural gas by producers to interstate pipeline companies.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A House judiciary subcommittee today gave ear to Communist arguments against outlawing the Communist party.
BOSTON, April 7 -- Samuel P. Sears returned to law practice in Boston today after one of the shortest Washington assignments on record.

This is a year of noteworthy educational anniversaries in New York. This week the Board of Regents in its annual convocation held in Albany invites the people of the state to look backward at the small, hesitant first steps in public education, then to the fine achievements that followed, and finally to examine the urgent, everchanging but never-lessening responsibilities of the future.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -Rather encouraging signs are discernible in the economy at present, President Eisenhower told his news conference today.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- The Republican National Committee previewed today a motion picture summary of "The Case of Harry Dexter White" before a cheering and booing audience of Republican women.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -President Eisenhower said today that a Communist conquest of Indo-China would set off throughout Asia a chain reaction of disaster for the free world.

As much a sign of spring as yesterday's delightful weather is the fact that shad is again running up the Hudson. The fish so associated with this pleasant season is available as roe shad, cut shad (roe removed) and buck shad.

Justice Peter M. Daly of the Supreme Court in Queens has denied an application of the New York Life Insurance Company for a review of its claim for a reduction in the assessed valuation of its Fresh Meadows housing development for the tax years 1950-51 and 1951-52.
G. L. Mehta, Indian Ambassador to the United States. rejected yesterday the idea that his country had practiced "neutralism" in her foreign relations.
Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, renewed yesterday his party's demand for a bipartisan investigation of the State Liquor Authority.
PARIS, April 7 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle made his most bitter attack on the United States' world policy today.

Last November at the Jamaica track a 2-year-old filly was claimed for $6,250 by Edwin Holton, who does his own horse- training. Yesterday at Jamaica the filly, Trisong, won $16,150 for him in the $23,400 Prioress Stakes.

Stockholders of the Babcock Wilcox Company at the annual meeting here yesterday elected Edward A. Livingstone, a vice president, as a director. He has also been placed in charge of the company's tubular products division to succeed Luke E. Sawyer, who becomes consultant to the company handling special assignments in that division.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 7 -- Richard G. Casey, Minister for External Affairs, said in the House of Representatives tonight that Australia had a number of suggestions to make at the Geneva conference for proceeding from an armistice in Korea to something more permanent.

More than one-fourth of the expected total vote in the hotly contested election for national and port offices of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., have been cast in the first five days of balloting, union sources reported here yesterday. Voting started last Thursday and will continue through June 30.
ALBANY, April 7 -- A. 26-year- old Cornell graduate told a House Un-American Activities subcommittee today that he had evidence of a Communist cell in the Cornell faculty between 1948 and 1951.

IN "Anniversary Waltz," which was acted at the Broadhurst last evening, Jerome Chodorov and Joseph Fields have combined two comedy staples. They are (1) the "Moma Love Poppa?" joke, (2) the mother-in-law joke. There are some other staple products along the course, but these are the fundamentals.
Public support of the city's program of one-way avenues is urged by two major citizens group.

Those concerned with the functioning of the courts and the administration of justice in this state are filled with dismay at the report that the Judicial Council faces extinction by the reduction of the appropriation for the council from $55,370 to $10,000. The cut would also result in the loss of Leonard S. Saxe, the council's able and devoted executive secretary.
The election of Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council, as Brooklyn Democratic leader to succeed Kenneth F. Sutherland was virtually assured last night.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., April 7 -- The Armed Forces Information School, operated jointly by the Army, Navy and Air Force since 1948, graduated its final class of 120 today at Fort Slocum here.
A change in Police Department trial procedure to assure members of defense counsel in all cases was announced yesterday by Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner today recommended the renewal until July 4, 1959, of the permit of Pan American World Airways to operate across the South Pacific to Africa.
CHICAGO, April 7 -- Substantial declines were registered in corn and soybean futures today, while wheat showed some response to bad weather reports from the Southwest and closed higher.

Steve Allen yesterday became the first star to be hired for next fall's new edition of "Your Show of Shows." It will be the first time that the television series, produced by Max Liebman, will be without the services of Sid Caesar and Imogene Coca, who are preparing separate programs.
The Metropolitan Opera last evening presented its superbly restaged "Barber of Seville," with Victoria de los Angeles making her first appearance as Rosina.
ATHENS, April 7 -- Sophocles Venizelos, veteran Greek politician, has announced his resignation from the post of co-leader of the Liberal party.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Ray H. Jenkins of Knoxville, Tenn., today was named special counsel for the Senate investigation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's dispute with the Army.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Department of Justice will not appeal the dismissal by Federal Judge Harold R. Medina of the Government's anti-trust suit against seventeen investment banking houses.
MEXICO CITY, April 7 -- A free man at last, Victor Raul Haya de la Torre arrived today to begin a second Mexican exile from his native Peru.

TRENTON, April 7 -- An official of the Port of New York Authority warned today that adoption of a resolution recently introduced in the State Senate to curb the bistate agency would "definitely result" in its dissolution.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- There were a lot of Jackie Robinson fans among the 21,443 spectators at Griffith Stadium tonight and Jack didn't let them down. His four straight hits drove in four runs as the Dodgers beat the Senators, 10 -- 4, for their third straight triumph over the Nats this spring.

Yesterday's statements by President Eisenhower, former President Truman and members of the Joint Atomic Energy Committee on Capitol Hill don't begin to tell the fantastic story of the United States Government's decision to make the first hydrogen bomb.
MANILA, April 7 -- Nationalist foreign policy makers split tonight over the United States proposal for a joint warning to Peiping against intervention in Indo-China.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Government officials told a Senate committee today they were doing all possible to increase production of better quality titanium at reduced prices.

The companies which make automobile fuel are putting on a race of their own. It will be run nationally in: newspapers and magazines, along with radio, outdoor boards and point-of-sale material. The racers line up this way:

A spokesman for organizations reported to represent 3,000 commuters protested yesterday against plans by the Delaware. Lackawanna and Western Railroad to abandon ferry service between Christopher Street and Hoboken. N. J.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 7 -- California Democrats today waited for Adlai E. Stevenson, the party's 1952 Presidential nominee, to take a public stand in the tempestous intraparty situation involving James Roosevelt and Representative Robert L. Condon.
Expenditures of $27,000,000 for improved facilities and equipment in the last five years enabled the Jersey Central Lines last year to cut transportation expenses by $1,359,608, or 5 per cent.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 7 -- Preston Hotchkis, United States expert, assured the United Nations Economic and Social Council today that the United States was moving to provide more incentive for private investments in underdeveloped areas. He referred specifically to President Eisenhower's recommendations for changes in tax laws that would ease the flow of such funds.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:

THE dogwood and yellow jasmine are appearing, along With the anglers, on the fringe of North Carolina's outer banks, and although it will be another two weeks before the channel bass appear in any numbers, a few are now being taken from the surf.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 7 (UP) -- An overflow crowd of 10,474, the largest in Little Rock baseball history, saw Harvey Haddix, the opening-day pitcher of the St. Louis Cardinals, tune up today with seven scoreless innings during a 2-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

SUNNYVALE, Calif., April 7 -- An 11 per cent increase in sales and "substantial" increase in earnings for the first two months of this year were reported to stockholders of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation today by Gwilym A. Price, the president The comparisons were with the corresponding period of 1953, a record business year.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 7 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan will ask Parliament Monday to request the transfer to the Union of South Africa of three British-protected territories on the Union's frontiers.

The Administration bill to permit the use of wire-tap evidence in national security cases in the federal courts has at least one serious weakness that we hope and believe the Congress will correct before the measure is finally approved.
CHICAGO, April 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MONTREAL, April 7 (AP) -- The Crown dismissed two charges today against Louis Glazer, a Montreal lawyer, in connection with the alleged illegal adoption of a baby by a New York couple.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 7 -- A new plan to help increase the supply of films coming out of Hollywood and to take the financial risk out of independent production is about to be activated by the Allied States Association of Motion Picture Exhibitors in association with Hal R. Makelim, producer.

After the Korean War had cost hundreds of thousands of lives and devastated much of the country Representative Albert Gore of Tennessee (now become Senator) urged the Defense Department to lay a radioactive strip across Korea, across which no one could pass and live.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The full transcript of the Senate debate on Indo-China that was published in the Congressional Record today emphasized the complexity of the central problem: how to induce the non-Communist population of the area and states of Southeast Asia wholeheartedly to support the military action directed against the Communist forces.
What makes the Maurice Rentner fashions outstanding are the multiple operations that go into the construction of all of his styles, giving well-balanced form and character.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused yesterday to investigate moves made by Robert R. Young to wrest control of the New York Central Railroad Company from its present management.

LONDON, April 7 -- Establishment of the European Defense Community would forge still more intimate links between France and Britain, Prime Minister Churchill said tonight in a message to Premier Joseph Laniel.

ALTHOUGH there are no poems by Dorothy Parker or T. S. Eliot in Mr. Williams' enormously hospitable volume, almost everyone else you can think of seems to be represented. For the book is an astonishing gallimaufry. It includes about a hundred poets and ranges across more than a century of time.
The W. T. Grant Company, which operates a chain of 502 variety stores in 39 states, had its highest sales and second largest earnings in the fiscal year ended last January.

DETROIT, April 7 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company today reported first quarter sales records had been broken for both Ford cars and trucks and Mercury automobiles. The company's Ford division said sales of its car and trucks in the first quarter of 1954 broke a thirty-year record.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Administration-supported bill designed to admit wiretapped evidence in Federal courts to obtain convictions of traitors, spies and saboteurs set off a fight in the House of Representatives today.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The Secretary of the Treasury urged today early enactment of the Administration's tax-revision bill to enable business and industry to expand, create more jobs and produce "better living for every one."

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, April 7 -- A Georgetown magistrate refused bail today to former Prime Minister Cheddi B. Jagan and two of his principal aides, Martin Carter and Richard Westmaas. The three are being held on charges of violating the emergency regulations by having paraded without a police permit.

YOSEMITE, Calif., March 14 -- Although 60 per cent more visitors are pouring into Yosemite National Park today than in the immediate prewar period, this majestically scenic area is being administered with a staff of park rangers no larger than in 1941.
The American Labor party sent to President Eisenhower yesterday a letter protesting the danger of "being dragged into a war in Indo-China without recourse to the constitutional process."

ATLANTIC CITY, April 7 -- Nearly 1,000 guests and visitors filed in orderly fashion to the lobby of the Ritz Carlton Hotel on the Boardwalk at Iowa Avenue early this evening when a fire was discovered on the sixteenth floor.

AUGUSTA, Me., April 7 (AP) -Sumner T. Pike, a member of the Atomic Energy Commission from 1946 through 1951, said today he did not know what Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, was talking about when he suggested that Communists caused an eighteenmonth delay in hydrogen-bomb development.

Biggest news in Easter season millinery is less trim and more brim. Interpretations of this new look are flourishing in the budget-priced field, which has a magical way of reproducing a trend even while it is being introduced by uptown custom designers or imported from Europe.

Many women of society, including Mrs. Peter Darlington and Mrs. James T. Van Norden, are aiding in furthering the success of the annual spring frolic and tea dance for the benefit of the Humane Society of New York. The fete will be held April 23 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- (UP) The Air National Guard has put its "week-end warriors" on a ready-to-go status that would get some squadrons into action within forty-five minutes after an air alert.
Harold Weinberg, 25-year-old slayer of Maxwell Bodenheim, the poet, and the latter's wife, Ruth, was sent to Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane yesterday.
TOKYO, April 7 -- Japan's Parliament has been told that new sea forces will not be used to escort fishing vessels on the high seas.

Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Democrat-Liberal of Manhattan, attacked Senator Joseph R. McCarthy last night as "a phony, a demagogue" and "un-American." He compared the Wisconsin Republican to Adolf Hitler.

A poor mental attitude of both passengers and crews was blamed yesterday for the great majority of marine accidents. The assertion was made at the ship operators session of the marine section of the National Safety Council.

LONDON, April 7 -- Hugh Gaitskell, Chancellor of the Exchequer in the former Labor Government, charged today that Britain's new budget was unfair because it neglected groups who should have first attention.

A five-story building containing fourteen apartments and occupying a lot 27 by 100 feet at 222 Hicks Street, corner of Remsen Street, in Brooklyn, has been purchase dby Phillip P. Zipes, operator. It is assessed at $52,500.
The program offered by Charles Munch of the Boston Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was devoted mainly, in this year of the Berlioz sesquicentennial, to that composer's works.

Ed Seuss singled home what proved to be the winning run in the first inning and hit a home run in the eighth yesterday as Queens College's baseball team downed Pace, 3 -- 1, on Remsen Field in Flushing, Queens. This was the first 1954 Knickerbocker Conference test for both teams.

MADISON, Wis., April 7 (AP) -- A great peril lies in the possibility that Americans will lose faith in constitutional government as an instrument of freedom, the board of directors of the Wisconsin Council of Churches said today.
Stockpiling plans and war tensions in the Far East gave strength to metals in yesterday's stock market.

Science is a powerful force for evil or for good, it was emphasized here last night by Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission. He presided at a presentation of awards for medical research to four scientists in the auditorium of the New York Academy of Medicine at 2 East 103d Street.
NEW HAVEN, April 7 -- Mrs. Margaret Spencer, 38 years old, daughter of a retired Yale professor, was found beaten to death at her home today.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- Chairman Harold H. Velde, Republican of Illinois, today announced appointment of Courtney E. Owens as chief investigator for the House Un-American Activities Committee.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 7 (UP) -- Premier Fawzi el Mulki of Jordan said today "the self-restraint often expressed by the Jordanian people will not continue indefinitely" if the United Nations failed to prevent use of "unjust force" by Israel.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- The Senate passed by a voice vote today a bill to increase Federal aid for highway construction from the present $652,500,000 to $1,010,000,000 in each of the next two fiscal years.

Frederic C. Dumaine Jr., president of the $500,000,000 New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, predicted last night that he and his assocites would elect a majority of the directors at the annual meeting of stockholders next Wednesday.

Enrico Caruso, hair stylist, bought the five-story dwelling on lot 18.9 by 100 feet at 110 East Fifty-fifth Street, near Park Avenue, from Miss Jean Dalrymple, theatrical agent, through Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers. He plans to use the ground floor for his business about Oct. 1.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended March 31:
State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman led an inspection party through West Side slums yesterday to point out the city's need to put its houses in order.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) established new records last year in virtually every phase of operation, according to the report for 1953 issued for publication today. Sales, crude oil production and net income were among the record- breakers.

LONDON, April 7 -- The British Government doubts the value under present conditions of any precipitate action on Indo-China and Southeast Asia that might prejudice the success of the Geneva conference.

THE new month-long exhibition of paintings which opened at the City Center Art Gallery yesterday brings forward few well-known names hut adds up to a lively affair with some fairly knowledgeable work. The jury this time consisted of Josef Albers, Milton Avery and James Brooks.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -- President Eisenhower said today that the United States had no intention of building bigger hydrogen bombs than those now in production.

BONN, Germany, April 7 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer received the unanimous support of the Bundestag today for a resolution reminding the Western powers of a threat to West Germany. The Federal Republic is the only legitimately constituted authority in Germany, it said.

Moses Polakoff, former counsel to Charles (Lucky) Luciano, is a candidate for appointment as Supreme Court justice to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice Kenneth O'Brien. The appointment is to be made by Governor Dewey.

" If there were no Communists in our Government why did we delay for eighteen months -- delay our research on the hydrogen bomb, even though our intelligence agencies were reporting day after day that the Russians were feverishly pushing their development of the hydrogen bomb?" So asked Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in the course of a broadcast attack on Edward R. Murrow.

Frank Costello's income tax returns depicted him yesterday as a man who kept track, even to the pennies, of where his money went, but retained only the vaguest recollection of whence much of it had come.
The city will get a first-hand view of part of its military might when Armed Forces Day is celebrated May 15.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

ROME, April 7 -- The Rome Radio Orchestra gave another concert this afternoon, at which it played an anonymous overture and an anonymous violin concerto, followed by Hindemith's Concerto for Orchestra and Gottfried von Einem's operatic suite, "Danton's Tod."

The late Edward Verrall Lucas left us four lines of verse which have a special value today as President Eisenhower, two members of his Cabinet and three distinguished clergymen gather for a unique ceremony in Washington to publicize an 8-cent postage stamp bearing a portrait of the Statue of Liberty:
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday and prices closed 12 points lower to 7 points higher than on Tuesday.

Five good-natured children spent two hours at the Health Department yesterday pretending to be inoculated. It was a "dry run" demonstration that trials of the Salk vaccine against poliomyelitis can get off to a smooth start April 26.

JERUSALEM, April 7 (UP) -- Premier Moshe Sharett of Israel said today war in the Holy Land was by no means likely "if the Arab states do not want it." But, "those who do not want a relapse toward war must make an advance toward peace," he added. Israel considers direct peace negotiations "to be both possible and desirable," Mr. Sharett said.

NORFOLK, Va., April 7 -- Back amid the more friendly surroundings of their old farm site, the Yankees today looked hopefully toward giving Casey Stengel a performance worthy of their lofty rank. However, in this they were only partially successful.
BOSTON, April 7 -- A new radar approach system, designed to keep smaller airports operating in bad weather, was demonstrated today at the Boston Airport.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 7 -- Johnny Antonelli's attempt to be the first Giant hurler to go nine innings failed today, but Hoyt Wilhelm's fine relief work in the ninth saved the southpaw's 2-1 victory over the Indians.
Formation of a committee to help absorb Puerto Ricans into the trade union movement was announced yesterday.

The "little" fur, the number one favorite of its kind for spring, shed the familiar look of such conventional styles as the five stripe stole and took on new life yesterday in Gunther Jaeckel's presentation of designs.
The city's biggest union of truck drivers denounced as a sham yesterday the American Federation of Labor's drive to police its own welfare funds here.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 7 -- A double error in the seventh inning followed by a two-bagger by the Yale captain, Bob Wahlers, gave the Elis a 6-4 victory over New York University today.
BALTIMORE, April 7 (AP) -- Baltimore hotel operators met with Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin and his Commission on Interracial Problems today but refused to lift their restrictions against Negro patrons.
WEST POINT, N. Y., April 7 -- City College shut out Army in baseball, 6 to 0, today at Doubleday Field as Joe Galletta hurled five-hit ball.

Today's new film is "Pit of Loneliness," a French-made drama produced by Memnon Films and directed by Jacqueline Audry, at the Normandie Theatre. Edwige Feuillere, Simone Simon, Yvonne De Bray, Suzanne Dehelly and Marie-Claire Olivia head the cast of the Arthur Davis Presentation, which Colette adapted from the novel, "Olivia."
HANOI, Vietnam, April 7 (AP) -- The French strengthened Hanoi's defenses today against a possible Vietminh thrust as ground fighting at besieged Dienbienphu continued in a lull.

We should like to express publicly our thanks to The New York Times on behalf of twenty-two organizations of exiles from the Iron Curtain countries. We thank the editors of The Times for the splendid editorial of April 4 on the question of forced labor, as well as for the dispatch containing references to certain evidence brought to the attention of the United Nations.
A Brooklyn judge proposed yesterday that dock union officials be required to get licenses from the Waterfront Commission as a means of cutting pier crime.

With a backlog of thousands of civil cases, meaning a delay up to four years in disposition of a normal case, the Federal Court in the Southern District of New York has long been in serious need of more men on the bench. Such help is now in immediate prospect with the appointment of four new judges by President Eisenhower.

About 80,000 square feet of space in the one-story building at 275 North Street in Teterboro, N. J., has been leased by Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc., from the Teterboro Service Company in a transaction negotiated by the Joseph J. Garibaldi Organization as broker.
NORWALK, Conn., April 7 -- The tragedy of the nine-month-old strike here against the Hat Corporation of America has many faces.
LONDON, April 7 -- The securities market here took in stride today the absence of tax cuts in the budget presented yesterday.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 7 (AP) -- The Evangelical Confederation of Colombia charged today that a United States Protestant missionary and his wife had been attacked and beaten by a group of fifteen persons in Sogamoso, Boyaca Department.
Smelter shipments of slab zinc to consuming industries last month were the largest since last July, the American Zinc Institute reported yesterday.
ALBANY, April 7 -- Governor Dewey cleared the way today for construction of five additional sections of the Thruway.
WASHINGTON, April 7 -President Eisenhower hinted today that he might approve statehood for the more populous half of Alaska.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 7 -- Abba Eban, Israeli representative in the United Nations, said today there was "not a man, woman, or child" in Israel who was "free of fear from attack."
LONDON, April 7 (AP) -- Both the men's and women's teams representing the United States suffered defeats today in the round-robin world table tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -The Atomic Energy Commission, which has been moving steadily toward giving private industry a greater role in working for peaceful use of nuclear energy, announced today appointment of an Assistant General Manager for Research and Industrial Development.

Africa and its racial problems are the subjects of four books published this month. On Tuesday the H. W. Wilson Company issued in its Reference Shelf series "Africa: The Racial Issue," a selection of articles by experts edited by Joan Coyne Maclean.
CAMDEN, N J., April 7 -- A sitdown strike of 6,200 workers on three shifts at the New York Shipbuilding Corporation, went into its second day.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., April 7 (AP) -- The favorite, Eddie Choong of Malaya, advanced to the third round in the men's singles division of the national badminton championships today, but Ernesto Villareal, the Mexican champion, was eliminated.

ROME, April 7 -- Premier Mario Scelba warned the Communists today that he would not allow them to paralyze parliament in their efforts to prevent ratification of the European Defense Community Treaty.

PARIS, April 7 -- The French Cabinet decided at a meeting today to postpone its reply to the United States proposal for a joint warning to Communist China against further intervention in the Indo-Chinese war.
A threat to close city reservoirs to fishing if sportsmen and picnickers continue to discard rubbish and garbage in the watershed areas was made last night.
The cornerstone of United States and French strategic and political policies in Indo-China for the last year has been the so-called Navarre plan.

The names of twelve current books that "best reflect American life" were announced yesterday for presentation to the American Library in Paris. They will be used as part of the Paris in New York Festival.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 7 (AP) -- Net income of the American Tobacco Company for the first quarter of this year is almost certain to be substantially higher than for the like 1953 period, Paul M. Hahn, president, said today at the annual meeting here.

The New York State Banking Board canceled restrictions yesterday against the use of the word "savings" in advertising by state banks, trust companies, industrial banks and private bankers. The action follows a United States Supreme Court decision handed down on Monday that New York State could not constitutionally prohibit national banks from using the word.

HALLANDALE, Fla., April 7 (AP) -- Fierce, owned by Fred Hooper, went to the front at the start of the $12,900 Gulfstream Park Juvenile Stakes and never was threatened while winning by two lengths before 10,967 spectators today.
WASHINGTON, April 7 (UP) -- Charles A. Lindbergh got his Air Force wings back today.
A broadcast by the Soviet-controlled East German radio last week-end asserted that the Soviet Union had developed a hydrogen bomb deliverable by long-range aircraft.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 7 -The president of the Packaging Machinery Manufacturers Institute predicted today that such manufacturers would do a record business in 1954 and 1955.

Absorption of freight charges has become a substantial cost item for steelmakers. Growing competition since late last year has forced the producers to pay a larger and larger proportion of the bill for shipping their products to customers.

The Societe des Ateliers Terrin, a French ship repair company, has named Edwin B. McCrohan Jr., to represent it in this country in a campaign to win from Italian yards the voyage repair business of American-owned tankers plying the Mediterranean.
Shirley Booth is the star of a new musical comedy, "By the Beautiful Sea," which opens tonight at 8 o'clock at the Majestic Theatre under the co-production banner of Robert Fryer and Lawrence Carr.

Advertising for public support of the self-help program recently developed by the CARE organization to assist improverished peoples of the free world will appear soon in newspapers throughout the country.

Commodity prices moved irregularly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Coffee, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, rubber, zinc, lead and burlap eased; cocoa, hides, silk, potatoes and tin were higher, and sugar, copper and wool closed mixed. The domestic sugar contract was active and rubber registered the second highest daily volume of the year.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Major manufacturers of farm equipment said today they had recalled thousands of employes who were out of work three and four months ago. The industry was one of the first to feel the effects of a dip in business in the second half of 1953.
The Massachusetts Turnpike Authority announced yesterday that it would ask for bids on May 4 on an issue of about $240,000,000 of turnpike revenue bonds.
Cars of ten manufacturers were displayed yesterday at the third annual Easter Parade of Stars automotive exhibition.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 7 -- With a starting field of record proportions, the eighteenth annual Masters golf tourney will get under way here tomorrow. Among the competitors will be Ben Hogan, who will attempt to retain the honors he won a year ago over the Augusta National Golf Club course.

An appeal for less emphasis on denouncing Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, was voiced yesterday by Brig. Gen. Telford Taylor (retired), Allied prosecutor at the Nuremberg war crime trials.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 7 -- High French civil and military quarters here generally approve the strong new Washington line regarding Indo-China. Bringing assurance of vigorous United States backing for the French Union forces in Indo-China, the recent United States statements have given a lift to French morale at a time when the hardest fighting of the war has been going on at Dienbienphu and in the Tonkin delta.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Capt. Elmer C. Caveny, the Navy's chief psychiatrist, said today that all military services must make better use of mentally marginal, substandard and handicapped men in future war emergencies because of manpower shortages.

The Eisenhower Administration, although lacking in brilliancy, has achieved broader support for American foreign policy than its Democratic predecessors, a group of New York school teachers was told yesterday.

An increase of 1,048,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 179,674,000 barrels, compared with 178,626,000 a week earlier and 160,899,000 a year earlier.

Columbia's unbeaten baseball team scored its third straight victory this season by defeating Manhattan, 11 -- 8, at Baker Field yesterday. The Lions pounded three Jasper pitchers for fifteen hits in scoring at least once in every inning but the first.

OAKLAND, Calif., April 7 (UP) -- Southpaw Chuck Davey, using a troublesome right lead and a jarring left-and-right combination, gained a unanimous ten-round decision over Gerry Dreyer of South Africa tonight in a nationally televised bout in the Oakland Auditorium.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 7 -- Indonesia's Christian minority has reported a growing terror campaign against Christians in southern Celebes. First Deputy Premier Wongsonegoro expressed the Government's regrets today.

Louis Jadot, the third generation of his family to head the burgundy wine shipping company of Maison Louis Jadot, at Beaune in the Burgundy district, today departs for France at the end of his first visit to the United States.

Increased use of rehabilitation processes for workers injured in industrial accidents was urged yesterday by Archie O. Dawson, Moreland Act Commissioner for the Study of Workmen's Compensation in New York State.

The situation in Indo-China has become a matter of the gravest concern in Washington in recent weeks for the reasons the President re-emphasized in his news conference yesterday. As the capital of the free world Washington cannot evade the responsibility of speaking up in the most unequivocal terms for the independent nations of Asia that are threatened by Communist aggression.
LONDON, April 7 -- A campaign for a nation-wide petition urging a conference of the great powers on the hydrogen bomb was launched tonight at a meeting sponsored by Labor members of Parliament.
A stand-in for Jack Frost was nipping at 13,000 gallons of water all Tuesday night to keep the surface of Wollman Memorial Skating Rink frozen.

United Funds, Inc., reported yesterday that sales of the four funds comprising the investment trust group in the first quarter of this year set a new high record for any similar quarter in the company's history. Sales were $7,928,211, compared with $6,836,208 last year, an increase of 16 per cent.

Resident buying offices are ready to fight hard against the proposed extension of the 3 per cent New York City sales tax. A bill extending the tax to certain services was introduced in the City Council on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP) -- A spokesman for many Protestant churches today supported President Eisenhower's proposal that Social Security retirement and death benefits be extended to about 250,000 ministers.

HUSAN, Jordan, April 7 -- Night raiders struck this area last night for the second straight time in ten days. They made a two-pronged attack on this village eight miles southwest of Jerusalem and less than a mile from the Israeli frontier. Volunteer guardsmen repelled the assault, apparently inflicting casualties on the raiders without loss to themselves.

Plans are being formulated at frequent meetings for the performance of "King of Hearts" on the night of May 6 at the Lyceum Theatre for the benefit of the Catholic Center for the Blind. Mrs. William F. Cogswell gave a tea Tuesday in her home at 141 East Seventy-second Street for members of the board of the beneficiary to further the success of the event.
HALIFAX, April 7 (UP) -- Brooke Claxton, Minister of Defense, gave four new minesweepers to France today and said Canada still could mobilize more than 100 other warships on short notice.
Fordham University launched Jack Coffey's thirty-second season as baseball coach by staging a late uprising to defeat Brooklyn College, 8-3, at Coffey Field in the Bronx yesterday.
George P. Monaghan, Harness Racing Commissioner, appointed J. Frank Wood, New York banker and lawyer, as his counsel yesterday. Mr. Wood formerly was counsel to the State Banking Department.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The United States is studying the possibility of pledging additional economic aid to Yugoslavia in a new effort to bring an end to the long-standing Trieste dispute.

The selection of a counsel who apparently has no record either pro or con Senator McCarthy has now at last been made by the Senate committee investigating the dispute between Mr. McCarthy and the Army.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 13 per cent below sales in the corresponding week last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board here, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the House voted today to authorize Federal judges, rather than the Attorney General, to issue final orders permitting wiretapping to obtain evidence:

Much leeway is permitted the cook in the choice of Easter dessert. If she is European in background, she may feel that lamb is an essential for the main dish. If she is of Yankee tradition, she may present a ham. But for the final flourish of the meal, she need not consult custom and is free to create something that meets her own degree of culinary skill.

HONG KONG, April 8 -- The Communist-sponsored Vietnam National United Front has decided to launch a nation-wide movement against American "intervention" in Indo-China, according to the Vietminh Radio.
Repayments by public utility, food, liquor and tobacco companies were a major influence in a decline of $21,000,000 in business loans by New York banks during the week ended on Wednesday.
President Eisenhower's health reinsurance bill received the support yesterday of the Blue Cross hospital service plans.

ALBANY, April 8 (AP) -- A confessed ex-Communist testified today that in three Northeastern industrial centers all the organizers for what is now the Independent United Electrical Workers Union were militant party members during the Nineteen Forties.

Despite a record executive budget, city departments and agencies serving children will continue to be handicapped by insufficient funds, the Citizens Committee on Children of New York declared yesterday. In support of its statement the group made public a detailed analysis of the Mayor's budget as it will affect work for and with the young.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein sought yesterday to close permanently an over-the-counter securities concern at 44 Wall Street. He charged that its liabilities exceeded its assets by more than $100,000.

London and Far Eastern advances pushed rubber prices to the sharpest gains in almost a year on the New York Commodity Exchange yesterday. The day's volume was the second largest since trading reopened on March 3, 1952. The President's statement on the seriousness of the situation in Indo-China influenced trading.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Four well-known authors appeared on Capitol Hill today to plead the cause of a universal copyright law and the protection it would afford authors.
PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, April 8 -- The United States has received a barrage of violent criticism here this week from its friends on basis of Washington's trade policies in the Caribbean area.

The two - story two - family dwelling at 1745 Forty-sixth Street in Brooklyn has been sold by Solomon Goldman to Antonio Santoro. The Weiss Realty Company was the broker in the transaction, in which title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Chester Bowles and Dr. William Barry Wood Jr. have been elected members and trustees of the Rockefeller Foundation and Dr. Detlev W. Bronk has been elected a member and trustee of the General Education Board, Dean Rusk, president of the foundation and of the board, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, April 8 -- The notion that all intellectuals are "eggheads" and trouble-makers who cannot be trusted is handicapping efforts to raise the general intellectual level of the nation, the convocation of the State Board of Regents heard today.
A longshoreman testified yesterday that telephone threats from "the mob" kept workers off a Jersey City pier in defiance of a Federal no-strike order.
Joseph Carattini, 21-year-old chauffeur, parked his automobile in the wrong spot yesterday when he drove a neighbor to the Criminal Courts Building at 100 Centre Street.

BRUSSELS, April 8 -- The Belgian Government announced today a series of measures designed to maintain and if possible raise the country's exports to 40 per cent of national production, which traditionally has been considered necessary for Belgium's economy.

CHATTANOOGA, April 8 -- The oldest Giant in point of service, Dave Koslo, today was sold to the Baltimore Orioles. The announcement of the sale of the 34-year-old southpaw, who had been with the Giants since September of 1941, came a few minutes after today's scheduled game with the Indians had been rained out.
The city and the state were at sword's points again yesterday. This time the topic was poor housing conditions here, and what is being said and done about them.

An ancient Greek script that for the last half century and longer has baffled archaeologists and linguists has been decoded finally -- by an amateur. The riddle was solved by Michael Ventris, an English architect and leisure-time scholar of preclassical scripts, who was a cryptographer during World War II.

HONG KONG, April 8 (Reuters) -- The Hong Kong Missionary Bulletin, a Roman Catholic newsletter here, said today Communist China had called a halt to further release of United States citizens held in its prisons.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- A Government luncheon today to promote international amity fired Arab-Jewish enmity instead.

A stockholder group opposing the management of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has renewed its request for an Interstate Commerce Commission investigation of the position occupied by the Amoskeag Company in the proxy contest.

Frank Costello and his wife deposited $269,154 in one bank here during the four years in which he is accused of cheating the Government of at least $73,437 in income taxes. That was indicated by bank records introduced yesterday in the racketeer's trial.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -A bill designed to make possible a $3,000,000,000 Government building program through leasepurchase contracts touched off a big controversy in the Senate today.

The Committee for One Million said yesterday it had evidence of a whispering campaign designed to sabotage its attempt to have 1,000,000 persons sign petitions opposing the admission of Communist China into the United Nations.

BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., April 8 -- Westchester County's newest parkway extension -- a three-mile link of the Saw Mill River Parkway from Mount Kisco to Bedford Hills -- will be completed before arrival of the summer traffic rush from New York.
Shipping men, bankers and investment specialists appeared yesterday to back a Senate bill that would provide a 100 per cent Government guarantee on loans to shipowners for new construction.

The opening of trade between Japan and the United States 100 years ago was commemorated here yesterday at a brief ceremony aboard the new O. S. K. Line cargo vessel London Maru at her berth at Kent Street, Brooklyn.

Plainclothes Man Transferred or Returned to Uniform Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday that more than 200 members of the plainclothes squads were being shifted or returned to uniform duty to be replaced by other men.
MADISON, Wis., April 8 (AP) -- A group of Madison residents started a campaign today to oppose a recall move against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

HARTFORD, April 8 -- Dr. Karl T. Compton was elected today as chairman of a twelvemember New England committee that will study the use of atomic energy for peacetime purposes in the northeastern region.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday numbered 599,302 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,124 cars or 0.4 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 105,215 cars or 14.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 107,587 cars or 15.2 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The House of Representatives passed today, by a vote of 378 to 10, a bill designed to admit to Federal court trials wiretapped evidence against alleged spies and saboteurs.

Renewal of a request to Eastern railroads to waive demurrage and storage charges on shipments tied up here by the longshoremen's strike was announced yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of ew York. The charges ordinarily apply when freight cars and other facilities are tied up longer than required by normal loading and unloading operations.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Eisenhower Administration urged today that the Federal Power Commission be allowed to decide who should develop the hydroelectric power potential of the Niagara River.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., April 8 (AP) -- Phil Boland, state mediator, today arranged a meeting for tomorrow between the WilkesBarre unit of the American Newspaper Guild, C. I. O., and the Wilkes-Barre Publishing Company.

FRANKFORT, Germany, April 8 (UP) -- A retired major general said today that he would pay $100 to "the first tough non-com" who gave a punch in the nose to Pvt. G. David Schine, former investigator for Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's subcommittee.

COLUMBIA, S. C., April 8 -Senator Burnet R. Maybank and four of South Carolina's Representatives were virtually assured of re-election today when the entry list for the June 8 Democratic primary election closed with no opposition in any of their races.

The State of Texas increased yesterday its market borrowings for financing the purchase of land for resale to war veterans. It sold $15,000,000 of new serial bonds maturing from 1960 to 1989 at an interest cost of 2.3386 per cent.

HONG KONG, April 8 -- Mrs. Sue Buol, 35-year-old secretary for the Civil Air Transport in Formosa, arrived here today from Taipei en route to the Geneva conference on a special, personal mission. She intends to make a direct appeal to the Chinese Communists to free her husband who has been their prisoner since Jan. 15, 1950.

Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, challenged yesterday two recent statements by Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein on ownership of harness race track stock. In a letter to Mr. Goldstein, he renewed his demand for a bipartisan investigation of the race track scandals.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, former Governor of Illinois and 1952 Democratic Presidential candidate, has suffered a recurrence of a kidney ailment. He entered Passavant Hospital tonight for observation and treatment.

Representative Cole of New York has made an important point in his statement clarifying the background of President Truman's 1950 decision to go ahead with the hydrogen bomb. Mr. Cole, chairman of the Joint Atomic Energy Committee, reveals that the question of making this decision did not come to the fore "until Sept. 23, 1949, when the Soviets exploded an atomic bomb years ahead of the date estimated by our experts."

The Navarre plan sets a timetable for breaking organized Communist fighting forces by the end of the 1955 fighting season -- that is, about April or May, before the rains begin, Secretary of State Dulles told the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Monday.

Still under leadership of the metals, especially those with molybdenum and uranium interests, the stock market shouldered its way ahead yesterday, establishing 143 new 1954 highs and at its high of the day exceeding every previous high since Sept. 18, 1930.

Three stars, Uta Hagen, Robert Preston and Lee Bowman, are employed in Julian Funt's play, "The Magic and the Loss," arriving at 8 o'clock tonight at the Booth. The odd title, borrowed from the prose of Thomas Wolfe, was substituted for the former label, "Child of Grace." Other members of the six-character cast, directed by Michael Gordon, are Edith Meiser, Charles Taylor and Danny Dennis.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -A $4,160,000 research and development program for synthetic rubber was announced yesterday by Laurence B. Robbins, acting administrator of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

Almost unnoticed in the flurry lover butter, cheddar cheese prices on both the mild and sharp varieties have declined as a result of the Government's recent reduction in support prices for dairy products.
LAMAR, Colo., April 7 -- Farmers in the croplands of southeastern Colorado were caught this week in a frantic race against the wind.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -Senate investigators were told today that the "best files that could possibly be gathered" on communism had disappeared from the New York Naval District one week-end in 1944.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, April 8 (AP) -- Three Studebakers took top place for each class in which they were entered in the 1954 Mobilgas Economy Run today.

Plans for altering the fivestory dwelling on lot 20 by 100 feet at 121 East Seventy-ninth Street into four apartments and a professional office have been announced in connection with the sale of the property by George Whitney to a client of Hamburger Green, attorneys.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York urged Congress yesterday to act favorably on a bill to make quarantine inspection service available to ship operators twenty-four hours a day. The association is comprised of 1,400 members and companies engaged in every major shipping activity of the harbor.
Fatalities in highway accidents are increasing in this state, James R. Macduff, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, said yesterday.

PARIS, April 8 -- King Norodom Siharnouk of Cambodia has ordered the general mobilization of his people and has announced that he will notify the United Nations and all the countries of the world of the "foreign invasion" of his kingdom by the Vietminh Communists.

The British, French and United States Governments have joined in a declaration to the effect that they do not recognize the sovereignty of the East German regime. They state that they will continue to regard the Soviet Union as responsible for the Soviet zone of Germany and the Federal Government at Bonn as the only freely elected and legally constituted Government of Germany.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- The Eisenhower Administration was accused tonight by Walter P. Reuther of confusing confidence with compacency in its failure to take positive action to reduce unemployment in this country.

THE town's top theatre is twenty-five years old this year. Distinguished players have clumped its boards and have looked dreamily down upon the stone and concrete landscape from the city's highest dressing rooms, up among real stars.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Eisenhower said today the Republican party was "by no means a conspiracy among people who simply thirst for power."

WASHINGTON, April 8 {UP) -- The general who built that fancy dog house at Fort Dix, N. J., will not have to live in it, as President Eisenhower suggested, but he has been required to pay for it, the Army reported today.
Department store expenses outran income in 1953, resulting in unsatisfactory profits.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Battle lines were shifted today for the public housing fight soon to hit the Senate.

The financial condition of the American consumer is a riddle to business men, employes and the Northern Trust Company of Chicago. The Windy City bank concedes this in the current issue of its monthly publication, "Business Comment."

George P. Monaghan, New York State's first Harness Racing Commissioner, got into the swing of his job yesterday as the honored guest and the presenter of prizes at the fourth annual driver awards luncheon at Yonkers Raceway.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -- Public school education can be improved to the extent than an enlightened citizenry is informed of basic needs, Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, United States Commissioner of Education, said here today.

Theodore Hemerline, a convicted life prisoner, is now a free man. General Sessions Judge Louis J. Capozzoli released the 60-year-old prisoner, who had spent his last twenty-four years in prison, after the prosecutor's office said it would not challenge Hemerline's contention that he was not a fourth offender under the Baumes Law.

The Maritime Administration in Washington yesterday set minimum base prices ranging from $4,120,000 to $5,072,000 a unit for the sale to United States shipping companies of thirty vessels of the Government-built fleet of thirty-five Mariner Class dry cargo vessels.

Edward C. Maguire, who holds a $15,000-a-year job as a member of the city's Board of Water Supply, disclosed yesterday that he was serving as a "legal adviser on labor problems" to the Algam Corporation, owner of Yonkers Raceway.
Constantly widening its work and influence, the changes in the field of home economics over the last two decades are due to those in the homes and families it strives to help.

The Lehman Corporation, one of the country's largest closed-end investment trusts, reported yesterday that its net assets were $157,044,438 on March 31. This was equivalent to $37.81 each on the corporation's 4,153,124 shares of capital stock outstanding, and compares with total assets of $136,218,106, or $32.80 a share, on June 30, 1953, the end of its fiscal year.

Reference to some very recent history reveals how incredibly swift has been the downfall of that most notorious of contemporary scientific quacks, Soviet Academician T. D. Lysenko. On Feb. 12 last Mr. Lysenko received the Order of Lenin at the hands of Marshal Voroshilov as one of a group of the most outstanding Soviet scientists so honored at that time in the Kremlin.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -The United States and Canada are going ahead with construction of a new radar fence across the Far North to forewarn both nations of approaching warplanes.

PARIS, April 8 -- The Entente Cordiale, entered into by France and Britain fifty years ago, was marked here today as a still cohesive force. The entente ended centuries of rivalry between France and Britain.
ROME, Friday, April 9 -- All Italian air-sea rescue stations from Rome south began a search at midnight for the missing British Comet.

In the Philippines they have made this an official annual national holiday -- Bataan Day. This is the twelfth anniversary of the fall of Bataan and it may seem strange to commemorate a dreadful defeat.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- President Eisenhower invited thirteen guests to a stag dinner with him at the White House tonight. Those invited:
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has proposed a 79 per cent rent increase for the 1,232 families living in Riverton Houses, a middle-income housing project in Harlem opened in 1947.

William White, president of the New York Central Railroad Company, in the 1953 annual report, issued for publication today, renewed his pledge of greater dividends for stockholders as soon as earnings permitted. The railroad paid dividends totaling $1 a share last year.
ROME, April 8 -- Last night the Rome Opera House was a turbulent place, inside and out.
TORONTO, April 8 (Canadian Press) -- The outlook for the newsprint market appears very strong, D. V. Ambridge, president of Abitibil Power and Paper Company, Ltd., said today at the annual meeting.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -- The Army, which has been trying on new uniforms since the end of World War II, disclosed today it finally had made up its mind.

LONDON, Friday, April 9 -A Comet jet airliner, with twenty-one persons aboard, was reported three and a half hours overdue at Cairo today. It was scheduled to land there at 9:20 P. M. Greenwich Mean time (4:20 P. M. Eastern Standard time) yesterday on a flight from Rome.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Like Old Faithful Geyser, the national park problem erupts periodically. But, unlike Old Faithful, the national park problem spouts emotion.

Events today: "La Boheme," Metropolitan Opera, 1 P. M.; Jazz concert for the benefit of The Lighthouse, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Columbia University Glee Club, Town Hall, 8:30; New York Folk Guitar Club, Adelphi Hall, 74 Fifth Avenue, 8:30, Program of chamber music, Juilliard School, 8:30; Gary Portadin, pianist, Greenwich House Music School, 8:30.

LONDON, April 8 -- The stock markets here remained fairly cheerful today but less buoyant than yesterday. Undated British Government securities made further gains ranging up to the equivalent of $1.225.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias was named today to receive the William D. Richardson Trophy as the person who made the outstanding contribution to golf within the past year.

LONDON, April 8 -- A suggestion that the Government use the United States need for air bases in Britain as a diplomatic weapon to force United States agreement on a joint policy for hydrogen weapons was put forward today.
