WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -Senators and their aides began laying the groundwork today for the public hearings due to start April 21, on the controversy between Senator McCarthy and Army officials.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Eisenhower dedicated today a new postage stamp designed to carry the symbols of American faith and freedom around the world.

Twenty-two persons, including a woman, were indicted yesterday by the Brooklyn rackets grand jury in connection with the operation of the borough policy ring. Fourteen of the group, in addition to being charged with possession of policy slips, also were accused of conspiracy.
NEW ORLEANS, April 8 (AP) -- Mrs. Babe Zaharias gained the lead with a three-under-par 72 as the $5,000 Colonial Country Club tournament opened today.

Hedley Woodhouse was the star of the show at the Jamaica race track yesterday. The amiable jockey from British Columbia had five mounts and brought home four winners, including the Saxon Stables' Marcador in the feature race.
A contract for underwriting West Texas Utilities Company's new issue of 60,000 shares of new $100 par value preferred stock was awarded yesterday to a syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.

The one-story building at 104-15 100th Street in Ozone Park, Queens, has been sold by Josephine Marino to the Hart Refrigeration Service in a transaction negotiated by the Colony Realty as broker. The building contains 7,000 square feet and occupies a plot 75 by 121 feet.

Paolo Rosi, Italian lightweight who has won all five of his fights in the United States, will seek his sixth victory tonight against Eddie Compo, New Haven, Conn., star, in a ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- An early increase in the volume of this country's exports to the European Soviet bloc is in prospect.

It might be wise to take a realistic view of the pending Geneva Conference. Inasmuch as Secretary Dulles has made it quite clear that the American Government will not even consider any suggestions for recognition of Red China, or support of its membership in the United Nations, there will be three other main topics for discussion: a settlement of the Korean question, cessation of Communist aggression in French Indo-China and the future status of Formosa.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 8 -- With a lull continuing in the ground fighting at Dienbienphu, the French Air Force has stepped up attacks against Vietminh transport routes and rear installations in Tonkin.

BERLIN, April 8 -- In an effort to make Berlin a meeting place of the East and the West, the Soviet Union, it was said today, has told West European airlines they can fly across East Germany to the airport in the Soviet sector of the city.

THERE is much to admire and enjoy in the water-colors by Charles Demuth and by Arthur Dove at the Downtown Gallery. Both of these twentiethcentury American artists died comparatively young, but their reputations have been growing ever since.
PHILADELPHIA, April 8 -The Government opened its case against nine alleged Communist leaders in United States District Court here today.

THE New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Dodgers will undoubtedly glance across the diamond at each other today and instant recognition of a most familiar pattern will smite them firmly between the eyes.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 8 -- Two studios announced today plans for aerial dramas dealing with jet planes and the men who take them into supersonic flight.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., April 8 (AP) -- American hopes of retaining the United States men's singles badminton championship were dealt a stunning blow today as invaders from Canada and the Far East knocked out all but two Yankees in the third round.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8 -- After an unusual opening round, the lead in the Masters golf tournament tonight was shared by an amateur and a professional.
Declining prices for zinc products reduce the net income of the New Jersey Zinc Company to $2,713,887 in 1953 from $12,060,192 in 1952, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

Carroll L. Wilson, who had been president of the Climax Uranium Company, has been made director of industrial development of the parent concern, the Climax Molybdenum Company, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. reported today that the Government had failed so far in its program for channeling defense contracts to combinations of small business concerns.
LONDON, April 8 -- Britain's major labor dispute was settled today. Union representatives of 3,000,000 workers in the engineering and shipbuilding fields agreed to accept a proffered wage increase.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 -Dr. Hu Shih, former Chinese Ambassador, predicted today that the Western nations that had recognized Communist China would "reconsider very soon and redress their wrongs."

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- For the first time France has expressed a willingness to internationalize the anti-Communist front in Indo-China. She has made this conditional on failure of the forthcoming Geneva conference to end the hostilities.
A fare rise to 15 cents or a bus franchise tax cut was indicated yesterday as the price the city would be willing to pay to convert Seventh and Eighth Avenues to one-way operation.
BONN, Germany, April 8 -- Informed West Germans are saying that the European Coal and Steel community may not survive for long a refusal of France to ratify the European Defense Community Treaty.

IN honor of Shirley Booth, several appreciative folks have assembled a bountiful, warm-hearted musical show in a happy period. "By the Beautiful Sea," they call it. It opened at the Majestic last evening.
TOKYO, April 8 -- Japan opened her doors a crack today to increase trade with the Soviet Union.

" Burma Under the Japanese," by Burma's Prime Minister, Thakin Nu, will be published April 23 by St. Martin's Press. It is a personal account of the events between 1942 and 1945, during which the country evolved toward the "permanent independence attained in 1947."
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Baseball isn't the glamour game it often appears and the idea of anyone "tampering" with a .250 hitter is so much "junk."

Your issue of March 29 gave an interesting account of the financial problems that now confront our private colleges and universities. As a business man who is also involved in higher education, I hasten to endorse the appeal for help made by Alfred P. Sloan to business men generally.

RICHMOND, Va., April 8 -Amid a fantastic setting perhaps without parallel in baseball, Richmond gave a roaring welcome today to its new International League entry as Luke Appling's Virginians engaged the Yankees in an exhibition game.
The Council Child Development Center will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Anniversary Waltz" on April 21 at the Broadhurst Theatre.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- India asked the United Nations Disarmament Commission today to study Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's proposals for an end to atomic and hydrogen bomb tests.
Seventy years ago a 14-yearold Hungarian immigrant passed through old Castle Garden, his first step toward becoming an American.

Overtime schedules for state tax offices from now until the deadline next Thursday for income tax returns were announced yesterday by Allen J. Goodrich, president of the State Tax Commission. He disclosed that nearly three-fourths of the returns were yet to be filed.

MEMPHIS, April 8 (UP) -- The Chicago White Sox scored five runs in the eighth inning to beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 to 2, today in a game that saw Negro athletes playing with whites for the first time on record here.

PALO ALTO, Calif., April 8 -- Stanford University fellowships valued at $2,000 each were awarded today to five "promising young authors" who are to enroll in the fall for a year's study at the university's Creative Writing Center.
Movements of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were irregular yesterday. Active months were 6 points lower to 5 points higher than on Wednesday.

The bronze plaques of the George Polk Memorial Awards, given annually since 1948 in the name of the Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent, who was slain while covering guerrilla warfare in Greece, were distributed yesterday.

Election of A. L. Billingsley, president of Fuller Smith Ross, Inc., New York and Cleveland advertising agency, as chairman of the board of the National Outdoor Advertising Bureau was announced yesterday by that organization. Mr. Billingsley, a director since 1939, succeeds the late Henry M. Stevens, vice president of J. Walter Thompson Company.
TRENTON, April 8 -- The Port of New York Authority was rebuked today by Gov. Robert B. Meyner for what he described as its negative attitude toward a study of rapid transit rail facilities.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 8 (AP) -- Don Quarles, a 23-year-old 178-pounder from North Carolina A. and T., tonight eliminated Wisconsin's Ray Zale, the only defending titleholder, in the National Collegiate boxing championships at Penn State University.
Fifteen teachers and a teacher-clerk who were accused of failing to cooperate with the Board of Education in its drive against suspected subversives were reccommended for dismissal yesterday.

The management of the New York Central Railroad Company and the Robert R. Young interests seeking to supplant it mailed their proxies and letters of solicitation to the Central's 40,000-odd stockholders yesterday.

Governor Dewey has signed the bill for local option permanent personal registration of voters which, as he says, will "afford the opportunity to evaluate the system in action and its trial will provide us with an accurate gauge of the value of the program." New York City or any county may now adopt permanent registration, under which a person once registered stays on the rolls if he votes at least once in two years.
IZMIR, Turkey, April 18 -- United States strategists, meeting at this eastern seaport (formerly Smyrna), are engaged in drawing up alternative plans for the defense of Greece and Turkey.
One of the best news sources in the country today is a college, a reporter taking graduate work at Harvard University reported yesterday.

LATE reports from most of the popular trout streams within a 150-mile radius of the city indicate that tomorrow's anglers will enjoy one of the best opening days in some years, at least as far as stream conditions are concerned.
PARIS, April 8 -- Discussion of the European Defense Community Treaty in the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly was put off today until May 5 after the Easter parliamentary recess.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (UP) -The Government warned movie operators, baseball parks and similar groups today that they must follow certain rules in revising ticket prices under last week's 10 per cent excise tax cut.
CINCINNATI, April 8 -- The six-story, $4,000,000 Robert A. Taft Sanitary Engineering Center was dedicated here today by Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
ALBANY, April 8 (AP) -- A bill authorizing creation of a special state commission to make a $25,000 study of local governments was among thirty-eight measures signed today by Governor Dewey.

SYRACUSE, April 8 (AP) -- Paul Seymour led the Syracuse Nationals to an 80-69 victory over the Minneapolis Lakers tonight and evened the National Basketball Association championship series at two games each. A crowd of 7,655 looked on.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $78,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
Yesterday's weather had just about everything but snow. The temperature ranged from 75 degrees, the warmest day of the year, down into the 30's. The day brought fog, sunshine, thunder and rain.

In the editorial on "The Delinquent Community" on March 31 you very aptly pointed out the need "to re- examine the whole environment in which we are rearing today's children." To assess the causes and evaluate the programs for treatment of this problem the Graduate School of Public Administration and Social Service at New York University, with the cooperation of the outstanding law enforcement, social welfare and civic organizations, has organized two professional level conferences.

Joseph T. Sharkey, majority leader of the City Council, was unanimously elected Brooklyn Democratic leader yesterday. He was named by his forty-seven fellow district chieftains at a meeting in the organization's headquarters at the Jefferson Building, 4-5 Court Square.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Federal Court of Appeals here affirmed today the conviction of E. Merl Young for perjury but reversed the conviction of his older brother, Herschel Young, for a similar offense.

Improved sales beginning late in February brought the volume of the Monsanto Chemical Company for the first quarter to $83,314,000, only about $2,200,000 below the $85,518,922 sales for the initial three months last year, Charles A. Thomas, president, reported yesterday at the annual meeting in St. Louis.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Heavy buying swung into the wheat pit today as reports from the Southwest drought areas brought traders to a keener realization of conditions in the major part of the hard winter wheat belt.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Thirty- seven years and six days after President Wilson went to the Capitol to ask Congress to declare war on the Central Powers the news comes of the death, in total retirement, of Joseph Patrick Tumulty, Wilson's devoted secretary.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Eisenhower Administration today put the armed forces under the general security risk standards already applied to civilian Federal employes.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 8 -- Herman (Hank) Greenspun, newspaper publisher who for months has been editorially attacking Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today as the result of an editorial on the Senator.

TRENTON, April 8 -- More than fifty of New Jersey's county court judges laid aside their calendars, stepped down from their benches and converged on this city today. The action was not induced by the balmy weather.

The National Society for Crippled Children and Adults is now well launched on its Easter Seals campaign to raise $10,000,000. The work financed by the sale of Easter Seals covers the whole field of aiding the crippled as its challenging province.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- India praised the United States today for its help to needy nations "without strings."

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Republican Senate leaders warned the Allies today that future foreign aid might depend on their willingness to join the United States in a common front in the Indo-China crisis.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, said yesterday that the United States should be "a free market of ideas, a market which must not, however, be upset by those who would enter with a blackjack." He addressed 350 students and faculty at an "Academic Freedom Rally" in the college's Great Hall.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus this afternoon at the Madison Square Garden for the benefit of the James Weldon Johnson Community Center.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The United States and the high authority of the European Coal and Steel Community opened negotiations today on a prospective loan by this Government to the sixnation organization.

ALBANY, April 8 (AP) -- The New York State Health Commissioner announced today he was satisfied with the safety of the Salk anti-poliomyelitis vaccine to be tested on thousands of children in the state this spring.
MOOSE JAW, Sask, April 8 -A Royal Canadian Air Force training plane rammed an airliner loaded with passengers today and thirty-seven persons were killed.

An action was filed in Supreme Court here yesterday by Textron, Inc., to compel the American Woolen Company to open its stock books for inspection. Named as defendants were Roy Young, chairman of the board of American Woolen, and the Guaranty Trust Company, the company's transfer agent.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 8 (AP) -Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today he had never heard of Ray H. Jenkins before the Tennessee lawyer had been named, yesterday, as special counsel in Mr. McCarthy's dispute with the Army.

Officials of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad, pressing to abolish its ferry service between Christopher Street and Hoboken, N. J., declared yesterday that the railroad would lose more than $170,000 annually even if commuters paid an extra charge of 10 cents a trip.

Former President Harry S. Truman will be the guest of honor May 8 at a $70-a-plate dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Proceeds of the dinner, honoring his seventieth birthday, will go toward the campaign to build the Harry S. Truman Library.
WASHINGTON, April 8 -- President Eisenhower wished success today to four foreign agricultural trade missions about to set out on explorations of world markets to help United States farmer.
Jane Engel's spring and summer collection of fashions for all ages from engaging children of 4 to smart older women was shown yesterday during luncheon in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel.
The steel industry employed 636,100 persons in February, a decline of 1.4 per cent from the previous month, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday.

CLEVELAND, April 8 -- Kenneth D. Johnson, dean of the New York School of Social Work of Columbia University, called for an "immediate and certain end to the kind of treatment" accorded to the men of the armed forces by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and his investigating committee.

There comes in spring a day that is perfect in every way, and it is then that a mild sort of lunacy begins to take light hold on human behavior. Men of affairs who are all briefcase and business the rest of the year will stroll amiably about bumping into things and inadvertently offering their subway seats to very old ladies.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The Dodgers completed a sweep of their four-game spring series with the Senators by beating them, 6 -- 2, tonight before 6,310 fans in the chilly confines of Griffith Stadium. The summery weather that had prevailed for the past two days disappeared today.
WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -Two New York tax attorneys today told the Senate Finance Committee that there were many flaws in the 875-page tax revision bill passed by the House of Representatives.

MONTREAL, April 8 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings took a 2-1 lead in the four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup hockey finals tonight with a 5-2 victory over the defending champion Montreal Canadiens before 14,481 fans at the Forum.

RICHMOND, Va., April 8 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, said today that draft quotas during the fiscal year 1955 probably would exceed this year's by 8,000 to 10,000 men a month.

THE long-awaited television reply of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to the attack of Edward R. Murrow, the C. B. S. commentator, may rank as one of the Wisconsin Republican's less astute moves. Certainly it was not one of his smartest.
While most women are planning Easter outfits, professionals in the fashion world are thinking of what the well-dressed woman will be wearing next fall.
The Transit Authority reported yesterday that its revenues from the 15-cent fare in March were up 35.36 per cent and passenger volume was down 9.42 per cent compared with March, 1953.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 8 -- The West urged the Security Council today to take a look at the entire Palestine situation. It called on the Council to try to get at the roots of Arab-Israeli tensions.

The Long Island Rail Road was the victim last night of three separate acts of vandalism at intervals of about one hour. The railroad has been subjected to a long series of similar depredations, particularly by stone-throwing boys.

LAUREL, Md., April 9 (AP) -- Two more of the rapidly thinning ranks of Kentucky Derby hopefuls, Galdar and For Free, get their chance to remain in consideration in tomorrow's Chesapeake Stakes at Laurel.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 9 -- Three unearned runs in the third inning gave Manhattan's baseball team a 3-1 victory over Princeton in an afternoon game at University Field today. The Tigers beat Tufts, 8 -- 1, in a morning encounter.

PANAMA, April 9 -- The deep-seated bitterness and resentment between Panamanians and the United States administration in the Canal Zone apparently is coming to a boil. The reason for this is that curtailment of zone activities is causing increased unemployment and a consequent economic pinch on the Panama Republic.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- Edward Lamb of Toledo, Ohio, publisher and broadcaster, said today that the Federal Communications Commission had exceeded its authority in again questioning his loyalty when he applied for renewal of a television station license.
The usual heavy spring flow of new financing is slowing up the primary public market for absorbing new issues of securities.
Leopold Stokowski has been summoned to appear before the executive board of the musicians' union on charges that he passed a picket line in front of Radio Station WOR last Monday.

MINEOLA, L. I., April 9 -- William C. DeKoning Sr., former American Federation of Labor chieftain on Long Island, was sentenced to three terms of one-year to eighteen months in Sing Sing Prison today on two counts of extortion and one of grand larceny. The sentences are to run concurrently.

THE selection of American paintings in the Brooklyn Museum collection now on view at Knoedler's covers a period of roughly 200 years, from about 1720 to 1951. There are gaps; no Whistler, for example; the American impressionists are, except for the inclusion of an unworthy Twachtman, ignored, and the moderns are on the timid side.

Dearborn, Mich., has borrowed $9,000,000 on serial bonds maturing over fourteen years to finance school construction. The issue was awarded Thursday night to a syndicate headed by First National Bank of Chicago at an interest cost of 1.7897 per cent.

Events today: Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conducting, Doriot Anthony, flutist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Cosi fan tutte," Metropolitan Opera, 2; "Madama Butterfly," City Center, 2:30; Morning Freiheit Choral Concert Carnegie Hall, 8:30; "Carmen," Metropolitan Opera, 8; "La Boheme," City Center, 8:15.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The American Federation of Labor called today for a cut of $4,500,000,000 in income taxes to increase purchasing power and promote a healthy national economy.
A Robin Hood aspect of Frank Costello's operations was disclosed yesterday at the racketeer's trial on charges of income tax evasion.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy won a twenty-four delay today in the opening of the Senate investigation into his dispute with the Army. The delay was granted so that the Senator could deliver a controversial speech in Houston on April 21, "Texas Independence Day."

Radio station WNYC will broadcast the city budget hearings before the Board of Estimate on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. The tentative broadcast schedule calls for coverage from 10:30 A. M. Until 1 P. M. and from 3 P. M. until conclusion.

In his continued efforts to streamline the Police Department. Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday the elimination of twenty detective districts. This will free that number of clerical men for detective duty.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9 -- The United States declared today that 62 cents of every dollar earned by American investors abroad had been plowed back to help develop foreign economies.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Jerome T. McGowan, special inquiry officer of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, recommended today suspension of the deportation order against Jacob Burck, 48 years old, cartoonist for The Chicago Sun-Times.

" Omnibus" advertising, in which copy offering discounts on a product or group of related products is signed by more than one manufacturer or distributor, is meeting determined opposition. On the premise that such advertising is harmful to their products, in this case household small appliances, a number of manufacturers have indicated cooperation with the Metropolitan Electrical Appliance Dealers Association in barring the use of their names in such copy.

The State Department has good reason to be worried. Between rumbles of alarm abroad at the risks Secretary Dulles is running in threatening Communist China and mumbles of protest at home against continuing aid to countries that do not cooperate, carrying out American foreign policy requires something like the patience of the Sphinx and the agility of a leaping gazelle.

The lack of a clear definition of enemy aggression may bring the United States into war with Soviet Russia, a speaker at the twenty-fifth annual conference of the Eastern Psychological Association said yesterday.

Two apartment houses at 941-947 Washington Avenue in the Bronx have been sold by Jacob Goldberg to the Biltmore Operating Coorporation, represented by the Sherman Management Corporation. The buildings contain forty-four apartments and four stores.
Comfort was extended yesterday to the plain citizen who sacrifices his Saturday golf game once in a while to polish the family car and otherwise keep it in good condition.

Operations of the St. Regis Paper Company in the first quarter of this year resulted in a net income of $3,949,456, equal to 70 cents each on 5,397,657 common shares outstanding, Roy K. Ferguson, president and chairman, reported yesterday at the annual meeting here.

The Navy's newly reconverted heavy-lift cargo ship Marine Fiddler will complete in Newport News today the first practical test of her powerful booms. The test consists of the loading of 150 fabricated and machined parts for a wind tunnel compressor weighing 2,600,000 pounds.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said today new statistics showed "some improvement" in the employment picture, but the data disclosed a substantial decline in weekly factory earnings.

The State Government and the people of New York cannot ignore the increased highway fatalities in 1953 reported by James R. Macduff, State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. The death rate rose to 6.1 for each 100,000,000 miles traveled, from a rate of 5.8 in 1952. Personal injury and property damage from highway accidents also rose.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was denounced today by a leading member of the Roman Catholic hierarchy of Chicago as a "pitifully ineffective anti-Communist" who appeared to be more interested in catching headlines than in catching spies.

The familiar ceramic tile, used as long ago as 1800 B. C. in the sewer pipes at Crete and for wall surfaces in the Assyrian palace of Khorsabad in the eighth century B. C., is receiving many unfamiliar treatments today.

Ever since the fall of Byzantium and the rise of the Italian city states the eyes of the Western World have looked back to Greece. Generations of early scholars ransacked monasteries for classical manuscripts and rediscovered an almost forgotten language. They were followed in their work by modern linguists and archaeologists.
PARIS, April 9 -- Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin was reported today to have created the threat of a Cabinet crisis by his failure to resign his Allied command of the Central European area.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- March retail sales were off 2 per cent compared with February and 5 per cent compared with March, 1953, according to a "flash" report issued today by the Department of Commerce.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams said yesterday that the solution of the juvenile delinquency problem lay in the return of the family as the main social unit.
A large subscription has been reported for the dinner dance to be given on April 22 in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club.

VANCOUVER, B. C., April 9 (Canadian Press) -- More than 1,000 companies in Canada and the United States employ the atom in day-to-day operation to benefit mankind, industrialist John Jay Hopkins said today.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- William White, president of the New York Central Railroad, charged today that Robert R. Young "never did anything * * * that was good" for the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway when he ran it.

Commodity prices moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, rubber, sugar, copper, lead and tin were higher; coffee, wool, zinc, silk and potatoes closed lower, and cottonseed oil, soybean oil, burlap and hides ended mixed.
PARIS, April 9 -- In spite of changes in method since the death of Premier Stalin and the purge of Lavrenti P. Beria, Soviet policy toward East Germany seems fundamentally the same.
CHICAGO, April 9 -- Americans for Democratic Action and the Democratic National Chairman, Stephen A. Mitchell, were declared today to have "cleared up" their differences.

Strict regulation of large corporations under a uniform Federal system of incorporation was advocated last night by Dr. Solomon Barkin, research director of the Textile Workers Union of America, C. I. O.
Optimism in the stock market yesterday moved prices forward to their best levels in twenty-four years.
ALBANY, April 9 -- Leo Jandreau, business agent for a union in General Electric's Schenectady plant, denied today that he had ever been a member of the Communist party.
TRENTON, April 9 -- Carl Holderman, New Jersey Commissioner of Labor and Industry, threatened today to halt work on parts of the Garden State Parkway if contractors "persist in flouting the law."

ROME, April 9 -- Scattered wreckage of the British Comet, reported missing early this morning on a scheduled Rome to Cairo run, was discovered this afternoon at a point about thirty miles north and slightly east of the volcanic island of Stromboli and thirty-five miles west of Paola on the coast of Calabria.
QUEBEC, April 9 -- Maurice Duplessis, Quebec Prime Minister, insisted today that 300,000 taxpayers in the Province of Quebec would be subject to "double" personal income tax this year.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, sat as the accuser yesterday when charges of lying were filed against a teacher. But before the Board of Education meeting ended, Dr. Jansen was the target of attack.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., April 9 -- Voters here and in near-by Rye decided tonight that they didn't want to spend $2,100,000 on a new high school.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 9 -- A group of American companies has received a contract for work to cost 25,000,000 Australian pounds ($56,000,000) on the next stage of the Snowy Mountains hydroelectric project.
It was all over yesterday for the Mark Twain House.

IN "The Magic and the Loss," which was acted at the Booth last evening, Julian Funt has written a private problem play. Although admirably acted, skillfully directed and put on with general good taste, it never becomes part of the public domain. It is as if the fourth wall should not have been removed.

Two multiple-alarm fires occurred yesterday morning, one in Manhattan and one in the Bronx. Four alarms were sounded for the Manhattan fire at 120 East Fourteenth Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues and opposite Irving Place.
The following is a round-up of household hints that may be of interest to the homemaker:

CHICAGO, April 9 -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, told the country's business leaders today that if they would "step on the gas right now," economic conditions should improve decidedly before many more months.

NYACK, N. Y., April 9 -- A model airplane found last Sunday at the Hudson River shore, a mile south of Tarrytown, was identified today as belonging to Edward Lias, 20 years old, a third-year divinity student of the Missionary Training Institute in South Nyack.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 9 -- The Republican majority in the New Jersey Legilature agreed agreed here tonight to approve here tonight to approve a $31,000,000 tax increase exclusively for school aid.

It wasn't like last October at Ebbets Field yesterday in any respect. The Dodgers beat the Yankees, 8 -- 2, for the world champions' sixth straight defeat by major league opposition, only 4,006 fans were present and all of them were chilled to the bone.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Senate Judiciary subcommittee on juvenile delinquency was told today that institutions for correcting juvenile delinquency were unable to compete with "cafe society" for psychiatrists.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- E. V. Huggins, a vice president of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, charged today that the economy and defense of the United States were being endangered so that our Allies might prosper.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies and Washington Senators battled to a 2-2 ten-inning tie today in a windswept exhibition at Griffith Stadium.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold declared today that in these troubled times he found some "object lessons" in his favorite sport of mountaineering. Mr. Hammarskjold, who arrived here a year ago to head the United Nations, suggested one such lesson:

LEXINGTON, Key., April 9 (AP) -- Sea O Erin, the Hasty House Farm's stakes-winning colt, beat Homestake in a stretch duel at Keeneland today to capture the featured $5,000 allowance test for 3-year-olds.

GARDEN CITY, Kansas, April 8 -- Southwestern Kansas today resembled a huge patchwork quilt. Great squares of it were pale gray, smaller squares were darker brown, and a few, scattered at great intervals, were green.

A meeting of six of the city's investment trade associations reached the conclusion yesterday that the proposed extension of the city's 3 per cent sales tax to brokerage transactions would be difficult to administer and would further underscore the tax advantages of carrying on the securities business outside of New York.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor told a House committee today that President Eisenhower's Social Security program was fine so far as it went but that it did not go far enough in raising either benefits or taxes.
Ignatz Mezei, 57-year-old Hungarian-born carpenter, is excludable from the United States as a security risk, a three-man special board of inquiry ruled unanimously yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Harold E. Stassen, Foreign Operations Administrator, advocated today expansion of nonstrategic trade with the Soviet bloc as a means of "turning the Soviet world toward peace."

BUENOS AIRES, April 9 -- Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Minister of Economics, left today after having thawed a frost in commercial relations that threatened to put Argentine trade with West Germany into a deep freeze.

Paul Hartman, the dancing comedian, with the rubber face and legs, has a hankering for the Broadway theatre again. Last seen here in the revival of "Of Thee I Sing," presented in 1952, Mr. Hartman is reading a play called "Mr. Nobody," written by Miriam Young.

Some important and reputable unions which welcome public scrutiny of their welfare funds have decided not to cooperate with or contribute financially to the investigation of such funds initiated by the Central Trades and Labor Council, coordinating body for A. F. L. unions in New York.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., April 9 (AP) -- Joe Alston, former United States badminton champion, today defeated Malaya's Dave Choong, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 7, in the quarter-final round of the national tournament.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 9 -- A $20,000,000 expansion program to meet the increased needs for electricity in Westchester County was announced today by the Consolidated Edison Company.

Two "common sense" methods of dealing with youngsters were discussed at a recent meeting by Prof. Alfred L. Baldwin of Cornell University. He is head of the child development and family relationships department there.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy told the Post Office Department in January that Herman Greenspun, the newspaper publisher indicted yesterday for an editorial on the Senator, was "either threatening or advising murder" in the article.

Justice S. Samuel DiFalco of the State Supreme Court ruled here yesterday that both Robert R. Young, who is seeking control of the New York Central Railroad Company, and William White, Central president, must submit to pre-trial questioning in a stockholders' suit.

Possessing a history predating the Revolutionary War by several generations, Westchester County is rich in tradition and its 448 square miles have a liberal assortment of historic shrines. The first public reading of the Federal Constitution in New York State took place at White Plains.
Attorney General Brownell last night brought the nation up to date on the Administration's present accomplishments and proposed methods in dealing with Communists within the United States.

TOKYO, April 9 (AP) -- The United States expressed "deep regret" today for the injury to twenty-three Japanese fishermen in the March 1 hydrogen blast at Bikini and expressed confidence that all would recover.

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged at 110.9 for the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for farm products and industrial materials were offset by lower average prices for processed foods.

Your editorial "Congress and Public Housing," which appeared on March 31, is most deserving of an expression of appreciation from all who are aware of the tremulous period through which our civilization is passing, and of the important part that a decent home plays in these times.

Paolo Rosi, the Italian lightweight with a wallop in both fists, stopped Eddie Compo, the New Haven left-hook artist, in 54 seconds of the sixth of a scheduled ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

KANSAS CITY, April 9 (AP) -- Former President Truman agreed today a 1948 United States-British agreement abrogated the restriction on use of atomic bombs provided in the original atomic agreement between the two nations.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Eisenhower received from St. John's College, Annapolis, Md., today a collection of the great books that compose the heart of its liberal arts curriculum.
Willie Pep of Hartford, the former world featherweight champion, yesterday was permanently suspended from fighting in New York State.

PATERSON, N. J., April 9 (AP) -- A twenty-four-year-old murder indictment against Abdul Tahid, a Pakistani waiter whose eating habits touched off a bizarre chain of events, was dismissed today for lack of evidence.
PARIS, April 9 -- Premier Joseph Laniel defined today French policy in the Indo-China war as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Eisenhower Administration intends to use "new and powerful constitutional weapons" to destroy the Communist party in this country, Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. said tonight.

CHICAGO, April 9 -- No moisture of consequence was reported in the drought sections and as a result there was a sharp advance in wheat prices at the market opening here. Shorts covered freely and from the early tops there was recession profit taking.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 9 (UP) -- The Detroit Tigers rolled up nineteen hits, their biggest total of the exhibition season, to down the Cincinnati Redlegs, 10 to 5, before 2,595 fans in 53-degree weather today.

In a letter to stockholders of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railway Company, the management proxy committee of Elbridge T. Gerry and John J. O'Brien declares that Ben W. Heineman, head of the opposition faction, "has used as bait for your votes charges against your management."

CINCINNATI, April 9 -- The lung cancer death rate in New York State rose 385 per cent among males, compared with 68 per cent for females, from 1930 to 1950, Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, New York State Health Commissioner and president-elect of the American Public Health Association, said here today.

Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley declared yesterday there was "a continuing need" for cooperation among city departments in selecting school sites where children will have the maximum amount of safety in automobile traffic.

" River of No Return," a Twentieth Century-Fox Technicolor, offering in CinemaScope, co-starring Robert Mitchum and Marilyn Monroe, has been scheduled as the next attraction at the Roxy, according to the management.

A study on baked products made by Michigan State College, reported in the current issue of the Journal of Home Economics, suggests that commercial mixes do not rate either a blanket commendation or condemnation. The researchers examined cakes and muffins home-made in the commercial manner, home-made and frozen before baking, home-made and frozen after baking, prepared from a home-made mix and prepared from a commercial mix.

The Experimental Free Handicap will serve as the main attraction at the Jamaica race track today. With favorable weather, it is expected that more than 45,000 fans -- the largest turnout of the current season -- will witness the $20,000 added six-furlong event.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- President Eisenhower gave the "Help Korea Train" a push today and praised the voluntary help that the men of the United States Army already had given to Korea.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9 -- Britain proposed today that the United Nations Disarmament Commission set up a subcommittee that would hold closed-door discussions of the atomic disarmament problem.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 9 -- Washtenaw County, one of twelve Michigan counties scheduled to participate in the nation-wide polio vaccine tests, withdrew from the study today.

The amazing statement of our Secretary of State to the effect that the "retaliation" formula may be invoked because Chinese technicians, working with the Vietminh, come "awfully close" to the line laid down by President Eisenhower points up the folly and danger of the "new look" in our foreign policy.

Yesterday's weather was "so typical that it's unusual." Ernest J. Christie, meterologist in charge at the local weather bureau, explained the seemingly contradictory statement this way: The average high temperature for April 9 in New York is 55 degrees.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 9 -- Billy Joe Patton of Morganton, N. C., gained golfing glory today by leading the field in the Masters tournament. No other amateur has ever been able to do this.

Congratulations are due to Luxembourg for becoming the fourth of the six nations involved to ratify the European Defense Community. Luxembourg is the smallest of the six, but its action completes ratification of the project by Benelux, which also comprises Belgium and the Netherlands and is a major military and economic factor in Western Europe.

WILLA CATHER once said that any first-rate novel or story must have in it the strength of a dozen fairly good stories that have been sacrificed to it. The more fairly good stories a writer knows, then, the more frequently he will have to choose which he will sacrifice for the sake of the main effect he is trying to bring about.

NEW ORLEANS, April 9 (AP) -- Betty Jameson of San Antonio, moved ahead of Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias of Tampa, today to take a two-stroke lead at the midway point of the inaugural $5,000 Colonial women's golf tournament.

BERLIN, April 3 -- A debate that has raged here since 1945 has ended with the decision to rebuild the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church. Its shattered main spire will stand untouched to remind Berliners of the wages of war.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Joe Adonis was sentenced today to eight to twenty-four months in jail for falsely swearing before Senate crime investigators that he was a United States citizen.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it did not intend to ask the tenants of its Riverton project to pay the full amount of the rent increase that the company is demanding of the Board of Estimate.
MILWAUKEE, April 9 (AP) -- Milwaukee became "the home of the Braves" again today to the ecstatic screams of 30,000 fans lining a twenty-five-block parade route through the heart of the city.

RALEIGH, N. C., April 9 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, National Director of Selective Service, said today he took full responsibility for postponing induction of a young University of North Carolina senior basketball player.

Encouraged by a $15,000,000 licensing deal for American sale of an electric shaver, a leading German electronics producer disclosed plans here yesterday for introducing other products into this country.
Clouds of civic opposition and dissent hung heavily over City Hall yesterday, portents of the tempest expected at next week's public hearings on the 1954-55 budget.

Caspar H. Citron took legal action yesterday in an attempt for election as Democratic leader of the Eighth Assembly District South. A plurality of the Democratic County Committee of the district, pledged to him, were elected at last year's primary.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 9 -- Preservation of one of California's most magnificent stands of giant redwoods -- the Calaveras South Grove in Tuolumne County -- was assured today when John D. Rockefeller Jr. donated a million dollars toward its purchase.
The Pacific Western Oil Corporation observed its twenty-fifth year in 1953 with the highest gross and net income in its history.
NEW DELHI, India, April 9 -- Hindi, the national language of India under the Constitution, is spoken by 42 per cent of the population, according to a census published today.
A police youth patrol averted a threatening gang war in the Bronx last night.
LONDON, April 9 -- Britain today weighed the cost of a stunning blow to her proudest pioneer industry, jet civil aviation, as the crash of a Comet airliner was confirmed.
WANTAGH, L. I., April 9 -- Two-year-old Daniel Daly of 1103 McLean Drive, here, whose family said he loved the water, drowned today in the Forest City community lake two blocks from his home.
CLEVELAND, April 9 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, emphasized here today that the final decision in any future war would be determined by "the individual fighting man on the ground."

HONG KONG, April 9 -- About 10 per cent of the villages in China have been pronounced politically "backward" by the Peiping People's Daily. The Chinese Communist organ declared recently that "correct implementation" of party and Government policy had been difficult in such villages.

LINDEN, N. J., April 9 -- Ernest Bussiere, 49 years old, of 26 East Nineteenth Street here, without a telephone to summon a physician or other aid, presided at the birth of identical twin girls born to his wife at their home early today.

JERUSALEM, Jordanian Sector, April 9 -- United Nations truce officials here asserted today that the clash "very definitely" occurred Tuesday night between volunteer guardsmen defending the Jordanian frontier village of Husan and an enemy force.
The New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced yesterday that it had broken a black market in the sale of fair-traded Paper-Mate pens in the metropolitan area.

DAYTON, Ohio, April 9 (AP) -- Assistant Secretary of State Henry Byroade advised Israel tonight to "drop the attitude of conqueror" and at the same time told Israel's neighboring Arab states that their own policy was "most dangerous."

We live in the twentieth century, and because we do some things seem almost too fantastic to be believed. On the big island of Mindanao, in the southern Philippines, an immense population of jungle rats has suddenly swarmed over 160,000 acres of farm land, taking more than 90 per cent of the food supply.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 9 -- Rock Hudson will be starred as an Irish Robin Hood in "Captain Lightfoot" at Universal- International. Douglas Sirk will direct the screen play, which was written by W. R. Burnett from his own novel of the same title. Filming will be done in Ireland this summer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 9 -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield presented today to Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, a souvenir album of the new eight-cent Statue of Liberty stamp that President Eisenhower dedicated in Washington yesterday.

TOKYO, March 29 -- Japan is moving progressively away from the free enterprise system proclaimed here after the advent of Premier Shigero Yoshida's conservative government in 1948, in the opinion of some competent experts.

JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, April 9 -- Tension increased today in the area around the Gaza strip with an Israeli Army report of four strikes across the border last night and early today by Egyptian armed bands.

The two-story industrial building at 14-16 Orchard Street in Wallington, N. J., has been leased by the Textile Rework Corporation, contractor and finisher of textile products. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker. The Art Novelty Linen Manufacturing Company, owner and former occupant of the property, recently moved its operations to a larger plant in Long Branch.

WEYMOUTH, Mass., April 9 (AP) -- Luxembourg's Josy Barthel -- star of the indoor mile circuit this winter -- suffered his first American defeat tonight as he lost to Dick Ollen of Northeastern University in the South Weymouth Naval Air Station invitation track meet.

New York libraries contain many of the rarest and most interesting books in the world and now the Morgan Library, over on East Thirty- sixth Street, has acquired one of three known copies of a missal Gutenberg is believed to have printed before he did the famous Bible, long hailed as the first book to have been printed from movable types.

A $2.50 American gold piece, minted in Philadelphia in 1841, was auctioned yesterday for 2,400-fold its face value as the Davis-Graves collections moved through the second day of a three-day sale at Steinway Hall, 113 West Fifty-seventh Street.

THE opening day of the trout season is one occasion when a discussion of trout fishing would be futile, for every New York angler with a fly or spinning outfit, plus a host of visitors from adjoining states, is fully occupied with the effort of getting a few trout for dinner.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (UP) -- The Senate voted today to keep a Congressional checkrein on a proposed system for buying new Federal buildings on the time payment plan.

WASHINGTON, April 8 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Minnesota, said today that the Eisenhower Administration had committed "the most colossal financial blunder in the nation's history, either by accident or design."

The one-story taxpayer, 50 by 200 feet, at 334-336 Fulton Avenue in Hempstead, L. I., has been sold by Harvey Newins and George Skouras to a client of Margold, Ersken Wang. John J. Reynolds, Inc., was the broker. John T. McCormick Jr. represented the buyer and Biller Snyder were attorneys for the sellers.
MOSCOW, April 7 -- Two playwrights who have won Stalin prizes have recently been rebuked by the Communists.

Not in my official capacity as Consul General of Venezuela in New York, but as a Venezuelan citizen and a Latin American, I take issue with the constant jabs that appear on the editorial page of The Times against the Venezuelan Government and the legitimate Governments of other Latin-American countries.
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- Is Senator Joseph R. McCarthy running for President? Is he trying to capture control of the Republican party?
Ten boys ranging from 4 to 16 years old were seized yesterday by policemen trying to combat vandalism against the Long Island Rail Road.

Blood donations to the New York Regional Red Cross on Thursday totaled 727 pints. Included were 161 pints given at the Bankers Trust Company, 9 Pine Street, and 137 pints at Congregation Derech Emunoh, Beach Sixty-seventh Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard Rockaway Beach, Queens.

While the average New Yorker was still asleep yesterday, one of the city's native sons awoke at 5:30 A. M., just as he has been forced to do for most of his adult life. He stared with wonder at the windows of his room because they were enormous, there were two of them and they were not barred.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 9 -- Supreme Court Justice Frank H. Coyne denied today an attorney's request that a $28,000 verdict against his client be set aside because a juror in the case brought two public library books into the jury room.
Leroy Gore, the Wisconsin country editor who started the petition drive to recall Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, is now receiving what he terms an "amazing" amount of support from New Yorkers.

BERLIN April 9 -- Three West European airlines are authoritatively reported to have received permission from the Soviet Union to fly into the East Berlin airport. The routes must be approved by the Western powers.
ALBANY, April 9 -- The State Board of Regents conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws on Sir Winston Churchill tonight at the closing session of its anniversary convocation.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday and prices closed slightly irregular, 2 points higher to 15 points net lower than Thursday on active months.
LONDON, April 9 -- The stock markets here advanced further today under stimulus of Wall Street's strength and more good dividend and profit statements.

Palm Sunday, commemorating the triumphant entry of Jesus Christ into Jerusalem, will be observed tomorrow in churches throughout the city as worshipers begin observance of the sacred Holy Week period.
WASHINGTON, APRIL 9 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has proposed an immediate temporary reduction in mail rates for the overseas routes of domestic airlines.

The liner United States will sail today with Clarence P. Gehrig as her new chief purser. His former duties in the same office aboard the America have been taken over by John J. Wilkinson, former executive purser aboard the United States.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 9 (AP) -- Thousands of Communist-led Vietminh rebels dug nearer the heart of Dienbienphu as rebel artillery roared today in apparent prelude to a new massive assault on the French Union fortress.
Adding spice to the simplest of dresses, belts appear in exciting new styles and a wide variety of fabrics this spring.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 9 -- The Giants lost no face when they lost a 1-0 decision to the Indians today. Their efforts stymied by three Cleveland double-plays in the last three innings, Manager Leo Durocher's men were within two outs of their first extra-inning contest of the exhibition season.

LONDON, April 9 -- Sir Winston Churchill and Anthony Eden will explain Britain's opposition to hasty Allied action in Indo-China and will raise other differences over foreign policy in their discussions with John Foster Dulles, United States Secretary of State, here.

Apropos the construction and operation of a Niagara power plant by the State of New York you write on April 2 that the private utilities label this "'socialism,' a conclusion reached by the only too-prevalent method of labeling everything done by a Government or governmental agency as 'socialism'."
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Two California men received a patent this week for a cart that takes the stoop, squat and kneel out of weeding.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- The Department of Agriculture was accused today of a "breach of faith with the Congress."
WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's production of winter wheat at 677,981,000 bushels. The crop has been plagued by drought and dust storms.

TUCSON, Ariz., April 9 -- Senator McCarthy said today that he would discuss further "in the near future" his charge that Communist influence had held up for eighteen months the development of the hydrogen bomb.

ST. THOMAS, V. I., April 9 -- Archie A. Alexander, a building contractor of Des Moines, Iowa, became today the first Republican Governor of the Virgin Islands since the establishment of civil government here in 1931.

Direct cargo-trade between the Great Lakes and Western and Mediterranean Europe, via the St. Lawrence River route -- a segment of international maritime commerce that has grown steadily over the years -- will attract a record fleet of sixty-eight foreign-flag, shallow-draft cargo ships this season.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 9 (AP) -- Wisconsin's fighters swept the four semi-final matches tonight to gain a commanding lead in the National Collegiate boxing championships at Penn State.
Changing social customs affect the job of the bridal consultant at large department stores.
CHICAGO, April 9 -- Demands that the United Automobile Workers will make on the major auto manufacturers next year for a guaranteed annual wage were revealed today.
WASHINGTON, April 9 -- Secretary of State Dulles will leave by plane tomorrow evening for urgently needed unity talks with Britain and France on a plan to win the war in Indo-China.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 9 -- According to an authoritative source, Arab representatives plan to walk out of the United Nations Security Council discussions on the Israeli frontier situation unless the Israeli attack on Nahhalin is treated as a separate item.
ROME, April 9 -- The concert given last night at the Rome Radio Auditorium was a particular success for the women participating.
DETROIT, April 9 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that March new-car sales reached a total of 493,000, a five-month high mark.
Aroused New Yorkers are preparing to fight legislation in Congress that jeopardizes the Columbus Circle Coliseum and other major building projects costing at least $200,000,000.

Josephine Herbst's latest book, "New Green World," will be the first of the American Procession Books, a series that will deal with crucial episodes in our history and cultural growth. Scheduled for May 3 publication by Hastings House, the volume concerns John Bartram and his group of eighteenth century botanists, whose work influenced naturalists, scientists and poets of the romantic movement.

Your March 31 editorial "The Delinquent Community" is a thoughtful, sound and comprehensive exposition of the depth and range of the enormous problem of juvenile delinquency. That editorial is indeed heartening and particularly welcome as superseding previous ones, which surprisingly advocated an ill-advised proposal for imposing fines, to the limit of $25, upon parents who "omit to exercise reasonable diligence" in preventing their children "from willful destruction of property of the city."
The Waterfront Commission denied a hiring agent's license yesterday to Daniel (Danny) St. John, an ex-convict and former hiring boss on Pier 84, Hudson River.

BOSTON, April 10 (AP) -- Joe Miceli, New York welterweight, scored his fifth straight boxing victory tonight with a sixth-round technical knockout over Steve Marcello of Providence in a nationally televised bout in Mechanics Building.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 10 -- It took about as long ashore tonight to establish the leaders in the Larchmont Yacht Club spring dinghy regatta as it took to sail ten races in the afternoon.

ROME, April 10 -- Two more anonymous contest pieces were played by the Rome Radio Orchestra last night, and at least one of them produced the conviction that here was music that one would gladly hear again.

DURING the next week the trout season will be wide open in the majority of the Eastern states. Although most of the conservation agencies have set records in trout- stocking, the problem faced by most anglers is not where they will find the most fish but how to get the most out of their fishing.
I HAVE been reflecting on the question you raised in an article some time ago with regard to the effect of greatly broadened reecorded repertory on concert programs and audience attitudes.

You have performed a highly important service by attempting to air both sides of the issue on the "instant retaliation policy." However, Senator Knowland's reply to Mr. Bowles, "The 'Instant Retaliation' Policy Defended" (March 21), was a disappointment to many seeking clarification of this question.

In his article on the Vice Presidency -- "Between Throttlebottom and Jefferson" (March 28) -- is not Sidney Hyman rather unfair to include William R. King among the men he describes as "wayward figures" of the "Mr. Throttlebottom tradition"?

LONDON, April 10 -- An explosion in half empty kerosene tanks or decompression of fuselage were among the theories advanced today to explain the destruction of the British Comet air liner off Italy Thursday.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 10 -- A controversial California law requiring an applicant for state tax exemption to sign a loyalty oath drew fire this week from a growing number of churches.

SAN JUAN -- With the number of winter tourists growing year by year, Puerto Rico is now directing its big pitch at the potential summer visitor. The biggest lures this year are such disparate attractions as grand opera and game fishing.

TRENTON, April 10 -- When the New Jersey Senate and Assembly reconvene here on Monday the Republican majority will seek to put through its legislative program, adopted after an all-day meeting in Princeton on Friday.
CHICAGO, April 10 (UP) -- Adlai E. Stevenson, Democratic Presidential nominee in 1952, will undergo an operation Monday for removal of a kidney stone, it was announced today.

Bishop Loughlin of Brooklyn and Mount St. Michael of the Bronx tied for team honors yesterday as the local outdoor interscholastic track season opened with the fifth annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association Relay Carnival at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. The meet drew more than 700 competitors from twenty-six metropolitan schools.

Security measures were tightened by the Long Island Rail Road and the Queens police yesterday as teen-agers committed eight new acts of vandalism against the railroad. These brought the total of such incidents in the last forty-eight hours to twenty-three.

PARIS, April 10 -- The French Government and French opinion are so divided on the question of Indo-China that the prospect of a stiffer Allied policy in Asia as proposed by the United States has merely tightened French tension.

LONDON, April 9 -- The British Government is re-examining the deployment of its armed forces in the Far East to see whether it could furnish military aid in Indo-China should the situation there seriously deteriorate.

THE jaunty title notwithstanding, this is a long, sober, judicious analysis of a significant social institution. Kimball Young is ideally qualified to write this volume. A grandson of Brigham Young, he knows from family recollections what it was like to live in a polygamous household. A distinguished social scientist and Professor of Sociology at Northwestern University, he commands the techniques and writes with the objectivity of the scholar.

HAVANA -- Air passengers arriving here these days find Cuba speeding the completion of the expanded Jose Marti airport, which will have among its features the best terminal facilities in the hemisphere.

New York State's harness racing campaign will get off to its earliest start in history tomorrow night when Yonkers Raceway will open its gates for its fifth season of the standardbred sport. Holding the featured spot on the program is the $5,000 Inaugural Class 14 Pace.

KINGS POINT, L. I., April 10 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy captured 15 of 16 events in a track-and-field meet with Hunter College at Roosevelt Field this afternoon, to triumph, 117 1/3 to 22 2/3.
Robert W. Purcell is a relatively young man -- he is 42 -who, as a salaried executive has made a small fortune for himself and a big fortune for his principals, simply by attending to his arithmetic.

IF a fellow had the slightest bit of gumption and if he were more man than mouse, he'd resolutely turn his back on the obvious and pick against both the Yankees and Dodgers in the about-to-begin pennant races. This reporter feels in his bones that these perennial rivals will not meet again in the next world series.

CHICAGO, April 10 (UP) -- The alleged leader of a $10,000,000-a-year narcotics empire was wounded seriously and his brother was killed early today when they were shot in the back by two men riding in the rear of their automobile.
In the most recent future-book listing for the Kentucky Derby, Joseph Gavegnano's Errard King was a 20-to-1 proposition. The odds shortened yesterday.
Experts studying proposed tax measures designed to increase private investment abroad concluded last week that the contents were far less stimulating than they had been labeled.
CHICAGO, April 10 -- The nation is being subjected to "political witchcraft," Senator Hubert H. Humphrey today told the seventh annual convention of Americans for Democratic Action.

OF the flowering plants grown commercially and sold for home decoration, perhaps the most popular now is the azalea. The hydrangea, once a great favorite in spring, is still in good demand in small communities.

The nation's newest major copper project successfully completed its thirty-day "trial run" last week. This means that under its contract with the Government it has qualified to begin its official production life on May 1.
The new military personnel security program explained last week to the Senate by Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson is certain to have repercussions upon service morale and discipline.
The R. Coulton Davis 1804 silver dollar, one of the rarest coins in this country, was sold yesterday at public auction for $8,000 to an anonymous Midwestern collector.

The stock market followed a roller-coaster pattern last week; down in the earlier part and up during the later sessions. Traders received an abrupt jolt on Tuesday when share prices declined drastically between 2 and 3 P. M. on sharply accelerated volume.

A QUARTER of a century ago Vernon Parrington wrote a memorable essay on Horace Greeley designed, in part, to revive a reputation that had been "carelessly ignored." Whatever else we might say of that reputation, today, we would not say that it had been neglected or ignored.
ATHENS, April 10 -- The expected reshuffle of the Greek Cabinet took place today. There were eleven replacements, but only few in important posts.

Many churches have taken up the fad of "Ministers (or Ministerettes) of Music," who in addition to playing the organ and conducting rehearsal of the choir(s), give vocal lessons. I wonder just how much vocal damage is being done to the choristers, throughout the land by this procedure.

BACK East there are little items in the papers now and then about dust storms. People back there doubtless read them casually and with little interest. But take it from an Easterner who now knows about dust storms -- there's nothing casual or uninteresting about them once you have been in one.

THIS is the capstone of a six-volume inquiry into ethics in relation to modern economic life conducted under the auspices of the National Council of Churches of Christ and its antecedent body, the Federal Council. "Ethics for a Business Society" utilizes material from the four books already published and from the two concluding volumes which will appear shortly.

WASHINGTON -- Cars, trains and planes to the contrary, walking is still the best way to get acquainted with the country. It was in support of this proposition, as well as with the specific aim of championing a historic landmark, that Justice William O. Douglas and his companions, among whom the author was one, made their hike last month down the old Chesapeake and Ohio Canal, which parallels the Potomac River.

HACKENSACK, April 10 -- An insurgent slate of five candidates has been entered in the April 20 Republican primary in Bergen County in protest against alleged "dictatorial" actions by State Senator Walter Jones in drawing up a slate for the regular organization.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Registered lobbyists report that they are spending less money on their Federal "legislative interests."

THE owner of a small rock garden has at least two choices as to the type of garden his will be. And therefore two choices as to the kinds of plants he can select. It may be the colorful ones, with bright masses of bloom, easily grown and effective.

MILWAUKEE, April 10 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Hawks, who have been as unsuccessful at the gate as they have been in the National Basketball Association, will remain in Milwaukee under a new public stock arrangement announced tonight by General Manager Ben Kerner.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The Administration asked Congress today to recommend that the states liberalize their absentee voting laws.
PARIS, April 10 -- The French Government is considering publishing a White Paper to clarify its dispute with Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin over his criticism of the European army treaty.

ADVANCE bookings for airline space during May and early June indicate that more persons will be flying to resort areas this spring than at any other similar period in the history of the industry. The upward trend in air travel during this time of the year is attributed by airline officials to the increasing varieties of attractive "packages" and low-cost fares.

BONN, Germany, April 10 -- The newly created East German satellite regime has scored a success in getting at least one Western Government to acknowledge its authority. This occurred despite the contention of the Western Big Three and the West German Parliament that the Federal Republic is the only legally constituted governing body in all Germany.

SMALL fruits such as strawberries are particularly well adapted to the home garden where space is often limited. For with a little planning and a few necessary precautions they will bear abundantly and provide luscious fruits for the entire family from June to September.
THE report in this column last week that the American can contingent to the recent international tournament in Monte Carlo had won great popularity by failing to win anything, proved to be premature.

A BIG city can be a lonesome place when, like Angela, one is too young to play in the street with the other children. Angela wanted a playmate very much. When a pigeon landed on her window sill she hoped he would be her friend, but he flew away. There was the amiable black cat she met in her father's vegetable store, but a dog chased him away.

If every one of our 160,000,000 men, women and children in the United States were a pleasure boat skipper there would be 160,000,000 varying answers and different points of view on the question: What are the chores in the fitting-out season?

Major league baseball sets out this week upon what promises to be one of its most interesting campaigns in years. Can the Yankees and their fabulous skipper, Casey Stengel, extend their phenomenal string of successes for one season more and make it six American League pennants in a row?
An antidote for juvenile delinquency in the school system was said yesterday to have been used continuously for seven years by the Board of Education -- but the doses were termed too small.

Dick Eichhorn, St. John's 190-pound 6-footer, who won Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference pitching honors in 1952, but who had only a so-so season last year, demonstrated yesterday at Dexter Park, Woodhaven, Queens, that he was out to cause rival batsmen trouble again.

SUPPOSE two professional fund raisers -- members of a generally respected and respectable firm -- were to see another of their partners, something of a no-good, commit a hit-and-run killing in Central Park one night? The witnesses, both decent fellows, know they should report the crime to the police. On the other hand, in the already queasy business of collecting charity for profit, such adverse publicity would permanently ruin the firm.
LONDON, April 8 -- Study of the classics was advocated today as a bridge across national divisions. Proponent of the theory was 88-year-old Gilbert Murray, Britain's most eminent Greek scholar.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 10 -- Princeton's baseball team collected ten hits off three Pennsylvania pitchers to defeat the Quakers, 9 -- 2, today at University Field.

MONTREAL, April 10 -- Johnny Wilson's second-period goal proved the big one tonight as the Detroit Red Wings scored a 2-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens and took a prohibitive 3-1 lead in games in their four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup hockey finals.
Travel last year cost American residents almost $1,300,000,000, an increase of $115,000,000 over 1952.

Parents were blamed last night for juvenile delinquency. The critics were six junior high school and high school students from the metropolitan area and upstate who took part in the New York Times Youth Forum televised over Du Mont Station WABD.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 10 -- A series of actions designed to strengthen the unity and effectiveness of the forces fighting the Communist-led Vietminh in Vietnam was announced here today. The plans were made known as Bao Dai, Chief of State, departed for France to take part in the negotiations there for full independence of his country.

The University of South Carolina has established a reading clinic which will provide a laboratory where students in the School of Education can take part in diagnostic and remedial work in the teaching of reading. Improved teaching methods will be devised. The first reading clinic in the southeastern states, it will also provide consultation services to parents and teachers.

Seven Brooklyn stores were robbed within two and a half hours last night, the crime wave being started by two teen-aged girls who stole $100 from a dry goods store cash register. One of the girls seized the money when the other was examining merchandise with the proprietor, Miss Pearl Shorr, in the store at 99 East Fourth Street.
CHICAGO, April 10 -- There was no comment today from Samuel Cardinal Stritch on the speech attacking Senator Joseph R. McCarthy made yesterday by the Senior Auxiliary Bishop of the Chicago Diocese.

LET it be said quickly: William March knows where human fears and secrets are buried. He announced it in "Company K," a novel published twenty years ago and equaled only by Dos Passos' "Three Soldiers" as a sampling of men at war.

IN the summer of 1901, Bruce Siberts, a horse rancher on the Cheyenne River in South Dakota, rode across the still unfenced range to join a round-up headed by a wealthy French-Indian. He found the cook, night wrangler and two or three cowboys white, while twenty-five others were Indians and mixed breeds.

LONDON, April 10 -- When Secretary of State Dulles arrives here tomorow to discuss United States foreign policy on Southeast Asia with the British Government, he will find that policy an issue in the bitter political battle between the Government and the Laborite Opposition.

ST. LOUIS, April 10 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals today stole six bases today, five in one merry inning, while outclassing their former neighbors, now the Baltimore Orioles, 8 -- 3, in the first game of a two-game hangover from a long-time city series.
PLEASANT VALLEY, N. Y., April 10 (UP) -- Two Yale University students were killed today when their car collided with another on Route 44 near here.

ST. THOMAS, V. I. -- The great summer attraction of the American Virgin Islands is something they do not have: weather. Instead they have climate, and there is none better in all the Caribbean. The three sisters -- St. Thomas, St. Croix and St. John -- float in an apparently non-humid corner of the southern sea, and remain sunny, insect-free, and breeze-fanned, kind to sufferers from arthritic and sinus complaints and hay fever.

IN 1872 Flaubert wrote to George Sand that he was about to begin a modern novel which he intended to be comic. This was "Bouvard and Pecuchet." He worked on it, with interruptions, for almost nine years, leaving it unfinished at his death in 1880.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 10 -- (AP) -- The Hasty House Farm's Pomace pulled away in the stretch today to capture the $10,000 added Phoenix Handicap at Keeneland.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- The issues of foreign policy are now so intricate and dangerous that honest men hesitate to pronounce dogmatic judgments about whether American policy in France and Indo-China, Britain or Korea, is right or wrong.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The text of a statement issued by Secretary of State Dulles at the White House today:

IN the United States about sixty-five million persons are drinkers. Of these, about four million are alcoholics. This represents the highest rate of alcoholism in the world, and the number of both drinkers and alcoholics is growing.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra completed its New York season yesterday with the final concert of its fifth visit to this city. The concert was at Carnegie Hall, Charles Munch conducted and Doriot Anthony, the orhcestra's first flutist, was the soloist.
THERE is many a bypath along which the gardener can pursue his hobby. One that presents somewhat of a challenge is the collecting of early American books on horticulture.

A radical reparture in the procedure of holding trade shows has been announced by the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. The group's national market week for spring and summer lines will be held Oct. 10 to 13 in individual showrooms in New York, rather than in a hotel.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the sponsor of the amendment which joined Alaska to the Hawaiian Statehood Bill in the Senate I have read with great interest your editorial of April 1 entitled "For Fifty Stars."
NEWARK, April 10 -- The Greater Newark Science Fair at the Newark College of Engineering was held this afternoon without 15-year-old Kenneth M. Mick's cyclosis demonstration.

NOW that much trans-Atlantic passenger tonnage has gone back to the traditional job of ferrying tourists to Europe, after lending a hand in the most successful winter cruise season since before the war, one might expect a lull on the summer cruise front.

ATLANTA, April 10 -- Factory employment in the Southeast declined 10,600 in February, continuing the downtrend which began last October, the Atlanta Regional Bureau of Labor Statistics reported this week. The level of 1,930,700 workers was estimated at one half of 1 per cent under that of January and slightly over 3 per cent less than February, 1953.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 10 (AP) -- A State Department official said today the United States would oppose any move to force the Soviet Union out of the United Nations because this might wreck the organization.

Department store business in New York City last week topped the same week a year ago by a healthy margin. Chief factor was the difference in dates of Easter in the two years. Last year this was the week immediately after Easter, a week when business is traditionally lower.

Two of the oldest maxims of the retail trade are: that you can't do business with an empty shelf and that the only way to get business is to go out after it. Both of them will be tested in -of all times -- the dog days of the summer.

ST. PAUL, April 10 -- Rural dissatisfaction with the Eisenhower Administration farm program and Democratic sentiment among labor groups in the cities are major factors in the Democratic-Farmer Labor party's campaign plans in Minnesota.
