Len Jordan, the author's husband and the canyon sheepman of the story, was during those years being shaped, conditioned and toughened for a much bigger job than lambing and shearing a few thousand sheep.

The United Negro College Fund officially opened its eleventh annual campaign last week with a goal of $1,750,000, an increase of $250,000 over the 1953 quota. This is the largest amount sought by the fund for the operating budgets of its thirty-one member colleges.

THE sun that always shines in the travel posters has a brighter glow this spring than it has had in many a year. There is more bounce in the travel agents' sales talk, a more expansive gleam in the eye of the prospective tourist.

THE three most famous American expatriate painters have been repatriated. For Whistler, Sargent and Mary Cassatt are joined in an exhibition which, originated by the Art Institute of Chicago, is now at the Metropolitan Museum.

Taking account of the great improvement in the economic situation of the free world, the Eisenhower Administration has submitted to Congress a foreign aid program for the coming fiscal year which has been reduced to $3,500,000,000. This is more than one billion dollars less than was appropriated for the preceding year, and more than two and a half billion dollars less than was needed for 1953.

MIAMI BEACH -- It is always nice to come back to Miami Beach on safari from the world of reality, if that is the right word for the world of the hydrogen bomb. While the air editions of New York's morning newspapers convey the details of freezing April weather back home, the Florida sun turns pale northern skins a tender pink, blazing from a sky that harbors no mushroom clouds.

WOODBURY, L. I., April 10 -- Fourteen earnest teen-agers have shouldered the entire responsibility of raising $50,000 to enlarge the facilities of the Woodbury Methodist Church, the only church in this village of 1,800.

Over the past six months, the issue of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and his activities have commanded more public attention than almost any other domestic question. The controversy reached a high pitch last month in the Senator's clash with the Army over the affair of Private G. David Schine.

AN eminent German theologian, Karl Heim, has defied current theological tendencies in Germany by devoting a lifetime to the study of the relation of science to religion. The current volume is the second to be translated of a series of six German volumes in which he has garnered the fruits of his lifetime labors.

NEXT Tuesday evening in the Governor's Palace of Colonial Williamsburg in Virginia there will be an evening of music in tribute to the birthday of Thomas Jefferson. Like Colonial Williamsburg itself, the concert will be an attempt to reconstruct the atmosphere of the evenings of music that Jefferson attended and often played a part in a little less than 200 years ago.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 10 -- purely statistical terms, the French Union side would appear have the advantage in the Indo-China War.
The Indian-dress type of styling, introduced in California in "squaw" dresses, is making its influence felt throughout the ready-to-wear market, according to resident buying offices.

ST. PETERSBURG -- Increasingly the west coast of Florida is thinking of itself less as a series of isolated locales and more as a continuous stretch from Homosassa and Tarpon Springs in the north down to and through Naples and Fort Meyers in the south.
The proposed extension of the New York City sales tax might drive away business and bring less, not more, revenue to the city, it was asserted yesterday.

None has existed in English, according to the publishers, although Havelock Ellis enthusiastically prefaced the translation of "Le Grand Meaulnes" (rechristened "The Wanderer" in English).

WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The armed forces will open bids Monday on the first installment of 83,000,000 barrels of jet plane fuel, the biggest item of a billion-dollar oil purchase program for the coming fiscal year.
BUENOS AIRES, April 10 -- Raul Lamuraglia, formerly one of Argentina's largest textile magnates, was arrested April 2 on unspecified charges, members of his family disclosed today.

SPRING brings with it an increasing number of short and inexpensive holiday trips for people who want to get away from the city for only a few days and at moderate cost. Many of these excursions are by modern motor coach. Tours by air coach are an answer for people who want to cover greater distances economically and on a limited time budget.

THROUGHOUT most of the country this week it is time to sow seeds of lettuce and to transplant seedlings if they are available. Since the crop from seed will be harvested in approximately six weeks, several sowings are essential for a continuous yield.
LONDON, April 10 -- A polite, discreet but definite antipathy toward the methods, though not the objectives, of United States foreign policy seemed to be developing within Government circles.

ERIC SEVAREID is one of the reasons there'll always be radio. In his five-minute essays at 11:10 P. M. each weekday evening over the C.B.S. network the Washington correspondent brings an unusual combination of perception, objectivity and wit to the airwaves.
The cornerstone was placed yesterday for F. W. Olin Hall, the ten-story residence for students at the Cornell University Medical College. The new building is scheduled for occupancy in October.

THIS latest volume in the Taste of Our Time series is probing reappraisal of the stature of one of the greatest artists of the nineteenth century. Francois Fosca, a French art critic, sets out to demolish the superficial view of many of the artist's contemporaries that he was a cruel realist, and also the later view which came with the rise of the modern movement, that Degas was primarily a chronicler of his time.

THE chinchilla, a luxuriously clad, highly prized rodent once native to the South American Andes, has become a full-fledged naturalized North American, so much so that some 12,000 breeders of the little animal are about to find out whether they have an expensive hobby or a home fur industry with an investment of more than $125 million.

The March 1 H-bomb blast at Bikini was still reverberating last week. In London the British Government pledged itself to rise all its influence to get top-level Big Three talks on the H-bomb and world tensions. In New York, the Big Three tried to get new discussions started in the United Nations Disarmament Commission on the long-deadlocked issue of international atomic controls.

Dr. B. F. Skinner, Professor of Psychology at Harvard University, was elected yesterday as president of the Eastern Psychological Association. He was chosen at the closing session of the organization's twenty-fifth annual conference in the New Yorker Hotel.
HARTFORD, April 10 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff of Hartford, a former United States Representative, has taken the lead in the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

THE current exhibition at the Matisse Gallery is called "Aspects of Significant Form," a rather pretentious title considering that it is a pleasant, fairly interesting anthology of twentieth century School of Paris painting and sculpture and no more.

The mysterious little round tin box started the whole thing. It was a going-away present to Oliver Wendell Holmes the elder, when that distinguished man of letters set out for Europe in the Eighteen Eighties.

Meeting under the awesome cloud of the hydrogen bomb, the United Nations Disarmament Commission assembled on Friday in a new effort to break the eight-year disarmament deadlock. All that the commission could do at this time, however, was to confirm the deadlock and move to entrust further negotiations on this issue of life or death to a subcommittee of the principal atomic Powers.
CINCINNATI, April 10 (AP) -- The Tigers blasted Corky Valentine, one of Cincinnati's prize rookie hurlers, for six runs in the ninth inning today and a 7-2 victory on the Redlegs.

Dust storms are blowing again in the Wheat Belt. This newspaper's correspondent describes a typical scene in southeast Colorado in these terms: "For mile after mile the flour-like topsoil has been piled against fences like drifting snow, tearing down the wire and snapping the poles."
TORONTO, April 10 (AP) -- A group of Soviet concert artists will arrive this month for a three-week tour of major Canadian cities, the Canadian -Soviet Friendship Society announced today.

Celebration in 1956 of the 250th anniversary of the birth of Benjamin Franklin will be observed by a worldwide program of communication of ideas organized by the Franklin Institute of Philadelphia. Approximately 100 societies, institutions, businesses, associations and public service units in twelve countries have agreed to work together in one committee of sponsors.

IT was not difficult, only foolish, to work seventh-grade problems when from the school window Tico Bravo would sight, any moment now, the Tiburon, bearing his captain-father home to their Costa Rica village. Soon, soon. Tico himself would surely go after the shark.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 10 -- Charley Deitlin pitched and batted Fordham's baseball team to a 2-1 victory over Yale on the Elis' field today.

The election of Annette D. Wilbois of Des Moines, Iowa, as president of the Athletic Association at Barnard College was announced yesterday. Miss Wilbois has been camp chairman of the association in the last year and has been secretary of the residence halls and a delegate to the Representative Assembly.
The award of 531 police citations for heroic conduct and exceptional duty was announced yesterday by Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 10 -- Outfielder George Watts collected three hits including a three-run homer in the third inning and batted in four runs to pace Lafayette to a 10-4 victory over Navy today.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 10 (UP) -- Thousands of Belgians headed home to vote today, and incidentally to enjoy a free visit with friends and families at public expense.

LONDON, April 10 -- In the perspective of history the most striking development in this week of tumultuous politicking in Britain probably was the evidence of a gradual but definite transfer of leadership within the Conservative party.

CLEVELAND, April 10 -- The serious threat to civil rights stems from a "general hysteria and an atmosphere in which demagogues flourish," Philip M. Klutznick, president of B'nai B'rith, asserted here today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- President Syngman Rhee of South Korea has proposed to President Eisenhower that the United States establish a new military organization to direct a unified training and equipment program for all the free nations of Southeast Asia.
SOMEWHERE IN VIETNAM, April 10 -- From a blacked-out transport plane 10,000 feet over Dienbienphu, I got a glimpse early today of the grim battle at Dienbienphu.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 10 -- A hitherto unpublicized merger of Pakistan and Afghanistan was reported today to be near.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 10 -- Synthesis of a chemical shown in preliminary animal tests to be the most effective agent of its kind for combating leukemia, the cancer-like disease of the white blood cells, was reported here today.
SEOUL, Korea, April 10 -- Top Allied officers think the machinery for policing the Korean armistice has proved inadequate.
TRENTON, Sunday, April 11 -- A 21-year-old murderer who had escaped from the death house in the New Jersey State Prison died here early today after he was shot down by a prison guard.

BUENOS AIRES, April 10 -- Dissatisfied with the terms of the collective-bargaining agreement offered them by the Peronista newspaper owners, the Argentine Syndicate of the Press has sent a strong telegram of protest to President Juan D. Peron today.
Two movements are afoot in Wall Street to make the position of customers' man in a Stock Exchange firm more attractive and better able to compete for recruits with other businesses or professions.
One of the most important educational developments in recent years has been the formation of citizens' groups to work with administrators and teachers for better schools.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., April 10 (AP) -- Wisconsin gained its seventh National Collegiate boxing championship tonight when Bobby Meath won the 156-pound title.

IT is the function of the stage designer not so much to decorate or embellish a stage work, as to help state it in terms of the theatre, to collaborate with authors and actors in the expression of ideas. Even no scenery, as in the case of "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial," serves that purpose. It concentrates attention on the essence of the play -- in this case, a conflict of abstract ideas.

RICHMOND, Va., April 10 (AP) -- Warrior Gay, a 12-year-old bay gelding piloted by his owner, Charles W. Stitzer of Southern Pines, N. C., made a runaway today of the twenty-ninth running of the Deep Run Hunt Cup.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles left tonight to win British and French agreement to his proposal for the creation of an anti-Communist "united front" in Southeast Asia before the Geneva conference opens April 26.

BLITHELY turning tradition upside down, Roger Duvoisin dresses Santa Claus in tweeds and sends him out into the world for an Easter escapade. Yearning for a whiff of spring, Santa comes incognito to the big city, but his tourist disguise fails to fool the children and forthwith he is accused of disturbing the peace.

It won't be long now, it can't be long, before spring shows its full face and keeps it in sight. And of all the spring tonics ever brewed the sight of spring itself is the most effective. Spring is bright and new and shiny, anything is possible, and you can laugh. You don't even have to take the weather seriously after the middle of April; you know it will even out pretty well.

LAMB CHOPS, a hound dog to top all hound dogs, was one of the first inhabitants of Elk Shanty to greet Bill Rawis and proved to be one of his stanchest friends. Just a few weeks before Bill's arrival in the mountain hamlet, the sudden death of his uncle had disclosed the fact that Bill's inheritance had been lost.
LONDON, April 10 (AP) -- The Wolverhampton Wanderers routed Charlton Athletic by 5 -- 0 today to take over the English soccer lead as the clubs raced into the home stretch.

HERE is a book about Chicago and what made it that way such as has never been written before. It is studied, factual and remarkably interesting even to one who lived in it from the days of "Mike McDonald's Democrats" until the last gun had been fired in the prohibition wars.
Consumers are worried that the price of coffee will rise to $1.50 a pound. The answer is in their own hands.

MADRID, April 10 -- The Spanish Government announced today the closing of its consulate in Gibraltar. The measure, which will take effect May 1, was held to be a gesture of protest against Queen Elizabeth's planned visit to that British Crown Colony May 10.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 10 -- Spring weather during the week started farmers into the fields of Minnesota and the Red River Valley, preparing for the fall harvest. According to University of Minnesota agronomists, most of the cash small grain crops would be allotted lower acreage this year, because of the current price level and Government restrictions.

SYRACUSE, April 10 -- The Minneapolis Lakers used their height and healthy condition to take a 3-to-2 lead in games in the National Basketball Association championship series today by defeating the battered Syracuse Nationals, 84 -- 73.

IN importance, subject-matter and size, Erwin R. Goodenough's "Jewish Symbols in the Greco-Roman Period" is a monumental book. The three handsome, large and extraordinarily well-printed volumes, two of text and one of illustrations, which are to be followed by three others, contribute much to the fuller understanding of some of the facets of the development of Judaism and the phenomena of Jewish life in the Hellenistic-Roman period.

THIS collection of hitherto unpublished letters of Hector Berlioz has a most interesting formal. The letters are printed in French on one page with a very careful English translation of them on the opposite page by Jacques Barzun, Professor of History at Columbia and author of a two-volume life of the composer.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., April 10 -- High voltage electrons crackled through the air in one exhibit at the fifth annual Science Congress at Adelphi College here today. Other exhibits showed a midget car powered by a lawnmower engine and the inside story of reptile life beneath the sea.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Prosperity and full employment at home and the checking of Communist aggression abroad will be the principal issues of the fall Congressional campaigns, Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois predicted today.

THE three most successful managers in baseball history were John McGraw of the New York Giants, Connie Mack of the Philadelphia Athletics and Joe McCarthy of the New York Yankees. McGraw won ten pennants, while Mack and McCarthy each won nine.

I enjoyed your article, "The Modern Church -- Or Traditional" (March 14), and I am particularly interested in the comments on it by the Rev. Frederic Fox of Williamstown, Mass., whose letter appeared, with a picture of his church, in your issue of March 28.

THE Amateur Cinema League's 1953 choice for the Hiram Percy Maxim Award for the best amateur film made during the year will top the Annual Gala Night Show of the Metropolitan Motion Picture Club, to be held May 1 in the Assembly Hall of Hunter College, Sixty-eighth Street between Lexington and Park Avenues.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., April 10 -- Boy Scouts, Cubs and Explorers from the troops, dens and posts of the Peconic Bay District will stage a parade and exposition here on May 1. Five hundred Scouts will unite to show adults and nonscouting youngsters what Scouting is all about.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 10 -- Columbia went fourteen innings to defeat Rutgers, 1 -- 0 today.
AMARILLO, Tex., April 10 -- Federal and state soil experts reported today that 16,000,000 acres of land had been badly damaegd by drought and blowing dust.
BRACED by warmer weather and a few artfully administered stimulants, business activity is beginning to look a little more robust than heretofore.

WASHINGTON, April 10 - With Senator Joseph R. McCarthy sidelined as the object of an investigation himself, the other six members of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations have been demonstrating of late a new sense of collective and bipartisan responsibility.

LOOKING at it one way, Herbert Krause is 287 pages getting to the subject promised by the title of his novel. Looking at it another way, he has written two novels that should be called -- say -- "The Town" and "The Trail." Either way you look at it, however, he has turned in a solid fictional performance.

IN 1933 Louise B. M. Dyer, a wealthy Australian woman who had settled in Paris, launched a music publishing house which she called Editions de L'Oiseau-Lyre. Her great love was baroque music and the firm was founded chiefly to make more of it available for performers.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Senator Karl E. Mundt said today that both sides of the Army-McCarthy dispute should tell the Senate subcommittee now what witnesses they wanted to call in public hearings.

IN the last few years, almost every woman who has lived a life slightly off the beaten track has rushed out a book about it -- or so it sometimes seems. This book by Evelyn Berglund Shore, happily, is notches above the usual product.

LEE LEIGHTON'S LAW MAN (Ballantine, $2 cloth, 35 cents paper) is the story of twenty-four hours in the life of Bill Worden, Sheriff of Grant County. The court had ordered Worden to hang Ed Lake at 9 in the morning.
ALBANY, April 10 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today vetoed a bill that would have required windshield defrosters on all new automobiles built after Jan. 1, 1957 and registered in New York State.

YEARS ago, before azaleas were so popular, it was the custom of home owners to plant Easter gift azaleas outdoors if they were hardy. This was generally done almost with abandon and no consideration for bloom sequence or timing with the rest of the garden display.

MOTOR trips during spring are growing in popularity with New Yorkers, who find advantages in touring before the tide of summer travel begins. There are generally less crowded conditions at hotels and sight-seeing areas and also fewer cars on highways leading to the principal resorts.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- State Department documents of eighteen years ago, released today, showed that the United States had declined to protest when Hitler broke two treaties on his march to the Rhine.
CAMP DRUM, N. Y., April 10 (AP) -- A total of 57,438 National Guardsmen and Reservists from the First Army will train this summer at this northern New York encampment.

THE problem of the rich old sire (or dame) who refuses to die reasonably soon so that others more worthy or more needy may inherit, stretches back to folklore. The "Devil by the Tail" presents a gleaning of contemporary southern Italian stories, held together by the anticipation of Don Cornullo's permanent death -- his previous two revivals had been quite irritating.

LOS ANGELES, April 10 (AP) -- Tony Melton got out of the Navy at noon today, signed a baseball contract with a New York Giant scout and began packing to join the Giant's farm club, Sioux City, Iowa, in the Class A. Western League.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The tests of the hydrogen bomb have accomplished what no amount of public education has been able to do so far. They have administered the kind of shock to the imagination which allows it to grasp our powers of self-destruction. But will the obvious moral be drawn?

WRITING about an intense and frustrated romantic who lives in a Pennsylvania mining town, Edward Abbey tells a harsh, and often brutal, story that at times rises to heights of lyrical beauty, and then descends to a real and calculated ugliness.
A 15-year-old boy's motive in the mercy killing of his pet dog yesterday had the sympathy of the police, but his weapon ran afoul of the law.

KINGSTON -- Following immemorial custom, summer will be warmer in Jamaica than winter, with more rain. But the heights are cool, and on the north shore breezes keep the sun in check. The beaches are just as white and finely powdered, and the water as crystal-clear.
An encouraging subscription has been reported for the annual "Bustles and Bonnets Party" to be held on April 29 in the Terrace Room of the Plaza for the benefit of the Bargain Box.

THE review of Pierre Berton's "The Royal Family" begins with a story of King George VI, returning by a royal train from a military review. Things had not gone right at the review and the King was in a fury. Then he noticed the name of a station, "Runnymede," flashing by and cried. "My God, that's where it all began!"

LOS ANGELES, Calif., April 10 -- California's most vociferous antagonist of Communists and left-wingers, State Senator Jack B. Tenney, was accused this week -- over his denials -- of injecting a female "ringer" into the coming primaries.

Why do you -- and others -- persist in calling the United States Senate "the world's most powerful legislature" as in Sidney Hyman's article on the powers, rights and privileges of the Senate -- "Shall Senatorial Power Be Curbed?" (March 21).

COLOMBO, Ceylon, April 10 -- Queen Elizabeth II received a warm reception on her arrival in Ceylon today. She was met with bouquets and garlands of Ceylon orchids amid sounds of wedding drums and other native music.

A DEPT at explaining in easy terms how things work and why, Creighton Peet describes here the most important types of bridges and the basic principles of their construction. This book is simpler and briefer than David B. Steinman's recently published "Famous Bridges of the World" and is, therefore, better suited to a slightly younger audience.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 -- Although Pennsylvania factories continued to reduce their work forces during February, there were indications that the rate of decline was diminishing. The decrease of 1 per cent to an estimated 1,087,000 workers was the smallest month's change since October.

THERE are many ways to set the Easter table. One, not without precedent in culinary history, is with a feast centered around roast lamb. In Italy and the Middle East we find lamb appearing on Easter tables as inevitably as frankfurters at an American baseball game, though with rather more ceremony.

CLEVELAND, April 10 -- Benefit claims filed by persons newly out of work in the Cleveland area dipped slightly this week and observers believe the decrease could indicate a leveling-off of layoffs in this area.

Fingerprinting of 1,500 persons at Yonkers Raceway as required by new harness racing regulations was virtually completed last night. The local trotting race season opens at the Yonkers track tomorrow night.

A new type of French language examination, which may change the traditional methods of language testing as well as teaching, is being used by Yale University. All the questions on this multiple-answer examination are heard, but not seen. The purpose is to test the student's ability to speak and to understand the language.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The proposed animal research laboratory at Plum Island, N. Y., will be operatedby the Department of Agriculture under agreement with the Army Chemical Corps, the Army and Agriculture Department announced this week.

THE furniture patterns now appearing on the market are a natural outgrowth of the packaged "knock-down furniture" so popular when first introduced five years ago. These new patterns can be taken to the nearest lumber yard, where the pieces can be cut to order or lumber purchased for the more ambitious craftsman to cut at home.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (UP) -- Rookie Vic Power's two-run homer in the top of the ninth inning gave the Athletics a 7-6 victory over the Phillies today in a city series game at Connie Mack Stadium before 5,961 fans.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- After one of the busiest winter seasons in its history as a resort, Nassau is looking to completion of a new hotel and a new series of week-end cruises from Miami to push this summer's tourist season to similar heights.

GARDENERS looking for "something different" in the way of spring bloom would do well to consider two new varieties of pulmonaria, which are now available. Pulmonaria has long been valued for its beautiful, small flowers and early bloom.

AMARILLO, Tex., April 10 -- The Panhandle regions of Oklahoma and Texas, the heart of the Dust Bowl in the mid-Thirties, were struggling this week to prevent the conditions that once before had plunged them into disaster.
The Dodgers wrapped up their spring series with the Yankees by edging the world champions, 3 -- 2, before 8,384 congealed spectators at the Stadium yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 10 -- Employment and production during March in the Chicago area held up well compared with February, the monthly survey of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago showed. There were other evidences of stability in business.

WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said today that the opening negotiations for restoring the vast Iranian oil industry merited "good hope that a satisfactory agreement can be reached."

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Remove mulches and clean up the perennial border, raking or cutting off any matted, brown top growth from last year. Pull out clumps of chickweed and any other large weeds. Then sprinkle a 5-10-5 fertilizer and cultivate lightly into the soil. Divide phlox, 'mums, asters and other autumn-flowering perennials.

THREE visits to the New Dance Group's series of performances up at the Ninety-second Street "Y" last week managed to compass all but one of the new works on the schedule, as well as most of the familiar ones. The quality of the series seems to have been much what on has come to expect from this active and ardent organization, with everybody working in full spirit and conviction.

IN presenting one important artist after another in full dress exhibitions to illustrate the development of the modern movement, the Museum of Modern Art has reached Edouard Vuillard. Less familiar to this country than the contemporary with whom he is most often compared -- Bonnard -- Vuillard presents something of an enigma.

President Eisenhower's choice of both words and ideas was singularly felicitous when he gave his warm encouragement to the campaign for the "Help Korea Train." He spoke with warmth of the fashion in which the gallantry and the needs of the Koreans had inspired our own soldiers to unprecedented acts of helpfulness.

FOR nine months production has been slowly dropping and employment is about 1.4 million less than a year ago. Views about the nature and seriousness of the contraction vary widely. President Eisenhower and Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey take a very optimistic view.

AFTER thirty years' service as a statistician and analyst of supply and demand in the Food Research Institute at Stanford University, M. K. Bennett is now director of that study group, which was begun by Herbert Hoover (as a private citizen) after World War I.

"ART in the blood," Sherlock Holmes observed, "is liable to take the strangest forms"; so it is with lively interest that one looks to see what form the art of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle may take in the fiction debut of his youngest son, THE EXPLOITS OF SHERLOCK HOLMES, by Adrian Conan Doyle and John Dickson Carr (Random, $3.95).

Last week's announcement of "deep cuts" in the off-shore procurement program, which resulted in plans to allocate $27,500,000 of small-vessel work to United States shipyards, has aroused something less than enthusiasm in this country's shipbuilding circles.

PERHAPS the most famed exhibit in the Channel Gardens at Rockefeller Center is the Easter display. And in Friday this midtown oasis will have more than 1,100 lily plants in full bloom with six to eight blossoms per plant.

LET there be no mistake about it. In the world at large, a new phase of the "cold war" has opened in which -- for the time being -- the Communists show every sign of seizing the initiative, The clouds rising hideously from the hydrogen tests or the grim battle for Indo-China may fill the foreground of the news.
Dr. David D. Henry, executive vice chancellor of New York University, yesterday excoriated "modern Ku Kluxers" as enemies of public education.

THE off-Broadway sector once again embraces all the activities of the week, which are few but range into almost every department of the dance. "Caribbean Carousel" continues for another week at the Open Door, 55 West Third" Street, and the single recitals and concerts are as follows:

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told more than fifty Citizens for Eisenhower workers today that all who believed in his program must continue to work for its adoption without any let-up.
TOKYO, April 10 -- Chinese Communist propaganda sources are serving notice on the West that the rehabilitation of North Korea is a project of the entire Communist bloc, not just Peiping.

MIDWAY in this discussion of the effects, probable and possible, of mass culture upon literature and the other arts, I am uncomfortably aware of having embarked on a topic of book-length dimension, but for which a few brief columns must here suffice.

NEW DELHI, India, April 1 -- The Community Projects Administration has issued a report of its country-wide rural uplift activities. These are expected to make life better for a quarter of India's population in the next two years.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 6 -- Landless peasants, the raw material from which chaos and revolution are manufactured elsewhere in the Middle East, are progressively disappearing from the Turkish scene.

DESPITE inherent weaknesses, two foreign films which opened here last week -- the British - made "Pickwick Papers" and the French "Diary of a Country Priest" -- have more to recommend them as adult movie fare than the several assorted homegrown items that also were dropped in our midst.

Brooklyn Technical High School, with 721 points, yesterday won the National Rifle Association junior regional championships for the third straight year. The competition, sponsored by the City College Reserve Officers' Training Corps, was held in the Lewisonn Stadium rifle range.
SAN MATEO, Calif., April 10 (UP) -- Blue Butterfly, with Johnny Longden up, collared Bubbley at the wire to win the $20,000 San Mateo Matron Handicap today at Bay Meadows.

THE publication of Allan Nevin's biography of Henry Ford reminds me of an assignment I had forty years ago. The day the news was published that Henry Ford had announced that his minimum wage would be $5 a day Alden March, then Sunday editor of The New York Times, asked me to run out to Detroit to see Mr. Ford.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- The West took a calculated political loss in the Middle East this week -- took it glumly and in the belief that there was no other way out.

Culminating the noisy and bitter struggle of the last few months for dominance of the $500,000,000 New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, a group of quiet New Englanders will sit down on Wednesday and count about 5,000 stockholders' proxies -- or ballots -- that will decide the issue.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 10 -- Ben Hogan assumed the lead in the third round of the Masters golf tournament today with a three-under-par round of 69. It gave the Texan, winner of this title along with the United States and British open crowns in 1953, a fifty-four hole total of 214.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UP) -- The Senate internal security subcommittee asserted today that the United Nations Secretariat was being used as a "cover shop" for Communist spy operations.
NEW ORLEANS, April 10 (AP) Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias shot a 1-under-par 74 today to take a 3-stroke lead after fifty-four holes of the $5,000 Colonial Country Club's golf tournament.
CLEVELAND, April 10 (UP) -- Senator McCarthy will speak "only where he is invited to speak" in this fall's political campaign, Leonard W. Hall, Repub lican National Chairman, said today.
The annual membership meeting of the Propeller Club of the Port of New York will be held on May 10 in the Downtown Athletic Club.
CHICAGO, April 10 (UP) -- The White Sox rallied for five runs in the seventh and eighth innings today to whip their crosstown rivals, the Cubs, 6 to 3, and gain a tie in the annual spring series.

HERE is a novel from France that is timely in a high degree. Its author is passionately agitated about the French Catholic experiment with worker-priests, which has drawn wide attention. Gilbert Cesbron, who has won several French literary prizes, celebrates with adulation the work of these priests.

Three new orders -- one for a large 33,000 - deadweight - ton tanker -- will help keep French shipyard activity at the busy pace it has been enjoying, according to the French Shipbuilders Association.

Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, paid tribute in his sermon yesterday to the Most. Rev. Bernard J. Sheil, senior Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago.

HEINRICH HARRER is a refreshing type of literary man. He wrote "Seven Years in Tibet" on a borrowed typewriter and thought "no one would read it except a few mountaineers." He plans not to write anything else until he again knows fully what he is talking about.
WEST POINT, N. Y., April 10 -- Army defeated Swarthmore, 11 to 4, on windswept Doubleday Field today.

PARIS, April 10 -- The current crisis in relationships between the United States and Europe appears to arise over disagreements on policy in Asia. That is the reason for Secretary Dulles' decision to visit London and Paris. But there is also a deterioration in understanding because of French delay in ratifying the European army. And there is a less discernible but fundamental shift in psychological balances betweeen the Old and New Worlds.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 10 (AP) -- Former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh boycotted the afternoon session of the Army Appeals Court today despite an offer by the chief prosecutor to kiss Dr. Mossadegh's toe.

ROME, April 10 -- Some Deputies belonging to parties pledged to support Premier Mario Scelba were revealed today to be secretly hostile to him. This was shown when a majority of the Chamber, overriding the Government's protests, approved a fiscal amendment proposed by the Communists.
WEMBLEY, England, April 10 (UP) -- Japan swept both men's and women's team titles tonight in the world table tennis championships before a capacity crowd of 10,000.

A SERIES of ten Monday evening talks on "Artistry in Photography" opened last week at Springfield Museum of Fine Arts in Springfield, Mass., under the sponsorship of the Massachusetts Department of Education, Division of University Extension.

READING, England, April 10 -- A Danish professor of prehistory chopped down a British fir tree with a Stone Age axe today. His purpose was to prove his theory that ancient Danes were able to clear forests in that way about 5,000 years ago.

A MODERN boy, snapping on the tail of his Dan'l Boone coonskin cap, may think that pioneering was all fun. He'll have another think coming when he meets Caje Amis, modest hero of "Winter Danger." Caje's father was a woodsy, which on the Tennessee frontier of the Seventeen Eighties meant following the game, sleeping in hollow logs, fighting Indians.

Earnings of leading New York City banks were higher in the first quarter of 1954 than in the corresponding period of 1953, despite a modest decline in assets from the end of 1953, condition statements of the institutions for March 31 disclosed.

OF all the months of the year, April is the ideal one for working on wooden fences. Whether it is tidying up an old one or building a new one, the job is best done in that brief period between the time when frost leaves the ground and when lawn, shrubs and perennials come to life.

TOKYO, April 10 (AP) -- The police today arrested the treasurer of Premier Shigeru Yoshida's Liberal party and the presidents of Japan's foremost shipping and shipbuilding companies on suspicion of being involved in the biggest shipping scandal in Japanese history.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- The Washington Senators collected sixteen hits off three Pittsburgh pitchers today en route to a 6-3 victory over the Pirates in an exhibition game.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., April 10 -- Two righthanders, Jack Sundberg, a junior, and Bob Laskowitz, a freshman, pitched Upsala College's baseball team to shutout victories over Dartmouth and Maine, 8 -- 0 and 2 -- 0, respectively, today.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Representative Edward R. Rees, Republican of Kansas, chairman of the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee, charged today that job duplications were creating a "costly waste" of manpower in the military agencies.

OPERA singers are said to watch each other like hawks, and there is jealousy when rivals get more and fatter parts. For this reason, probably, the Metropolitan Opera never releases statistics about the number of appearances made by its singers.
A special meeting Tuesday of the Transit Authority was proposed yesterday by Harris J. Klein, a member, to change its policy on religious holidays for 3,000 administrative personnel.
FOLLOWING are excerpts from comments on some of the exhibitions reviewed in The Times during the week just closed.

EVER since Commodore Perry opened up Japan to trade with the Western world a hundred years ago, there is practically no aspect of the American dream -- from horn-rimmed glases and miniature cameras, to baseball and golf -- that the Japanese have not seized upon with marvelous avidity.

THE New York Philharmonic will complete its spring tour this afternoon with a concert conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos in Constitution Hall in Washington, D. C. If the 3,844-capacity auditorium is as full as previous halls have been, the orchestra will have been heard by about 55,000 in a space of two weeks.
EAST HARTFORD, Conn., April 10 (AP) -- Town officials barred the doors today against the Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey Combined Shows Circus.

ONE of the more unusual theatrical boarding houses is a five-story brownstone house on West Eighteenth Street. The "actors" are animals and their "landlady" is Mrs. Lorrain D'Essen, who operates a business she calls Animal Talent Scouts in the high-ceilinged parlor of her home amidst a small menagerie.
ONE reason why libel is one of the most interesting criminal and civil concepts is that it changes with the customs and language of the times.

THESE words, spoken, according to the Book of Mormon, by Nephi in giving blessing to his son Jacob, who had been born in the wilderness, might well be Ezra Taft Benson's words in speaking of himself as Secretary of Agriculture. It is not the purpose of this article to evaluate the paths Mr. Benson has chosen through the wilderness that is Washington.

DURING the next two months spring will bring an imposing array of organized tours of old homes, gardens and orchard areas to the Northeastern states. From Maryland up to Maine there will be plenty of events to lure motorists in the metropolitan area out on week-end trips or even longer excursions.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 10 (UP) -- Nine years ago Monday a quiet, unassuming man from Independence, Mo., was catapulted into the Presidency of the United States by the sudden death of Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

PARIS, April 9 -- After much debate an agreement has been reached in Government circles to lift quantitative restrictions from 53 per cent of France's imports from seventeen other members of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 10 -- Unless the United Nations Disarmament Commission, which convened Friday, improves on its predecessors' record, some other source of relief from the threat of nuclear destruction will have to be found.

GROWING fruits at home can be an interesting hobby. And a well-managed plot can supply a family with lengthy harvest that starts with strawberries in June and is followed by cherries, currants, raspberries, blueberries, peaches, plums and grapes.

The increasing tension and bitterness in the relations between Israel and its Arab neighbors threaten a major crisis in the near future. Border incidents are on the increase as each side retaliates against the other's attacks. The massacre at Kibya was answered by the slaughter at Scorpion Pass, to mention merely the two most shocking recent clashes.

FOR a few pages, as we watch Felix Tallemand -- prosperous, tense, ambiguous -- climb the dingy stairs to ask forgiveness of the mistress he discarded thirty years before, we may think we are reading another of those flabby mea culpas or another of those abstract shockers that the French agony produced in the lucid French mind.

PARIS, April 10 -- In the siege of Dienbienphu some of the most admirable French qualifies have been demonstrated dramatically on the world stage -- qualities that rarely get into the news except in time of war or other emergency.

THOSE love-seats that they have installed in the first few rows of the Morosco Theatre are most beguiling. I found myself getting very cozy with a perfectly strange man, ensconced beside me at a recent matinee of that diverting and touchingly amusing high comedy.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla. -- Three events in April will put this 80-year-old resort town more firmly on the tourist map than it has been in many years. A new $900,000 steel and concrete bridge over the Halifax River, connecting U. S. 1 with state route A1A along the beach, will be dedicated, having been open for traffic the past few weeks.

BOSTON, April 10 -- Former Gov. Paul A. Dever's "unequivocal" withdrawal from the 1954 campaign this week opened the field for the Democratic nomination as Governor.

THE theatre benefit, boon to charitable enterprises and a blessing to most producers, threatens to surpass both the gabby threatregoer and tardy babysitter as a prime enemy of the playgoer. Insatiably, benefits have gobbled up tickets in such quantities during the first few months of new shows this season that even ticket scalpers have become irate.

The management of the New York Central Railroad charged yesterday that Robert R. Young lied in the newspaper advertising space that he bought last week to promote his fight to win control of the railroad.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- A White Russian woman, who said she had given the Federal Bureau of Investigation information on espionage dealings between "certain high ranking" American officers and Soviet agents, voluntarily entered the District of Columbia jail tonight because she said she feared Red reprisals.

MEXICO CITY -- Although Mexicans like to call their capital the city of permanent spring, there are in fact just enough variations in climate to make springtime the most pleasant for a visit. The rains that dampen each summer afternoon, almost without exception, have not yet started and the sun that heats summer mornings is not yet so intense.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 10 (AP) -- A newspaper editorial said today that Gov. George N. Craig had Closed "an iron curtain of censorship on the voters" by declaring a pre-election moratorium on news of findings by the Indiana State Board of Accounts.

ElectroData Corporation, a new California subsidiary producing equipment for processing electronic data for scientific and industrial use, is offering to certain holders of common stock of Consolidated Engineering Corporation the right to subscribe to 438,000 new shares of ElectroData capital stock at $3.50 a share.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, said today that Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. was "a little less than generous" in failing to credit Congressional committees with ferreting out Communists.

PORT-AU-PRINCE -- During spring and summer Haitians usually sit back to digest their never-expected winter profits, slash their hotel rates from one-third to one-half, lazily greet the influx of small-budget tourists, marvel over the daring of the new hotel builder and wonder once again what hit them.

TRENTON, April 10 -- The New Jersey primary election campaign is fast drawing to a close. With few heated contests, it has drawn a minimum of interest on a statewide basis. Balloting will take place April 20.

An outstanding development in the oil industry since World War II has been the emergence of Great Britain as an important refining center. As a result, a revolutionary change has taken place in the British economy.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Neither the Pakistani nor Afghan Ambassador nor the State Department have been informed about a plan to merge Pakistan and Afghanistan.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 10 -- Kansas City department store business reached its best level of the year with the approach of Easter. Summer temperatures were credited with arousing interest for wearing apparel. While major household appliances moved slowly, other home furnishings sales pushed to a seasonal peak.

Legislation that would enhance the marketability of certain top-grade local government bonds by widening the investment compass of New York State savings banks has been adopted by the Legislature and is awaiting final action by Governor Dewey.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, took occasion in his sermon yesterday to challenge "some" Christian preachers and teachers who refer to Jews as "the people who killed Jesus."
JERUSALEM, April 11 -- King Hussein of Jordan has decided to call a conference of Arab and Moslem heads to discuss the Israeli problem.

The reports of the round-table conferences of the National Industrial Conference Board are among the dwindling number of documents that this writer makes it a point always to read from cover to cover.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Monday, April 12 (Reuters) -- Queen Elizabeth II acclaimed the British Commonwealth as "a powerful instrument in safeguarding freedom and peace" when she opened the Ceylon Parliament in the Independence Memorial Hall here today.
CAIRO, April 11 -- The Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission, with the Egyptian delegation absent, accused Egypt today of four violations of the Armistice Agreement.

Palm Sunday, commemorating Christ's entry into Jerusalem to eat the Passover meal with His disciples, was observed yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral with a two-and-one-quarter-hour ceremony. The service included the ceremonial blessing of palms, procession of palms and celebration of the solemn mass of Palm Sunday.
Concerned, perhaps, over their sorry showing in spring training, the Yankees last night came up with another of those amazing inter-league waiver deals.

Retail sales of perfumes, cosmetics and other toiletries set a new high of $1,020,800,000 in 1953, according to a report issued over the week-end by the Toilet Goods Association. The new record represented an increase of about 1.6 per cent over volume for 1952, which was the first year in which toilet goods sales topped the $1,000,000,000 mark.

TRENTON, April 11 -- Two investigations were started here today into the escape of a convicted murderer from the death house of New Jersey State Prison last night. The prisoner, John L. Vaszorich, 21 years old, was killed by machine-gun fire when he refused to surrender after being found on an adjoining roof.
A continuing steady tone prevailed in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Rates moved narrowly and volume of business transacted was reported as light.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 11 (AP) -- Jim Neal dropped a 27-foot side shot with four seconds left to play to carry Syracuse to a 65-63 victory over Minneapolis today and send the National Basketball Association's championship playoff into its seventh and final game.

More signs of revival in business activity are appearing now than were evident at similar stages of the three previous economic contractions since 1929, according to Dr. Geoffrey H. Moore, associate director of research of the National Bureau of Economic Research.

CLEVELAND, April 11 (AP) -- Hal Newhouser, the lefthander who thought he was washed up in baseball when he left the Detroit Tigers last July, got his chance for a comeback today with the Cleveland Indians.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 11 (AP) -- Former Premier Mohammed Mossadegh maintained tonight that he was still on a hunger strike, but his chief prosecutor has branded him a secret cookie nibbler.
Historic Joseph Rodman Drake Park, Hunts Point and Oak Point Avenues, the Bronx, restored at a cost of $19,000, has been reopened, the Parks Department announced yesterday.

Dr. Clair Wilcox in a letter to you published April 4 deplores the renegotiation of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (G. A. T. T.) proposed by the Commission on Foreign Economic Policy (Randall Commission) and endorsed in President Eisenhower's recommendations to the Congress March 30.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said yesterday that it was up to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's colleagues rather than President Eisenhower to curb the Wisconsin Republican.

Even before this country was a nation, proponents of "hard money" were clashing with advocates of an ample money supply. The British forbade colonial issues of paper money and were defied. Hard money advocates were called Tories; ample money backers considered themselves patriotic.
Palm bearing was mingled yesterday morning with the solemn chanting of the Passion of St. Matthew at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

TOKYO. There is no doubt that religious activity has increased here in recent years, but it is doubtful whether respect for the gods or religious observances even re motely equal those of prewar and wartime Japan.

Nearly 100 special programs comprising a week-long radio documentary on American education are scheduled for WNYC, beginning May 3. The series, to be known as "The Educational Institute of the Air," will be produced by the city station under
CLEVELAND, April 11 -- Seven hundred Jewish communal leaders appealed here today for support of the National Jewish Welfare Board's 1954 budget of $2,232,155.
MELBOURNE. Leaders of all religious denominations in Australia are confident that their constituents are exhibiting many signs of growth and development.

ZURICH, Switzerland, April 11 -- The seventieth annual report of Ciba, Ltd., of Basle, covering the year ended on Dec. 31, reviews business conditions typical of those of the whole Swiss chemical industry.

A New York Central stockholders committee, representing all sections of the country, has been formed to aid the present management of the railroad in its proxy fight against Robert R. Young. Harold S. Vanderbilt, a director and member of the executive committee of the New York Central, will act as chairman of the committee.
MINEOLA, L. I., April 11 -- Nassau County's industry, with wares ranging from sleek jet fighter-planes to plastic toys, continues to register greater development than any other county in the state.

NEW HAVEN, April 11 -- The appointment of Luther Noss, Professor of Music and university organist, as dean of the Yale School of Music, was announced today by Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, university president. The appointment is effective July 1.

I have followed the remedies for the cure of juvenile delinquency prescribed by various authorities, most of which are practical and may yield good results. It seems to me, however, that the cause of this evil condition has not been sufficiently explored.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 11 -- Ten career civilians in the Federal Government have been named recipients of the second annual Rockefeller Public Service Awards. Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, announced the awards today.

AUCKLAND. Church leaders here see signs that the pendulum is beginning to swing back after a period of declining interest in religion. This decline, they say, was not so much anti-religious as a tendency to indifference.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., April 11 (UP) -- Dr. Samuel M. Brownell, United States Commissioner of Education, said today educators had the responsibility of making everybody "aware of the false allure of communism."
ROME. The "cold war" has weakened the faith of many whose faith was weak, but has strengthened the faith of many whose faith was strong. On the balance, the Church is not losing out.

OTTAWA. In any attempt to appraise the state of religion here, Roman Catholic French-speaking Quebec must be considered separately from the nine other provinces. The consensus among churchmen is that in Quebec, and to a lesser degree elsewhere in Canada, the Catholic Church is doing little better than holding its own, but that Protestant churches are slipping.

BALTIMORE, April 11 (AP) -- The president of the Michigan Restaurant Association has accepted a challenge from his Baltimore counterpart to feed the winners of the Detroit Tigers-Baltimore Orioles baseball game there Tuesday.
MEXICO CITY, April 11 -- Another major contribution to the strengthening of foreign-owned public utilities here has been announced by the Mexican Government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, April 11 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, outbidding two other studios with an offer of more than $100,000, is about to conclude negotiations for the purchase of "Bhowani Junction," the newly published novel by John Masters.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11 -- The Masters golf title is still at stake. With a par round of 72, Sam Snead moved into a tie today with Ben Hogan at the end of seventy-two holes.

The Health Department announced yesterday the 222 public and Roman Catholic parochial schools where pupils in the first three grades are eligible for trials of the Salk polio vaccine if their parents request it.

A casual influence in clothes is noted this season. It is due partly to a new trend in the spring French collections and partly to the good common sense of the American woman, who looks for clothes that are both smart and practical.
Increased efforts to diagnose cancer while the disease is still in its "silent" stage will save many who would otherwise die, according to the 1953 annual report of the American Cancer Society.
TRENTON, April 11 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, it was learned today, is planning major shifts in his Cabinet and will appoint at least one new Cabinet member within the next few weeks.

DETROIT, April 11 (UP) -- Center Ken Mosdell dashed nearly the length of the rink, pivoted away from Defenseman Bob Goldham and pushed a ten-foot backhander into the Detroit net tonight to gain a 1-0 overtime victory for the Montreal Canadiens. The triumph kept alive Montreal's hope of successfully defending the Stanley Cup.

It is not inappropriate with Easter in the offing to call attention to an American country-style ham that has come to New York from Poughkeepsie. There, in a city more famous for Vassar College and Smith Brothers cough drops than for ham, Knauss Brothers, Inc., has been turning out hickory-smoked pork products for more than half a century.

Fifty years of virtually uninterrupted service to the Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church in Brooklyn were commemorated yesterday in a Palm Sunday service in honor of the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish, rector emeritus.

BOMBAY, India, April 11 -- Communists from India's Redinfested Madras State appear to have captured a predominant share of the "peaceful rebellion" in Pondicherry, one of four small French possessions on India's coastline. New Delhi wants to take over these foreign pockets for sentimental reasons.

CARACAS. The post World War II period in South America has been marked by an increased militancy on the part of the Roman Catholic Church, which is predominant in all these countries. The church seems to have gone back to an older tradition of intransigence toward other sects, and more emphasis is being laid on keeping up active religious practices.
WASHINGTON, April 10 -- Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the period April 3 through April 10:

WASHINGTON, April 11 (UP) -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican National Chairman, said today that party differences over Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were not "as big as they seem to be" and had "no effect" on Republican unity.

The Senate Labor Committee has raised a highly controversial question by approving a proposal that the Taft-Hartley Act permit states to enact laws dealing with emergencies which "constitute a clear and present danger" to health or safety. Since the federal law already provides for action in emergency disputes affecting interstate commerce, the new provision would not apply to cases in which the Federal Government is already acting.

BUENOS AIRES, April 11 -- Argentina has promised a limited departure from the principles of bilateral trade, Dr. Alfredo Gomez Morales, Minister of Economic Affairs, disclosed last night. Under the terms of a pact signed Friday with Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West German Minister of Economics, Argentina will attempt to agree on specific triangular trade deals.

PARIS, April 6 -- Man's faith in God does not, on the whole, appear to have suffered any crippling blow in the last two decades as a result of the horrors of war, the discoveries of science, the encroachments of materialism or the political and ideological conflicts of the current era.
The problem of juvenile delinquency in our schools has been "monstrously exaggerated," Arthur Levitt, Brooklyn member of the Board of Education, declared yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, April 11 (UP) -- Right-handers, Bob Turley, Joe Coleman and Marlin Stuart, combined today to pitch the Baltimore Orioles to a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals at Busch Stadium.

Holy Week began in New York yesterday with the traditional religious observances, afternoon showers and the annual preview of the Easter parade. It was a warm day, and sunny during the morning, when thousands of Christians attended Palm Sunday services commemorating Christ's triumphal entry into Jerusalem six days before His Crucifixion.

Puccini's "La Boheme" received its first performance of the spring season of the New York City Opera Company Saturday night at the City Center. The cast included two young artists who had not been heard before in this work, Dolores Mari as Mimi and Peggy Bonini as Musetta.

THE Yonkers Raceway, an organization legally licensed to conduct gambling at night, will fling open its doors -- and mutuel windows -- this evening. For the past five months a clock over the betting windows carried the sign, "Next race at -- ." For these five months the hands haven't budged from 8:25. But they'll begin advancing at approximately twenty-five minutes a clip henceforth.

The United States Lines announced yesterday that it would open a district freight office in Detroit on May 1, with James H. Hooley as manager. Mr. Hooley's former post in charge of the Cleveland office will be taken over by Walter G. Hauser.

CAPETOWN. Church membership and attendance in South Africa, both white and nonwhite, has increased with the population. Church authorities seem uncertain in the absence of recent statistics whether church membership is merely keeping up with the population rise or holding its own and better.
VIENNA. Against all religions in Czechoslovakia communism has struck shrewd blows.

JERUSALEM. In Israel, where fifteen of every seventeen persons are Jewish out of a population of 1,700,000 there seems to be no question that the trend since the establishment of the state in 1948 has been toward religion. Yet there are some indications of a slow drift away from some of the multitudinous practices required by a completely orthodox observance of the Jewish faith.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- Cuts totaling $8,000,000,000 in nondefense items from Federal budget obligations are possible for the 1955 fiscal year, the Committee on Federal Tax Policy asserted today.

The recent publication of "The Secret Diary of Harold Ickes" prompts the reflection that outside of such historical-minded statesmen as Ickes, James Forrestal and others dealing with momentous affairs, the keeping of a diary seems to be a vanishing art, at least in these United States.

This is the time of year when schoolboys seem to breathe deeply again. It's almost as though they had emerged from hibernation. The snows and winter have gone and students once again may be found thronging about the athletic fields. It happens every spring.
PHILADELPHIA, April 11 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies gained a split in their week-end city series with the Athletics today by taking a 1-0 decision before 7,951 spectators at Connie Mack Stadium.

THE HAGUE. There is little doubt among Dutch men of religion that their faiths are steadily, but almost inexorably, losing ground in the Netherlands. The Protestants are apprehensive over Roman Catholic growth. Catholics view with alarm the specter of Socialist strength, and look aghast at Communists.

NEW DELHI. Trends in politics, as well as the evidence of religious activity itself, indicate that a revival in spirituality has been going on in this country. No firm statistics are available as to temple attendance and there are no significant Hindu religious orders or organizations.

A novelty in the piano recital that Felice Takakjian gave on Saturday evening in Town Hall was the first performance of Alan Hovhaness' Concerto No. 9 for Piano and Strings. The composer was present to conduct the five players (string quartet plus bass violin) and the pianist.

Extensive improvements are planned for the Oakland Pool at Dearborn Avenue and Cornell Place in Rye, N. Y., which has been purchased by the Dearborn Realty Corporation from the Oakland Beach Bath and Pool, Inc., of which Allen Kendell is president. Walter Rostenberg and Louis Jacobs were co-brokers in the transaction and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Monday, April 12 -- The Social Christian party lost its majority in Parliamentary and county council elections held yesterday. The tiny Communist party crumbled.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- President Eisenhower will give baseball its opening pitch on Tuesday before taking off for a golfing vacation in Augusta.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, April 11 -- The Amsterdam diamond industry is optimistic with regard to the effect of the reduction in the American excise tax on jewelry from 20 to 10 per cent.

It would have been unthinkable to order the Port of New York Authority to come to a dead stop on the undertaking of all new projects, air, sea or land, while the New Jersey-New York community completes a cooperative study of rapid-transit needs and solutions.

Two policemen swooped down in a helicopter yesterday to rescue a man in the middle of the Hudson River only to find themselves in a lusty fight with an indignant swimmer. The "rescuers" won by lashing the swimmer to a pontoon and towing him, still struggling, behind the plane to shore.

MILWAUKEE, April 11 (AP) -- Leo Kiely, a southpaw, gave the Milwaukee Braves only four singles during an eight-inning mound stint today and the Boston Red Sox scored a 5-2 victory in the final spring exhibition game for both teams.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon blasted a home run, double and single and batted in five runs today to lead Washington to a 9-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

CLEVELAND, April 11 (AP) -- Player-representatives of the major league baseball clubs today approved -- with two changes -- proposals for a player pension plan which the club owners adopted in Miami last March 12.
INDIANAPOLIS, April 11 -- When the bell rings Tuesday the Giants will be ready.
LONDON, April 11 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles arrived in London today proclaiming a common danger in Indo-China and need for intimate consultation between Britain and the United States.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs pushed across eight runs in the fourth inning to hang a 12-9 defeat on the cross-town rival White Sox before 20,490 fans in Wrigley Field today.

PARIS, April 11 -- Unless the British stand should weaken, Secretary of State Dulles will have trouble convincing the French of the need for a common Allied warning to Peiping on the state of Southeast Asia.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 11 -- A Cabinet shake-up that may result in the resignation of Foreign Minister Muhammed Zafrulla Khan is expected tomorrow.

MOSCOW. The Journal of the Moscow Patriarchy in the course of a review of Russian Orthodox church life in 1953 published in its January, 1954, issue listed, at random, seven or eight churches and cathedrals in the Soviet Union that were remodeled, restored and put back into operation in the course of 1953.

MADRID. The feeling of the Spanish populace is that the Roman Catholic episcopacy and clergy, but especially the former, are allied with and supporting the present regime. This has been the traditional policy of the Church in Spain, and its continuance is undoubtedly harming its growth at present.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., April 11 -- George R. Hinman of Manhasset Bay, piloting his Class BO boat, Felix, finished two days of dinghy racing at the Larchmont Yacht Club this afternoon with low score of 62 points to supplant Arthur Knapp Jr. as champion of the annual spring Frostbite regatta.
CHICAGO, April 11 -- The increasingly serious crop situation in the Southwest, with indications of large and irreparable damage, was the dominant subject of discussion in the grain trade last week.
WASHINGTON, April 11 -- A Senate Republican pictured President Eisenhower today as likely to approve a one-year extension of high price supports on major crops.

Cotton prices moved moderately lower on the New York Cotton Exchange last week, with active futures contracts down 4 to 27 points from the week before. During most of last week there was an easing of the nearer deliveries and a strengthening of the new crop months, a pattern that was reversed in the final day's session.

Earnings of the Omnibus Corporation for 1953, reflecting the last four months of earnings of Hertz Stations, Inc., amounted to $202,631, equal to 31 cents each on the 647,739 shares of common stock outstanding.

The dispatch originating with Arnaldo Cortesi in Rome which you carried on March 30 reported "a victory whose political repercussions will be felt throughout Italy." In a local election at Castellammare di Stabia, a Center-Right coalition had overthrown a Communist government. This fact was considered all the more significant in that Castellammare di Stabia had long been under a Communist government.
Courtauld's Ltd., the world's largest producer of rayon staple fiber, will expand its operations both in Great Britain and abroad, according to Sir John Hanburry-Williams, chairman of the board.
Nature -- to the extent of thirteen trees -- will invade in the next few days East Ninetieth Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, now abloom with apartment buildings and private dwellings.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 11 -- Adlai E. Stevenson said today that the party dispute in California over James Roosevelt and Representative Robert L. Condon "is a matter for them and their Democratic constituents to decide."
PANAMA, April 9 -- Plans are being formed to transfer the bulk of the non-United States workers in the Canal Zone from homes in the Zone to others in Panama.

CAIRO. Islam, like the other great world religions, is struggling to retain a significant place in the lives of its adherents against the assaults of what Moslem leaders call twentieth century materialism.
DALLAS, April 11 (UP) -- Heavy week-end rains in portions of drought-stricken west Texas and the lower Rio Grande Valley of south Texas raised farmers' hopes today for their 1954 crops.

IN semi-abstract paintings by Murray Jones, at Contemporary Arts, Mexican themes are seen at a far remove. Landscape and buildings are disintegrated into a conglomeration of flinty shapes that bristle together in emblematic images. Subject matter and atmosphere are pretty well lost in this process, but the pictures have a complex constructive logic of their own. Color is dark and sullen and the pictures have, on the whole, a forbidding air.
ST. LOUIS, April 11 (AP) -- "We have just traded one of the greatest baseball players in the history of the St. Louis Cardinals."
MOBILE, Ala., April 11 -- The United States Steel Corporation threw open its giant new multi-million-dollar ore-handling facility here last night.

Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera House, was held up and robbed at 7 o'clock last night while walking his dog, a small dachshund, in Central Park in the rain. He told the police that $70 in cash and a wrist watch worth $40 were taken from him.
VIENNA. Ninety-three per cent of Austrians are Roman Catholics, but the Church is not satisfied with the manner in which most of them practice their religion.

The country estate of John Grimm on Plumb Beach Point Road, Sands Point, L. I., has been purchased by George Goodsitt through Douglas L. Elliman Co. and the Harvey Craw Company of Manhasset, L. I. It includes a Colonial residence with four master bedrooms and bathrooms, five-car garage with apartment and about one acre of land fronting on Long Island Sound.

Starting under more favorable auspices than similar efforts in the past, negotiations are now under way in Teheran to settle the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute which has imperiled both Iran and the whole Middle East. The auspices are more favorable because of American intervention which prepared the ground for the new negotiations and internationalized them to a degree which should remove some of the political and emotional obstacles to a settlement.

PARIS, April 11 -- A compromise on the controversy over Marshal Alphonse-Pierre Juin's retention of his post as Atlantic alliance commander for Central Europe is believed to have been reached during his recent interview with President Rene Coty.
PARIS. According to the results of a recent poll, 85 per cent of the French people consider themselves Roman Catholics. However, only about 60 per cent attend mass either regularly or occasionally.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $78,746,034,440. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:...

It was good news that the Government has succeeded in finding an excellently qualified successor to Joseph M. Dodge as Budget Director even before the effective date of Mr. Dodge's resignation, April 15. One reason this was possible is that the man needed was right in Washington; in fact, he was in the Budget Bureau itself.

West Texas Utilities Company is issuing 60,000 shares of $100 par value 4.4 per cent dividend preferred stock. Of these, 47,370 shares are being offered share-for-share in exchange for the company's $6 dividend preferred stock.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., April 11 -- Linda Thomas triumphed with Lady Luck in a jump-off for the individual championship and gained the challenge trophy for the host team in the Junior Olympics horse show at the Thomas School of Horsemanship today.

Secretary of State Dulles is in Europe on a delicate and difficult mission. He is undertaking to forge something of a united front among Britain, France and ourselves in respect to Far Eastern policy prior to the opening of the Geneva conference. His mission may be expected to meet with some uneasiness, some apprehension and some outright opposition.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 11 -- The action of the Israeli-Egyptian Mixed Armistice Commission in effect holds Egypt responsible for the over-all situation in the Gaza Strip, the senior Israeli delegate, Col. Arieh Shalev, contended today.

MOSCOW, April 11 -- A strong indication that the Soviet Union will raise at the Geneva conference the question of United States intentions toward Communist China was given today by Pravda, the Communist party newspaper.
NEWARK, April 11 -- A New Jersey legislative committee took the rare action tonight of going on television to kill a proposal to stop all new projects by the Port of New York Authority.
BONN. Religion in West Germany is not only holding its own, it is still gaining some strength during these "cold war" days, both Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders here say.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 11 -- Appointment by Mayor Robert F. Wagner of an executive committee of the city's United Nations Committee was announced today by Richard C. Patterson Jr., who was named chairman. Mr. Patterson said the panel would constitute a policy group, to work out problems arising in the sphere with which the city is directly concerned, with respect to United Nations personnel.
A cooperative ownership plan for the apartment building at 470 Park Avenue is offered present tenants and others by a group headed by Oliver C. Wagstaff.
CHICAGO, April 11 -- Industrial workers were warned today by Senator Hubert H. Humphrey that if they let the Eisenhower Administration "get by with clipping the farmer, you're next."

BELGRADE. Even pro-Government sources concede the continued strength of religious devotion in Communist Yugoslavia, and the comment is general that in addition to the fact that people are in trouble, a usual cause for religious faithfulness, anti-church activity also may contribute.

VIENNA. To assess the strength of religious feeling in Communist-dominated countries is highly difficult since in all, although far less in some than in others, religion has been driven more or less underground.
With all signs pointing to a record-breaking campaign, the lights will be turned on again tonight for the opening of the fifth harness racing season at Yonkers Raceway.
PITTSBURGH, April 11 -- There was more optimism in the steel market last week than for some time.

VIENNA. In Hungary, as in Czechoslovakia, the Communist regime has imprisoned or otherwise silenced all those members of the Catholic hierarchy who dared to oppose it, has severed all administrative bonds with the Vatican, has suppressed religious orders, arrested priests on any pretext or none, discouraged religious education and suppressed the Catholic press.
NAIROBI, Kenya, April 11 -- The Government has dropped its offer of mass surrender terms to the Mau Mau and opened a new all-out offensive.

THE tiny Red Cross contribution buttons, or lapel tabs, that are moving out pretty briskly in the current Red Cross campaign, went to dwarf size during World War II when it was difficult to get enough metal for full-sized buttons.

Stockings this spring make news with the "nude look." Two important factors help to create this look: The first is the extreme sheerness of the stocking yarn, the other the new spring and summer colors, so pale as to be almost invisible.

The Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra, under Karl Muenchinger, gave the second and final New York concert of its initial American tour yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The program presented was interesting and, for the most part, received intelligent and carefully detailed interpretations.

Public hearings will be held on the personal service budget request of the New York City Department of Health before the Board of Estimate on April 14. The supplementary request of $98,520 which relates to services for handicapped children, for which Commissioner of Health Dr. Leona Baumgartner requested support, has been denied.

BONN, Germany, April 11 -- A United States Jewish service organization reported tonight that it had found anti-Semitism still in existence among the West Germans, particularly in the generations that lived through the Hitler period.

The League of New York Theatres, organized in 1930 by stage producers and operators of legitimate houses, faces a crisis. The situation was precipitated by the resignation of J. J. Shubert, who controls nineteen of Broadway's thirty-one legitimate houses as well as many on the road.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 12 (AP) -- King Baudouin was arranging today for consultations to find a new Premier after the election defeat of the Social Christian party and the resignation of Premier Jean van Houtte.

BOSTON, April 12 (AP) -- Martin R. Gainsbrugh, chief economist of the National Industrial Conference Board, said today that "the steady decline in business operating rates since mid-1953 has begun to taper off."

Five chamber works by contemporary Swiss composers were performed last night at Carnegie Hall. The concert was presented by the Swiss Music Library, which in the four years of its existence has done yeoman service in making this country conscious of Swiss music.

Coffee futures opened off the 2-cents-a-pound limit in most positions yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and closed the limit lower in all months. There were selling orders in all positions at the close but no buyers. Volume was thus held to 55,750 bags.
ROME, April 12 -- Yesterday's and today's concerts at the Rome Conference on Twentieth Century Music provided an opportunity for hearing three recent outstanding contributions to chamber literature.
