PORTLAND, Ore., April 12 (UP) -- Gov. Len Jordan of Idaho predicted tonight that the Pacific Northwest will need an additional 6,000,000 kilowatts of electrical power by 1964.

The Korean Children's Choir, composed of twenty-five small-fry fresh from their war-shattered homeland, flew into town yesterday. The choristers are in this country to help the American-Korean Foundation raise $10,000,000 for Korean reconstruction.

The character of "purchasing power" needs clarification. There is a widespread conception which, in failing to understand that as unused ability it has little value, neglects the urgent need of using purchasing power to effectuate consumption.
PARIS, April 12 -- A French Cabinet crisis will greet Secretary of State Dulles on his arrival here tomorrow.

Six more units were chartered as branches of yachting's largest membership body, the United States Power Squadrons, at the bimonthly governing board meeting yesterday at the Astor Hotel This brings the total to 156 squadrons.
TRENTON, April 12 -- A serious rift between Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, and leaders of the Republican-controlled New Jersey Legislature appeared tonight to have been averted.

New York broke ground yesterday for its long-delayed Coliseum at Columbus Circle. Accompanying this act was a determination to wage an all-out battle before Congress next week against the abolition of Federal aid for this and other major slum-clearance projects.
MANILA, April 12 -- President Ramon Magsaysay placed the Philippines tonight behind the United States proposal for a joint warning to Peiping against intervention in the Indio-China war.

The American Chamber Opera Society ended its first season at Town Hall last night with the stately, tragic muse of Henry Purcell. Beginning with the brief "Witch of Endor" and continuing with "Dido and Aeneas," this was an evening dedicated to somber sorrows and dark enchantments -- set to beautiful music, it is true, but freighted with a heavy measure of woe all the same.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- Mr. Hollyday has been connected with the housing industry for more than thirty years.
ALBANY, April 12 (AP) -- Cuts in state equalization rates today gave eleven more cities power to increase their debt ceilings. Five of them were authorized to raise real estate taxes.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the man who directed the making of the first atomic bomb, has been suspended by the Atomic Energy Commission pending a review of his security file.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson asserted today he was "confident" that President Eisenhower would veto any farm bill extending present high, rigid Federal farm price supports.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned barely steady yesterday and prices declined 2 to 29 points.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 12 -- The new Vietnamese war Cabinet, in its first meeting here today, adopted stringent measures for intensifying the struggle against the Communist-led Vietminh rebels.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- At the heart of the Oppenheimer case are two unanswered questions:

Harold W. Scott, partner in Dean, Witter Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, and a Big Board governor since 1949, was nominated yesterday as chairman of the Exchange. Elections will be held Monday, May 10.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Following is a cast of the main persons mentioned in the case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer. Much of the material was found in sworn testimony and reports of the House Committee on Un-American Activities and in reports of the Joint California State Committee on Un-American Activities:
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- The Administration's plan to slash the sending of surplus farm goods overseas under the foreign-aid program came under sharp attack today.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- President Eisenhower, a confirmed golf enthusiast, will toss out a baseball at 3 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, and the Yankees will begin their quest at Griffith Stadium for a sixth straight American League pennant.
SEOUL, Korea, April 1 -- Rarely has a young nation faced problems so complex and numerous as those confronting the Republic of Korea today.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Earl Shreve, national director of the Treasury's savings bonds division, said today sales of Series E and H bonds set a nine-year record in March.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today left the National Labor Relations Board without authority to challenge non-Communist affidavits filed by union officers.

Demands for investment capital are likely to show a measurable decline this year, but the supply of savings available for investment will probably be at the same magnitude as in 1953, according to a study prepared for the Bankers Trust Company by Dr. Roy L. Reierson, a vice president of that institution.

YONKERS, April 12 -- Once a harness racing fan, always a harness racing fan. A crowd of 25,769 proved this was true tonight by turning out at Yonkers Raceway for the opening of New York State's long season despite chilly temperatures and pre-Easter depleted pocketbooks.

The opening baseball game of the season at the Polo Grounds between the Giants and the Dodgers will be presented today, beginning at 1:25 P. M., over Channel 11 and radio stations WMCA and WMGM. The game between the Yankees and the Senators in Washington will be broadcast by WINS beginning at 2:25 P. M.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12 -- Sam Snead beat the champion today to win the Masters golf title for the third time. In the eighteen-hole play-off, necessitated because he and Ben Hogan deadlocked after seventy-two holes at 289, Sam was the winner, 70 to 71.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12 -- The United States called today for the release of two newspaper men and thirty other Americans held by the Chinese Communists.

PARIS, April 10 -- Cotton clothes for summer activity, made of Boussac moderately priced fabrics, were shown last week. The models, enchantingly fresh and cool, were designed by Marie-Jose de la Sayette and Jacques de la Forterie for the Etablissements Boussac.
The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday the creation of two new offices "as part of its continuing program to improve its passenger services."
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- In the Federal Government, loyalty and security charges have struck the high and the low, the dead as well as the living.

VIENNA, April 8 -- The Austrian Government says that Soviet "liberation" and occupation have cost Austria $1,250,000,000. This figure is borne out by United States experts. It is only $250,000,000 less than the total United States aid to this country.
Air raid sirens "alerted" the city in a scheduled test yesterday morning in which most of the public went about its business unperturbed. Public participation had not been called for.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12 -- The Arabs agreed conditionally today to take part in a wide debate on Arab-Israeli border clashes.

An eighteen-story building at Third Avenue and Fiftieth Street to accommodate 137 families was among plans filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The improvement is estimated to cost $2,700,000. The new structure, at 817-25 Third Avenue and 201-15 East Fiftieth Street, also will have garage facilities for about 125 cars.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 12 (AP) -- President Crawford H. Greenewalt told stockholders today that sales of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., for the first quarter of 1954 were about 8 per cent lower than sales for the first quarter of 1953.

A series of walking trips will be conducted during the spring by Miss Farida A. Wiley, assistant chairman of the public instruction department of the American Museum of Natural History. Local birds, plants and animals will be studied.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 12 -- a new chemical substance, prepared from a normal constituent of bile, may become a key factor in the development of a test for detecting cancer in its early and still controllable stages.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Supreme Court affirmed today lower court rulings that repulsed the first attack by longshoremen and "public loaders" upon the constitutionality of parts of the New York-New Jersey waterfront compact.

The crippling effect of the twenty-nine day longshoremen's strike in the Port of New York was reflected vividly in the sharp drop in customs shipping receipts last month. Revenue declined by more than $11,000,000 from the March, 1953, level.

The New York Community Trust, holder of $21,423,329 in funds for charitable purposes, reported yesterday that within forty-eight hours of the signing by Governor Dewey of legislation requiring reports from charity organizations the trust had sent its report in.
Just before he caught a plane in Memphis, Tenn., for New York last night, Playwright Tennessee Williams said that he had completed two plays, "Cat on a Tin Roof" and "Orpheus Descending."

WEST POINT, N. Y., April 12 -- The New York Giants made their annual stop at the U. S. Military Academy today and warmed up for the season's opener by defeating the Cadets, 6 to 5, before an overflow crowd of 8,000 at Doubleday Field.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- An effort to set up a Congressional conference committee to resolve the Hawaiian-Alaskan statehood issue was blocked today in the House of Representatives.
Heavy Easter shopping has begun to make itself felt in reports of business of the city's department stores.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- A Senate investigating subcommittee today made its first real start toward establishing the truth in charges and countercharges between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

Your editorial of April 7 commenting on consolidation of court structure for family and juvenile problems is excellent and timely. Unification of the five separate courts which presently deal with family problems is a long range aim requiring constitutional amendment and a period of years before fulfillment.

LOS ANGELES, April 12 -- The Bethlehem Pacific Coast Steel Corporation recently displayed the results of an eight-year expansion program at its plant here which has boosted the West Coast's steel production capacity considerably.

LONDON, April 12 -- The British Government "welcomes" the inter-company agreement that has brought about negotiations with Iran on the possible resumption of oil production there, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today.
City employes converged in droves on City Hall yesterday to tell the Board of Estimate one emphatic thing about the $1,639,388,325 city budget for 1954-55 -- they did not like it.

ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP) -- V. E. McKelvey of the United States Geological Survey said tonight "the search for uranium in the United States is one of the most intensive ever made for any metal in our history."
SAIGON, April 12 -- A point on the east side of the main French defenses of Dienbienphu was bitterly contested in an all-night battle between French Union and Vietminh troops last night.

The State of Minnesota announced yesterday that it would make an offering on May 4 of $9,800,000 of rural credit certificates of indebtedness. Dated June 1, 1954, the certificates will come due from 1955 to 1967.

The chairman of the Republican National Committee, Leonard W. Hall, believes that President Eisenhower's legislative program "is going along in splendid fashion." This comment is in accord with Vice President Nixon's prediction a week ago that a "substantial part" of the Eisenhower program would be enacted by the present Congress.

LONDON, April 12 -- Britain urged Secretary of State Dulles today to accept Western unity of intention and action at the Geneva conference as an interim substitute for his proposal for an immediate warning to the Communist bloc against further aggression in Southeast Asia.

Reflecting record sales, Warner-Hudnut, Inc., increased net income 23 per cent last year to $3,618,923 from $2,927,168 earned in 1952, the annual report of Elmer H. Bobst, board chairman, disclosed yesterday.

In 1954, there has been a shift in emphasis from the building of a large Air Force to a concentration on "qualitative improvement,'' Roger Lewis, assistant secretary of the Air Force for materiel, declared yesterday.
Prices of lead, tin and brass and bronze ingot advanced here yesterday following a general strengthening of metals in London.

Millions of dollars are expended by the City of New York annually for the education and care of idiots, imbeciles, morons and other subnormals in our schools and so little money for our superior students. What a travesty on our school system!

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- Labor leaders joined Gene Tunney, former heavyweight boxing champion, and prominent business executives as President Eisenhower's guests at a White House stag dinner tonight.

A Health Department spot-check indicated yesterday that one-third of the parents of school-children eligible to take part here in trials of the Salk vaccine against polio had signed the application forms.
The Board of Higher Education last night suspended three associate professors at Hunter College on charges arising from a special investigation into Communist activities.

Major league baseball gets under way today on all fronts and from here on the boys will be shooting strictly for keeps. For the National League, founded in 1876, it will be the seventy-ninth championship season. For the American League, a product of the twentieth century, it will be the fifty-fourth.
" Dandy" Phil Kastel, New Orleans racketeer who split his slot machine profits with Frank Costello, shared the income from a jukebox venture with Costello's wife, a jury was told yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Rumania has released two youths whom it used as hostages a year ago in an attempt to make their father, a naturalized United States citizen, spy for his former homeland.

Strolling through Gimbel's third-floor boutique, which recently was filled with spring imports, is like taking a shopping tour through the glamorous fashion streets of Paris, Rome and Florence. A collection of original designs and copies of separates, sportswear and accessories from leading couture houses and small boutiques in France and Italy are on sale.
LINCOLN, Neb., April 12 -- The death of Senator Dwight P. Griswold in Washington today left state Republicans with the task of finding a strong successor.
RIO GRANDE, Ohio, April 12 (AP) -- Rio Grande College today expelled basketball star Bevo Francis.

MINNEAPOLIS, April 12 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers won their third straight National Basketball Association championship tonight with an 87-80 victory over Syracuse that crushed the Easterners' rags-to-riches play-off bid. The victory come in the seventh and last game of the series.

Some new and revealing findings are hoped for this summer as a result of a special pilot study to be conducted for the first time on how mentally retarded boys and girls adjust to a regular camp program.

Department stores have succeeded in whittling down stocks of goods in the last year. Their success was set forth yesterday in a report by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The report - compares inventories in establishments in the Second Federal Reserve District as of Feb. 28 with those of the same date last year.
New York University's baseball team scored a 6-3 victory over Manhattan College in a Metropolitan Conference game at Ohio Field yesterday.

Union and industry leaders in the construction field pledged their support yesterday to the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., in its effort to avert a threatened recurrence of the cement strike that halted building here last summer.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (UP) -- The country's stockpile of seventy-five strategic materials cannot be considered satisfactory at the moment, Arthur S. Flemming, director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, said today.

Severe restrictions imposed recently by Chile on imports from the United States and Great-Britain are expected to continue for several months despite favorable results of a copper sales agreement with this country. This was the conclusion drawn by the National Foreign Trade Council in reporting yesterday on Chilean conditions.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a case involving the refusal of a cemetery in Sioux City, Iowa, to permit an Indian hero of the Korean war to be buried there.

LISBON, Portugal, April 12 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar invoked the North Atlantic Treaty and British-Portuguese pacts dating as far back as 1642 to explain today why Portugal would not even discuss handing over part of her overseas territories to India.

Harris J. Klein, a member of the Transit Authority, and his archenemy, Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., formed a united front yesterday. Both pleaded with the authority to give 3,000 transit office workers a day off with pay to observe Good Friday, but their joint efforts failed to budge the agency.

We don't expect the Bowery Savings Bank to become a full-fledged partner with the city on financing capital improvements in the subway system. But the public owes the bank a vote of thanks for the newly opened two-speed escalator, reversible up and down, depending on rush hour needs, which has been installed just outside the bank's office on Forty-second Street opposite Grand Central Terminal.

One hundred and fifty mothers and children staged a fifteen-minute protest demonstration yesterday by blocking traffic on Twentieth Street, midway between First Avenue and Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive, where they want a stop-and-go traffic light installed.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Treasury Department announced tonight that its short-term borrowing costs had increased. It reported that its latest offering of $1,500,000,000 in 91-day discount bills was sold at an average price equal to an annual interest rate of 1.066 per cent.
TRENTON, N. J., April 12 (AP) -- Hollyday referred all questions to Mr. Cole.
NEW HAVEN, April 12 -- Two Norway maple trees on city streets were cut down during the night in the latest outbreak of vandalism to plague park and police officials.

CHICAGO, April 12 -- Light to heavy rains covering most of the Oklahoma and Texas growing areas started heavy selling of wheat futures here today. Some of the heaviest rains were in areas where much of the crop is just a forlorn hope, but the moisture in general was beneficial.

Directions accompanying dyes for Easter eggs give complete details on how to apply various colors and designs. But a few notes might be appropriate on the correct method of hard-cooking eggs so they will be suitable for eating after their role in the holiday festivities has ended.

IF the Yankee front office was genuinely worried about a too complacent ball club, as it claimed, those worries now can be dismissed. Enos Bradsher Slaughter, a firebrand with matchless competitive spirit, has been magically added to the Yankee roster. Old as he is, Country is not only a total stranger to complacency but is its mortal enemy.

New York, in the opinion of two leaders of the City Council, would be "a far happier place if unnecessary noise were eliminated." This observation, made by the Democratic majority leader, Mr. Sharkey, and the Republican-Liberal minority leader, Mr. Isaacs, seems indisputable. To back it up they have joined in urging general observance of this week as Noise Abatement Week.
JACKSON, Miss., April 12 (UP) -- A life-size bronze statue of the late Senator Theodore G. (The Man) Bilbo was unveiled in the Mississippi Capitol today.

SAIGON, April 12 (AP) -- Today's decisions marked the first time in the seven-year Indo-China war that the Vietnamese Government had ordered conscription on a broad scale. So far the French Union forces, including North Africans and Foreign Legionnaires as well as Vietnamese troops, have been carrying the load.
TOKYO, April 12 -- Japan would decline any invitation to join in a united action against the Communists in Indo-China, Premier Shigeru Yoshida told the diet today.

NAZARETH, Israel, April 12 -- The people of this sacred town of Christianity voted today for their first municipal council under Israeli rule. The election was a three-way struggle among Christian church groups, the Communist party and Moslem patriarchs for leadership of the 21,000 all-Arab population.

LONDON, April 12 (AP) -- Bernard Bukiet of Chicago kept alive America's hopes of winning the world table tennis championship today as he moved into the fourth round while two of his countrymen were going down to defeat.
Louis M. Boulware has been appointed assistant production manager of the textile division of the United States Rubber Company.

Eduardo Lausse, South American middleweight champion, extended his winning streak to fifteen last night when he gained a split decision over Jesse Turner of St. Louis in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn.

At frequent intervals the economy of New York City has benefited from ideas advanced by the progressive leadership of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. The chief of this union's women's coat and suit organization, Isidore Nagler, is now sponsoring a plan to encourage the use of mass production methods in making lower-priced garments.

HASTINGS - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., April 12 -- A controversy over the candidacy of Mrs. Albert Dekker for the presidency of the Parent-Teacher Association here ended tonight when she withdrew from the anticipated contest. This resulted in the election of Mrs. Edward L. Plimmer without opposition.

LONDON, April 12 -- Prince Nicholas of Yugoslavia, nephew of the Duchess of Kent, was killed early today when his sports car plunged into a water-filled ditch about five miles from Iver, the home of the Duchess. He was 25 years of age.

Much fashion emphasis is being placed on the little fur for spring, whether it be jacket, stole, cape or scarf. Jackets appear in the brief bolero, emphasizing the Empire line with their above-the-waist cut, or flared very much like the Dior jackets with their almost circular fullness. Especially newsworthy are the bloused back waist-length style. Chic also is the straight boxy jacket.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12 -- Ivar Rooth, head of the International Monetary Fund, said today that there were grounds for believing the world economy would continue to grow.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The White House today launched an inquiry into alleged nation-wide housing frauds that might have cost homeowners and the Government many millions of dollars.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Supreme Court ruled today in a maritime insurance case, but the ruling appeared not to be completely satisfactory to any of the nine justices.

MOSCOW, April 12 -- Pravda charged today that the United States had tried to provoke Communist China into intervening in Indo-China and that failure of this attempt had "infuriated" American diplomats.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The sudden death today of Senator D. P. Griswold of Nebraska will not long subtract from the number of Senate Republicans, because a member of that party is Governor of the state and presumably will replace Senator Griswold with another Republican.
A two-mile course, with a large free area for spectators on the Harlem River Driveway, will be used by Columbia Saturday for the first time in its opening rowing regatta with Rutgers.
ROME, April 12 -- The whole of modern civilization shares in the responsibility for creating the hydrogen bomb and for threatening to use it, the Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano said today.

ROME, April 12 -- The Christian Democratic party threatened severe disciplinary measures today for its Deputies in Parliament who had joined the small group of "snipers" against Premier Mario Scelba's Government.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today again refused to intervene in the fight for control of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

Tide Water Associated Oil Company lifted its net income 19 per cent last year. The company cleared $36,951,568, equal to $2.89 a share, compared with $31,082,246, or $2.43 a share in 1952, according to the annual report of D. T. Staples, president, issued for publication today.

Dr. Leona Baumgartner, New York City Health Commissioner, praised voluntary agencies yesterday for their "wisdom" in contributing to research in health fields. She spoke briefly as Buddies League, Inc., presented a $10,000 check for research and patient service to the Muscular Dystrophy Association of America, Inc.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 12 -- Marshal Tito, President of Yugoslavia, arrived here tonight on a six-day state visit designed to consolidate Yugoslavia's strong position in Turkey and thereby bolster her standing with the West generally.
LONDON, April 12 -- British exports, which had declined during the first two months of 1954 from the high level of the last quarter of 1953, improved considerably last month.
CHICAGO, April 12 -- Voter apathy is expected to hold balloting in Illinois' primary election tomorrow to a point far below the total voting strength of the state.
John W. Davis quoted Epictetus and Samuel Johnson and praised Margaret Mitchell and Winston Churchill yesterday, in an interview on the eve of his eighty-first birthday.

WINTER-WEARY New Yorkers may have their faith in spring (and summer, too, for that matter) resplendently restored for the next month by visiting an exhibition titled "The Magic of Flowers in Paintings," which opened with an invitation preview last evening at the Wildenstein Galleries.

Supreme Court Justice Carroll Walter directed Walter Winchell yesterday to give responsive answers and refrain, from volunteer observations in his sixth pre-trial examination in companion libel suits seeking $1,525,000 damages from him and his employers.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12 -- India suggested today that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold be asked to issue periodic reports on the destructive powers of hydrogen and atomic bombs.
The domestic steel industry turned out 7,290,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings last month, the American Iron and Steel Institute estimated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer is one of the most brilliant scientists America has produced. Essentially, he is a theoretical physicist, but it was a down-to-earth project of the starkest reality that brought him his greatest fame. He is known as "the man who built the atom bomb."
FULTON, Mo., April 12 -- Former President Truman tonight declared this nation was being subjected to a modern day witch-hunt conducted by "crude and sinister men."

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Following are the texts of letters from Maj. Gen. K. D. Nichols, general manager of the At Energy Commission, listing charges against Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, and of Dr. Oppenheimer's reply:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 12 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer ended negotiations today for the purchase of film rights to "The Blackboard Jungle," to be published soon by Simon Shuster.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, urged Congress today to abandon its new concentration on legislation to outlaw the Communist party.

The Soviet Government has begun to prepare its people to reject any revelations of Soviet espionage that may be made by Yuri A. Rastvorov, former second secretary of Moscow's mission to Japan. He disappeared last January.
Cardinal Spellman and his luncheon guest -- Rocky Marciano, heavyweight boxing champion -- opened the new $400,000 Harlem Catholic Community Center yesterday afternoon.

Plans of the United States to close the smelter in Texas that has been used to process tin ores from Bolivia and elsewhere is viewed with dismay by that country, Victor Andrade, Bolivian Ambassador, said last night. He spoke at a meeting arranged by the Pan-American Women's Association and the Women's City Club, at the latter's clubrooms, 277 Park Avenue.

PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., April 12 -- Roman Catholics of the Holy Innocents parish opposed bitterly at a public hearing tonight a proposed zoning amendment that they said was aimed at preventing construction of a $350,000 parochial school.
ALBANY, April 12 -- A bill to define the term "immoral" for the purposes of censoring undesirable motion pictures was signed today by Governor Dewey.

BUFFALO, April 12 -- The methods of some politicians "in this hour of hysteria and fear constitute a principal threat to freedom for American education," Dr. Buell Gallagher, president of the City College of New York, said today. He spoke at the convention of the American Personnel and Guidance Association.
EXCELLENT stream conditions, coupled with uncooperative trout, and a sunny opening day, followed by a wet and dismal Sunday, sent a large percentage of the Catskill anglers home with empty creels.

Senator Milton R. Young of North Dakota, an ardent supporter of high price supports for farm crops, is of the opinion, he says, that the Administration would uphold a continuation of such supports if it was limited to a single year.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 12 -- The hole-by-hole description of the play-off between Sam Snead and Ben Hogan in the Masters golf tournament today follows:
Hours for the use of building incinerators were limited yesterday in a series of new regulations announced by Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of the Department of Air Pollution Control.
LIMA, Peru, April 12 (UP) -- A merger of the American-owned Panagra and Braniff Airlines may be effected in the near future, a spokesman for Braniff said today.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today rejected a petition of motor carriers, for a floor under truck freight rates in the New York-Philadelphia area.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- One evening early in March, 1947, David E. Lilienthal, then chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, received a telephone call at home from J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Stock price changes were relatively small yesterday. Most of the limited interest centered in specialties -- particularly metal issues associated with the Atomic Energy Program -- rather than the general list.

NAIROBI, Kenya, April 12 (Reuters) -- Seven hundred Mau Mau supporters have been rounded up in the last twenty-four hours, after the breakdown of talks on a mass surrender of terrorists, British Army headquarters said today.

Three floors in the eleven-story building to be built soon at 156 William Street, northeast corner of Ann Street, have been leased by the Commercial Union-Ocean Group of Insurance Companies. The lease, negotiated by Ivor B. Clark, Inc., broker, is for twenty-one years and involves about 30,000 square feet of space.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Congress was asked today to give tax relief to civil servants who retire before the age of 65.
A group of professional entertainers won an ovatoin yesterday at the Mark Hellinger Theatre, where they appeared in a showcase production sponsored by the Stage Managers' Club.

Many of the 80,000 year-round volunteers of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis have asked what the foundation is going to do in the future if the new polio vaccine, developed by Dr. Jonas E. Salk of the University of Pittsburgh, turns out to be as successful as everyone hopes.

The motion-picture industry eventually will unite in using one projection process of the many now on the market, it was predicted yesterday by Adolph Zukor, chairman of the board of Paramount Pictures.
An Englishman observing one of America's big spectacular signs for the first time remarked: "Frightfully ingenious, but don't you think it's rather conspicuous?"

The military requirements for modern aircraft that fly faster than sound, finding their way mainly by electronic means, have brought about a new series of fighter planes and bombers that are far larger, far more complex and much more costly than ever before. The production knowledge needed to produce these aircraft has become equally intricate.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- A Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company spokesman today called "wholly untrue" statements made by Representative Charles G. Oakman, Republican of Michigan, about the company's gas reserves.

Donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program last Friday totaled 714 pints of blood, of which 213 pints were collected at the Bronx campus of Hunter College and 172 at Queens College. Of the 196 pints collected on Saturday, 157 were donated at Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 -- Seven canners of tomato paste filed suit for $3,708,384 damages here today against Hunt Foods, Inc. They charged the company with attempting to destroy competition and obtaining a monopoly and asked that it be enjoined from acting in restraint or trade and from selling tomato paste below cost.

The Second Honeymoon Spring is here now, and its outward manifestations are many. The birds are singing, the trees are indulging in chlorophyll orgies and the buds of early flowers are rising toward the sun.

DETROIT, April 12 -- Two stockholders of the Hudson Motor Car Company sought an injunction in Circuit Court here today to halt the merger of Hudson with Nash-Kelvinator Corporation. The merger was approved by stockholders last month by a vote of 1,400,000 shares to 245,000 shares.
WATERFORD, N. Y., April 12 -- The Erie Canal, New York State's original throughway, began its 129th season today.
A Seeing-Eye dog became painfully wedged in a Third Avenue Elevated turnstile for twenty minutes last night because his blind master had decided to rush for a train.
WASHINGTON, April 12 -- Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer described himself as very much the cloistered scientist and professor, indifferent to what was going on in the world, until late 1936.

WASHINGTON, April 12 -- From 75 to 90 per cent of the 3,500,000 acres turned to high price crops since 1942 in the drought-stricken Southwest never should have been put to the plow, the Soil Conservation Service said today.

Eleven banking syndicates competed yesterday for the purchase of $33,000,000 of debt securities of Central Power and Light Company and National Fuel Gas Company. Both issues are to be reoffered to investors at prices to yield 3.1 per cent.
ALBANY, April 12 (AP) -- Republican county chairmen gave added force today to pressure on Governor Dewey to run again, whether he wanted to or not.
The old International Longshoremen's Association asked the National Labor Relations Board yesterday to find the Waterfront Commission guilty of unfair labor practices.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) -- Legislation authorizing the President to proclaim Oct. 16, 1954, as National Olympic Day was approved by the House today.

There has always been considerable doubt in sporting circles that Mr. Doubleday of Cooperstown fame "invented" our national pastime. In fact, the encyclopedias refer to Abner Doubleday as the "alleged" originator of baseball while pointing out that the game is more certainly derived from the English games of cricket, rounders and a very old children's game called "one old cat."

Leaders of the shipping industry, headed by Louis S. Rothschild, Federal Maritime Administrator, yesterday honored three Great Lakes ore carriers for their part in the rescue of fourteen crew members of the freighter Henry Steinbrenner, lost last May in Lake Superior during a violent storm.

Lavender Hill, owned by Mrs. Charles Silver and ridden by Eric Guerin, won the Bonnie Beryl Handicap, the $10,000 added race that marked the activity at the Jamaica race track yesterday. The event was a mile and a sixteenth test for fillies and mares, and provided more than a fair share of excitement for the crowd of 27,635.
LONDON, April 12 -- The day's stock market trading here resulted in small irregular price changes. The undertone remained firm however and gains outnumbered losses.

BOWIE, Md., April 12 (AP) -- This track opened its twenty-first spring meeting today with Bill Hartack capping a string of three straight winners before a crowd of 10,379. He rode Mrs. Ada L. Rice's Pet Bully to a five and one-half furlong track record in the $5,000 Sation Purse.

MADRID, April 8 -- Spaniards who have just returned home after many years of captivity in the Soviet Union assert that about "eighty German scientists formerly working on atomic projects" have been interned in a special concentration camp near Borovichi, in western Russia.

FULTON, Mo., April 13 -- Former President Truman, an enthusiastic history student, delivered a lecture at Westminster College here today on the importance of preserving Presidential papers as historical documents.
A long-term school assistance program for the 4,000,000 students in Korean institutions will be started formally next Tuesday by the American-Korean Foundation.
The 1954 major league baseball season received a grand opening at the Polo Grounds yesterday. How grand, however, depended largely on where your allegiance lay. If in Brooklyn, it wasn't so hot.
Sigma Delta Chi, national journalism fraternity, announced its twenty-second annual journalism awards last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LOS ANGELES, April 13 -- One of the most damning pieces of information about Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, in the view of California investigators responsible for many of the current charges against him, was that he was classified in secret Communist party communications as unsympathetic to communism.

Career guidance, economy and efficiency campaigns, civilian management experts, specialists in everything except fighting, and emphasis on security instead of opportunity and adventure have helped to "civilian-ize" the armed forces.

Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer is continuing actively as the director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, N. J. The board of trustees reported yesterterday that it "never had any occasion to doubt his complete loyalty and sincerity."
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and Americans for Democratic Action urged Congress today to provide tax relief that would bolster consumer buying.

CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- The $28-hog reappeared on the livestock market for the first time since 1948 today when that price was paid for a few loads of choice 190 to 220-pound butchers. Prices generally were steady to 15 cents up.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 13 -- The Arabs' plea for immediate agreement to condemn the Israeli attack on a Jordanian village last month was denounced today by Abba S. Eban, Israeli representative.
Gov. Herman Talmadge came north yesterday to drum up industrial and shipping business for his State of Georgia.

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 13 -- The Naphao Valley, whence the Vietminh began its offensive across Laos to the borders of Thailand four months ago, was re-entered by French Union and Laotian troops yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Following are the texts of statements on the Oppenheimer case issued today by the Atomic Energy Commission and by Representative W. Sterling Cole and Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, heads of the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy:
American freedom is in danger because of a "spreading passion for conformity," Miss Dorothy Shaver, president of Lord Taylor, declared last night.
New issues of corporate securities totaling more than $80,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, A. F. L., a leader in the fight against union racketeering, took stern action yesterday to punish wrongdoers in its own ranks.
" ISN'T it a lovely day?" Manager Leo Durocher of the Giants virtually sang out the words as he stood on the dugout steps before yesterday's opener at the Polo Grounds.

BOISE, Idaho, April 13 (AP) -- Harry Orchard, 88 years old, who blasted a trail of violence through the West that ended in the 1905 bomb-slaying of a former Idaho Governor, died quietly early today in the state penitentiary.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has turned down suggestions from Republicans and Democrats alike that he remove himself entirely from the Senate subcommittee investigating his controversy with the Army.

B-29 bombers, the heaviest long-range bombing planes in common use by the United States Army Air Force in World War II, are being sought by the French for use in Indo-China, Louis Christiaens, Minister for Air in the French Cabinet, disclosed yesterday at a press conference here.

CAIRO, April 13 -- Egyptian leaders castigated their domestic and foreign enemies today and expressed doubts that the United States had the will or the ability to aid Egypt in her dispute with Britain over the Suez Canal zone.

Investors turned yesterday to stock market areas that were neglected in last week's general advance. Rails, as on Monday, were favorites. Not one leader among them showed a loss and at their high for the day they almost broke through the February peaks.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The new Ambassador of Yugoslavia, Leo Mates, declared today that he expected a solution of the Trieste problem within a few months "in view of the concessions" his Government had made.

Yesterday, while Mr. Dulles and Mr. Eden were issuing in London their compromise agreement on policy in Southeast Asia, the British signed in Paris a treaty with the six nations of the European Defense Community defining the terms of Britain's association with the European Army.
Edward R. Murrow, Columbia Broadcasting System commentator, said last night that he required "no lectures from the junior Senator from Wisconsin upon the evils of communism."
The outcome of a proxy fight for control of the Blair Holdings Corporation was still undecided late last night.

The division of opinion on Mayor Wagner's proposed executive budget of $1,639,388,325 is even more emphatic this spring than usual at the public hearings. Some think that, at $99,079,170 above the current year, the new budget is too large, while others believe it too small.

One of the three Hunter College faculty members suspended on charges involving Communist party membership admitted yesterday that he had been in the party from 1936 to 1941, but said that for many years since he had been "alien and hostile to communism."

St. Francis Prep of Brooklyn Princeton (N. J.) High shared honors in the scholastic section of the First Collegiate Track Conference Relay Carnival at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. The collegians will compete there Saturday.
Once again, in Indo-China, the free world is confronted with the decision of whether to stand firm or to appease.
A resolution condemning the "abrupt dismissal" of Guy T. O. Hollyday as Commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration was adopted yesterday by the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
The board of directors of Associated Hospital Service, New York's Blue Cross Plan, elected Henry C. Brunie and John J. Kelly as board members yesterday.
PARIS, April 13 -- Britain's proposals for association with the projected European Defense Community were approved here today by the six governments that are to form it.
THE Pennsylvania trout season opens at 5 A. M. tomorrow, and reports from most of the eastern streams indicate that water conditions are excellent.

Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer is one of the nation's most brilliant scientists. The contribution he made to the atomic strength of the United States through his work at Los Alamos and elsewhere has been surpassed by no other individual. Such eminently qualified spokesmen as Dr. Hans Bethe, president of the American Physical Society, say that we might not have even had the atomic bomb without his genius.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- President Eisenhower directed the Atomic Energy Commission last autumn to raise a "blank wall" between Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer and secret Government data.
I read in your newspaper where Raul Lamuraglia, respected Argentine business man, was taken to prison with his son on April 2.

GEORGETOWN, British Guiana, April 13 (Reuters) -- Cheddi Jagan, deposed Premier of this British colony, today drew his second court sentence in two days when he and five members of his left - wing People's Progressive party were convicted of holding an illegal procession.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Federal Government contends that millions of dollars of taxes were avoided because of the strange way Federal housing laws were administered.

By refusing to review two lower court rulings the Supreme Court has dealt a stunning blow to the National Labor Relations Board's reasonable efforts to challenge non-Communist affidavits filed under the Taft-Hartley Act by union officials. The high court has left in effect two lower court decisions.

Although it has not been desperately quiet so far, this week -- in case you haven't heard above the din -- is national Noise Abatement Week, so designated by the people who take care of that sort of thing, and your silence is respectfully solicited.
City high school teachers voted yesterday to discontinue all direction of after-school activities after this month.
LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- The text of a statement issued at the conclusion of meetings in London of Secretary of State Dulles and British Foreign Secretary Eden:

ATLANTIC CITY, April 13 -- Experiments revealing that the hormone of the adrenal gland, hydrocortisone, enhances an animal's resistance to the effects of toxic substances produced by bacteria were described here today.

Sir John Slessor, Marshal of the Royal Air Force, has outlined in a forthcoming book his proposals for averting another world war. In "Strategy for the West," he presents a "dynamic" military program that can "drive the Communists back behind their own frontiers and keep them there."

PITTSBURGH, April 13 (UP) The Pittsburgh Pirates baseball team, which will travel by air this season, had a reminder today that when planes are grounded by weather, the Pennsylvania Railroad still will be operating.

The National Broadcasting Company confirmed yesterday that it would present the Boston Symphony Orchestra in weekly concerts next season to take the place of the concerts of its own N. B. C. Symphony, which is being dissolved.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 (UP) -- The nation's first full-scale atomic power plant, which will generate enough electricity for a community of 400,000 persons, will be built on an Ohio River site twenty-five miles northwest of Pittsburgh.

ALBANY, April 13 -- A bill designed to ease traffic congestion and promote highway safety by reducing the maximum length of tractor-trailers and encouraging them to use safer equipment was signed today by Governor Dewey.
LONDON, April 13 -- The United States and Britain have taken the first step toward the establishment of a collective defense system guarding Southeast Asia against Communist aggression.
Precise records of expenses and only lump sum figures for income of two of Frank Costello's business establishments were introduced yesterday in the trial of the gambler for income tax evasion.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UP) -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organization, said today that Congress would win no political friends by taking "a few mincing steps" toward improving the social security system."

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Strength in May corn was the feature of the grain markets on the Board of Trade today, showing a gain of 2 cents. Cash corn had even bigger upturns, No. 2 yellow selling at 7 cents above the near delivery.

LONDON, April 13 -- Prime Minister Churchill hinted in Parliament today that the United States had now given Britain certain information regarding the latest hydrogen bomb tests in the Pacific. However, he refused Labor requests to disclose this information publicly.
Prayers of thanksgiving were said yesterday by the Georgescu family.

Mrs. John D. Hertz's Double Speed, a four-star flash in California last year, was a three-alarm flop in Jamaica's top race yesterday. He finished third. That was a blow to many pocketbooks. He was a 3-to-4 proposition.

Between February 28 and March 31 the average market value of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange rose 3.15 per cent from $42.53 to $43.87. Over the same period, The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks rose 3:35 per cent.
Five of the leading privately owned utility companies in the Pacific Northwest banded together yesterday to supply additional billions of kilowatt hours to the power-hungry region.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The governors of the Federal Reserve Board approved today a rediscount rate drop from 1 3/4 to 1 1/2 per cent voted by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. The new level will go into effect in Chicago tomorrow.
This is Pan-American Day. It marks the anniversary of the day in 1890 when the American republics formed the hemispheric union that since 1948 has been known as the Organization of American States.

Smart clothes for street wear and dressier costumes and separates for afternoon and evening, from the collection of Branell, were shown yesterday by Gunther Jaeckel at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
LONDON, April 13 -- Publication of a book assailing T. E. Lawrence has been postponed following a number of protests, including a letter from Sir Winston Churchill.

Two cakes, pretty and delicious enough for an Easter dessert, and several breakfast breads that might be served on that holiday morning are new at the Leonard Baking Company, 1814 Second Avenue, at Ninety-fourth Street. This is a small shop distinguished for the high quality of its products and famous for a cheese cake that is among the best in New York.

Men have ingeniously devised, with fractions and decimals, a way of breaking up the difference between 1 and 2 into an infinite number of infinitesimal parts. But, try as he might, no one can split the difference between 70 and 71 as recorded at Augusta Monday by Sam Snead and Ben Hogan in the Masters play-off.

In wartime atomic project days, American intelligence agents were watching Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer and other physicists, Sumner T. Pike, former acting chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said last night.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 (AP) -- Outfielder Del Ennis lost Cal Abrams' high fly in the sun and the Pittsburgh Pirates rallied in the eighth ining for four runs off Robin Roberts to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-2, before 32,294 fans at Forbes Field today.
NAZARETH, Israel, April 13 -- The Communists scored a success in yesterday's elections here. This represented a significant, although minor, penetration into the Arab world.

PITTSBURGH, April 13 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates presented a special plaque to John (Honus) Wagner, baseball's Mr. Shortstop, in ceremonies preceding the Pirates-Philadelphia Phillies National League opener today.
TRENTON, April 13 -- A two-year experiment in educational television that has cost New Jersey $100,000 came to an abrupt end today.

DOROTHY RAEDLER'S minstrels, who function under the distinguishing appellation of the American Savoyards, moved on to Gilbert and Sullivan's "The Gondoliers" last night at the intimate President Theatre.
LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- The world's merchant shipping tonnage reached a record total of 93,351,800 tons last year, Lloyd's Register of Shipping said today. This was 3,171,401 tons more than in 1952.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The United States has informed the Soviet Union that an investigation of the disappearance of Yuri A. Rastvorov, who was a Soviet diplomat and espionage agent in Tokyo, is still continuing.

ROME, April 13 -- Surely not for days now has there been such a roomful of contented smiling people as there was this afternoon in the Palazzo Pecci when Bernard Greenhouse and Sylvia Marlowe played Bach's Sonata in G minor for 'cello and harpsichord.
Shipments of copper to domestic fabricators rose to 95,795 tons last month, the highest level since December.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 13 (AP) -- Suspension of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer "was long overdue -- it should have been taken years ago," Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, said today.

Gordon Manley, pianist, played his first recital in two years at Town Hall last evening. The artist, a native of Vancouver, B. C., studied with Egon Petri at Cornell University and made his debut here in 1945.

The addition of three prominent Greek-Americans to the board of directors of the Prudential Steamship Corporation -- a move designed to strengthen the corporation's financial structure -- was announced yesterday by Stephen D. Stephanidis, chairman of the board.
Donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Monday totaled 503 pints, of which 188 pints were received at St. John's University, Brooklyn, and 154 at Yeshiva University.
Long before Mayor Robert F. Wagner threw out the first ball at the Polo Grounds yesterday Commissioner Ford C. Frick had tossed a few words at two managers.

LONDON, April 13 -- British Government securities stood out today with fresh gains in generally dull stock markets. Favorable overseas trade figures for last month stimulated buying of gilt edged securities, particularly undated funds.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, saw atomic power today as promising new kinds of food and adding new products to promote a high standard of living for the United States.

Directors of the Diamond Alkali Company yesterday elected John A. Sargent as president to succeed Raymond F. Evans, who was elected to the newly created office of chairman of the board. Mr. Evans will continue as chief executive officer concerned with long-range planning and policy making, while Mr. Sargent will direct the general management of company activities.

Coffee fell the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit and cocoa dropped the 1-cent limit yesterday on the New York exchanges. The spot price of coffee tumbled 4 1/2 cents a pound, with Santos 4s (the basis for American brews) at 85 cents. This was the sharpest one-day decline in several years.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 13 -- Turkish leaders were understood to have told Marshal Tito today that a binding military alliance among Turkey, Greece and Yugoslavia was out of the question at this time.
Security risk charges against Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer brought statements of shock yesterday -- and numerous expressions of confidence in his loyalty -- from scientists here and abroad.
THE Easter Parade tradition in New York isn't as old as many people seem to think. It started, in a small way, about 100 years ago, down around Old Trinity when the city had not begun to spread.
Attorneys for the old International Longshoremen's Association argued for three hours yesterday in a vain effort to kill contempt charges against the union and three leaders of its West Side locals.

A Manhattan publisher who was arrested last night with his wife on a charge of printing obscene literature quickly found himself in triple trouble: a detective also accused him of simple assault (swinging fists) and a Senate subcommittee on juvenile delinquency subpoenaed him for a special hearing.

ST. LOUIS, April 13 (AP) -- Lefty Paul Minner set the rookie-sprinkled St. Louis Cardinals down on six hits today and joined his teammates in a sixteen-hit barrage by slugging a two-run homer to make Stan Hack's debut as Chicago Cub manager a 13-4 success.

CHICAGO, April 13 (UP) -- Cleveland blasted fifteen hits, including five for extra bases, off four Chicago hurlers today to give Early Wynn an 8-to-2 triumph before the largest opening day crowd in White Sox history, 31,026.

TOKYO, April 13 (AP) -- Former Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura, Ambassador to Washington when Japan attacked Pearl Harbor, called today for a ten-year construction program to give this nation a defensive navy.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 14 (Reuters) -- Unusually swift reaction came from the Soviet press today to Secretary of State Dulles talk in London with Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden on the situation in Indo-China and Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- "We have an opportunity in India we never had in China -- an opportunity to reach the people with economic development," the State Department told Congress today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 13 -- A Russian diplomat who fled from his embassy has given the Australian Government information about a Soviet spy ring here. Prime Minister Robert G. Menzies announced in the House of Representatives tonight that Vladimir M. Petrov, third secretary in the Soviet Embassy, had been granted political asylum.
Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonon had a recipe yesterday for a 50-year-old circus and carnival chef who had cooked up a scheme to defraud the Government of $15,000. It was six years in jail.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 13 -- The United States challenged the Soviet Union today to lift censorship on foreign correspondence.
LONDON, April 13 (AP) -- Ichiro Ogimura of Japan and Tage Flisberg of Sweden swept through three matches each, today, to gain the final round in singles of the world table tennis championships.

Two strikingly modern designs printed on a traditional white cotton velveteen provide an unexpected note in a collection of fabrics introduced by the new Wolfin Associates, 13 East Fifty- third Street, where they are available through decorators.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The United States told Israel and the Arab countries today to renounce the use of force if they wanted peace in their area.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- Specialist in family life at the University of Chicago have reached the half-way point in a two-year parent education project. Their aim is to develop materials and effective study group methods to help parents in rearting their young.
PRINCETON, N. J., April 13 -- Dick Emery, a right-hander, allowed only two hits as Princeton's baseball team blanked C. C. N. Y., 1 -- 0, on University Field today.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, riding herd on rival factions in three of the most hotly contested proxy battles in recent times, has not yet been forced to use its punitive powers against anyone.

Governor Dewey used statistics and invective last night to picture Mayor Wagner as an inept official and irresponsible politician who sought to blame the state for all of New York City's difficulties except the water shortage.
A fireman was buried alive under a huge mass of debris in the basement of a burning building early today when the roof of a studio and factory building collapsed in the downtown section of Brooklyn.

George Cummings, University Club pro, and Richard McAvoy triumphed as the pro-amateur invitation squash racquets doubles tournament for the W. H. O'Reilly Trophy began yesterday on the University Club's courts.
" The Teahouse of the August Moon," "Ondine" and "The Golden Apple" were chosen yesterday by the New York Drama Critics Circle as the best presentations of the 1953-54 stage season here.
VIENNA, April 13 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party will hold its second congress since World War II on June 11, the Prague radio announced tonight.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 13 (AP) -- Eugene G. Grace, chairman of the board, told stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Company today that "we will have a good year in 1954 relative to the economic conditions of the country."
Wanted: more information from industry and from public relations men on special events activities scheduled for fall.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 13 -- Directors of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company today decided to sell a new $65,000,000 bond issue and buy back an issue sold last July.

New York, most modern of cities, turns to one of man's most ancient symbols during Easter week. The egg, which has been used to express life in many cultures, is found under various guises in toy shops, food stores and on gift counters, a brief look around the city showed yesterday.

PARIS, April 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles arrived here today and stressed that peace was the objective of the Indo-China conference in Geneva. This statement paved the way for a better atmosphere than had been expected for his talks tomorrow with Premier Joseph Laniel and Foreign Minister Georges Bidault on the defense of Southeast Asia.
A joint city-state committee to analyze the financial relationship between New York State and New York City was urged yesterday by the City Council.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- In a statement here today, Mr. Hollyday said: "In recognition of the privilege of working for this Administration for a year, I am going to Towson (Md.) in the morning to change my registration from Democratic to Republican."

Dr. Howard Selsam, the philosophy teacher who has been director of the Jefferson School of Social Science since its inception in 1944, testified in its behalf yesterday at a hearing of the Subversive Activities Control Board.

The days of 15-cen@ lunches and'5-cent dinners-with claret --were recalled last nightat a i meeting Of %he Standing commit@tee of the Association of Alumni {of Columbia College. The gath{ering commemorated the 167th anniversary of the granting of a charter to the college by the Legislature.
LONDON, April 13 -- Sir Winston Churchill rejected today South Africa's demand for three protectorates now under British administration.

A survey on the stake of American business in the $500,000,000 annual export trade with Venezuela was released yesterday to strengthen opposition to restriction of petroleum imports from that country.

Several changes are being planned for the "Comedy Hour" television program on N. B. C. next season. Instead of being presented each Sunday from 8 to 9 P. M., the program will be televised three Sundays out of four and alternated with a series of color programs.
TOKYO, April 13 -- A plan of reparations payments designed to yield the Philippines $1,000,000,000 was approved by the Japanese Cabinet today, according to reports here.
OTTAWA, April 13 -- The Canadian Government made public today the 40,000-word transcript of the questioning of Igor Gouzenko, former Soviet cipher clerk, by two United States Senators.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned somewhat irregular yesterday and closed 5 points lower to 10 points higher than on Monday.
BONN, Germany, April 13 -- The Social Democratic party moved today to weaken the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced an agreement today closing a restraint of trade case against the Alaska salmon industry.

President Eisenhower threw out the first ball as the baseball season opened in Washington yesterday and three hours later congratulated the player who hit the last pitch in the game between the Senators and the New York Yankees.

MAHWAH, N. J., April 13 -- Residents of this Bergen County community were divided into two camps today after the failure of the Board of Education last night to renew the contract of Superintendent of Schools Roy S. Austin.

The New York Academy of Medicine urged the city yesterday to establish a Municipal Laboratory Center. This would house three existing laboratories here and one proposed laboratory dealing with public health, and possibly others in related field.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 13 -- Anne Francis, who was introduced by Twentieth Century-Fox two years ago in "Lydia Bailey" and now is free-lancing, signed contracts with two studios today. She will have featured roles in "Battle Cry" for Warner Brothers and in "Rolled Top" for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

ATLANTA, April 13 (AP) -- The president of the American Bankers Association today called upon free enterprise to "take up the slack" in business and forestall Government moves to bolster the economy against a recession.
SEOUL, Korea, April 2 -- Korea's strained relations with Japan are a major irritant in Asian politics and an imposing barrier against the formation of any non-Communist front in this area.

AMMAN, Jordan, April 13 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet delegate, was acclaimed today in Jordan for his defense of the Arab case in the United Nations Security Council against the United States, France and Britain.
CINCINNATI, April 13 (UP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs rallied to beat the Milwaukee Braves today, 9 -- 8, as Andy Pafko was struck on the head by a pitched ball.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- For Mickey Vernon, the 36-year-old Washington Senators' first baseman, this was a memorable day. Vernon blasted the tenth-inning two-run homer that defeated the New York Yankees, 5 -- 3, and in full view of 27,160 spectators at Griffith Stadium, the President of the United States went out of his way to shake Mickey's hand.

On behalf of the Women's City Club I should like to congratulate The Times, and especially your reporter Charles Grutzner for his distinguished articles, "Hardship Common in Clearing Slums" and "City Lags in Help to Slum Tenants," which appeared in your issues of April 1 and 2.

Orleans Parish, La., awarded $3,000,000 of school bonds, due from 1955 to 1992, to Blyth Co., Inc., and associates at a net interest cost of 2.67 per cent for a combination of 4s, 2 1/4s, 2 1/2s and 2 3/4s.

The city's high schools, which have never fully recovered from a sixteen-month teacher boycott of extracurricular activities in 1950 and 1951, were confronted yesterday with the threat of another such "strike."
ROME, April 13 -- A plan to use fear of hydrogen bombs in case of war to lure Roman Catholics into the Communist camp was unfolded by Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, today.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (AP) -- Big Gus Zernial's two-run homer and a first-inning double by Bill Renna propelled the Philadelphia Athletics to a 6-to-4 decision over the Boston Red Sox today, but the victory was tempered by an apparent recurrence of Bobby Shantz' arm injury.
The Fire Department stopped an off-Broadway theatre production a few minutes before the opening night curtain last night, a theatre spokesman said. It was the third such closing in recent weeks.
Operations of the Republic Aviation Corporation for the quarter ended with March resulted in a net income of $924,905, compared with $1,901,870 earned in the first quarter of 1953.

YONKERS, April 13 -- Meadow Gene, a 4-year-old bay horse by Adios owned by the Peter Pan Stables of Washington, Pa., and driven by Jimmy Jordan, scored a one-length victory over Prince Eton in 2:07 in the Dunwoodie Pace before 18,181 persons at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

VIENNA, April 13 -- Today was the ninth anniversary of Austria's "liberation" by the Soviet Army but public buildings flew no flags. The only places that did so were those owned by the Soviet occupation authorities.

RIO GRANDE, Ohio, April 13 (UP) -- Coach Newt Oliver and Clarence (Bevo) Francis probably will know in two weeks what they will be doing next season, now that Francis has been expelled from Rio Grande College.

Your issue of April 9 reported an unfortunate incident at an official Government luncheon in Washington when remarks made by the president of the Synagogue Council of America caused embarrassment to the United States Government.

DETROIT, April 13 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles returned to American League competition today after an absence of fifty-two years and received a rough lesson that the home run still is baseball's most potent weapon.

Welfare Island Bridge, the $6,500,000 vertical lift span being built across the east channel of the East River between Astoria, Queens and the big hospital island in midstream, is two-thirds finished.

IN 1950 Tom Osborne was 30 years old and had been a successful editor in a New York publishing house for five years. Tom had a pleasant bachelor apartment in New York. He was agreeably in love with Mary Allison, a nice and attractive girl who loved him, too. /Life should have seemed goocl tb Tom, but' it: dtdn't
Heavy crowds are expected on the Bostonian, the New Haven Railroad's noon train going north from New York today. But when the train pulls out of New Haven there should be plenty of seats.

SEVEN young painters have collaborated in the establishment of a new gallery at 302 East Forty-fifth Street that, for reasons which will become apparent to the visitor, has been christened the Loft Gallery.

ROME, April 13 -- Former Premier Alcide De Gasperi denied in a Milan court today that he wrote in January, 1944, to the headquarters of Field Marshal Earl Alexander of Tunis, now British Minister of Defense, asking for Rome to be bombed from the air.

Leopold Stokowski, conductor, has promised to explain in writing today to Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, why he crossed a musicians' picket line to enter Station WOR, 1440 Broadway, on Monday, April 5.
The Long Island Lighting Company, serving electricity and gas to fast-growing Nassau and Suffolk Counties, reported gains in gross revenues and net income yesterday.
The Danish Maersk Line, active in regularly scheduled trans-Atlantic cargo service for the last seven years, has decided to withdraw from that run.

CHICAGO, April 13 -- The Chicago Corporation, oil and natural gas producer, announced today that it had entered into an agreement to purchase all the stock of Champlin Refining Company, Enid, Okla., and its subsidiary, Peppers Refining Company, Oklahoma City, for $55,000,000.

CHICAGO, April 13 (AP) -- The Bulletin of the atomic scientists said today that President Eisenhower's proposal for an international atomic pool offered little hope for removal of the danger of atomic destruction.
ALBANY, April 13 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. was favored today in an Associated Press poll of Democratic chairmen on their preferences for the party's gubernatorial nomination.

MONTREAL, April 13 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, the defending champions, evened their four-out-of-seven Stanley Cup hockey finals with the Detroit Red Wings at three games each tonight when they scored a 4-1 victory before 14,622 fans at the Forum.
Burlington Mills, the nation's largest producer of synthetic textiles, has reduced output on some cloths by almost one-third.
MONTICELLO, N. Y., April 13 (AP) -- A court upheld today this city's right to order its adult males to grow beards for next fall's sesquicentennial celebration.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, today urged legislation to lessen the rigid legal requirement for proving perjury.

Despite a 13.8 per cent drop in revenues the Erie Railroad maintained black-ink operations in the first quarter of this year, Paul W. Johnston, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.

The N. B. C. Symphony has ceased to exist. The official bulletin revealing its demise was issued yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company. But when Arturo Toscanini announced little more than a week ago that he was laying aside his baton, it was clear that the orchestra had received its death blow.

Today's new film is "Knock on Wood," a Paramount comedy in Technicolor starring Danny Kaye, at the Capitol Theatre. Norman Panama and Melvin Frank wrote, directed and produced the offering. The supporting cast is headed by Mai Zetterling, Torin Thatcher, David Burns, Leon Askin, Abner Biberman and Gavin Gordon.

The New York Public Library, now celebrating its 100th anniversary, has become an influence that permeates the whole fabric of New York life. Its services have been widened so that it now offers, besides books, a variety of programs to entertain and enlighten the citizens.

THE Paulist Fathers long have specialized in the pulpit debate as a means of presenting religious issues and now they have brought their technique to television. Regardless of a viewer's personal religious affiliation, the program is thoroughly absorbing and enlightening.

CHICAGO, Wednesday, April 13 -- In one of the lightest primary votes of recent years in this state Illinois Republicans yesterday chose Joseph T. Meek, president of the Illinois Federation of Retail Associations, to challenge Democratic Senator Paul H. Douglas in the November elections.

London gets the Huntington Hartford adaptation of "Jane Eyre." (Parenthetical note: Mr. Hartford, who is related to the A. P. grocery family and was named after his grandfather, has decided to drop the supplemental designation of "2d" after the surname.)

ALBANY, April 14 -- Governor Dewey rejected tonight the New York City Council's proposal for establishment of a fourteen-member joint committee to study fiscal relationships between state and city government.

ROME, April 14 -- The last two competition pieces in the category, "Chamber Music for Voice and Instruments," have been presented to the public and jury at the Twentieth Century Music Conference here.
CAIRO, Thursday, April 15 -- Political leaders of Egypt between 1942 and 1952 were deprived today of all political rights for the next ten years
BERLIN, April 14 -- Two top officials of anti-Soviet organizations in West Berlin vanished into the Soviet sector of Berlin last night.
SEOUL, Korea, April 3 -- South Korea's economy is a ramshackle structure prevented from toppling only by the props of foreign aid.

The Tri-Continental Corporation, one of the nation's largest closed-end investment companies, completed the first quarter of its twenty-fifth year of operations with net investment assets at a new high of $190,780,000, Francis T. Randolph, chairman, reported yesterday.
A quick-thinking truck driver forestalled a possible disaster in Staten Island yesterday when the driver of the bus on which he was a passenger died at the wheel.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson said today the case of former Army Maj. Irving Peress had been referred to the Justice Department because "there is some question that Peress may have committed perjury."

In Senator McCarthy's absence in the Southwest the other members of his subcommittee are showing a welcome independence of judgment toward the conduct of the McCarthy-Army hearings that are scheduled to begin a week from today.

The Boston and Maine Railroad does not expect 1954 to be "too good a year," T. G. Sughrue, president, told the annual meeting in Boston yesterday. The road is seeking permission to abandon unprofitable train runs and branch lines.

JERUSALEM, April 14 -- For the third time the Israeli Government denied today that Israelis had made a night raid April 6 on Husan, a village near Bethlehem. A spokesman for the Foreign Affairs Ministry said the Jordanian charge that.
The pianist, David Tudor, played a program of contemporary works at Carl Fischer Concert Hall last evening.

Stockholders of the world's largest telegraphic enterprise, the Western Union Telegraph Company, were told yesterday that earnings of the company for the first quarter this year totaled $1,186,000, against $1,943,000 in the same period a year ago.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 14 (AP) -- Billy Kilgore, an unrated Miami fighter, outpointed the former world middleweight champion, Jake La Motta, on a ten-round split decision tonight.
It didn't take the Dodgers long to square matters with their ancient foes on the Harlem along with taking their first important stride toward that coveted third straight pennant.

ALBANY, N. Y., Auril 14 (UP) -- New York state farmers will harvest less wheat and cabbage in 1954 than they did last year, the State Department of Agriculture and Markets predicted today. The department said it expected the strawberry crop, however, to be about the same as in 1953.

Coffee prices fell the 2 cents a pound daily limit at the opening yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. However, heavy buying entered the market late in the day and raised prices the permissible maximum of 200 points from the lows. Prices closed unchanged on 84,500 bags.

" Time is running against this country's shipyards" and at least half of our major yards face "mere maintenance employment" in less than a year, Leigh R. Sanford, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, asserted yesterday.
The Alfred Rainer collection of furs, shown yesterday at 17 East Fifty-fifth Street, was marked by its quality and almost timeless elegance and simplicity.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 14 -- The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's annual meeting came to no conclusion today about who is to be boss of that $500,000,000 transportation system. Frederic C. Dumaine Jr., who inherited the presidency from his father three years ago, and Patrick B. McGinnis, Wall Street stockbroker, are contesting for the office.

BATON ROUGE, La., April 14 (AP) -- Louisiana opened its offshore oil lands for leasing today for the first time in six years and received the largest bonus offer in the state's history -- $3,127,668 bid by the Sinclair Oil Company.

TRENTON, April 14 -- New Jersey voters will probably be asked in November to approve a $150,000,000 bond issue to finance a program designed to double the state's potable water supply. A biparisan bill is being prepared and its passage by the Legislature seems assured.

Mrs. Ruth Hakohen, a 28-year-old Israeli resident, was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in a penitentiary by Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo in Brooklyn Federal Court. She had pleaded guilty last Thursday to an indictment charging her with seeking to smuggle into the country 913.45 carats of diamonds worth $104,655.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Senator William F. Knowland told the Senate today that the United States-British agreement to consider a collective defense system for Southeast Asia seemed to defeat its own purpose.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 14 -- A dispute over who should set certain bolts in wood made 7,300 construction workers idle at two Oak Ridge atomic projects today.

LINCOLN, R. I., April 14 (AP) -- The Red Head Stable's Roedna, a 16-to-1 shot, raced the fastest mile and a sixteenth of the spring meeting today at Lincoln Downs to win the second division of the $25,000 Lincoln Special after John S. Phipps' Parnassus had captured the first section of the divided feature.

The Celanese Corporation of America, a major producer of acetate yarns for the textile industry, had an estimated sales volume of $29,000,000 in the first quarter of this year. This represented a decline of about $3,000,000 from the preceding three months, Harold Blancke, president, informed shareholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.
The New York Central Railroad announced yesterday plans to build a new station and related facilities at Harmon, N. Y.

Spring is here, and one of its proofs in that the sun is much brighter today than last week. This affects various people in various ways. Some it encourages to consult travel folders, with a view to planning summer vacations.
Nine out of ten persons in a canvassed sampling of leaders of American public opinion are in general agreement with the present United States policy toward the Soviet Union.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 14 (AP) -- The Journal-Bulletin today printed a story saying ten Boston newspaper men had been paid sums by the Rockingham Park race track last year ranging from $100 to $2,500.

PARIS, April 14 -- Secretary of States Dulles left Paris for the United States tonight believing that his quick trip to Britain and France had laid the basis for a common effort to defend Southeastern Asia.
TROUT seasons are opening all over the map, and tomorrow finds Connecticut joining the list, with prospects pleasant for one of the best opening days in years.
