A rare fifteenth-century illustrated book of the story of Passover that probably survived because its pages are of durable parchment, was presented yesterday to the American Fund for Israel Institutions for the Bezalel Museum in Israel.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- The United States pledged $27,000,000 today for the relief of refugees of the Palestine war. It also urged other members of the United Nations to be more open-handed in their own contributions.
The Metropolitan Opera will open its next season on Nov. 8 with a "gala performance" of scenes from four operas instead of the performance of a single opera, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Two ninth-inning errors by Wayne Terwilliger paved the way for the New York Yankees' first victory of the season today at Griffith Stadium.

The downtrend in chain store and mail order sales continued into March. A check of forty-three companies by The New York Times showed that their monthly volume was $953,563,161 or 7.2 per cent less than March, 1953.

The current bills pending before a subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee to outlaw the Communist party deserve both careful consideration and calm appraisal, rather than the emotional reactions such proposals have previously stimulated.

Some of the most exotic Easter flowers in town can be found in an apartment house basement at 502 East Seventy-ninth Street. Here presenting a contrast to the dusty, torn up street, the All Shopping Service Corporation's office is heavy with the scent of Easter lilies and bright with tropical blooms.
LONDON, April 14 (AP) -- The text of the agreement between Britain and the proposed European Defense Community on British cooperation with the defense community.

Opponents of the city's proposal to broaden the 3 per cent retail sales tax to include commercial services were rebuked yesterday by Mayor Wagner. Everyone wants "good things," the Mayor declared, but "no one wants to pay for them."

CHICAGO, April 14 -- The Container Corporation of America increased the quarterly cash dividend on its common stock and voted a 25 per cent dividend payable in common stock after closing the first quarter with a 78 per cent increase in net earnings compared with those of a year earlier.

BOWIE, Md., April 14 (UP) -- Jockey Nick Shuk and Mrs. H. A. Parr 3d's Staffordshire, a 2-5 favorite, shared the spotlight at Bowie today. Shuk booted home four winners. Staffordshire, a Kentucky Derby hopeful, romped to a four-length victory in the $5,000 Sophomore Purse.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 -- Citizens of suburban Gardena, Los Angeles' "Little Las Vegas" where gambling flourishes under a quirk in the state law, have voted to keep their $4,000,000-a-year major "industry."

ATLANTIC CITY, April 14 -- A crude filtrate of a penicillium mold, a member of the species that is the source of penicillin, has been found to "exert distinct anti-virus action in monkeys infected with Type 1 of the polio virus."

With the count of proxies unfolding slowly, the outcome of the contest for control of Blair Holdings Company, $25,000,000 investing concern, was still not established yesterday, the second day of the annual stockholders' meeting.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Oppenheimer case has opened up some strong and even bitter feelings, not only between Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer and his former associates at the Atomic Energy Commission but also between many leading scientists and the Eisenhower Administration.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- The grain markets were decidedly irregular today, with news of various sorts affecting prices. Both wheat and corn were strong in the early trade. May wheat rose upon indications of export business to various European countries and to Japan.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The conviction of Representative Ernest K. Bramblett, who was found guilty of falsifying his payroll in a salary kickback scheme, was nullified today until the Supreme Court acts upon it.

The Republic Steel Corporation, first major steel company to announce first quarter operating results, yesterday reported its net income at $11,079,012, a decrease of 19.6 per cent from the $13,779,049 earned in the initial three months last year.

Bob Goldsholl pitched a four-hit shutout for New York University as the Violets downed Brooklyn College, 7 -- 0, on the loser's diamond yesterday. This was N. Y. U.'s third straight Metropolitan Baseball Conference victory.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- The Senate today passed and sent to the White House a compromise bill authorizing $966,000,000 a year for highway construction in the fiscal years 1956 and 1957. The House had approved the measure earlier today.

Vassily Smyslov, challenger for the world chess championship, again opened with 1 P-K4 in the eleventh game of his match with Mikhail Botvinnik in Moscow. Botvinnik countered with an old-time variation of the Ruy Lopez defense, according to the record received yesterday.
Harold J. Chase has been named manager of marine turbine sales of the General Electric Company.

BOGOTA, Colombia, April 14 (AP) -- Two Protestant missionaries, the Rev. and Mrs. Warren O'Dell Nowowiejski of Salem, Ore., were insulted and threatened recently by a group of fifteen persons who later shot at their car, Colombia's Evangelical Confederation says. The confederation said three Colombian fellow worshippers had been beaten and kicked.
Twenty-two Sea Scouts from Minneapolis continued their tour of the East Coast yesterday with a visit to Columbia University.
The regional Red Cross Blood Program received 670 pints of blood on Tuesday.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 14 (Reuters) -- The French Army withdrew some restrictions on press cables from Hanoi tonight after foreign corespondents had formally protested that the world was receiving warped and misleading reports about the battle for Dienbienphu.

Commissioner Ford C. Frick yesterday served notice on major and minor league baseball alike that he would demand strict inforcement of the new rule requiring the removal of gloves and other equipment from the playing field during the course of a ball game.
MILWAUKEE, April 14 (AP) -- Andy Pafko arrived home today and tumbled into bed at his apartment.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The United States, Britain and France notified the Soviet Government today that the Geneva meeting on Far Eastern questions was not to be regarded as a five-power conference.

CHICAGO. April 14 (UP) -- Bob Lemon pitched a three-hitter for Cleveland today as the Indians tallied their second straight victory over the Chicago White Sox, 6 to 3, before 7,872 fans. Lemon faced only twenty-six batters in the last eight innings.
ALBANY, April 14 -- A broad program designed to provide ethical guidance for public officials and employes and to protect the interests of the public was signed today by Governor Dewey.

Agreement by the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and the nation's railroads to submit a wage dispute to arbitration does credit to their regard for the public welfare and for their industry as well. So rarely has voluntary arbitration been used as a method of settling major railroad disputes in recent years that this agreement is almost in the man-bites-dog category of news.
The New Jersey Turnpike Authority borrowed $27,200,000 in the public market yesterday to finance construction of a connection with the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

Nearly half the take-offs and landings at the metropolitan area's three major airports have been shifted in the last two years to areas least objectionable to the airports' neighbors, Vice Admiral C. E. Rosendahl reported yesterday.

In behalf of the Sunken Forest in Fire Island Beach, L. I., Mr. and Mrs. James N. Dunlop of New York and Driftwood, Point O'Woods, L. I., will give a reception and supper this evening in their home at 535 Park Avenue. Mr. Dunlop is chairman of the Sunken Forest Committee, members of which are seeking to preserve the area.

For the past year I have been stationed at Limestone Air Force Base in northern Maine, only a few minutes' drive from the "French Canada" described by Tania Long in the April 2 issue of The Times. Time and again my wife and I have been impressed, indeed inspired, by the deep religious devotion of the French Canadians, by their clean, peaceful towns and villages and by their sturdy, cheerful children.
Spurred by Tuesday's cut in the Chicago Federal Reserve re-discount rate, stocks surged forward yesterday over a broad front.
The annual services of Maundy Thursday and Good Friday will be held today and tomorrow.
DETROIT April 14(AP) -- Duane Pillette, a tall right-hander, gave the Baltimore Orioles a fancy going-home present today -- a strong six-hit effort for a 3-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

All the Americans who applauded last May when Valeriu C. Georgescu refused to barter his loyalty to his adopted country to secure the safety of his two sons in Communist-controlled Rumania will rejoice at the happy ending that finds father, mother and the two boys safely reunited in an apartment on Manhattan's East End Avenue.
PARIS, April 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of a communique on Southeast Asia issued jointly today by Secretary of State Dulles and Foreign Minister Georges Bidault:

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The New York Central Railroad charged anew today that unauthorized collaboration designed to effect common control of competing railroads had taken place in the fight for control of the Central.

William White, president of the New York Central Railroad Company, announced yesterday that he would sever all connections with that road in the "unlikely event that Robert R. Young and his associates should prevail" in their proxy fight.

Commuters and other riders on the Long Island Rail Road face a bleak future. Fares have risen 122 per cent above the levels of 1942. Further increases are threatened. No relief is in sight from the unsafe, crowded, uncomfortable, inadequate and outmoded facilities and services being furnished.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended April 7:

LONDON, April 14 -- British funds again appeared as the brightest spot in the stock markets today. Gilt-edge issues rose as much as 5 shillings (70 cents) but other sections were irregular, with the over-all tendency weak under light profit-taking before the Easter holiday.
The bill for permanent registration that the Governor has signed does not inspire those of us who have worked to secure P. P. R. to throw our hats into the air.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- Raymond O'Keefe, former Binghamton, N. Y., police officer, and six co-defendants asked the Supreme Court today to reverse their convictions in a 1951 gambling trial.

WASHINGTON, April l4 -- The New York Board of Trade called on Congress today to close "about the biggest loophole in our tax law" by subjecting interest on state and municipal bonds to Federal income taxes.
Frank Costello's gambling casino in New Orleans made nearly $750,000 in four years, but losses at an associated restaurant reduced the net profits to $174,486.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- The Soviet Union demanded today that Communist China, India and Czechoslovakia be invited to the closed-door atomic-control talks proposed by the West.
The Knott Hotels Corporation, which operates twenty-one hotels, reported yesterday its net income for 1953 was $803,470, compared with $742,910 the year before.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Two Congressional committees vied today to be the first to investigate housing scandals that bridged the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations.

THE other evening a beautiful European girl told me all about America. The catalogue of our manners and malaises she unrolled was awesome. One melody in her song was the notion that we were now taking altogether too much part in the affairs of the world -- a refreshing contrast, of course, to the days when America was scolded for not joining the League of Nations and sharing the polyglot burdens of man.

The city wide range on a pound of shrimp now is from 65 cents to $1.25 a pound. These prices are from 5 to 10 cents a pound lower than a month ago and indicate shrimp as a worth-while as well as a seasonally appealing dish.
Edward R. Murrow and Imogene Coca were among ten winners of George Foster Peabody Awards made yesterday for distinguished achievement by television and radio in 1953.

Governors of the Federal Reserve Board, in Washington, have just approved a reduction in the rediscount rate from 1 3/4 to 1 1/2 per cent voted by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. According to reports from banking circles this action initiated in the Seventh Reserve District is regarded as the probable forerunner of similar moves in other districts.
Potential Southern reactions to a possible Supreme Court decision banning segregation in public schools were forecast yesterday by John N. Popham, correspondent for The New York Times in the South.
Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, chairman of the Transit Authority, defended yesterday the agency's new policy of requiring its administrative employes to attend religious services on their own time.

CLEVELAND, April 14 (AP) -- Policemen used clubs and horses today to clear the way through an estimated 3,000 excited union men for carloads of non-strikers entering the Park Drop Forge Company plant.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams expressed his hope yesterday that television, radio and newsreel coverage of the Easter Parade here this year would be on as dignified a plane as it was in 1953.

New issues of public utility securities valued at more than $42,000,000 will be offered to investors today. Money raised by the financing will be used for the most part to pay bank loans incurred for capital purposes and to cover additional expenditures for expansion.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., April 14 -- Young cardiac patients, some on a limited activity schedule, had an unlimited good time here today at Irvington House as members of the Masonic order moved in and brought their seventh annual spring party with them.

An increase last week of 55,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end the aggregate was 179,729,000 barrels, compared with 179,674,000 a week earlier and 159,393,000 a year ago.
CHICAGO, April 14 -- Battle lines were being drawn today for what promises to be a bitter, free-swinging Senatorial campaign in Illinois this year.
BOSTON, April 14 -- A Federal court jury today acquitted George D. O'Brien of Wollaston, Mass., of complicity in the $681,700 robbery of an armored car in Danvers, Mass., two years ago.
The National Labor Relations Board threw out yesterday charges filed by the old International Longshoremen's Association against the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.
Camp Fire Girls throughout the nation are being asked to pack and send "Friendship Boxes to Korea" as part of the "Help Korea Trains" program that was announced last Friday by President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today it will accept bids on Friday for $1,000,000,000 worth of tax anticipation bills.

Francis R. St. John, chief libraria nof the Brooklyn Public Library, said yesterday that he had received and rejected a Veterans of Foreign Wars' protest against the presence of books by Communist authors.

Two new films will open at first-run theatres today. "Out of This World," a feature-length color documentary of modern Tibet, photographed on an expedition led by Lowell Thomas and Lowell Thomas Jr., is at the Guild Theatre.
PARIS, April 14 -- In its second annual report completed today, the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community reviewed achievements in its first year of operation.

Most banks in the country will remain open for business tomorrow, which is Good Friday. Stock and commodity exchanges, however, will be closed. Canadian grain and security exchanges also will shut down for the day. European financial markets will be closed Easter Monday as well as tomorrow.

ST. PAUL, April 14 -- Members of the Minnesota State Board of Health announced today that they did not believe the new polio vaccine developed by Dr. Jonas E. Salk of the University of Pittsburgh had been sufficiently tested to justify mass inoculations here.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Congressional interest in housing scandals stems largely from the tremendous Federal commitments represented in the broad loan insurance and guarantee programs of the Housing Act.

Thirteen firemen were injured in a five-alarm factory fire in Brooklyn that was brought under control at 2 o'clock yesterday morning. One of the men, buried under debris from midnight until 4 A. M., was rescued without apparent injury to himself.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 14 -- Vincent A. G. O'Connor, New York City Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, was a witness today in the trial of Walter G. Winne, superseded Prosecutor of Bergen County. He testified that in 1948 he had given information to the defendant about a Lodi, N. J., gambling house operated by Joe Adonis.
PHOENIX, Ariz., April 14 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy suggested today that he be permitted to place a seventh Senator on the investigations subcommittee that will look into his dispute with the Army.
Textron Incorporated will terminate on Monday its offer to exchange Textron shares for American Woolen Company common stock, Royal Little, chairman of Textron, announced yesterday.
A proposal to liberalize zoning rules for garages and gasoline stations evoked protests yesterday before the City Planning Commission.

Major league baseball's secondary openers are set for today. This will give the two champions, the Yankees and Dodgers, their chance to start the 1954 championship season on their respective home fields.

Confusion and dismay must grip those in Moscow who are charged with supervision of the Soviet spy networks in the free world directed by Russian diplomats abroad. Last January a member of the Soviet Mission in Japan, Yuri Rastvorov, disappeared. Reports that he has surrendered to American intelligence officers and has revealed facts about Soviet espionage have not been denied by our Government, though they have not been confirmed explicitly.

CANBERRA, Australia, April 14 -- Strict precautions were taken here today to insure the safety of a former Soviet Embassy official who has given the Commonwealth Government material showing Russian espionage in Australia.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 14 -- The Matson Navigation Company is considering building for its projected passenger service between California and Australia two one-class ships of twenty knots speed carrying 500 passengers each or two of twenty-six knots with accommodations for 800 each.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 14 -- Twentieth Century-Fox and Allied Artists have entered into a joint production and distribution agreement on two pictures originally scheduled by Allied. These are the Walter Wanger film, "The Adventures of Hajji Baba," which goes before the camera tomorrow, and The Black Prince," to be started June 15 in London.
CHICAGO, April 14 (AP) -- Hogs moved up to another new high since 1948, and the highest April price on record, for the second straight day today. The new top was $28.20, up 20 cents from yesterday.

PARIS, April 14 -- Foreign Minister Georges Bidault is expected to go before the French Cabinet tomorrow morning to ask that the long-delayed date for debate on the European Defense Community Treaty be set for May 25.

Sales of rayon and acetate yarn and staple are improving, according to a report of the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc. During March shipments of yarn and staple amounted to 90,800,000 pounds, a gain of 12 1/2 per cent over February and the largest total since October.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 14 -- The Netherlands Government agreed today to resume negotiations with Indonesia in the second half of June on ending the formal but largely dead-letter union between the two countries.

TOKYO, Thursday, April 15 (UP) -- A squadron of C-119 Flying Boxcars will be sent to the Philippine Islands "to aid in airlifting supplies to French Union forces in Indo-China," the United States Far East Air Forces announced today.

Both of the former chairmen of the Atomic Energy Commission -- David E. Lilienthal and Gordon Dean -- are due to appear as defense witnesses in the hearing of security risk charges against Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer.

Charles F. Kettering, inventor, declared last night that over-specialized technical education had imperiled original thinking by American scientists and engineers. He said some educators did not seem to realize "that a cross-section education may be as good or better than knowing everything about one thing."

KIBYA, Jordan, April 14 -- On the western slope of this Judean hilltop village, overlooking a hazy plain that stretches to the sparkling Mediterranean in the distance, new stone buildings in an ancient pattern gleam in the afternoon sun.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, April 14 -- The Netherlands Government rejected today the Soviet Union's protest against plans for stationing United States Air Force units in the Netherlands. In an aide memoire that Joseph M. A. H. Luns, co-minister of foreign affairs, handed to Stephan P. Kirsanov, Soviet Ambassador here, the Dutch said the protested plans "cannot endanger the consolidation of peace or the peace-loving relations between the lands."
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 14 -- Official Vietnamese quarters here estimate that 200,000 more men will be called for military service under the new draft.
Department and specialty stores are looking forward to more sales and better profits this year than last.

Msgr. Joseph M. Pernicone, pastor of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church, 627 East 187th Street, the Bronx, has been named by Pope Pius XII at auxiliary bishop of the New York Archdiocese and titular Bishop of the Diocese of Hadrianopolis in Asia Minor.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A Senate inquiry into orders of the National Advisory Council on International Monetary and Financial Problems, which are said to have handcuffed the lending activities of the Export-Import Bank of Washington, will be sought this week.

Most fishermen, we know, are very serious about their sport. In fact, some of them are so intent on getting a "strike" that they may be unintentionally discarding rubbish and other garbage in the watershed areas. This represents "an increasingly dangerous problem," according to Water Commissioner Arthur C. Ford, since further accumulations might endanger the municipal water supply.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 14 -- Economic aid to needy nations has tended to be improvised and inconsistent, Eugene R. Black, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said today.
LONDON, April 14 -- Aneurin Bevan, leader of the Labor party's left wing, resigned tonight from the "shadow cabinet," or parliamentary directorate of his party.

Children in the Marymount School at 1028 Fifth Avenue got the shock of their lives at 11:40 A. M. yesterday when a massive chimney of the former Frederick W. Vanderbilt mansion, next door, fell against the building.
Another local union that got its American Federation of Labor charter through John Dioguardi, convicted extortionist, is in trouble with the law.

MANILA, April 14 (AP) -- Vice President Carlos P. Garcia said today after a two-hour meeting with Katsumi Ohno, the Japanese Minister, that the Philippines accepted in principle the latest Japanese reparations offer.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- A cautious Congress waited today to see what might come of the security-risk charges against the nuclear physicist Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer.

LONDON, April 14 -- Prime Minister Churchill rejected today a recommendation that the salaries of members of the House of Commons be increased 50 per cent and that they receive non-contributory pensions.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) -- The American Viscose Corporation said today it plans to "furlough" all employes at its Marcus Hook, Pa., rayon plant except those engaged in research and development or other corporation services.
With only one of its runs in the earned category, Fordham's baseball team stopped Columbia's winning streak at four by taking a 7-5 decision yesterday at Jack Coffey Field, the Bronx.

A neighborhood campaign to beautify residential East Ninetieth Street between Madison and Park Avenues came to fruition yesterday as thirteen London plane trees were planted. The hybrid sycamores had been bought by residents of the block, who contributed $1,200 in what now appears to be a spreading idea to grace Manhattan with more shade trees.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The origin of the inquiry into the official acts and personal associations of J. Robert Oppenheimer, now being conducted in private by a panel of three headed by Gordon Gray, is to be found in the following passage from the President's State of the Union message, delivered to Congress on Feb. 2, 1953:

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- About 400 members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors are expected to attend the society's annual convention which opens tomorrow. The sessions will close with a banquet Saturday night at which former President Hoover will speak.
WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson, whipped the bipartisan farm bloc in Congress on a major test of farm policy today.

Publication yesterday of the Tobacco Industry Research Committee's "white paper" quoting cancer authorities as denying any link between smoking and lung cancer apparently failed to convince the industry itself that any theme other than health was the best in advertising. The apparent reason is that the public responds to this theme.

Seventeen prominent churchmen, professors and public figures requested President Eisenhower yesterday to deny further economic aid to Spain until "guarantees are made for the granting of freedom to the Spanish people."

Mayor Wagner accused Governor Dewey last night of "conniving" in dishonesty in government. He applied the term "fraud" to the presentation Mr. Dewey had made of state-city financial relations over radio and television on Tuesday night.

The French request for B-29 bombers for use in Indo-China and this week's visit to Paris of Secretary of State Dulles are different facets of the same problem. These two interrelated but distinct problems have created much of the air of the crisis atmosphere that has existed in Washington in the last few weeks.

PITTSBURGH, April 14 (AP) -- Third baseman Willie Jones moved from seventh to lead-off in the batting order, contributed a two-run homer, a double, which drove in a tally, and two singles in five trips to the plate to lead the Phillies to a 6-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- The Army formally charged in writing today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and his key aides sought "by improper means" to obtain preferential treatment for Pvt. G. David Schine.

Many reservations have been made for the annual card party for the benefit of the National Cathedral Association to be held next Thursday afternoon at the Colony Club under the auspices of the New York committee of the association.

SCOTTS BLUFF, Neb., April 14 (AP) -- Former United States Representative Terry Carpenter said today he would be a candidate for the full term Senate seat held by the late Senator Dwight Griswold, Republican of Nebraska.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., April 14 -- Water in New York City's reservoirs has never before been so low in any mid-April of modern times.

YONKERS, April 14 -- Retlaw Winchell, owned by Arthur Nardin of New York and driven by Stanley Dancer, achieved the best time of the new season, 2:05, to win the one-mile Hutchinson Pace before 13,300 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

CHICAGO, April 14 -- More than half the machine tools in the country's metalworking plants are obsolete, representing a replacement market of tremendous size for tool manufacturers, Ralph J. Kraut, president of the Giddings Lewis Machine Tool Company, Fond du Lac, Wis., said today.

WEMBLEY, England, April 14 (UP) -- Ichiro Ogimura of Japan won the men's singles crown in the world table tennis championships tonight by trouncing Tage Flisberg of Sweden, 21 -- 7, 21 -- 12, 18 -- 21, 21 -- 10. The match required less than thirty minutes.
Ed Wynn and his horn-rimmed glasses, befuddled look and funny hats may be seen on the Broadway stage again next season in a musical production.
Gov. Herman E. Talmadge tried yesterday to get New York shippers and shipping men to march through Georgia with business for the port of Savannah.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday afternoon that he would confer today at City Hall with Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, about the vote of the High School Teachers Association Tuesday night to discontinue after - school activities after May 1.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (UP) -- The Navy has ousted twenty-one officers and four enlisted men since 1950 on the ground that they had "connections with Communist activities."
CAIRO, April 14 -- The first tanker load of the 350,000 tons of Soviet "bargain" oil purchased by Egypt has proved to be unusable without expensive reprocessing.

One of the world's youngest crafts is having a comprehensive exhibit, opening today at the Cooper Union Museum. The display is devoted to enamels and traces the history of this material from the second century to the present.

LONDON, April 14 -- Prince Charles, 5, heir to the British throne, and his sister, Princess Anne, 3, embarked today on the royal yacht Britannia at Portsmouth on the first stage of a 2,800-mile journey to Tobruk in North Africa. Queen Elizabeth II and the Duke of Edinburgh, who are on a Commonwealth tour, will be joined by their children there May 1.

LONDON, April 14 -- Britain has pledged an armored division to service in the proposed European army and has declared her forces will be stationed on the Continent as long as the Soviet Union threatens the security of the Western world.

RICHMOND, Va., April 14 (AP) -- Reynolds Metals Company today asked the Henrico County Board of Supervisors for permission to build a multimillion-dollar, sixteen-story headquarters in Richmond's suburban West End.
The features of the proceedings at the Jamaica track yesterday were (a) the race-riding of Wee Willie Shoemaker, and (b) the race-running of the filly High Voltage.
TWO of the week's group shows bring together work by twentieth-century French artists.

GUATEMALA, April 14 -- The Roman Catholic Church here will continue throughout Holy Week its campaign against communism in Guatemala. It is based on a pastoral letter issued last week by the Most Rev. Mariano Rossell y Arrellano, Archbishop of Guatemala.
Newly available in housewares sections of department stores is the Rival Grind-O-Mat, a handsome modernization of that kitchen indispensable, the meat grinder.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 14 -- Those twenty-six G. I.'s who were so eager to get home for Easter that they tried to borrow the President's airplane apparently are not so homesick after all.
NEWARK, April 14 -- The citizenship of Albert Anastasia, reputed former head of Murder, Inc., in Brooklyn, was canceled today.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) -- Admiral Arthur Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, emphasized to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that the nation's defense plans were not based on the belief that ability to deliver massive atomic retaliation was in itself "adequate to meet all our security needs."

An American edition of "David," a re-creation of the story of the Biblical hero-king by Piero Bargellini, will be issued next Thursday by P. J. Kenedy. The publication will introduce to the American public a contemporary Italian author whose books number in the sixties. Bargellini is a native of Florence and a member of the city's Municipal Council in charge of fine arts.

BALTIMORE, April 14 -- This normally sedate old city was prepared tonight to pull out all the stops in celebration of the return of major league baseball to one of the diamond sport's original hotbeds after an absence of fifty-two years.
One of the major automobile dealers here announced yesterday that the company's agency on Manhattan's "automobile row" would be closed because of high operating costs and crowded traffic conditions.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet but steady all day and active months advanced 3 to 10 points.
PARIS, April 14 -- Nina Ricci opened the midseason showings with flowered prints as lovely as a herbaceous border in an English garden.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) The Philadelphia Athletics left today for a Yankee Stadium date with New York's world champions tomorrow without their ace left-hander, Bobby Shantz, but with high hopes the little pitcher would soon be rid of a shoulder injury.
Promotion of more dollar trade and acquisition of technical "know-how" were listed yesterday as major aims of an Argentine private business mission now visiting the United States.

The 515 Atlantic Avenue Realty Corporation has purchased the three-story building at that address in Broklyn from Bertram R. Bearns in a transaction negotiated by Thomas F. Ellenbogen as broker. The property, at the corner of Third Avenue, contains a bar and grill and furnished rooms.

A "clam shell" that reverses the blast of a jet engine, enabling a jet transport plane to stop on an icy runway in the same distance as a conventional transport with reversible propellers, was described yesterday before the Society of Automotive Engineers.
ALBANY, April 15 -- The Court of Appeals upheld unanimously today the constitutionality of the Dewey program for redrawing the lines of the state's Senate districts. There was no opinion.

MILWAUKEE, April 15 (AP) -- Billy Bruton scored all the way from first base on Danny O'Connell's single to right and Outfielder Rip Repulski's muff in the eleventh inning today to give the Milwaukee Braves a 7-6 victor over the St. Louis Cardinals.

THE Yankees were gathered around the batting cage before their home opener with the Philadelphia Athletics at the Stadium yesterday, considerably relieved that they had finally broken into the victory column the day before.

The second step in young Leslie Stevens' career as a dramatist will be Broadway. Early this year his first play, "Bullfight," successfully produced at the downtown Theatre de Lys, earned him the right to be called a promising playwright.

BOSTON, April 15 (UP) -- Bill Henry spaced three hits and Sammy White got four in four times at bat today to pace the Boston Red Sox to a 6-to-1 home opening victory over the Washington Senators before 17,272 chilled fans at Fenway Park.

Left-wing groups got a permit yesterday for a May Day demonstration at Union Square after they had protested to Mayor Wagner that the Park Department's original refusal was "prejudiced against labor."

WESTBURY, L. I., April 15 -- Conrad H. Rothengast, who retired last December as Chief Inspector of the New York City Police Department, was appointed today to head the Roosevelt Raceway police force. He will succeed Harold R. King, who resigned because of ill health.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The Communications Commission ruled today that a newspaper may oppose a television station application on grounds that the station would be its competitor for advertising and cause "economic injury" to it.

LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- A leader of Britain's biggest film technicians union called today for a chain of publicly owned movie houses to combat what he termed the pressure of American and British combines.

Izvestia has called for a drastic tightening of discipline in Soviet schools. The Government newspaper hinted that officials were seriously considering instituting a system of forced labor for unruly youths expelled from school.

ANGLERS, poised for flight to the Catskill trout streams, should find the conditions much better than during the opening week-end. The reports from some of the lower Adirondack streams indicate that prospects there are much brighter.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- Senators William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, and Pat McCarran, Democrat of Nevada, said today the Senate Internal Security Subcommittee had uncovered "voluminous information" on Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer in 1952 and turned it over to "the proper agencies of the Government."
CAIRO, April 15 -- A purge of Egyptian press elements accused of corrupt practices was announced tonight by the ruling military junta.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 15 -- Prof. Joseph Clifton Elgin, chairman of the Department of Chemical Engineering at Princeton University, has been appointed dean of the university's School of Engineering, retiring Dean Kenneth H. Conduit announced tonight.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 15 -- Dr. Ralph J. Bunche is expected to become a high-ranking political trouble-shooter for the United Nations under a reshuffling of the organization's top jobs.
Referring to your reports of interviews given to the press by K. C. Wu, and to your very just and wise editorial, may I be permitted to add a word.

LONDON, April 15 -- Some Conservative politicians proposed today an early general election. They favored this to take advantage of the gap in Laborite unity opened by the resignation of Aneurin Bevan from the Labor party's front bench.

Leopold Stokowski's explanation for crossing a musicians' union picket line has been received by Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, and forwarded to the union's international offices in Chicago.

When Ira Wolfert's novel, "An Act of Love," was published in 1948, it received both acclaim and severe criticism. Feeling that he had not "fully achieved his intention as a writer," Mr. Wolfert collected all the reviews that took issue with the work and found that in many cases the comments were just and to the point.
Directors of Cone Mills, Inc., have elected Lewis M. Heflin to the new office of executive vice president and Thomas R. C. Hood and Robert C. Shaw as vice presidents, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday numbered 606,790 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

SYRACUSE, April 15 -- Secretary of State Dulles declared here today that if the free world stood firm, "the Geneva conference will advance the cause of freedom in southeast Asia and the Pacific." He added that he was "well satisfied" with the results of his conferences in Britain and France on Indo-China.

Chicago civic boosters who never sleep in their search for "firsts" for the Windy City must have sighed with satisfaction yesterday. Directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York voted to cut the rediscount rate from 1 3/4 to 1 1/2 per cent.
Two railroads raised $6,540,000 in the public market yesterday to help finance the purchase of new equipment.

DETROIT, April 15 -- At 6:56 A. M. today the freighter Carl W. Meyers of Detroit passed through the American Locks at Sault Ste. Marie. The lake shippers' long icy winter of discontent that began last Nov. 29 was ended.

There is no end to the enchantments of Verdi's "Falstaff." It is quicksilver and wisdom, laughter and compassion -- as difficult to produce as to probe the many facets of its humanity. Say for the New York City Opera Company, which made its first attempt at producing it last night at the City Center, that it has done a charming job.
DALLAS, April 15 (UP) -- Seeded players encountered little trouble in the opening round of the Dallas Country Club's annual invitation tennis tournament today.
WASHINGTON, April 15 (UP) -- A Federal Court auditor has ruled that a former Chinese Air Force officer owes the Chinese Nationalist Government a default judgment of $6,368,503.47.

THE first ship in the Honorable East India Company's Service to reach India docked at Surat in 1608 after a voyage of sixteen months. Early in the following year William Hawkins journeyed to the court of the Mogul Emperor, Jehangir, at Agra to plead for permission to trade. It was a small beginning, but out of it grew the conquest of India by a commercial company and all the subsequent history of India.

ROME, April 15 -- The Rome Conference on Twentieth-Century Music met this morning for the last time at the Capitol for the awarding of Twentieth Century Masterpieces prizes. The assembly was greeted by Mayor Salvatore Rebecchini and by Denis de Rougemont.

Governor Dewey displayed more fortitude than Russ Meyer at Ebbets Field yesterday. Despite the reported 47-degree temperature -- which felt more like 37 -- the Governor lasted nine innings, while Meyer was compelled to give up in the eighth with the bases filled with Pirates and nobody out.
Long-simmered tomato sauce, the inseparable companion of Italian spaghetti, may be made in quantity and used in a great variety of ways to add flavor-interest to family meals.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The country's highest military authorities gave a grave but essentially confident estimate of the world military position today to the foreign policy leaders of the Senate.

In 1952 the average American was eating six and a quarter dozen eggs more a year than he did in 1929. He was consuming forty-seven more quarts of milk and twenty-four pounds a year more meat. He was using more citrus fruits, but eating less potatoes, flour and cereal products.

VIENNA, April 1 -- Next to a state treaty, what the Viennese dream about these days is the reopening of the Vienna Opera House, which was bombed by the United States Army Air Forces in 1944. By October, 1955, the 85-year-old building will have been rebuilt.

HANOI, April 15 (Reuters)-- The United States has moved two aircraft carriers, with their full striking force of war planes aboard, into the Gulf of Tonkin, off northern Indo-China, an authoritative source said here today.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- An Administration measure calling for three-year renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act was put before Congress today.
ST. LOUIS, April 15 (AP) -- Fred M. Saigh said today that he had made a bid for the mechanical equipment of The Washington Times-Herald.

Lovers of the outdoors who want to be sure that mosquitoes will not interfere with their pleasure this summer may do well to take a trip down to the United States Appraiser's Stores at 201 Varick Street, next week to participate in a two-day auction of abandoned, unclaimed and seized merchandise.

A portion of the blockfront on the north side of Horace Harding Boulevard between Ninety-eighth and Ninety-ninth Streets in Corona, Queens, comprising 100,000 square feet, has been purchased by Michael Kennedy for improvement with a ten-story apartment building.

As one of the eight million New Yorkers who suffer from the inefficiency of our postal service I thought it might interest my fellow sufferers to know how some of the major post offices abroad serve the public. Here are the facts:
Youthful summer fashions for expectant mothers were displayed yesterday by Macy's maternity shop.
LONDON, April 15 -- The stock market here was quiet today on the eve of the Easter week-end holiday.
The New York Stock Exchange, through its member concerns, and twelve listed corporations, will begin this month to use show windows to advertise investments in common stocks.

Plans are being formulated at luncheon meetings in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria and in private homes for the card party in behalf of the Youth Consultation Service to be held on April 28 at the Colony Club. The benefit has been arranged by members of the Service Club of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church.
Passover, which begins tomorrow night, and Easter on Sunday mean bulging market baskets this week-end for the housewife planning festive meals.
YONKERS, April 15 (AP) -- Bill Haughton drove Florita, the 7-5 favorite, to victory in the $3,000 Eastchester Pace tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick announced yesterday that he had imposed 50 per cent rent reductions on five landlords referred to him by Chief City Magistrate John M. Murtagh.

The Republicans of Illinois have now selected the man to represent them in the Senatorial election next November. He is Joseph T. Meek, president of the State Federation of Retail Associations. His opponent on the Democratic ticket will be Senator Paul H. Douglas.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 15 -- Dr. Ernest C. Pollard, chairman of the Scientists Committee on Loyalty and Security, defended Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer today and said "the free world is still free because of him."
Three new films will open at first-run theatres this morning.
ROME, April 15 -- Giovanni Guareschi, author of "The Little World of Don Camillo" was sentenced in Milan today to one year in jail for having libeled former Premier Alcide De Gasperi.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, warned Congress recently that the Dulles doctrine of instant retaliation would raise "serious appre hensions" in Western Europe.
The bankrupt Long Island Rail Road increased its demands for higher fares yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 15 -- Julie Harris has signed with Warner Brothers to play the co-starring role of Abra in "East of Eden," to be directed and produced by Elia Kazan from the John Steinbeck novel. The only other cast member engaged is James Dean, for the role of Caleb.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Industrial production dipped again in March but the decline, 1 per cent compared with February, was slight, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Judge Harold A. Stevens of General Sessions resigned yesterday as chairman of a committee set up to police the no-bias employment policy adopted last year by employers and unions in the brewery industry.

HANOI, Vietnam, April 15 -- Communist-led Vietminh troops smashed to within 2,400 feet of the heart of Dienbienphu today and split the battered bastion's east-west defenses. The move was seen as a prelude to another mass rebel assault on the northwest Indo-China fortress.

SAUK CITY, Wis., April 15 (UP) -- Leroy Gore, weekly newspaper editor who started a sensation with his campaign to oust Senator Joseph R. McCarthy from the Senate by recall vote, found out today that some of his fellow townsmen were not exactly wild about h/m, either.

More than 10,000 signatures have been received from persons who believe a court should decide on charges of fraud and deceit by former Senator William Benton of Connecticut against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, the "I Believe" Committee said here yesterday.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday a slowing down in the rate of growth in telephone demand and the use of long-distance lines.
CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP) -- Mickey Mars upset Nate Brooks tonight, and another favorite, Rocky Castellani, had trouble outpointing Pedro Gonzales at the Cleveland Arena.
SEOUL, Korea, April 15 -- The Republic of Korea has expanded its embargo on trade with Japan to include goods purchased for Korean reconstruction with United States aid funds.

PITTSBURGH, April 15 (AP) -- I. W. Wilson, president of the Aluminum Company of America, told a meeting of stockholders today that the controversy between Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, and TV-commentator Edward R. Murrow has caused Alcoa some uneasy moments.

Assurances that there would be no recurrence today of last summer's costly two-month strike of 1,800 cement drivers were given yesterday by John J. O'Rourke, president of Local 282 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L.

The Church Club of New York, a sixty-seven-year-old organization of Episcopal laymen, has become involved in controversy over the refusal of its admissions committee to grant membership to a Negro judge.
The state and city continued yesterday to throw verbal brick-bats at each other over the city's fiscal affairs.
The Transit Authority voted yesterday to change its capital budget for 1954 to increase from 240 to 300 the number of new cars to be ordered this year for the I. R. T. subway.

ROME, April 15 -- Premier Mario Scelba's Government was weakened today when some leading exponents of his own party's Right Wing said they favored a Center-Right government. This was thought to show a lack of confidence in the present Government, which is exclusively of the Center, and has repudiated any alliance with the Monarchists.

Station WOR-TV asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday for authorization to conduct experimental broadcasts with Phonevision, a form of subscription TV developed by the Zenith Radio Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Congressional leaders appealed to the Federal Bureau of Investigation for help today as housing scandals put key Administration bills in jeopardy on Capitol Hill.
BUFFALO, April 15 -- The present vocational guidance program in the schools is not adequate, Dr. Howard C. Seymour, Assistant Superintendent of Rochester public schools, said today.

Mayor Wagner refused yesterday afternoon to cross a musicians' union picket line at Yankee Stadium to throw out the first ball at the season's opening game between the New York Yankees and the Philadelphia Athletics.

EVERY school morning Sam picks up Veronica, Mary-Jo, Debbie, Davey, Jackie and Julio in a limousine owned by the Parochial Bus System, Inc. He drives Mary-Jo and Debbie to 59 East Fifty-seventh Street, between Second and Third Avenues.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- It is understood that the United States will formally assure France that American troops will be kept in Europe as long as is necessary to our Allies there.

That truth is stranger than fiction is demonstrated again by the latest and most fantastic case of Soviet intelligence kidnapping in West Berlin. Some months ago moviegoers here saw the British film "The Man Between," in which James Mason played the role of a secret Soviet agent whose job it was to kidnap West Berliners who were interfering with Moscow's plans.

The United States must play the dominant role in achieving a permanent peace between Israel and the Arab states to thwart Communist infiltration in the Middle East, it was stressed last night at two meetings. Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Representative Jacob K. Javits and several Zionist leaders spoke.

JERUSALEM, April 15 -- Israel's development plans will have to be reduced in view of the announcement that United States aid for the year ending June 30 will total $52,500,000, compared with the $65,000,000 to $70,000,000 that were sought.

CHICAGO, April 15 (UP) -- Jim Greengrass hit a grand-slam home run in a six-run seventh inning today to spark the Cincinnati Redlges to an 11-to-5 triumph over the Chicago Cubs before 17,271 fans at the Wrigley Field opening.
Dr. Milton Helpern, deputy chief medical examiner in charge of the Bellevue Morgue, will be sworn in Monday as chief medical examiner, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
DETROIT, April 15 -- William White, president of the New York Central Railroad, said today that Robert R. Young did not measure up to good management standards.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Abraham Chasanow, dismissed as a security risk after twenty-three years of service in the Navy Department, took his fight for his job into the court of public opinion today.
" THAT'S My Boy" is a new situation comedy presented at 10 P. M. Saturdays over the C. B. S. television network. It is an excellent excuse for getting out of the house.

Parents of more than half the eligible children attending public and Jewish schools have made application to have their children included in the tests here of the new Salk vaccine against poliomyelitis.
TAMPA, Fla., April 15 (AP) -- The Airport Operators Council unanimously endorsed today the proposed resumption of Federal aid for airport construction.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told 400 newspaper editors today that "due to the massive militant nature" of the Communist threat the world was in a period of tension that could last a century.
J. Waties Waring, retired United States District Judge, discussed yesterday controversial issues raised by an address he made here on Feb. 28 attacking segregated schools in the South.

MOSCOW, April 15 -- An indication was given today that despite the severe censures directed against Prof. Trofim D. Lysenko, the Soviet Government and the Communist party regarded his practical agricultural services as of considerable value.

Some wonderful music-making, and some debatable questions of taste, "tradition," "style," etc., distinguished the concert given by Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic - Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall.
Although they expect a 2 per cent decline in sales, large manufacturers plan to spend for new plants and equipment this year as much or more than they did in 1953.

BOSTON, April 15 -- The research and strategy director of the Massachusetts Council of Protestant Churches took issue today with a claim that more than 4,000,000 Roman Catholics had been converted to Protestantism in the last ten years.

FLEMINGTON, N. J., April 15 (AP) -- Settlement of a proxy fight on changes in the American Car and Foundry Company's capital stock was postponed today when a special meeting of stockholders here decided to adjourn to May 27.
The wildness of two City College pitchers enabled Columbia to rally for four runs in the seventh and defeat the Beavers, 7 -- 5, yesterday at Baker Field.

Connecticut borrowed $33,416,000 in the public market on serial bonds yesterday to finance construction of institutional and vocational school buildings. The interest cost on the borrowing, which is to be paid off from 1955 to 1974, was 1.8862 per cent.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Friday, April 16 -- The outcome of the bitter battle for control of the $500,000,000 New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company remained in doubt early today as the annual stockholders' meeting went into its third day.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 15 -- Plans for integrating approximately 20,000 troops of the Cao Daist religious sect into the Vietnamese National Army faced disruption today.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- A Senate Judiciary subcommittee today delayed until Monday action on the nomination of Leonard E. Walsh, a former counsel to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, to be a Federal judge for the Southern District of New York.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was irregular yesterday. Prices closed 8 points higher to 13 points lower than Wednesday, with old May showing unusual strength.

May I supplement the letter of J. H. Landman. In connection with his discussion of the need for being concerned with the exceptional student as well as with defectives and delinquents he suggests that in New York the least we might do is to reestablish Townsend Harris Hall.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- There are numerous evidences that the script writers and producers of Hollywood do not read the Congressional Record. Any movie about political life in the United States is enough to demonstrate this fact. But almost every day in the pages of the periodical are to be found the makings of a thrilling political drama, and in the current issue there is a splendid sample.

ANKARA, Turkey, Friday, April 16 -- Col. Gen. Koca Popovic, Yugoslav State Secretary for Foreign Affairs, announced here yesterday that Turkey and Yugoslavia had decided during President Marshal Tito's current visit to Ankara to transform their treaty of collaboration with Greece into a binding military alilance.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby told a House Appropriations subcommittee today that the importance of the functions of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare was "out of all proportions to the size of the appropriations."
BOMBAY, India, April 15 -- Indians have taken sharp objection to the Washington-sponsored move for a ten-nation collective security alliance in Southeast Asia and the Pacific.

The Dow Chemical-Detroit Edison group of companies which is developing an atomic reactor for power production plans to spend $2,500,000 on research during the next year. The group announced yesterday it had signed a new agreement with the Atomic Energy Commission.
If it were more generally known that doctors do not have a cure for radiation injuries there would be a greater outcry for the cessation of atom and hydrogen bomb experimentation.
TOKYO, April 15 -- Mrs. Margaret Sanger, noted advocate of birth control, today became the first woman from the United States to testify before the Japanese Diet.

KYOTO, Japan, April 15 (AP) -- Japan's foremost nuclear physicist spoke out today against hydrogen bomb tests, breaking a self-imposed silence because "this is a problem of atomic energy versus mankind."

An aggressive campaign is coming up to promote Puerto Ricar rums. These already dominate the market; the purpose of the drive is to double their volume. All drinkers of spirits will be regarded as prospects, and the advertising, using chiefly. text matter and a minimum of illustration, will attempt to convert them to users of rum.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- With the wind and the rain and Little Murry Dickson continually in their hair, the Giants dropped a 2-0 decision to the Phillies in an abbreviated local home-opener at Connie Mack Stadium today. The field became too wet for play when the Phils went to bat in the seventh inning and, following a wait of 1 hour 21 minutes, the umpires called it quits.
HOUSTON, Tex., April 15 (AP) Senator McCarthy said today that Senator Symington had violated a Senate subcommittee rule in making public the Army Bill of Particulars.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- President Eisenhower's plan for a speedup in corporation tax collections will mean higher electricity bills for householders and industrial users if it goes into effect, Congress heard today.

MOSCOW, April 15 -- The Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs. Andrei A. Gromyko, has been wearing a dinner jacket to Western, diplomatic, black-tie functions, and it appears that a new trend in Soviet dress may be in the making.

PARIS, April 15 -- The French Cabinet decided today to discuss on May 18 the date for the Assembly debate on the European Defense Community treaty. The decision was said to open the way for France to obtain the United States guarantee that had been one of the French pre-conditions for the treaty's ratification.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission adopted today a controversial new rate-making policy in approving a $12,778,864 rate increase for the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company. The commission, by a 4-to-1 vote, decided Panhandle's rate should reflect the "fair field value" of its gas reserves.
JERUSALEM, April 15 -- Hostility along the armistice line dividing Jerusalem interfered today with Holy Week observances.

Clint W. Murchison and Sid W. Richardson, through counsel, served a summons and complaint on the New York Central Railroad Company yesterday, seeking to compel the road to transfer to them their 800,000 shares of Central stock.
The National Dairy Products Corporation has appropriated $36,000,000 this year for new plants, improvements and replacements, representing the largest capital expenditure in its history.

WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP) -- Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt, Democrat of Manhattan, introduced today a 300-page bill designed, he said, to maintain the nation's economy by increasing consumer purchasing power.

The Dow Chemical Company reported yesterday net profit of $24,184,963, equal to $1.03 a common share, for the nine months ended Feb. 28, compared with $25,269,416 or $1.11 a share for the nine months to Feb. 28, 1953.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The case of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer was focused today on an alleged former German street-fighting Red who had denounced the American Communist party as being too soft.

After an hour-long conference at City Hall, Mayor Wagner and Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said at a joint press interview that they could offer no hope for more than $450 in pay increases for teachers this year.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Wheat was the weak spot in the grain markets today, suffering substantial declines as the result of liquidation. Commission houses accumulated wheat futures on the declines, but buyers were still indisposed to follow upturns.
It was moving day yesterday for ninety-six adult patients of Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today imposed at least a temporary boycott on the Senate investigation of his dispute with the Army.
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Eisenhower Administration proposed today a fundamental revision of the Atomic Energy Act of 1946.
The Crucifixion of Christ on Calvary will be solemnly commemorated today by thousands of New York churchgoers at Good Friday services.
Dr. Robert Kerr, Mayor of Cortland, flew back to the United States yesterday with new, and first hand information about Pakistan for the 18,000 citizens of his upstate New York town.

The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor is successfully resisting a series of legal assaults aimed at weakening its powers to regulate certain waterfront activities. The Supreme Court has affirmed lower court rulings banning "public loaders" from the piers and regulating employment.

Regional officials of the National Labor Relations Board will go to Washington next Monday to confer with the national board on arrangements to prevent hoodlum interference with a new waterfront election here. It is expected that the election will be held late in May.

BALTIMORE, April 15 -- Baltimore gave its Orioles a big league welcome back to American League baseball today. There never has been a parade in the State of Maryland to match the one staged in celebration of this city's first major league contest since 1902.

Anita Associates, Inc., which recently bought 239 and 241 East Seventy-ninth Street from Herbert H. Bachrach, Ira Rosenstock and others, has added the adjoining properties 1523 to 1537 Second Avenue, 243 East Seventy-ninth Street and 246 East Eightieth Street to gain control of the entire blockfront on west side of Second Avenue from Seventy-ninth to Eightieth Streets.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Following are the texts of the Army Bill of Particulars to the Senate inquiry on the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, as carried by the Associated Press, and of a telegram and supplementary telegram sent by Roy M. Cohn, aide to Mr. McCarthy:
CHICAGO, April 15 (AP) --Producers continued to ship hogs to market in surprisingly light numbers and prices once again went to a record high for April today.

AUGUSTA, Ga., April 15 -- President Eisenhower varied his vacation today by signing a dozen bills, but he didn't neglect his golf. After working in his office all morning, he played eighteen holes in the afternoon.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., April 15 -- Following is the text of the letter from Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer to The Rochester Times-Union printed on July 5, 1949:

" Copying down," a process by which high-priced ideas of famous designers reach the middle income homes of America, is the feature of new furniture shown yesterday at the new showrooms of Robert Barber, Inc., 6 East Fifty-third Street.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 15 (AP) -- Jody Alderson, 19-year-old University of Illinois sophomore, today won the 100-yard free style in the National A. A. U. women's indoor swimming and diving championships, bettering the new American record which she had set in the morning qualifying trials.

The Korean Children's Choir stood at the foot of the Statue of Liberty yesterday morning and sang America's national anthem and then their own "Ai Gook Ka." Beside them and joining in occasionally was an old friend of the organization, Gen. James A. Van Fleet, former commander of the United Nations forces in Korea.
Passover -- the Jewish festival that commemorates the exodus of the Israelites from Egyptian bondage -- will begin at sundown tomorrow with services in synagogues and temples.

CLEVELAND, April 15 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers put two walks and Bill Tuttle's scratch infield single together in the ninth inning today to beat the Indians, 3 -- 2. The defeat was Cleveland's first of the season. Rain delayed the home opener an hour and a half after the eighth inning ended with the score tied, 2 -- 2.

The May price of fluid milk (Class 1-A) produced for the New York Metropolitan Milk Marketing Area will be $4.45 a hundredweight (46.5 quarts), it was announced today by Dr. C. J. Blandford, market administrator. The price for April is $4.77. In May, 1953, it was $4.51.

Seven Argentine cruising yachts were scheduled to leave Buenos Aires yesterday aboard the Argentine State Line's cargo vessel, Rio Atuel, for starts in the Newport to Bermuda ocean race. The race begins June 19. The yachts are due in New York about May 6.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 15 -- Dr. Arthur M. Schlesinger will retire from the Harvard University faculty in the summer at the age of 66.

Otto Erhardt, stage director, supervising yesterday morning's dress rehearsal of "Falstaff" at the City Center, became so engrossed in his work that he absent-mindedly stepped off the stage and fell into the orchestra pit, landing on a kettledrum and delivering a glancing blow to a woman tympanist.

DETROIT, April 15 -- A readjustment of wages at the Kaiser-Willys auto plant in Toledo that was accepted last night by the workers eventually should result in a pay increase, a union official said today. It had been interpreted as a voluntary "pay cut."
WASHINGTON, April 15 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $21,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
ALBANY, April 15 -- Three bills aimed at assisting local law enforcement officers in clearing newsstands of obscene magazines and comic books were signed today by Governor Dewey.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 15 -- The isolation and identification from the nerve tissue of a marine animal of a new biological substance may provide important clues to the understanding of the functioning of nerves in higher animals, including man.

KANSAS CITY, April 15 (AP) -- Member schools of the National Collegiate Athletic Association gave an emphatic "no" to the Big Ten Conference in voting for the seventh straight year to continue its limited nationally controlled program of televising football games.

Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger, retired, civil defense adviser to Mayor Wagner, recommended yesterday that the city's defense plan continue to be built around organization and training "to meet any threatened attack."

SAIGON, Vietnam, April 15 -- Maj. Gen. John W. O'Daniel said on his arrival here today to head the American Military Assistance Group in Indo-China that his mission did not include a training program for Vietnamese troops.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 15 -- Slower demand for iron ore in lower Great Lakes ports indicates a reduction of about 15,000,000 tons in this year's shipments from Minnesota, according to state officials.

LONDON, April 15 -- Reports that Prime Minister Churchill recently had privately hinted at his retirement this summer were cited by diplomats here today as one reason why there was likely to be a further delay in the resumption of long suspended British-Egyptian talks on the future of the Suez Canal base.

LONDON, April 15 (AP) -- The world chess championship series between the Russian grandmasters, Mikhail Botvinnik and Vassily Smyslov was even today at seven games each, Moscow radio reported. The defending champion, Botvinnik, resigned today's match after the thirty-third move.
Governor Dewey released yesterday the text of the following letter from the State Controller, J. Raymond McGovern:

The price of coffee soared 200 points again yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. All options were up the daily limit at the close. Trading was influenced by overnight buying orders. There was short covering, hedge lifting and buying by Brazilian interests.

MELBOURNE, Australia, April 15 -- Prime Minister Robert Gordon Menzies ridiculed today the Soviet Embassy's allegation that a former Soviet diplomat who sought political asylum in Australia had been kidnapped.

BALTIMORE, April 15 -- The Baltimore Orioles, playing their first American League game at home in fifty-two years, defeated the Chicago White Sox, 3 -- 1, before more than 48,000 wildly enthusiastic spectators at Memorial Stadium today.

The Board of Estimate has concluded its three-day public hearings on Mayor Wagner's proposed $1,639,388,325 executive budget. It listened patiently to a full exposition of citizens' views, from morning well into the evening. While there were a few specific suggestions for abandonment of certain services, the general weight of testimony was in support of a "budget with a heart," as Mayor Wagner put it.

Open Show, the Lester Manor Stable's 4-year-old Amphitheatre gelding, got one of those typical Eric Guerin stretch rides and won the mile-and-a-sixteenth classified handicap that served as the top race at the Jamaica track before 21,879 spectators yesterday.

" I don't mean to belittle the experts, but their work must be supplemented by lay people who can give information out of their life experiences, not just their problems." This is the opinion of Mrs. Helen F. Southard, an expert herself, who is a member of the staff of the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association and a specialist on family relations.

New York bank loans to business dropped $40,000,000 last week, marking the fourth successive week of decline and bringing the total contraction since the start of the year to $444,000,000 against a decline of $56,000,000 in the similar period a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 16 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:

BERLIN, April 15 -- Maj. Gen. William P. Oliver, British commandant in Berlin, demanded today that the Russians return the two persons who had vanished in an elaborate abduction from the British sector of the city.
Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn announced yesterday the purchase of an eight-story building on the periphery of the borough's new Civic Center.

The Yankees opened another season in their plush "home of champions" yesterday and put on a performance that must have settled a lot of doubts in the minds of 23,494 onlookers. They still seem to have what it takes.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., April 15 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' statement today upon his return from meetings in London and Paris dealing with the Far East:

Among the many efforts now under way to forge a world-encircling front of free nations to cope with Communist aggression one of the most important and potentially most fruitful developments is the new treaty between Britain and the European Defense Community.

It is good to know that the long deadlock on the question of Japanese reparation in and for the Philippines has been broken. The Japanese have proposed a workable plan through investment and services, and it has been greeted with prompt acceptance in Manila.

In these days which mark the climax of the Christian year there is an interesting development to be observed: a small but significant revival of religious drama. The link between the drama and the church is an ancient one.
Moses Ward, Detroit middleweight and George Johnson, Trenton boxer, are slated to clash in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena tonight.

After lying in wait every night for two weeks in a dark, cramped tunnel under a platform in Pennsylvania Station, a railroad patrolman and a postal inspector yesterday morning shot and captured a thief who had been rifling sacks of parcel post.

NEW DELHI, India, April 15 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru warned today that India would strongly oppose any move by foreign powers to use French and Portuguese possessions in this country as bases.

A funeral service for United States Commissioner Edward W. McDonald, who had served in that capacity since 1949 in the United States Courthouse, Foley Square, was held in Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church, 467 West 142d Street, yesterday.

Newsprint production in North America during March set a record for any month of 613,597 tons, according to the report yesterday of the Newsprint Service Bureau. Shipments during the month amounted to 582,072 tons.

Sharp advances by a number of market leaders yesterday lifted The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks to its mark of Sept. 17, 1930. That was 201.27. The close, at 200.70, up 1.25 on the day, was the best since Sept. 13, 1930.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 (UP) -- H. Roy Hamey, who developed into a shrewd judge of baseball talent after giving up the game because of a bad throwing arm, moved from the New York Yankees organization today to become general manager of the Phillies.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A high Administration official today expressed the opinion that Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer "is a loyal American" and should not be barred from Government work if he was not a security risk.

VICTORIA Tex., April 16 (AP) -- Air Force officers said today that a young airman had committed suicide by setting the controls of an altitude chamber so that he died just as if his oxygen mask had failed at 25,000 feet.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 16 (AP) -- Timely Tip beat Admiral Porter by a nose today as the two Kentucky Derby nominees engaged in a stretch duel in a seven-furlong sprint on a sloppy track at Keeneland. Hasty Road, another Derby eligible, finished out of the money.

Few men of sense will disagree with Lewis Mumford's general thesis that the hideous potentialities of the hydrogen bomb make it imperative that we immediately examine "the many alternatives to the policy to which we have committed ourselves, practically without debate."
Two determined thugs forced their way into an A. P. grocery store at 306 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, shortly before 10 o'clock last night, took $4,000 and fled in an automobile belonging to a clerk.
PARIS, April 16 -- The promotion of Col. Christian de Castries, commander of the French Union garrison at Dienbienphu, to brigadier general was made official tonight.

Though city officials may be worrying over the shortage of spring showers, rainwear manufacturers are not sharing the same degree of concern because the majority of weathering coats will also be purchased as lightweight summer wraps or conveniently packable apparel for summer travel.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The chairman of the Senate subcommittee investigating the dispute between the Army and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, suggested publicly today that the Wisconsin Republican remove himself entirely from the investigation.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The American Institute of Architects announced today the recipients of its 1954 medal awards.
AIKEN, S. C., April 16 (UP) -- The three Eisenhower grandchildren should find two plastic Easter eggs apiece and heaps of jelly beans in their bunny baskets Sunday morning.
YONKERS, April 16 -- A new rule of the United States Trotting Association was invoked because of rain tonight at Yonkers Raceway and resulted in cancellation of the night's harness racing program.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message today to the Premiers of the six European Defense Community nations:

WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper said in a radio interview tonight that work on the hydrogen bomb had been delayed "several years" because of "definite and powerful objections" of "important people."

After a whirlwind attack in the fourth round, George Johnson, Trenton middleweight, stopped Moses Ward of Detroit in the fifth of their scheduled ten-round fight at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Referee Pete Scalzo called a halt to the proceedings at 1:19 as Ward wobbled about the ring.
Despite a steady drizzle, the traditional three-hour devotions of Good Friday drew capacity congregations yesterday to St. Patrick's Cathedral and most of the larger Fifth Avenue churches.

A grim future is predicted for all but the sturdiest of video fans by Dan D. Halprin, general sales manager of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc. He says: "In-laws and the maid, or both, may require the home owner of the future to have three or four sets in his home."
MONTE CARLO, April 16 (AP) -- Tony Vincent of Miami and Lorne Main of Montreal today entered the final of the Monte Carlo invitation tournament, main event of the international tennis tournament.

Thirty years ago Fifth Avenue above Thirty-fourth Street was lined with gems of architecture created by Richard M. Hunt, Stanford White and George B. Post, who built the famous Vanderbilt homes. All are gone, and with the exception of three churches the charm and beauty have changed to impressive monuments dedicated to commerce exclusively.

Only a few months ago our political leaders were discussing United States policy in the event of a Chinese invasion of Indo-China. Only a few days ago Secretary Dulles declared that the Chinese were "coming awfully close" to an invasion. On April 9 in an otherwise thoughtful letter to The Times, H. G. W. Wood-head speaks of asking the Chinese to "abandon their invasion of Indo-China."

Major league baseball will resume full-scale activity today following the general Good Friday break in the schedule. Locally, the Dodgers and the Giants will have their first 1954 clash at Ebbets Field, while the Yankees will meet the Senators at Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Senators were told today that a House-approved reduction in funds for the National Advisory Committee on Aeronautics would make idle three big wind tunnels or force a "drastic" curtailmtnt in basic research on high-speed aircraft.

Silver, the world's most useful precious metal, is now employed more widely by industry than by the arts in this country. Behind this transformation lies a story of research and development that started before World War II. The scales were tipped in favor of industry by the many new uses found for the metal during and after the war.
ALBANY, April 16 -- A motorist driving from New York to Buffalo on the State Thruway will have to pay a minimum of $5.25 in tolls.

TINSLEY GREEN, England, April 16 -- The old masters of the county of Sussex held the world marbles championship today against brash challengers of half their years from the United States Navy, the Yanks bettered their score of last year, however.

Sometime within the next ten years, America will be required by law to turn on the faucet that twice in the past has poured out the world's greatest merchant fleet. However, a survey shows that shipping men think there is a good chance that the nation may find that the pipes have rusted in the meantime.
LONDON, April 12 -- Biologists have discovered that a species of huge European shark sheds its teeth in winter and probably lives without food at the bottom of the sea until it grows a new set.
