That disagreeable job of dishwashing, about which nothing good may be said, is complicated these days by the number of plastics being used in cooking and eating implements. All are sturdy at room temperature, but not all can stand up under hot water.

NEW YORK deer hunters who are willing to hike to a wilderness area and rough it, will have an opportunity to harvest some of the over-abundant antlerless deer in the remote areas of the Adirondack Park next fall.
Automobile Row on Broadway is going down hill, Harvey S. Turnure, president of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York, said yesterday.
LONDON, April 16 (AP) -- Soccer clubs started the Easter scramble for points today as the English League program went into the home stretch. Most clubs were due to play three games in four days.
Ketchup was the wages of sin for two out-of-town bandits yesterday morning.

SEATTLE, April 16 (AP) -- Refiguring of bids has placed the English Electric Export Trading Company of London apparently low at $1,946,410 for two generators at Chief Joseph Dam on the Columbia River in north central Washington, the Army Engineers reported late today.
The following is a round-up of household hints that may be of interest to the homemaker:

Continued delays in getting work started on clearing the site for the big show place projected for Columbus Circle and called the Coliseum have given opportunity not only to explore the condemned two-block area, but -- for people prone to look backward rather than forward -- to refresh memories, now sometimes a bit faded, of what went on there during the past half- century -- or since 1903.

ORANGEBURG, N. Y., April 16 -- A pair of bandits robbed bank messengers of a $32,000 payroll here today in a bit of old-fashioned Wild West gunplay. No one was hurt, and the holdup men made the classic "clean" getaway.

Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd., increased its earnings last year to $3,867,069, highest in its twenty-five-year history, from the $2,535,241 earned in 1952, Thayer Lindsley, president, reported yesterday.

A Panagra (Pan American-Grace Airways) plane left Miami for Buenos Aires yesterday with an advanced type of radar aboard, which is expected to permit pilots to detect heavy storm centers at a distance of 150 miles.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Clark Griffith was displaying a new memento for his already-crowded souvenir chest today: a scorecard autographed by President Eisenhower.

SALT LAKE CITY, April 16 -- Gov. J. Bracken Lee has tendered to the United States Government a bill for $15,872.50 to cover board and lodging for two Federal death row inmates of the Utah State Prison.

A family ownership of more than 100 years has been terminated in the sale by Alexander and Jerry Verity of their farm in Baldwin, L. I., to Baldwin Knolls, Inc. The new owner plans to develop the property with 250 dwellings in the $14,000-$17,000 price range.

Many people, after viewing the photographs of the hydrogen bomb explosions which were released recently, expressed the attitude both verbally and mentally: "The whole thing leaves me cold" or "I, personally, am in a state of complete apathy."
HONG KONG, April 14 -- Red China has decided to "strengthen" the prosecution of "all counterrevolutionaries and criminal elements" regarded as obstructing the state's economic programs.

That modern medicine may have overlooked the value of exercise as a preventive measure and also as a therapeutic technique in some diseases, was a conclusion reached here yesterday at a scientific conference.

Anthony Parella's plan to wed the legitimate theatre to the restaurant and cabaret mediums and to house them in the basement of the Paramount Hotel, the place where Billy Rose's Diamond Horseshoe club once prospered, is moving forward.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A household invention patented this week offers comfort to those who, as soon as they are a few miles away from home, begin to worry whether they have closed the bedroom windows.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- The radio-television industry asked Congress today for tax relief to help it meet competition from the movies.
Cow-milking, fish-catching and fly-casting all will be in season today in the Bronx. The New York Zoological Park, familiarly known as the Bronx Zoo, is responsible for this.
CHICAGO, April 16 (AP) -- Ten candidates have been named for election to the American Merchants' Honor Roll.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- A high Administration source said today that if France stopped fighting in Indo-China and the situation demanded it the United States would have to send troops to fight the Communists in that area.
ROME, April 16 -- More than 250 civil servants formerly assigned to Communist-dominated labor unions went back to work for the Government today.

In your issue of Feb. 26 mention is made of the Constance Missal at the Pierpont Morgan Library. This Missal is spoken of as the "Oldest Book." The Gutenberg Bible is spoken of as the "first book of the printed word," printed between 1450 and 1455.

Sixty-two officers and directors of the world's largest manufacturing company shared salary and bonus compensation of $11,850,117 last year. These statistics are part of the proxy statement and notice of annual meeting being mailed out to the General Motors Corporation's 466,000 common stockholders.
PARIS, April 16 -- The Municipal Council of Paris has voted 2,860,000 francs ($8,171) to put an old source of Easter eggs and music back in working order.

Fog, which thickened through a wet afternoon, brought air traffic to and from New York airports virtually to a standstill yesterday afternoon. With record holiday week-end bookings reported by most airlines, the murky weather disrupted scores of carefully planned holidays.
Eddie Arcaro rode three winners at the Jamaica track yesterday.

JERUSALEM, April 16 -- Three thousand Easter pilgrims, some struggling under the burden of huge wooden crosses, crowded the narrow, winding streets of Jerusalem today as they retraced the steps of Jesus from the place of His sentence by Pontius Pilate to the site of the Crucifixion.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., April 16 (AP) -- Shelley Mann, 16-year-old high school star, twice bettered the mark for the 100-yard backstroke and started her team on its way to a record-breaking 400-yard free-style relay performance in the National Amateur Athletic Union women's indoor swimming and diving championships today.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- U. E. Baughman, Secret Service chief, today announced the arrest of three men and the recovery of over $5,000 more of the $160,000 stolen from the Bureau of Engraving on New Year's Eve. This left about $20,000 of the loot still outstanding.

The first of a number of early warning radar aircraft for the Pacific was officially accepted by the Navy yesterday in Honolulu. It is expected to extend and expand the radar protective power of the Pacific Fleet.
ANKARA, Turkey, April 16 -- Turkey and Yugoslavia assured Greece tonight that her approval would be sought on "all questions of principle" in their efforts to conclude a Balkan military alliance.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Public health officials told Congress today that there was pressing need for research into the health dangers of newly-developed chemicals.
THE offerings at the ACA Gallery include a group of drawings by artists associated here and, in the main room, a larger selection of work by four painters.

NEWARK, April 16 -- Six Cuban nationals, including a former regional Communist party secretary in that country, were taken in custody in a Bloomfield factory by Immigration and Naturalization Service inspectors this morning.
GIBRALTAR, April 16 -- British military authorities said today that they were ready to cope with any attempt Spain might make to isolate Gibraltar from the hinterland.
The celebration of Easter will begin in the early hours of tomorrow in thousands of communities from coast to coast.

Twenty-eight acres of land at the junction of Route 1, Milltown Road and Georges Road, in North Brunswick Township, N. J., have been selected as the site for shopping center development to serve an area containing about 200,000 residents. The cost was estimated at $4,000,000.

On Feb. 17 the President sent to Congress a message in which he recommended changes in the Atomic Energy Act to widen "cooperation with our allies in certain atomic energy matters," to improve "procedures for the control and dissemination of atomic information" and to facilitate development of atomic energy for peacetime uses.

The Jewish festival of Passover -- a sacred symbol of the freeing of the Israelites from bondage in Egypt -- will begin at sundown tonight. Reform Jews will observe the season for seven days and the Conservative and Orthodox branches of the faith for eight days.
CANBERRA, Australia, April 16 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Opposition leader, charged tonight that Robert Gordon Menzies, the Prime Minister, was over-eager to exploit the Petrov affair.
The following are among the special programs of Easter music arranged by the city's churches for tomorrow:
JUNEAU, Alaska, April 16 (UP) -- A 140-foot tug has foundered in heavy seas and all fourteen crewmen apparently have been lost, the Coast Guard reported.
A 60-year-old woman entered a Greenwich Village liquor store during a hold-up and was shot by the lone gunman as she struggled to retain her pocketbook.
The following books of a religious and an inspirational nature have been issued recently:

The two-story building containing six stores and twelve apartments at 271 to 277 South Orange Avenue in Newark, N. J., has been purchased for investment by the Thirtieth Hudson Corporation. Sam Garruto was the seller and the sale was made through Herbert Apfelbaum.
ATLANTA, April 16 (AP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge's political weekly, The Statesman, today charged that Southern income tax money in effect was being spent to foster a fight on Southern segregation.

It's Easter again -- in some ways the most troubled Easter since the war ended. Last year, in the upsurge of hope that always comes with the return of spring and the feast of Resurrection, many political wise men thought a "new phase" of East-West relationships might be beginning.

President Eisenhower will soon have to decide for or against Tariff Commission recommendations for a 100 per cent increase in tariffs on imports of scissors and shears coming chiefly from West Germany.

BOMBAY, India, April 16 -- Indians of all political shadings except Communists are dismayed by the sharpness of the opposition in the United States Congress to increased economic and technical aid to this poverty stricken country.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 16 -- Janet Leigh, who made the Cinderella fable come true in 1946 by becoming a starlet over night in "The Romance of Rosy Ridge" will leave Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer after completing her co-starring role with Robert Taylor in "Rogue Cop."
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- The Labor Department reported today that the number of persons claiming unemployment insurance had inched downward in the week ended April 3 for the fifth straight week.
The printing industry is drawing closer to a feasible process of photographic typesetting that: can be adapted to the high-speed requirements of newspapers and magazines.

DETROIT, April 16 (UP) -- Tony Leswick brought the Stanley Cup to Detroit tonight with a dramatic goal after 4 minutes 29 seconds of a "sudden-death" overtime period. His 40-foot shot sailed into the Montreal net to lift the Red Wings into a 2-to-1 hockey victory before a record crowd of 15,792 at Olympia.
BEAUMONT, Tex., April 16 (UP) -- Diminutive Betty Hicks took the lead on a soggy course in the second annual Babe Zaharias open tournament today with a 39, 35 -- 74.

As the parent of three children who like dolls, toy pistols and action movies I wish to take stronge exception to Lazarus Monfried's comments which appear in The Times of April 12. In arriving at a conclusion that would ban toy pistols and restrict the showing of movies having violent scenes I believe that he has confused child's play with potentiality for juvenile delinquency and capacity for murder.

SEATTLE, April 16 (AP) -- The mystery of Seattle's pockmarked windshields was investigated by a group of scientists today and their first reaction was that there was very little substance to the widespread stories of damage.

A hook and ladder truck was called in at 2 P. M. yesterday to rescue a Brooklyn warehouse man who became dizzy and panic-stricken after scaling the steel girders sixty feet above the pier where he worked.

NEW HAVEN, April, 16 -- Control of the $500,000,000 New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad passed today to Patrick B. McGinnis and his supporters. A proxy count that started at 2 P. M. Wednesday wound up here at 7:30 o'clock this morning.
OTTAWA, April 8 -- The Canadian Post Office is investing $1,000,000 in developing an electronic mail sorting device.
LONDON, April 16 (Reuters) -- Results of British soccer and rugby matches played today:
TOKYO, April 16 -- Japan plans to send a ship to the Southwest Pacific to survey the spread of radioactivity from the waters around Bikini.

Langston Hughes, poet and author of "Simple Speaks His Mind," has been named by The Saturday Review of Literature as winner of the 1953 Anisfield- Wolf Award for the novel contributing most toward better race relations.

PARIS, April 16 -- President Eisenhower's message guaranteeing the maintenance of United States forces in Europe was received today with greatest satisfaction in French official circles. The French said its terms were even stronger than those contained in the agreement with Britain.
Invincible for two years, Navy will start another campaign today as the rowing season opens in the East for heavyweight crews.
HANOI, Vietnam, April 16 -- French tanks artillery and infantry kept the Vietminh rebels from widening their foothold, only 800 yards from the heart of Dienbienphu, today.
VIENNA, April 16 -- Austria has removed quantitative restrictions from three-quarters of her imports but at the same time has substantially increased her tariffs.

PARIS, April 16 (AP) -- The French Foreign Ministry denied tonight that Brig. Gen. Christian de Castries had ever considered resigning his command. And, a spokesman added, "certainly not for the trivial reasons which have been reported."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- The Israeli delegation announced today that because of the Passover holidays it would not attend Monday's meeting of the United Nations Security Council on Palestine.
LINCOLN, Neb., April 16 -- Mrs. Eva Bowring, 62-year-old ranch operator and vice chairman of the Republican party in Nebraska, was named today to the United States Senate by Gov. Robert Crosby.
BURLINGTON, Vt., April 16 (UP) -- Blaming Russia for all the world's troubles was criticized by James P. Warburg today.
A Japanese Government munitions mission, representing twenty-one manufacturing companies, started yesterday a three-month tour of arsenals and manufacturing companies.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Average primary market prices advanced 0.1 per cent to 111.0 in the week ended on last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The all-commodities index was at a point equal to the 1953 high point reached last September.
DETROIT, April 16 (AP) -- The proposed merger of Nash-Kelvinator Corporation and Hudson Motor Car Company faced a possible barrier today.

In a Washington dispatch published in The New York Times yesterday, it was erroneously stated that the National Lawyers Guild had been listed by Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, as a Communist-front organization. It has never been so listed.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- President Eisenhower's pledge of United States support to the European Defense Community sharpens this Government's present intentions. It makes no new commitments, however, for maintaining United States troops abroad.

A new 1,500-foot section of Manhattan's long-projected $12,800,000 Harlem River Drive is slated to open late this year under construction schedules made public yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

A three-day donation at the United States Military Academy, West Point, N. Y., to the Red Cross regional blood program ended yesterday with a grand total of 729 pints. Yesterday's total was 256, against 233 the day before and 240 Wednesday.

LAWRENCE, Kan., April 16 (UP) -- Track and field stars representing twenty-four universities and twenty-nine colleges will make an all-out attack on the record book tomorrow, but most of the attention will center on Wes Santee in the twenty-ninth Kansas Relays.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16 -- President Eisenhower directed Federal agencies today to give all possible help to Congress and to the Administration in the investigation of housing scandals.

George E. Judd, an official of the Boston Symphony for forty years and its manager since 1935, announced his imminent retirement to members of the orchestra at a rehearsal last Wednesday morning, it was learned yesterday.

The revolution wrought in American foreign policy during the past decade is manifested again and confirmed by President Eisenhower in his message to the six European Defense Community nations. In this message, sent after discussion with Congressional leaders of both parties, the President not only reaffirms our commitment to the North Atlantic alliance, which initiated the break with the "no entangling alliances" doctrine of America's youth; he makes two further declarations:

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Administration's investigation into alleged housing frauds was inspired by a report to the Federal Bureau of Investigation of heavy gambling losses by an official of the Federal Housing Administration.

Steadily accelerating dress business was enjoyed by stores throughout the country with the approach of Easter, resident buying offices reported this week. The late surge of buying was so strong that a number of stores expected to pass the March-April figures of a year ago.

Elliott White Springs, president of Spring Mills, a cotton textile company, informed Mayor Wagner yesterday that he would have to move his New York City organization out of the city if the proposed extension of the 3 per cent sales tax is extended to commercial services.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- J. Monroe Johnson, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, said today that Robert R. Young could himself have bought 800,000 disputed shares of stock in the New York Central Railroad in his battle for control of the company.

The initial major Eastern outdoor collegiate track event of the season will take place at Randalls Island today, when twenty-five teams participate in the first Collegiate Track Conference championship relay meet. Manhattan, Georgetown, Villanova, Morgan State, Columbia and Syracuse are among the entrants.

ATHENS, April 16 -- Greece wants to be counted in on a military alliance such as General Popovic for Yugoslavia said in Ankara yesterday had been decided upon by Yugoslavia and Turkey. Since the Ankara Pact was signed, Greek hopes have been pinned upon its further development along definite and binding military lines.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department reported today there were widespread declines in milk prices after the Government lowered price supports for butter, cheese and non fat-dried milk April 1.

Easter business in New York City's department stores was better this year than last. Hard work and good weather helped not only to put stores ahead for the holiday period but to make it possible for them to overcome March deficits and show a gain for the March-April totals.
Traffic congestion is the major cause of Manhattan's erratic bus service.
NEWARK April 16 -- Appeals were made here today both for and against the legalization of bingo and raffles in New Jersey municipalities.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., April 16 -- When the camera clubs of South Mountain Public School here stage their second annual photographic exhibit in the auditorium on Monday, members will have more than one reason for a modest selfpat on the back.

A "thorough investigation" of the racial controversy in which the Church Club of New York has become involved was promised last night by Edward Townsend Look, a faculty member at General Theological Seminary and an influential member of the organization of Protestant Episcopal laymen.

JERSEY CITY, April 16 -- Accusing his critics of having made a "deal" with Democratic Gov. Robert B. Meyner for control of the Hudson County Bureau of Elections, Edmund Stevenson of Kearny resigned today as county Republican chairman, a post he had held for seven years.

NEWARK, April 16 (AP) -- Two officers of the American Jewish Congress today urged Secretary of the Navy Robert B. Anderson to investigate a charge that anti-Semitism might have played a part in the dismissal of Abraham Chasanow after twenty-three years as a Navy civilian employe.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 16 -- President Eisenhower has assured France that United States armed forces will stay in Europe as long as a threat to the area exists.

The traditional Good Friday performance of "Parsifal" took place at the Metropolitan Opera yesterday afternoon with two last-minute changes of cast. George London substituted for the ailing Mack Harrell as Amfortas and Astrid Varnay sang Kundry in place of the indisposed Margaret Harshaw.

DALLAS, April 16 (UP) -- Sven Davidson, who rates as Europe's No. 1 tennis player, knocked Art Larsen out of the eighth annual Dallas Country Club invitation tournament today, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3, in a quarter-final upset.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UP) -- The President's atomic energy labor relations panel stepped into the wage dispute at two atomic centers today and headed off a midnight strike by 9,000 workers.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- The Washington Post Company announced today that it had bought the presses that were excluded from the deal last month when The Post bought The Washington Times-Herald and combined the newspapers.
SAIGON, Vietnam, April 16 -- the Vietminh has brought its system of entrenchments up to the barbed wire of the French defense points in some places at Dienbienphu.

LONDON, April 16 -- Labor party and trade union leaders called today for unity within the strife-ridden party. They were worried that it might lose public confidence and destroy its chances of returning to power.

The Rev. William Augustus Muhlenberg, the Episcopalian clergyman who founded St. Luke's Hospital in 1850, described it as a hospital built around a church. Now, in its second century of service here, the venerable hospital is basing its newest project on faith.

CHICAGO, April 16 (UP) -- The Central Lions Club of Chicago said today it would present an award to Roman Catholic Bishop Bernard J. Sheil that last was given to Senator Joseph R. Mc- Carthy. The Bishop strongly criticized Mr. McCarthy last week.
MOSCOW, April 16 -- The Soviet press hailed Nikita S. Khrushchev today as a "true student of Lenin and a comrade-at-arms of Stalin," in awarding him high honors marking his sixtieth birthday.
Comic books, often accused of causing juvenile delinquency, also can be used to help cure it, in the opinion of A. Alfred Cohen, Superintendent of the State Training School for Boys at Warwick, N. Y.

Four new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Casanova's Big Night," a Paramount comedy in Technicolor, with Bob Hope and Joan Fontaine, is at the Victoria Theatre. Paul Jones produced and Norman Z. McLeod directed the film from a screen play by Hal Kanter and Edmund Hartmann, based on a story by Aubrey Wisberg.

LONDON, April 16 (UP) -- The Soviet Union disclosed today that it was creating a new inland sea to power a huge hydroelectric project on the border of Mongolia and China's vital Sinkiang province [cross on map].

The Spaniards who returned from Soviet prisons earlier this month have given us important and illuminating information regarding the present distribution and nature of slave labor in Moscow's realm. Slave labor camps, they report, range from the Leningrad area in the west to Magadan in the far east, from Norilsk in the far north to Karaganda in central Asia.

WASHINGTON, April 16 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was attacked as an unreliable news source and praised as a hard-hitting crusader in a debate today before the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

Despite yesterday's welcome rain, New York City's water shortage has been going from bad to worse. Two months ago Water Commissioner Ford said that the outlook was "not bright"; last month he warned that the situation was "serious"; a few days ago he said that the water shortage had become "increasingly acute" and that there was "practically no chance of filling our reservoirs by June 1, when the season of heavy depletion starts."

Young women headed by Mrs. Malcolm Ormsbee MacLean and Miss Janet Jeffery and including Mrs. Albert Perry-Miller are serving on the junior committee for the Easter tea dance for the benefit of the art gallery of the City Center of Music and Drama.

BOSTON, April 16 -- The American Woolen Company began contract negotiations today with union representatives of twelve of its twenty-one mills. The company asked for wage cuts and increased work assignments.

The Composers Forum presented a program of contemporary works last evening at McMillin Theatre, Columbia University. The event was sponsored by the Jean Tennyson Foundation, in cooperation with the university and the New York Public Library.

BERLIN, April 16 -- The West Berlin police said today that a top official of one anti-Soviet organization in West Berlin was an accomplice Tuesday night in the political abduction of the head of another such group.

BONN, Germany, April 16 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer said today the United States and its President had earned "the thanks of all Europeans" for the decision to maintain a fair share of the United States armed forces in West Europe, including Germany, for the duration of the threat to security.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 16 -- Nineteen religious and civic leaders of the United States urged their country today to set up a huge Middle Eastern development fund on condition that the Arabs make peace with Israel.

IN Florida, the Daytona Beach Chamber of Commerce has come up with a doubleheader attraction for Easter Week that must have promotion managers of many other resorts gnashing at their press clippings. C."

FOLLOWING Washington ceremonies which the Post Office Department calls "the most impressive of their kind in the history of the United States," what is believed to be a new record in the servicing of philatelic covers and first-day sales in connection with a high-denomination stamp in any regular American series was established when the 8-cent blue and red "Liberty" item was released on April 9.

THIS is the engrossing and entertaining story of the 1951 Severn Wild Fowl Trust Expedition to central Iceland in search of the breeding grounds of the pink-footed goose. The English members of the expedition were Peter Scott, bird artist; James Fisher, ornithologist, and Phillipa Talbot-Ponsonby; Icelandic members, Finnur Gudmundsson, ornithologist, and several farmer-guides who tended the horses required for this trek into the interior.

" BUT remember also, young man," Scott Fitzgerald wrote in his letter of advice to young writers, "that you are not the first person to be alone and alone." Nor is Gordon Webber, the author of this deeply felt novel, the first writer to be preoccupied with the theme of man's aloneness.

THE operatic rarities continue to appear in records. The LP operatic catalogue now offers, in addition to version after version of the standard repertory works, oddities that one would not hear in a lifetime of Metropolitan opera-going.

THE official production log on Columbia's "The Long Gray Line," now being filmed on location at West Point (see photo at right) doesn't tell the whole story about how this tribute to the Military Academy came into being.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17 -- After the initial shock, residents of this area took a wait-and-see attitude in the case of Dr. Oppenheimer. There was a general feeling that it was better to have the allegations produced in full, along with Dr. Oppenheimer's reply, than to have them the subject of rumor and possible misinterpretation.

Capt. O. J. (Chuck) O'Connor, who looks more like a salty seafarer than aviator, last week celebrated his twenty-fifth year of flying with American Airlines. All told, however, the 58-year-old multi-million-miles pilot has been flying for thirty-six years.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., April 17 -- A Ford-sponsored experiment in teacher education, which may well influence the course of teacher preparation throughout the country, is now under way in Arkansas. All fifteen of the state's four-year colleges and universities are cooperating in the project.

FLOWERING shrubs are to the landscape designer or the home gardener as wallpaper designs are to the interior decorator. There are scores of species and hundreds of varieties from which to choose. In fact, there are so many kinds of shrubs to select from and so many different places where they can be used that it becomes a real problem to pick the few that can be accommodated.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 17 -- Navy collected 67 1/2 points to defeat Yale, Princeton and Penn in a quadrangular track and field meet here today.

The annual luncheon and card party for the benefit of the Christ Child Society will be held Wednesday in the main ballroom of the Pierre. Proceeds will be used to further the work of the organization, which provides layettes for infants of destitute parents, irrespective of race, creed or color.

CONSUMER reaction to Easter, from the retailer's viewpoint, was eminently satisfactory. Department store volume, as expected, rose sufficiently in the last two weeks to counterbalance the lag in previous weeks and even out the disparities in figures resulting from the late Easter this year.

THERE is still time to solve the problems of getting color and bloom into shady corners of the garden. For there are many perennials, annuals and even a few bulbs that perform best in shade, most of which may be set out now for display this summer.

Wednesday's noon to 2 P. M. recorded concert at the New York Public Library, on the Easter theme, will bring to an audience in the Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street building familiar cantatas and oratorios by masters of the past.

NEW YORK, I understand, is trying to ease its traffic problem by reducing the size of its taxicabs to that of London's. It is a strong argument, for I have always felt that the land-battleships propelled through the streets of New York were a superfluous lot of steel.

WHERE Mary was weak, Elizabeth had learned early to be strong. Before she was 3 her mother was dead by the headsman's axe. When she was a red-haired, white-skinned 15, the peril of Admiral Seymour's courtship nearly lured her to a like fate. For his ambition the admiral died.

The creation of a new department at Columbia for the study of a language area extending from Hungary in Central Europe to the easternmost reaches of Siberia was announced yesterday by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of the university.

FOLLOWING close on the heels of Arturo Toscanini's retirement from the leadership of the N. B. C. symphony was a release from Victor throwing some statistical light on the Maestro's total record sales -- 20,000,000 records over the past thirty-three years, for which the public has spent $33,000,000.

THERE was a time when the May festival was the big thing in summer music in this country. The institution has not proliferated in the manner of the now over-shadowing June, July and August festivals, but in the places where it sprang up it remains a sturdy growth.

NEW DELHI, India, April 17 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru criticized today both Western and Communist tactics in respect to Indo-China. He said these were "no helpful" preparations for the Geneva conference.

GIBRALTAR, April 17 -- The Spanish Government has forbidden its nationals to visit Gibraltar on holidays without special permits. The decision was viewed by British officials today as another Spanish gesture of protest against Queen Elizabeth's two-day visit here next month.

ONE of the not-so-pleasant surprises of parenthood takes place in homes throughout the land probably every hour of the day or night. A child acts logy, a child loops flushed, a child cries out in his sleep.
GUATEMALA, April 17 -- The Archbishop of Guatemala said today that the Roman Catholic Church in Guatemala would fight Communism until it was driven out of the country.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon is the Administration official who said yesterday that the United States might have to send troops to Indo-China if the French quit fighting there.
MUNICH, Germany, April 17 (Reuters) -- The America Joint Distribution Committee announced today that $1,400,000 had been made available for resettling 2,000 Jews in displaced persons camps in Europe.

LONDON, April 17 (AP) -- The Board of Trade Journal, a British Government publication, said today many United States Great Lakes ports would have to expand and improve before full benefit could be had from the St. Lawrence Seaway.
A third bid to acquire some of the bus lines operated by the Transit Authority has been made by a group of authority employes who have organized as the Queens County Bus Employes Association.

THE most successful second comedian in television today, a distinction which he wears with the flamboyance of a paying teller in a branch bank or a yard of unbleached muslin, is a determinedly middle-class type of 35 named Art Carney, who is seen weekly opposite Jackie Gleason by roughly 39,600,000 people and is paid more than $50,000 a year for being spectacularly subsidiary.

LOS ANGELES, April 17 -- Draw poker for stakes, which manages to squeeze through a loophole in California's anti-gambling laws, received a community vote of confidence in suburban Gardena but setbacks in two other communities in municipal elections this week.

A new general education course in the humanities at Goucher is being given jointly by members of the music, fine arts and literature departments. To teach students how to analyze and appreciate a work of art, the course will study, in books, classroom and workshop, the basic elements of the arts, dimension, form and different types of organization in all three fields.

Martha Raye and Vicki Carlson, television actresses, were bitten last night at the National Broadcasting Company studios in the Center Theatre by J. Fred Muggs, the celebrated chimpanzee and TV actor.
JACK CARTER, an exponent of the rapid-fire gag, stand-up comedy style in the night-club tradition, is being groomed for a television comeback by C. B. S., but as a different man.
GREENWICH, Conn., April 17 -- Jack Sutphen of Larchmont Yacht Club today claimed the first official Frostbite championship of Long Island Sound's Yacht Racing Association.

THE gates of the National Arboretum, which borders the west bank of the Anacostia River, will be open to the public every day during the next few weeks through May 15. The main gate is located in the northeast section of the dis--trict on M Street.

SPRING is generally thought of as a time of delicate pastel coloring. Today, however, city parks and private gardens are bright with the crayon blues of scilla and speedwell, the true reds of species tulips and the primary yellow of forsythia and daffodil.

LINCOLN, R. I., April 17 (UP) -- Condamion, Draw and Susan's Pet wound up in a blanket finish in the $10,000 New Haven Handicap today, but the pictures showed Condamion the winner by a nose on the final day of Lincoln Downs' thirty-day spring meeting.

COULOMBS, France. TEN THOUSAND miles southeast of Paris, on a dusty plain ringed with hills, in a strongly fortified place called Dienbienphu, the hardest battle in the seven-year history of the Indo-China war was being fought. On its outcome depended the course of war, or peace, in France's former colony and, perhaps, in the whole of Southeast Asia.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 17 -- A world-wide political and commercial effort to get Iranian oil back into international markets entered its third phase this week with the opening of negotiations in Teheran between oil company representatives and the Iranian Government.
PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., April 17 -- New Jersey's Governor Robbert B. Meyner joined thousands of other Garden State fishermen today in opening the four and a half month trout season.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (UP) -- The Army and Air Force have drawn up plans to withdraw virtually all combat units from Korea in the year to begin July 1.

PAINTINGS by Dutch masters have been recently acquired by two American museums. The third important gift by the Friends of the City Art Museum of St. Louis is "Portrait of a Laughing Girl," by Gerard van Honthorst (1590-1656).

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) -- A top official of the American Federation of Labor urged today that the A. F. L. and Congress of Industrial Organizations go ahead with a proposed peace pact though some major A. F. L. unions are against it.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., April 17 -- Residents of half a dozen South Jersey communities served by the Shore Memorial Hospital at Somers Point are circulating petitions on behalf of Dr. Ling Nun Wang, a member of the hospital staff.
HARRISON, N. Y., April 17 -- A woman was killed and seven persons were injured here today in a head-on motor crash.

Livingston and Hope Sheridan at the Ninety-second Street Y.M. and Y.W.H.A., which, as the management is careful to point out in bold-face type, is air-conditioned.

LONDON, April 17 -- A promising peace negotiation in Kenya has come to ruin and this week the Mau Mau warfare in that bloody colony in East Africa is raging at a new pitch.
ORANGE, N. J., April 17 (AP) -- Judy Devlin of Baltimore tonight won her sixth United States girls' singles badminton championship, defeating Sally Thomas of Mountain Lakes, N. J., 11 -- 2, 11 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- Herbert Hoover said tonight that inflation had not been stopped and would not be stopped until deficit spending had been ended.

JERUSALEM, April 17 -- As Easter dawn rises over the Judean hills tomorrow a solitary figure will cross a cobblestoned courtyard worn smooth by the tread of pilgrims down the ages. He will unlock the wooden doors of a central shrine of Christendom, the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, where, according to tradition, Christ was buried and rose again from the dead.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 17 -- King Baudouin called today upon Max Buset, Socialist leader who helped to force his father King Leopold to abdicate, to form a new Belgian Government.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Federation of American Scientists today expressed shock at the barring of Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer from atomic secrets and said his case made "essential" a speedy review of the entire security program.
BOWIE, Md., April 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Samuel M. Pistorio's Brazen Brat won the $10,000-added Rowe Memorial Handicap here today.

A dried-out, ball-like handful of foliage, which to all appearances is dead, will send up, shortly after being placed in water, long fresh fronds of green.

THE Marigny Theatre is Jean-Louis Barrault's Paris headquarters. In that circular building handsomely set in the Champs-Elysees gardens, Barrault has opened a second theatre, the "Little Marigny," which he operates simultaneously with the regular Marigny.

VIENNA, April 17 -- The Soviet satellites in Europe are ready to take more consumer goods from the West to further their new economic course, but they seem no more able to pay for them than in the past.

Whenever gangsters, kidnappers, spies, dishonest politicians or just plain sharp operators appear in the headlines we reach for a bottle of sticky ink and a pile of fingerprinting forms.

PARIS, April 17 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles has become personally acquainted with the leaders of Europe more swiftly than most American statesmen for the simple reason that he appears to regard an airplane journey across the Atlantic Ocean as the equivalent of a commuter's ride to New York on the 8 A. M. Special.
Columbia's crews swept the river against Rutgers yesterday as the Lions opened their rowing season with three races on the Harlem.
A gray transport eased into the harbor yesterday with two great golden thunderbirds displayed on diamond-shaped red banners against the side. The vessel brought nearly 3,000 soldiers from Korea.
MINNEAPOLIS, April 17 (AP) -- A statement charging the chairman of the board of the Minneapolis and St. Louis Railway with flagrant extravagances" was assailed by the road management today.

Whitney colt won the mile-and-a-sixteenth race almost as he pleased was not nearly so surprising as the fact that there were 31,392 on hand to see him do it.

SAIGON, April 17 -- Five years ago an appraisal of popular feeling in Vietnam toward political forces in the country presented no difficulty. It was obvious that a vast majority of people were for Ho Chi Minh and his Communist-nationalist Vietminh regime.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- The Air Force has cautioned Congress that money cannot buy a dramatic improvement in the ability of the United States to protect its cities against atomic attack. In testimony published today, Air Force officials conceded, however, that the increased atomic striking power of the Soviet Union dictated a more effective air defense system at home.

SOME annuals and perennials have individual growing characteristics that impose certain limitations on their use in the flower border. Taking these into consideration before any planting is done, helps to prevent any sudden lack of bloom or perhaps a yawning bare spot.

THE Baltimore Orioles have returned to the big leagues for the first time in more than half a century and thereby have rekindled one of the most flaming traditions baseball has yet produced. The official birthplace of the game is Cooperstown, N. Y., where Abner Doubleday supposedly outlined the first diamond. But most of the strategic concepts which were to revolutionize the sport burgeoned in Baltimore.

Robert Oppenheimer, they can be reassured by the fashion in which this case is being handled. If they are grieved that it is necessary to make a review of the security findings in this case, they can be comforted by the qualities of decency and integrity in the review.
LONDON, April 17 -- The peculiar relationship between the United States and Britain, which is both more and less than a written alliance, sailed through one of its periodic squalls this week.

RICHMOND, April 17 (AP) -- Champion Ernharkenburg's Stormson, offspring of the famed Doberman Ch. Rancho Dobe's Storm, won best in show today in the twentieth annual all-breed dog show of the Virginia Kennel Club.

SHE came out of a little German principality at 15 to marry the heir to the throne of Russia. Her prospective husband was, to put it kindly, childish, and his aunt, the Dowager Empress, an interfering harridan. For seventeen years Catherine endured, while intrigue seethed about her and Peter, her husband, played with toy soldiers.

CLEVELAND, April 17 -- Business activities in Cleveland for the first quarter of this year were virtually all short of a year ago, the size of the declines varying from moderate to substantial. All current business indicators, however, point to a substantially higher level of activity than prevailed in the first quarter of 1949, the last recession year.

NORFOLK, Va., April 17 -- In the thunder and lightning of a summer storm in 1887, the roof of old St. Luke's Church, near Smithfield, Va., crumbled. One of the bricks that came tumbling down with the old hammer beams that held up the roof showed the date 1632 chiseled on it.

RENEWED proof of the continuing vitality of Scandinavian design may be seen in an exhibit scheduled to open Tuesday at the Brooklyn Museum. It is called "Design in Scandinavia." More than seven hundred "objects for everyday use" were selected by a committee of twelve -- three each from Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden.

A CUT in round-trip coach fares to Florida, effective May 15 through Sept. 15, was announced last week and this action was expected to provide a strong stimulus to summer travel southward. Somewhat unexpectedly, the Seaboard made known that it would reduce fares by 25 per cent and the Atlantic Coast Line said the same reduction would be in effect on its line.
THE New York season of 1953-54 of the Metropolitan Opera Association came to an end last night, and now Mr. Bing may draw a breath after a season of adventures, successes, and escapes!

CRISP salads have an important place in the American diet, a fact that many gardeners should keep in mind. For most of the salad ingredients are easy-to-grow vegetables -- lettuce, cabbage, spinach, onions and radishes -- that require little space or care. And furthermore, now is the time to plant them, for these cool season crops should have the jump on the weather and mature before the hot days of summer.
